title: J. Carter Brown Leaves Arts Posts
description: J. Carter Brown, the former director of the National Gallery of Art, has severed all formal ties to nearly two dozen arts and educational organizations, including the Commission of Fine Arts, on which he served for 30 years. Through his efforts, Washington was significantly reshaped by projects like the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. More recently, the commission obtained Congressional and presidential approval for the much debated World War II Memorial, to be built near the Vietnam memorial on the Washington Mall.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWNSTEIN, STANLEY
description: BROWNSTEIN-Stanley June 1, 1932-August 31, 1999 Your 70th Birthday. Gone three sad lonely years. I think of you daily with love and remembrance. Hilda and Family

title: An Unexpected Censor in Bosnia
description: Seven years after the end of the war in Bosnia, the country has far to go to build the institutions of a successful European state. One of the few bright spots has been its local television stations, some of which do aggressive and professional reporting. A new law, however, could result in their closing -- a law written not by the country's politicians but by Wolfgang Petritsch, who was the international community's High Representative in Bosnia until last Monday. His successor, Paddy Ashdown, should make overturning the law one of his first tasks.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Raises For Lawmakers
description: Fresh off a grueling budget battle to erase a $930 million deficit, legislators received a plan that would raise the governor's salary to $155,000 from $95,000 and lawmakers' salaries to $36,000 from $24,000. The plan, developed by a state commission that meets every two years, now goes before the governor and Legislature. A previous proposal was scaled back by Gov. Jane Dee Hull, whose current salary ranks 32nd among the 50 governors, then rejected by the State Senate. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Text of Bush's Speech at West Point
description: Following is the full text from President Bush's commencement address at the United States Military Academy at West Point Saturday, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Kidd's Play Speaks Louder Than Boos From the Crowd
description: Jason Kidd walked through the tunnel after halftime tonight. As he emerged into the crowd, one fan, in a tirade interspersed with expletives, told Kidd in colorful terms that he was unwelcome at the Fleet Center.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Judge Puts Hold On Grazing
description: A federal judge has issued an injunction that prohibits livestock grazing on about 2,000 acres of federal land outside of Yellowstone National Park. Animal rights and environmental protection groups had opposed the grazing because they said it increased the number of bison who were killed to stem the spread of brucellosis among cattle. Bison that leave the park are rounded up and killed if they test positive for the disease. The Forest Service must now conduct an environmental analysis before a grazing permit can be reissued. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: The Cities And Their New Elite
description: Should Pittsburgh recruit gay people to jump-start its economy? Should Buffalo -- another fiscally flat-lining city -- give tax breaks to bohemians? As policy prescriptions go, these sound absurd. But according to a new theory devised by Richard Florida, a professor of regional economic development at Carnegie Mellon University, towns that have lots of gays and bohemians (by which he means authors, painters, musicians and other ''artistically creative people'') are likely to thrive.

title: Offer for TRW Is Extended
description: The military contractor Northrop Grumman extended its $11.9 billion tender offer for TRW to June 14 while the two companies try to reach a merger agreement.

title: Nets' Jordan Interests Denver
description: Officials for the Denver Nuggets, the only N.B.A. team with a coaching vacancy, made preliminary contact with the Nets this week and will ask for permission to talk with Eddie Jordan, the Nets' top assistant coach, after the season is over, according to several people familiar with the process.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JUDY
description: GOLDMAN-Judy. We share your grief and great loss and will miss our Judy and think of her always as a shining star. Marilyn and Jerome Weiss

title: Hope for Adelphia Deal Fades Under Investors' Opposition
description: Adelphia Communications continued to negotiate the sale of some of its cable systems to the entrepreneur Paul Allen yesterday, but it seemed increasingly unlikely that the two sides would pull off a deal, people close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: Five Are Indicted In Fraud Case
description: Five people have been indicted on charges of defrauding international banks, including the FleetBoston Financial Corporation and the PNC Financial Services Group, out of $600 million.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Officials Quit After Air Crash
description: All nine senior officials at the China Aviation Development Foundation, a quasi-governmental group that owns 71 percent of China Airlines, resigned to take responsibility for the crash last Saturday of a China Airlines Boeing 747 into the Taiwan Strait. all 225 aboard died. Rough seas and powerful currents have prevented the recovery of the aircraft's data and cockpit voice recorders and most of the wreckage. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Nathan Smith, 65, a Glib Man of the Bowery
description: Nathan Smith, the raspy-voiced manager at the Sunshine Hotel, one of the Bowery's last flophouses, died on Sunday at a hospital in Queens. He was 65.

title: Voting and Race
description: To the Editor:

title: TIER TECHNOLOGIES TO BUY OFFICIAL PAYMENTS
description: Tier Technologies Inc., which provides information-technology consulting, agreed to buy the Official Payments Corporation for about $74.5 million in cash to expand its business to government agencies. Tier, which is based in Walnut Creek, Calif., will pay $3 a share, 50 percent above Official Payments' closing price Thursday of $2 a share. Tier expects to keep the Official Payments brand after the purchase closes in August, the company said. Official Payments products allow consumers to pay government taxes, fees, fines and utility bills by credit card using the Internet or by telephone. The company is a primary credit card processor for the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, MIRIAM B.
description: KLEIN-Miriam B. Of Harrison, NY on May 31, 2002, age 91. Wife of the late Louis M. Klein. Mother of Honie Ann Peacock, Arthur Klein (Patricia) and Toby Haynes (Wilson). Grandmother of Chiara Peacock, Justin Haynes, Joshua Haynes, Zoe and Isaac Klein. Funeral service Monday, 1:30PM Chapel in the Woods at Congregation Kol Ami, Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. Interment Mount Pleasant Cemetery. Friends will be received at 69 South Road, Harrison, New York, Monday 4:30 P.M. until 8 P.M. and Tuesday 12 noon until 7 P.M.

title: Harvard Student Drops 'Jihad' From Speech Title
description: A Harvard student who caused an outcry with his plan to discuss ''jihad'' in a commencement speech says he is hoping that a little artful disguise will quell the complaints.

title: Apology Cites 'Contrition, Shame and Emptiness'
description: Following is an excerpt from the apology that Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee offered yesterday, as posted on the Web site of The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel. A full transcript is online at nytimes.com/national.

title: Teamsters' Leader in Chicago Is Expelled by Oversight Board
description: The longtime Chicago leader of the Teamsters has been expelled from the union by an independent oversight board, which found that he had betrayed the membership's interests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, WILLIAM P.
description: BERGER-William P. Founder and president of Bill Berger Associates literary agency, died of cancer on May 28, 2002 at Cabrini Hospice, New York City. He is survived by his sister Florence Lynne, four nephews and three nieces. Known for his humor and charm, Bill will definitely be missed by family, friends, colleagues and clients.

title: The Building Blocks of a Good Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Democrat For Governor Of Hawaii Withdraws
description: Democratic hopes for extending a 40-year grip on the Hawaii governor's office have been dealt a major setback.

title: For Ordez and Mets, An Offensive Revival
description: Rey Ordez hit his first home run of the season tonight in the 10th inning to help the Mets outlast the Florida Marlins, 6-5, in a rain-interrupted game at Pro Player Stadium.

title: Bravo Breaks Wrist In Monmouth Spill
description: The jockey Joe Bravo will be sidelined for three months after breaking his left wrist in a fall during a race Thursday at Monmouth Park.

title: The Building Blocks of a Good Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Nets Prove They Are Better Team
description: THERE comes a time in a playoff series when the better team has to step up and win. Last night, the Nets, the N.B.A.'s most surprising team and the better team in their series with the Celtics, stepped up and won. The Nets continued their rampage through the playoffs, this time beating Boston by 96-88 and earning the franchise's first trip to the N.B.A. finals.

title: Kashmiri Impelled to Lead by His Father's Death
description: AS a teenager, Umar Farooq had the typical conflicts an only son has with a busy and important father, his being the spiritual leader of Kashmir's Muslims and political leader of the struggle for an independent Kashmir.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Fiber Optic Bankruptcy
description: KPNQwest, which operates one of Europe's largest fiber optic networks, filed for bankruptcy in a Dutch court after receiving court protection from creditors last week. The company, whose largest shareholders are KPN, the Dutch phone company, and Qwest Communications of the United States, said it had been unable to sell assets to meet financial commitments. Talks with potential buyers are continuing, but KPNQwest said it had no choice but to ask the District Court of Haarlem to convert a moratorium on payments to creditors to bankruptcy proceedings. The company said that a number of subsidiaries across Europe would file for protection in their local jurisdictions, with the exception of KPNQwest Portugal Telecomunicaes and KPNQwest Italy, among others. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Tillman Leaves N.F.L. to Join Army
description: Pat Tillman, the former safety for the Arizona Cardinals, officially joined the United States Army yesterday, a spokesman confirmed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: A Nation Reshaped
description: Parliament overwhelmingly endorsed a looser union between the two remaining republics. Constitutional experts now have to work out the exact structure of the new state, to be called Serbia and Montenegro, which was created under pressure from the European Union to stave off a Montenegrin independence bid and to discourage other Balkan separatists, especially in Kosovo, a province of Serbia. Serbia and Montenegro will be broadly autonomous but share a president, cabinet and army; either can leave the union after three years. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: New U.S. Commander At Helm in Afghanistan
description: Lt. Gen. Dan K. McNeill, the new commander of the American-led forces in Afghanistan, formally assumed command of the base here today, and his priorities could not have been clearer.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Stagnant Economy
description: The economy of Hong Kong continued to stagnate in the first quarter, with output falling nine-tenths of a percent from a year earlier, near the low end of economists' expectations. A small increase in exports of services, notably a big jump in tourists from mainland China, failed to offset record unemployment of 7 percent and sinking exports of goods. But the economy fared slightly better than it did in the fourth quarter, when output shrank 1.4 percent compared with a year earlier.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: EUROPE YUGOSLAVIA: A NATION RESHAPED Parliament overwhelmingly endorsed a looser union between the two remaining republics. Constitutional experts now have to work out the exact structure of the new state, to be called Serbia and Montenegro, which was created under pressure from the European Union to stave off a Montenegrin independence bid and to discourage other Balkan separatists, especially in Kosovo, a province of Serbia. Serbia and Montenegro will be broadly autonomous but share a president, cabinet and army; either can leave the union after three years.    Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: The Lakers Get to Play Another Day
description: Shaquille O'Neal, Kobe Bryant and the N.B.A.'s marquee team survived another evening of incredibly taut playoff basketball. They will play Sunday not because they displayed the flair and panache for which they have come to be known. No, the Los Angeles Lakers beat the Sacramento Kings tonight on sheer resolve, lowering their collective shoulder until they got to the free-throw line and Game 7 of the Western Conference finals at Sacramento.

title: The Special Agent In the Chat Room
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloomberg Will Not Attend Families' Ground Zero Ceremony
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would not attend a ceremony tomorrow at ground zero held by family members of those killed in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

title: The Nets Follow Their Dream to the Finals
description: The Nets stormed onto the court, punching their fists toward the rafters of the Fleet Center, running in all directions and finally throwing themselves into each other's arms. Kenyon Martin ripped off his jersey and grinned in the frenzy of the moment.

title: A Powder Keg in South Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Second Hand Low, Right? Well, Maybe Not That Low
description: The Reisinger Knockout Teams, a great tradition in New York bridge for 72 years, began Monday with an entry of 14 teams. Three days of play reduced the field to four teams, and the semifinals began Thursday at Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PANERA BREAD CO., St. Louis, a provider of fresh-baked bread, muffins and pastries, plans to enter the California market next year by opening 14 bakery-cafes in northwest Los Angeles County in conjunction with Mariposa Bread, a franchise group. Panera will supply fresh dough to the bakery-cafes from a new plant in Los Angeles.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Residential Real Estate column yesterday. about plans for market-rate rental buildings in East Harlem, misidentified the agency responsible for the Cornerstone urban development program, under which land is to be provided for two of the buildings. It is the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, not the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies on May 19 about the Christie's Collectors' Car Exhibition and Auction at Rockefeller Center misidentified an automobile on display. It was a 1951 Bentley Mark VI, not a 1936 Rolls-Royce Phantom III.

title: Death Row Inmate Fights Ban on Nude Pictures
description: A man on death row in Tennessee for a 1980 crime spree that included the murder of an elderly Memphis couple sued the State Department of Corrections yesterday over new prison regulations banning magazines like Playboy and Penthouse.

title: Holyfield-Rahman: Not Much Interest
description: While the upcoming Mike Tyson-Lennox Lewis match is attracting most of the klieg lights and psychotherapists, there is another heavyweight bout that is getting about as much news media attention as a youth soccer game in suburbia.

title: Despite Protest, Moody's Cuts Japan Rating
description: Alarmed by Japan's climbing debt load, Moody's Investors Service lowered the nation's credit rating by two notches today.

title: Drugs in Baseball
description: Ken Caminiti, the former major league infielder, has backed off from his assertion in this week's Sports Illustrated that fully one-half of all major league baseball players use illegal steroids. But as the magazine demonstrates in compelling detail, Caminiti's underlying point is certainly true: The use of performance-enhancing drugs is far more widespread than previously suspected. It is also clear that the owners and the players' union, currently engaged in talks aimed at averting a strike, should move the drug issue much higher on their agenda. Unlike professional basketball and football, Major League Baseball has no steroid policy or testing program for big-league players.

title: Shuttle Is Grounded For Next Few Days
description: The space shuttle Endeavour will remain grounded until at least Monday because of a weather forecast that calls for thunderstorms throughout the weekend here at the Kennedy Space Center.

title: All the Pretty Horses, And a 6-Ton Gear Drive
description: When 10 brilliantly painted ponies, a frog, a cat, a deer and a bunny arrived yesterday, the new Bryant Park Carousel finally began to resemble a merry-go-round. Which was a relief, because when it arrived on Tuesday, it was affixed with wheels, a New York State license plate and functioning red brake lights; it rather closely resembled a U-Haul van.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Irvington: Officer Shoots Driver
description: A police officer shot and wounded a man in a stolen car who drove into him after leading the police on a chase, the authorities said. The officer, Douglas Polk, was treated for leg injuries and released from Irvington General Hospital, Acting Chief James Galfy said. The driver, who was not identified, was listed in critical condition at University Hospital in Newark after being treated for a single gunshot wound to the head, said Charlotte L. Smith, the executive assistant to the Essex County prosecutor. Ms. Smith said the chase began in South Orange after a report of a stolen dark green BMW convertible, then went through Newark and on to Irvington, where the car was stopped. As Officer Polk walked toward the car, it struck him, prompting him to shoot, Ms. Smith said. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: I.B.M. Gets Contract for Weather Supercomputer
description: As part of an effort to close a growing gap facing United States scientists in weather prediction, the government awarded I.B.M. a $224.4 million contract today to build a powerful new supercomputer.

title: COURT BLOCKS LAW THAT LIMITS ACCESS TO WEB IN LIBRARY
description: A federal court panel struck down a law requiring libraries to filter the Internet for material harmful to minors yesterday, saying that the technology blocks so much unobjectionable material that it would violate the First Amendment rights of library patrons.

title: National Briefing | Washington: College To Study Blacks And Seat-Belt Use
description: Meharry Medical College in Nashville, a historically black school, has started a $10 million, five-year study to learn why blacks are half as likely as other groups to wear seat belts, officials from the university and the Department of Transportation said. State Farm Insurance will pay for the study. The officials said the results should help improve campaigns promoting seat-belt use. ''You have to understand behavior before you can begin to change it,'' Dr. John E. Maupin Jr., president of the college, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLICH, TOBY G.
description: PERLICH-Toby G. On May 30, 2002, at the age of 91. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Myron Perlich. Superlative mother of daughter Kay Brover and husband Arthur Bennett of NYC, and son Martin Perlich of Los Angeles. Baby sister of Rabbi Albert S. Goldstein of Brookline, humorous and elegant grandma of Alice Andrews, Max Perlich, Miles Perlich and Neil Porter, and loving great grandma of Sophie, Lliana and Maya. Toby was our mother goddess, our soulful word crafter, and our funny bone. Service Friday June 14, 2002, 1 PM at ''the Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to Hadassah.

title: Cordial Notes Resound, As Tough Downbeats Fade
description: Nothing sounds quite as happy as a happy ending. Certainly, the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night was not the orchestra it was a few years ago, when one heard it smarting weekly under the intense discipline of its now-departing music director, Kurt Masur. All that harsh, tight honesty seemed to melt away. Bartok's Divertimento for String Orchestra floated on air, ripe and relaxed. If cordiality could be translated into musical sound, Philharmonic players, even the ones who did not appreciate Mr. Masur's tough regime, were extending it here.

title: MACERICH TO BUY WESTCOR REALTY FOR ABOUT $747 MILLION
description: The Macerich Company, a West Coast mall owner, will buy Westcor Realty for about $747 million in cash and convertible bonds to enter Arizona, a rapidly growing retailing market. Macerich, which is based in Santa Monica, Calif., will pay $741 million in cash, issue about $80 million of bonds and assume $733 million of Westcor debt. Westcor gives Macerich some of the best-performing malls in Phoenix, a metropolitan area second only to Washington in population and employment growth, according to LaSalle Investment Management.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Effort To Ease Tensions With U.S.
description: Prime Minister Jean Chrtien has set up a Liberal Party task force to study ways to improve relations with the United States as tensions over bilateral trade grow. Mr. Chrtien announced the formation of the group after he failed to persuade President Bush to end tariffs on Canadian soft wood lumber. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREITZER, SHIRLEY ARONOFF
description: GREITZER-Shirley Aronoff. Of New York, died suddenly but peacefully on Wednesday, May 29, 2002. The pianist and former Director of Placement at the Juilliard School of Music was inspirational to those she helped and those she loved. Her family mourns her loss with the deepest love and affection, knowing that her many talents will live on through her three children and six grandchildren. Her sister and niece mourn as well. Services will be held on Sunday, June 2, 2002 at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St. at 11:45am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Juilliard School of Music.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Land Proposed For Protection
description: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has proposed creating 550,000 acres of critical habitat to protect 146 threatened or endangered plant species on Oahu and the Big Island. The measure would restrict development and activity on federal lands included in the habitats, and on affected state and private land when federal money, permits or workers are involved. The service has proposed protecting 840,000 acres across the state -- or 20 percent of Hawaii's land mass. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: BUICK DRAWS TOP-RANKED PLAYERS
description: Eight of the top nine players in the world ranking will compete in next week's Buick Classic (June 6-9) at Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y.

title: City's Water-Quality Plan Working So Far, U.S. Finds
description: New York City's five-year effort to maintain the purity of its drinking water primarily through land management in the upstate watershed areas is on track and working, a federal government evaluation has concluded. That means the city -- at least for now -- won't have to build a staggeringly expensive filtration plant to meet water-quality standards.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Strip-Search Settlement
description: Boston and the Suffolk County Sheriff's Department will pay $10 million to settle a class-action suit brought by women strip-searched at the county jail after being arrested for minor offenses. The settlement was reached nearly a year after a judge in Federal District Court ruled that the automatic searches violated constitutional rights. About 5,400 women searched from 1995 to 1999 are eligible for the payment. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Teachers Want A Vote in Plan To Extend Day
description: After agreeing to a plan that would require New York City teachers to work an extra 20 minutes a day, the union representing them has irked Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg by proposing that teachers, not principals and superintendents, decide how that additional time be used.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ADAM JEFFREY
description: KATZ-Adam Jeffrey, 34, of Wilton, CT, unexpectedly in Los Angeles on May 30, 2002. He will be dearly missed by Julie Sillins Katz and their three sons, Zachary, Nicholas and Jonathan Henry, his mother, Holly Katz Klein, his father, Howard C. Katz, sisters, Betsey and Sara, and his grandmothers, Pauline Schur and Eleanor Aberle. Services will be held Monday, June 3rd, at 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave. at 81 St., NYC. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the NYU Child Study Center, 577 First Avenue, NY, NY 10016.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Airline Settles Suit
description: U.S. Airways settled a religious discrimination lawsuit by agreeing to allow an employee from Jamaica to keep his hair long. The employee, Orsino Allen, who worked at Philadelphia International Airport, had asserted that the airline's efforts to force him to cut his hair violated his Rastafarian religious beliefs. In settling a lawsuit brought by the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, U.S. Airways agreed to pay Mr. Allen $50,000 in damages and to use training and improved communication to reinforce policies that prohibit discrimination. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVENKRON, RACHEL
description: LEVENKRON-Rachel June 1, 1988. Mother, you live on forever in our hearts. Your Children

title: $1 Billion Settlement Over Faulty Implants
description: Sulzer Medica, Europe's leading maker of orthopedic devices, said today that it had completed a deal to settle a host of lawsuits by American patients over faulty hip and knee implants. It agreed to pay about $1 billion.

title: Moody's Sees Risks in Threats to Landmarks
description: In another indication of financial concerns about the threat of terrorist attacks in New York and other cities, a leading bond-rating agency said yesterday that it was reviewing its ratings on $5 billion in loans on about a dozen big commercial buildings and groups of buildings, including the Rockefeller Center complex.

title: U.S., in Court Filing, Backs Maine's Drug Discount Plan
description: The Bush administration told the Supreme Court today that it should allow Maine to carry out a state law that tries to force drug companies to reduce the prices of prescription medicines sold in the state.

title: Bomb Attack Shows That Russia Hasn't Rooted Out Anti-Semitism
description: The sign was the size of a large poster, pounded into a green roadside about 20 miles southwest of here. It stated its ugly message in thick, block letters: ''Death to Yids.''

title: Lear in the Wild West, With a Ranch to Divide
description: Just about everything in ''King Lear'' depends on the first scene. When Lear, the elderly monarch with a kingdom to divide, asks his three daughters to declare their love for him to ''earn'' their inheritances, there has to be good reason for the youngest, Cordelia, to refuse to play the game. If not, the hate and death and destruction that follow seem completely avoidable, not to mention less than credible.

title: CITING TENSION, U.S. ADVISES AMERICANS IN INDIA TO LEAVE
description: The Bush administration warned today that ''tensions have risen to serious levels'' between India and Pakistan, urging the 60,000 Americans now in India for business, study or tourism to leave immediately and authorizing nonessential diplomats and all dependents to depart.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column of Circuits on Thursday about W.E.P., a security protocol for wireless computer networks, misstated its full name. The initials stand for Wired Equivalent Privacy, not Wireless Equivalent Privacy.

title: Pollyanna Meets Cassandra
description: Now that we've all had a good laugh at the spectacle of our fastidious treasury secretary touring African misery with a middle-aged rock star, now that we've snorted at Paul O'Neill and Bono in matching Ghanaian robes and tortured all the obvious U2 lyrics, it's time to ask whether anything is going on here besides soliciting MTV votes for the Republican Party.

title: Sports of The Times; Steroids to Test The Players' Union
description: IT'S so comforting to know that baseball's labor negotiations are progressing. The owners and the union have actually discussed whether the Florida Marlins and the Tampa Bay Devil Rays should be allowed to travel by bus when they play each other. And when so many of their players would prefer a limo.

description: NEW YORK

title: Medical Marijuana
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Beliefs; American bishops are preparing to meet on the sex abuse crisis. Just what can they achieve?
description: For the nation's Roman Catholic bishops, D-Day is two weeks away. In their case, the D stands for Dallas, where they will meet June 13-15 to deal with their church's sex abuse scandal.

title: Tipping Her Hat to New York
description: When Sheryl Crow inaugurated the Downtown NYC River to River Festival 2002 on Thursday evening at Battery Park, she cheerfully adhered to the city's unwritten concert guidelines.

title: Death and a Peak's Lure, The Never-Ending Story
description: At midmorning, with the perennial snow on the volcano of Mount Hood softening underfoot in the sun's glare, Janet Quackenbush looked up toward the summit and saw the chain reaction. A party of four slipped just short of a pass called the Pearly Gates, picked up speed, knocked down two other groups, and were soon swallowed by the big blue opening in the mountain's glacial ice.

title: On the Streets of Paris, Senegal Has Plenty of Happy Fans
description: Abdoulaye N'Diaye was wrong when he made his prediction today, before his native Senegal and his adopted France played soccer in a distant land.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: BANK LOWERS FORECAST Commerz- bank lowered its profit forecast because a cost-cutting program for the bank, Germany's fourth largest, has been less effective than expected. The chief executive, Klaus-Peter Muller, left, told investors the overhaul, which includes slashing jobs and closing branches, would help increase net income by 640 million euros ($600 million) from 2001 to 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTAT, BONNIE
description: EISENSTAT-Bonnie. Suddenly on May 30, 2002. Beloved wife of Mark, devoted mother of Stephanie and Nicole, loving daughter of Natalie and Stephen Gross, sister of Andrew Gross (Ann), cherished aunt, and caring friend to many. Services on Sunday 11:30 A.M. at Gutterman's Inc., 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: The Special Agent In the Chat Room
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Orders Study Of City Trucks' Soot
description: A state appeals court has ruled that New York City must study the health effects of soot from the diesel sanitation trucks it has added to Manhattan's streets in recent years. That could lead to the city's installing emission controls on the trucks.

title: The Building Blocks of a Good Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Running Game's Progress Starts Up Front
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 31  Giants running back Ron Dayne squeezed a handoff the other day, ran right and turned into a herd of defenders. When he emerged on the other side of the mass virtually untouched, there were a few animated whoops from teammates.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I apologize to all the faithful of the archdiocese, which I love so much, to all its people and clergy for the scandal that has occurred because of my sinfulness.''

title: INSIDE
description: Relatives of Victims Shun Federal 9/11 Fund

title: Bill Clinton Joins Top Democrats At Major Torricelli Fund-Raiser
description: Almost five months after federal prosecutors decided not to indict him after a lengthy corruption investigation, Senator Robert G. Torricelli held the first major fund-raiser of his re-election campaign this evening, with former President Bill Clinton as the main speaker.

title: Retired Bishop Offers Apology For 'Sinfulness'
description: At a tearful and somber prayer service, Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland apologized tonight to Roman Catholics here. He said he accepted ''full responsibility for the inappropriate nature'' of his relationship with a man who accused the archbishop of sexually assaulting him and was paid $450,000 in an out-of-court settlement.

title: FARMLAND IN BANKRUPTCY AFTER REJECTING SMITHFIELD BID
description: Farmland Industries, the nation's largest farm cooperative, filed for bankruptcy after failing to win a reprieve from lenders and rejecting a takeover bid from Smithfield Foods Inc. Farmland sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code, and plans to shed jobs, sell assets and reduce debt, company officials said on a conference call. The cooperative, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., has already sold its domestic grain business and closed its international trading unit to cut costs and pay interest on its debt after a four-year slump in demand for the fertilizer, seeds and fuel it sells to its 600,000 members.

title: S.E.C. Taking Closer Look At Wall St.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened 10 inquiries over the last year into potential conflicts of interest by securities analysts, and 5 of the inquiries have been upgraded to formal investigations, according to an S.E.C. memorandum released today by a congressman.

title: Demus Sets Record In 400-Meter Hurdles
description: Lashinda Demus of South Carolina set a world junior record of 54.85 seconds in the women's 400-meter hurdles at the N.C.A.A. championships yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, KATE
description: MOORE-Kate. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Katonah Museum of Art express their deepest condolences and sympathies to our Trustee and past President, Katherine Moore, her husband David and their family on the loss of their daughter. Victoria Morris, President, Board of Trustees Susan Edwards, Executive Director

title: Commencements; Joy, Tempered by Memory and Touched by Mettle
description: The joy of graduation at the Borough of Manhattan Community College yesterday was tempered with the lingering memories of Sept. 11.

title: Suspect in 1993 Bombing Says Trade Center Wasn't First Target
description: Abdul Rahman Yasin, the sole suspect in the World Trade Center bombing in 1993 who got away, said the twin towers were not the original target for that attack, because the mastermind of the plot had originally wanted to blow up Jewish neighborhoods in Brooklyn. Mr. Yasin spoke with Lesley Stahl of CBS News in an interview on May 23 in Iraq, where he fled after the bombing.

title: One Recent S.& L. Acquisition Does Not a Merger Wave Make
description: Citigroup's announcement last week that it was acquiring Golden State Bancorp has some analysts handicapping which savings and loans will be sold next, perhaps a couple of institutions in the New York area.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Grand Concourse Lease
description: The electronics retailer P. C. Richard & Sons will open its second store in the Bronx this year, a company executive said yesterday. The company has leased 35,000 square feet of ground-floor space on the corner of East Fordham Road and the Grand Concourse, said Thomas Pohmer, a vice president of P. C. Richard, which is based in Hauppauge, N.Y. The six-story Bronx building used to house an Alexander's department store and was later leased to Caldor, a discount retailer that went out of business in 1999.

title: An American Coffeehouse (or 4) in Vienna
description: It takes some hubris to bring an American coffee shop to Vienna, the city of cafes, and then to ban smoking in it.

title: A Powder Keg in South Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: UBS and Malaysian Utility In Costly Dispute on Bonds
description: When UBS Warburg helped the Malaysian utility company Tenaga Nasional Berhad sell $800 million in bonds back in 1997, the deal was hailed as a financial coup for both. Now a tangled closed-door legal dispute over those bonds has burst into the open and threatens to cost both companies a lot of money, and much else.

title: Enron's Ready Access
description: Pressed by Congressional Democrats, the White House has begun disgorging new information about the administration's extensive contacts with Enron executives. Alberto Gonzales, counsel to President Bush, asserted recently that the evidence showed that officials had responded in ''appropriate and responsible'' ways whenever they were in touch with the giant energy company, which collapsed last winter. But Mr. Gonzales's comment reflects precisely what is wrong with this picture. In Washington it is considered perfectly ''appropriate'' for officials to grant access to a company that used vast campaign donations to influence policy.

title: The Distant Drums of War; In Queens, Indians and Pakistanis Live in Harmony
description: The magazines and newspapers for sale on the streets of Jackson Heights, Queens, deliver the latest news from India and Pakistan with photographs of missiles and headlines like ''War Clouds,'' ''Retaliation'' and ''Armageddon?''

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Agency Criticized On Abuse
description: A new state report has accused the Department of Children and Families of failing to protect about 40 children at a facility for troubled youths that closed in 2001. The report, released on Thursday by Attorney General Richard Blumenthal and the state's child advocate, Jeanne Milstein, says the department chose ''a sustained pattern of denial and delay'' rather than address incidents of drug and sexual abuse at Haddam Hills Academy in East Haddam. Gary Kleeblatt, an agency spokesman, said that three Haddam Hills staff members had been fired for misconduct and that many recommendations had been carried out.

title: Excerpts From Opinion Rejecting Internet Law
description: Following are excerpts from a ruling yesterday by a federal appeals panel in Philadelphia that struck down the Children's Internet Protection Act, which required libraries to filter the Internet for material harmful to minors. The full text of the court decision is online at nytimes.com/national.

title: Andersen Witnesses Defend Intent of Shredding
description: The defense in Arthur Andersen's criminal case had its strongest day since the trial began last month, with two witnesses challenging government evidence that members of the firm intended to obstruct a federal inquiry by destroying thousands of documents related to Enron.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 23 about the mayor's presentation of the city's Doris C. Freedman Award to the Battery Park City Authority referred imprecisely to the position of the award's namesake in the Lindsay administration. She was the first director of the Department of Cultural Affairs, but not the city's first cultural affairs director. Barbara- lee Diamonstein (now Diamonstein-Spielvogel) was director of the Office of Cultural Affairs, a precursor to the department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTIS, ALAN A.
description: KURTIS-Alan A., 83, of Palm Beach, FL, passed away peacefully on May 30. Beloved by family and friends. He is survived by his wife, Arlene, daughter Fran Kurtis and son Jonathan and his wife, Jodi, and four grandchildren. Funeral June 2nd, 11AM at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach. Shiva at the residence.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHIN, JAMES P.
description: CHIN-James P. 11/6/36-6/1/96 You are our guardian angel and we love and miss you always. Elaine.

title: National Briefing: West
description: HAWAII: LAND PROPOSED FOR PROTECTION The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has proposed creating 550,000 acres of critical habitat to protect 146 threatened or endangered plant species on Oahu and the Big Island. The measure would restrict development and activity on federal lands included in the habitats, and on affected state and private land when federal money, permits or workers are involved. The service has proposed protecting 840,000 acres across the state  or 20 percent of Hawaii's land mass.

title: Manager Testifies Woody Allen Disregarded Films' Profitability
description: Woody Allen's business manager testified yesterday that Mr. Allen made one film after another, with little concern for the films' finances, even though they were struggling at the box office.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PALAY, EARL.
description: PALAY-Earl. May 12, 1932-June 1, 1982. Remembered always with love. Elizabeth and Gabriell

title: HEARST BUYS VERANDA MAGAZINE FOR UNDISCLOSED PRICE
description: Hearst Magazines said yesterday that it had purchased Veranda, an interior design magazine, from Veranda Publications Inc. of Atlanta. The purchase price was not disclosed. Veranda was founded in 1987 as a Southern quarterly by the editor in chief, Lisa Newsom, and Charles Ross, a former art director of Architectural Digest, and began coming out every two months in 1999. Both founders will remain with the publication. Veranda's paid circulation for the second half of 2001 was 393,270, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

title: Procter Is Suing Coca-Cola On Calcium Drinks Patent
description: Procter & Gamble, the consumer products giant, filed a lawsuit yesterday against the Coca-Cola Company, asserting that Coke's Minute Maid division had violated Procter's patent for adding calcium to fruit drinks.

title: One Bush Helps Another
description: For the second time in a year, President Bush has moved to limit offshore drilling for oil and natural gas along Florida's Gulf Coast. He also proposed to buy the privately held oil, gas and other mineral rights under three nature preserves adjacent to Everglades National Park. If approved by Congress, his proposals will protect the beaches that provide much of Florida's tourist income, and will greatly assist the fragile South Florida ecosystem, which has suffered from development and years of official neglect. It is hardly coincidental that they will also help his brother Jeb's re-election prospects in the Florida governor's race this fall.

title: Letter From Fehr Showed He Had Hope for Talks
description: Debate over the direction of secret talks in baseball's labor negotiations a year ago refuses to go away. Although those talks will not determine the outcome of the ongoing negotiations, the fallout from them continues to infect the bargaining environment.

title: Radiation Pills to Be Given Away
description: Westchester County will begin giving away potassium iodide tablets next week to people living within 10 miles of the Indian Point nuclear power plant to help protect them from possible radiation exposure during an emergency.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Abortion Case Ruling
description: A federal judge in Massachusetts ruled that the Department of Defense violated a woman's right to equal protection under the Constitution by denying health coverage for the abortion of a fetus with a fatal brain condition. The case involved Maureen Britell, the wife of a captain in the Air National Guard, who was told in her 20th week of pregnancy that her fetus was anencephalic, missing parts of the brain and certain to die outside the womb. The Civilian Health and Medical Program of the Uniformed Services refused to pay for an abortion. Judge Nancy Gertner of Federal District Court in Boston ruled that the agency had to reimburse the Britells for the abortion. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: High-Grade Marijuana Seized
description: Investigators arrested two men and seized about $1.5 million worth of high-grade marijuana early yesterday morning during a raid on a Tudor-style house in Douglaston Manor, Queens, the authorities said. The men, Vincent Sansone, 32, and Robert Diaz, 34, have been charged with possession of marijuana and drug paraphernalia, prosecutors said. Both were awaiting arraignment last night and could face up to 15 years in prison if convicted. Detectives also recovered $1,200 in cash, high-powered heat lamps and other equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLLOY, JOHN FRANCIS RAYMOND JR.
description: MOLLOY-John Francis Raymond Jr. A resident of Larchmont, died on May 30, 2002 at his home. He was 80. Mr. Molloy was born on April 4, 1922 to the late John Sr. and Nora (O'Leary) Molloy. During World War II he served in the US Navy on the USS Norton Sound. He studied Engineering at the University of Notre Dame, Manhattan College and Columbia University. As a Civil Engineer he worked at Hardesty and Hanover; Howard, Needles and Bergendoff; and Ammann and Whitney. He was member of Cai Epsilon and a fellow of the American Society of Civil Engineers where he was elected President of The Metropolitan Section. He was a talented musician who was a pianist, music arranger and leader of his own orchestra which played at the Palmer House in Chicago. In retirement, he played the piano for the Seniors at the Taylor Care Center in Valhalla. Mr. Molloy is survived by his wife, Kathleen Colligan Molloy; his children, John F.R. Molloy III, Patrick Molloy, Anne Molloy Fazio Lucker, Mary Elizabeth Molloy Spagnoli, and Dr. Raymond Molloy; his grandchildren, Lt. Teresa Fazio, USMC, Michael Fazio, Christopher Fazio, and Joshua Lucker; his son-in-law, Dr. Jay Lucker; his brother Daniel Molloy and his wife Kathleen (Kennelley); and his brother-inlaw, John Morrissey and his wife Eileen. Visiting will be Sunday 2-4, 7-9PM at Lloyd Maxcy & Sons Beaucamp Chapel, 16 Shea Place, New Rochelle. A funeral mass is scheduled for Monday at 10 A.M., at Sts. John and Paul Church. Interment will follow at Holy Mount Cemetery.

title: Star Power Isn't Fleeting For Giuliani
description: THE new issue of Family Circle crossed the desk the other day. A small item caught the eye. The magazine had asked American women in an online poll whom they would choose if they could switch places with a famous man for 24 hours.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Procter Is Suing Coca-Cola On Calcium Drinks Patent

title: Chinese Court Hands Down Prison Sentences for 2 Leaders of a Banned Party
description: Two leaders of the outlawed China Democracy Party have been given long prison sentences on subversion charges, a human rights monitor reported today.

title: MICROSOFT IS CHARGED WITH VIOLATING BOOKKEEPING RULES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has voted to charge Microsoft with violating bookkeeping rules when it held millions of dollars in reserves from 1995 to 1998, an S.E.C. commissioner, Isaac Hunt, said. The bookkeeping charges, approved in a meeting Thursday, will not result in a fine because the violations did not harm investors and because Microsoft cooperated with the inquiry, Mr. Hunt said. He added that without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Microsoft agreed that it would be subject to stiffer sanctions if the company committed similar violations in the future.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 23 about the mayor's presentation of the city's Doris C. Freedman Award to the Battery Park City Authority referred imprecisely to the position of the award's namesake in the Lindsay administration. She was the first director of the Department of Cultural Affairs, but not the city's first cultural affairs director. Barbaralee Diamonstein (now Diamonstein-Spielvogel) was director of the Office of Cultural Affairs, a precursor to the department.

title: Hewitt Advances As French Look Away
description: On a midmorning ideal for tennis at Roland Garros, the world's No. 1 player found himself in a stadium court turned abandoned warehouse.

title: The Yankees And Posada Let This One Get By Them
description: Through the lengthy rain delays, through the brief interruptions to offer updates on the Nets-Celtics game and through every draining inning, David Wells and Derek Lowe kept showing why they have been two of the most successful pitchers in the American League this season. The more they pitched through dicey situations, the more it seemed as if the first mistake might decide this tense game.

title: Keeping a Forest Safe
description: To the Editor:

title: A 79-Year-Old Master Joins His Disciple in an Adventure
description: The pianist Jason Moran has brought one of his idols to join his band this week at Iridium; if he's not quite fitting in like a fourth member, he's filling in the spaces around a tightly organized unit.

title: Another Quiet Ending For Walker and Pierce
description: In the morning, as the Celtics prepared for their last shot at keeping their season alive, Coach Jim O'Brien insisted that his two stars, Antoine Walker and Paul Pierce, would respond.

title: Martnez To Skip Start This Series
description: Pedro Martnez would have his normal four days' rest if he were to pitch against the Yankees in tomorrow's finale of the three-game series at Yankee Stadium. But the Red Sox, to preserve his right arm, have scheduled Martnez's next start for Monday in Detroit on five days' rest.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Inquiry Into Security Forces
description: A retired Canadian Supreme Court judge, Peter Cory, was named by the British and Irish governments to investigate six disputed cases where the police and security forces are said to have colluded in sectarian murders with paramilitary fighters in Northern Ireland. Among the cases are the killings of two Catholic civil rights lawyers, Pat Finucane in 1989 and Rosemary Nelson in 1999, and the gunning down of the Protestant paramilitary leader Billy Wright in the Maze prison outside Belfast in 1997 by Catholic inmates. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Outbreak of E. Coli Leaves Tight-Knit Village Uneasy
description: As health officials searched for the source of an outbreak of E. coli poisoning here, Mirl Fleischer wheeled her shopping cart out of the Rockland Kosher Supermarket today and worried about the health of this close-knit, largely Orthodox Jewish and Hasidic hamlet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, ANDREW
description: SCHLESINGER - Andrew. The Board of Governors and members of Bocaire Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Andrew Schlessinger, on Thursday, May 30, 2002. We extend condolences to all of his family. Graveside service will be held Sunday, June 2nd, 2 P.M. at Beth El Memorial Park Cemetery, Livonia, Michigan. Eugene Lowy, 1st V.P.

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Report Cites Dropout Rate
description: Nearly 25 percent of the state's high school students drop out before graduation, a new report has found. Conducted by researchers at the New Hampshire Center for Public Policy, the study shows that the state's official dropout rates are misleading, because they reflect yearly figures rather than cumulative data. Starting with the class of 1996 and ending with the class of 2000, researchers tracked how many students dropped out of a class over four years. Gov. Jeanne Shaheen said she was ordering educators to develop ways to reduce the dropout rate. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Pentagon Official Warns Asians to Guard Against Terror
description: Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz warned America's allies in Asia today to keep their guard up against terrorist activities within their borders, cautioning that even nations with large Muslim populations remain targets for attack by Islamic extremists.

title: Soccer-Challenged, but Not Soccer-Deprived
description: The World Cup, soccer's greatest showpiece, which opened in South Korea and Japan yesterday, is certainly a global sporting phenomenon, possibly even bigger than the Olympic Games. To millions around the world soccer offers reassurance that their countries can take on the best. Across much of Europe and Latin America soccer is more a national obsession than a game. In countries like Brazil, Argentina, France, Italy and England soccer teams have become symbols of the nation, and their illustrious track records in the World Cup a source of great national pride.

title: Robert L. Bien, 78, Architect Noted for Apartment Buildings
description: Robert L. Bien, a prolific architect who designed a number of Manhattan apartment buildings from 1959 to 1967, often using the fashionable white-brick facades of the era, died on May 25 at his home near Stuyvesant Square in Lower Manhattan. He was 78.

title: Pakistani President at the Fulcrum of Crisis
description: With South Asia teetering on the edge of war, President Bush has imposed on Pakistan the burden of dragging it back into balance.

title: G.I.'s Mistakenly Attack Friendly Afghan Soldiers, Killing 3
description: American Special Forces troops mistakenly fired on a group of friendly Afghan soldiers in a predawn firefight today in eastern Afghanistan, killing three men and wounding two other people they mistook for Qaeda fighters, American military officials said.

title: Jefferson and Harris Give Nets a Big Lift
description: Lucious Harris has seen it all in his five seasons with the Nets: the piles and piles of embarrassing losses, the wacky actions of the front office, the coach versus player dramas, the freak injuries. So this Eastern Conference championship means more to him than to most, and he is not afraid to say so, especially to the Nets' rookies.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officer Injured In Crash
description: An off-duty rookie police officer was critically injured early yesterday morning when he lost control of his car on a steep hill in Upper Manhattan and hit a tree, the authorities said. The officer, Luis Reyes, 24, was not far from his apartment in Fort George around 5:40 a.m. when his car spun out of control on the bend of Fort George Avenue that connects Amsterdam and St. Nicholas Avenues in High Bridge Park, the police said. The car caught fire after striking the tree. No other cars were involved. Officer Reyes, who started his career in March at the 33rd Precinct in Washington Heights, was taken to Columbia-Presbyterian Center of New York-Presbyterian Hospital, where he was listed in critical condition last night. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: After Barely Qualifying, Germany Erases Doubts
description: SAPPORO, Japan, June 1 - Germany, it seems, is a team that seems to play its best around tournament time, "gamers" to American baseball fans.

title: Israel's Forces Move Into Nablus, Seizing 100 and Imposing Curfew
description: Israeli tanks and troops stormed into Nablus and its neighboring Balata refugee camp before dawn today, rounding up about a hundred Palestinians, in the largest of the daily raids since its virtual occupation of most West Bank cities in April.

title: U.S.O.C. Begins Search for President
description: Marty Mankamyer and Paul E. George, two of the United States Olympic Committee's five vice presidents, emerged yesterday as the leading and perhaps only major candidates for president.

title: Help at Family Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Scandals Tainting Japan's Pride In Its Food
description: Long a point of national pride, the sterling reputation of Japan's food industry has been tarnished in recent months by scandals tumbling out one after the other: four cases of mad cow disease, most recently in mid-May here in Japan's farming heartland; Brazilian chicken labeled as Japanese; Vietnamese salt labeled as Japanese; mixed rice labeled as single-variety; American beef sold as Japanese.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Making A Point On Global Warming
description: To make the point that European nations, unlike the United States, are squarely behind the Kyoto treaty for the reduction of greenhouse gases, diplomats and officials from all 15 members of the European Union presented their countries' ratifications to the United Nations in a group ceremony. Seventy countries have ratified the treaty, more than the required 55, but together the ratifying nations must account for at least 55 percent of total emissions from industrial countries, and that target has not been met. Japan is to ratify the pact next week, and the Europeans are pressing Russia to ratify so the treaty can come into force. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Seeing the New Era Before 9/11
description: It is easy to feel, as Virginia Woolf once said about an earlier cataclysm, that after Sept. 11 human consciousness changed, that beforehand no one could have guessed at the kinds of traumas and transformations that were about to unfold. But judging from this book -- which, after a decade of work, must have been all but complete at the time -- the historian Philip Bobbitt had a pretty good idea. Apart from a postscript added on Dec. 13, 2001, and a smattering of inserted footnotes and allusions, Mr. Bobbitt's evolutionary map of warfare's impact on the state foreshadow the kinds of events still unfolding. What has happened since -- even last week's announcement that Russia is now affiliated with its onetime nemesis, NATO -- fits eerily well with his speculations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, ELEANOR D. ''SIDDY''
description: WILSON-Eleanor D. ''Siddy'', 93, actress and artist, died peacefully after a year-long struggle with lung cancer on May 31, 2002 at her home in Williamstown, MA. A memorial service will be held Monday at 1:00 PM at St. John's Episcopal Church, 35 Park St, Williamstown, MA. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to The Actors' Fund of America, 729 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10019.

title: TEACHING PRO LEADS N.F.L. CLASSIC
description: James Mason shot the round of his life -- a 65 -- for the first-day lead in the N.F.L. Golf Classic, the Senior Tour event that teams the pros with present and former National Football League players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARASOW, MARC SIMON, DR.
description: TARASOW-Marc Simon, Dr. Died on May 30, 2002. Born March 14, 1966 in Buffalo to Helene (nee Toub) Tarasow and the late Rabbi Morris Tarasow. A graduate of SUNY Binghamton & Downstate Medical School. He worked in a variety of Emergency Medical Care Clinics. A funny man who was full of life, Dr. Tarasow lived his life to the fullest for the past 7 years before succumbing to brain cancer. He is survived by his mother Helene, loving partner, Henry Grullon, sisters Deborah Salomon and Lisa Langwell, nieces Micole, Gabi, Madison and Erin & his dog, Sammy. A funeral service will be held on Sunday 11AM at the pavillion at Dolphin Cove in Stamford, CT. Burial will be at New Montefiore Cemetery in Farmingdale. For more information, Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 E. Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck, www.zionmemorialchapel.com phone 914-381-1809.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: YUGOSLAVIA: A NATION RESHAPED Parliament overwhelmingly endorsed a looser union between the two remaining republics. Constitutional experts now have to work out the exact structure of the new state, to be called Serbia and Montenegro, which was created under pressure from the European Union to stave off a Montenegrin independence bid and to discourage other Balkan separatists, especially in Kosovo, a province of Serbia. Serbia and Montenegro will be broadly autonomous but share a president, cabinet and army; either can leave the union after three years. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Agent Who Wrote Critical Letter May Testify
description: The nation will probably soon get to see and hear Coleen Rowley, the Minneapolis F.B.I. agent who has been widely lauded for her complaint that bureau officials in Washington brushed aside information about terrorist plans before Sept. 11, Congressional officials said today.

title: A Powder Keg in South Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Zimbabwe Acts to Obtain AIDS Drugs At Low Prices
description: Desperate for cheaper AIDS treatments, Zimbabwe has declared its H.I.V. epidemic a national emergency, a move that allows it to sidestep patents on essential drugs and import generic substitutes.

title: Costs of Medicines Still Hurt
description: Partisan politics is on the verge of claiming another victim in this country: older Americans. Both political parties promised in 2000 that help was on the way in the struggle with prescription drugs. Roughly one of every five television ads for federal candidates was about prescription drugs. Today, two years later, both parties have delivered nothing but reams of rhetoric while smiling and telling our older citizens, You're next on the agenda, we promise.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Chappaqua: No Jail For Party Parents
description: A mother and father who gave their son's high school football team -- which included 15-year-olds -- a pre-season party that featured a stripper, will not go to jail. The parents, Robert Wien, 50, and Rochelle Wien, 48, pleaded guilty in New Castle Town Court on Thursday night to endangering the welfare of a child, a misdemeanor, and disorderly conduct, a noncriminal violation. They will have to fulfill 100 hours of community service and one year of probation, after which the misdemeanor charge may be thrown out, their lawyer said. The party for the team, the Horace Greeley Quakers, was broken up by the police after a neighbor complained about the noise. Since the party on Sept. 1, Mr. Wien has lost his job as a senior managing director at Josephthal & Company and Mrs. Wien has lost her job as a special education teacher at Howard Haber Early Education Center.

title: Palestinian Bombers
description: To the Editor:

title: Lost in Translation at the F.B.I.
description: In announcing his restructuring of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Robert S. Mueller III, its director, stressed the importance of upgrading the F.B.I.'s intelligence capabilities by recruiting ''the right people with the right experience.'' If my own experience with the agency is any guide, that should include an urgent recruiting drive for people with the right Arabic language skills.

title: More Than Two of the Pas de Deux
description: In one way or another, the pas de deux was at the heart of nearly all the dances presented by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater. Two revivals from past Diamond Project seasons of new choreography wore that heart on their sleeves.

title: Ventura's Bat Complicates Yanks' Plans
description: Robin Ventura is enjoying a renaissance with the Yankees, but he insisted that he had not thought about where he might play next season. Ventura even said he would dissuade the Yankees from discussing a contract extension if they approached him, something they are surely weeks from deciding.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSHFELD, FRANCES ROSENBLUM
description: HIRSHFELD-Frances Rosenblum, left us three years ago today. Mama, I miss you more than you will ever know. You should see how things have changed around here.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: A Writer's Place
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: MONTANA: JUDGE PUTS HOLD ON GRAZING A federal judge has issued an injunction that prohibits livestock grazing on about 2,000 acres of federal land outside of Yellowstone National Park. Animal rights and environmental protection groups had opposed the grazing because they said it increased the number of bison who were killed to stem the spread of brucellosis among cattle. Bison that leave the park are rounded up and killed if they test positive for the disease. The Forest Service must now conduct an environmental analysis before a grazing permit can be reissued. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Nabors Shareholder Files Suit On Plan to Move to Bermuda
description: Nabors Industries, another big company planning to move to Bermuda in address only so it can sharply reduce its United States taxes, misled shareholders about the costs of the plan while withholding critical information about the dangers, according to a lawsuit filed on Thursday in Federal District Court in Houston.

title: A Powder Keg in South Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: An Escalating Blame Game Ensues Over the High Price of Auto Insurance
description: With costs soaring for auto insurance companies, New York is moving toward becoming the most expensive state in the country for coverage. But legislation intended to cut one of the biggest expenses -- fraudulent claims -- has stalled in Albany; adjournment of the state's Assembly is just weeks away, and the odds are rising against a compromise even as the problem worsens.

title: John B. Keane, Irish Novelist And Playwright, Is Dead at 73
description: John B. Keane, an Irish writer who recorded the voice of a disappearing generation from his pub in County Kerry, died on Thursday in his beloved hometown, Listowel. He was 73.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economic Growth Rises
description: Canada's growth rate accelerated sharply in the first quarter, with gross domestic product expanding at an annual rate of 6 percent, after adjusting for inflation, compared with 2.9 percent in the previous three months and 0.6 percent a year earlier, Statistics Canada said. Investment in new housing surged 10.5 percent, an all-time high. The rebound was also driven by robust consumer spending, a slowing rate of inventory depletion and a recovery in exports and factory output. The strong performance has reinforced expectations that the Bank of Canada will raise its overnight interest rate by a quarter of a point, to 2.5 percent, the next time it considers rates, on Tuesday. It would be the second increase in two months. By Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Author Goodwin Resigns From Pulitzer Board
description: The historian Doris Kearns Goodwin resigned yesterday from the board that chooses the winners of the Pulitzer Prize. The prize had begun an inquiry into accusations that Ms. Goodwin copied the work of others in her 1987 book ''The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Chile Military Tells Public To See Swords As Plowshares
description: After 60,000 acres of forest went up in flames this year, the government made an announcement that irritated more than a few Chileans. It said it had agreed to purchase 10 F-16 jet fighters from the United States, but could not afford the planes and helicopters needed to put out forest fires.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Mugabe Tells Rival To Accept Defeat
description: President Robert Mugabe, left, urged his opposition party rival, Morgan Tsvangirai, to accept for the benefit of the country the fact that he was defeated in the presidential election in March. Mr. Tsvangirai has contested Mr. Mugabe's victory, saying he believes the poll was rigged. Talks between the opposition and Mr. Mugabe's party about the possibility of a coalition government have collapsed. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: So What Would You Call It? Toilettown?
description: Every night, just after 8 in Henry Miller's Theater, Jeff McCarthy senses the resistance. Taking his place onstage, he gazes into the audience and, disconcertingly, can feel an undercurrent of antipathy from the crowd.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Abuses Persist, Rights Group Says
description: Amnesty International called the recent release from house arrest of the pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, a positive development. But it urged continued international pressure on the military government over human rights abuses, including forced labor and political arrests. Despite a highly publicized program of releases, it said that at the start of this year, about 1,600 political prisoners were still being held. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Many Relatives, Wary and Anguished, Shun Sept. 11 Fund
description: Nearly six months after the federal government opened its checkbook to the relatives of the 3,200 people killed or seriously injured on Sept. 11, fewer than 10 families have filed completed applications, illustrating the complex nature of the process, the anguish or wariness some families still have about settling a victim's financial affairs and lingering concerns about the government fund's fairness.

title: U.S. Argues War Detainee Shouldn't See A Lawyer
description: The government argued today that Yasser Esam Hamdi, a prisoner from the Afghan war who was born in Baton Rouge, La., and is in custody in Norfolk, should not be allowed to see a lawyer for national security reasons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTENHABER, MORRIS BERNARD
description: GERSTENHABER-Morris Bernard, 88. Died Thursday, May 30th, 2002. Active attorney until recent retirement, W.W. II Veteran US Army Signal Corps Thirty-Sixth Division. Beloved husband of the late Audrey Abeles Gerstenhaber, the late Frances Einstein Gerstenhaber, and companion of Jean Rosenstone. Devoted father of Brett, Garth & Melissa and fatherin-law of Blanche and Gary. Adored grandfather of Dana, Bart, Rodd, Meg and Adam. Funeral service at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 331 Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, 1 P.M. Contributions may be made to ADL, Department DJ, 823 United Nations Plaza, New York, New York 10017, or to the charity of your choice.

title: F.B.I. Report Found Agency Not Ready To Counter Terror
description: A top secret report warned top officials of the F.B.I. in the months before Sept. 11 that the bureau faced significant terrorist threats from Middle Eastern groups like Al Qaeda but lacked enough resources to meet the threat, senior government officials said.

title: In a Stunner, Senegal Tops The Champion
description: When it was over, the victorious players leaped on one another's backs and danced in the corner of the field and dropped to the grass in joyous disbelief. How improbable was this? Senegal, making its first appearance in the World Cup, had defeated none other than France, the reigning champion and its former colonial master.

title: Fund-Raising Fatigue Sets In for New Jersey G.O.P.
description: Lean times or not, Republicans found $30 million to give to their national party organization in just one soiree last month at the Washington Convention Center. No one thinks the party is running out of money.

title: Northeast Hit By Tornadoes, Wind and Hail
description: Wild weather hit the New York region yesterday, with several tornadoes reported, and one person was killed when a severe storm swept through a crowded amusement park in western Pennsylvania.

title: Study Finding Celebrex Safer Was Flawed, Journal Says
description: An editorial in the June 1 issue of The British Medical Journal harshly criticizes a scientific study that the drug company Pharmacia used to promote Celebrex, the arthritis drug that is its best-selling product.

title: New Twist in Case of U.S. Reporter Killed in Mexican Hills
description: ''Civilization be dinged! It is the mountains and the desert for me,'' the American journalist Ambrose Bierce wrote before disappearing in Mexico in 1913.

title: Rights Group Says Circus Spied on It
description: The nation's largest animal rights group has accused the leadership of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus of using a former government intelligence official to help steal documents, tap phones and plant informers in an effort to stifle criticism of the circus, according to a lawsuit filed in Virginia on Thursday.

title: A Powder Keg in South Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Metro Briefing column yesterday about an outbreak of E. coli poisoning among children in Monsey, N.Y., in Rockland County, misstated the town's location. It is about 40 miles south of Poughkeepsie, not 60 miles north.

title: A Powder Keg in South Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Graying Now, McCarthyites Keep the Faith
description: For more years than he can remember, Jerome Flemming has been coming to St. Mary Cemetery here every May for a memorial service at the grave of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. Like others who make this pilgrimage to McCarthy's birthplace and resting place, Mr. Flemming, 87, was both a friend to the senator and a supporter of his cold war crusade against what he called communist subversion in Washington.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Lowers Forecast
description: Commerzbank lowered its profit forecast because a cost-cutting program for the bank, Germany's fourth largest, has been less effective than expected. The chief executive, Klaus-Peter Mller, left, told investors the overhaul, which includes slashing jobs and closing branches, would help increase net income by 640 million euros ($600 million) from 2001 to 2003.

title: Roy's Fall Helps Detroit Stay on Course to Finals
description: The Detroit Red Wings are going to the Stanley Cup finals with a chance to win the trophy for the third time in six seasons, and their goalie, the veteran Dominik Hasek, has an opportunity for his first Cup in his first season with the team.

title: A Changed Debate on Smoking Restrictions
description: The State Senate plans to vote for the first time on a law that would ban smoking in restaurants statewide, except in bar areas and separately ventilated smoking rooms, said John McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate Republican majority.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in The Arts on Thursday about new photography exhibitions in Washington misstated the opening date of one show and omitted the site of another. ''Open City: Street Photographs Since 1950'' at the Hirschhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden is to open June 20, not tomorrow. ''Edward Weston: Photography and Modernism,'' which opens today, is at the Phillips Collection.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  APFEL, IKE
description: APFEL-Ike, 6/1/52-10/2/92. I wish I could celebrate your 50th birthday. I wish. Always grieving, always loving you. Mom

title: Two Convicted In a Tax Case
description: A federal jury in Sacramento convicted two leaders of Anderson's Ark, a seller of tax avoidance products, on money-laundering and conspiracy charges yesterday, bringing to seven the number of Ark associates who have been convicted or pleaded guilty.

title: John Middleton Murry, 76; Wrote Novels of the Paranormal
description: John Middleton Murry, a British science fiction writer who published almost two dozen novels and several collections of short stories exploring themes that included how the paranormal might affect ordinary lives, died on April 29. He was 76.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Higher Fees For More College Courses
description: The Board of Regents is considering charging students at public colleges higher tuition for taking excess credit hours or repeating courses. Strained by record enrollments and growing budget deficits, board members have proposed tripling or quadrupling in-state tuition for students who take more than 135 percent of the credit hours required for a major. In-state tuition at the state colleges ranges from $1,529 to $3,043. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Government and Media Spar in Zimbabwe
description: Over the past two months, the authorities in Zimbabwe have arrested 11 journalists, ordered state agencies to stop advertising in newspapers that criticize the government and canceled the broadcasting license of the only privately owned television station.

title: Senegal stuns France as World Cup opens
description: SEOUL:  Sport is able to conjure magic. Here in the capital of South Korea on Friday, Senegal, at its first World Cup, beat France, the champion of the world and Senegal's former colonial master, 1-0. The solitary goal was scored by a big midfielder, Pape Bouba Diop.

title: On the Street
Introduction
description: Frank Rich's report on anchormen prompted mail protesting the put-down of older viewers and of the prime-time advertisements for remedies aimed at them. An injection of cable's spirited style might be just the remedy for the malaise that, some readers said, ails network news.
