description: Children like to hear a story over and over again, and each time they want it told exactly the same, word for word. Grown-ups, on th0" width="468" align="left" valign="top">

title: Film Series Listings
description: AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE  Rescued Treasures From the Library of Congress. Today, 2: Hitchcock's "Spellbound" (1945; at 4: Dieterle's "Portrait of Jennie" (1948). Christine Vachon and Killer Films. Sat., 1: Haynes's "Dottie Gets Spanked" (1993) with Hestand's "He Was Once" (1989); at 2: Harron's "I Shot Andy Warhol" (1996); at 4:30: Haynes's "Velvet Goldmine" (1998). Repertory Nights. Sat.-next Sun., 7:30: Melville's "Bob le Flambeur" (1955). 35th Ave. at 36th St., Astoria, Queens. (718-784-0077)

title: Enduring
description: Pearls are the single accessory that never go out of style. Only the way they are worn changes, from the baroque pearls of Renaissance princesses and Elizabeth I to the yardlong strings of 19th-century belles. Last year they were printed trompe-l'oeil-style on T-shirts, left. But the pearl bead was not to be outdone, right, with five-strand swags at the throat or under the arm. For others, a few strands worn as a belt accented small waistlines. Some people had it both ways, below, with a pearl-bead bracelet and a pearl T-shirt print.

title: May 26-June 1; COMING UP
description: The House considers granting $225 billion to enhance security at the nation's seaports. On Wednesday, a Senate panel reviews legislation to overturn Nevada's veto of the Yucca Mountain nuclear waste proposal. President Bush meets with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt at Camp David on Saturday.

title: International Food Court
description: THE early signs are unmistakable: the Bradford pear trees are in bloom and the smell of barbecued chicken and the sounds of music are in the air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIEN, ROBERT L.
description: BIEN-Robert L. Prominent New York City mid-century architect and a distinguished gentleman, died on May 25, 2002. Our mentor and friend, the consummate professional who always had time for a story and a laugh. Mr. Bien was a walking historian of New York City and its architecture. Our deepest sympathy to his wife and our dear friend Lynne, daughter Deborah, grandchildren Jocelyn and Robert and sister Phyllis McGovern. We will forever be graced by his spirit and guidance. A public memorial service will be held Tuesday, June 4, at 12 noon at the chapel of St. George's Church, 6 Rutherford Place (between 16th and 17th Streets and 2nd and 3rd Avenues). Craig J. Smith Christina Romann Victor Samulari Partners at Smith Palmer + Famulari

title: Are Large Caps Back in Style? Ask Again in a Year
description: LARGE-CAPITALIZATION stocks came to life in May, considerably outperforming the small caps. That was a reversal of the situation that had prevailed for two years, and it has led some bullish advisers to declare that happy days are here again for the market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, MIRIAM B.
description: KLEIN-Miriam B. Of Harrison, NY on May 31, 2002, age 91. Wife of the late Louis M. Klein. Mother of Honie Ann Peacock, Arthur Klein (Patricia) and Toby Haynes (Wilson). Grandmother of Chiara Peacock, Justin Haynes, Joshua Haynes, Zoe and Isaac Klein. Funeral service Monday, 1:30PM Chapel in the Woods at Congregation Kol Ami, Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. Interment Mount Pleasant Cemetery. Friends will be received at 69 South Road, Harrison, New York, Monday 4:30 P.M. until 8 P.M. and Tuesday 12 noon until 7 P.M.

title: Two Conservatives Tell Bush They Oppose Plan for Police
description: Two leading conservatives have joined a chorus of police officials and immigrant rights advocates in opposing a Justice Department proposal to allow state and local law enforcement agencies to track down illegal immigrants as a way to fight terrorism.

title: Tiviakov and Others Enjoy New Battle of the Pyramids
description: The Golden Cleopatra Open near the pyramids of Cairo was a harvest for foreigners. Sergei Tiviakov of the Netherlands took first place with 8 1/2--2 1/2 in the 11-round event.

title: Critics of Weatherspoon Grow Quieter
description: Teresa Weatherspoon of the Liberty has heard the whispers from fans, the news media and even some of her colleagues in the Women's National Basketball Association.

title: May 26-June 1: NATIONAL; RX FOR R.N.'S
description: When nurses are in short supply, hospital patients suffer: they are more likely to contract urinary infections and pneumonia, to stay longer and to die of treatable conditions like shock or cardiac arrest, according to a study in the New England Journal of Medicine. Researchers, who looked at 6 million cases from 1997, found that only the number of registered nurses -- and not of less skilled aides or practical nurses -- had that effect. The U.S. has a serious shortage of nurses. Denise Grady

title: Executing a Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Jasmine Vasavada, Christopher Herzog
description: Jasmine Balendu Vasavada, a daughter of Dr. Maria R. Vastesaeger and Dr. Balendu C. Vasavada of Scotch Plains, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Parker Herzog, the son of Elaine Parker Herzog and Prof. Gregory F. Herzog of Highland Park, N.J. The Rev. Charles J. Stephens, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Princeton Academy of the Sacred Heart in Princeton, N.J.

title: What's Your Opinion? He Knows
description: PEOPLE often ask Dr. Frank Newport for his opinion, but he isn't talking.

title: Nineteen Songs With a Single Beat
description: Reggae producers have hit-making down to a science. They'll create a simple beat, then get a wide range of singers to record their own vocals on top of it, letting listeners decide which ones they like best. The practice has spawned a peculiar tradition: ''rhythm albums,'' collections of songs based on the same beat.

title: Global Education: Reach Ever Higher
description: To the Editor:

title: A Castle Restored, Including the Quirks
description: FOR proof that William Gillette was quirky, check with the professionals who have worked to renovate his former retirement house at Gillette Castle State Park, along the banks of the Connecticut River in Lyme and East Haddam.

title: Investing; Beyond the Big Loss at Vodafone
description: RECORDING the largest loss in British corporate history should not be cause for jubilation, yet shares of the Vodafone Group jumped nearly 10 percent just minutes after the company announced the news on Tuesday.

title: Yvonne Gonzales and Paul Redman
description: AS chief usher at the Metropolitan Opera House, Paul Arthur Redman knows well the dramatic roles that send ill-fated lovers tumbling to their graves. Which may explain why in 1992, Yvonne Gonzales, a starry-eyed soprano with a repertory of Mozartean ingnues, held his gaze as she performed in the winners' round of the Met's National Council auditions.

title: Kathryn Barry, Zachary Taylor
description: Kathryn Barry, the daughter of Patricia M. Barry and Desmond T. Barry Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Zachary John Taylor, the son of Gabrielle S. Taylor and John R. Taylor of West Grove, Pa. The Rev. Barry Furey performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Church in Darien, Conn.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Natasha and Andre are quitting before graduation -- like 1 in 5 who attend New York City public high schools.

title: Airports Urge Delay in New Security Rules
description: The top officials of 39 airports, which handle most of the nation's air travelers, have warned the secretary of transportation that air travel will be seriously disrupted in January unless Congress delays the Dec. 31 deadline for screening all checked bags, a major defense against terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLETSKY, MAXINE SVIGALS, RN.
description: SOLETSKY-Maxine Svigals, RN. On May 30, in Houston, TX. Wife of Louis M. Soletsky. Beloved mother of Marjorie Leventon, Susan Soletsky, Beth Lodinger and Philip Soletsky. Grandmother of Isaac, Nathan, Natalie, David, Jacob, Zachary, Ari and Samuel. She made the world a better place. In lieu of flowers Jewish Children's Regional Service, P.O. Box 7368, Metairie, LA 70010-7368.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOKKENHEUSER, DR. VICTOR D.
description: BOKKENHEUSER-Dr. Victor D. On May 31, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Elize. Affiliated with St. Luke's/Roosevelt Hospital and Columbia University. Memorial service Wednesday, June 5, 6 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made in Victor's name to the National Leukemia Foundation.

title: What If Investors Won't Join the Party?
description: BY many measures, the United States economy is rebounding smartly from its desultory performance in late 2001. But even as economic output surges and corporate profits appear once more to be rising, one closely watched indicator of economic oomph remains depressed: the broad stock market indexes. All of the big-company indexes, the ones that reflect what investors are most likely to own through mutual funds, are still down for the year.

title: Life Without Parole?
description: Years ago, I worked in a drug-treatment center in Washington, helping to ensure that heroin addicts took their methadone and received productive counseling (Jennifer Gonnerman, May 19). I was struck then by the fact that those who did the best had the best supervisory help. And those supervisors who had the best records in helping addicts find meaningful jobs, good housing and solid relationships had the lowest case loads.

title: After Fight Is Stopped, the Winner Is Holyfield
description: It must get tiring to hear that you are over the hill, that one day your beaten body will be carted out of the ring like a slab of beef. It must get annoying to constantly read and hear to get out, get out now, before the brain in your head starts doing back flips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBAITO, ANTHONY
description: LOBAITO-Anthony. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Anthony Lobaito, associated with The Times from 1959 until retiring in 1992.

title: Play That Old Piece if You Must, but Not for Old Time's Sake
description: LORIN MAAZEL conducts the New York Philharmonic in Shostakovich's Fifth Symphony! Esa-Pekka Salonen conducts the Los Angeles Philharmonic in Shostakovich's Fifth Symphony! Christoph Eschenbach conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in Shostakovich's Fifth Symphony!

description: To the Editor:

title: Blood Donors Sought To Take Up the Slack
description: LONG ISLAND hospitals are appealing to donors to avert a blood shortage after a government ban on blood from Europe went into effect on Friday. The ban is aimed at preventing mad cow disease.

title: Ratings Increase For Nets-Celtics
description: The Nets' 96-88 victory Friday night over the Boston Celtics to clinch the Eastern Conference championship earned an 8.7 overnight Nielsen rating. The game peaked at a 12.7 rating in the final half-hour, from 9:30 to 10 p.m., Eastern Daylight Time.

title: Girls of Summer, Without Ruffles
description: This year, stylish wedding parties -- are avoiding the precious effect of fussy, matched flower-girl dresses and livening up the aisle with a bouquet of mixed patterns and colors. Fashionable brides are cutting through the pastel treacle by dressing little attendants in unmatched Lilly Pulitzer summer frocks ($62 to $72 at Saks Fifth Avenue). The company's most popular bridal styles, the Annette and the Little Lilly, come in buoyant hues and refreshingly unprissy patterns, like pink hippos, turquoise turtles and green monkeys.

title: Still Speaking His Mind After All These Years
description: THE talk that drew a standing-room-only crowd at a Ronkonkoma hotel on a recent Friday morning was titled, rather blandly, ''Long Island's Unexploited Assets.''

title: Lake Champlain
description: Stretching 125 miles from southern Quebec to the tiny Vermont town of Benson's Landing, Lake Champlain is inland New England's answer to the Atlantic. Stay by it long enough, and your eye will expect tiers of mountains on the far side of large bodies of water. Seascapes may forever disappoint.

title: Julia Herr, Scott Smith
description: Julia Ellen Herr, a daughter of Judge Marilyn Rhyne Herr and C. Ryman Herr, both of Stanton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Scott Godfrey Smith, a son of Rodger F. Smith of Darien, Conn., and the late Sarah Godfrey Smith. The Rev. Richard A. Miller performed the ceremony at the Stanton Reformed Church.

title: A Designer at His Peak Without a Label
description: IT'S been nearly half a century since the fashion designer Karl Lagerfeld arrived in Paris from his native Hamburg. And though he is in many ways France's most famous German migr and has kept with him, in whatever place he has lived, a nearly exact reproduction of the bedroom he had as a child, the German word for home or motherland, heimat, doesn't exist for him.

description: Honoring Firefighters

title: A Little Ella, Some Patsy, All Norah
description: ''IT'S kind of scary to be called the next anything,'' Norah Jones wrote in an e-mail during a tour stop in Portugal. But since the release in February of her debut album, ''Come Away With Me,'' which has sold more than a half-million copies, critics have compared the 23-year-old Ms. Jones to performers as disparate as Billie Holiday, Joni Mitchell, Aretha Franklin, Cassandra Wilson and even Willie Nelson. Her tour stops in Manhattan on Thursday and Friday, when she'll perform at Town Hall, on West 43rd Street in Manhattan.

title: Eminem Becomes A Franchise
description: THE way Eminem tells it on his new album, ''The Eminem Show,'' he's every parent's nightmare, every misfit's hero, every politician's comeuppance and every tabloid's fodder. He's a hard-working artist, a hip-hop champ, a hair-trigger sociopath, a furious son and a loving dad. As if we didn't already know.

title: Leigh's Introduction
description: To the Editor:

title: Advances in Flies, if You Can See Them
description: I figure that my friend the fly-tier, whose creations are so perfect it seems a shame to fish with them, knows everything about trout flies. So I asked him why the artificials that he and others create were so small now, when once they were clearly visible even to anglers of a certain age.

title: The Curse Of the InStyle Wedding
description: A YEAR ago this month, Kelly Rutherford, an actress who starred on ''Melrose Place,'' married Carlos Tarajano, a Venezuelan banker, at the Good Shepherd Catholic Church in Beverly Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREITZER, SHIRLEY ARONOFF
description: GREITZER-Shirley Aronoff. Of New York, died suddenly but peacefully on Wednesday, May 29, 2002. The pianist and former Director of Placement at the Juilliard School of Music was inspirational to those she helped and those she loved. Her family mourns her loss with the deepest love and affection, knowing that her many talents will live on through her three children and six grandchildren. Her sister and niece mourn as well. Services will be held on Sunday, June 2, 2002 at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St. at 11:45am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Juilliard School of Music.

title: Both Sigel and Bland Are Surprised by Success
description: Until last week, Jay Sigel had not won on the Senior PGA Tour since 1998. John Bland is still searching for his first victory since 1996.

title: Private Sector; Have Skis, Will Barbecue?
description: For George N. Gillett Jr., leisure sports and meat consumption definitely go hand in hand. ''I obviously like to ski, hunt and fish,'' he said with a laugh. ''And I also love to eat beef and pork. We've been active in both of these businesses for a long time.''

title: For 100 Million, He Is Saturday Night
description: FOR sheer longevity and number of viewers, nothing on American television compares to the variety show ''Sbado Gigante,'' or Giant Saturday. Week after week for 40 years, this three-hour program has been a Saturday night fixture, and it's now seen by up to 100 million Spanish-speakers in 20 countries, including the United States.

title: Ideas & Trends: Film Noir Lite; When Actions Have No Consequences
description: AN S.U.V. sits at a deserted intersection as the traffic light turns red to green to red. Outside, a squat building with a neon sign: Police. Inside the car, a calculating couple -- a wife and a husband planning to escape a murder charge.

title: Music Listings
description: Classical/Opera

title: Buzz Cut, Company Car And Plastic
description: WOODY GUTHRIE painted the words ''This machine kills fascists'' across the face of his guitar. Phranc, the self-described all-American Jewish lesbian folk singer, put a sticker that reads ''This machine sells Tupperware'' on the front of hers.

title: A Horse Tale With a Finish to Come
description: Like most great horse tales, this one begins in a sales ring, a minor one in Ruidoso, N.M. It turns on a missed opportunity, a last-chance flight to Las Vegas and involves a craps table, a cowboy hat and a hot tub. It might very well end historically on Saturday if a colt named War Emblem runs off with the Belmont Stakes to become only the 12th Triple Crown winner in thoroughbred racing.

title: Tapas, Sun and Sherry
description: Tapas, the tasty small dishes traditionally served with sherries and other wines at Spanish bars, are a good light meal in warm weather.

title: A Handsome Hunk Of a Glass Tower
description: ALTHOUGH Donald Trump prefers to publicize the aggressive side of his nature -- it's the manly thing to do -- he is also the only beauty freak at large in New York City real estate development. Aggression and desire, violence and sex: put them together and they add up to Trump World Tower, undeniably the most primal building New York has seen in quite a while.

title: May 26-June 1: INTERNATIONAL; MYSTERY IN TAIWAN CRASH
description: Without so much as a distress call from the pilot, a China Airlines Boeing 747-200 25 minutes into a flight from Taipei to Hong Kong broke into four pieces and plunged more than five miles into the Taiwan Strait. The crash killed all 225 people aboard and scattered debris across hundreds of square miles of ocean between China and Taiwan. Choppy seas and powerful currents made the recovery of wreckage and bodies difficult, leaving air safety investigators at a loss to explain the accident. The Taiwanese government moved to take over the airline, the country's largest, which has one of the worst safety records in commercial aviation. Keith Bradsher

title: Correction
description: Afront-page article in this section last Sunday about Korean-owned delis misstated the number of grocery businesses in the city. According to the state's Department of Agriculture and Markets, the current number is 11,481, not 3,000.

title: Flying in Pairs
description: Two people flying together to London (Heathrow or Gatwick) on British Airways can get both fares for the price of one and a half, through Sept. 25. With the discount, sample fares per person for midweek flights are $543 from Kennedy, Newark or Boston; $603 from Washington; $738 from Los Angeles. Tickets must be bought by July 31, booked at least a week ahead and paid for when booking. A Saturday-night stay-over is required; taxes and fees add about $90. Other restrictions apply. These fares can be booked only at www.britain2002.org .

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Charleston, Staten Island; Neighborhood That Grew From a Clay Pit
description: THE mid-19th century was a time of intense development on Staten Island, as manufacturing flourished in several areas. On the southwestern shore along the Arthur Kill, clay deposits attracted a Manhattan brick manufacturer, Balthazar Kreischer. In 1854, he founded a brickworks factory and clay mining business that also produced tile and terra cotta.

title: Diamond Head Fee Set for (All) Visitors
description: Visitors to Oahu who want to climb Diamond Head's 279 stairs and crawl through its pre-World War I fortifications will have to pay $5 per car starting in September. The fee increases to $40 for commercial buses carrying more than 25 passengers, and walk-ins will pay $1.

title: Want to Slake a Thirst? Pass the Umbrellas!
description: SOMETHING about summer makes us order a drink with a berry in it. The temperature rises above 60 and suddenly, we're wild. We squirt the kids with the garden hose. We order spit-roasted pork and eat mesclun salads and wear loud shirts. Twelve to 16 years of 10-month school calendars have conditioned us to feel liberated when June rolls around.

title: A Sporting Chance for Girls
description: Walk around almost any school or college in the nation and you will see something that would have been rare 30 years ago: girls and women running and sweating across gym floors and athletic fields as they engage in competitive sports. Students today take this for granted, but for anyone who went to school before the 1970's, it is a remarkable development. Of all the societal shifts produced by the women's movement, the explosion of sports for girls and women has been among the most remarkable and, in a way, most profound.

title: The Weight of An Anchor
description: Rich writes that ''polls found Cronkite to be 'the most trusted man' in the country.'' In 1989, Marketing Week published news of a survey among people ages 50 to 64 to identify ''celebrities whose endorsement would influence purchases.'' Results: 1) Betty Crocker; 2) Walter Cronkite; 3) Bob Hope; 4) James Garner; 5) Bill Cosby; 6) Alan Alda; 7) George Burns; 8) Cliff Robertson; 9) Mary Tyler Moore; 10) Chuck Yeager.

title: Legacy of World Cup May Be the Stadiums Left Behind
description: With blasts of compressed air, the 2.5-acre soccer field levitates four inches. Then, like a giant green tray, the expanse of grass slowly rolls into a silvery, flying-saucer-shaped stadium. Inside, computer commands have folded away baseball bleachers like steel origami, part of a recent practice run for the first World Cup soccer game here, on June 1.

title: Stacey Schwartz, Yves Saada
description: Stacey Michele Schwartz, the daughter of Ellen and Robert Schwartz of New City, N.Y., was married last evening in Westhampton Beach, N.Y., to Yves Sauveur Saada, the son of Charles Saada of Paris and the late Michele Saada. Rabbi Marc Schneier officiated at the Atlantica, a caterer.

title: New Study Adds to Debate on E.P.A. Rules for Pesticide
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is embroiled in several fierce legal and scientific debates as it struggles to write new rules governing the use of atrazine, one of the nation's most widely used pesticides.

title: From Hoover to the 21st Century
description: DIRECTOR: J. EDGAR HOOVER

title: Hysteria Hysteria
description: Last fall, something peculiar began to happen at more than two dozen elementary and middle schools scattered across the country. Suddenly, groups of children started breaking out with itchy red rashes that seemed to fade away when the children went home -- and to pop up again when they returned to school. Frustratingly for the federal, state and county health officials who were working to explain this ailment, it did not conform to any known patterns of viral or bacterial illness.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 19 about the history and continuing relevance of network news misspelled the surname of the correspondent who was considered for the anchor of ''The CBS Evening News'' after Walter Cronkite announced his retirement. He was Charles Kuralt, not Kurault.

title: The Rewards of Taking It Slow and Easy
description: Searching for summer pleasures? They can be found as nearby as your own porch, which is where Dorothy Dunn enjoyed strawberries and cream at her Dobbs Ferry home. Or they can be as far away as a driver can get, armed with a good map and a full tank of gas; Sandy Cherman, lower left, takes his 1961 MGA on an early evening cruise between Chappaqua and Mount Kisco. The important thing, for those who hit the road, is not making time; it's taking time for those detours and dalliances that make summer memories. For one person, the perfect place to pause could be an antiques store, like the Yellow Monkey in Cross River. For another it could be a quiet spot of natural beauty; Croton Point Park in Croton-on-Hudson is at lower right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REUSCH, DR. ALFRED S.
description: REUSCH-Dr. Alfred S. Of Massapequa, NY (formerly of Great Neck), on May 31, 2002, at the age of 94. Beloved husband of Gladys Rinard Reusch. Loving father of Alfred R. (Ann) and Robert (Eileen). Cherished grandfather of Devon and Lisa and Christine and Matthew. Adored great-grandfather of two great-grandchildren. Caring brother of Melvin Reusch. Dr. Reusch was a graduate of Lafayette College and received his medical degree from NYU Medical School. He served as a lieutenant commander in the Pacific Campaign from 1942-1946. At the time of his death he was a retired commander in the U.S.N.R. Dr. Reusch practiced family medicine in Great Neck for 48 years. He was on the medical staff of Winthrop University Hospital (formerly Nassau Hospital), Manhasset Medical Center, Meadowbrook Hospital and North Shore University Hospital. Dr. Reusch served on the Founders Committee of North Shore University Hospital. For many years he served as Chief of Family Practice at North Shore University Hospital. In addition he was the surgeon for The Vigilant Alert Fire Company in Great Neck. He also served as the school doctor for the Great Neck School system. He was one of the founders of the Community Church of Great Neck. He served on the Board of the Long Island Council of Christians and Jews. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, June 4, at the Massapequa Funeral Home, Inc. (North Chapel), 1050 Park Blvd, Massapequa Park, NY, from 1:30 to 4:30 PM, with a religious service at 3:30 PM. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to your favorite charity.

title: 'Malaise'
description: It was the spring in New York, that uncertain season. I had just flown in from the other coast. I heard there had been snow in April in New York, followed by incessant rain, and then one of those heat waves in the high 90s that occur once in a century. There was a massive thunderstorm the night I arrived to visit the city in late May. At my hotel the security guy and the doorman discussed sports, in their common humanity, watching the tremendous storm. Maybe you have to live in the desert to really appreciate rain. The town I had just come from on the other coast, not far from the Mexican border, was very parched. Every day the sun blazed out of a clear blue sky, a sun that could be destructive of all you have known and believed. But it had not destroyed this: my loyalty to the East Coast and the green Atlantic.

title: His Really Big Show
description: On a cool, drizzly spring evening, Okwui Enwezor is sitting in La Frasca, an intimate Italian restaurant in Kassel, Germany. People at neighboring tables, mostly fair-skinned, stare at him as if he were a matinee idol. Enwezor, a tall, long-limbed Nigerian who moves with balletic grace, takes this in stride, nonchalantly ordering a bottle of Champagne. He sticks out here, and not just because he is the best-dressed man in a small provincial city. Kassel is the home of Documenta, the most prestigious exhibition of contemporary art in Europe and perhaps the world, and Enwezor, the show's artistic director this year, has become one of the town's most famous residents. ''The Germans are very inward-looking,'' he says, when I remark upon the startling effect he has on the room. He gazes around him at the sea of blond hair. ''You can't really find a cosmopolitan city in Germany, not even Berlin.''

title: TUESDAY'S PRIMARY
description: New Jersey voters can go to the polls Tuesday between 6 a.m. and 8 p.m. for a primary election. At the top of the ticket is the United States Senate seat held by Democrat Robert G. Torricelli, who is unchallenged for renomination. His Republican opponent will be selected from among Douglas R. Forrester, a wealthy businessman; and Diane Allen and John J. Matheussen, both state senators. The 14 seats in the House of Representatives are up for election but primary contests are being held in only four districts. Four Republicans are vying to run for the seat of retiring Representative Marge S. Roukema in the Fifth District in Bergen County. Representative Donald Payne, a Democrat of the 10th District in Newark, is the only incumbent being challenged. Also on the ballot are numerous local and county offices. Voters who have previously cast ballots in either a Democratic or Republican primary can vote only in that party's primary. Voters unaffiliated with either party can vote in either primary. Karen DeMasters

The Rev. Dr. Paul Smith performed the ceremony at the Wayne Presbyterian Church in Wayne, Pa.

title: In Tough Times, Bigger Boats Rule the Sea
description: Boat sales ebb and flow with each turn in the economy. So it is probably no surprise that purchases of new boats dropped 6 percent in 2001, to 541,000 from 574,000 in 2000, according to the National Marine Manufacturers Association.

title: Hilary Glazer, Craig Bromberg
description: Hilary Haika Glazer and Craig Bromberg are to be married today in New York. Rabbi Elliot K. Ginsburg will conduct the ceremony.

description: Andrea Helen Despins, a daughter of Renee J. Despins of New York and Karl A. Despins of Scottsdale, Ariz., was married last evening to Neal Alan Potischman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest M. Potischman, also of New York. Rabbi Scott Corngold officiated at Synod Hall on the grounds of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York.

title: Ports That Reflect a Grand Era
description: OUT of the thick fog swirling around Winter Island, a lone brown pelican soared into sight, flew silently past the small sailboats anchored offshore and disappeared back into the mist. Nearby, a solitary fisherman cast his line at the foot of the Fort Pickering Lighthouse as small waves lapped the rocky beach.

title: As Seen on Television, Prohibited EPO on Sale
description: Professional cycling, its reputation besmirched by doping scandals in three of the last four years, is under siege again. Recently, two top racers, Stefano Garzelli and Gilberto Simoni, dropped out of the Giro d'Italia, one of the world's three biggest races, after drug tests turned up traces of banned substances in each cyclist.

title: 2 Portraits of a Legacy: East End Art and Artists
description: TWO books that will be released this month seek to show a side of the Hamptons that tends to fade from view: an artistic legacy that has enriched an entire nation.

title: When Instability Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Playing With Their Food
description: ASK professional chefs about summer cooking and in some ways they sound like the rest of us. They enjoy good local produce. They like to grill. They try to keep it light. But those who cook in Westchester's top restaurants can't get away with serving customers a burger and corn on the cob. As the weather heats up, they combine their culinary expertise with available fresh fruits and vegetables to produce dishes that capture the essence of summer.

title: Huntington Affordable Housing Being Stalled by Opposition
description: WITH homes in short supply and area home prices increasing at a rate that leads the nation, the Town of Huntington is looking for ways to ease its deepening housing crisis. But in a tug-of-war that has pitted school districts against advocates for affordable housing, the town finds itself on both ends of the rope.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Panera Bread Is Planning To Open 20 Bakery-Cafes

title: 2 Guys Building an Entertainment Empire
description: JED MOREY and John Caracciolo like to think of themselves as turnaround artists. The Vanderbilt, a catering hall in Plainview, was a bankrupt nightclub when they took it over three years ago. They turned it into an entertainment complex for weddings, cigar dinners, bachelor auctions, concerts with headliners like Marc Anthony and over-the-top bar mitzvah expos. Their two Suffolk County-based radio stations, WDRE and WXXP, a rhythmic dance and top 40 station respectively, were not broadcasting when they purchased them in 1997. They also own WLIR, an alternative rock station. ''Jed and I seem to have found our knack in making lemonade from lemons,'' said Mr. Caracciolo, 37, of East Northport.

title: Lehman Sweeps Adams to Advance
description: It was fitting that the ball ended up in the hands of Lehman High pitcher Argalis Rosario at the end of yesterday's Public Schools Athletic League semifinal game against John Adams at the Ballpark at St. John's.

title: Dining by the Dock of the Bay (or the Lake)
description: ON a late Sunday morning in springtime, the temperature was already an unseasonable 78 degrees at Down the Hatch, a restaurant in Brookfield. This meant that Al Parente had better get moving.

title: Lightest Hitter Delivers the Heaviest Blow for the Yankees
description: Alfonso Soriano is too talented to be the next Wally Pipp. And it is only June, so Bucky Dent's place in Yankee lore is safe. But for one afternoon at Yankee Stadium, Enrique Wilson brought together two fairy tales with one improbable swing.

title: Latest Chapter in Louima Case Is to Begin
description: About 700 New Yorkers are expected in federal court in Brooklyn tomorrow to begin the latest legal journey through one of the city's wrenching memories, the sexual assault of Abner Louima in a Brooklyn police station bathroom in 1997.

title: Where's Papa?
description: ''See that?'' says Harvey Johnson, pointing to a photograph on the wall of his restaurant, Captain Runaground, in Key West, Fla. ''That was the catch we used to get in these waters.'' The picture features a 40-foot boat and what appear to be hundreds of bales of marijuana. ''In the 70's, whoo, we got that all the time, but Nancy Reagan pretty much put a stop to it when she brought in the military. Now we worry about refugees,'' he says, handing Red and me glasses of julep with fresh mint. We are here to go deep-sea fishing and cook up the catch, and Harvey's company is supplying the yacht, the captain and the mate. Three 40-foot fishing boats bob in the Caribbean outside.

title: Wary of Risk, Slow to Adapt, F.B.I. Stumbles in Terror War
description: When the director of the F.B.I., Robert S. Mueller III, acknowledged on Wednesday that the agency had missed warning signals on terrorism, he stunned many Americans. But his statement was not news to some veterans of the agency -- or lawmakers who now say they treated the F.B.I. with too much deference for too many years.

title: The Weight of An Anchor
description: For all the talk about good journalism, it's unfortunate that Frank Rich allowed Roger Ailes to level unsubstantiated criticism at two of our anchors, Brian Williams and Ashleigh Banfield, without giving us an opportunity to respond.

title: Engle Has to Answer for Mets' Hitting Woes
description: MIAMI, June 1 — Dave Engle does not like to risk disrupting his hitters' concentration by giving them advice during games. But against the Florida Marlins eight days ago, Engle, the Mets' hitting coach, noticed Jeromy Burnitz on the bench sulking about striking out twice and walking in his first three at-bats.

title: Investing; S.& P. Tries a Hedge-Fund Gauge
description: HEDGE funds claim to have been among the few bright spots in the investment world the last two years. But just how well these alternative investment vehicles stack up against stocks, bonds and mutual funds is difficult to gauge, because there is no generally accepted benchmark for measuring the performance of the nearly 6,000 hedge funds now operating around the world.

title: Malpractice Insurance Is Indeed in Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: May 26-June 1: NATIONAL; MORE STATES' RIGHTS
description: The 11th Amendment provides that ''the judicial power of the United States'' does not encompass private suits against states. The Supreme Court's states-rights majority breached a federalism firewall in extending the states' immunity from the courtroom to proceedings before federal administrative agencies. Like other agencies, the Federal Maritime Commission, which was investigating the state-owned Port of Charleston, S.C., exercises executive-branch, not judicial authority, but the 5-to-4 majority said the real issue was the sovereignty and ''dignity'' of the states. Linda Greenhouse

title: A Demimonde in Twilight
description: FOR Willard Moody, a New York writer and musician, the late 1970's to the mid-1980's were more than just the glory days of the city's punk bands and the Mudd Club. Those years were also, at least to Mr. Moody, a very good time for pornographic magazines. New titles appeared almost monthly, writers mingled at klieg-lighted Times Square premieres (before sex films went straight to video) and editors had leeway in what they assigned.

title: All Aglow To Create Proper Illusions
description: Today's brides not only crave the spotlight, -- they also want that spotlight to create the glamour of a Hollywood wedding. ''Romance and drama are better achieved through lighting than through a lot of flowers or decoration,'' Elizabeth K. Allen, a wedding planner, said. So, couples are paying lighting designers $2,000 to $300,000 for full-blown installations with fabric, rewiring and custom-made fixtures to make the bride, the room and the food look more beautiful.

title: Lessons in Discipline, Taught With Blisters
description: THE last time anyone wore white gloves at Miss Porter's, the private high school for girls in Farmington, was probably the 1960's, but the image endured despite the school's rigorous college preparation and determination to groom students as leaders. Yet with its undefeated rowing crew ready to do battle at the Henley Women's Regatta later this month, the image may be laid to rest. The gloves are off and the hands on these girls are blistered and calloused.

description: For Collegiate Chorale

description: When a car is abandoned on a city street, it becomes the responsibility of the Department of Sanitation, which picks up 10,000 vehicles a year. But who takes responsibility for abandoned bikes?

title: A Friendship in Letters Bound by Gardens
description: IF you are feeling frantic about all those weeds growing in your garden, as well as some impossible workload, you might find take to your hammock for a day with the new ''Two Gardeners: A Friendship in Letters,'' a collection of correspondence between Katharine S. White and Elizabeth Lawrence. The break will do you good and so will reading about two other extremely harried women, deadline-driven writers and devoted gardeners.

title: A Season for Music, Both Indoors and Out
description: HEARD any good carnyx's lately? Want to see (and hear) a human mobile, with drummers suspended 100 feet in the air? How about encounters with an Egyptian pop star, a Latin combo from Paris, a South African take on ''Carmen''? These and literally hundreds of other happenings are part of the International Festival of Arts and Ideas, a cultural whirlwind that will blow through New Haven from June 13 to 30.

title: Business; How a Side Effect Might Turn Into Success
description: LEONARD S. SCHLEIFER, the son of a sweater manufacturer who grew up in the Rego Park section of Queens, was on his way to becoming a distinguished scientist. But after he earned an M.D. and a Ph.D. and started a research career in 1984 at Cornell University, he became fascinated with the biotechnology revolution. Though he had never held what he jokingly calls a ''real job,'' he decided to build a company that delivered better drugs to people.

description: The Boston Celtics' coaches had spent countless hours studying film, scouting every tendency, to find a way to slow down the offensive schemes of the Nets, who use a system made famous at Princeton.

description: ANNE M. MULCAHY did some radical things on Memorial Day weekend. She saw her son Kevin in a track meet. She had a facial. She invited friends over for dinner. In between, she recalls, she ''just hung out.''

title: The Market Rewards Size, And Brewers Know It
description: THE beer industry is entering its peak selling season. But it is doing so as one of the biggest companies in the business is moving to the sidelines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKLAR, ANN SKOLNICK
description: SKLAR-Ann Skolnick. Born West Haven, CT, 1907, died May 21, 2002, Queens, NY. Married to Philip Sklar (d. 1956), Toscaninni's principal bassist with the NBC Symphony. Worked for the Queens Public Library. Graduate of Ann Arbor University, MI, and Columbia University, NY. Beloved by her children, Arle Sklar-Weinstein of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, and Martin Sklar of Bloomfield, NJ. Daughter, Sondra Lamberton-James, predeceased her in 1997. A family service will be held at the Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ, June 3 at 1 PM.

description: On this side of Kashmir's disputed frontier, the soldiers wait and watch, their guns ready for the assault that they expect could come at any moment.

title: In Search of a Bridge to Medicare
description: LAST year, I wrote about people who want to retire before they turn 65 -- meaning that they don't yet qualify for Medicare -- but have no retiree health care benefits from their employers.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: AT a New Year's Eve party in Hong Kong, welcoming 1997, a student activist calls for every-one's attention, places a gun in his mouth and commits very public suicide. In CHINESE BOX (1997), the party guests include an expatriate British journalist (Jeremy Irons) who soon learns that he's terminally ill. Deciding not to tell his family back home (''I don't want the look in their eyes to remind me I'm dying''), he drinks and smokes too much, gets disruptive at bars, attempts videotaped interviews and longs for another man's mistress (played by Gong Li, the filmmaker Zhang Yimou's longtime muse). Directed by Wayne Wang, the film is a vivid, lyrical metaphor for the passing of Hong Kong from Britain's rule to China's - Friday at 8 and 10 p.m. on Bravo, Sunday/Early Monday at 2:15 a.m., Friday at 11:30 p.m. and Friday/Early Saturday at 3:15 a.m. on IFC.

title: The Dark Side of France
description: IN April, Jean-Marie Le Pen, the right-wing politician eager to deport Arab immigrants, among other ambitions, unnerved France's political establishment by outpolling the Socialist prime minister in a presidential primary. By then the literary establishment had already experienced its own surprise. It was the return of the novelist Michel Houellebecq, who last caused a fuss in 1998, when, not always sober, he went around promoting his grim, dirty and provocative novel ''The Elementary Particles'' (published here in 2000). That book condemned in leering detail the sexual mores of the revolutionary generation of 1968 -- the Soixante-Huitards, who, having attained important positions in French society, now have thinner skins than their more regularly ridiculed American counterparts.

description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops are negotiating with groups representing victims of sexual abuse by priests over whether to allow victims to speak at the bishops' annual meeting in Dallas this month, church officials say.

title: GARDENING
description: I should be outside in the garden, and so should you. The sheets of newsprint lying at your feet would make excellent mulch. If you put the Book Review down now, you could squeeze in an hour of weeding or thinning or repotting. After such an ungenerous spring -- a frigid April with record-setting heat, a March wind howling us into May, a drought hovering over the entire Northeast -- not a moment of good gardening weather should be wasted. Meanwhile, those of you without gardens or who are resting from having gardens or for whom reading about gardening is as gratifying as gardening itself, come along with me. But bear in mind that every book mentioned in the paragraphs that follow will make you want to put down the paper and take up the hoe.

description: JONES MURPHY might not have noticed what his colleagues at the Williams Companies were doing if they had not been gloating.

title: Blending Sounds of Nature and Man
description: THE tuning has begun for summer's symphony. Feathered divas chirp their ritornellos over a lawn mower's drone. Baseball bats crack like a rim-shot. Big dopey bees buzz like a bass string. In the evening, the crickets take over the theme, much like the high register of first violins. Little frogs are antiphonal piccolos all through the night. Thunder doubles as kettle drums. At waterside the gulls cry like Pavarotti singing Puccini, and the ocean surf crashes as cymbals. Along the Housatonic River, a riffle mimics applause.

title: Staying Engaged in the Mideast
description: For a while last month, hope stirred in the Middle East. The encouraging signs, though limited and tentative, stood in sharp contrast to the violence and paralysis of the past year and a half. Much of that momentum already seems to be slipping away. Only a strong diplomatic push by Washington can sustain it. This weekend's visits to the region by the State Department's top Mideast diplomat, William Burns, and the director of central intelligence, George Tenet, can help prepare the way.

title: In Essex, Democrats Will Be Democrats
description: Those watching the Democratic primary for Essex County executive will need a scorecard, no doubt, when heading to the polls on Tuesday. How else to figure which candidate has the support of fellow Democrats.

title: Week in Review: May 26 - June 1
description: NATO'S NEWEST ADDITION President Vladimir V. Putin took one big step westward when he formally made Russia a nonvoting member of NATO, the organization created 53 years ago to contain Soviet power. Under the agreement, a new NATO-Russia council will focus on counterterrorism, nonproliferation and containing outbreaks of regional hostilities. But Russia won't be part of NATO's commitment to "collective defense," and will not have the right to veto new members. No one is quite sure how this one-foot-in, one-foot-out strategy will work.

title: The Spray, The Leap, The Splash Of Falls
description: WATERFALLS are nature's dramatic solution to a mundane enough problem: how best to gather in all the rain and snow melt that accumulates on the upper reaches of mountains and transport it down to sea level. For the most part, up high in the notches and ridges, this is accomplished by oozes and trickles, seeps and springs, a gentle, subtle process with charms -- damp and boggy charms -- of its own. Often, all this seepage is organized by gravity into little rivulets; sometimes these rivulets broaden into slick, rocky streams; occasionally these streams, following the declivities of topography, reach a cliff and with a daredevil, why-not kind of bravado, leap over, precipitously leap, leap in an exhilarating way that gladdens the heart.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review in the Book Review last Sunday about ''The Count and the Confession: A True Mystery,'' by John Taylor, included outdated references to the legal status of Beverly Monroe, who was convicted in 1992 of having murdered Roger de la Burde at a horse farm outside Richmond. In March 2002, a federal judge vacated her conviction. The ruling was issued after the distribution of bound galley proofs to book reviewers, and an addendum from the book's publisher went astray. The published book includes an account of the judge's ruling.

title: Yanks' Versatility Is Problem for Red Sox
description: It was only one game, but the Yankees and the Red Sox demonstrated yesterday why they will almost certainly finish the season in that order.

title: The Weight of An Anchor
description: Rich may well be correct in rejecting the cable rants. But the reality is that most of us are put off by the predictable slant, spin and self-indulgence that appear to be de rigueur for network news. Roger Ailes's observations on the new generation of news readers is accurate. Short on knowledge, historical context and perspective, they rely on props (battle gear, draped sweaters) and an MTV style to disguise ignorance and inexperience.

title: Haynes Is Hired to Keep Players Out of Financial, Legal and Other Trouble
description: Mike Haynes is in the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and the first thing you notice when meeting him is that he looks as if his playing days ended yesterday, not 13 years ago, when he played his last game for the Oakland Raiders after a seven-year career in New England. He is lean and fit. If the Giants get into a spot this season and need another cornerback in a pinch, they should give Haynes a call.

title: At a Wedding, Calories Don't Count
description: Couples who don't want a traditional - tiered wedding cake can now sate their sweet tooth with some offbeat alternatives.

title: Kim Possible: Saving the Day in Her Spare Time
description: MOVE over, boy wonders. The newest superhero on the block doesn't need a gimmicky mask or a jolt of testosterone to get the job done. With a whip of her auburn tresses and a twist of her cheerleader's tiny torso, Kim Possible is ready and able to rescue humankind from evildoers without sacrificing her interest in boys and clothes.

title: The Elderly Man and the Sea? Test Sanitizes Literary Texts
description: At first, Jeanne Heifetz thought she had merely tripped over one of those quirks that occasionally worm their way into standardized tests. Words were missing from a book excerpt she was familiar with on a Regents English exam. But when she discovered a second extensively altered excerpt, she began to wonder, ''If there were two, could there be more?'' Was something sinister afoot?

title: Endangered Species
description: THE LAST AMERICAN MAN

title: Keystrokes of Genius
description: ''I WORK on the same 1909 Russian Glab-Porkovnyka 'Daisy' portable with a Cyrillic keyboard that I found in a souk in Morocco 36 years ago,'' says the famed mystery writer Rex Regis. ''Sure, it means flying in the only living Glab-Porkovnyka mechanic from Smolensk twice a year for a tuneup, but what else can I do? That machine and me, we're partners. It's a bond that all those poor slobs staring at their word processors will never know. Everything I'll ever write is already in that Glab-Porkovnyka, just waiting for me to type it out.''

title: Cherished, but for What?
description: BY now the R.S.V.P.'s have been counted, the thank-you notes have been ordered and the wedding dress has been molded to flatter every inch of the bride's body. But as the parade of summer weddings begins, a particularly graceless task still faces many first-time brides and grooms: writing a prenuptial agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNICK, WILLIAM
description: WERNICK-William, 91, recently of Newton, MA and previously of Brookline, MA; Yonkers, NY, The Bronx, NY; and Great Barrington, MA, died May 16th at his home. He was the husband of the late Ruth Lindenbaum Wernick, father of Peter Wernick (Joan) of Niwot, CO and Sarah Wernick (William Lockeretz) of Brookline, MA. Grandfather of David Lockeretz, Benjamin Lockeretz and Will Wernick. Dr. Wernick was Chairman of the Mathematics Department of Evanderchilds High School for many years; he was Associate Professor of Mathematics at CUNY. After retirement, he bacame a philanthropist benefiting the Workmen's Circle, Hadassah, UJA, and many others. A memorial was held May 19th in Brookline; burial was May 20th at Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodbridge, NJ.

description: THE plot is enough to make a community activist's heart bleed with delight: longtime tenant in one of Brooklyn's roughest neighborhoods, blue-collar Puerto Rican guy, gets a chance to buy his building from the city, help stabilize a block, maybe make a little money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, BENJAMIN B.
description: KAPLAN-Benjamin B. Passed unexpectedly Friday, May 24, 2002, one day and one month short of his 100th birthday. We cannot describe how much this extraordinary man will be missed by his many dear relatives and loving friends. He is survived by his devoted wife, Eleanor; beloved children, Jordan and Hilary; caring daughter-in-law, Dori; adoring grandchildren, Dovid, Rachel, Yosef, Yaakov, Naomi, Malkie, Estie, and Rikki. Bridging a generation gap among his admiring nieces and nephews, he was a learned and innovative man who generously shared his lifelong pursuit of knowledge. May his expectation for eternal sleep be fully realized. A donation to a charity of your choice in his name would be gratefully appreciated.

title: QUICK BITE/Hoboken; Where Early Birds Are Richly Rewarded
description: ''A three-course meal for $10?'' a friend said when I told him about Amanda's early dinner menu. ''What do you get -- soup, rolls, and the check?'' Yes, an early bird special at elegant Amanda's, no joke. From 5 to 6 p.m., Mondays through Saturdays, guests can order from a prix-fixe menu (actually, $10.01) that includes choices among three appetizers (soup, salad or polenta), four entrees (salmon, chicken, steak or pasta) and three desserts (apple strudel, chocolate mousse or Key lime pie). The menu never changes, but that's fine by me: I could eat the polenta with three-cheese sauce followed by the grilled skirt steak every night of the week. And apparently some do. ''Some people come in two or three times a week, then tell me they'd like to try something different,'' said Joyce Flinn, who owns the restaurant with her husband, Eugene. ''I just laugh and think, 'That's what the regular menu is for.' '' The atmosphere at Amanda's is intimate, with two fireplaces and with windows overlooking a well-tended garden. It's the perfect spot for a special occasion, which is to say, the last place you'd expect to find such a bargain. So why do it? ''This is the way we advertise,'' Ms. Flinn said. ''It costs us $10 for the cloth napkins and the basket of bread, but it gets people in the restaurant.'' The hope is they'll return for the regular menu, where entrees alone cost two to three times as much. My only complaint is with the hour, but eating at 5 p.m. is a small price to pay for a small price. Gretchen Kurtz

title: Beach Blanket Bingo
description: This teenage girl's room -- in the attic of an 1895 Shingle-style house on Fire Island -- embodies what its designer, Thomas Jayne, loves most about summers at the beach: a poignant blend of tradition and throwaway style.

title: BackTalk; A Horse's Unseen but Fatal Weakness
description: ''She was 10 minutes away from being a champion,'' the trainer Randy Schulhofer said. He was referring to Exogenous, his prize racehorse, as she headed into the Breeders' Cup last October at Belmont Park. A victory would have sealed her reputation as the best 3-year-old filly of last year's racing season. She never made it to the gate.

title: The Nation; The Haunting Final Words: 'It Doesn't Look Good, Babe.'
description: PERHAPS only mythology can convey the strangeness of this story: that people trapped high in the World Trade Center spoke to their loved ones even as the flames rose and the towers fell. The channels of communication -- cell phones and BlackBerry communicators and a few surviving land lines -- were the by-now familiar miracles of modern technology.

title: Carbo Loading: On the Brink of the Dollar Bagel
description: It happened to the pizza slice. It happened to the subway token. It looks as if the bagel is next.

title: Tenants Win; Artist Speaks
description: MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS -- Tenants in two rent-stabilized buildings on West 122nd Street won what might be the final round in their six-year legal battle with the Jewish Theological Seminary, which sought to evict them to make room for student housing. On May 16, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled in favor of the tenants.

title: The Day's Catch
description: EVERY summer when I was a child, I fished off the Pleasure Beach Pier in Bridgeport. We fished there, my father, brothers and I, whenever the snappers were running or when it was too hot for neighborhood kick ball. The simple ritual of these mornings and afternoons, the mesmerizing sight of sunlight sluicing through the blue-green water and the unfettered sense of beyond, where the pier met the Sound, remains emblematic of summer for me.

title: Struggling Into the Director's Chair
description: ONCE, back in the 80's, when Callie Khouri was a waitress at a Beverly Hills restaurant, she spotted Gloria Steinem sitting in another server's station.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Life Without Parole?
description: Changing human behavior is a long-term process that, unfortunately, must involve negative sanctions or ''technical'' parole violations.

title: Rachel Dickstein, Blake Eskin
description: Rachel Ariela Dickstein, the daughter of Lore Dickstein and Dr. Morris Dickstein of Manhattan, is to be married this evening to Blake David Eskin, the son of Eden Force Eskin and Robert Eskin, also of Manhattan. Rabbi Mychal B. Springer will officiate at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: 'Atlantic'
description: It was the final, privileged tournament of a gilded age: the last great race of princes, whether titled by birth in the Old World or minted by money in the New.

title: War Of Ideas
description: I'm glad that frustrated F.B.I. agents are banging away at all the missed signals that might have tipped us off to 9/11, but we need to remember something: not all the signals for 9/11 were hidden. Many were out there in public, in the form of hate speech and conspiracy theories directed at America and preached in mosques and schools throughout the Muslim world. If we are intent on preventing the next 9/11, we need to do more than just spy on our enemies better in secret. We need to take on their ideas in public.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 14 about the instinctive revulsion of humans at the desecration of the dead misidentified the Greek tyrant who denied funeral rites to Antigone's brother Polynices in the Sophocles play. A reader's letter, dated April 15 but overlooked at The Times until last week, points out that he was Creon, not Cleon.

title: Ulster Leaders Give Pep Talk To 2 Sides In the Mideast
description: A group of Israeli and Palestinian politicians have met for unusual talks in the English Midlands, joined by figures who negotiated Northern Ireland's breakthrough peace accord of 1998.

title: Drama on The High C's
description: When Maria Callas declined to reappear after an especially weak first act of ''Norma'' in Rome in 1958, the audience swelled forth like a pack of feral dogs ready to devour their heroine for disappointing them. So impassioned was their response that Callas's husband had to smuggle her out through a convenient underground tunnel that connected the opera house to their hotel in order to make an escape. Some accounts claim that she had been in poor health that night and simply could not continue. Those who were less charitable believe she refused to continue because of the tepid applause after the first (and final) act. Such is the stuff of opera legend.

title: The Weight of An Anchor
description: Geezerville? A step or two from the grave? So the nightly news is filled with commercials hawking products for the over-60 population. These remedies for impotence, incontinence, high cholesterol, bladder problems and acid reflux may in fact enable over-60's to accomplish even more than their younger counterparts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORE, ALLAN E.
description: SHORE-Allan E. On May 27, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Carol Tilles. Devoted father of Allan E. Shore Jr. and his wife Jill, William T. Shore & Marylu Simon. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer, Christopher, Beth, Michael and Julie and great-grandfather of Benyamin Yaakov and Dovid. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Donations in his memory may be made to the Junior Achievement of Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Bich Nguyen, Porter Shreve
description: Bich Minh Nguyen, a daughter of D. Nhu Nguyen and a stepdaughter of Rosa Fraga of Ada, Mich., was married last evening to Porter Shreve, a son of Susan Richards Shreve of Washington and Porter Shreve Jr. of Houston. Gloria DeAngelis, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Society for Arts, a gallery in Chicago.

Robinson, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Dorland Memorial Presbyterian Church in Hot Springs, N.C.

description: Lara Christina Hession, the daughter of Cynthia Hession of Wilmington, Del., and the late Cmdr. J. Michael Hession, was married last evening to Steven Elie Coury, a son of Doris and Elie S. Coury of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Alan J. R. description: THERE was a time when presidents turned out for the Yale-Harvard Regatta on the Thames River between New London and Groton, when thousands of people lined the banks and the water was covered with expensive yachts.

title: In the West End, the Accent Is Decidedly American
description: SOME years, so many British plays and productions cross the Atlantic that you could redefine the Great White Way as London-on-Hudson. But right now a lot of valuable traffic seems to be going the other way. With Madonna, Gwyneth Paltrow and Matt Damon joining a throng of American performers in the West End, Kenneth Lonergan and Stephen Adly Guirgis among the dramatists getting rave reviews from the London critics, and world premieres from Neil LaBute and Christopher Shinn at top addresses, what are we to call the traditional center of the British theater? A blend of Broadway-on-Thames and Tinseltown U.K., perhaps.

title: Corrections
description: The Mortgage Rates chart last Sunday misstated the date for the figures listed, and for the index rate for adjustable rate mortgages. They were for the week ended May 17, not May 26.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMS, MILTON LOUIS ''ED''
description: HYMS-Milton Louis ''Ed''. Died 4/ 27/02 at age 88. Merchant Marine 1928-1930. Entered U.S. Navy 1930. Served in WW II in Atlantic and Pacific campaigns on the submarines: S11, R-14, S-20, Balao, and Muskellunge. Awarded S/M Combat Award. Retired 1953 as a Chief Petty Officer. Ran Harbor Survey boat for NYC to monitor NY Waterways. Traveled to more than 100 countries. Honorary guest of Russian government in reunion of Allied Submariner Naval Officers. Son of Esther & Louis. Husband to the late Mildred, brother to late Bess Chanko, and best friend to Austin Maeder. Survived by loving daughter Gail T. Kunz, son-in-law John, grandsons Gregg and Scott, granddaughters Tracy & Theresa, and four loving great grandchildren: Victoria, Isabelle, James, and Anna. One of many American War Heroes to whom we owe our freedom. His Motto: ''Be open to all points of view and draw your own conclusions.'' He will truly be missed by all. A Real Gentleman.

title: Geneva Voters to Take a Practice Run for Internet Elections
description: GENEVA, June 1  E-democracy will get its first real test on the European continent as 16,000 university students in Geneva use the Internet to vote on whether to legalize abortion and on other issues on this Sunday's ballot.

title: Seeing the State Through Field Glasses
description: THE origins of one of New Jersey's premier naturalists are to be found in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: In a Power-Hungry Neighborhood, High Tensions With Con Edison
description: This summer Consolidated Edison plans to install eight diesel generators, which look like large tractor-trailers with exhaust fins, outside power-hungry buildings in Chelsea. The machines are meant to prevent power failures, but to many neighbors they are unsightly and intrusive.

title: Skeletons in the Classroom
description: THE ride up North 5 Road in the piney woods of southwestern Maine is one most teenagers make reluctantly, in the back seat. North 5 goes to only one place: the Elan School, a treatment center for troubled youths that bills itself as a last resort.

title: Practicing Without a Net
description: DOCTOR, heal thyself. Again.

title: A Neighborhood Feels the Loss of Its Supermarket
description: Susan Barrett has to leave the neighborhood now if she wants Carr's crackers or Tidy Cats litter. Colleen Segarra cannot shop for groceries while she waits for her children to be dismissed from P.S. 14 across the street. Donna Pignone's two-block walks to the supermarket are over.

title: Denmark Gets on the Board to Defeat Uraguay
description: Denmark beat Uruguay, 2-1, yesterday, the second day of the World Cup, to move ahead of France in Group A, and Cameroon, the African champion, drew with Ireland, 1-1, in the first Group E match.

title: Ancient Synagogue To Reopen in Recife
description: What is believed to be the first synagogue in the New World has recently reopened after Portuguese colonists closed it four centuries ago. Its address in Recife, Brazil, is a clue to the temple's story: 197, Rua do Bom Jesus, antiga Rua dos Judeus (Street of Benevolent Jesus, formerly the Street of Jews), Bairro Recife Antigo.

title: The Hard Work of Transforming the F.B.I.
description: The sweeping changes announced by the F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, last week constitute one of the most far-reaching organizational transformations in the long history of the bureau, which began in 1908. Unfortunately, creating new units, hiring new people and announcing a new focus on fighting terrorism are destined to fail unless Mr. Mueller can also transform the insular culture of the agency.

title: Germany Asserts Itself In Rout of Saudi Arabia
description: Germany, it seems, is a team that seems to play its best around tournament time. The players are ''gamers,'' in the parlance of baseball fans.

title: 26 Peasants Are Killed in Ambush on Rural Mexican Road
description: Twenty-six peasants were shot and killed on Friday night in an ambush on a remote dirt road in southern Oaxaca, officials from the state attorney general's office said tonight.

title: Shuttle Is Delayed Again
description: The launching of the space shuttle Endeavour was postponed again today, this time so technicians could replace a faulty engine valve.

title: New Jersey? Bad Taste? Well Then, Don't Eat It.
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago, I read an article on the health of New Jerseyeans that said obesity had almost doubled in adults in the 1990's. The next day, in my son's school, the entire fourth grade assembled and ate a gigantic cake shaped like New Jersey.

title: Little Feeling of Emergency In American Exit From Delhi
description: At the American Club here today, the mood was more like the last day of summer camp than an emergency evacuation of diplomats and their families ahead of a possible nuclear war.

title: POSTINGS: Architects and Engineers Shifted by 9/11; Firms Finding New Homes
description: Devastated on Sept. 11, the downtown architectural and engineering community is getting back to business, though in some cases far from ground zero.

title: When Monopoly's More Than a Game
description: DOES anybody still play Monopoly? Yes and no, Nagle Jackson might say. He wrote ''A Hotel on Marvin Gardens,'' a comedy with five characters now at 12 Miles West Theater Company. Mr. Jackson seems to be of two minds about every concern that pops up here, from the pursuit of trivia to the meaning of life.

description: JENNIFER JASON LEIGH is, she says, in an advanced state of dread. First she must sit opposite a stranger and talk about herself on her day off. Then, on Thursday, she will have to talk again, this time to nearly 300 people gathered to pay her tribute at Lincoln Center.

He is survived by his wife of sixty-three years, Rosalind (Hausthor); his daughter Susan Graham Harrison of Orinda, CA; his son Kenneth R. Graham of Berkeley Heights, NJ; his grandchildren, Melinda Graham, Laura Graham and Craig A. Harrison; his sister, Ruth G. Shriro of Walnut Creek, CA, and many nieces and nephews. Memorial contributions may be made to John Muir Foundation, 1400 Treat Blvd, Walnut Creek, CA 94596.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEISS, HELGA
description: DEISS-Helga. Of Lugano, Switzerland, formerly of Hamburg, Germany. Our dearest beloved mother and grandmother, we will never forget you. Your Family

title: Milkweed, for Summer's Scent
description: CLOISTERED in our suburban gardens, encircled by impatiens and bounded by well-tended lawns, we can easily forget about the common milkweed (Asclepias syraica). Out of sight and out of mind, it is often found in rural areas, keeping company with the likes of wild chicory, daisy fleabane and Queen Anne's lace. A few related species, like the flashy butterflyweed (Asclepias tuberosa), have caught the public's fancy, but somehow milkweed has never been able to overcome its country cousin status in the community of garden plants.

description: 'Hansel and Gretel'

title: Atlanta Journal; Burned Rubber and Other Not-So-Natural Hazards
description: ''You're never going to see a bigger pile of rubber than this,'' said Jay Harris, a security guard at the closed Gibson Recycling plant in the dense pine forests just south of this East Texas town.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column last Sunday about Harry Houdini's leap into New York Harbor misstated the location of a 1999 stunt by a Houdini admirer, the magician David Blaine. He was buried alive not in Central Park but at the Trump Place development, near West 68th Street and the Hudson River.

title: BackTalk; The Child Becomes the Father to a Soccer Maven
description: Memo to all taxi and bus drivers who are scheduled to be working around 5 o'clock on Wednesday morning: Please look out for a silver-haired, 80-year-old man crossing Madison Avenue with a preoccupied look on his face and an extra spring in his step. That will be my father, Max, en route to my apartment where the juice will have been freshly squeezed, the coffee will have been ground to specifications and the sesame bagel will be in the toaster. Breakfast will be ready and everything else in life -- family, work, sleep -- will be put on hold for the next two hours, if not the next two weeks. You see, we will be watching the World Cup, exactly as we have been doing in one site or another and in one country or another for the past 40 years.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on May 12, about Chicago, misstated the admission fee at the Art Institute of Chicago, the site of a retrospective of the German artist Gerhard Richter. The institute suggests $10; it does not require $14. A picture caption misstated the title and location of a Richter painting. It is ''Betty,'' not ''German Betty,'' and is displayed at the Art Institute, not the Newberry Library.

description: To the Editor:

title: Following All the Rules in a Close Encounter With a Grizzly
description: As the grizzly approached, taking his sweet time, Abigail Thomas tried to practice good bear etiquette.

title: Ubiquitous Ads Devalue All Messages
description: AT a gas station the other day, I saw an advertisement attached at eye level near the fuel hose. I have also seen ads on shopping carts and heard commercials on the phone when a business puts me on hold. And I begin each day at my computer beneath an avalanche of e-mail sales pitches for laser printer cartridges, low-interest mortgages and cut-rate Viagra.

title: Seeking Je Ne Sais Quoi Along Madison Avenue
description: On a typical summer evening, illegal tables and chairs spill from a smattering of small restaurants onto the sidewalks of Madison Avenue.

title: BUSINESS TAX PLAN
description: Mr. McCormac last week outlined a plan to the Senate Budget Committee that would close loopholes that allow companies with an economic presence in New Jersey to avoid paying corporate taxes by creating holdings in other states. The proposed changes would also require that companies pay taxes on 100 percent of their dividends earned on net income and would end tax breaks for select companies like investment companies and real estate investment companies. Jo Piazza

title: Q. & A.
description: Q. Can a condominium have rules that interfere with a homeowner's rights? I was interested in buying a condo in the Riverdale area. However, when the condominium owner showed me the rules of the condominium (including rules prohibiting unapproved alterations, ''objectionable odors'' and storage of Christmas decorations on terraces), I thought the rules interfered with my basic rights.

title: In Assisted Living, a Matter of Geography
description: For the elderly, assisted-living communities have meant new options. Their residents can keep much of their independence while still having access to varying degrees of support services like meals and medical care.

title: Downturn and Shift in Population Feed Boom in White-Collar Crime
description: The bursting of the stock market bubble, combined with the changing face of the American population, has led to a surge in business fraud and corruption prosecutions and investigations.

title: May 26-June 1: NATIONAL; G-MAN CONVICTED
description: The F.B.I. finally got its man. Only he was a retired agent, John J. Connolly, below, who was convicted by a federal jury of becoming a member of an organized crime gang, providing its leader, James (Whitey) Bulger, with news of a secret indictment that enabled Mr. Bulger to avoid arrest and become a fugitive. Mr. Connolly's conviction, for racketeering and obstruction of justice, was another embarrassment for the beleaguered F.B.I. Fox Butterfield
