description: A DOUBLE THREAD

title: The Case for Queens and Kings
description: In his recently published diaries, Kenneth Tynan, the English theater critic and self-proclaimed socialist, related a conversation with some like-minded friends. One of them had made a list of the countries in the world where it was possible to live ''a free and liberal life.'' There are five, he decided: Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Holland and England. This alarmed him because they are all monarchies, and he is opposed to kings and queens.

title: Christina Romas, Charles Connant Jr.
description: Christina Stavra Romas, a daughter of Kassandra Romas of Short Hills, N.J., and the late Dr. Christos Romas, was married yesterday to Charles Ellis Connant Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Connant of Short Hills. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: Pentagon Official Seeks Support for Moderate Muslim Nations
description: The Pentagon's second-in-command sought to rally support in Asia today for moderate Muslim nations and their people who find themselves ''on the front lines of the struggle against terrorism.''

title: Castile and Leon To Come to New York
description: Bringing other cultures to New York is becoming a trend. Last year there were ''invasions'' by Britain, Brazil and Quebec. This year and next, the Castile and Len region of Spain is in the spotlight, beginning June 11 with a concert at Carnegie Hall, to be followed by a variety of events through March 2003 with the theme ''Treasures of Castilla y Len.''

title: Personal Business; A New Temptation for the Ears, Via Satellite
description: WITHIN a few weeks of having an XM Satellite Radio antenna and receiver installed in the family minivan, I found myself thinking of the old joke about the taciturn farmer who loved his wife so much that he almost told her. XM had lent me the equipment so that I could try its service, which costs $9.99 a month. I liked what I heard so much that I almost bought the equipment and subscribed.

title: American Web Browsers Continue a Global Turn
description: It was not surprising that many Americans took a greater interest in foreign affairs after the attacks on the United States last September. But what does surprise foreign policy experts is that an eagerness to comprehend the world remains high nearly nine months later.

title: From Russia With Tsoris
description: Draining his third glass of horseradish vodka, Gary Shteyngart is starting to feel chummy. Sliding over on the curved banquette, the young novelist asks to show me some photographs -- snapshots, he says, of a recent trip he took in the ''disaster that is my homeland, the former Soviet Union.''

title: Rebecca Adams, Julian Trotman
description: Dr. Rebecca Layburn Adams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael B. Adams of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Julian Eric Trotman, a son of Louise Trotman of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Peter A. Trotman of Melbourne, England. The Rev. Susan Harriss, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ's Church in Rye.

title: Baby Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tradition, Badges, Comes Under Police Fire
description: Passing out what look like sheriff's badges to unqualified civilians might seem like a bad idea. But like other questionable practices in the state, it's a tradition.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOPLIK, KENNETH E.
description: KOPLIK-Kenneth E. For all that you gave us...for the pride we had in being your family...we remember you with gratitude and devotion. Sharing your life was a blessing...living the love you left us is an everlasting gift. Diane and David

title: A Historic Gem Hiding in Plain Sight
description: I DISCOVERED Portsmouth, N.H., by sinking into a fugue on the Interstate highway system, and ending up almost in Maine on I-95 instead of heading toward Vermont on I-93. I veered off on the last possible New Hampshire exit ramp, drove too far up a road called the Market Street Extension, looked around and said to myself: ''Wow! What is this place?''

title: Finding Religion in the Theater, Drama in the Church
description: OFTEN called cold and inexpressive, Stravinsky's music can seem ill suited to the secular space and secular rituals of the concert hall. Its rightful homes may be sacred: the theater of the church and the church of the theater. Robert Craft's revelatory new recording of three of Stravinsky's choral monuments, the ''Symphony of Psalms,'' ''Les Noces'' and ''Threni'' demonstrates that the theatrical and religious impulses, based on the willing suspension of disbelief, are at the core of Stravinsky's art.

title: China to Vaccinate Infants Against Hepatitis B
description: BEIJING, June 1  China plans to vaccinate all newborns against hepatitis B within the next five years, a major step toward eradicating a disease that is widespread here and whose aftereffects are a leading cause of death in this country.

title: For Historic Cemeteries, New Chapters
description: TWO of the largest communities in the Bronx and Brooklyn, with 849,000 residents between them, are coping with the challenges faced by any desirable old neighborhood: how to meet demands for a dwindling amount of space; how to design multifamily buildings that cater to modern tastes without disrupting their verdant and historical context; and how to care for aging architectural landmarks whose owners cannot or will not.

title: Commercial Property; Sloan-Kettering Branches Out
description: ON sunny days, a brilliant rainbow arcs gracefully across the lobby of the new 50,000-square-foot outpatient center built in Commack by Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: May 26-June 1: NATIONAL; MORE THIN AIR
description: High-altitude climbing is a booming sport. Last year, some 8.1 million people headed up American mountains for alpine-style ascents. But the perils were all too apparent in the snow-laden peaks of the West. Six climbers died in separate accidents: three after a group tumbled into a crevasse on Oregon's 11,237-foot Mount Hood, and three in a storm atop 14,410-foot Mount Rainier in Washington. And there were collateral injuries: while trying to pull a Mount Hood survivor to safety, an Air Force Reserve helicopter struck the mountain and rolled 1,000 feet, injuring its crew of six. Nick Madigan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLK, EVELYN
description: WOLK-Evelyn. 83, died on May 31, 2002, in Miami, FL. Loving wife of the late George Wolk. Loving mother of Cynthia Nachmani (Gilead) and Jane Wolk (Catherine Gooch). Loving grandmother of Jacob Nachmani. Funeral service Sunday, June 2, 9:45 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

title: Light at the End of the Reservoir: Replacing an Unloved Fence
description: The rusty chain-link fence surrounding the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis reservoir in Central Park may finally be replaced. The eight-foot fence has been a view-obscuring irritant for at least 67 years. Now, two park fans, Donna D. Schwartz and Marvin C. Schwartz, have offered to underwrite the Central Park Conservancy's $2 million project to replace the unloved fence. The new one would be five feet high, three feet shorter than the current fence, but 10 inches higher than the 1862 original design, on which the new fence is modeled. If the Art Commission and Landmarks Preservation Commission approve, construction could start in a year. JOYCE PURNICK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, DONALD
description: RYAN-Donald. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Donald Ryan, associated with The Times from 1980 until retiring in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTENHABER, MORRIS BERNARD
description: GERSTENHABER-Morris Bernard, 88. Died Thursday, May 30th, 2002. Active attorney until recent retirement, W.W. II Veteran US Army Signal Corps Thirty-Sixth Division. Beloved husband of the late Audrey Abeles Gerstenhaber, the late Frances Einstein Gerstenhaber, and companion of Jean Rosenstone. Devoted father of Brett, Garth & Melissa and fatherin-law of Blanche and Gary. Adored grandfather of Dana, Bart, Rodd, Meg and Adam. Funeral service at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 331 Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, 1 P.M. Contributions may be made to ADL, Department DJ, 823 United Nations Plaza, New York, New York 10017, or to the charity of your choice.

title: Our Towns; The Rent Is an Arm and a Leg. The Security Deposit? Don't Ask.
description: MARLENE BALL is a real estate broker in Westchester County, where 578 homes sold for a million dollars or more last year and the median home price was $449,900. She drives a leased Acura with leather seats and a sunroof. Her cellphone rings with ''The Entertainer,'' the theme song from ''The Sting'' -- background music for the real estate market.

title: May 26-June 1: NATIONAL; RECOVERIES AT BRIDGE
description: Emergency workers pulled the 14th victim from the Arkansas River, four days after a dozen vehicles fell in when barges being pushed upstream knocked out a 580-foot section of a bridge on Interstate 40. The tug pilot reportedly blacked out at the wheel. No drugs or alcohol were involved, said the tug's owners, but test results were still pending. Ross E. Milloy

title: A Quicker Look At S.E.C. Filings
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is speeding up public access to corporate documents on its Web site.

title: Rachel Mayer, Michael Judlowe
description: Rachel Andrea Mayer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Mayer of Newton Centre, Mass., was married last evening to Michael Louis Judlowe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Judlowe of New York. Rabbi Chava Koster performed the ceremony at the 200 Fifth Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMEOLA, JOHN
description: CAMEOLA-John. Past president, the Camera Club of NY. Mentor and teacher to any who came on a photographic or artistic quest. Served with distinction, 8th Air Force, during World War II. Poet, artist, photo maven of the digital age, and friend-we hope your spirit lingers with us. The Camera Club of New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ANNE KALMIKOFF
description: MILLER-Anne Kalmikoff. Died on May 25, 2002. She will be remembered for her great strength, vitality, unsinkable spirit, common sense, and remarkable inner and outer beauty. She was a caring woman who was generous in every way. She was a devoted wife to her late husband, Sidney, an adoring mother to her late daughters, Robin and Carol, and a wonderful sister to the late Sol, Marty and Suddie. She is survived by her beloved son, Gary; wife, Patty; grandchildren, Doug, his wife, Alissa, Gregg, his wife, Lynn, Todd, Sloane and Max, and great-grandchildren, Alexander and Rebecca. She will be missed deeply by all those whose lives she touched. Burial was on May 26th.

title: Hard Hats and Soft Hands at a Ground Zero Bar
description: TAKING a woman to a construction workers' party is like taking a steak to a dog run. Nothing but panting and paws.

title: Nora Francescani, David Skinner
description: Nora Elizabeth Francescani, a daughter of Maureen Francescani and David R. Francescani of Plandome, N.Y., was married Friday to David Morris Skinner, a son of Elizabeth M. Skinner and Robert M. Skinner of Verona, N.J. The Rev. Paul Wierichs performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, N.Y.

description: QUINN-Thomas. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Thomas Quinn, associated with The Times from 1977 until retiring in 1993.

title: Sports of The Times; Nets Run Existential Errand
description: THERE was no wild whooping for the Nets in Boston on Friday night. Yes, there was a lot of hearty cheering and plenty of hugging; the players embraced the Eastern Conference championship trophy they had won. But there were no tears of joy and down-on-the-knees celebrations.

description: CORRIGAN-Ethan. In memory of our beloved son, Ethan Corrigan. 1962-2000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANTERNACH, ELIZABETH MITCHELL
description: MANTERNACH-Elizabeth Mitchell, 83, of Bloomfield, CT, on May 29, 2002. Graduated Smith College '41. Former resident of Wilton, CT, Farmington, CT and Vero Beach, FL. Survived by husband Bruce W. Manternach, children Thomas R. Cox, Christopher Cox, Mally CoxChapman, Zabby Cox, stepchildren and grandchildren. Service held June 1 in Bloomfield, CT.

title: Michelle Brown, Christopher Barber
description: Michelle Alexandra Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Brown of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher William Barber, the son of Catherine M. Barber and John B. Barber, both of Weekapaug, R.I. Msgr. John G. Woolsey performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: Police Weapons Prove Vexing for a British Town
description: The gun startled John Moss.

title: Trading Places
description: It's not for control freaks. Nor is it for people who are possessed by their possessions. Swapping houses is a growing trend in vacations. According to HomeExchange.com, there are more than 250,000 happy swaps every year, from families around the world who switch everything from villas in Italy for R.V.'s in Oregon to somewhat more conventional exchanges like Greenwich Village apartments for flats in Paris.

title: When Music Called, She Just Had to Listen
description: SUMMER for the English major meant time to study painting in romantic places. One year it was Provincetown, where the smell of turpentine mingled with the salt air. Another it was Aspen, in a studio ringed by sagebrush. Just as she had painted the countryside as a 10-year-old, instructed in the many shades of green, so now would she spend college vacations with art, courtesy of generous parents.

title: SUMMER READING
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Holiday Books issue of December 2001. The books are alphabetized under genre headings; the complete reviews can be found at nytimes.com/books.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF MR. KURTZ: Living on the Brink of Disaster in Mobutu's Congo, by Michela Wrong. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $13.95.) A foreign correspondent who spent several years in Congo (formerly known as Zaire) recounts the depredations of Mobutu Sese Seko, who during his 32 years as dictator looted the nation of billions while creating ''a parody of a functioning state.'' ''Her firsthand, and first-rate, account'' is filled with ''well-reported anecdotes,'' Ian Fisher wrote in the Book Review last year. ''The details are what give her story its juice.'' In The Graves Are Not Yet Full: Race, Tribe and Power in the Heart of Africa, by Bill Berkeley (Basic Books, $16), another well-traveled journalist argues that the continent's ruinous violence and chaos are fostered by governments that operate like criminal syndicates (the West also deserves much of the blame). Fisher found this ''a smart and broad introduction to the political crisis in Africa.''

title: Refinancing A Co-op's Mortgage
description: WHEN a homeowner contemplates refinancing a mortgage, the critical calculation is whether the lower interest rate being offered will produce net savings quickly enough to justify the cost of obtaining the new loan.

title: Global Education: Reach Ever Higher
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkish Gambit
description: THE TURK

title: Hong Kong Reignites Fire Of China's Regional Cuisines
description: HONG KONG'S bounty of regional Chinese restaurants is one of the chief lures of this great eating city. Visitors can sample specialties like crisp Peking duck, spicy Sichuan dan-dan noodles, juicy pork dumplings from Shanghai, and a vast selection of the dim sum of southern China. Deciding which regional style to try is the only difficulty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENKLAR, NORMAN, M.D.
description: SONNENKLAR - Norman, M.D. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Alan and Jill, Eric and Lisa. Adored grandfather of Jacob, Adam and Harris. Cherished brother-in-law of Bette and Richard. Loving uncle of Risa and Leslie. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Always in our hearts.

title: Nets Leave Doubting to Others
description: Before anyone believed in the Nets, Jason Kidd did.

title: An Idea, at Least, Amid the Job Hunting
description: ''YOU work your whole life in this city, filling out your taxes and voting, and when you need help, you don't get it.''

title: Taken to the Bank
description: I was working at Home Depot, where I'm a manager, when the Discover Card fraud unit called my home to find out why I'd requested an additional credit card. It was Jan. 3, 2000. My wife waited for me to come home before telling me. She knew I'd be upset. After confirming my Social Security number, the Discover agent asked when I had moved to 1919 Madison Avenue, Norfolk, Va. My stomach turned inside out; I live on Long Island. I'd never even been to Virginia. The agent told me to notify the credit bureaus immediately.

title: Nassau's Dome: Symbol of Suozzi Plan
description: THE Old County Courthouse was once a symbol of Nassau's prominence and promise. Theodore Roosevelt, who was governor of New York at the time, laid the cornerstone in 1900 when the county was in its infancy. And the majestic dome could be seen for miles across the flat and mostly treeless Hempstead Plain.

title: A Quicker Look at S.E.C. Filings
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is speeding up public access to corporate documents on its Web site.

title: Where Cowgirls Go to Get Their Due
description: WHEN Vicki S. Bass married Edward P. Bass in 1995, she soon learned that being a Bass wife was at least as challenging as being a Bass brother.

title: The Art of the New, the Art of the Deal
description: THE movers and shakers of the international art world are packing their bags for next weekend's grand opening of Documenta 11, the latest edition of the contemporary art jamboree that takes place every five years in an unremarkable German town called Kassel. Documenta is not this year's only group show, but Kassel is definitely Rendezvous 2002 for museum directors, curators, dealers, gallery owners and collectors. They will be there because everyone will be there.

title: A Prospective Baby Makes 3
description: More and more women -- are visibly pregnant when they take their vows, and the market for maternity wedding dresses is expanding accordingly. For nine-month brides going the whole nine yards, Liz Lange is arguably the Vera Wang of the maternity bridal world, offering form-fitting custom-made silk dresses for brides and bridesmaids ($335 to $450) with matching wraps or coats.

title: GROWING DEFICIT
description: The state's financial problems got even worse last week as John E. McCormac, the state treasurer, announced that declining tax revenues in April have put another $589 million hole in the budget for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30. The state has already closed a $2.9 billion budget gap for this fiscal year. The readjusted deficit will require the use of $400 million from the state surplus, an additional $64 million in budget cuts and $125 million borrowed from the Unemployment Insurance Fund before the end of the month, Mr. McCormac said. Karen DeMasters

title: Molly Falconer, Guillaume de Ramel
description: Molly Falconer, a television correspondent, and Guillaume Henry de Ramel, a financial analyst, were married yesterday at Trinity Church in Newport, R.I. The Rev. John Lawrence, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REEVES, ROBERT, JR.
description: REEVES-Robert, Jr. On May 29, 2002. Reverend Robert B. Reeves Jr. of Warren, CT, retired Head Chaplain of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and former pastor of First Presbyterian Church, Forest Hills, NY. Beloved husband of the late Marion Reeves. Loving father of Robert T. Reeves, Barbara R. Worthington and Carolyn R. Dunn. Dear brother of John D. Reeves and Virginia Cathcart. Devoted grandfather of eight grandchildren and 8 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date at the Warren Congregational Church. Memorial contributions may be made to The Warren Congregational Church, 4 Sackett Hill Road, Warren, CT. 06754.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Postings column last Sunday about the expansion of a building that runs between West 13th and 14th Streets in Manhattan omitted the name of the design architect. It is Selldorf Architects; Steven Kratchman was the architect of record.

title: Is It a Hard Day at Work or Is It a Dream?
description: In his formative years spent canoeing, rowing, water-skiing and exploring the Bahamas aboard the family's 32-foot sailboat, the 25-year-old native Floridian Steve Tadd simply thought he was enjoying a terrific childhood. It probably never occurred to him that he was laying the foundation for a career on the water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, FRANK, SR.
description: ROSS-Frank, Sr. The Board of Directors and staff of Queens CP, grateful for his support of their efforts, extend their sympathies to the family of Frank Ross, Sr.

title: Today's Medici
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Gordan and Stewart Ellis
description: Dr. Elizabeth Le Senne Gordan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Gordan III of New York, was married yesterday to Stewart Andrew Ellis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Ellis of Pewee Valley, Ky. The Rev. Stewart E. Ellis, a Presbyterian minister and an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Life's Work
description: Q: This spring marks the publication of two of your books: a 10th collection of your essays from Natural History, ''I Have Landed,'' and a 1,400-page treatise, ''The Structure of Evolutionary Theory.'' How would you describe the differences between the two?

title: Private Sector; A Sprinkling of Glitter To Help the Lessons Go Down
description: Does starring on ''Dynasty'' qualify Joan Collins to be an investment expert? The organizers of a conference in San Francisco this week apparently think so, for they have asked her to advise the assembled venture capitalists on building a public persona -- ''The Brand You,'' as her talk is titled. ''I'm interested in bringing a little sex to money, a little Hollywood to Wall Street,'' said W. Randall Jones, a friend of Ms. Collins. Mr. Jones is the founder of Worth magazine and the person responsible for the conference, the Worth/Futuredex Investor Exchange. ''And how better to do that than by bringing in the incomparable Joan Collins?''

title: Big Hands Working With Tiny Wares
description: WORKING as a museum guard in the same galleries for hours and days and years could easily be a mind-numbing experience. But for Charles LeDray, it was pivotal to his becoming an artist. For two and a half years at the Seattle Art Museum in the mid-1980's, Mr. LeDray watched over treasures from around the world.

title: The Nation; Spy Game: Changing the Rules So the Good Guys Win
description: THE F.B.I. director Robert S. Mueller III says the bureau is reinventing itself to fight terrorists as its No. 1 priority, but what about the Central Intelligence Agency? The Sept. 11 attacks, though carried out on American soil, were hatched overseas, which is the C.I.A.'s turf.

title: Delta and US Airways Charge for Paper Ticket
description: Delta Air Lines and US Airways no longer provide traditional paper tickets for most itineraries. The airlines will issue a paper ticket if requested, but charge $10 for it. Since May 1 for Delta, and May 22 for US Airways, unless travelers are on code-share flights, or unless they are headed to certain international destinations, all are issued electronic tickets. The e-tickets come with a receipt containing the flight itinerary, ticket number and fare data. The fee will be waived for Delta's Medallion-level frequent fliers and US Airways' three premier-level frequent fliers, and customers buying full-fare unrestricted tickets. The fee also does not apply for paper tickets issued or converted by a travel agent.

title: Marching Orders
description: Harvard has its crimson, Princeton bright orange. Brown has, well brown, with a little cardinal red thrown in for pizazz. But that doesn't mean its graduation ceremonies aren't fabulous looking. They were last Monday, with the attention to every detail of dress that made the campus into a catwalk.

title: Borrowing Privileges
description: A YEAR ago in February I bought a manuscript that I believe to be the first novel written by a female fugitive slave. ''The Bondwoman's Narrative'' was written in the 1850's by Hannah Crafts and is patterned after Gothic and sentimental novels and the slave narratives. Unpublished for 150 years, it is a source of fascination as a testament to the will and intelligence of a determined black woman. When I began to investigate the author's identity, and that of her various masters, I came across another trove, the library of the person who was her master.

title: The Price of Summer Spent at the Register
description: LIKE so many things in life, I learned to appreciate summer only after I had lost it.

title: The First Cosmo Girl, With Daddy All to Herself
description: IF you were born female in the mid- to late portion of the last century with parents who were not averse to books, there is reasonable cause to believe that you developed some sort of intimacy with a young woman of superior self-possession named Nancy Drew.

title: COOKING
description: POTS and pans are a lot like sweaters, the novelist and food writer Laurie Colwin once wrote: ''You may have lots of them, but you find yourself using two or three over and over again.'' Colwin might as well have been talking about cookbooks. It's never hard to tell, when you walk into someone's kitchen for the first time, which few have been put to good, honest use. (Ignore any pert titles, unblemished in their dust jackets, written by of-the-moment chefs -- those are up there for show.) The cookbooks that get used in my house tend to look like they've been pickled in malt vinegar and then shot from a cannon. They resemble scarecrows as much as they do books.

title: Editorial Observer; America's Favorite Television Fare? The Normals vs. the Stigmatized
description: The latest from the world of reality TV -- and it is hard to keep up -- is that E! Networks has signed ''The Anna Nicole Smith Show.'' Designed, seemingly, for those who find the Osbournes insufficiently lurid, it will record the life and times of Ms. Smith, the ex-Playboy Playmate best known for marrying an 89-year-old Texas oil billionaire at age 26, and later fighting his son for an inheritance -- she was awarded $88 million. Also on the show, scheduled for August, is Ms. Smith's 16-year-old-son, Daniel, and her personal assistant, Kim, who has purple hair and a tattoo of Ms. Smith on her arm.

title: Where Horses Trip the Old Fantastic
description: Once again, the New York music world can only look on enviously as the nation's premier early-music festival and exhibition shuttles between Boston and Berkeley, Calif. This year it is Cal Performances' turn to present the Berkeley Festival and Exhibition, an international feast of performances, symposiums and exhibitions of music, instruments and merchandise, beginning today and ending next Sunday.

title: Singapore Cools Off, And All Must Pitch In
description: EVEN the dead get air-conditioning here, less than 100 miles from the Equator.

title: Helen Weatherall, Christopher Florio
description: Helen Caroline Weatherall, the daughter of Robert K. Weatherall of Ipswich, Mass., and the late Sally Lunt Weatherall, was married yesterday to Christopher John Florio, a son of Maryanne J. Florio of Runnemede, N.J., and former Gov. James J. Florio of Metuchen, N.J., Alexander Weatherall, a brother of the bride who is a Church of Life minister, officiated at Omni Camp, a conference center and camp in Poland Spring, Me.

title: BEST SELLERS: June 2, 2002
description: Weeks

title: Weighing Car Rental Insurance
description: Confused about whether to get additional insurance when renting a car?

title: Are There Midgets in Midgetville? Don't Ask the Residents
description: The only thing the people of Midgetville want printed about their block is this: There are no midgets here, only midgetized houses.

title: In the Race's Final Stretch, The G.O.P. Is Stretched Thin
description: Robert G. Torricelli, New Jersey's senior senator, offered an alluring target for Republicans only months ago. Mired in an ethics investigation by federal prosecutors, Mr. Torricelli's poll ratings were slumping.

title: Divisive Race Echoes a Past Loss For Democrats
description: You'd think they would have learned. Eight years ago, voters here in Essex County -- New Jersey's Democratic heartland, where registered Republicans are outnumbered more than 3 to 1 -- jolted the state's political establishment by giving the Republican candidate, James W. Treffinger, the coveted county executive seat.

title: BEQUEST TO DREW
description: Drew University will receive a $5 million gift, the second-largest ever made to the school, the bequest of a Maplewood widow who died earlier this year. Marion Broderson Melander, 93, died in February, and stipulated the donation should go to Drew's theological school in Madison. University officials said last week that the money would be used for family counseling services and financial support for students and to upgrade housing. The daughter of an Essex County developer, Ms. Melander left another $5 million to area hospitals and charities. Jeremy Pearce

title: An Impatient Sisterhood
description: IN 2001 an obscure screenwriter named Stephen Gaghan won an Oscar for ''Traffic,'' a complex and highly acclaimed tale of the drug wars as seen from all sides. Today Mr. Gaghan is directing a $25 million thriller he wrote called ''Abandon'' starring Katie Holmes and Benjamin Bratt.

title: HELP FOR COMMUTERS
description: After a number of delayed debuts, New Jersey Transit officials finally put a date and a name on the direct service on the Boonton train line into Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. It will begin Sept. 30 as the Montclair-Boonton Midtown Direct service, and it will carry about 9,500 passengers a day. The announcement came as part of a press conference by Governor McGreevey and the state transportation commissioner, James Fox, about a plan to help find seats for the roughly 4,000 rail commuters who find themselves standing each day. They said that they plan to add trains during rush hours and expand Saturday schedules. Officials also announced a commitment of $250 million from the Port Authority for the purchase of 231 two-level passenger cars, expected to be running in 2005. John Holl

title: Dance Listings
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER  Mon.-Thu., 8 and Wed., 2: "La Fille Mal Gardee." Fri.-Sat., 8 and Sat., 2: "Firebird" and "Rite of Spring." Metropolitan Opera House (212-362-6000) Through July 6.

title: This Nippy Season, a White Cardigan Wrap
description: Now that pashminas are being cut up -- for Halloween costumes and burp cloths, women are again faced with that conundrum: What to wear over bare shoulders at outdoor weddings when there's a chill in the air? This year's model cover-up is the little white cardigan, worn neat or draped over the shoulders.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about the Prabhupada Sankirtan Society, a Hare Krishna temple on Avenue B in the East Village, misstated its location. It is between East Third and East Fourth Streets, not near East First Street.

title: The Big Board Is Standing Up for Independence
description: THE term ''business ethics'' does not have to be an oxymoron. But in today's scandal-a-minute atmosphere, it has surely become one. Public trust in corporate America has been undeniably shattered. What is less clear is exactly how and when confidence in the markets, regulators, and business in general will be restored.

title: Coral Pink, Like a Sunset
description: Ren Bouvier's dry 2001 Marsannay ros is the color of a coral-pink sunset. A miniature Burgundian pinot noir, with strawberry perfume, it's as delicate as chiffon. Rosenthal Wine Merchant, 318 East 84th Street (Second Avenue), Manhattan, asks $15.25. This choosy shop offers eight inviting European ross. They include Bisson's cherrylike 2001 Ciliegiolo, Golfo del Tigullio ($11.25). HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: A Little Bit Of Inflation Could Go A Long Way
description: EVERYBODY knows it's possible to have too much of a good thing. Too much rich food leads to indigestion; too many e-mail messages can drive you to the delete button.

title: Airline Seating: Timing, Luck
description: WHEN Nadya Sagner booked a flight last year from Washington to Paris, she called Air France eight weeks in advance. Still, she and her husband were assigned to middle seats in different rows. ''No matter how many times I called, they said, 'We've filled all the seats we've assigned, you'll have to do it at check-in,' '' Ms. Sagner said. On the day of the flight the Sagners got to the airport early and tried one more time. They were given ideal seats, the window and aisle in a two-person row.

title: INVESTING WITH/Neil J. Hennessy; Hennessy Cornerstone Growth Fund
description: NEIL J. HENNESSY, who runs the $310 million Hennessy Cornerstone Growth fund, relies on a computer model that, he says, gives his shareholders the consistency they crave.

title: In the Time of Hugo Chvez
description: Early one Sunday, when morning mist still shrouded the Avila Mountains encircling Caracas, I arrived at the Venezuelan leader's hacienda-style residence for a live broadcast of his weekly program, ''Hello, President!'' Sixties-era revolutionary ballads wafted from a crackling speaker as I made my way inside, past soldiers standing sentry in red-laced boots and a grandfather clock that no longer keeps time.

title: Prison Boom Has Not Deterred Crime, Report Suggests
description: Despite the prison-construction boom of recent years, the rate at which inmates released from prison committed new crimes actually rose from 1983 to 1994, suggesting that the increased number of criminals put behind bars has not been an effective deterrent to crime, according to a Justice Department study released today.

title: An Early Sign of Alzheimer's Brings Fear, and New Insight
description: Until recently, a patient like Carolyn E. Hoard would never have been told she was progressing toward Alzheimer's disease. A 61-year-old mental health counselor in Kittanning, Pa., she reported nothing more than a mild loss of memory, particularly when it came to recalling what someone had said in conversation a few minutes ago. Her first neurologist told her she was fine.

title: The Nation: African Genesis; Flirting With Free Markets
description: AFTER the horrific human suffering and wrenching transitions that have accompanied Africa's passage through colonialism, the cold war, brutal regional conflicts and the ravages of AIDS, the continent is starting to face another, potentially more positive challenge: how to become part of the global economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TABAK, WALLACE J.
description: TABAK-Wallace J. Age 86, on May 22. Beloved husband of the late Harriet. Loving father of Jeffrey. Cherished father-in-law of Susan. Adoring grandfather of Alexis, Elizabeth and Philip. Dear brother of Freida. Contributions may be sent to the Richard Tucker Music Foundation, 1790 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10019.

title: Bring a Blanket: The Met's in the Park
description: IT costs a pretty penny to hear the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall or to attend an opera at the Met, across the Lincoln Center Plaza. Come summertime, though, and those musicians move much closer with prices pegged at the best of all possible levels: zero.

title: Claire Mackey, William Thompson III
description: Claire Emily Mackey, a daughter of Rosemary Wiggins Mackey and a stepdaughter of Dr. Irwin Krakoff of New York, was married yesterday to William Samuel Thompson III, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thompson Jr. of Laguna Beach, Calif. The Rev. David Rider performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARIAM, RUDOLPH K. ''RALPH.''
description: MARIAM-Rudolph K. ''Ralph.'' Of Kew Gardens, NY, on May 31, 2002, at the age of 90. Devoted husband of Lisa Mariam for 60 years. Beloved father of Rita Golden and her husband, Steven, of Scarsdale, NY, and Tom Mariam and his wife, Alyce, of Rye Brook, NY. Proud grandfather of Meredith and Alissa Golden and Michael Mariam. Treasured brother of Hortense Lewin. Born and educated in Germany, a U.S. citizen since 1938, and a founding member of Congregation Habonim, his kindness and compassion will be missed by all. Services will be held 11 o'clock today at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd. at 76th Rd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: Williams Takes Fourth Title in 100
description: Angela Williams, a senior sprinter from Southern California, did something last night in Baton Rouge, La., that only two other women have ever done when she won her fourth straight title in the N.C.A.A. track and field championships.

title: Rachel Elkin, Benjamin Lebwohl
description: Rachel Tamar Elkin, the daughter of Esther S. Elkin and Dr. Richard M. Elkin of Wayland, Mass., is to be married today to Benjamin Lebwohl, a son of Vida and Dr. Oscar Lebwohl of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Jacob S. Rubenstein will perform the ceremony at the Hyatt Regency in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Word for Word/Japanese Etiquette Tips; English 101: How to Handle A Thirsty, Big-Bodied Soccer Fan
description: THE Japanese are proud of their long history of repelling attacks -- the Mongols, Chinese, Russians. But as the World Cup soccer tournament gets underway here and in South Korea (the games began on Friday), the Japanese are steeling themselves for another invasion: English soccer hooligans.

title: Alyssa Klapper, Avery Samet
description: Alyssa Devorah Klapper, the daughter of Erika Klapper and Dr. Raphael Klapper of Riverdale, the Bronx, is to be married today to Avery Samet, a son of Naomi and Walter Samet of Pikesville, Md. Rabbi Dr. Norman Lamm will officiate at the Hilton Pearl River in Pearl River, N.Y.

title: Shafts of Light Seen In the Merger Tunnel
description: Corporate America has had little appetite lately for mergers and acquisitions. In fact, 2002 is already shaping up as one of the slowest years in overall activity in recent years. But a new study suggests that a turnaround could be ahead.

title: Elizabeth Gordan, Stewart Ellis
description: Dr. Elizabeth Le Senne Gordan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Gordan III of New York, was married yesterday to Stewart Andrew Ellis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Ellis of Pewee Valley, Ky. The Rev. Stewart E. Ellis, a Presbyterian minister and an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Kingston Journal; If Washington Woke Up, He Wouldn't Sleep Here
description: It's hard to imagine anyone, let alone George Washington, sleeping at Rockingham, the 288-year-old clapboard mansion that served as his final headquarters toward the end of the American Revolution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVENEY, KENNETH
description: DEVENEY-Kenneth. Of Manhattan, former senior art restorer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died on May 25 after a courageous and dignified battle with lung cancer, as reported by his Friend of 39 years, Dr. Prospero Sanidad.

title: Delicate Balancing Act With a Bit of a Swagger
description: BILL BARRELL is a Jersey City fixture. He was born in London in 1932 but has lived in Jersey City since the mid-1950's, painting steadily and showing regularly in New Jersey, across America and abroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILEY, HELEN PHELPS, PH.D.
description: BAILEY-Helen Phelps, Ph.D. May 28, 2002. Professor Emeritus of French and French Literature and former Dean of Studies, Barnard College. Frank Patti Funeral Home, 327 Main St., Ft Lee, N.J., Monday, June 3, 2-4, 7-9PM; funeral at St. John's Church, Leonia, N.J. Broad Ave and Harrison St., Tuesday, June 4th, 10:30AM.

title: Initial Impressions
description: SHORTLY after moving to Plainsboro, I heard about a singles organization sponsored by a local Jewish organization. It was called Y.A.D. -- Young Adult Division. My fellow man-hunters called it Young and Desperate. I did, too, after attending a few events.

title: Charming the Snake and the Husband; Making the Fire Drills Count
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Sarah Gallant, Rocky Kurita
description: Sarah Woods Gallant, the daughter of Mary P. Grandy and the stepdaughter of Jeffrey R. Grandy of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Hiroki Michael Kurita, a son of Kaneko T. O'Dea of Arnold, Md., and the late Koichiro J. Kurita. The Rev. Kathryn Nichols, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, BOB (JEROME)
description: GOLDMAN-Bob (Jerome). Of Westport, CT, age 88, died peacefully at his home on May 30, 2002. His life was one of integrity & caring, sharing joys with family & friends. He will be dearly missed by his wife Stemmie, daughters: Sue and Gwen, sons-in-law: Jay Rosenblum and Peter McLoughlin, & grandchildren: Steve, Sarah & Abby. Services Monday, June 3, 11:30 AM, from Abraham L. Green & Son, 88 Beach Rd., Fairfield, CT. The family will be at home on Tuesday, June 4, after noon.

title: Executive Life: The Boss; Lesson on a Dinner Plate
description: MY dad instilled a work ethic in me. He owned an industrial supplies business in Nashville. I was less than 10 when we'd go for a drive on Sundays and look at the inventory in competitors' yards. At 12, I learned to demonstrate a forklift -- really a power dolly that was used to move things around the warehouse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITLOCK, BACHE MCEVERS

title: 'The Turk'
description: Automata are the forgotten ancestors of almost all modern technology. From computers to compact-disc players, railway engines to robots, the origins of today's machines can be traced back to the elaborate mechanical toys that flourished in the eighteenth century. As the first complex machines produced by man, automata represented a proving ground for technology that would later be harnessed in the industrial revolution. But their original uses were rather less utilitarian. Automata were the playthings of royalty, both as a form of entertainment in palaces and courts across Europe and as gifts sent from one ruling family to another. As well as being a source of amusement, automata provided a showcase for each nation's scientific prowess, since they embodied what was, at the time, the absolute cutting edge of new technology. As a result, automata had a far greater social and cultural importance than their outward appearance as mere toys might suggest.

A speech pathologist, she worked for 15 years at the Cotting School in Lexington, MA. where she was the team leader of the Communication Therapy Department. She graduated from Clark University with a BA in Psychology from Lesley College with an EdM in Special Education and from Boston University with an MS in Speech Pathology. She had a special gift with children, particularly her students, and her nieces and nephews. She was an enthusiastic unicyclist, whittler, musician, canoeist, and juggler who had a passionate love of the outdoors and an active interest in protecting the environment. Services will be held Monday, June 3rd, at 11 A.M., St. John's Episcopal Church, Revere St. and Roanoke Avenue, Jamaica Plain, MA. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Kate C. title: Getting the Lowdown on the High Season

Not all the parties, hot tubs, nightclubs and summer rentals (some with six beds to a room) may strike you as worth writing home about; the same goes for the characters. Ms. Kopple zeros in, dizzyingly, on dozens, granting equal film time to haves and have-nots alike. But the excursion has its fascinations, including a midseason scandal that rocked the gossip-page set and a sentimental subplot -- a featured character's ornery but beloved old mutt doesn't make it through the summer -- that becomes a bit less the sob story when the pet owner eases his grief Hamptons style: with a new BMW.

title: Reyna and Mathis May Not Start
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 3 -- After waiting to play the very last game of the first round of the World Cup, the United States is suddenly running out of time to recuperate from injuries. Both Claudio Reyna, the dependable captain, and Clint Mathis, the most explosive offensive force on the team, are in doubt for the opener against Portugal on Wednesday. Reyna said this afternoon that his chances are "50-50" to play the first game, while Mathis left practice this morning to have an MRI on his surgically-repaired left knee. The test was negative, but Mathis is also unsure for Wednesday. Often bothered by injuries in his career with the national team, Reyna said he felt a twinge in his right quadriceps while reaching for a ball 10 days ago. It has not healed despite treatment. On Monday afternoon, he appeared at a press conference and, when asked about the injury, he did not deny it. "Me and Clint are a little banged up," Reyna said. "In the worst-case scenario, I'd only miss a game. But I've got another day to get treatment." He said the decision would be made on Tuesday. Coach Bruce Arena, who was seated next to Reyna when the captain made his 50-50 statement, raised his eyebrows. Asked about the prognosis, Arena said, "I don't know, I'm not a mathematician." But Arena also said, "We've been used to injuries. We rarely have the full lineup." He said all teams have to get used to them because of the long league seasons, including cup games, and the heavy national-team schedule tucked into the league schedules. "Would we like Chris Armas to be here?" he said of another regular midfielder who tore up his knee last month. "It's not going to happen. Would France have liked Zidane to play in their first game? It didn't happen." And he gave several other examples of injuries. Mathis tore up his knee exactly one year ago to the day of Wednesday's game with Portugal, had surgery, and did not play for the national team again until late January. Arena has suggested that Mathis is not in the best possible shape, but today's visit for an MRI was a new development. "He practiced briefly today," Arena said. "He took a precautionary MRI -- nothing. There's a little inflammation, but it went well." Could Mathis play Wednesday? Arena replied, "I'm told he could." Arena would not speculate on who would replace either player, but then again, he has declined to discuss potential starting lineups, saying, "I've never seen where it does me any good." Reyna said it was not his job to make out the lineup, but he noted that Earnie Stewart could move into his role in the midfield, or that Pablo Mastroeni, a newcomer to the team, "has done well there." If Mathis cannot go against Portugal, this would open room for another offensive-minded player like Landon Donovan, DaMarcus Beasley, Josh Wolff or Joe Max Moore to work with Brian McBride up front. There are also hints that Frankie Hejduk has been training at left outside back perhaps to start instead of David Regis, who took a while to adjust after a long grueling season with his team in Metz, France. The U.S. is not that deep that it can afford to lose players like Reyna and Mathis against a powerful team like Portugal. But Reyna said he knows his own body, and right now he cannot play. Mathis did not comment. He was taking treatment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWEY, GORDON CHIPMAN
description: DEWEY-Gordon Chipman. Age 79, died peacefully on May 30, 2002 at his home in New York City. Mr. Dewey was born in New York on April 9, 1923, to the late Fredrick A. and Elisabeth (Braley) Dewey and is the grandson of John Dewey, the American philosopher and educator. Mr. Dewey studied nuclear physics at Harvard during WW II, earning a bachelors and masters degree. During the war years, he worked at the Radiation Laboratory at MIT on early radar technologies and was also involved in the Manhattan Project. He was later recruited to work at the Pentagon for the Joint Chiefs of Staff with the Weapon Systems Evaluation Group, focusing on the nuclear retaliatory mission. In the 1950's consulted to the Pentagon, the White House, and companies such as the Rand Corporation. Mr. Dewey was appointed to the Air Traffic Control Board by the President of the United States in 1957. He founded the Dewey Electronics Corporation in 1955 where he continued his work with the defense industry and also began developing snowmaking technology. The company went public in 1960 and Mr. Dewey continued as the President and CEO until his death. Mr. Dewey's extensive philanthropic efforts centered on education. He had served as the chairman of the Navy League's scholarship committee and was the current and longtime President of the Board at the New York Institute for Special Education, which began as an institute for the blind and was then expanded to meet the needs of children with other disabilities. He was an avid sailor and spent his summers in Nantucket. Mr. Dewey had the distinction of being one of the longestrunning members of the New York Yacht Club. His warm and wise presence will be missed. Mr. Dewey is survived by his wife of 48 years, Frances Dear; his children, Fredrick R., Dede W., John H. D. (Sara); and his sister Joanna. A memorial service is scheduled for Wednesday, June 5, at 3 PM, at the Heavenly Rest Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Institute for Special Education, 999 Pelham Parkway, Bronx, NY 10469.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOYD, REV. DR. NATHANIEL TYLER
description: LLOYD-Rev. Dr. Nathaniel Tyler. The Reverend Dr. Nathaniel Tyler Lloyd, Pastor of Trinity Baptist Church in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, New York, passed away on Wednesday, May 29, 2002. He was 71 years old. Pastor Lloyd came to Trinity Baptist Church in 1960. During his 42 year tenure, the church experienced tremendous growth under his leadership-a new edifice, increased membership, and a transformative impact in the lives of individuals and institutions in its surrounding communities. National Baptist Convention U.S.A., Inc., and other local and national ministries, Pastor Lloyd was a past president of Lott Carey Baptist Foreign Mission Convention, and at the time of his death, he was a vice president of Baptist World Alliance. Pastor Lloyd was a prolific preacher, renowned for his love of worship and his giftedness as a liturgist. Pastor Lloyd is survived by his wife, Mrs. Portia K. Tyler Lloyd, his son, Dr. Mark David Tyler-Lloyd, and his daughter, Rev. Naomi Elaine Tyler-Lloyd. His body will lie in state on Thursday, June 6, 2002, from 9 AM to 9 PM at Trinity Baptist Church, 808 East 224th Street, Bronx, New York. Final viewing will be held at the church on Friday, June 7, from 8 AM to 8:45 AM. A farewell service of worship and celebration will begin at 9 AM. title: World Briefing | Asia: The Hague: Indonesia-Malaysia Island Case
description: Indonesia is taking Malaysia to court over two scenic islands, Sipadan and Litigan, which Indonesia claims. The tiny islands are valued as favorite spots for divers and also for reported oil and gas reserves. Indonesia says it was accorded the islands by an 1891 Anglo-Dutch treaty between the region's colonial powers, and says Malaysia erred by printing maps showing the islands as its territory and by building tourism sites on Sipadan. The case is before the International Court of Justice, which hears disputes among nations. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Talks On A Rights Tribunal
description: The special United Nations envoy to Cambodia for human rights, Peter Leuprecht, said a number of countries were pressing the United Nations and Cambodia to resume talks on holding an international trial for the surviving leaders of the Khmer Rouge. The United Nations recently withdrew from the talks, saying the Cambodian side did not seem serious about reaching an agreement. This is the first time a United Nations official has publicly suggested in Cambodia the possibility that the talks could resume. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOYD, REV. DR. NATHANIEL TYLER
description: LLOYD-Rev. Dr. Nathaniel Tyler. The Reverend Dr. Nathaniel Tyler Lloyd, Pastor of Trinity Baptist Church in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, New York, passed away on Wednesday, May 29, 2002. He was 71 years old. Pastor Lloyd came to Trinity Baptist Church in 1960. During his 42 year tenure, the church experienced tremendous growth under his leadership-a new edifice, increased membership, and a transformative impact in the lives of individuals and institutions in its surrounding communities. In addition to serving both church and community through American Baptist Church U.S.A. National Baptist Convention U.S.A., Inc., and other local and national ministries, Pastor Lloyd was a past president of Lott Carey Baptist Foreign Mission Convention, and at the time of his death, he was a vice president of Baptist World Alliance. Pastor Lloyd was a prolific preacher, renowned for his love of worship and his giftedness as a liturgist. Pastor Lloyd is survived by his wife, Mrs. Portia K. Tyler Lloyd, his son, Dr. Mark David TylerLloyd, and his daughter, Rev. Naomi Elaine Tyler-Lloyd. His body will lie in state on Thursday, June 6, 2002, from 9 AM to 9 PM at Trinity Baptist Church, 808 East 224th Street, Bronx, New York. Final viewing will be held at the church on Friday, June 7, from 8 AM to 8:45 AM. A farewell service of worship and celebration will begin at 9 AM. For more information contact McCall's Bronxwood Funeral Home, 718-231-7647.

title: Experts Searching for Ways to Fill the Vaccine Gap
description: Within blocks of Dr. Max Van Gilder's bustling pediatric office near Central Park in Manhattan, patients and their parents can readily find bubble bath from France, chocolates from Belgium and fresh melon from South America. But for months now, Dr. Van Gilder's youngest patients have had to wait for their shots against diseases like measles and diphtheria and to come back to his office once they were available.

The number of young women -- beautiful, multinamed and transcontinental -- who have taken up jewelry design appears to be expanding at the same pace as Californians becoming nutritionally dependent on wheat grass.

description: Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz came to the Philippines today to assess plans for American troops to extend a counterterrorism training mission with the Philippine military and to become more involved in searching for two Americans held by a militant Muslim group.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: BISHOPS DEPLORE ABORTION VOTE Roman Catholic bishops denounced a voters' decision on Sunday to legalize abortion, but other officials said the overwhelming outcome of the national referendum represented progress. Several Catholic bishops asserted that the vote, which will allow abortion in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy, would open the door to euthanasia. But Justice Minister Ruth Metzler — who campaigned for the abortion proposal, which her Christian Democratic party opposed — said the vote was "a historic victory for women."    (Reuters)

title: BIRMINGHAM STEEL FILES FOR CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
description: The Birmingham Steel Corporation, which makes concrete reinforcing bars for the construction industry, sought bankruptcy protection from creditors to complete its sale to the Nucor Corporation. Birmingham Steel listed $487.5 million in assets and $681.9 million in debts in Chapter 11 papers filed in bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del. The company, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., has had nine consecutive quarterly losses because of low prices caused by falling demand and competition from imports. It is the eighth steel maker to file for bankruptcy protection during the last year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Arbitrator Named In Retail Bid
description: Castorama Dubois Investissement SCA and Kingfisher P.L.C. agreed to name Rothschild & Cie Banque to arbitrate their dispute over Kingfisher's 5.3 billion euro ($5 billion) offer for the rest of the French company. Rothschild replaces Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, which was opposed by Castorama, lawyers for Kingfisher and Castorama said. The bank must assess Kingfisher's 67-euro-a-share offer for Castorama, a home-improvement retailer, under the terms of the 1998 agreement when Kingfisher, owner of the Comet consumer electronics chain, bought 55 percent of Castorama. Castorama's chief executive, Jean-Hugues Loyez, said Schroder Salomon failed to disclose its position as adviser to Compass Group P.L.C., whose chairman, Francis Mackay, above, also is chairman of Kingfisher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUESCH, DR. ALFRED S.
description: RUESCH-Dr. Alfred S. Of Massapequa, NY (formerly of Great Neck), on May 31, 2002, at the age of 94. Beloved husband of Gladys Rinard Ruesch. Loving father of Alfred R. (Ann) and Robert (Eileen). Cherished grandfather of Devon and Lisa and Christine and Matthew. Adored great-grandfather of two great-grandchildren. Caring brother of Melvin Ruesch. Dr. Ruesch was a graduate of Lafayette College and received his medical degree from NYU Medical School. He served as a lieutenant commander in the Pacific Campaign from 1942-1946. At the time of his death he was a retired commander in the U.S.N.R. Dr. Ruesch practiced family medicine in Great Neck for 48 years. He was on the medical staff of Winthrop University Hospital (formerly Nassau Hospital), Manhasset Medical Center, Meadowbrook Hospital and North Shore University Hospital. Dr. Ruesch served on the Founders Committee of North Shore University Hospital. For many years he served as Chief of Family Practice at North Shore University Hospital. In addition he was the surgeon for The Vigilant Alert Fire Company in Great Neck. He also served as the school doctor for the Great Neck School system. He was one of the founders of the Community Church of Great Neck. He served on the Board of the Long Island Council of Christians and Jews. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, June 4, at the Massapequa Funeral Home, Inc. (North Chapel), 1050 Park Blvd, Massapequa Park, NY, from 1:30 to 4:30 PM, with a religious service at 3:30 PM. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to your favorite charity.

title: NEW RULES FOR FANNIE MAE AND FREDDIE MAC
description: The government agency that oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two largest buyers of mortgages, has issued rules that require the companies to maintain audit and compensation committees made up of independent board members. In its rule, the agency, the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, will require the two companies to follow guidelines for audit committees being proposed by the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said the rule would not result in broad changes to the way the companies operate. Congress and federal regulators are seeking to force companies to increase disclosure and oversight of accounting and reporting requirements after the bankruptcy filing of Enron.

Noon-in-China does business as Tony & Tina. Intercosmetics, which is based in New York and is a subsidiary of Cosmopolitan Cosmetics, Wella's cosmetics and fragrance business, acquired the 75 percent stake in Tony & Tina. A Wella spokesman, Klaus Wolfram, said the Tony & Tina unit expects sales of $10 million this year.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: COLORADO: BUDGET-CUTTING INCUMBENT Gov. Bill Owens, a Republican seeking re-election this year, has cut $228 million from the Legislature's budget proposal for the 2003 fiscal year. Governor Owens said the plan, which he called "woefully irresponsible," represented a 7.3 percent increase in spending when state revenues have slid 13 percent. As part of his adjustments, he ordered every state agency to cut spending by 4 percent, an action that Rollie Heath, his Democratic opponent, criticized as falling hardest on children and low-income groups. Those rates include all meals, drinks, snacks, non-motorized water sports, nightly entertainment, taxes and tips. Information: (800) 888-1199.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: More Requests For Restraining Orders

Court commissioners say the fee had helped weed out frivolous complaints, but others say it may have kept victims of violence from obtaining orders of protection. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWEY, GORDON CHIPMAN
description: DEWEY-Gordon Chipman. 79, died peacefully May 30, 2002, at his home in New York City. Mr. Dewey was born in New York on April 9, 1923, to the late Frederick A. and Elisabeth (Braley) Dewey and is the grandson of John Dewey, the American philosopher and educator. Mr. Dewey studied nuclear physics at Harvard during WW II. During the war years, he worked at the Radiation Laboratory at MIT on early radar technology, as well as on The Manhattan Project. He was later recruited to be at the Pentagon for the Joint Chiefs of Staff with the Weapon Systems Evaluation Group, analyzing the nuclear retaliatory mission. In the 1950's he was a consultant to the Department of Defense, the White House (as a presidential appointee to the Air Traffic Control Board) and companies such as the Rand Corporation. In 1955, he founded The Dewey Electronics Corporation, taking it public in 1960. Today the company is active in the snowmaking and defense industries. He was President and CEO until his death. Mr. Dewey's extensive philanthropic efforts centered on education. He was past chairman of the Navy League Scholarship Committee. For 27 years he led The New York Institute for Special Education through a period of major building and transformation as the president of its board. The Institute began for the blind and was then expanded to meet the needs of children with other disabilities. He was an avid sailor and spent his summers in Nantucket. Mr. Dewey had the distinction of being one of the longest-running members of the New York Yacht Club. His warm and wise presence will be missed. Mr. Dewey is survived by his wife of 48 years, Frances Dear; his children, Frederick R., Dede W., John H. D. (Sara); and his sister Joanna. A memorial service is scheduled for Wednesday, June 5 at 3 PM at the Heavenly Rest Church, 2 East 90th St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Institute for Special Education, 999 Pelham Parkway, Bronx, NY, 10469.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Moldova: Telecom Sale Set
description: The impoverished former Soviet republic of Moldova will sell a 51 percent stake in its state-owned telecommunications monopoly by August, the government said. The Communist Party returned to power in Moldova in March, and international lenders have made privatization a central demand for them to unlock loans and prevent the country from defaulting on $200 million in foreign debt servicing due this year. No minimum price has been set for the sale, but a 1997 effort to sell the telecommunications company failed when it drew only one bidder, Greece's national phone company, OTE. Moldova's 4.3 million people have an average 164.9 telephone lines per thousand people, one of the lowest penetration rates in Europe.

title: WORLDCOM AGREES TO SELL UNIT TO U.S. REALTEL
