The purchase of the unit, Advanced Building Networks, will let U.S. RealTel's Cypress Communications unit enter 18 markets, including Washington, San Francisco and Phoenix, a spokeswoman, Manda Hunt, said. RealTel's subscribers will increase more than threefold to 8,500 from 2,500 small and medium-size businesses. As part of the sale, U.S. RealTel, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., agreed to buy $40 million of network services from WorldCom within three years. WorldCom is based in Clinton, Miss.

title: Hybrid Embryo Mixture May Offer New Source Of Stem Cells for Study
description: Researchers at a New Jersey fertility clinic are proposing a new way to get human embryonic stem cells -- by mixing together embryos that are made in the clinic for infertile couples but that turn out to be so aberrant that they would ordinarily be discarded.

title: INVESTMENT FIRM INCREASES STAKE IN ADELPHIA
description: Highfields Capital Management has increased its stake in Adelphia Communications, the troubled cable operator, to 9 percent from 6.8 percent, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Highfields bought 4.98 million shares on Friday, according to the filing. Highfields, based in Boston, paid 74 to 77 cents each for the shares and now owns 20.5 million shares. The purchase suggests that Highfields thinks the stockholders will receive something even if Adelphia files for bankruptcy protection. Adelphia came under scrutiny after acknowledging that it had guaranteed billions in loans to partnerships of the Rigas family, which founded the company.

title: The Science Of the Tonys, Impenetrable And Inexact
description: Those looking for logic could be forgiven for coming away confounded from Sunday night's Tony Awards. ''Awards events are bizarre,'' said Rocco Landesman, a producer of ''The Producers,'' which set a record last year with 12 awards. ''Weird things happen.''

title: A Winning Encore From Agassi
description: In baggy shorts and a backward cap, in the beginner's stage of facial hair, Paul-Henri Mathieu had the look of a dorm-hall ringer.

title: The World According to Lucas
description: The critics were carping at George Lucas's new ''Star Wars'' movie before it even opened. Such tedious political talk! (Former Queen Amidala: ''You really don't like politicians, do you?'' Anakin Skywalker: ''I don't think the system works.'') One reviewer cruelly compared the film's palaver to a Sunday morning interview show. Predictably, it is a big hit anyway.

title: Hal Riney, Founder Of Agency, to Retire
description: Hal Riney, the creative executive and founder of the agency that carries his name, Publicis & Hal Riney in San Francisco, is retiring.

title: Whalers and Their Foes Enlist Scientists
description: With the hunting of hundreds of whales at stake, the debate over the scientific value of Japan's whaling program boils down to dueling photograph displays of whale digestive systems.

title: Amityville Boys Show the Way
description: Amityville High School of Long Island won two fast sprint relays and Charles Mayrer of La Salle Institute in Troy, N.Y., was a double winner in field events yesterday in the 46th annual Eastern States Boys Interscholastic Championships at Mount St. Michael Field in the Bronx.

title: Poverty and Sisyphus
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil fights back theatrically to beat stubborn Turks : The Rs roll as Ronaldo returns
description: ULSAN, South Korea:  You are not at a World Cup until you have sampled Brazil's color, skill and drama. On Monday, the most famous of the 204 countries who enter this tournament extricated itself from a losing situation to win, 2-1, against brave and committed Turks. At one time, with the industrial smog closing in and a distinctly sulfurous stench rising, the smell could have been Brazil's reputation burning. Turkey, in its first finals since 1954, had scored first and was defiantly resisting even Ronaldo and Rivaldo. But those are "gods" of the game against you; nothing is safe.

title: Channeling the Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Ants' Demolition Derby

title: Court Orders Militant Freed; Palestinian Leaders Balk
description: A Palestinian court today ordered the immediate release of a Palestinian hard-liner jailed in a deal reached with American help to lift the siege of the headquarters of Yasir Arafat. But the Palestinian leadership stopped the release, saying it feared that Israel might assassinate the militant.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CAMBODIA: TALKS ON A RIGHTS TRIBUNAL The special United Nations envoy to Cambodia for human rights, Peter Leuprecht, said a number of countries were pressing the United Nations and Cambodia to resume talks on holding an international trial for the surviving leaders of the Khmer Rouge. The United Nations recently withdrew from the talks, saying the Cambodian side did not seem serious about reaching an agreement. This is the first time a United Nations official has publicly suggested in Cambodia the possibility that the talks could resume.    Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: No Regrets Letting This Winner Get Away
description: Russell Reineman is neither broke nor senile. He is a businessman and a horse trader who sold 90 percent of War Emblem, the colt that is a mile and a half away from capturing the Triple Crown. His net income from the deal stands at approximately $1.2 million and growing, or, he insists, enough to make the same deal again. Frank Springer, meanwhile, is somewhat tormented.

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Candidate For Governor
description: As expected, Senator Frank H. Murkowski, a Republican, has formally filed to run for governor. Mr. Murkowski, left, a 22-year Senate veteran with two years remaining in his fourth term, said Alaska's troubled economy prompted his run. Citing a net outflow of people from the state, Mr. Murkowski said, ''This tragic loss of the best and brightest of our youth has me deeply troubled.'' The state usually favors Republicans, and Mr. Murkowski is favored by many analysts to win. But he could face a competitive race in November, probably against Lt. Gov. Fran Ulmer, a Democrat who has also filed to run. Term limits bar Gov. Tony Knowles, a Democrat, from seeking a third term. Timothy Egan (NYT)

title: 3 Awards for Dance on Broadway
description: The Theater Development Fund has named Susan Stroman, Sutton Foster and Justin Bohon the winners of its 2002 Astaire Awards for the best dance on Broadway.

title: The Regents Exam That Failed
description: To the Editor:

title: Determined Lakers Learn From Kings
description: Rick Fox stood in the middle of a humid Lakers locker room at Arco Arena in Sacramento on Sunday night, patting sweat from his brow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSJEAN, PRISCILLA (TOOTY)
description: GROSJEAN - Priscilla (Tooty). Nee Weld. Of Haverford, Pa. and Wareham, Ma. On May 31, 2002. Wife of the late Charles A. Grosjean. Mother of Claire de Villers Grandchamps, Michelle Grosjean Brewster and Daphne de La Hamaide. Also survived by five grandchildren Eric de Villers Grandchamps, Sylvia Weld Brewster, Charles Erskine, Scott Brewster, Jean Charles de La Hamaide and Sybille de La Hamaide and five greatgrandchildren Coralie, Nicolas, Gregoire, Valentinne, Guillaume de Villers Grandchamps and her sister Sylvia Weld Bigelow. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday June 5 at 3PM at the Church of the Good Shepherd, Lancaster and Montrose Avenues, Rosemont, Pa. Interment private. A second memorial service will be held on Friday, June 7, at 3:30PM in the Church of the Good Shepherd, High Street, Wareham, Mass. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name may be made to the Coalition for Buzzards Bay, 17 Hamilton St, New Bedford, Mass. 02740. For information contact Stuard Funeral Home, Ardmore, PA. 610649-0243.

title: Inmate Whose Lawyer Slept Gets New Trial
description: The Supreme Court, acting in a case that has come to crystallize arguments over the adequacy of legal representation in death penalty cases, today let stand an appellate ruling that a Texas death row inmate is entitled to a new trial because his lawyer fell asleep repeatedly during his original trial.

title: Film Studio Where Dietrich Dazzled Seeks New Heyday
description: Just inside the studio gates here, on Billy Wilder Place, there is a sign in English that says, ''Studio Babelsberg since 1911 where Fritz Lang shot Metropolis and Marlene Dietrich crossed her lovely legs.''

title: Deal to Take I.B.M. Out of Disk-Drive Business
description: I.B.M. said in a release today that it was withdrawing from the disk-drive manufacturing business as part of a previously announced agreement to create a new company that over three years will become a subsidiary of Hitachi, the Japanese computer and electronics company.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Vernon: Deal Preserves 1,700 Acres Of Wilderness
description: New Jersey will pay $7.1 million to preserve 1,700 acres on Hamburg Mountain, an environmentally sensitive area in the state's northwestern corner that is home to the Mountain Creek ski area, state officials said yesterday. In return, the ski area's owners said they would no longer pursue plans to build a golf course. The deal was announced by Gov. James E. McGreevey and other officials in Vernon, where the mountain is part of the New Jersey Highlands. Under the agreement, the owner of the ski resort, Intrawest Corporation of Vancouver, British Columbia, will sell the state 467 acres for $7.1 million and donate another 1,262 acres, reserving the right to cut additional ski trails within Mountain Creek's existing system. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Fire Near the Shore Is Tamed After Destroying 1,300 Acres
description: Firefighters said today that they had contained the bulk of a windswept blaze that ravaged acres of pineland, devastated homes and frayed nerves along this wooded stretch near the Jersey Shore.

title: For Saturday, Buy the Chips And the Visine
description: We are heading toward sports overload. Screens are melting down. Remotes are imploding. Conspiring against us have been the Wee Hours World Cup; grand hoops operas composed by Mike Bibby and Jason Kidd; War Emblem's equine trash talk (''Proud Citizen -- eat my hooves!'') and the hematoma that swelled like a helium balloon on Hasim Rahman's noggin.

title: Windows on the World Workers Say Their Boss Didn't Do Enough
description: Immediately after Sept. 11, David Emil, whose company ran Windows on the World at the top of the World Trade Center, pledged to do his utmost to help the restaurant's workers and their families. Not only did he promise to help find work for the 350 Windows workers who survived but were left jobless, but he also helped set up a charity that has raised $18 million for the families of more than 100 food workers who died that day at Windows and other trade center restaurant operations.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sharman Added To Copyright Suit
description: The Recording Industry Association of America told a federal judge in Los Angeles yesterday that it intended to add Sharman Networks -- which administers the Kazaa online music file-sharing service -- to a continuing copyright infringement lawsuit. In the lawsuit, the record industry has already named Kazaa and Music City, asserting that the companies help people trade music free online. Industry officials said they intended to add Sharman to the case because the company, which is based in the Netherlands, recently bought assets from Kazaa and distributes software that people use to trade files.

title: Smaller Turnout for Tiananmen Memorial
description: HONG KONG, June 4  Maybe it was the recession, maybe it was the government's toughening stance toward critics and maybe it was just competition from the World Cup, but the annual candlelight vigil here to remember the protesters killed by the Chinese military in Beijing's Tiananmen Square drew a sparser crowd than usual tonight.

title: Retrial of Ex-Officer in Louima Case Begins
description: The third trial of Charles Schwarz, the former police officer accused in the Abner Louima torture case, began yesterday, as 671 people answered questions to screen them as potential jurors.

title: About the Results
description: These results are provided by The Associated Press and will be updated continuously after the polls close at 8 p.m. Tuesday in New Jersey.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: DDi Will Cut Work Force By 13%
description: The DDi Corporation, which makes printed circuit boards, said it would cut 13 percent of its work force and close or sell manufacturing plants in Dallas and Moorpark, Calif. The company, based in Anaheim, Calif., has about 2,000 employees, officials said. Bruce McMaster, DDi's chief executive, said the moves -- to be completed within 60 days -- would permit the company to ''lower our cost structure without compromising our ability to respond to market demand.'' Company officials said DDi would take a pretax restructuring charge of $15 million to $20 million during the second quarter, when sales are expected to be $60 million to $65 million. Shares of DDi closed unchanged at $2.75; the stock has fallen 86 percent in the last year.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Leadership Struggle Heats Up
description: Bitter supporters of the former Canadian finance minister, Paul Martin, who was fired on Sunday by Prime Minister Jean Chrtien, began mounting a campaign to replace the Canadian leader. Mr. Martin's dismissal, part of a struggle for the leadership of the Liberal Party, caused a sudden drop in the value of the Canadian dollar in the morning, but the currency rebounded by the afternoon. Mr. Martin has been widely regarded as one of the likely candidates to succeed Mr. Chrtien as prime minister. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: INGERSOLL-RAND BUYS ELECTRONIC TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company, maker of Schlage locks and Interflex security systems, bought the Electronic Technologies Corporation for an undisclosed price to expand its security business. Closely held ETC, based in Dover Plains, N.Y., has 33 offices in the United States and had sales of about $40 million in 2001. The company integrates security systems for businesses with multiple locations like national retailers, manufacturers and banks. Ingersoll-Rand's commercial- and residential-security businesses accounted for about $1.4 billion of its $9.68 billion in sales last year. Ingersoll-Rand is based in Bermuda and is run from Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: Hartford Budget Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Milky Way's Tidal Forces Ripping Apart Star Clusters
description: The disruptive tidal forces of the Milky Way have for the first time been caught in the act of ripping apart a dense cluster of stars and scattering them as so much stellar flotsam in a spectacular arc across the sky, astronomers reported here today.

title: Greed Is Bad
description: ''The point is, ladies and gentlemen, greed is good. Greed works, greed is right. . . . and greed, mark my words, will save not only Teldar Paper but the other malfunctioning corporation called the U.S.A.''

title: Questions From Justice Department Delay Plan to Add District to New York Senate
description: Civil rights lawyers at the United States Justice Department have raised questions about expanding the State Senate to 62 seats from 61, delaying federal approval of the Legislature's redistricting plan.

title: Housing for Downtown
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion Pats Its Own Well-Clad Back
description: There is a funny moment when the flashbulbs fade and the paparazzi lenses swing on toward the next famous face, when celebrities are left standing in the psychic residue of their own brief performance. It's an odd moment that no one knows quite what to do with. If you are Ralph Lauren or David Bowie or Iman or Christina Ricci or Tommy Hilfiger or Lauren Bush, and you are climbing the marble steps of the New York Public Library for the awards ceremony of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, you are absolutely necessary for about 90 seconds and then forgotten in the next 2.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERSON, IVAN D.
description: GERSON-Ivan D. ''A Unique Man'' You are gone from our lives but not our hearts. We love and miss you terribly. Rest peacefully in Heaven today on your birthday. Hugs, Mom, Dad and Adrienn

title: A Big Change in Style, And Staff, at Hugo Boss
description: As chief executive of Hugo Boss USA since 1998, Marty Staff probably had more fun than anybody else in the business of selling suits. Mr. Staff, 51, dyed his hair blonde and had a butterfly tattooed on his back; at parties he frequently wore cargo pants and worn T-shirts instead of the stylish unstructured coat and trousers for which his company is known.

title: Connecting Depression And Artistry
description: Everyone knows that creative geniuses are all mad. At least that is what the time-honored notion linking creativity and mental illness holds.

title: Investors Cast Doubt on Energy-Trading Businesses
description: The stocks of several large energy companies fell sharply yesterday as the industry was buffeted by fresh doubts about the continued viability of electricity trading as a major component of its business.

title: Four-Day National Holiday Celebrating Queen Comes to an End
description: LONDON, June 4  The party's over, but the British monarchy, it appeared today, is more than ever here to stay.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The New York chapter of the American Marketing Association elected a new board. The new officers are: president, James McDowell, vice president for marketing for BMW of North America, owned by BMW; president-elect, Eugene Dunkin, president at Godiva International; and first vice president, Lee Ann Daly, senior vice president for marketing at ESPN, part of the Walt Disney Company. Two board members were re-elected: Bruce Meyers, a marketing and advertising consultant, and Bruce Zanca, a communications and marketing consultant. There are four new directors: Edward Dandridge, managing partner at BrandSphere Partners; Wenda Harris Millard, chief sales officer at Yahoo; Gary Steele, executive vice president and managing director at the retail division of Bates USA, part of the Bates Worldwide division of the Cordiant Communications Group; and Victoria Vitarelli, senior director for brand building at MasterCard International.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENTWORTH, FRANCIS XAVIER, SR.
description: WENTWORTH-Francis Xavier, Sr., on June 3, 2002, of Ocean City, NJ, and Naples, FL. Beloved husband of fiftytwo years of Margaret ''Peggy'' (nee McKenna). Loving father of Kathleen Lavell of Convent Station, NJ, Kevin Wentworth of High Bridge, NJ, MaryAnn Wentworth of Boonton Township, NJ, Shaun Wentworth of Mt. Tabor, NJ, Finn Wentworth of Mendham, NJ, Pegeen Luther of Mt. Tabor, NJ, Rose Nakamura of Mendham, NJ, Geraldine Pierson of Parsippany, NJ, Tina Earle of Elprado, NM, and Lisa Wentworth of Litchfield, CT. Dear brother of Thomas ''Howard'' of Convent Station, NJ. Cherished grandfather of twenty-one. Relatives and friends are invited to attend his funeral mass on Friday, June 7, 2002, at 10:30 AM at St. Mary's Abbey at the Delbarton School in Morristown, NJ. Interment Holy Rood, Morristown, NJ. Visiting hours are on Thursday, 4-8 PM, at the Par-Troy Funeral Home, 973-887-3235. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his memory to The Deborah Hospital Foundation, PO Box 820, Brown Mills, NJ, 08015.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with an article about the election campaign for Alabama's Seventh Congressional District included outdated population information for the district, and a map showed outdated boundaries. The population is 635,300 (not 544,117). The district is 36 percent white (not 28.7); 62.4 percent black (not 70); and 0 percent Hispanic (not 1). A corrected map appears today, on Page A16.

title: Morgan Is Asked About Enron Loans
description: J. P. Morgan Chase is again confronting questions from a Democratic lawmaker about the nature of a complicated financing arrangement it set up for Enron.

title: Wyndham's Frequent Guests Get Some Vital Services Free
description: Now that hotels have largely abandoned all those annoying extra fees they used to tag onto bills, Wyndham International has upped the ante to attract business travelers. Effective yesterday, members of Wyndham's ByRequest guest loyalty program get free, unlimited domestic long-distance and local phone calls, free high-speed Internet access and free copy and fax service. No fine print, Wyndham says.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, ABE
description: RICHMAN - Abe. Beloved father of Iris and Moishe, adored Grandpa of Anna, dear brother of Selma and Doris, died on June 2, 2002. Shiva observed at 355 South End Ave. We will miss you.

title: Andersen Partner Says He Advised Against Shredding
description: An Arthur Andersen partner testified today that he advised the senior auditor on the Enron account against shredding documents during the same period that accountants at the firm were destroying large numbers of records related to the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, ROBERT B., D.V.M.
description: MORRIS-Robert B., D.V.M. On June 2, 2002. Beloved husband of Iris. Devoted father of Laurie, the late Mitchell, Alice, Barbara, Carol and Donald. Cherished grandfather of Jessica, Gordon, Pamela, Melissa, Martine, Suzanne, Evan, Shari, Benjamin, Kate, Ned and Marty. Loving brother of the late Alex and Gus. Services Tuesday, June 4, 10 A.M. at Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Rd., Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to the charity of your choice.

title: Novel Steps Train the Body To Tolerate Donor Tissue
description: Four years ago, Janet McCourt of Pembroke, Mass., was trying to stay alive long enough to see her first grandchild born. She had a form of blood cancer, multiple myeloma, and her kidneys had been destroyed by the cancer.

title: ABC Lagging In Shift Toward Strong Demand For Ad Time
description: An unexpected robustness in demand for broadcast television commercial time before the start of the 2002-2003 prime-time season means the long-awaited recovery in the advertising and media marketplaces may be under way.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Budget-Cutting Incumbent
description: Gov. Bill Owens, a Republican seeking re-election this year, has cut $228 million from the Legislature's budget proposal for the 2003 fiscal year. Governor Owens said the plan, which he called ''woefully irresponsible,'' represented a 7.3 percent increase in spending when state revenues have slid 13 percent. As part of his adjustments, he ordered every state agency to cut spending by 4 percent, an action that Rollie Heath, his Democratic opponent, criticized as falling hardest on children and low-income groups. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, LILLIAN
description: BLACK-Lillian. Formerly of Cedurhurst, NY, died May 31, 2002, in her home in Los Angeles, CA. She was the devoted wife of the late Philip Black, and daughter of Rose and Abraham Stein. She is survived by her son Michael, and her son Daniel, his wife Jan and their children Alex and Jonny, who always will lovingly remember their ''Mumsy.'' A highprofile travel agent, she co-founded Woodmere Travel and was most recently affiliated with Taylor Made Travel. Charity work included The Junior League of the Rainbow Auxiliary for the Home of the Incurable, which honored her as Woman of the Year. A graveside service will be held 1 PM, Wednesday, June 5, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles this week about celebrity marriages that were featured by the magazines InStyle and InStyle Weddings but dissolved before the issues reached newsstands misspelled the surname of InStyle's managing editor, who described her magazine's efforts to avoid covering shaky unions. She is Charla Lawhon, not Lawhorn.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about efforts by book companies to chronicle the sexual abuse scandal inside the Catholic Church misidentified the publisher that has rereleased ''Lead Us Not Into Temptation'' by Jason Berry, previously issued by Doubleday. It is the University of Illinois Press, not the Louisiana State University Press.

description: Carolina Slim -- born Elijah Staley 75 years ago on a farm near Denmark, S.C. -- remembers the air of disrepute that dogged bluesmen like him around the South.

title: Market Place; Now Will Come the Sorting Out Of the Chief Executive's Legacy
description: More than nearly any other chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski will probably find his reputation shaped after he leaves the company. For what happens now will determine which of two competing views of his long tenure at Tyco International prevails.

title: Push Up the Weights, and Roll Back the Years
description: Though petite, I have always been a strong person -- physically strong, with visible muscles. So why, I thought smugly, would I need to do strength-training exercises?

title: The Numbers Are Adding Up for Kittles
description: Kerry Kittles had one goal this season, one statistic he wanted to record: 82.

title: Airlines Fail in Third Attempt To Raise Their Leisure Fares
description: The attempts by airlines to raise advance-purchase fares, usually regarded as leisure fares, are starting to look like that scene from ''Monty Python and the Holy Grail'' where King Arthur yells ''Run away!'' to his knights to signal a retreat from attempts to storm a castle defended by Frenchmen hurling insults and livestock at the hapless attackers.

title: An Elite Black Family Haunted by a Secret History
description: THE EMPEROR

title: Misdirected Snooping Doesn't Stop Terror
description: When Attorney General John Ashcroft announced last week that he has freed F.B.I. agents from restrictions on counterterrorism investigations, he no doubt hoped to ease the concerns of Americans alarmed by F.B.I. blunders before Sept. 11. But the mistakes that kept the F.B.I. from picking up on hints of the violence to come arose from a failure of vision, not an absence of legal authority. The agency needs to focus on terrorist crime; it doesn't need to indulge in wasteful and undemocratic monitoring of legitimate political and religious activity.

title: Errors in Tracking Medical Errors
description: Studies that rely solely on reviews of hospital charts to measure how often doctors make mistakes risk being in error themselves, a study released yesterday said.

title: Veteran Trainers Offering a Triple Threat to a Triple Crown
description: Neil Drysdale sent Sunday Break short and easy yesterday, Allen Jerkens decided Puzzlement needed an unusually long workout, and Bobby Frankel announced that Medaglia d'Oro would get another rider for the third leg of the Triple Crown.

title: Channeling the Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: India-Pakistan Feud Has Not Stopped U.S. Search for Qaeda, Rumsfeld Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 4  Preparing for a trip in which he will meet officials in India and in Pakistan, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld expressed guarded optimism today that leaders of both countries want to avoid nuclear war.

title: White House Gets 24 Hours To Turn Over Enron Papers
description: White House officials were given 24 more hours today to turn over information about their contacts with Enron, as the administration and Democrats on the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee debated how thousands of pages of documents covered by subpoenas would be handled by investigators on the panel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENZVEIG, MAX
description: ROSENZVEIG-Max. Beloved husband of Pearl; father of Regina (Roger) Gradess and Bonni (Steven) Kraus; grandfather of Yashi, Olivia, Tzivya, Shoshana, Daniel and Aviva; oldest brother of Jack, Joseph and Ruth; brother-inlaw of Faith; uncle of Bobby, Helene, Holly and Laurie, passed away from colon cancer at the age of 88. Funeral June 4, 11:15 a.m. Hirsch and Sons, Bronx. He was a teacher at Stitt Junior High School, George Washington Night School and Brandeis High School, and a veteran of WW II and Korea. Lifelong resident of Manhattan, Max's charm, graciousness, and wit will be missed by his family and neighbors. Donations in his memory may be made to the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society (HIAS) or to the Jacob Perlow Hospice whose caring services allowed him to die peacefully at home.

title: India Tones Down War Talk as U.S. Presses Pakistanis
description: After a week of blunt American pressure on Pakistan, senior Indian officials seemed to pull back a bit from the brink of war today and said it would take more time to see whether Pakistan stopped the infiltration of Islamic militants into India.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Sentenced In World Series Threat
description: A federal judge has sentenced a Queens man to six months in prison for posting an Internet message the day after the attack on the World Trade Center in which, using an Arab name, he threatened to bomb the World Series and kill 60,000 people. The defendant, Kenneth Harrell, 31, was also fined $5,000. When he pleaded guilty in March, Mr. Harrell told Judge Victor Marrero that the threat was meant as a joke. In the Sept. 12 message on an ESPN message board, Mr. Harrell called himself Alik Aman and declared, in part, according to court documents: ''It is about time you Americans get what you deserve! The job isn't done.'' The F.B.I. traced the message to a computer in New York.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: NAPSTER FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY Napster, which operated a music file-sharing service that was once among the fastest-growing features on the Internet, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday. The filing, which people close to the company had said was imminent, comes on the heels of Napster's reaching a deal to sell its remaining assets to Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate. In its filings, Napster said it had $101 million in outstanding liabilities. Included in its liabilities is $91 million that the company owes to Bertelsmann, which lent Napster money to help it develop a for-pay music service. Napster officials said that filing for bankruptcy would permit the company to reorganize, resolve the legal claims against it  the record companies have sued Napster, accusing it of copyright infringement  and, by so doing, pave the way for a sale of its assets. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Egypt Lending 115 Objects From Antiquity to U.S. Show
description: The largest trove of antiquities Egypt has ever let leave the country will open at the National Gallery of Art in Washington on June 30.

title: Hollywood Accounting Cost Him $12 Million, Allen Hints
description: In his first day on the stand in his civil suit against his longtime friend and former producer, Woody Allen said yesterday that he had agreed to a less lucrative arrangement with her than he had had with his previous studio because they were such good friends.

title: Wyndham's Frequent Guests Get Some Vital Services Free
description: Now that hotels have largely abandoned all those annoying extra fees they used to tag onto bills, Wyndham International has upped the ante to attract business travelers. Effective yesterday, members of Wyndham's ByRequest guest loyalty program get free, unlimited domestic long-distance and local phone calls, free high-speed Internet access and free copy and fax service. No fine print, Wyndham says.

title: Thomas Qualifies for Buick Classic
description: Craig Thomas of the Lawrence Golf Club on Long Island sank a 40-foot birdie putt on the par-4, 368-yard No. 18 yesterday to finish with a five-under-par 66 in the Buick Classic open qualifying at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Setback on Insurance for Trade Center Developer
description: A federal judge in Manhattan yesterday rejected a request by Larry A. Silverstein, the real estate developer who controlled the World Trade Center, to rule immediately on his insurance claim that the destruction of the twin towers amounted to two events, requiring a $7 billion payment.

title: Confident Detroiters Take Aim At the Hockey-Come-Latelys
description: Residents here get a bit touchy sometimes when fans and reporters from other places tease the Motor City in the context of sports. But the locals are not above dishing it out, albeit with tongue in cheek.

title: With Early Goals, the Italians Have No Worries in Beating a Newcomer
description: Few World Cup lineups are as scrutinized as Italy's, but the Italians soothed their high-strung fans today by beating Ecuador, a first-time qualifier, 2-0.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Group Backs Insurance Changes
description: An independent panel recommended ways yesterday to cut consumer costs and increase customer payments by the state's heavily criticized auto insurance industry. Requiring insurers to pay their claims more promptly was one of the recommendations, as was getting insurers to fight insurance fraud more aggressively. Known as the Auto Working Group, the panel was created by Gov. James E. McGreevey in March and consists of what the Banking and Insurance Department describes as ''a group of 30 professionals.'' A rival group of businesses and organizations, the Coalition for Auto Insurance Competition, criticized the panel for not recommending that insurance be made more widely available to New Jersey residents.

title: KMART BRINGS FORMER VICE PRESIDENT OUT OF RETIREMENT
description: In the latest move intended to revitalize the Kmart Corporation's 1,900 stores, the company said yesterday that it had replaced a longtime executive in charge of merchandising with a Kmart veteran who had retired. The executive who is leaving, Cecil B. Kearse, got $2.5 million last December as an incentive to stay on as Kmart's finances worsened. His replacement is William D. Underwood, who joined the company in 1962 and retired in 1999 as a senior vice president. Mr. Underwood will oversee ordering and delivery.

title: In Los Angeles
description: A trip to Los Angeles is a bit like a visit to Disneyland. There is Adventureland (the Sunset Strip after dark), Frontierland (the gentrified Los Feliz district) and Critter Country (the hills above Los Angeles where wild deer and raccoons wander amid mansions).

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexican Cellphone Concern Expands
description: The Mexican mobile telecommunications operator Amrica Mvil S.A. agreed to more than double its stake in Telecom Americas Ltd., a leading cellular phone provider in Brazil. Amrica Mvil, Latin America's largest mobile phone service provider, will buy a 39 percent stake in the company from Bell Canada International for $146 million in cash and a $220 million interest-free note, Bell Canada said. Amrica Mvil will also exercise an option to buy SBC Communications Inc.'s 11 percent interest in Telecom Americas, increasing its stake to 93 percent from 42 percent.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Stopping Teenage Smoking
description: The state's legal smoking age would rise to 21 from 18, making it the oldest in the nation, under an amendment to an anti-smoking bill introduced in the Legislature. Assemblyman Paul Koretz, a Democrat from West Hollywood who introduced the amendment, called it ''the next step in reducing teen smoking.'' The American Lung Association estimates about 90 percent of all smokers start before the age of 21. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Cost Cutting Gives Giants Some Room
description: After months of being squeezed by the salary cap, the Giants can breathe just a little. They have a little cash to play with if they decide to pursue a safety or an offensive lineman. The Giants will have created about $2.2 million in salary-cap room by the time they complete a couple of cost-cutting moves, although about a third of the extra money will most likely be reserved for roster moves this summer.

title: Vehicle Sales Fell in May Even as Big Rebates Continued
description: Weak sales in May at General Motors helped drag car sales to their lowest monthly pace in nearly four years.

title: Tyco Chief Out As Tax Inquiry Picks Up Speed
description: L. Dennis Kozlowski resigned as chairman and chief executive of Tyco International Ltd. yesterday as prosecutors in Manhattan sped ahead with a criminal investigation into whether he had evaded sales taxes on the purchase of millions of dollars' worth of art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLIEDMAN, ANTHONY
description: GLIEDMAN - Anthony. A very special, talented and rare gentleman; a wonderful housing innovator who carved a niche in the mosaic of the City of New York. Those who were fortunate to know him and call him friend, will miss him deeply. Former President AMREP Corporation; former Housing Commissioner NYC; former Executive VP Trump Enterprises. Love to Ginny, and his sons, Greg and Chris. Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York Jerome Belson, President Michael Kerr and Arnold Sollar, Vice Chairmen Nicholas LaPorte, Exec Dir

title: Koizumi Aide Hints at Change to No-Nuclear Policy
description: A senior official has said Japan might someday possess nuclear weapons, creating a furor here and enraging the country's neighbors.

title: A Radical Overhaul for South African Mining
description: After more than a year of painstaking revision and top-level deliberation, the government here is about to alter the balance of power in the country's mining industry.

title: USA Interactive Bids for 3 Web Affiliates
description: USA Interactive, the constantly transforming company run by Barry Diller, offered to buy all the publicly traded shares yesterday of three Internet companies it already controls -- Expedia, Hotels.com and Ticketmaster.

title: Ballet Theater: Signs of Promise Amid Struggle
description: American Ballet Theater's opening night at the Metropolitan Opera House last month was the quintessence of glitter and grace. The black-tie audience shouted bravos throughout the performance, the critical notices that followed were glowing, and the mood at the dinner afterward was festive and upbeat.

title: A High-Wire Test, Pass or Fail; New Council Leader Is on the Spot as Deficit Looms
description: Growing up, Gifford Miller never gave much thought to what he would do with his life, despite an early interest in politics that surfaced, his mother tells him, around the third grade. But during college, as Mr. Miller and his girlfriend bicycled one day near a beach on Martha's Vineyard, a truck driver clipped his girlfriend's handlebars and she was crushed to death beneath the back wheels.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: MADAGASCAR: 2 KILLED IN NEW FIGHTING Two people were killed in fighting in a northern town, Sambava, between forces of the rival claimants to the presidency of this Indian Ocean island, state radio said. Marc Ravalomanana, a tycoon sworn in as president by his supporters on May 6, controls the capital, Antananarivo, and one province in the southeast. But four other provinces remain in the hands of Didier Ratsiraka, the former president, who refuses to accept that Mr. Ravalomanana won the Dec. 16 election.    (Reuters)

title: Rail Projects Are Sign of a Quiet Revolution in Short-Haul Trips
description: DELTA AIR LINES, for one, is plenty worried about business travelers who are so fed up with airport problems that they're switching to the train on East Coast routes. In an attempt to portray the train as an inferior option to flying, Delta's ads do everything but imply that train passengers have to watch out for Jesse James and his gang shooting up the lounge car.

title: Accountability for Accountants
description: Enron, Tyco, Adelphia, Global Crossing: These days, business news can resemble a financial police blotter. The erosion of credibility of many corporations continues, as the Enron affair has unleashed a rash of allegations of dubious accounting practices, and of market insiders corrupted by conflicts of interest. These revelations of trouble at individual companies will continue to rattle the entire stock market so long as Congress and regulators refuse to shore up safeguards against corporate chicanery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEWITT, MARGARET E.
description: HEWITT-Margaret E. On behalf of the Officers and Staff of Solow Building Company, we deeply mourn the passing of Margaret E. Hewitt, who served as our Executive Vice President for more than 22 years. Her integrity, loyalty, dedication and leadership was truly unsurpassed. Our heartfelt condolences to her husband Peter and their family. We mourn her loss and will miss her dearly. Solow Building Company

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTAT, BONNIE
description: EISENSTAT - Bonnie. The Trustees, Dean, Faculty, students, and staff of New York Law School express our sorrow for the great loss to our community of Bonnie Eisenstat, beloved and esteemed first-year student. We offer our deepest condolences and sympathies to her husband, Mark, and daughters Stephanie and Nicole, and to all her family and many friends. Arthur N. Abbey, Chairman, Board of Trustees Richard A. Matasar, Dean and President

title: Can Pakistan Avoid Sliding Into War?
description: Over the weekend, the likelihood of a war between India and Pakistan receded slightly. Secretary of State Colin Powell has confirmed that orders have been relayed to Pakistani forces manning border posts to stop infiltration by militants across the Line of Control dividing Kashmir, as President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan promised on May 27. As a result, Indian leaders are now willing to give American diplomacy more time to turn General Musharraf's pledge into a permanent commitment.

title: Merrill Weighs a Giuliani Role
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has hired a pollster to find out whether former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani can help burnish its image.

title: China Loses Its World Cup Inaugural to Costa Rica
description: KWANGJU, South Korea, May 4  China celebrated its first game in the World Cup today but the world's most populous nation will have to wait to celebrate its first goal, its first victory or its first tie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAVORS, SOL
description: JAVORS-Sol, of Long Beach, N.Y., peacefully at his home on June 3, 2002. He was the devoted husband of Geraldine, loving father of Russell and Suzanne Javors, Lynne and Robert Bernhard, and Amy and Bruce Pruzansky. Cherished grandfather of Jesse, Julia and Molly. Services Wednesday, 10 AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Good Shepherd Hospice, 528 Mineola Ave., Carle Place, NY 11514.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Landmarks Agency To Meet
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission will hold a regularly scheduled meeting. Ninth floor, Municipal Building, 1 Centre Street, Manhattan, 9 a.m. Information: (212) 487-6800.

title: Cost of Vigilance: This Broken Home
description: Christine Shahab, a Long Island wife and mother with a toddler and a job and a three-bedroom house, spends a lot of time these days in county jails in New Jersey.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: G.M. Buys Stake In Automaker
description: General Motors said it would buy a $30 million stake in a Chinese minivan and minitruck maker, moving into the largest sector of China's auto market. General Motors said it would take a 34 percent stake in SAIC-Wuling Automotive, based in the southern province of Guangxi. The original Chinese owners, the Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation and Wuling Automotive, will retain a controlling 66 percent share. Minivans and minitrucks accounted for almost a third of all vehicles sold in China last year, making them the largest segment of the mainland market.

title: A Fledgling Choreographer Takes Chances In Her Stride
description: Melissa Barak looked like a Romantic-era ballerina, with her perfect oval face and dark eyes, as she sat backstage at the New York State Theater the other day and talked about her young but productive life in dance. There was also a hint of an innocent-seeming but naughty child in her blithe recounting of that somewhat unruly life. But Ms. Barak is one of the most talked-about younger choreographers in New York ballet, and tonight, at a mere 22 years of age, she will take a big step into major prominence with the premiere of her ''If by Chance,'' commissioned by the New York City Ballet for its 10th-anniversary Diamond Project festival of new choreography.

title: NBC Scores With Game 7
description: Game 7 of the Lakers-Kings Western Conference finals on Sunday generated a 16.9 overnight Nielsen rating, up 66 percent from a 10.2 for the comparable game a year ago, Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Warning Of A Deficit
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee said the state would probably incur a $56 million deficit without action by the General Assembly before June 30, the end of the fiscal year. Mr. Huckabee set a meeting last night with legislative leaders to discuss options for closing the budget gap. Since last fall, Mr. Huckabee, a Republican, has ordered two rounds of cuts totaling $171 million from the state's $3.5 billion budget, blaming an economic slowdown, which he said had been aggravated by the Sept. 11 attacks. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Lew Wasserman, 89, Is Dead; Last of Hollywood's Moguls
description: Lew R. Wasserman, the former chairman and chief executive of the Music Corporation of America, who was arguably the most powerful and influential Hollywood titan in the four decades after World War II, died yesterday in Beverly Hills. He was 89.

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: West
description: ALASKA: CANDIDATE FOR GOVERNOR As expected, Senator Frank H. Murkowski, a Republican, has formally filed to run for governor. Mr. Murkowski, left, a 22-year Senate veteran with two years remaining in his fourth term, said Alaska's troubled economy prompted his run. Citing a net outflow of people from the state, Mr. Murkowski said, "This tragic loss of the best and brightest of our youth has me deeply troubled." The state usually favors Republicans, and Mr. Murkowski is favored by many analysts to win. But he could face a competitive race in November, probably against Lt. Gov. Fran Ulmer, a Democrat who has also filed to run. Term limits bar Gov. Tony Knowles, a Democrat, from seeking a third term. Timothy Egan (NYT)

title: Time to Beware of Brazilians Who Accept Gifts, and Cards
description: For 86 minutes tonight, Rustu Recber played sturdily in goal for Turkey, repelling a Brazilian attack that had regained its flair and insistence. But Rustu proved better with his hands than his feet. And with one stunning lapse, the chance of a well-earned tie for the Turks became an unraveling 2-1 defeat.

title: Choreographer Sees Change of Heart on Frankfurt Ballet
description: The American choreographer William Forsythe said today that Frankfurt city officials have told him they want his acclaimed dance company, the Frankfurt Ballet, to continue working in the city after his current contract ends in 2004. But he added that a deal was not assured, as the city's finances are in dire straits.

description: GATES-James Benedict. 64, on June 3, 2002. It is with deepest sadness that we announce the passing of James Benedict Gates. He leaves his sister Patricia Gates and his nephew Joseph Gates of Massachusetts. He also leaves devoted, close friends, Ben Wichman, Ursula Meyer, Jeannie Michaels and Laurie Winfrey. A Memorial Mass for James will be announced later this month in The New York Times.

title: Ex-Chairman At Sotheby's Is Considering Sale of Stake
description: A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's who was sentenced in April to a year and a day in prison for his role in a price-fixing scheme with his counterpart at the archrival Christie's, said yesterday that he was working with Sotheby's officials to explore a possible sale or merger of the auction house or the sale of his stake.

title: Letter Writer With Grudge Burned Coroner, Police Say
description: He signs his ranting letters ''Steel in the hand of the King of Kings.'' He hears messengers of God speaking to him on radio talk shows. He is convinced that a man on death row for killing a police officer would have been exonerated but for the testimony of a lying medical examiner.

description: Today is Primary Day in New Jersey. Polls open at 6 a.m. and close at 8 p.m. Questions may be addressed by calling the New Jersey Division of Elections, at (609) 292-3760. Page B6.

title: When the Dead Keep Coming Back to Life
description: You have to admire a venturesome spirit like Kenny Finkle, the young author of ''Transatlantica.'' The play at the Flea Theater in TriBeCa is a lunatic fable that considers love and death and fate in a series of ever more preposterous iterations. Meant to be Dadaist or surreal, it's the kind of show that consciously walks the line between purposeful wit and meaningless idiocy, that wants to make you laugh at its zany nonsense and reflect upon it philosophically as well.

title: Rifts Plentiful As 9/11 Inquiry Begins Today
description: Early on Sept. 11, Senator Bob Graham and Representative Porter J. Goss were having a quiet breakfast meeting in the Capitol with the chief of Pakistani intelligence, Lt. Gen. Mehmood Ahmed. Mr. Graham and Mr. Goss, the chairmen of the two Congressional intelligence committees, were quizzing their guest about Osama bin Laden and other issues when an aide to Mr. Goss rushed in with a note.

title: Too Much, Too Soon, Too Little, Too Late
description: Steve Trachsel dropped a big curveball and Vinny Castilla reached for it from the right side of the plate, slicing the ball down the right-field line. Trachsel turned and watched it clang off the bottom of the foul pole. The Braves estimated the first-inning grand slam traveled 334 feet, and Trachsel stared at the pole in disbelief. Mike Piazza remained on his knees looking in the same direction as Castilla rounded the bases.

For further information contact Bailey Funeral Home, Inc., 973-543-4720.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Peregrine Names New Chief Executive
description: The software maker Peregrine Systems said yesterday that Gary G. Greenfield would become its chief executive, replacing Richard T. Nelson, who had filled the position on an interim basis for about one month. On May 6, the company dropped 65 percent of its market value as its stock fell below $1 a share and two executives resigned: Steve Gardner, chairman of the board and chief executive, and Matt Gless, chief financial officer and also a director. The company had announced that its audit committee would investigate whether it had failed to adjust revenue from software deals made through partners, consultants and retailers when such products were returned; it would restate results, company officials had said, to correct inaccurate accounting of as much as $100 million in revenue.

description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about nicotine-laced water misstated the relationship between the Johnson & Johnson Company and the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, a contributor to the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, which has joined a petition for the product to be regulated as a drug. The foundation was created by Mr. Johnson, a former chief executive, not by the company itself.

title: The Role of Anytown Is Played by Boston
description: Thomas Menino, the mayor of Boston, plays himself on a new six-part documentary series from ABC News, ''Boston 24/7,'' which begins tonight. Gruff, blunt and shrewd, this big bear of a man is very appealing as he lumbers through the business of running a large city. He comes off as a cross between Tony Soprano and ''West Wing's'' Josiah Bartlet.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster Files For Bankruptcy
description: Napster, which operated a music file-sharing service that was once among the fastest-growing features on the Internet, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday. The filing, which people close to the company had said was imminent, comes on the heels of Napster's reaching a deal to sell its remaining assets to Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate. In its filings, Napster said it had $101 million in outstanding liabilities. Included in its liabilities is $91 million that the company owes to Bertelsmann, which lent Napster money to help it develop a for-pay music service. Napster officials said that filing for bankruptcy would permit the company to reorganize, resolve the legal claims against it -- the record companies have sued Napster, accusing it of copyright infringement -- and, by so doing, pave the way for a sale of its assets. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: At Elders' Home, Each Day Is Valentine's Day
description: Not long ago while doing morning rounds at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, the Bronx, Edna Adams, a nurse's aide, knocked on a resident's door. As was her habit, when she didn't hear an answer, she pushed it open, and found two of her patients -- each over 80 and with Alzheimer's disease -- nude and making noisy, passionate love.

title: Dusted for Life's Fingerprints, Rocks Fail
description: Just when life began on Earth tells, in part, how easy or difficult it is for life to arise.

description: HERSHEY-Tinnie. Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the death of our cherished member Tinnie Hershey. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Rabbi Michael A. White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Toni Wiener, President

title: Technicians Complete Work on Space Shuttle
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 4  Technicians wrapped up work today associated with an engine valve replacement job, clearing the way for the planned launch on Wednesday of the space shuttle Endeavour on a mission to the International Space Station.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in a picture grouping on Sunday recalling notable criminal cases, with an article about the F.B.I.'s efforts to transform itself to fight terrorism, misstated the crime for which Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were executed in 1953. It was conspiracy to commit espionage, not the passing of secrets to the Soviets. Another caption referred incompletely to the bureau's role in the case of Al Capone. While the bureau investigated him, Capone's conviction for tax evasion was based largely on the work of Treasury agents.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: 2 Charged In 3 Killings
description: A tip to the police has led to the arrest of two Newark men in the killings of two men from Irvington and a Clark man, officials said yesterday. Henry Bullock, 34, was arrested Friday and Antwan Mitchell, 28, was arrested Saturday, after investigators were told that someone threw a cellular phone from a Ford Taurus that had been described in reports about the crimes, the Union County prosecutor's office said. Investigators traced numbers called on the phone to the suspects, officials said. Christopher Demetrius Cooper, 32, of Clark, was killed during a botched robbery attempt on March 26 after he called out for help. The two other victims, Larry Harris, 27, and Amir Merryweather, 28, were found bound and shot to death in their Irvington apartment last Tuesday. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHONEY, MOST REVEREND JAMES P., D.D.
description: MAHONEY-Most Reverend James P., D.D., retired Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of NY, died June 1, 2002, at Calvary Hospital. He was born in Kingston, NY, on August 16, 1925, to James A. and Ella (Daly) Mahoney. He graduated from Blessed Sacrament Parochial School and following graduation from Cathedral Preparatory School in 1947, he entered St. Joseph's Seminary, Yonkers, to begin his theological studies. He was ordained by Francis Cardinal Spellman on May 19, 1951, at the Cathedral of St. Patrick. His first assignment was at St. Mary's Church, Katonah, where he also taught at St. Mary's High School. He served as a Chaplain in the US Army from 1954-58 and remained a Captain in the Army Reserve for eight years after active duty. From 1958 to 1964 he taught English at Cardinal Hayes High School, Bronx, and parttime at Mt. St. Ursula's Academy and St. Catherine's Academy. In 1964 he was named Procurator at St. Joseph's Seminary in Dunwoodie and was elevated to the rank of Papal Chamberlain by Pope Paul VI. In 1968 he was appointed Vice Chancellor of the Archdiocese and Chairman of the Priests' Personnel Board. In 1971 Terence Cardinal Cooke named him Vicar General of the Archdiocese. On September 15, 1972, Pope Paul VI elevated him to the office of bishop as Auxiliary Bishop to Terence Cardinal Cooke and he took the motto ''To be rich in faith'' (James 2:5). In September, 1974, Bishop Mahoney was named Pastor of St. John the Evangelist Church, Manhattan. He also served as chaplain to the NYPD Anchor Club. In 1978 he was appointed pastor of St. John the Evangelist Church in Mahopac and Vicar of Northern Westchester and Putnam. After 12 years in Mahopac he then served as pastor of Holy Trinity Church, Poughkeepsie, and Vicar of Dutchess County. He then resided at St. Mary's Church, Wappingers Falls, St. Peter's Church, Poughkeepsie, and Assumption Church, Peekskill. Following retirement he resided at the residence for retired priests at Stepinac High School, White Plains. Bishop Mahoney will repose at St. John the Evangelist Church, Mahopac, today (Tuesday) from 1-7:30 PM, when a Mass of the Eucharist will be celebrated. Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated by Edward Cardinal Egan at 10 AM, Wednesday, at the Cathedral of St. Patrick. Interment will follow at Assumption Cemetery, Peekskill, NY.

title: China Makes World Cup Debut
description: KWANGJU, South Korea -- The Chinese fans put on their game faces as the train pulled into the station. They wore bright red wigs (fluffy ones for the men, reasonably stylish ones for the women) and designer wraparound shades. They were already wearing white and red T-shirts that proclaimed them a part of the entourage for the first Chinese World Cup game, ever.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Steel Tariff Case Advances
description: The World Trade Organization has agreed to the European Union's request to set up a panel of experts in the trans-Atlantic dispute over United States steel tariffs. The Bush administration had blocked the union's initial request, as it is allowed to do under trade rules, but the second request automatically leads to the establishment of a panel. The United States also denied requests by Japan and South Korea for a similar panel. Unless an agreement is reached, those requests will be automatically granted later this month. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Albin Krebs, 73, Obituary Writer
description: Albin Krebs, a reporter for The New York Times who specialized in writing obituaries of prominent artists, performers and politicians, died on Friday at his home in Key West, Fla. He was 73.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEATMAN, FRANCES L.
description: BEATMAN - Frances L. Board of Trustees and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services acknowledge with great sadness the death of Frances L. Beatman, a nationally respected professional social worker, family therapist and family theorist. Beginning as a young social worker in 1938, she became a key force in the development of services to alleviate family conflict. Throughout her career as executive director of Jewish Family Service (a JBFCS predecessor agency) from 1958-1977 and later as a JBFCS trustee, Frances was a creative and visionary leader. She was instrumental in expanding JFS' reach into the community through such innovations as a fee-for-service model, new family treatment approaches, a quick response unit and mental health consultation. Frances valued public support of demonstration projects aimed at preventing more serious problems. She was extremely devoted to her husband Joseph, a JFS board member for whom our Riverdale out patient mental health clinic is named. After the merger with Jewish Board of Guardians, Frances remained involved with JBFCS as an active Vice - President and member of many board committees. She believed the merger stimulated the creation of more services to troubled families and children. Frances understood the critical role JBFCS was obligated to play in helping those most in need. She was a bold thinker and receptive to new ideas but always challenged assumptions not based in sound clinical thinking. Frances will remain an inspiration to all of us. Our condolences to her nieces, nephews and friends. Jean L. Troubh, President Joseph S. Kaplan, Chairman of the Board Seymour R. Askin, Jr., Hon. Chairman of the Board Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Executive Vice Pres. & CEO

title: Conductor's Wagnerian Farewell to Cleveland
description: In orchestra land, the parade of farewells has disbanded for the summer. But it has been a busy spring, with subscription audiences in Boston, New York and now Cleveland, one after the other, standing at the docks and waving their music directors goodbye.

title: Le Pen Accused of Torturing Prisoners During Algerian War
description: Less than a week before a French parliamentary election that is regarded as a critical gauge of right-wing sentiment, a major newspaper today published what it said were new allegations by four witnesses that the far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen tortured people he accused of hiding weapons during the Algerian war of independence.

title: South Asia's Hair Trigger
description: Tensions between India and Pakistan eased slightly yesterday but remain dangerously high. This latest crisis demonstrates the urgency of getting Indian and Pakistani nuclear weapons and the policies governing their use under much firmer control than they now are.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: A Concern For Special Education
description: Nearly two-thirds of special education teachers in the state said they plan to stop teaching handicapped students in the next five years, according to a survey by the state branch of the National Education Association, the teacher's union. The teachers complained of massive paperwork requirements, staff meetings and uncompensated overtime; a third said they had been assaulted by students. Three of four teachers planning to leave special education said they would reconsider if the job entailed less paperwork. Diana Jean Schemo (NYT)

title: Prosecutors Weave a Web Of Inferences
description: In closing arguments, state prosecutors tied together a bundle of circumstantial evidence today, depicting Michael C. Skakel as a disturbed teenager who bludgeoned Martha Moxley to death in a jealous rage. They also accused him and his family of a 27-year effort to thwart investigators that included destroying evidence and fabricating an alibi.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Jury Continues Meeting On Dupont
description: The jury hearing a pollution lawsuit against the DuPont Company reported yesterday that it was deadlocked on many issues and had agreed on some. At the start of its eighth day of deliberations, the 14-member jury asked the presiding judge, Frank M. Donato, if it could return a partial verdict on issues it had resolved. The judge agreed, but after he asked whether more deliberation might end the impasse, the jury said it would continue meeting. Four women who grew up in Pompton Lakes have sued the company, saying they were sickened by pollution at an old DuPont explosives plant in the town. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Bryant, Once a Teammate and Protg of Scott's, Is Now a Respectful Rival
description: Byron Scott was on the last legs of his playing career, opting to come back for one more season in 1996-97, when the Lakers swung a deal on draft day to bring Kobe Bryant to Los Angeles. Rather than resent Bryant, an 18-year-old who was taking away minutes from his final run, Scott chose to help.

title: ITT BUYS WATERLINK'S WASTEWATER TREATMENT BUSINESS
description: ITT Industries, the largest maker of industrial pumps, bought the Pure Water businesses of Waterlink Inc. yesterday, expanding ITT's line of wastewater-handling products. ITT would not disclose terms, said Tom Glover, a company spokesman. Pure Water had sales of $16 million last year, employs 85 people and builds systems that purify water and desalinate seawater. Pure Water's businesses, based in Clearwater and West Palm Beach, Fla., and in Woodlands, Tex. will become part of ITT's Sanitaire unit. ITT is based in White Plains. Waterlink is based in Columbus, Ohio.

title: S.E.C. BEGINS FORMAL INVESTIGATION INTO ALPHARMA
description: Alpharma Inc. said the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun a formal investigation of the company's methods for recognizing revenue. The company's stock declined 13 percent, falling $2.75 to $17.90 a share. The investigation, reported in a Form 8-K filed with the commission, relates to revenue recognition practices in connection with a restatement of earnings the company reported last November. The company, which is based in Fort Lee, N.J., manufactures generic drugs and animal health products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUMAN, ALDEN
description: SHUMAN-Alden. On June 3rd, 2002 at age 77. Devoted brother to Earl and sister-inlaw Peggy. Beloved uncle to Cathy, Daniel and Steve. Adored cousin to the Kaplan Family of Washington, DC and California. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, June 6th, 4 PM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center, 16th St. at 1st Ave., NY NY 10003.

title: To Be Safe, Tyson's Not Talking
description: The marketing slogan for Saturday's heavyweight championship fight is ''Lewis-Tyson Is On!'' One day into the local promotion of the bout and Mike Tyson's only scheduled news conference is off.

title: Begonias and Beyond: A Voice For the Tropical Forests
description: The soft-spoken woman shaking off a monumental case of jet lag at a Manhattan apartment one recent morning was Dr. Ruth Kiew, 56, the keeper of the herbarium and library of the Singapore Botanic Gardens, and one of the world's great experts on tropical begonias.

title: Corrections
description: Acaption in a picture grouping on Sunday recalling notable criminal cases, with an article about the F.B.I.'s efforts to transform itself to fight terrorism, misstated the crime for which Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were executed in 1953. It was conspiracy to commit espionage, not the passing of secrets to the Soviets. Another caption referred incompletely to the bureau's role in the case of Al Capone. While the bureau investigated him, Capone's conviction for tax evasion was based largely on the work of Treasury agents.

title: Choreography All Ready For the Scrimmage Line
description: Elizabeth Streb is at it again.

title: California Lottery Picks 4 Finalists in Review
description: Four finalists have been selected in a contentious review for the account of the California Lottery, with billings estimated at $125 million for a five-year contract.

title: G.I.'s Scour Old Qaeda Base, but Find Little
description: More than 100 American soldiers finished a daylong sweep through a former Al Qaeda training base in eastern Afghanistan today, a mission intended to discourage Al Qaeda and Taliban forces from crossing into the country from Pakistan, American military officials said.

title: Voters Picking Candidate To Run Against Torricelli
description: The primary race of no big names and few big issues ends Tuesday, when Republican voters go to the polls to choose their candidate to face United States Senator Robert G. Torricelli in the fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVENS, BERNARD
description: EVENS-Bernard. Age 86, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, died peacefully on Saturday, June 1, 2002; beloved husband of Violet (Sommer), father of the late Charles Evens, Nancy Evens of Chico, CA, and Earl Evens of Wexford, PA; grandfather of five. Bernard, a former resident of Roslyn, NY, was a founding Partner of the accounting firm of Margolin, Winer, and Evens, LLP, retired Captain in the U.S. Army 11th Armored Division, a member of Old Westbury Golf and Country Club and Eastpointe Country Club. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Candidate Says He Has The Delegates
description: William E. Curry Jr., a Democratic candidate for governor, said yesterday that he had gathered enough delegates at the city and town level to win the party's nomination at next month's convention. Mr. Curry, 50, left, of Farmington, a former state comptroller and aide to President Bill Clinton, said he had commitments from more than 800 delegates, 22 more than are required for a majority at the convention. The announcement placed added pressure from party officials on another candidate, George C. Jepsen, the State Senate majority leader, to withdraw and avoid a September primary fight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEROW, DR. JOSHUA REYNOLDS
description: DEROW-Dr. Joshua Reynolds. Born November 3, 1911, New York City, died June 1, 2002, Hastingson-Hudson, in his home. Survived by his wife Dr. Elisabeth F. Derow-Turnauer, his daughter Deborah Bruenell (Craig), grandsons Brad and Saul Bruenell, brother Bernard S. Derow, and nieces, a nephew and many cousins. Graduated from Boston University Medical College 1937, Colonel U.S. Army Retired, Brooklyn V.A. Department of Radiology 1956-1972. Memorial serice to be announced.

title: Waterford Journal; Haul Up Your Anchor, Mate, and Stay Awhile
description: Here where the Hudson River meets the Erie Canal, the big pleasure boats were lined up for days last month, waiting for the canal to open for the season. But the boaters didn't seem to mind.

title: Social Security Issue Is Rattling Races for Congress
description: No other issue is generating more scrambling in this year's Congressional elections than Social Security and what Democrats assert is the looming threat of privatization. Consider the House race in this slice of northern Indiana, where the Republican candidate, Chris Chocola, issued a solemn warning recently to the local Rotarians meeting at Honkers Restaurant.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Settles S.E.C. Charges
description: The Microsoft Corporation filed false financial reports stemming from its improper use of as much as $900 million in reserves set aside from revenue from 1995 to 1998, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday. Microsoft, the world's largest software maker, settled the reporting, disclosure and bookkeeping charges by agreeing to be subject to stiffer penalties if it commits similar violations in the future, the S.E.C. said in a statement. Microsoft, which was not fined, neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing. The Microsoft charges followed an increase in S.E.C. scrutiny of financial reporting after Enron's bankruptcy in December.

title: A Study of Endometriosis Brings Surprising Results
description: Women who engage in sexual activity or use tampons while menstruating seem to lower their chances of developing the painful condition known as endometriosis.

title: Cocaine and Its Sneaky Heat
description: Cocaine overdose deaths have often been linked to the drug's ability to raise the body temperature through a jolt to the metabolism. But a study released yesterday reports that it is more complicated than that.

title: Sports of The Times; Zen Master On the Beauty Of Being Him
description: GREETINGS, fans, from sunny Los Angeles, still the center of the basketball universe now that I, Phil Jackson, have spared David Stern a finals in a cow pasture and a chorus of critics chanting: ''Moooooooo.''

title: Tracks From a Primordial Sea Are Found in Canada
description: Scientists investigating an abandoned quarry in Canada have found what appear to be the oldest known footprints of terrestrial creatures -- footlong critters resembling modern bugs that crawled from the sea onto land and left tracks in sandy dunes.

title: On a Reinvented Death Row, The Prisoners Can Only Wait
description: There are six of them in cells that are always locked along a gray corridor. Separated by cement block walls, they wait for their appeals. Or for a lethal injection.

title: On the Queen's Jubilee, Rocking at the Palace
description: With 12,000 cheering guests and an estimated million more following on giant screens set up in parks around London, a Buckingham Palace concert marking Elizabeth II's 50 years as queen took on the feeling of a love-in tonight as a who's who of British pop/rock's own royalty sang homage to her.

description: Restraint in India

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Airgate Shares Drop
description: Shares of AirGate PCS Inc., which sells wireless service in smaller United States markets under the Sprint PCS brand, fell nearly 11 percent yesterday on concern that fiscal third-quarter growth may lag forecasts, analysts said. The stock declined $1.10, to $9.06. The shares have fallen 80 percent in the last 12 months. AirGate's third-quarter forecast was higher than those of other affiliates, like Alamosa Holdings Inc., said Mark Giese, a fund manager at the Nicholas Company in Milwaukee, owner of AirGate shares. The company has the least cash on hand of the publicly traded Sprint PCS partners ''so if anyone thinks there's weakness, they tend to hit AirGate the worst,'' Mr. Giese said. AirGate's controller, Michael Picchi, did not return two telephone calls seeking comment.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Citrus Law Is Widened
description: A Broward County judge has ruled that his decision in May that the state's new citrus canker eradication law is unconstitutional applies throughout the state. The law, passed earlier this year, allows agricultural agents to cut down all healthy citrus trees within 1,900 feet of any infected with canker. The law also said the agents could enter the yard of any home and cut down trees under a single countywide search warrant. Judge Leonard Fleet of Circuit Court ruled on Monday after lawyers for the State Department of Agriculture asked for an emergency hearing to clarify his May ruling. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: Ex-Tyco Chief Is Indicted In Tax Case
description: L. Dennis Kozlowski, former chairman and chief executive of Tyco International, was indicted yesterday by a grand jury in Manhattan on charges of evading more than $1 million of sales taxes on six paintings that he bought last fall.

title: Forrester to Represent G.O.P. in Race to Unseat Torricelli
description: Douglas R. Forrester, a former divinity school student who went on to become a multimillionaire businessman, defeated two other Republicans today in a low-key primary for the United States Senate seat held by Robert G. Torricelli.

title: A Gift to Train African Women
description: OPRAH WINFREY has given $2.5 million to New York University's Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service to endow a program to bring African women to the school for graduate work in public policy and management. Ms. Winfrey made the announcement last month at a Wagner School dinner honoring Nelson Mandela. The women will take part in Wagner's seven-month master's program in management of international public service organizations, or in its two-year Master of Public Administration program. Karen W. Arenson

title: A New Welfare Policy for New York
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg took a courageous stand when he announced that he was moving away from a welfare policy fixated on reducing the number of people on welfare toward one that would encourage education and training and provide vital support like child care. The new policy will do more to help New York City's welfare recipients find real, lasting jobs. It also reflects a growing awareness that the Giuliani administration's so-called ''work-first'' policies were less effective than they might have been, and in some instances harmful.

title: Jihad and Veritas
description: Tomorrow Harvard's many communities will come together for the university's 351st commencement exercises. Yet it will be a campus divided, with the division made sharper when a university committee announced that my classmate and friend, Zayed Yasin, would deliver a commencement speech entitled, ''Of Faith and Citizenship: My American Jihad.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Flextronics Lowers Outlook
description: Flextronics International, a leading maker of electronics for brand-name companies, cut its profit forecast for the first six months of its fiscal year, setting off a sharp decline in its share price. In a conference call after the close of trading on Monday, it said it would lay off an unspecified number of workers in the current period, part of a reorganization that would cost $150 million. Michael Marks, the chief executive of Flextronics International, said profit in the first quarter, which ends June 30, was expected to be 5 cents to 8 cents a share, down from an earlier forecast of 10 cents to 13 cents. Shares in the company, which is based in Singapore but operates from San Jose, Calif., fell $2.43, or almost 20 percent, to $9.89, on Nasdaq.

title: She Has a Knife And She Knows How to Use It
description: BY history and tradition, sushi-making has always been a man's world. Men, naturally, have come up with all sorts of good reasons for keeping it that way.

title: The Man Who Put the Spring Back in Spidey's Web
description: SURE you know Spider-Man as the teenage superhero out of Queens with the ability to dive and swoop among New York City skyscrapers on a hand-thrown web and more angst than Albert Camus. Teenage angst, of course.

title: Hong Kong Passions About Tiananmen Seem to Be Fading
description: Maybe it was the recession, maybe it was the government's toughening stance toward critics or maybe it was just competition from the World Cup, but the annual candlelight vigil here to remember the protesters killed by the Chinese military in Tiananmen Square in Beijing drew a sparser crowd than usual tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, E. STEPHEN.
description: FOSTER-E. Stephen. November 22, 1963-June 3, 2002. A Southern gentleman and a dedicated Brooklynite, Stephen was an ebullient human being with extraordinary political knowledge, an unmatchable sense of humor, and true joy in life. Stephen was Director of Government Affairs at Brooklyn Public Library for many years and, earlier, Borough President Howard Golden's representative to the Library Board. He loved the Library and we loved working with him. We will sorely miss him. From his colleagues and friends at BPL

title: House Republican Plan Would Increase Medicare Payments to Providers
description: Under intense pressure from health care lobbyists, House Republicans say they have decided to increase Medicare payments to doctors, hospitals and health maintenance organizations, reducing the amount of money available to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly.
