description: TWO KEY MATCHUPS

title: Rare Iguanas in Galapagos Are Victims of Oil Spill
description: It was thought to be a fortunate near miss when the grounded tanker Jessica disgorged 150,000 gallons of diesel and bunker fuel amid the biological riches of the Galapagos Islands in January 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHKOPF, TILLEE
description: ROTHKOPF-Tillee. Beloved wife of the late Mac. Loving mother of Bert and Carol, and Gene and Rita. Cherished grandmother of Mitchell, Gary and Robin, Lisa, Marc and Marna, Richard, Lori, and Charlie. Great-grandmother of Lindsay, Cori, Kasey, Ashley, Lenny, Max, Stephanie, Josh, Mac, and Charlie. Services ''BoulevardRiverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 10 AM Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREISKEL, BARBARA SCOTT
description: PREISKEL-Barbara Scott. Died June 4, 2002. Beloved wife of Robert. Mother of Richard and John, grandmother of Malakai. Private funeral services. Memorial service will be announced.

title: A Market That Is Organic, to a Point
description: Christina Cassano believes in organic food but refuses to let great flavor take a back seat to her commitment. So her homey, countrified new store, Pumpkins Organic Market, 1302 Eighth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, is what she calls 90 percent organic. ''I don't want any of that funky organic food,'' Ms. Cassano said. ''All my produce is organic, but I also sell other high-quality products like Ronnybrook Farms milk.'' She specializes in foods made by small companies, like berry jams and dessert sauces from Kris & Pete's in Eaglebridge, N.Y. In season, the produce is from local farms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORTHINGTON, ELMER HARRY
description: WORTHINGTON - Elmer Harry, 91, of Southbury, CT, died on June 3, 2002. Mr. Worthington began his banking career at New Milford CT Savings Bank in 1928 leaving as Treasurer in 1942 to attend Harvard Business School Advanced Management Program. Upon graduation he became Treasurer of Belknap Manufacturing Company in Bridgeport, CT. In 1945 he joined Public National Bank in New York City as Assistant Vice President until moving to Bank of Commerce as Vice President in 1956. He retired in 1976 and then served as branch manager and training officer for Savings Bank of Danbury until 1980. He leaves wife Mildred; son Bob and wife Anita, Las Cruces, NM; daughters June Mendell, Mattapoisetti, MA, and Diane Worthington and husband Jerry West, Portland, ME; six grandchildren, six greatgrandchildren; brother Raymond and wife Audrey, Rockville, MD. A memorial service will be held in the Roxbury, CT Congregational Church, Sat. June 8, at 2P.M.

title: F.A.A. Faulted On Installation Of New System
description: A new air traffic system that is intended to power the radar screens of most of the nation's controllers has serious flaws and is not ready for use, according to the inspector general of the Transportation Department and the union that would maintain it.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Apple Introduces Media Player
description: Apple Computer made available the first public version of its software media player, QuickTime 6, yesterday. The new software competes directly with Real Player from Real Networks and Windows Media Player from Microsoft. All three companies are using their technologies to push personal computing into the entertainment and interactive media businesses. Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, said yesterday that QuickTime 6 was distinguished by its support for a new international standard for view multimedia called MPEG-4, which offers a variety of enhancements for viewing video and listening to audio via the Internet. Both Real Networks and Apple have endorsed the MPEG-4 standard while Microsoft has chosen to support a proprietary technology named Corona. Apple also said yesterday that it would make its new Emac computer more widely available. When the computer was originally introduced this year, Mr. Jobs aimed the machine at the educational market. He said the computer, which is priced at $1,099, was being sold more broadly because his customers ''had beaten him up'' for not making it available to all potential buyers. John Markoff (NYT)

title: Things to Know About the Yankee Clubhouse
description: For baseball players, it is their sanctuary, the place that is like their living rooms before a game. For baseball reporters, it is part of our work place, a place where we watch, wait and wonder about our next stories. For baseball fans, it is the place you will rarely ever see in person. It is the Yankees' clubhouse, and I think there are some things you should know about its inhabitants.

title: Mom and Dad, You Were Perfect . . . Nightmares
description: In his autobiographical play ''Joe and Betty,'' the playwright Murray Mednick puts us in an awful place, looking in on the living room of a slum apartment where the title characters are perpetually bellowing at each other with malicious stupidity. The staccato insults are as pelting as hailstones, the mutual ill will painful to witness even for strangers to the family like us. So you can imagine the anguish of Emile, the 11-year-old boy (and stand-in for the author) who is never seen onstage but whose bedroom would be in the audience.

title: Americans Stun Favored Portugal
description: SUWON, South Korea, June 5  All around the field, and on the bench, the Americans had disbelief on their faces. Could it really be this easy? Could Portugal, the world's fifth-ranked soccer team, be this comically inept in goal? The answer, stunningly, was yes. Splendid at putting the ball in the net, the Portuguese were laughably insufficient at keeping it out.

title: Scott Returns to City Of His Winning Ways
description: Byron Scott was the star of the team, a high school All-American who wowed teammates, opponents and fans with his tremendous dunking ability. But few at Morningside High School envisioned him as a future coach, mainly because he hated to speak in public.

title: Big Field Reduces Shot For a Triple
description: War Emblem has already outrun his modest record as a 2-year-old as well as the challenges of 29 other horses in the Kentucky Derby and Preakness, all while having bone chips in two ankles and a knee. What other obstacle can the racing gods toss out on the oval of Belmont Park to prevent the speedy, black colt from sweeping the Triple Crown?

title: President Distances Himself From Global Warming Report
description: Under intense criticism from conservatives, President Bush distanced himself today from a report by his administration concluding that humans were to blame for far-reaching effects of global warming on the environment.

title: Not Much News, but Anecdotes From Torre
description: There wasn't much to talk about in Joe Torre's pregame chat with reporters on Monday. There were updates on some minor injuries -- everyone was O.K. -- and a couple of questions about players doing well lately. Not much more, except a few entertaining anecdotes that often enliven Torre's sessions.

title: Cuban Wizardry Keeps Tail Fins From Drooping
description: There is one thing about present-day Cuba that unfailingly leaves visiting Americans awestruck: the sight of streets filled with 1950's Chevrolets, Buicks, Fords, Chryslers and Cadillacs, some as well-maintained as those in the hands of vintage car collectors in the United States. The fleet, estimated at about 60,000, is believed to be the largest collection of classic American cars outside the United States, and is as much a part of the Cuban landscape as palm trees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDO, TESSIE
description: BENDO-Tessie. June 4, 2002. Beloved wife of Alexander Bendo. Devoted mother of Catherine and her husband Dickerson Wright, Areta Bendo, John Bendo, MD and his wife Lea. Cherished grandmother of Lauren, Stephanie, Christina, Alexis, Alexander and Andrew. Loving sister of Agnes and Peter. She was a lady admired for her strength and courage and will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Wednesday, June 5th, 5-9pm. Service Thursday June 6th 10am at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral 319 East 74 St., NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUND, LEONARD
description: FREUND-Leonard. Loving, caring and sharing husband of Shelley, father of Jay and Bud, grandfather of Jesse P., Daniel, Hannah Rachel and Charlotte Grace, and fatherin-law of Dana Sherman and Cathy Bernstein. We love you and will miss you, Poppa. You helped all of us build a beautiful world.

title: F.T.C. Is Urged to Take a Hard Line on Snuff
description: Antismoking advocates in Congress opened an offensive against snuff makers yesterday, urging the Federal Trade Commission to derail the industry's attempts to promote chewing tobacco as a safer alternative to cigarettes and contending that its largest company, UST Inc., unfairly focuses on children with its advertising.

title: Letters
description: 'Appalling' Drinking

title: Congress's Inquiry Into 9/11 Will Look Back as Far as '86
description: The House and Senate intelligence committees announced today that they would investigate the government's overall response to international terrorism dating back to 1986, adopting an extremely broad charter for the review of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Sutton Must Now Overcome His Age and Putting Woes
description: Hal Sutton was on the practice green at Westchester Country Club this afternoon, sifting through a golf bag filled with new putters.

title: A Fusion Spirit at This Year's Spoleto
description: The woman on my left took a catnap after intermission. The man on my right actually startled himself awake with a snore. It was a steamy afternoon, and stuffy in the Dock Street Theater, a snug, historic auditorium with the feel of a legislative chamber and one of several idiosyncratic sites used by the annual Spoleto Festival USA here. In addition, the performance was right after lunch, so perhaps there was some excuse for my neighbors' snooziness.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swissair Faces Claims
description: The former national airline of Switzerland, the Swissair Group, which collapsed in October, is facing claims of $25 billion, according to its bankruptcy administrator. The amount includes claims against the company's subsidiaries, among them SAirLines and Flightlease. SAirGroup, the airline's holding company, plans to contest more than 60 percent of the claims, which include amounts its former French and Belgian carriers are seeking. Swissair has assets of $1 billion. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Pacific: Samoa: New Zealand Regrets Abuses
description: Western Samoa received a formal apology from its former semicolonial ruler New Zealand for a decade of deaths and ill treatment. The New Zealand prime minister, Helen Clark, made the apology in the capital, Apia, on the nation's 40th anniversary of independence. She said the apology was for negligence in an influenza epidemic in 1918 that killed 8,000 islanders and police suppression in 1929 of an independence movement and later banishment of island chiefs. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEGER, BARBARA
description: KRIEGER-Barbara. Died on Tuesday, June 4, 2002. Original settler and well respected 54 year resident of Elmont, retired secretary to Principals at Dutch Broadway Elementary School, PTA past Presidents, member of Five Towns Forum Executive Board, considerate and caring friend and neighbor, beloved wife of the late Louis Krieger, loving mother of Lenore and David, cherished grandmother of Sari, Daniel, and Alexander. A memorial service will be held at Gutterman's 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre on Thursday, June 6, 2002 at 3PM.

title: Injuries Becoming Classified
description: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman surprised reporters Sunday by telling them the team would no longer disclose any medical information about players. If a player left a game with an injury, fans would not be able to find out what the injury was unless that player volunteered it himself.

title: Martin Esslin, Drama Theorist, Dies at 83
description: Martin Esslin, a drama critic, teacher and author of ''The Theater of the Absurd,'' a seminal book that identified and codified experimental playwrights with a tragicomic view of what he called ''a world that has gone mad,'' died on Feb. 24 in London. He was 83.

title: Shift-Alt-Ctrl: A Duo Throbbing to a Binary Beat
description: Four musical acts came to Fun, a nightclub in Chinatown, on Thursday: Vladislav Delay, AGF, Luomo and AGF/DLAY. It was a diverse night of electronic experimentation, even though the acts boast a combined membership of two.

title: Snatched From the Jaws of Extinction
description: THE GHOST WITH TREMBLING WINGS

title: 'Hamptons' on ABC Has Modest Ratings
description: The two-part documentary ''The Hamptons'' on ABC proved to be only marginally appealing to the national television audience Sunday and Monday nights, attracting more than seven million viewers each night. The series fared better Monday night when it did not have to face off against the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: Bismarck and Bush
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fervent Pitcher for Columbia Goes Back to Teaching
description: As an A student at Jamaica High School in Queens in 1960, Jonathan R. Cole was admitted to both Columbia University and Princeton. He chose Columbia, where his mother had studied with Lionel Trilling, Jacques Barzun and other big-name intellectuals. Dr. Cole fell under Columbia's spell and never left.

title: Son of South Korea's President Indicted
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 5  Kim Hong Gul, the youngest of President Kim Dae Jung's three sons, was indicted today on charges of having accepted approximately $3 million in payoffs, using his influence for companies in search of lucrative government contracts and evading taxes.

title: Sales are up for networks but maybe not for all media.
description: IN the wake of the broadcast television networks' surprisingly strong performance selling commercial time for the coming season, the rest of the media are fervently hoping that the rebound will augur improved results for them, too.

title: Hollywood Has a Setback in Controls for Digital TV
description: Hollywood studios seeking to impose electronic controls on digital television broadcasts suffered a setback yesterday as a coalition of technology and consumer electronics companies supporting their efforts crumbled in a cross-industry power struggle.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: IRELAND: AER LINGUS DISPUTE ENDS A government arbitration court brokered a compromise to end a labor action by pilots at Aer Lingus, Ireland's state-owned airline, that had grounded planes for five days. The carrier resumed flying its regular routes to Europe, with trans-Atlantic flights to follow today and tomorrow A standoff developed after a one-day strike by pilots to protest reductions in their minimum rest period between flights. Aer Lingus responded by shutting entirely, insisting that the change was an essential to a survival plan to save it from bankruptcy. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Facing Veto Threat, Senate Debates Counterterror Funds
description: The Senate today took up a $31.4 billion emergency counterterrorism measure that Republican critics called too expensive and replete with spending that had little or nothing to do with responding to the Sept. 11 attacks. The White House threatened a veto.

title: PANEL RECOMMENDS DISMISSING PRIESTS IN NEW ABUSE CASES
description: After five months of unrelenting revelations about sexual abuse by clergy members, a committee of Roman Catholic bishops today proposed a mandatory set of procedures that would obligate American bishops to remove from the priesthood anyone who abuses a minor in the future.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Surprise Winner For Fashion Award
description: Rick Owens, the Los Angeles fashion designer who won the Perry Ellis Award for newcomers from the Council of Fashion Designers of America on Monday night, professed surprise at receiving the award, which is often referred to as a fashion Oscar. More than a decade older than his competitors, who are all in their 20's, Mr. Owens, above, said, ''I'm not really a young designer.'' Among the other top winners were Carlos Falchi, accessory designer of the year; Narciso Rodriguez, women's wear designer of the year; and Marc Jacobs, men's wear designer of the year. Guy Trebay (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, LEW R.
description: WASSERMAN-Lew R. birthright israel mourns the death of our philanthropic partner, Lew Wasserman. A distinguished humanitarian and civil rights activist, his generous support helped make birthright israel a reality for thousands of young adults. Our condolences to his wife Edie, his daughter Lynne Kay and his grandchildren Carol Leif and Casey Wasserman. Charles R. Bronfman, Michael H. Steinhardt Founding Chairmen, birthright israel

title: New Head for Newark Institute
description: New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark has named ROBERT A. ALTENKIRCH, the vice president for research at Mississippi State University, as its next president. He succeeds SAUL K. FENSTER, who will retire after 24 years as president of the institute. A mechanical engineer, Dr. Altenkirch earned a Ph.D. from Purdue University and a master's degree from the University of California. From 1997 to 2000, while he was vice president for research at Mississippi State, science and engineering spending at the university increased 57 percent. Karen W. Arenson

title: French Far Right Makes Headway in Battle for Left's Onetime Northern Stronghold
description: Meandering through the open-air marketplace here that sells everything from corsets to plucked pigeons, Marine Le Pen was looking for a crowd to work.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: ZIMBABWE: LEADING LAWYER ARRESTED The police arrested Sternford Moyo, the president of the Zimbabwe Law Society, and accused him of calling on people "to rebel" against the government of President Robert Mugabe, the state news agency reported. Mr. Moyo, a longtime critic of the government, was accused of calling for protests after the March presidential election, which opposition officials and Western governments believe was rigged. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Curse of the Jaded Audience: Woody Allen, in Art and Life
description: A grand total of eight people showed up yesterday for the matinee of Woody Allen's latest movie, ''Hollywood Ending,'' one month out of the box and now playing in exactly one theater in Manhattan, a $4.95-a-ticket discount house in Times Square.

title: Mark Militello
description: EVERYONE has a favorite barbecue sauce. Mine is a little different. I use mangoes, Scotch bonnet peppers and tamarind to give the sauce spiciness and a strongly sweet-and-sour accent. But it has what you want from a barbecue sauce: richness, spiciness and sweetness coming together. My sauce has a smokiness, too, which I like -- even when you don't use it for grilling, you get some of the wood-fired flavor into your food.

title: Speaker Watches Backyard In Battles on Tax Incentives
description: One of the things holding up approval of the city's $400 million tax package in Albany is a $3 million disagreement, according to state and city officials. The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, has said that a tax incentive zone for business investment should encompass everything below Houston Street.

title: Manhattan School Recruiting
description: Manhattan's Community School District 2 is recruiting students for a new high school below 14th Street. The school, Millennium High School, is among 23 financed with a $30 million grant from the Carnegie Corporation, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and George Soros's Open Society Institute.

title: India Rejects Putin's Effort on Kashmir
description: India decisively rejected a Russian diplomatic effort this evening to defuse a nuclear-armed standoff with Pakistan, saying that it would neither negotiate nor rein in a powerful military buildup until Pakistan halts a flow of armed guerrillas into Kashmir.

title: HALLIBURTON AND HONEYWELL WIN ASBESTOS CLAIMS DELAY
description: The Halliburton Company and Honeywell Inc. won a 30-day extension of a stay on more than 250,000 asbestos-related claims against former units. Judge Judith Fitzgerald of United States District Court in Pittsburgh extended the stay she ordered in February to give the companies more time to negotiate a settlement of the claims. The asbestos claims involve the Harbison-Walker Refractories Company, formerly owned by the Dresser unit of Halliburton, and the North American Refractories Company, a former Honeywell subsidiary. The units, now owned by RHI A.G. of Austria, sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors in January. Halliburton, Honeywell and lawyers for the asbestos creditors agreed to the extension.

title: Ideas for a School Master Plan
description: With visions of a Marshall Plan for New York City schools dancing in his head, JERROLD ROSS, dean of the school of education at St. John's University, recently asked Deputy Mayor DENNIS M. WALCOTT to meet with a group of education school deans. They met last Friday at City Hall, and a number of possible ideas emerged. One is that the education schools focus on selected grades (perhaps four and eight) or selected school districts, and study the effectiveness of various projects. They also discussed options for preparing and certifying new teachers, besides the Teaching Fellows program.

title: The Towers' Footprints
description: To the Editor:

title: The Musical 'Sweet Smell of Success' Is to Close
description: ''Sweet Smell of Success,'' one of the most expensive and eagerly anticipated musicals of the season, is to close on June 15 with a loss of some $10 million. The cast was informed about the closing before Monday's performance at the Martin Beck Theater.

title: RIGAS FAMILY MEMBERS RESIGN FROM ADELPHIA SPINOFF
description: James P. Rigas resigned as president, chief executive and vice chairman of Adelphia Business Solutions Inc. yesterday, and three other members of the Rigas family resigned from the company and its board. The Rigas family made the decision so that Adelphia Business Solutions could pursue its Chapter 11 reorganization without the distraction of the family's involvement with the Adelphia Communications Corporation, the company said in a statement. Adelphia Business Solutions was spun off from Adelphia Communications in January and filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in March. The other family members who resigned were John J. Rigas, the chairman; Michael J. Rigas, vice chairman and secretary; and Timothy J. Rigas, vice chairman, chief financial officer and treasurer.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: EAST ORANGE: SUSPECT SOUGHT IN SHOOTING OF OFFICER

title: Hurricanes Speed Past the Red Wings in Overtime
description: Dominik Hasek's workday began with red lights flashing behind him and it ended the same way. The first burst of color came when the Detroit police pulled him over and ticketed him for speeding outside Joe Louis Arena when he was on the way to practice. The last flash came within the first minute of overtime, when Ron Francis of the Carolina Hurricanes ignited the goal light by scoring from short range to give the underdogs a 3-2 victory in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals.

title: A Family Affair Keeps It Light, Wry and Swinging
description: Watching John Pizzarelli play jazz guitar duets with his father, Bucky, suggests a variation of an old saw: the family that plays together stays together. Both Pizzarellis are technical whizzes whose musicianship is infused with a sly sense of humor and a fondness for games of hide-and-seek. In a typically engaging gambit, they soften their dual strumming until it's nearly inaudible, then suddenly burst back with a flurry of enthusiasm. Both are proud minimalists whose quiet, carefully sculptured arrangements eschew dissonance, feedback and plugged-in fireworks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENAUER, MARK
description: GENAUER-Mark. Age 56. Of Montclair, N.J. On June 3, 2002. Beloved husband of Jeanine. Devoted father of Lynsey and Mackenze. Dear brother of Brenda Mendle. Loving uncle of Gilian and Felene Abramowitz, and Jodi and Karen Genauer. Graveside service to be held Wednesday, 2:30PM at the Mount Hebron Cemetery, Upper Montclair, N.J. A memorial service to follow at 4PM at Temple Sholom of West Essex, 760 Pompton Ave, Cedar Grove, N.J. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Mackenze and Lynsey Genauer Educational Fund, c/o Joyce Foley, 9 The Fairway, Upper Montclair, N.J. 07043. For further information, please call Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1 - 800 938-6372.

title: Graduate Faculty Dean Is Named at New School University
description: Bob Kerrey, the president of New School University, said this week that he had named Richard J. Bernstein, a philosophy professor, as the new dean of the Graduate Faculty. He will replace Kenneth Prewitt, the former director of the Census Bureau who joined New School University in March 2001. Dr. Prewitt announced in March of this year that he was resigning because of disagreements with Mr. Kerrey over the direction and financing of the Graduate Faculty, the university's graduate school of social science.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENTWORTH, FRANCIS XAVIER, SR.
description: WENTWORTH-Francis Xavier, Sr., on June 3, 2002, of Ocean City, NJ, and Naples, FL. Beloved husband of fiftytwo years of Margaret ''Peggy'' (nee McKenna). Loving father of Kathleen Lavell of Convent Station, NJ, Kevin Wentworth of High Bridge, NJ, MaryAnn Wentworth of Boonton Township, NJ, Shaun Wentworth of Mt. Tabor, NJ, Finn Wentworth of Mendham, NJ, Pegeen Luther of Mt. Tabor, NJ, Rose Nakamura of Mendham, NJ, Geraldine Pierson of Parsippany, NJ, Tina Earle of Elprado, NM, and Liza Wentworth of Litchfield, CT. Dear brother of Thomas ''Howard'' of Convent Station, NJ. Cherished grandfather of twenty-one. Relatives and friends are invited to attend his funeral mass on Friday, June 7, 2002, at 10:30 AM at St. Mary's Abbey at the Delbarton School in Morristown, NJ. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Morristown, NJ. Visiting hours are on Thursday, 4-8 PM, at the Par-Troy Funeral Home, 973887-3235. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his memory to The Deborah Hospital Foundation, PO Box 820, Brown Mills, NJ, 08015.

title: Bill Is Proposed In Cable Dispute
description: A bill was proposed yesterday in the New York State Legislature that seeks to resolve the impasse between YES and Cablevision over the broadcast of Yankees games. But the bill is not expected to be taken up before the legislative session ends in two weeks.

title: INSIDE
description: Ex-Head of Tyco Is Indicted

title: Study Calls L.I. Most Segregated Suburb
description: This village and Garden City have been municipal neighbors for decades, one stop away from each other on the Long Island Rail Road, a four-minute ride. But despite their shared boundary, they are worlds apart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYLE, MARY AGNES (NEE MAHON)
description: BOYLE-Mary Agnes (nee Mahon) on June 3, 2002 of Dunwoody Village, Newtown Square, PA, formerly of Brooklyn and Floral Park, NY. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Francis Boyle. Loving mother of Kathleen M. (Connell) Cannon of Haverford, PA., Elizabeth A. (R. James) Sutton of Willimantic, CT and John D. (Barbara H.) Boyle of Floral Park, NY. Sister of Daniel Mahon of Lynbrook, NY. Grandmother of Amanda Clarke of New York, NY., Maura & Caroline Cannon of Haverford, PA. and David & Peter Sutton of Willimantic, CT. Funeral Mass Saturday, June 8, 10:30 AM Our Mother of Good Counsel Church, Pennswood Rd., Bryn Mawr, PA. Relatives and friends may call at the Church after 9:30 AM. Interment Monday June 10, 11:00 AM, Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the American Diabetes Assoc., 1 Plymouth Meeting Suite 250, Plymouth Meeting, PA 19462 - 1316. McConaghy Funeral Home, Ardmore, PA.

title: Following the Red Trail of Sam's Army
description: They started slowly, did Sam's Army. There were hundreds of them, or so it seemed, to thousands of the Portuguese fans. At least, that's how it looked and sounded.

title: European Court Tightens Use of State-Owned Shares
description: The European Union's highest court dealt a heavy blow today to ''golden shares,'' an archetypal tactic used by governments to shield favored companies from foreign takeovers, but did not entirely rule out their use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANLEY, THOMAS ALOYSIUS, SR.
description: HANLEY-Thomas Aloysius, Sr. Suddenly on June 4, 2002 in Port Washington, NY. Beloved husband of Maureen. Devoted father of Dorothy McGovern (Lawrence), Maureen Reedy (John), Ellen Whiteman (Brian), Thomas, Jr. and John (Jennifer). Loving grandfather of fifteen wonderful grandchildren. Dear brother of Eileen Byrne, Catherine Brethel, Elizabeth Crowley and Ellen Koneck (deceased). His life was one of endless generosity, kindness and love. Donations in lieu of flowers to Regis High School, 55 E. 84th Street, New York, NY 10028. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel,1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Thursday& Friday 3-5 & 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass Saturday 10am St. Peter of Alcantara R.C. Church, Port Washington. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: Beware of Hitchhikers  la Polanski, O.K.?
description: Just in time for the vacation motoring season comes another little thriller that illustrates the perils of picking up hitchhikers.

title: A Killer, Yes, but She's a Good Old Girl
description: Aileen Wuornos was big news 10 years ago. At age 35 she was convicted of the murders of six male motorists in Florida, and people were soon referring to her as America's first female serial killer. Some also called her the Highway Hooker, because she worked along Interstate 75.

title: South Korea Delights A Raucous Sea of Red
description: After five futile appearances in soccer's global championship, South Korea earned its first victory in the World Cup finals tonight, and a whole country seemed to burst in ecstatic release.

title: Sports of The Times; Thanks, Mike Tyson, For Using Mouthpieces
description: HERE in the cotton and soybean fields near the Mississippi River, Fitzgeralds Casino resembled a toy castle. In its great hall with the heat on and the air-conditioning off, Mike Tyson perspired briefly. He punched the small red bag in short bursts, ducked under a swinging taped bottle and departed without a word for the assembled notebooks and microphones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, SAM. CPA.
description: BECKER-Sam. CPA. The Partners and Staff of Livingston Wachtell & Co., LLP express our heartfelt sorrow at the loss of our dear friend. For over 25 years at the Firm, Sam counseled his clients in a scholarly, as well as, more importantly, a caring manner. His kindness and soft spoken demeanor was an inspiration to us all. Our sympathy is extended to his wife Betty, his children and his grandchildren of whom he spoke often and loved dearly. Sam, you will truly be missed. the Partners and Staff of Livingston Wachtell & Co.

title: Our Towns; Strange Days Of Glory And Loathing
description: LET us now praise sweaty men.

title: The Eyes and Ears of the Hospital
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Europe Mission Chief Departs
description: The mission chief for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, Andrew Carpenter, left Belarus after being denied a visa extension. He is the third O.S.C.E. representative to be refused a visa by Belarus this year. The West has accused President Aleksandr Lukashenko of persecuting the opposition and crushing the free press. The O.S.C.E. has said Mr. Lukashenko's re-election in 2001 was fraudulent. Meanwhile, witnesses in Grodno, in western Belarus, said the police beat supporters of two journalists charged with libeling Mr. Lukashenko. A senior police official denied the reports. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Abortion Access For Inmates
description: Prison inmates in Cuyahoga County will have better access to abortion services as part of a settlement of a lawsuit by the American Civil Liberties Union. The A.C.L.U. sued the county after a woman said after six months in prison that her pregnancy was too advanced to have an abortion when she was released. The county has formally adopted a policy that requires prisoners to have timely access to prenatal care or abortion services in a timely manner. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LANDS' END INC., Dodgeville, Wis., said it received a license to make an exclusive line of clothing bearing the logos of the Major League Baseball clubs through 2004. Terms were not disclosed.

title: In South Africa, He Let the Goats Out
description: THE wine is called Goats do Roam. No, not Ctes-du-Rhne, and before you laugh, be aware that it's one of South Africa's best-known and hottest-selling wines. Particularly overseas.

title: Warily Circling the Sept. 11 Fund
description: The idea behind the Victims Compensation Fund approved by Congress after last September's terror attacks seemed simple enough. It was to provide reliable and expeditious compensation to victims' families so as to spare them the uncertainties of drawn-out litigation and save the airlines from potential bankruptcy. But the fund has been dogged by controversy from the start, requiring forbearance from the victims and flexibility from the special master appointed by the Bush administration, Kenneth Feinberg, to run the fund.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: No 'Shoplifter' Badge
description: A state appeals court has ruled that a woman convicted four times of theft need not wear a four-inch red badge that says ''convicted shoplifter'' in stores. Judge Bradford Charles added that requirement to the year's probation to which he sentenced Regina Zimmerman for stealing $66 worth of cosmetics. The appeals court ruled that ''wearing a badge is not reasonably related to Zimmerman's rehabilitation.'' Ms. Zimmerman said others have been doing her shopping. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: At Ground Zero, a New Divide; Some of 9/11's Neediest Get the Least Government Aid
description: When the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation convened its first public hearing last month about efforts to rebuild the shattered core of the city, what quickly emerged was a growing schism between two groups that live and work within a mile of each other.

title: India-Pakistan Tensions Prompt New Appeal and New Warning
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  President Bush appealed to the leaders of India and Pakistan today to use words rather than guns to resolve their differences. But with feelings still high, the State Department strongly urged Americans in those two nuclear-armed countries to leave and said Americans planning to travel to the region should postpone their trips.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: London Murder Suspect Sought Here
description: New York Police Department investigators and federal marshals are seeking a 27-year-old man from England for questioning in the murder of a man whose body parts were found on Friday in Hampshire, England, the police said. Investigators believe that the suspect, Richard Markham, arrived in New York on Friday aboard a plane from London. He had cleared a United States Customs checkpoint and was spotted on Saturday in Central Park, the police said. The murder victim, Tristian Lovelock, 25, an unemployed carpenter, had been with Mr. Markham on Thursday, according to reports in British newspapers, and was a friend of the suspect, the police said. The police urged anyone with information to call (800) 577-8477. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Islamabad Remains a Capital of Calm
description: It was an ordinary Tuesday on the streets of this sleepy city today, maybe a little hotter than usual. The main activity seemed to be sitting at plastic outdoor tables eating plates of curry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, ROBERT
description: MORRIS - Robert. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Franklin S. Abrams,President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: From Unknown to the Most Known
description: Doug Forrester and his money made it look easy.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption yesterday about Nets fans who waited in line at Continental Arena to buy tickets to the National Basketball Association finals misstated the day they were photographed. It was Monday, not Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSNER, CLARK J.
description: COSNER-Clark J. Age 48, of Crystal River, FL, died June 1, 2002. He is survived by his parents Joseph and Dorothy Cosner, and two sisters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASKEY, NORMAN F., M.D.
description: LASKEY-Norman F., M.D. It is with profound sorrow that The Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the passing of our distinguished friend and colleague. Dr. Laskey came to Mount Sinai in 1925 as a resident in the Department of Surgery, and devoted the next 60 years to clinical teaching and the excellent and compassionate care of his patients. Greatly admired as both clinician and teacher, he will be remembered most fondly for his commitment to his patients and to the institution, as well as for his kind and gentle nature. He will be missed. Our sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. Jeffrey S. Freed, M.D., Pres. William G. Stein, M.D., V.P. Maria L. Padilla, M.D., Secy. George Raptis, M.D., Treas.

title: Japan Comes to Play, but So Does a Stubborn Belgium
description: In the farmlands north of Tokyo, where a world-class stadium had been built for soccer's global tournament, more than 55,000 Japanese fans screamed in hopes of a world-class team to match.

title: Prelates' Proposal Draws Praise and Skepticism
description: Prominent advocates for people who have been abused by priests said yesterday that the bishops' draft plan for responding to the crisis of clerical misconduct included some positive approaches. But several also scorned the plan's failure to include sanctions for bishops who have transferred priests from parish to parish, and their criticisms suggested that the plan would not calm protests by victims' groups, which have been growing.

title: Records Detail Repeated Reinstating of Accused Priests
description: A lawyer suing the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston released hundreds of its documents today, providing yet further detail on how the church repeatedly responded to sexual abuse accusations against priests by allowing them to continue in the ministry.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Privatization Is Delayed
description: The Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation has delayed a plan to begin privatizing the Cho Hung Bank, which it took over in the economic crisis of 1997-98. Korea Deposit, an arm of the ministry of finance and economy, said an increase of 8 percent in the value of the South Korean won against the dollar would make it difficult to carry out a program for marketing global depository receipts overseas covering 15 percent of the value of the bank. Kim Jong Tae, who is in charge of the program for privatizing several banks acquired by the corporation, said it would offer Cho Hung Bank depository receipts ''whenever the market looks favorable.'' Korea Deposit owns 81 percent of Cho Hung. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a biographical sketch on Sunday about Firefighter Timothy M. Welty, a World Trade Center victim known for his athletic ability, misstated one of his physical accomplishments. He could do pull-ups (not push-ups) using just two fingers.

title: From Tanzania, a Rich Start to the Morning
description: Arabica from Tanzania is the cabernet of coffee: a dark, rich brew with an aroma that hints of raisins and is balanced with good acidity. That describes the dark roast coffee from Sweet Unity Farms, a cooperative community in southern Tanzania that was started about 20 years ago by David Robinson, who settled in Tanzania. Mr. Robinson is a son of Jackie Robinson, the baseball player. A 12-ounce bag, caffeinated only, ground or whole bean, is $8 at Garden of Eden in Manhattan and Brooklyn, Jerry's Red Horse Market in East Hampton, N.Y., or from www.sweetunityfarms.com.

title: States Accuse Bristol-Myers of Fraud on Taxol
description: Attorneys general from 29 states accused Bristol-Myers Squibb yesterday of illegally profiting through several fraudulent schemes to keep lower-priced generic versions of Taxol, a life-extending cancer drug, off the market.

title: U.S. Indicts Gottis, Saying They Operated Dock Rackets
description: In a case that harks back half a century to the mob's storied control of New York's waterfront, prosecutors unsealed a labor racketeering indictment yesterday that charges two of John J. Gotti's brothers, his nephew and six others with plundering the docks and the dockworkers' union.

title: U.S. Threatens Energy Traders With Limits On Pricing
description: Federal regulators threatened today to strip four large energy traders of their ability to charge unregulated rates for electricity because of their responses to inquiries about their strategies in California.

title: A Sampler Calculated To Catch The Eye
description: The Blue Muse Dance Project presented a choreographic showcase on Friday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Most of the works were more notable for their neat construction than for their flights of fancy.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: 50 Million Children Without A Nationality
description: A study by the United Nations Children's Fund said as many as 50 million babies born in 2000 were never legally registered, which means they start life without an official nationality, putting them at greater risk of being exploited or trafficked. The ''unregistered child may be unable to apply for a passport or formal job, open a bank account, get a marriage license (or) stand for elective office or vote,'' according to research by the fund in Italy. This violates the automatic registration outlined in the 1989 Convention on the Rights of the Child, which 191 countries have ratified. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Health Insurers Are Seeking 20% Rate Rise
description: Health insurers are demanding premium increases of more than 20 percent on average for next year, a sharp increase from earlier forecasts, a national survey reported yesterday. Indications of similar increases were reported by employer groups across the country as many companies opened negotiations with health insurers on rates for 2003.

title: Remembering Walleye
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNHAM, B. DWIGHT, JR,
description: DUNHAM-B. Dwight, Jr, 71. On June 4, 2002, in Norwalk, CT. Loving father of Jennifer, Timothy, James and the late Christopher. Devoted grandfather of Willow, Tristan and Timothy Pears. He is also survived by brother, Thomas and sister, Elaine Knowles. Memorial service to be announced. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Lung Association.

title: Fish Tacos Worth Gasping Over
description: SUNSET BOULEVARD east of Hollywood doesn't look like much of a culinary destination as it winds through rolling hills on the way downtown. Passing through the terminally hip zones of Silver Lake and Echo Park, the boulevard is crowded with thrift shops full of 1950's muumuus and quaint little boutiques featuring leather bustiers, nestled against auto body repair shops and open-front garages that install car alarms.

title: First-and-Long: China Is Left With an Empty Feeling
description: China celebrated its first game in the World Cup finals today, but the world's most populous nation will have to wait to celebrate its first victory, its first tie, or even its first goal.

title: In the Interests Of Potato-Peelers Everywhere
description: Roger Bryant, a former high-speed test driver for General Motors, frequently had to peel about 20 pounds of potatoes for his extended family of 25. Finding nothing on the market to make this chore easier, he improvised, and made a plastic prototype. He is now selling his potato holder, Peeler Pal, a gadget with a handle sturdy enough to hold a large Idaho potato. The handle's other end is an apple corer. The holder comes with a mate, a potato peeler with a sharp, thin blade. Mr. Bryant's wife, Christine, who handles marketing, said the holder helps people who have arthritis and can't hold a potato or carrot easily. So why doesn't it have a cushiony handle? ''Those peelers are too heavy, so they take off too much when you use them,'' she said. It's also left- or right-handed. A set of holder and peeler is $5.99 for one, $9.95 for two from (888) 298-8325. The gadget will soon be sold in supermarkets, including A.&P. and Albertson's.

title: A Jockey's View
description: Richard Migliore, the Brooklyn-born jockey, said yesterday that in order to beat War Emblem, the Triple Crown favorite at Saturday's Belmont Stakes, someone will have to ''sneak up on him.''

title: Hamilton Succeeds Minus Armstrong
description: The cyclist Tyler Hamilton used to be known as Lance Armstrong's trusted lieutenant. As his teammate, he protected Armstrong up mountains, guided him down harrowing descents and provided food and water from the team car.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Shuttle Repair Completed
description: Technicians finished work on replacing an engine valve, clearing the way for the planned launching today of the space shuttle Endeavour on a mission to the International Space Station. Forecasters said thunderstorms could force NASA to postpone the flight for a fifth time in six days.

title: The Eyes and Ears of the Hospital
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit Buys Software Company
description: Intuit, a maker of financial and tax preparation software, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Management Reports Inc., a property-management software company, for about $92 million in cash. Intuit, which makes the popular Quicken software, said the acquisition would help it become a leader in the global property management software market. That market is worth $400 million, according to Intuit. Management Reports, which is based in Cleveland, designs software for landlords of commercial and residential property. The company has 300 employees in 13 offices. Intuit said it expected to retain ''virtually all'' of Management Reports' employees, including Bob Lasser, its chief executive. Shares in Intuit rose 40 cents, to $43. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Iowa, Where Girls Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Survivors Recount Details of Killings Above Carnegie Deli for 2 Juries
description: Rosemond Dane told two juries yesterday that something ''didn't seem right'' when two men entered her friend's apartment above the Carnegie Delicatessen. The tension that froze everyone else in the room. The heavy coats on a hot summer day.

title: State Department Issues Report on Human Trafficking
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  At least 700,000 people, and possibly as many as 4 million, were bought and sold or otherwise treated like slaves throughout the world in the past year, the State Department said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat's Chairman Returns
description: Fiat's honorary chairman, Gianni Agnelli, left, returned to Italy yesterday after having medical treatment in the United States for a prostate condition. His return raised speculation that Fiat would sell 80 percent of its car unit to General Motors. Mr. Agnelli, whose grandfather founded the company in 1899, is seen as the leading opponent of such a sale; the Agnelli family controls 34 percent of Fiat, which has debt of 6.6 billion euros ($6.21 billion). At a news conference, the chief executive, Giancarlo Boschetti, denied rumors that the company had been contacted by General Motors and predicted that Fiat would break even in 2003. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Jackson's View of Old Nets Is Less Than Scenic One
description: Lakers Coach Phil Jackson never had much of an affinity for New Jersey, stemming from his seasons as a player and then as an assistant coach for the Nets from 1978 to 1981.

title: Hand Injury Blunting Alfonzo's Power
description: Edgardo Alfonzo has only one home run in 189 at-bats, despite averaging 23 homers the past three seasons. And even though he has spent most of this season as the Mets' No. 5 hitter, behind Mike Piazza, Alfonzo has eight fewer runs batted in than Rey Ordez, the light-hitting shortstop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAIGELMAN, HENRY
description: BAIGELMAN - Henry. The Anti - Defamation League mourns the passing of Henry Baigelman, beloved father of ADL National Executive Committee Member, Riva Berelson. We extend our condolences to Riva, her mother Gita and the entire family. Glen A. Tobias National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: Kaye Takes Over Jets' College Scouting
description: Dick Haley's career as a draft maven officially wound down yesterday as the Jets named Jesse Kaye the team's college scouting director. General Manager Terry Bradway said Kaye's role on draft day would be similar to Haley's. ''Dick had been the moderator of the room,'' Bradway said.

title: Data Revised on Soot in Air and Deaths
description: Revisiting their own data with new methods, scientists who conducted influential studies that linked sooty air pollution with higher death rates have lowered their estimate of the risk posed by bad-air days.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Leading Lawyer Arrested
description: The police arrested Sternford Moyo, the president of the Zimbabwe Law Society, and accused him of calling on people ''to rebel'' against the government of President Robert Mugabe, the state news agency reported. Mr. Moyo, a longtime critic of the government, was accused of calling for protests after the March presidential election, which opposition officials and Western governments believe was rigged. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Big Belmont Winner May Be Towers Fund
description: Bob Baker, David Cornstein and Bill Mack think they have given New York's firefighters and police officers and their families the horse to root for in Saturday's Belmont Stakes. The three owners of the Belmont hopeful Proud Citizen, all of whom have New York roots, have stepped up their efforts to use their 3-year-old colt to recognize heroes and victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: India's Restraint
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times Magazine on Sunday about President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela and the conditions that led to his brief removal in April misstated the nature of a march on which sharpshooters fired just before the coup. It was anti-Chvez, not pro-; pockets of Chvez supporters circulated through the streets, and initial investigations indicate that both opponents and supporters of Mr. Chvez were shot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGARTY, JOHN J. (JACK).
description: FOGARTY-John J. (Jack). 81, of Mount Kisco, N.Y. Died on June 3. Husband of Jean. Father of Jack, Marisa and Jeanne. Grandfather of Michael, Mark, Kimberly, Siobhan and Cash. Visiting hours Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9PM at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, N.Y. Funeral Mass on Thursday, June 6, at 11AM at St. Francis of Assisi RC Church, Mount Kisco, N.Y. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: India Backtracks on Joint Patrols of Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI, June 6  Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee briefly lifted hopes this morning for a rapprochement between India and Pakistan when he said India would consider joint patrols with Pakistani troops to catch Islamic militants trying to sneak into Indian Kashmir.

title: Corrections

title: Teammates Drafted By Mets And Expos
description: Making baseball draft history, the Montreal Expos and the Mets selected players from the same high school in the first 15 picks yesterday. To hear the coach of the players, both pitchers, tell it, the Mets landed the better of the two with the 15th pick.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Derby: Strike Ends At Baseball Cap Maker
description: After an 11-month strike, the New Era Cap Company, which makes the official caps for Major League Baseball, reached a tentative settlement yesterday with the union representing 330 workers at its factory in Derby, outside Buffalo. The main issue was New Era's efforts to speed up production. The union, the Communications Workers of America, said that would increase on-the-job injuries. The two sides agreed on the hiring of an engineering firm to recommend production rates. They declined to disclose details about wages and benefits. A ratification vote is set for June 21. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Greenwich Offices, and Rents, Are Sprucing Up
description: While vacancy rates in this upscale town are somewhat lower than elsewhere in Fairfield County, owners of a number of Greenwich office buildings have been investing heavily in refurbishing their properties.

title: Edison Schools Gets $40 Million in Loans
description: Edison Schools, the nation's largest commercial manager of public schools, announced yesterday that it had arranged to borrow the $40 million that it needs to finance its takeover of 20 public schools in Philadelphia. But the company will pay a high price, with interest rates that will range into the low teens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIDES, FRED H.
description: SIDES-Fred H. Age 86. Died Monday, June 3, 2002 at home in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was born in Charlotte, N.C. and educated at Wake Forest, Davidson College and at UNC Chapel Hill. His business career spanned six decades, ranging from senior positions in transportation and printing, to executive recruiting and real estate development. He was an accomplished woodworker, photographer and outdoorsman, and a dedicated golfer who was a past president of the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club, and five times its Senior Golfing Champion. He is survived by his wife Louise, daughter Silvia, son and daughter-in-law Randolph and Tracey, his sister Mary Anne McCarley and grandson John Randolph Sides. Calling hours will be held at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, Mount Kisco, Thursday, June 6th, 7-9PM. A funeral service will take place at Saint Mark's Church, Mount Kisco, Friday, June 7th, 4PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Salvation Army of Greater New York or the Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco.

Contributions in his memory may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center, 16th St. at 1st Ave., NY NY 10003.

title: Fedorov Raises Stakes for Detroit's Cup Run
description: DETROIT, June 4  As the Winter Olympics approached in 1998, Sergei Fedorov had no team. Fedorov was a restricted free agent and had no contract offers. The compensation  giving up to five first-round draft choices to the Detroit Red Wings  was a discouraging factor.

description: The rhythm and blues star R. Kelly was indicted today in Chicago on charges of child pornography in connection with a videotape that authorities say shows the Grammy-winning singer having sex with a minor.

description: United States intelligence and law enforcement officials said today that they had concluded that a possible relative of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, who coordinated the first bombing of the World Trade Center, in 1993, and a later unsuccessful plot to bomb American airliners over the Pacific, played a pivotal role in planning the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington.

description: WASHINGTON, June 5 - Calling for a new ``vital line of defense'' against terrorists, Attorney General John Ashcroft proposed Justice Department regulations today that would require 100,000 foreign students, tourists, researchers and other visitors to register with the federal government.

title: Hip-Hoppers Help Teachers Stage a Rally
description: An estimated 20,000 people rallied outside City Hall yesterday to protest Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposed cuts to the public education budget at a demonstration that featured hip-hop performers, advocates for the schools and teachers' union officials.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Kursk Fragments Recovered
description: Navy salvagers recovered fragments of the Kursk submarine's bow and a torpedo tube before gales cut short the operation in the Barents Sea. Most of the Kursk was lifted from the seabed in an international effort last year. The submarine sank in August 2000, killing all 118 people on board. At first officials said a collision with a foreign submarine might have caused it to sink. Later a faulty torpedo was given as the probable cause, although it was not explained why the topedo might have exploded. Ilya Klebanov, the government minister in charge of the salvage operation, said the cause of the disaster would be announced next month. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORR, JACK
description: DORR-Jack. Of Merrick, NY on June 4, 2002. Beloved husband of Geraldine. Loving brother of Cathy Kreuscher and Wendy Milliman. Brother-in-law of Kenneth and Don. title: US AIRWAYS PILOTS OFFER TO TAKE PAY CUT
description: The pilots union of the US Airways Group proposed an average 26 percent pay cut and savings of $328 million annually to help the carrier return to profitability. The Air Line Pilots Association, in response to a cost-saving proposal made by the airline, said it would reverse two pay increases since May 2001 and let the airline fly as many as 315 small jets, up from 140 now. US Airways last month said it wanted $595 million a year in savings from the pilots. The airline is trying to reduce labor and other costs to support an application for a $1 billion federal loan guarantee. US Airways is based in Arlington, Va.

title: Renaissance Madrigals, And Others From Today
description: The New Amsterdam Singers and their conductor, Clara Longstreth, began their concert at Merkin Hall on Thursday with an intriguing bouquet of excerpts from late Renaissance madrigal comedies -- operas happening in collective song, without action or scenery. The prologue from Orazio Vecchi's ''Amfiparnasso'' was an apt opener with its invitation to listen. Then came Banchieri's ''Ad un Dolce Usignolo,'' whose chromatic opening was beautifully in tune, followed by a comic master-servant dialogue by Lassus.

title: Charges Against Gooden Reduced
description: A charge of driving under the influence against Dwight Gooden, the former Yankee and Met, for a February incident on a Tampa, Fla., highway was reduced to reckless driving yesterday in Hillsborough County Court, opening the door for him to work for the Yankees again.

description: The Baltimore Orioles kept giving and giving some more to the Yankees last night, a script assured of producing disaster. As if overrunning a single into two bases, missing a grounder, dropping a throw or freezing and turning the wrong way on a line drive were not damaging enough, Jeff Conine helped gift-wrap a game-turning eight-run sixth inning for the Yankees.

title: 5 Passengers Say Airlines Discriminated By Looks
description: In separate civil rights lawsuits filed yesterday, five men said they were wrongly removed from commercial airline flights after Sept. 11 solely because other travelers or crew members objected to their Middle Eastern appearance.

title: Honoring Holocaust Teaching
description: RABBI DOV LEREA, a teacher and administrator at the Abraham Joshua Heschel School in Manhattan, was one of two winners of the Korczak Teaching Awards, sponsored by the American Friends of the Ghetto Fighters Museum, a group that raises money for the famed Holocaust museum, which is in an Israeli kibbutz. Rabbi Lerea and SHANNON MURPHY of Central High School in Louisville were honored for their work in getting students in Israel and the United States to share thoughts and sentiments via e-mail about Holocaust books by authors like Elie Wiesel.

title: Barge Bargains in France
description: From July 21 to Aug. 17, French Country Waterways is taking up to $400 a person off the price of six-night barge cruises in Burgundy, the Upper Loire and Alsace-Lorraine. The barges hold 8 to 18 passengers, and the fares include all meals, wines, sightseeing trips, use of bikes, transfers between Paris or Strasbourg and the cruises, and one meal in a Michelin multiple-star restaurant. Rates start at $3,195 to $4,195 a person, based on double occupancy, depending on the barge; (800) 222-1236 or www.fcwl.com .

title: Facing Redistricting, Congressman Ponders Switch
description: United States Representative Benjamin A. Gilman said today that he was thinking about switching from Republican to Democrat, hoping to stave off political extinction under a proposed redistricting plan.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Sex Offender Listing Rejected
description: A federal judge declared the state's sex offender registry unconstitutional, saying that it denies people whose names are listed on a state Internet site the opportunity to challenge their designation as a threat to society. Judge Victoria A. Roberts of federal District Court made the ruling on Monday, two weeks after the Supreme Court agreed to to decide whether listing all the names of convicted sex offenders, without determining whether an individual still poses a potential danger, violates the right of due process. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: General Motors Chairman Announces He'll Retire Next Year
description: John F. Smith Jr. said today that he would step down next year as chairman of General Motors when he reaches the company's retirement age of 65.

title: From Tanzania, a Rich Start to the Morning
description: Arabica from Tanzania is the cabernet of coffee: a dark, rich brew with an aroma that hints of raisins and is balanced with good acidity. That describes the dark roast coffee from Sweet Unity Farms, a cooperative community in southern Tanzania that was started about 20 years ago by David Robinson, who settled in Tanzania. Mr. Robinson is a son of Jackie Robinson, the baseball player. A 12-ounce bag, caffeinated only, ground or whole bean, is $8 at Garden of Eden in Manhattan and Brooklyn, Jerry's Red Horse Market in East Hampton, N.Y., or from www. sweetunityfarms.com.

title: A Bud From the Old Country
description: American visitors to the Czech Republic are often surprised to discover a popular beer called Budweiser Budvar there. In the republic, the term Budweiser traditionally refers to a golden lager that has been made since 1795 in the city of Budweis, also called Ceske Budejovice. Because Anheuser-Busch has a trademark on the name, no other Budweiser can be sold in the United States. So Budweiser Budvar is called Czechvar here, and has been sold in fancy food stores for about a year. The refreshingly bitter brew is going head to head with the ubiquitous Budweiser for about a dollar a bottle in supermarkets like Key Food and D'Agostino in New York.

title: In Partial Verdict, Jury Finds DuPont Caused Illnesses of 2 New Jersey Women
description: A jury found today that the DuPont Company had caused the illnesses of two women who grew up near the company's shuttered, polluted explosives plant in Pompton Lakes. But the jury was deadlocked over how much money to award them in damages.

title: Polish Farmers Leery of European Union
description: A Polish farmer's life is not easy these days, Edward Zawadzki said as he walked through the cattle barn his father built, long vacant because of low milk prices.

title: A Dulcet Tenor's 'Popsical' Debut
description: Strolling the stage of Carnegie Hall on Saturday night with a wireless microphone, Russell Watson was singing Verdi, more or less. The aria was ''Va, Pensiero'' from ''Nabucco''; he was accompanied by the New York Pops and the Juilliard Choral Union. As it began, Mr. Watson sang in a breathy croon in English. Then he switched to Italian and opened up his operatic tenor, turning himself from George Michael to Ezio Pinza.

title: Canadians Are Focusing on Curbing Inflation
description: Pointing to an unexpectedly robust economy, the Bank of Canada raised its crucial overnight interest rate today for the second time in less than two months.

When the rain passed, and the Mets took a 1-0 lead in the top of the first inning, electricity in some of the bulbs on the lights above the grandstand had gone out, darkening the field slightly.

title: Hoboken Mayor Seeks Inquiry On Delay in Building a Garage
description: After years of delays and millions of dollars in cost overruns, the mayor of Hoboken has called for an independent investigation into the construction of this city's long-overdue automated parking garage.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about high school students who give dinner parties in their parents' homes misspelled the surname of one student at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn Heights and misstated her grade level and that of another girl there. The girl who said boys eat more than girls is Lena Neufeld, not Neufield; she is in the 10th grade, not the 11th. The one who said she enjoys baking and making gravlax, Liz Broadwin, is in the 11th grade, not the 10th.

title: Mozart and Wagner Plus a World Premiere
description: Like a fine old house, Mozart's ''Cos fan Tutte'' is an opera that relies on an underlying sense of proportion; inflating it to fit in a 3,000-seat opera house results in something akin to a McMansion. Fortunately, the Spoleto Festival USA (through Sunday) has a fine sense of proportion and of history and for that matter of opera, to judge from the two productions of its current season.

title: Different Journeys, Same Destination
description: Kobe Bryant glided in, his wingspan and wondrous ability delivering him to his third N.B.A. finals in three years. Michael Jordan, Julius Erving and Isiah Thomas had no championships before they were 26. Bryant is working on his third at 23. He is the chosen player, pro basketball's lord of the rings, save the youthful turmoil and torturous journey.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Border Offensive Planned
description: The military government of the former Burma gave warning that it planned a large-scale offensive against ethnic Shan rebels who have been fighting a separatist war in the jungles for half a century. It said its warning was meant as ''advance notice'' to the Thai Army that its operations would be carried out near their common border. Tensions have heightened in recent weeks between the two neighbors, who have engaged in firefights when the Burmese Army came close to the border. ''We will under no circumstances intrude into Thai territory,'' a military spokesman said. Seth Mydans (NYT)

description: Manhattan's Community School District 2 is recruiting students for a new high school below 14th Street. The school, Millennium High School, is among 23 financed with a $30 million grant from the Carnegie Corporation, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and George Soros's Open Society Institute.

description: Alex Corretja was constructing tense points long enough to require Cliffs Notes this evening, but the 15,000-seat stadium at Roland Garros was as sparsely populated as a Wyoming whistle-stop.

This year, in the 38th installment of this trial by fire, performances on Saturday afternoon and evening at the Juilliard Theater were happily for the most part pure entertainment.

It was 1997, not 1987.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Kidnapping And Murder Trial Starts
description: Just four months after the disappearance of 7-year-old Danielle van Dam, the man charged with her murder went on trial in a San Diego courtroom. David Westerfield, a 50-year-old neighbor, is charged with kidnapping and killing Danielle, who disappeared from her family's home after being put to bed on Feb. 1. Her body was found by searchers Feb. 27. In opening the trial, Judge William Mudd of Superior Court cautioned jurors to avoid news reports about the case. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Corrections

Wolfowitz to assess plans for American troops to extend a counterterrorism training mission with the military there misstated a phrase in his description of the situation. He said, ''The stakes are large there, and so are the problems'' -- not ''Mistakes are large.''

title: Joseph Garba, 58, a Nigerian Coup Plotter and, Later, a Diplomat
description: Joseph Garba, a Nigerian soldier turned diplomat who helped organize a military coup that briefly restored civilian rule to his country, died on Saturday in the capital, Abuja. He was 58.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: BANK PRIVATIZATION IS DELAYED The Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation has delayed a plan to begin privatizing the Cho Hung Bank, which it took over in the economic crisis of 1997-98. Korea Deposit, an arm of the ministry of finance and economy, said an increase of 8 percent in the value of the South Korean won against the dollar would make it difficult to carry out a program for marketing global depository receipts overseas covering 15 percent of the value of the bank. Kim Jong Tae, who is in charge of the program for privatizing several banks acquired by the corporation, said it would offer Cho Hung Bank depository receipts "whenever the market looks favorable." Korea Deposit owns 81 percent of Cho Hung. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: PEPSICO TO COMBINE QUAKER AND BEVERAGE UNITS
description: In a move to further consolidate its business units after the acquisition of the Quaker Oats Company last August, PepsiCo Inc. said yesterday that it would combine its North American beverage operations and its Quaker Foods business into a single unit. PepsiCo, the world's second-largest soft drink maker, will unite its flagship Pepsi Cola business with its Gatorade, Tropicana and Quaker food units in the United States and Canada. Gary M. Rodkin, the president and chief executive of Pepsi-Cola North America since 1999, will lead the new division, named PepsiCo Beverages and Foods North America. Mr. Rodkin, 50, will report to Robert S. Morrison, PepsiCo's vice chairman. Mr. Morrison, 60, has agreed to remain in his position until February 2003, the company said.

title: French Bank Uses Bugs to Sell Itself
description: No longer the heroes of the stock market boom, investment bankers have seen their reputations sullied in recent months by a series of scandals, ranging from the ethical practices of securities analysts to their involvement in the Enron fiasco. Their standing may hit a new low next week, when BNP Paribas, the giant French bank, introduces an advertising campaign that compares bankers to insects.

title: U.S. CANDIDATES TO BE CUT TO TWO
description: The United States Olympic Committee said yesterday that it would cut its list of candidate cities for the 2012 Summer Games to two from four in September after a second round of visits through next month to evaluate the cities.

title: A Fish That Takes to Grilling
description: MOST fin fish have qualities in common, and chief among these is that they become tender quickly. So tender and so quickly, in fact, that fin fish can be difficult to grill, falling apart even before they have browned.

title: Gains of 90's Did Not Lift All, Census Shows
description: Despite the surging economy of the 1990's that brought affluence to many Americans, the poor remained entrenched, the Census Bureau reported today. The bureau's statistics for the 50 states and the District of Columbia show that 9.2 percent of families were deemed poor in 2000, a slight improvement from 10 percent in 1989.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank Sells Stake
description: The second largest bank in Spain, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, agreed to sell a 24 percent stake in Metrovacesa, a real estate company, for 545 million euros ($512.9 million), helping offset losses from Argentina's currency devaluation. Bami, Spain's fifth-largest real estate company, will pay Banco Bilbao 36.55 euros a share, or 59 percent more than Metrovacesa's closing price on Monday, Banco Bilbao said. Bilbao and Santander Central Hispano, Spain's two biggest banks, are speeding their pace of asset sales after Argentina's default and devaluation cut 2001 profit, and economic growth slowed in its main markets.

title: Red Cross Is Pressed To Open Its Books
description: Driven by anger and concern over the performance of the American National Red Cross in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, federal and state officials are demanding fuller disclosure of the relief agency's finances and are moving to enforce more stringent monitoring of its disaster aid operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWEY, GORDON CHIPMAN
description: DEWEY-Gordon Chipman. 79, died peacefully May 30, 2002, at his home in New York City. Mr. Dewey was born in New York on April 9, 1923, to the late Frederick A. and Elisabeth (Braley) Dewey and is the grandson of John Dewey, the American philosopher and educator. Mr. Dewey studied nuclear physics at Harvard during WW II. During the war years, he worked at the Radiation Laboratory at MIT on early radar technology, as well as on The Manhattan Project. He was later recruited to be at the Pentagon for the Joint Chiefs of Staff with the Weapon Systems Evaluation Group, analyzing the nuclear retaliatory mission. In the 1950's he was a consultant to the Department of Defense, the White House (as a presidential appointee to the Air Traffic Control Board) and companies such as the Rand Corporation. In 1955, he founded The Dewey Electronics Corporation, taking it public in 1960. Today the company is active in the snowmaking and defense industries. He was President and CEO until his death. Mr. Dewey's extensive philanthropic efforts centered on education. He was past chairman of the Navy League Scholarship Committee. For 27 years he led The New York Institute for Special Education through a period of major building and transformation as the president of its board. The Institute began for the blind and was then expanded to meet the needs of children with other disabilities. He was an avid sailor and spent his summers in Nantucket. Mr. Dewey had the distinction of being one of the longest-running members of the New York Yacht Club. His warm and wise presence will be missed. Mr. Dewey is survived by his wife of 48 years, Frances Dear; his children, Frederick R., Dede W., John H. D. (Sara); and his sister Joanna. A memorial service is scheduled for Wednesday, June 5 at 3 PM at the Heavenly Rest Church, 2 East 90th St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Institute for Special Education, 999 Pelham Parkway, Bronx, NY, 10469.

title: Market Place; Edison Schools Gets Reprieve: $40 Million In Financing
description: Edison Schools Inc., the nation's largest commercial manager of public schools, announced yesterday that it had arranged to borrow the $40 million that it needs to finance its takeover of 20 struggling public schools in Philadelphia. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENKLAR, DR. NORMAN,
description: SONNENKLAR-Dr. Norman, joined the staff of the Department of Anesthesiology as a House Staff Officer in 1967 and was appointed to the faculty as an Assistant Clinical Professor in 1968. In 1984, he assumed responsibilities as Director of Urologic Anesthesia and Assistant Clinical Coordinator of the operating rooms at The Mount Sinai Hospital. In January 1985 he undertook one of the most important and challenging positions in the Department of Anesthesiology as Chief of Anesthesia at the Elmhurst Hospital Center. Dr. Sonnenklar was promoted to the rank of Associate Professor of Clinical Anesthesiology effective January 1, 1986. He was appointed as Assistant Dean for Clinical Affairs and represented Elmhurst faculty as a member of the Dean's Committee and Academic Council. He also served as President of the Elmhurst Medical Board and President of the Faculty Practice at Elmhurst and Queens Hospital Centers. Dr. Sonnenklar was an outstanding clinical anesthesiologist who for over 30 years contributed to the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and its related educational programs. In the time that he served as Chief of Anesthesiology at Elmhurst Hospital Center, he made dramatic changes in both clinical care and teaching. His colleagues and friends in the Department of Anesthesiology at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Elmhurst Hospital Center will miss Norman. We extend sincere condolences to Susan, Alan and Jill, Eric and Lisa, and his three grandsons, Jacob, Adam, and Harris.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink To Sell Internet Access At Gateway
description: EarthLink Inc., the third-largest Internet service, will sell high-speed online access at Gateway stores. The access will be sold at 56 stores in cities like New York and San Diego, and the first month of the $41.95 service will be free, the companies said in a statement yesterday. The agreement calls for EarthLink to resell fast access provided by AOL Time Warner's cable television lines, part of an accord struck two years ago between EarthLink and AOL Time Warner. EarthLink, with about 4.9 million subscribers, has more than 532,000 high-speed customers. It is seeking to bolster that as more consumers opt for speedier Web access instead of service through traditional phone lines. Gateway will sell EarthLink's service to shoppers buying PC's in the stores and to those wanting to upgrade their computers with high-speed access. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Berkeley Township: Wildfire Is Nearly Contained
description: Fire officials have contained nearly all of a windblown fire that destroyed more than 1,300 acres of the New Jersey Pinelands. The fire destroyed one house and damaged a dozen others. Officials said the fire was more than 90 percent contained and should be fully under control in the next few days. Investigators are still trying to determine what set off the blaze, which began in a cranberry bog around 1 p.m. Sunday. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

''We brought him in with Lomas Brown, and I don't think we would've made the Super Bowl without them,'' Giants General Manager Ernie Accorsi said, referring to Parker. ''He left his mark here.''
