title: Technology Briefing | Software: I.B.M. Plans Job Cuts In Semiconductor Unit
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that it would lay off 1,500 employees in its semiconductor unit, or about 7.5 percent of the work force, as part of a companywide reorganization plan to focus on more profitable business areas. The layoffs, which will be concentrated in Burlington, Vt., and Fishkill, N.Y., come in addition to about 4,500 job cuts I.B.M. has made in other units, including its server division and software group. Earlier in the week, the company announced it would leave the disk-drive business. The layoffs, widely expected, were less than had been rumored. I.B.M.'s semiconductor business had been underperforming other I.B.M. units for some time. I.B.M. employs 8,000 people in Vermont and is the state's largest private employer. Shares in I.B.M. rose $1.20, or 1.5 percent, to $79.31. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: A Recipe for a Fish That Is Not A Household Name
description: Blowfish tails are often sold under the names sea squab or chicken of the sea, though the odd-looking delicacies have nothing to do with birds. This has been a good season for blowfish, found off Long Island's south shore and the north New Jersey coast. The tails are delicious morsels, with a single slender bone running their length. But few markets in Manhattan sell them because, the owners say, few people buy them and many do not even know what they are. I cook them like jumbo shrimp, dusting them with flour before sauting in butter and garlic, or I briefly sear the tails on the grill. Sometimes I add them to paella or bouillabaisse. There are about 20 to a pound, and they cost $6 to $8 a pound. In Manhattan, they are often carried by Pescatore Seafood in the Grand Central Market, Catalano Fish in Eli's Manhattan and the Vinegar Factory; Rosedale; and Pisacane. In Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, look for the tails at Henry's Fish Market. But they are not available every day, so it pays to check.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Orange: Suspect Sought In Shooting Of Officer
description: A manhunt was under way yesterday for a suspect in the shooting of an off-duty East Orange police officer during a robbery last week. The suspect, Khalid Fate, 26, escaped from a locked holding cell. Mr. Fate was the driver of a getaway car during a robbery at the Topps Market early Friday morning, the authorities said. Two other men, Thomas Williams and Anthony Irving, were also arrested. Michael Allman, a veteran East Orange officer, was moonlighting as a security guard when two masked men announced a robbery. The robbers were wounded in an exchange of gunfire, as was Officer Allman, who was released from University Hospital in Newark on Saturday. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCAW, SUSAN
description: McCAW-Susan, wife, mother and mentor, died June 2, 2002 from complications caused by Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Early on she assumed the role of caretaker, helping to raise her seven brothers and sisters. She was an ambitious student, graduating as salutatorian of her high school and then entering Georgetown School of Foreign Service as part of the first class of 25 women ever to enroll. There she met her husband, Robert B. McCaw, & started a loving partnership that lasted 38 years. While raising her children, Susan obtained her MBA from George Mason University and her CPA from the University of Virginia. She served as the Director of Finance and Administration at the NEA's Health Information Network in Washington, DC and at the Alan Guttmacher Institute in New York. She is survived by her husband; two children, Anne Meredith McCaw & Benjamin H. McCaw; her mother, and her seven siblings. She will be remembered with love as a generous, nurturing and courageous woman.

title: A Clubby Atmosphere and a Ticker-Tape Theme
description: The designer Philippe Starck and the restaurateur Laurent Taeb have joined forces for their second Bon restaurant, near the Place de la Bourse, a business and financial district, and convenient to the headquarters of Agence France-Presse. Bon 2, left, uses a stock market theme to play with the idea of a gentleman's club; it serves seafood and fois gras surrounded by a ticker-tape screen, makore wood finishings, leather sofas, thick carpets and a crystal chandelier. For fun, diners can write messages to each other on a giant plasma screen, upper right. Mr. Starck and Mr. Taeb have also announced their plans for a restaurant called Kong. They will be working with the luxury goods company LVMH, which owns a building that once housed part of the Samaritaine department store. LVMH is installing one of its Kenzo stores in the building, and, on the top floor, with a panoramic view of Paris, the Kong restaurant. On the street level, Mr. Taeb will also open a sushi bar designed by Andre Putman. Bon 2 is at 2, rue du Quatre-Septembre; (011) 33.1.44.55.51.55.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: NORTHERN IRELAND: A SINN FEIN LORD MAYOR The Belfast City Council elected Alex Maskey as the first lord mayor from Sinn Fein, the political party of the Irish Republican Army. Mr. Maskey, 50, was jailed twice as an I.R.A. suspect in the 1970's and shot in the stomach at his home in 1987, one of many attempts on his life. He became Sinn Fein's first councilman in 1983 and for years his attempts to speak provoked walkouts and choruses of catcalls. The once predominantly Protestant 51-member council now has 14 Sinn Fein members. It chose its first Roman Catholic mayor, Alban Maginness of the moderate Social Democratic and Labor Party, in 1997. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: RULING ON BLOCKED MERGER APPEAL DUE The Eu- ropean Court of Justice will decide today whether the European Commission was right to block the merger of two travel companies, Airtours and First Choice, three years ago. If the court supports the Airtours appeal of the merger ruling it will not revive the deal, but it would set an important precedent and would curb the powers of the competition commissioner, Mario Monti. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: McBride Makes It Sound Easy

title: Some migrs Who Brought Musical Riches With Them

Three of them -- Franz Waxman, Alexandre Tansman and Erich Wolfgang Korngold -- quickly found jobs writing scores for Hollywood films. The fourth, Kurt Weill, continued to pursue the theatrical impulse that had been successful for him in Europe. The fifth was Arnold Schoenberg.

title: Preserving Liberty and Security; The Role of Congress
description: Robert Mueller's planned appearance before the Senate Judiciary Committee today ought to be the occasion for a tough grilling of the beleaguered director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The immediate issues before the committee are the bureau's mishandling of warnings last summer about terror threats and the steps Mr. Mueller is taking to reorganize his agency. Members of the committee should use the opportunity to demand that Mr. Mueller explain why Congress was not consulted before Attorney General John Ashcroft granted the F.B.I. new domestic spying powers last week. The senators should also ask for a detailed report on how the administration has used other law enforcement tools it sought after Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARANGO, MILTON
description: ARANGO-Milton. It is with great sadness that the Trustees, the Women's Board, the staff and especially the members of The Boys' Club of New York note the death of their dear friend on June 4th. ''Miltie'' joined the club in 1945 as a swimming coach at the Jefferson Park Clubhouse, eventually moving to the Harriman Clubhouse where he was Aquatics Director and finally, the Milliken Clubhouse, until he retired to Florida in 1990. An active retiree, he returned to Camp Cromwell each summer as mentor and friend. He will be remembered by us all with deep affection. The Milton Arango Annual Swim Meet will be held Friday, June 14th, 7:00 PM at the Harriman Clubhouse, 287 East 10th Street, NYC.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: A New Opposition Leader
description: Ireland's principal opposition party, Fine Gael, which suffered the worst losses in its history in last month's vote that returned Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, the Fianna Fail candidate, to office, chose Enda Kenny as its new leader replacing Michael Noonan who resigned on election night. Mr. Kenny, 51, has been in the Irish Parliament since 1975 and was tourism and trade minister for four years in the 1990's. Beaten by Mr. Noonan in the leadership election 18 months ago, he promised to rebuild the party, which lost 23 seats, including some of its most prominent members, in the May 17 election.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Education Board Rebukes Levy
description: In a rare rebuke to a chancellor, the Board of Education yesterday voted 4 to 1 to reverse Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy's dismissal of a community school board member. In March, Mr. Levy removed the board member, Amy Velez, after she was accused of practicing voodoo on a colleague. Ms. Velez, a board member for School District 1, denied the charge. Mr. Levy yesterday called the board's reversal misguided. The board's president, Ninfa Segarra, an opponent of Mr. Levy, said his decision to fire Ms. Velez was politically motivated. Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Northwest
description: OREGON: SETBACK FOR PHILIP MORRIS A panel of the State Court of Appeals reinstated $79.5 million in punitive damages against Philip Morris, which a jury awarded to a smoker's widow three years ago. A trial court judge had deemed the amount excessive and cut it down to $32 million. The panel found that company's perpetuation of a specious controversy over the risks of cigarettes justified "strong judicial punishment."

title: Polishing Up a Well-Cut Gem
description: AS poised as a chess piece on a green playing field, the stalwart little house that Charles Gwathmey built for his parents in 1965 -- and that catapulted him to prominence at the tender age of 27 -- looks as sculpturally inscrutable as ever. In fact it appears all the more commanding, as does the little studio set behind it at an obsequious angle, now that the architect has planted privet trees all around the smooth one-acre plot. ''My father hated privet,'' Mr. Gwathmey said last week. ''He thought it was too bourgeois, and not very neighborly.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Manugistics Shares Fall After Loss Is Posted
description: Shares of the Manugistics Group, a software company in Rockville, Md., dropped almost 26 percent yesterday after it said it recorded a first-quarter loss because of weakened sales. The company had predicted a profit. Shares fell $2.04, to $5.90. Sales declined in April and May, company officials said on Tuesday, compared with March when demand appeared to be recovering. Gregory J. Owens, the company's chief executive, said ''financial performance this quarter was adversely impacted by the continuing global economic downturn.'' The company said it lost $16 million to $18 million in the period that ended Friday. While sales were $71 million to $73 million for the quarter, the company had predicted a range of $84 million to $85 million. Mr. Owens said he would consider some job cuts. Manugistics, makes software that helps companies share inventory, pricing and planning information with customers and suppliers over the Internet.

title: Israel Attacks Arafat Compound in Swift Response After Palestinian Suicide Bombing Kills 17 in Bus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, LEW
description: WASSERMAN - Lew. The board of directors and staff of the American Foundation for AIDS Research (amfAR) mourn the loss of their friend and benefactor, Lew Wasserman. As a prominent executive in the entertainment industry, he effected sound, groundbreaking changes in how the business and the artistic sides of the industry work together. At the same time, he established himself as a preeminent philanthropist and a dedicated promoter of civil rights. We are profoundly grateful for his leadership in all those areas, but most especially we thank him for his unwavering commitment to amfAR and the fight against AIDS. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Edie, one of amfAR's founding directors. The generosity of Edie and Lew Wasserman and many of their friends in the film industry continues to benefit amfAR and its mission. Lew Wasserman personified the humanitarian values he espoused, and today, through our deep sorrow, we reaffirm our commitment to those values and to the work he and Edie supported with such conviction. Mathilde Krim, Ph.D., Founding Chair and Chairman of the Board Jerome J. Radwin, CEO American Foundation for AIDS Research

Her set on Sunday night at the Bowery Ballroom was a series of unhurried vamps that left room for her to sing, to rap, to talk and to moan. She was introducing songs from her new album, ''Cookie: The Anthropological Mixtape'' (Maverick), persuading and seducing side by side.

description: IT is a trying time to follow the World Cup soccer tournament in the United States. Although it is the largest international sporting event, it is still considered an oddity by many Americans who associate a football with pigskin. And because the games are being played in the afternoon and evening in South Korea and Japan, they are broadcast live in North America in the early hours of the morning, inevitably resulting in sleep deprivation.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Families In Venture
description: In a deal valued at $925 million between two of Southeast Asia's most prominent business families, the Philippine conglomerate JG Summit Holdings said it would form a joint venture with First Pacific of Hong Kong to buy First Pacific's Philippine assets, including a controlling stake in Philippine Long Distance Telephone and a central Manila real estate development. JG Summit is the flagship of the Philippine tycoon John Gokongwei, while First Pacific is controlled by the Salim family of Indonesia. The board of Philippine Long Distance issued a statement opposing the sale, however, saying it would violate company bylaws and would probably break antitrust laws since JG Summit controls a rival operator. Phlippine Long Distance barred employees from giving JG Summit the financial information it is likely to need to complete the purchase. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Capital Spending Falls
description: Japanese companies cut capital spending plans 16.8 percent in the January-March quarter from the period a year earlier as they continued to cut costs to offset the country's 18-month recession, the Finance Ministry said. During the same period, sales fell 7.4 percent, almost twice the rate of the previous three-month period. The weak numbers have led many economists to lower their forecasts for first-quarter gross domestic product figures to be released tomorrow. However, experts say these cost-cutting measures should improve corporate profitability later this year even if sales do not improve dramatically. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: TRACES OF TERROR: THE CHARITY
description: A federal appeals court refused yesterday to dismiss a suit against a group of Islamic charities accused of supporting terrorism, saying the parents of an Israeli-American killed in a terrorist attack have a right to sue the charities for damages.

title: Paul Gottlieb, Longtime Publisher of Art Books, Dies at 67
description: Paul Gottlieb, the former publisher and editor in chief of Harry N. Abrams, who helped bring lavishly illustrated fine-art books to a mainstream audience, died yesterday at his home in New York. He was 67.

title: Reclaiming Art Caught in the Cuban Revolution; In Cases Reminiscent of Looted Nazi Art, migrs Trace Fate of Their Collections
description: As a young bachelor architect in Havana, Manuel De La Torre used to buy paintings from his artist friends, members of a small circle later known as the Cuban avant-garde. ''Whenever I had a good commission on a building, I would buy a painting,'' recalled Mr. De La Torre, now 84. ''When I married, I wanted to have a good home with good paintings and sculptures.''

title: Questions About Arthritis Drugs
description: The saga of two costly and heavily promoted drugs to relieve the pain of arthritis gets more disturbing with each passing revelation. The two drugs -- Celebrex and Vioxx -- have been touted as better alternatives to such over-the-counter medicines as ibuprofen and other anti-inflammatories. Yet there is no evidence they are any more effective at relieving pain, and there is increasing evidence that their supposed main virtue -- that they cause fewer side effects -- has been oversold, especially in the case of Celebrex.

title: Red Cross Works to Renew Confidence Among Donors
description: The American National Red Cross announced sweeping changes today to its fund-raising practices, which came under intense criticism after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Youth and Inexperience Are Not Slowing Down Hurricanes
description: When you are the captain of the underdog team and you score the winning goal in overtime in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals, you have a full day to crack wise. Being a hockey player, Ron Francis of the Carolina Hurricanes understands that his sport requires its heroes to practice self-deprecating humor and accept teasing from younger teammates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERBERICH, E.
description: HERBERICH-E. Alfred on June 3 at Yarmouthport, MA. Senior Vice President and Director of the Exxon Chemical Company. Services Saturday, June 15 at 2 PM at the Westfield Presbyterian Church.

title: Bush Aide Reveals Worry Over Loss of Adviser
description: Andrew H. Card Jr., the White House chief of staff, is anguished over the announced departure of the presidential adviser Karen P. Hughes, saying she had been an essential counterweight to Karl Rove, a hard-charging and more ideological adviser, according to Esquire magazine.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: VOTE ON HOLLYWOOD'S FATE

title: King of Pop Wants A Promotion Budget Fit for a Jackson
description: Michael Jackson, once the king of pop music, has a beef with the Sony Music Group, his recording company. He is unhappy, say people close to him, with how Sony's Epic label promoted his most recent album, ''Invincible,'' which sold only two million copies in the United States and five million worldwide.

title: This Visit to Staples, Martin Is Healthy
description: LOS ANGELES, June 4 — Coming to Staples Center in June is not a new experience for Kenyon Martin. He has been here the last two years.

title: From Yesterday And the Time Before That
description: The 20th-Century Furniture and Objects Fair is today through Sunday in Paris. Forty galleries, bookstores and antiques dealers from Europe and the United States are attending the event, the first fair of international scale dedicated to 20th-century decorative arts. The organizer, Rik Gadella, said galleries specializing in the 20th century ''don't want to be mixed with all kinds of antiques.'' The contingent from New York includes A/D, Antik, Galerie de Beyrie, Barry Friedman and R 20th Century. The Swedish hanging lamp at right dates from 1923, and is $14,115. Carrousel du Louvre, 99, rue de Rivoli; www.xxsiecle.com.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: New Business Products From SAP
description: Europe's No. 1 software maker, SAP of Germany, said yesterday that it would introduce more products for small and midsize businesses. The effort will help SAP fend off a challenge from Microsoft, which by its recent plans to acquire Navision and its purchase of Great Plains Software, now offers a wide range of products to small businesses. Speaking at the company's annual conference in Orlando, Fla., Hasso Plattner, the co-chief executive of SAP, also reiterated financial projections for the year. In mid-April the company posted a 40 percent drop in earnings in the first quarter and forecast that its sales would grow about 15 percent during 2002. SAP's American shares, which have declined more than 16 percent this year, closed yesterday at $26.65, up 38 cents, or 1.4 percent. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDLANDER, KURT A.
description: FRIEDLANDER-Kurt A. 6/6/99. 3 sad years have passed since losing a wonderful husband & father. You are missed and loved so much, more than words can say. Pie and Poohsie

title: Militant's Claim: Arafat Can't End Attacks
description: If there is one thing that the Palestinian militant group Islamic Jihad does not fear, one of its leaders said today, it is the repressive force of Yasir Arafat and his Palestinian Authority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, PHILIP A., D.D.S.
description: MORSE-Philip A., D.D.S. On June 4, 2002. Beloved and adored husband of Doris. Loving father of Merry, Lee and Robyn. Gentle and caring grandfather of Ilana. Service at Temple Israel, Pinebrook Blvd, New Rochelle, N.Y. Thursday, June 6th, 12 Noon. Interment Mount Pleasant Cemetery.

title: Bush Proposes Restructuring of Homeland Security
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  President Bush told the American people tonight that he wants to create a Cabinet-level domestic security office in what the White House says would be the biggest government reorganization in more than a half-century.

title: A Face for Cosmetics That Changes Regularly
description: The French makeup artist Stphane Marais, below, has opened a flagship store near the Tuileries that was done by the Milanese architect and designer Sergio Calatroni. (Stores in London, Berlin and Milan will open in September, and next year in New York.) In Paris, the gallerylike atmosphere is punctuated with mobile furnishings. Photographs, drawings and graphics will transform the shop, at bottom, every three months. ''We wanted something outside the marketing rules of big cosmetic companies, something creative, stimulating and open,'' Mr. Calatroni said. Stephanemarais is at 217, rue St.-Honor; (011) 33-01.42.61.73.22.

title: The Tools of a Titled Green Thumb
description: Founded by a real prince, Louis-Albert de Broglie, Le Prince Jardinier sells garden tools and accessories that are coveted by elegant European gardeners like Prince Charles. The store, in the garden arcade of the Palais Royal, carries handmade pruning shears ($75), spades with polished wooden handles ($150), oak and zinc buckets ($225), stainless-steel watering cans ($85 to $120), aprons ($60), hats ($30), shirts ($38), dungarees ($90) and canvas gardening vests ($115). Now, Prince de Broglie has bought Deyrolle, a venerable shop on the Rue du Bac famous for taxidermy and scientific prints and adored by academics and decorators alike. In New York, Le Prince Jardinier is available at at Treillage, 418 East 75th Street; (212) 535-2288.

title: Sapporo Braces Itself For Match
description: Ichiro Sato looks more like an elder statesman than a potential vigilante. In a blue suit and yellow tie, Sato, a 70-year-old businessman, appears the pillar of the community, a proud member of the local Lions Club. But when it comes to Susukino, this city's entertainment district, he is downright defensive.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Gay Adoption
description: The only county court in the state that permits adoptions by gay couples has halted the practice after several judges from across the state complained that it violated the law. The chief judge of Washtenaw County Court, Archie Brown, told judges to cease processing adoption applications from all unwed couples. Though Michigan has no law banning adoptions by gay couples, its statute permits only married couples and single individuals to adopt. Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

title: Former Trader Indicted On Bank Fraud Charges
description: The currency trader who hid losses of $691 million for five years was indicted today on seven counts involving bank fraud and making false financial entries.

title: Insider Women With Outsider Values
description: It's hard to imagine a less likely fictional plot than the true story of Coleen Rowley. A memo from a Minneapolis suburban mother of four calls into question the accountability of one of the country's most impenetrable government agencies, the F.B.I. And by sending this memo, 30 years after the bureau hired its first woman agent, a woman becomes a key player in the overhaul of an institution whose structure and priorities have largely gone unquestioned since the time of J. Edgar Hoover.

title: SoHo Design Store Closes After 20 Years
description: AD HOC SOFTWARES, the original resource for industrial-style housewares, is going out of business on June 23. The closing comes two years after its unsuccessful move off West Broadway, SoHo's main shopping drag.

title: Health, Downtown
description: To the Editor:

title: With AOL Linkage and Speed, New Netscape Jabs at the Giant
description: Not so long ago, the release of a new version of a Web browser was a big event. Netscape was the early leader in the field, but after a game of catch-up, Microsoft's Internet Explorer now commands almost 70 percent of the browser market, according to the research firm Jupiter Media Metrix. (Some researchers put Microsoft's market share at more than 90 percent.)

title: Some European Catholics Find Fault With U.S. Bishops' Proposal on Abuse Problem
description: The Vatican had no formal reaction to the American bishops' proposals for dealing with sexual abuse by clergy members, saying the text presented on Tuesday was a working draft. But church officials here and in other European countries indicated today that at least some of the proposals were expected to be viewed critically here, including requirements that bishops inform law enforcement officials and that the pope be called upon to defrock priests who abuse minors.

title: Defying Crackdown, North Koreans Stream Into China
description: Late last month a young North Korean conducted reconnaissance in Beijing's embassy district, once a serene tree-lined oasis of stately buildings, now laced with barbed wire and dotted with roadblocks.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Orange: Suspect In Shooting Surrenders
description: A shooting suspect who escaped from a locked holding cell on Monday night turned himself in yesterday, the authorities said. The suspect, Khalid Fate, 26, surrendered to officers at the East Orange Police Department's headquarters around 10:45 a.m. The authorities said Mr. Fate had escaped a locked cell where he was being held in the shooting of Officer Michael Allman during a robbery at a convenience store last week. It was not immediately clear how Mr. Fate, of Newark, escaped or why he surrendered so quickly, the authorities said. They said he was the getaway driver during the robbery at the Topps Quik Mart in which Officer Allman was shot in the arm. Two other men, Thomas Williams and Anthony Irving, have also been arrested in the shooting. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Testimony on Cuban Arms
description: The United States believes that Cuba is developing biological weapons in at least a limited way, but Washington does not have direct evidence for the charge, a senior State Department official said today.

title: Economic Scene; Productivity and profitability: an odd couple in an odd recession.
description: ONE notable feature of the recent mini-recession was the unusual behavior of productivity. Normally productivity falls during a recession and expands during a recovery. But not this time.

title: SHARES OF VERIDIAN CLIMB 13% ON FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: Stock of the Veridian Corporation, a maker of computer software used by intelligence agencies, rose 13 percent in its first day of trading, reflecting investors' interest in the military industry. The stock rose $2.15, to $18.15 a share. The company, which is based in Arlington, Va., sold 13.5 million shares at $16 each, raising $216 million. ''The government has deep pockets and they are expanding,'' said Paul Bard, an analyst with the Renaissance Capital Corporation. Veridian also makes products used to detect chemical and biological weapons and provides security services for computer networks.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Chip Sales Expected To Rise
description: Worldwide semiconductor sales are expected to rise 3.1 percent in 2002 and jump 23.2 percent in 2003, according to a midyear forecast released yesterday by an industry trade group, the Semiconductor Industry Association. The association, which represents most American chip makers, said the market was now in the initial phases of recovery after its most challenging year in history. ''Our expectation is that the recovery will gain momentum in the second half of the year and continue with strong growth through 2003 and 2004,'' said Dwight W. Decker, the chief executive of Conexant Systems and an association board member. Worldwide sales of all chips are expected to total $143 billion in 2002, $177 billion in 2003 and $213 billion -- a 20.9 percent increase -- in 2004. The growth will be led by increases in sales of cellphones and personal computers as well as other digital consumer electronics equipment.

title: Just how much did the networks get from advertisers? For once, they seem to want to tell.
description: WITH one eye on Wall Street and the other on newspaper headlines, the broadcast networks are taking a decidedly different approach this year in spreading the news about how much advertising they have sold against their fall prime-time lineups.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I cannot think of a time when business over all has been held in less repute.''

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday carried a joint byline erroneously. The sole writer was Stuart Elliott.

title: Preserving Liberty and Security; Handling Foreign Visitors
description: This need to balance tolerance and vigilance applies also to immigration policy. It is important that the country police its borders and enforce its immigration laws in a way that is both fair and effective. Unfortunately Mr. Ashcroft announced a plan yesterday that seems to lead in the wrong direction. He proposed to fingerprint tens of thousands of visitors from Muslim and Middle Eastern countries as they enter the United States. His plan would also require them to register with the government if they stay 30 days or longer. This is a poorly conceived and inadequate substitute for the serious overhaul of the immigration system that should be among Washington's most urgent priorities.

title: Software Sees the Paths Of Wireless Web Surfers
description: In these days of wireless networking, new fronts have opened up in the venerable business of gauging the collective consciousness. At a recent conference on emerging technologies organized by the technology publisher O'Reilly & Associates, Rob Flickenger, the company's systems administrator, decided to track which Web sites participants were visiting as they listened to a panel discussion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Buying a Car From Afar

title: Vacancies Reflect Conflict Over Who Runs the Schools
description: Most of the 200 parents, teachers and children who gathered at the monthly meeting of Community School Board 3 in Manhattan last month to beg, haggle and rage were there for the same reason: They needed leadership in their schools.

title: 'Freedom to Farm' Law Becomes Freedom to Add Subsidies
description: Farmers who raise lentils, a crop so ancient it is mentioned in the Book of Genesis, have survived for years without government assistance. But Congress has decided they need a little help.

title: National Briefing | Labor: New Chief For Auto Workers
description: Members of the United Automobile Workers elected Ron Gettelfinger as president, a move expected since last year. Mr. Gettelfinger, 57, will replace Stephen Yokich, who is retiring. He takes over a shrinking union that has been unable to organize a plant solely owned by a foreign automaker. Mr. Gettelfinger had led relations with the Ford Motor Company. The union also elected Elizabeth Bunn as secretary-treasurer, making her the highest-ranking woman in its history. Danny Hakim (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: USA INTERACTIVE SAYS IT WON'T RAISE BIDS USA Interactive, Barry Diller's TV shopping and Internet conglomerate, said yesterday that it was pulling back  somewhat  from its $4.5 billion plan, announced on Monday, to buy all the remaining shares of three companies in which it holds a controlling stake: Expedia, Hotels.com, and Ticketmaster. On Monday, USA said it hoped to begin an offer to exchange its shares for those of the three companies in the near future. But USA's shares fell nearly 13 percent on Monday as those of the target companies rose, causing some investors to demand USA raise its offers. Yesterday, USA released a statement saying that "circumstances may change, but we have no intention of increasing" the bids and that it would not begin the offer in the near future. In an interview, Mr. Diller said the company remained committed to buying all of each of the companies. "This could take two months or two years," he said. "We are never withdrawing." Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: German Politician Forced Out Over Remarks Offensive to Jews
description: BERLIN, June 6  In an awkward effort to restore credibility and control over his own Free Democratic Party, Guido Westerwelle today engineered the resignation of a party politician who had compared Israel's tactics in the West Bank to "Nazi methods" and complained of "the influence of the Zionist lobby" in the world's news media.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Barrington: Two Shot After Car Chase
description: Two men were shot by Camden police officers yesterday after leading the authorities on a seven-mile car chase through southern New Jersey. The wounded driver, Timothy Carlson, 35, of Runnemede, was listed in critical condition at Cooper Hospital. The passenger, Ralph J. White, 44, of Camden, was treated at the same hospital and released. Officers spotted the men at 4:52 a.m. in a car bearing plates for a vehicle that had been reported stolen, the authorities said. Officers pursued them to a dead-end street in Barrington, where they approached the car on foot. Suddenly, the driver turned the vehicle and struck Sgt. James Revelli, whose leg was injured slightly, the police said. Other officers fired on the car, wounding the two men. Both men face charges of eluding the police and receiving stolen property. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: KRAFT FOODS DISCUSSES PURCHASE OF MEXICAN JUICE MAKER
description: Kraft Foods Inc., a unit of the Philip Morris Companies, is in talks with Jugos del Valle of Mexico over the possible acquisition of the company, Mexico's largest juice maker. Jugos, which operates 10 plants, began negotiations with Kraft after PepsiCo broke off talks with it in January. ''Kraft sees Jugos as a possible acquisition alternative, but it's still not definite,'' said Alfredo Huerta, director of investor relations for Jugos. Mr. Huerta said negotiations had just started and that Jugos was not holding talks with any other company. Sales by the juice maker rose 14 percent last year, to $385 million.

title: City Hall Memo; Battles Loom, but Bloomberg Keeps Voice and Profile Low
description: Yesterday, the official deadline for closing a gap of more than $5 billion in the city budget was hours away, and the City Council scrambled as it approached. State and city lawmakers pondered the final details of a historic agreement to give the mayor control of the public school system. And schoolteachers continued to threaten to strike.

title: Mathis Still Questionable
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 6  When he appeared for warmups before Wednesday's World Cup opener, Clint Mathis sported a Mohawk haircut. However, his hair was not shaved nearly as much as his playing time.

title: Violent Mexico Kidnapper Held After a Nine-Month Manhunt
description: MEXICO CITY, June 6  After years of sowing fear, the man considered to be one of Mexico's most violent kidnappers is under arrest.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Freeze Sought In Special School Aid
description: The New Jersey Department of Education has asked the State Supreme Court to allow a freeze on special payments to aid poor schools. The request came despite the court's mandate in the landmark Abbott v. Burke school financing case that the state pay for the special needs of 30 low-income districts. The request to freeze $400 million in aid to the districts follows efforts by Gov. James E. McGreevey to close a budget deficit. Lawyers for three Abbott districts -- Passaic, New Brunswick and Neptune -- argued against the request, insisting they might have to lay off staff members or cancel programs if the freeze is imposed. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Judges Are Told To Aid Children Who Immigrate To U.S. Alone
description: The head of the American Bar Association said today that he would urge immigration judges to take a more active role in ensuring that children who arrive in the United States without any relative or guardian get appropriate legal protection.

title: Deal Reached in Windows on World Dispute
description: David Emil, the president of the company that ran Windows on the World, opened his Latin-themed restaurant, Noche, last night after settling a dispute with former Windows workers who had complained that Noche had not hired enough of them.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: EDUCATION BOARD REBUKES LEVY

title: Vacant Stares for Mets During a Vicious Cycle
description: Scott Strickland sat facing his locker, staring at the right hand that had just surrendered a game-winning home run to the Atlanta Braves. Jeromy Burnitz was a few feet away, a bundle of frustration. Across the room, John Valentin faced an otherwise vacant and quiet Mets clubhouse, his head in his hands.

title: Go Ahead, Make Her Day
description: Anissa Mack, a performance artist, is inviting thieves to steal pies from her windowsill in a live art piece on display at the Brooklyn Public Library.

title: Abortion Foe Fights Charges In Killing Of Doctor
description: More than three years after a doctor who performed abortions was killed by a sniper near here, the man accused of the crime was extradited from France and whisked today to a federal courthouse where he proclaimed his innocence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAIGELMAN, HENRY C.
description: BAIGELMAN-Henry C. June 2, 2002, beloved husband, father, grandfather, and uncle. Born in Lodz, Poland in 1911, survived World War II in The Lodz Ghetto, and was a survivor of Auschwitz. Married for fifty-five years to his wife, Gita, also a survivor. A talented violinist, composer and band leader, he performed for U.S. Troops and DP Camps in post-war Germany. Was successful in New York real estate. He is survived by his wife, Gita, children, Riva Berelson, and Simone Baigelman, grandchildren Serj Berelson, Selina, Aron, and Abby Baigelman. We will all miss his wit, determination, devotion and love.

title: Waksal Kin Said to Sell ImClone Shares
description: ImClone Systems has found that more than one relative of its former chief executive, Samuel D. Waksal, sold shares in the days before the company received an unfavorable ruling from the Food and Drug Administration, two people close to the situation said.

title: NATO Must Attack Terrorists Before They Hit, Rumsfeld Says
description: BRUSSELS, June 6  As NATO seeks to maintain relevance as a military alliance, it must take the war on terrorism to the terrorists by pre-emptive attacks on shadowy networks or hostile states armed with biological, chemical or nuclear weapons, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today.

title: The Brooklyn Guy and the Movie Guy: It's a Mobster Scenario
description: It sounds like a story pitch some writer might have made to a studio boss in Hollywood last night.

title: In a Sampler, The Moods Have Unease In Common
description: Johannes Wieland, a dancer who has studied and performed in Switzerland, the Netherlands and his native Germany, offered his first full New York program of choreography on Sunday night at the Joyce SoHo. The dances made one curious to see more by him.

title: India Success In Software Is Set Back By War Talk
description: The tensions and war fears mounting in South Asia are taking a toll on one of India's major economic success stories, its software industry.

title: Sleep With the Crayfish, Ditch the Alarm Clock
description: OYSTER

title: Delayed for Days, Shuttle Liftoff Sends Crew of 7 to Space Station
description: The space shuttle Endeavour blasted off this afternoon for the International Space Station, setting out on a 12-day mission to ferry a new resident crew to the station and erect a mobile base for a construction crane.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, BARBARA
description: COHEN - Barbara. Dearest friend and sister, I will miss you forever. Joyce

title: From Dream Team at Tyco To a Refrain of Dennis Who?
description: They were Dennis and Mark, Mark and Dennis, a team as closely linked as any chief executive and chief financial officer in the United States. On Wall Street, analysts and investors joked that they were the only two people who really understood the maze of acquisitions that built Tyco International Ltd. into a $36 billion giant. And when Dennis created a trust to buy a house on Nantucket, he named Mark as trustee.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Norwalk: Skakel Jury Rehears Testimony
description: On its second day of deliberations, the jury in the murder trial of Michael C. Skakel yesterday requested to rehear testimony of several key witnesses and seemed to focus on questions about Mr. Skakel's alibi on the night Martha Moxley was bludgeoned to death. The day of deliberations was punctuated by the surprise courtroom appearance of Thomas Skakel, an older brother, who was himself a longtime suspect in the 1975 killing. It was his first appearance at any court proceeding since his brother's arrest two years ago. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: The 'Jihad' Uproar at Harvard
description: To the Editor:

title: A Motion by Agassi, And the Match Stops
description: Juan Carlos Ferrero was concocting a devilish blend of drop shots and forehand winners in a cold drizzle when Andre Agassi ended the young Spaniard's assault with the crook of his finger.

title: KPNQwest Lays Off a Third Of Dutch Headquarters Staff
description: KPNQwest laid off nearly one-third of its employees in the Netherlands today, moving the embattled company, which owns Europe's largest fiber optic network, a step closer to collapse.

title: 'Dear Doctor' Meets 'Return To Sender'
description: DR. ADAM SCHNEIDER, an internist in Austin, Tex., is as computer-adept a doctor as you are likely to find. He uses a Compaq iPaq hand-held for quick access to reference materials and medical records and to navigate the Web. He has three computers at home, and he is the one who configures all the computers for his practice.

title: Poor Visibility Caused Crash That Killed A Governor
description: A plane carrying Gov. Mel Carnahan of Missouri on a campaign flight crashed in October 2000 because the pilot became disoriented in poor visibility, the National Transportation Safety Board said today. The crash killed all three aboard the plane.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Consulting Units Bought
description: Atos Origin, a French information technology company, said that it had agreed to buy the consulting businesses of KPMG in Britain and the Netherlands for 657 million euros ($617 billion) in cash and bonds that can be redeemable for Atos shares. The combined company would have 30,000 employees in more than 30 countries and would give Atos a foothold in the British market, as well as making it a leader among Dutch consulting firms, the company said. The transaction is subject to the approval of partners, shareholders and regulators. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: 2 Rooms, River View, A.T.M. in Lobby
description: AUTOMATED teller machines have become so common, it now seems there are almost as many places to get cash as to spend it. Convenience stores, nightclubs and office buildings are all well supplied with A.T.M.'s. In a few big cities, cash machines have even begun popping up in the lobbies of large apartment buildings.

title: One Horse Races nor History, and 11 Race to Deny It
description: War Emblem is on the doorstep of becoming the 12th Triple Crown winner and the first since Affirmed in 1978. In the 134th running of the Belmont Stakes, he has the look of a winner, and sits atop a field of 12 that was handicapped by Joe Drape, who provided the comments and listed the horses in order of preference. The morning line odds are by Don LaPlace, the Belmont Park handicapper.

title: Nets Comforted by West Coast Ties
description: LOS ANGELES, June 5 — East is only east, as the N.B.A.'s Western Conference teams have been quick to remind their challengers since Michael Jordan left the Chicago Bulls.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: A Sinn Fein Lord Mayor
description: The Belfast City Council elected Alex Maskey as the first lord mayor from Sinn Fein, the political party of the Irish Republican Army. Mr. Maskey, 50, was jailed twice as an I.R.A. suspect in the 1970's and shot in the stomach at his home in 1987, one of many attempts on his life. He became Sinn Fein's first councilman in 1983 and for years his attempts to speak provoked walkouts and choruses of catcalls. The once predominantly Protestant 51-member council now has 14 Sinn Fein members. It chose its first Roman Catholic mayor, Alban Maginness of the moderate Social Democratic and Labor Party, in 1997. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Wrecker, Pass That Landmark By
description: MORE than a century ago, thousands of sturdy 65-foot wooden sloops called skipjacks cast off each dawn from docks along Maryland's Eastern Shore. The boats were designed with only one task in mind: to dredge the bottom of Chesapeake Bay for oysters -- and they did it superbly.

title: Yankees Try Using Rookie in Right Field
description: Shane Spencer and John Vander Wal have combined to bat .265 with 4 home runs and 23 runs batted in for the Yankees this season, which are better statistics than Mo Vaughn has with the Mets. But in the always demanding and pressurized world of George Steinbrenner, those numbers were too flimsy, so the Yankees suddenly have a new right fielder.

title: Questions Raised Over Energy Dept. Official's Industry Ties
description: Before he was named under secretary of energy by President Bush last year, Robert G. Card was a top executive of the companies whose multibillion-dollar contracts his office now controls. Those companies performed some of the nation's most sensitive and expensive jobs, cleaning up highly toxic waste from nuclear weapons factories.

title: McCall Urges Upstate Voice in 9/11 Recovery Agency
description: H. Carl McCall said yesterday that upstate and suburban New Yorkers should have a direct say in planning the reconstruction of Lower Manhattan, and that the state agency overseeing the rebuilding effort should be enlarged to include members from outside New York City.

title: Boy's Body Found in Pool Police Never Entered
description: When 7-year-old Paolo Alexander Ayala disappeared from a friend's birthday party in the exclusive neighborhood of Holmby Hills on Sunday afternoon, the police began an extensive search of the area.

title: Els Thinks It's Time To Pull Up His Socks
description: Ernie Els believes strongly that he is a better player today than he was five years ago. So why hasn't he won a major championship since 1997? Why did he go the entire 2001 season without winning on the PGA Tour?

title: Repaired Hubble Telescope Yields Better Look at the Stars
description: With one of its principal cameras revived after three years of inactivity, the Hubble Space Telescope has now resumed infrared observations of the universe with even greater sensitivity than before, peering deeply through obscuring dust into the hearts of galaxies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, MURRAY
description: KATZ-Murray. Beloved husband of Loretta. Devoted father of Philip (Leilani), Steven, Cathy Fisher (Steven), Lori Zaintz (Marc) and Suzy. Cherished grandfather of Zak, Hilary and Richard. Dear brother Allen (Eleanor) and the late Blanche Finkel (Alfred). Services on Friday at 1 P.M., ''Sinai Chapels,'' 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Notes From Ground Zero
description: Weekly highlights from 150 forums  from observations about the ground zero memorial to sports overload.

title: Several U.S. Allies Criticized in Powell Report on Slave Trading
description: South Korea, Romania and Israel all stepped up efforts to stop slave trafficking within their borders last year, but some of the United States' closest allies, including Turkey, Saudi Arabia and several Persian Gulf states, did not, according to a State Department report issued today.

title: Comptroller Criticizes New York City's Animal Shelters
description: Asharp difference of opinion has emerged between two New York City agencies on whether animals are properly cared for at shelters under contract to the city.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about India's rejection of an effort by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to defuse its military standoff with Pakistan gave an erroneous year in some copies for the Cuban missile crisis, which Mr. Putin cited as an example of the way a nuclear war was avoided. It was 1962, not 1961.

title: Life's Learning Experiences, Etched Forever in Memory
description: Many players have a sad memory of one that got away imprinted on their bridge psyche. For this columnist, it happened more than half a century ago, in my first international championship. The contract was three no-trump, and the defense had four obvious tricks. The only possible fifth was in a suit in which I held Q-x-x and my partner J-x-x. I hit on the rare lead of the queen, deceiving the declarer, and my partner eventually scored his jack. But he then failed to find the play to cash our five tricks.

title: A Year of Squeezing 6 Into 4; Students Embrace City's Early-College Experiment
description: For many students, the last year or two of high school feel like a waste.

title: World Briefing | Australia: Standing With U.S. On Warming Accord
description: Despite ratification of a climate treaty by Japan and the European Union recently, Prime Minister John Howard of Australia told Parliament he would continue to oppose it unless the United States signed on. Last year President Bush rejected the treaty and has not wavered. If enacted, the treaty, the Kyoto Protocol, would require industrialized countries to cut emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases by 2012 below levels measured in 1990. Environmentalists are pressing Mr. Howard to embrace the pact, but -- echoing the views of Mr. Bush -- he says it would harm the economy.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with a front-page article about President Bush's commencement address at West Point misidentified the cadet shown with Mr. Bush. She was Nicole R. Robbins, not the valedictorian, Erica Watson.

title: Australia's Premier Poet Receives Musical Tribute
description: Songs bring together literature and music -- and using an evening of songs to spotlight both new music and the works of a single poet, juxtaposing his own readings with musical settings of his poetry, is a very good idea. But at the celebration of the poet Les Murray on Sunday evening, part of the Works and Process series at the Guggenheim Museum, the two worlds seemed less to join than to collide.

title: Go Ahead, Make Her Day
description: Anissa Mack, a performance artist, is inviting thieves to steal pies from her windowsill in a live art piece on display at the Brooklyn Public Library.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Netbank Plans To Offer Insurance
description: NetBank Inc., a financial services and holding company for NetBank, the country's largest independent Internet bank, said it would expand into the insurance market. The company, based in Alpharetta, Ga., said it planned to offer property and casualty insurance, underwritten by major national insurance companies, through its family of businesses: NetBank, RBMG Inc., the Market Street Mortgage Corporation and the Meritage Mortgage Corporation. After NetInsurance.com filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy protection, NetBank bought select assets of the company. E. Robeson MacKethan, the founder and former president of NetInsurance, will serve as president of NetBank's insurance operations, officials said.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Sentence For Fraud
description: Mel Spillman, a former probate clerk in San Antonio who pleaded guilty to bilking nearly $5 million from the estates of at least 122 people, was sentenced to 10 years in prison and ordered to pay a $10,000 fine. Mr. Spillman forged documents to have himself named as temporary administrator for people who died without apparent heirs. He then kept nearly all of their money and bankrolled his penchant for Ferraris -- he bought five. Mr. Spillman, who made only $33,000 a year as a clerk, told co-workers that he had inherited money from relatives. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Bush Intervenes In Effort to Stop A Kashmir War
description: President Bush directly intervened today in the effort to keep India and Pakistan from going to war, calling the leaders of the nuclear-armed rivals and urging them to listen to new proposals that two of his envoys will be delivering in the next few days.

title: King Nervous About Women's Sports
description: In accepting an award for her powerful role in the women's sports movement, Billie Jean King struck a cautionary tone yesterday, pointing out ''the playing field is far from level'' and adding that sentiment expressed by some lawmakers and men's sports advocates to reinterpret Title IX ''makes me nervous.''

title: The Starbucks Invasion: Next Stop Paris?
description: To the Editor:

title: An Astonishing Move by the Rangers
description: The Rangers have made little good news during recent seasons, but they sure do create a stir when they don't play. This year is no exception with the expected hiring today of Bryan Trottier as head coach. Even by the risky standards of the Rangers, the move is astonishing. Trottier is a high-strung, tightly wrapped person with a vast history of tremendous successes and humiliating failures.

title: The 'Jihad' Uproar at Harvard
description: To the Editor:

title: American Envoy Meets with President of Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 6  Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage sounded a positive note today after meetings at which Pakistani officials said the American envoy used blunt talk and made detailed demands.

title: Kidd's Efforts Are Not Enough
description: LOS ANGELES, June 5  Jason Kidd must have felt as if he had gone back in time, as if he were back in the purple and orange of the Phoenix Suns, back to fighting a battle his team was ill-equipped to win. What he experienced tonight in the Nets' 99-94 loss to the Los Angeles Lakers was what he experienced in his previous five seasons in the Western Conference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMAN, CHARLES
description: SCHUMAN - Charles. The Bard College community mourns the passing of Charles Schuman, who for many years served with dedication and distinction as Bard's public relations director. His warmth, wit, and skill served the college well, and he was regarded throughout the Bard community as a respected colleague and a loyal friend. We send our deepest condolences to his family. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab II, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, ANNA K.
description: BENNETT-Anna K., 89, June 4, 2002 in Richmond, VA, formerly of Neponsit, NY. She will be greatly missed by her daughter and son-in-law, Naomi and Mark Finkel, and grandsons Jason, Adam and Jonathan. Brooklyn College grad and NYC school teacher. Burial Old Montefiore, Elmont, NY, Friday, 10:30AM.

title: Moving Up the Ballet Company Ranks
description: American Ballet Theater and the New York City Ballet have announced the promotions of nine dancers, effective immediately. At Ballet Theater, Gillian Murphy and Marcelo Gomes have been named principal dancers, with Maria Riccetto and Gennadi Saveliev promoted from corps de ballet to soloist. Monique Meunier, a City Ballet principal, will join Ballet Theater as a soloist. Ballet Theater performs at the Metropolitan Opera House through July 6.

title: The Next Attack
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Census Bureau statistics on the number of families living in poverty misstated the name of the organization that analyzed the numbers by county to determine levels of child poverty. It is the Children's Defense Fund, not the Children's Fund.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Oil Pipeline Planned
description: Europe's biggest oil company, BP P.L.C., and its partners agreed to build a $2.9 billion pipeline across Turkey to move Caspian Sea oil to world markets, ending more than eight years of debate. The partners, which include Eni of Italy, Statoil of Norway and Unocal of the United States, have completed all the agreements to start construction and will make a final decision later this month, the project director, Philip Allison, said at a conference in Baku, Azerbaijan. The 1,090-mile line will link fields containing as many as 40 billion barrels of oil with the Mediterranean Sea port of Ceyhan.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Set To Introduce New Technology
description: Microsoft will introduce a new technology today called TrustBridge as part of its revised .Net Web services strategy. Both Microsoft's Passport identity system and its HailStorm consumer services proposal have been criticized by competitors and consumer advocates for their potential threat to privacy and because they were designed to lock customers into Microsoft. More recently, Microsoft has taken a new approach that supports sharing management of identity services among competing companies. The company says the technology will become increasingly useful as users connect from one consumer service to another on the Internet and as business increasingly automates buying and selling operations. John Markoff (NYT)

title: Cardinal Read Accusatory Letter in '85, 3 Say
description: Answering questions in the case of a priest accused of repeatedly molesting boys, Cardinal Bernard F. Law acknowledged in a deposition today that he had read a letter from 1985 that complained that the priest was advocating sex between men and boys, two plaintiffs and a lawyer who attended the deposition said.

title: International Hangout; From Videos to Playful Votes: Soccer Central
description: WHEN it comes to following the 2002 World Cup finals on the Internet, FIFA, soccer's governing body, owns the clicks to the kingdom.

title: First Taste of Summer, Fresh Off the Vine
description: PART of me still thinks it's a mistake to admit openly to my clandestine efforts to farm the bushy, overgrown strip of public land that runs down the middle of my street.

title: Joys of Digital Darkrooms
description: To the Editor:

title: Chilling Portrait of Lindh Drawn In Prosecutors' Pretrial Motions
description: The government painted a chilling portrait of John Walker Lindh this week, describing him in pretrial motions as someone who bears some responsibility for the Sept. 11 attacks and for the death of Johnny Micheal Spann, a Central Intelligence Agency officer, in a prison uprising in Afghanistan.

title: New Tone, Old Goal
description: As the capital wakes up almost daily to disclosures about intelligence warnings before Sept. 11, the White House has abruptly switched its strategy of mounting ferocious partisan assaults on Democrats to one of self-inoculation -- admitting past mistakes and preparing for more bad news to come.

title: EFUNDS REDUCES ESTIMATES ON REVENUE AND PROFIT
description: The eFunds Corporation, a provider of electronic-payment services, cut its revenue and profit forecasts for the rest of the year and said its chief financial officer would leave at the end of this month, setting off a 30 percent decline in its stock price. EFunds projected revenue of $130 million to $134 million and profit of 11 cents to 18 cents a share in the second quarter, down from its earlier forecast of $139 million to $145 million in revenue and 24 cents to 26 cents. The company, which is based in Scottsdale, Ariz., made the forecast after the close of trading Tuesday. Shares of EFunds fell $3.93, to $9.32. The company did not say why the financial officer, Paul H. Bristow, was leaving.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Ex-Mayor To Fight Corruption
description: Jan Kasl, who resigned last week as mayor of Prague, vowed to return to City Hall on a reform ticket in elections this fall and to fight official corruption. Mr. Kasl resigned and quit his center-right party last week after accusing City Council members of blocking anticorruption reforms. Mr. Kasl is seen as a contender to succeed President Vaclav Havel when his final term expires in January. Parliamentary elections are set for June 15 and 16, and Mr. Kasl's Civic Democrats are in a tight race with the governing Social Democrats. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Turmoil At School
description: After several incidents of sexual misconduct and assault, the Milton Hershey School, a free residential school for disadvantaged children in Hershey, has announced plans to add staff, increase security and supervision, and delay its planned expansion to 1,500 students from 1,200. Tamar Lewin (NYT)

title: A Novel's Jab Is Rattling Book World In Germany
description: Martin Walser, one of modern Germany's finest novelists, has always embraced controversy as the price of moral literature.

title: Critical F.B.I. Agent Tells of Need for Reform in Bureau
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  The F.B.I. agent whose criticism of the bureau's pre-Sept. 11 performance has caused a political storm in Washington testified today that dozens of other agents across the country have told her they too believe the agency is cumbersome and that cases are needlessly stalled.

title: When Their Caps Beep, Swimmers Find Rhythm
description: AT the edge of a sun-drenched Olympic-size pool here, members of the Stanford women's swimming team awaited a go-ahead signal from their coach, Richard Quick, as he introduced the next drill.

title: Keeping Belmont's Track Fit for the Triple Crown
description: HIGH above Belmont Park, where his glassed-in office overlooks the mile and 7/16 pole and is privy to every finish-line mini-drama, Gerard B. Porcelli is not quite king of all he surveys. But he is, finally, the track superintendent, courtesy of a three-decade trudge up the union ladder. Actually, he hit the track trifecta: Mr. Porcelli's purview extends to Aqueduct and Saratoga, too.

title: Adorning the Patio Without Leaving It
description: IF the rosebushes need controlling or you long to create a temporary patio on the lawn, relax, pour a glass of iced tea and sit down and shop. No need to search the interminable aisles of garden supply centers. A variety of gates, fences, trellises and garden tiles can be found on Web sites and in catalogs. With all that's available, you might never have to leave the backyard.

Putin of Russia to defuse its military standoff with Pakistan gave an erroneous year in some copies for the Cuban missile crisis, which Mr. Putin cited as an example of the way a nuclear war was avoided. description: GOGGINS-Bertha C. On June 5, 2002. Survived by Hubert Baxter, Joyce Howard, Mary Perillo, Marilyn Sattler, Patricia Smith, Debby Weiss and James Wylie. She was the former historian of the Village of Saltaire, Fire Island, NY. Visitation today 2-4 and 79PM at the White-Voltz Funeral Home, 364 East Main St, Bay Shore, NY. title: MSNBC Signs 'Hardball' Host Into 2009
description: Chris Matthews, the host of MSNBC's talk show ''Hardball With Chris Matthews,'' has agreed to stay with the network through June 2009, MSNBC announced yesterday.
