description: Following is part two of the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on counterterrorism on June 6, 2002, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Stake For Sale
description: Goldman Sachs plans to sell half of the 6.82 percent stake that it acquired in Kookmin Bank during an economic crisis in Asia in 1999. The bank said Goldman Sachs would sell 11 million shares in the form of American depository receipts that it would list on the New York Stock Exchange. Goldman Sachs paid $500 million for the shares, whose value now is about $1.5 billion. The price of shares in Kookmin, the largest bank in Korea, fell 4.6 percent on the Korea Stock Exchange after the announcement. Goldman is the bank's largest shareholder after the government, which holds 9.62 percent of the shares. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: At Allen Trial, Investor Testifies Agreement Was Oral, at Dinner
description: The main investor for eight Woody Allen films testified yesterday that his business arrangements with Mr. Allen were rooted in an oral agreement made during a brief dinner chat.

title: Ebensburg Journal; Traffic Ticket Spurs Fight on Religion
description: It was a picturesque scene as 22-year-old Jonas Swartzentruber, a typically shy member of an ultra-plain sect of the Old Order Amish, guided his horse and buggy along Lemon Drop Road while S.U.V.'s and other engines of modernity passed him by.

title: Accord Nears To Give Mayor School Control
description: With possibly just one last sticking point delaying an agreement to give Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg control of New York City's vast school system, Mr. Bloomberg and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver are to meet this morning in hopes of reaching a quick compromise on the historic deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLER, EDWARD
description: GALLER-Edward. Beloved husband of Ruth and the late Anne. Devoted father of Randy and Dr. Steven. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer and Brian. Dear brother of Lillian Miller. Services today, 12:30PM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Corrections
description: A schedule for the N.B.A. finals on the first sports page yesterday misstated the sites for the potential fifth and six games. Game 5 would be played in New Jersey and Game 6 in Los Angeles.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Ex-Guerrillas Enter Politics
description: The leader of last year's ethnic Albanian insurgency in Macedonia formed a political party to push for enactment of minority rights reforms agreed to in a peace deal brokered by the West. Ali Ahmeti, a leader of the Albanian minority, will not stand for Parliament in elections scheduled for September but experts say he may promote stability as a political figure.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: FAMILIES IN VENTURE In a deal val- ued at $925 million between two of Southeast Asia's most prominent business families, the Philippine conglomerate JG Summit Holdings said it would form a joint venture with First Pacific of Hong Kong to buy First Pacific's Philippine assets, including a controlling stake in Philippine Long Distance Telephone and a central Manila real estate development. JG Summit is the flagship of the Philippine tycoon John Gokongwei, while First Pacific is controlled by the Salim family of Indonesia. The board of Philippine Long Distance issued a statement opposing the sale, however, saying it would violate company bylaws and would probably break antitrust laws since JG Summit controls a rival operator. Phlippine Long Distance barred employees from giving JG Summit the financial information it is likely to need to complete the purchase. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: ISRAEL: FIRST CASE OF MAD COW DISEASE The Agriculture Ministry said it had confirmed the country's first case of mad cow disease, in the Golan Heights at Ortal Kibbutz. The ministry said the sale to the Palestinian Authority of beef from cows aged over 30 months  the age when the disease manifests itself  had been banned. Veterinarians also imposed a ban on the slaughter of all cattle over that age. (Agence France-Presse)

title: U.N. on Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Budding Scientists, Let Loose in a World They Can Save
description: LATELY Chandreka Wright, 13, has been chatting with friends online while playing a computer game. This is not exactly atypical behavior for a seventh grader, except that she is chatting and playing during her science class at the James P. Timilty Middle School in Boston.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: STRYKER CORP., Kalamazoo, Mich., a maker of orthopedic devices, said it would buy Surgical Dynamics Inc., a provider of spinal implants, from Tyco International Ltd., Pembroke, Bermuda, a diversified manufacturer, for $135 million.

title: Torricelli, His Opponent Chosen, Comes Out Swinging for the Fight
description: Having quietly watched Republicans disparage his record and ethics throughout the primary season, Senator Robert G. Torricelli officially began his re-election bid today by blazing onto the offensive -- promising New Jerseyans that he would fight to keep Democrats in control of the United States Senate and to protect working families and the elderly.

title: Low Offices Are Suggested For Towers Site
description: A plan for low office buildings that could be enlarged at a later date is under consideration for the World Trade Center site, the top planner for the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, Alexander Garvin, said yesterday.

title: The New PowerBook G4: Sleek Looks and Hot Legs
description: If you see me in shorts this summer, don't ask about the burn marks on my thighs.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Jailed Journalist
description: A retired journalist, Paul Trummel, is in solitary confinement in a Seattle jail for refusing to comply with a judge's order that he delete statements on his Web site, www.contracabal.org, criticizing a residence for older people. Mr. Trummel, 69, was jailed for contempt by Judge James A. Doherty on Feb. 27. Mr. Trummel's lawyer said he was recently moved to solitary confinement in an apparent effort to restrict his access to telephones. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREISKEL, BARBARA SCOTT
description: PREISKEL-Barbara Scott. Barbara Scott Preiskel, a magnificent human being who graced our earth, physically passed away on June 4th. Her spirit, her values, her modeling and advocacy of the deep worth of every human being, and the easy good humored way she went about the most serious business of mankind, will never pass. She was a true American heroine who blazed trails for all of us yet never sought praise or recognition for her catalytic contributions to innumerable causes benefiting humanity. From our founding to her passing, she was our inspired and inspiring Vice Chairman for Development. How blessed we all were to have her with us! With every molecule and fiber of her being, she lived a life committed to equality of opportunity for all women and people of color. Our deepest condolences to her beloved, indefatigably devoted life partner, Bob, her equally beloved and devoted sons, John and Richard, her family, innumerable friends, admirers, associates and beneficiaries. We dedicate ourselves and our work to honoring her grand and glorious life. Karen Hastie Williams, Chairman Beatrice A. Fitzpatrick, President The BOLD Initiative

title: Commerce Follows Artists Into the SoHo of Shanghai
description: An artists' community is growing here along the meandering Suzhou Creek, which empties into the Huangpu River at the northern tip of this city's riverside esplanade. Abandoned waterfront warehouses, hulking memorials to the manufacturing days of Shanghai, provide artists with huge work spaces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEIGER, FANNIE G.
description: TEIGER-Fannie G. Mother of David Teiger, grandmother of Douglas and Sabrina Teiger, Lauren Teiger. Greatgrandmother of Zachary, Aiden, Catherine and Christopher. For futher information, please call Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel at 973422-0600.

title: Sports of The Times; The Race Before The Race
description: THE Belmont Stakes won't be run until Saturday, but the inner race has already begun -- with a bite.

title: Sandor Konya, 78, Tenor at Met Known for Wagnerian Roles
description: Sandor Konya, a Hungarian tenor who was a mainstay of the Metropolitan Opera roster from 1961 to 1974, died on May 20 at his home on the Spanish island of Ibiza. He was 78.

title: Creating Dots and Connecting Them, Too
description: Andrea Barrett's new collection of stories, ''Servants of the Map,'' sweeps through the 19th and 20th centuries and crosses several continents, moving from the Himalayas to the Dakotas, while conjuring portraits of adventurers and pioneers. In common with her earlier collection, ''Ship Fever,'' and her novel, ''The Voyage of the Narwhal,'' Ms. Barrett's new book mixes real people (like Charles Darwin and the naturalist William Bartram) with fictional figures, as she weaves a rich tapestry of science and history. Oliver Sacks once quoted a 17th-century naturalist referring to ''the secret mysteries of nature.'' That could stand as an apt description of Ms. Barrett's creative territory.

title: The Cat, the Mouse And the Keyboard
description: Q. Will excessive amounts of cat hair in my keyboard hurt it?

title: Johannesburg Journal; In Purple, the Kings of African Evenings
description: It is a dingy hall in a forlorn neighborhood where bullets sing in the darkness and drunks stagger between sips of sweet forgetfulness. But every Saturday night the place is packed for a beauty contest like no other.

title: Kozlowski's Quest for Entree Into the Art World
description: L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chairman and chief executive of Tyco International who was indicted on Tuesday on charges of evading New York sales tax on the purchase of millions of dollars of paintings and sculpture, has recently sought a prominent profile in New York's art world.

title: From a Slab, Fashioning A Clutch PC
description: FROM Babylonian cuneiform to the recent crop of failed Internet appliances to Microsoft's grand plan to introduce a customized operating system later this year called Windows XP Tablet PC edition, communicating on a flat slab of material is the Once and Future Thing.

title: Reporters at Washington Post Withhold Bylines
description: Virtually all the reporters who wrote articles appearing in The Washington Post yesterday refused to allow their names to appear over their work, in protest of the newspaper's position in contract talks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, WOLFGANG
description: MEYER - Wolfgang. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the brother of its devoted member of the Board of Trustees, Manfred Meyer. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Rachel Lurie, Sisterhood

title: Abuse Scandal Spreads Ripples Over Functions Of the Church
description: The priest sex abuse scandal has taken its toll on the men who run the Archdiocese of New York, which tends to 2.4 million Roman Catholics but also runs a school system, a hospital network and a bevy of social services.

title: R. Kelly, R & B Star, Is Indicted on Child Sex Charges
description: R. Kelly, the Grammy-winning R & B singer, was indicted today on 21 counts of child pornography after the authorities said he made a sexually explicit videotape with an underage girl that has been selling in bootleg versions on street corners across the country.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPMAN, ROBERTA
description: LIPMAN-Roberta. Missed, loved and remembered by us all. You are always in our hearts. Larry, Beth, Reed, Samara and Donn

title: Johnson's Free Throws Give Liberty the Edge
description: With 17.6 seconds left in last night's game, there was good news and bad news for the Liberty, who trailed the Detroit Shock by a point.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, PAUL
description: GOTTLIEB-Paul. Paul Gottlieb began his involvement at The Museum of Modern Art more than 30 years ago, initially as an advisor to its publishing activities. He became an integral part of the MoMA family when in 1975 he joined the Museum's Board of Trustees where he served actively until now. For many years, he was Chairman of both the Trustee Committees on Publications and Membership, and a longtime member of the Finance Committee. In recent years, he was an active member of the Museum's Committee on Archives, Library and Research and its Marketing and Membership Committee. Paul had an especially close relationship with his fellow trustees and the staff of the Museum who will miss his stimulating presence and the pleasure of his good company. We send our most heartfelt sympathy to his wife Elisabeth Scharlatt, his mother Liza, his sister Gail, and his children Andrew and Nicholas and their families, and his stepson Nicholas Scharlatt. David Rockefeller Chairman Emeritus Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Board of Trustees The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: Ashcroft Proposes Rules for Foreign Visitors
description: Calling for a new ''vital line of defense'' against terrorists, Attorney General John Ashcroft proposed Justice Department regulations today that would require 100,000 foreign students, tourists, researchers and other visitors to register with the federal government.

title: The Miniature Optical Mouse Makes the Big Leap to Cordless
description: The mini-mouse is not new, and even the optical mini-mouse has been around for a while. But in a further twist, Targus, which specializes in accessories for laptops and other mobile devices, has crossed the two and developed a cordless optical mini-mouse. This U.S.B. mouse is less than half the size of conventional mice. Targus also reduced the size of the transceiver, which enables the computer and the mouse to communicate with each other.

title: A Con Artist's Criminal Charm
description: Rogue, charlatan, scoundrel. For some reason, these are words that sit on the tongue like sweets, bringing a grin. This season, there seems to be a notable number of books, fiction and nonfiction, about con artists and their cons. The con man is perhaps in some singular and romantic way America's answer to Robin Hood, as long as you're not the mark. (We're not thinking about the corporate con, which will doubtless produce a load of books next year.)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: USA Interactive Says It Won't Raise Bids
description: USA Interactive, Barry Diller's TV shopping and Internet conglomerate, said yesterday that it was pulling back -- somewhat -- from its $4.5 billion plan, announced on Monday, to buy all the remaining shares of three companies in which it holds a controlling stake: Expedia, Hotels.com, and Ticketmaster. On Monday, USA said it hoped to begin an offer to exchange its shares for those of the three companies in the near future. But USA's shares fell nearly 13 percent on Monday as those of the target companies rose, causing some investors to demand USA raise its offers. Yesterday, USA released a statement saying that ''circumstances may change, but we have no intention of increasing'' the bids and that it would not begin the offer in the near future. In an interview, Mr. Diller said the company remained committed to buying all of each of the companies. ''This could take two months or two years,'' he said. ''We are never withdrawing.'' Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Albany Draws New Lines to Keep the House Safe for (Most) Incumbents
description: Concluding the painful process of eliminating two of New York's seats in Congress, the Legislature passed a redistricting bill today that leaves four incumbents fighting for two seats, in western New York and the Hudson Valley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ADAM JEFFREY
description: KATZ-Adam Jeffrey. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the tragic passing of Adam Jeffrey Katz, son of Howard C. Katz who is a cherished friend of UJA-Federation. Our hearts and prayers are with the Katz family at this very difficult time and we extend our condolences to Howard and his wife, Ellen; to Adam's wife, Julie, and their three sons, Zachary, Nicholas, & Jonathan Henry; to Adam's mother, Holly Katz Klein; and to the entire Katz family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Board Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & Chief Executive Officer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, BEATRICE
description: BENJAMIN-Beatrice. In tribute to the feisty and undauntable spirit of Beatrice Benjamin, friend and office manager extraordinaire, you made a difference in all our lives. Lee National Corp.

title: In the Land of Toile, Murder Most Foul
description: HAVE you ever wanted to commit murder?'' asked the novelist Jane Stanton Hitchcock -- a surprising question coming from a woman sitting in a genteely appointed East Side duplex near Gracie Square with a commanding river view.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the sparseness of audiences for both Woody Allen's latest film and his civil court fight with a former business partner misstated the occupation of Abel Feldhamer, who watched the court testimony. He is a law student, not a lawyer.

title: India Believes Pakistan Restrains Militants
description: Citing intercepted communications between members of Islamic militant groups as well as on-the-ground observations, Indian intelligence and military officials believe that orders have been given to the Pakistanis fighting Indian control of Kashmir not to cross over into the Indian territory.

title: To Baffert, War Emblem Looks Like $5 Million
description: Watching War Emblem parade around the shed row at Belmont Barn 7 yesterday shortly after his arrival in New York, the trainer Bob Baffert was the one asking the questions.

title: Officials Follow Money To Link Suspect to Attack
description: Federal law enforcement officials said today that a trail of financial transactions and other information had led them to believe that Khalid Shaikh Mohammed was a ''principal designer'' of the Sept. 11 attacks. They also said his importance was confirmed recently by Abu Zubaydah, the captured leader of Al Qaeda.

title: Goldman Chief Urges Reforms In Corporations
description: In a rare public appearance, the chairman and chief executive of Goldman Sachs, Henry M. Paulson Jr., called for changes today in how public companies are run, audited and regulated to help restore investor confidence.

title: For Candlelight Romance And Summer's Flowery Scent
description: Diptyque, the Paris perfumery and candlemaker, doesn't introduce new candle scents very often. When it does, devotees rush to the shop on the Left Bank to indulge themselves. The newest scent, Geranium Rosa, above left, is at the Diptyque boutique at 123 Newbury Street in Boston for $40.

title: Driskill (Who?) Shuts Down The Yanks
description: It took Travis Driskill 10 seasons to make it to the major leagues. A decade of wondering if his career would ever blossom and a decade of waiting for it to happen. Ten long years that finally ended when the Baltimore Orioles summoned him from Class AAA Rochester in April.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOODMAN, HOWARD
description: GOODMAN-Howard. June 5, 1993. Beloved husband, father, twin brother. ''Benefactor to all''. Nine years always remembered. Roni, Mara, Goodman and Kulick Families

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENKLAR, NORMAN, M.D.
description: SONNENKLAR - Norman, M.D. The Medical Board of Elmhurst Hospital Center and the entire medical staff mourn the loss of Norman Sonnenklar, M.D. We express our sincere condolences to his wife, Susan, and sons, Eric and Alan, and their families. Until his retirement, Dr. Sonnenklar was the Director of the Department of Anesthesiology at Elmhurst Hospital Center, and Assistant Dean for Faculty Practice at Mount Sinai School of Medicine; he was also Past President of the Medical Board. During his many years of service at Elmhurst, Dr. Sonnenklar was a dedicated physician to his patients as well as a devoted teacher to his students and residents. After his retirement, Dr. Sonnenklar continued to offer his advice on a regular basis. We will miss our beloved colleague, teacher and friend.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Setback For Philip Morris
description: A panel of the State Court of Appeals reinstated $79.5 million in punitive damages against Philip Morris, which a jury awarded to a smoker's widow three years ago. A trial court judge had deemed the amount excessive and cut it down to $32 million. The panel found that company's perpetuation of a specious controversy over the risks of cigarettes justified ''strong judicial punishment.'' Greg Winter (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: MICROSOFT SET TO INTRODUCE NEW TECHNOLOGY Microsoft will introduce a new technology today called TrustBridge as part of its revised .Net Web services strategy. Both Microsoft's Passport identity system and its HailStorm consumer services proposal have been criticized by competitors and consumer advocates for their potential threat to privacy and because they were designed to lock customers into Microsoft. More recently, Microsoft has taken a new approach that supports sharing management of identity services among competing companies. The company says the technology will become increasingly useful as users connect from one consumer service to another on the Internet and as business increasingly automates buying and selling operations. John Markoff (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSTEIN, DOROTHY (FRUHLINGER)
description: ROSENSTEIN - Dorothy (Fruhlinger), on June 5, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin, loving mother of Rita, devoted daughter and sister, dear aunt. Service Thursday 1PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSELL, MORTIMER M.
description: KASSELL-Mortimer M. Died June 2, 2002, at his home in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida. Age 97. Graduate of CCNY 1926 and Columbia Law School 1929. Former Deputy Commissioner and Counsel, Department of Taxation and Finance, State of New York, 1937-1959. Beloved husband of the late Minette Berman Kassell. Survived by daughters Nancy Kassell of Brookline, MA, Susan Kassell of Potomac, MD, and Wendeen Eolis of New York City; and by five grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren.

title: Serving Up a Variety of Brief Works and Modal Images
description: The latest edition of Second Helpings, the new music series offered by the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble, had a relaxed, friendly feel. Joan Tower -- host for the show at the Dia Center on Saturday afternoon -- smiled a lot. All four composers came out and spoke briefly, bashfully about the pieces the audience was going to hear. One of the musicians, the pianist Margaret Kampmeier, was also given the chance to say a few words. Everybody thanked everybody else. Everybody was pleasant and eager to please.

title: Girl Abducted From Bedroom In Her Salt Lake City Home
description: A 14-year-old girl was abducted from her bedroom here at gunpoint early this morning, devastating her parents and five siblings and prompting hundreds of residents to scour the area for a trace of her.

description: At first glance, the political landscape here seems more than rich in women as firmly embedded in their nation's myths and history as Joan of Arc or Marie Antoinette.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREWS, LAVONE DICKENSHEETS
description: ANDREWS-Lavone Dickensheets, (1912-2002), a resident of Houston, Texas, and Fishers Island, New York, died in her Houston home on June 4, 2002. Mrs. Andrews received her Bachelor of Architecture degree from Rice Institute in 1935, the only woman in her class to do so. She apprenticed with noted architect, John Staub, and opened her own office in 1938. She was made a Fellow in the American Institute of Architects in 1977. In the 1960s, she restored Knappogue Castle, a mediaeval castle in Ireland, which she and her husband owned. Based on the excellence of her work, she was made a member of The Royal Institute of Architects in Ireland, was awarded the An Taisce Award for architectural excellence in Ireland and the Europa Nostra Award for important restoration of a European monument. In 1994, she was made a Fellow in the Royal Institute of Architects in Ireland. She and her husband, Mark Edwin Andrews, formed and built Ancon Oil & Gas, a private energy company, of which Mrs. Andrews was Vice President from 1957 to 1992. Mrs. Andrews was a member of St. John the Divine, Houston, and St. John's Church, Fishers Island. Her son, Mark Andrews, his wife Beth, and two grandchildren, Elizabeth Quay Andrews and Mark Edwin Andrews IV, survive her. Memorials may be made to Kilnasoolagh Church in Newmarket-on-Fergus, Ireland, and sent to Vicki Arbuthnot at 604 Euclid, Houston, Texas 77009.

description: While Ethiopia's Derartu Tulu flew to New York yesterday, her chief rivals in the New York Women's Mini Marathon ate bagels at Tavern on the Green. Why let the last-minute addition of Tulu, a two-time Olympic gold medalist in the 10,000 meters, spoil breakfast?

description: CERTAINLY outdated and maybe undeserved, the cheesy image of the Poconos as a backwater dotted with low-end honeymoon resorts persists.

title: Half the Afghans, the Women, Fight to Establish Their Rights
description: When Afghanistan's grand council convenes next week to begin creating a new political order, one task will be to select the writers of a new Constitution. There has never been a moment with more promise -- or long-term danger -- for Afghan women.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Belmont Will Have Heightened Security
description: Pity the New York sports fans. They have endured nine months of beefed up security at athletic events. They have had their sandwich bags searched and their bodies scanned for weapons. Stadiums have resembled military forts, with enough blue uniforms and guns to safeguard some small towns.

title: White House Is Working To Nail Down Mideast Plan
description: The latest suicide bombing and Israeli reprisal raids elicited strong and familiar condemnations from senior administration officials today. But those officials were just as quick to insist that the events would not deter them from discussing new proposals for peace with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt this weekend and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel on Monday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a closed-door deposition by Cardinal Bernard F. Law of Boston in a lawsuit over allegations of sexual abuse by a priest misattributed a description of what the cardinal said. It was a plaintiff -- Paula Ford, the mother of a man who said he had been abused by the Rev. Paul R. Shanley -- who said Cardinal Law had acknowledged reading a 1985 complaint that Father Shanley had publicly advocated sex between men and boys. The account was not from Roderick MacLeish Jr., a lawyer for the plaintiffs.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Owners Of ReplayTV Recorders File Lawsuit
description: A civil liberties group asked a federal judge in Los Angeles yesterday to rule that owners of ReplayTV recorders are not violating copyright law when they use the device to compile a library of television shows, send a show over the Internet to other Replay owners, or automatically fast-forward through commercials. In filing the lawsuit on behalf of five Replay owners, the Electronic Frontier Foundation argues that the interests of consumers are being overlooked in an continuing lawsuit that pits the major TV networks and movie studios against Sonicblue, the maker of Replay. The media companies said that Sonicblue was contributing to copyright infringement by allowing consumers to engage in activities like assembling an entire season's episodes of a given show or skipping through commercials. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: The Way Kelly Sees It, Every Event Is a Major
description: Every player here claims he is not looking past the Buick Classic just because the United States Open happens to be a week -- and a short drive to Long Island -- away. Jerry Kelly, though, just may be telling the truth.

title: WEYERHAEUSER TO CLOSE PLANTS AND CUT 206 JOBS
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, the lumber and paper producer, said yesterday that it would eliminate 206 jobs as it closes plants in Colorado, Louisiana and Oregon after its purchase of Willamette Industries. Weyerhaeuser, based in Federal Way, Wash., will eliminate 83 jobs in Denver by closing a packaging plant and shifting production to its facility in Golden, Colo. Weyerhaeuser, which employs more than 60,000 workers, will cut 123 more jobs by closing two lumber plants in Louisiana and Oregon, said Bruce Amundson, a company spokesman. Weyerhaeuser has been closing plants to cope with a decline in demand for paper used in boxes, magazines and books. The company completed its $7.8 billion acquisition of Willamette in March.

title: France, Still Scoreless, Can Only Tie
description: In a rough-and-tumble match edged with a certain desperation on both sides, France and Uruguay played to a scoreless tie tonight that left both teams still in the running for the second round in the World Cup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRENREICH, AMELIA
description: EHRENREICH-Amelia. On June 5, 2002 at the age of ninety-four. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Robert and the late Jonathan and David. Loving mother-in-law of Sally and Judy. Cherished grandmother of William, Joanna and Allison. Services Friday 11am at the Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: The On the Ground column in Business Day on Tuesday, about places to stay, eat and visit in Los Angeles, misstated the name of a popular street guide. It is the Thomas Guide for Los Angeles County, not Thompson.

title: 36 Hours | Saratoga, N.Y.
description: SARATOGA: It's a name that evokes privilege and leisure, spas and cures, gambling and bars and, of course, horses, especially during the August thoroughbred season. But there's more to this town than high living and horseflesh. The Saratoga Performing Arts Center, the summer home to the Philadelphia Orchestra and the New York City Ballet, offers a schedule of cultural events that rivals that of any big city. The Saratoga National Historical Park, site of the first major American defeat of the British and one of the 15 most decisive battles of all time, is nearby. Just north is the Adirondack wilderness; directly south is the capital city of Albany. Saratoga, the summer destination of many of the most famous names in American history, is a small town with a big vision. DAVID A. KELLY

title: Vestiges of Harlem's Jewish Past
description: ON the map of the Jewish diaspora, Harlem is Atlantis. That it was once the third largest Jewish settlement in the world after the Lower East Side and Warsaw -- a vibrant hub of industry, artistry and wealth -- is all but forgotten. It is as if Jewish Harlem sank 70 years ago beneath the waves of memory, beyond recall.

description: Thousands of New Jersey Transit commuters were delayed this morning after a train derailed, halting service on the Morris and Essex Lines' direct service to Midtown Manhattan.

description: Three hours separated their weigh-in times today, the final act in Mike Tyson's and Lennox Lewis's official week apart.

title: Young, Smart and Pressed Toward a Bad Decision
description: Even though the three contemporary fables that make up ''Mama Africa'' are set in Namibia, Nigeria and South Africa, their cautionary messages to urban youth to stick to the straight and narrow are equally applicable to young adults trying to get ahead on the meaner streets of the United States and Europe. Each of the three films, ''Uno's World,'' ''Hang Time'' and ''Raya,'' tells the story of a smart, attractive young person, bursting with potential, who is pressed to go bad. The warnings to resist temptation in this film, which opens today in New York City and on Long Island, are blunt and challenging and offer no easy rewards for staying clean.

description: Investment bankers and lawyers say that two European Union court rulings this week, while unlikely to set off an immediate surge in merger activity, will help foster cross-border deals in the future.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and New York State legislative leaders reached a tentative agreement yesterday that would give the mayor control of New York City's problem-plagued school system and strip local school boards of their last major power in the most significant overhaul of the system in more than three decades.

description: After nearly two years of testing consumer interest, Cond Nast Publications announced yesterday that it would turn its teenage version of Vogue into a magazine coming out once every two months, beginning in 2003.

description: Users of KaZaA, a popular Internet service for sharing music files, frequently expose personal files on their computers by misconfiguring the program, according to a study by two researchers at HP Labs.

description: Sonia Sanchez, 27, remembers the very first time she heard the Ramones. It was years ago -- she and a friend were the last two stragglers in a club in Spain -- and the disc jockey let one of the band's records spin from start to finish.

title: Skakel Convicted in 1975 Beating Death of Greenwich Neighbor
description: NORWALK, Conn., June 7 — A jury convicted Michael C. Skakel today of murder in the 1975 bludgeoning death of Martha Moxley, using more than a quarter century of circumstantial evidence, incriminating statements and erratic behavior by Mr. Skakel to conclude that he killed Miss Moxley, his friend and neighbor, when they were both just 15 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMAN, CHARLES
description: SCHUMAN-Charles. The administration, faculty and Board of Overseers of Simon's Rock College of Bard are saddened by the recent death of friend, colleague and neighbor, Charles Schuman. Mr. Schuman made a significant contribution to our understanding of the world through his thoughtful journalism. We are also grateful for the efforts he made to advance the understanding of Simon's Rock College through his public relations efforts on our behalf. We send our deepest condolences to his family. Bernard F. Rodgers Jr. Vice President and Dean

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Names 2 To Women's Agency
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday appointed Carmen Rita Torrent as executive director of the New York City Commission on Women's Issues. Anne Sutherland Fuchs will be chairwoman of the commission, which advises the mayor about housing, education, employment and health care issues as they relate to women. The agency was formerly known as the Commission on the Status of Women. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Girlhood Chums, Rallying Round
description: ''Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood'' offers the pleasantly groggy sensation of sinking under a down quilt and being fussed over by a group of garrulous, high-strung women. Amid their collective chatter, which includes bursts of raucous laughter, enough fuming emotion erupts to slake the thirst of an undiscriminating drama queen.

title: Yankees Hope Rivera Adds Stability in Right
description: Juan Rivera's professional career was nearly over before it began. He was a skinny 17-year-old playing in the Dominican Summer League in 1996, and he had three singles in 18 at-bats for the season. Some of the Yankees' talent evaluators did not think he was worth another look.

description: Security concerns in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks have slowed refugee admissions to the United States to a trickle, even as the numbers of civilians fleeing war worldwide have inched up over the last year, according to refugee resettlement groups.

title: Tobacco Company Reneged on Youth Ads, Judge Rules
description: After vowing in a 1998 tobacco settlement to market solely to adults, the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company has violated the agreement by pursuing an advertising strategy that promotes youth smoking, a California judge ruled yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: N.Y.U. Teacher Group Seeks Union
description: New York University's part-time teachers, known as adjuncts, voted to form a union, according to the results of a mail ballot announced yesterday. Of 2,700 adjuncts deemed eligible to vote, 743 voted for the United Auto Workers, 552 for the American Federation of Teachers and 294 for no representation. Since no choice won more than half the vote, a runoff between the two unions will be held. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Waterworks Is at Center Of a Battle In New Jersey
description: Almost a decade after the Hackensack Water Company donated a mammoth water filtration plant here to Bergen County, the property finds itself in the middle of an unusual battle, with historic preservationists on one side and local officials and environmentalists on the other.

description: How many times can we be horrified?

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Trial Begins In Infant's Starving
description: A man who belonged to an Attleboro religious sect kept detailed notes on how he and his wife starved their infant son to death, a prosecutor said in an opening statement in the man's trial on a first-degree murder charge. The man, Jacques Robidoux, is accused of starving his 11-month-old son, Samuel, over two months in 1999 after Mr. Robidoux's sister, Michelle Robidoux-Mingo, who also belongs to the sect, said God told her the child should not eat solid food. The prosecution contends that Mr. Robidoux let the child have only breast milk, which his pregnant wife, Karen, could not produce. She will be tried separately on second-degree murder charges. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Save Some Escarole
description: Tuscan Way, based in Coconut Grove, Fla., is taking 20 percent off its four- and seven-day cooking-instruction tours in southern Tuscany on June 29 and July 6. Classes have no more than 10 students, who stay in a country estate or the 900-year-old Casa Innocenti, in or near the village of Arcidosso. Rates include all meals, lessons by local cooks, wine tastings, market excursions and airport transfers. With the discount, the four-day program is $992 a person, double occupancy; one week is $1,752 to $1,832 a person, double; (800) 766-2390 or www.tuscanway.com .

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Indians Back School Mascot
description: The chairman of the Snoqualmie Indians, Joseph O. Mullen, said his tribe wanted Issaquah High School, in suburban Seattle, to keep its Indian name and mascot despite a recent school board ban on racial and ethnic emblems and team names. School district officials said they were confused and surprised by a letter from Mr. Mullen, after years of debate over the name. Timothy Egan (NYT)

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. title: Small German Party Tries to Calm Uproar Over Slurs About Jews
description: In an awkward effort to restore credibility and control over the Free Democratic Party, its leader today engineered the resignation of a party politician who had compared Israel's tactics in the West Bank to ''Nazi methods'' and complained of ''the influence of the Zionist lobby'' in the world's news outlets.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Sues Verizon Over Layoffs
description: The union representing employees at Verizon asked a federal judge yesterday to temporarily stop Verizon from dismissing 2,100 telecommunications workers who could be laid off by summer's end. Verizon has proposed reducing its work force through voluntary and involuntary measures. But the union, the Communications Workers of America, said such cutbacks would hurt customer service, including lengthening repair time for damaged phone lines. Under the union contract, Verizon must declare a ''surplus'' of workers before layoffs can begin. ''We are claiming that the surplus is not only not real, but that this will do tremendous harm,'' said Gay Semel, a union attorney. John J. Bonomo, a Verizon spokesman, said there was no merit to the lawsuit.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Former Governor Hospitalized
description: Former Gov. William A. O'Neill is in satisfactory condition after being hospitalized for a lung infection, a hospital spokesman said yesterday. Governor O'Neill, who suffers from emphysema, was admitted to St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center in Hartford on May 30. Mr. O'Neill, 71, was governor from 1980 to 1991, serving two terms after succeeding Gov. Ella T. Grasso. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Growing Outrage Leads Back to Centralized Leadership
description: For more than a century, the New York City public school system has cycled through centralized and decentralized forms of leadership. The understanding announced yesterday between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, giving Mr. Bloomberg substantial control of the schools was the latest turn of the wheel.

Mr. Katz was the son of Benne Katz, past Chairman of Brookdale's Board of Trustees. Our sincere condolences to the entire Katz family. Alvin I. Kahn, MD, Chairman, Board of Trustees David I. Schachne, Chairman, Executive Committee David P. Rosen, President and CEO Edwin L. Schulman, President Emeritus, Schulman Inst. Bd. of Dir.

title: House Backs Permanent End to Estate Tax
description: Trying to put election-year pressure on the Democratic-led Senate, the Republican-led House voted today to make permanent a repeal of the estate tax.

title: Torricelli and Forrester Senate Campaigns Point Fingers Over Prescription Costs
description: Striving to make the high cost of prescription drugs a prominent issue in New Jersey's United States Senate race, Senator Robert G. Torricelli's campaign charged today that the Republican nominee, Douglas R. Forrester, made his fortune in business by unfairly inflating the price of medications.

title: For a Grown-Up, a Few Growing Pains
description: I AM the prodigal son who did not get very far. I grew up in northern New Jersey -- the banlieue of New York -- and I now live in Brooklyn. I am separated from my parents by about 50 miles, but really there is almost no distance between us. I speak to them nearly every day.

title: Plan for Security Agency Draws Bipartisan, but Not Unconditional, Support
description: President Bush's proposal for a new cabinet agency to oversee domestic security drew wide bipartisan support today in Congress, with Democrats pointedly saying it was about time the president heeded calls for an overhaul of the government to deal with the terrorist threat.

description: SINGER-Rebecca, Rebittzen. Loved greatly and missed a lot. Always in our thoughts and hearts. Love, Vivia

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Twin Towers Fund Distribution
description: The Twin Towers Fund has begun distributing its third round of benefits totaling more than $103 million. The distribution will go to rescue workers not included in previous distributions. The fund was established by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to benefit the families of uniformed rescue workers who perished during the terrorist attacks. It has distributed a total of $155 million to 436 families, including 789 children. The typical distributions are $150,000 to each spouse, $60,000 to each child 23 and younger and $25,000 to children 24 and older. The fund continues to seek donations and hopes to include unmarried domestic partners in the next distribution, Laurence Levy, the president of the fund, said.

title: Movie Agent Is Likable But Not Nice
description: ''Ivans XTC,'' a new film by Bernard Rose, is adapted from Tolstoy's classic novella ''The Death of Ivan Illyich.'' The locale is late-20th-century Hollywood instead of 19th-century Russia, and Tolstoy's severe humanism has been grafted onto a scabrous, cynical view of the movie industry reminiscent of ''The Day of the Locust'' or ''The Player.''

description: Christina Binko was named senior director for the marketing communications practice at Dittus Communications, Washington. She had been a senior marketing manager at the registry division of VeriSign, Sterling, Va.

title: The Nets Are Overshadowed by the Lakers' Glitz
description: The physical contact represented the first and only sign of aggression from a Nets player, and it caught one of Los Angeles's biggest stars flush in the sternum.

title: A Demure Wife Learns to Throw Her Weight Around
description: ''Secret Society,'' which opens today in New York, is the latest in an apparently endless series of British comedies in which an unlikely competitive activity becomes a way for hard-pressed ordinary folk to overcome adversity, gain self-esteem and find a moment of modest glory. To a roster that includes striptease (''The Full Monty''), hairdressing (''Blow Dry'') and gardening (''Greenfingers''), we may now add female sumo wrestling, the semi-clandestine pastime of a group of hefty Yorkshire cannery workers, among them Daisy, our heroine.

title: Battered but Defiant, Arafat Surveys the Damage
description: Yasir Arafat's command compound here was a wreck today after a six-hour Israeli assault that sent a tank shell through his bathroom, killed two people, left half a dozen buildings in ruins and rendered the position of the aging Palestinian leader shakier than ever.

description: A victims' group filed a class-action lawsuit yesterday to void the secrecy provisions in all settlements signed by people who say they were sexually abused by Roman Catholic priests.

Even the specter of facing a potential Triple Crown winner in the Belmont Stakes will not really be anything new. Big races, big money and world-class competition dominate his rsum.

description: A man accused of killing a doctor who performed abortions here pleaded not guilty to murder today as the physician's widow looked on in a packed courtroom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKER, NATALYA A.
description: BARKER-Natalya A. It is with inconceivable regret that we say good-bye to our beloved wife and mother Natalia Alexandra Smolianinova. She was & always will be the spirit of our family. Natalia was always unattainable, now she truly is. Natalia was educated in Rostov, Russia and received her B.A. in foreign languages there. After coming to the U.S. to attend a small business program for Russian students at Wharton in 1995 she returned to Russia. In 1997 after a lengthy cross continent courtship she returned to the U.S. and was married to Michael Barker whom she leaves with a three year old daughter Polina Grace Barker of Manhattan. Natalia also leaves a mother, father and younger brother of Bataisk, Russia. She was 32 years old. There will be a memorial service for Natalia, June 12th at Calvary Church, 21st Street and Park Avenue South, at 3 P.M.

title: Defense Secretary Tells NATO To Beat Terrorists to Punch
description: With NATO seeking ways to maintain its relevance as a military alliance, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld urged today that it take the fight against terrorism to the terrorists with pre-emptive attacks on shadowy networks or hostile states armed with biological, chemical or nuclear weapons.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bank Cuts Jobs

title: The Global Warming Dropout
description: In its business-as-usual approach to climate change, the Bush administration is increasingly out of step not only with other industrialized powers, but also with the growing support in this country for action to prevent global warming. The administration's oddly two-sided report last week to the United Nations brings the White House into the scientific mainstream on the subject -- acknowledging that human activity is probably the cause of global warming and that America itself faces serious consequences -- but at the same time lays out a strategy ensuring that American emissions of greenhouse gases will continue rising sharply for at least a decade.

description: DETROIT, June 6 — The buzz word in baseball is contraction. In hockey, Commissioner Gary Bettman of the National Hockey League also says his sport has economic problems and he would like to resolve them even before the Collective Bargaining Agreement with the Players Association expires in the summer of 2004. But Bettman said he did not think the N.H.L. needed to reduce its size from 30 teams.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Severe Storms Lash New York And New Jersey
description: Heavy storms hit New York and New Jersey last night, with one small tornado reported in upstate New York. No serious injuries were reported. The ceiling of the emergency room at Southern Ocean County Hospital in Manahawkin, N.J., partly collapsed around 5:45 p.m., and 12 patients were moved to another part of the hospital. The National Weather Service confirmed a funnel cloud touched down in Bainbridge, N.Y., around 8 p.m., with winds estimated at 70 miles per hour, said meteorologist Michael Spoorer in Binghamton. More than an inch of rain fell on Central Park, with not quite two inches falling on northeastern New Jersey, said George McKillop, a hydrologist with the National Weather Service.

So far this year, sales have been flat at Richemont, the maker of Cartier jewelry, Montblanc pens and Lancel bags, as tourism has slumped since Sept. 11 and deprived the luxury market of many of its best customers. A bright spot in the Swiss company's business was watch sales, which were up 4 percent in the last two months, particularly in the high-end gold and jewelry models. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Take 2 Posts Profit, But Shares Fall
description: Take 2 Interactive Software Inc., the maker of the video game Grand Theft Auto 3, had a second-quarter profit as sales surged. The shares fell 16 percent after it said profit this quarter would trail estimates. The company said it had a profit of $9.64 million, or 25 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $11.5 million, or 35 cents, a year ago. Sales in the quarter ended April 30 almost doubled to $170.3 million from $88.2 million. The company forecast that third-quarter profit will be 7 cents a share, less than the 12-cent average forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The shares fell 59 cents, to $25.50, in regular trading.

title: NOVARTIS RECEIVES APPROVAL FOR NEW FORM OF RITALIN
description: Novartis A.G. said yesterday that it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration for a once-daily form of Ritalin, its drug for attention deficit disorder. The product contains the same active ingredient as Johnson & Johnson's Concerta, a once-daily drug for attention deficit disorder. Concerta won F.D.A. approval in 2000. Some children have had to take the older form of Ritalin twice a day.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sales-Tax Holiday Set
description: In an effort to increase retail and other sales in Lower Manhattan, city and state officials said yesterday that they had agreed to a moratorium on the 8.25 percent sales tax for nine days during the summer. The temporary exemption applies to shops, restaurants and hotels below Houston Street, where business has been hurt since the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. Goods and services costing up to $500, including restaurant meals and hotel rooms, will be exempt from the tax from this Sunday to Tuesday; July 9 to 11; and Aug. 20 to 22. The tax relief will not apply to gasoline and cigarettes and other tobacco products.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AirGate Shares Fall On Reduced Forecast
description: Shares in AirGate PCS, an Atlanta-based company that sells wireless telephone service under the Sprint PCS name in the Southeastern United States, plummeted yesterday after it reduced its quarterly forecast for new subscribers. It was the second consecutive day of trouble for the company, whose stock lost nearly 11 percent of its value on Wednesday. AirGate said it now expected to add 22,000 to 27,000 new subscribers in the third fiscal quarter. Previously the company said it expected to add 35,000 to 40,000 new customers. J. P. Morgan Chase downgraded AirGate to market perform from buy and lowered its 12-month price target to $13 from $31. AirGate shares, which once traded at more than $100, dropped $5.65, or about 67 percent, to $2.75. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: As images of gay and lesbian life proliferate in the mainstream media and more and more gay celebrities emerge from the closet without a big to-do, the casual observer of popular culture might wonder what purpose is still served by a gay and lesbian film festival. Many emphatic answers to that question can be found in the nearly 200 films and videos from around the world programmed in the 14th Annual New York Lesbian and Gay Film Festival (also known as the New Festival). Last night, that program opened with a screening at the New School of Margaret Cho's forthcoming concert film, ''Notorious C.H.O.,'' due to open on July 3.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bid For Convenience Stores
description: Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc., Canada's biggest convenience-store operator, offered $80 million for 450 stores run by Dairy Mart Convenience Stores, which filed for bankruptcy protection last year. In the bid, Couche-Tard offered to manage stores it did not acquire and would eventually close them or sell them on behalf of Dairy Mart. Dairy Mart, based in Hudson, Ohio, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in September, citing debt from acquisitions and lower profit because of competition. The sale of assets to Couche-Tard will go ahead if Dairy Mart does not receive higher bids in an auction scheduled for late July or early August, a Dairy Mart spokeswoman, Diana Lueptow, said.

description: The European Union's second-highest court today overturned a European Commission decision that had blocked the merger of two British travel companies. The ruling sets an important precedent by narrowing antitrust review of mergers and acquisitions in Europe, experts said.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Texas Instruments Reaffirms Forecast
description: Texas Instruments, which makes chips that power more than half of the world's cellular phones, said its forecast for the second quarter of about $2 billion in sales and profits of 5 cents a share remained accurate. The company, based in Dallas, said in April that it expected revenue to be up about 10 percent from $1.83 billion in the first quarter. Texas Instruments reported a net loss of 11 cents a share on $2.04 billion in sales in the second quarter of last year, officials said. The company said it had reduced annual costs by about $600 million, while continuing to invest in more efficient manufacturing methods.

title: World Briefing | Australia: Saving The Patagonian Toothfish
description: Australia wants an Antarctic fish prized in American and Japanese restaurants given international protection against poachers who it says are decimating stocks. Australia will ask the fall meeting of the 153-member United Nations Convention for the International Trade in Endangered Species to list the Patagonian toothfish, which is marketed under the name Chilean sea bass. Australia recently seized two ships in Australian Antarctic waters with illegal catches of toothfish valued at $1.5 million. Australian companies with legal catch quotas valued at about $10 million annually are lobbying for increased naval action against the poachers, whose known catches are estimated at $6 million a year. John Shaw (NYT)

Dr. Bildner, a graduate of New York University College of Dentistry, was a periodontist in private practice in the Bronx, a clinical professor at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Dentistry and Executive Director of the Bronx County Dental Society. He was a member of the New York State Society of Periodontology, the American College of Dentists, the International College of Dentists and the Pierre Fauchard Academy. Heavily favored to defeat the Carolina Hurricanes in the Stanley Cup finals, the Wings found themselves in a tense tie late tonight and fearing overtime. After all, the Hurricanes have won all but one of their overtime games in this year's playoffs and the Wings have lost all but one.

He transformed the lives of hundreds of our students through his support. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Edie and the entire Wasserman family.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Anti-Extremism Bill Advances
description: A bill to combat political extremism passed the first of three votes in Russia's lower house of Parliament. If passed, the law would increase Russian law enforcement authorities' control over fascist groups by disbanding them or suspending their activities. President Vladimir V. Putin called for the law in his April address to the nation, after concerns about rising numbers of fascist organizations caught the Kremlin's attention. The current draft, however, has been strongly criticized by human rights activists, who say it gives too much power to the police and prosecutors. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

description: GOTTLIEB-Paul. Paul Gottlieb began his involvement at The Museum of Modern Art more than 30 years ago, initially as an advisor to its publishing activities. He became an integral part of the MoMA family when in 1975 he joined the Museum's Board of Trustees where he served actively until now. For many years, he was Chairman of both the Trustee Committees on Publications and Membership, and a longtime member of the Finance Committee. In recent years, he was an active member of the Museum's Committee on Archives, Library and Research and its Marketing and Membership Committee. Paul had an especially close relationship with his fellow trustees and the staff of the Museum who will miss his stimulating presence and the pleasure of his good company. We send our most heartfelt sympathy to his wife Elisabeth Scharlatt, his mother Liza, his sister Gail, and his children Andrew and Nicholas and their families, and his stepson Nicholas Scharlatt. David Rockefeller Chairman Emeritus Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Board of Trustees The Museum of Modern Art, NY

description: THERE are several different schools nationwide that offer introductory fly-fishing classes. Here are some of the better-known ones around the country.

title: Ace Hardware Picks Goodby, Silverstein
description: The Ace Hardware Corporation in Oak Brook, Ill., has selected Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group , to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Mayor Wins Third Term As Write-In
description: Mayor Beverly O'Neill of Long Beach, the state's fifth largest city, won a third term despite having to run as a write-in candidate. An ordinance limits officials to two terms but allows them to run as write-ins. With more than 16,500 votes, Ms. O'Neill, 71, defeated Vice Mayor Dan Baker, the only candidate on the ballot, by a 10-point margin. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ad Campaign For Bond Sales
description: Japan's Ministry of Finance, trying to reduce the country's debt burden, has hired a popular actress, Norika Fujiwara, to appear in commercials promoting bond sales to individual investors. Ms. Fujiwara, a 30-year-old model who has appeared in ads for the Vodafone Group's wireless unit, J-Phone, and has promoted the World Cup soccer tournament, will appear in a string of commercials aimed at persuading individuals to invest their summer bonuses in Japanese bonds. Moody's Investors Service recently downgraded Japan's debt rating to a level beneath that of Botswana. Japan's outstanding debt will probably rise to 693 trillion yen (at the current rate of exchange, about $5.6 trillion) by the end of March 2003, according to the Ministry of Finance.

title: The New Time Share: More Choice, Even Finer Print
description: OWNING a vacation house may have its charms, but easy maintenance isn't one of them. For people who want a regular place to go without worrying about burst pipes or dead shrubs, time shares have long been appealing.

title: Funny Business
description: The Toyota Comedy Festival runs from Tuesday through Saturday at various Manhattan sites, including the Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (212) 307-7171; Boston Comedy Club, 82 West Third Street, (212) 477-1000; Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street, (212) 247-7800; Caroline's on Broadway, Broadway and 49th Street, (212) 757-4100; Comedy Garden, Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue and 32nd Street, (212) 307-7171; World Famous Comic Strip Live, Second Avenue and 81st Street, (212) 861-9386; Directors Guild Theater, 110 West 57th Street, (212) 307-7171; Gotham Comedy Club, 34 West 22nd Street, (212) 367-9000; Pier 40, West Houston Street and the Hudson River, (212) 307-7171; Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, (212) 840-2824 or (212) 307-4100; the 92nd Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, (212) 415-5500; Stand-Up N.Y., 236 West 78th Street, (212) 595-0850; Joseph Papp Public Theater, Joe's Pub and the Newman Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, (212) 539-8770.

title: Senate Passes Counterterror Spending Bill
description: The Senate passed a $31.4 billion emergency counterterrorism measure early today. The vote was 71 to 22.

title: Back to the Drawing Board
description: After months of trying on the fly to mobilize numerous federal agencies in a unified front against terrorist threats at home, President Bush belatedly but wisely told the nation last night that an ambitious reorganization of the government was needed to get the job done. His proposal to draw together more than a dozen federal agencies in a new Department of Homeland Security makes sense. But no one should underestimate the obstacles to pulling off the biggest overhaul of federal machinery since Harry Truman and Congress established the Defense Department, the Central Intelligence Agency and the National Security Council in the late 1940's. Creating effective defenses against terrorism out of this reshuffling will require a degree of leadership and cooperation rare in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCAW, SUSAN L.
description: McCAW-Susan L. The staff and Board of Directors of The Alan Guttmacher Institute are deeply saddened by the passing of our friend and colleague, Susan L. McCaw, our former Director of Finance and Administration. Although Susan worked at the Institute for only a short time before her illness struck, her professional skills, warmth and humor made an immediate and lasting impression. She was everything we could hope for in a coworker--smart, funny and caring. We will miss her and extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Bob and children Anne and Ben.

title: England Beats Archfoe Argentina
description: SAPPORO, Japan, June 7  In the history of World Cup soccer, few matches are as exalted as showdowns between England and Argentina. The game between these two bitter foes  the most anticipated of the weekold tournament  was another one for the books.

description: They started moving earth around at the site of Bill Clinton's presidential library here on Wednesday, and one might have picked up a sigh of relief in the breeze coming off the Arkansas River.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Cement Stake
description: The International Finance Corporation, part of the World Bank, plans to acquire as much as 13 percent of Cia. de Cemento Argos S.A. of Colombia for $60 million, to help Colombia's economy at a time of political violence. The corporation has given Argos, Colombia's biggest cement company and part of the Medellin-based Grupo Empresarial Antioqueno, an option to reacquire the stake at market prices, Argos said.

title: BFMA SAYS IT IS CONSIDERING ANOTHER BID FOR MORTON'S
description: The BFMA Holding Corporation, which sought to buy the Morton's Restaurant Group last year, said it was considering another bid and urged Morton's shareholders to reject a buyout offer from Castle Harlan, the chain's former owner. BFMA, which holds 14 percent of Morton's, filed a proxy statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission saying investors should reject a buyout offer of $12.60 a share from Castle Harlan because it is too low. Carl C. Icahn, who backed BFMA's bid of $28.25 a share in May 2001, has also bid on Morton's, offering $13.50 a share on his own last month, and BFMA said that bid was too low, as well.

title: Martin on His Image
description: Nets forward Kenyon Martin, who was suspended for seven games during the regular season because of flagrant fouls, was quoted in the basketball magazine Dime as saying that race might have influenced what he called his ''thug image.''

title: Beckham Ends 4 Years of Suffering
description: SAPPORO, Japan, June 7  He ran directly to the Argentina stands, containing all those celestial blue and white jerseys, and he tilted back his head and he roared.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Grocer's Profit Rises
description: Royal Ahold N.V., the world's largest food distributor, said earnings growth would accelerate in the second half after acquisitions in the United States helped lift first-quarter profit 3.8 percent. The shares rose 5.2 percent. The Dutch owner of the Stop & Shop and Giant supermarket chains reiterated its target for annual earnings to rise 15 percent. Net income in the period that ended April 21 rose to 328 million euros ($307 million), or 34 cents a share, from 316 million euros, or 37 cents a share. Operating profit in the United States was lifted by the integration of Alliant Foodservice and Bruno's Supermarkets. Profit in Latin America fell 43 percent, hurt by devaluation in Argentina, and profit in Europe fell 11 percent.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Family Aids MedicaL School
description: The Pritzker family of Chicago, which owns the Hyatt Hotel chain, celebrated the 100th anniversary of the business with a $30 million gift to the University of Chicago's Biological Sciences Division and Pritzker School of Medicine. The university plans to use the money to recruit faculty members, to be known as Pritzker Scholars, in areas like neuroscience and genetics. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Governor Vetoes Castration Bill
description: Gov. Frank Keating has vetoed legislation that would have allowed judges to order castration for men convicted of rape or forcible sodomy. He said castration was ''an unnecessary and arguably unconstitutional punishment.'' He signed a law providing for life without parole for a number of sex crimes, including rape.

title: Accountants Are Reviewing Old Audits
description: After many reports of questionable bookkeeping, accounting firms are quietly taking a fresh look at clients' audited financial statements -- and identifying those companies most likely to draw unwanted attention from regulators and plaintiffs' lawyers.

title: Havana Builds a Shrine To Detroit (Naturalmente)
description: CUBA'S government regularly excoriates the venality and duplicity of the United States, blaming ''Yankee capitalists'' for almost all of the country's problems, from the global investment climate to the weather.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 14 about a robbery and shooting in Greenwich Village gave an outdated name for the university where the victim earned his engineering degree. An article on April 15 about the police investigation repeated the error. The institution is Polytechnic University, formerly the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. The university reported the error at the time, but this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about L. Dennis Kozlowski, former chairman and chief executive of Tyco International, misspelled the given name of a philanthropist who participated with him in a fund-raising dinner for the New York Botanical Garden. The collaborator was Laurance S. Rockefeller, not Laurence.

title: PARKER DRILLING MAKES TOP BID FOR AUSTRALIAN COMPANY
description: Parker Drilling, an oil and gas drilling contractor based in Houston, offered 162 million Australian dollars ($92.5 million) for the Australian Oil and Gas Corporation of Sydney, topping bids by two Canadian rivals. Parker offered 2.50 Australian dollars a share and 1.30 Australian dollars for each listed option in Australian Oil, 8.7 percent more than the closing price yesterday. The bid tops those of the Ensign Resource Service Group and the Precision Drilling Corporation. Australian Oil and Gas said it would review all three bids.

Grandmother of Tom & Renee, Susan Brodie & Mark Hall, Jim & Lynne Brodie, Wendy Gruenberg and Jon Gruenberg. Also survived by five great grandchildren. Interment will be private.

title: Paper Publishes Photo of Head of Reporter Who Was Killed
description: The Boston Phoenix broke ranks with the rest of the print media yesterday and published a photograph of the severed head of Daniel Pearl, The Wall Street Journal reporter who was killed by Islamic militants in Pakistan. The picture accompanied an editorial defending its decision to provide a link on its Web site to the video of Mr. Pearl's execution.

title: An Agent Not in the Inner Circle Who Seems Upbeat, Polite and Sensible

title: It's a Splash: Two Sinks, No Waiting
description: WHENEVER I am able to stay in a really nice hotel, the first thing I notice is the size of the bathroom. Nothing for me is more luxurious than a huge, perfectly appointed space with a separate shower and a freestanding bathtub, as well as two sinks separated by a long expanse of white marble.

title: Smallpox Vaccinations Urged for Health Care Workers
description: Smallpox vaccine should be made available to certain groups of health care workers like those in emergency rooms even before a bioterrorist attack, a number of speakers said yesterday at a forum on vaccination policy.

title: Corrections
description: The list of winning lottery numbers for Tuesday and Wednesday carried erroneous dates yesterday in some copies. The numbers were drawn on June 4 and 5, not May 4 and 5.

title: Bush Is Said to Be Set to Back Patients' Bill
description: Representative Charlie Norwood, a leader of the six-year campaign for legislation defining patients' rights, said today that the White House had expressed a new willingness to support a compromise letting patients sue health insurers for medical injuries caused by substandard care.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Peace Plan Stalls
description: Aton Balasingham, political adviser to the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, told the weekly Tamil Guardian that efforts to end 19 years of civil war are at an impasse. He said the Tamil ethnic rebels are unhappy that parts of the cease-fire agreement are not being carried out more quickly. But experts believe that the rebels are upset that the government has backed off earlier plans to focus the talks on an interim arrangement. The government insists that the core political issues for a long-term settlement must be addressed from the start and has ruled out an independent Tamil nation. Hopes that talks would begin in May or June seem to have fizzled. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

description: Berry-Hill Galleries

title: Blunt Talk by an Investment Banker
description: For much of corporate America, Goldman Sachs has long epitomized the discretion and solicitude of a Wall Street investment bank. That is what made Wednesday's call for corporate governance reforms by Henry M. Paulson Jr., the firm's chief executive, so compelling and unusual. Amid the gathering storm of corporate scandals that threatens to thwart the stock market's comeback, Mr. Paulson delivered a stern warning to his clients and to other major companies in a speech at the National Press Club: Either clean up your act or we are all in serious trouble. He ought to be heeded.

description: Sometimes, Andre Agassi's talent is dialed in like a 50-watt radio station, fading in and out around the bends of a match.

title: Intel, in Surprise, Reports Its Sales Won't Meet Goals
description: In an announcement that surprised semiconductor industry analysts and threatened to dispirit investors, the Intel Corporation said today that it would not meet its expectations for sales or gross profit margin for its second quarter.

title: Mathis Patiently Waits to Play
description: When he appeared for warm-ups before the American national team's World Cup opener on Wednesday, Clint Mathis sported a Mohawk haircut. However, his hair was not shaved nearly as much as his playing time.

title: 2 Medical Groups Moving Offices Downtown
description: The American Lung Association and the American Thoracic Society announced yesterday that they were moving their national headquarters from Midtown Manhattan to 61 Broadway, near Wall Street about four blocks from ground zero.

title: Into the Ring, Again
description: Boxing's heavyweight champion is generally considered ''the world's most dangerous man.'' True or not, this claim has a powerful hold on the public imagination; and because for the past 60 years (with one exception) the heavyweight champion has been African-American, the title fight has become a kind of referendum on black masculinity. Which type of black man is more dangerous (or more acceptable), the brash young Cassius Clay or the menacing Sonny Liston? The black nationalist Muhammad Ali or the blue-collar Joe Frazier? The primal spectacle encourages the projection of every sort of stereotype and fantasy about manhood and race.

title: Verizon Reverses Increase at Some Pay Phones
description: Verizon Communications officials said yesterday that they had decided to reverse a recent rate increase on thousands of pay phones in New York City, meaning that many phones will require only 25 cents for calls, instead of 50 cents.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Peace And Scandals
description: On the South Korean Memorial Day holiday honoring those killed in the Korean War, President Kim Dae Jung promised to keep up the search for peace with North Korea. He did not mention the scandals reverberating around his government or the indictment of his youngest son, Kim Hong Gul, on charges of corruption and tax evasion. Prosecutors were questioning Yoo Sang Boo, the chairman of Pohang Iron and Steel who is suspected of having ordered subsidiaries to pay excessive prices for shares in a sports lottery firm that transferred funds to Kim Hong Gul. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Review Is Sought on Comments By Judge About Sex and Minors
description: A state judicial conduct committee has been asked to review comments made by a New Jersey judge that appeared to play down the impact of sex between minors and adults. The comments were made in May during a sentencing hearing in which the judge allowed a teacher who admitted having had sex with a 13-year-old boy she had taught to avoid jail time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSON, JEAN
description: MANSON - Jean. Beloved mother of Alan and Sheryl; devoted sister to Lou Sarfati, Lillian Cohen, Esther Hasson, Rae Russo. Loved by all. She will be missed.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: No Mystery, Just A Virus
description: Twenty-nine British soldiers and medical workers who fell ill last month with a ''mystery infection'' at an air base in Bagram, north of Kabul, turned out to have a gastrointestinal virus that is common in military settings. The United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the illness, which included fever, vomiting and diarrhea, was caused by Norwalk-like viruses that caused similar outbreaks among soldiers during Persian Gulf war operations. Those infected have recovered. Denise Grady (NYT)

title: FORD MOTOR NAMES A NEW EXECUTIVE FOR ITS LUXURY UNIT
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it had named Dan Werbin to lead the Volvo, Aston Martin, Land Rover and Jaguar brands in North America, changing management at a luxury unit that it sees as crucial in efforts to end losses. Mr. Werbin, 60, who has led Volvo's United States operations since November, will switch jobs on June 17 with Victor H. Doolan, who is the North American executive director of Premier Automotive Group, Ford's luxury unit. Mr. Doolan, 61, has led the unit in North America since July 1999. Ford's chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., has said that Premier, based in London, will generate a third of the automaker's profit by the middle of the decade.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Regent Selection Affirmed
description: The Court of Appeals, New York's highest court, yesterday upheld the way the Legislature selects the Board of Regents, which sets educational policy. The seven-member court ruled unanimously that the process was legal. Each time there is an opening, the Legislature elects a new regent in a joint session. That currently gives the Democratic majority in the Assembly, the larger house, effective control of the process, even though Republicans hold a majority in the Senate. A Republican state senator from Long Island, Kenneth P. LaValle, sued, arguing that such joint votes violated the State Constitution, and that the appointment of Regents needed the approval of each house separately. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Scratch Manhattan, and It's a Big Jewel Box
description: With its diamond district and glittering jewelry emporiums like Tiffany's and Harry Winston, Manhattan has always been a top destination for the gem-obsessed. If you want a big rock, this is a good place to get it. But what most people, even rock hounds, may not know is that buried below the skyscrapers and sidewalks, the city's bedrock is a trove of minerals, crystals and gem-quality stones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONYA, SANDOR
description: KONYA-Sandor. The Metropolitan Opera deeply mourns the death of Sandor Konya, who was heard at the Met from 1961 to 1974 in a broad repertory of leading roles in German and Italian works, including new productions of ''Lohengrin,'' ''Die Meistersinger von Nuernberg,'' and ''Der Freischuetz,'' as well as Cavaradossi in ''Tosca,'' Edgardo in ''Lucia di Lammermoor,'' and Pinkerton in ''Madama Butterfly.'' We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

description: With a ''conceptual agreement'' announced yesterday at City Hall, New York City's 1.1 million public school students have reason to hope that their uneven and often decrepit school system is entering a new era.
