title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Suicide Pact Survivor Does Not Contest Sex Charge
description: Jennifer Holey, who survived a suicide pact with her husband, has pleaded no contest to third-degree criminal sexual conduct involving a 14-year-old girl. Ms. Holey, 19, was accused of helping her husband, Patrick Holey, 19, rape the girl on April 1. Ms. Holey's mother-in-law, Kathleen K. Holey, has been charged with two counts of assisted suicide for driving the couple to an abandoned farmhouse on April 9 so they could overdose on her prescription pain killers. Patrick Holey died. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

description: ICAP, the world's largest interdealer broker, is in talks to buy BrokerTec Global, the online bond broker, a person close to one of the companies said yesterday.

description: The oldest woman golfer to win a major championship was Babe Zaharias, who captured the 1954 United States Open at the age of 43 years 7 days. Beth Daniel can break the record by nearly three years with a victory at this week's McDonald's L.P.G.A. Championship.

description: After rising to its highest level in nearly eight years in April, the nation's unemployment rate unexpectedly slipped to 5.8 percent last month, the government reported today.

description: A Jersey City man who drew early and intense scrutiny in the terror investigation after Sept. 11 pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of conspiracy to commit credit card fraud and seems likely to be deported soon, his lawyer said.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Media Metrix Sold To Comscore
description: Jupiter Media Metrix, the ailing Internet research firm, said yesterday that it had sold its well-known unit that measures the audience of Web sites to Comscore Networks, a Reston, Va., rival, for $1.5 million. The Media Metrix unit briefly had a stock market value of $1.2 billion in 1999, before its ill-fated merger with Jupiter Communications. Last month, Jupiter, which is based in New York, sold its international business and patents to NetRatings, another rival. It is now looking for a buyer for its last remaining unit, the Jupiter research unit that prognosticates on Internet trends. Comscore, meanwhile, said it had raised another $20 million in venture capital. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Cablevision Seeks 2 Years to Prepare Antitrust Defense
description: Cablevision plans to ask a federal judge to grant the company nearly two years to prepare its defense against a lawsuit filed by YES that accuses Cablevision of violating antitrust laws.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Grandparents Lose Visitation Right
description: Grandparents cannot rely on a state law guaranteeing their right to visit their grandchildren. For the second time, the State Supreme Court ruled that the state's grandparent-visitation law was unconstitutional, saying that only parents have the right to decide who can visit their children. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Yes, He Looks Like His Brother, but Does He Listen to Mozart?
description: ''Like seeing a ghost,'' mutters Agent Oakes (Anthony Hopkins) after first laying eyes on Jake Hayes (Chris Rock) in ''Bad Company.'' Oakes, whose manner is so lethargic as to make you suspect narcolepsy, is speaking of the resemblance between Jake, a chess hustler and ticket scalper, and the low-energy C.I.A. operative Kevin Pope (also played by Mr. Rock). Oakes could also be talking about the script for this originality-deficient comedy thriller, produced by Jerry Bruckheimer.

title: BOARD PLANS MEETING TO DISCUSS ADELPHIA FINANCES
description: The board of Adelphia Communications will meet today to discuss the company's financial condition, people briefed on the meeting said yesterday. The directors of the company, which has been teetering on the edge of bankruptcy, met on Saturday and agreed to explore Adelphia's options, including asset sales, private equity investments and bank loans. However, there has been no indication that the company has been able to find fresh sources of capital. As a result, fixed-income analysts who follow Adelphia as well as some major bondholders say that a bankruptcy filing is imminent. The company has until June 15 to raise the money to make $50 million in interest payments on some outstanding bonds. Separately, the company filed documents with the government yesterday confirming that it would not cover the legal costs and expenses for four members of the founding Rigas family and another former employee. The filing also said that Adelphia had hired Christopher Dunstan as chief financial officer and Steven Teuscher as chief accounting officer. Geraldine Fabrikant (NYT)

title: U.S. Official Says She Met Central Figure in 9/11 Plot
description: Mohamed Atta, the man believed to have been the ringleader of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, asked a Department of Agriculture official for a loan in April or May 2000 to buy a crop-duster and questioned her about security at the World Trade Center and buildings in Washington, the official said in an interview that appeared last night on ABC News.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Like the music of Gloria Estefan, the food at Q Caf is Latin in the mildest way. Myriam Crdova, the Venezuelan chef, draws on the flavors and ingredients of South America and the Caribbean to establish tone and color, without committing herself to anything in particular. Salmon with ratatouille gets a Caribbean lilt from its rum reduction sauce, and roasted lobster tail with green risotto, one of the best entrees, picks up a slight tropical tang from grilled mango sauce.

title: A Mission To Save Money, A Record Of Otherwise
description: One of the nation's most powerful hospital-owned buying groups, which has a mandate to help nearly 1,500 nonprofit hospitals hold down costs, has posted a rise of 84 percent in its own spending over the last three years, the group's internal records show.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Priceline Buys Trademarks From Lowestfare
description: The Internet travel service Priceline.com said yesterday that it had purchased the trademarks and registered domain names of Lowestfare.com, a discount online travel seller based in Las Vegas. Priceline has already begun marketing its ''name your own price'' services on the Lowestfare Web site, allowing customers to bid on airline tickets, hotel rooms and vacation packages. The terms of the Priceline deal were not disclosed. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: James P. Mahoney -- Roman Catholic Bishop, 76
description: The Rev. James P. Mahoney, a retired auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, died on Saturday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 76 and had lived in the residence for retired priests at Archbishop Stepinac High School in White Plains.

title: Martha Stewart Said to Sell Shares Before F.D.A. Ruling

title: Wonders of Daily Life In Millennial Europe
description: For the photographer Frank Horvat, 1999 held not the gloom and doom of Y2K but the alluring promise of crossing from the 20th to the 21st century. That year he created a day-by-day photographic diary to take stock of his career and to document the life he shares with his children, grandchildren, friends and with Vronique Aubry, his companion of 20 years, in Boulogne, a suburb of Paris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREISKEL, BARBARA
description: PREISKEL-Barbara. To lose a close friend of over 50 years is devastating. It is hard to accept that a woman of such strength, fortitude and optimism can now live only in the thoughts of her family, friends and colleagues. Barbara was generous to a fault with her time and energy. She participated in the cultural and political life of the city, serving on a myriad of boards of educational institutions, philanthropic organizations, cultural organizations and ethics panels. Her kindness and grace endeared her to all who knew her. She will be missed. Our hearts go out to Bob, John, Rickey and Malakai. Rita and Leon Silverman

title: How Bloomberg Captured a Prize That Others Found Elusive
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is fond of saying that he is the right mayor for this time. But his ability to wrangle control of the New York City public school system after less than six months in office suggests that perhaps this is the right time for this mayor.

title: Banished to Her Home but Not Bored

For one, the movie has an individually wrapped, American singles affection for forgettable pop music; the title comes from the lighter-than-NutraSweet song by the Association that has made many of us want to flee weddings at which it was played. Mr. Taylor sets the picture in San Francisco, the home of the Association and of Zoe, played by Robin Tunney, another asset.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Unemployment Rises
description: German unemployment rose at the fastest pace in five years in May, as companies including Deutsche Telekom and Siemens continued to cut jobs to counter losses stemming from last year's economic slump. The number of people out of work rose a seasonally adjusted 60,000, the Federal Labor Office said, almost 10 times what economists had forecast. The unemployment rate rose to a two-year high of 9.7 percent, the Bundesbank said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Accord Against Bioweapons
description: An informal grouping of 33 countries from Europe, the Americas and the Pacific urged new measures to prevent the spread of chemical and biological weapons. Meeting in Paris, the so-called Australia Group, which was formed in 1984 in response to the use of chemical weapons in the Iran-Iraq war, said the nonbinding measures included new rules covering the export of toxins and technology that could be used to manufacture weapons. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Bishops Won't Meet With Victims Group
description: Weeks of dialogue between the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops and the main group that represents victims of sexual abuse by clergymen collapsed yesterday, as the bishop who leads the conference abruptly ended dicussions about having the leaders of the victims' group address the bishops' national meeting next week in Dallas.

title: On Eve of Sharon's U.S. Visit, 2 Settlers Are Killed in Raid
description: At least three people were killed early this morning, including one attacker, and four more were wounded when a pair of Palestinian gunmen sneaked into a heavily guarded Jewish settlement in the West Bank and opened fire on trailers where families were sleeping, a military spokeswoman said.

title: Custody Case In California Paves Way For 'Fathers'
description: In a case that could have a huge impact on child custody rights, the California Supreme Court has ruled that a man who cared for a 6-year-old boy can be considered his parent, even though the man is not the boy's biological father and was never married to the boy's mother.

title: Insuring Against Terrorism
description: Last fall, Congress responded energetically to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But the response was incomplete. When the fog of normalcy, with its paralyzing partisanship, again descended on Capitol Hill late last year, Congress had not yet enacted urgently needed legislation to provide federal help in insuring against similarly catastrophic terrorist attacks in the future. It must do so now, particularly in light of the constant stream of Bush administration warnings about new potential terrorist threats.

title: Some Relief, But No Joy, As 'Guilty' Rings Out

title: A New Court for Terrorism
description: Prosecuting terrorism is compromising our traditional court structures. The courts that are currently trying to handle such cases are clearly inappropriate. What we need is a specialized, secure and protected federal court dedicated to matters involving domestic and international security.

description: After 12 days of deliberation, a jury awarded $380,000 today to three women for illnesses it said the DuPont Company had caused by polluting a now-shuttered explosives plant in Pompton Lakes.

title: Mayor's Report Gives Hazy Peek At His Finances
description: There is only one precise dollar amount in the hundreds of pages of financial disclosure documents for 2001 that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg provided to news reporters at his accountant's offices yesterday: $122,520,000. That was not the mayor's net worth; nor was it his annual income from Bloomberg L.P., the financial information conglomerate he founded. Neither of those amounts was disclosed. The nine-digit figure is simply the amount Mr. Bloomberg gave away last year to more than 540 organizations across the country.

title: Evangelical Sales Are Converting Publishers
description: For decades, the world of Evangelical Christianity was as remote from the New York literary scene as the Bible Belt is from the canyons of Times Square. Now, as surging sales are propelling avowedly Evangelical books to the top of even the mainstream best-seller lists, the major publishing houses are getting religion, pushing for shelf space in Evangelical stores and paying blockbuster advances for their best-selling authors.

title: Defense Says Louima's Lawyer Questioned Officer's Guilt
description: Two weeks before the start of testimony in the retrial of a former police officer, Charles Schwarz, in the Abner Louima torture case, defense lawyers claimed yesterday that a lawyer who once represented Mr. Louima raised questions about Mr. Schwarz's guilt.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Raising Tobacco Tax
description: Gov. Mark Schweiker said he wanted to triple the cigarette tax to ease a projected budget deficit and discourage teenagers from buying tobacco. Under his plan, the cigarette tax, now 12 cents a pack below the national average, would rise to $1 from 31 cents, raising an additional $617 million a year. The governor also wants a 40 percent wholesale tax on chewing tobacco, which he estimated would raise up to $12 million a year.

title: Global Warming Follies
description: President Bush continues to stumble on the issue of global warming. Last year, to the dismay of America's allies, he rejected the 1997 Kyoto Protocol committing industrialized nations to reduce greenhouse gases. He also reneged on his campaign pledge to impose mandatory caps on carbon dioxide, the most important of those gases. Now he has dismissed a report written by his own experts. It asserts that human activities are largely responsible for global warming and warns that the environmental consequences could be severe.

title: CLEAN HARBORS GETS A CHEMICAL UNIT FROM SAFETY-KLEEN
description: The Safety-Kleen Corporation said yesterday that it had accepted a $311.3 million offer from Clean Harbors for its chemical-services unit because the bid was the only qualified one under bankruptcy court guidelines. Clean Harbors shares rose $3.09, or 36 percent, to $11.76. Clean Harbors, a provider of hazardous-waste removal services based in Braintree, Mass., is to pay $46.3 million in cash and assume $265 million in environmental liabilities. The company will get 21 service centers, 6 wastewater-treatment centers, 9 landfills and 4 incinerators, expanding the company's business in the West and Southwest, Canada and Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKNALL, ANN MACY HAMILTON

She is survived by her husband, William Stafford of Greenwich; two sons, William H. of Emigrant, MT, and G. Stafford of Greenwich; a daughter, Elizabeth Macy Bucknall Petty of Newburyport, MA; and five grandchildren, Meredith and Thomas Petty; and Christen, Ford and Jonathan Bucknall; and a sister Peggy Steers of Rye, NY. An energetic and accomplished volunteer, she was an international award-winning flower arranger and judge. She served on the Boards of Westover School, Greenwich Land Trust, The Mews, Hortulus Garden Club, Garden Club of America, New York Horticultural Society, Onteora Club, and the Onteora Arboretum. Memorial service on Wednesday June 12 at 2pm at Christ Church, East Putnam Ave, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Westover School, PO Box 847, Middlebury, CT 06762; NY Horticultural Soc, 128 W 58 St, NYC 10019; All Souls Church, Tannersville, NY 12485; All Saints Church, 300 Harrison Ave, Harrison, NY 10528.

The move came as insurers put a war-risk premium on shipping companies serving India and at least one airline, the Japan Airlines Company, canceled a flight. The dispute has already sent India's and Pakistan's financial markets reeling. Investors say a prolonged standoff may stunt India's economic recovery from a two-year drought.

title: Off to the Races
description: This afternoon, millions of people who never pay any attention to horse racing will be likely to flip on their television sets to watch the Belmont Stakes. War Emblem, a horse with a difficult personality and legs full of bone chips, is trying for the Triple Crown. If he wins he will become one of racing's immortals, right up there with Secretariat and Affirmed and Seattle Slew. If he loses, he will be consigned to the ranks of Canonero II, Real Quiet and Silver Charm, who all won the Derby and the Preakness but failed to make it in New York.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Principal Says He Is Gay
description: An elementary school principal in a Minneapolis suburb told parents in a letter that he is gay and planned to appear on a children's news program about gay families on Nickelodeon. The principal, Mark French, of Oak View Elementary School in Maple Grove, said he wanted to give parents a chance to talk to their children about his homosexuality before the program. Rosie O'Donnell will also appear on the program. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Keith Fuller, Who Led the Associated Press, Dies at 79
description: Keith Fuller, a newspaper reporter whose career took him from small-town Texas to the top job at the world's largest news agency, the Associated Press, died yesterday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 79.

title: A Barker, a Mill Worker and Oh, That Fatal Chemistry
description: Certain people, no matter what their size, seem to turn into giants when they set foot onstage. The Australian actor Hugh Jackman, as it happens, is a tall man. But that doesn't account for his towering presence on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall. It's not that Mr. Jackman, a fledgling movie star (''Kate and Leopold,'' ''X-Men''), is larger than life. It's that he makes real life look large.

title: Lakers' Express Takes the Nets for a Ride
description: Twice in the fourth quarter, the Nets drew to 6 points behind the two-time defending champion Lakers, frantically draining 3-pointers to cut what had been a 20-point deficit.

title: Many Americans, Unfazed, Go On Doing Business in India
description: Despite a warning from the United States government ''strongly urging'' its citizens to leave India, most American businessmen have yet to depart, hoping instead that war clouds will dissipate between India and Pakistan, nuclear-armed neighbors.

title: PFIZER DROPS OUT OF DRUG PARTNERSHIP WITH INDEVUS
description: Indevus Pharmaceuticals said its anxiety drug showed disappointing results in clinical trials and its partner, Pfizer, dropped development of the compound, setting off an 81 percent decline in Indevus's stock price. Pfizer, the world's biggest drug maker, will not pursue the development of the drug, called pagoclone, because the drug did not show the same effectiveness demonstrated in earlier tests, Indevus said. Indevus, which is based in Lexington, Mass., said it would decide whether to continue developing the compound after consulting with Aventis S.A., which licenses the drug to Indevus. Indevus's shares fell $4.45, to $1.07 a share, on Nasdaq.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: INSURER SEEKS INVESTORS Citigroup and Lehman Brothers Holdings are among companies in talks to buy as much as a quarter of China Life, the biggest insurance company in China. "We are talking to a lot of foreign companies, including Lehman Brothers and Citigroup," said Wang Xianzhang, general manager of the company, which has forecast premium income of 120 billion yuan ($14.5 billion) this year, giving it two-thirds of China's market. China Life is shopping for a foreign investor to help it compete as China's entry into the World Trade Organization allows foreign companies to invest there. (Bloomberg News)

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the dance listings in Weekend yesterday was published in error. It duplicated the illustration with the section's Family Fare column, showing the Madrid company Noche Flamenca, which is at the New Victory Theater in Manhattan through June 16. (The Streb company, mentioned in the caption, was cited correctly in the listings; it is appearing at the Joyce Theater, also through June 16.)

title: Bonds Still Blaming Everyone but Himself
description: They sold T-shirts with ''What will Barry do?'' on them before last night's game featuring Bonds at Yankee Stadium. Only kidding. There are savvy entrepreneurs around 161st Street, and they would have sold Bonds's first-grade picture if they had it, but they were not actually hawking any such shirts.

title: Forty Years Later, Yanks Win Again
description: There were two outs and two on in the seventh inning last night when David Bell's line drive whistled toward right-center field. A single would have tied the game, but second baseman Alfonso Soriano snared it, ending the threat. Bell slammed his bat on the dirt in front of home plate. The Yankees-Giants rivalry is back after 40 years, with line outs to second still frustrating San Francisco.

title: W.N.B.A. Lets Sting Go It Alone in Charlotte
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The Charlotte Hornets are packing their bags, loading their trucks and preparing to relocate to New Orleans for the next N.B.A. season. But they're not taking everything with them.

title: F.D.A. Takes Mixed Stance On a Leading Arthritis Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that Celebrex, a top-selling arthritis drug, must continue to carry a warning on its label that it can cause serious ulcer complications just as many other pain relievers can.

title: A New Department of Security
description: To the Editor:

title: ImClone Said to Have Known Early of Adverse Ruling on Drug
description: Executives of ImClone Systems heard that the Food and Drug Administration might turn down the company's application for approval of its cancer drug a few days before the announcement, people close to the situation said yesterday.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MICHIGAN: STATE SUED OVER DRUG DENS

title: Advertising Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Centers Still Lack Answers
description: After another familiar performance from Shaquille O'Neal, who scored 40 points tonight, the three overmatched Nets centers could only offer the same familiar answers.

title: Counterterror's Management Style
description: President Bush's proposed new Department of Homeland Security, bringing together scattered agencies with roles in protecting against terrorism, provides laudable managerial tidiness. Its creation will focus these agencies on their new priority of protecting the country. But the basic problem of overall strategy and coordination remains, and inserting a new agency into the mix will not solve it. Only the White House itself can play the crucial coordinating and planning role that is required.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, MURRAY
description: KATZ-Murray. You will always be #

title: Marijuana Studies
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKST, JEROME HENRY
description: BAKST-Jerome Henry. On June 7, 2002, age 83, in Verona, N.J. Retired National Director of Research and Evaluation for the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith. Former reporter and editor for N.Y. newspapers. Editor at The Voice of America. 1940 graduate of Harvard College. Survived by his wife Barbara, children Larry and Ellen, and beloved daughter-in-law Cristina and grandson Dylan. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, N.Y.C. Monday, June 10th, 1:30PM. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations be made to Harvard College.

title: Ex-Nets Star Pleads Not Guilty in Shooting Death of Limousine Driver
description: Jayson Williams, the former New Jersey Nets star, pleaded not guilty today to aggravated manslaughter and eight other counts in the fatal shooting of a limousine driver at Mr. Williams's estate in February.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: State Sued Over Drug Dens
description: The Wayne County prosecutor, Michael Duggan, has sued the state, saying it is not doing enough to stop drug dealing at houses it owns in Detroit. The state, which owns at least 5,000 houses in Detroit that were seized after the owners failed to pay taxes, said it was immune from such suits. The suit by Mr. Duggan, whose county includes Detroit, cites 20 properties where drugs continue to be sold after state seizure. He asks that the state sell the houses or knock them down. Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

title: School Control Nears Reality For Bloomberg
description: An agreement to put Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in charge of the school system could become law as soon as Monday or Tuesday, three Republican state senators said yesterday.

title: Bush Tells Security Adviser To Testify Before Congress
description: President Bush said today that he had asked Tom Ridge, his chief adviser on homeland security, to testify before Congress on the need for a new cabinet department to coordinate domestic defense, but neither the White House nor Mr. Ridge would say whether he was in line to become secretary of the new department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTKER, ELAINE (NEE BIENSTOCK)
description: ROTKER-Elaine (nee Bienstock). A resident of New Rochelle, NY for 50 years, passed away on June 7, 2002; she was born on November 20, 1927 in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late Martin Rotker. Together they cofounded Big Top Stores. Elaine was devoted to her family and friends. She was a homemaker and known throughout her community as ''Mrs. Big Top''. Dear mother of Ronnie (Abraham) Deutsch, Allen, Steve (Joy) and Glenn (Nancy). Beloved grandmother of Michelle (Michael) Grossberg, Benjamin (Melissa), Jonathan, Adam, Rachel, Jennifer, Lindsay, Alicia and Harry. Cherished great-grandmother of Jordan, Matthew, Jacob and Justin. Services are at Beth-El Synagogue, Northfield Road and North Avenue, New Rochelle, New York, Sunday at 10:30 AM. Interment, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: LET THEM READ 'GRAPES'

title: Sports of The Times; Greatness Is Now Harder to Define
description: WHAT will it take, someone asked D. Wayne Lukas the other day, for War Emblem to earn the imprimatur of greatness? The answer seemed to be open and shut: winning the Triple Crown today.

title: A Radio Spot On Burials
description: Following are excerpts from a recent radio commercial for the Catholic Cemetery Association of the Archdiocese of Boston:

title: Tottenville Wins Title
description: Elizabeth Delnavis and Tina Cortese each scored yesterday as Tottenville defeated McKee/Staten Island Tech, 2-0, to win the P.S.A.L. girls soccer title. Tottenville (24-3) won its eighth title in 10 years.

title: Searching For a Champion
description: If you were to build the perfect racehorse, it would be sound and move symmetrically and its optimum speed would be very high. Racehorses aren't built, of course, they're bred, and the thoroughbreds that actually make it to the racetrack have remarkably homogenous anatomies. It is other factors - personality, competitiveness, determination - that often give one horse the advantage over another. Still, when evaluating a young racehorse for purchase, and hoping it might turn out to be a Triple Crown winner, physical features become crucial. Here are the vital ones, using War Emblem, right, as a model.

title: Sports of The Times; Scarlet Humiliation, Public Redemption
description: HE ran directly to the Argentine stands, containing all those celestial blue and white jerseys, and he tilted back his head and he roared.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: 'Omaha Beach' As A Brand?
description: A proposal to build a commercial mussel bed on the D-Day landing beaches in Normandy has drawn protests from American World War II veterans and French villagers. The plan, devised by two French fishermen, foresees mussels being branded ''Omaha Beach'' mussels after one of the most famous landing sites. French local authorities declined to say whether the plan would be approved. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A profile of the militant Palestinian group Islamic Jihad on Thursday misspelled the surname of a leader based in Damascus and misidentified an American university where he once taught. He is Ramadan Abdullah Shallah, not Shalah. He taught at the University of South Florida, not the University of Florida.

title: China Detains Leading Lawyer And Keeps Him Incommunicado
description: In a case that has sent shivers through legal circles, the Beijing police have detained one of China's most prominent private lawyers for more than a month, holding him incommunicado for reasons that have not been disclosed.

title: Lakers Gain Glory From Fisher's Grit
description: LOS ANGELES  On the outside of his left biceps, Derek Fisher has the remnants of a minor abrasion from Wednesday night - a four-inch scratch that broke the skin and is coated with iodine. He was trying to keep up with Jason Kidd.

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: Mushroom Cloud Plates . . . Nah
description: State officials have rejected a design featuring a mushroom cloud for a special license plate to commemorate the Nevada Test Site. The Legislature approved plans for a plate that would honor the history of the federal government's 1950's and 1960's atmospheric tests of atom bombs about 65 miles outside Las Vegas. Department of Motor Vehicles officials said the threat of nuclear war between India and Pakistan and the debate over the Yucca Mountain nuclear waste depository in the state influenced their decision. They added that the state still planned to have a license plate honoring its nuclear history but that a new and less controversial design would have to be chosen. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Judge Delays Release of Cardinal's Deposition
description: Responding to an appeal by the Boston Archdiocese, a state judge today delayed the release of a transcript and videotape of a deposition that Cardinal Bernard F. Law gave this week in a sexual abuse case involving a priest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESEND, ESTELLE L.
description: KESEND-Estelle L. On June 6, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Michael, Samuel and Ellen. Cherished grandmother of Hadley. Dear sister of David Lansky and the late Milton Lansky. Devoted aunt and sister-in-law. Service Monday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Youthful Energy Enlivens An Often-Heard Symphony
description: Audiences for concerts by youth orchestras are typically packed with the proud family members and friends of the players. Still, there are good reasons for those who hear top-flight professional orchestras all the time to check out youth orchestra programs occasionally. It can be affecting to hear staples of the repertory performed by unjaded student musicians who have never played them before and are thrilled to be doing so. That was certainly true on Monday night when the Young Symphonic Ensemble presented its eighth annual Discovery Concert at Alice Tully Hall.

title: INSIDE
description: Priest Abuse Talks Collapse

title: National Briefing | West: California: Let Them Read 'Grapes'
description: The state's first lady, Sharon Davis, gave Californians a reading assignment, asking them to finish ''The Grapes of Wrath,'' by the native son John Steinbeck, by October. ''We hope this unique program will not only bring communities together,'' she said, ''but also inspire more Californians to make independent reading an everyday habit.'' State libraries will organize discussion groups and programs related to the book. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Insurer Seeks Investors
description: Citigroup and Lehman Brothers Holdings are among companies in talks to buy as much as a quarter of China Life, the biggest insurance company in China. ''We are talking to a lot of foreign companies, including Lehman Brothers and Citigroup,'' said Wang Xianzhang, general manager of the company, which has forecast premium income of 120 billion yuan ($14.5 billion) this year, giving it two-thirds of China's market. China Life is shopping for a foreign investor to help it compete as China's entry into the World Trade Organization allows foreign companies to invest there.

title: Snobs Are Made, Not Born
description: Joseph Epstein drives a Jaguar S-Type. His son went to Stanford. He has hobnobbed with Saul Bellow and shared meals with five other Nobel laureates (three 8" valign="top" align="left">

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: A Gain In Employment
description: Canada added 30,500 jobs in May, capping the busiest five months of hiring since 1994 and heightening expectations that the central bank will raise interest rates to restrain inflation. New positions in education and professional and scientific services led the surge. The unemployment rate rose to 7.7 percent from 7.6 percent in April as students looking for summer work drove up the number of job seekers.

title: Alberts Is Here to Race, Not Race Around
description: By the time Magic Weisner made it through the Belmont Park stable gate yesterday, Nancy Alberts had figured that New York was not as crazy and hectic as she had been led to believe. She had been told the 226-mile trip from Laurel Park in Maryland to Belmont would take at least five hours, an hour or so of which would include the inevitable traffic snarl. But from barn to barn, it took the van just a shade over four hours.

title: U.S. SMOKELESS STOPS ADS IN YOUTH-ORIENTED MAGAZINES
description: Responding to allegations that it has breached its 1998 tobacco settlement with 44 states, the U.S. Smokeless Tobacco Company, the nation's largest maker of snuff and chewing tobacco, said yesterday that it would suspend advertising in magazines with a disproportionate share of teenage readers. Earlier this week, two members of Congress and some state health officials urged state attorneys general to investigate the company for increasing its advertising in magazines with more than 15 percent of readers under 18, despite its pledge three years ago to leave teenagers out of its marketing plans. The company, which is owned by UST Inc., says it will cease placing ads in youth-oriented magazines like Sports Illustrated, Hot Rod and Motor Trend while it reviews the accusations. Greg Winter (NYT)

title: In Israeli Bed, Failed Bomber Tells of 'Love of Martyrdom'
description: On one ward of an Israeli hospital here, gilded tonight by votive candles honoring the Jewish Sabbath, Israeli soldiers wounded in a devastating suicide attack lie just a few rooms away from a failed Palestinian suicide bomber, who had hoped to kill as many of their comrades as possible.

title: Reaching for a Crown
description: War Emblem is on the doorstep of becoming the 12th Triple Crown winner, and the first since Affirmed in 1978. In today's 134th running of the Belmont Stakes, he has the look of a winner, and sits atop a field of 11 that is handicapped by Joe Drape, who lists the horses in order of preference. The morning-line odds are by Don LaPlace, the Belmont Park handicapper.

title: War Emblem Poised To Take Final Step
description: The wind swirled and the sloppy track sucked horses' hooves deep into the Belmont Park oval as War Emblem stretched his legs with an easy gallop yesterday morning. The would-be Triple Crown champion was not exactly walking on water, but he skipped over the soupy surface, deftly slicing through the raindrops as pleased as a child darting through a lawn sprinkler on a hot summer day.

title: Pittsburgh's Music Director Is Leaving
description: Mariss Jansons, the music director of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, will leave the orchestra when his contract expires in 2004.

title: Mubarak's Realism: Egypt Needs Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Sale of Home Of Tyco Figure Gets 2nd Look, Prosecutors Say
description: Manhattan prosecutors investigating L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco International, will reopen an inquiry into two transactions in which the $2.5 million home of a Tyco director was sold to the company's general counsel, a senior investigator said yesterday.

title: The Many Faces Of Amr I. Elgindy
description: The faces that Amr Ibrahim Elgindy offered the world were as different as the names he used.

title: Religion Journal; Efforts to Ensure a Catholic Burial
description: It is not a sale, per se. And price slashing would be the wrong term. But there is no denying that the Archdiocese of Boston hopes to attract customers with the low-cost burial packages it introduced this year.

title: Court Psychiatrist Concludes Defendant Is Not Mentally Ill
description: A court-appointed psychiatrist has determined that Zacarias Moussaoui, the sole person charged in the Sept. 11 attacks, is not mentally ill. The finding could clear the way for Mr. Moussaoui to be his own lawyer, government papers filed today showed.

title: Roberts Leads Gossett by One At Buick Classic
description: Loren Roberts and David Gossett have much in common. They both live in Germantown, Tenn. They both have won on the PGA Tour. And they both are disappointed that they did not qualify for next week's United States Open.

title: Nathan Mantel, 83, Developer Of Statistical Research Method
description: Nathan Mantel, who in the 1950's developed statistical techniques still widely used in epidemiology and cancer research, died on May 25 at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 83.

title: World Briefing | Europe: England: Progress Reported In Lockerbie Talks
description: British, American and Libyan officials made progress in a London meeting to work out compensation for the families of the 270 victims of the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland in 1988, a Foreign Office spokesman said. The meetings began last year after the conviction of Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi, a Libyan, and will continue, the spokesman said. An American lawyer said last month that Libya was willing to pay $2.7 billion. The current talks are addressing Libya's response to various United Nations resolutions seeking acknowledgment of responsibility for the bombing. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Deceptive Tans and Health Risks
description: Nothing quite marks the beginning of summer like the profusion of women's magazines filled with golden brown faces. Although the bronzed look on models and celebrities comes more from makeup than the sun, young readers get the wrong message.

title: US Airways and Unions Fail to Agree on Concessions
description: US Airways and its unions negotiated throughout the week on concessions by workers, but labor leaders said they were dissatisfied with the carrier's proposals. The airline has said it wants the unions to agree to concessions by next Saturday so it can apply for $1 billion in federal loan guarantees.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDONESIA: NO POLITICS, MILITARY CHIEF VOWS The new chief of the military, which once held a central role in governing, vowed that the armed forces would not delve into politics. Gen. Endriartono Sutarto, 55, left, a former army commander, follows an officer from the less politicized navy. The military's role has diminished since Suharto stepped down as president and the country moved toward democracy. General Sutarto, who once commanded Suharto's presidential guards, took a tough stand on independence movements in Aceh and Irian Jaya, saying Indonesia "will not tolerate separatists, whoever they are, wherever they are." (Reuters)

title: Man Gets Probation For Stabbing Two
description: The nephew of a reputed foot soldier in the Gambino crime family was sentenced to five years' probation yesterday after pleading guilty to stabbing the son of a reputed captain in the rival Genovese crime family and another man outside a Queens nightclub, the authorities said.

title: A California Downtown Is Poised for a Comeback
description: At high noon on a shirt-sleeve Saturday, one of the oldest downtown pedestrian malls in the country is as quiet as Christmas morning.

title: 150-Year Rivalry To Be Celebrated
description: The men's heavyweight crews of Harvard and Yale will meet on the Thames River in New London, Conn., today to race for the 137th time in a rivalry that inaugurated intercollegiate athletics in America.

title: Japan Set to Press Ahead On Privatizing Railways
description: Next week, in its latest effort to narrow its yawning budget deficit, Japan will finish privatizing a large chunk of its national railway system, completing a process that has dragged out for 15 years.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: MobilCom Retains Executive
description: MobilCom's supervisory board declined to dismiss the founder and chief executive, Gerhard Schmid, left, at a supervisory board meeting even after he admitted he broke German securities regulations. Mr. Schmid failed to inform fellow managers of a 68 million euro ($64.2 million) payment to a fund controlled by his wife, the board said last week, and ordered him to return the money by today. A spokesman, Rainer Sedat, said he did not know if the money had been repaid. France Tlcom, which owns 28.5 percent of MobilCom, had been expected to push for Mr. Schmid's ouster as part of a battle for control of the company.

title: Prosecutor Wove Snippets of Evidence Into Believable Pattern, Jurors Say
description: There was no direct evidence tying Michael C. Skakel to the murder of Martha Moxley. So prosecutors pieced together what they could: an array of circumstantial evidence that included a murder weapon that came from the Skakel home, incriminating statements by the defendant over the years, a witness who said Mr. Skakel had unrequited romantic feelings for Miss Moxley.

title: Barbara S. Preiskel, 77, Lawyer Who Fought Race Bans in Films
description: Barbara Scott Preiskel, a lawyer whose career helped break down racial barriers in entertainment law as well as on the numerous corporate boards on which she served, died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 77 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Republican's Candidacy Is Challenged By Democrats
description: The state Democratic Party today formally challenged the qualifications of Mitt Romney as the Republican candidate for governor, arguing to the State Ballot Law Commission that he had not been a resident of Massachusetts for the necessary seven years.

title: Argentine Ex-Minister Freed After Jailing on Arms Sale Charges
description: A federal appeals court in Argentina today ordered the release of Domingo Cavallo, a former economy minister who was jailed more than two months ago on charges that he approved more than $100 million in illegal arms sales while in office during the early 1990's.

title: A Triple Victory Gets Away From a Reisinger Winner
description: A unique triple almost materialized in the last three weeks. It began when Glenn Milgrim was a member of the team that captured the New York Grand National Teams title, earning the right to go to Washington next month for national playoffs. A week ago he won the Reisinger Knockout. In between, he entered for the Goldman Pairs with a different partner, Michael Polowan.

title: Computer System That Makes Data Secure, but Hard to Find
description: The origins of the F.B.I.'s computer problem go back in part to the long history of paper records at the bureau, and its reliance on secure computer systems of its own creation instead of the standardized systems that make the Internet so easy to search, say former Justice Department officials and others familiar with the technology.

title: Phyllis Wattis, 97, Collector Who Contributed to the Arts
description: Phyllis Wattis, a philanthropist and art collector who contributed more than $150 million to cultural institutions in California, and who was instrumental in financing a stellar collection for the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in the 1990's, died on Wednesday in San Francisco, where she lived. She was 97.

title: Little Progress Seen as U.S. Envoy Meets Indian Premier
description: Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage emerged from a meeting with Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee on Friday but gave no sign of a breakthrough in trying to persuade India to step back from a conflict with Pakistan.

title: Benitez Is Welcomed as Mets Return to Winning
description: This city welcomed back Roberto Alomar tonight, only a few boos creeping into the respectful applause that accompanied his first at-bat. Al Leiter returned to Jacobs Field for the first time since the 1997 World Series and labored to produce his finest effort in weeks.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Redrawn Congressional Map Approved
description: The United States Department of Justice approved a new map for Florida's Congressional districts that was drawn by the Republican-controlled Legislature and approved by Gov. Jeb Bush. The department found that the map, which takes into account the two additional Congressional seats awarded as a result of the 2000 census, would not diminish the voting strength of minorities. Democrats are challenging the plan in state and federal court. David E. Rosenbaum (NYT)

title: Remembering 9/11 With a Free Concert
description: An ambitious free music and dance concert to commemorate the terrorist attacks in New York, Washington and Pennsylvania is being planned for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here on Sept. 9, to be telecast nationwide on Sept. 11.

title: LAWMAKERS ASKING IF PLAN ON TERROR GOES FAR ENOUGH
description: Congressional leaders began wrestling today with President Bush's proposal to create a Department of Homeland Security, even as lawmakers and experts on terrorism questioned whether the new agency would significantly improve the government's ability to sift through mounds of intelligence data to extract clues about future attacks.

title: U.S. Lets Drug Tied to Deaths Back on Market
description: For the first time, the Food and Drug Administration is allowing a drug to go back on the market after it was removed for safety reasons.

title: Pope Selects Cardinal Egan To Serve on Top Vatican Court
description: Pope John Paul II has named Cardinal Edward M. Egan to the Supreme Tribunal of the Apostolic Signatura, the Roman Catholic Church's highest court, a sign of the Vatican's confidence in him even as his diocese is embroiled in the priest sex-abuse scandal.

title: A New Department of Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Lewis and Tyson Offer Contrast in Just About Everything
description: For nearly a decade, Mike Tyson and Lennox Lewis moved in opposite directions in virtually every way, year by year providing new and different reasons they could not step into the same boxing ring.

title: Finding the Beauty In Vintage Tech; To an Industrial History Group, Brooklyn Has Much to Admire
description: ''The good news,'' Conrad Milster boomed into the tour-bus microphone yesterday morning, ''is that we have an extra site today. It wasn't listed on your brochure.''

title: 1,100 Flee A Wildfire In California; 7 Homes Burn
description: A wildfire sparked by a welding accident on Thursday has roared through more than 25,000 acres of tinder dry brush in northern Los Angeles County, destroying at least seven homes and forcing the evacuation of more than 1,100 residents of the rural area, fire officials said.

title: E.P.A. and Budget Office to Work Jointly on Diesel Soot Rules
description: The Bush administration announced yesterday a controversial effort to engage budget watchdogs in writing environmental regulations, in this case a rule on cutting emissions of harmful soot by bulldozers and other off-road diesel equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, LEW
description: WASSERMAN-Lew. The Jerusalem Foundation mourns the passing of Lew Wasserman, a devoted friend of Jerusalem whose generous spirit will live on in the projects he helped to bring to life. His support for the Jerusalem Cinematheque expressed his deep commitment to the cultural life that has enriched all Jerusalemites. Our sincerest condolences to Edie and his entire family. Teddy Kollek, Int'l Chairman Ruth Cheshin, Int'l President Sandra Rubin, Exec Director Kenneth Bialkin, Acting Chair

title: A Phone Call Brings Sad News but Fails to Dent Faith
description: After a year of faithful prayers, an answer finally came early this morning.

title: Friends of Liz, and Dissenters, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Andersen Jury Rehears Some Testimony
description: In their second day of deliberations, jurors in the criminal trial of the Arthur Andersen auditing firm asked today to hear testimony from two people, including the government's main witness, read back to them. But they left the court at the end of the day without having reached a verdict on the obstruction of justice charge against the firm.

title: Victims' Remains Found Near Ground Zero
description: In the week since a ceremony marked the end of the recovery effort at ground zero, Fire Department and construction crews have found the remains of about a dozen victims in nearby buildings damaged in the Sept. 11 attack.

title: It's a Grudge Match
description: The game will not be played until Monday, but South Korea's meeting with the United States in the World Cup long ago became a grudge match. Passion is being stirred by a perceived injustice involving Olympic speedskating as much as by fervent nationalism over soccer.

title: Possible Charges Are Seen Over Ernst & Young Audit
description: Prosecutors are considering filing charges against one or more people involved in the Ernst & Young audits of CUC International that failed to detect a fraud involving hundreds of millions of dollars, a person involved in the investigation said last night.

title: To Signal the Saudis
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the improved infrared camera on the Hubble Space Telescope referred incorrectly to the device's sensitivity. It is 30 to 50 percent more sensitive than before, not 30 to 50 times.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: UNEMPLOYMENT RISES German unemployment rose at the fastest pace in five years in May, as companies including Deutsche Telekom and Siemens continued to cut jobs to counter losses stemming from last year's economic slump. The number of people out of work rose a seasonally adjusted 60,000, the Federal Labor Office said, almost 10 times what economists had forecast. The unemployment rate rose to a two-year high of 9.7 percent, the Bundesbank said. (Bloomberg News)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about accusations of anti-Semitism against the German novelist Martin Walser misstated the birthplace of Marcel Reich-Ranicki, a German literary critic who has condemned Mr. Walser's new novel. It is Wloclawek, Poland, not Berlin.

title: Daring Eclecticism That Turns Ominous
description: Most club disc jockeys tend to stick to a single kind of music. One reason may be that beyond the genre boundaries lie far too many choices amid the recorded sounds of an entire century. D.J. Shadow, from San Francisco, happily sifts sonic information and assembles collages. Although he kept busy with side projects, it has been six years since his first solo album, ''Endtroducing . . . . .'' (Mo' Wax/FFRR). He performed at a sold-out Irving Plaza on Monday night, the eve of the release of his new album, ''The Private Press'' (MCA).

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Swipe Card Replaces Food Stamps
description: Debit cards have replaced food stamps in Montana. Under the new system, food stamp benefits are transferred electronically to an account linked to the participant's card, known as the Montana access card. Gov. Judy Martz, who saw a demonstration of the system on Thursday, said she hoped it would encourage applications from those embarrassed about using food stamps.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: No-Show Lawyer Is Out Of Jail
description: A state appeals court released a lawyer jailed for contempt of court after the lawyer's repeated delays and failures to appear at trial. The lawyer, Joseph Hudak, was ordered jailed for six months on Tuesday by Judge David R. Cashman of Common Pleas Court after Mr. Hudak skipped two trial dates in late May for Kevin Somerville, who has been awaiting trial for 18 months on drug and robbery charges. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Calgary Signs Top College Player
description: The Calgary Flames signed Jordan Leopold, the former University of Minnesota defenseman who led the school to the national championship this year and won the Hobey Baker Award as Division I's top college hockey player.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Poland: Rover Considers Daewoo Plant
description: The British automaker MG-Rover Group confirmed that it was negotiating to take over the troubled Warsaw factory of the bankrupt Korean automaker Daewoo. A Rover spokesman said the plant would produce Rover-MG engines and cars for markets in Europe, and would continue building Daewoo models. The move would help Rover overcome high labor costs at its sole factory in Longbridge, England. The plant in Warsaw is operating at about 10 percent capacity, after the bankruptcy of Daewoo's Korean parent. No price has been set for the sale, but with unemployment at 17.8 percent and 320,000 Polish workers losing their jobs so far this year, the Polish government wants to keep the jobs of the 10,000 workers. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: PALM HARBOR BUYS NATIONWIDE, A MODULAR HOME BUILDER
description: Palm Harbor Homes, a maker and seller of factory-built homes, acquired the closely held Nationwide Homes for about $32 million to expand its line of custom-built modular homes. The acquisition is expected to add to per-share profit in Palm Harbor's fiscal year ending in March, the company said. Nationwide, based in Martinsville, Va., had revenue of $57 million last year.

title: MECHANICS REJECT A SOUTHWEST AIRLINES CONTRACT
description: Mechanics at Southwest Airlines rejected a final contract offer from the carrier yesterday. The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, representing about 1,400 mechanics, said the proposed contract was too long and the wage offer too low. More than 93 percent of the mechanics voted against the contract. ''What the company had on the table was substandard,'' said Ray Benning, director of the airline division at the Teamsters. If the carrier and the union cannot reach an agreement, the talks will go to the National Mediation Board. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, PAUL
description: GOTTLIEB-Paul. Paul Gottlieb began his involvement at The Museum of Modern Art more than 30 years ago, initially as an advisor to its publishing activities. He became an integral part of the MoMA family when in 1975 he joined the Museum's Board of Trustees where he served actively until now. For many years, he was Chairman of both the Trustee Committees on Publications and Membership, and a longtime member of the Finance Committee. In recent years, he was an active member of the Museum's Committee on Archives, Library and Research and its Marketing and Membership Committee. Paul had an especially close relationship with his fellow trustees and the staff of the Museum who will miss his stimulating presence and the pleasure of his good company. We send our most heartfelt sympathy to his wife Elisabeth Scharlatt, his mother Liza, his sister Gail, and his children Andrew and Nicholas and their families, and his stepson Nicholas Scharlatt. David Rockefeller Chairman Emeritus Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Board of Trustees The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: A SUCCESSFUL NORTEL STOCK SALE RAISES $1.3 BILLION
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation, North America's second-biggest maker of telephone equipment, said a sale of shares and equity units gave it net proceeds of $1.3 billion, about 40 percent more than it had planned to raise. The company, which is based in Brampton, Ontario, sold 550 million common shares, 400 million more than planned, raising $775.5 million and increasing Nortel's outstanding stock by 17 percent. Nortel also sold $714 million of units convertible to common stock. Nortel said it also gave underwriters the option of selling more than $200 million additional securities to meet demand.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: VENEZUELA: OFFICERS SEEK ASYLUM AFTER COUP One officer accused of taking part in the April 12 coup against President Hugo Chavez has taken asylum in El Salvador, and three others announced that they were seeking shelter in the United States. Rear Adm. Carlos Molina Tamayo, former head of the presidential guard, arrived in El Salvador aboard a commercial jet amid tight security. The other three officers are currently in Coral Gables, Fla. (AP)

After all, the girl-meets-perfect-gown scene is just as crucial to the fairy tale as the prince, and every high school girl looks for the dress that will, in an instant, turn her into the woman she hopes to become.

title: Playing the System
description: If you were a 12-year-old boy growing up in Darien, Ill., all the endless acres of perfectly flat green lawns might give you the idea that you should play baseball, and the monotony of mowing those lawns for $10 per might give you the idea that there must be better ways to make money. Twenty-five such kids signed up this year to be umpires for the Darien Youth Club, which for most of its 41 years has been hiring 12- and 13-year-old boys to officiate little kids' games. But in early spring, the Darien Youth Club's baseball commissioner received a phone call from the Illinois Department of Labor. Illinois state law stipulates that it is illegal for children under 14 to work for money (except to baby-sit, deliver newspapers, do yardwork, caddy or act in films); 14- and 15-year-olds must first obtain work permits. Following umpire sign-ups this winter, somebody filed an anonymous complaint against the Darien Youth Club. While the baseball commissioner tried to discern whether this call was a practical joke, the civil servant on the line informed him that his league was in violation of 86 counts of the state child labor laws, carrying a fine of up to $655,000.

title: The Man Who Makes It All Click

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKER, NATALYA A.

Natalia was always unattainable, now she truly is. Natalia was educated in Rostov, Russia and received her B.A. in foreign languages there. After coming to the U.S. to attend a small business program for Russian students at Wharton in 1995 she returned to Russia. In 1997 after a lengthy cross continent courtship she returned to the U.S. and was married to Michael Barker whom she leaves with a three year old daughter Polina Grace Barker of Manhattan. Natalia also leaves a mother, father and younger brother of Bataisk, Russia. She was 32 years old. There will be a memorial service for Natalia, June 11th at Calvary Church, 21st Street and Park Avenue South, at 3 P.M.

description: BAGRAM AIR BASE, Afghanistan, June 9  The officers from Company A had just sat down in their commander's tent to watch a bootleg DVD of "Star Wars: Episode II  Attack of the Clones" when the hot line to division headquarters clanged off its hook. The tent suddenly became very quiet.

title: Transporting Children Back to a Fabulous Dublin
description: ENTERING the lobby of the Ark, the children's cultural center in Dublin, to see its current production, ''Dublin 1742,'' everything seems as it should be: tickets are being sold and programs bought, and excited 9- to 14-year-olds circle around their teachers and parents. But walk up a flight of stairs to the center's Long Room, and the world of the play is flickering to life.

title: Judith Turner, David Gedzelman
description: Judith Marcia Turner and Rabbi David Alan Gedzelman are to be married today by Rabbi Irving Greenberg at Congregation Ansche Chesed in New York.

title: Debating Lawyers' Role In Malpractice Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAY, ALBERT, NEE KIZELSTEIN
description: KAY-Albert, nee Kizelstein, 87, Chairman of Albert Kay Associates, Inc., Concert Artists Management, international representatives of performing artists, having graced the fields of opera and classical music virtually his entire adult life, passed June 1. Our renowned impresario we lovingly called ''Butzie'' is survived by many adoring and devoted friends & family. Honoring his wishes, Butzie's ashes will be laid to rest with his longtime partner's in Central Park. We will gather today, June 9, at 1:00 PM, 58 West 58th Street, #

title: Final Accounting
description: The first time we went to see Len, he spent an hour and a half talking about movies and musicals and the actors he'd had as clients way back when nobody knew their names. ''F. Murray Abraham owes me,'' he said. My wife, Kate, finally cut in and explained that we were pretty worried, that most of our income that year had been untaxed and that we hadn't paid any quarterly estimates. Len looked at us incredulously. ''Can one of you explain to me,'' he said, ''how the hell 'Ordinary People' beats out 'Raging Bull'? Does that make a lick of freakin' sense?''

title: Korean Troops Are on Alert For World Cup
description: A division of 10,000 South Korean troops was placed on alert today in and around the southeastern city of Taegu as South Korean and American athletes prepared to face each other in a crucial match on Monday in the World Cup soccer tournament.

title: No Windmills! Mini Golf Gets Serious
description: GROWING up in Yonkers, N.Y., Gary Shiff did not have many opportunities to play golf on a real golf course. So he played putting games with his brother and sister in their living room, trying to roll a ball across the carpet into a cup.

title: Extra Innings?
description: BARBARA MALDONADO and Crystal Rudolph, postal workers in Port Chester, just wanted to play a little softball this spring, on the post office team. The village's softball league was traditionally all male, but that didn't seem to be a problem.

title: INVESTING WITH: Bernard R. Horn Jr.; Polaris Global Value Fund
description: IN some respects, investing overseas was more challenging two decades ago, says Bernard R. Horn Jr., who runs the Polaris Global Value fund.

title: The Nation; Redrafting the Church's Rules on Redemption
description: FOR a religion based on redemption and forgiveness, Roman Catholicism has not always been consistent about how those states of grace can be attained and who can attain them.

title: A Snake Census on Fire Island
description: ''FIRE ISLAND is a good habitat for snakes,'' said Dave Brotherton, who was using a headless golf club to poke under a 2-by-4-foot sheet of corrugated metal lying amid the scrub of the Sunken Forest. ''They like sand.''

title: The Love of Her Life
description: RARE AND COMMONPLACE FLOWERS

title: Feeding the Urge to Stoke and Sear
description: FOR Americans, and especially American men, outdoor cooking is practically a constitutional right. Republican or Democrat, Northerner or Southerner, black, white or anywhere in between, the primal urge to ignite fires and sear hunks of meat transcends almost all bounds. Even stray vegetarians can satisfy the need to play with fire with the various meatless patties that masquerade as burgers.

title: Kashmiri Militants Angry at Being Blocked From India
description: Pakistani soldiers are blocking Kashmiri fighters from crossing into India for the first time since the insurgency began 13 years ago, militant leaders said this week.

title: Chess Moves Are Artistic With Pieces Made of Glass
description: THE game of chess is not merely an idle amusement, wrote Benjamin Franklin in 1779. A passionate player, Franklin believed the rules and etiquette of chess offered beneficial lessons for shaping moral character. He overlooked the visual element; the game with its two opposing teams of sculptural figures has considerable artistic potential.

title: An Aging Beauty Gets A Very Public Makeover
description: ART conservators are used to being strictly behind-the-scenes players, but these days one of them is taking a very public role here at the Museum of Fine Arts. Every Tuesday and Wednesday through this month, Liza Leto Fulton can be seen at work in the Romanesque Sculpture Gallery restoring a fresco, a monumental 14th-century Italian crucifixion. Since large-scale frescos are rare in American museums, the sight of one being repaired in public is especially novel.

title: Down From the Peaks
description: The last economic golden age probably peaked not much more than two years ago. That's when the Dow Jones industrial average reached its all-time high of 11,723, on Jan. 14, 2000, just after a fourth quarter in 1999 in which gross domestic product grew at an annualized rate of 8.3 percent, the largest quarterly increase in just over 15 years.

title: June 2-8: ENVIROMENT; DELAYED OIL DAMAGE
description: In the Galapagos, where Darwin conceived of natural selection, a bit of unnatural selection took place after a tanker spilled its load in January 2001. Sea lions and birds were largely spared, but, in a finding that suggests even small amounts of oil can have disastrous consequences, thousands of marine iguanas appear to have died from an indirect toxic effect, scientists reported. They eat seaweed, and the oil may have killed the bacteria in their guts that help digest the algae, causing them to starve. Andrew C. Revkin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNE, MARIE P.
description: DUNNE-Marie P. Age 92 on June 5, 2002 of Locust Valley, New York. Beloved mother of Robert C. Dunne. Fond sister of Jean Eakins. Also survived by two nieces and one nephew. Retired librarian at the Locust Valley High School for 16 years. Memorial service to be held Tuesday 11AM, June 11 at St. John's of Lattingtown Church. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Locust Valley Library in her name would be appreciated. For information call Roslyn Heights Funeral Home at 516621-4545.

title: Jennifer Heyman, David Millstone
description: Jennifer Laura Heyman, a daughter of Ronnie F. Heyman and Samuel J. Heyman of New York, is to be married today at her parents' weekend house in Greens Farms, Conn., to David James Millstone, a son of Margaret A. Cotter of Potomac, Md., and Robert J. Millstone of Chicago. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to officiate.

title: Daniel Does Not Let Her Play, or Lead, Slip
description: Beth Daniel responded well after every bad hole today in the third round of the $1.5 million McDonald's L.P.G.A. Championship, the second major of the season. She made birdies twice after bogeys and that helped her go into the final round with a four-shot lead.

title: Swiss Expo: Four Towns and a Barge
description: Through Oct. 20, the Swiss National Exposition brings the country into the 21st century spotlight. The last Swiss Expo was held in Lausanne in 1964, but the current fete breaks the single-site tradition by spreading out to four lakeside towns -- Neuchtel, Biel, Murten and Yverdon-les-Bains -- where innovative ''art beaches'' have been constructed along the shoreline. A fifth site, the barge Jura, billed as a modern pirate ship, moves among the four towns.

title: Ideas & Trends; Scoring Hits, Runs and Asterisks
description: AND so the uproar over the illegal use of steroids by baseball players has passed, trampled under the persistent parade of home runs. The games go on. Balls keep sailing over fences in beguiling arcs. Fans dance as box scores grow as bloated as the sluggers' physiques.

title: Word for Word/Rhymes and Misdemeanors; His Beat Is Cops and Cadence, For There's Poetry in Commotion
description: ASK most reporters on the cop beat, and they'll tell you it's hard enough turning grammatically challenged police incident reports into publishable prose. But Kevin L. Hoover sees poetry in them. He is the founder, publisher, editor and irreverent police-blotter reporter of the six-year-old Arcata Eye (circulation: about 3,000), a weekly serving an enclave in the coastal redwoods of Northern California where serious crime is rare, and environmental activism and ''alternative'' lifestyles brush up against more traditional ways.

title: No Longer Defenseless, Dance Finds an Advocate
description: YOU could almost hear the collective thud of sinking hearts when the first announcements of the new Jazz at Lincoln Center complex were made two years ago. What about modern dance, that other indigenous American art form? It badly needs a theater of its own, with a seating capacity large enough for performances by major dance troupes. And why was dance hardly mentioned as a possible use for the jazz theater on dark nights?

title: June 2-8: ENVIROMENT; GLOBAL WARMING HEAT
description: In a sudden shift from merely calling for more research, the Bush administration sent a report to the U.N. listing many likely harms from global warming, including more heat waves and the disappearance of coastal marshes and Rocky Mountain meadows. But the report seemed to please no one: environmentalists were upset it called only for voluntary measures to cut emissions linked to the problem. And groups financed by coal, oil and car companies said President Bush erred by accepting that humans were the likely cause of most of the warming. In California, The Santa Rosa Press Democrat searched for the positive. Its editorial page said, ''If there is a 12-step program for global warming, last week President Bush took the first step: He acknowledged that the problem exists.'' Andrew C. Revkin

title: Women Soon to Be Majority of Veterinarians
description: Veterinary medicine used to be a man's world. The veterinarian yanked calves from their mothers' wombs, wrestled with horses to give them shots and dressed the wounds of dogs, cats and the occasional canary.

title: Dana Ostrowsky, Ethan Orlinsky
description: Dana Freas Ostrowsky and Ethan George Orlinsky are to be married today by Rabbi Reuven Siegel at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: Learning to Work on Both Sides of the Camera
description: FOR the past two months, 150 youngsters holding digital video cameras or trailed by film crews have ranged far and wide over the South Fork. They have visited cemeteries and abandoned barns, wandered over dunes and shot scenes in a film studio and in their own homes.

title: Poem: 'Fluke'
description: Don't go -- let me explain.

title: New in Montreal: The Old Lachine Canal
description: The Lachine Canal, a nine-mile waterway in southwest Montreal, has reopened to pleasure boating after being closed for 32 years. Built in 1825 to link Lake St. Louis with the Old Port, the canal recently underwent a five-year refurbishment, which will be celebrated in a summerlong program of concerts, tours and art exhibitions. A new visitors center explores the history of the canal, which formed the backbone of industrial Montreal for more than a century. Made obsolete by the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway in 1959, the route was closed to shipping in 1970.

title: Baffert Learned to Appreciate Triple Crown
description: Even the harshest critics and enemies of the trainer Bob Baffert would acknowledge that the Triple Crown chase has given him more than his fair share of heartbreak.

description: To the Editor: Suzanne Berne eloquently described visiting ground zero in ''Where Nothing Says Everything'' (April 21). When my husband, I and one of our sons visited in April, a feeling of deep sadness permeated the neighborhood.

title: Baggage Bomb Detector Is Unreliable, Experts Say
description: The Transportation Department's stopgap method for detecting bombs in checked bags -- a system it intends to install at 429 airports by Dec. 31 -- will not reliably detect explosives in a suitcase, European and American experts say.

description: The Giants left New York when Joe Torre was 17 years old, but his memory drifted back that far when he slipped while answering a question on Friday night. Torre, the Brooklyn-born Yankees manager, called San Francisco's baseball team the New York Giants. "I used to be a Giant fan," Torre explained.

title: Justice for Hoaxers' Threats Has a Court System Divided
description: On May 31, Kenneth Harrell went before a federal judge in Manhattan to be sentenced for a cruel hoax. Calling himself by an Arab name, Mr. Harrell had posted an Internet message last Sept. 12, one day after the attack on the World Trade Center, threatening to bomb the World Series and kill 60,000 people. ''It is about time you Americans get what you deserve!'' he wrote. ''The job isn't done.''

Only in New York, however, are small parties rewarded for nominating someone who is not a member, has probably never attended a meeting and is possibly unclear about what the party stands for.

description: WIENER-Sivan. Died June 5, 2002. Of Holon, Israel. Killed by a suicide bomber while riding on a bus near Megiddo. Beloved sister of Dudu Wiener had just celebrated her 19th birthday in Tel Aviv the night before the bombing. A friend said, ''She was so happy and full of life.''

title: Film Can't Be Our Hamptons, Locals Say
description: IT was hot on the South Fork last week, and that's not a weather report. Tempers flared from Montauk to Westhampton after ABC's two-part broadcast of ''The Hamptons,'' a documentary by Barbara Kopple.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TICINETO, FELIX L.

Devoted grandfather of Daniel Steppe, Alissa Maples, Christopher M. Clough and Kevin Maples. Also survived by his brother Alfred. Loving great-grandfather of Anabelle Maples. description: CHATTING with reporters on the last night of his trip to Africa last month, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill suggested that he was returning home a changed man.

''Manhattan Condo Guide'' is the second edition of a book first produced four years ago by Yale Robbins Inc., a publisher of real estate data.

title: ASBURY PARK PLAN
description: Asbury Park's city council last week approved a $1.2 billion plan to redevelop 56 acres of waterfront. The plan, which could take a decade to complete, calls for the creation of a hotel and construction of 2,500 new housing units. Some residents oppose the redevelopment, and financing for the plan has not been secured. Jeremy Pearce

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 112 of The Times Magazine today about the lucrative market for used books on the Internet misstates the amount paid for a first edition of ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' at a rare-book shop in Manhattan, which benefits from customers' wish to see and touch high-priced items in person. The sale was $8,000, not $12,500.

title: War Is Hell. Then There's Town Ball.
description: ENOUGH, already, with the dressing up in ancient uniforms and re-enacting slaughters from a century or two ago. There's a better type of history to celebrate, as anyone who saw the Hogs square off against the Bulls last weekend can tell you.

title: Houston Does Not Believe In Tears
description: After the disaster, I got back to Houston as quickly as possible and at first could hardly tell anything had happened. It was not as if a bomb had exploded or a building had collapsed. There had been a disappearance, that is all, and the effect was not apparent until I got out of the car. It was the fear I noticed, and I saw it first when I sat down with Elyse Lanier.

description: To the Editor:

title: Congress's Experiment Overseeing Spies
description: The ongoing joint investigation by the House and Senate intelligence committees into the intelligence failures preceding Sept. 11 opens a new chapter in the experiment to bring democratic oversight to secret government activities. Democracy and spying don't mix well. Secrecy runs counter to democratic accountability; openness threatens the success of espionage. We need the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. to acquire information that may protect us, but we recoil at having secret agencies in our open society.

title: U.S. Open Ticket Sale is Set
description: Tickets for individual United States Open sessions, as well as Arthur Ashe Kids' Day, will be sold starting tomorrow at 9 a.m. at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens.

title: Your Friend, the Universe
description: Children like stories; science can be a harder sell. But Jennifer Morgan of Princeton has combined ''once upon a time'' with subjects like the relationship of energy and matter, black holes in space and the formation of elements in ''Born With a Bang: The Universe Tells Our Cosmic Story.'' Yes, it's a first-person recounting by the universe (''Like you, I started as a tiny speck.'') that ends with the formation of the Earth. Ms. Morgan had attended a workshop that combined cosmology with an ''inner'' point of view and noted the interest of her son, then 6, when she told him about it. She took two cosmology courses at Princeton, consulted with the professors and with local schoolchildren, found an illustrator -- Dana Lynne Andersen -- and published her book, for ages 7 to 12, a few weeks ago. The book, $19.95 in hardback and $9.95 paperback, is available from its publisher, Dawn Publications, (800) 545-7475, www.dawnpub.com. A second book, which continues the story through the extinction of dinosaurs, is due next year, and she plans a third.

title: Bishops' Abuse Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Nets Go From Poverty to Misery to Glory
description: HE had a killer jump shot and no public profile. Who, we asked, was this guy wearing out our chain-link nets?

title: Villeneuve Detoured From Victory Lane
description: Five years since becoming the first Canadian to win the Formula One drivers' title and five years without a victory  let alone another overall title  the short, hunched, balding guy with glasses returns to the Canadian Grand Prix in Montreal today still one of the sport's biggest stars.

title: Company In Trouble? Just Let Him Loose
description: DAVID BOIES is a more passionate litigator than softball player. His teammates at last Sunday's game at the home of Steven Brill, the journalist and entrepreneur, were therefore not surprised when he sat out an inning or two to conduct some business. Mr. Boies found a spot on the bleachers at Mr. Brill's private softball diamond in Katonah, N.Y., and listened in by cellphone on a board meeting of Adelphia Communications, the cable operator facing questions about its accounting and its dealings with its founding family.

description: The Capital Group Companies, Wellington Management and Legg Mason were the biggest buyers of Tyco International shares in the first quarter, according to regulatory filings.
