title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSSE, MALCOLM JOSEPH JR.
description: BOSSE-Malcolm Joseph Jr. Died on May 3, 2002. Author of 20 novels. Professor of literature. Father of Mark Bosse and husband of Lori Mack. His work will be cherished after those now living are long gone.

title: Term Limits Drove Them Out of Public Life, Redistricting May Help Them Get Back In
description: A line is already forming for people who want to run for the New York State Legislature this year.

title: The Day of the Big Game
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 10  Funky old Seoul Station bustling at 6 a.m. Young people in red shirts gently line up for southbound trains. No chanting, no banners, no attitude. Like going to a church picnic. Stacks of Korean-style sushi in wrappers. Too early in the day to even think about it. Dunkin Donuts opens up precisely at 6:30 a.m. I go for one plain and one chocolate and a pretty good cup of black coffee. Front page of the Korea Times has article about resentment toward United States. Who is this Apolo Ohno, anyway?

title: Business; A Cloth Man With an Iron Will on Trade Policy
description: A FEW months ago, Jim DeMint expected an easy path to a third term in the House from a western section of South Carolina. Instead, he is facing a tough Republican primary on Tuesday.

title: Where The Buck Stops
description: In May 1948 President Harry Truman faced one of the most excruciating decisions of his presidency: whether to extend U.S. recognition to a newly declared Jewish state in Palestine, a recognition that was sure to complicate U.S. interests in the Arab world. What made the decision even more difficult was the fact that the president's two smartest advisers disagreed, and were passionately pulling him in opposite directions. Mr. Truman's secretary of state, Gen. George C. Marshall, strongly opposed recognizing Israel. But the president's most trusted political adviser, Clark Clifford, argued forcefully in favor of creating a Jewish homeland.

title: State to Buy Ski Area's Land To Preserve a Mountaintop
description: After years of contention over plans to develop the top of Hamburg Mountain, the site of the Mountain Creek ski area, the state and the area's owners have come up with a arrangement intended to preserve the spot.

title: Mercy Pleas and Other New Issues Arise in Challenges to Death Penalty
description: While New York's highest court is considering the first appeal of a death sentence imposed under the state's 1995 capital punishment law, an appeal of a second death sentence is posing a new set of challenges to the law and the way it is being applied.

title: Splicing Spiky And Romantic
description: DANCERS and choreographers are like lovers, their affairs consummated in dreary rehearsal studios but nonetheless filled with delight. Take Wendy Whelan and Christopher Wheeldon. They will be reunited on Thursday in Mr. Wheeldon's untitled new piece, which will be performed by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater as part of the company's 10th-anniversary Diamond Project.

title: Sarah Ginn and Gregory Harris
description: Sarah Elizabeth Ginn, the daughter of Margaret G. and Frank H. Ginn of Winnetka, Ill., was married yesterday to Gregory Scott Harris, a son of Helene B. Hickey of Hanover, N.H., and the late Ralph E. Harris. The Rev. Mark E. Bruce performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church on Nantucket Island.

title: Jane Veronis and Santi Aguado
description: HAVING grown up on Park Avenue, Jane Shepard Veronis knows every Rollerblade-friendly doorman and can identify every private school uniform in the neighborhood (she herself wore the ones for Sacred Heart and Spence). You can always hear her coming. A jewelry designer, she generally wears about 20 bangles on each wrist and necklaces as long as jump-ropes.

title: More Sleeping Room On the Way to Asia
description: Singapore Airlines' sleeper seat, called the SpaceBed, which flattens into a bed, is being introduced in business class on the carrier's London-Singapore route this month, said airline spokesman James Boyd. The SpaceBeds are 6 feet 6 inches long and 27 inches wide.

title: June 2-8: BUSINESS; INDICTED
description: With corporate America under scrutiny for aggressive accounting and business practices, L. Dennis Kozlowski -- an executive whose company, Tyco International, epitomized the deal-making of the 1990's -- became the first top executive indicted in the post-boom era. Mr. Kozlowski, below, resigned as Tyco's chairman just before prosecutors in Manhattan charged him with evading more than $1 million in New York sales taxes on artwork. Mr. Kozlowski pleaded not guilty. Alex Berenson

title: Start Me Up
description: In 2000, near the height of the economic boom, 8.6 percent of American adults -- about 15.7 million people -- were in the process of starting businesses. In 2001, that number fell to 7 percent, or 12.7 million. Here, in ascending order of capital invested, are some who braved the tougher climate and got businesses rolling in the past 18 months. The costs reflect only what the owners spent before opening their doors. The break-even dates represent their own (optimistic) predictions.

description: IT'S official: Westchester County has terrible air.

title: Let the Circus Come to Town
description: ON Wednesday, May 22, Paul J. Feiner, the Greenburgh supervisor, and several other representatives passed a law prohibiting circus animals from performing in the town of Greenburgh. I want to call to Mr. Feiner's attention the Clyde Beatty Cole Brothers troupe. Friends and family members have had the privilege of traveling with this fine group of performers over the years. My father was a treasurer for the Circus Fans Club of America, and had a long relationship with the Clyde Beatty Cole Brothers troupe. And I wanted to introduce him to John Pugh, the owner of this nearly century-old show, or Renee Storey, their spokeswoman. I'm certain that they would have welcomed the chance to show Mr. Feiner and the other officials around the back lot.

title: LANGUAGE REQUIREMENTS
description: State Education Commissioner William Librera last week asked the Department of Education to consider eliminating the two-year language course requirement for graduation from high school and replacing it with a requirement that graduates be proficient in a foreign language. The commissioner said proof of proficiency was more important than the amount of time a student spends in a language class. The board will consider the request next month. Karen DeMasters

title: Police Struggle to Stop Headlight Thefts
description: WHEN it comes to taking advantage of new technologies, the black market never seems to be far behind the automobile manufacturers.

title: A Tycoon And His Conscience
description: At 4:30 p.m. on a Wednesday afternoon, a silver Jaguar convertible with white leather interiors and vanity plates (CAT 1, as in cool cat) sweeps up the driveway of a grand residence north of Johannesburg and comes to a halt outside an outsized porte-cochere. Moss Ngoasheng is just returning home from a golf outing. He bounces out of his car, apologizes for being slightly late and offers to show me around. ''When I was in prison,'' he says, ''I promised myself that when I was free I would build my own house as soon as I could afford it.''

title: The Shock Of the New Took Place Every Day
description: In 1900, Queens was a collection of towns and villages, some dating to the 17th century, connected by roads with forests and farms in between. Only 39 years later, it was the host of the World's Fair and its vision of a new urban world of expressways, bridges and buildings designed in a Modernist style that was both brutally simple and lyrical in its hope for a noble future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKNALL, ANN MACY HAMILTON
description: BUCKNALL-Ann Macy Hamilton. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother, died of cancer June 5, 2002 at Greenwich Hospital. She is survived by her husband, William Stafford of Greenwich; two sons, William H. of Emigrant, MT, and G. Stafford of Greenwich; a daughter, Elizabeth Macy Bucknall Petty of Newburyport, MA; and five grandchildren, Meredith and Thomas Petty; and Christen, Ford and Jonathan Bucknall; and a sister Peggy Steers of Rye, NY. An energetic and accomplished volunteer, she was an international award-winning flower arranger and judge. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIKLER, NORMA JULIET
description: WIKLER-Norma Juliet. 60, on May 28, at her home in Rincon de Salas, Costa Rica. Professor Emerita (sociology), University of California, Santa Cruz; Norma had also been Senior Research Associate at the Institute for the Study of Social Change, University of California, Berkeley, and Bunting Fellow at Harvard University. She was founder and first director of the National Judicial Education Program to Promote Equality for Women and Men in the Courts (NJEP), sponsored by the NOW Legal and Education Fund and the National Association of Women Judges, which led to the creation of over fifty gender bias task forces for the state and federal courts, most of which were chaired by the Chief Justices of the state court systems. She was also a frequent advisor to court systems abroad. Her several overlapping careers included the sociology of the legal, medical, and military professions and the establishment of an organic pineapple industry in Costa Rica. Norma co-authored the first children's booklet on organic agriculture that is now used throughout Costa Rica's primary school system. She will be missed by her large and adoring family, by friends and colleagues worldwide, and by the children and working people of Rincon de Salas. Information on a June 30 memorial event and charitable fund will be posted at www.wikler.net. Norma's loving sisters and brother, Marjorie Senechal, Daniel Wikler, Jeanne Wikler

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEENY, JOHN PAUL
description: SWEENY-John Paul. 73, of Huntington Beach, CA, found eternal peace on May 30. Born and raised in New York City, Dr. Sweeny received his secondary schooling at De La Salle Institute, pre-med at Manhattan College, and graduated from New York University Medical School in 1956. Military service included: Occupation of Japan at the end of World War II with the 11th Airborne; Army Medical Corps during the Korean War; and as a U.S. Navy (MC) surgeon from 1956 until 1966. He resigned as Commander U.S. Navy (MC). He served his internship at Great Lakes Naval Hospital, his surgical residency at NYU School of Medicine, Bellevue Hospital; and as a surgeon at U.S. Naval Hospital, Portsmouth, NH; and at U.S. Naval Hospital, USS Haven, Long Beach, CA. He also seved as a trauma surgeon with the U.S. Marine Corps on an attack transport as part of the blockade of Cuba during the Missile Crisis, and with the Third Marine Division as a field surgeon in Vietnam, where he was awarded the Navy Commendation Medal with V for valor. Dr. Sweeny was a FellowAmerican College of Surgeons; Diplomate, American Board of Surgery; and member, American Board of Surgery of Trauma. He was Assistant Clinical Professor of Surgery at UCLA, Harbor General Hospital, Long Beach, CA, and Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery at UC Irvine, Irvine, CA. He was licensed to practice medicine in New York, California and Nevada. He was in solo practice in general, vascular and trauma surgery in Long Beach, CA, and on staff at Long Beach Memorial Medical Center and served as Chairman, Department of Surgery; Medical Director, Department of Surgery; and at Long Beach General County Hospital, where he was Medical Director, Department of Surgery. Doctor Sweeny is survived by his wife Donna M. (nee Stojakovic); 10 children: Dr. Patricia Rywak, Nora Brizgys, John P. Seeny, Joan Chimento, Helen Beardsworth, Dr. Francis M. Sweeny, Matthew Sweeny, Sarah Sweeny, Jessica Sweeny, and Christopher Sweeny; and 20 grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife Patricia (nee Jenkins) and a daughter, Elizabeth. He was the eldest of the 14 children of John P. and Helen (nee Hays) Sweeny. He is survived by seven sisters: Joan Sweeny, Helen Sweeny, Brigid Hankin, Mary Healy, Rita Kenny, Nora L'Eplattnier and Deborah Hirsch; and four brothers: Michael Sweeny, Denis Sweeny, Paul Sweeny, and Timothy Sweeny. He was predeceased by two sisters, Patricia Malach and Priscilla Sweeny. A wake service was held on June 4 at Brothers Funeral Directors, Huntington Beach, and a Mass of the Resurrection was celebrated at St. Bonaventure R.C. Church, Huntington Beach, on June 5. Visiting will be at Campbell - Dean Funeral Home, 260 Main St., Oneida, NY, on Tuesday, June 11, from 4 to 8 PM. A Mass celebrating his life will be offered at 10 AM, Wednesday, June 12, at St. Patrick's R.C. Church. Burial will follow in St. Patrick's Cemetery.

title: 'The Emperor of Ocean Park'
description: The news of the Judge's death reached us several times in the years before the event actually occurred. It is not that he was ill; he was, as a rule, so vigorous that one tended to forget his wavering health, which is why the heart attack that at last cut him down was, at first, so difficult to credit. It is simply that he led the sort of life that generated rumor. People disliked my father, intensely, and he returned the favor. They spread stories of his death because they prayed the stories were true. To his enemiesthey were legion, a fact in which he gloriedmy father was a plague, and rumors of a cure always raise hopes in those who suffer, or love those who do. And, in this case, some of those my father plagued were not people but causes, which, in America, can always count their lovers in the millions, unlike individual people, who die unloved every day. Not one of his enemies but hated my father, and not one but spread the stories. Self-styled friends would call. They were always whispering how sorry they were. They had heard, they would say, about my father's heart attack while promoting his latest book up in Boston. Or his stroke while taping a television interview out in Cincinnati. Except that there would not have been one: he would be alive and well in San Antonio, speaking to the convention of some conservative political action committeethe Rightpacs, Kimmer calls them. But, oh, the gleeful rumors of his demise! My mother hated the rumors, not for the heartache, she said, but for the humiliationthere were standards, after all. But not in the rumor mill. Waiting in the checkout line at the supermarket, just before my son Bentley was born, I was astonished to read on the cover of one of the more imaginative tabloids, just beneath the weekly Whitney Houston story (TALKS CANDIDLY ABOUT HER HEARTBREAK) and just above the latest way to lose as much weight as you want without diet or exercise (A MIRACLE DOCTORS WON'T TELL YOU), the gladsome tidings that the Mafia had put out a contract on my father, because of his cooperation with federal prosecutorsalthough, when Kimmer made me go back to the store and buy it and I read the whole thing, all one hundred fifty words, I noticed a pointed lack of detail as to what my father could possibly have to cooperate with prosecutors about, or what he might know about the Mafia that would be so dangerous. I called Mrs. Rose, the Judge's long-suffering assistant, and finally caught up with him on the road in Seattle. He took the opportunity to warn me yet again on the insidiousness of his enemies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURCHELL, GEORGE D.
description: BURCHELL-George D. Of Larchmont, a retired Supreme Court Justice died June 7, 2002, at the Sarah Neuman facility in Larchmont, New York. He was 92, born on October 7, 1909, to Edgar and Josie Burchell. A retired Justice of the New York Supreme Court, he was a graduate of Amherst College and New York University School of Law. He was admitted to the Bar in 1937. Judge Burchell served as an Assistant District Attorney in Westchester County, the Town Supervisor for the Town of Mamaroneck, Town Justice for the Town of Mamaroneck, County Court Judge; and Justice of the Supreme Court. Upon his retirement at age 76, he continued to work as a judicial hearing officer at the Westchester County Courthouse for many years. In World War II, he attained the rank of Major in the United States Army and was assigned to the military government in Germany, serving as Military Government Commander and President of the Intermediate Military Government Court. Judge Burchell served as a member of the Board of Directors for the Westchester Shore Humane Society, the Larchmont - Mamaroneck Harrison Bar Association, the Larchmont Chamber of Commerce and the United Nations Association. He was appointed Honorary Chief of the Town of Mamaroneck Fire Department and Trustee of the Westchester Community College. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Burchell and his nephew, Richard Burchell, his nieces, Janet Norcross and Wendy Schlinger, and his grandnephews, Peter Schmitt and Jonathan Burchell. Visiting hours will be 2-4 PM and 79 PM, on Monday, June 10, 2002, at the Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, New York, and the funeral will be at 10 AM, on Tuesday, June 11, 2002, at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church in Larchmont, with burial following at the Kensico Cemetery.

title: Crime

The more they struggle to leave the past behind and move on, the more they become mired in family history, compelled to relive their childhood traumas and pay for their fathers' crimes. Burke treats his favorite theme with unusual depth and considerable sorrow in JOLIE BLON'S BOUNCE (Simon & Schuster, $25) by linking two savage rape-murders in a Louisiana bayou town with the casual sexual sadism once practiced on the plantation of the town's most prominent family. title: QUICK BITE/Red Bank; The Dogs Are Fine, but the Soup Is Stirring
description: Gary Sable started out a hot dog man. That was seven years ago when he christened his Red Bank deli That Hot Dog Place. If he knew then what he knows now, he may have given ''soup'' a place in that title. There is no denying that Mr. Sable's hot dogs are a cut above the rest. The jumbo stadium-style hot dogs are placed neatly inside a kaiser roll, big enough to contain the heaps of toppings Mr. Sable endows them with. The Junk Yard Dog ($2.75), for example, covered in cole slaw, sweet and hot relishes, chopped onions and mustard, is as filling a meal as any overstuffed deli sandwich. But since the store's early days, it has been Mr. Sable's homemade soups that gain most of the attention. Hungry customers line up outside the store and into the adjacent alley to grab one of three daily soup specials (it's standing room inside, too, as there are no tables). The soups come in three takeout sizes, 12 ounces ($2.25), 16 ounces ($2.85), 24 ounces ($4.25) and 32 ounces ($5.35). There are also sandwiches ($1.75 for a half, $3.50 whole): tuna, chicken salad, roast beef, baked ham and roast turkey and cheeses. Mr. Sable, who has always been the store's only employee, has no set schedule for soup recipes. He decides his flavors only the night before and posts them on his Web site, www.soupmeister.com, early in the morning so his customers can easily check if their favorites, everything from sausage gumbo to split pea, are being served. Jo Piazza

title: Photographic Wonderlands
description: Little girls were not Lewis Carroll's problem; Victorian science was. Before he starting writing books for children, before he began his quarter-century-long hobby of creating the luminous images collected in LEWIS CARROLL, Photographer: The Princeton University Library Albums (Princeton University, $49.95), Charles Lutwidge Dodgson taught mathematics at Oxford. He was a man of science at a time when science had taken a decidedly dark turn -- geologists pondered the implications of extinction, chemists calculated how many years were left before the sun would stop shining, geometers contemplated what lay beyond the eternal fixities of Euclid. In 1860, the British Association for the Advancement of Science met at Dodgson's college to discuss, among other things, the theories of Charles Darwin. ''The ensuing debate,'' Roger Taylor, a British photographic historian, writes, ''has gone down in history as a defining moment that saw the evolutionists successfully argue their case against the fundamental beliefs of the established Church.'' Dodgson set up an outdoor studio to document the meeting. The many hundreds of collodion-process photographs included in the book (out of an estimated lifetime total of 2,500) include striking tableaus of the very latest in comparative anatomy, the juxtaposed skeletons of monkey and man. Dodgson's portraits of the living (among them Tennyson, Ruskin and Faraday) exhibit faces as gaunt and haunted as their fleshless peers, but tucked between the legs and sitting on the laps of these tortured Victorians lounge their ethereally composed children. Yes, Dodgson liked to photograph children. Naked ones, too. Taylor and Edward Wakeling's studied yet entirely accessible book shows that the children in Dodgson's studio harbored no apprehensions about what they were doing or who they were doing it with. Frederick Kaufman

But inside, in the dark smoke-filled corners, it's the art-scene version of the celebrity-packed club Moomba during its heyday in the late 1990's. On any given night, provided it's after midnight, you can usually spot Chlo Sevigny in her latest vintage get-up, chatting with an independent film director like Harmony Korine. Members of the band the Strokes, a mass of unwashed hair and jeans, may be holding court among the bottles of beer, and local musicians like Interpol, the Yeah, Yeah, Yeahs and the Liars might be mingling with record label scouts and the fashion stylist Pat Fields.

Miss Moxley and Mr. Skakel were friends and neighbors; both just 15 when she died. With witnesses' memories faded and no direct forensic evidence, the jury had to piece together circumstantial evidence to reach its verdict. Mr. Skakel faces up to life in prison when he is sentenced on July 16. David M. Herszenhorn

title: Solo in Italy
description: To the Editor: Mr. Rotella's essay reminded me of an experience about 30 years ago. I was having lunch with a friend in one of the many trattorias under the typical arcades of Piazza Malpighi, next to the old University building in Bologna. It was market day, and the square was filled with farmers, most in a typical black hat and coat. Around 1 p.m., small groups of the farmers, chatting in a most friendly way, began to enter the trattoria. To my surprise, each was seated at a small table set for one. There they proceeded to eat alone, slowly and in silence.

title: June 2-8: INTERNATIONAL; 26 DIE IN LAND FEUD
description: In Santiago Xochiltepec, a dirt-poor mountain village in the southern Mexican state of Oaxaca, 26 men and boys were killed, and 87 children left fatherless, when a long-simmering dispute over land boiled over. The attackers, armed with assault rifles, came from the next village, Las Huertas, whose people have fought their neighbors since 1935 over the rights to 40 square miles of forest lying between them. Land disputes are common in Mexico, but few have ever turned so violent. Tim Weiner

description: HARRISON-David A. III. Of Prince George County, Virginia, on June 8, 2002, from complications of Alzheimer's disease at age 85. Born on August 30, 1916, to David A. and Elizabeth D. Harrison. Graduated from the Episcopal High School, Alexandria, VA, and received his undergraduate and law degrees from the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, VA. He was the husband of Mary Anderson Harrison who died in 1990 and the father of two sons, David A. IV of Richmond, VA, George A. of Prince George County, VA, and three daughters, Marjorie H. Webb of Greenwich, CT, Mary T.H. Keevil and Anne L.H. Armstrong, both of Manakin-Sabot, VA, and thirteen grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A brother also survives him, Richard D. Harrison of Richmond, VA, two sisters Anne H. Brown of Wilmington, DE, and Elizabeth H. Monroe of Bethesda, MD. His brother James G. Harrison died in 1989. He served in the army during the Second World War and attained the rank of captain. He spent his career at White & Case and Reynolds & Company (now Morgan Stanley) in New York City and retired to Flowerdew Hundred Farm in Prince George County, VA, in 1978 to pursue his love of farming, and to devote time to the architectural excavations on Flowerdew, which date back to 1617. He was closely affiliated to the University of Virginia and served as a trustee of the Law School Foundation, and a member of the Alumnae Association Board of Managers. Mr. and Mrs. Harrison endowed three professorships, the David A. Harrison Awards for Undergraduate Research that are given annually, and supported the football program and the rebuilding of the Law Grounds that carry his name. The Mary and David Harrison Institute of American History, Literature and Culture is under construction. A memorial service will be held on June 13 at Flowerdew Hundred Farm, Prince George County, VA, at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in his name can be made to the University of Virginia School of Medicine, Department of Neurology, P.O. Box 800394, Charlottesville, VA 22908-0394.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEENY, JOHN PAUL
description: SWEENY-John Paul. 73, of Huntington Beach, CA, found eternal peace on May 30. Born and raised in New York City, Dr. Sweeny received his secondary schooling at De La Salle Institute, pre-med at Manhattan College, and graduated from New York University Medical School in 1956. Military service included: Occupation of Japan at the end of World War II with the 11th Airborne; Army Medical Corps during the Korean War; and as a U.S. Navy (MC) surgeon from 1956 until 1966. He resigned as Commander U.S. Navy (MC). He served his internship at Great Lakes Naval Hospital, his surgical residency at NYU School of Medicine, Bellevue Hospital; and as a surgeon at U.S. Naval Hospital, Portsmouth, NH; and at U.S. Naval Hospital, USS Haven, Long Beach, CA. He also seved as a trauma surgeon with the U.S. Marine Corps on an attack transport as part of the blockade of Cuba during the Missile Crisis, and with the Third Marine Division as a field surgeon in Vietnam, where he was awarded the Navy Commendation Medal with V for valor. Dr. Sweeny was a FellowAmerican College of Surgeons; Diplomate, American Board of Surgery; and member, American Board of Surgery of Trauma. He was Assistant Clinical Professor of Surgery at UCLA, Harbor General Hospital, Long Beach, CA, and Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery at UC Irvine, Irvine, CA. He was licensed to practice medicine in New York, California and Nevada. He was in solo practice in general, vascular and trauma surgery in Long Beach, CA, and on staff at Long Beach Memorial Medical Center and served as Chairman, Department of Surgery; Medical Director, Department of Surgery; and at Long Beach General County Hospital, where he was Medical Director, Department of Surgery. Doctor Sweeny is survived by his wife Donna M. (nee Stojakovic); 10 children: Dr. Patricia Rywak, Nora Brizgys, John P. Seeny, Joan Chimento, Helen Beardsworth, Dr. Francis M. Sweeny, Matthew Sweeny, Sarah Sweeny, Jessica Sweeny, and Christopher Sweeny; and 20 grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife Patricia (nee Jenkins) and a daughter, Elizabeth. He was the eldest of the 14 children of John P. and Helen (nee Hays) Sweeny. He is survived by seven sisters: Joan Sweeny, Helen Sweeny, Brigid Hankin, Mary Healy, Rita Kenny, Nora L'Eplattnier and Deborah Hirsch; and four brothers: Michael Sweeny, Denis Sweeny, Paul Sweeny, and Timothy Sweeny. He was predeceased by two sisters, Patricia Malach and Priscilla Sweeny. A wake service was held on June 4 at Brothers Funeral Directors, Huntington Beach, and a Mass of the Resurrection was celebrated at St. Bonaventure R.C. Church, Huntington Beach, on June 5. Visiting will be at Campbell - Dean Funeral Home, 260 Main St., Oneida, NY, on Tuesday, June 11, from 4 to 8 PM. A Mass celebrating his life will be offered at 10 AM, Wednesday, June 12, at St. Patrick's R.C. Church. Burial will follow in St. Patrick's Cemetery.

description: French Back Chirac at Polls

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSTEIN, BERNARD
description: ADELSTEIN-Bernard. The officers and members of B'nai B'rith Project H.O.P.E. Foundation mourn the loss of our beloved founder and mentor, Bernie Adelstein. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at Riverside Chapel. Shelly Rothman, President Warren Lew, Secty.-Treas. Henry Segal, Administrator

title: Mayor Confident as City and Teachers Hold Talks
description: Negotiators for New York City's teachers and the Bloomberg administration met for more than five hours yesterday as they sought to reach a new teachers' contract within the next few days.

title: Long Day's Journey Into a 3rd Overtime
description: Around midnight Saturday, after Lennox Lewis had turned Mike Tyson into an entity as bubbly as old King Tut, it seemed unfair that my long viewing day was ending. Hadn't I swept aside my schedule of grocery shopping and laundry for the French Open 13 hours before? But then I flipped to ABC and there were the Detroit Red Wings and the Carolina Hurricanes in overtime. This game would not stop.

title: You Kidding Me? How Global Crossing Pursued Tony Soprano
description: The F.B.I. is investigating the business practices of both men, leaders who depend on street smarts to run their respective organizations.

title: Martin Sparks Nets, But It Is for Naught
description: This morning, hours before Game 3 would begin, Jason Kidd implored his teammates to follow his lead: if the Nets were going to go down, go down fighting. His comments were directed at all of the Nets, but he had particularly stern words for Kenyon Martin, who had been all but invisible in Game 2.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOTTLIEB, PAUL
description: GOTTLIEB-Paul. Memorial service, Great Hall Cooper Union, on Wednesday, June 12, at 6 P.M.

title: Alan Kranowitz, 61, Reagan Legislative Adviser
description: Alan M. Kranowitz, whose knack for bipartisan politics during his tenure as chief Congressional liaison for Ronald Reagan helped further the president's second-term legislative agenda, died on June 3 at a hospital here. He was 61 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: McDonald's Second Is Good Enough
description: Debbie McDonald and her horse, Brentina, placed second in yesterday's musical freestyle phase in Gladstone, N.J., enough to overcome a fifth-place finish in last week's grand prix competition and earn the top spot on the United States equestrian team dressage squad that will compete in the world equestrian games at Jerez, Spain, in September.

title: Bermuda for Buddies
description: The Bermuda Department of Tourism has arranged five-night accommodation packages for two people with a $400 air-fare credit for the the companion. At the 47-unit Ariel Sands, for example, rates for the first person start at $1,568, the second, $1,168, including air fare from New York. At the 244-room Elbow Beach, it's $1,378 and $978; and the 43-room Rosedon, $1,263 and $863. You must book by June 30 and travel by Oct. 31. Call (800) 237-6832 and ask about the Compliments of Bermuda  Companion Flies Free package. Taxes extra; subject to availability and good for travel Monday to Thursday.

title: Models in Glass
United States Salvages a Point
Rumsfeld Sounds Optimistic Note as He Arrives in India for Talks
description: NEW DELHI, June 11  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld arrived here tonight declining the title of peace negotiator, but saying he carried a number of American ideas for calming two militaries facing off in a dispute that just days ago seemed to be rapidly drawing India and Pakistan into large-scale, perhaps even nuclear, war.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Paying Children To Pull Weeds
description: Officials in several counties are paying children to pull out a pernicious weed to help eradicate it. With the aid of a federal grant, children under 16 years old will receive $10 for every bag of the weed, yellow flowering dyer's woad. The plant originated in Europe, where it is still used in textile dye, but in the western United States it sucks up more water from the soil than native vegetation and crowds out plants that are a food source for a variety of wildlife. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: A Visual Collaborator And His Accompanists
description: There's a guy named Jim, who has an affable, bearded face and draws charcoal renderings of uneasy dreams. He doesn't draw real things, but most of the drawings are suggested by real things. This is a partial list of what seems to haunt him: frogs, chess pieces, deep-sea creatures, pigs, beetles, fetuses, early Mickey Mouse, wattles, coats of arms.

title: Contract Will Cost City More Than It Expected
description: To pay for some of the raises included in the new teachers' contract, New York City is relying on a one-time infusion of $275 million from the state that may not be available to cover the city's rising education costs in the future, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, WALLACE A., JR.
description: BROWN-Wallace A., Jr. Of New York City and Ponte Vedra Fla. Passed away on June 9, 2002. Born July 8, 1920 in Atlantic Beach, Fla. to Wallace A. and Nelle C. Brown. Graduated from St. Andrews Academy, Sewanee, Tn. and from North Carolina University, Chapel Hill, class of 1943. Member of the North Carolina Society, The University Club, Doubles and the Ponte Vedra Golf and Tennis Club. Reception at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., on Wednesday, June 12, 2002 at 6-8PM. Funeral Service, Thursday, June 13, 2002 at 12:30PM at The Church of the Epiphany, Episcopal, 74th St. at York Ave.

title: Healthy Household Improvement
description: A study released last week has concluded that lung cancer rates in developing countries could be lowered sharply by a change relating to smoke that has nothing to do with tobacco: switching from fire pits to vented stoves.

title: Bloomberg's Test: Control of Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, BENJAMIN
description: WARD-Benjamin. On June 10, 2002, at age 75. Beloved husband of Olivia. Devoted father to Benjamin Ward, Jr., Jacquelyn Ward, Gregory Ward, Margie Ward Lewis and Mary Ward. Loving grandfather of nine and great-grandfather of two, with numerous nieces, nephews, cousins and godchildren. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Saint Patrick's Cathedral, 5th Ave. at 51 St., Friday, 10 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Lupus Foundation, 149 Madison Ave., NY, NY 10016 or the American Diabetes Association, 149 Madison Ave., NY, NY 10016.

title: THREE GOLD MINING COMPANIES ANNOUNCE MERGER
description: Continuing the consolidation of the global gold mining industry, three midsize North American producers, the Kinross Gold Corporation, Echo Bay Mines Ltd. and TVX Gold Inc., said today that they planned to merge through an exchange of stock. The combined company, which would be the world's seventh-biggest gold producer, will have a market value of about $2 billion and an annual output of two million ounces. The company, to be based in Toronto, will be 40.3 percent owned by existing Kinross shareholders. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the News Summary yesterday for the obituary of the art dealer Holly Solomon misstated her age. She was 68, as the obituary reported, not 79.

title: Taking Them Out to Breakfast, All for a Ball Game
description: ONE day soon, if you are a multimillionaire, the phone could ring and you could get an invitation from Bob Tisch to breakfast at the Regency Hotel, which he happens to own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, BERYL DAWSON
description: THOMAS - Beryl Dawson, died June 9, widow of Lewis Thomas, beloved mother of Abby, Judy and Eliza. We can hear her and our father laughing, together again.

title: Powell Says Details of a Palestinian State Will Come Soon
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  President Bush will soon give a more specific vision for creation of a Palestinian state, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today.

title: Hour of Reckoning in the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Newest Skill for Future Ob-Gyns: Abortion Training
description: Like just about every fourth-year medical student, Nicole Fanarjian recently made the rounds of hospitals in search of a residency program that would train her for her specialty: obstetrics-gynecology. This spring, she visited 13 programs, and in nearly every interview, she asked this direct, but sometimes eyebrow-raising question: ''Do you provide residents with abortion training?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERLE, CLOTILDE FARGO
description: MERLE - Clotilde Fargo. June 6th, 2002 in San Francisco. Her family and friends celebrate eighty-eight years of a wonderful life.

title: Baby Boom? Nobody Told the Stork; Little Evidence Seen Yet of a Post-9/11 Surge in Births
description: There has been a fair amount of talk about the prospect of rambunctious times at hospital delivery rooms this summer. There has been discussion of how the tragedy of 9/11 has caused many people to rethink their priorities, put first things first. First things often start with family. First things often start with a baby.

title: Williams Sharply Cuts Annual Forecast
description: The Williams Companies sharply reduced its 2002 earnings forecasts yesterday and announced plans to scale back its energy marketing and trading business, as part of an effort to shore up its creditworthiness.

title: New York Canals, Waiting to Be Explored
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGDOFF, BEATRICE
description: MAGDOFF-Beatrice. Died peacefully at home on June 9, 2002. She is survived by Harry, her husband of 69 years, her son Fred and his wife Amy Demarest and grandson David.

title: Defending Champs France Are Out of World Cup
description: INCHON, South Korea, June 11  David Trezeguet's body language told it all. After hitting the cross bar in the 74th minute, Trezeguet lifted his palms to the sky and smiled meekly, as if to say, "What can you do?'

title: John Gotti Dies in Prison at 61; Mafia Boss Relished the Spotlight
description: John J. Gotti, who seized control of the Gambino crime family in a murderous coup, flaunted his power during a flamboyant reign as a Mafia boss, and then spent the last years of his life locked away in a maximum security penitentiary, his gang in shambles, died yesterday at the federal prison hospital at Springfield, Mo. He was 61.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: New Palm Operating System
description: Palm, the largest maker of hand-held computers, said yesterday that it had begun shipping the final version of its new operating system to licensees and developers. The new system, Palm OS 5, offers better security, performance and support for wireless standards, the company said. The new system will not be available until later this year. The software is the first big release from PalmSource, the software subsidiary the company created last year. Palm shares, which have been down recently, rose 27 cents, or 22 percent, to $1.49. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Association of Independent Commercial Producers, New York, honored eight companies and two unions for the equipment and assistance they provided to illuminate ground zero so that workers at the site could complete recovery efforts. The companies and unions, which typically provide lights for shooting movies and commercials, received the association's Jay B. Eisenstat Award for Distinguished Service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONGAN, ELIZABETH
description: MONGAN - Elizabeth. Of Rockport, MA, on June 7, 2002. Elizabeth, well-known author of many art publications, daughter of the late Charles and Elizabeth Mongan, survived by nephew, Charles Mongan, of Cambridge, MA. Funeral mass will be held on Wednesday, June 12, at 11 AM, at Sacred Heart Church, Gloucester, MA. Visiting hours will be held at the Burgess and Mackey Funeral Home, 201 Main Street, Rockport, MA, on Tuesday from 48 PM. The burial will be held at Holy Cross Cemetery, Malden, MA. Contributions to Bryn Mawr College, 101 North Marian Ave., Bryn Mawr, PA 19010.

title: Parents on Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Parties in South Korea, Not Protests
description: On the vast city hall plaza where a half-million demonstrators shouted protests against dictatorial rule a generation ago, about 200,000 red-shirted young people roared a new set of slogans this rainy afternoon with an equally nationalist message.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETKIN, ELAINE
description: ETKIN-Elaine. Beloved wife of Asher. Loving mother of Daniel and Benjamin. Devoted daughter of Mary and Samuel Grossbart. Dear sister of Ted and Rosalie Grossbart. Caring sister-in-law of Judy and Sol Levy. Loving motherin-law of Geri. Services Tuesday, June 11, noon, at Beth Shalom Chapels, 760 Smithtown Bypass, Smithtown, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bridge Lanes To Reopen
description: The final two lanes of the Williamsburg Bridge will open nearly two months ahead of schedule this week, because of an incentive clause in the $202 million contract for the reconstruction project, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. Rebuilding of the north roadways began in January 2001. Work on the north inner roadway was completed 50 days ahead of schedule and qualifies for the maximum $5 million incentive. In December, the north outer roadway was also finished almost two months ahead of schedule. The bridge will now also have a pedestrian and bicycle path, which should be finished by fall. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Direct Train To Midtown In Sight at Last For Montclair
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey announced plans today for a new train station and parking garage here that will eventually give rail commuters in northern Essex County and Passaic County a direct connection to Pennsylvania Station in New York.

title: The Abomination of Whaling
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Bishop Daily Testifies
description: Bishop Thomas V. Daily of Brooklyn, a former top official in the Roman Catholic Church in Boston in the 1970's and 80's, gave a sworn deposition yesterday about his dealings with John J. Geoghan, a defrocked Boston priest whose case began the current scrutiny of the church over child molestation. Bishop Daily cooperated fully in his deposition, his spokesman said. But Patrick McSorley, 27, who said he was victimized by Mr. Geoghan, said the Bishop Daily evaded many questions. Mr. Geoghan was convicted this year of groping one boy, and more than 130 people in the Boston Archdiocese have accused him of molesting them. Jason Begay (NYT)

title: H.I.V. Survey in South Africa Suggests Plateau in Infections
description: The number of H.I.V. infections in South Africa appears to have leveled off at about one-quarter of the adult population, according to the results of an annual survey announced today by the Health Ministry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAX, IRWIN GARY
description: WAX-Irwin Gary. Age 52. Beloved brother of Milton, Albert and Sally. Brother-in-law of Robert and Margaret, uncle of Julie and Leslie. Our hearts ache at your passing. We love you. Rest in peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOVE, SAMUEL
description: RABINOVE-Samuel. At age 79, of White Plains, NY, on June 9, 2002, after a long illness. Devoted and beloved husband of Anna. Cherished father of Beth, Amy, David and Ellen. Loving grandfather of Brian, Daniel, Justin, Zachary and Benjamin. Father-in-law of Barry and Cathie. Also survived by many lifelong friends and devoted colleagues. National Legal Director of The American Jewish Committee from 1966 to 1997. He dedicated his life to his family and the pursuit of human rights and civil liberties and will be lovingly remembered for his keen intellect, his sharp wit, and his passion for living. Memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the American Jewish Committee, 165 East 56th St., New York, NY 10022.

title: Bush Sees Sharon and Says Time Isn't Ripe for Peace Conference
description: With Israeli troops still surrounding Yasir Arafat's headquarters, President Bush met Prime Minister Ariel Sharon today and declared that the time was not ripe to call together a summit meeting on Mideast peace because ''no one has confidence in the emerging Palestinian government.''

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Annan Opens Food Conference
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan opened a United Nations conference on hunger by urging a fairer distribution of food supplies and support for farmers. ''While some countries produce more than they need to feed their people,'' he said in Rome, ''others do not, and many of these cannot afford to import enough to make up the gap.'' Most speakers on the first day were African heads of state who called for removal of barriers to farm trade with developed countries and greater access by farmers in poorer nations to land, cheap loans, and technology for producing hardier crops. Mr. Annan, who is from Ghana, said that almost 200 million people in Africa, or 28 percent of the population, are chronically hungry, and that several countries in southern Africa face ''outright famine'' in coming months. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: The Rove Doctrine
description: Some months ago an academic colleague -- a man with strong Democratic connections -- urged me to write a couple of columns praising the Bush administration. ''What should I praise?'' I asked.

title: Belmont's Ratings Top the Field
description: The big winner in Saturday's marathon of national sports viewing was NBC's broadcast of the Belmont Stakes. The anticipation of War Emblem winning the Triple Crown elevated the overnight Nielsen rating to a 9.2, up 88 percent from last year's 4.9.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Woodbury: West Nile Virus Detected
description: For the first time this year, the West Nile virus has been identified on Long Island, the authorities said yesterday. The mosquito-borne virus was discovered in two dead crows, one found May 27 in Woodbury and the other found the next day in Plainview, Nassau County health officials said. So far this year, 11 dead birds infected with the West Nile virus have been found in New York State, 5 of them in Albany County and 4 in Rockland County, a spokeswoman for the State Health Department said. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Big Spender in the Primary Is Looking for Donations
description: During New Jersey's primary campaign for the United States Senate, Douglas R. Forrester used money like a clenched fist to overpower and intimidate his Republican rivals. Mr. Forrester put more than $3 million of his own money into the race, his campaign manager crowed, ''There's more where that came from,'' and his opponents suddenly found that their potential donors had been scared off.

title: Priest's Defenders See Affection Where an Accuser Sees Abuse
description: Danny Donohue was captain of the basketball team, a top student and hard-praying seminarian on a fast path to the priesthood. Charlie Kavanagh was everybody's favorite priest, a stand-out athlete himself who inspired dozens of students as a teacher and later rector at Cathedral Preparatory Seminary.

title: French's Mustard's campaign tries for smart-alecky spots.
description: FRENCH'S MUSTARD, aiming to bolster the marketplace dominance of its 98-year-old brand, is ditching the image of Norman-Rockwell-infused tranquillity for something a little more rebellious.

title: Must You Have the Bags They Say You Must Have?
description: Mombasa -- not the East African seaport but the chic Saint Laurent handbag -- arrived in stores last December and immediately sold out. Bergdorf Goodman, which had cautiously ordered only 60 of the $700 bags because of concern about the economy, asked for another 500, received 420 and ran an ad for the horn-handled Mombasa as the must-have accessory for spring. On March 6, under the headline ''Mombasa's the One?'' Women's Wear Daily reported that demand for the bag ''had reached a fever pitch'' and noted a waiting list at the Saint Laurent boutique in New York.

title: Chirac's Challenge: Moving From Triumph to Action
description: Apparently headed for overwhelming victory in this roller-coaster election season, President Jacques Chirac and his center-right followers look set to secure the kind of mandate that politicians often crave. The question is whether the president and his allies will find the boldness to use it.

title: A Drug for Everything?
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect in Murders Above Deli Says He Lied in Police Tape
description: A suspect in the triple murder above the Carnegie Deli last summer completed nearly two days of testimony yesterday that almost completely reversed statements he gave to the police and prosecutors after his arrest last year.

title: Food Magazine Leaves Out a Big Ingredient: Advertising
description: Four cameras home in on Christopher Kimball, the editor and publisher of Cook's Illustrated magazine and the host of ''America's Test Kitchen,'' a cooking show on public television. Bridget Lancaster, his co-host, has taken a bite of the cherry cobbler they just baked and pronounced it ''perfect.'' As the cameras roll, Mr. Kimball's Adam's apple bobs up and down over his signature bow tie, working on both the cobbler and the word ''perfect.''

title: Ratings Are Way Down
description: The N.B.A. finals series between the Nets and the Lakers is on course to be the lowest rated in 21 years, since Boston beat Houston in six games in 1981 and CBS generated a meager 6.7 Nielsen rating.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: ABBEY FORECASTS LOWER PROFIT The Abbey National Group said it expected to report a "substantial fall" in first-half pretax profit compared with the period a year ago, as it takes greater reserves and writes off some bad loans. Write-offs at the wholesale banking unit for the six months ended June 30 are expected to be "at a broadly comparable level to the whole of 2001," the bank said. The extra provisions and loan write-offs are related to investments in telecommunications, cable, private equity and high-yield securities, the bank said. Abbey National also said profit for the entire year was expected to fall well below current market estimates. Abbey National is in the process of revamping its wholesale bank.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Fired Before He Could Quit
description: Prime Minister Costas Simitis fired Health Minister Alekos Papadopoulos, who said he was planning to leave politics. The statement by Mr. Papadopoulos, one of the Socialist government's most popular members, added to growing disarray in the party and fueled accusations by the opposition that Mr. Simitis is losing hold of his cabinet. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Benjamin Ward, New York City's First Black Police Commissioner, Dies at 75
description: Benjamin Ward, who began his career as a traffic officer in white gloves on First Avenue, moved through a succession of state and city law-enforcement posts and eventually became the first black commissioner of the New York City Police Department, died yesterday at a Queens hospital. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILDNER, DR. BERTRAM S.
description: BILDNER-Dr. Bertram S. The Executive Board and the membership of the Bronx County Dental Society mourns the passing of Dr. Bertram S. Bildner, honored colleague, dedicated official and beloved friend. The wisdom, energy, commitment and sense of perspective of our devoted Founder and Past President of the New York State Dental Association will be sorely missed. His warmth and sincerity endeared him to all. Dr. Robert S. Yeshion Executive Director Bronx County Dental Society

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORWIN, SHEILA
description: CORWIN-Sheila. 63. Of White Plains, NY on June 9, 2002. Loving mother to Donna Moss and Ellen Flaks. Sister to Judith Hochman. Devoted grandmother to Nathan, Rosalie, Ray and Ariel. Service will be Tuesday 10am at Temple Kol - Ami, White Plains, NY. Sheila's generosity of spirit enriched the lives of all around her and instilled in her family the values of kindness, community, humanity and patience.

title: Albany Backs Mayoral Rule Over Schools
description: Hours after negotiations appeared to fall apart in a wave of recriminations, state lawmakers agreed today on a bill to give New York City mayors more control of the city's schools.

title: Bankruptcy Of a Division May Signal Adelphia's Fall
description: Complications mounted yesterday for the embattled cable company Adelphia Communications, as one of its units filed for bankruptcy protection, two newly appointed Adelphia directors resigned and the company filed documents showing it had overstated revenue and cash flow for the last two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABB, MAXWELL M.
description: RABB-Maxwell M. June 9, 2002 at age 91. Beloved husband of Ruth; father of Bruce, Sheila Weidenfeld, Emily Livingston and Priscilla Ayres; grandfather of Jeremy Maltby, Alexander and Katy Rabb, and Nicholas and Daniel Weidenfeld; and brother of Warren Rabb, and the late George Rabb and Frances Jones. Family will be receiving Tuesday evening 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Services Wednesday, June 12th, 11am at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Av at 65 St. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to Lighthouse International, 111 E. 59 St., NY, NY 10022.

title: Home-Grown Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Wings Move Closer To Winning the Cup
description: In the final minute of this convincing Detroit victory tonight, the capacity crowd at the Entertainment and Sports Arena seemed to sense that there was a dwindling chance for the Stanley Cup finals to return here for Game 6 on Saturday night. They stood and cheered long and loudly for their Carolina Hurricanes, vanquished by the Red Wings, 3-0, in Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals. Perhaps they were saying goodbye and thank you for a season of overachievement by a team of underdogs.

title: Investment Manager Found Guilty Of Fraud
description: Alan B. Bond, a money manager who made frequent appearances on television, was convicted yesterday of defrauding pension funds of millions of dollars and was sent straight to jail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, HOLLY
description: SOLOMON-Holly. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of their colleague. We are proud that this delightful human being, who was passionately devoted to art and to the artists she represented, was a longtime ADAA member. Our sympathy and condolences to her sons Thomas and John, and to her brother Donald. Richard Gray, President Gilbert S. Edelson, Admin. Vice President

title: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Criticism On Censorship
description: The Committee to Project Journalists, the international press watchdog based in New York, urged Uzbekistan to release three journalists imprisoned for their work and to stop censorship and harassment of independent reporters. Uzbekistan, an American ally in Central Asia, has been criticized repeatedly by human rights organizations. The press group's statement came after a nine-day tour of the country. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Study Finds Inefficiency in Health Care
description: Warning that a surge in costs threatens to swamp the employer-subsidized health system within a decade, a new study by a group representing large employers says that $390 billion a year is being wasted on outmoded and inefficient medical procedures.

title: From Chicago Gang to Possible Al Qaeda Ties
description: The man suspected of plotting a radioactive bomb attack, a Brooklyn-born Hispanic Catholic who converted to Islam when he married a Middle Eastern woman, had a lengthy criminal record in two states. The record started with an arrest in connection with a murder when he was a teenager, according to law enforcement officials and court records.

title: As Sharon Meets With Bush, Israeli Forces Continue Ramallah Sweep
description: As Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel met with President Bush in Washington, Israeli troops and tanks continued the sweep of Ramallah, the de facto Palestinian capital in the West Bank, that began early this morning, making 27 arrests by nightfall.

title: Man, 71, Kills 2 at Missouri Monastery and Then Himself
description: A 71-year-old man wielding an assault rifle opened fire today in a rural Benedictine monastery in northwest Missouri, killing two people at the abbey and seriously wounding two others before fatally shooting himself, law enforcement officials said.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Workers At 2 Hotels End Strike
description: Ending a two-week strike, workers at two hotels on Walt Disney World property near Orlando voted on Sunday to approve a new contract. Many of the 400 housekeepers, laundry workers and some attendants at the Swan and Dolphin hotels walked out after rejecting a proposed three-year contract. The strikers, members of the Teamsters union, had sought a guaranteed 40-hour work week. The new agreement makes it easier for them to file grievances when they are assigned less than 40 hours of work. The hotels are owned by the Tishman Hotel Corporation and managed by Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Anorexia Strategy: Family as Doctor
description: When a teenage girl develops anorexia, a team of experts usually takes charge of bringing her back to a normal weight, while her parents stand on the sidelines.

title: A New System for Storing Data: Think Punch Cards, but Tiny
description: I.B.M. scientists say they have created a data-storage technology that can store the equivalent of 200 CD-ROM's on a surface the size of a postage stamp.

title: Front Row
description: Soccer Winner

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Legislators Oppose Governor's Budget Plan
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee's plan for keeping the state budget in balance met bipartisan resistance only minutes after the General Assembly convened in a special session. Legislators indicated that they would accept Mr. Huckabee's formula for averting a $56 million shortfall in the fiscal year that ends June 30 by transferring an equal amount from a half-dozen small state accounts into the larger General Fund. But there was broad opposition to his plan to divert revenues reserved for property tax relief to a special fund to cover any shortfalls in the fiscal year that begins July 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMBARD, LEE
description: LOMBARD-Lee, native New Yorker and retired professor of English at Pratt Institute, died of lung cancer in Palm Springs, CA on May 27 at age 88. At age 19, he graduated from CCNY, in 1934 received an MA from Columbia University and in 1949 his PhD from NYU. His doctoral dissertation on African American writers between World Wars I and II was one of the earliest studies of the subject. His teaching career began in Benjamin Franklin High School in Harlem. Later he taught at CCNY Extension Division, Teachers College of Columbia University and Pratt. During World War II, he was an Army interpreter and editor. On various occasions he lectured on African American writers and on Shakespeare on radio station WNYC. After moving to Palm Springs in 1983, he was active in the Palm Springs Tennis Club. When an arm injury ended his tennis playing, he began to devote himself to volunteer work at the Stroke Activity Center in Palm Springs, turning his expertise in the English language into a therapeutic tool to foster the rehabilitation of stroke victims. His class ''Word Power'' attracted the enthusiastic participation of ever-increasing numbers of Stroke Activity Center clients. Dr. Lombard's wife, Jane Wade Lombard, an international art dealer, died in 1996. He is survived by his sisters, Blanche Lombard of Palm Springs, CA and Juliette Lombard George of Stanford, CA, by his brother-in-law Alexander L. George of Stanford, CA, by nieces Leslie Rotstein of Morongo, CA and Mary Lombard Douglass of Edmonds, WA, and by his nephew and namesake, Lee George of Soquel, CA. Contributions in Lee Lombard's memory may be made to the Stroke Activity Center, 2800 Alejo Rd., Palm Springs, CA 92263

title: Employers, in 9-0 Ruling by Justices, Extend Winning Streak in Disabilities-Act Cases
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the Americans With Disabilities Act does not require employers to hire people whose own health or safety would be put at risk by performing the job.

title: He Looked in the Mirror And Heard an Opera Coming
description: When he set out to write ''the tragedy of an ugly man,'' Alexander Zemlinsky was thinking of himself. Both ''Der Zwerg'' (''The Dwarf'') and ''Eine Florentinische Tragdie'' (''A Florentine Tragedy''), one-act operas that the American Symphony Orchestra presented at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon, are based on works by Oscar Wilde; but an even stronger link is their tacit autobiographical component.

title: VIVENDI ALLOWED TO BID FOR SAFETY-KLEEN DIVISION
description: A bankruptcy judge delayed the Safety-Kleen Corporation's sale of its chemical-services division to allow a North American unit of Vivendi Universal to offer a competing bid. Judge Peter Walsh of United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., made the delay and ordered Safety-Kleen to provide financial and litigation information to help the Vivendi unit decide if it wants to compete with the existing bid, one for $311.3 million by Clean Harbors Inc. The Vivendi unit, Onyx North America, a waste treatment company, had objected to the sale, saying it had not been given enough information to submit a higher bid. Safety-Kleen is based in Columbia, S.C., and Clean Harbors is based in Braintree, Mass.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELES, BILLIE
description: ABELES - Billie, formerly Pretzfeld, 91, previously of Scarsdale, NY, and Hollywood, FL, passed away June 9th in Miami, FL. Widowed twice, Billie married Richard Abeles after the death of her first husband, George ''Jim'' Pretzfeld, with whom she resided in Scarsdale, NY. In the late 1920's, Billie played on a professional women's basketball team in New York City. She worked as a professional model and went on to become a successful fashion designer. Billie was an accomplished artist and retained her love of sports, especially enjoying sailing, tennis and golf. She is survived by her loving children, Jill Fink of Aspen, CO, and Tom (Lynne) Pretzfeld of Miami, FL; grandchildren, Laura (Bob) Katter, Carolyn Fink, Greg and Gary Pretzfeld; and great-granddaughter, Julia. Memorial contributions may be made to the Ileitis & Colitis Foundation, 386 South Park Avenue, NY, NY 10016.

title: Fear Itself Is the Main Threat Of a Dirty Bomb, Experts Say
description: A dirty bomb would be simple an Oklahoma City truck bomb laced with a few pounds of something radioactive -- but the death and destruction would be from the bomb part, not the dirty part, experts say.

title: Raquel Welch Is Reinvented As a Latina; A Familiar Actress Now Boasts Her Heritage
description: On ''American Family,'' the PBS television series about a Mexican-American family in East Los Angeles, now in its first season, Aunt Dora is the drama queen of the family, a passionate, romantic woman who might have become a Hollywood star had she vigorously pursued her acting career. The actress playing Aunt Dora is Raquel Welch, who infuses the role with her familiar sultriness and smoky voice.

title: Nets' Harris Changes His Look, but Not His Luck
description: When he was called from the bench late in the third quarter of Game 3 on Sunday night, Lucious Harris seemed almost unrecognizable. As he entered the game, he had shed the clear plastic mask that he had worn since returning from a broken bone on the right side of his face just before the playoffs. He was hoping to cast off the shooting woes that had plagued him throughout the N.B.A. finals.

title: Close-Up Views of Sun Give Astronomers More to Think About
description: For reasons as obvious as daylight and its nurturing warmth, no single star commanded more attention at the 200th meeting of the American Astronomical Society here this week than the nearest and most familiar one: the Sun.

title: Donald S. Fredrickson, 77, Researcher on the Links of Fat to Heart Disease
description: Dr. Donald S. Fredrickson, the former director of the National Institutes of Health and the Howard Hughes Medical Research Institute who discovered two genetic disorders and was a leading researcher on the links between lipids and fats and heart disease, died on Friday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 77.

title: MEMO PAD
description: Passenger Traffic Fell At Airports in 2001

title: US Airways Asks Government To Back a Loan of $1 Billion
description: US Airways filed an application today with the federal government seeking a $900 million loan guarantee for a $1 billion loan that it intends to use to revamp the company.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: The Wind Beneath Her Tent

title: Some in Yonkers Say Ballpark Plan Would Unfairly Take Their Turf
description: In his City Hall office here, the deputy mayor keeps a cherished Norman Rockwell picture that reminds him of growing up in northeast Yonkers: three rosy-cheeked boys, toting a baseball bat and mitt, plead with developers not to bulldoze their neighborhood ballpark.

title: Day 5, No Verdict In Andersen Case
description: Jurors in the Arthur Andersen criminal case continued their deliberations for the fifth consecutive day today with no indication of which way they were leaning.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: KOIZUMI BACKS AIDE AFTER A-BOMB REMARKS Despite strong criticism in Parliament, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, left, said he would not consider firing his chief cabinet secretary for suggesting that Japan could soon consider acquiring nuclear weapons. Yasuo Fukuda had told reporters that Japan's self-imposed ban on nuclear weapons could be changed as easily as the Constitution, which governing-party lawmakers say should be amended to allow Japan to field a regular army rather than just a self-defense force. Mr. Koizumi, at a special session of a parliamentary committee, said his cabinet planned no changes concerning the nuclear ban.
