description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAZAN, LESLIE BETH
description: HAZAN-Leslie Beth. 39 years old, on June 10th, 2002. Beloved daughter of Maxine (Stan) Landau and the late Michael Hazan. Loving sister of Fred S. (Glynnis) Hazan and adoring aunt of Michael and Spencer. Beloved granddaughter of the late Freddie and Lily Hazan and the late Pearl and Leon Seider. Funeral services will be held at Boulevard Park West Chapels, Hewlett, NY, Wednesday, June 12th, 9:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSI, AMERICO ''RICK.''
description: ROSSI-Americo ''Rick.'' Of Long Beach, NY, went to the beach in the sky on June 8, 2002. Survived by his wife, Susan M. Flaherty, parents, Americo and Jean Rossi, brothers, Larry and Ronnie, sister, Dolores Nisito, and adoring nieces and nephews.

title: Congress Begins Its Debate Over Homeland Security Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  Senior members of Congress questioned today how the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. would cooperate with the new homeland security department proposed by President Bush and whether the proposal would adequately address the lack of communication and missed signals before the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Scotland: Mandela Visits Lockerbie Bomber
description: Nelson Mandela said Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi, the Libyan intelligence agent convicted in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie, which killed 270 people, should be moved from his high-security prison in Scotland to a Muslim country ''trusted by the West'' and be permitted to appeal his case to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg. Mr. Megrahi lost an appeal in Scotland in March. Mr. Mandela, who played a crucial role in persuading Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to hand over Mr. Megrahi for trial, met with Mr. Megrahi in his Glasgow prison. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Gov. Davis Runs Ad Attacking Opponent
description: Gov. Gray Davis, a Democrat known for his bare-knuckles campaign style, broadcast the first attack advertisement of his re-election campaign today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Visa Plan Angers Putin
description: President Vladimir V. Putin denounced plans by Poland and Lithuania to require residents of the Baltic seacoast enclave of Kaliningrad to obtain visas before crossing their territory en route to Russia. Kaliningrad, which Russia seized from Germany during World War II, is nearly 250 miles from mainland Russia; Poland and Lithuania want to require visas as part of border-tightening measures that are a condition for joining the European Union in 2004. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: In Treason Trial, Echoes of Soviet Past and K.G.B. Secrets
description: In a closed chamber, inside a hulking concrete courthouse in northeast Moscow, President Vladimir V. Putin's Russia is settling a score from its Soviet past.

title: Hour of Reckoning in the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IVERS, PHILIP ''SKITCH.''
description: IVERS-Philip ''Skitch.'' On June 9, 2002. He is survived by his wife Nancy; children Cathi Rimalower, Mitchell, Daniel Isaacs and Kim Katz; sons-inlaw George Rimalower, Mark Swirsky and Elliot Katz; daughter-in-law Lisa Isaacs; grandchildren Benjamin, Lucy and Harry Rimalower and Steffanie and Jacob Katz; sisters Gladys Horowitz and Elaine Nehemiah. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Avenue, Riverdale, NY

title: Advisory Panel to Be Named For Proposed Cabinet Post
description: President Bush is to hold the first meeting of a new domestic security advisory council on Wednesday, convening a panel of business executives and state and local government officials who will help shape policy for what the president has called the biggest government reorganization in 50 years.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: VISA PLAN ANGERS PUTIN President Vladimir V. Putin denounced plans by Poland and Lithuania to require residents of the Baltic seacoast enclave of Kaliningrad to obtain visas before crossing their territory en route to Russia. Kaliningrad, which Russia seized from Germany during World War II, is nearly 250 miles from mainland Russia; Poland and Lithuania want to require visas as part of border-tightening measures that are a condition for joining the European Union in 2004. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Patrols in Jewish Neighborhoods Face Arrest, Commissioner Says
description: A rabbi's plan to organize armed civilian patrols to protect Jewish neighborhoods in Brooklyn drew a promise from the police commissioner that those who take up weapons would face arrest.

title: Laker Sheds Anonymity With Play in Game 3
description: Devean George admitted that he was preoccupied. As the minutes ticked down in the fourth quarter on Sunday, he kept wondering when Coach Phil Jackson was going to pull him out of the game.

title: Lots of Fans Outside, With Empty Seats Inside
description: The World Cup may be the globe's most popular sporting event, but you would not know it looking at all the empty seats at stadiums across Japan and South Korea. Instead of grappling with unruly foreigners as feared, the tournament's organizers are instead trying to calm irate local fans who have been denied a chance to see the games even though thousands of tickets have gone unused.

title: Who's the Fossil Hunter?
description: To the Editor:

title: PEDIATRIX MEDICAL SHARES DROP ON NEWS OF U.S. INQUIRY
description: Shares in the Pediatrix Medical Group, which disclosed late last week that the Federal Trade Commission was investigating its 2001 acquisition of the Magella Healthcare Corporation, fell 31 percent yesterday. Shares of the company, a provider of health care for newborns and their mothers, fell $11.91 to $26.20 on the New York Stock Exchange, where it led the list of percentage losers. The F.T.C. is requesting information about its competitive position in cities in which it acquired Magella physician groups, a Pediatrix spokesman, Bob Kneeley, said. The F.T.C. is not accusing Pediatrix of wrongdoing related to the May 2001 acquisition, Pediatrix said.

title: The Woodpecker's Revenge
description: It's hard to know which verb tense to use when discussing the ivory-billed woodpecker, which is/was the largest North American woodpecker, and is/was by all accounts an arresting creature 20 inches tall with a 30-inch wingspan. There hasn't been a confirmed sighting for more than 50 years, and when somebody shows up with a photograph, it almost always turns out to be the similar but smaller pileated woodpecker.

title: CUNY to Add Teachers to Nurse Program
description: Responding to a severe shortage of nurses, the City University of New York, the city's largest producer of nursing graduates, plans to sharply expand its training programs, adding 30 full-time nursing professors and scheduling more classes on nights and weekends.

title: Is There Something Out There?
description: To the Editor:

title: Human Genome Sequence Has Errors, Scientists Say
description: Based on a new genetic map of the human genome, Icelandic scientists say more than 100 large-scale corrections are needed in a recent draft of the human genome sequence produced by a public consortium of academic centers in the United States and abroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, LOUIS A., ESQ.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Louis A., Esq. On June 10, 2002, at the age of 81. Beloved husband of Irene for fifty years. Loving father of Melody Kuney, Mitchell and Elissa. Father-in-law to Scott Kuney and Robin. Cherished grandfather of Andre, Allegra, Aaron and Samantha. Dear brother of Rose Minkin. Practicing attorney and accountant since 1946, on Court Street. Appointed Court Examiner since 1980. Active until his last day. Graduate of City College and Saint John's School of Law. Devoted to his family, friends, clients and the court system. Services Wednesday, 12:15 PM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162 - 05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the UJA-Federation. We will all miss his wit, intelligence, generosity, devotion and love.

title: Partisanship in Insecure Times
description: For the moment the domestic politics of the war on terrorism have become bureaucratic and therefore bipartisan. Some form of President Bush's proposed reorganization of homeland defense will probably pass Congress if only because there aren't competing ideas floating around. But the war is sure to pose other questions that will prove more divisive.

title: African Clerics Acknowledge They've Failed to Combat AIDS
description: A broad array of African religious leaders gathered here today to acknowledge that they have been far too silent as AIDS has swept through their congregations.

title: A Milestone For Festival With New And Familiar
description: The American Dance Festival's theme at a gala benefit here on Sunday night was ''25 years in North Carolina at Duke University.''

title: Advice to Boardrooms
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Shares Of Cree Rise
description: Shares of Cree increased 15 percent yesterday after the company, a semiconductor manufacturer, increased its revenue outlook for the fiscal fourth quarter, saying improved performance and lower prices for chips used in wireless handsets resulted in stronger demand. The company, which is based in Durham, N.C., said it expected revenue growth of 8 percent to 11 percent in the quarter, ending June 30. That was up from a previous estimate of 5 percent. But Cree said it expected to post a net loss in the fourth quarter. The company said it planned to write down the value of investments in publicly traded companies that have declined. It estimated the charge at $17 million after tax. Shares of Cree closed at $12.67.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Friday depicting the size of the New York City school system through statistics misstated the figure in some copies for full-price school lunches served daily. It is 70,415, not 5,712.

title: EarthLink Will Acquire Corporate Computer Seller
description: PeoplePC, which briefly won acclaim during the Internet bubble as a model for how companies could encourage workers to get online, will be acquired by EarthLink, a leading Internet service provider, the two companies said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Novell Buys Silverstream
description: Novell, a maker of network software, said yesterday that it would acquire SilverStream Software for $9 a share, or $212 million. That price reflected a 43 percent premium above Friday's closing price of $5.14. SilverStream, based in Billerica, Mass., makes software that permits different computing systems to interact online. Once the deal is done, SilverStream will become a Novell unit and its Extend product line will be rebranded under the Novell name. Novell said the acquisition should add about 1 percent to total revenue in 2002. Shares in SilverStream rose $3.76, or 73 percent, to close at $8.90. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the Food and Drug Administration's decision to permit the sale of Lotronex, a medicine for irritable bowel syndrome that had been withdrawn from the market because of safety concerns, referred incompletely to patients eligible to use the drug. Although the F.D.A. has approved Lotronex only for women with a severe form of the bowel disorder, doctors can legally prescribe an approved drug for any patient; thus, as in the past, they will be free to prescribe Lotronex for men.

title: Fear Not That Carrot, Potato or Ear of Corn
description: When someone at a party said, ''I don't eat carrots -- they have too much sugar'' and his companion replied, ''I don't eat corn or potatoes for the same reason,'' I realized there was an urgent need to put the so-called glycemic index into proper perspective before anyone else decided to avoid delicious, nutritious foods packed with health-protective substances.

title: A Pianist Reappears, His Mood Casual
description: The pianist Rodney Kendrick hasn't made a record obtainable in the United States in five years. (It was ''We Don't Die We Multiply,'' put out in America by Verve; its follow-up, ''No Dress Code,'' came out only in France.) And he has all but vanished from the New York club scene: strange, because the last we saw of him, he wasn't yet 40 and was making a string of adroit, original albums, working primarily within the legacies of Duke Ellington and Thelonious Monk, playing with great, iconoclastic young rhythm sections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMESSER, DAVID K.
description: FELDMESSER-David K. On June 10, 2002. Husband of the late Jewel. Father of Anthony and Marta.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Commission Approves Pennsylvania Avenue Promenade
description: The National Capital Planning Commission, which evaluates security and design issues, has approved plans to redesign a block of Pennsylvania Avenue in front of the White House that has been closed to traffic since 1995. The new design will turn the street into a promenade, with granite walkways lined with trees and benches. City officials and other groups in Washington had been lobbying to reopen the street. Officials said the design was chosen because it would permit reopening of the stretch in the future.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: University's Administrators Will Teach
description: As a result of budget cuts, Appalachian State University in Boone has asked all administrators with the proper academic background to teach classes next year. The university, a public institution with 12,550 students, fears it will not be able to hire enough part-time instructors to staff all undergraduate courses and sections. The university started the academic year with an $86.6 million state appropriation, but the state has cut its contribution by 6 percent. A spokeswoman for the university said it could face another round of budget cuts next year. Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: Democrats Fault White House After Briefing on New Agency
description: Top White House officials urged Congress today to move rapidly to create a Department of Homeland Security, but received a skeptical reaction from Democratic aides when they said the administration would not initially seek money to finance that reorganization, Congressional staff members said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDER, BETTY RICE
description: FELDER-Betty Rice. A longtime resident of East Hampton, NY, died peacefully in her sleep Sunday at home. She was 91. Although she had grown increasingly frail in recent months, she was blessed with good health. Her children were with her at the time of her death. She is survived by her daughter Bettina, and by her son Wilson and daughter-in-law Laura, and their children William and Julia. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to the Girls Vacation Fund, Inc, 370 Lexington Ave, NY, NY 10017.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Chancellor Search Panel
description: Nat Leventhal, who headed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's post-election transition, will lead the search committee for a new chancellor and new appointees to the Board of Education, the mayor said yesterday. Mr. Bloomberg said that the searches were just starting and that there was no short list for chancellor, but acknowledged that Paul Vallas, former head of the Chicago school system, was a contender. ''There's lots of people who will want to be chancellor of the New York City school system,'' Mr. Bloomberg said, noting the recent agreement to centralize authority for school administration. ''Everybody's going to be shocked at the number and the quality of people that we will have to select from.'' Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Slip 'n' Slide Glaciers

title: A Strong Push Into Europe Lifts Profit Of Ryanair
description: While other European airlines were struggling through the tourism-depressing foot-and-mouth epidemic in Britain and the fallout from the Sept. 11 terror attacks, Ryanair, the Irish-based low-budget airline, expanded aggressively. The strategy paid off in sharp increases in both revenue and profit, the company reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, EDWARD WILLIAM
description: WINTER-Edward William. Architect, 77 years old, died in West Palm Beach, FL on Friday June 7, 2002. Quattlebaum Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, FL (561) 832-5171

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREMEN, JOSEPH (YUS)
description: KREMEN - Joseph (Yus). Died June 9, 2002, age 82. Survived by his beloved, cherished wife, Ruth S.; adoring father of Erica and Douglas Rosenthal, Andrea and Arne Kotlen; special, doting grandfather of Ben, Mila, Lizzie Rosenthal, Jessica and Gillian Kotlen. During WWII, a meteorologist in the US Army Air Force, served in the Pacific. Graduate of CCNY, graduate work at NYU. Had a lifelong passion for Yiddish language and culture. Was loved by all who knew him. Services Wednesday, June 12, 11:15 AM, ''The Riverside,'' Amsterdam Ave and 76 St.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a contemplated change in Harvard's system of early admissions referred incorrectly to a new policy of the National Association for College Admissions Counseling, cited by the university as a reason for considering a shift. The association permits students, for the first time, to apply to one college with a binding early-decision program, as well as to any other college  like Harvard  that does not require students to promise that they will attend if admitted. The new policy does not limit the number of colleges with nonbinding programs to which students may apply.

title: Yes, Those Walls Have Ears, and They Sure Do Get an Earful
description: Everybody in the building is a little wacky: the crack addict who has found religion; the hairdresser from Trinidad and her dangerously stressed-out husband; the good-hearted Polish handyman with misguided ideas about what other people need; the ex-hippie couple (he's now a banker, she's obsessed with an old television series) and their Dartmouth-bound son, who has trouble with commitment, even to baby-sitting jobs; the mentally unstable six-foot-tall woman who rambles on about the ghost in her room; the 50-ish drug dealer and his constantly carping wife who is fed up with both their children: the son because he has fathered a child, the daughter because she's a lesbian in Poughkeepsie.

title: Hate Crimes Bill Dealt a Setback in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  A hate crimes bill suffered a big setback in the Senate today as its supporters fell six votes short of defeating a move to stall it.

title: Black Course Is Ready to Dole Out Punishment
description: After playing in 13 United States Opens, Davis Love III knows a demanding golf course when he sees one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIPE, TIMOTHY W.
description: KNIPE-Timothy W. 79, of East Hampton, NY on June 8, 2002. Beloved husband of Mary Grace (nee Harris). Loving father of Timothy W. of Los Angeles, CA., G. Stevenson of Richmond, VA and Anna Marie Donahue of New Canaan, CT. Also survived by four grandchildren, Nicholas and Lily Donahue and Alden and Natalie Knipe. Services Saturday June 15, 11 A.M. at St. Lukes Episcopal Church, East Hampton. Memorial donations to the Lighthouse International, 111 E. 59th St., NY 10022 would be appreciated.

title: Hour of Reckoning in the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonds Return to Southeast Asia
description: International capital markets are offering Southeast Asian borrowers interest rates so low even Communists can't resist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMER, JOHN, M.D.
description: COMER-John, M.D. of North Caldwell, NJ on June 9, 2002. Husband of the late Jean (nee Savidant). Beloved father of Jean C. Sylvester of Washington, DC.; Joan V. Comer of Chevy Chase, MD and Jill C. Abbott of Essex Fells, NJ. Loving brother of Marie Meeker of Wayne, NJ; Regina Nani of Whiting, NJ and the late Chief William Comer and Eileen Comer. Loving grandfather of Kathryn, Margaret, Carl, Ted and Kelly. A mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Wednesday at 10 AM in Notre Dame R.C. Church, North Caldwell. Interment Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Totowa. For information Dancy Funeral Home, 9 Smull Avenue, Caldwell. If so desired donations may be made to the West Essex First Aid Squad, PO Box 662, West Caldwell, NJ 07007-9999.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Koizumi Backs Aide After A-Bomb Remarks
description: Despite strong criticism in Parliament, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, left, said he would not consider firing his chief cabinet secretary for suggesting that Japan could soon consider acquiring nuclear weapons. Yasuo Fukuda had told reporters that Japan's self-imposed ban on nuclear weapons could be changed as easily as the Constitution, which governing-party lawmakers say should be amended to allow Japan to field a regular army rather than just a self-defense force. Mr. Koizumi, at a special session of a parliamentary committee, said his cabinet planned no changes concerning the nuclear ban. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Accused Of Religious Bias
description: A former police cadet accused the New York Police Department of discrimination yesterday, saying that his religious rights were violated when he was asked to trim his beard and wear department-issued headgear. The former cadet, Amric Singh Rathour, 25, of Ozone Park, Queens, is a Sikh who was dismissed from the Police Academy last August after refusing to obey regulations. Sikh men must keep a beard and wear turbans, he said. He has filed a complaint with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Deputy Chief Michael Collins said other Sikhs, including Mr. Rathour's brother and father, have been able to comply with departmental rules. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Experiment Offers Look Through Eyes of Autism
description: Enlisting Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor and a high-tech eye-tracking device developed for the military, researchers at Yale ran experiments that came closer than anything yet to offering a look at the world as seen through the eyes of people with autism.

title: When Peer Review Produces Unsound Science
description: Medical journals are the prime source of information about scientific advances that can change how doctors treat patients in offices and in hospitals. And to ensure the quality of what journals publish, their editors, beginning 200 years ago, have increasingly called on scientific peers to review new findings from research in test tubes and on animals and humans.

title: Gangsters Are Blamed in Killing Of a Serbian Security Official
description: Serbian officials blamed gangsters today for the assassination of a police chief who served under Slobodan Milosevic, then switched sides to help reformers oust him from power.

title: Nokia Warns of Falling Sales, but Remains Optimistic on Earnings
description: LONDON, June 11 — Nokia of Finland, the world's biggest mobile phone maker, said today that it would meet second-quarter earnings estimates, though it sharply reduced sales forecasts for the period.

title: . . . Starring The Original Houston Cast
description: It has been some time since all the big musicals started on Broadway and then filtered out to the hinterland. Now the trend -- becoming stronger and perhaps permanent -- is for them to open first in cities like this one and then move to New York.

title: Spring Classic Evokes Memories of Fall Theatrics
description: Marcus Thames took two deep breaths and stared out at the 6-foot-10 left-hander with the pterodactyl's wingspan, the pitcher he had watched on television for many years and from the rafters of Bank One Ballpark during the World Series last fall.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Protestant Fighter Dead
description: Mark Fulton, 42, a Protestant paramilitary fighter who succeeded Billy Wright as head of the Loyalist Volunteer Force after Mr. Wright was shot to death in 1997 by Catholic inmates, was himself found dead, a belt around his neck, in his prison cell outside Belfast. He had been in jail since December 2001, accused of conspiring to murder a Protestant rival, and had expressed fear of being murdered. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Tyco Turmoil Deepens as It Fires Lawyer
description: The turmoil at Tyco International worsened yesterday as the company fired its general counsel, Mark A. Belnick, setting off a public fight over the reasons for his dismissal.

title: Ozone Park Journal; Fond Tales of Gotti, and a Lot of 'No Comment'
description: Standing outside his auto body shop on Liberty Avenue in Ozone Park, Freddie Rodriguez said he was not afraid to let the world know what he thought of John Gotti, the mob boss who died yesterday in prison.

title: Easing Asthmatics' Congestion
description: A study being released today has found that about half of a group of people with chronic asthma also suffered from low-level lung infections, and that antibiotic treatment improved their breathing.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: A Reasonable Disabilities Ruling
description: When the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, the landmark disability rights statute, became law, it was a breakthrough for a group of Americans who had few rights in the workplace. It is a sign of the enormous strides made since then that the open questions of disability rights are no longer straightforward ones of access or equal treatment. Instead they are more nuanced issues like the one the Supreme Court ruled on yesterday: whether an employer can refuse to hire someone whose disability makes a job physically dangerous for him. We agree with the court that a company was within its rights to reject the disabled applicant under these circumstances.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Honduras: Panel To Investigate Assassinations
description: The government announced the creation of a ''truth commission'' to look into the political assassinations of 187 people during the 1980's. The commission, which is to start work next month under the sponsorship of the United Nations, will have access to military archives. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: PUBLIC SERVICE ENTERPRISE TO BUY TWO POWER STATIONS
description: The Public Service Enterprise Group, the owner of New Jersey's largest utility, agreed to buy two Connecticut power stations from the Wisvest Corporation for $220 million. Public Service's generating unit, PSEG Power, will finance the acquisition of the stations in Bridgeport and New Haven with cash, debt and equity, and expects to complete the purchase this year, it said. Public Service is based in Newark. Wisvest's parent, the Wisconsin Energy Corporation of Milwaukee, lost money on the plants, which it bought for $272 million in 1999, expecting to profit from power demand in New England, a spokesman, Jack Powell, said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Abbey Forecasts Lower Profit
description: The Abbey National Group said it expected to report a ''substantial fall'' in first-half pretax profit compared with the period a year ago, as it takes greater reserves and writes off some bad loans. Write-offs at the wholesale banking unit for the six months ended June 30 are expected to be ''at a broadly comparable level to the whole of 2001,'' the bank said. The extra provisions and loan write-offs are related to investments in telecommunications, cable, private equity and high-yield securities, the bank said. Abbey National also said profit for the entire year was expected to fall well below current market estimates. Abbey National is in the process of revamping its wholesale bank.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: Improving Communications
description: North and South Korean officials have agreed in principle for companies in the South to provide the North with mobile telephone service able to communicate with the South. Such service would mark the first time North and South Koreans could talk by phone across the demilitarized zone that has divided the peninsula since the 1950-53 Korean War. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Casting a New Light Into the Shadows of a Familiar Family
description: The woman in the title of Oscar A. Coln's ''Becoming Bernarda'' is of course the matron of ''The House of Bernarda Alba,'' who locked her crazed mother away in the dark, confined her five daughters to the shuttered rooms of her home and finally drove one of them to suicide. She is such an overwhelming dark force onstage that to most of us it might seem dangerous to inquire how she got that way.

title: A Jury Orders Genentech to Pay $300 Million in Royalties
description: A jury in California yesterday ordered Genentech Inc. to pay $300 million to the City of Hope National Medical Center, saying the company had deprived the hospital of royalties it deserved for work that helped lay the foundation for the biotechnology industry.

title: Expressions of Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Tentative Pact for City Teachers Increases Pay, and Workweek
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and New York City's teachers' union announced a tentative contract yesterday that calls for raises of 16 percent to 22 percent over 30 months, putting the city in a better competitive position to hire the 10,000 teachers the mayor says it needs by September.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Waterford Journal article last Tuesday about riverfront attractions in Waterford, N.Y., listed a plant erroneously among sources of pollution that once discouraged recreation on nearby waterways. Although the plant operated by Mohawk Paper Mills has a state permit to discharge into the Mohawk River, it has never been cited for water pollution.

title: Germany Moves to Next Round With 2-0 Victory Over Cameroon
description: SHIZUOKA, Japan, June 11  Germany and Cameroon had never met before in World Cup play, but their showdown here was one game they will both remember  for entirely different reasons.

title: Justices Reject Cases on Right to Bear Arms
description: There will be no debate at the Supreme Court over the right to bear arms, at least in the immediate future.

title: Abundance Of 'Cures' Brings Ills
description: Recently my mother, 94, lay slowly dying. She was skeletal, feeble, disoriented, delusional and agitated, and she slept fitfully. She took water by medicine dropper and refused all food. Helpful, caring hospice and health care workers attended her in my brother's house around the clock.

title: INDIA TAKES STEPS TO EASE TENSIONS
description: India took its first concrete measures to ease tensions with Pakistan today by lifting a five-month-old ban on Pakistani commercial aircraft flying over India and pulling a flotilla of naval vessels away from Pakistan's coast, officials said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a contemplated change in Harvard's system of early admissions referred incorrectly to a new policy of the National Association for College Admissions Counseling, cited by the university as a reason for considering a shift. The association permits students, for the first time, to apply to one college with a binding early-decision program, as well as to any other college -- like Harvard -- that does not require students to promise that they will attend if admitted. The new policy does not limit the number of colleges with nonbinding programs to which students may apply.

title: Clarifying the Bush Mideast Plan
description: A good host caters to his guests. We hope, then, that it was hospitality, not a failure of leadership, that caused President Bush to offer such different messages in public appearances with Hosni Mubarak of Egypt on Saturday and Ariel Sharon, Israel's prime minister, yesterday. In President Mubarak's company at Camp David, Mr. Bush said the United States must start working immediately toward establishing a Palestinian state. In the Oval Office yesterday with Mr. Sharon, the president said that until there was sweeping reform of the Palestinian Authority there could be no progress on Mideast peace.

title: U.S. Gets a Point in a Frenzied Sea of Red
description: A 1-1 draw with South Korea in the World Cup today left the United States with conflicted emotions. The Americans were both disappointed not to win and lucky not to lose. Finally, only the result mattered, and it was encouraging. As players showered, frustration seemed to wash away with the sweat of the afternoon.

title: Germany Nears Deal With U.S. to Provide Terror Trial Evidence
description: BERLIN, June 11  Germany and the United States will soon reach an agreement on how Berlin can supply evidence in the American trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder said today.

title: Cablevision Seeks a Dismissal
description: Cablevision asked a federal judge yesterday to dismiss nearly all the claims made by YES in its antitrust lawsuit filed in April against the cable operator for not carrying the Yankees' new channel.

title: Cabin for Four
description: Through December, Cunard is offering an $899 rate for the third and fourth persons in a cabin, in any grade stateroom, on its six-day Atlantic crossings between Southampton, England, and New York; economy return air fare to any of 120 North American cities is included. Fares for the first two passengers in a cabin start at $999 a person; (800) 728-6273 or www.cunard.com .

title: A Road to Destruction Paved With Fine Words
description: HART CRANE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARR, SAM
description: STARR-Sam. The New York Chapter of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International records with deep sorrow the death of Mr. Sam Starr, beloved father of Board Member Allan Starr. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family. Lawrence B. Sorrel President, New York Chapter Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Tobacco Tax Bill Advances
description: A bill that would raise New Jersey's cigarette tax by 60 cents a pack narrowly passed the State Assembly Budget Committee yesterday on a party-line vote of 7 to 4. Democratic legislators said the tax increase would help close a 2003 budget gap that is expected to be $5.3 billion by raising $200 million to $240 million in extra revenue. They also agreed with testimony that the tax would prompt more than 50,000 current smokers to quit, which Republicans questioned. The measure would increase by 10 cents the 50-cent tobacco tax Gov. James E. McGreevey proposed this year. A pack of cigarettes now costs about $4.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREUER, CONSTANCE L.
description: BREUER-Constance L. On June 8, 2002, at her residence. Widow of Marcel Breuer. Mother of Thomas Breuer and Franchesca Wallace.

title: Woods's Practice Round Leaves Fans in a Frenzy
description: Tiger Woods doesn't have to ask whether people are excited to see him compete in a major championship in New York.

title: Bloomberg's Test: Control of Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets' Modest New Goal: Just Avoid Being Swept
description: They bravely tried to project hope, but in between measured breaths, the Nets let slip some knowing sighs.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Not America's Game
description: I was in on the birth and death of soccer in America, and now, bemused, I watch its resurrection. The events of this week are what promoters have been dreaming about, forever it seems: the United States in the World Cup facing the game of its life. After having tied South Korea yesterday, the team needs a victory or a tie Friday against Poland to move on to the second round.

title: Tunnel Vision; A Difficult Call When Nature Calls
description: Since the early 1980's, when the subway system seemed on the verge of ruin, almost everything about it has gotten better. Hundreds of miles of rusty rails have been replaced. Stations that looked like decommissioned coal mines look like stations again. Announcements have become more frequent (and sometimes even intelligible!). Subway cars nearly always have lights and no longer come with ''a thick layer of rectified garbage juice'' applied to the floors, as Russell Baker once described it.

title: The Big City; A Flophouse With a View (On Survival)
description: SIX years ago, I went down to the Bowery looking for a bed and ended up spending the night at a flophouse near Bond Street called the Whitehouse Hotel. The good news was that you could still find a reasonably comfortable cubicle for $10. The bad news was that the owner, Mike Ghelardi, was going broke.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Declined 6.3% in May
description: The number of magazine advertising pages continued to decline in May, though the drop was the smallest so far this year, according to data released yesterday by the Publishers Information Bureau.

title: The Genetics of Living Beyond 100
description: What's the best way to live to 100? Have an older brother or sister who did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAITI, BEN
description: GAITI-Ben. Age 89. Of Fort Lee, on June 10, 2002. Beloved father and husband. Loved his family and tennis. We will miss him. Services are today, 12 Noon, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W - 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: U.S. SAYS IT HALTED QAEDA PLOT TO USE RADIOACTIVE BOMB
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had broken up a plot by Al Qaeda to detonate a radioactive bomb inside the United States by arresting an American citizen in the case.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SETTEL, RUTH C.
description: SETTEL-Ruth C. You were a role model and a dear friend. We treasure you forever. Ginette and Joshua Becke

title: Assembly Backs Bill On Mayoral Control
description: Hours after negotiations appeared to fall apart in a wave of recriminations, state lawmakers agreed on a bill to give New York City mayors more control of the city's schools.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOULD, LOIS
description: GOULD-Lois. A memorial service at the Century Association, 7 West 43rd St., on Tuesday, June 11, at 5:30 PM.

title: WORLD CUP TRACKER
description: A SCOTTISH MAN fell from the upper tier of the stands yesterday during the Portugal-Poland match in Chonju, South Korea, and into a concrete moat surrounding the field, leaving him in critical condition with head injuries. Another spectator fell from the upper tier but landed on seats and was in stable condition. (Associated Press)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOTTLIEB, PAUL
description: GOTTLIEB-Paul. Memorial service, Great Hall Cooper Union, on Wednesday, June 12, at 6 P.M.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ARKANSAS: LEGISLATORS OPPOSE GOVERNOR'S BUDGET PLAN Gov. Mike Huckabee's plan for keeping the state budget in balance met bipartisan resistance only minutes after the General Assembly convened in a special session. Legislators indicated that they would accept Mr. Huckabee's formula for averting a $56 million shortfall in the fiscal year that ends June 30 by transferring an equal amount from a half-dozen small state accounts into the larger General Fund. But there was broad opposition to his plan to divert revenues reserved for property tax relief to a special fund to cover any shortfalls in the fiscal year that begins July 1. (NYT)

title: Airports Bracing for Bigger Problems
description: HERE in a sun-dappled realm of gated communities, where security guards see to it that tranquillity reigns, the men and women who run operations at some of the world's airports seemed singularly anxious.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Amazon is told not to help anyone fake results ever again.
description: THE good news for Amazon.com is that the Securities and Exchange Commission did not charge it with faking its own books in connection with its Amazon Commerce Network, an alliance of other Internet sites in which Amazon both invested and received advertising revenue. The bad news is that the S.E.C. concluded that Amazon did help one of those companies falsify its books.

title: Financial Restatements Are Up Sharply
description: Financial restatements by public companies have more than doubled over the last five years, with the largest number of revisions involving improperly recognized revenue on transactions, a consulting group said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about documents on energy trading in California, sent to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission by Xcel Energy, a power company based in Minneapolis, misstated the name of one company whose ability to charge unregulated rates for electricity has been threatened by the commission. It is El Paso Electric. (The El Paso Corporation is unrelated.)

title: Sex Scandal Threatens House Leader In Virginia
description: Speaker S. Vance Wilkins Jr. was under severe pressure from fellow Republicans today to resign his leadership post after the publication of accusations that he had sexually harassed two women and paid one of them $100,000 for her silence.

title: Footlights
description: Impact Players

title: U.S. Is Urged to Be Selective on Terrorism Insurance
description: An executive of a leading consumer advocacy group called yesterday for the government to take a highly selective approach to protecting businesses against big losses from terrorist attacks, saying that terrorism insurance was widely available from commercial carriers.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES ALLERGAN'S SUIT AGAINST BAUSCH & LOMB
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said a federal judge dismissed a patent-infringement suit and cleared the way for the company to seek approval to sell a generic version of a rival's glaucoma treatment. The rival, Allergan Inc., sued Bausch & Lomb in January, accusing the company of infringing two patents Allergan owns relating to Alphagan, a brimonidine tartrate solution. A similar suit Allergan filed against Alcon Laboratories Inc. was dismissed last month, and Allergan said it would appeal both decisions.

title: Final Written Arguments Are Filed in Microsoft Case
description: Microsoft and the group of states that are suing it each filed their final and most exhaustive written arguments yesterday, outlining why the landmark antitrust case should be resolved in its favor.

title: It's Not the Playoffs, So Johnson Is Fallible
description: If this is June, it can't be the playoffs. Secure in that knowledge, the Yankees bravely faced Randy Johnson last night.

title: Bloomberg's Test: Control of Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Did This Man Just Rewrite Science?
description: You can try this at home.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The conditions are so dry that it's frightening to think we've had this many and the season is only starting. We're facing a very, very tough situation.''

title: Jakarta Journal; Boy Kisses Girl: That's Sweet, and Sensational!
description: It was the kiss. Lips to lips. Not a deep Hollywood smooch, but not a light brush either.

title: Former Afghan King Rules Out All but a Symbolic Role
description: The former king of Afghanistan announced today that he would not be a candidate for any executive position in the government taking shape here.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DESA INTERNATIONAL INC., Bowling Green, Ky., a maker of space heaters and security equipment, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and said it planned to sell the company by late September and continue operating with the same workers.

title: Restoring an Ecosystem Torn Asunder by a Dam
description: Forty years after one generation dammed the Colorado River at the upper end of the Grand Canyon, a new generation of engineers and scientists is struggling to deal with the consequences: colossal loss of sand, shrinking beaches, an invasion of outside fish and plants, the extinction of native species, erosion of archaeological sites and the sudden appearance of an Asian tapeworm, to name a few.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MENOWITZ, SOPHIE
description: MENOWITZ - Sophie (1914-1979). Gone but not forgotton these many years. We think of you always. Love from your family who meant so much to you.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: More North Koreans Seek Refuge
description: Despite heavy Chinese security, five more North Koreans seeking political asylum sneaked into foreign diplomatic compounds in Beijing over the weekend. Two men got into the Canadian compound and two women and a child entered a South Korean consular building. So far this year, 38 North Koreans have gained political asylum and safe passage to Seoul via foreign embassies and consulates in China. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Restructuring At Elan
description: The Elan Corporation, an Irish drug maker, will sell off assets unrelated to its core development areas of neurology, pain management and autoimmune diseases, and will close many of its 32 global locations, according to a reorganization plan meant to reassure investors. The company appointed Dick Thornburgh, a former United States attorney general and governor of Pennsylvania, as an independent director who will lead a committee to oversee board appointments and corporate governance standards. Shares in Elan have fallen 84 percent since January, mostly from concern that its sprawling network of Enron-style joint ventures and partnerships may conceal accounting irregularities. The stock closed up nearly 7 percent, at 8.55 euros, on the Irish Stock Exchange. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: McCall Criticizes Pataki
description: H. Carl McCall, a Democratic candidate for governor, yesterday accused Gov. George E. Pataki of appointing major fund-raisers to key state posts for which they were not qualified. Mr. McCall, beginning a four-day tour around the state, issued a series of proposals that he said would guard against ethics abuse, including the formation of a committee to screen and recommend people for appointed posts and he promised that fund-raisers would not be appointed to those positions. ''This administration has represented favoritism and failure,'' Mr. McCall said. Mollie Fullington, a spokeswoman for the Pataki campaign, called Mr. McCall's accusations ''hypocrisy.'' ''This is a joke,'' she said in a statement.d ''But the idea of going back to the failed policies of the past is not a laughing matter.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Rose
description: Japanese companies ordered more equipment than expected in April, a sign the slide in business spending that has restrained growth in the country may be easing. Private machinery orders, excluding those by shippers and electric power utilities, rose 8.4 percent in April from March, government figures showed. That was more than twice the 3 percent increase economists expected.

title: Westchester Bishop Resigns After Admitting Several Affairs
description: An articulate and charismatic bishop in the New York Archdiocese, James F. McCarthy, has admitted having affairs with women and resigned his posts as both pastor at a Westchester church and as an auxiliary bishop, the archdiocese said today.

title: After a 'Dirty Bomb' Explodes
description: The age of terrorism is forcing all of us to learn a whole new vocabulary that describes potential threats and their consequences, if for no other reason than to calibrate how terrified we should be as each new menace emerges. The latest worry came yesterday with the revelation by Attorney General John Ashcroft that an American terrorist associated with Al Qaeda has been planning to explode a radiation-laced ''dirty bomb'' in the United States. We can fervently hope that no such weapon is ever exploded here. But should one ever be detonated, it is important to know that the number of fatalities would probably be small. The chief impact would be psychological and economic. Dirty bombs are not mass killers, they are weapons designed to inspire panic and cause disruption.

title: Chief Executive of Fiat Resigns in Streamlining
description: The chief executive of the struggling Fiat group, Paolo Cantarella, said today that he would resign. Fiat said the departure of Mr. Cantarella, 57, would streamline the central management of the company. His duties will be assumed by the company's chairman, Paolo Fresco, who is 68.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMANOVICH, JOHN J., SR.
description: ROMANOVICH-John J., Sr., age 77, formerly of Glendale, NY. WWII US Marine Vet. A Memorial Mass Tuesday July 23, 9:30am at Sacred Heart RC Church, Glendale, NY. For information 630-355-0213.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Rights Advocates Get Death Threats
description: Eleven leading human rights advocates who met last month with a United Nations official investigating abuses in the country received death threats that said ''Visible Activists, Dead Activists.'' The threats, faxed to their offices, warned they would be ''exterminated like a cancer.'' Last month, four forensic anthropologists who were investigating mass killings left the country after receiving similar threats. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: 2 Criticized Plants Set For Sale
description: The Wisconsin Energy Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell two power plants on critics' list of the worst polluters to a New Jersey company for $280 million. The company, based in Milwaukee, signed an agreement with PSEG Fossil for the sale of the two fossil-fuel power plants, in Bridgeport and New Haven. The plants have a combined generating capacity of about 1,000 megawatts. They are two of six remaining coal- or oil-burning plants in the state and are heavily criticized by environmentalists. Last month, Gov. John G. Rowland signed a law creating stricter emissions standards for the plants. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Mets Endure More Delays, But Still Beat the White Sox
description: The Mets won their first game tonight without their hitting coach, Dave Engle, who was fired this morning, but it had more to do with pitching than any hitter. Pedro Astacio dominated the Chicago White Sox for seven innings and the bullpen held on for a 3-1 victory that included rain and power delays for the second time on this trip.

title: Corrections
description: A Sports of The Times column on Sunday about the boxing match in Memphis between Lennox Lewis and Mike Tyson, and about past championship fights that took place off the beaten path, referred incorrectly in some copies to the site of Malcolm X's assassination, which gave rise to speculation that Muhammad Ali might be a target of those seeking vengeance when he fought in Lewiston, Me., in 1965. The assassination occurred at the Audubon Ballroom on Broadway between 165th and 166th Streets, not near the old Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKNALL, ANN MACY HAMILTON
description: BUCKNALL-Ann Macy Hamilton. The Westover School Board of Trustees, Alumnae and Staff mourn the loss of Ann Bucknall, a past Trustee, who was a loyal volunteer and inspiring leader. Charlotte Beyer Fiveson President, Board of Trustees Ann Pollina Head of School

title: Musharraf Calls Indian Steps a 'Small Beginning'
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 11  As Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld arrived in India today, President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan said he was still waiting for more substantive gestures from New Delhi to ease the two nations' military confrontation.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Beer Acquisition Challenged
description: Heineken N.V., the Dutch brewer, filed a suit to block Cia. de Bebidas das Americas of Brazil from purchasing one-third of the Argentine beer maker Quilmes Industrial, or Quinsa, for $700 million. Heineken and Quinsa jointly operate Quilmes International Bermuda Ltd., a venture that includes all of Quinsa's brewing operations. Heineken, which owns 15 percent of the venture, has exclusive rights in transactions that concern the brewing business, a Heineken spokeswoman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEWIRTZ, ABRAHAM J. (JIMMY), M.D.
description: GEWIRTZ-Abraham J. (Jimmy), M.D., on June 9, 2002 at age 92. Cherished friend of Carole Newman and her children Jeffrey, William and Cynthia. Dear uncle of Barbara, Dolores, Morty, Michael, George, Bill, Mark, and cousin of Leonard. Interment private. Remembering Jimmy Tuesday, June 18, at the Harmony Club, 4 E. 60 St., at 4pm.

title: Dangerous Currents
description: Q. Why, exactly, shouldn't you put a plugged-in toaster in the bathtub?

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Governor Begins Senate Campaign
description: Gov. Jeanne Shaheen kicked off her Democratic campaign for United States senator on Sunday in Dover, saying her performance as the first woman to serve as governor shows that she should be the first woman to represent the state in the Senate. Mrs. Shaheen said that as governor she created more than 65,000 jobs, began a statewide kindergarten program and tried to lower prescription drug and energy costs. Mrs. Shaheen faces no Democratic opposition. Possible Republican opponents include the incumbent, Senator Robert C. Smith, and Representative John E. Sununu. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Fueled by Drought, a Wildfire Gets Closer to Denver
description: After starting on Saturday as a campfire, a fast-moving wildfire in central Colorado had scorched its way through nearly 120 square miles of forest land by today. It swept to within 50 miles of metropolitan Denver, and the local authorities warned thousands that they might have to evacuate their homes.

title: Tristar Is in a Group That May Bid for KirchMedia
description: German executives confirmed today that Columbia Tristar Television, owned by Sony, is part of a consortium that wants to bid for KirchMedia, the bankrupt company that controls Germany's biggest commercial television broadcaster.

title: TENET HEALTHCARE PROFIT SURPASSES ESTIMATES
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the second-largest hospital chain in the nation, said profit in its most recent quarter beat estimates as it treated more patients, raised prices and cut costs. Excluding one-time items, profit for the fourth quarter of its fiscal year, which ended May 31, was higher than the 90-cent estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call, Tenet said. Tenet has increased profit by raising the prices it charges managed care insurers and investing in profitable medical services like cardiology and orthopedics.

title: Credit Card Issuers Face a Class Action
description: The Supreme Court refused today to block a class-action lawsuit that seeks at least $24 billion from Visa USA and MasterCard International for trying to extend their credit card dominance into debit cards.

title: To Cheers and Drums, the Irish Beat Saudis and Forge Ahead
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan, June 11  As Ireland sailed on the wings of a 3-0 win over Saudi Arabia to the second round of the World Cup, Irish soccer fans were hoisting their beers tonight to their star striker, R. Keane. But it was Robbie, not Roy.

title: Germany Disputes Visit of Qaeda Figure
description: Intelligence officials in Washington have not responded to requests for information about a visit to Germany by Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, an operative for Al Qaeda who has emerged as a central figure in the Sept. 11 attacks, German officials said today. They added that their own checks had turned up no trace of Mr. Mohammed's ever visiting or living here.

title: Sports of The Times; Koreans And Yanks Sweat It Out
description: THREE. One. X, for Unknown. Welcome to World Cup Mathematics for Beginners. Does this total equate with optimism or pessimism or simply a mild case of mental dehydration after a muggy afternoon in Taegu?

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: CHANCELLOR SEARCH PANEL Nat Leventhal, who headed Michael R. Bloomberg's post-election transition, will lead the search committee for a new chancellor and new appointees to the Board of Education, the mayor said yesterday. Mr. Bloomberg said that the searches were just starting and that there was no short list for chancellor, but acknowledged that Paul Vallas, former head of the Chicago school system, was a contender. "There's lots of people who will want to be chancellor of the New York City school system," Mr. Bloomberg said, noting the recent agreement to centralize authority for school administration. "Everybody's going to be shocked at the number and the quality of people that we will have to select from."

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the planned appointment of George Stephanopoulos as sole anchor of ''This Week'' on ABC misstated the given name of the chairman of the Committee of Concerned Journalists in Washington, who commented on Mr. Stephanopoulos's government background. He is Bill Kovach, not William.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSTEIN, BERNARD
description: ADELSTEIN-Bernard. The Officers and Staff of State of Israel Bonds mourn the passing of a devoted friend of Israel who was a founder and long time chairman of its Labor Division. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Joshua Matza, Presidential Nominee Burton P. Resnick, Chairman of the Board Irwin Hochberg, National Campaign Chairman Roberta Goldstein, National Associate Campaign Chairman Stuart Davidson, Esq. Barbara J. Easterling Co-Chairs, National Labor Advisory Board

title: Maxwell Rabb, 91, Eisenhower Official and Former Ambassador
description: Maxwell M. Rabb, former United States ambassador to Italy, died on Sunday at the New York Weill Cornell Center in Manhattan. He was 91 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: The End of An Uncivil War
description: The historical mutual sneering between America's soldiers and its universities is coming to an end.

title: Cities and States Clamor to Be Bio Town, U.S.A.
description: Michigan is spending $1 billion to create a ''life sciences corridor.'' St. Louis bills itself as the BioBelt, while Hawaii boasts of its biodiversity.

title: At Harvard, Century-Old Plants That Glisten With Life
description: The Harvard Museum of Natural History holds some of nature's most charismatic offerings, thundering dinosaurs, snarling tigers and great towers of raw gemstones. Yet it is a room full of unassuming botanical specimens, mere copies of flowers, that draws the crowds each day.

title: Instinet Plans to Acquire Island ECN for $508 Million in Stock
description: The Instinet Group, a stock trading network popular with institutional investors, said yesterday that it would acquire a rival, Island ECN, for about $508 million in stock to compete better with the Nasdaq stock market and other trading platforms.

title: Rumsfeld Says Iraq Has Chemical Arms Ready
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that Iraq had already prepared chemical weapons for attack and was developing nuclear and biological arms. He rejected President Saddam Hussein's denials by telling hundreds of cheering American sailors and marines tonight that Mr. Hussein is ''a world-class liar.''

title: Hour of Reckoning in the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Hour of Reckoning in the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Ballet Contest In Mississippi
description: Professional dancers from 25 nations will compete for medals, cash awards and scholarships in the seventh USA International Ballet Competition, which opens on Saturday in Jackson, Miss. The event, held there every four years, is considered one of the major world competitions. Edward Villella, the former New York City Ballet star and now the director of the Miami City Ballet, is the honorary chairman of the competition.

title: Some Help on Hiring but a Hindrance on Mayor's Other Goals
description: The tentative contract settlement that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reached yesterday with the New York City teachers' union will almost certainly help Mr. Bloomberg achieve his most urgent education goal: hiring up to 10,000 new teachers for September. By raising starting salaries in the United Federation of Teachers to a more attractive $39,000, the agreement will also get Mr. Bloomberg closer to complying with a daunting state requirement that all 80,000 city teachers be certified by September 2003.

title: When Works Must Be New, They Get Old Pretty Fast
description: The Locrian Chamber Players have a guiding principle that has endeared them to fans of new music: they never play works that are more than a decade old. That means that when the ensemble celebrates its own 10th anniversary, in 2004, works that were hot off the press during its inaugural season will begin to slide into the mists of antiquity, from the group's point of view.

title: Spinning Drum Flies Off Cabbage Shredder, Killing Factory Worker
description: A spinning metal drum broke loose yesterday from a cabbage shredder in a Lower East Side food factory, fatally crushing one worker, severing the arm of another and injuring two others, the authorities said.

title: Splitsville's Sad Song: 'I Said I Do but Now I Don't'
description: In the small office on Main Street that houses Tiptonville's city hall, chamber of commerce and history museum, Fran Hearn, the treasurer and water clerk, was speaking up for marriage this afternoon.

title: Eye Surgery's Good and Bad Bets
description: Although laser surgery to correct vision problems is growing in popularity, it is not for everybody, according to guidelines issued last week by the American Society of Cataract and Refractive Surgery.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Program Requiring Inmates to Acknowledge Unrevealed Crimes
description: Prison rehabilitation programs that require inmates to reveal undisclosed crimes do not necessarily violate the constitutional right against compelled self-incrimination even if inmates lose privileges for refusing to participate, a sharply divided Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE

title: Effectiveness of Grants to Keep Jobs Downtown Is Questioned
description: The American Stock Exchange is the latest company to get a cash grant from the state and city for remaining downtown.

title: Kidd Wants Jordan Back
description: Point guard Jason Kidd gave a public vote of confidence for the assistant coach Eddie Jordan to stay with the Nets. Kidd has already said the same in private to Rod Thorn, the Nets' president and general manager.

title: Legal Help for Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: In So Paulo
description: Too much traffic? Join hundreds of local businesspeople in buying a helicopter. Want to go mountain climbing? Try rappelling off the city's overpasses. With 10 million people living inside the city limits, So Paulo is always a step away from chaos. But the disorder has bred a vitality that makes the city one of the most dynamic and unorthodox in Latin America.

title: WELLPOINT HEALTH NETWORKS RAISES EARNINGS FORECAST
description: WellPoint Health Networks Inc., one of California's biggest health insurers, raised its 2002 earnings forecast to $4.30 a share from $4. The revision is based primarily on strong medical membership growth in important regions and assumes the continuation of current economic conditions, the company said. Wellpoint said 2002 membership would grow by nearly 10 percent, more than the 5 percent to 7 percent growth the company had forecast earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNIS, ABRAHAM MAXWELL
description: KUNIS-Abraham Maxwell. Beloved husband of Jeanette Kunis. Devoted father of Dr. Cheryl Kunis and Dr. Richard Kunis. Dear brother of Manuel Kunis and Edith Krimstock. Loving grandfather of Dana and Jonathan Rapoport and Lauren and Brian Kunis. Services Wednesday, 1PM at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, N.J. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Consulting Acquisition
description: The WPP Group, the second-biggest advertising company in the world, said it had bought 60 percent of H-Line Worldwide Ltd., a Chinese public relations firm. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed. WPP's Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide division will take control of the Chinese company, which had revenue of $2.9 million last year, WPP said. The company, to be called H-Line Ogilvy, will handle publicity for companies from its Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou offices. H-Line was founded in 1994 and has 80 employees.

description: RALEIGH, N.C., June 10  Paul Maurice and Scotty Bowman have a few things in common. But the contrast in their personalities is one of many interesting comparisons in the Stanley Cup finals between two vastly different franchises.

description: Mets General Manager Steve Phillips had watched his $95 million team underachieve for more than two months. He had waited patiently, hoping that the high-priced players he acquired during a hectic off-season would finally start producing the way he envisioned.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Smartforce To Buy Skillsoft
description: SmartForce, a supplier of education software, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the SkillSoft Corporation, a provider of Web-based business training, for about $219.8 million in stock. SmartForce said it expected to have revenue of about $99 million and, before acquisition-related expenses, a loss of about 6 cents a share for the year that will end Jan. 31, 2003. Company officials did not comment.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: MACHINERY ORDERS ROSE Japanese companies ordered more equipment than expected in April, a sign the slide in business spending that has restrained growth in the country may be easing. Private machinery orders, excluding those by shippers and electric power utilities, rose 8.4 percent in April from March, government figures showed. That was more than twice the 3 percent increase economists expected. (Bloomberg News)

title: Memory Is a Big Part Of One-Acts
description: Promise is always in the air when Ensemble Studio Theater, under the artistic direction of Curt Dempster, holds its annual festival of one-act plays. Even if fulfillment remains elusive, something to savor in writing or acting usually rewards attendance. So it is with Series C, the four plays running through Sunday at Ensemble Studio Theater in Clinton as the final installment of Marathon 2002.

title: Law May Forbid Leagues to Say If Player Is Hurt
description: Joe Torre's daily routine includes updating reporters on injuries affecting his players. Torre, the Yankees' manager, may discuss a pitcher's shoulder tendinitis or an outfielder's chronic knee trouble. It has been standard operating procedure in baseball and other professional sports for decades.

title: Poll Finds New York Fearful, But Upbeat Over Future, Too
description: Nine months after the destruction of the World Trade Center, New Yorkers say they are struggling with the psychological fallout from the attack, with many avoiding visits to skyscrapers, landmarks and stadiums, and reporting persistent anxiety and sleeplessness, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: The Secret Is in the Saffron
description: IN Italy, I've been in restaurants where they make simple, free-form lasagnas. They cook a couple of sheets of fresh pasta and layer them with a simple filling, sometimes no more than a few spoons of pesto or tomato sauce and a dusting of cheese. The pasta is usually a little crumpled, very informal.

title: Pied Guitarist of Cuba Takes Joy on the Road
description: Miguel Del Morales, the 76-year-old troubadour who strums and sings his way through Karim Dridi's uplifting film ''Cuba Feliz,'' embodies the wandering minstrel as a man of the people and the repository of an impoverished nation's hard-won emotional wisdom. As he travels from one city to another in his native Cuba, meeting up with local musicians and jamming with them, Mr. Del Morales, who is known as El Gallo (the Rooster) suggests a Latin-American Willie Nelson (without his band), indefatigably making his way along his country's dusty roads.

In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Young Concert Artists, Inc, 250 West 57th St, Suite 1222, New York, NY 10019. The men worked the stuff into a rectangular mold, and dumped it out as it hardened.

description: New York City is unlikely to pass a budget in time to meet its deadline today, officials said yesterday, as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to suspend bottle and can recycling emerged as a major sticking point in his talks with the City Council.

title: Senate Votes To Increase Debt Ceiling
description: The Senate voted today to increase the government's legal borrowing limit, taking a step toward resolving a partisan dispute that has threatened to set off a financial crisis at the end of this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOEHM, HERMAN
description: BOEHM-Herman. After a long illness, our beloved Herman, 92, ''The Judge,'' died peacefully at home in NYC on June 9, 2002. The ultimate gentleman, he treated everyone with kindness, intelligence, and tact. His generosity of spirit, as well as of his resources, was boundless (CR&T, Habonim Preschool, Baeck Institute, Young Artists of Israel, and The Museum of Jewish Heritage, etc.). The son of Else and Max Bohm of Berlin, Germany, he came to the U.S. at the start of WWII, married Antoinette Praschkauer (deceased) and served in the U.S. Army Intelligence Corps. After the war, he achieved great success in the food import business. A masterly bridge player, award-winning ballroom dancer, raconteur, lifelong horse lover and opera lover, he was a joy to be with. He is survived by and deeply mourned by his wife Anna KarchmarBoehm; a sister, Hilda Oliven; a nephew, Herbert David; a niece, Eleanor Rosenthal; his great-grandnephew Daniel Rosenthal and Emmy Kondo; his great-grandniece Susan Rosenthal and Brett. Also mourned by his stepson Robert Karchmar and Yosefa Klein-Karchmar; Sylvia Karchmar, Dorian and Lara Karchmar, and his extended family. Irena Starzec, Maia Matcharashvili & Joanna Sobyczak, who so enhanced the quality of his last years, join the family in mourning. Darling Herman, we will always remember your wisdom, thoughtfulness, and engaging smile. Your family and friends will miss you so very much. Memorial service to be announced.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Redrawing Districts
description: The State Court of Appeals has declared the legislative redistricting plan of Gov. Parris N. Glendening unconstitutional and is taking the redrawing task into its own hands. Ruling that the districts were not compact enough nor properly sensitive to county lines, the court plans to draw a new plan for the 188 General Assembly districts in time for the November elections. title: From the City, 5 Votes Against
description: Although the New York State Assembly voted overwhelmingly on Monday to allow mayoral control of the New York City school system, five members of the Assembly from the city, all Democrats, opposed the measure. They were EDWARD C. SULLIVAN of Manhattan, PETER J. ABATE JR. of Brooklyn, WILLIAM SCARBOROUGH of Queens, WILLIAM COLTON of Brooklyn and AURELIA GREENE of the Bronx. Several of the dissenters criticized the provision to abolish the 32 community school boards, saying that it would stifle parental input. At least one, Ms. Greene, began her political career as a member of her community school board in the South Bronx, District 9, which has been at the center of several scandals over the years. In one, Ms. Greene and her husband, the REV. JEROME A. GREENE, were indicted on charges of stealing a school piano in 1989. Though they were acquitted of that charge, Mr. Greene later pleaded guilty to charges of theft for having school employees print campaign literature with school supplies. Abby Goodnough

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Waiver Ruling Stands
description: Students and parents can be required to forfeit the right to sue before a student can participate in extracurricular activities, the State Supreme Judicial Court has ruled. The decision came in the case of Merav Sharon, a former Newton High School student whose family sued after she broke her arm during cheerleading practice in 1995. Ms. Sharon and her father said they signed a waiver under distress and did not understand what they were signing. The court refused to invalidate the waiver. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Mural Reflects Students' Visions
description: For several months, the Greenwich Village Middle School housed students from Public Schools 89 and 150, both of which were evacuated after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. For the past six months, the 60 seventh-grade students painted and sculptured their vision of the ruptured New York skyline for a 20-foot mural. Yesterday, nine months after the students saw the twin towers of the World Trade Center collapse, they unveiled the mural. The artist INGRID MENENDEZ helped the students design and complete the clay and paint mural, which includes images of skyscrapers, local stores and the Greenwich Village school itself. The artist was part of the studio-in-a-school program sponsored by The New York Times Company Foundation. Jennifer Medina

title: Teachers' Settlement Could Echo in Next Round of Negotiations With City Unions
description: The tentative settlement for New York City's teachers could sharpen tensions in coming municipal union negotiations, labor and municipal finance experts said, because the double-digit raise promised to the teachers could embolden other unions to make hefty demands.

title: For the East Side Set, 'Hot Chocolate' for All Seasons
description: ''I wanted to make a cold version of the hot chocolate we served this winter,'' said Florian Bellanger, above, the pastry chef at Fauchon. So he came up with smoothies for sophisticates. Chocolate, of course, is one flavor, but chocolate-hazelnut, blood orange, mango and an intense wild strawberry are others. Called Summer Frozen Delights, they are $5 each in Champagne flutes at Fauchon, 442 Park Avenue (56th Street) and 1000 Madison Avenue (77th Street). Starting this weekend, they will be available to go, in plastic containers, for $4, at the stores' new takeout counter.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: ADVENT REDUCES SALES FORECAST Shares of Advent Software , which makes software that automates securities trade orders for companies like Lehman Brothers and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter , dropped 38 percent yesterday after the company reduced its sales forecast for this year. Advent's shares declined $13.37, to $22.10. The stock has fallen about 55 percent in the last year. The company, based in San Francisco, said it would begin selling some software by subscription rather than receiving full payment up front. The change is expected to cut software license sales for this year about $21 million, the company said, but permit an increase of more than 40 percent next year. Advent, which competes with companies like SunGard Data Systems and the Thomson Corporation, also said it would buy the Techfi Corporation for about $23 million. Techfi, a software company in Denver, develops technology for financial services companies to organize online accounts and for portfolio and client management.

title: Antiquities Dealer Is Sentenced To Prison
description: In a case that has been closely watched by the art world, a prominent Manhattan antiquities dealer was sentenced yesterday to 33 months in federal prison and fined $50,000 for his role in a conspiracy to sell antiquities stolen from Egypt.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Electronic Arts Agrees To Buy Black Box
description: Electronic Arts, the largest video-game software maker in the United States, agreed yesterday to buy Black Box Games, a game developer, for an undisclosed amount. Black Box is developing the Electronic Arts Need for Speed racing franchise and has produced other sports games, including Sega's NHL 2K and Soccer Slam, Electronic Arts said in a statement. Electronic Arts, which makes the EA Sports titles, will get Black Box's 100-person studio in Vancouver, British Columbia. Company officials could not be reached for comment.

title: The Education Mayor's Big Win
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg has won the first crucial rounds in his war to improve New York City's public schools. The negotiations for a teachers' contract, stalled for 19 months, finally concluded with a tentative settlement on Monday. Yesterday the State Legislature put the final touches on an agreement that gives Mr. Bloomberg substantial control over the city schools. Now comes the hard part. Having achieved enough of what he wanted from the Legislature and the teachers, the mayor has to produce what he promised -- better education.

title: How Much Fun Can a Guy Have Without Garbage?
description: JOHN J. DOHERTY looks very much at home, sitting at the head of the long, gleaming conference table that dominates his austere, wood-paneled corner office at 125 Worth Street. As the commissioner of the New York City Department of Sanitation, Mr. Doherty is in charge of one of the few agencies that make house calls. And it seems he just can't get enough of the place.

title: For the Literary Set, Home Cooking, Unedited
description: ''OH, heavens, I did them wrong!'' Maria Elena Schiffrin exclaimed, peering into a pan of onions. ''I added the sugar and vinegar later than I should. And I can't remember if I should have covered them or not.'' She consulted the recipe. ''I usually don't do these because they're such a bother,'' she went on, exasperated. ''What I like is to do something simple, and more or less forget about it.''

The convict, Kevin Saxon, 32, left, a former leader of a Harlem drug gang, was the focus of a citywide manhunt for 20 days in May. Mr. Saxon, 32, was sentenced yesterday for the September 2000 murder of Richard Gaines of Harlem. Susan Saulny (NYT)

description: A bishop who was a confidant of Cardinal John O'Connor has resigned as a pastor and auxiliary bishop after admitting having had sexual affairs with women over the course of several years, the Archdiocese of New York said yesterday.

title: MERIT PAY IS DELAYED FOR FORD'S MIDLEVEL EMPLOYEES
description: The Ford Motor Company will delay merit raises for 47,500 midlevel salaried employees in North America until at least Aug. 1 as the company, the second-largest automaker, seeks to conserve cash. The raises would take effect after the company has had a chance to review second-quarter results fully, the chief operating officer, Nicholas Scheele, said in an e-mail message to employees. Ford previously delayed the increases from April until July 1, a spokesman, Nick Sharkey, said.
