title: Palestinian Suicide Bomber Kills a Girl and Wounds 8
description: A Palestinian with a bomb hidden under his shirt walked into a restaurant today on a main street in this town north of Tel Aviv, asked for a bottle of water and blew himself up, killing a 15-year-old girl and wounding eight other people.

title: STANDARD & POOR'S DOWNGRADES XEROX DEBT
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its rating on about $17 billion in Xerox Corporation debt because of concern about the company's debt burden and cash flow. Xerox's bonds were cut one grade to BB- from BB, Standard & Poor's said. Lower credit ratings usually increase a company's future borrowing costs. Xerox's debt was already rated as below investment grade. The ratings are at risk of being cut again until Xerox refinances a $7 billion bank loan due in October. Shares of Xerox, which is based in Stamford, Conn., fell 46 cents, to $7.86 a share.

description: When a fire broke out in the engine room of a ferry on the Hudson River in November 2000, there were plenty of life jackets, but they were all stowed near the fire. There were fire hoses, but the pump to fill them was in the engine room too, out of reach of the crew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, GERTRUDE M.
description: BERGER-Gertrude M. Died yesterday, June 11, 2002 at age 91. She was a lifelong resident of Brooklyn, N.Y. She graduated from Hunter College Class of 1931, Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa. She also did graduate work at Columbia University. She taught French in the New York City school system for many years, retiring in 1976. She was predeceased by her late, beloved husband Robert, of 64 years. She is survived by her sister, Ethel Segal of Manhattan, her sons, Dr. Avram S. Berger of West Simsbury, CT, Professor Selman A. Berger of Staten Island, NY, four grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Funeral services will take place on Thursday, June 13, 2002 at 12:30PM, at the Menorah Chapels Inc, 2145 Richmond Ave, Staten Island, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Indian Point Power Plant Survey
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democratic candidate for governor, said yesterday that a spot survey in Westchester County by his campaign showed that potassium iodide pills, useful for combating thyroid cancer after a nuclear accident, are difficult to find there. The county has begun distributing free pills to residents within a 10-mile radius of the Indian Point nuclear power plant, and has publicized a list of pharmacies that have agreed to carry the pills. But Mr. Cuomo said a check of 40 pharmacies within the same radius found that 95 percent of them did not stock the pills. Lisa W. Foderaro (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS CONTRACT DISPUTE France Telecom pulled out of an accord to finance a new network for MobilCom, the German mobile phone company that declined to dismiss its chief executive, Gerhard Schmid, even though Mr. Schmid admitted he violated securities laws. France Telecom said it was still in talks with MobilCom's banks about taking control of the company without absorbing its debt. France Telecom's chief financial officer, Jean-Louis Vinciguerra, said on a conference call, "The last straw was the board's decision not to fire Schmid." MobilCom said it saw "no basis" for France Telecom to end the accord and that it had not breached the contract. MobilCom's shares fell 47 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, FLORENCE
description: STRAUSS-Florence. On June 11th, 2002. Beloved wife of Bernard, sister of the late Jessie, Carl and Selma. Aunt of Marian and Norm Adams, Flo and the late Peter Strauss. Great-aunt of Dara and David Adams, Diane Adams, Tami and Mark Strauss. Also survived by six great-great nieces and nephews. Services private.

title: Union Pushing For Higher Salaries
description: The players union of the W.N.B.A. wants a new, short-term contract that will increase salaries significantly from the $40,000-a-year average and give the players leverage to market themselves without league restrictions.

title: Finding a New Experience In a Different Company
description: Peter Boal, a longtime principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, continually reaches out for new experiences. An American danseur noble, he seems to have focused in recent years on shading the beauty of his pure classical dancing with dramatic nuance, bravely allowing himself to grow in public.

title: Environmentalists Win Bombing Lawsuit
description: Twelve years after they were accused of carrying a bomb that exploded in their car, two Earth First environmentalists were awarded $4.4 million in a federal civil suit contending that their rights had been violated by the local and federal officers who arrested them.

title: Bishop Quits as Others Prepare to Meet on Abuse Scandal
description: A day before the nation's Roman Catholic bishops are to meet in Dallas to debate how to respond to the clergy sexual abuse scandal that has devastated the church, another bishop resigned under the shadow of sexual abuse accusations.

title: Railroads Raise Freight Rates
description: The Union Pacific Corporation and the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation, the largest railroads in the nation, have raised some rates as much as 13 percent as shipments increase because of the strengthening economy.

title: Psychiatrist Is CUNY Trustee
description: The City University of New York has a new trustee: HUGO M. MORALES, a psychiatrist who was formerly the medical director of the Bronx Mental Health Center. CUNY, which has nearly 19,000 students of Dominican ancestry, said that he is its first Dominican board member. He was nominated by the governor, who appoints 10 of CUNY's 17 trustees, and approved by the State Senate yesterday. Dr. Morales, 69, was a member of Hostos Community College's advisory board for several years. Karen W. Arenson

title: National Briefing | West: California: First Poet Laureate
description: Quincy Troupe, a New York native, was appointed California's first poet laureate by Gov. Gray Davis. A recipient of two American Book Awards and the Peabody Award, Mr. Troupe teaches creative writing and American and Caribbean literature at the University of California at San Diego. ''Quincy Troupe will serve as an excellent ambassador of poetry,'' said Barbara George, the California Arts Council's chairwoman. During his two-year term, the poet laureate will give at least of six readings across the state. Catherine Billey (NYT)

title: Recipe: Angel-Hair Pasta With Creamy Peas and Prosciutto
description: Time: 25 minutes

title: Menus at Hand, at a Turn of the Web Page
description: Since its inception, Amazon.com has helped with dinner, with cookbooks, then cookware. Now it has a new service: menus from thousands of restaurants in New York, Boston, Chicago, San Francisco, Seattle and Washington are on the Web site. The menus are cross-referenced by neighborhood, cuisine or even a particular dish. Prices, addresses, telephone numbers are given, and driving directions can be obtained. There is no charge to the consumer or the restaurant. Carrie Peters, a spokeswoman for Amazon, stressed that the service was an experiment. Indeed, the listings have not been fine-tuned: some menus are not given, some are outdated and some restaurants have closed. The restaurants whose menus appear were not consulted. ''I don't know how it happened but I don't think it can hurt,'' said Danny Meyer, an owner of Union Square Cafe and Gramercy Tavern, two New York restaurants that are featured. Ms. Peters said restaurants could have their menus removed if they wished. The site (click on ''Restaurants'' under the Service heading of Amazon.com) also has a list of the most popular restaurants in each city, based Zagat-style on consumer response.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline on Friday about House approval of a measure to make a repeal of the estate tax permanent misstated the vote in some copies, as did an entry in all copies of the Business Digest. The vote was 256 to 171, not 71.

title: Shifts at Citigroup Renew Speculation on Succession; 4 Executives Are Given Expanded Duties
description: Citigroup broadened the responsibilities of four of its top executives yesterday, generating new speculation about who will succeed Sanford I. Weill as chairman and chief executive.

title: Foreigners in Flight Schools Must Undergo New Screening
description: The Justice Department announced a new screening program today for international students who want to learn to fly large jets in the United States, and it will require fingerprinting and background checks before they can climb into a cockpit.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Telecommunications Contract Dispute
description: France Tlcom pulled out of an accord to finance a new network for MobilCom, the German mobile phone company that declined to dismiss its chief executive, Gerhard Schmid, even though Mr. Schmid admitted he violated securities laws. France Tlcom said it was still in talks with MobilCom's banks about taking control of the company without absorbing its debt. France Tlcom's chief financial officer, Jean-Louis Vinciguerra, said on a conference call, ''The last straw was the board's decision not to fire Schmid.'' MobilCom said it saw ''no basis'' for France Tlcom to end the accord and that it had not breached the contract. MobilCom's shares fell 47 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, DANIEL J.
description: SULLIVAN-Daniel J. Of New Canaan, CT, on June 10, 2002. Born on November 9, 1932, in Brooklyn, N.Y., to Daniel J. and Mary M. Sullivan and formerly of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. and Katonah, N.Y. Beloved father of Kathryn E. Sullivan of Mt. Vernon, N.Y., Margaret A. Egan of Pawling, N.Y., Daniel J. Sullivan of Lexington, MA, Kieran J. Sullivan of Kingston, N.H., and Maura S. Gaughan of Natick, MA. Brother of Francis P. Sullivan of Savannah, GA; grandfather of eight; uncle of numerous nieces and nephews and fiance of Claire O'Gara Grimes of Pound Ridge, N.Y. Predeceased by his parents, by his brother John L. Sullivan, and, in 1982, by his beloved wife of 26 years, Joan M. Sullivan. A 1958 magna cum laude graduate of St. John's University, he was a certified public accountant and devoted his entire career to Price Waterhouse, from which he retired in 1992 after 22 years as a partner. He served for two years in the United States Army, including one year's tour in Japan. He was a member of the Country Club of Darien, The University Club, The New York Athletic Club, The Waccabuc Country Club, and the Senior Men's Club of New Canaan. Calling hours will be on Thursday, June 13, and Friday, June 14, from 2PM until 5PM and from 7PM until 9PM each day, at Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main Street, New Canaan. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, June 15, at 1 PM, at St. Thomas More Church, 374 Middlesex Road, Darien, CT. Interment will be at Lakeview Cemetery in New Canaan directly from church. A reception will follow at the Country Club of Darien. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to Nativity Preparatory School, 30 Lamartine Street, Jamaica Plain, MA. 02130.

title: AES WILL SELL ITS NEWENERGY UNIT TO REDUCE DEBT
description: The AES Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its energy services unit, AES NewEnergy, to the Constellation Energy Group for $240 million to help reduce debt. AES NewEnergy sells power to offices and factories in 13 states, including New York, New Jersey, Texas and California. NewEnergy's British operations are not included in the sale, the utility owner said. AES, based in Arlington, Va., has said it will sell $1.5 billion in assets to reduce its debt. Constellation Energy is based in Baltimore and owns Baltimore Gas and Electric.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREISKEL, BARBARA
description: PREISKEL-Barbara. Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc. mourns the passing of Ms. Barbara S. Preiskel, a distinguished leader and beloved friend. Ms. Preiskel served on our Board for 26 years. Her generous support and myriad contributions to the Federation will be long remembered. Our sincerest condolences are extended to her husband, two sons, family and friends.

title: Where a Casual Style Is Quite Serious
description: WASHINGTON PARK is one restaurant that almost needs a screenplay rather than a review. The title: ''Waiting for Waxman.'' The concept: ''Big Night'' meets ''Bright Lights, Big City.'' It's the story of a brash young chef, Jonathan Waxman, who lands in Manhattan in the mid-1980's, sets the town ablaze with his California-inspired menu at Jams and becomes dizzy with fame and success. Jams begets Bud's which begets Hulot's. A Jams opens in London.

title: Police Commissioner Defends Recruiting
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly defended the Police Department's recent recruiting drive yesterday in the face of criticism from the largest police union that it had fallen short of its goals.

title: Holocaust Payments by Swiss Delayed Further by New Approach
description: A controversy over speeding up payments to Holocaust victims has further delayed disbursement of money set aside to compensate some of them.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: YUGOSLAVIA: FIRST WAR-CRIMES TRIAL IN SERBIA The first war-crimes trial on Serbian soil began hearing evidence against a former Yugoslav Army reservist accused of killing two Kosovo Albanian civilians in May 1999. Four former colleagues testified that Ivan Nikolic was a brave soldier, and they gave a hazy description of the incident, which occurred during NATO's bombing campaign to halt Serbian repression of Kosovo's Albanian majority. Serbia, the dominant republic in Yugoslavia, is under heavy Western pressure to cooperate in the prosecution of those charged with war crimes.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Work On Space Platform
description: Astronauts anchored a $254 million work platform outside the International Space Station, an important step in extending the reach of a construction crane that is essential to finishing the outpost. The work set the stage for the station's robot arm to be mounted on the platform this month or in early July. Later, American astronauts Daniel Bursch and Carl Walz, who had moved out of the space station and into the space shuttle Endeavour in advance of their return to Earth, broke NASA's space endurance record, exceeding the 188-day, four-hour mark set by Shannon Lucid in 1996. Todd Halvorson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Enron Law Firms May Be Sued
description: Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said yesterday that within weeks, he would file lawsuits against individuals or firms that helped devise a $220 million deal last year between the Enron Corporation and the state trash agency. He did not identify the targets, but in the months since the money the agency gave Enron was lost in the company's collapse in December, he has repeatedly criticized the two law firms advising the trash agency, the Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority. One firm, Murtha Cullina in Hartford, the trash authority's longtime counsel, helped draft the deal; the other firm, Hawkins, Delafield & Wood, of New York City, was the agency's bond counsel. The firms insist that the deal was a legal energy transaction; Mr. Blumenthal has called it an illegal loan to Enron made to increase the trash agency's revenue. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Last Witness In Deli Murder Trial
description: The last witness in the trials of the two men accused of shooting five people -- three of them fatally -- in an apartment above the Carnegie Deli in Midtown last year testified yesterday. The witness, LaShondra Clinton, said that she heard one defendant, Sean Salley, talk about needing to rob someone for money in the days before the triple murder. Ms. Clinton is the granddaughter of the funk musician George Clinton, for whom Mr. Salley, 30, worked as a stagehand before being fired two years ago. Mr. Salley's defense is that the co-defendant in the trial, Andre Smith, pulled a gun and forced him into the botched robbery. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKLAREW, HELEN
description: SKLAREW-Helen. Passed away peacefully at 92 years of age on June 8th. Mrs. Sklarew was born in New York City and lived there before moving to Palm Beach, FL. more than 20 years ago. She enjoyed a rich and full life and relished every moment. She always had a twinkle in her eye and had a keen sense of humor. Mrs. Sklarew had a passion for ballroom dancing, loved travelling and was an enthusiastic bridge player. She was happily married to Sidney Siegel for 32 years and Sidney Sklarew for 12 years, both of whom predeceased her. She will be greatly missed by her caring sister Frances Shiftan. Her adored brother Abraham Levenson died in 1996. Mrs. Sklarew is survived by her devoted children Susan Naiman, Jane Silver, Bronni Stein, her sonsin-law Peter Naiman, Steve Shane, John Connolly, her grandchildren Kenneth Silver, Fiona and Steven Silver, Marjorie Fox and Jeffrey Naiman, Kara Naiman Roberts and Larry Roberts & her five great grandchildren. Her burial was private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVOTI, LORETTA FRANCES
description: LIVOTI-Loretta Frances. Affectionately known as aunt Lottie, on June 11, 2002. Dear sister of Frank Livoti. Cherished aunt of 10 nieces and nephews. Friends may call Thursday 2-5, 7-9:30 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Avenue (at City line), New Hyde Park. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday 9:45 A.M. at American Martyrs RC Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: DEFENSE CAN VIEW PEARL VIDEO A court ruled that defense lawyers in the trial of four men accused in the killing of the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl could view the videotape of his killing. The lawyers also said they wanted to call his widow, Mariane Pearl, to testify after prosecutors dropped her from their witness list when a doctor said she could not travel for medical reasons. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on Wednesday, June 12, about a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of sales practices at XO Communications erroneously included a reference to a company not connected to the investigation. Nextel - the subject of an unrelated report in the column - should not have been mentioned in the S.E.C. report.

title: Against All Odds, Sweden Knocks Argentina Out of World Cup
description: MIYAGI, Japan, June 12  With a tenacious defense, plucky Sweden unexpectedly knocked soccer giant Argentina out of the World Cup today, marking the first time in 40 years that the Latin Americas soccer powerhouse will not advance beyond the first round.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: FUND MANAGER ACQUIRED The National Bank of Canada said it would acquire the fund manager Altamira for up to 314.1 million Canadian dollars ($204 million) in a deal that will expand its presence outside Quebec. The bank said the deal would double its mutual funds under management, to 10.4 billion Canadian dollars. The purchase price will be 277.1 million to 314.1 million Canadian dollars. National Bank will also assume Altamira's debt of 195.9 million Canadian dollars. Altamira manages about 5 billion Canadian dollars in mutual funds for individual investors. It manages an additional 1 billion Canadian dollars in assets for institutional clients. (Reuters)

title: Another Keane Helps Irish Advance
description: As Ireland sailed on the wings of tonight's 3-0 victory against Saudi Arabia to the second round of the World Cup, Irish fans were saluting their star striker, R. Keane. But it was Robbie Keane, not Roy.

title: Aeropostale Turns a Profit
description: Aeropostale Inc., a clothing retailer that aims at teenagers, had a quarterly profit, reversing a year-earlier loss as it opened more stores and sales increased.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Drug Seller Surges
description: The Goldshield Group, Britain's leading retailer of mail-order pharmaceuticals and vitamins, said its profit rose 29 percent in the second half of its fiscal year, setting off a 19 percent rise in its share price. Net income rose to 5.8 million ($8.5 million) from 4.5 million, for the period, which ended March 31. Sales climbed 32 percent, to 50 million. Goldshield said sales were strong in the United States.

title: AFGHANS CONVENE TO CHOOSE LEADER
description: As Afghanistan turned a page in its history, with the former king convening a traditional assembly to choose a new government, the withdrawal of a chief challenger for the leadership today made it increasingly likely that Hamid Karzai, the current interim leader, would remain in power.

title: As Poland Endures Hard Times, Capitalism Comes Under Attack
description: In Communist times, no one was louder than Poland's famously feisty shipyard workers about the state's inability to provide a decent standard of living. So now it seems a cruel joke that, as the sparkle fades from the market economy, it is private enterprise that has failed them.

title: Still No Verdict In Andersen Case
description: Jurors in the Arthur Andersen criminal case continued their deliberations today for the sixth consecutive day, with no indication of which way they were leaning.

title: Senate Shelves Bill Outlining Hate Crimes More Broadly
description: The Senate shelved legislation today that would make attacks on gays federal hate crimes. The move came after six Republicans who had previously voted for the measure refused to vote to limit debate on it.

title: Court Rules Co-op Sponsor Has to Sell Its Apartments
description: In what real estate lawyers called a major decision affecting co-op apartments, New York State's highest court ruled unanimously yesterday that sponsors of buildings' conversions from rental to co-op status have a contractual duty to sell apartments in a reasonable time.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City To Seek Out Heart-Risk Patients
description: Dr. Benjamin Chu, who oversees the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, said yesterday at a conference on racial disparities in health care that the agency would begin a new cardiology program in July. The agency will actively try to recruit patients who are at risk for heart disease for early intervention programs and treatments at the city's public hospitals. Blacks, for example, suffer disproportionately from problems like diabetes and heart disease, studies have shown. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Besieged Chrtien Announces Campaign Ethics Rules for Canada
description: Prime Minister Jean Chrtien today announced new ethics rules that would oblige him and any cabinet minister competing to succeed him to disclose the sources and amounts of all their campaign donations.

title: Monastery Gunman Ignored Pleas for Mercy From Monk
description: The man who shot his way through a rural Benedictine monastery here on Monday ignored pleas for mercy from a Roman Catholic monk he had wounded in a hallway, killing the brother with two more shots from his Chinese-made assault rifle, investigators and the head of the abbey said today.

title: 6 Years of Talks End in Pact For Labrador Nickel Project
description: Capping six years of often acrimonious negotiation, the Toronto-based Inco Ltd. and the provincial government of Newfoundland signed an agreement today to develop one of the world's richest nickel and cobalt deposits, at Voisey's Bay, Labrador.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERLE, CLOTILDE FARGO
description: MERLE - Clotilde Fargo. June 6th, 2002 in San Francisco. Her family and friends celebrate eighty-eight years of a wonderful life.

title: Albert to Call N.B.A. on TNT
description: Marv Albert was named the lead National Basketball Association voice of TNT for the next six seasons yesterday, after nine years of working in the same role for NBC Sports. He will also continue to call Wimbledon for TNT.

title: Recipe: Moroccan Chicken Smothered in Olives
description: Adapted from "Mediterranean Cooking" by Paula Wolfert (Ecco Press, 1985)

title: The Best of Enemies?
description: Quick quiz: Which Muslim Middle East country held spontaneous candlelight vigils in sympathy with Americans after Sept. 11? Kuwait? No. Saudi Arabia? No. Iran? Yes. You got it! You win a free trip to Iran. And if you come you'll discover not only a Muslim country where many people were sincerely sympathetic to America after Sept. 11, but a country where so many people on the street are now talking about -- and hoping for -- a reopening of relations with America that the ruling hard-liners had to take the unprecedented step two weeks ago of making it illegal for anyone to speak about it in public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, BENJAMIN
description: WARD - Benjamin. The trustees and staff of the Vera Institute of Justice extend their deepest sympathy to the family of Benjamin Ward, honorary trustee since 1998 and trustee from 1990-1994. We miss his intelligence, integrity, counsel and good humor. The City has lost a talented and committed public servant. Christopher Stone, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHANE, SUSAN MOORE
description: McSHANE-Susan Moore, 75, of Watch Hill, RI and Gulf Stream, FL. Died Monday, June 10 at Yale New Haven Hospital from breast cancer. Beloved wife of Gordon McShane. She also leaves five children from her first marriage to the late Dean F. Markham, her daughters, Pamela Markham Heller and Marion Markham Abood, both of NYC, and Ann Markham Judd of Southwest Harbor, ME, and sons Dr. Dean F. Markham, Jr. of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, and George W. Markham of Westerly, RI. Survivors also include her brothers Thomas F. Moore of Stonington, CT and George C. Moore of NYC, ten grandchildren, eight stepchildren, and numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. The family will receive relatives and friends at her home, Fairways, 46 Ocean View Highway, Watch Hill, RI, Thursday from 5-7PM. A Mass in celebration of her life will be held at the Watch Hill Chapel, Bluff Ave., Watch Hill, RI, Friday, 11 A.M., followed by interment in River Bend Cemetery, Beach St., Westerly. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be sent to either the American Cancer Society or the Westerly Hospital, Wells St., Westerly, RI 02891. Information: GaffneyDolan Funeral Home, 59 Spruce Street, Westerly, RI.

title: Recipe: Rum-Glazed Mango and Papaya
description: Time: 15 minutes

title: Terrorist Yields Clues to Plots, Officials Assert
description: After nearly 100 sessions with C.I.A. and F.B.I. interrogators at a heavily guarded, undisclosed location, the captured terrorist Abu Zubaydah has provided information that American officials say is central to the Bush administration's efforts to pre-empt a new wave of attacks against the United States.

title: Before the Champagne, a Taste of Home
description: Shaquille O'Neal acknowledged he has a ''boom, boom, boom'' game. If the first two booms fail, O'Neal, the hulking center of the Los Angeles Lakers, goes to the third boom.

title: The Sharon Path
description: To the Editor:

title: In France, Cheers for Soccer Champions Fade Into Stony Silence
description: It made Page 1 of the nation's most prestigious newspaper. It plunged spectators clustered around television screens in homes and boulevard cafes into grief and immense Gallic shrugs. But, ultimately, said one French student who watched his national team's exit from the World Cup on his computer screen here today, it was ''the story of a death foretold.''

title: Fields on Wheels
description: THE fruit pushcart down the block from my apartment stands out like a Gauguin on a prison wall, the one splash of bright color on a grim stretch of Columbus Avenue high-rises. But I never considered it anything but street art until the day I trudged 28 blocks home from Fairway carrying a bagful of hard green papayas.

title: BMG to Buy Rest of Zomba, The Home Of Pop Stars
description: BMG Music, a division of the German media giant Bertelsmann A.G., agreed today to acquire the rest of the Zomba Music Group, which has fostered superstar music acts like Britney Spears and 'N Sync.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on June 4 about reducing the risk of the uterine condition endometriosis misstated the affiliation of Erika L. Meaddough, the lead author of a study. When it was made, she was a graduate student at Southern Connecticut State University working under the direction of faculty members there and at Yale; she was not enrolled at Yale.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: First War-Crimes Trial In Serbia
description: The first war-crimes trial on Serbian soil began hearing evidence against a former Yugoslav Army reservist accused of killing two Kosovo Albanian civilians in May 1999. Four former colleagues testified that Ivan Nikolic was a brave soldier, and they gave a hazy description of the incident, which occurred during NATO's bombing campaign to halt Serbian repression of Kosovo's Albanian majority. Serbia, the dominant republic in Yugoslavia, is under heavy Western pressure to cooperate in the prosecution of those charged with war crimes. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Bronxville Records Good Medley Time
description: Bronxville High School recorded the second-best time in New York State this outdoor season, 11 minutes 49.77 seconds, in winning the distance medley relay, and Paul Robeson of Brooklyn captured the 4x100 and 4x200 relays last night in the Eastern States girls interscholastic championships at Mitchel Field in Uniondale, N.Y.

title: Summer Of All Fears
description: Washingtonians are well known for being hypersensitive to the elements. A dusting of snow or a heat wave can shut down schools. A Code Red unhealthy air alert, as we had here yesterday, leaves the streets deserted.

title: In the Garment District, a New Caribbean Beat
description: FEW dishes pack as heavyweight a punch as mofongo, the Caribbean preparation of mashed green plantains that is anything but tropical. Like a roundhouse right -- bam! -- comes enough garlic to silence even Emeril Lagasse. Like a double left uppercut -- boom! boom! -- lard and crisp pork cracklings are laced throughout, rich as a shot of butter with a bacon chaser. The only response after a dose of mofongo is a long nap.

title: Dirty Bombs and Civil Rights
description: The word from Washington yesterday was that Abdullah al-Muhajir, the American citizen accused of plotting a ''dirty bomb'' attack on the United States, may never be given a trial, or at least not anytime soon. ''We are not interested in trying and punishing him at the moment,'' Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld declared yesterday. ''We are interested in finding out what he knows.'' What the Bush administration must realize is that its job, even during these challenging times, is to do both: to investigate terrorism while also protecting the constitutional rights of those caught in the dragnet.

title: Benjamin Ward's Gifts
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of Business Day on Monday about annual awards by the Association of Independent Commercial Producers misstated the number won by the four companies that led in the production category. The companies -- @radical.media in New York; Anonymous Content in Culver City, Calif.; HSI Productions in Culver City; and Hungry Man in New York -- received six honors apiece, not four.

description: Time: 25 minutes

title: Fans Can Expect Searches and Visible Security
description: Not since Hubert Green won at Southern Hills in Tulsa, Okla., in 1977 while playing with a police escort has security played such a visible role at the United States Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWINING, KINSLEY
description: TWINING-Kinsley. 83, Old Lyme, CT, died June 9, 2002. Yale '41, CIA, environmentalist. Beloved husband of Cynthia Thebaud and father of Dorothy Globus, Kinny Kreiswirth, Alexander Twining, Edith Twining. Sister Edith Buck. Memorial at Old Lyme Congregational Church, 11AM, June 15. Donations to Old Lyme Conservation Trust in lieu of flowers.

title: Office Tower Moves to Fifth Avenue (Sort Of)
description: The limestone-clad building towering over Saks Fifth Avenue's flagship store has a new owner, and its entrance at 10 West 50 Street will soon display a new address: 623 Fifth Avenue.

title: CBS and Coca-Cola Reach N.C.A.A. Deal
description: The CBS division of Viacom and the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that they had signed an 11-year agreement valued at more than $500 million. The deal awards Coca-Cola the marketing and media rights to 87 championship tournaments overseen by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, including the annual basketball tournament on CBS.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about an application by US Airways for a federal loan guarantee misstated the amount of a bailout package approved by Congress for the airline industry after Sept. 11. It was $15 billion, not million.

title: Recipe: Berries Brle
description: Adapted from "Jeremiah Tower's New American Classics" (Harper & Row, 1986)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: NEXTEL SAYS IT WILL MEET GOALS A short, optimistic statement from an executive at Nextel Communications , the fifth-largest wireless telephone company in the United States, ignited a rally yesterday in the company's shares. Stock in the company jumped after it issued a statement in which Paul Saleh, the chief financial officer, said, "Nextel is executing on its business plans and posting strong operating results." He said that the company was "on track" to meet expectations for 2002, which call for earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of at least $2.5 billion and two million new domestic subscribers. If these trends continue, Mr. Saleh said, "Nextel will likely exceed our expectations for 2002." Nextel, however, is not without its problems. The company has an estimated debt load of $15 billion, and last month its international wireless phone unit filed for bankruptcy after missing an $8.3 million loan payment. Shares in Nextel rose 63 cents, or 16.6 percent, to $4.42.

title: New York's Unemployed
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Leader, in Surprise Move, Opens Debate on Estate Tax Repeal
description: The majority leader Tom Daschle abruptly opened Senate debate today on a Republican plan to repeal the estate tax permanently, complicating lobbying efforts by those on both sides of the issue.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Celerity Files For Initial Offering
description: The Celerity Group, a company based in Milpitas, Calif., that makes devices used to manufacture computer chips, filed for an initial public offering yesterday that is expected to raise as much as $300 million. Celerity is a unit of the Kinetics Group, a Silicon Valley concern that focuses on the semiconductor and biopharmaceutical industries. Proceeds from the initial public offering will be used to repay about $170 million in outstanding debt and for general corporate purposes, which could include working capital and acquisitions. According to its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Celerity makes the gas- and chemical-delivery process modules used to manufacture semiconductors. The number and price of common shares for sale were not set in yesterday's registration statement. Deutsche Bank and Morgan Stanley will lead the underwriting of the offering, with assistance from Merrill Lynch, Lehman Brothers and UBS Warburg. The company plans to list its shares on the Nasdaq stock market under the symbol CLRT.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: CMGI Loss Narrows As Costs Fall
description: CMGI, an Internet venture firm, said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter loss narrowed as the company cut costs like research spending. The net loss was $125.2 million, or 32 cents a share, in the period ended April 30, compared with a loss of $986.6 million, or $2.87 a share, in the period a year earlier, the company said in a statement. Sales declined 35 percent, to $187.4 million. Total operating expenses plunged to $321 million from $1.32 billion. CMGI, which owns AltaVista, a World Wide Web search service, said last month that third-quarter sales would miss its forecast of at least $205 million because of a revenue shortfall at two units: uBid, an auctioneer, and Engage, an advertising company.

title: Isolated Heroes as Two Sides of a Coin
description: What do these men have to sing about? It's not as if either of them is going to get the girl, any girl, though not for want of opportunity. They're introspective, aloof and passive in ways that make you gnash your teeth. ''Alone'' is the cornerstone of their vocabularies, and alone is how they wind up. So what the heck are they doing at the centers of their own musicals?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Master Appointed In Case Of Indicted Lawyer
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that a special master should be appointed to review materials seized from the law offices of Lynne F. Stewart, a Manhattan lawyer who was arrested in April and charged with providing support to terrorists through one of her clients, an imprisoned Egyptian sheik. Ms. Stewart's lawyers had argued that an independent special master was necessary so that prosecutors would not have access to privileged documents that were among the items seized from her office by federal agents after her arrest on April 9. Prosecutors had argued that a government team could adequately review the seized materials, and that the appointment of a special master would needlessly delay prosecution. Judge John G. Koeltl wrote that he would appoint Gary P. Naftalis, a Manhattan criminal defense lawyer and former federal prosecutor, as special master. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Seas Thwart Search For 'Black Boxes'
description: Powerful undersea currents, tall waves and worsening weather have further delayed the search for the data and cockpit recorders of a Hong Kong-bound China Airlines Boeing 747 from Taipei that broke apart at 30,000 feet on May 25 and plunged into the Taiwan Strait, killing all 225 aboard. The currents briefly slowed and the sea became calmer over the weekend, allowing divers to recover six more bodies, bringing the total to 109. But aviation officials said waves up to 13 feet and strengthening currents interrupted the diving again yesterday. The recorders, in water nearly 200 feet deep, are designed to emit locator beacons for 30 days. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Expanding Without Managing
description: Looking at the group of troubled corporate leaders Dennis Kozlowski of Tyco, Ken Lay of Enron, Bernie Ebbers of WorldCom, Gary Winnick of Global Crossing and John Rigas of Adelphia -- it is easy to conclude that flaws in board governance or shady accounting practices are behind their problems. This diagnosis overlooks the commonality in the approach of these corporate executives: All of them are ''serial acquirers'' of other companies. Proud of his leadership model, Mr. Kozlowski once even offered a ''C.E.O. Academy'' to help new chief executives follow his path.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: New Currency Issued

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIPE, TIMOTHY W.
description: KNIPE-Timothy W. On behalf of the Board of Directors and staff of Lighthouse International, we are deeply saddened by the loss of Timothy W. Knipe, a longtime friend and supporter of our organization. Mr. Knipe began his extensive and meaningful relationship with the Lighthouse in 1986 as a volunteer reader to people with impaired vision. He joined the Board in 1990, served as its Chairman from 1993-1999 and remained a director until his passing. Under Mr. Knipe's visionary stewardship as Chairman, the Lighthouse expanded its leadership role both nationally and internationally, helping more people worldwide overcome the challenges of vision impairment. In recognition of Mr. Knipe's unwavering support of, and dedication to, the Lighthouse, the Timothy & Mary Grace Knipe Volunteer Center-a floor of the Lighthouse headquarters building in Manhattan-was recently named. We express our deepest condolences to his wife and family. While he will be missed tremendously, we can cherish the indelible mark he left on our institution. William B. Follett, Chairman of the Board Barbara Silverstone, DSW President and CEO Lighthouse International

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cable Concern Narrows Loss
description: NTL, the struggling cable company that is in the process of revamping its operations, said it had narrowed its first-quarter loss to $600 million, compared with a loss of $1 billion a year earlier. Revenue rose 1.5 percent, to $894 million. NTL filed for bankruptcy protection in May after amassing $17.5 billion in debt from an acquisition spree. As part of the revamping, the company has handed control to bondholders in exchange for the forgiveness of $10.9 billion in debt. Barclay Knapp, the chief executive, said today that he expected to continue running the company once it emerged from bankruptcy in September.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: SUPERMARKET WORKERS AUTHORIZE STRIKE Workers at the 55 Pathmark supermarkets in and around New York City voted Monday night to strike if a new contract is not agreed upon by the end of next week. The United Food and Commercial Workers Union Local 1500 represents 7,500 Pathmark cashiers and clerks. Frank Meehan, the local's president, said that the vote to strike was unanimous, and that the main issues included health care, pensions, wages and Sunday overtime pay. A Pathmark spokesman, Rich Savner, declined to comment. Mr. Meehan said another meeting was scheduled for next Monday; the current contract expires on June 22.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, ANN WARD
description: COLLINS-Ann Ward. 94. Died at home peacefully on June 10, 2002 in the presence of her family, as she wished. Ann was a woman of great spirit, independence and compassion. Her joy of life was unwavering, as was her sense of humor, and she shared both freely. Know that she left life as she lived it, with dignity, serenity and love. She will be greatly missed. Ann was a former President of the Casita Maria and was a member of the Order of the Holy Sepulcher. A longtime resident of New York and Palm Beach, Ann is survived by her daughter Jill Hyland Frankenhoff, her son-in-law William, and her grandchildren William Jr. and Christine. Ann is also survived by her stepchildren, Monsignor Timothy S. Collins, Richard W. Collins, Marianna Tostanoski and their children. A Mass of the Resurrection will be held at 10AM, Thursday, June 13, at St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89 St. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Casita Maria, 928 Simpson St., Bronx, New York 10459.

title: Cheese From the Hayloft With Sweet Smells of Summer
description: Unwrap a wedge of Vento d'Estate, a cheese made near Treviso, an Italian town north of Venice, and you'll think you've uncorked a good sauvignon blanc. A cheese for a summer afternoon, it has an alluring, meadow-fresh aroma and a somewhat nutty flavor that hints of white wine. The rind of the firm ivory-colored cheese is embedded with strands of herbs and straw, the result of having been wrapped in hay and aged in wine barrels. It is $14.99 a pound at Citarella markets and $18.36 a pound at Fairway markets.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Interest In Oil Field
description: Norway's largest oil company, Statoil, said it would bid to be a partner with Venezuela's state oil company in an offshore natural gas project that would entail its investing up to $3 billion. Statoil said it was interested in investing in the Deltana Platform project in the Caribbean Sea. The field is between Venezuela and Trinidad and Tobago.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Says It Will Meet Goals
description: A short, optimistic statement from an executive at Nextel Communications, the fifth-largest wireless telephone company in the United States, ignited a rally yesterday in the company's shares. Stock in the company jumped after it issued a statement in which Paul Saleh, the chief financial officer, said, ''Nextel is executing on its business plans and posting strong operating results.'' He said that the company was ''on track'' to meet expectations for 2002, which call for earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of at least $2.5 billion and two million new domestic subscribers. If these trends continue, Mr. Saleh said, ''Nextel will likely exceed our expectations for 2002.'' Nextel, however, is not without its problems. The company has an estimated debt load of $15 billion, and last month its international wireless phone unit filed for bankruptcy after missing an $8.3 million loan payment. Shares in Nextel rose 63 cents, or 16.6 percent, to $4.42.

title: Back From the Edge on Kashmir
description: The danger of nuclear war between India and Pakistan is receding, and American diplomacy deserves much of the credit, along with parallel efforts by Britain, Russia, the European Union and China. Yet with a million troops still poised on either side of the border and the two countries as far apart as ever in their views on Kashmir, the crisis is scarcely over.

title: Key Lime Pie  la Brooklyn, And It's the Real Thing
description: Searching for a classic Key lime pie -- one that's yellow, not green, and made with fresh, not bottled, lime juice -- can lead you to an industrial complex overlooking New York Harbor in Brooklyn. There, Steve Tarpin, left, a native of Miami and the owner of Steve's Authentic Key Lime Pie, adds a tiny bit of gelatin to his pie filling of juice and sweetened condensed milk so the filling is less fragile. His pies, which come without topping -- he recommends fresh whipped cream just before serving -- are sold at his factory in Red Hook, 204-207 Van Dyke Street (Columbia Street). A four-inch pie is $3; an eight-inch one is $12; a 10-inch pie is $16. He will deliver three 10-inch pies in Manhattan for $20 each. The pies are also sold at Citarella stores and Pret a Manger shops in Manhattan, Garden of Eden and Key Food in Brooklyn, and Pumpkins Organic Market in Park Slope. Within a few weeks he will start selling them online from www.keylime.com and shipping them overnight. He will also be selling frozen chocolate-covered Key lime pie on a stick.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Advent Reduces Sales Forecast
description: Shares of Advent Software, which makes software that automates securities trade orders for companies like Lehman Brothers and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, dropped 38 percent yesterday after the company reduced its sales forecast for this year. Advent's shares declined $13.37, to $22.10. The stock has fallen about 55 percent in the last year. The company, based in San Francisco, said it would begin selling some software by subscription rather than receiving full payment up front. The change is expected to cut software license sales for this year about $21 million, the company said, but permit an increase of more than 40 percent next year. Advent, which competes with companies like SunGard Data Systems and the Thomson Corporation, also said it would buy the Techfi Corporation for about $23 million. Techfi, a software company in Denver, develops technology for financial services companies to organize online accounts and for portfolio and client management.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Running For Governor
description: Steve Largent, the former football star and Republican congressman, officially began his campaign for governor this week. Mr. Largent, who resigned his seat in Congress this year, began touring the state in an effort to succeed Gov. Frank Keating, a Republican in his second and final term. Mr. Largent faces Jim Denny, a motivational speaker, in the party primary; several candidates seek the Democratic nomination. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Stutterers' Words Flow More Easily On the Stage
description: On Sunday night David Nachman, a handsome 15-year-old and Hunter College High School freshman who has stuttered since the age of 3 stood onstage at the Blue Heron Arts Center on East 24th Street in Manhattan and confronted one of his biggest fears: a theater packed full of people, all waiting for him to speak.

title: Talks on Pact Progress
description: Given the stagnant status of baseball's labor negotiations, yesterday appeared to be a good day. Representatives of the players and owners moved close to final agreement on a package of minor issues, and the negotiators returned to a discussion of the major issues of revenue sharing and payroll tax.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: Clearing A Hurdle To European Union
description: Lithuania agreed with European Union foreign ministers on a plan to scrap its Ignalina nuclear power plant by 2009, removing the ministers' principal objection to Lithuania's eventual entry, probably in 2004. European nations want the Chernobyl-type reactor closed for safety reasons and have agreed to help Lithuania with at least part of the $2.3 billion cost of closing the plant. With this accord, Lithuania has met 28 of 30 standards for union membership. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Engaged Couple Die as Two Cars Crash Into Theirs on Long Island
description: Invitations were mailed out Friday, a bridal gown adorned with pearls and sequins was selected, and relatives of Jean Desir and Sophia Bretous were to gather at a Long Island catering hall in August to celebrate the couple's wedding.

title: Plunge Over the Precipice In the Mind of a Dreamer
description: It's always risky to transplant a great story or novel to the stage. It becomes even more so if the attempt is in the form of a monologue. A lone actor reciting an abridged version of a classic can easily end up being not much more than an audiobook with a pulse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVENEY, KENNETH
description: DEVENEY-Kenneth. Died May 25, 2002. At 12 noon on friday June 21, a Mass will be offered for his soul's repose at the Holy Name of Jesus Church, 207 West 66th Street.

title: Giants' Dayne Sporting a Cast
description: Running back Ron Dayne walked the sideline at the Giants' passing camp practice today in East Rutherford, N.J., a football in his left hand and a cast on his right.

title: Rangers Are Expected To Name Two Assistants
description: The Rangers are expected to announce shortly that Jim Schoenfeld and Terry O'Reilly will be hired as assistant coaches to fill out the staff of Coach Bryan Trottier, two N.H.L. officials confirmed yesterday.

title: Final Buzzer For NBC and N.B.A.
description: The sun was setting in Marina del Rey, Calif., last Thursday, the night before Game 2 of the National Basketball Association finals. Guests walked into the open-air hotel restaurant, where four TV sets would soon blare NBC's N.B.A. theme music.

title: A Rib-Eye in G (for Grilling) Flat
description: A spatula-wielding father can always use a new grilling gadget like this steak weight, left, which prevents meat from curling and helps it cook faster. The rectangle of chrome-plated steel, 4 1/2 by 9 inches and just right for a generous strip or rib-eye steak, weighs nearly three pounds. It's terrific to flatten a butterflied chicken on the grill or for Tuscan chicken ''al mattone'' (under a brick) in a skillet. The weight, made by Vollrath, is $15.70 plus shipping from www.nextdaygourmet.com. Express delivery for Father's Day is available.

title: One More Worry for Wall St.: A Potential Plunge in the Dollar
description: So what else could go wrong?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: State Senate Passes Bill Giving Mayor Control of Schools
description: The State Senate gave final passage today to a bill that gives New York City's mayor control over city schools but does not spell out how to replace community school boards.

title: Here He Comes to Save the Da: Super Rico Is Born
description: After they heard the roar of Flight 11 over their classroom and watched on television as the World Trade Center crumbled, the students in Nina Anastasia's class at Public School 721 on the Lower East Side wondered if the people would have been saved if Superman had swooped in from above or Catwoman had scampered up the towers.

title: A Festival Gives Modern Dance a Toehold in Ireland
description: Last month a crowd of modern-dance companies took over the stages here, supplanting the city's often reputable but staid theatrical fare with something adventurous and far less familiar.

title: Sports of The Times; Nets Don't Want to Take A Step Back
description: THERE has been a little too much ''We'll get 'em next year'' talk coming from the Nets. They haven't surrendered, but the thought is clearly in some players' minds.

title: U.S. Orders Scrutiny of All Yemeni Travelers
description: Federal authorities have ordered special scrutiny of all Yemeni citizens seeking to enter or leave the United States and are thoroughly inspecting all their baggage, the Justice Department said tonight.

title: Convicted Killer and Rapist Says He Attacked Central Park Jogger
description: Manhattan prosecutors are investigating a claim by a convicted murderer and rapist that he attacked the woman who was raped and badly beaten in the racially charged Central Park jogger case in 1989, a senior prosecutor has said. A group of black and Hispanic teenagers was convicted in the attack on the white jogger, a 28-year-old investment banker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRUS, GERALD
description: CARRUS-Gerald. The College of Physicians & Surgeons at Columbia University mourns the passing of Gerald Carrus, a remarkable supporter of medicine and a loyal friend. The scientific and clinical community at Columbia is saddened by his loss. Since he first came to the Medical Center in 1986, Gerald Carrus with his wife Janet was inspired to support programs in medicine and surgery, especially those to advance research and diabetes. The Carrus's philanthropy helped establish a major laboratory in Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center and a chair in the surgical sciences, and launched the careers of talented young scientists. Gerald Carrus was a generous and unassuming man whose generosity and kindness touched many lives. We extend our deepest sympathy to Janet and the Carrus family. Gerald D. Fischbach, MD Executive Vice President For Health and Biomedical Sciences, Dean of the Faculty of Medicine, Columbia University

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the efforts of two software engineers to use the wireless data standard known as Wi-Fi, or 802.11b, to build a system that can transmit Internet data up to 20 miles included three companies erroneously among those that backed an earlier, unsuccessful attempt to establish a commercial wireless industry based on technology known as the Multipoint Microwave Distribution System. The three -- AT&T, Winstar and Teligent -- used other methods.

title: Former ImClone Chief Is Charged With Securities Fraud
description: Samuel D. Waksal, the former chief executive of ImClone Systems , was arrested today and charged with securities fraud. He is accused of tipping off family members to sell their shares in the company before the public announcement of an unfavorable regulatory ruling on an experimental cancer drug.

title: From the City, 5 Votes Against
description: Although the New York State Assembly voted overwhelmingly on Monday to allow mayoral control of the New York City school system, five members of the Assembly from the city, all Democrats, opposed the measure. They were EDWARD C. SULLIVAN of Manhattan, PETER J. ABATE JR. of Brooklyn, WILLIAM SCARBOROUGH of Queens, WILLIAM COLTON of Brooklyn and AURELIA GREENE of the Bronx. Several of the dissenters criticized the provision to abolish the 32 community school boards, saying that it would stifle parental input. At least one, Ms. Greene, began her political career as a member of her community school board in the South Bronx, District 9, which has been at the center of several scandals over the years. In one, Ms. Greene and her husband, the REV. JEROME A. GREENE, were indicted on charges of stealing a school piano in 1989. Though they were acquitted of that charge, Mr. Greene later pleaded guilty to charges of theft for having school employees print campaign literature with school supplies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABB, MAXWELL M.
description: RABB-Maxwell M. June 9, 2002, at age 91. Beloved husband of Ruth; father of Bruce, Sheila Weidenfeld, Emily Livingston and Priscilla Ayres; grandfather of Jeremy Maltby, Alexander and Katy Rabb, and Nicholas and Daniel Weidenfeld; and brother of Warren Rabb, and the late George Rabb and Frances Jones. Services Wednesday, June 12, 11 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. at 65th St. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to Lighthouse International, 111 East 59th St., NY, NY 10022.

title: Revenge of the Underlings Becomes a Literary Genre
description: A subversive literary genre is sweeping the publishing industry: boss betrayal. Bookstores are suddenly being deluged with memoirs and romans  clef by servants and office assistants trying to cash in on former employers' fame and follies.

title: Condemn North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Toms River: Jury Selection In Boat Deaths
description: Jury selection began yesterday in the trial of a boat owner accused of killing three sailors and injuring a fourth when his boat collided with theirs. The collision occurred off Long Beach Island in October 2000. The boat owner, Barry Flowers, was heading to Florida on his 60-foot yacht when it struck a 20-foot vessel. The Associated Press quoted the Ocean County prosecutor as saying that the throttle on Mr. Flowers's boat was at or near full capacity at the time of the collision. Mr. Flowers, 64, of Livingston, would face up to 30 years in prison if convicted of the three counts of death by vessel. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIEGEL, PEARL KLUGER
description: SIEGEL-Pearl Kluger. November 29, 1912-June 12, 2001. In my heart and thoughts always. Roberta

title: Perfect in the Right Setting, but Don't Expect It to Lift a Pinkie
description: IT is difficult to drink Chianti without growing hungry. It brings to mind pleasing thoughts of pasta with a pork rag, cured meats, roasted carrots and braised rabbit with olives.

title: City Tech Has a Name Alteration
description: When New York City Technical College was founded in 1946, it was called the New York State Institute of Applied Arts and Science, and its aim was to meet the postwar economy's need for highly trained technicians. In the years since, the college shifted its sights and its name as the economy changed. Last week, with the approval of the State Legislature and the governor, the college, which is in Brooklyn and has more than 11,000 students, became the New York City College of Technology. ''In today's educational marketplace, technical colleges are generally two-year schools offering vocational programs,'' said FRED W. BEAUFAIT, the college's president, noting that the college, which is part of the City University of New York, offers 12 baccalaureate degree programs, as well as 28 associate degree programs, in fields like health care, hospitality and engineering, and more are planned. One thing that will not change is its nickname, City Tech. Karen W. Arenson

title: Brickyard 400 To Use Safer Walls
description: The steel and foam barriers used last month for the Indianapolis 500 will remain in place with only minor alterations for the Brickyard 400 on Aug. 4 at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, Nascar announced yesterday in a teleconference.

title: Clearing Customs Rarity for Trophy
description: When the discussion yesterday turned to the Conn Smythe Trophy for most valuable player in the Stanley Cup playoffs, Brendan Shanahan of the Detroit Red Wings asked, ''Can Peter Forsberg still win it?'' He was kidding, sort of, in the way that many a truth is told in jest.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Reprieve For An Inmate
description: The United States Supreme Court granted a stay of execution to a Texas inmate after his lawyers argued that he was mentally retarded. The inmate, William Mack Modden, convicted of murder in 1984, won the reprieve less than four hours from being taken to the death chamber. Mr. Modden is the third Texas death row inmate claiming mental retardation to have his execution halted by the Supreme Court in recent months. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Trade Center Widows Lobby for Independent Inquiry
description: The widows marched through the halls of Congress today, brandishing photos of their dead and a potent brew of patriotism, grief and indignation. The four women, New Jersey homemakers whose husbands vanished in the rubble of the World Trade Center, head a group demanding an independent inquiry into the events surrounding Sept. 11.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Lawsuit Dismissal
description: A state appeals court affirmed the dismissal of a lawsuit against the producers and director of ''Natural Born Killers'' that contended the film inspired a crime wave. The suit was brought by the family of Patsy Byers, who was shot and paralyzed in a 1995 rampage. The court said the film by the director Oliver Stone glorified violence but ruled that it was protected by the First Amendment because it did not directly incite the shooting. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: If That Big Mac Leaves a Little Hole
description: ''WOULD you like to try some doughnuts?''

title: Piazza's Soundtrack and an Upcoming Showdown
description: It was late Tuesday afternoon in the visitors clubhouse at Comiskey Park as a group of reporters began gathering around Mike Piazza, hovering for the remarks everyone was waiting for. Piazza was chatting politely, passing the time before he had to dash off for batting practice, discussing his usual trivial subjects.

title: Most Unlikely Ingredients From a Most Unlikely Place
description: WILD blueberries and seaweed are abundant along Maine's rocky shores, but Dan Stevens, a former Casco Bay Line ferry captain, may have been the first to think of putting the two together. Blue Flame hot sauce combines these classic Maine ingredients in a vibrant sauce that offers fruit and heat in equal measure.

title: HUMANA OFFERS HEALTH INSURANCE FOR INDIVIDUALS
description: The Humana Insurance Company unit of Humana Inc. announced a health plan for individuals called HumanaOne yesterday, representing the company's first large-scale venture into the individual health insurance market. Humana said HumanaOne is meant to appeal to individuals and families not insured by their employer, including self-employed entrepreneurs, students, early retirees and those between jobs. Humana is offering the plan in Illinois and Ohio.

title: Mets Revive Offense, But Still Fall Short
description: When the Mets get good pitching, they are capable of winning low-scoring games. When they do not, they seem helpless even against a team that has also been reeling.

title: Clemens and Piazza in Swirl of Storm
description: It has been almost two years since Roger Clemens drilled Mike Piazza in the head with a 92-mile-an-hour fastball and 20 months since he threw a hunk of Piazza's broken bat toward him during the 2000 World Series. On Saturday at Shea Stadium, Clemens will bat against the Mets for the first time since then, and there is widespread curiosity about whether the Mets will retaliate.

title: Recipe: Sweet-and-Sour Onions
description: Adapted from "Essentials of Classic Italian Cooking" by Marcella Hazan (Knopf, 1992)

title: Endings and Aftermaths, With Gradual Fade-Outs
description: Alejandro Escovedo, one of the most celebrated songwriters from Austin, Tex., took great care with the way his songs ended when he performed at the Mercury Lounge on Sunday night. There were long, gradual fade-outs that selectively revealed a lightly picked acoustic guitar, a sustained cello line or brushes on the drums; there were crescendos of feedback courting chaos. As his music scrutinized endings and aftermaths, so did his lyrics, in songs that pondered departures, breakups and death. He began with ''Way It Goes,'' an elegy for an ex-wife who committed suicide that becomes a meditation on mortality.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Generator Maker of Fraud
description: Aura Systems, a maker of portable electric generators, fraudulently overstated revenue by at least $26.5 million by recording nonexistent sales of computer monitors, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged today.

title: Benefit for Music and Art at P.S. 89
description: More than 300 parents and Battery Park City residents attended a fund-raiser at the Embassy Suites Hotel in Manhattan last night to benefit Public School 89, a grammar school two blocks north of the World Trade Center site. Run by the PTA, the fund-raising program helps to pay for music and arts programs, author visits and the school library. The students of P.S. 89 have moved three times since Sept. 11 and money that might have gone toward a dance performance or a music class was instead spent on new school supplies. The benefit is expected to have raised about $75,000.

title: Lewis-Tyson Bout Provides a Knockout Revenue Figure
description: Lennox Lewis's eighth-round knockout of Mike Tyson in their pay-per-view bout Saturday night attracted 1.8 million buyers and grossed a record $103 million, according to projections by HBO and Showtime, the event's co-producers.

title: Woody Allen Settles Suit Against Longtime Producer
description: Ending nine days of sporadically comical but overwhelmingly dry testimony about Hollywood accounting that routinely left jurors asleep, Woody Allen reached a settlement yesterday in his civil suit against his longtime friend and producer.

title: Rumsfeld, in India, Offers Linked Ideas but No Peace Plan
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld arrived here tonight saying he was not a peace negotiator but only carried some American ideas for calming a dispute that seemed just days ago to be drawing India and Pakistan toward large-scale war.

title: CBS and N.C.A.A. In Deal With Coke
description: The CBS division of Viacom and the National Collegiate Athletic Association said yesterday that they had signed an 11-year agreement with the Coca-Cola Company valued at more than $500 million. The deal awards Coca-Cola the marketing and media rights to 87 championship tournaments overseen by the N.C.A.A., including the annual basketball tournament on CBS.

title: Once a Victim, A Priest Wants Zero Tolerance
description: Some boys love baseball. Gary R. Hayes loved church.

title: Menus at Hand, at a Turn of the Web Page
description: Since its inception, Amazon.com has helped with dinner, with cookbooks, then cookware. Now it has a new service: menus from thousands of restaurants in New York, Boston, Chicago, San Francisco, Seattle and Washington are on the Web site. The menus are cross-referenced by neighborhood, cuisine or even a particular dish. Prices, addresses, telephone numbers are given, and driving directions can be obtained. There is no charge to the consumer or the restaurant. Carrie Peters, a spokeswoman for Amazon, stressed that the service was an experiment. Indeed, the listings have not been fine-tuned: some menus are not given, some are outdated and some restaurants have closed. The restaurants whose menus appear were not consulted. "I don't know how it happened but I don't think it can hurt," said Danny Meyer, an owner of Union Square Cafe and Gramercy Tavern, two New York restaurants that are featured. Ms. Peters said restaurants could have their menus removed if they wished. The site (click on "Restaurants" under the Service heading of Amazon.com) also has a list of the most popular restaurants in each city, based Zagat-style on consumer response.

title: Now, Questions Turn to Why Tyco's Lawyer Received Bonus
description: Mark A. Belnick, Tyco's former general counsel, received a $2 million bonus near the end of 2000 that was tied to a decision by the Securities and Exchange Commission to end an inquiry into Tyco's accounting without taking action, according to a person briefed on the payment.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the On Stage and Off column of Weekend on May 17 about Bob Boyett, a producer who invested in five plays that were nominated for Tony Awards this year, referred imprecisely to his work as a television producer. As a creative consultant and producer on ''Laverne and Shirley,'' a contributing producer on ''Mork and Mindy'' and an executive producer on ''Full House,'' he helped create those shows; he did not create them alone.

title: Bush to Set Out Broad Approach on Mideast Soon, Powell Says
description: As Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel wrapped up his visit here with a warm, bipartisan embrace on Capitol Hill, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that President Bush would set out his views on how to proceed toward Middle East peace ''in the very near future.''

title: Love, American Style
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
