Held-Held G.P.S.
One Person's Hedge, Another's Chef-d'Oeuvre
description: The landscape architect Perry Guillot has done 140 privet drawings and watercolors for a Peconic Land Trust benefit.

title: Citing Errors, Lawyer Seeks New Trial For Skakel
description: Michael C. Skakel's lawyer asked a judge today to set aside the guilty verdict a jury rendered last week and acquit his client or to order a new trial.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Muslim Leader Arrested
description: State security forces have arrested the co-founder of the militant Islamic Group and another member of the group, their lawyers and security officials said. No reason was given. Salah Hashem, the co-founder, has been one of the main supporters of a cease-fire announced by the group, which killed 58 tourists and 4 Egyptians at Luxor in 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEEDS, MORTON
description: LEEDS-Morton February 2, 1925-June 13, 1984. You will live in our hearts forever

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a federal inquiry into a November 2000 fire on a New York Waterway ferry misstated the purpose of an unused bracket on the boat. The bracket, near a life preserver, was intended to hold an optional flotation device, not a fire extinguisher.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Court Grants Freeze On Special School Aid
description: The State Supreme Court, responding to New Jersey's budget shortfall, granted a request to temporarily freeze one category of special state aid to low-income urban school districts. The aid totals $400 million this year for court-ordered reforms stemming from the Abbott v. Burke school financing case. What are known as the 30 Abbott districts had sought more than $1 billion in aid for 2002-2003. But with a growing budget deficit, the state sought a one-year freeze. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Benjamin Ward, the first black commissioner of the New York City Police Department, misidentified the school where he earned his law degree. It was Brooklyn Law School, not Brooklyn College. In some copies the obituary also misstated the year he was appointed commissioner. It was 1983, not 1984.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Residential Sales column on May 30 about a condominium at 2109 Broadway that sold for $1,395,000 included an erroneous figure from the broker, for its square footage. The apartment is 1,505 square feet, not 2,300.

title: Abandon Hope Ye Who Enter the Rough Here
description: Players fear it. They will curse it. But more than anything, they hope to avoid it.

title: Critic of Corruption in Rural China Is Arrested in a Crackdown
description: Li Lan, a villager in southern China who has crusaded against corruption and lawlessness in the countryside, was arrested Sunday night on the charge of malicious slander of local officials, relatives said today.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Deal Preserves Passenger Train Service
description: The state's only passenger train, the Heartland Flyer, will run at least through 2004 under a new contract between the state and Amtrak. Oklahoma will provide $9.4 million, including $1.3 million from the state's share of ticket sales and concessions. The Heartland Flyer, which runs twice daily -- once each way -- between Fort Worth and Oklahoma City, has carried more than 185,000 passengers since its inception in June of 1999.

title: Pakistan Holds Terror Suspects; Cites U.S. Ties
description: Several men believed to be American citizens have been taken into custody here during the past few weeks on suspicion of being linked to Al Qaeda, senior Pakistani officials said today.

title: Nets May See a Future Without Van Horn
description: Every day during the N.B.A. finals, Byron Scott seemed to mention that it was two against one, two Los Angeles Lakers All-Stars (Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant) against one Nets All-Star (Jason Kidd).

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: No Hard Feelings

title: Getting Away, On the Web And From It
description: THERE are times when cruising the Web -- looking for mountains or swamps to visit, or rivers to canoe -- that I must tear myself away from tales of grappling for catfish (you use your own hand as bait), or of a guided llama trek in West Virginia, or of the waterfalls of Transylvania. That's Transylvania County, in North Carolina.

title: Import Prices Are Steady; An Increase Had Been Expected
description: Import prices were unchanged in May, according to a Labor Department index, reflecting cheaper computers and the biggest decline in automobile costs since 1992. Food and fuel prices increased.

title: Desert Island Cameras
description: IT must be a conspiracy: all of my favorite reality shows ended the same week. There was ''Survivor'' (contestants are eliminated until only a $1 million winner remains), ''The Amazing Race'' (teams are eliminated until only a $1 million winner remains) and ''The Bachelor'' (single women are eliminated until only one doesn't feel used and cheapened).

title: North Dakota Tightens Law On Bank Data And Privacy
description: North Dakotans voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to require banks and credit unions to get customers' permission before selling data on them, and privacy advocates say the vote will send a message across the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAZAN, LESLIE
description: HAZAN-Leslie. We were deeply saddened at the untimely passing of Leslie Hazan, daughter of Maxine Hazan Landau and the late Michael Hazan. Granddaughter of the late Freddie Hazan and Lillie Hazan. Condolences to brother Fred S. Hazan and the entire Hazan family. The Sephardic Home Skilled Nursing and Rehabilitation Center LASHA Boards of Directors

title: Diocese of Brooklyn Denies Funeral Mass for Gotti
description: John J. Gotti, the notorious crime boss who died on Monday, was denied a public funeral Mass by the Diocese of Brooklyn yesterday, although his family will be allowed to bury him near the body of his son in a Roman Catholic cemetery.

title: Sports of The Times; Woodses Have Eerie Link To Bethpage's Black Course
description: IF his father hadn't decided to play golf for the first time on a New York City public course about 30 years ago, Tiger Woods might be doing something else somewhere else today instead of teeing off in the 102nd United States Open.

title: Climate and Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Restructuring for Security
description: America is now divided between those who think the worst is over -- and therefore we can resume business as usual -- and those who believe we are engaged in a new form of conflict. We are among those who believe we face a threat that is neither conventional war nor traditional crime, and that combating it requires new government structures, new policies and new thinking.

title: Sports of The Times; A Little Bit Of Clemens In Them All
description: RANDY JOHNSON offers no alibis for Roger Clemens, the man or his methods. But pitchers, even the tallest and toughest, know what they have come to represent when throwing baseballs for a living has become a more athletic version of feeding quarters into a high-volume pinball machine.

title: Voices of Afghan Democracy, Loud and Unclear
description: The delegates complained about the food. They ridiculed the man running the meeting. They even criticized the warlords in the front row.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Judge Upholds States In Microsoft Case
description: A federal judge upheld the right of nine states to pursue antitrust penalties against Microsoft yesterday even though the Justice Department and nine other states have agreed to a proposed settlement. Microsoft had argued that Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly of Federal District Court in Washington should dismiss the case because the states did not have the authority to ask for restrictions that would apply to the entire nation. The software maker also said that the states had not proved that their citizens were injured by the antitrust violations it had committed. Microsoft underestimated the Court of Appeals, Judge Kollar-Kotelly wrote in her ruling, noting that the higher court had an opportunity to rule on the states' role in the case in its decision last June. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rights Group To Meet Rebels
description: Amnesty International representatives will meet with the leadership of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam in Sri Lanka for the first time. Amnesty delegates will also discuss with government officials what human rights monitors see as the government's failure to effectively prosecute soldiers and policemen who have killed or raped civilians. The delegates will talk to the rebels about their recruitment of child soldiers and the need to allow Muslims -- expelled from northern Sri Lanka by the Tigers -- to return home.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Many creditors are increasingly worried that big banks have conflicting roles as both lenders and advisers.
description: SOME of the nation's biggest banks are being challenged for serving in dual roles as lenders and advisers to troubled companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARIN, MURRAY K., D.D.S.
description: MARIN-Murray K., D.D.S. Of Woodmere, L.I., passed away June 12, 2002. Devoted husband of Shiela and honored father of Reina, Michael and Morisa. Beloved grandfather of Rachel, Elissa, Alan, Jordan, Jason, Jacqueline, Benjamin, Laurence and Gregory. Cherished father-in-law of Emilio, Marla and Eugene. Dear brother of James and life-long friend of Melvin. A highly respected dentist and teacher who practiced in Manhattan and was an Associate Attending in the Department of Dental Medicine at the Queens Hospital Center. A gifted photographer, musician and athlete. ''The whole package''. He will be missed by all whose life he touched. Funeral service will be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York on Thursday, June 13th at 1:30 PM. Directions at 516-295-3100

title: Snippers, Snackers and Garden-Tour Gaffes
description: CHARITY tours, backyard parties or simply swapping visits with fellow enthusiasts -- whatever the particulars, trekking through gardens has become the voyeur's national pastime. This year the Garden Conservancy's national listing, Open Days, offers 450 private gardens to visit, up 50 from last year. In that sense, garden tours have become the new house tours. On a house tour, people may look under beds or rifle through drawers; in the garden, they may trample your beds and filch cuttings. In both, you will probably find yourself staring down barbarians at the garden gate.

title: U.S. Open Prize Money Will Exceed $16 Million
description: Prize money for the United States Open championships will exceed $16 million for the first time, the United States Tennis Association will announce today. The Open will be played Aug. 26 through Sept. 8 at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Secret Detentions
description: A New Jersey appeals panel ruled yesterday that two county jails do not have to reveal the names of immigrants held since Sept. 11 -- a ruling that an expert said was the first to uphold the federal government's efforts to detain and process those immigrants secretly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, CELIA
description: COHEN-Celia. Beloved wife of Larry. Devoted mother of Phil Kennelty-Cohen (Sharon) and Steven (Andrea). Cherished grandmother of Nova, Derrick, Charlie, Coral and Eliot. Dear sister of Saul Grossman. Services Friday, 12:15PM ''Sinai Chapels'', 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day yesterday about a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of sales practices at XO Communications referred erroneously at one point to a different company, not involved in the situation. Nextel -- the subject of an unrelated article elsewhere in the column -- should not have been mentioned in connection with the S.E.C. report.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Poor Outlook At Pearson
description: Pearson warned that its earnings for the first half of the year would continue to be depressed by weaker advertising sales and that a recovery was not expected this year. Marjorie Scardino, the chief executive, said at a conference in London that advertising revenue at its newspaper unit, the Financial Times Group, was significantly lower than in the period last year. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: Lawmakers Vote To Extend Terms
description: Suffolk County's legislators have voted to extend their term of office to four years from two, beginning in 2003. But to go into effect, the plan would have to be approved by the county executive and a countywide referendum. The county law limiting legislators to a total of 12 years in office would remain unchanged. The legislators narrowly approved the change, in a vote of 10 to 8, on Tuesday night. Proponents said it would reduce electioneering; opponents said it would reduce the number of times that voters were able to exercise their right to choose their representatives. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: A Truce: The Army and the Ivy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A map on Saturday about plans for stores around Times Square, including a Hershey candy outlet in the Crowne Plaza Hotel, gave an erroneous location for the site that will include a 7-Eleven store. It is 1 Times Square, north of 42nd Street at the junction of Broadway and Seventh Avenue. The map also misstated the name of a store that recently closed. It was the Museum Company, not the Museum Store. The name of an avenue was also misstated. It is Eighth Avenue, not Eighth Street.

title: Corrections

The top picture, which showed housing near Nassau Community College, was made in East Garden City, not Garden City. The bottom picture, of a row of houses with porches, was made in Garden City, not Hempstead.

title: Time to Move on Drug Law Reform
description: With New York State's legislative session scheduled to end next Thursday, and election-year politics in the air, the Democrat-led Assembly and Gov. George Pataki unveiled separate proposals last week to break the partisan gridlock that has doomed previous efforts at reforming the notoriously harsh Rockefeller-era drug laws. The state is now close to achieving a decent compromise bill. Neither side should let politics-as-usual stand in the way.

Captain U.S. Army Medical Corps, W.W. II. Subsequently served as physician in New York City tuberculosis clinic. Graduate of NYU and NYU Medical College. Survived by Martha Melnick Richheimer, husband of the late Edith Aarons Richheimer, father of David and Aniko Richheimer and Judy Richheimer, grandfather of Dr's Stephanie Richheimer Ashman and Ed Ashman and Dr. William Richheimer, brother of Stanley Richheimer and Lucille Dorsey. Stepfather to Marsha Melnick and the late Lloyd Melnick; step grandfather to Gregg, Jayme and Danielle. Services are at the Riverside Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, on Thursday, June 13th, 2002 at 10 A.M. Donations to the Israel Emergency Fund or charity of one's choice.

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: More Calls For Speaker To Resign
description: Calls for the resignation of S. Vance Wilkins Jr., the speaker of the House, have increased in the face of mounting sexual harassment accusations. Attorney General Jerry Kilgore, a fellow Republican, called on Mr. Wilkins to step aside, as did Lt. Gov. Timothy Kaine, a Democrat, who said women who are lobbyists told him they had been harassed by Mr. Wilkins, the state's most powerful Republican and the architect of the party's takeover of the legislature. Francis X. Clines (NYT)

title: AMERICAN AND CALIFORNIA AIRPORT AGREE ON SLOTS
description: American Airlines and the City of Long Beach, Calif., have completed an agreement to allow the carrier to use an additional four slots at Long Beach Airport, a company spokesman said yesterday. The slots are temporary and will remain in American's use until at least January. The carrier is still in talks with city officials to make those slots permanent. The recent approval from the city means American can start nonstop service to New York and Chicago on Saturday, as it had advertised. The airline will be competing with JetBlue, which began nonstop service to New York last November. JetBlue took over all of the 27 idle slots at the airport last year, causing American to protest on antitrust grounds. To appease American, Long Beach agreed this spring to grant the airline 4 of those 27 slots temporarily. The initial agreement was completed this week, said Al Becker, a company spokesman. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Typos Flaw Ratings Guide
description: THE motto of The Franklin Report reads: The truth will set you free. But the people who put out the report, an annual guide to architects, interior designers and home-improvement services published in New York, might want to add, But typographical errors will really ruin your day.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the arrest of a man suspected in 10 murders around St. Louis misstated the term for an Internet identification that was used to trace the source of an online request for a map that was mailed to The Post-Dispatch and led investigators to a body. The clue was an Internet Protocol number -- the unique identifier of a particular computer -- not an internet provider address.

title: Fabrics Smart Enough to Change Colors and Keep You Dry
description: JACKETS with coatings that let perspiration out but keep the rain from coming in are much more comfortable than heavy rubber-coated raincoats. But they are not perfect. Exercise too vigorously, perspire too heavily and even a jacket made from the most advanced fabrics can become a personal sauna.

description: Annual awards have been presented by three organizations.

description: It was a standard ''F-9'' on the scorecard, no extra notations needed. Even John Vander Wal, the Yankees' right fielder, who caught Luis Gonzalez's harmless first-inning fly ball, could not remember much about it. But for Mike Mussina, it was a premonition.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: More Migrants Join Protest
description: At least 100 illegal immigrants reportedly slipped past a police cordon to join a sit-in at Pablo de Olavide University in Seville, where protesters are demanding work permits for the foreigners, mostly North African, who traditionally harvest strawberries in Andalucia. Organizations supporting the sit-in say more than 500 people, almost all men, have joined the protest, a response to the farmers' decision to import labor from Eastern Europe. Seville will be the site of a European Union summit meeting next week where immigration issues will be high on the agenda. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Prom Night, Lost in Translation; Teenagers Want to Go, but Immigrant Parents Frown
description: The odds were not in her favor, but Nowrin Khanam, an immigrant from Bangladesh, believed the prize was worth the effort. So she begged her mother for permission to go to her senior prom.

title: A Pair of Portable Speakers Puts a New Spin on Hot Air
description: Summer means inflatable: inflatable beach chairs, rafts, inner tubes, even the occasional giant blue banana. Now that Ellula HotAir has come to the United States, you can add speakers to that list.

title: Postcards From the Cutting Edge
description: THIS summer, 60,000 Americans are expected to visit Switzerland, and not just to commune with their inner Heidis. Instead, they will be strolling around four lakeside towns near the French border and gawking at the kind of architecture that is more brave-new-world than yodel-ready chalets.

description: To the Editor:

title: Police Seek Man Seen Near Abduction Site
description: A man with a criminal record who was spotted near the home of a 14-year-old girl who was kidnapped at gunpoint here last week became the focus of the case today as law enforcement officials asked the public for information on his whereabouts.

title: As Bloomberg Takes Over Schools, Pataki Takes Center Stage
description: Although he played a fairly limited, behind-the-scenes role in creating legislation that gives control of New York City's schools to the mayor, Gov. George E. Pataki seized the spotlight yesterday by signing the bill into law, with a flourish.

title: A Site for Real Surfers Catches a Wave
description: ON a gloomy, overcast Southern California afternoon, Sean Collins's third-floor office still offers a surfer one of the best views in the state.

title: DOW JONES SAYS IT WILL FALL SHORT OF FORECASTS
description: Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said second-quarter profit would fall short of analysts' forecasts because advertising sales fell at the paper. Profit per share will be in the ''low 20-cent range,'' Dow Jones said in a statement. In April, the company forecast profit of 20 cents to 30 cents, excluding some expenses. At that time, analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call lowered their estimates to 28 cents a share from 45 cents. Advertising volume at The Wall Street Journal will fall more than 20 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier, worse than the publisher's previous forecast for a 10 percent to 20 percent drop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABB, AMBASSADOR MAXWELL M.
description: RABB-Ambassador Maxwell M. The President, Chancellor Emeritus, Boards of Governors and Overseers, faculty, administration and students of Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion record with profound sorrow the death of Ambassador Maxwell M. Rabb. A former member of the Board of Governors, and an honorary alumnus of the College-Institute, Ambassador Rabb was a distinguished advisor to presidents and international delegations and councils, and a dedicated servant of the Jewish people. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Ruth, and to his entire family. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, Pres. Rabbi Alfred Gottschalk, Chancellor Emeritus Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Motorola Says It Will Meet Its Forecast
description: Motorola said yesterday that it would meet, or perhaps exceed, its forecast for the second quarter. In April, the company said it expected $6.3 billion to $6.4 billion in sales and a loss of about 4 cents a share during the quarter. But in remarks at a conference in New York, Motorola's president and chief operating officer, Edward Breen, said growth had returned to most of the company's businesses. The company, based in Schaumburg, Ill., said it expected to record profits for the third quarter and full year.

title: A Familiar Face Is Trying to Put Corning Back on the Right Track
description: James R. Houghton's seeming pleasure at being back at Corning, the company his family founded 151 years ago -- and whose stock represents a solid chunk of his own wealth -- is so palpable that one could forget for a moment that he is there by need, not choice.

title: Log On, Then Tee Off: Golf Lessons Online
description: WORKING as a golf caddy each summer during college, I logged enough trips around the course to hear every golf tip there was. So, when I began to play, I navely assumed that all I had to do was put everything I had heard into action. Not surprisingly, I found there was more to it than that.

title: Officials Say Heroin Arrests Show New Supply Routes
description: Federal authorities said yesterday that they had broken up a major Colombian drug-exporting ring that was smuggling millions of dollars worth of heroin each month into New York and elsewhere.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: No Right To Elect School Board
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit upheld a 1999 state law that replaced the elected Detroit school board with appointed officials. A group of community activists sued after the law was enacted, saying they had been deprived of their right to elect board members and had been discriminated against because most Detroit residents are black. The court ruled that citizens do not have a fundamental right to elect administrative officials like school board members. Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

title: Vermont to Require Drug Makers To Disclose Payments to Doctors
description: Amid rising concern about the cost of prescription drugs, Vermont is expected today to become the first state in the nation to require pharmaceutical companies to disclose their gifts and cash payments to doctors, hospitals and other health care providers.

title: At Summit, a Push for a Proven Cure for Hunger: School Lunches
description: While world leaders at the Rome food summit meeting were sparring over how to tackle global hunger, the World Food Program said today that one proven way was to provide school lunches, which now guarantee that more than 15 million children have a good meal every day.

title: Assembly to Vote On MetroStars' Plan
description: The MetroStars' plans for a new stadium as the centerpiece of a development project on the banks of the Passaic River across from Newark in Harrison, N.J., could receive support today when the New Jersey State Assembly is scheduled to vote on creating a Sports Entertainment District that would allow sales taxes to be dedicated to paying for part of the development.

title: In Midday Sun, English Get Draw to Advance
description: England and Nigeria played to a scoreless tie on a blistering afternoon today in a game that proved lusterless but gave England the point it needed to reach the second round of the World Cup.

description: If there is something to write home about in the dance world, it is the startlingly imaginative work of the Chinese-born choreographer Shen Wei.

description: And you thought the days of the itinerant Mr. Fix-It were over. Not so. Jon Caico, who repairs and refinishes wood furniture, has his workshop on Eastern Long Island, but picks up and delivers as far west as New York City. ''And there is never a pickup or delivery charge,'' he said.

description: At age 37, Brett Hull recently revealed, ''I'd rather be old and smart than young and stupid.'' Those who have watched Hull grow up over 17 seasons in the National Hockey League may legitimately wonder whether he was speaking from experience in all categories.

But in the role of mobster, he was almost perfect -- perfect in the sense that he lived up to everyone's expectations of what a gangster is, particularly a man of the Mafia.

description: A Long Island construction contractor was arrested this morning on charges that he refused to pay four workers $8,360 in promised wages. The state attorney general's office said it was the first time it had filed criminal charges against an employer for failing to pay immigrant day laborers.

title: A New Direction For Rolling Stone
description: Rolling Stone, the magazine that all but defined the American countercultural epoch, yesterday named a British managing editor who has been schooled in the racy ways of contemporary English men's magazines. The new editor, Ed Needham, comes from the English-owned FHM (For Him Magazine), whose two-year-old American version is the nation's fastest-growing magazine.

title: Northern Waters
description: Usually, cruises to Norway and the Baltic get cheaper as the daily dose of sunlight dwindles. But Fred Olsen Cruise Lines is taking 40 percent off its Northern Europe cruises through July on the Braemar (729 passengers) and Black Watch (761). Cruises leave from Dover, England, and range from 8 to 17 nights. The eight-night cruises (to Amsterdam, Bergen and through fjords) start at $1,053 a person, based on double occupancy. Cruises of 13 nights, with stops including Oslo, Copenhagen and Stockholm, start at $1,707 a person, double. Air fare extra; (800) 843-0602 or www.fredolsencruises.co.uk .

title: Mets' Minds on Clemens After a Long, Bad Trip
description: Al Leiter has pitched in monumental games against the Yankees. Three years ago, he beat Roger Clemens to stop a long losing streak and help the Mets turn their season around. Two years ago, he lost to the Yankees in Game 5 of the World Series, the finale, as his last pitch was bounced a hundred times up the middle by Luis Sojo.

title: All Across Switzerland, Fresh Design
description: FOR years, friends had been telling me that Switzerland was the place to see great architecture, especially the work of Peter Zumthor, whose small buildings in the area of Chur, 70 miles southeast of Zurich, are, they said, too subtle to be understood from photos.

title: Renting Space in Shaq and Kobe's World
description: The big man was in the lane, turning this way, feinting that way, before releasing a soft, 8-foot floater in the face of a frontline that never had a chance. One minute 24 seconds remained in another championship season for Shaquille O'Neal and his Los Angeles Lakers, and all he could do was turn toward the stands and begin shouting defiantly.

title: McCall Says Pataki Camp Threatened Donors
description: H. Carl McCall, a Democratic candidate for governor, charged today that officials in the Pataki administration have threatened business people that if they contributed to Mr. McCall's campaign, they would not receive state contracts.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: SHUNNING NATO SUMMIT Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov said Russia had no intention of attending NATO's summit meeting in Prague in November, when as many as nine countries are expected to be invited to join the 19-member alliance, including three former Soviet republics, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. NATO and Russia agreed last month to a new partnership that gives Russia a voice on some issues but NATO membership is not one of them. Mr. Ivanov's comments underscored the lingering animosity some Russians feel about NATO's expansion.

title: At the Buzzer, Lakers Love Having Horry
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 12  It is entirely possible, even probable, that the Los Angeles Lakers would not be the kings of the basketball universe were it not for Robert Horry. When Kobe Bryant had failed and the Lakers' self-proclaimed Superman, Shaquille O'Neal, had run out of heroics, only Horry and the 3-point arc stood between the Lakers and likely elimination in Game 4 of the Western Conference finals.

title: Paul Newman Chronicles Life At Bustling Grover's Corners
description: ''You know how it is,'' the actor was saying from the stage. ''You're 21 or 22, and you make some decisions. Then, boom!'' -- and he clapped his hands with a sudden and surprising liveliness -- ''you're 70.''

Plans call for spending in the next 18 months to reach $15 million to $20 million.

title: Martin, at Least, Refuses to Go Away Quietly
description: With 11 seconds to play, with the clock ticking down to the Lakers' celebration, Kenyon Martin got up from the bench and walked into the tunnel toward the locker room. He skipped the congratulatory handshakes and, his face appearing near tears, hid his anger with his own team for a moment.

title: Ontario Trims Plan for a Privatization
description: Ontario's conservative government backtracked today on plans for the total privatization of Hydro One Inc., the province's dominant power-distribution company.

title: Arts Festivals Buzz With Digital Deviltry
description: SUMMER has a special resonance for Liz Phillips, a New York sound artist. She is attuned to the vibrations of the season, from the rush of a river to the shimmer of sunshine. In a new interactive installation that is to open on July 8 at Lincoln Center, Ms. Phillips will turn the pulse of summer into sound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, ALBERT J.
description: KAPLAN-Albert J. On June 11, 2002. Beloved husband of Leah. Cherished father of David and Matthew. Devoted brother of Marvin. Adored grandfather of Manda, Noam, Amital and Yaara. His family and friends will miss him dearly.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Lloyd's Names Chairman
description: Lloyd's of London said that its next chairman would be Lord Levene of Portsoken, vice chairman of Deutsche Bank London. This is the first time in Lloyd's 314 years that it has named an outsider to the post. Lloyd's current chairman, Sax Riley, is planning to retire at the end of the year. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Serbian Rift Widens Into a Parliament Walkout
description: A rift among the reformers who ousted Slobodan Milosevic deepened today when lawmakers from President Vojislav Kostunica's party stormed out of the Serbian Parliament and accused their rivals of authoritarian behavior.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: SENATE HEARING ON DOMAIN NAMES The Senate Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Science, Technology and Space held a hearing yesterday to address widespread dissatisfaction with the organization charged with managing the Internet's address system, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers. The group, also known as Icann, has embarked on its own effort to change, but among the questions raised at the hearing was whether Icann is capable of managing its overhaul or whether the Commerce Department should take a more active role in the effort as the governmental body that manages Icann's contract. There was little consensus among those who testified, but Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, the subcommittee chairman who presided over the hearing, concluded, "If Icann is going to reform itself, the Department of Commerce is going to have to push that organization harder than they have done in the past."

title: Andersen Jury Tells the Judge It's Deadlocked
description: After seven days of deliberating, jurors in the Arthur Andersen criminal trial said today that they were unable to reach a unanimous verdict, but the judge ordered them to continue their efforts to reach a decision.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Bishops Open Talks on Sexual Abuse by Priests
description: The leaders of the country's Roman Catholic bishops gathered in Dallas for an extraordinary meeting on sexual abuse by members of the clergy, acknowledged today that too many church leaders had treated the smoldering scandal as a public-relations problem and in so doing had betrayed the faithful.

title: Analyst Studies For Open
description: Johnny Miller, the NBC Sports golf analyst, looks at the breaks and nuances of a green the way a seismologist looks at earthquake fault lines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, CONRAD S.
description: SIMON-Conrad S. Of Laurel Hollow, NY, passed away peacefully on June 9th after a long illness. Beloved husband of Dr. Phyllis Simon. Loving father of Thomas, Stephen and Robert. Adoring grandfather of Dawn, Alec and Richard. For funeral information call Connell Funeral Home, 631-427-1123.

title: Education Dept. Says States Have Lax Standards for Teachers
description: Facing a federal deadline for getting a ''highly qualified'' teacher in every high poverty classroom by September, many states have begun hiding unflattering data about teacher qualifications and defining quality downward, so that even poorly prepared teachers win top ratings, the Education Department said in a report presented to Congress on Tuesday.

title: Fall in Orders Leads Lucent to Warn of Declining Revenue
description: Faced with declining orders from major North American telecommunications companies for its switches and other equipment, Lucent Technologies warned Wall Street today that its revenue in the current quarter would decline as much as 15 percent from the first three months of 2002.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Cloning Discussion Stalls
description: Talks between Senate Democrats and Republicans on bringing to a vote a bill banning all human cloning broke down, prompting the chief sponsor of the measure to say he would try to attach it to unrelated legislation. The Senate is divided over whether to adopt the ban, sponsored by Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, or an alternative measure, supported by the Senate Democratic leadership. That measure would ban cloning for reproduction, but permit scientists to conduct cloning experiments intended to produce cells and tissues for medical research. Sheryl Gay Stolberg (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Jury in Andersen Case Says It Is Deadlocked

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: JUDGE UPHOLDS STATES IN MICROSOFT CASE A federal judge upheld the right of nine states to pursue antitrust penalties against Microsoft yesterday even though the Justice Department and nine other states have agreed to a proposed settlement. Microsoft had argued that Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly of Federal District Court in Washington should dismiss the case because the states did not have the authority to ask for restrictions that would apply to the entire nation. The software maker also said that the states had not proved that their citizens were injured by the antitrust violations it had committed. Microsoft underestimated the Court of Appeals, Judge Kollar-Kotelly wrote in her ruling, noting that the higher court had an opportunity to rule on the states' role in the case in its decision last June. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: German Officials Deny Knowing Whereabouts of Important Figure in Hamburg Plot
description: Senior German officials said today that they did not know the whereabouts of an important figure in the Hamburg plot that led to the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and the Pentagon, and they speculated that he was being held in a third country at the request of the United States.

title: Top-End Camera From Fuji Tells Stories in 6 Million Pixels
description: Fuji's new 6.1-million-pixel digital camera will look more than a little familiar to many photographers. Its body and mechanical parts are manufactured by Nikon and are based on that company's N80 film camera.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Pension Measures Could Be Costly
description: Bills before the State Legislature to discourage a record number of senior New York City police officers from retiring this year could add more than $70 million a year to the city's costs and accelerate retirements in the future, the Independent Budget Office warned yesterday. Pensions are calculated on officers' last year of earnings, and many officers posted record overtime this year and last year because of antiterrorism efforts. The budget office said that a change in the way pensions are calculated could increase costs and worsen the problem. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Lakers Sweep Nets for Title

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Compromise On Budget
description: The General Assembly wrapped up a three-day emergency budget session after Gov. Mike Huckabee, in a reversal, accepted a plan to cushion any Medicaid spending cuts in the fiscal year that begins July 1. The compromise would allow the Arkansas Medicaid program to borrow $15 million from the state's share of a lawsuit settlement with major tobacco companies. Mr. Huckabee and the legislature also met a June 30 deadline for closing a $56 million budget shortfall in the current fiscal year by transferring money from idle state accounts.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Monetary Policy Unchanged
description: The Bank of Japan kept its zero interest rate policy unchanged after two days of deliberations. The central bank, in a unanimous decision, said it would continue to keep up to 15 trillion yen ($119 billion) of surplus cash in money markets and guide short-term interest rates toward zero. With the economy gradually recovering and the banking system stabilizing, the central bank is facing less pressure to ease policy further. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, MARTHA (RUBIN)
description: SILVER-Martha (Rubin). Of Belle Harbor, NY, died on June 11th, 2002. Beloved, devoted wife of the late Louis Silver. Loving, cherished mother of Stanley, Phyllis (Gerald Gelles), Robert and Martin (Dale). Adored, loving grandma Martha of David & Robin, Stuart & Carol, Steven & Caron, Richard, Denise & Julian, Clifford, Enid, Wendy & Jordan and Laurie. Beloved great-grandma of Alisha, Stefanie & Matthew, Joshua, Rachel & Dana, Noah & Grant, Samantha and Carli. She leaves her dear sister Sunny Rosenberg and many devoted nieces and nephews. Philanthropy was part of her life, together with her husband Louis, they gave generously of their financial means, and their time and efforts to many causes, both here and abroad, Jewish and secular, including The Martha and Louis Silver Day Training Center at AHRC in Brookville, LI; Peninsula Hospital, Far Rockaway, NY; Kingsbrook Medical Center, Brooklyn; Boys Town of Jerusalem; UJA; Jewish Theological Seminary of America; National Holocaust Museum, Washington, DC. Staunch supporters of Israel Bonds from its inception, she was a delegate on the first Women's Delegation to Israel in 1952 and was a dedicated member of Temple Beth El, Rockaway Park, for over 70 years. These and many more benefited from their humanitarian efforts. Her wise counsel, witty ''grandma Martharisms,'' warm smile and loving kindness to her family and friends will always be remembered by all who loved, admired and respected her. A wonderful example of a true matriarch and an Aishes Chayil. We shall miss you. You will live in our hearts forever. Funeral services today, June 13, 2002 at 1 PM, Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREVOR, ANNE E. LACY
description: TREVOR-Anne E. Lacy, 50, wife of John B. Trevor III and a widely-known Adirondack artist and illustrator, died June 9th at home in Lake Placid, NY after a long illness. The daughter of Elizabeth and the late F. Prentice Lacy of Durham, NC, she was born in Dalls, PA. She was a member of the first co-educational class at Kenyon College in Ohio where she graduated cum laude with honors in Studio Art in 1973. After interning with sculptor Nancy Graves in New York and doing additional graduate work at Syracuse University, she joined the Smithsonian's Museum of Natural History in Washington, DC as a scientific illustrator and artist. Her work at the Smithsonian includes a diorama background in the Hall of Western Civilization. She was subsequently employed by the New York State Science Service. She moved to Elizabethtown in 1981 to work for the Adirondack Council as illustrator of the ''Adirondack Wildguide'' by Michael DeNunzio. It was the first of many distinguished books, posters, maps, and other projects for the Council, ''Adirondack Life'' magazine, Niagara Mohawk Power, Central Park Conservancy of New York City, Fort Ticonderoga, the Essex County Adirondack Garden Club and other North Country groups. Additional books illustrated include Philip Kopper's ''The Wild Edge'', Dr. Eugene Ogden's ''Field Guide to Northeastern Ferns'', ''Field Notes From the Northern Forest'' by Curt Stager, and most recently, ''River Study'' by the Essex County Adirondack Garden Club. Her illustrated map of the Adirondacks, commissioned by the Adirondack Council, with its depiction of varied Park environments from boreal and hardwood forests to alpine meadows, bogs, and beaver flows, shows her varied talents. Honors and awards include Educator of the Year from the Adirondack Council in 1998 and the Zone III Horticultural Arts Award in May, 1998. In addition, she was a member of the Essex County Adirondack Garden Club. In addition to her husband and mother, she is survived by her sister Gail Lacy and her brother David. A funeral service will be held at the Keene Valley Congregational Church, Saturday, June 15th at 12:30 p.m. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Adirondack Medical Center, Lake Colby Drive, Saranac Lake, NY 12983, or St. Eustace Church, 44 Main Street, Lake Placid, NY 12946 in memory of Anne E. Lacy Trevor. For information Clark Funeral Home, Lake Placid.

title: Pills for Nuclear Plant Radiation
description: Spurred by memories of Sept. 11, more than a dozen states are beginning to acquire potassium iodide pills to protect people living or working near nuclear plants from potential radiation exposure should a terrorist attack or accident occur. Both those who are apprehensive about a terror attack and those who think, as we do, that the likelihood of a successful attack is small should welcome any effort to stockpile potassium iodide as a sensible precaution. The pills carry little risk except to those with iodine sensitivities, thyroid problems or certain rare conditions. They provide substantial protection against thyroid cancer if taken just before or within a few hours after exposure to radiation.

''I want it to be very unfussy,'' said Mona Nerenberg, the owner. Her store has a sophisticated beach-meets-country look. title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Senate Hearing On Domain Names
description: The Senate Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Science, Technology and Space held a hearing yesterday to address widespread dissatisfaction with the organization charged with managing the Internet's address system, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers. The group, also known as Icann, has embarked on its own effort to change, but among the questions raised at the hearing was whether Icann is capable of managing its overhaul or whether the Commerce Department should take a more active role in the effort as the governmental body that manages Icann's contract. There was little consensus among those who testified, but Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, the subcommittee chairman who presided over the hearing, concluded, ''If Icann is going to reform itself, the Department of Commerce is going to have to push that organization harder than they have done in the past.'' title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: American Reporter Goes On Trial
description: On the opening day of his trial, an American reporter who is the first journalist to be tried under the country's new press law pleaded not guilty to publishing false information. Andrew Meldrum, the Zimbabwe correspondent for The Guardian, reported that an opposition sympathizer had been beheaded by supporters of President Robert Mugabe. The story, first reported in a local newspaper and then picked up by a number of news organizations, turned out to be false and was retracted by the paper, The Daily News. A reporter for The Daily News is to go on trial later this month in connection with the report. Mr. Meldrum maintains that he did not intend to publish false information and that the police were unable confirm or deny the account of the woman's death.
