description: To the Editor:

title: Judge, Fearing Potential Aid to Terrorists, Denies Moussaoui Access to Aviation Security Files
description: A federal judge has ruled that Zacarias Moussaoui, the sole person charged in the Sept. 11 attacks, may not have access to classified prosecution evidence about the aviation security system because it might end up in the hands of terrorists ''intent on attacking civil aviation.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hyundai In Malaysian Deal
description: The Hyundai Motor Company has entered an agreement for DRB-Hicom of Malaysia to assemble trucks with technology and parts made by Hyundai. A company spokesman said DRB-Hicom would make about 6,000 2.5-ton Hyundai trucks for sale in Malaysia over the next five years. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Buying the Right Digicam
description: If you read my State of the Art column in today's Circuits section, it might have struck you that my roundup of 4-megapixel digital cameras was longer than usual -- especially with the accompanying Table That Ate Cleveland. (And hey, I'm allowed to make Cleveland jokes. I'm from Cleveland.)

title: In Suicide Bombings, the Taxi Man Got Away
description: In a land where ethnic and religious identity is worn like a badge or a brand, Ibrahim Sarahne was a blur.

title: Banks Sold Dynegy Stock to Recoup Loans
description: Charles Watson, the former chairman and chief executive of Dynegy Inc., disclosed that bankers sold about one-third of his company stake to recoup millions of dollars in loans.

title: Visit Provence, Right in Sag Harbor
description: Bagley Home, a minuscule store in Sag Harbor, N.Y., looks as if it could be in Provence. The shop, which Terry Bagley (above, with her dog, Dave) recently opened on Main Street, has a disparate mix of objects for the home -- mostly antique or vintage. The changing inventory includes 1930's French breakfast bowls ($26 to $45) and old French linens (pillowcases are $175 a pair; hand towels, $24 to $48). Large pillows with antique ticking are $250 to $350, and 19th-century industrial light fixtures are $450 to $3,800. Honey-scented cricket soaps, inset, are $6 a bar; jars of pink bath salts are $28. Bagley Home, 34 Main Street, Sag Harbor; (631) 725-3553. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: INSIDE
description: AIDS Drugs and Babies

title: Spanish Broadcasting Sues Two Rivals
description: Spanish Broadcasting System Inc. sued two rivals today, Clear Channel Communications and the Hispanic Broadcasting Corporation, accusing them of anticompetitive conduct meant to weaken or eliminate the company from the Spanish-language radio market.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: PENSION MEASURES COULD BE COSTLY

title: Sweden Eliminates A Stunned Argentina
description: With a tenacious defense, plucky Sweden unexpectedly knocked Argentina out of the World Cup today, making the first time in 40 years that the South American powerhouse did not advance beyond the first round.

title: Face of Rwanda Genocide Now on U.S.-Backed Wanted Posters
description: Flicien Kabuga, who is accused of sponsoring the 1994 genocide in Rwanda by supplying machetes and hoes for weapons, has long used his huge bank account and official connections to keep one step ahead of the law, authorities say.

title: O'Brien's Leap of Faith Pays Off for the U.S.
description: International soccer does not involve itself in the same hand-wringing as American basketball about high school players jumping directly to the pros. Everywhere but the United States this kind of leapfrogging is the rule, not the exception.

title: Loaf of Bread, Jug of Wine And Puccini in Central Park
description: Opera is never so generic and seldom so purely pleasant as it is in the park. On Tuesday night an estimated 45,000 to 50,000 people spread out on blankets, using balloons to flag their picnic spots for late arrivals, on the Great Lawn of Central Park, a space punctuated with birdsong and the occasional gentle purring of a cellphone. The occasion was the opening of the Metropolitan Opera's annual Met in the Parks Concert Series with a performance of Puccini's ''Bohme.''

title: EFFORT TO REPEAL ESTATE TAX ENDS IN SENATE DEFEAT
description: The Republican push for a permanent repeal of the estate tax collapsed today in the Democratic-led Senate, but Republicans promised to use their legislative defeat as an issue in the election campaign this fall.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: KIRCH'S COLLAPSE The collapse of Germany's Kirch Group was completed today when Taurus Holding, the umbrella company that controls its subsidiaries in everything from film and sports rights to television broadcasting, filed for bankruptcy. The move has little operational effect, because all of Kirch's subsidiaries had already filed for bankruptcy and are being carved up, sold off and closed. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Kirch's Collapse
description: The collapse of Germany's Kirch Group was completed today when Taurus Holding, the umbrella company that controls its subsidiaries in everything from film and sports rights to television broadcasting, filed for bankruptcy. The move has little operational effect, because all of Kirch's subsidiaries had already filed for bankruptcy and are being carved up, sold off and closed. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Rumsfeld Ends South Asia Visit With Plea for Talks on Kashmir
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 13  Completing a shuttle-diplomacy mission across south Asia, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the leaders of both India and Pakistan were "concerned and determined" to reduce tensions, and he called for a resumption of dialogue between the two nuclear rivals.

title: QUARTERLY PROFIT AT H&R BLOCK IS UP 23%
description: H & R Block Inc. said its profit rose 23 percent in its most recent quarter, and announced that its chairman would retire later this year. Helped by an increase in tax preparation and consumer lending, the company said its profit rose to $463.5 million, or $2.46 a share, from $378.1 million, or $2.02, a year earlier. Revenue in the period, which ended April 30 and was the fourth quarter of Block's fiscal year, rose 12 percent, to $1.9 billion. The chairman, Frank Salizzoni, said his retirement would be effective at the close of the company's annual meeting on Sept. 11. No successor has been named.

title: Outsiders' Precautions Taking a Toll on India
description: Bracing for war has become a major headache for Indian businesses.

title: Young Readers, Harsh Reality
description: While New York State was nervously cleansing the book excerpts on its Regents English exam of words like ''Jewish,'' ''gentiles,'' ''Polish,'' ''bar'' (as in drinking), ''wine,'' ''fat'' (changed to heavy) and ''gringo,'' publishers of course were happily continuing to churn out books for that very same teenage population. These included stories about a boy accused of putting his baby sister into a coma, a young master criminal robbing fairies of their gold, a 14-year-old pondering not only her lingerie but also which way to turn her head when kissing, a parentless child with cerebral palsy and a tattooed druggie, and a brilliant, stunted 12-year-old and his gigantic friend whose father is in prison for killing his wife.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Siebel Shares Drop On Gloomy Outlook
description: Shares in Siebel Systems Inc. slumped yesterday after an executive at company, a business software maker, predicted a gloomy second quarter. On Tuesday, Ken Goldman, Siebel's chief financial officer, said at the annual Bear Stearns analyst conference in New York that the information technology ''environment is every bit as challenging, if not frankly more challenging, this quarter than it was last quarter.'' Shares dropped more than 4 percent in Tuesday's after-hours trading on news of the statement. In April, Siebel, the No. 1 maker of sales and customer service software, said that it expected second-quarter revenue to be flat with the first quarter. Shares in Siebel, which is based in San Mateo, Calif., were at one point yesterday down as much as 18 percent, but they recovered a bit to close at $15.18, down $2.48, or 14 percent. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: State's Delegation to Request More Federal Aid for 2 Utilities
description: Several members of the New York delegation in Congress say they are planning to ask the Bush administration for an extra $150 million for Verizon Communications and Consolidated Edison to pay the cost of repairs related to the World Trade Center attack.

title: A Closer Look
description: Eventually, almost certainly, a distinguished bipartisan commission will be convened to examine the conditions that led to the catastrophe of Sept. 11.

title: Omnicom Shares Tumble 20%
description: The Omnicom Group, the large advertising agency company, scrambled yesterday to repair damage caused by a newspaper article critical of its accounting practices.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: OHIO: COURT REVIVES GUN SUIT

title: Last-Minute Switch Sends Italy to Round 2 After Tying Mexico
description: OITA, Japan, June 13  Until the final five minutes of play against Mexico, Italian players must have thought that Big Eye stadium was giving them the World Cup evil eye.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Candidate's Ad Puts Focus On Home
description: The Republican candidate for governor, Mitt Romney, will release a 30-second television spot this week accusing Democrats of ''dirty politics'' for challenging his candidacy on residency grounds. In the advertisement, Mr. Romney walks through Belmont, a Boston suburb, talking about how he and his family have lived there for 30 years. The Democrats asserted before the state Ballot Law Commission that Mr. Romney had not been a state resident for the seven years the Massachusetts Constitution requires of candidates for governor. Mr. Romney claimed nonresident status in Massachusetts while organizing the Winter Olympics in Utah in 1999 and 2000. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a court ruling that the sponsors of building co-op conversions have an obligation to sell apartments in a reasonable time misstated the ownership of the building in the case, 511 West 232nd Street in the Bronx. The sponsor, the Jennifer Realty Company, owns 41 of the building's 66 co-op apartments; it no longer owns the building.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: PC Shipments Higher Than Reported
description: Personal-computer makers shipped 8 million more PC's last year than previously reported, according to revised figures that include a closer count of small manufacturers, the research firm IDC said yesterday. Worldwide shipments were 133.5 million, 6.3 percent more than the previous estimate of 125.5 million, said Loren Loverde, director of IDC's Worldwide Quarterly PC Tracker. Closer scrutiny of the smaller producers means that a larger base of PC users exists than previously thought, and that will affect estimates for purchases of peripheral products and services, like printers and Internet access, Mr. Loverde said.

title: Making the Outdoors Sing, With Color
description: A burst of color can help almost any room, even an outdoor room, and ''Susan Sargent's New Country Color'' (Watson-Guptill, $29.95) shows, for example, how lime green and raspberry work with tomato red. The book demonstrates vivid color schemes and explains how to paint outdoor furniture. The table and chairs below are at the home in Vermont that Ms. Sargent shares with her husband, the management guru Tom Peters. ''I always go for this violet blue,'' she said. For those disinclined to paint, her line of color-saturated pillows ($40 to $100) and rugs (4 by 6 feet, $595) is at Design Solutions in New Canaan, Conn., (203) 966-3116; and Liten Hus, Mall of America, Bloomington, Minn. (952) 858-8256. For other stores: (802) 366-4955. LINDA LEE

title: AIDS Drugs During Pregnancy Don't Harm Fetus, Study Finds
description: American doctors routinely prescribe antiretroviral drug cocktails to pregnant women infected with the AIDS virus despite nagging fears that the medicines might result in premature or low birth-weight babies. But those fears are largely unfounded, according to a study made public today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLIKEN, SARAH GORDON
description: MILLIKEN-Sarah Gordon. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great grandmother, dearest sister and aunt, died on June 12, 2002. Services are private.

title: Shot Across a Bow: A Sail Recaptured
description: THE sparse aluminum-hulled motorboat skimmed at full power across the choppy bay, approaching two possible targets sailing together.

title: ImClone Case Drags Martha Stewart Shares Down
description: The arrest of Samuel D. Waksal, the former chief executive of ImClone Systems, on criminal charges of insider trading was not a good thing for Martha Stewart, or for shareholders of her company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia.

title: Echo of F.B.I. Abuses In Queries on New Role
description: Consider the following set of circumstances: Using the new guidelines for fighting terrorism, an F.B.I. agent visits a mosque and hears an imam declare that United States policies are starving children in Iraq or killing children in Palestine and that people need to ''do something'' about this situation.

title: Separating the Birdies From the Bogeys
description: Heading into the Open, here are some top players who have performed well recently, and some who haven't. By CLIFTON BROWN

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: ZIMBABWE: AMERICAN REPORTER GOES ON TRIAL On the opening day of his trial, an American reporter who is the first journalist to be tried under the country's new press law pleaded not guilty to publishing false information. Andrew Meldrum, the Zimbabwe correspondent for The Guardian, reported that an opposition sympathizer had been beheaded by supporters of President Robert Mugabe. The story, first reported in a local newspaper and then picked up by a number of news organizations, turned out to be false and was retracted by the paper, The Daily News. A reporter for The Daily News is to go on trial later this month in connection with the report. Mr. Meldrum maintains that he did not intend to publish false information and that the police were unable confirm or deny the account of the woman's death.

title: With a Tray of Drinks, Jeeves Rolls Out to the Terrace
description: Remember Rosie the Robot? The idea of robotic home helpers is at least as old as ''The Jetsons,'' but few of the models released over the years have made much real-world splash. Now, a well-known Silicon Valley entrepreneur is giving the home robot another try -- with a laptop-based hybrid kit.

title: A Truce: The Army and the Ivy
description: To the Editor:

title: Fassel Not Happy With Hilliard
description: Giants officials admire Ike Hilliard's tenacity on the field, his ability to get open and his competitiveness. They also know by now that he is an iconoclast who is not always going to do exactly what they want.

title: Text of Craig Martin's Statement to Bishop's Conference
description: Good morning. I believe it is still morning. I'm not sure, it's been a long day so far. My name is Craig Martin. My presence here today represents [a stop?], which has been a very difficult and long journey for myself, my family and others who are close to me.

title: LoVecchio Transfers From Notre Dame
description: Quarterback Matt LoVecchio went home to Franklin Lakes, N.J., last month when he decided to leave Notre Dame after spring practice. Now he is heading back to Indiana.

title: A Bouncy Collage of Styles, Each Given a Personal Twist
description: The African diaspora is no place for a musical purist. Its styles have evolved by constantly adding any promising sound without worrying about where it came from. Corey Harris, who brought his band, the 5X5, to the Mercury Lounge on Monday night, continues that process. While his foundation is the blues, he also ranges through gospel, Louisiana Creole music, reggae and African pop. Over the good-timey rhythms, he sings about slavery, struggle and faith.

title: A Premier's Rsum: Not Pretentious, Not Parisian
description: Less than two months ago Jean-Pierre Raffarin was barely known outside France, or even inside. He was a provincial senator with modest credentials, propelled into the prime minister's job by an electoral upset and seen as little more than a puppet of the praetorian guard surrounding President Jacques Chirac.

title: Democrats Complain About Missile Test Secrecy
description: Leading Senate Democrats today accused the Missile Defense Agency of excessive secrecy in reporting on its tests, timetables and cost estimates.

title: 50 Held in European Offshoot of Bank of New York Investigation
description: As a tangential part of a money laundering investigation of the Bank of New York, police officials in several European countries this week detained more than 50 people suspected of involvement in a network that funneled millions of dollars from Russia through Western banks and companies.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Court Revives Gun Suit
description: The State Supreme Court reinstated a lawsuit brought by the City of Cincinnati against the handgun industry. The suit seeks to hold manufacturers, trade associations and a distributor responsible for their asserted failure to make guns safer and to keep them away from criminals and children. Cincinnati says these failures have increased its police, emergency, corrections and other costs. Courts around the country are divided about whether such lawsuits may be permitted. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Brazil Displays Skill in a Win Over Costa Rica
description: SUWON, South Korea, June 13  Brazil never knows how to hold back. Already qualified for the second round of the World Cup, the old champion came out on a crisp, sunny afternoon and enjoyed a romp in the park, with dazzling runs and deft passes and alert shots. It was all so pretty, but Costa Rica was in no position to enjoy it.

title: Critic's Notebook; In the Ranks Of the Idols
description: Ever in search of idols, the international ballet world has rightly found one in Carlos Acosta, the charismatic 29-year-old Cuban who is dancing with American Ballet Theater for the first time this season.

title: Making 7 Hearts Wasn't the Best in a Worldwide Contest
description: Two Worldwide Bridge Contests were played last week under the auspices of the World Bridge Federation, with all players match-pointed as one field. On Friday evening, players competed in 312 clubs in 41 countries. The overall winners, with a score of 76 percent, were Ken Barbour and Markland Jones playing at the Arizona Bridge Center in Phoenix.

title: Add-On Helps the Organizer Keep Its User on the Right Path
description: Nothing illustrates the adage ''Wherever you go, there you are'' better than seeing your location pinpointed on an electronic map by a Global Positioning System device. For those packing Palm or iPAQ Pocket PC organizers on their next trip to unfamiliar territory, Navman USA makes a series of G.P.S. receivers that can turn a simple hand-held computer into a navigation system that can determine location every two seconds.

title: When the Shark Doesn't Bite
description: NOT since the 1975 release of ''Jaws'' have sharks received as much media attention as they did last summer, when three people were killed in a series of attacks along the East Coast. And just when you thought it was safe to go back into the water, experts are predicting that the number of shark attacks in the United States this summer may surpass the 55 reported last year, as more and more people flock to the beach.

title: Tax-Cut Cynicism
description: At a time of terrorism anxiety and scarce budget resources, Congress is increasingly in the grip of a bad case of warped priorities. Were Americans to be asked if they wanted to cut taxes for the wealthy just now, the answer would be no. Yet that is what President Bush and Republican Congressional leaders are seeking. Yesterday rationality prevailed in the Senate, which killed an attempt to make permanent the repeal of the estate tax enacted last year. But other unnecessary tax cuts will be on the agenda soon, just as Congress is scrimping on funds for homeland security.

title: Deal in Albany On Coverage For Women
description: After two years of grueling, often emotional talks, the Senate and Assembly have come to terms on a bill that would require insurers to cover a range of women's health services, like birth control and mammograms, officials said tonight.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about plans for stores around Times Square, including a Hershey candy outlet in the Crowne Plaza Hotel, misstated the name of a store that recently closed. It was the Museum Company, not the Museum Store.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, BENJAMIN
description: WARD-Benjamin. The Board of Directors and the employees of Medallion Financial Corp. mourn the loss of its esteemed Board Member. Our heartfelt condolences to the family. Alvin Murstein, Chairman Andrew Murstein, President

title: Separating Spiritual and Political, He Pays a Price
description: AS a young refugee, Henry Siegman found himself fleeing advancing German troops in Belgium early in World War II. He, his pregnant mother and younger brothers and sisters stumbled into one of the worst debacles of the war -- the frantic retreat of Allied troops at the Battle of Dunkirk. They huddled in a pitch-black cellar as the fighting raged overhead. In the morning, to the horror of the young boy, the door was kicked open by victorious German troops.

title: Effies and Addys and Other Awards
description: I.B.M. and its agency, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group , took the top prize as the New York chapter of the American Marketing Association presented its 34th annual Effie Awards, which recognize effectiveness. I.B.M. and Ogilvy won the Grand Effie for an e-business infrastructure campaign, which also won a Gold Effie in the category of computers and related equipment.

title: Less Is More, Mayor Suggests On World Trade Center Site
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he believes the development of the World Trade Center site must balance the commercial and residential needs of the neighborhood with the need for a memorial, and should not turn the site into ''a cemetery.''

title: White Substance in Surf Closes Beaches in Suffolk
description: Many ocean beaches along the South Shore in Suffolk County were closed yesterday after lumps of a white, rubbery substance washed up in the surf, the authorities said.

title: John Sinkankas, 87, Gem Expert and Author, Dies
description: John Sinkankas, an internationally known mineralogist, gemologist, lapidary, author and illustrator, died on May 17 in San Diego. He was 87.

title: ABC And ESPN2 To Broadcast W.N.B.A. Games
description: ESPN2 and ABC Sports will televise Women's National Basketball Association games for six seasons, starting next year, the league and the networks said yesterday. ABC replaces NBC as the league's broadcast outlet.

title: With the Masters, In Their Element
description: On the theory that any artist, regardless of age or experience, can benefit from guidance, Rolex S.A., the Swiss watchmaker, has created a novel mentoring program that will link up five up-and-coming artists with five world-class masters in their fields.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: No More 15-Year-Old Soldiers
description: Parliament raised the minimum age for military service to 18, following more than 100 countries that have signed an international treaty to bar child soldiers. The Swiss had allowed military service as early as 15, and about 400 teen-agers under 18 have entered the service annually.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLEVELAND, RICHARD J., M.D.
description: CLEVELAND - Richard J., M.D. Of Wellesley, MA. died on June 11, 2002. Husband of Carol (Hossin) Cleveland and the late Marjorie Hanna Cleveland. Father of Richard Jay Cleveland of Natick, MA., Melissa Salameh of Greenwich, CT, and Dr. Janice Washburn of Wellesley. Also survived by his stepdaughters, Elyse Eisenberg of Los Angeles, CA, Ellen Eisenberg of Woodbridge, CT, Andrea Michaels of San Francisco, CA, and eight grandchildren. A Memorial service and celebration of his life will be held on Thursday, June 13 at 11 AM at St. Mary's Episcopal Church, 258 Concord Rd, Newton Lower Falls, MA. The Rev. Dr. Craig B. Adams will officiate. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend. Burial at Woodlawn Cemetery will be private. Donations in Dr. Cleveland's memory may be made to the Richard J. Cleveland, MD Fund for Brain Tumor Research, C/O John Erban, MD, Division of Hematology/ Oncology; New England Medical Center Hospital, 750 Washington Street, Box 245, Boston, MA. 02111. For more information, please contact JS Waterman & Sons-Waring at 781-235-4110.

title: Waiting in Gaza, Grieving in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Step Lively? Tell It to My Crosstown Bus!
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Shunning NATO Summit
description: Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov said Russia had no intention of attending NATO's summit meeting in Prague in November, when as many as nine countries are expected to be invited to join the 19-member alliance, including three former Soviet republics, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. NATO and Russia agreed last month to a new partnership that gives Russia a voice on some issues but NATO membership is not one of them. Mr. Ivanov's comments underscored the lingering animosity some Russians feel about NATO's expansion.

title: The Sierra Club criticizes Ford's chief in a campaign for fuel-efficient cars.
description: THE Sierra Club introduced an advertising campaign yesterday that ties fuel economy to patriotism and calls for action by William Clay Ford Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, who was once viewed by the group as an ally.

title: Burglar Slays Man in One Apartment, Then Kills Elderly Couple Downstairs
description: A prowler climbed through the bathroom window of a Lower East Side apartment early yesterday, shot a sleeping man in the head, police officials said, then drank the dead man's whiskey and watched sex videos before heading downstairs, where he killed an elderly couple.

title: Plan to Relax Air Pollution Rules for Some Utilities
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 — The Environmental Protection Agency called today for changing some air-pollution rules that cover utilities and other plants. The E.P.A. said the changes were dictated by common sense, but environmental groups said they may as well have been dictated by industrial polluters.

title: Lesson for the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SAID TO WEIGH PROVISIONAL STATE FOR PALESTINIANS
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the Bush administration was considering backing the formation of a Palestinian state even before its borders and other details are agreed on, but he emphasized that the idea was only one of several still under review.

title: Meeting With Bishops, Victims Seek Strict Rules on Abuse
description: In an emotional start to a national conference of Roman Catholic bishops, more than a dozen victims of sexual abuse by clergy members met behind closed doors with bishops and cardinals to share their experiences of childhood abuse by priests and to demand that the bishops adopt and enforce a zero tolerance policy for abusers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, ANN WARD
description: COLLINS-Ann Ward. 94. Died at home peacefully on June 10, 2002 in the presence of her family, as she wished. Ann was a woman of great spirit, independence and compassion. Her joy of life was unwavering, as was her sense of humor, and she shared both freely. Know that she left life as she lived it, with dignity, serenity and love. She will be greatly missed. Ann was a former President of the Casita Maria and was a member of the Order of the Holy Sepulcher. A longtime resident of New York and Palm Beach, Ann is survived by her daughter Jill Hyland Frankenhoff, her son-in-law William, and her grandchildren William Jr. and Christine. Ann is also survived by her stepchildren, Monsignor Timothy S. Collins, Richard W. Collins, Marianna Tostanoski and their children. A Mass of the Resurrection will be held at 10AM, Thursday, June 13, at St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89 St. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Casita Maria, 928 Simpson St., Bronx, New York 10459.

title: A Bathroom Uplift In a Nautical Mode
description: IF the bathroom is one place in the home where small luxuries can make a big difference, imagine what a complete overhaul could do. At opposite ends of the style spectrum, there are two new fixture collections: a French system made of teak that can create a bathroom fit for a yacht and, for traditionalists, an expanded English-style collection from Restoration Hardware. For a small upgrade, try a new cabinet, wallpaper or a waterproof mat.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''All the great media adventures of the 20th century have been visual. Television, movies, the Internet, they're all visual mediums and I don't think people have time to sit down and read.''

title: Former Biotech Chief Is Charged in Trading
description: Samuel D. Waksal, the former chief executive of the biotechnology company ImClone Systems, was arrested yesterday and charged with insider stock trading.

title: DYNASTY OVERWHELMS DESTINY
description: Shaquille O'Neal smiled and basked in his own untouchable sphere, accepting high-fives in the middle of his court -- the N.B.A. finals. His sidekick, Kobe Bryant, slipped over to Nets Coach Byron Scott and hugged him.

title: Sports of The Times; Dream Season or Not, The Pain Is Palpable
description: THIS was probably the most disorienting moment of the entire Nets season.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Best Buy To Open In Chelsea
description: Best Buy, the nation's largest electronics retailer, is opening its first store in Manhattan tomorrow, five years after its biggest rival, Circuit City, entered the New York market. A retail consultant, Burt Flickinger III, said the heightened competition was likely to drive down prices and put pressure on regional electronics retailers that lack the buying power of the big chains. The new Best Buy store, at Avenue of the Americas and 23rd Street in Chelsea, covers 35,000 square feet and will have 150 employees. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Univision Buys Big Holder of Hispanic Radio Stations
description: In another sign of the huge growth expected in Spanish-language media, Univision Communications announced yesterday that it would buy the Hispanic Broadcasting Corporation -- the largest holder of Spanish-language radio stations -- for roughly $3 billion in stock.

title: 3 Servicemen Killed in Crash Of a U.S. Plane In Afghanistan
description: An American military supply plane crashed on takeoff in eastern Afghanistan today, killing 3 of the 10 military personnel aboard, the Pentagon said.

title: The Chroming Of the Front Yard
description: WHEN Lillie Simms peers out at her neighbors' yards, the word ''concrete'' instantly becomes a verb. ''They concreted that one,'' she said, referring to the latest trend to hit this densely packed, parking-crazed city: the paving of front yards for parking. ''See that BMW and Ford over there? That used to be shrubbery. They concreted it.''

title: Scheme City
description: The city of Houston started out as a real-estate scam.

title: Former Chief of ImClone Systems Is Charged With Insider Trading
description: Samuel D. Waksal, the former chief executive of the biotechnology company ImClone Systems, was arrested at his Manhattan home early yesterday morning and charged with insider stock trading.

title: Fastness and Firmness Are Subject to Rain
description: ''If this golf course plays the way it has in the practice rounds,'' Tom Kite said this afternoon about the Black Course at Bethpage State Park, host this week of the United States Open, ''even par could win.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Judge's Bribery Trial Advances
description: The way was cleared yesterday for the bribery trial of a Brooklyn State Supreme Court justice, Victor I. Barron. In his decision, Justice Nicholas Colabella, who usually sits in Westchester, rejected a defense request to dismiss the charges and said he was setting jury selection for July 16. Justice Colabella said the evidence presented by the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, to the grand jury was legally sufficient. Mr. Barron was suspended after he was charged in January with taking $18,000 as part of an arrangement to approve settlement of a civil suit. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Tahseen Bashir, Voice of Tolerance in Egypt, Dies at 77
description: CAIRO, June 12 -- Tahseen Bashir, the erudite Egyptian diplomat who served as spokesman for the first two post-revolutionary Egyptian presidents and proved a bete noire to the third, died of heart failure in a London hospital on Tuesday. He was 77.

title: Waiting in Gaza, Grieving in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: As Lawsuits Spread, Church Faces Questions on Finances
description: After spending the past six months fending off accusations that it covered up allegations of sexual abuse by priests, the American Roman Catholic church now faces a new wave of scrutiny about how its finances are handled, particularly because of the large and confidential settlements that dioceses have reached with victims of that abuse.

title: New Loan-Sharking Charges for S.I. Man on House Arrest
description: A reputed member of the Colombo crime family was charged yesterday with running a loan-sharking operation while he was on house arrest and laundering the gains by buying sports memorabilia, including a pair of Muhammad Ali's boxing gloves, a basketball autographed by Michael Jordan and baseball gloves that belonged to Babe Ruth and Mickey Mantle.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Inquiry Sought In Affidavit Leak
description: A lawyer for Lynne F. Stewart, the lawyer accused of helping her Egyptian client to direct terrorist operations from his prison cell, asked a federal judge yesterday for an investigation of how a secret F.B.I. affidavit in the case became public. It was posted on thesmokinggun.com Web site of Court TV. The government has said that the affidavit's release was inadvertent, and that it was not ''properly sealed at the time it was signed'' by a magistrate. Ms. Stewart is charged with improperly assisting her client, the imprisoned sheik Omar Abdul Rahman. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Job Benefits Bill Advances
description: A New York State Assembly bill to give thousands of jobless New Yorkers an extra 13 weeks of unemployment insurance benefits advanced yesterday, said a spokesman for Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker. As many as 100,000 New Yorkers will have exhausted their temporary benefits by the end of next week, according to data from the Federal Department of Labor. Two Assembly committees approved the bill, and the full Assembly is likely to consider the bill on Monday. Senator Guy J. Velella of the Bronx has introduced similar legislation in the Senate. Both bills extend payments to those who have used up six months of regular unemployment benefits and three months of federal benefits. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: FOUNDER OF ICN PHARMACEUTICALS TO RETIRE AS CHIEF
description: The founder of ICN Pharmaceuticals, Milan Panic, will retire this month as the chief executive and chairman after years of battling shareholders and regulators. Mr. Panic, 72, who founded the company in Los Angeles in 1959, lost a proxy fight with dissidents led by two of the company's largest investors over three board seats last month. In December, ICN agreed to plead guilty to securities fraud and pay a $5.6 million penalty to end a six-year investigation by the United States attorney's office in Los Angeles.

title: World Wide Waterfalls
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Another Title for O'Neal, This One Amid Family

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Manugistics To Shut Some Offices
description: The Manugistics Group will close its United States offices from July 1 to July 5 and force employees to take four unpaid vacation days as part of its effort to reduce expenses. The company, which last month moved into new corporate headquarters in Rockville, Md., told its 1,500 employees about the ''unpaid company shutdown'' last week, a spokeswoman, Didi Blackwood, said yesterday. Customer service and support operations will not be affected, nor will employees involved in installing software that customers have already purchased, she added. Ms. Blackwood declined to say how much the company would save. Brad Reback, a software analyst at the CIBC World Markets Corporation, calculated that the weeklong shutdown would save about $2 million in expenses in the quarter ending in August. Manugistics, a vendor of supply-chain software, said June 4 it would take steps to reduce costs and lay off an unspecified number of employees after announcing a revenue shortfall and a wider-than-expected loss for the May quarter.

title: Metromedia Fiber Is Under S.E.C. Inquiry
description: Metromedia Fiber Network, a fiber optic network operator that filed for bankruptcy protection last month, announced today that federal regulators were investigating its accounting practices.

title: For Florists, A Challenge To Outdo Themselves
description: On Tuesday, within 24 hours of John J. Gotti's death, Dennis Rigas put the staff on high alert at his flower shop in Richmond Hill, Queens. ''We first got the call about two days ago and they told us that they didn't know exactly when, where or how,'' Mr. Rigas said. ''We did not know when or where, but we have been on alert for two days.''

title: BANK OF MONTREAL NAMES NEW CHIEF FOR HARRIS BANK UNIT
description: The Bank of Montreal said yesterday that it was naming Frank Techar to replace Alan G. McNally as the chief executive of its Chicago-based Harris Bank unit when Mr. McNally retires Sept. 1. Mr. Techar, 45, will move to Chicago from Toronto, where he has been executive vice president of small-business banking. He will report to William Downe, a deputy chairman, Bank of Montreal said.

title: The Intelligence Puzzle
description: As President Bush and Congress reorganize the government to deal with terrorist threats, they had better get the intelligence side of the equation right. Nothing would be more detrimental to American security than rewiring the nation's spy machinery in a way that worsens longstanding problems. Unfortunately, some proposals now circulating on Capitol Hill would do just that by further fragmenting control over the nation's spy operations.

Bob was a Director-Cash management at Bristol-Meyers Squibb Co. in New York. Funeral services will be held on Monday, June 17 at 11 AM directly at Holy Family Church, Fairfield, CT. title: Study Says Many Children Are Still Poisoned by Lead
description: Thousands of children continue to be exposed to lead, especially in minority neighborhoods, despite legislation passed three years ago that set new lead paint regulations for landlords, according to a report released yesterday by the New York Public Interest Research Group.

title: Astronomers Detect Signs That Jupiter Has Distant Cousin
description: Astronomers have for the first time found a planetary system of a distant star that in significant respects reminds them of the Sun's family of planets.

description: KAPLAN-Hyman. Father of Bob, Syma Silverman and Harriet Shea. Father-in-law of Marcia, Irwin and Ed. Brother of Ethel Warner and Fay Penn. Brother-in-law of Gladys Kaplan. Adored grandfather and great-grandfather. A memorial service will be held Friday 10AM at ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 66th Avenue, Rego Park. A service will also be held Sunday 10AM at the Levitt-Weinstein Chapel in Tamarac, FL. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Workman Circle Second Century Fund, 45 East 33rd Street, New York City 10016.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Fire Island: Beaches Reopen
description: Ocean beaches on the south shore of Suffolk County were reopened yesterday afternoon, after laboratory tests determined that a mysterious white, rubbery substance that had washed ashore was not hazardous. Officials said they suspected that the substance, which was first spotted off Smith Point County Park on Fire Island Tuesday evening and later found in waters as far east as Southampton, is commercial or industrial rubber that detached from a ship. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

description: SHRUB OAK: FORMER BISHOP APOLOGIZES

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Shrub Oak: Former Bishop Apologizes
description: A Roman Catholic bishop in Westchester County who resigned this week after admitting he had sexual affairs with women apologized yesterday to his parishioners, saying, ''There is no excuse possible for this.'' The bishop, James F. McCarthy, 59, above, had been the pastor of St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Parish in Shrub Oak, and auxiliary bishop in charge of northern Westchester, Putnam and Rockland Counties. A woman informed the New York Archdiocese about the affairs, which took place 20 years ago. ''I cannot begin to imagine the thoughts and emotions which are yours because of my sinfulness so many years ago,'' Bishop McCarthy wrote in a letter posted on the parish's Web site. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: A Start at Some Healing, But for One Day, at Least, Wounds Are Still Raw
description: Craig Martin, a Minnesota businessman, wept openly throughout his speech before 300 American bishops here today as he described being abused by a priest in a motel many years ago.

title: If the Saturday Morning Show Wasn't Enough . . .
description: For a while, ''Scooby-Doo'' looks as if it will turn out to be the half-successful realization of a spectacularly stupid idea. For some reason and against a great deal of evidence (''The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas''; ''Rocky and Bullwinkle''), Hollywood studios persist in believing that the public is clamoring for elaborate, digitally souped-up feature films based on old cartoons. The idea, presumably, is that parents who grew up on the originals will have their already overstimulated nostalgia receptors prodded again, while their kids will thrill to the dumb jokes and eye-popping effects.

title: Ventura Can't Predict What's Going to Happen
description: When Roger Clemens's fastball hit Mike Piazza in the head, Robin Ventura was on deck. When Piazza hit a broken-bat foul ball and Clemens threw the shattered bat near him, Ventura was on deck again.

title: For Wall Street's Sake: Art to Lure Visitors Downtown
description: Will art power help make Wall Street whole again? Julie Menin, a lawyer and former restaurateur whose husband owns the baronial Exchange Building at 25 Broad Street, is banking on it. Spurred by the drop in residents and businesses in the financial district after the Sept. 11 attack, she has created an upbeat organization called Wall Street Rising, which aims to bring new life to the area in part through the restorative spirit of art.

title: Trouble Over Recycling
description: New York City's budget negotiations have stalled on the issue of recycling. Although there are other points of disagreement between the City Council and Mayor Michael Bloomberg, the big sticking point is Mr. Bloomberg's desire to save money by suspending a key part of the city's recycling system. Council members argue that before junking the entire plan, the city should take six months and scramble to find ways to make recycling a better deal. It took years to train New Yorkers to separate their garbage. If they stop now, it may take years to get them going again. Six months is not too long to give the Council, the mayor's office and the Sanitation Department to start improving things.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Treason Trial To Continue
description: A court in Moscow rejected a lawyer's request to dismiss the treason trial of Oleg D. Kalugin, a former K.G.B. general now living in the United States, ruling that he could stand trial in absentia. Mr. Kalugin, who has been accused of disclosing state secrets from the Soviet era, has refused to appear in Russia to defend himself, and his lawyer, Yevgeny A. Baru, has told the court that made it impossible to defend him fairly. Mr. Baru said yesterday that he had asked for more time to contact Mr. Kalugin and to consider his defense. The court scheduled another hearing in the case on Monday.

title: 36 Hours | Santa Monica, Calif.
description: THOUGH only five miles or so from the heart of Los Angeles, Santa Monica feels a world away from the urban sprawl, the clogged freeways and the downtown traffic jams that make a visit to this part of Southern California often seem so maddening. Even apart from the pedestrian mall that has been created on Third Street, this ocean-front community is a town made for walkers, from the beachside promenade that was once the playground for stars like Mary Pickford and Cary Grant (and, more recently, the casts of ''Baywatch'' and ''Beverly Hills 90210'') to the famed Santa Monica Pier with its vest-pocket amusement park and its old-fashioned Ferris wheel offering spectacular views of the coastline. And though the omnipresent joggers, the preening bodybuilders and the outdoor Pilates classes might cause a moment's hesitation as you pursue your own less-ascetic activities over the weekend, pay them no mind. You're here to have a good time. The gym can wait until Monday. STUART EMMRICH

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Legislature Overrides Governor's Budget Veto
description: The heavily Democratic Legislature has voted to override Gov. Lincoln Almond's veto of a $2.64 billion state budget. Mr. Almond, a Republican, rejected the budget last week, saying the state faced a crisis if it did not sell $135 million in bonds by June 30 to offset a deficit. The state's Constitution forbids ending a fiscal year with a budget shortfall. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Senate Debating a U.S. Role In Terror Insurance Coverage
description: The Senate began debate yesterday on insurance legislation that would require the government to pay the vast majority of losses in a terrorist attack, with Democrats and Republicans sharply divided over restrictions on terrorism-related lawsuits.

Martin was an educator for 32 years, and was a member and past president of the Freeport Rotary Club. He was also an Lt. JG in the U.S. Navy during the Korean occupation. Beloved husband of Doris W.B. Smith. Loving father of Deborah A.P. Snyder, Queensbury, NY; Martin P. Smith Jr. and Henry Heller Smith, both of Bolton Landing, NY. Cherished grandfather of Alyssa Mae Post Snyder. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St, Garden City, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Friday. Religious service at The Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, Saturday 11 AM. Interment to follow at Greenfield Cemetery.

title: Keeping a Wary Eye on the E.P.A. at Ground Zero
description: A BURST of knocking and buzzer-pushing goes unrequited, but the scientist-in-residence finally answers her door when a last-ditch telephone summons reminds her that she's got company on the threshold. Marjorie J. Clarke, whose City University of New York doctorate certifies her as an urban environmentalist to be reckoned with -- current target, the Environmental Protection Agency's role at ground zero -- apologizes for ignoring her visitors. She was distracted. Scientists get that way, especially the eccentric ones. Dr. Clarke, who plays guitar in a Moody Blues cover band and moonlights as an unofficial tour photographer for those antique rockers, handily qualifies as eccentric.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Cinnaminson: Bolt Problem Stalls Ride
description: A carnival ride that left 17 people hanging upside down Wednesday night malfunctioned after several bolts were sheared off the ride's rotating mechanism and jammed its gears, state investigators said yesterday. No one was injured because shoulder harnesses kept riders in their seats at the carnival for St. Charles Borromeo Church. The inspectors will try to determine the cause of the malfunction, said E. J. Miranda, a spokesman for the State Department of Community Affairs. The ride will be sent for repairs to the Cleburne, Tex., office of the English manufacturer, Tivoli Manufacturing. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

description: Gov. George E. Pataki and his Republican colleagues in the State Senate today unveiled a bill that is meant to give state and local police some of the same powers in fighting terrorists that federal authorities have.

description: As the first publicly owned golf course to play host to the United States Open, Bethpage State Park takes pride in running what some people are calling the ''people's open.'' The reality, of course, is more complicated.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: State Must Release Documents
description: The Pataki administration must publicly disclose the subpoenas it was served during a district attorney's investigation, the state's highest court ruled. Newsday asked for the subpoenas but the administration refused to turn them over. The Court of Appeals decision stemmed from the Manhattan district attorney's investigation of the state's Empire State Development Corporation and its chairman, Charles A. Gargano. No charges were filed. The agency refused Newsday's request by arguing that the Freedom of Information Law exempts courts from disclosing internal documents, including subpoenas. But the appeals court held unanimously that when the agency received the subpoena, it became a public document. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: In Bell-Bottoms, 70's Autos Crash the Vintage Car Club
description: THEY'RE b-a-a-a-ck. Those cars of the 1970's, whose designers grooved to the beat of the Captain and Tennille and owned harvest-gold appliances and avocado shag carpets, have reappeared.

title: Ruling Favors Church's Homeless Camp
description: A federal appeals court has upheld the right of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Midtown Manhattan to let homeless people sleep on its steps without fear that they will be rousted by the police. The unusually swift ruling, framed in terms of religious freedom, could have national significance, legal experts said.

description: IOWA: COURT REJECTS UNEQUAL GAMBLING TAXES

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Number Of Executions Jumps
description: Amnesty International reported that 213 people were executed in Egypt in the past decade compared with 35 in the previous one. The human rights group's report criticized the 21-year-old emergency law, state security courts and the practice of trying Islamic militants before military tribunals. Sixty-seven militants have been executed since 1992, when President Hosni Mubarak decided they should be tried in the military courts, where sentences cannot be appealed. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: A Gangster Plays 'All About Eve' To Be No. 1
description: The unsettling rhythms of Paul Bettany, David Thewlis and Malcolm McDowell help the crisp, tart and often infuriating British crime film ''Gangster No. 1'' fall squarely into the tradition of British noirs. That is, pictures that are launching pads for actors with the fierce confidence that they can wrap the dialogue around their ring-laden pinkies.

description: After more than a decade of debate in Washington and despite years of heavy lobbying by American companies, a powerful Japanese supercomputer has finally been installed at a United States government-financed research center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, PAUL
description: GOTTLIEB-Paul. Japan Society mourns the passing of Paul Gottlieb, a great friend and mentor who initiated our co-publishing venture of exhibition catalogs on Japanese and East Asian art with Harry N. Abrams, Inc. His efforts did much to bring Asian art into the mainstream of art book publishing, and we appreciate his bold vision to support the expanding field of modern Japanese art as well. We shall miss his passion for art and for life. William Clark, Jr., President Alexandra Munroe, Director Japan Society Gallery

title: Weekends vs. Young Angst (Angst Wins)
description: FOR years, the Wheelwright family had loved being together at their weekend cottage in Columbia County in upstate New York, a 1,500-square-foot comfortably rustic dwelling on 200 acres of rolling countryside. It was a golden age, when the children -- Lily, Josephine and Matt -- liked to swim in a nearby pond, explore the woods and hang out with Mom and Dad.

title: On Basilan, Roads and Wells to Fight Rebels
description: TABIAWAN, the Philippines  On the tiny jungle island of Basilan, success in the fight against terrorism may hinge more on digging wells and building roads than on training Philippine soldiers to shoot straighter and track elusive Muslim militants across rugged terrain.

title: MERITAGE TO BUY THE CLOSELY HELD HAMMONDS HOMES
description: The Meritage Corporation said yesterday that it was buying Hammonds Homes, a closely held home builder, for about $82.8 million in cash. The price includes an undisclosed amount of debt to be paid when the purchase is closed about June 30, said Steven J. Hilton, the co-chief executive. With the acquisition, Meritage, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., expects to sell 3,000 more homes in Texas next year, Mr. Hilton said. Hammonds, based in Dallas, has operations in Houston, Dallas, Fort Worth and Austin, and had $181.1 million in sales in 2001. Hammonds is the second purchase in two months for Meritage, which builds in Arizona, California and Texas.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: PEARL'S WIDOW WON'T HAVE TO TESTIFY A court ruled that the widow of the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl would not be required to testify in the trial of four men accused in his kidnapping and murder. The prosecution had demanded the testimony of the widow, Mariane, after the defense dropped her from its list of witnesses. When the trial resumes on Monday the defense is due to cross-examine the prosecution's final witness, an investigating officer in the case.

title: Extent of Priests' Accountability Debated
description: DALLAS, June 13  As the American bishops struggled to create a national policy to protect children from sexually abusive priests, New York's influential cardinal, Edward M. Egan, suggested today that bishops could still follow their own path.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLANYI, ALICE
description: POLANYI-Alice. Age 90. Of Bolton, Mass. Died peacefully on June 9 after a valliant struggle. Beloved wife of Thomas G. Polanyi, treasured aunt of Ruth Danon of New York City and Livia Polanyi of Palo Alto, Calif. Also survived by her brother-inlaw Michael Polanyi and her grand-nephew Mishka, both of Palo Alto, as well as by her nephew-in-law Gary Buckendorf of New York City. Born in Budapest, she received a Doctorate in Education from the University of Pecs. She emigrated to the United States in 1940. She studied at the University of Chicago and at New York University from which she received a Master's Degree in Social Work. In New York City, she worked at St. Albans Naval Hospital and later, for many years, at Altro Health and Rehabilitation Center. In 1967 she moved to Massachusetts, there she worked at Jewish Family Service and Catholic Charities in Worcester until her retirement. The family will receive callers between 4PM and 7PM on Saturday, June 22 at 105 Vaughn Hill Road, Bolton, Mass. A private memorial service will be held the following day.

title: Whatever Happened to the Recovery Rally?
description: THERE is a recession pattern to the stock market. Prices fall going into a downturn, but turn up before the recession ends and then leap once it is over.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Arrests In Chemical Plant Blast
description: Several top managers of a chemical plant in Toulouse, in southern France, were detained for questioning as the police continued to investigate the explosion that killed 30 people and injured about 2,000 last September. The explosion of ammonium nitrate stocks at the AZF fertilizer plant resulted in the largest industrial accident in Europe in recent decades. It also damaged hundreds of buildings around the AZF chemical fertilizer plant. An experts' report last week said the blast had been an accident and not an act of sabotage, as some originally feared. Among the 11 people under investigation for negligence are the plant manager, deputy manager and safety chief. The factory is owned by TotalFinaElf, the oil and chemical group. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: AMR EXECUTIVE TO BECOME CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER AT AT&T
description: The AT&T Corporation named Thomas W. Horton, the chief financial officer of the AMR Corporation, senior executive vice president and chief financial officer yesterday. Mr. Horton, 41, succeeds Charles H. Noski as chief financial officer. Mr. Noski was named AT&T's vice chairman in February, although in May, he announced his intention to leave the company when its cable unit merges with Comcast. Mr. Noski will continue as vice chairman through the closing of the merger, which is expected by the end of the year. Separately, AMR named Jeffrey C. Campbell, 41, chief financial officer and senior vice president for finance, replacing Mr. Horton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLASS, BILL
description: BLASS-Bill. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of one of the most cherished members of the Library family, Bill Blass. A devoted Trustee, a most generous benefactor, a warm and wise friend, and a sage counselor, Bill Blass embraced with enthusiasm and promoted with flair the Library's role of transmitting the world's cultural record to an ever-expanding audience. As was the case in his business, Mr. Blass did everything at the Library with great personal style, with wit, and with charm. He was a leader in every way-creatively, entrepreneurially, and philanthropically-and in 1994 the Trustees named one of the Library's grandest spaces the Bill Blass Public Catalog Room in honor of his many contributions to the Library and its program. Bill Blass was deeply loved by us all, and he will be greatly missed. Mrs. Vincent Astor, Honorary Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Chairman Andrew Heiskell Elizabeth Rohatyn Marshall Rose Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Increase In Rape Reported
description: Government figures show that the number of reported rapes nationwide is rising rapidly, to 200 last year from 150 the year before. Statistics in Cambodia tend to be unreliable and human rights workers say many rapes go unreported. Chanthol Oung, a leading women's rights advocate, said weak laws, ignorance and a culture of impunity had contributed to the rise. She said 5 percent of the reported rapes had resulted in death and that a number of victims were infected with the virus that causes AIDS.

title: He Knows a Lot, Just Not His Name
description: The fat, plot-stuffed novels of Robert Ludlum are perennially popular among airline passengers. It is not surprising, then, that Doug Liman's adaptation of ''The Bourne Identity,'' Ludlum's 1980 best seller, seems like an ideal selection for in-flight viewing. The story moves swiftly enough to make the time pass pleasantly, and it is not so complicated that you are likely to miss anything if you take a brief nap, wander off to the lavatory or devote your concentration to the difficult task of removing the plastic wrap from your meal.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Alliance Will Acquire Liquid Audio
description: Liquid Audio, a company based in Redwood City, Calif., that makes software for online music distribution, said yesterday that it would be bought by the Alliance Entertainment Corporation, a home entertainment distributor, for about $118.3 million in stock. Alliance distributes video games, compact discs, DVD's and videotapes. The companies hope that the deal will create a major media delivery company with both online and off-line impact. The move comes two weeks after Josh Schechter, a dissident Liquid Audio shareholder who owns a 9 percent stake, called on executives to sell the company after it reported a large drop in revenue. Liquid Audio's first-quarter revenue fell to $135,000 from $1.7 million a year earlier and $768,000 in the fourth quarter. However, another shareholder, Musicmaker.com, which has a 6.9 percent stake in Liquid Audio, criticized the proposed merger in a letter to Gerald W. Kearby, Liquid Audio's chief executive. He described the deal as a ''shotgun wedding.'' Still, Mr. Kearby said that ''the combination with Alliance offers the most significant return of value to Liquid Audio stockholders.'' Shares in Liquid Audio ended the day down 26 cents, or 10.1 percent yesterday, to close at $2.30.

title: LOOKING FOR SUSPECT
description: A spokesman for the German Foreign Ministry said it had requested information from the State Department about the whereabouts of Mohamed Heidar Zammar, a German citizen under investigation for involvement in the Hamburg plot that led to the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. The official said the Foreign Ministry was responding to a report in The Washington Post, which quoted an American counterterrorism official who suggested that American officials knew where Zammar was and that he ''is not walking the streets.'' The German Foreign Ministry said there had not yet been a response from the State Department. Mr. Zammar, who was in Germany at the time of the attacks, left in October for Morocco. Though he was under investigation, German police say that there was insufficient evidence to charge him and that he was issued a one-year passport immediately before his departure. His family in Hamburg has reported him missing and requested information from the Foreign Ministry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODWIN, HENRY SAGE
description: GOODWIN-Henry Sage, 97. Of Avon, Connecticut, died at his home on June 12, 2002. He was born October 14, 1904, in New York City, the second son of Walter L. Goodwin and Elizabeth Sage Goodwin (later Elizabeth Sage Hare). He grew up in Hartford, Connecticut, attending Kingswood School and later Groton School in Massachusetts. He went to Yale University first as an undergraduate and then as a student at the School of Architecture, graduating with an M.F.A. in 1927. A few years later he and his colleague Robert Schutz opened the architectural firm Schutz & Goodwin in Hartford, out of which for the next thirty years, together and separately, they designed many houses, offices, schools and libraries in the Hartford area, most notably the Hartford Public Library, whose innovative design placed it astride a major highway going under Main Street. Goodwin also designed the restoration of the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Connecticut. In 1962, Goodwin retired from the practice of architecture and turned fulltime to his lifelong passion for painting and drawing. Over the next thirty years he produced three illustrated books and hundreds of oil paintings commenting with wit, irony and sometimes romantic nostalgia on various aspects of American life. His paintings have been exhibited in New York, Paris and in the greater Hartford area at such places as the University of Hartford, the Canton Gallery on the Green, the Mattatuck Museum in Waterbury, Connecticut, the Goodspeed Opera House and the New Britain Museum of American Art. Goodwin served in the U.S. Navy in the South Pacific during 1942-45. In Hartford, he served on the Boards of Trustees of the Hartford Conservatory and the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art. He leaves behind two sons, Phillip Manning Goodwin of West Sussex, England, and Rufus Stockton Goodwin of Boston, from his first wife, Anne Stockton (still living). He leaves one daughter, Judith Goodwin Pott, of New York City, from his second wife, Susan Taylor Goodwin (deceased). Also surviving are eight grandchildren, one great-grandchild, two stepdaughters from his second wife, and their families. All of them will miss him deeply and will continue to draw inspiration from his creativity, inner strength, and self-reliance. A Memorial Service will be held at Christ Church Cathedral, corner of Church and Main Streets, Hartford, CT on Friday, June 21, 2002, at 1:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Canton Gallery on the Green, Canton Green, Canton, CT 06019, or to the Connecticut Hospice Inc., 270 Farmington Avenue, Farmington, CT. 06032.

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: Group Says Marijuana Amendment Makes Gains
description: Nevadans for Responsible Law Enforcement, a group seeking to liberalize the state's marijuana laws, said its petition drive to put a constitutional amendment about the issue on the November ballot was going well, but declined to say how many signatures it had gathered. It needs to submit 61,336 by June 18. The amendment would, among other things, let adults possess three ounces of marijuana, impose a tax on marijuana sales and authorize the Legislature to create a distribution system for medical marijuana. Voters would have to approve the amendment this year and in 2004 for it to become part of the state's Constitution. Mindy Sink (NYT)

It's a village, the developers say, not another sea of stucco rising at the urban edge of San Diego.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, DANIEL J.
description: SULLIVAN-Daniel J. Of New Canaan, CT, on June 10, 2002. Born on November 9, 1932, in Brooklyn, N.Y., to Daniel J. and Mary M. Sullivan and formerly of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. and Katonah, N.Y. Beloved father of Kathryn E. Sullivan of Mt. Vernon, N.Y., Margaret A. Egan of Pawling, N.Y., Daniel J. Sullivan of Lexington, MA, Kieran J. Sullivan of Kingston, N.H., and Maura S. Gaughan of Natick, MA. Brother of Francis P. Sullivan of Savannah, GA; grandfather of eight; uncle of numerous nieces and nephews and fiance of Claire O'Gara Grimes of Pound Ridge, N.Y. Predeceased by his parents, by his brother John L. Sullivan, and, in 1982, by his beloved wife of 26 years, Joan M. Sullivan. A 1958 magna cum laude graduate of St. John's University, he was a certified public accountant and devoted his entire career to Price Waterhouse, from which he retired in 1992 after 22 years as a partner. He served for two years in the United States Army, including one year's tour in Japan. He was a member of the Country Club of Darien, The University Club, The New York Athletic Club, The Waccabuc Country Club, and the Senior Men's Club of New Canaan. Calling hours will be Friday, June 14, from 2PM until 5PM and from 7PM until 9PM at Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main Street, New Canaan. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, June 15, at 1 PM, at St. Thomas More Church, 374 Middlesex Road, Darien, CT. Interment will be at Lakeview Cemetery in New Canaan directly from church. A reception will follow at the Country Club of Darien. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to Nativity Preparatory School, 30 Lamartine Street, Jamaica Plain, MA. 02130.

Already qualified for the second round of the World Cup finals, the old champion came out on a crisp, sunny afternoon and enjoyed a romp in the park, with dazzling runs and deft passes and alert shots. It was all so pretty, but Costa Rica was in no position to enjoy it.

description: Taiwan said it received only one bid for 5.7 percent of the Chunghwa Telecom Company, the second time it has failed to generate interest in the company. The government, which owns 95 percent of the company, declined to identify the bidder, saying only that it was a foreign company. Some analysts said the minimum price of 50.80 Taiwan dollars ($1.49) a share was still too expensive given Chunghwa's potential earnings and a slide in phone shares globally. The Ministry of Transport and Communications adjourned the auction until Tuesday, saying it needs time to check the validity of a guarantee given by the bidder.

Over three hours, this ambitious and informative documentary offers a broad survey of the failures of leadership that have contributed to the current crisis, along with the region's legacy of disasters, illusions, occupation, assassinations, corruption and genocide.

But when it comes to larger historical events, such speculations tend to seem frivolous and beside the point. What if, say, the Nazis had won World War II? Well, they didn't, thank heavens. So let's not waste any more time wondering.

description: The central bank of Sweden, the Riksbank, named Lars Heikensten as its governor as Sweden's government paves the way for a possible referendum on the euro next year. Mr. Heikensten, the deputy governor at the bank, will take over for a six-year term starting Jan. 1, 2003. Mr. Heikensten, 51, contradicted government policy in 1999 when he called for the country to drop its currency, the krona, ''as soon as possible.''

title: In New York, A World of Jazz

I've felt pangs of jealousy, for in those places people throng to central spots around outdoor stages, and the city officials are aware that jazz can create revenue. The residents, welcoming the action, line up to see bands they may never have heard of. It's not about phoning Ticketmaster and driving in from the suburbs for a Cultural Event; it's about people coming together where they live. Incredible, no?

title: Songs for All Occasions, But Sparing Ground Zero

To open his concert on Wednesday night at the World Financial Center, he rolled out the bluesy, ultra-materialistic ''It's Money That Matters.'' When the gray sky gave way to rain, he was ready with his anatomy of melancholy, ''I Think It's Going to Rain Today.'' But he had no comment on his proximity to ground zero when he sang a song fans always request: ''Political Science,'' an ironic America-first song that concludes, ''They all hate us anyhow/ Let's drop the big one now.''

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Seeks Clearance On Long Distance
description: Qwest Communications International said yesterday that it had asked the Federal Communications Commission for clearance to re-enter the long-distance phone business in Colorado, Iowa, Nebraska, Idaho and North Dakota, 5 of the 14 Western states in which it is the dominant local phone company. Qwest, which acquired the local phone business when it took over U S West in 2000, is expected to file similar requests for the other states in the region later this year. Like the other regional phone companies spun off from AT&T in 1984, U S West had been barred from offering long distance in its home territory until it could prove to regulators that its local service market was open to competitors. The strike had curbed steel output at the BHP Steel plant and threatened to stop production at Australia's four biggest automakers. BHP Steel said it and the three unions involved reached a labor agreement without providing further details. BHP employs 1,380 people at its Western Port plant.

The river, in the state's Panhandle, is dredged by the Army Corps of Engineers to maintain a channel nine feet deep for the barges that use it. Congress voted last year to spend $4.9 million on removing dredged sand from the banks of the Apalachicola in a bill that also allocates $8 million to continue dredging and other maintenance on the river and its tributaries.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Traffix Lowers Revenue Estimates

Revenue in the year ending Nov. 30 will be $41 million to $46 million, lower than the $49 million to $54 million it previously forecast. Second-quarter revenue fell about 20 percent from the first quarter, Traffix said in a statement. Revenue in the period ended May 31 was hurt by problems with the company's e-mail delivery campaign, Jeffrey Schwartz, the chief executive, said in the statement. Traffix, based in Pearl River, N.Y., also cut forecasts for full-year operating income to $5 million to $6 million, down from the $9.5 million to $10.5 million it previously estimated. Traffix shares fell $1.31, to $3.65.

The man, a 34-year-old computer expert with a record of fraud in Ireland and Switzerland, has been charged with offenses against public health and industrial property, and fraud. Pills confiscated from the man's home near the seaside resort of Malaga contained sildenafil citrate, the active ingredient in Viagra, but were not made by Pfizer, the only company licensed to sell the drug. title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Thai food in New York immediately suggests a tiny dining room, tinier tables and a lunch special for less than $10. The Basil has none of the above. This offshoot of Holy Basil, a popular East Village Thai restaurant, pushes even further toward black-tie Thai, working pan-Asian accents into the mix, turning down the heat and stepping up the elegance of the surroundings. At funky Thai restaurants, you can order iced litchi drinks, a flowery Asian answer to iced tea. At the Basil, the waiter looks confused, but then steers you toward a litchi martini. It's that kind of place.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Complaint About Reagan Airport's Ban On Corporate Jets

The Transportation Department had devised a program to address security concerns, in hopes of allowing corporate jets to resume using the airport. But the department told the association that security officials from other agencies were not satisfied, and that it would wait 30 days to see if the security situation changed. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Research: Study To Develop New Computing Systems
description: The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency has chosen I.B.M., Sun Microsystems, Cray Inc. and SGI to run research programs aimed at developing the next generation of high-performance computing systems, which it expects to fill the gap between today's supercomputers and the expected arrival of quantum computing in 15 or 20 years. Each program will receive about $3 million for an initial one-year study to develop basic concepts and realistic performance measurements. The agency expects the initial studies to be followed by two additional development phases resulting in the deployment of the new computer systems for military needs, starting in 2007. Barnaby Feder (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Closing Statements In Trial
description: Closing statements began yesterday in the seven-week trials of the two men accused of a triple murder above the Carnegie Deli in May 2001. The prosecutor said for the first time that one of the men, Sean Salley, was the lone gunman. Mr. Salley has admitted shooting one of the victims, Jennifer Stahl; he blamed the shooting of her four guests, two of whom died, on his co-defendant, Andre Smith. Mr. Smith's lawyer, Edna Schwartz, maintained yesterday that Mr. Smith had been wrongly accused, and that he made a false confession under duress. Summations are to continue today, and the jury is expected to begin deliberating on Monday. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Kidd's Plans Haven't Changed
description: Jason Kidd went through the end-of-season meetings, then walked through the offices of the Champions Center with his son, T. J., saying his goodbyes for the summer. But Kidd, the team's All-Star point guard, was not rushing out of New Jersey, which could be the first good sign for the Nets' hopes of keeping him beyond next season. Kidd, who can opt out of his contract after next season, has stated that he will test the free agent market. But when asked if New Jersey was starting to feel like home, he said: ''This felt great. ''T. J., Joumana, and the girls, the people have been wonderful to us. So it is like home. It has an Oakland-San Francisco flavor in the sense of living in Oakland, you can always go into the city. Growing up in that type atmosphere has been wonderful for our family.'' He said he would not make the decision on his future home until sometime next year.

Two years before coming to the city, she was gang-raped in her hometown, and about 10 minutes into Takashi Ishii's grim minimalist exercise in sex and brutality, one of her attackers shows up at her door. He threatens to distribute a videotape of the assault and promises that his two accomplices will be along shortly to re-enact it. The residents, welcoming the action, line up to see bands they may never have heard of. It's not about phoning Ticketmaster and driving in from the suburbs for a Cultural Event; it's about people coming together where they live. Incredible, no?

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: HIGHER RATES LIKELY The European Central Bank raised its projection for inflation this year, underlining pessimism about prices that suggests the bank may raise interest rates later this year. In a report, the bank's economists forecast 2002 inflation of 2.1 percent to 2.5 percent, significantly higher than the 1.1 percent to 1.7 percent they had predicted in December. The bank, which sets monetary policy in the 12 countries using the euro, has set itself a goal of keeping inflation at 2 percent or less, a goal that appears increasingly out of reach for this year. (AP)

The loya jirga offered Afghans a chance to overcome the grave defect of the interim administration Mr. Karzai has headed since talks in Bonn six months ago: control of the government by a former Northern Alliance clique of ethnic Tajiks from the thinly populated Panjshir Valley.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: ADOBE POSTS DECLINES IN EARNINGS AND SALES Adobe Systems Inc. , the largest maker of software for publishing and graphic design, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings dropped as sales fell for a fourth straight quarter amid a slump in advertising spending. Net income fell to $54.3 million, or 22 cents a share, from $61.3 million, or 25 cents, a year earlier, Adobe said in a statement. Sales in the period ended May 31 declined 7.8 percent, to $317.4 million. The company said sales in the current period would fall short of forecasts, sending the shares down as much as 4.9 percent. Corporations have scaled back spending on newspaper and magazine advertising to cope with declining profits, crimping business for designers and advertisers that use Adobe's photo-editing software, PhotoShop, and programs like Illustrator. Adobe shares fell as low as $34.41 in after-hours trading after the release of the results and the forecast. The stock fell $1.12, to $36.19, during regular trading hours. Excluding acquisition-related expenses, investment gains and losses and restructuring charges, Adobe said profit last quarter would have been 27 cents a share. On that basis, which does not comply with generally accepted accounting principles, Adobe was expected to earn 25 cents, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. (Bloomberg News)
