But it's an honor that these clichs don't deserve. We expect more from this director, who has almost single-handedly saved the action movie from exhaustion by grafting the yearning heartbeat of classic musicals to the leathery skin of wanton gunplay.

title: Sponsors Assert Soft Money Ban May Be Diluted
description: The ban on unrestricted political donations to the national political parties enacted by Congress earlier this year could soon be significantly weakened by regulators at the Federal Election Commission, the four authors of the legislation say.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Insurer's Bankruptcy
description: An Indonesian court declared the Manulife Financial Corporation's local business bankrupt after a lawsuit brought by the liquidator of a company owned by the Dharmala Group, a one-time partner with Manulife, a Canadian insurer. The court said it declared Manulife bankrupt because the company did not pay Dharmala, with which it had a joint venture, a 22.4 billion rupiah ($2.6 million) dividend in 1999 before Manulife bought Dharmala's stake. Manulife's chief legal counsel for Asia, Mitch New, said in a statement that the decision by the Jakarta Commercial Court was ''upsetting'' and would deter investment in Indonesia.

title: Dancers and Civilians, Take to the Stage!
description: An impressive quotient of the creative elite gathered at the New Victory Theater on Tuesday night for a gala that was a 50th-birthday celebration for the dancer and choreographer Bill T. Jones. It was an evening of warmth and hilarity, even including a dance performed by lawyers, corporate executives and a city councilman, Bill Perkins.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: TAIWAN: ONE BID FOR PHONE COMPANY STAKE Taiwan said it received only one bid for 5.7 percent of the Chunghwa Telecom Company, the second time it has failed to generate interest in the company. The government, which owns 95 percent of the company, declined to identify the bidder, saying only that it was a foreign company. Some analysts said the minimum price of 50.80 Taiwan dollars ($1.49) a share was still too expensive given Chunghwa's potential earnings and a slide in phone shares globally. The Ministry of Transport and Communications adjourned the auction until Tuesday, saying it needs time to check the validity of a guarantee given by the bidder. (Bloomberg News)

title: Bishops Adopt Stricter Policy on Sexual Abuse of Children
description: DALLAS, June 14  Faced with a public outcry over sexual molesters within the church, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops meeting here voted, 239 to 13, to approve a policy that would remove all offenders from parish life but not necessarily from the priesthood.

title: Belgium Blindsides the Russians, Sending Them Home to Moscow
description: SHIZUOKA, Japan, June 14 -- Belgium's "Red Devils" inflicted an excruciating 3-2 defeat today on a complacent Russian team that thought it was riding an easy draw to the next round of the World Cup.

title: Hewlett-Packard Drops Foote, Cone
description: In another blow to Foote, Cone & Belding, the Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that it would eliminate the agency from its roster in consolidating accounts after its acquisition of Compaq Computer.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Pearl's Widow Won't Have To Testify
description: A court ruled that the widow of the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl would not be required to testify in the trial of four men accused in his kidnapping and murder. The prosecution had demanded the testimony of the widow, Marianne, after the defense dropped her from its list of witnesses. When the trial resumes on Monday the defense is due to cross-examine the prosecution's final witness, an investigating officer in the case.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Posts Declines In Earnings And Sales
description: Adobe Systems Inc., the largest maker of software for publishing and graphic design, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings dropped as sales fell for a fourth straight quarter amid a slump in advertising spending. Net income fell to $54.3 million, or 22 cents a share, from $61.3 million, or 25 cents, a year earlier, Adobe said in a statement. Sales in the period ended May 31 declined 7.8 percent, to $317.4 million. The company said sales in the current period would fall short of forecasts, sending the shares down as much as 4.9 percent. Corporations have scaled back spending on newspaper and magazine advertising to cope with declining profits, crimping business for designers and advertisers that use Adobe's photo-editing software, PhotoShop, and programs like Illustrator. Adobe shares fell as low as $34.41 in after-hours trading after the release of the results and the forecast. The stock fell $1.12, to $36.19, during regular trading hours. Excluding acquisition-related expenses, investment gains and losses and restructuring charges, Adobe said profit last quarter would have been 27 cents a share. On that basis, which does not comply with generally accepted accounting principles, Adobe was expected to earn 25 cents, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Westchester Teacher Sentenced
description: A captured fugitive in a decades-old Canadian jet hijacking, who hid in plain sight as a Mount Vernon schoolteacher, has been sentenced to three years in a Canadian prison. The fugitive, Patrick Critton, 54, was arrested and extradited in September in the hijacking of a jetliner in 1971 from Ontario to Cuba. The sentence, announced Wednesday, was reduced by Justice Casey Hill of Ontario Superior Court from five years because of Mr. Critton's lengthy confinement before trial. Mr. Critton had eluded authorities until detectives read about him in a Westchester newspaper, obtained fresh fingerprints from him and matched them to those on a ginger ale can found in the jet 30 years earlier.

description: THE LETTERS

title: Sleep-Deprived Doctors
description: Patients can only welcome the prospect of stricter limits on the number of hours that medical residents will be allowed to work in the nation's teaching hospitals. Nobody wants a bleary-eyed beginning doctor, numb after extraordinarily long hours without rest, to be making critical medical decisions or performing surgical procedures.

title: Log Cabins: From Douglas Fir, an Architect Builds a Place to Fish
description: WHO: Tom Blurock, an architect who lives in Newport Beach, Calif.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer Pleads Guilty In Fraud
description: A suspended Brooklyn police officer pleaded guilty yesterday to participating in a fraud ring that staged auto accidents, then collected more than $1 million in medical insurance payments for fake injuries. The officer, Rodney Hawkins, formerly of the 70th Precinct in Flatbush, said he wrote reports for collisions that never occurred. Mr. Hawkins, 34, pleaded guilty to participating in a conspiracy to defraud insurance companies and defrauding the city of his honest services. Under a plea deal he is to be sentenced to up to 30 months in prison. William Glaberson (NYT)

description: COLE - LEWIS - Jonathan Agabus, fifty, NY, NY, born in Sierra Leone. Funeral Saturday, June 15, 11AM, Rock of Ages Lutheran Church, 5135 Memorial Drive, Stone Mountain, GA. Survived by his daughters, Heather and Yasmin, & their mother, Tina; sisters, Ivy, Winifred, Harolda, and Alice; and many other relatives and friends. title: Wielding Broom, Teacher Attacks Class, Police Say
description: A substitute teacher attacked his first-grade class with a broom handle in Washington Heights yesterday, sending 20 of 27 children in the classroom to the hospital, the authorities said. The children were treated for injuries, including welts and bruises.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: ARRESTS IN CHEMICAL PLANT BLAST Several top managers of a chemical plant in Toulouse, in southern France, were detained for questioning as the police continued to investigate the explosion that killed 30 people and injured about 2,000 last September. The explosion of ammonium nitrate stocks at the AZF fertilizer plant resulted in the largest industrial accident in Europe in recent decades. It also damaged hundreds of buildings around the AZF chemical fertilizer plant. An experts' report last week said the blast had been an accident and not an act of sabotage, as some originally feared. Among the 11 people under investigation for negligence are the plant manager, deputy manager and safety chief. The factory is owned by TotalFinaElf , the oil and chemical group. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RANDOLPH CRUMP
description: MILLER-Randolph Crump, 91. On June 13, 2002. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, brother & uncle. Memorial service June 17 at Trinity Church on the Green, New Haven, 12 Noon.

Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.+ means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.

title: MERCK OFFERS MORE DETAILS ON A UNIT'S STOCK OFFERING
description: Merck & Company said yesterday that its initial public offering for a subsidiary that manages pharmacy benefits would include up to 46.7 million common shares at a price of $22 to $24 each. The unit, Medco Health Solutions, filed for a $1 billion initial offering in April. Merck provided new details in a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Merck is selling a 19.9 percent stake in Medco, which is based in Franklin Lakes, N.J., and manages prescription drug plans for employers. The parent company plans to distribute its remaining 80.1 percent stake in Medco to Merck shareholders.

title: Estes Walking on Eggshells As Clemens Matchup Nears
description: Shawn Estes trudged through the empty visitors' clubhouse at Comiskey Park Wednesday night, towing his suitcase in the wake of another dispiriting defeat.

description: A picture caption in The Arts on Monday with the continuation of a Critic's Notebook article about the possibility that American writers will be allowed to compete for the Booker Prize in Britain referred incorrectly to Martin Amis. While the article cited him as the kind of author who might have a harder time winning the prize if the field included Americans, he has never won it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAVANAUGH, SISTER JOSEPHINE, C.S.J.
description: CAVANAUGH-Sister Josephine, C.S.J., of St. Joseph's College Convent, Brooklyn, NY. Reposing at the Convent, 232 Clinton Ave., Brooklyn. Visitation Saturday and Sunday 2-9PM. Mass of Christian burial on Monday at 10AM in Queen of All Saints Church, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Sisters of St. Joseph, Brentwood, New York 11717-5587.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Steve Bowen, director for business development at Merkley Newman Harty & Partners, New York, was named to the new post of president at the agency's Atlanta subsidiary, Bayless Cronin. Merkley Newman is owned by the Omnicom Group.

title: It's Not a Wrap; There's More
description: As DVD proliferates, some ardent boosters contend that its extra features are adding dimensions to moviemaking by allowing directors a second chance to sharpen and expand on their original films. The director Ron Howard doesn't go quite that far, however. ''I love DVD's, watch them at home, but I don't scan a lot of the extras so I don't have a real sense of it as a medium per se,'' he said this week.

description: A city that calls itself Hockeytown is again on top of the hockey world. By beating the Carolina Hurricanes, 3-1, in Joe Louis Arena tonight, the Detroit Red Wings won the Stanley Cup for the third time in six seasons.

description: On a map, even the daintiest thumb would cover the knob of land and water in a hidden place where the city and suburbia meet, at a wooden footbridge separating the haves from the have-nots.

title: For Wall Street's Sake: Art to Lure Visitors Downtown
description: Will art power help make Wall Street whole again? Julie Menin, a lawyer and former restaurateur whose husband owns the baronial Exchange Building at 25 Broad Street, is banking on it. Spurred by the drop in residents and businesses in the financial district after the Sept. 11 attack, she has created an upbeat organization called Wall Street Rising, which aims to bring new life to the area in part through the restorative spirit of art.

description: Six and a half games. The Mets are six and a half games out of first place. They are six and a half games behind the Atlanta Braves, who just a few weeks ago were being written off as former division champions.

title: CARDINAL HEALTH TO BUY SYNCOR FOR $900 MILLION
description: Cardinal Health Inc., a leading drug wholesaler, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Syncor International Corporation for about $900 million in stock. The purchase, Cardinal's third this year, will make it the leader in sales of radioactive materials that help diagnose cancer and other diseases. Syncor shareholders will receive 0.52 Cardinal share for each outstanding Syncor share, Cardinal said. The offer, valued at $32.42 a share, represents a 15 percent premium over Syncor's closing price Thursday. Cardinal will also assume $202 million in Syncor debt.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced appointments to the city's redistricting commission yesterday, signaling the start of the next major political battle facing the City Council, after the budget.

title: 'Bohme' Rescheduled
description: The Metropolitan Opera performance of ''La Bohme'' that was to have taken place last night in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx, was postponed because of rain. The opera, by Puccini, has been rescheduled for 8 p.m. Sunday. Confirmation of the performance may be obtained by calling (212) 362-6000.

description: The Avista Corporation, the Williams Companies and two other energy traders, threatened by regulators for not cooperating with an investigation of California power prices, stood by claims today that they did not manipulate the state's energy markets.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Gun Law Vote
description: The lower house of Parliament has voted to tighten gun laws, raising the legal age for ownership to 21 from 18, forbidding pump guns and requiring gun buyers under 25 to present certification that they are medically and psychologically fit. The move came after a school massacre on April 26 in the eastern city of Erfurt, where a former student shot and killed 16 people, then himself. The upper house of Parliament is widely expected to ratify the decision. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: WORLDCOM, SEEKING LOANS, INTENDS TO CUT 16,000 JOBS
description: WorldCom Inc., seeking to line up $5 billion in new loans, received $450 million in commitments from its top three banks, executives said yesterday. The chief executive, John Sidgmore, speaking at WorldCom's annual meeting in Clinton, Miss., said the company would cut about 16,000 jobs, or 20 percent of its staff. Some reductions will be by attrition and some involve contractors, Mr. Sidgmore said. WorldCom, with $30 billion in debt, is trying to avoid a credit squeeze. The company needs $5 billion to replace credit lines that expire next month and to repay $4.1 billion in bond debt maturing in 2004. Mr. Sidgmore also plans to sell or shut down a wireless operation, saving $700 million to $800 million annually, and to sell real estate.

title: From Ground Zero, a Bond and a Calling
description: Neither of them can remember exactly how they encountered each other, working in the flaming ruins of the World Trade Center. But Mike Bellone, a Red Cross medic, and Firefighter Bobby Barrett became friends. And, since March, they have been making the rounds of elementary schools in the city and suburbs, trying to bring some reassurance to children who still worry about the terrorist attacks and wonder whether more are on the way.

title: Modern-Dance Troupe Is to Close After 24 Years
description: Donald Byrd/The Group, a modern-dance company that has brought African-American history and culture to new audiences for 24 years, is closing because of financial problems caused by its most ambitious and important undertaking: the transformation of ''The Nutcracker,'' ballet's great Christmas classic, into ''The Harlem Nutcracker.''

description: The judge in the criminal trial of Arthur Andersen ruled today that jurors could find the firm guilty of obstruction of justice even if they could not agree on which of the firm's employees had the intent to commit the crime.

title: ROCKWELL COLLINS WILL ACQUIRE A UNIT FROM ACTERNA
description: Rockwell Collins Inc., a maker of cockpit instruments, agreed to buy the Acterna Corporation's Airshow unit for $160 million to gain electronic-control products for business jet passenger cabins. Airshow, which is based in Tustin, Calif., makes climate, light and video controls. The purchase is to close by Sept. 30. Acterna is based in Germantown, Md.; Rockwell, in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

title: Lead Levels At School Are Linked To Sept. 11
description: Classroom ventilators at Stuyvesant High School in downtown Manhattan have been contaminated with nearly 30 times the federally acceptable level of lead, some of it believed to have come from the collapse of the World Trade Center, tests by the Board of Education have found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLASS, BILL
description: BLASS-Bill. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of one of the most cherished members of the Library family, Bill Blass. A devoted Trustee, a most generous benefactor, a warm and wise friend, and a sage counselor, Bill Blass embraced with enthusiasm and promoted with flair the Library's role of transmitting the world's cultural record to an ever-expanding audience. As was the case in his business, Mr. Blass did everything at the Library with great personal style, with wit, and with charm. He was a leader in every way-creatively, entrepreneurially, and philanthropically-and in 1994 the Trustees named one of the Library's grandest spaces the Bill Blass Public Catalog Room in honor of his many contributions to the Library and its program. Bill Blass was deeply loved by us all, and he will be greatly missed. Mrs. Vincent Astor, Honorary Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Chairman Andrew Heiskell Elizabeth Rohatyn Marshall Rose Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President

description: The disaster could not have come more rapidly or astoundingly. Five minutes. That's all it took for four years of hopeful resurrection of American soccer to lapse into staggering unfulfillment.

description: A couple with six foster and adopted children have been charged with child abuse three months after they were chosen as the Foster Family of the Year by the local chapter of the National Association of Social Workers. The husband, Daniel Vesterfelt, 34, was charged with predatory criminal sexual assault of a child, and his wife, Lisa, 33, was charged with aggravated battery of a child and domestic battery. The department, Ms. Chao said, will appoint a director of compliance assistance and offer small business more information about labor laws through a Web site: www.dol.gov/elaws. Bloomberg's weekly radio program yesterday and criticize remarks he made earlier in the week about Lower Manhattan, remarks in which he said a memorial at ground zero should not be too large.

title: Martin Aronstein, 65, Designer Who Lighted Broadway Shows
description: Martin Aronstein, the five-time Tony Award nominee who was one of the American theater's most prolific lighting designers both on Broadway and beyond, died on May 3 in Van Nuys, Calif. He was 65.

title: Trying to Restore a Faith
description: Yesterday I accepted a request by the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops to become chairman of a special lay commission that will address the crisis of confidence -- and in too many cases, a crisis of faith -- in my church. I undertook this task after much thought and prayer, and only after specific criteria were established defining the powers and goals of the commission. Those goals can be easily summarized: to protect the innocent from abuse and exploitation, and to restore faith in the church and its leadership.

title: COURT APPROVES LIQUIDATION PLAN FOR T.W.A.
description: Trans World Airlines, the bankrupt carrier bought last year by the AMR Corporation, won court approval of its liquidation plan to pay creditors. T.W.A.'s plan calls for the distribution of as much as $270.5 million to some secured and other creditors. Unsecured creditors will receive a share of 3.33 percent of recoveries from property transfers made before the filing. Shareholders will receive nothing.

title: A Hard Day for the Fatherless
description: When I was a small child, Father's Day was an exercise in longing and a gantlet of shame. I can still feel the scald of embarrassment as I sat motionless at my desk at school while the other children crayoned their Father's Day cards. I had been named for my father (Laura for Larry), but I never knew him. I lived with my single mother.

title: City and Bank Agree on Plan To Sift Through 9/11 Debris
description: The search for human remains is under way at the last large building in the World Trade Center area that needs to be examined, city officials said yesterday after reaching an agreement with Deutsche Bank detailing how the city will sift through and remove debris from the bank's 130 Liberty Street building.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Cellphone Subsidies Hurt Vodafone
description: The Japanese unit of the Vodafone Group, J-Phone, has started providing subsidies to retailers for its wireless handsets, reversing a pledge it had made earlier to increase profit by reducing subsidies. The action set off a sharp decline in Vodafone's share price, and Vodafone's stock, which was also under pressure because of selling across the entire telecommunications industry, fell 3.5 pence, or 3.7 percent, to 91 pence a share.

title: Quake Hits Near Nevada Site Proposed for Nuclear Dump
description: A low-intensity earthquake shook the desert floor early yesterday near Yucca Mountain in Nevada, where the government plans to install the nation's first long-term repository for high-level radioactive waste. The authorities reported no damage or injuries.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Tax Increase Advances
description: The state Senate overwhelmingly approved a budget for the 2003 fiscal year that includes $1.2 billion in tax increases. The package raises the tax on cigarettes and capital gains, eliminates deductions for charitable contributions, and freezes the income tax at 5.3 percent. The Senate will work out budget differences with the House before submitting a final plan to Acting Governor Jane Swift. The Senate also voted to allocate $9.6 million for a state fund for candidates who agree to spending and fund-raising limits. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: South Korea Gains Berth In 2nd Round
description: Guus Hiddink, the South Korean team coach, said he was aware that the United States was losing badly to Poland at the half and knew that his team could get into the second round of the World Cup just by tying Portugal tonight. But Hiddink told his players to go for the victory.

title: COMDISCO PLANS SALE OF ASSETS TO PAY CREDITORS
description: Comdisco Inc., a computer service company, said yesterday that it had reached a reorganization plan with its creditors and was planning to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in mid-August. Comdisco, which filed for bankruptcy-law protection from its creditors last July, said the plan called for a three-year sale of the company's remaining assets. The proceeds from the sale, as well as accumulated cash, will enable the company to pay about 90 percent of the creditors' claims, the company said. Under the reorganization plan, common shareholders will receive 3 percent of the remaining net proceeds once creditors have recovered 85 percent. The shareholders could recover up to 37 percent if creditors' claims are paid in full.

title: More Thinking on the Tweed
description: The Tweed Courthouse stands in its freshly cleaned tux, a partygoer robbed of its festivities. Some time ago Mayor Michael Bloomberg halted the plan to move the Museum of the City of New York into the building, a magnificently refurbished structure that stands behind City Hall. He threatens to put the education bureaucracy there instead, sometimes adding that he wants a working school as well. The mayor should consider creative ways to use the Tweed more successfully.

title: Winter's Frustrations Linger On Stubbornly For U.S. Airline Industry
description: Gordon M. Bethune usually struts with enough Texan swagger to stave off the clouds of gloom and doom. He drives a Porsche, rides a Harley and takes spins in the Boeing jets flown by Continental Airlines Inc., which he happens to run.

How the fragile Estes must have hoped that he would not be the Mets starter who would wind up in this delicate situation. The safest place for Estes today would be a cozy seat in the first-base dugout to witness the potential drama.

title: R. W. B. Lewis, Biographer and Critic, Is Dead at 84
description: R. W. B. Lewis, the literary critic and Yale scholar who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1976 for his biography of Edith Wharton, died on Thursday at his home in Bethany, Conn. He was 84.

title: Major Disappointment Looms for Mickelson
description: After sloshing his way through a rain-soaked, three-over-par 73, Phil Mickelson was asked today if he could still win the 102nd United States Open, even though he is eight shots behind the leader, Tiger Woods.

description: DALLAS, June 14 — The rules adopted today by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops to prevent sexual abuse by clergymen could lead to the permanent removal of scores of priests from ministry.

title: MOODY'S DOWNGRADES DEBT OF HEWLETT-PACKARD
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company's debt ratings were cut yesterday by Moody's Investors Service, which said Hewlett, the world's largest personal computer maker, faced challenges in integrating the $18.9 billion purchase of the Compaq Computer Corporation. The downgrade affects $7 billion of debt, Moody's said in a statement. Hewlett-Packard's senior unsecured debt was reduced to A3 from A2. Its short-term rating was cut to Prime-2 from Prime-1. Hewlett-Packard is combining its operations with Compaq's and trying to squeeze out costs in a difficult economic and competitive environment, Moody's said. A spokeswoman for Hewlett-Packard, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., had no comment.

title: Sports of The Times; Water, Water Everywhere, but Not Enough to Stop This Round
description: BEFORE the 102nd United States Open began, the Black Course at Bethpage State Park was considered somewhat different: the only water on it was the pond in front of No. 8, a 210-yard par 3.

title: 'The Perfect Store': The Rise (and Rise) of eBay
description: Utopias don't last. We know that, of course, if only from the American experience of the 19th century, when utopian communities flourished briefly before fading away. And if you think about it in a certain way, we also know it from the more recent history of the Internet. So many of the early user groups, the early computer clubs and the early Web sites began as places where like-minded people could gather -- at least virtually -- to offer one another advice and small talk, support and comfort. So many of them also had an idealized vision of how Internet communities would act: generously, selflessly, honorably. But as these communities grew -- and especially as the Web sites morphed into real businesses -- that early utopian spirit invariably gave way to the harsher realities of both human nature and American commerce. As for what was left, well, a good place to look for that answer is eBay , the Internet's dominant auction site.

title: Federal Election Wrecking Crew

They have gotten the Federal Election Commission, a supposedly independent body that actually dances like a puppet to the tune of the parties it is supposed to regulate, to propose ridiculously elastic rules on the law's execution that open up the very loopholes it explicitly closed. The commission's sneak attack could be approved next week. That must not be allowed to happen.

title: Seeking Atonement in Dallas
description: The conference of Roman Catholic bishops in Dallas demonstrated that the leaders of the American church are at last ready to confront the extraordinary moral and managerial carelessness that allowed so many abusive priests to flourish for so long at such great cost. The conference's president, two prominent Catholic intellectuals and then a parade of actual victims of sexual abuse by priests appeared in succession at the lectern in a dimly lit hotel ballroom. They detailed the horrors of the past and accused the 300 or so assembled bishops of arrogance and irresponsibility almost beyond measure. The bishops listened in mortified silence, some with tears in their eyes, all -- it appeared -- with atonement in their minds.

title: Fear Factor
description: During the maximum jitters of the Cuban missile crisis, the high school where I was an impressionable freshman happened to be holding an assembly. The star speaker was a priest from San Francisco, who arranged to have his remarks interrupted by a student delivering a note. The priest studied the note, then looked up with a somber face and announced that the Soviet Union and the United States had just launched nuclear missiles at each other.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bankruptcies Decline
description: The number of Japanese companies going bankrupt declined last month, but the amount of corporate debt they left behind climbed 6.2 percent from a year earlier, a private credit research firm said. The number of companies that failed in May totaled 1,696, down 1.6 percent from a year earlier, according to the research firm, Teikoku Databank. Failures of manufacturers rose 9.8 percent from a year earlier and made up 18.5 percent of all bankruptcies, indicating that Japan's industrial sector continued to struggle in the face of competition overseas.

title: The Specter of Starvation
description: In southern Africa today, a combination of extended drought, an AIDS epidemic and criminally irresponsible governments has put some 13 million people at risk of starvation over the next few months. In Angola, thousands have already died of hunger. It is up to rich countries, primarily America, the world's largest food donor, to contain this little-noticed emergency.

title: For Indian Troops on Line of Control, Anger Hasn't Subsided

title: World Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Balkans Suspect Arrives
description: A Bosnian Serb linked to a massacre of 200 unarmed prisoners in 1992 arrived at the United Nations prison in The Hague to face charges before the war crimes tribunal. The suspect, Darko Mrdja, 34, was pulled out of his car by NATO-led soldiers on Thursday in the Bosnian Serb town of Prijedor. Prosecutors have accused Mr. Mrdja, a reserve policeman, of participating in the execution of a convoy of prisoners who were ordered off their buses, told to kneel at the edge of a cliff and then shot. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Report Provides New Details Of Soviet Smallpox Accident

title: France's shorter work week turns out to be mixed blessing

title: WITH OUTLOOK WEAK, SPRINT SHARES DROP 18%
description: The Sprint Corporation said customer growth at its wireless unit, the PCS Group, would be 10 percent to 15 percent below forecasts this year. Sprint disclosed the forecast late Thursday and the news set off an 18 percent decline in Sprint's share price yesterday. The company said it would add 300,000 new subscribers in the period ending June 30, compared with analysts' forecasts for 550,000 to 725,000. Sprint attributed the shortfall to more-stringent credit checks and to price cuts by rivals. Sprint also reduced planned capital spending at Sprint PCS by $100 million, to $3.3 billion, and at the FON Group, which includes local and long-distance operations, by $100 million to $2.6 billion. Sprint's stock fell $2.54, to $11.75 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLMSSEN, ULRICH V.
description: SOLMSSEN-Ulrich V., 92. Formerly of Essex Fells, NJ, died on Sunday, June 9, 2002 in Hightstown, NJ. Born in Berlin, Germany, in 1909, he attended MIT as an exchange student in 1932. After receiving his Ph.D in chemistry from the University of Zurich, he returned to the United States in 1938 to pursue his life's career in pharmaceutical research first at Hoffman-LaRoche and then at Warner Lambert. Prior to his retirement in 1972, he served as scientific director of the international division and president of the chemical division. A resident of Essex Fells, NJ for 36 years, he served on the boards of the Essex Fells Public Schools, Montclair-Kimberley Academy, Mountainside Hospital and the NJ Chamber Music Society. Admired and respected by many, he will be greatly missed by his wife of 66 years Tinka Solmssen of Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ; his four daughters: Julie Steedman of York Harbor, ME; Lily Moureaux of New Rochelle, NY; Wendy Sommer of Washington, DC; and Teresa Shartar of Toronto, Canada; nine grandchildren, & one great-granddaughter. He is also survived by his brother, Harold of Muskeegan, MI. Memorial contributions may be made to Lekotek of Georgia, a non-profit organization dedicated to serving the needs of children with special needs and their families. title: Father Time
description: We used to think that the male human being could reproduce almost indefinitely. Look at George Plimpton, now 75 and the father of 7-year-old twins, and at the durable Saul Bellow, who at 84 became a father for the fourth time, with his fifth wife. And then there are those puzzling guys who often turn up on Madison Avenue on weekends -- the ones with the Barbour jackets and the sleek but gray $300 haircuts, and with very young children in tow. They could be grandpops, but in that neighborhood, chances are they're dads working on their second families, maybe even their third. In theory, they could have children younger than their grandchildren.

title: 'Lone Patriot'
description: The enemy took John Pitner, by subterfuge and surprise, on a hot midsummer Saturday when no one could really have been expected to stand and fight, and the result was that John lost his liberty before he had a chance to save America. The date was July 27, 1996, the time was five in the afternoon, and the place was a low, gray, prefabricated house–the prosecutor said "trailer" and the papers "mobile home," but the company that made it said " manufactured home"–hidden in a small riverine clearing in the woods of Whatcom County, Washington, about eighteen miles inland from Bellingham Bay, and not much farther than that from the Canadian border. In Bellingham, at five, people were already shaking off the day–getting into their cars and heading down to the harbor to watch the kayaks come in and then, maybe stop, for a drink and dinner while the sun melted into a pink line over the San Juan Islands. But out in the county, in the tangled scrub and wayward ash woods that a few very old Whatcom loggers could still remember as breathing forest, the air was heavy, and people were sitting around watching reruns, too listless to enjoy the liberty they had. John himself wasn't watching anything. He was thinking about the real estate agent who had called twice to tell him she was on her way, and, of course, he was also thinking about the invasion of the New World Order, wondering whether, given the imminence of the invasion, it was worth his while to put a second coat of gray paint on the wooden deck of a house that was up for sale anyway. John was very concerned about his liberty. He believed that liberty was something God had guaranteed to men like him, men who were Patriots, and that now the New World Order was chipping it away, like the deck paint on his own porch.

title: Air-Conditioner Surcharge in a Co-op
description: Q: I live in a studio apartment in a 200-unit co-op building in Manhattan. Electricity and heating costs have always been included in the maintenance charges, which are billed based upon the number of shares owned. Recently, however, the board instituted a $40 a month per apartment air-conditioning surcharge to make up for the higher electricity costs in the summer months. This fee is added to the maintenance bill from June to September. To some extent the fee is optional since a tenant who chooses not to use an air-conditioner does not have to pay it. The building, however, includes studios, one-bedroom apartments and several multiroom apartments. All tenants who use air-conditioning pay the same fee, no matter how big their apartments are or how many air-conditioning units they have. The surcharge seems to fall unfairly on those who own smaller units with fewer shares and should pay a proportionally lower fee. Can a co-op simply elect to bill electricity surcharges to tenants without regard to the number of shares or the number of air-conditioning units they use? . . . Jon Medwick, Manhattan.

Tough talk, but even experts seemed uncertain how much to care. Start 2 was never more than informally binding because the two nations never ratified identical versions. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEMPF, DR. WILLIAM HEATON, COLONEL, USAR, (RETIRED)
description: SCHEMPF-Dr. William Heaton, Colonel, USAR, (retired), of Cornwall, New York, the thirteenth Teacher of Music, Commander and Conductor Emeritus of the USMA Band at West Point, passed away on Saturday, June 8 in Peekskill. He was 84. He was born in Milwaukee and earned a BM in clarinet from the University of Wisconsin in 1939. From 1939-42, he was a graduate assistant and earned his MM in music theory at the Eastman School of Music. During the summer of 1940, he studied under Koussevitzky at Tanglewood. In 1942-1945, he attended NYU for meteorological training before spending two and onehalf years as a meteorology forecaster in the 8th Army Air Force. After the war, he resumed his studies at the Eastman School. In 1947, he was named Chairman of the Music Department at Lehigh University. During this time, he was selected for conducting workshops with Szell and Ormandy and in 1952, won a Fulbright Scholarship for a year's study in Vienna, Austria. In 1957, he was appointed Teacher of Music at West Point-a position created in 1817 by USMA's founder, Sylvanus Thayer. During his tenure at West Point, 1957-74, the Band was noted for the excellence and vibrancy of their musical programs. The Band frequently appeared at many regional and national events, and they were often joined by distinguished soloists and performers. He was also the conductor of the Cadet Glee Club from 1958-70. In 1960, he completed his PhD in musicology from the Eastman School. He also composed and during his early years at West Point played viola in an amateur string quartet comprised of members of the USMA faculty. In addition to his music interests, he was an Eagle Scout and remained fond of camping, alpine skiing, and sailing. He also built a harpsichord and furniture and was an amateur photographer. He retired from the army in 1974 and became the Chairman of the Music Department at Central Michigan University. Upon his retirement in 1981, he returned to NY & conducted occasionally; he participated annually in the USMA Band's reunion concert held each June. He received the following awards for military service: Air Medal with First Oak Leaf Cluster; American Campaign Medal; EuropeanAfrican-Middle Eastern Campaign Medal; World War II Victory Medal; National Defense Service Medal; Armed Forces Reserve Medal, and the Legion of Merit. He is survived by his wife, Marjorie, two sons, Bryan H. Schempf and Kevin W. Schempf, his daughter Ruthanne, and six grandchildren.

title: June 9-15: NATIONAL; BISHOPS' NEW POLICY
description: At a meeting in Dallas prompted by the pedophilia scandal, America's Roman Catholic bishops adopted a policy on abusive priests: any priest known to have abused a child, no matter when, will not be allowed to dress in clerical garb or say Mass in any public setting, be it in church, school, a nursing home or a hospital. And the bishops, some of whom have been harshly criticized for covering up for predator priests, adopted a broad definition of sexual abuse that includes situations that do not involve force or even physical contact. Catholic reaction included satisfaction, disappointment, and concerns that the measures would pit bishops against priests and that the policy is too harsh for a church built on the concepts of forgiveness and redemption. It is unclear how the bishops' decisions will be received in the Vatican.

title: The Attorney General Goes To War
description: A few years ago, Eliot L. Spitzer, the attorney general of New York and a Democrat, was invited to speak before the Federalist Society, the legal group whose members abhor the use of courts to force political change -- at least liberal political change -- and have helped formulate the key conservative tenet that power should devolve from the central government, including the federal courts, to the states. ''I told them that I had had an epiphany and I was now a fervent Federalist,'' Spitzer said. ''Having won this job as attorney general of a state, this devolution of power was a wonderful thing: they were limiting the feds, they were shifting to us, so we could go off and sue the tobacco companies.'' Spitzer claims that his audience was ''ashen.'' This seems unlikely, but melodrama is so foreign to Spitzer's nature that perhaps he can be permitted this one moment of self-satisfied hyperbole.

title: Who Owns the Recording? At This Label, It's the Artist

title: QUICK BITE/Jersey City; For Name of Delicatessen, See Above
description: Was it destiny, or was I played for a fool? I simply couldn't avoid writing a Quick Bite item about the Quick Bite deli. And yet, I don't think the owners named the establishment just to be noticed by The Times. For on this auto parts/tires-fixed/car wash/body shop stretch of Routes 1 and 9, not many care to linger for more than, well, a quick bite. This deli makes that possible. For the on-the-go traveler, there is the usual assortment of candy, chips, cigarettes, cold-relief products, Krazy Glue and toothbrushes. For those of us with a little more time, there are three booths where you can sit, enjoy a meal and watch the traffic heading north to the George and south to the Holland. Breakfast offerings include hot bagels, omelets, pancakes, French toast and the menu's priciest item, steak and eggs ($6.75). For lunch and dinner, there are hot and cold sandwiches (all served with fries), wraps, soups and salads. I ordered the char-broiled pizza burger deluxe ($3.95). My traveling companion selected the turkey wrap ($4.95, with lettuce, tomatoes, onions, bacon and mayonnaise). The one-man crew took the order, prepared the food, brought it to the table, and kindly asked how everything was. I told him, and I'll tell you: ''Very good.'' The Quick Bite has even made a stab at dcor, with artificial flowers in vases on the tables, artwork on the walls and a couple of hanging plants. And the deli is spacious, perhaps too spacious. Was that a dance floor by the Drakes Cakes? Don't expect the Russian Tea Room; it's more like the Rush-In Tea Room. But for a fast feed, speedy snack or nimble nosh, this new deli is aptly named. Jack Silbert

title: Nuclear Nightmares
description: I, too, grew up during the Cuban missile crisis. I was scared but not helpless or hopeless, which is the way I feel now after reading your terrifying account of the many ways for terrorists to kill thousands and of the warnings that it will happen, but there is nothing we can do about it. The difference then and now is not fear. It's the fact that we, the greatest country in the world, seem defeated without trying. We have the resources to develop a response to this threat. Let us see that our government is in charge and is not just giving us color-coded alerts that give us no sense of control.

title: Amtrak Must Die
description: Before we start on Amtrak, I should confess a longstanding bias. I have been praising trains for as long as I have been speaking. In March 1954, at the age of 11 months, I was on the station platform in Lafayette, Ind., when a train from Chicago suddenly appeared around the bend. The sight and sound of the huge diesel locomotive apparently triggered something in my brain. After my grandmother got off the train, I described her arrival by uttering my first sentence.

title: Securing the Home Front; The New Politics of Antiterrorism
description: To the surprise of many seasoned Washington veterans, Congress has gotten off to a fast start meeting President Bush's goal of creating a new domestic security agency this year. The White House has even had to acknowledge sheepishly that while Mr. Bush was racing around the country urging lawmakers to act immediately, the administration had not yet finished drafting a bill for them to pass. Posturing aside, both parties seem to realize that they cannot go empty-handed before voters anxious about terrorist attacks.

title: Hotel Groups' Web Vow: We'll Beat Any Price
description: In an effort to attract travelers to their Web sites and assure them that the rates found there are the best available, Six Continents Hotels, Starwood Hotels and Resorts, and the Cendant Corporation are pledging to beat any online travel site's lowest rate.

title: Word for Word/Wired; Forget Power, Fame and $3,000 Suits. Give That Man a Sandwich.
description: JOHN J. GOTTI, the telegenic Mafia boss who died of head and neck cancer in federal prison last week at the age of 61, was famously flamboyant, but he had an old-fashioned godfather's aversion to being wiretapped and bugged. ''Don't ever say anything you don't want played back to you someday,'' he warned his Gambino family cronies.

title: Letters
description: Bill Keller's ''Nuclear Nightmares'' riveted readers, prompting many to offer grim thanks for his graphic report. Others accused the article of providing directions for terrorists (in fact, it gave away no secrets). Some were disturbed at people's resignation to the inevitability of an attack.

title: A Head, a Leg, a Flank: A New Kind of Monument
description: FOR 24 years, the British-born sculptor Gillian Jagger, 71, has lived and worked in this small town in the Hudson Valley, near Mohonk Mountain. Respected by her peers and admired by her students, Ms. Jagger, who teaches at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, has kept spacious studios in the old barns of a former dairy farm here, where she makes art that defies easy classification.

title: In Hawaii, Dances to Honor Ancestors
description: Summer is Obon season in Hawaii, when worshipers at dozens of Buddhist temples celebrate their ancestors with bon dances. The free events draw hundreds of residents and visitors who join in Japanese folk dances, sample local fare like shaved ice and saimin (noodle soup), and listen to music played on Japanese flutes and drums.

title: FREEZE ON SCHOOL AID
description: The state Supreme Court last week approved the state's request for a one-year spending freeze on $400 million for court-mandated changes in 30 poor school districts, though financing for full-time kindergarten and half-day preschool programs will be maintained. The court said individual districts could appeal the decision if they can show they will be unable to meet the ''core elements of whole-school reform,'' which include improving curriculum and instruction. Jo Piazza

title: 'This Cold Country'

She liked the thickness of their coats, their efficient sharp teeth, and their stubborn refusal to establish a relationship with their owners, or—as Daisy, and maybe the ferrets themselves, thought of the humans who caged them—their captors.

description: The Kopple documentary coverage of the Hamptons [''Film Can't Be Our Hamptons, Locals Say,'' June 9] was appalling. The frivolous focus on weekenders, group renters, nightclub devotees, the Grubman case and shallow lifestyles proved to be awkward indeed.

title: Body Found in Alley In 3 Separate Bags
description: Sanitation workers cleaning up an alley in Brooklyn known for illegal dumping found a dismembered human body decomposing in three garbage bags, the head and torso in one, the arms in another and the legs in a third, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Hey Dads, Thanks for the Love And Support (and the Credit Card)
description: ALEXANDRA LEBENTHAL knows the rap on the daddy's girl by heart. Spoiled, whiny and manipulative. An over-groomed show dog. She can tick off the classic examples, too. Barbara Hutton and Christina Onassis racing miserably through their fathers' fortunes. Cybill Shepherd's character tearing up the town in ''The Last Picture Show.'' Lizzie Grubman, a portrait in petulance, slamming her father's Mercedes S.U.V. into reverse.

description: IN the late 1970's, when the town of Madison became known as ''the Greenwich of Eastern Connecticut,'' it became a target for developers, and its population rose from 9,800 to 18,200 today, not counting some 6,000 city folks who decamp annually to its beachfront cottages and stately summer homes. Its older, financially secure residents want to retire here in smaller carefree quarters among friends and familiar surroundings.

On the other hand, these teachers are enabling M. to deceive the student body, faculty and M.'s high-school girlfriend. The deceivers had the opportunity to wrestle with the ethics of this decision. The others have to live with the results, unaware that such a decision was made. Whose rights and well-being should take precedence?

She knew because she had cornered half a helpless flock in Woodstown just the day before.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Disabled Children Get to Share in the Summer's Fun
description: At first glance, Camp Hidden Valley appears to be like any of the other four Fresh Air Fund summer camps on Sharpe Reservation in Fishkill, N.Y. Wooden cabins are perched on a hill behind an arts-and-crafts hut where campers ex press themselves creatively. At the bottom of a hiking path through a canopy of trees, boats rest on their bellies along a pond's edge, waiting to be rowed into deeper waters. An open field awaits the first dodge-ball game of the summer.

title: During the Trial, a Few Places Where the Regulars Were New
description: AS the local merchants warily eyed the upcoming Skakel trial, many envisioned Norwalk under siege. They had visions of television trucks clogging narrow streets, overflow parking harming area businesses and a news media horde disrupting daily routines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRUS, GERALD
description: CARRUS-Gerald. The Columbia University Department of Surgery mourns the passing of Gerald Carrus, an outstanding philanthropist and friend. Soon after we established the Department's Surgical Science Division, Mr. Carrus and his wife, Janet, generously endowed the Gerald and Janet Carrus Professorship of Surgical Sciences and of Physiology and Cellular Biophysics in our Department. We are immensely grateful for the Carruses' recognition of the importance of basic research to the advancement of medical practice. Their benefaction will have a lasting impact on scientific and medical progress as we learn more about disease processes and apply this knowledge to patient care. We extend sincere condolences to Janet and the Carrus family. Eric A. Rose, M.D., Chairman Columbia University Department of Surgery Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center New York-Presbyterian Hospital

title: You Earned Your Wings, So Return to the Nest
description: NO matter how you slice it, the trend of returning to the nest after college is not much fun. For four years, you had autonomy, all-night escapades and the chance to run around the world as if you owned it. Then, one June day, your universe collapses like a warped mortarboard. Health insurance disappears. Loans kick in. With no money and no job, you often have no choice but to go home to your parents.

title: The World: 1001 Afghan Nights; Picking Up a Nation's Story Where It Left Off
description: AFGHANS are officially turning to a new page of their history with the loya jirga, or tribal assembly, that began meeting last week in a vast tent on the grounds of Kabul Polytechnic. After the endless pictures of rubble and blasted ruins, of fighters with Kalashnikovs and rocket launchers on their shoulders, suddenly, for the first time in more than 20 years, the country is watching elected representatives debating the election of a new government.

description: To the Editor:

title: 'Beautiful Bodies'
description: She was out, at night, in New York, laughing on the near-empty street, laughing like a crazy person, which perhaps she was. She didn't feel the record-breaking cold; she was wearing an extra mantle. She was afraid to name the feeling, but she recognized it. Only love could warm you like this, lying soft and unseen, like a cape across your shoulders. She felt wrapped in cashmere and wondered for an instant if all the conspicuous consumption of good woolens and fur that she'd just walked past in the brighter lit shopping district of SoHo was an attempt to substitute for this sensation, when it was missing.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Evening Hours column last Sunday about the Whitney Museum's annual dinner to honor corporate contributions to the arts misspelled the surname of the woman shown with Henry A. McKinnell, chairman of Pfizer Inc., and misstated their relationship. She is Joanna Slonecka, not Slopecka, and she is his fiance, not his wife.

title: Habitats/East 12th Street, Near Broadway; Returnees to New York Opt for the Village Life
description: FOR years, Delia Edoga was a lawyer with her own practice in Morristown, N.J., where her husband, John, is a surgeon. But eight years ago, she closed her office and started coming regularly into New York City to study at the Art Students League.

description: EMILY PHILLIPS heard a lot of great stories while she orchestrated the creation of an ambitious ceramic mural here at the Muriel H. Morabito Community Center.

description: High finance and high-level bridge evidently have something in common.

description: Just about the time Herman Edwards should be taking his first real vacation since becoming the Jets' coach, he was taking on something far from relaxing -- a clinic for 200 New York City youngsters in Central Park yesterday, a first for the Jets in the city.

title: Jeter Ends an 0-for-7 Slump Against Benitez
description: When Derek Jeter comes to the plate, every pitcher's name might as well be Meat. If a pitcher has had success against Jeter, Jeter does not think about it, not even to come up with a way to adjust.

title: For House And Garden
description: Cantina Monrubio's 2001 Orvieto Classico shows how a genre that was once carafe fare can be transformed aromatically into a piccolo giardino, a little garden, as an Umbrian would say. This white, drunk lightly cool, is delicious and more complex than its refreshingly citric surface lets on. It could be habit-forming. Spring Street Wine Shop, 187 Spring (Thompson Street), SoHo, asks $10. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Afghan Leader Urges Unity To Build a New Parliament
description: Hamid Karzai, who was selected as interim leader by the traditional grand council gathered here, tried today to reach out to all of the nation's ethnic and regional groups as he asked the delegates to form a National Assembly to work with him.

title: The Field Strikes Back at Woods
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y., June 15  While Sergio Garcia, Phil Mickelson and Jeff Maggert showed their talent and tenacity today, Tiger Woods showed how difficult he was to catch.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Impossible Demands On America's Airlines
description: FEW American industries have to meet the demands that the public makes of the airlines. People want carriers to operate with the reliability of utilities, providing frequent flights on-time, at low cost and with cozy amenities. But the airlines are also supposed to thrive as businesses in a competitive marketplace, earning enough profits to expand their operations and enrich shareholders. This tightrope act has never been easy to pull off, with big carriers taking financial nosedives and customers growing increasingly disgruntled since deregulation in 1978.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENKINS, JULIA HODGES
description: JENKINS-Julia Hodges. We are deeply saddened by the death of our beloved member. title: E-ZPASS WARNINGS
description: A financial analyst for the company that installed the E-ZPass system in the state testified to an Assembly committee last week that he warned state officials that violators' $25 fines would not pay for the system, as the state had projected. Dan Morash, who had been hired by MFS Network Technologies, told the committee that he warned officials in letters and meetings that toll road authorities would have to make up the difference. So far, E-ZPass has spent more to collect fines than the amount of fines collected.

title: A Duet for Clarinets That Echoes Across the Years
description: LARRY and I grew up together in Manhattan, and have been best friends for more than 25 years. In high school, he played the alto saxophone, and I played the clarinet. I eventually talked him into taking up the more serious instrument (the clarinet, of course), and he taught me to love jazz. And so we spent much of our early friendship prowling around the musical life of the city.

''They're a little frisky,'' a technician explains, shooing them back toward their playpen toys. ''It's artificial insemination time, you know.''

title: Larchmont Jewelry Store Features Lesser Known Stones
description: Peridot, a 500-square-foot store in Larchmont, opened in May, but it is named for the lime-colored August birthstone. Owned by Dawn Hendricks, the jewelry store carries a range of contemporary pieces by designers who, Ms. Hendricks said, are ''rediscovering gemstones less traditional than diamonds, emeralds and rubies.'' Prices range from $75 for sterling silver to $5,000 for 22-carat gold jewelry. In renovating the space, which previously housed an antiques store, Ms. Hendricks painted everything white. The goal, she said, ''was to create a palate, so that the store could reflect changes throughout the year.''

description: To the Editor:

title: An Unlikely Clarion Calls for Change
description: THREE years ago, it would have been hard to imagine anything that Henry M. Paulson Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the Goldman Sachs Group, could have done to draw public praise from Jon S. Corzine. Mr. Paulson had just engineered the ouster of Mr. Corzine from the top job at Goldman, one of the nation's biggest investment banks.

title: Citizens, Combatants and the Constitution
description: The Bush administration's legal treatment of American citizens said to be active members of Al Qaeda has been anything but consistent. Two such Americans have been arrested in Afghanistan; one, John Walker Lindh, is being tried in federal court for assisting in the murder of American soldiers, while the other, Yasser Esam Hamdi, is being held by the military and has yet to be charged with a crime. Meanwhile, Jose Padilla, who is the first of these ''Qaeda Americans'' to be apprehended in the United States, was initially detained by the Justice Department, then transferred to a military jail.

title: Norway by Rail
description: To the Editor: Music lovers visiting Bergen might also consider a visit to Troldhaugen (the Hill of the Trolls), five miles south of the city. The site contains the home of Norway's famous composer, Edvard Grieg, where he spent 22 summers, the little garden hut where he composed many of his best-known works, his cliff-hewn tomb, and the Troldsalen, where concerts are given.

title: For a Preacher's Son, Resurrection
description: CURTIS BASHAW is unhurried as he inspects the residue from the first gala weekend at Congress Hall, the dowager of Cape May hotels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOWS, GRACE MARIAN SMITH
description: PLOWS - Grace Marian Smith. With sadness at the loss, yet with thankfulness for the gift of 95 years of life, the family of Grace Marian Smith Plows announces her passing on June 13, 2002. Brooklyn born in 1907, she was an enthusiastic city resident for nine decades before moving to a Stamford, CT, retirement home four years ago. For more than 65 years she pursued her passion for books as a librarian in NYC high schools, at St. John's University, at the Watson Library of the Metropolitan Museum of Art (where she volunteered for more than two decades), and, over the past four years, in the library of the retirement community where she lived. She is survived by her two sons, William and Robert, two grandchildren, Jonathan and Julie, three great - grandchildren, Andrew, Erica and Ronald, and many friends, young and old. A Manhattan memorial service is being planned for later this month. The family prefers that any remembrance be in the form of a charitable contribution to The Metropolitan Museum of ArtGrace Plows Fund, 1000 Fifth Avenue, N.Y., New York 10028. Any such gift will be used to support the Watson Library at the Museum.

title: Giving Hamptons-Bound Travelers a Wave of Options
description: A THRONG of otherwise civilized Manhattanites scrambled for position on a recent Friday as a gleaming green bus came barrelling down East 40th Street. To be near the end of the line might mean sacrificing precious space on the interminable crawl along the Long Island Expressway, and Alex Jakowec of Southampton knows what that can be like.

title: A Bare-Bones Approach To 70's Soul
description: Raphael Saadiq has an oatmeal voice. He has siphoned off a little of Stevie Wonder's elasticity, and his sense of rhythm is unfailingly expert, yet the voice remains indistinct. When he multitracks it into a backing chorus, it's big but still bland. Yet he knows how to work with what he's got; his first solo album, ''Instant Vintage'' (Pookie/MCA), is one long demonstration of mind over matter.

description: ''FAMILY'' at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield has it over most other theme shows, because it has heart. The family is a ubiquitous theme and, naturally, an emotional one. But not all families, happy or unhappy, are alike, and the sprawling Aldrich show bears this out in a wealth of family stories presented from many angles.

title: POSTING: $14 Million Building to Open in Fall 2003; Residence Hall For Adelphi
description: A $14 million residence hall under construction at Adelphi University in Garden City, Long Island, will offer students hotel-like accommodations with private bathrooms and individual climate controls for each room, lounges and laundry facilities on each floor and a large meeting room with terraces on the ground floor. The three-story brick building, which is to hold up to 183 students, will open in the fall of 2003.

description: THE First Union Bank building in Elizabeth and the Summit Opera House in Summit, two historically significant structures in New Jersey that had fallen on hard times, are being given new lives as commercial office space.

description: NEXT February, passengers on one Western Caribbean sailing of the CostaAtlantica are likely to spend more time doing yoga poses and meditation than visiting the disco and the casino.

title: Nuclear Nightmares
description: Wouldn't it be possible to rig all containers entering this country with indestructible plexiglass windows, top and sides? It isn't a perfect solution, and there would still be ways to disguise various shipments, but at least we could get some idea of what's inside the damn things.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBENSKY, HELENA
description: DUBENSKY-Helena. June 14, 2002. Partner in life of Seymour for 57 years, beloved mother of Ken (and Gayle) and Joyce (and Philip). Grandmother of Joshua, Ravital, Laurence and Geremy. Sister of Gladys (deceased) and Leona (deceased). She created beauty in every way. We will miss you forever. Donations may be made to Alzheimers Disease Research, 15825 Shady Grove Road, Rockville, MD 20850-4022.

description: John A. Cella, who oversaw the development of such skin care products as Visible Difference and Millennium for Elizabeth Arden, died on June 8 in San Diego. He was 76.

title: About a Boy Who Isn't
description: By definition, a person anatomically and genetically female who prefers sexual contact with other females is lesbian, despite the fact that M. does not perceive the contact in this way. I consider M.'s girlfriend to be potentially at great risk for emotional trauma once she realizes that she has been involved in a ''lesbian'' relationship. She certainly should not be used to encourage M.'s self-delusional behavior.

description: Jennifer Berger Mason, a daughter of Catherine Berger Mason and John J. Mason, both of Washington, is to be married there today to Stphane Lon Lagonico, the son of Carmela and Pierre Lagonico of Lausanne, Switzerland. Rabbi M. Bruce Lustig is to perform the ceremony at the Washington Hebrew Congregation.

description: Americans aren't the only ones worried about financing their retirement.

description: ARMED with magnifying glasses, reference books and ultraviolet lights, members of the Associated Antique Dealers of New Jersey estimated the value of all manner of unusual objects at a recent appraisal fair.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: In 1884, an English schoolmaster named Edwin A. Abbott wrote a short book called ''Flatland: A Romance of Many Dimensions.'' Although Abbott's academic specialty was classics, not mathematics, he set out to describe what life might be like for creatures who lived in a two-dimensional world. The result is a charming brainteaser that challenges inhabitants of what Abbott called Spaceland -- that is, our three-dimensional world -- to imagine an existence strictly delimited by plane geometry. ''Flatland,'' which is still in print, purports to be the memoirs of A. Square, who has the dubious fortune to spend 24 hours in Spaceland yet cannot convince his 2-D compatriots that reality extends beyond their familiar plane of existence.

title: 3 Witnesses Questioned In Fatal Karachi Car Bombing
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, June 15  Three witnesses were taken into protective custody today and were being questioned about a car bomb explosion that killed at least 11 people outside the American Consulate here on Friday, the police said.

title: Move Over, Pocket Monsters; Here Come the Little Hamsters
description: JAPANESE animation may become even more popular in the United States -- and it's not because of a new ''Pokmon'' television series, video game, feature film or trading card. Earlier this month, Cartoon Network introduced its newest anime character, a curious hamster who has the title role in the weekday series ''Hamtaro.''

title: Beginning a Second Year Of Life Without Father
description: It was Father's Day 2001 and they were all waiting for their husbands to come home. In East Rockaway, N.Y., Mary Fahey was packing up the family's winter clothes. A few miles away, Denise Ford was reading over the boys' cards to Daddy. In Port Jefferson Station, farther east, Anne Downing was fretting over a flooded basement.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, FRANCES BENDER
description: ROSENTHAL-Frances Bender. June 16, 1919-October 10, 1998. Loving wife, mother and grandmother. I miss you a lot.

title: Madrid and Its Airport Are Closer Together
description: A new subway link from central Madrid to Barajas Airport opened last month in a new underground transport hub in the city's financial district at Nuevos Ministerios. The trains, fitted with luggage racks, make the journey in 12 minutes with three stops on the way, compared with the two station changes and more than 30 minutes that were required before.

title: Six in the City
description: BEAUTIFUL BODIES

title: Mason Smith, Allen Custard
description: Ruth Mason Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ware Smith Jr. of Roanoke, Va., was married there last evening to William Allen Custard III, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Custard of Dallas. The Right Rev. Arthur Heath Light, a retired Episcopal bishop of the Diocese of Southwestern Virginia, performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE COLD SIX THOUSAND, by James Ellroy. (Vintage, $15.95.) Everyone's up to something in this sequel to ''American Tabloid'' (1995), which picks up a few minutes after President Kennedy's assassination and continues through to the deaths of Robert Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968. Once again, the tale depicts an America teeming with conspiracy, as it follows three antiheroes who become involved at various times with organized crime, the Ku Klux Klan, the C.I.A., the F.B.I., Howard Hughes and the Mormons. ''The prose is so hard-boiled you could chip a tooth on it,'' Laura Miller wrote here in 2001. ''As uniformly depraved and vicious as the world he depicts may be . . . Ellroy never seems truly cynical because he's so endlessly jazzed by it all.''

title: When the Substitute In Class Is a Parent
description: DEPENDING on your feelings about parents turned loose in a classroom, the Rye city school district's recent plan to recruit and train parents as substitute teachers in the elementary schools could be considered a brilliant solution to the chronic shortage of substitute teachers -- or a potential nightmare that could create more problems than it solves.

title: Sports of The Times; How Golf Has Opened the U.S. Open to Everybody
description: IN the steady rain that soaked Bethpage State Park on Friday, the United States Open golfers kept playing and the galleries kept watching. Unless there's lightning or the greens are flooded, that's what you do at a golf tournament. Whether you're a golfer or a spectator, just put up your umbrella and keep moving.

Republicans were able to muster only 54 of the 60 votes they needed to permanently rescind what they call the death tax, but they promised the issue would live on in Congressional races this fall. title: The Dangers Of Glaring Lighting
description: I read with interest your article ''East Hampton Will Dim Its Street Lights'' [May 26]. I am a doctor of optometry and have always been concerned with the problems of glare that many of my patients encounter while driving at night. For patients with even mild lens changes or early cataracts, the glare caused by poorly designed or misdirected lighting can be extremely dangerous while behind the wheel.

title: Private Sector; Celebrating the Gifted and Black
description: Don King is going from ringside to center stage. The Reverends Jesse Jackson and Al Sharpton will share the spotlight (a feat unto itself). Robert L. Johnson, the founder of BET, will receive lectures from Tavis Smiley, a commentator he fired last year. Berry Gordy will be serenaded by the Temptations he once produced. And Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. will be on hand to lend tips to all on finding new clients.

title: Going Back in Time, Briefly
description: THE ancient sites of the Bay of Naples deserve a couple of weeks, but sometimes all you have is a day to make an excursion from Rome. Since friends often ask me about the wisdom of such a day trip, as well as whether they should take an organized tour, hire a guide or go solo, I decided to try it myself. I traveled alone entirely by rail, starting a little before 7 a.m. at the Colosseo subway station near my home in Rome. I returned 12 hours and 15 minutes later after a most diverting day.

title: For Starters
description: HERE'S a modest proposal: Take every other fast food joint along the New Jersey Turnpike and turn it into an adaptation of Aladin's Restaurant. Lose the boring burgers with American cheese and serve falafel wrapped in pita with tahini sauce instead. Drop the fries; replace those gut expanders with kibbeh balls, delicate spinach pies or stuffed grape leaves. And deep-six the hot dogs; substitute Elie Chedid's delectable kebabs, mild sausage wraps or, for the spice-lovers, the spicy version of sausage called sujok.

title: Questions Remain On D'Amato Courthouse
description: When I saw the Central Islip Federal Courthouse for the first time, I was awed by the beauty of the building. The setting is extraordinary, with a sweeping view of the coastline, and the architecture is truly exceptional. Naming it after former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato [''A D'Amato Courthouse? Some Say No,'' June 2] may be a fair tribute, but the words of Congressman Nadler's spokesman capture my reservations. ''Seeing as Senator D'Amato wasn't evicted from office and didn't serve any jail time or anything like that, and his record is of serving in the Senate for a very long time, naming a courthouse is an appropriate way to honor that,'' the spokesman said.

description: TEVONIAN-Marie, 97, cherished mother of Stephanie, sister Anahid Iskian. Born Turkey, survivor Armenian genocide 1915. Graduated Barnard 1925. Commercial artist; Assistant City College Library. Oldest member Armenian Evangelical Church, NY. A resident of White Plains, she started the movement saving the extraordinary Highland's School lawn. We will all remember her unfailing wit and wisdom.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAWSON, THOMAS DAVID
description: LAWSON - Thomas David. We miss you every minute, but see you every day by watching Justin, Harris and Dylan. The light of your life shines in their eyes. Your legacy lives on through us.

description: KIRSCHNER-Roselyn. 78, of Coconut Creek, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, passed away on June 13th, 2002 after a prolonged illness. She will always be remembered as a paragon of strength, grace, and love. She is survived by her adoring husband, Dr. Stephen A. Kirschner; loving children: Mitchell Kirschner, Susan Shank, Joan Kirschner; cherished grandchildren: Britt, Dara, Jill, Daniel, Tracy, and Eric. Chapel services on Sunday, June 16, 2002 at 12:45 PM, Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, 5808 West Atlantic Avenue, Delray Beach, FL. Interment at Eternal Light Cemetery, Boynton Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, donations to Pancreatic Cancer Action Network.

description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN

title: Still Growing Children in Harlem
description: NED O'GORMAN, hulking as a longshoreman, sits on the stoop of his school, the Ricardo O'Gorman Garden and Center. The school occupies parts of two adjoining town houses on West 129th Street in central Harlem, on a block once known as one of the most drug-infested in the city. These days, many of its brownstones are recently restored and exude tidiness and easy elegance, much like Mr. O'Gorman himself.

title: Honeysuckle Afloat in the Air
description: Never mind roses: at beauty counters, everything's coming up honeysuckle -- the latest star ingredient in perfumes and bath and body products. Le Chevrefeuille, Annick Goutal's limited-edition perfume ($65), sold out within a week at Saks Fifth Avenue last month. A second shipment is in the store.

title: A Prodigal Son Turned Novelist Turns Playwright
description: THE writer Denis Johnson has three homes. The first is a typical suburban town house outside Phoenix, just around the corner from his parents. The second is in Austin, Tex., where his 17-year-old son Daniel is the caretaker. The third is a rugged, often snowy ranch in northern Idaho, where he often finds solace with his wife, Cindy Lee, and his 16-year-old daughter, Lana. He can write, he says, in all three places.

title: A Tooth Fairy's Gift: Freedom From Fear
description: JULIA STOECKERT, a computer technician from Rocky Point, used to get so nervous she felt as though her throat was closing when she had her teeth checked. ''I am really phobic of the dentist,'' Ms. Stoeckert said. ''When I was a kid, the dentists had smelly hands and they hurt me. It was agony to sit there.''

title: June 9-15: ENVIRONMENT; KNOCK KNOCK
description: What is the sound of one woodpecker rapping? Gunfire? In January, searchers in Louisiana thought they heard a series of raps very much like those of the Ivory-billed woodpecker, a glorious bird of Southern hardwood forests that may or may not be extinct. The sounds were also picked up by remote listening devices, all part of an organized search prompted by a possible 1999 sighting. But the Cornell Lab of Ornithology in Ithaca, N.Y., reported that its analysis of digital recordings showed the raps were actually distant gunshots. Next question: Who was shooting? Elvis? James Gorman

title: 'The Double Bond'
description: Italy is the oldest home of Jews in Europe, and Jews are among the oldest continuous inhabitants of Italy. There were Jews in Rome two centuries before Christ: neither Ashkenazim (German and East European Jews) nor Sephardim (Spanish and Portuguese Jews), since neither of these two main families of European Jewry yet existed, but still earlier exiles direct from Palestine, Egypt and Babylonia.

title: The System Broke Down, but the Law Still Prevailed
description: THE justice system broke down completely, but somehow the law prevailed and managed to set things right. This, it seems, is how a jury of six men and six women in State Superior Court convicted Michael C. Skakel of murdering Martha Moxley: They focused on the law and not on the system's failures.

title: Murphy's Law: The Wedding Version
description: JULIA LOMMATZSCH JOHNSON chuckles when she hears what bridal magazines and wedding Web sites consider to be wedding-day ''disasters'': misplaced wedding bands, whiny flower girls, ripped tuxedos, guests who never show. And wedding experts' advice to pack a nuptial ''emergency kit'' of pins, thread, tape, pantyhose, comb and toothbrush brings out an equally bemused response.

title: June 9-15: BUSINESS; DISABILITY RULING
description: The Americans With Disabilities Act does not oblige employers to hire people whose illness or disability presents a direct threat to others in the workplace. The question for the Supreme Court was whether employers can also refuse to hire those whose condition poses a threat to themselves. The answer, in a suit brought by a man whose liver disease made it dangerous for him to be exposed to chemicals at an oil refinery, was yes. The man had been on the job as a contract worker for years; the issue came up when he failed a physical for a full-time job. Linda Greenhouse

title: Down-to-Earth Turkish Food in Lynbrook
description: THE year-old Istanbul Kebab House in Lynbrook serves humble, working-class ethnic food. More earthy than elegant, the walls at this double storefront at 88 Atlantic Avenue (516-596-6800) are festooned with lanterns, hanging carpets, musical instruments, water pipes, Ali Baba-like silver slippers with red pompoms, oversize eating utensils and decorative dishes from the Middle East.
