title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: SOME movies cry out to be seen twice, and MEMENTO (2000) is one of them. This ingenious low-key thriller is the story of Leonard Shelby (Guy Pearce), a recent widower with the worst case of short-term memory loss ever. He's searching for his wife's killer but ever since her murder he can't create new memories. He recalls most of his life, but if you meet him at noon he won't remember you at 1 o'clock. Carrie-Anne Moss and Joe Pantoliano play Leonard's closest associates, who may be helping him or deliberately misleading him. Christopher Nolan wrote and directed -- Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/ Early Sunday at 3:05 a.m. on Starz.

title: Nuclear Nightmares
description: I believe it is far better to have Bill Keller's description (May 26) of the peril and possibility of a nuclear attack on the United States than the persistent, color-coded, curiously timed warnings. The latter threaten to become so much white noise. The former, chilling as it is in its depth and candor, serves the important purpose of informing both public and policy debates. Speaking as a member of Keller's generation, I can say that the Cuban missile crisis and ''On the Beach'' still stand as my twin towers of terror.

title: Alison Foster, Michael Reining

title: 'Think of England'
description: On that night, a Sunday in February, Jane read under the covers with a flashlight, skimming a novel for a page she wanted to read again. Every so often, she closed the book and looked at the cover, where her own name appeared in the title. It was exciting to see it that way, in carved letters. It made the book hers. She had a pen and her notebook with her, too, just in case; she liked to write things down. She was the kind of girl who felt New Year's should be in the fall, at the beginning of school, the kind of girl who begged for chores and saved quarters in a jar to buy a pony. Beneath her nightgown she wore a pair of fresh underpants — she'd spent the night with a girl who put them on before bed and she'd copied the idea. As usual she'd braided her hair to make it look smoother for school. Her brother Sean slept in the other bed, flat on his back with his hands dangling. Their little sister and brother — twins — were in their room down the hall. At nine Jane had begun to want a room of her own. She was writing a book.

title: In Chappaqua, Eating in the Wine Cellar
description: SINCE John Crabtree and his family took over Kittle House 20 years ago, the fine-tuning has never stopped. Not only are the dining areas constantly refreshed, but the kitchen renews itself as well, as Gregory Gilbert, the chef, and Anibal Romero, the dessert chef, take advantage of seasonal markets to add continuing excitment to their dishes.

His compassion, kindness and concern for all will long be remembered. We extend sincere sympathy and condolences to his wife and family. Those fortunate enough to have known this wonderful man will miss him.

title: Nuclear Nightmares
description: Your article makes it clear, between the lines, that our best defense against terrorist attacks is intelligence that will enable us to foil them pre-emptively. This suggests that the overriding objective of our defense and homeland security investments should be to build a best-ever intelligence-gathering and analysis capability. The value of Crusaders, Ospreys and antiballistic-missile defense systems pale in comparison.

title: June 9-15: BUSINESS; ANDERSEN VERDICT
description: After a complex criminal trial that lasted almost six weeks, a Federal District Court jury in Houston yesterday found the Arthur Andersen accounting firm guilty of obstructing justice when thousands of documents about Enron were destroyed last fall. At the time the Securities and Exchange Commission was looking into Enron's finances. The consequences could include $500,000 in fines and S.E.C. proceedings that could leave Andersen barred from auditing publicly traded companies.

title: Mexico Is Familiar Opponent For U.S.
description: After a stunning 3-1 loss to Poland on Friday in the World Cup, the United States can at least regroup on Monday against an opponent that offers familiarity, even a bit of reassurance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEWIRTZ, ABRAHAM J. (JIMMY)
description: GEWIRTZ-Abraham J. (Jimmy), M.D., on June 9, 2002 at age 92. Cherished friend of Carole Newman and her children Jeffrey, William and Cynthia. Dear uncle of Barbara, Dolores, Morty, Michael, George, Bill, Mark, and cousin of Leonard. Interment private. Remembering Jimmy Tuesday, June 18, at the Harmonie Club, 4 E. 60 St., at 4pm.

title: The World as a Cavalcade Patterns, Not Always Pretty
description: WHAT looks at first like a snake is actually an undulating colony of bungalows in a Florida swamp. A splotch of turquoise is really one of the alligator rivers in Australia's Kakadu National Park. Scattered toothpicks turn out to be hundreds of trees that have been stripped from a rain forest and are being floated to market.

title: Garca Feeding On Cheers And Jeers
description: To his fans, Sergio Garca, a 22-year-old Spaniard, is fondly known as El Nio. His detractors dubbed him Waggle Boy during the third round of the 102nd United States Open today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZILBERGELD, BERNARD, PH.D.
description: ZILBERGELD - Bernard, Ph.D. Age 63, renowned psychologist, author, psychotherapist, died on June 12, 2002 at his home in Oakland, CA. due to diabetic complications. He leaves a daughter Claire, his partner Marilynne, a brother George, a sister Hannah, and Ian whom he considered his son. Donations in his memory to The American Diabetic Association.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: GOOD NIGHT, SLEEP TIGHT, DON'T LET THE BEDBUGS BITE! Written and illustrated by Diane deGroat. SeaStar. $15.95. (Ages 5 to 8) Sometimes didactic stories are just what an anxious child getting ready for a camp overnight needs in order to be brave enough to pack a special stuffed animal. Here's another story in the series about Gilbert, the opossum, who is a worrier. He and Lewis, the beaver who claims to be courageous, confront their true fear of getting up and going to the bathroom in the middle of the night.

title: Free Fallin'
description: Parachuting into Panama with the Army's 82nd Airborne Division, the unnamed narrator of Raul Correa's darkly comic first novel, I DON'T KNOW BUT I'VE BEEN TOLD (HarperCollins, $24.95), tells us: ''It was like falling through a painting that you see real and in person. It's too good, too much like everything should be.'' Or maybe it was just the mescaline he and his squad had ingested. These kinds of observations litter Correa's coming-of-age story of a military misfit who enlists for lack of a better choice. Stationed at Fort Bragg, the young paratrooper finds camaraderie among a pack of underachieving ''doper scouts'' and their maverick Platoon Daddy, who keeps a casual eye on his unruly unit. It's 1980 and the book zeroes in on the minutiae of military life in peacetime: reconnaissance exercises, cultivating cool nicknames, meeting women in foreign countries. Correa sandwiches this inside a plot about a loosely sketched, ill-fated scheme to steal arms for a man known only as Mr. Big. The plot unfolds in sporadic flashbacks over the course of one miserable night in New York City 20 years later. His Airborne days behind him, the narrator is again a wounded loner, exploring the city's underbelly in his free time. His only comforts are a copy of ''Huckleberry Finn'' and a letter from Paola, a Panamanian prostitute. The narrator's story feels aimless, and he admits as much: ''My Army stories that surround my Paola story are mostly just about walking around places in the world with a weapon.'' Correa served as a sergeant in the 82nd Airborne, and the glimpses of the languorous side of military life are frank and funny. Some of the dialogue has just the right pitch, balancing innocence and savvy. For Correa's narrator, reminiscing is meant to be cathartic, but the story's stream-of-consciousness style occasionally feels as if it's in a free fall of its own. Ihsan Taylor

title: June 9-15: SCIENCE; COMPANY?
description: Astronomers have been finding planetary systems for seven years, but none quite like ours: the planets orbited too close to their stars or traveled eccentric trajectories. But astronomers looking at 55 Cancri, a Sun-like star 41 light-years away, have detected a massive planet in a near-circular orbit almost the same as Jupiter's. Jupiter's serves as a protective shield against comet impacts, enabling life to flourish on Earth, so the discovery encouraged speculation that an Earth-size planet could exist between Cancri and its Jupiter, and that it might harbor life. John Noble Wilford

title: Sunmi Kim, Richard Lin
description: Dr. Sunmi Kim, a daughter of Suk Hee Min and Myong Kon Kim of Little Neck, Queens, was married last evening to Dr. Richard Lin, a son of Mary Ann and Jonathan Lin of Hollis, Queens. The Rev. Nam Gon Kim, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Swan Club in Roslyn Harbor, N.Y.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-10

title: Clapping and Foot-Stomping in the Classroom
description: PHYLLIS BETHEL stood on a multicolored rug in the Nellie Thornton Elementary School music room in Mount Vernon and clapped her hands. There were soprano claps and bass claps, above-the-head claps and ankle-level claps, claps with knee-slapping and claps with foot-stomping.

title: Fighting for Their Life
description: AS if they were in a ravaged war zone, wounded soldiers climb over the backs of their dead brethren lying scattered in the tall grass. Inside command central, tyranny reigns as the army plots to overthrow its leader.

title: The World; In Mideast Diplomacy, Few Secrets or Solutions
description: THROUGHOUT his presidency, it seems, George W. Bush has tried to impose a lockstep, lockjaw style of government. Secrets are kept; when they are spilled, there are consequences. Press briefings sometimes reveal so little information that they tend to confuse as much as they enlighten. Meetings are small, which helps to minimize leaks.

title: BackTalk; A Young Soccer Player's Dream Ends Unfulfilled
description: Bishop Dike had a lot of potential, everyone said so, but he didn't have a lot of luck. Every time he seemed to be climbing, the ladder gave way. Ten days ago, with his green card and his high school degree in sight, while trying out for a semipro soccer team, he dropped dead. He was 21. He will be buried tomorrow in Philadelphia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, ALBERT J.
description: KAPLAN-Albert J. On June 11, 2002. Beloved husband of Leah. Cherished father of David and Matthew. Devoted brother of Marvin. Adored grandfather of Manda, Noam, Amital and Yaara. His family and friends will miss him dearly.

title: Poquott Files Lawsuit Against LIPA Plant
description: RESIDENTS here gave what they called an ''unhappy birthday party'' last weekend to mark the 55th year of operation of the Long Island Power Authority power plant in nearby Port Jefferson. Armed with balloons and bullhorns, protesters marched along Main Street near the power plant's main gates in hopes of pressuring LIPA to refrain from installing two new 79.9-megawatt generators at the site.

title: Sports of The Times; No Secret Weapons, U.S. Must Wake Up
description: THIS was going to be a special World Cup from the very first night, when Senegal thumped France right smack in the chest. It was going to be a World Cup of fresh faces, and it has been just that, with South Korea and Japan each reaching the knockout round for the first time.

title: June 9-15: ENVIRONMENT; UP IN SMOKE
description: Fueled by high winds and dry conditions, a small, illegal campfire in Pike National Forest quickly grew to the worst wildfire in Colorado history, creeping to within 30 miles of the Denver metropolitan area. More than 100,000 acres were burned in central Colorado as part of an unusually early start to the summer fire season; the increase in home-building in wilderness areas worsened the damage. Firefighters battled at least eight blazes around the state, prompting Gov. Bill Owens to seek federal emergency resources and to ban open fires as well as the sale of fireworks. Michael Janofsky

title: A Prince, a Moor, 2 Lovers and a Scottish Play
description: IT isn't Stratford-Upon-Avon, but come summer Long Island turns into Shakespeare country. This year, six productions by five companies will be performed from Old Westbury to Montauk.

title: What Is It About 'The Women'?
description: EVERYBODY remembers the cat fight. When Sylvia learns that Miriam, a fellow lodge guest in Reno, is the woman Sylvia's husband has been seeing, there is slapping, drink-throwing, kicking and biting. But ''The Women'' -- Clare Boothe Luce's 1936 play revived on the New York stage last fall and taped in January for PBS's ''Stage on Screen'' -- is so much more.

title: McCarron to Retire Next Sunday
description: Chris McCarron, whose mounts have earned more money than any jockey in history, yesterday announced his plans to retire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, JAMES B.
description: GROSSMAN-James B. 31, after a long illness. Son of Martha and Dan Grossman of Short Hills, NJ, brother of Kate, a graduate of Princeton and The Pingry School and a doctoral candidate at Yale, Jim was the most wonderful son and brother any family could have. A service will be held on Sunday, June 16, at 2 PM, at Bernheim - Apter Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ, 973-422-0600.

title: Success Is No Coincidence
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sipping the Gloom, With Hank on the Jukebox
description: OFFICER JACK COLLINS works at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Midtown, a portal to New Jersey, Hell's Kitchen and hell, in no particular order.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Lamborghini Murcilago; A $273,000 Ride to Fantasy Island
description: HERE'S not a lot of room for luggage in the front trunk of a midengine Lamborghini Murcilago, possibly not enough for $273,000 in cash, which is what the car costs, plus several thousand in taxes. But this extreme streamliner with its 575-horsepower engine and racecar soundtrack is a veritable freight train when it comes to hauling psychological baggage.

title: Ventura Turns Tables on Mets
description: Robin Ventura had played this game before, but for the other side. Three years ago, on a rainy October night at Shea Stadium, Ventura hit the ball over the right-center-field wall with the bases loaded in the 15th inning against the Atlanta Braves.

title: Investing; Hotels Are Adjusting to a Travel Slump. Are Their Stocks?
description: BUSINESSES are still cutting back on employee travel, and hotel profits remain weak. Yet some investors say those are signs to buy hotel chains' shares.

title: For Cruise Ships, A History of Pollution
description: ON April 19 the Carnival Corporation pleaded guilty in United States District Court in Miami to criminal charges related to falsifying records of the oil-contaminated bilge water that six of its ships dumped into the sea from 1996 through 2001.

title: Tired Caddies Enjoy the Rub Off the Green
description: Walking the hilly Black Course caused some grumbling among fans and volunteers at the United States Open. But for caddies, who must lug a 50-pound golf bag over the terrain, it has caused some sore backs.

title: Philip K. Dick's Mind-Bending, Film-Inspiring Journeys
description: TO call Philip K. Dick, whose 1954 story ''The Minority Report'' is the basis for the new Steven Spielberg movie, a science-fiction writer is to the underscore the inadequacy of the label. Dick, who died of a stroke in 1982 at 53, was fascinated by the scientific future largely as a vehicle for examining his own anxieties, longings and unstable perceptions. It would be more accurate to call him one of the most valiant psychological explorers of the 20th century.

title: Finding New Steps in Ravel's Dance of Seduction
description: SOMETIMES the dancer Joyce Herring cannot stop herself from rolling her eyes, however discreetly, when she hears of yet another choreographic scheme by her husband, Pascal Rioult.

title: Courtney Geelan, Anthony Belsito
description: Courtney Anne Geelan, a daughter of Mary Ellen and Daniel J. Geelan of East Hampton, N.Y., was married yesterday to Anthony Martin Belsito, a son of Patricia and Peter Belsito of Paxton, Mass. The Rev. Michael Healy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Sacred Heart in Suffern, N.Y.

title: Man Tied to Bomb Suspect Is Arrested
description: Federal authorities said today that agents of a terrorism task force in Florida had detained a man on immigration violations who was believed to be an acquaintance of Jose Padilla, the American citizen being held in military detention on suspicion of plotting attacks in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STOKVIS, JOSEPH WILLIAM
description: STOKVIS - Joseph William. March 15, 1915 to February 15, 1999. Happy Father's Day. Forever missed every day. All our love. Irene, Paul, & Jonathan Land

title: Basement Science Project
description: TUXEDO PARK

title: He's Cool. He Keeps MTV Sizzling. And, Oh Yes, He's 56.
description: IN Tom Freston's world, the beat goes on -- an endless, pulsing, driving rhythm that carries him and everyone who works for him along, like participants in the ultimate dance marathon, all facing the same challenge: Keep up or face elimination.

title: Along the Fringe
description: LONE PATRIOT

title: Country Earthiness in a Stylish Setting
description: ''WHY do you bother remaining anonymous, once you have finished your meals at a restaurant?'' is a question I, as a reviewer, am occasionally asked. The most obvious answer -- ''because a chef or owner often changes and I have to return to review the same place at a later time'' -- came to mind recently when I returned to Spagone Ristorante in Ridgefield.

title: June 9-15; COMING UP
description: On Tuesday, a Senate panel examines steroid use in professional baseball. On Wednesday, Senate subcommittees debate penalties for white collar crimes and restrictions on exports to Cuba.

title: Indians Are a Wanted Team in Interleague Play
description: This is prime rivals weekend, the weekend on the interleague schedule when geographical or otherwise natural rivals play each other.

title: Private Sector; Status Trips on the Wal-Mart Rapids
description: Some companies like to give souvenirs -- duffel bags, paperweights, alarm clocks -- to the Wall Street analysts who cover them. Wal-Mart, the giant retailer that racked up $218 billion in sales last year, prefers to send them down the river.

title: Auditors Recalculate Delaware Dredging
description: WHEN the Army Corps of Engineers agreed to undertake a controversial plan to deepen the Delaware River's shipping channel, it said the project would save about $40 million a year in transportation costs for the region.

title: New Haven Coliseum's Days May Be Limited
description: SOME eyebrows were raised when Gov. John G. Rowland talked so openly recently about closing the New Haven Veterans Memorial Coliseum. The governor mentioned the coliseum while discussing a $13.1 million state grant for the Ninth Square redevelopment project, which is located nearby.

title: Nuclear Nightmares
description: Now that we have been educated about what to expect from terrorists, what can we expect from civil and corporate leaders in the way of planning to minimize the human toll? It is time to begin a dialogue about ways to protect the public, to the extent possible, from nuclear fallout, especially in high-risk areas like New York City.

title: An Alliance Made in Good Times Comes Back to Haunt
description: DURING the fast times at Wall Street High, investors paid little notice to companies' balance sheets and capital structures. Since the world would be ever awash in capital, why worry whether your company had planned for a drought?

title: Where Do Babies Come From?
description: Outside Phnom Penh, along a road running west to Cambodia's more rural provinces, sits an orphanage. It was built on a defunct rice paddy and caters exclusively to Americans wishing to adopt children. To get there, would-be parents travel from the city in air-conditioned cars with hired Cambodian drivers, passing windowless garment factories and the shanty settlements that have grown up to house thousands of workers. They pass legless land-mine victims begging money and old women wheeling carts of coconuts in the stultifying sun.

title: The Sounds of New Jersey. Uh, No, Not Those
description: Move over Bruce Springsteen and Jon Bon Jovi, New Jersey has put out a CD that has hundreds of residents leaping from their (lily) pads to gobble up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERES, JOHN
description: BERES-John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John Beres, associated with The Times since 2000.

title: Jaime Teevan, Alexander Hehmeyer
description: Jaime Brooks Teevan and Alexander Marliave Hehmeyer were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in San Francisco. Judge Wallace A. Douglass of the San Francisco Superior Court officiated.

title: Experts Wary of G.O.P. Drug Plan
description: A Republican plan to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly through private insurers is drawing a skeptical reaction from many health policy experts. The plan, they say, would face problems like those that have plagued Medicare's attempt to encourage the use of health maintenance organizations.

title: Goal Drought Over, England Tops Denmark to Reach the Quarterfinals
description: Under pouring rain, England ended its goal drought, scoring three goals in the first half to knock a stunned Denmark out of the World Cup.

title: The Boys of Summer? No, the Guys of Fall
description: ONE Korean killed 70 million Turks tonight," complained the head of the delegation. No, it wasn't the axis of evil at work: the arch-villain in question was Kim Young Joo, a hapless referee who officiated a World Cup soccer match this month between Brazil and Turkey.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Airport Security
description: To the Editor: In his article, Mr. Wald didn't mention another type of profiling at security checkpoints. In Tweed-New Haven Airport, I saw a muscular guard single out an attractive young woman for the full treatment. She, of course, had to remove the stiletto boots. He, of course, had to pat her down -- thoroughly -- and without warning that the physical contact was coming. He also searched all the pockets of her very tight jeans. I doubt she could have smuggled a credit card, let alone a weapon of mass destruction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOBER, PHYLLIS PRAY
description: BOBER-Phyllis Pray. The College Art Association mourns the loss of its dear friend and colleague Phyllis Bober, Professor Emeritus at Bryn Mawr College and CAA President from 1988 to 1990. Her contributions to the field and her generous and loving nature will be long remembered. Michael Aurbach, President Susan Ball, Executive Director

title: Investing; Gearing Up for Lower Expectations
description: BRYAN HEALY did not begin saving for retirement until the long bull market was well under way. ''Five years ago, your money was growing very quickly,'' Mr. Healy said.

title: Goodnesss Gracious!
description: Donald Rumsfeld is what used to be called a ''man's man.'' He is tough-minded, direct, virile, authoritative and sure of himself. As head of the Cost of Living Council in the early 70's, the designated inflation-fighter kept a tight lid on wages and prices and taught his deputy, a kid named Dick Cheney, how to crack the whip. He ran a tight White House as President Ford's chief of staff and later, in the business world, was named one of the 10 toughest executives by Fortune magazine. He is again secretary of defense, and woe betide the brass hat who tries an end run to lobby for a favored weapon.

title: Small Businesses Fight Eviction Over Port Chester Project
description: A HANDFUL of small businesses is fighting eviction from South Main Street in downtown Port Chester, delaying the construction of a $100 million redevelopment project. The project, the Waterfront at Port Chester, is an attempt to revitalize the village's downtown, now a mix of small and a few high-end businesses. The project, if built entirely, will encompass 27 acres, including a promenade along the Byram River.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, ROBERT ROSWELL
description: PALMER-Robert Roswell, 93. June 11, 2002, in Newtown, PA. Known professionally as R.R. Palmer, he was Dodge Professor of History at Princeton, Professor Emeritus at Yale, and Dean of Arts & Sciences at Washington University in St. Louis. Author of thirteen books, he was best known for his widelyacclaimed text, ''A History of the Modern World'' (1950), now in its 9th edition. His extensive writings, deep knowledge, & dry wit inspired generations of students and colleagues. He is survived by Esther, his wife of 59 years, his children Stanley, Richard & Emily, and 4 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in the fall.

title: Getting to Know Your Cabby, Running in a Privileged Place
description: SUNDAY JEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, PEARL
description: SCHWARTZ-Pearl. Passed away on June 11th, 2002, at Arborview at Willow Valley in Lancaster, PA. She was the adored and adoring wife of the late Nathan, and cherished mother of Ilene and Gloria and son-in-law Robert.

title: Nuclear Nightmares
description: Thank you for balancing ''Nuclear Nightmares'' with the centerfold of United States World Cup hotties (''The Boys of Soccer''). In a post-9/11 world where ''duck and cover'' doesn't cut it, it's important to remember that there are life-affirming ways to achieve meltdown.

title: Bronxville Team Sets Record
description: The Bronxville, N.Y., 4xmile relay team of Kate Ogorzaly, Caroline Mullen, Catha Mullen and Michelle Rorke got the second day of the Adidas Outdoor Championships off to a rousing start today with a national-record-setting triumph at North Carolina State's Paul Derr Track and Field Stadium.

title: Jersey Suite
description: The town of Red Bank, N.J., near the northern Jersey Shore, has become a popular place to shop for antiques, browse in boutiques and enjoy dining out. The contemporary 58-room Oyster Point Hotel, a block from the antiques district, with a small fitness center and a restaurant overlooking the Navesink River, has summer rates through Aug. 31 that include a Continental breakfast served in the room, ranging from $141 a night, double, up to $315 for a suite. Information: (732) 530-8200 or www.mollypitcher-oysterpoint.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, HARRIET MAY
description: WEISS-Harriet May. Beloved mother, grandmother, friend and New York Times Crossword Puzzle Goddess. She had a sweet tooth, a generous heart and the spirit of a warrior. Resilient, loving and beautiful, she was the best listener and will always be part of us.

title: Do Doctors Really Need to Sleep?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Doctrine: Lock 'Em Up
description: PICKING through conflicting evidence last week, the 12 cloistered jurors in Houston trying to decide whether Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm, is guilty of obstruction of justice became the first laboratory in the Bush administration's risky response to the wave of corruption that seems to be engulfing much of corporate America.

title: When Noise Is Too Much To Bear
description: FIONA BAYLY, a Manhattan tenant, recently sent a letter to the Real Estate Q. & A. column asking whether a ''late-night, heavy-drinking, music-blaring party'' between 10 p.m. and 1 a.m. in the courtyard below her apartment would be considered ''unreasonable noise at unreasonable hours.''

title: Liberty Seeks to Settle Old Score With the Sting
description: The last time the Liberty played the Charlotte Sting, the Women's National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference title was at stake and the Sting defeated the Liberty, then the reigning two-time conference champion, in the final minutes.

title: My Father, My Architect
description: When my mother married Charles Gwathmey in 1974, he was already a celebrated architect and something of a superhero. He built buildings and made bold houses rise up from the earth. He did chin-ups from scaffolding and had abs of steel. He drove a dark green Triumph Spitfire convertible and wore jeans to work. I was 10.

title: Looking Back at the Bonfires, Personal and Professional
description: ''APPOINTMENT in Samarra'' by John O'Hara is one of the director Brian De Palma's favorite novels. He often quotes the crucial moment when the central character, Julian English, throws a drink into the face of his boss. This foolhardy act begins a chain of self-destruction that leads to Julian's financial ruin and ultimately his suicide. Unlike Julian, however, Mr. De Palma's survival instincts are as powerful as his self-destructive urges, and his life has been a dramatic duel between those conflicting impulses. His movies reflect his twin desires to please and to rebel.

title: A Woman Walks Into a Bar . . .
description: When is pornography not pornography? What are the standards by which a smutty novel or memoir acquires sufficient gravitas to propel it into the category of literary erotica, or even of the sexy masterpiece? Does the judgment hinge on artistic intention or is it the level of execution? Is there some sort of unspoken system of contextual accounting, some accepted ratio of heady rumination to carnal activity, that redeems, say, a Leopold Bloom or a Humbert Humbert?

title: If the Lawn Is Green, Your Face Is Red
description: LAST September, visions of green grass dancing in his head, Charlie McKenna spent $1,700 on an underground sprinkler system. Six months later, Jim McGreevy declared a drought emergency, making lawn watering -- underground or otherwise -- a highly suspect activity. Not to mention illegal -- at least in Millburn, where Mr. McKenna lives.

title: Both Sides in French Vote Are Battling for Hearts and Minds
description: At just about every stage of France's eight-week electoral contest, voters have been called upon to pass judgment on hefty matters touching the core of how France is governed and the destiny of an increasingly right-wing Europe.

title: More Black Stock Investors
description: The number of higher-income American blacks who are investing in the stock market has jumped sharply in the last five years, according to a new survey.

title: Norway by Rail
description: To the Editor: Bruce Bawer's article, ''One Rail Trip, Many Sides of Norway'' (May 19), brought back memories of the same trip my husband and I took in August 1997. Scandinavia was suffering from a rare heat wave, and the train's air-conditioning (if it had any) was overwhelmed. We were mighty happy to get out at Finse and cool off in the snow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RANDOLPH CRUMP
description: MILLER-Randolph Crump, 91. On June 13, 2002. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, brother & uncle. Memorial service June 17 at Trinity Church on the Green, New Haven, 12 Noon.

title: Biting the Bullet
description: As the host of Colombia's most popular talk show, Claudia Gurisatti had everything at the age of 28 -- fame, fortune, boyfriend, bulletproof car and five bodyguards. Soccer players, rebel commanders and paramilitary leaders, among many others, all answered her questions. But because she lived in a country where ''a question that is not liked is a bullet hole on the head,'' as she puts it, and because she was told to add a bomb-sniffing dog to her entourage, in February the star decided to pack up and move to New York.

title: Do Doctors Really Need to Sleep?
description: To the Editor:

title: Don Giovanni's Servant, Who Would Also Be King
description: AS a rule, opera stars who did a show yesterday will not sing one tonight. But here it was last month, in black and white on the flier for the Staatsoper Unter den Linden: the Italian baritone Lucio Gallo, announced for the title role of Verdi's ''Macbeth'' on a Sunday and as Leporello, manservant and alter ego of the hero in Mozart's ''Don Giovanni,'' on Monday.

title: A Hunger for Fantasy, an Empire to Feed It
description: SO far, this year's two most lucrative summer movies concern the perilous adventures of male teenagers, one in contemporary New York and the other long ago in a galaxy far away, struggling with the moral and physical burdens of their special powers. Over the winter, the box office was dominated by two rather similar young men, one at an English boarding school, the other in the meticulously mapped Anglo-Saxon dreamworld of Middle Earth. Together, these four movies, ''Spider-Man,'' 'Star Wars: Episode II -- Attack of the Clones,'' ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'' and ''The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring,'' have earned more than $1 billion in domestic ticket sales.

title: Spielberg Challenges the Big Fluff of Summer
description: LOOKING around at a summer filled with sequels, special-effects franchises and kiddie fluff, Steven Spielberg decided that there was no better time to release his latest film, ''Minority Report,'' a dark, complex, futuristic whodunit starring one of Hollywood's top stars, Tom Cruise.

title: Fishing That's Far From the Crowds
description: You want shopping? This town's got it, from Coach and Scoop and Entre Nous to Obligato and Cole Haan. But if it's 7:12 a.m. and you're in a ragtop Jeep with a rusted-out undercarriage, towing a 16-foot white boat with a poling platform, and elderly ladies and wailing children in Ralph Lauren Polo are scattering as you drag the squeaking rig through the town parking lot, chances are you're heading, as we were one morning last week, for Dreesen's.

title: Indiana State Museum Triples in Size
description: The Indiana State Museum recently reopened in a new building in White River State Park adjacent to downtown Indianapolis.

title: Confidence in the Economy, But Not the Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Nils Ringertz, 69; Built Online Nobel Museum
description: Dr. Nils R. Ringertz, who helped create a substantial Internet presence for the Nobel Foundation by transforming its outdated Web site into an online museum that includes recorded oral histories, died in his sleep on June 8 at his home in Stockholm. He was 69.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Finding Contentment Away From Contention

title: Turning Blond in Private
description: Less-than-natural blondes who are loath to be seen in public with foil-wrapped heads, can find safe haven at the new John Frieda specialty salon at 30 East 76th Street.

title: Here's to You, Mr. Robinson
description: Perry Robinson is a jazz clarinetist, magician and when not at home in Jersey City, a world traveler. He's put it all down in ''Perry Robinson: The Traveler,'' recently published. Mr. Robinson, 63, grew up in Hollywood, the son of the popular music and film-score composer Earl Robinson. Earl Robinson's friend, Woody Guthrie, spotted young Perry's talent and encouraged him to pursue music. The family moved to New York City, where Perry Robinson grew up to become a leading clarinetist and exponent of the 1960's free jazz movement, recording with Charlie Haden, Carla Bley, Archie Shepp and Dave Brubeck, and outside jazz with, the Fugs, Allen Ginsberg and Bob Dylan. Mr. Robinson was also in the Navy Band, once led a Middle Eastern music group and worked as a professional magician. In his book, written with Florence F. Wetzel, Mr. Robinson tells anecdotes about people like Benny Goodman, Paul Desmond, Sonny Rollins, Chet Baker, Ginger Baker and Mr. Robinson's cousin, the actor Alan Arkin. title: Let Your Fingers Do the Walking
description: How can you resist a book that opens with a two-page color-splashed illustration of an infant's twitching feet and an approaching giant hand, accompanied by the words ''Me papa tickle me feet / he call it 'finger treat' ''? With its singsongy cadences and ebulliently thick brushstroke illustrations, TICKLE, TICKLE (Roaring Brook Press, $14.95; Ages 2 to 5), by Dakari Hru and illustrated by Ken Wilson-Max, manages to turn a father-and-son tickling session into an infectious homage to one of life's simplest pleasures. The playfully scrawled text by Hru, a poet and children's book author who died in 1994 at the age of 42, adopts a baby's-eye view of the world -- He tickle me tummy, me chest, me arm / his fingers fly so wild'' -- where resistance is futile: ''Me twist and swing and laugh and kick / but he hold me anyway.'' Not that either really cares -- Me scream and run (but oh, what fun!) / when papa tickle me feet.'' Wilson-Max's vibrant paintings, rendered in bright primary colors, work well with the book's large format; there's a captivating freshness in the broadly drawn figures -- father, son and mother. The ethnicity of the characters, and the slightly unfamiliar ring of lines like ''He say, 'Come here, little man. You my ticklin' chile,' '' seem entirely inconsequential, which is the point, of course. The message is universal: the pure exuberance coursing through the pages of this charming book is bound to make even the most jaded, bleary-eyed parent smile -- and more than a few fingers start wandering. Scott Veale

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 5 Accused Of Credit Card Fraud
description: Five men have been accused of cheating credit card companies out of more than $1.5 million by running up large bills on credit cards obtained through false information and then immediately filing for bankruptcy. Federal authorities charge that the five bought airline tickets, furnishings and other items, according to the United States attorney's office. One man, Ali Mahd Ayed Qareen, 47, of Fort Lee, is accused of recruiting others into the scheme. He was ordered held without bail on Thursday. Mr. Qareen has a murder charge pending against him in Israel. His public defender did not return a call for comment. The others charged were Qasem Abedrabbo, 35, of Paterson; Sayel Abedrabbo, 38, of Clifton; Soud Almuhtadi, 46, of Clifton; and Labib Elaridi, 49, of Fairview. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRIBBIN, MSGR. THOMAS F.
description: CRIBBIN-Msgr. Thomas F. 85, Associate Executive Director, Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn, June 13, after a short illness. Son of the late Michael and Catherine Cribbin, he is survived by nieces and nephews, Katherine and Donald Barton, Patrick and Micheline St. John and Mary and Stanley Weglikowski; grandnieces and nephews Donald, David and Laura Barton and Kate Louise Weglikowski; and, devoted extended family Bro. Joseph Moloney, OSF and Sr. Bernadette Downes, CIJ. He was ordained to the priesthood on May 30, 1942. Msgr. Cribbin devoted his life to persons with disabilities after picking up sign language as a youngster from a deaf teammate on a neighborhood baseball team. In 1946, he was assigned to Catholic Charities, establishing the Diocesan Apostolate for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing; subsequently serving as Director of the Office of the Handicapped and Associate Executive Director. In 1948, he founded Operation FUN (from the trunk of his car), the first American Catholic summer camp for deaf children which he later expanded to serve the developmentally disabled. A founding member of the International Catholic Deaf Association; the National Catholic Office for Persons with Disabilities; and, presented at the Vatican on Inclusion and Access. A member of the Knights of Columbus since 1936 and chaplain for Brooklyn and Queens. Vice Chair of the NYS Advisory Council to the Advocate for Disabled Persons; the NYC Community Services Board Department Mental Health/Mental Retardation and Alcoholism Services; President of the Interagency Council of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities Agencies, Inc.; and, delegate to the United Nations International Year of Disabled Persons. Responsible for opening Garfield Manor, Builders For Family and Youth, an affiliate agency of Catholic Charities first residence for the developmentally disabled and 17 additional residences. Thomas DeStefano, Executive Director of Catholic Charities remembers a beloved friend and mentor ''who dedicated his life to God whom he saw in each person he met. He lived each day in anticipation of being united with God in the hereafter and now he is where he prepared to be all his life. All of us at Catholic Charities will miss the blessing of his presence.'' Msgr. Cribbin's wake took place at Torregrossa Funeral Home this past Saturday and Sunday. Mass of Transferral was celebrated yesterday at St. James Cathedral. Bishop Thomas Daily will celebrate a funeral Mass, Monday, June 17th, St. James Cathedral, 10:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Catholic Charities Disability Services 718-722-6215.

A Masonic Service will be held on Wednesday, June 19, at 8 PM, at the Dancy Funeral Home in Caldwell, NJ. He shall be fondly remembered by all in Kane Lodge. Thomas W. Brown, Master Paul D. Reitz, Secretary

title: Marion Levy Jr., 83, Authority On the Modernization of Societies
description: Marion J. Levy Jr., a scholar of sociology and international affairs who wrote about modernization theory, which seeks to explain why some societies undergo rapid economic development and corresponding social change, died on May 26 in Princeton, N.J., where he lived. He was 83.

title: Toehold on a Long Trek to Heal India-Pakistan Rift
description: American diplomacy in Pakistan and India this month has produced a tiny victory for each side in the struggle over Kashmir, a toehold on which to proceed. But the car bomb that killed 11 people outside the American Consulate here on Friday made clear that the road to any long-term solution will be difficult and dangerous.

title: Forest Worker Is Held in Fire In Colorado
description: A Forest Service employee who told officials she had angrily burned a letter from her estranged husband was arrested yesterday and charged with setting what has become the largest wildfire in Colorado history.

title: New Economy; A Senate subcommittee hearing amplifies the Internet domain name debate.
description: WITH Congress busy investigating failures within United States intelligence agencies that have national and global consequences, the shortcomings of the organization charged with managing the Internet's address system may seem trivial by comparison.

description: The fact jumped off the page it was printed on after the game, after the Mets turned what was about to become another interleague loss to the Yankees into a 3-2 victory.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Dr. Richard J. Wyatt, chief of the neuropsychiatry branch at the National Institute of Mental Health, referred incompletely to his survivors. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Kay Redfield Jamison of Washington; his sons Christopher, of Washington, and Justin, of New York, and his daughter, Elizabeth, of New York -- all children of his first marriage, to Rollyn Simon Wyatt of Cleveland -- and a sister, Donna Placzankis of Cleveland.

Adored grandmother of C. Griffin Boucher, Ryan Elizabeth Boucher, William W. and Harrison J. Barnwell. Dear friend of Patricia A. Garrett. description: Hubbard Glacier, one of the world's largest, is threatening the economic life of this tiny, predominantly Tlingit fishing village on the southeast Alaskan coast.

title: The Neighbors Meet Again
description: SUWON, South Korea, June 16 -- Serapes and sombreros at the other end of the train. Chants of "May-hee-co! May-hee-co!" A touch of home right here in Korea.

description: Joseph P. Nacchio, the chairman and chief executive of Qwest Communications International, was forced to resign last night by the company's board, executives involved in the decision said.

description: WHEN a reporter asked a Bloomberg adviser recently whether it was really safe to talk confidentially on a cellphone, the official laughed through the static and cracked: ''Better than the bullpen!''

title: France's short work week a mixed blessing
description: VALENCIENNES, France:  At 1:15 p.m., workers at a Toyota plant here finish the early 7-hour shift. Thanks to France's 35-hour work week, "We are going to work less and have more and more hobbies," says Afekir Ahmed, a union leader.

title: Metals May Be Exception in City Plan to Suspend Recycling
description: With the City Council balking at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to suspend the city's program for recycling metal, glass and plastics, officials said yesterday that the mayor had offered a compromise that would keep metal recycling in place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, JANET (SOFORENKO)
description: CANTOR-Janet (Soforenko). Died at home on June 16th in her 102nd year. Born in Fall River, MA. She was a graduate of the Rhode Island School of Design. She was one of the first independent interior decorators in New York. Widow of her beloved Michael, adoring mother of Barbara and Myron Baum, grandmother of Billy and Robin, GG of Michael and Carli. She had great spirit, a generous heart to friends, and friends of friends, and most of all to her beloved family.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Friday about ''Windtalkers,'' based on the history of the Navajos who used their spoken language to deliver coded messages in World War II, misidentified the island where a Native American helped raise the American flag in one of the war's most famous images. It was Iwo Jima, not Okinawa.

title: Drawings Are Still Kicking Nixon Around
description: Richard M. Nixon's most endearing quality was the way his body -- vulture eyes, Pinocchio nose, sweating upper lip, 5 o'clock shadow, hunched shoulders and phlebitis-plagued legs -- always brought him down. Anatomy really did seem to be destiny for him. So it was hard not to pity the man just a little. Even the most hardened Nixon haters could find a soft spot for the poor presidential body. Yes, even in the summer of 1971.

title: Executive Leaves DDB To Join a Havas Unit
description: John Berg is leaving DDB Worldwide, where he had been president at the New York office, to join Euro RSCG MVBMS in New York, also as president.

title: Jeter Hurts Knee But Keeps Playing
description: Derek Jeter despises discussing injuries because he feels that talking about them is making an excuse. Why bother? Jeter can drill a foul ball off his left knee and hobble around in obvious pain in the first inning, as he did last night, and he will tell Joe Torre and the Yankees' trainers that he is fine. No problem.

description: The computerized voice of the National Weather Service is getting a makeover.

title: Mets' Blueprint Finally Works
description: Roberto Alomar was the first one in the receiving line, waiting as Mo Vaughn lowered his head and rounded the bases in the eighth inning last night. Alomar provided a high-five when Vaughn crossed home plate. Mike Piazza waited next. After holding up his arms and clenching Vaughn's palms, Piazza leaned forward and gently butted helmets with him. Piazza smiled for what seemed like the first time in a week.

title: Afghan Council Adjourns in Fray Over How to Elect an Assembly
description: Today's session of Afghanistan's grand council here broke up in disarray, as delegates argued furiously over how to elect a smaller assembly from among their number to serve for the next 18 months.

title: Complex, Spare And Inventive In Ligeti's Flow
description: For the seventh premiere in this season's Diamond Project at the New York City Ballet, Christopher Wheeldon has choreographed ''Morphoses'' to music by Gyorgy Ligeti. It has the same stupefying inventiveness and the same complex movement within a spare style as ''Polyphonia,'' the major work that Mr. Wheeldon created last year to some of Ligeti's piano pieces.

title: A Nation in Search of Its Mission
description: President Bush deserves praise for proposing to create a new architecture for homeland security, a reversal of his earlier position. And he will win acclaim if -- in reversing his previous hands-off stance on the Middle East conflict -- he settles differences within his team and produces a solid plan for that conflict. Too many presidents in the past have stubbornly clung to their ideas, refusing to adjust to changing circumstances and forcing the country to pay a cruel price. Remember Woodrow Wilson? Hoover? L.B.J.?

title: Lilliputians Gaining Stature at Global Extravaganza
description: Despite its reputation as the most popular international sporting event, the World Cup remains a private, exclusive club. In 72 years of this quadrennial tournament, only seven nations have won a championship. The title is akin to a soccer ball kicked around among elite friends.

title: U.S. Group Is Said to Acquire Irish Company
description: Madison Dearborn Partners, a private investment firm in Chicago, has agreed to buy the Jefferson Smurfit Group, an Irish paper and packaging company, for 3.53 billion euros ($3.34 billion), people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEMER, BILL

In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to American Breast Cancer Association or American Diabetes Association. Services 1 PM, today, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: MediaTalk; After a Gloomy Prognosis, a Loss at Random House

To adjust to it, Mr. Olson instituted cost cuts and layoffs at Random House, the largest trade book publisher, that sent ripples of anxiety through authors and agents but left some rivals scratching their heads.

description: The mayor of Beijing ordered all Internet cafes in the city today to shut down temporarily after at least 24 died in an early-morning fire in an unlicensed cafe in the university district.

description: Two agencies are closing offices.

title: Crossing the Hudson
description: For those who want to spend weekends in Manhattan but don't want to look for a parking spot, the Hyatt Regency Jersey City, scheduled to open July 2, will have introductory rates of $99 on weekends (Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights) through Sept. 15. The hotel is a short walk to Manhattan ferries and a 10-minute ride by light rail to the Grove Street PATH station. The 350-room hotel, at 2 Exchange Place, overlooks the Hudson on the Harborside Financial Center south pier. Call (201) 469-1234.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURLANSKY, PHILIP MENDEL
description: KURLANSKY-Philip Mendel, 86. Still a practicing dentist, husband of Roslyn for 60 years, died June 2. Always eager to help anyone in pain, or work for his community, his life, by example, taught the meaning of social responsibility. But the thing of it is this, I loved having a martini with him and talking over world events. I loved his stories with the middle missing-big deal-and though I never learned the meaning of bully - for - you - and - the - Red Sox, nor why he sang driving over the George Washington Bridge, I will always love and miss him and a martini will never taste as good. His son Mark daughter-in-law Marian and grand-daughter Talia

title: Bad Bargain on Clean Air
description: The Bush administration's decision last week to relax air-quality rules governing older coal-fired power plants is exasperating. It would have been one thing if the administration had unveiled its proposals in tandem with a strategy for dealing with the extra air pollution that the rollbacks will inevitably cause. But it offered no such strategy, beyond another vague promise to deliver its much-touted ''Clear Skies'' proposals. In effect, the president has asked the country to trade real health protections now for hypothetical gains later on.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: UNEMPLOYMENT RISES Unemployment jumped sharply in Hong Kong, rising to 7.4 percent for the period from March to May, compared with 7.1 percent from February through April. Construction companies, retail stores, restaurants, export-import businesses and communications enterprises all shed jobs, more than offsetting modest growth in the financial sector. Underemployment, particularly a problem in the construction sector, edged up to 3.1 percent from 3 percent. As Hong Kong's border with the rest of China becomes ever more open, many manufacturing and retail businesses are moving to lower-cost cities nearby. Hong Kong's government warned yesterday that a fresh crop of high school and university graduates now entering the job market could keep unemployment high in the near future.

title: Court Strikes Down Curb on Visits by Jehovah's Witnesses
description: People have the right to go door to door to advocate for religious, political or other noncommercial causes without first getting the government's permission, the Supreme Court ruled today in a lopsided constitutional victory for the ministry of the Jehovah's Witnesses.

title: End of History? For U.S., Only the Beginning
description: It was, simply, the most important victory by a United States men's soccer team. Yet a berth in the quarterfinals can no longer be considered a surprise at a World Cup where history has no meaning, where the unforeseen has become the expected and the unfamiliar is now the everyday.

title: Israeli Forces Raid West Bank After Suicide Bomber Kills 19
description: JERUSALEM, June 18  Slipping through this city's heightened defenses and sharpening its fears, a Palestinian suicide bomber detonated an explosive packed with ball bearings on a crowded city bus during rush hour this morning, killing himself and 19 passengers.

description: Of the three Division I-caliber quarterbacks who live within a golf shot of one another in Bergen County, Chris Olsen was the most likely to stay close to home for college. After all, his mother was fighting breast cancer during his senior season at Wayne Hills High School.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Seeking To Split School By Sex
description: A failing middle school in Philadelphia would be divided into boys and girls' academies under a proposal by Victory Schools Inc., an operator of public schools that is to manage the school in the fall. An executive, Dr. Margaret R. Harrington, said Victory hoped that the move would help the 300 boys and 300 girls at Fitzsimons Middle School focus on schoolwork. The school is one of more than 40 in Philadelphia to be run by outside companies. in the nation's largest experiment in school privatization. Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

description: COLLINS - Frances Fisher. Formerly of Millbrook, NY, died at Hartford, CT, June 15, 2002, age 94. Predeceased by her husband Hugh Gawtry Collins, she is survived by her daughter Anne Flagler Collins, M.D., her sons Dennis Gawtry Collins, Farnham Fisher Collins and Anthony Philip Collins, seven grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. Services will be held at Grace Episcopal Church, Millbrook, NY, Thursday, June 20, at 11 AM.

title: R. R. Palmer, 93, History Text Author, Dies
description: R.R. Palmer, a historian through whose eyes generations of college students have learned to see modern history, died on June 11 at his home in Newtown, Pa. He was 93.

title: The Mets May Be Disciplined For Throwing Behind Clemens
description: Bob Watson, baseball's vice president for discipline, said yesterday that he would probably discipline the Mets for throwing behind the Yankees' Roger Clemens on Saturday.

title: More Than a Kick in Mexican Dips
description: Tourists who venture into areas of Mexico where diarrhea is a problem will do well to avoid more than just the water. They should also watch out for the dips on the tables at many restaurants, a study warned yesterday.

title: Catholic Bishops Take Steps To Enforce Policy on Abuse
description: On the first work day after the American bishops of the Roman Catholic Church adopted a binding policy to bar permanently from ministerial duties any priest who has abused a minor, officials in dioceses across the nation said yesterday that they were taking steps to comply with the new rules.

title: Honoring One Known for Romanticism
description: Robert Helps was an inventive composer whose works found many champions and a superb pianist who promoted other composers' music as avidly as his own. Mr. Helps died at 73 last November, and on Saturday evening a fairly starry assembly of his colleagues and admirers presented a free concert in his honor in the Great Hall at Cooper Union.

title: Path to DiMaggio's Record Is All Uphill
description: Thirty-one is barely halfway to 56, which means Luis Castillo has a long way to go to reach Joe DiMaggio's venerable hitting streak. How long?

title: Bush Administration Says Two Americans Detained in Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The Bush administration disclosed today that two American citizens of Afghan origin were detained in Pakistan last month along the Afghan border, and that one of them was deported to the United States last weekend.

title: Iginla's Dream Season Heads Into Overtime
description: The full name on his birth certificate is Jarome Arthur-Leigh Adekunle Tig Junior Elvis Iginla. Personally and professionally, he goes by Jarome Iginla. It is not yet a household name in the United States, but it is growing in recognition, as is his face. It is a friendly, brown-skinned and marketable face. All these things are important, especially when attached to talent and honor.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: READY TO MATCH AN INDIAN PULLBACK A government spokesman said Pakistan would reciprocate once India starts withdrawing some of its forces from the border in Kashmir, where one million soldiers from both nations are facing off. On Sunday, India announced that for the first time since its buildup began in December it would allow some troops to go on leave. "We will reciprocate that particular gesture," said Aziz Ahmed Khan, Pakistan's foreign ministry spokesman. "I think it's a very desirable thing that should be done immediately."    Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: McDONALD'S SAYS PROFIT WILL RISE THIS QUARTER
description: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that second-quarter profit would rise after six quarterly declines as European sales increased and the euro gained against the dollar. Sales rose 9 percent in Europe, McDonald's second-biggest market after the United States, in the first two months of the quarter, McDonald's said. The euro has gained about 3.7 percent in the past year, helping results when reported in dollars. Profit will be 38 cents or 39 cents a share, compared with 34 cents a year earlier, McDonald's said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected the company to earn 37 cents a share. McDonald's is based in Oak Brook, Ill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLANDER, JESSE
description: ENGLANDER-Jesse. 77. Beloved brother of Rose and Stanley Rich, died on June 17, 2002. He was a 50-year resident of Westport, CT and the owner of Englander Associates, a residential real estate firm. He was a veteran of the Korean War and saw service there. He is survived by his favorite nephew, Jonathan S. Rich, five nieces and their husbands, Deborah Rich and Dana Rhoads, Amy Rich and Jim Ratliff, Sally and Brent Harwood, Melanie and Earl Timothy, Allison and Ron Miller; plus three stepchildren Louise and Jerry Buckley, Susan Desmond, and Richard and Susan Desmond. He is also survived by many great nieces and nephews and step grandchildren. The funeral will be held on Thursday, June 20, at 11:30 AM at Collins Funeral Home, 82 East Ave., Norwalk, CT. The family will sit shivah immediately following the funeral service on Thursday, Friday and Sunday at the home of Rose and Stanley Rich, 739 Catamount Rd, Fairfield, CT. Donations will be appreciated to the American Diabetes Association in lieu of flowers.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Little Egg Harbor Township: Pilot Error Cited
description: The crash of a fighter jet near a freeway in January was attributable to the error of the pilot, who performed some maneuvers inadequately and suffered ''spatial disorientation,'' the Air Force said yesterday. The pilot, Maj. Robert G. McNally, failed to tighten his lap belt, leading to ''an incorrect perception of his position and motion relative to the ground'' as rapid acceleration forces confused him, a report by the Air Combat Command Accident Investigation Board said. Major McNally ejected safely from his F-16C, which costs $19 million, before it crashed in a wooded area. He has resumed flying, but his commanding officer will decide on disciplinary measures. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Suit Over Music-Exchange Site Is Settled
description: The major record companies and a group representing music publishers said yesterday that they had settled a copyright infringement lawsuit against Audiogalaxy, which operates a Web site, Audiogalaxy.com, that lets people exchange music and other files over the Internet. Under the settlement, Audiogalaxy, based in Austin, Tex., has agreed to pay an undisclosed sum of money and to prevent users from exchanging copyrighted files without authorization from the groups that brought the lawsuit, the Recording Industry Association of America and the National Music Publishers' Association. A spokesman for the recording industry group said the settlement did not dictate the technical means that Audiogalaxy must use to prevent unauthorized trading. The spokesman declined to say how much money Audiogalaxy was paying to settle the lawsuit, but he said it was ''substantial'' in relation to Audiogalaxy's assets. The lawsuit was filed in late May in Federal District Court in New York. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Politicians Irk Racetrack
description: A budget battle in Frankfort, the capital, over capping campaign spending is reaching all the way to Churchill Downs in Louisville. Like other institutions that depend on the state, the Louisville racetrack complains that the legislative deadlock will cost it a million-dollar tax break that could affect a renovation needed to keep the track competitive. Francis X. Clines (NYT)

title: In Effort to Change Drug Laws, Some See Too Little Change
description: Neither of the two competing bills intended to soften New York's drug laws tampers with the fundamental legal structure that critics say has led to injustices.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Clothes Catch Up To Books
description: Apparel has joined books atop the list of online shoppers' most popular categories of goods, according to new research from Retail Forward, a consulting company based in Columbus, Ohio. Thirty-two percent of the online shoppers surveyed in May said they had bought clothing and jewelry in the previous 30 days, compared with 36 percent who had bought books. In the last six months, clothing purchases have sometimes outpaced book sales, said Mary Brett Whitfield, a senior vice president at Retail Forward; just 25 percent of online shoppers bought clothing last August. ''Now that apparel has caught up to books,'' she said, ''I think we'll see these two categories jockeying for best-seller position.'' Software and music compact discs were in the second tier of online shopping categories, with 22 percent of consumers choosing those items. Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

title: Cat Food for Aardvarks, and Other Zoo Diets
description: Talk about picky eaters! Koalas will eat only eucalyptus, and only its tender young leaves. Giant pandas, whose diet is 75 percent bamboo, will reject any leaves and stems that have begun to dry out. Duoc langurs, small primates from Vietnam, must be fed five mini-meals a day because their delicate digestive systems are overwhelmed by one or two big meals.

description: The Indonesian police said they had shot dead four separatist rebels and were holding another in connection with the killing of two politicians last week in the war zone in the northern province of Aceh. The police action came as the number of deaths of civilians in the war between the government and the rebels continues to rise. The police blamed the rebels for the two politicians' deaths; the rebels blamed the police. Jane Perlez (NYT)

title: What to Do About Yasir Arafat
description: As the Bush administration prepares a major policy pronouncement on the Middle East, it faces a major dilemma. There is an elephant in the room named Yasir Arafat. The Israeli government wants to drive him away. The Arabs say work with him because no one else in the room matters. The administration seems to be choosing a third approach -- proceed as if the elephant were not there. Even if that sounds hard to imagine, it strikes us as the best of some bad alternatives.

Sustiva is an antiretroviral drug, but not in the protease inhibitor class, a class the study tentatively associated with low birth weight.

title: Agency Delays Official Ruling On Soft Money Contributions
description: Under pressure from lawmakers who have accused them of trying to eviscerate the new campaign-finance law, federal election regulators postponed a decision today about how to interpret a crucial provision designed to eliminate the use of soft money in national elections.

title: How to Split Up the Bipolar F.B.I.
description: When Robert S. Mueller III, director of the F.B.I., testifies this week before the Congressional intelligence committees, one important question will be whether to move counterterrorism operations out of the bureau. The Congressional leaders who favor doing so are right about the need to break up the F.B.I. But its counterterrorism and counterintelligence work should not be shifted, as some have proposed, into the new Department of Homeland Security envisioned in President Bush's bold proposal. They should go instead to a new, separate office, an American version of Britain's domestic intelligence agency, MI5.
