description: To the Editor:

title: Afghan Leader Vows Political Reforms and War on Corruption
description: Afghanistan's newly elected president, Hamid Karzai, laid out his plans for government to the 1,600 delegates of the grand council today, promising to defend them against intimidation and to reform the intelligence service and judicial systems.

title: Death Penalty Reform in the Spotlight
description: Amid intensifying national concern about unfairness and errors in administration of the death penalty, momentum is building on Capitol Hill to reduce the risk of executing innocent people. Today both the House and Senate are to hold hearings on the bipartisan Innocence Protection Act, marking the beginning of a concerted drive by its sponsors to achieve concrete reform before the Congressional session ends.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: THE HAGUE: BOSNIAN SERB PLEADS NOT GUILTY A former Bosnian Serb police commander arrested by NATO forces in Bosnia last Thursday on charges of crimes against humanity pleaded not guilty at the United Nations war crimes tribunal. Drako Mrdja, 34, is accused of taking part in the so-called Vlasic Mountain massacre of Aug. 21, 1992, when Bosnian Muslim prisoners were said to have been lined up on the edge of a cliff and shot or pushed to their deaths by Bosnian Serb police officers. The indictment says 228 people were reported missing after the incident.    Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Letters
description: Questioning `New Kind of Science'

title: Growing Up in the 60's, a Gay Boy Undaunted
description: Growing up gay in the new middle-class suburbs of Long Island in the 1960's was not a tough assignment, if you believe Tony Abatemarco's ''Cologne,'' a one-man play he performs. But for a teenage boy, growing up at all was the same obstacle course everyone else has run.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Some at Wall St. Journal Fear Return to Manhattan
description: Nine months after the attacks on the World Trade Center forced the staff of The Wall Street Journal to flee its nearby offices, the paper's executives say the former newsroom is ready to reopen. But many of the reporters and editors say they are afraid to go home.

title: Staple of Evolutionary Teaching May Not Be Textbook Case
description: A leading example of evolution given in biology textbooks has come unglued, evoking jeers and jubilation in the camp of creationists, who have been trying for years to expel Darwin from the classroom.

title: Footlights
description: Coming Attraction

title: Chicago Firm Plans to Acquire an Irish Conglomerate
description: Madison Dearborn Partners, a Chicago-based private equity firm, has reached an agreement to acquire the Jefferson Smurfit Group, a major global paper and packaging conglomerate based in Ireland, the two companies said today.

title: Federal Workers Recruited to Screen Airline Passengers
description: The Department of Transportation has started to recruit federally employed workers to screen airline passengers and their baggage at four major airports in the Northeast, officials said today.

title: Sports of The Times; Call It Dodgers Lite, But Brooklyn Loves It
description: TWO freshly minted Brooklyn Cyclones, members of this Class A baseball team that is more or less a wisp -- less would be the key word here -- of the late, loved and lamented Dodgers, were in this kaleidoscopic part of the universe for the first time yesterday, and feeling their way.

title: President Quickens Pace As Panels Shift Focus
description: Speeding up its timetable, the White House planned to deliver its legislation for a homeland security department to Congressional leaders on Tuesday, even as the House and Senate intelligence panels turn their focus to the heads of the intelligence agencies most under scrutiny for their response to terrorist threats.

title: Front Row
description: Street Photos of Celebrities

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: U.S. Clears New District Lines, but a Court Blocks Petitions
description: The United States Justice Department today approved New York's new legislative district lines, but a federal court blocked the circulation of candidates' petitions to get on the ballot, which was scheduled to begin Tuesday.

title: Paths for the Church, After Dallas
description: To the Editor:

title: House G.O.P. Offers Bill for Drug Payments for the Elderly
description: House Republicans today displayed a final version of their bill to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly. They promised to secure approval by the full House in 10 days. Democrats objected, saying the elderly needed more extensive coverage.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Pipe Bomb Spurs Station House Evacuation
description: The 115th Precinct station house was evacuated briefly after a woman brought in a pipe bomb and a weapons collection as part of the gun amnesty program, the police said. The woman, 42, whom the police would not identify, went to the station house at 92-15 Northern Boulevard in Jackson Heights around 5:30 p.m. with a bag containing a rifle, a shotgun, a revolver, a silencer, assorted ammunition and a pipe bomb. She told the police that the bag belonged to her estranged husband. The police disabled the bomb and arrested the man, Rafael Peralta, 45, of 33rd Street in Queens. Charges against him were pending last night, the police said.

title: The Chill Extravagance of a Duet's Eroticism
description: Fashion passes, ''Agon'' remains. Forty-four years after its creation, this ballet is as coolly remote and intensely immediate, as crisply assertive and meditative as ever. The iconoclastic masterpiece was the highlight of an all-Balanchine program presented by the New York City Ballet last Tuesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Coors Sounds Fine After Trying Weekend at Shea
description: The Yankees were relieved to shove last weekend's three-day visit to Shea Stadium in the rearview mirror late Sunday night, the always intense series with the Mets that they kept claiming was not about redemption. Of course it was. The Yankees had to know that the animosity the Mets still felt toward Roger Clemens was legitimate.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Friday with an article about two communities joined by a bridge across the New York City line -- Meadowmere in Queens and Meadowmere Park on Long Island -- misstated the name of a road. In Nassau County it is Rockaway Turnpike. It becomes Rockaway Boulevard in Queens.

title: South Korea Stuns Italy in World Cup
description: TAEJON, South Korea, June 18  The great pulsating national celebration goes on. South Korea will play again, after tonight's stunning 2-1 victory over Italy in the round of 16 of the World Cup, setting up a quarterfinal match with Spain in Kwangju on Saturday.

title: The Soviet Smallpox Accident
description: New information about an apparent accident in the former Soviet biological weapons testing program three decades ago has raised some troubling questions about our own nation's ability to protect its citizens against a potential terrorist attack. The open-air test of a Soviet smallpox weapon in 1971 caused a small outbreak of the disease in a port on the Aral Sea, in what is now Kazakhstan, even among people who had been vaccinated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOBRER, JEAN
description: DOBRER-Jean. Dear Jeannie, We love you and miss you. Love, Mom, Dad and Nina.

title: Picture of Health as America Ages
description: Any doubt that the American population is aging can be put to rest by a quick glance at a new report issued by the federal government.

title: Without Twisting Any Arms, Wiseguys Influence Fashion
description: The hoary adage claiming clothes make the man was taken out of mothballs last week as the news media worked up an elegiac frenzy over the death of John J. Gotti, the self-styled Dapper Don. True, the obituaries following Mr. Gotti's death at 61 from head and neck cancer fulfilled their responsibility to inform readers that Mr. Gotti had a long rap sheet of brutal crimes. But the gruesome, and salient, details tended to be buried in the 10th paragraph. It was in the leads that readers encountered the juicier, if less obviously relevant, fact that Mr. Gotti was a snappy dresser. He was a man who favored hand-painted silk ties with matching pocket squares and who had a weakness for handmade shoes and $2,000 (or was it $3,000, or $4,000?) Brioni suits.

title: National Briefing: Science And Health
description: SHUTTLE EXTENDS STAY The space shuttle Endeavour and seven astronauts circled Earth in an orbital holding pattern after thunderstorms led them to cancel a landing at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Fla. The shuttle is to try again today, but stormy weather in central Florida and high winds at a backup site in California could force another postponement. The Endeavour is returning from a mission to the International Space Station. Its crew includes two astronauts who have been in space for 194 days, an American record. Todd Halvorson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Go Fly Takeover Approved
description: Shareholders of EasyJet approved the purchase of Go Fly Ltd. from 3i Group for 374 million ($552 million) to overtake Ryanair Holdings as Europe's largest low-fare airline.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Organizing To Sell Ads
description: Five online publishers are forming a group, the At-Work Brand Network, to encourage marketers to buy advertising space on their Web sites in addition to the ad space they buy on big portals like CNN.com and MSNBC.com. The network has its first advertiser, AT& T Wireless, which is making a four-week, $1 million ad purchase for a campaign from its interactive agencies, White Horse and the Avenue A division of Avenue A. The network was organized by CBS MarketWatch in San Francisco, part of Viacom, which will coordinate its efforts; the other members are CNET Networks; NYTimes.com, part of The New York Times Company; USAToday.com, part of the USA Today unit of the Gannett Company; and weather.com, the Web site of the Weather Channel, owned by Landmark Communications. Stuart Elliott (NYT)

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: DROPPING QUAKE INSURANCE Facing major budget deficits and skyrocketing premiums for earthquake insurance, two transit agencies in the Bay Area are taking their chances rather than pay for coverage. Officials with the agencies, Caltrain and the Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority, said that they had suffered little damage in recent earthquakes and that deductibles were so high they would face significant payments, anyway.   Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Articles on June 10, 13 and 14 about the investigation of the abduction of Elizabeth Ann Smart in Salt Lake City misstated the date of her disappearance from her home. It was June 5, not 6.

title: Juilliard Student Is Winner of Piano 'E-Competition'
description: The first International Piano-e-Competition, which gained attention as the first such event to use a remote judge -- Yefim Bronfman, who heard a final round of the competition from a studio in Japan on a Yahama Disklavier Pro concert grand piano -- concluded on Sunday night, when the winners were announced at Orchestra Hall in Minneapolis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURITZ, ZITHA R.
description: TURITZ-Zitha R. June 5, 2002, Berkeley, CA. Born Dorchester, MA, 1907. Mother, wife, social worker. Lived in Manhattan; Sunnyside, Queens; Tenafly, NJ; White Plains, NY. Graduated from Radcliffe College, 1928; Simmons School of Social Work, 1930. Worked at Child Welfare League of America, National Association of Mental Health. Active in SANE/Nuclear Freeze, WESPAC, NASW. Survived by Margot T. Elkin, White Plains, NY, and Eugene Turitz, Berkeley, CA, his wife, Louise Rosenkrantz. Grandchildren: Charlotte Elkin, Samuel Elkin, NYC; Sarah Turitz Rosenkrantz, Los Angeles; Jeannette Gross, Berkeley; great - grandchildren; close family, friends.

title: A Revival After 30 Years Shows That Sexual Stereotyping Is on the Run
description: Perhaps it is a measure of enlightenment that the messages of the 30th-anniversary revival of the relentlessly cheery and well-meaning ''Free to Be . . . You and Me'' seem so obvious and dated.

title: Fix the Schools, Without the Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: Have 8-Iron, Will Buy Shares in Jet
description: WEDGED there in a middle seat of one of those dreadful little 737's between a sloppy snoozer and a button-holing babbler, with a two-hour O'Hare layover ahead and the airline lunch cart dispensing bags of peanuts that might be enough to feed a parrot, you may not be especially sympathetic to the travel problems of guys who get to play golf for a living.

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: The Patents column in Business Day on June 10 described the efforts of the General Patent Corporation to help inventors protect their patents, whether through licensing agreements or by litigation. In describing General Patent's work, the column said the company ''specializes in helping cash-strapped independent inventors in pursuing patent claims'' and mentioned that John Mickowski, an inventor, was among its clients.

title: MEMO PAD
description: More Corporate Travel Is Done at Leisure Fare

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Home-Care Workers Rally
description: More than 100 home health aides demonstrated yesterday at the offices of Premier Home Health Care to protest that the company had not signed a contract with them even though the workers voted 18 months ago to join the giant health care union 1199/S.E.I.U. On Saturday, workers from Premier voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike this summer by the company's more than 3,000 unionized employees. Many Premier workers say their pay, typically $6 to $8 an hour, is unsatisfactory. Arthur Schwabe, Premier's president, said a strike would hurt many people needing care. He also said Premier's wages were held down by low health care reimbursement rates. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Senate Passes Measure on Terrorism Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  Over the objections of leading Republicans, the Senate passed legislation this afternoon that would require the government to pay the overwhelming majority of losses in any major terrorist attack.

title: Tyco Sues Ex-Lawyer And Director
description: Tyco International filed suit yesterday against Mark A. Belnick, its former general counsel, and Frank E. Walsh Jr., its former lead independent director, contending in separate cases that the men wrongly took millions of dollars from the company.

title: Makeover Is Doing Wonders for U.S. Soccer Team
description: Four years ago in France, the United States left the World Cup in last place among the 32 competing nations. It was a dysfunctional team, unfit, lacking respect for the coach, incapable of putting the ball into the goal, unable to put aside selfish needs of the players for the good of the team.

title: Scott Shuger, 50, Pioneer Internet Journalist
description: Scott Shuger, an early Internet journalist who wrote the popular column ''Today's Papers'' for the online magazine Slate, died on Saturday while diving off the coast of California just south of Los Angeles. He was 50 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, LEO, M.D.
description: RUBENSTEIN-Leo, M.D. On Sunday, June 16, 2002. Leo Rubenstein of Chevy Chase, MD. Devoted husband of the late Sadie Rubenstein. Beloved father of Enid, and James (Terry) Rubenstein. Dear grandfather of William (Sandy) Rubenstein, Elizabeth (Will) Minkin and Charles Rubenstein. Dedicated physician and committed Jew. Graveside funeral service will be held Wednesday, June 19, 2002, 2 PM, at King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ. The family will receive friends at the home of Enid Rubenstein on Saturday and Sunday evening. Memorial contributions may be made to New York University Medical School, 560 1st Ave., NY, NY. Inquiries, Torchinsky Hebrew Funeral Home, 202541-1001.

title: For Suspect in Rampage, Depression, and an Arrest Record
description: About a week before a rampage in the East Village in which the police say Steven Johnson shot three people and used kerosene and a lighter to terrorize a bar filled with hostages, he called his father in North Carolina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, HERMAN
description: ALBERT-Herman. CEO and owner of Spectrum Fabrics, Inc., died Sunday, June 16, 2002, at Duke University Medical Center where he and his wife Ruth were benefactors. The Alberts, who live in Purchase, NY, and Palm Beach, Fla., became personally involved at Duke in 1998, when Ruth received treatment that restored her vision. The couple established the Ruth Albert Endowment for Eye Research at the Duke Eye Center. Later that year, convinced of the importance of genomic research to advance human health, they presented a major gift to the Duke Center for Human Genetics. Both Mr. and Mrs. Albert were members of Duke Advisory Boards and in December, 2001, they announced plans to bequeath the bulk of their estate to the Medical Center. Their gift will create the Ruth and Herman Albert Eye Institute for Research at the Duke Eye Center, and the Herman and Ruth Albert Lung Cancer Genomics Fund for research at the Duke Comprehensive Cancer Center. Ralph Snyderman, MD, Chancellor for Health Affairs, and CEO of the Duke University Health System, called Herman Albert ''a truly great man, one of the strongest I've ever known. The legacy that he and Ruth created at Duke will live and benefit the health and lives of generations to come.'' Herman Albert was born on November 23, 1922. At the end of WWII he began his career in an entry-level position with a home furnishing textile manufacturing firm in New York City. With a combination of innovation, hard work, and calculated risk, he rose through the ranks to become CEO and owner of the company. In May, Mr. and Mrs. Albert were honored at a dinner at the home of Duke University President, Nannerl O. Keohane, where they received an official proclamation approving construction of the Albert Eye Institute. Herman Albert is survived by his wife, Ruth, of Purchase and Palm Beach; a daughter, Lena Albert of Santa Fe, NM; a son, Richard Albert, and wife, Janet, of Greensboro, NC; three sisters, Belle Wang of New York, NY; Irene Goldberg of Englishtown, NJ; and Edith Lederman of Massapequa Park, NY. A memorial service was held today.

title: Drinking Like a Whale
description: Q. How do marine mammals like whales, porpoises and dolphins manage to live without access to fresh water for drinking?

title: Physically Abused Children Recognize the Face of Anger
description: Physical abuse in childhood is associated with a wide variety of problems in later life -- a fact documented by decades of research.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Opposition Members Arrested
description: The police arrested dozens of opposition party supporters over the weekend who were trying to commemorate the killings of schoolchildren in South Africa by the apartheid government in 1976. The authorities accused the party, the Movement for Democratic Change, of holding an illegal public gathering. Party officials went ahead with the demonstration, even though they lacked permission from the authorities, to protest a law that sharply restricts public meetings. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Study Faults U.S. Regulators In Aftermath Of Power Crisis
description: More than a year after California endured power shortages and soaring energy prices, the nation's energy regulators are still not up to the task of protecting consumers and ensuring that electricity is sold at reasonable rates, a Congressional study to be made public on Tuesday has concluded.

title: Critics Christen Ship Project As an Off-Course U.S.S. Pork
description: Two years ago, with waving flags and hula dancers swaying, the government announced an ambitious program to build two passenger cruise ships -- the first in a United States shipyard since the 1950's -- and provided more than $1 billion in loan guarantees to get the program going.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: A Slap From Wall Street
description: A Wall Street bond-rating company has lowered the state's financial outlook, to negative from stable, leading to finger-pointing by state officials. Gov. Jesse Ventura said Roger D. Moe, the Senate majority leader, and Tim Pawlenty, the House majority leader, had balanced this year's budget but created a $2.5 billion deficit for next year, causing the downgrading by Moody's Investors Service. Mr. Moe, a Democrat, and Mr. Pawlenty, a Republican, are running for governor. Mr. Ventura, an independent, has not said if he will seek re-election. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paths for the Church, After Dallas
description: To the Editor:

title: MARSHALL & ILSLEY TO BUY MISSISSIPPI VALLEY BANCSHARES
description: The Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Wisconsin's biggest bank, agreed to buy Mississippi Valley Bancshares for $494 million to expand in Missouri, Illinois and Arizona. Marshall & Ilsley will pay $26.25 a share in cash and 0.8486 share of its stock for a total of $52.40 for each share of Mississippi Valley, based on Marshall & Ilsley's closing share price yesterday. The price is 25 percent more than Mississippi Valley's closing price of $41.90 on Friday. The Milwaukee bank will gain seven offices in the St. Louis area and one in Phoenix, $1.7 billion in deposits and $2 billion in assets, the companies said.

title: Racing to Plug A Budget Hole In New Jersey
description: New Jersey legislators started their final, frantic attempt today to close a multibillion-dollar budget gap for the next fiscal year, a quest that has consumed Gov. James E. McGreevey's first months in office.

title: STEAKHOUSE CHAIN ACCEPTS INCREASED BUYOUT OFFER
description: The Morton's Restaurant Group agreed to a raised buyout offer from Castle Harlan Inc. that matched last month's $56.6 million offer for the steakhouse chain by the billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn. Castle Harlan, a leveraged buyout firm that is Morton's former owner, raised its bid to $13.50 a share from $12.60 a share, or $52.8 million, Morton's said. Morton's is based in New Hyde Park, N.Y., and Castle Harlan is based in New York.

title: Despite a Barrage of Attacks, Japan Forced Out of World Cup
description: MIYAGI, Japan, June 18 — Japan's World Cup dreams dissolved in a steady downpour today as the blue-shirted players never recovered from a diving header by a Turkish attacker 12 minutes into the game.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Planetary Crash Tests

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLAN, ROSAMOND BELT
description: ALLAN-Rosamond Belt, 75, died New York City June 8. Widow of William Allan, daughter of John and Rosamond Starr Belt. Memorial service June 26 at 1pm, Church of the Epiphany, York Ave and 74th St, NYC.

title: The Widow, Still Witty But Not Too Wise
description: ''The Merry Widow'' is a broadly comical, sumptuous spectacle that drew laughter and cheers when American Ballet Theater presented the crowd-pleaser on Wednesday afternoon and evening at the Metropolitan Opera House. Subtlety and substance are not the point, either in Ronald Hynd's choreography or the Franz Lehar operetta from which the ballet is drawn. But it is always fun to watch dancers bring their own color and movement qualities to bear on what there is.

title: G.O.P. Is Moving to Slow Action on Tax Loophole
description: Republican leaders in Congress are using procedural tactics like walking out of committee hearings to keep Congress from voting on measures to close the so-called Bermuda loophole in the federal tax code, measures that would almost certainly pass overwhelmingly if given the chance.

title: Paths for the Church, After Dallas
description: To the Editor:

title: Met Opera's Former Head Will Lead Lincoln Center
description: Stepping into shoes filled by Beverly Sills for eight years, Bruce Crawford, former president and general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, was named chairman of Lincoln Center at the board's annual meeting yesterday.

title: Blaming City, Workers Strike 3 Bus Companies in Queens
description: For the third time this year, employees at three private bus companies in Queens went on strike yesterday, leaving more than 115,000 daily riders scrambling for alternatives and, in some cases, at wits' end.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WYSELL, BERTRAM JAY
description: WYSELL-Bertram Jay. Born May 23, 1920, died June 18, 2001. Think of him as living in the hearts of those he touched-for nothing loved is ever lost and he was loved so much. In our hearts forever. Your Loving Family.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on June 10, 13 and 14 about the investigation of the abduction of Elizabeth Ann Smart in Salt Lake City misstated the date of her disappearance from her home. It was June 5, not 6.

title: Op-Art
Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: LITTLE EGG HARBOR TOWNSHIP: PILOT ERROR CITED The crash of a fighter jet near a freeway in January was attributable to the error of the pilot, who performed some maneuvers inadequately and suffered "spatial disorientation," the Air Force said yesterday. The pilot, Maj. Robert G. McNally, failed to tighten his lap belt, leading to "an incorrect perception of his position and motion relative to the ground" as rapid acceleration forces confused him, a report by the Air Combat Command Accident Investigation Board said. Major McNally ejected safely from his F-16C, which costs $19 million, before it crashed in a wooded area. He has resumed flying, but his commanding officer will decide on disciplinary measures. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Women's Rights: Why Not?
description: We now have a window into what President Bush and America's senators think of the world's women: Not much.

title: Looking to the Sky While Keeping the Wright Brothers' Goal in Mind
description: The Dayton Contemporary Dance Company has fallen in love with flying. On Saturday night it brought some of its choreographic flights to the American Dance Festival on the campus of Duke University here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRYOR, WILLIAM YOUNG
description: PRYOR-William Young. Of Essex Fells, NJ on June 14, 2002. Husband of the late Marianna (nee Brand). Devoted father of Ann Love Pryor of West Milford, NJ and William Brand Pryor and his wife Beverly of Caldwell, NJ. Loving grandfather of Morgan and William. Funeral service will be held in Dancy Funeral Home, 9 Smull Ave, Caldwell NJ on Thursday at 11AM. Friends may call Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Masonic Service will be held by Kane Lodge #

title: Dire Warning for Light Smokers
description: Light smokers -- people who smoke just a few cigarettes a day -- may reasonably assume that they are in less danger than heavier smokers. But a new study offers evidence to the contrary when it comes to cardiovascular disease.

title: Veteran of Police Dept. to Head La Guardia Security
description: A40-year veteran of the New York City Police Department will be the federal security director of La Guardia Airport, Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta announced today.

title: $11.50-an-Hour Wage Law Debated at Westchester Hearing
description: More than 200 union members, health care workers and community leaders packed a hearing room here today to debate Westchester County's proposed version of the so-called living-wage laws that several cities around the country have adopted.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: More North Koreans Seek Asylum
description: Two more North Koreans sneaked into the South Korean Consulate in Beijing, seeking political asylum in Seoul. There are now 20 asylum seekers stuck inside, their fate in dispute. South Korea says they should be allowed to decide where they want to live; China, bound to return asylum seekers under a treaty with North Korea, insists the North Koreans should be turned over to its police. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, THERESA (TERRY), RET.
description: REISS-Theresa (Terry), Ret. Supervisor of U.S. Passport Agency in NYC. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Cherished mother of Cookie Spancer and Martin (Lina) Reiss. Dear sister of Daniel Gelles. Also survived by four adoring and loving grandchildren and three great - grandchildren, and many nieces and nephews. Services Wednesday 11:45am at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Gunmen Fire At U.S. Troops
description: Military officials said American soldiers who have been helping the Philippine military hunt down Abu Sayyaf guerrillas came under fire, the first such attack since the operation began in February. It was not known if there were any injuries. The soldiers, who are operating on the island of Basilan, the Abu Sayyaf stronghold, are not permitted to fire their weapons except in self-defense, and it is not known what action they took in response. Earlier this month, an American missionary, Martin Burnham, who had been held by Abu Sayyaf for more than a year, was killed during a rescue operation by Filipino soldiers. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGEL, IRENE (NEE GREEN)
description: ENGEL-Irene (nee Green). Of Riverdale. Formerly of Oceanside, L.I. On June 16, 2002 at the age of 76. Of lung cancer. Dearly loved wife of Nat, mother of Debbie, Diane and Peter. Grandmother of Rebecca Goldstein. Motherin-law of David Goldstein. Funeral services were held. Shiva will be observed through Friday, June 21, at the home of Nat Engel in Riverdale. Contributions to the Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center, 10 Nathan D. Perlman Place, New York, N.Y. 10003.

title: Silently Shifting Teachers in Sex Abuse Cases
description: Duane C. Johnson turned up in southern Nevada nine years ago, a school recruiter's lucky break. He was a former high school football coach from Utah, game to work with the most troubled students here in Nevada. When a job opened at Child Haven, a shelter for neglected children, school administrators did not hesitate to send him over.

title: Jury Selection For Schwarz Moves Ahead
description: A white bank worker and a black transit supervisor were among those selected yesterday as potential jurors for the retrial of former police officer Charles Schwarz in the Abner Louima brutality case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHENOV, ALBERT
description: GERSHENOV - Albert. On June 17, 2002 of Larchmont. He was 84. Husband of Doris, (nee Yasgur) and father of Joseph Gershenov, Barbara Rubin and the late Gail Gershenov. He is also survived by a brother William and five grandchildren. Services today, (Tuesday) 10 a.m. at the Westchester Jewish Center Palmer Ave., Mamaroneck followed by interment at Cedar Park. For information Zion Memorial Chapel is conducting the arrangements. 914-381-1809 zionmemorialchapel.com

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Television section on Sunday with the highlights for today, about ''Driven: Madonna'' on VH1, has become outdated. That show will be seen at 9 p.m., not 8; ''Driven: Marilyn Manson'' will be seen at 8.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a headline on Sunday about the conviction of the Arthur Andersen auditing firm on a charge of obstruction of justice and an entry in the News Summary referred incorrectly in some copies to the rationale for the jury's decision. Though the charge was based on the firm's destruction of documents, jurors said they had based their decision on an Andersen lawyer's critical deletions to an internal memorandum, not on the shredding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASMIN, ALLAN
description: KASMIN-Allan. Dad, you were the most independent, tough, loving, and sincere person we knew. We love you and miss you always. Franklin, Esther, Rebecca, and Devorah Kasmin

title: Real Safety for Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Armed Man Stopped At Court
description: A Bronx man tried to take a loaded semiautomatic weapon into State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday morning, officials said. The man, Antonio English, 25, entered the courthouse at 111 Centre Street and put his bag through an X-ray machine, they said. Court officers immediately spotted the weapon, and Mr. English ran north on Centre Street, said Officer Peter Burke, a state court officer. Mr. English was caught about a block away outside 125 White Street, a city detention center. He was charged with criminal possession of a weapon, possession of an altered firearm and resisting arrest, Officer Burke said.

title: National Briefing: South
description: KENTUCKY: POLITICIANS IRK RACETRACK A budget battle in Frankfort, the capital, over capping campaign spending is reaching all the way to Churchill Downs in Louisville. Like other institutions that depend on the state, the Louisville racetrack complains that the legislative deadlock will cost it a million-dollar tax break that could affect a renovation needed to keep the track competitive. Francis X. Clines (NYT)

title: Accounting Change Gets Fresh Support
description: The chief executive of PricewaterhouseCoopers, Samuel DiPiazza, said today that worldwide accounting standards should be based on broad principles instead of specific rules to restore investors' confidence.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: He Might Think Prison Food Is Worse
description: Jos Bov, who in 1999 led a group of French famers in using tractors to smash a McDonald's in the town of Millau, was finally ordered to serve three months in prison for vandalism, starting this week. Mr. Bov, who became a folk hero for opposing American fast-food chains and United States tariffs on French cheese, was sentenced to three months in February but prosecutors did not jail him, saying they did not want to disrupt national elections, which ended Sunday. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Makes City's Bid For 2004 G.O.P. Convention
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg traveled here today to deliver New York City's bid for the 2004 Republican National Convention.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Kearny: Catholic Elementary School Closes
description: A 105-year-old Roman Catholic elementary school has been closed, after shrinking enrollment led to a doubling of tuition for the upcoming school year, the Archdiocese of Newark announced. The school, St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Elementary School, had enrolled 51 fewer students for the next school year, for a total of only 99, said Elizabeth Kepniss, a diocese spokeswoman. Based on the current enrollment, tuition would have jumped to nearly $4,500 per child and all family tuition and other discounts would have ended, she said. Parents were advised that their children could enroll at two other Catholic schools in Kearny. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNTERMEYER, SOPHIE G.
description: UNTERMEYER-Sophie G. 92, of New York City, passed away Saturday, June 15, after a long illness. Aunt of Charles S. and Randolph Guggenheimer Jr., and sister-in-law of Elinor C. Guggenheimer. Daughter of the late Charles and Minnie Guggenheimer, sister of the late Randolph Guggenheimer. She excelled in many sports, mainly golf, in which she won numerous tournaments including the prestigious Women's MGA Championship. She ran the Lewisohn Stadium Concerts following the death of her mother, the legendary ''Minnie,'' and was an honorary member of the Board of Directors of the New York Philharmonic. Contributions in her memory may be made to the New York Philharmonic, Avery Fisher Hall, 10 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023.

title: Data Storage That Lasts
description: To the Editor:

title: Bahrain Tries to Fill In Potholes on Road to New Government
description: Behind the pricey hotels and pruned palm trees, much of this capital and its surrounding villages consist of cramped little streets that a car negotiates with difficulty.

title: A Genomic Treasure Hunt May Be Striking Gold
description: In the year 874, Viking crews from western Norway started to drop in on Ireland, capture an allotment of young Celtic women and sail off northwest to a remote island beyond the reach of retribution.

title: Burnett and Images End Relationship
description: Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, the lead agency for the Army, and Images USA in Atlanta have ended an agreement under which Images created Army campaigns aimed at attracting black recruits. The Army spends $5 million to $6 million on advertising focused on blacks and $95 million over all.

title: Disney Shifting to Linux for Film Animation
description: The Walt Disney Company, the doyen of animation studios, is joining Hollywood's embrace of a technological upstart -- the GNU Linux operating system.

title: Factory Fire Injures One Worker And Prompts 8-Block Evacuation
description: A fire erupted in a large mixing drum at an aluminum company in Wanaque, N.J., yesterday afternoon, injuring one worker and prompting the authorities to order the evacuation of dozens of residents as a precaution, officials reported.

title: For Qwest's New Chief, A Question of Longevity
description: Is Richard C. Notebaert the right man for the job at Qwest Communications International? And just what is that job, anyway?

title: Bush Is Said to Back Growth Of Mission in Philippines
description: President Bush supports expanding an American military training mission in the Philippines, which would probably increase the risks to scores of American military advisers there, administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITEHEAD, ROBERT.
description: WHITEHEAD-Robert. The Board of Trustees and staff of Theatre Development Fund deeply mourn the loss of our dear friend, Robert Whitehead. Bob was a true champion of the theatre who nurtured the greatest playwrights of the Twentieth Century. In addition to his innumerable gifts to the theatre, he provided invaluable counsel and guidance to TDF-first as a trustee from 1985-1992, and from 1993 to the present, as the Honorary President of TDF's Chairman's Council. Robert Whitehead's quest for artistic excellence and his extraordinary skills as a producer will provide a benchmark to the field for generations to come. Our deepest condolences to Zoe, Charlie and Sam. John F. Breglio, Chairman Victoria Bailey, Executive Director Theatre Development Fund

title: AQUILA CUTS DIVIDEND TO PROTECT CREDIT RATING
description: Aquila Inc., an energy company, cut its 2002 profit forecast and slashed its dividend yesterday to pay debt and help maintain its investment-grade credit rating. The company is selling $400 million in common stock and $500 million in bonds, the chief executive, Robert Green, said in a conference call. Aquila is withdrawing from ''broad-based, market-making'' energy trading to focus on selling power and gas it owns, Mr. Green said. Profit this year will decline to $1.30 to $1.40 a share, the company said in a statement. The annual dividend was cut to 70 cents a share from $1.20 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, DAVID
description: ROSEN-David. Beloved husband of Sarah, devoted father of Jack and Phillis, Joseph and Marilyn. Dear brother of Rose Blatman. Loving grandfather of Danielle, Jordan, Alison, Brian and Adam. Services Tuesday, 10 AM at Park East Synagogue, 163 E. 67 St.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a headline on Sunday about the conviction of the Arthur Andersen auditing firm on a charge of obstruction of justice and an entry in the News Summary referred incorrectly in some copies to the rationale for the jury's decision. Though the charge was based on the firm's destruction of documents, jurors said they had based their decision on an Andersen lawyer's critical deletions to an internal memorandum, not on the shredding.

title: Senate Panel Passes Bill to Tighten Accounting Oversight
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 - Despite a fevered lobbying effort by the accounting industry, the Senate Banking Committee approved accounting legislation today that would impose tough measures to limit the lucrative consulting that auditing firms could perform.

title: New and Improving Retrieval of Signals From Distant Space
description: ''This entire plain is one big telescope,'' Dr. James Ulvestad, an astronomer, said with proprietary pride.

title: Search Is Widened for 4 Lost On Shark Trip Off Long Island
description: The search for four men lost in rough waters during a shark-hunting competition in the Atlantic Ocean on Saturday was widened yesterday, Coast Guard officials said.

title: Questioning 'New Kind of Science'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, R. W. B.
description: LEWIS-R. W. B. We note with sadness the death of R. W. B. Lewis, advisor and friend of the Library of America since its beginnings over 20 years ago. Scholar, writer, and literary critic, Dick Lewis's immense knowledge and keen appreciation for American writing, his generosity of spirit, and his unfailingly good counsel have contributed greatly to our enterprise. On behalf of our Board of Directors, we send our sympathy to his wife, Nancy, and to his children and grandchildren. Cheryl Hurley, President Richard Poirier, Chairman The Library of America

title: Death Images Hide the Truth of Danny Pearl
description: Two months before his abduction, my son, Daniel Pearl, wrote an e-mail message to us from Pakistan: ''Hi! It looks pretty dicey from here -- at least your papers don't run front-page photos of the corpses of journalists.'' Six months later, an American weekly ran photos of Danny's murder and posted video of that gruesome scene on a Web site for millions of viewers to watch. As devastating as this experience has been for us, the issue goes beyond the anguish of one family -- displaying this murder undermines efforts to fight terrorism and anti-Semitism.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Press Card for Amy Fisher

title: National Briefing | West: California: Dropping Quake Insurance
description: Facing major budget deficits and skyrocketing premiums for earthquake insurance, two transit agencies in the Bay Area are taking their chances rather than pay for coverage. Officials with the agencies, Caltrain and the Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority, said that they had suffered little damage in recent earthquakes and that deductibles were so high they would face significant payments, anyway. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: New Faces In Class, And They Hold Chalk
description: Lawyers, bankers, physicians and salesmen were there, choosing a new career in midlife. Retirees with grandchildren in public schools and expectant parents attended, wishing to improve the public schools. Some graduated from college in the 1960's and some just two years ago.

title: Forest Worker Held in Fire Creates Anger and Sympathy
description: As she sat in federal court here this morning, Terry Lynn Barton looked a little disoriented, a little sad and completely overwhelmed, in effect, not unlike many Coloradans affected by the largest wildfire in state history said they were feeling today.

title: Mets Could Fill Needs With Rolen, for a Price
description: At some point over the next month, Mets General Manager Steve Phillips will have to determine whether the grand lineup he assembled over the winter is as shallow as it has looked for two and a half months. And if it is, he must decide whether to gamble that it will correct itself or address the situation before the July 31 trading deadline.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Bosnian Serb Pleads Not Guilty
description: A former Bosnian Serb police commander arrested by NATO forces in Bosnia last Thursday on charges of crimes against humanity pleaded not guilty at the United Nations war crimes tribunal. Drako Mrdja, 34, is accused of taking part in the so-called Vlasic Mountain massacre of Aug. 21, 1992, when Bosnian Muslim prisoners were said to have been lined up on the edge of a cliff and shot or pushed to their deaths by Bosnian Serb police officers. The indictment says 228 people were reported missing after the incident. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Solicitation Ban Overturned

title: Push for 9/11 Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSCHNER, KATHRYN
description: KUSCHNER-Kathryn. Age 83. Passed away on June 14, 2002. Beloved wife of Marvin. Loving mother of Jason and mother-in-law of Andrea. Devoted grandmother and good friend of Zack and Cy. She was a kind, gracious, and caring person who touched many peoples lives. We will miss her very much.

title: Woods Drove the Ball, And the Ratings, Too
description: Ratings stories can be boring unless they tell a story. And the best sports tale told by Nielsen numbers is about Tiger Woods. He plays, ratings rise. He wins, ratings soar. He alone justifies scheduling a golf tournament like the United States Open to end one hour into prime time Sunday. And who minds an extra 45 minutes because of a rain delay if Tiger is leading during the approaching darkness? Woods has more power to extend the ratings of his sport beyond its core audience than any current athlete or team.

title: June Jordan, 65, Poet and Political Activist
description: June Jordan, who came of age as a poet when the voices of black female writers were just beginning to be heard, died on June 14 at her home in Berkeley, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEDICK, HAROLD
description: BEDICK-Harold. 82. Of Hackensack, NJ, formerly of Teaneck, on June 17, 2002. Beloved husband, father, and grandfather. Graveside service Wednesday, 11am, Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, Queens.

title: Among Jews, Urge to Panic Is Premature
description: THERE was something almost Dickensian about a report issued in New York the other day by the Anti-Defamation League, on the state of anti-Semitism in America as reflected in a new opinion poll. This was Dickensian in the ''best of times, worst of times'' sense. You could go either way, depending on how you looked at the numbers.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Government Marshals Support
description: The Communist Party newspaper said 7.4 million Cubans -- of a population of a little more than 11 million -- had signed a petition that says the Communist state is ''untouchable.'' The petition drive was President Fidel Castro's response to the Varela Project, an opposition movement that is seeking a referendum on greater individual and political freedoms. Opponents noted that many people felt pressure to sign since signatures were collected by local committees used to keep tabs on neighborhood residents. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENVENISTE, SYLVIA
description: BENVENISTE-Sylvia. Age 81, on June 16, 2002, after complications from a stroke. Beloved mother of Richard; grandmother of Jonathan, Danielle, Elizabeth and Olivia; cherished mother-in-law of Donna Grell. Preceded in death by her husband, Isaac; daughter, Lorraine; brothers, Milton, Paul and Alexander, and sister, Leah. Funeral service will be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., at 12:30 PM, on Wednesday, June 19, 516-295-3100. Family will receive guests at the home of Steven and Sherri Davis, 588 Lakeview Ave., Rockville Centre, L.I., 5-7 PM, June 19; and at Richard and Donna's home in Washington, D.C., on Thursday, June 20, where shiva service will begin at 7 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Religious Action Center for Reform Judaism, 2027 Massachusetts Ave, NW, Washington, DC 20036.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, CHARLOTTE E.
description: GROSSMAN - Charlotte E. Heimberg of York PA, died suddenly on June 12 in NYC. The wife of the late Jack Grossman, she is survived by beloved daughters Leslie Abrams of Dobbs Ferry, NY and Beth Grossman of NYC and devoted son Howard Grossman of Weston CT, three grandchildren, Sara and Joshua Abrams and Susan Grossman, sister Mae Schild of Hilton Head SC and brother Robert Heimberg of Somers NY. Service was held.

title: So What Does A Bonobo Eat?
description: Just as humans need a varied diet, so do animals in zoos. And a zoo nutritionist's job is complicated by a variety of factors, starting with the facts that every species has different needs, and needs often change with age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VISOTSKY, HAROLD M., M.D.
description: VISOTSKY-Harold M., M.D. A renowned psychiatrist and former Chairman of the Department of Psychiatry at Northwestern University Medical School. Beloved husband of Gladys (nee Mavrich). Loving father of Dr. Jeffrey (Lisa) and Robin L. Visotsky. Cherished grandfather of Zachary and Trevor. Dear brother of the late Mary (the late Sam) Solowitz. Services Wednesday at The Piser Chapel, Skokie, Illinois. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Ark, Northwestern University Hospital, or the charity of your choice. Information: 847679-4740

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: CONSTRUCTION STRIKE German construction workers began their first major strike in more than 50 years, after a walkout earlier this year by members of the country's main manufacturing union to back up demands for higher wages. The IG BAU union said at least 8,000 workers stayed off the job at 400 sites in Berlin, as well as the northern city of Hamburg and the industrial Ruhr Valley area in the west in strikes that some fear could hurt an already sagging economy. Union officials are pushing for a 4.5 percent annual increase for Germany's 950,000 construction workers and for wages in the economically depressed eastern areas to be brought up to levels in the western sections. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JOHN A.
description: MURPHY-John A. Philip Morris Companies, Inc. notes with sorrow the death of retired Philip Morris executive and director, John Murphy, who during his 30 year career played an enormous role in the growth and development of the company. Mr. Murphy served as a member of the Boards of Directors from 1971 until 1992. He retired in 1992 as vice chairman of the company, a post he had held since 1991. Mr. Murphy served as president of the company from 1984 to 1991. He also served as group executive vice president responsible for Miller Brewing Company and two other Philip Morris subsidiaries; group executive vice president of Philip Morris Incorporated; chairman and chief executive officer of Miller Brewing Company; executive vice president of Philip Morris Incorporated; and president and chief executive officer of Miller Brewing Company. He was elected a vice president of Philip Morris Incorporated in August 1967, and an executive vice president in August 1976. Before his election as president and chief executive officer of Miller, he was assistant to the president and executive vice president of Philip Morris International. Under his stewardship, Philip Morris became the largest American tobacco company in Europe, Africa and Latin America. Mr. Murphy joined Philip Morris in 1962 as assistant general counsel. The Philip Morris Board and employees pay warm tribute to his memory and extend their deepest sympathy to his wife, Carole; his children, John, Kevin, Robert, Timothy, Kellyann, and Kathleen; twenty grandchildren; and his extended family. A wake will be held Wednesday, June 19, 2002, from 6pm to 9pm at Whitting Funeral Home, 300 Glen Cove Ave, Glen Head, NY 11545. The funeral Mass will be Thursday, June 20, 2002 at 10am at St. Paul the Apostle R.C. Church, 2534 Cedar Swamp Rd (Rte 107), Brookville, NY 11545.

title: Longer Review Period Urged For Nonpartisan Vote Plan
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to put an amendment on the ballot this November that would eliminate partisan elections in New York City drew criticism yesterday from government watchdog groups, who said that the public should be given more time to study such a fundamental change in the way they elect their leaders.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Wireless Company Acquisition
description: Proxim, which makes wireless-network equipment, said yesterday that it planned to buy a wireless equipment unit from Agere Systems for $65 million to bolster its ownership of local area networks. Proxim expects the purchase to add to its earnings per share in the quarter after the acquisition closes, a move that is expected within 60 days. Warburg Pincus and Broadview Capital Partners agreed to invest $75 million in Proxim to finance the purchase, Proxim said. Agere, a communications chip maker spun off this month from Lucent Technologies, agreed to provide chips, modules and cards to Proxim for the next three years. Shares of Proxim, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., rose 39 cents, or 18 percent, to $2.40, up 22 cents, after rising to $2.94 earlier. Shares of Agere, based in Allentown, Pa., rose 6 cents, to $2.47.

title: An Acrid Comic Parable About Nazis
description: The seven-year-old Colleagues Theater Company has all the trappings of a young and eager troupe far more excited by putting on a show than making a living. Its theater -- the Neighborhood Playhouse -- is snug and a little musty. The stage is small; the wing space is, well, what wing space? The productions are distinctly low budget.

title: Of Swimming, Jumping and Summer Safety
description: It can happen in your own backyard, or your neighbor's. One false move, a back turned for a minute and next thing you know, it's a trip to the emergency room with an injured child, or worse.

title: Politicians On Drugs
description: Yesterday House Republicans announced their prescription drug plan for retirees. It was, of course, an election-year gesture. So, to be sure, was last week's rival announcement by Senate Democrats. Soon each side will be accusing the other of obstructionism. What's a voter to think?

title: Peruvians Riot Over Planned Sale of 2 Regional Power Plants
description: Hundreds of troops took control of Peru's second-largest city today after the government imposed a state of emergency to end violent protests against the sale of two state-owned electricity generating companies.

title: Judge in Lindh Case Refuses Defense Request to Move Trial
description: The judge in the John Walker Lindh case rejected a defense motion today to move the trial to California from here in Northern Virginia, nine miles from where 189 people were killed on Sept. 11 when a hijacked airplane slammed into the Pentagon.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: The Joy Of Politics
description: With national elections scheduled for Sept. 22, Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's Social Democratic colleagues have found an unorthodox way of campaigning: selling condoms in the party's bright red color with the slogan ''Feel Good, SPD.'' Boxes containing 100 condoms are being sold for $40. Mr. Schrder is in a tough battle for re-election as his center-left coalition government trails the conservative opposition by about 4 percentage points in the polls. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK/Kari Stefansson; Hunting for Disease Genes In Iceland's Genealogies
description: When Kari Stefansson was growing up, Iceland could afford so few imports that fruit appeared in the stores only once a year.

title: Suicide Bomber Hits Jerusalem; At Least 14 Die
description: A suicide bomber detonated a powerful explosion on a bus during rush hour here this morning, killing at least 14 people, the police said.

title: Council Seeks State Approval Of Mayor's Taxes, and Its Own
description: The lingering budget differences between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council will be apparent in two laws the Council plans to pass today: one will ask the State Legislature to approve a number of taxes and fees that the mayor is seeking, while a second asks it to approve two tax increases that the mayor opposes.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH/Kate O'Hanlan; Promising Judgments That Are Purely Medical
description: On a waiting room wall at Dr. Katherine A. O'Hanlan's office sits a small framed sign that reads: ''This office appreciates the diversity of women and does not discriminate based on race, age, religion, ability, marital status, sexual orientation, gender or perceived gender.''

title: Self-Made, So-Called
description: To the Editor:

title: Chirac, Riding High, Reappoints His Prime Minister
description: President Jacques Chirac reappointed his prime minister today after a landslide election victory for Mr. Chirac buoyed his authority and status and prompted a remarkable resurgence in his political fortunes.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think that the United States always has seen us as inferior and it always has tried to humiliate us. And now they've really gone and done it.''

title: Nestl and Dreyer's to Merge in $2.4 Billion Deal, Creating Top U.S. Ice Cream Seller
description: Nestl agreed to merge its United States ice cream business, which includes the Hagen-Dazs and Nestl Crunch brands, with Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream yesterday in a $2.4 billion deal that will give Nestl control of the new company.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Falun Gong Members On Trial
description: Sixteen followers of the spiritual movement Falun Gong went on trial in the former British colony, accused of public obstruction during a protest in March at the Chinese government's main offices in Hong Kong. Nine are also accused of willfully obstructing the police, who removed them from the site of the protest, and three have been charged with assaulting police officers; all 16 pleaded not guilty to the charges. The trial is the first in Hong Kong dealing with adherents to Falun Gong, which has been banned in the rest of China as a cult. Officials deny that they are cracking down on dissent before a visit on July 1 by President Jiang Zemin. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, DANIEL GERARD
description: COLLINS-Daniel Gerard. Suddenly on Sunday June 16th at age 72 after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Anne Weld Collins, dear brother of Muriel Collins, devoted father of Caitlin Ahl, Deirdre, Charles and Geoffrey Collins. Loving step-father of Serena, Evelyn, Alexander and Blake Crawford. Adoring grandfather of five. A memorial service will be announced at a future date.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on June 10, 13 and 14 about the investigation of the abduction of Elizabeth Ann Smart in Salt Lake City misstated the date of her disappearance from her home. It was June 5, not 6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACLISE, DOUGLAS L.
description: MacLISE-Douglas L., 68, of West Redding, Connecticut, formerly of Guilford, Connecticut, died peacefully at home on June 13, 2002, after a long illness. A distinguished landscape designer whose presence lives on in the gardens he created, he will be deeply missed as artist and friend by all whose lives he touched. Memorial celebration will be held at a future date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the Redding Land Trust, Post Office Box 76, Redding, Connecticut 06875, or The Nature Conservancy, 4245 North Fairfax Drive, Suite 100, Arlington, Virginia 22203.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMALLBERG, DOROTHY (LANZOFF)
description: SMALLBERG - Dorothy (Lanzoff), born and raised in New York, February 14, 1907, passed away on June 15 in her home in North Miami Beach at age 95. Longtime resident of Brooklyn. She was married to the late Joseph and is survived by her children, Joan Coe of Connecticut and Leonard Smallberg of Long Island and was the beloved mother-in-law of Warren and Madelyn. She was the grandmother of Terri LaChance, Kenneth, Carolyn and Peter Coe; Jordana, Bradley and Shellie Smallberg; as well as two greatgrandchildren Morgan and Ethan. Services will be held on Wednesday at 1:30pm at The Parkside, 2576 Flatbush Ave (at Ave U), Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to UJA or ORT, or any other worthy charity.

title: Civil Rights on a Greyhound
description: In the Fourth Amendment, the founders guaranteed us the right to be secure against unreasonable searches and seizures. Over the years the Supreme Court has developed a complex set of rules for searches in different venues -- homes, cars, factory floors. Yesterday the court decided a case about passengers on a Greyhound bus who had not been told they had the right to refuse to be searched. By a 6-to-3 vote it upheld the search, a decision we believe is mistaken.

title: Baseball 101: Hits, Runs, Footnotes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINKLEVOSS, AMANDA GESINE
description: WINKLEVOSS-Amanda Gesine. Age 23. Beloved daughter, loving sister, cherished niece and cousin, dearest friend, died in an accident on June 14 in New York City. Born May 23, 1979, she is survived by her parents, Carol and Howard Winklevoss; brothers Cameron and Tyler, all of Greenwich, Ct. and Quogue, L.I.; aunt and uncle, Lynda and Ralph Confessore; cousins Christopher and Nicholas Confessore; grandmothers Marian Winklevoss and Mildred Leonard. She attended Greenwich Country Day School, Greenwich Academy, Williams College and Georgetown University. An accomplished athlete and thespian, her inner beauty and shining spirit are irreplaceable. A bright star overlooks her beloved beach. Visiting hours will be held from 4-8 p.m. on Tuesday, June 18 at Leo P. Gallagher & Son, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich (203) 869-1513. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday, June 19 at 10:00am at the Second Congregational Church, 139 East Putnam Avenue followed by a graveside ceremony and interment at the Quogue Cemetery, Quogue, Long Island. Memorial contributions can be made to the Amanda Winklevoss Scholarship Fund, c/o Quogue Junior Theatre Troupe, Box 1303, Quogue, NY 11959.

title: This Guy Still Finds the World Baffling. Blame the World.
description: Life doesn't seem to be getting any less baffling for the monotonal comedian Steven Wright. His intellect remains dedicated to misreadings of the world's ordinary signals to its citizens, and in his comic persona he seems incapable of sharing commonly accepted tools of communication. Where his mind lives -- in the vacant spaces that language creates -- confusion, ambiguity, absurdity, irony and paradox grow like mold.

title: EgyptAir Chairman Ousted Amid Mounting Criticism
description: Its business battered by the tensions in the Middle East, the post-Sept. 11 falloff in international tourism and its own poor safety record, EgyptAir removed its chairman of two decades today and promised rapid progress on a sweeping reorganization announced last month. But there will be no change in the government's ownership and control of the airline, officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Romania: Vampire Theme Park Seeks Funds
description: Romania hired PricewaterhouseCoopers to help it find about $30 million of financing needed to build a Count Dracula theme park. The firm has been given 60 days to find financing for a Romanian organization that wants to build the park near the medieval town of Sighisoara, in the Transylvania region, the government said. Romania has been criticized both at home and abroad over the park, which the government estimates could generate annual revenue of as much as $27 million.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Shuttle Extends Stay
description: The space shuttle Endeavour and seven astronauts circled Earth after thunderstorms led them to cancel a landing at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Fla. The shuttle is to try again today, but bad weather in central Florida and at a backup site in California could force another postponement. The Endeavour is returning from a mission to the International Space Station. Its crew includes two astronauts who have been in space for 194 days, an American record. Todd Halvorson (NYT)

title: Bush Calls Transformed Area A Model Program for Housing
description: President Bush visited a once-blighted neighborhood on the south side of Atlanta today that an innovative federal housing project has transformed. Mr. Bush said the program should be a model for government efforts to help 5.5 million black and Hispanic families buy homes in the next eight years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELDON, DOROTHY
description: SELDON-Dorothy, of Tamarac, FL, on June 16, 2002. Devoted wife of 59 years to her husband Bernard. Loving mother of Terry and Richard and mother-in-law of Mindy, and devoted grandmother of Amanda, Adam, and Corey.

title: The Color of One's Skin
description: To the Editor:

title: A Slaying in 1982 Maintains Its Grip on Asian-Americans
description: The tone for the event had to be just right solemn but powerful, backward-glancing, but forward-moving. For more than two hours, in the cramped suburban office of a group called American Citizens for Justice, a gathering of mostly Asian-American college students mulled over programs and speakers, buttons and T-shirts to make their message resonate.

title: Under a Spotlight, the Grass Is Still Blue
description: Small, white-haired and elegant, Ralph Stanley was telling the crowd at the Bottom Line that he was happy to be recognized. And he was doing it in his typical way: tersely, with earned self-confidence. But the numbers were confusing him. Was it in 1954 that he had last been on Columbia Records? (His new album, ''Ralph Stanley,'' has taken him back to that label.) Or was it 1948, which would mean 54 years had passed? ''Well,'' he said with a shrug, ''in any case, it's been too long.''

title: Officials Got a Windfall Before Enron's Collapse
description: In the year before the Enron Corporation collapsed last December, about 100 executives and energy traders collected more than $300 million in cash payments from the company, according to documents filed today in bankruptcy court.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: SUPPORTING ISRAEL, VIA BONDS The state plans to invest $10 million in Israel bonds, the Illinois treasurer's office said. The move was made possible by legislation signed last week that lets the state invest in foreign government securities, as long as the governments have never defaulted on obligations. "It sends an unmistakably clear message of support for the state of Israel," said Representative Jeffrey M. Schoenberg, an Evanston Democrat who was a co-sponsor of the bill. That is the problem, Rafeeq Jaber, an Arab-American, said, adding, "We're going to send taxpayers' money to support the terrible things Israel is doing to the Palestinian people." (AP)

title: $9 Million in Aid For Port Security
description: The federal Department of Transportation announced $9.2 million in federal aid yesterday to increase security at the New York region's maritime ports after the Sept. 11 attack.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buffalo: Murder Suspect To Get Separate Mass
description: James Kopp, left, an anti-abortion activist accused of fatally shooting a doctor who performed abortions, has won the right to attend a weekly Roman Catholic Mass separate from other prisoners. The authorities at the Erie County Holding Center said yesterday that they had approved a request by Mr. Kopp's lawyer, Paul J. Cambria Jr. ''When someone has a case that has received a lot of attention, many times other prisoners will make unfounded claims of a confession in order to try to reduce their own sentences,'' Mr. Cambria said. Mr. Kopp, 47, has pleaded not guilty in the 1998 killing of the doctor, Barnett A. Slepian. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Corrections

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Unemployment Rises
description: Unemployment jumped sharply in Hong Kong, rising to 7.4 percent for the period from March to May, compared with 7.1 percent from February through April. Construction companies, retail stores, restaurants, export-import businesses and communications enterprises all shed jobs, more than offsetting modest growth in the financial sector. Underemployment, particularly a problem in the construction sector, edged up to 3.1 percent from 3 percent. As Hong Kong's border with the rest of China becomes ever more open, many manufacturing and retail businesses are moving to lower-cost cities nearby. Hong Kong's government warned yesterday that a fresh crop of high school and university graduates now entering the job market could keep unemployment high in the near future. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, ESMOND BRADLEY
description: MARTIN-Esmond Bradley, a graduate of Princeton and Columbia University, and the grandson of Henry Phipps, the Pittsburgh steel magnate and partner of Andrew Carnegie, died peacefully on Sunday, June 16, at the age of 87 at his family estate of ''Knole'' in Old Westbury, New York. Esmond Martin had an astonishing mind, alive with dynamism and originality that knew no horizons. Often a paradox, he was shy yet gracious and always a gentleman. His creative mind was interested in everything around him. He was a brilliant chess player, having been selected as a backup to Samuel Reshevsky in an international tournament. He was a discerning philatelist of long standing, a well-known orchid cultivator, with a patent on a species of his own creation, as well as a collector of fine pocket watches, books and English antique furniture. His magnificently restored estate and elegant gardens appeared in many feature films over the years and in the Smithsonian Institute. He was a very talented amateur lawn and court tennis player, having beaten the likes of Pierre Etchebaster, the then reigning 20 year world champion in court tennis, and even chalking up a 60 victory over Pancho Gonzales during a challenge match in the course of Gonzales' reign as world champion. For many years he was the world's fly-fishing record holder for Atlantic salmon that he landed on the Cascapedia River, Canada, in 1939. He excelled in many of his personal financial affairs, successfully wildcatting in gas and oil and other varied investments. Esmond Martin is survived by his twin brother, Alastair, his daughter, Serina Sanchez of Palm Beach, Florida, his two sons, Esmond, Jr. living in Kenya, and Peter, resident of the S.W. of France and five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A funeral Mass will be celebrated Thursday, June 20th, at 10 A.M. at St. Brigid's Church, 50 Post Ave., Westbury. Attendees are invited to Knole for a repast.

description: The Argentine government has agreed to rescind restrictions recently imposed on petroleum exports out of concerns that oil producers would try to circumvent informal price controls. With the value of the Argentine currency having fallen more than 70 percent this year, exporting has become far more attractive than supplying the local market, but had been limited to 36 percent of total production. That ceiling was lifted, however, in return for a pledge by Repsol YPF of Spain, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and other producers to assure an adequate fuel supply at current prices throughout the coming winter in the Southern Hemisphere. title: Technology Briefing | Software: Loudcloud Cuts Deals With E.D.S.
description: Loudcloud, a leading Silicon Valley start-up company, is selling its data-center services business to focus on becoming a software supplier. The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said yesterday that it was buying Loudcloud's services business for $63.5 million. In a three-year, $52 million deal, Electronic Data is also licensing Loudcloud's Opsware software, which is used to automate tasks in corporate data centers. E.D.S., a major computer services company, said it expected to save more than $100 million by using Opsware in its global network of data centers. Marc Andreessen, the chairman of Loudcloud, said the Electronic Data deal would give his company a swift way to become a pure software company, leaving a services business that had proved hard for a small company to sustain. Of Loudcloud's 380 employees, 140 will be transferred to Electronic Data, 100 will stay and 140 will be laid off. Loudcloud will change its name to Opsware. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: What to Do With It Once You Bring It Home

I have put lardons in an apple pie that has bacon fat in the pastry, and Cesare Casella, the chef at Beppe, makes bacon tuiles to serve with coffee. So why not try Ms. Perry's hazelnut-bacon crunch or pecan-bacon brittle? The paperback book (Chronicle, $18.95) has 70 recipes, including the classic bacon, lettuce and tomato sandwich, herb pasta with white beans, green beans with lemon zest and an elaborate dish of seared sea scallops wrapped in bacon and served on celeriac pure. The book offers tips on buying and storing bacon and bacon terminology, including the differences between lardon (a French term for a little chunk of bacon) and rasher (British for a slice).

Mr. Stancik was the only person to hold the post, which was created in 1990 by Mayor David N. Dinkins in response to complaints of incompetence in the Board of Education's in-house investigative unit. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

description: ON the northeastern tip of Long Island, about halfway between the villages of Southold and Greenport, a developer has put up a cluster of single-family homes in a modest enclave named Chardonnay Estates.

title: Report Predicts Deep Benefit Cuts Under Bush Social Security Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  Opponents of President Bush's plan to create personal investment accounts within Social Security released a report today concluding that the administration's approach would lead to deep cuts in retirement benefits and still require trillions of dollars in additional financing to keep the system solvent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, PHILIP
description: FRANK-Philip. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member Philip Frank. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Samuel Wasserman, President

description: PROTTER-Violet. At age 96. Beloved wife of the late Marcy, devoted mother of Susan Ann Protter. Services on Thursday, June 20, 11:30 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Companies To Form Chip Venture
description: Infineon Technologies, Motorola and Agere Systems said yesterday that they would start a venture to develop and market chips that process video, music and voice information for computers and wireless devices. Infineon, Europe's No. 2 semiconductor maker; Motorola, the world's second-largest maker of mobile phones; and Agere, a communications chip maker spun off from Lucent Technologies, will start operations as StarCore in Austin, Tex., in the third quarter, the companies said at a news conference in Munich, where Infineon is based. StarCore will employ about 100 people. ''This is about bringing technical and engineering know-how together,'' Ulrich Schumacher, left, the chief executive of Infineon, said. ''We think there will be more interested parties joining.'' The market for such processors will be about $6.5 billion next year, Mr. Schumacher said. Infineon shares rose as much as 2.4 percent to 16.75 euros, while Motorola closed at $16.18, down 22 cents.

title: Forward and Backward in One Family
description: Last September was not a great time to introduce a new theater troupe, and no one would have blamed the artists who make up the nonprofit Epic Theater Center if they had just given up. But the group, which is devoted both to arts education and to producing new and classic works. persisted, staging some workshops and school programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, JUNE
description: JORDAN-June. This week June Jordan, lifelong activist, poet, writer and member of MADRE's founding Board of Directors, died. With her passing, the volume of passion in the world is diminished. In June's memory, we rededicate our own passion to building the world we dream. Staff and Board of MADRE

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about immigrant students who have embraced the tradition of the high school prom misstated the percentage of public high school students in New York City who are recent immigrants. It is about 16 percent, not nearly half.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RYAN, COL. GENE E.
description: RYAN-Col. Gene E. 10 years today. I think of you always. A toast to you. Fly high, love. Roz

title: Jury Member Wants to Tell All, But Publishers Aren't Lining Up
description: For all those Enron fanatics out there dying to find out every twist and turn in the deliberations of the jury that convicted Arthur Andersen on Saturday, the jury's foreman, Oscar H. Criner, has an answer. He wants to write a book about the experience and its broader significance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLECKER, RUTH L.
description: BLECKER-Ruth L. Born June 2, 1902 (NYC), died June 18, 2002. Mother of Mathias Lloyd Spiegel (Harriet Yarmolinsky), grandmother of Paul A.S., and Andrew E. (Catherine Smith) Spiegel, great grandmother of William A., and Matthew B. Spiegel, widow of Louis Blecker and Saul Spiegel.

title: Qaeda Attack Was in Works For 3 Years, Officials Say
description: Osama bin Laden's terrorist organization began serious planning for a major attack inside the United States soon after it bombed two American embassies in East Africa in August 1998, top intelligence officials told a Congressional committee today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Runoff In Firefighter Election
description: None of the four candidates seeking the presidency of the New York City firefighters' union won a majority of votes yesterday, so the union will hold a runoff next month. Stephen Cassidy, a firefighter with Engine Company 236 in Brooklyn, fell 17 votes short of getting the more than 50 percent required, said a spokesman for the 9,000-member union, the Uniformed Firefighters Association. In the runoff, Mr. Cassidy will face William Mirro, the union's recording secretary. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: A Basement Revolution No Matter How You Slice It
description: IN the cool, cramped wine cellar at Lupa in Greenwich Village on a June afternoon, Wade Moises, a sous-chef, sidled down a passageway between two racks of bottles. He carried a wooden dowel, from which hung eight long links of freshly stuffed fennel salami, and then suspended it across the aisle, blocking access to one end of the cellar.
