title: Drug Makers Sponsor Event For G.O.P. as Bill Is Debated
description: As lawmakers battle over a prescription drug bill, pharmaceutical and health-care concerns are providing major support for a fund-raiser scheduled for Wednesday night that is expected to raise more than $20 million for Republican candidates in this year's Congressional election.

title: Arrests of Teens in Fatal Fire Stirs Internet Debate in China
description: BEIJING, June 19  Two teen-aged boys have been arrested on charges that they intentionally set a fire that killed 24 last weekend in an unlicensed Internet cafe, the city government said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: The Price Of Online Privacy
description: A report released this week by the technology consultancy Forrester Research said consumers do have a price when it comes to abandoning their online and off-line privacy -- and it is not high. Forrester surveyed 6,000 online consumers, and 36 percent said they would permit their World Wide Web surfing habits to be tracked in exchange for a $5 discount on their monthly Internet service. Half said they would permit their television viewing habits to be tracked for the same amount. The report said that women are more likely to permit others to track their Internet and television viewing than men, with 39 percent of women saying they would permit such surveillance online for $5 discounts, compared with 33 percent of men. The reason for the difference, Forrester said, is that ''men partake of more behaviors like visiting adult Web sites that they might not want the world to know about.'' Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

title: What George Packed For Sunday in the Park
description: A proper French pique-nique needs a crusty baguette, a slab of pt and spreaders like the one below, with handle in a toile de Joy pattern. There are also handles in checks, stripes and Provenal prints. The knives are $26 each at La Cafetire, 160 Ninth Avenue (19th Street), and the new La Cafetire, 83 Main Street, East Hampton, N.Y. As for pt, a rustic, slightly peppery pt de campagne is the latest from D'Artagnan. It comes in a nine-ounce terrine for $7.95 at the shop, 152 East 46th Street, and at www.dartagnan.com.

description: ROSEN-David. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations mourns the passing of the beloved father of our esteemed colleague and friend Jack Rosen, President of American Jewish Congress. We pray that the Rosen family will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mortimer B. Zuckerman, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: An Astonishment of Riches In a Tiny English Town
description: ONLY 9,000 people live in this charming market town near the Welsh border, surrounded by lush and rolling hills. Just 9,000, but Ludlow has no fewer than three Michelin-starred restaurants -- the greatest concentration anywhere in Britain outside London.

title: Albany's Work Is Not Done
description: In a State Legislature as addicted to behind-the-scenes dealmaking as New York's, it's possible to accomplish a great deal very quickly. As the lawmakers in Albany move into the final days of their official session, there is plenty of work still on the table. Some important proposals, such as reorganization of the jumbled judicial system, can't be jump-started at this late date. But others are close to resolution. If officials don't get them done, they should be ashamed to face the voters this November.

title: Citigroup Fills International Post
description: Citigroup announced today that it had named Stanley Fischer as president of Citigroup International, a newly formed unit that will include the company's troubled emerging markets business.

title: $3.1 Million in Grants for Arts Education
description: The Center for Arts Education is doling out $3.1 million in grants across the city to help schools combine traditional academic subjects with the arts. More than 30 partnerships each received a $100,000 grant. Jennifer Medina

title: Britney Spears: Not Yet A Woman, Already A Restaurateur
description: NYLA, the restaurant partly owned by the pop star Britney Spears, opened loudly on East 41st Street last Friday night, not to the roar of a crowd or to the flash of cameras, but to the rumble and squeal of a garbage truck making the rounds on an otherwise empty block.

title: Saudi Arabia Arrests 13 Men Tied to Attack on a U.S. Base
description: Saudi Arabia, reversing months of denials that any members of Al Qaeda might be lurking in the kingdom, announced today that it had arrested members of the terrorist network that it believes tried to shoot down a United States military aircraft with a shoulder-fired missile.

title: INSIDE
description: Afghan Mission Unfinished

title: Celebrating a Sprite of Astonishment
description: Doris Kornish's keen, fine documentary ''Not Nude Though: A Portrait of Rudy Burckhardt,'' which begins a run today at the Two Boots Pioneer Theater in the East Village, manages to dance with the soul of an artist. Ms. Kornish peers into the heart of the visual artist Rudy Burckhardt, who was, according to the downtown poet Bob Holman, ''a filmmaker, a photographer, a writer, an actor -- what an actor!'' He then dissolves into giggles, and we see clips of Burckhardt, who died in 1999, showing his, well, less than vast range as an actor. (Expounding on the one-note goofiness of Burckhardt, his son Jacob, a filmmaker, remarks, ''In the first one, he played a crazy bum, and in this later one not a bum but crazy.'')

title: Another Cousin to Jupiter Is Found
description: For the second time in a week, astronomers yesterday announced the discovery of a Jupiter-like planet around a distant star, and they say this one could be part of a planetary system more similar to the Sun's than any yet discovered.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: NEW MICROSOFT OFFICES The Microsoft Corporation said that it would occupy two floors of Hong Kong's Cyberport, a struggling project that is supposed to create a campuslike setting for information technology businesses. Microsoft will move its local operations in October to two floors of the project, totaling 40,000 square feet of office space. Situated beyond the end of Hong Kong's subway system, Cyberport is a 20-minute taxi ride or a 30-minute bus ride from downtown, and has one-third the rents of downtown because the Hong Kong government and its partner, Pacific Century CyberWorks Ltd., have had trouble finding tenants. The project has been controversial because it was awarded to Pacific Century, which is now the city's largest phone company, through a private tender instead of through the land auction system on which Hong Kong usually relies. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Daniel Collins, 72, Labor Arbitrator, Dies
description: Daniel G. Collins, a professor and labor arbitrator who had a key role in smoothing the way for the New York City contract with its teachers this month, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Challenge From Insurer
description: The Manulife Financial Corporation of Canada challenged the authority of a court-appointed receiver to oversee the management and assets of its Indonesian unit, which was declared bankrupt last week. The court named Mr. Kalisutan, who goes by one name, as the receiver for PT Asuransi Jiwa Manulife Indonesia. Manulife challenged the appointment saying he was not a registered member of the local receivers' association, known as AKPI. Mr. Kalisutan was not available to comment. Manulife is asking the Supreme Court to overrule the lower court ruling, an appeal that will take at most two months. During that time, Manulife's local unit is not supposed to pay out claims without the consent of Mr. Kalisutan. The Jakarta Commercial Court's ruling declaring the Manulife unit bankrupt has been widely criticized by lawyers and analysts who say it will undermine confidence in the local insurance industry. Indonesia's ministry of finance said the company was solvent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, LILLIAN
description: WALKER-Lillian. 92. Died in Palm Beach, FL, on June 16, 2002. She is survived by her loving children Carol and Kenneth, her sister Sydel, son-in-law David, daughterin-law Mary, grandchildren Andrew & Cheryle, Doug & Elena, and her great-grandchildren Sarah, Brian, Peter and Michael. God speed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telephone Concern Cuts Options
description: The chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, Ron Sommer, who is facing calls for his resignation, and seven other board members will forgo stock options in 2002 after the company posted its first loss last year. The stock has fallen 45 percent this year and shareholders have blamed Mr. Sommer's $35 billion purchase of the VoiceStream Wireless Corporation and the 67.3 billion euros ($63.6 billion) in debt he amassed making other acquisitions. A spokesman, Ulrich Lissek, said bonuses for 3,000 executives would be cut in half this year.

Burial to follow at Mount Carmel Cemetery in Tenafly, NJ. The family requests that memorial donations be made to the Holy Family School, Summit Street, Norwood, NJ 07648, or the Pan Am Historical Foundation, 52 Vanderbuilt Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

title: Iran and The War Of Ideas
description: What if a theocracy and a democracy had a baby? What would it look like? It would look like Iran.

description: A military investigation has found that an F-16 pilot mistakenly dropped a 500-pound bomb on Canadian soldiers conducting a nighttime live-fire exercise in Afghanistan in April because he did not take time to assess the threat properly before striking, military officials said today.

title: Deutsche Bank Is Shedding All Its Shares of Munich Re
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., Europe's biggest bank, said today that it was selling its entire 1.6 billion euro ($1.51 billion) stake in Munich Re, the world's largest reinsurer, to increase earnings and raise cash to buy back its own shares.

title: P.&G. Wants Heartburn Drug to Be Nonprescription
description: Procter & Gamble will ask a Food and Drug Administration panel on Friday to allow one of the world's most lucrative drugs -- AstraZeneca's indigestion remedy Prilosec -- to be sold without a prescription. But it faces a fight.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: THE HAGUE: DELAY IN MILOSEVIC'S TRIAL The war crimes trial of Slobodan Milosevic was suspended for a second day yesterday because the former Yugoslav President has the flu, a tribunal spokesman said. It is the second time that the trial, which will not resume before tomorrow, has been adjourned. The trial, which began on Feb. 12, was also suspended for two weeks in March because Mr. Milosevic was ill, and some lawyers at the court wonder if his insistence on conducting his own defense is taking its toll. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Turkey Sends Japan Home With Nothing
description: Japan's World Cup dreams dissolved in a steady downpour today as its team never recovered from a header by Umit Davala of Turkey 12 minutes into the game.

description: The Microsoft Corporation said that it would occupy two floors of Hong Kong's Cyberport, a struggling project that is supposed to create a campuslike setting for information technology businesses. title: Couple Plead Guilty in Kidnapping Case
description: They were all there in one crowded courtroom, the main characters of a 22-year drama that began with the disappearance of a baby boy in 1980 and ended yesterday with guilty pleas from a couple who fled to New Mexico, after losing a custody dispute, where they lived as fugitives while they raised the child.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Simone Lazer was named to the new post of director for new business development at Slingshot, New York. She had been business development manager at Zero 2 Sixty, a New York production company.

title: 'Corsaire' Tells Its Tale By Leaps and Bounds
description: Art and entertainment do go together, as the ultra-spectacular level of dancing showed on Monday night when American Ballet Theater presented ''Le Corsaire'' for the first time this season.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: No Progress Reported In Bus Talks
description: A three-hour meeting between union leaders and city officials yesterday afternoon yielded no progress toward resolving a bus strike that has stranded thousands of Queens commuters. Roger Toussaint, president of the union representing the 1,500 striking employees of three bus lines, said the city's labor commissioner, James F. Hanley, had offered an unacceptably small increase in health benefits. The lines are privately owned, but subsidized by the city and state. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that the city had no role in resolving a labor dispute between a private company and its workers. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: After Detour, Shuttle Lands in California
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 19  Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour took a cross-country detour today to California, taxiing two Americans back to Earth after the longest space mission in United States history.

title: Lesson From Woods Is a Dream Come True
description: Tiger Woods, the United States Open champion, was standing a few feet from Randall Brown and 13 other youngsters as they waited for a few golf pointers from him today at the Palm course at Walt Disney World. Randall could see a menacing string of black clouds approaching.

title: Bloomberg Appoints Conflict Board Chief
description: Steven B. Rosenfeld, a lawyer, was named chairman of the New York City Conflicts of Interest Board yesterday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Banks In Joint Venture
description: Ireland's two largest financial institutions, Bank of Ireland and Allied Irish Banks, will merge their information technology operations in a stand-alone joint venture that will eventually sell data management, storage, help desk and other services to banks and corporate customers. The venture, which has yet to be approved by European Union competition authorities, will employ 700 people, and requires Bank of Ireland to end its current relationship with Perot Systems of Dallas. A Bank of Ireland spokeswoman said that planning for the new company began last October. She added that it was unrelated to speculation about a possible merger between Bank of Ireland and Allied Irish.

title: G.M. Plant Gets Extra Year, And Workers Get New Hope
description: In the sprawling General Motors plant here, age and seniority confer privileges, while youth requires optimism and patience. So as the news spread today that the plant, originally scheduled to close in 2004, would get a year's reprieve, reaction split along generational lines.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Ravioli di Harlem: Mangia! Mangia!
description: Jennifer Holiday, the singer, was miffed. Unlike C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president, and Johnnie Cochran, the lawyer, her name was not on a dish at Amy Ruth's, 113 West 116th Street. It still is not, but she inspired Carl Redding, right, the chef and owner of Amy Ruth's, to create soul-violi, ravioli in soul food flavors, in her honor. And it says so on the menu. Mr. Redding uses sweet potatoes or collards in the pasta dough and has created six fillings, among them pured black-eyed peas, chopped barbecued pork, minced fried catfish and collard greens. A plate of soul-violi, $9.95, comes bathed in creamy sweet potato or chicken sauce. Soul-violi is also available to go, for the same price. And it will make a kind of debut at a benefit for Blue Nile Passage, a charity that helps children, tomorrow from 7 to 9 p.m. at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street. Tickets, $100 a person: (866) 777-0426.

title: Senate Panel Passes Curb on Tax Moves
description: A bill that would deny tax breaks to some American companies that have reincorporated in Bermuda, or plan to, was passed by the Senate Finance Committee yesterday on a voice vote.

description: Jack Reyna, age 3, has been to a couple of World Cup games. And what is his favorite cheer? "U-S-A!" he says with a big grin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITEHEAD, ROBERT
description: WHITEHEAD-Robert. The Officers and Board of Directors of the American Theatre Wing note with profound sorrow the passing of Robert Whitehead, a mentor and loyal supporter of the Wing and its activities. We will sadly miss this esteemed producer and distinguished member of the theatrical community and express sincere condolences to Zoe, Sam and Charlie. Isabelle Stevenson, Chairman of the Board Roy A. Somlyo, President

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Second Delay In Shuttle Return
description: Thunderstorms in Florida prompted NASA to postpone for a second consecutive day the return of the space shuttle Endeavour. The shuttle and seven astronauts are scheduled to land today. The shuttle has enough electrical power to stay in orbit until Thursday.

title: lectricit de France Buying Seeboard, a British Utility
description: The American Electric Power Company said today that it would sell its Seeboard regional power utility in Britain to the state-owned French power monopoly lectricit de France for $975 million in cash and the assumption of $1.05 billion in Seeboard debt.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about scrutiny of the finances of the Catholic Church in the United States referred incorrectly to the availability of information from the Archdiocese of Chicago about its $58 million reserve endowment. The fund was indeed included in a budget statement last year, under the heading "pastoral center savings" in the archdiocese's newsletter. It was not omitted.

title: A Health Care War Is Raging in the House
description: The great health care war of 2002 has erupted with a vengeance, as Republicans began to push their prescription drug bill through the House this week. The ferocity has as much to do with the stakes in November's elections as with disputes over policy.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about an upgrade of the National Weather Service's automated radio advisory system misstated the timing for installation and the site for testing. The installation, which includes the addition of an automated female voice, is expected to be completed next month, not begun then. The system was tested at offices in five cities, not in Phoenix.

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Joining Testing, At Last
description: After holding out for more than three decades, South Dakota will join all other states next year in the National Assessment for Educational Progress. President Bush has stipulated that states must give the test in reading and math to fourth- and eighth-grade students to qualify for federal money. The test results are used to compare schools by state. South Dakota had previously objected to the cost of the test. Under the Bush plan, the federal government will pay for the tests, which began in 1969.

title: Bush Allies Direct Heaviest Fire Against Both F.B.I. and C.I.A.
description: The sharpest criticism of the intelligence lapses at the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. has not come from liberal Democrats but from two conservative Republican senators, Charles E. Grassley of Iowa and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama.

title: JUDGE REJECTS CHALLENGE TO PHILIP MORRIS'S NAME CHANGE
description: The Philip Morris Companies can change its corporate name to the Altria Group, a federal judge in Denver said yesterday in a ruling that rejected a challenge by a venture capital firm with a similar name. The firm, Altira Group, sued to block the name change, arguing that institutional investors might be confused. The ruling allows Philip Morris to make the change until a trial can be held on a trademark-infringement issue. Philip Morris is changing its name to differentiate the parent company from its tobacco units.

title: Union Not Ready to Commit To Mandatory Steroid Tests
description: The head of Major League Baseball's players association told a Senate panel today that the players would give ''serious and thoughtful discussion'' to the issue of steroid use among its players, but he stopped short of saying the union would agree to permit mandatory testing for steroids in a new collective bargaining agreement. Donald Fehr, the union leader, said he would share concerns from Congress over reports of widespread use of steroids in baseball to the players association when it meets Wednesday in Montreal.

title: Bloomberg's 'Bullpen'
description: To the Editor:

title: Colorado Wildfire May Have Been Intentionally Set
description: Federal investigators have concluded that the Forest Service employee charged with starting a fire that has burned more than 100,000 acres in central Colorado set the blaze deliberately and lied when she said she had done so accidentally by burning a letter inside a campfire ring, a senior Forest Service official said today.

title: Parish Shaken by Reports of Sexual and Financial Misdeeds
description: Something bad was going on at St. Elizabeth's parish in Ozone Park, Queens, and Barbara Samide said recently that she had tried to get the Diocese of Brooklyn to do something about it since shortly after she was hired as principal of the parish's elementary school nearly two years ago.

title: Frequently Asked Questions about News Tracker
description: How many alerts may I create?

title: Barneys Reports a Profit
description: Barneys New York reported today that it had a first-quarter profit of $478,000 as it cut costs and kept inventory levels low.

title: Governor Could Hold Up A Deal on Minimum Wage
description: The Senate and Assembly have reached a consensus on raising the minimum wage to $6.75 an hour from $5.15 over the next year and a half, but officials said today that resistance by Gov. George E. Pataki was keeping the Senate from closing the deal.

title: Book-Club Smarts in a Nutshell: Get Notes
description: ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'' was a blockbuster book, spawning blockbuster sequels and a blockbuster movie. Next month, it will achieve that mark of a true classic: the publishers of SparkNotes, a CliffsNotes knockoff, will publish a study guide -- also known as a cheat sheet -- to the tale of the little boy with the lightning-bolt scar.

title: Retired Police Chief Will Oversee Security at La Guardia
description: A retired three-star New York Police Department chief was named federal security director for La Guardia Airport yesterday by Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: 2nd Suspect In Police  Shooting
description: The police have arrested a second man in connection with the shooting of a New Haven police officer last week. The man, Michael Rice, 37, of Milford, was arrested on Saturday; he was accused of providing the .38-caliber gun used to wound Officer Robert Fumiatti during a drug raid, said the office of the chief state's attorney. The police earlier arrested Arnold Bell, 36, charging him with attempted murder and assault on a police officer. Mr. Rice, who was released on bond, did not return a call seeking comment yesterday. Officer Fumiatti was listed in serious condition at Yale-New Haven Hospital. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Parents Will Gain Power in Public Schools, Deputy Mayor Says
description: Deputy Mayor Dennis M. Walcott tried to reassure parents yesterday that they would have more of a voice in how public schools are run under mayoral control than they did under the old decentralized system.

title: G.O.P. Candidate Seeks to Clarify Massachusetts Residency Issue
description: In his second day before a commission investigating whether his residency status could disqualify him from running for governor, Mitt Romney, the Republican candidate, said today that he never reviewed tax returns prepared by his accountants and therefore did not realize that the returns omitted his legal home state.

title: Former Regent Lauds a CUNY Decision
description: It was only a few years ago that the New York State Regents were deciding whether the City University of New York should be allowed to remove remedial instruction from its senior colleges. In a close vote, the board backed CUNY, but said it would keep a close eye on the results. Last week, at a commencement ceremony at CUNY in which he was awarded an honorary doctorate, CARL T. HAYDEN, the former Regents chancellor, said he believed it was the right decision, and that the university had greatly improved its quality. Karen W. Arenson

title: Illinois Dean to Lead Albany Law School
description: THOMAS F. GUERNSEY, the dean and a professor at Southern Illinois University School of Law, is to become the dean of Albany Law School in September. He will succeed THOMAS H. SPONSLER, who has been Albany's dean since 1995 and will retire at the end of this month. Albany has about 700 students. Stephanie Rosenbloom

description: To the Editor:

title: President Puts Off Outlining Ideas As Bombing Snags the Diplomacy
description: The suicide bombing in Israel this morning and continued debate over how strongly to endorse an interim Palestinian state have put off for at least a day or two a speech President Bush was expected to give this week outlining new ideas for Mideast peace efforts, senior administration officials said today.

title: Little Sign of Injury As Jeter Has 3 Hits
description: Derek Jeter got to first base and slapped his hands in satisfaction. He had just fisted a single over the infield in the sixth inning to score the Yankees' eighth run in a ballpark in which every run matters. It was Jeter's third hit and third run batted in of the game, and he did not seem hobbled at all.

title: Federal Funds to Help Troubled Students
description: The Human Resources Administration announced yesterday that it would provide $622,689 in federal funds to help students who attend public school near the World Trade Center site cope with lingering anxieties or nightmares about Sept. 11. Six community organizations in Lower Manhattan -- Grand Street Settlement, University Settlement, Educational Alliance, Henry Street Settlement, the Y.M.C.A. and Chinatown and Loisaida Inc. -- will use the funds to provide free after-school counseling and arts therapy to more than 1,500 students. The After-School Corporation, a nonprofit organization, will match the government funds. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Valley Stream: Ex-Official Admits Theft
description: A former Valley Stream school district official pleaded guilty yesterday to embezzling nearly $600,000 from the district over 10 years, the Nassau County district attorney said. The official, David Kutcher, 59, a former treasurer and assistant superintendent for one of four Valley Stream school districts, acknowledged that between 1990 and 2000 he wrote himself checks from a bank account that he had secretly set up in the district's name. Mr. Kutcher pleaded guilty to one count of third-degree grand larceny. He repaid the district and is expected to be sentenced to five years probation, said Marshall Trager, an assistant district attorney. Mr. Kutcher, who retired two years ago, is ''very remorseful,'' his lawyer said. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, DANIEL GERARD
description: COLLINS-Daniel Gerard. Suddenly on Sunday June 16th at age 72 after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Anne Weld Collins, dear brother of Muriel Collins, devoted father of Caitlin Ahl, Deirdre, Charles and Geoffrey Collins. Loving step-father of Serena, Evelyn, Alexander and Blake Crawford. Adoring grandfather of five. A memorial service will be announced at a future date.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILLER, ROBERT W.
description: MILLER-Robert W. June 19, 1948-December 25, 1998. You've not been forgotten.

title: An F.C.C. Move Catches the Media Industry in Mid-Yawn
description: Douglas H. McCorkindale, chairman of Gannett, and Shaun Sheehan, Tribune's vice president for Washington affairs, sounded like the last angry men in the media industry yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Soccer Is Still Not a Passion In the U.S.
description: I REMEMBER soccer. I played it on occasion many years ago in grade school gym class in our gravel-strewn schoolyard. I remember that when Mr. Kennedy, our gym teacher, told us what was on the agenda for the period -- no baseball, no football -- it was as if we were being sentenced to soccer.

title: Big Auditor's Return to Downtown Seems Dead
description: It was just the kind of move the city needs to herald the revival of corporate interest in Lower Manhattan: an effort by KPMG, the third-largest accounting firm in the world, to move its headquarters from Midtown to Lower Manhattan, near ground zero.

title: Israel's Pain, and Arafat's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; Now the Geese Must Watch Their Step
description: IN the suburban menagerie, geese are at the bottom of the pecking order.

title: ISRAEL ACTS TO SEIZE ARAB LAND AFTER BLAST; BUSH DELAYS TALK
description: Israel announced early this morning that it would begin seizing territory held by agreement by the Palestinian Authority, in response to a Palestinian suicide bombing on Tuesday that killed 19 people..

title: Appeals Panel Upholds Ruling For Open Court
description: A federal appeals panel refused today to block a judge's order that the Immigration and Naturalization Service hold open deportation hearings for so-called special-interest cases involving detainees held after Sept. 11.

title: Jets' Abraham Hopes To Be More of a Force
description: The playoff memory for Jets defensive end John Abraham is little more than a swirl of nausea and the cool hardness of a trainer's table in a dank locker room in Oakland, Calif. The first Jets playoff game since 1998 was played without him and, as a result, without much hope for a Jets victory.

title: A Teacher Of Dance Is Honored
description: Words, movement and music helped pay tribute to Martha Myers on Sunday night when she became this year's recipient of the American Dance Festival's Balasaraswati/Joy Ann Dewey Beinecke Endowed Chair for Distinguished Teaching.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: IRELAND: BANKS IN JOINT VENTURE Ireland's two largest financial institutions, Bank of Ireland and Allied Irish Banks , will merge their information technology operations in a stand-alone joint venture that will eventually sell data management, storage, help desk and other services to banks and corporate customers. The venture, which has yet to be approved by European Union competition authorities, will employ 700 people, and requires Bank of Ireland to end its current relationship with Perot Systems of Dallas. A Bank of Ireland spokeswoman said that planning for the new company began last October. She added that it was unrelated to speculation about a possible merger between Bank of Ireland and Allied Irish.

title: Italy Sees Nothing But Red in Loss To South Korea
description: The great pulsating celebration goes on.

title: Voucher Program Gets Failing Grade in Special Ed
description: FLORIDA has two school voucher programs. One, small but widely publicized, pays private tuition for students who abandon public schools that have low test scores. Students from 10 Florida schools, all in low-income areas, can get vouchers next year; experience suggests that few will use them.

title: Nassau Plan For Recovery Faces Hurdle On Key Point
description: State legislative leaders say that this week they will approve several measures critical to Nassau County's new fiscal recovery plan -- with a notable exception. The Senate is balking at one item that county officials say would save as much money as all the others combined.

title: Commander Sees at Least Another Year in Afghanistan
description: The commander of American troops in Afghanistan said today that he expected to need at least one more year to complete his mission here, namely to crush the remnants of Al Qaeda and the Taliban and to build the foundations of an Afghan national army.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Students Protest Plan To Change Test Policy
description: The news created an uproar at some of the nation's most competitive high schools, from Stuyvesant in New York City to Lakeside in Seattle. Students, many with their eyes set on the nation's top colleges, huddled in the hallways to vent their anger. Friends ranted over boxed lunches about their frustration. Articles in student newspapers berated the policy change.

title: Andersen Team Weighs Asking Judge to Undo Guilty Verdict
description: Lawyers for Arthur Andersen are discussing plans to ask a federal judge to throw out the firm's conviction on an obstruction of justice charge, based in part on the rationale given publicly by jurors for the verdict, members of the defense team said yesterday.

title: GILLETTE ORDERED TO PAY $10 MILLION TO SYNDIA
description: The Gillette Company was ordered yesterday by a jury to pay $10 million to the Syndia Corporation for infringing patents covering a method for coating razor blades with diamond-like carbon to make them stronger. Syndia said it might ask United States District Court Judge Joan Lefkow in Chicago to block Gillette from selling its Mach3, Mach3 Turbo and Venus razor blades because of the patent-infringement finding unless Gillette signs a licensing agreement. The $10 million is intended to compensate for past infringement, said Syndia, which is based in Chicago. Boston-based Gillette said that it would ask the judge to overturn the jury's finding and appeal the case if necessary. The jury finding does not affect the company's ability to make or sell its razors and will have ''no material impact on our business under any foreseeable outcome,'' a Gillette spokesman, Eric Kraus, said.

title: Reinventing the Hole
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Case Has a Surprise Near Its End
description: The federal judge in the Microsoft antitrust trial indicated for the first time yesterday that she was questioning the government's proposed settlement, which she could reject if she found that it was not in the public interest.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a segment of the Wall Street Journal staff that opposes a return to the paper's office near ground zero omitted the name of the union whose newsroom director commented on the findings of a survey. It is the Independent Association of Publishers' Employees, part of the Communications Workers of America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASMIN, ALLAN
description: KASMIN-Allan. Dad, you were the most independent, tough, loving, and sincere person we knew. We love you and miss you always. Franklin, Esther, Rebecca, and Devorah Kasmin

title: U.S. Officials Differ On Strategy for Iraq
description: The Bush administration has concluded that options short of an all-out military assault against Iraq, including bolstering opposition forces or fomenting a coup, should be used in an effort to dislodge President Saddam Hussein. But many in the administration expect those attempts to fail, and there is disagreement over how to proceed with a more robust military strategy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUNSELMAN, ELIZABETH STRONG
description: COUNSELMAN - Elizabeth Strong, 77. Died June 10 in Hightstown, NJ. Survived by brother, William Lord Strong of Rumson, N.J., daughter, Elizabeth B. Counselman of Princeton, many nieces, nephews, and cousins. Memorial service-July 9, 11 AM. Quaker Meeting, 470 Quaker Road, Princeton, NJ, ReceptionNassau Club in Princeton. In lieu of flowers, contributionsWorld Wildlife Fund. For information A.S. Cole Funeral Home, Cranbury, N.J.

title: Bloomberg to Fight Ban on Shelter Evictions
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will appeal a state court ruling that barred the Giuliani administration from ejecting homeless families from shelters and putting their children in foster care, city lawyers informed legal advocates for the homeless yesterday.

title: Filling Your Cup To Its Pacific Rim
description: Teas' Tea, bottled teas from Ito En of Japan, are made from brewed tea, not powdered concentrate, and are unsweetened, so there is a purity to the flavors: golden oolong, which hints of tropical fruit; pure green, with an almost chocolaty aftertaste; and the richly floral green jasmine. The teas, in 16.9-ounce bottles, are $1.50 each at the Ito En store, 822 Madison Avenue (69th Street), and $1.99 at Gourmet Garage and Healthy Pleasures stores.

title: Vaughn Still Seeks That Perfect Swing
description: Mo Vaughn's eyes sparkled, something they have not done much this season. His hand gestures went only so far, so he lifted his large frame from the folding chair in front of his locker and faced a visitor as if he were in the batter's box.

title: John A. Murphy, 72, Creator Of Brands at Miller Brewing
description: John A. Murphy, the president of the Miller Brewing Company at the time it began brewing different beers for different people, started advertising on sports broadcasts and introduced Miller Lite, died on Sunday at a hospital in his hometown of Glen Cove, N.Y. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, JOHN
description: LEE-John. Age 62. June 16, 2002 of Sayville, N.Y. Harrow & Trinity College, Cambridge, England. Author, editor, advertising and public relations executive. Memorial at Raynor & D'Andrea, 245 Montauk Hwy, West Sayville, N.Y. Thursday, June 20, 7-9:30PM. A private cremation will follow. Contributions to Sayville Rotary Club, Box 34, Sayville.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Nobody's going to read that 500-page John Adams book, but people still want to know what they missed and what they should retain.''

title: New Dean for Douglass College
description: Rutgers University last week named CARMEN TWILLIE AMBAR, assistant dean for graduate education at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University, the dean of Douglass College, the women's school at Rutgers with about 3,000 students. Ms. Ambar received a bachelor's degree in foreign service at Georgetown University and is a 1994 graduate of both Columbia School of Law and the Woodrow Wilson School.

title: Footlights
description: History's Seafarers

title: Keeping Eye on the Ball, Not the Skyline; At a Staten Island Ballpark, the View Has Changed, but Dreams Endure
description: Only a pair of eyes young, innocent and newly arrived could look out across New York Harbor and conjure up a clear vision of the future. Only those eyes could gaze at the Lower Manhattan skyline and not see the scars.

title: How Secure Is a Nuclear Waste Truck?
description: With the arrest of Jose Padilla, our worst fears were confirmed: Al Qaeda was planning to build and detonate a dirty bomb containing nuclear material in an American city. A danger previously relegated to Hollywood screenplays is now a reality.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about scrutiny of the finances of the Catholic Church in the United States referred incorrectly to the availability of information from the Archdiocese of Chicago about its $58 million reserve endowment. The fund was indeed included in a budget statement last year, under the heading ''pastoral center savings'' in the archdiocese's newsletter. It was not omitted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNIFFE, JOHN F.
description: CUNNIFFE-John F. On June 17, 2002 at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania at the age of 61. Beloved father of Colleen, Anne-Marie, Katie and Kieran, and grandfather of Mariah. Dear brother of Hugh & Patrick. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Wednesday, 7-9 P.M. and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Holy Family Church, Bronx New York, on Friday, June 21, at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations be made to Transplant Speakers International Inc., P.O. Box 6395, Freehold, New Jersey 07728 (501C3).

title: For Agent in Phoenix, the Cause of Many Frustrations Extended to His Own Office
description: The year was 1990, and of the thousands of newcomers arriving in Arizona, at least two were not lured by the blue skies and the dry desert heat. Kenneth Williams, fresh from the F.B.I. Academy, came as a rookie agent and would soon become the terrorism expert at the bureau's office here. Hani Hanjour, only 18, came to study English, and later flying. He would become a terrorist.

title: Battle to Beat Schrder Finds Hope in Europe's Tilt to Right
description: The conservative challenger for the German leadership, Edmund Stoiber, made an unusually emotional and bitter attack today on the current chancellor, Gerhard Schrder, and promised to oust the current government in elections Sept. 22.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIHALY, DR. EUGENE
description: MIHALY-Dr. Eugene. The President, Chancellor, Boards of Governors and Overseers, faculty, administration and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion record with profound sorrow the death of Dr. Eugene Mihaly, Deutsch Professor Emeritus of Jewish Jurisprudence and Social Justice, Professor Emeritus of Rabbinic Literature and Homiletics, former Executive Dean and Vice President for Academic Affairs and Cincinnati faculty member for over four decades. Dr. Mihaly touched the souls of generations of students with his passion for text, his erudition and creativity. His book, ''A Song to Creation'', inspired his students not only to understand text but to find their own voices as they study the complexities of Torah. His keen insight and leadership was instrumental in the academic growth nd vitality of HUC-JIR. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Cecile, sons Eugene and Marc and family whose loss we share. May they find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, Pres. Rabbi Alfred Gottschalk, Chancellor Emeritus Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors

title: For Cheaper Confit and a New Definition of Relaxed
description: THINGS got off to a shaky start at Caf Lebowitz. It was 8 p.m. when we arrived, and the staff was still setting tables and lighting candles. As I wedged into the red vinyl booth and moved toward its end, the bench lifted up like a seesaw. ''Whoops!'' I said, scrambling toward the middle.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Flights May Be Canceled
description: Three airlines, British Airways, Deutsche Lufthansa and Air France, plan to cancel as many as 90 percent of European services today as air traffic controllers in France and across Europe strike to protest a reorganization. British Airways, Europe's biggest airline, is dropping 97 percent of French flights, while Lufthansa, the region's No. 2 carrier, is canceling 86 percent of service to and from France. Air France has canceled 9 out of 10 European and domestic flights and 10 percent of long-haul services. French air traffic controllers will strike from 6 a.m. to 11 p.m. London time today, leading a Europewide walkout to protest the creation of a cross-border air traffic management system.

title: A Morning Commute by Bus Is Transformed Into a Shattering Blood Bath
description: Michael Lasri overslept a little this morning. So he had no breakfast cereal and left late for the technical high school where he is working on a project to build a remote-controlled car.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: New Terrorism Law
description: Legislation requiring that terrorist acts resulting in death be punished by a minimum of life in prison without parole was signed into law yesterday by Gov. James E. McGreevey. The law also makes criminal the production, development and possession of certain chemical weapons, and punishes those harboring or providing financial support to terrorists.

title: Some Progress for Turkish Women
description: As a result of a change in the law this spring, school officials in Turkey are no longer authorized to test girls for virginity. In recent years, Turkey has also overturned the legal supremacy of men in marriage and allowed women threatened with violence to get orders of protection. These vital moves represent welcome progress, but the very need for them illustrates how far Turkey still has to go to protect the rights of women and girls.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Settlement In Diesel Complaint
description: Six companies that operate fleets of diesel-powered vehicles, including Greyhound Lines and Frito-Lay, have agreed to pay for community projects after being accused of violating antipollution laws continually. The settlement, announced yesterday by Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer, covers companies that have a combined fleet of about 1,500 trucks, vans and buses. State law prohibits excessive engine idling. The companies agreed to pay more than $100,000 to plant 100 trees in the South Bronx, Harlem, Fort Greene and other neighborhoods that complained about diesel fumes. Jason Begay (NYT)

title: Red Cross Relief Effort for Colorado
description: The American National Red Cross said yesterday that it had collected enough donations to cover the needs of victims of the wildfires in Colorado.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Delay In Milosevic's Trial
description: The war crimes trial of Slobodan Milosevic was suspended for a second day yesterday because the former Yugoslav President has the flu, a tribunal spokesman said. It is the second time that the trial, which will not resume before tomorrow, has been adjourned. The trial, which began on Feb. 12, was also suspended for two weeks in March because Mr. Milosevic was ill, and some lawyers at the court wonder if his insistence on conducting his own defense is taking its toll. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Teachers on the Edge
description: To the Editor:

title: A Vigorous Skeptic Of Everything but Fact; His Target: The Paranormal on TV and in Film
description: These are some of the things that Paul Kurtz, chairman of the Committee for the Scientific Investigation of Claims of the Paranormal and publisher of the magazine Skeptical Inquirer, does not believe in: parapsychology, holistic cures for animal illnesses, the universal effectiveness of chiropractic, extraterrestrial beings, alternative medicine, Bigfoot and organized religion.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Doctors Reduce Reliance On Antibiotics
description: A new study suggests doctors are prescribing antibiotics for children far less often. Bacteria can gain resistance to antibiotics over time, and needless prescriptions shorten the useful life of the drugs. Researchers at the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention surveyed about 3,000 doctors and estimated that 30 million children received such prescriptions in 2000, down from 46 million in 1989. The new study appears in The Journal of the American Medical Association. Philip J. Hilts (NYT)

title: At One of 1,000 Front Lines in U.S., Local Officials Try to Plan for War
description: Driving around her pristine village, Mayor Karen Bushy does not see the McMansions with manicured lawns, the shopping center whose lots brim with BMW's, the gleaming windows in all those office buildings.

title: Seeking the Perfect Squeeze: Juice Without Seeds
description: NEXT to slicing onions, one of the most common kitchen techniques may be squeezing juice from lemons and limes. It is a straightforward task with one annoying aspect: seeds. As you juice the fruit, the seeds inevitably drop into your vinaigrette, salad or batter, and then you must carefully fish them out.

title: New Dean for Douglass College
description: Rutgers University last week named CARMEN TWILLIE AMBAR, assistant dean for graduate education at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University, the dean of Douglass College, the women's school at Rutgers with about 3,000 students. Ms. Ambar received a bachelor's degree in foreign service at Georgetown University and is a 1994 graduate of both Columbia School of Law and the Woodrow Wilson School. Karen W. Arenson

title: Retirement Rules Gone, the Ivory Tower Goes Gray
description: At 78, Robert G. Shulman remains an active and distinguished member of the academic community at Yale.

title: Queen's Treasures on Parade
description: For the last 40 years, even avid art lovers could be forgiven for not noticing the Queen's Gallery at Buckingham Palace. Opened in 1962 on the site of a Victorian chapel destroyed in World War II, its single large room was reached through a dingy corridor that led from an unassuming side entrance to the palace. It could not compete with London's many fine museums and was ill-equipped to present even a sample of the vast Royal Collection.

title: Nursery School Head to Resign on Request
description: CHERYL A. KELLY, the director of the Episcopal School, a nursery school on East 69th Street in Manhattan, has agreed to resign at the request of the school's board, said Joy McLendon, the board president, citing differences of opinion. Ms. Kelly was director of the 220-student school for about eight years. Robert Worth

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Shooting Suspect Is Arraigned
description: A man accused of shooting three people and threatening to ignite kerosene in an East Village bar full of hostages early Sunday morning appeared for an arraignment in Manhattan criminal court yesterday. The man, Steven Johnson of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, did not enter a plea. The district attorney is investigating whether Mr. Johnson, 34, tried to escape from the authorities on Monday night. Mr. Johnson is accused of three counts of attempted murder, three counts of assault as a hate crime, six counts of criminal possession of a weapon and reckless endangerment. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Refurbishing Tweed Courthouse
description: The city will spend an additional $6.5 million to prepare the Tweed Courthouse so that the Board of Education can move in, said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's press secretary. The building requires electrical work, painting, carpeting and office furniture. The money, to be spent by the Department of Citywide Administrative Services and the Economic Development Corporation, will not cover turning the first floor into classrooms. Mr. Bloomberg said earlier this year that he would move the board and one school into the courthouse, which had been scheduled for use by a museum. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Anniversary Party
description: The Mayflower Park Hotel, at 405 Olive Way in Seattle's shopping and business district, has been in business 75 years. To mark that anniversary, it is offering a discounted rate of $129 plus tax for one of its newly renovated guest rooms. The 171-room hotel is a few blocks from the Pike Place Market. Rates are subject to availability. Information: (800) 426-5100 or at www.mayflowerpark.com .

title: The Agnellis Still Make Fiats, Don't They?
description: There has been much speculation lately that the Agnelli family of Italy is planning to get out of the automobile business. What has gotten little notice is that it has already begun.

title: A Dutch Oven From France Turns a Home Into a Hearth
description: Most home cooks need only one heavy Dutch oven, and one usually lasts a lifetime. Mine  more than 50 years old  belonged to my mother. But I am sorely tempted to buy one by Staub, a French brand adored by top chefs and now available in America. These casseroles "conduct heat beautifully, and yet they're elegant enough to go into the dining room," said David Waltuck of Chanterelle, which uses them. The black matte finish gives the pots a cast-iron look, but heavy enamel actually covers the cast iron. The pots are rustproof and need no seasoning. The lids have brass knobs, and studs on the underside encourage cooking juices to condense onto the surface of the food, automatically basting it. The pots range from one cup to 12 1/2 quarts. Sur La Table in Manhasset, N.Y., and around the country sells the cookware, which is $29.95 for the one-cup version to $235.95 for an eight-quart size. It can be ordered from (800) 243-0852, www.surlatable.com or from Staub, which carries the entire line and whose prices are slightly lower. Green, blue, yellow and purple casseroles are available from Staub, (866) 782-8287 and can be special-ordered from Sur La Table.

title: Irne Lidova, 95, Dance Critic and Producer
description: Irne Lidova, a dance critic and producer who played a major role in founding creative ballet companies in postwar France, died on May 23 in Paris. She was 95 and lived in Paris.

title: A Park Performance Called by the Elements
description: Some 50,000 hopeful people showed up at the Great Lawn in Central Park on Monday night for the Metropolitan Opera's free concert performance of Rossini's ''Barbiere di Siviglia'' on what seemed at first a perfect night. The skyline to the south was vividly clear. The only threatening weather seemed to be some overly perky winds, which twice during the overture rustled sheet music off the stands of violinists in the Met's orchestra.

title: Prospero, Sugar-Free, In Debut Of Troupe
description: Prospero is brooding and angry in the production of ''The Tempest'' by the Kings County Shakespeare Company, flirting with vengeance against the enemies he torments with hallucinations. So it is his salvation from his own black magic that gives the play's last scene its great sense of peace.

title: The Mets' Momentum Expires Quickly
description: On Sunday night, the Mets were cheered going off the field, carried by the euphoria of beating the Yankees in two of three games. The few boos they heard last weekend were mostly directed at the Yankees' Roger Clemens.

title: Removing Gold Buffs Up An Old Park Ave. Nugget
description: Sometimes it improves matters to ungild the lily. When Harry B. Helmsley decided in 1978 to update the building astride Park Avenue between 45th and 46th Streets, one of his solutions to deteriorating surfaces was gold paint. Lots of it.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Bombardier Drops Interest In Rival
description: The Canadian maker of small commercial aircraft, Bombardier, said it was no longer interested in buying a European rival, Fairchild Dornier. Bombardier said it reviewed Fairchild's plans to build two regional business jets and determined that the potential profit was not worth the investment. Fairchild Dornier has already said it will cut up to a third of its 3,600 employees. Fairchild, which is owned by the German insurer Allianz and the New York investment firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, filed for the European equivalent of bankruptcy on April 2. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: White House Condemns Bombings but Says Peace Must Be Pursued
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  The White House stood by Israel today in its retaliation for the suicide bombing that killed 19 people on Tuesday. But the timing of the expression of support  a day later than usual  and a second bloody bombing today underlined the Bush administration's difficulties with its Middle East policy.

title: White Seeks a Fourth Opinion
description: Afew years ago, I interviewed Chuck Bednarik, the football Hall of Famer who played on both sides of the ball from the 1940's to the 60's. Shaking hands with Bednarik, it was impossible not to notice the gnarled fingers a hard-playing career had given him.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHORR, DAVID
description: SHORR-David. Ten years. We all miss you. The Family

title: Clemens Pitch to Cost Estes
description: Bob Watson, baseball's vice president for discipline, told the Mets yesterday that he would fine Shawn Estes $750 for what he said was his intention to hit the Yankees' Roger Clemens with a pitch last Saturday.

title: Doctors Learn in the Long Night Hours
description: Even though I completed my residency 13 years ago, I will never forget the night when, as resident on call, I admitted 12 patients and was paged with the news that three more were coming from the emergency room. I had a bunch of IV's to start, a couple of blood tests to draw -- not to mention a ward already full of sick children. I was so tired that even my hair hurt.

title: Germans Say Figure Linked To Sept. 11 Is in Syria Jail
description: A Syrian-born German citizen who is considered an important figure in the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington is being held in a Syrian jail, senior German officials said today.

title: Ratings Wake Up Network Projections
description: Despite being televised at what qualifies as the wee hours of the morning in the East, the World Cup soccer matches from South Korea and Japan have been viewed by audiences of up to seven million viewers, greatly exceeding expectations for all three television networks that have carried the games.

title: Willie Davenport, 59, Gold Medal Olympian in High Hurdles
description: Willie Davenport, who won the 110-meter high hurdles at the 1968 Summer Olympics and also appeared in a Winter Olympics, competing as a bobsledder at Lake Placid in 1980, died Monday in Chicago. He was 59.

title: Navratilova Transforms the Old Into the New
description: Behind the familiar spectacles that appear cut from a Mason jar, on feet that have done the cha-cha at the net on every surface but a moonscape, Martina Navratilova could have stood as an indulgence for nostalgia lovers yesterday.

title: 2 Americans Detained in Pakistan Near Afghan Border Had No Ties to Terror, U.S. Says
description: The Bush administration disclosed today that two American citizens of Afghan origin were detained in Pakistan last month for immigration violations along the Afghan border, and that one was deported to the United States last weekend.

title: Drug Bill Clears One Hurdle but Quickly Encounters Another
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  A Republican bill to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly was approved early today by one House committee, but became bogged down in another panel, where Democrats denounced the legislation as a gift to the drug industry in return for large campaign contributions.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HUFFY CORP., Miamisburg, Ohio, a maker of bicycles, said it would purchase privately held Gen-X Sports Inc., Toronto, maker of Tommy Armour golf and Sims snowboard products, for about $54.9 million in cash and stock, to diversify its products and extend its business into Canada.

title: Israel's Pain, and Arafat's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Tenet Healthcare Settles Billing Dispute
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the second-biggest United States hospital chain, said today that it would pay $55.75 million to settle allegations that two of its hospitals overbilled the Medicare program.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Peace Talks With Rebels
description: Sudanese officials and their rebel counterparts gathered in the Kenyan town of Machakos to start five weeks of talks aimed at ending the 18-year civil war, Africa's longest-running conflict. Both sides declared themselves committed to peace but outsiders were skeptical of an early end to the war. The Sudan People's Liberation Army is seeking self-determination. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: A Dutch Oven From France Turns a Home Into a Hearth
description: Most home cooks need only one heavy Dutch oven, and one usually lasts a lifetime. Mine -- more than 50 years old -- belonged to my mother. But I am sorely tempted to buy one by Staub, a French brand adored by top chefs and now available in America. These casseroles ''conduct heat beautifully, and yet they're elegant enough to go into the dining room,'' said David Waltuck of Chanterelle, which uses them (left). The black matte finish gives the pots a cast-iron look, but heavy enamel actually covers the cast iron. The pots are rustproof and need no seasoning. The lids have brass knobs, and studs on the underside encourage cooking juices to condense onto the surface of the food, automatically basting it. The pots range from one cup to 12 1/2 quarts. Sur La Table in Manhasset, N.Y., and around the country sells the cookware, which is $29.95 for the one-cup version to $235.95 for an eight-quart size. It can be ordered from (800) 243-0852, www.surlatable.com or from Staub, which carries the entire line and whose prices are slightly lower. Green, blue, yellow and purple casseroles are available from Staub, (866) 782-8287 and can be special-ordered from Sur La Table.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAYAN, EZRA
description: DAYAN-Ezra. Of Delray Beach, FL, passed away June 18, 2002. Loving husband, father, grandfather and brother. Services Thursday, June 20, 1:00 PM at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. For information: ''Gutterman's'', Woodbury, LI.

title: Police Trades Workers Are Top Overtime Earners
description: The top individual overtime earners in city government this fiscal year were Police Department trades workers like painters, plumbers and carpenters, but such spending by the agency has dropped sharply compared with the previous year, city and police officials said yesterday.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: West Side Provenal

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Voting Reforms Proposed
description: A state task force appointed after the disputed 2000 presidential election proposed yesterday that the state replace aged mechanical voting machines with a computerized system. It also recommended a computer database of voter registration, so that counties can share information and combat voter fraud. The task force, appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders, estimated that its recommendations would cost $200 million and take several years to implement. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: J. Carter Brown, 67, Is Dead; Transformed Museum World
description: J. Carter Brown, the eloquent, populist, patrician museum director who, as head of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, did as much as anyone to reshape art museums during the second half of the 20th century, died on Monday at a Boston hospital. He was 67.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Convictions In Attack On Foreigners
description: Three former skinheads have been found guilty of attempted murder for throwing firebombs at an apartment complex housing asylum seekers in the city of Rostock 10 years ago. They were given suspended sentences of 12 to 18 months. The trial was the last of dozens of hearings into the attack, for which about 30 other people have been convicted, receiving sentences of up to three years' imprisonment. The court said it regretted that it had taken 10 years to bring all the attackers to justice. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Senate Passes Aid to Insurers On Terrorism
description: The Senate passed legislation today requiring the government to pay the overwhelming majority of financial losses in a major terrorist attack, though the measure takes a markedly different approach from one approved by the House.

title: From 'Cats' to Cicero
description: On Air Force One on Friday, Ari Fleischer gave reporters a preview of the president's schedule, including a pitch for fitness in Orlando, a Republican fund-raiser in Florida, a T-ball game on the South Lawn, a Presidential 3 Mile Run in Washington, the White House Fitness Expo and another fund-raiser at the Washington Convention Center.

title: Making Waves on Air: Big Radio's Bad Boy
description: Wall Street admires the nation's largest radio broadcasting conglomerate, Clear Channel Communications, as a fast-growing, profitable multimedia empire. It includes the largest chain of radio stations -- five times the number of its nearest rival -- and the biggest collection of billboards, as well as growing collections of television stations and concert halls.

title: Taking His Panache to TV, Stalking Injustice, His Way
description: ''Power, Privilege and Justice,'' a new weekly crime program on Court TV, embraces the two lessons of Dominick Dunne's bipolar career as vigilante and social gadfly: you can get away with murder, but you cannot buy your way into Palm Beach society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONZEIT, DAVID
description: SCHONZEIT-David. Beloved husband of Irene. Devoted father of Darin and Michael. Cherished grandfather of Samuel and Gregory Sharpe. Loving brother of Marvin, Shain and Doris Wagner. Service 2:30PM, Wednesday, at Garden of Remembrance Cemetery, Clarksburg, MD. Contributions to American Cancer Society.

title: Indefinite Detention
description: To the Editor:

title: Witnessing the Witness: Looking Over a Shoulder at War's Deprivation
description: Even if you have never heard of James Nachtwey, the award-winning photojournalist who is the subject of Christian Frei's new documentary ''War Photographer,'' it is likely that you are familiar with his work. For more than two decades Mr. Nachtwey has traveled to places in the world devastated by war, famine and poverty and documented the cruelty and suffering he has found with an devastating, eloquent clarity. He was in Nicaragua at the height of the contra war, in South Africa during the bloody mid-1980's and in Rwanda in the aftermath of the 1994 genocide.

title: Estes Caught in the Middle
description: Shawn Estes had completed his round of interviews before Friday night's game, in anticipation of the most scrutinized start of his career. Estes, in his first year as a Met, was facing the Yankees on Saturday at Shea Stadium and, more notably, Roger Clemens in the batter's box. Clemens would be batting against the Mets for the first time since beaning Mike Piazza two years ago and then throwing a shattered bat at him in that World Series.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IGNATOW, ARCHIE
description: IGNATOW-Archie. Thoughts of you are with us always, especially on your birthday. Remembered with love, Gene and three generations

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a judge's decision to overturn the murder conviction of Marjorie Knoller, a San Francisco woman whose dog mauled a neighbor to death, misstated the name of the dog in some copies. It was Bane, not Dane.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Refinery Deal Completed
description: In another move by a Russian oil company to buy oil assets in Eastern Europe, Yukos, Russia's No. 2 oil producer, completed the purchase of a 26.85 percent stake in the Mazeikiu oil refinery in Lithuania. The agreement was concluded with the refinery's other owners, Williams International of the United States, and the Lithuanian government. Yukos will pay $75 million, lend the refinery a further $75 million and supply it with crude for the next decade. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Bush Proposes Spending $500 Million on AIDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  With both Republicans and Democrats in Congress urging him to spend more to fight global AIDS, President Bush announced today a $500 million initiative to prevent expectant mothers from infecting their babies with the virus that causes the disease.

title: Market Place; Lehman had another somber quarter, but its performance wasn't without silver linings.
description: NAVIGATING through rocky financial seas, Lehman Brothers Holdings reported yesterday that its second-quarter profit fell 31 percent as a sharp decline in merger advisory work and stock underwriting more than offset strength in bond operations. It was the fifth decline in the last six quarters.

title: Jack Buck, 77, Measured Voice of Cardinals Baseball
description: Jack Buck, whose nearly 50 years as the voice of the St. Louis Cardinals positioned him to describe the baseball exploits of Stan Musial and Mark McGwire and to work alongside his son, died yesterday. He was 77.

title: On Cooking Peas
description: To the Editor:

title: Downtown Columbus Loses Out to Its Fringe
description: A coffee shop in the heart of this city is called Insomnia. A sign on the door says it closes at 5 p.m., but that is not true. It never even opens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ROBERT M.
description: MILLER - Robert M. Of Larchmont on June 9, 2002 at age 69 after a long illness. Survived by his wife Helaine, daughters Jennifer Miller (NYC) and Alicia (husband Scott) Talmadge (Rye Brook) granddaughters, Eliza and Larsen and a sister Linda. For more information Zion Memorial Chapel 914-381-1809

title: Don't Stop Recycling
description: To the Editor:

title: McSorley's Stormy Career Makes Track Change in Springfield
description: Marty McSorley was an enforcer of some repute, and the best ones learn fast to throw their hardest punches early. McSorley was introduced today as the coach of the American Hockey League's Springfield Falcons. Before anyone asked, McSorley made a point to mention that he had other job offers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRYOR, WILLIAM YOUNG
description: PRYOR-William Young. Of Essex Fells, NJ on June 14, 2002. Husband of the late Marianna (nee Brand). Devoted father of Ann Love Pryor of West Milford, NJ and William Brand Pryor and his wife Beverly of Caldwell, NJ. Loving grandfather of Morgan and William. Funeral service will be held in Dancy Funeral Home, 9 Smull Ave, Caldwell NJ on Thursday at 11AM. Friends may call Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Masonic Service will be held by Kane Lodge #

title: Morocco Detainee Linked to Qaeda
description: A senior agent for Al Qaeda with links to the group's former operations chief has been arrested in Morocco, goverment officials said today.

title: Israel's Pain, and Arafat's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes From Tysons Corner; A Suburb All Grown Up and Paved Over
description: The first commandment of the suburbs used to be Not in My Back Yard. Apparently now it is Not in Your Front Yard -- at least here in Fairfax County, Va., just over the Potomac from Washington.

title: STEAKHOUSE CHAIN RECEIVES A HIGHER BID FROM FINANCIER
description: The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn raised his offer for the Morton's Restaurant Group, the steakhouse chain. Last month, he bid $13.50 a share, or $56.6 million. That was matched on Monday by Castle Harlan, a leverage buyout firm that is Morton's former owner; Morton's agreed to accept Castle's bid. The new offer from Mr. Icahn, at $15 a share, would be worth $63 million, an 11 percent premium over Castle Harlan's offer. Shares of Morton's, based in New Hyde Park, N.Y., rose $1.15, to $15.10.

title: Man Is Shot at Tire Store
description: A 26-year-old man was shot to death yesterday while he was buying oil at a tire store in the New Lots section of Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: Chambers of Memory Within a Scarred Heart
description: MARTIN SLOANE

title: Bush Officials Differ on Way To Force Out Iraqi Leader
description: The Bush administration has concluded that options short of an all-out military assault against Iraq, including military support to opposition forces or fomenting a coup, should be tried over the next few months to dislodge President Saddam Hussein from power.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Agreement On New Government
description: The Czech Social Democrats said they had reached a preliminary agreement with the two-party center-right Coalition to form a new government that could lead the country into the European Union by 2004. The government would have only 101 seats in the key 200-seat lower chamber of Parliament and analysts fear that it may not be able to push through key reforms. The prime minister-designate, Vladimir Spidla, whose left-of-center Social Democrats came first with 71 seats in national elections last weekend, has said he wants to create a modern welfare state and bring the country into the European Union. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The Cabaret Guide in Weekend on Friday included an outdated cast listing for ''Our Sinatra'' at the Reprise Room at Dillon's on West 54th Street in Manhattan. Johnny Rodgers has left the show; Ronny Whyte replaced him.

title: Warning the Public to Get Its Dukes Up
description: JOHN WHEELER, after graduating from West Point in 1966, was assigned to a missile crew for a year in Franklin Lakes, N.J. The missiles, which had the capacity to carry nuclear tips, were to be fired over New York City in the event of an attack by Soviet-bloc bombers. In training drills, the crew tracked B-52's zeroing in on the Empire State Building.

title: Stephanopoulos Named Anchor Of 'This Week'
description: The long-expected naming of George Stephanopoulos as the sole anchor of the ABC public affairs program ''This Week'' finally became official yesterday. There was also some actual news in the announcement: George Will, the conservative commentator, will remain as a panelist on the program.

title: Bucharest Journal; The King's Heir? Hmm, That's Not Fully Apparent
description: Ever since he first visited Romania 12 years ago, a man named Paul has been fighting to be recognized as the heir to a throne that no longer exists.

title: Accountants on Trial
description: The Senate Banking Committee did its part yesterday in putting to rest any concerns that Arthur Andersen might be made the sole scapegoat for the systemwide failure of the nation's accounting industry. On the heels of last Saturday's conviction of Andersen for obstructing a federal inquiry into the Enron collapse, the committee approved -- by an unexpectedly wide margin -- a bill creating a strong oversight body for the profession and removing some of its current conflicts of interest.

title: Corrections
description: A letter on Monday about the nursing shortage referred incorrectly to plans by the City University of New York to add 30 faculty positions in nursing. That number applies to all 12 CUNY nursing programs, not only to the one at the Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: Two Men Convicted In Murder of Three Above Carnegie Deli
description: The two men accused of fatally shooting three people and wounding two others in a bloody, botched robbery in an apartment above the Carnegie Delicatessen last year were found guilty of second-degree murder yesterday by separate juries.

title: KIRBY, A RIVER HAULER, CUTS PROFIT FORECASTS
description: The Kirby Corporation, a hauler of petroleum products and other goods on rivers, pared its second-quarter and full-year profit forecasts yesterday because of falling demand for liquid fertilizer. Profit this quarter will be 36 cents to 38 cents a share, less than an earlier forecast of 46 cents to 50 cents. Full-year profit will total $1.60 to $1.70, instead of the $1.92 to $2.02 previously predicted.

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review last Wednesday about Washington Park, which opened recently in Greenwich Village, referred incorrectly to the location it occupies at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Ninth Street. That is not the former site of the old Brevoort House hotel and restaurant. The Brevoort was at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighth Street.

title: There's Joy in South Korea, And There's Agony in Italy
description: In South Korea, an estimated four million people, nearly 10 percent of the country's population, poured into the streets last night to celebrate. In Italy, sweltering in a heat wave, the mood was sullen, with fans blaming a referee for Italy's stunning 2-1 overtime loss.

title: Pope (U.S.) and Klose (Germany): A Big Game's Big Guys
description: They play for different teams and speak different languages, these tall and quietly confident men who will bring opposing resolve to the quarterfinals of the World Cup. One will be assigned to put the ball into the American goal, once, twice, as many times as possible. The other's urgent purpose will be to keep it out.

title: Big Brother vs. Terrorist in Spy Camera Debate
description: Amid uncertainty about whether surveillance cameras should be used to control crowds, detect terrorists or scare off drug dealers, the authorities in the nation's capital are debating rules intended to keep them from becoming a tool of Big Brother spying on citizens.

title: Martha Stewart Submits Plane and Phone Records
description: Trying to resolve questions about her sale of ImClone shares last December, Martha Stewart hired a new lawyer yesterday and submitted several documents to Congressional investigators.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Underwear Check Leads To Demotion
description: An assistant principal who raised girls' skirts and parents' ire when she screened for proper underwear at a San Diego high school dance was demoted on Monday to a teaching position. An investigation by the Poway Unified School District found that the administrator, Rita Wilson, 47, of Rancho Bernardo High School, ''went far beyond the grounds of propriety.'' Ms. Wilson said later she was not against thongs, but against bottoms being exposed when girls danced. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

description: The usual happy endings are missing in the new productions of ''Swan Lake'' and ''La Bayadre'' by Yuri Grigorovich that the Bolshoi Ballet has just performed here and will take on a United States tour next fall.

title: Boston Airport, Sept. 11 to Live Down, Aspires to Big Changes
description: Logan International Airport may never erase its Sept.11 stigma, inflicted by 10 terrorists who boarded two American Airlines jets here on their way to destroying the World Trade Center.
