description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Boys Charged With Setting Fatal Fire at a Beijing Internet Cafe
description: BEIJING, June 19  Two teenage boys have been arrested and charged with intentionally setting the fire that killed 24 last weekend in an unlicensed Internet cafe, the city government said in a statement today.

title: Russia Seeking to Dismantle Collective Farms
description: A decade after it began its spasmodic transition to capitalism, the Russian government is moving to dismantle one of the lasting legacies of the Stalinist era: the collectivization of the nation's farmlands.

title: G.O.P. Must Control Congress, Bush Tells Donors
description: President Bush told more than 6,000 people at a multimillion-dollar Republican gala tonight that it was essential for the party to retain control of the House and to win back the Senate.

title: Leslie Midgley, 87, Prolific TV News Producer
description: Leslie Midgley, a newspaperman who overcame his skepticism about television and became producer of 1,500 programs for CBS News, including coverage of the Kennedy assassination, its aftermath and the fall of Saigon, died yesterday in White Plains. He was 87.

title: Calendar
description: Garden Tours

title: A Little Kitsch For the Playboy Of the 21st Century
description: It's not too late to be a bachelor from the 1960's, and not just in your mind. Playboy Enterprises has consigned close to 10,000 items to Butterfields for auction in Los Angeles on Sunday, including club keys with a velvet drawstring bag; a rug, above, from the Playboy Clubs, which is expected to sell for $600 to $800; and a maquette of the logo, inset, which is expected to sell for $2,000 to $3,000. ''Playboy had such an impact on young men of that generation,'' said Peter Loughrey, the sale's director. ''Teaching bachelors how to be more sophisticated -- the best cars, the most stylish clothes, what kind of Scotch to drink, what kind of jazz to listen to.'' Information: www.butterfields.com or (323) 436-5451. WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

title: You Can't Fish for This Trophy
description: Rather than waiting for a real marlin to bite during your summer vacation, you can accessorize your weekend cottage with a full-size fake. ''Our painted-tin marlin was inspired by the whole funky Tiki look in home decorating,'' said Lisa Frudden, marketing director of Palecek, the California-based company that imports it. The marlin -- 51 inches long and made in the Philippines -- is $165 at Beach Bungalow, 26 Main Street, Sag Harbor, N.Y. Or call Palecek for other stores; (800) 274-7730. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Soccer Boss Cheap-Shots His Own Ref
description: SEOUL, South Korea

title: Research Clinic Opens in Ohio for Genetic Maladies That Haunt Amish Families
description: ''We've been waiting 16 years for an answer,'' said Mark Kauffman, an Amish farmer whose four profoundly handicapped children thrashed spasmodically in wheelchairs and a crib before the watchful gaze of the visiting physician.

title: When Asylum Seekers Knock, Europe Is Deaf
description: If the Denmark that Muhammed al-Bayati reached after a harrowing journey from Iraq is not the one he hoped to find, neither, for that matter, is the rest of Europe.

description: Manhattan

title: Technology Briefing | Software: E.D.S. In $100 Million Bank Deal
description: Electronic Data Systems said yesterday that it had agreed to a $100 million contract to overhaul Bank Leumi's information-technology operations over the next five to seven years. Electronic Data Systems, based in Plano, Tex., said that Bank Leumi, based in Tel Aviv, would receive new software systems and an overhaul of all its major systems. A spokesman for E.D.S. said that the new systems should significantly cut Bank Leumi's operational and maintenance costs and cut the time it takes to move products and services to market. The spokesman said he expected Bank Leumi to recover the cost of the system in five to six years after installation.

title: Office Turf: No. 1 Faces An Upstart
description: MICROSOFT once ran a great ad for Office, its business-software cash cow. It went something like this: ''Over 94 percent of the business world uses Microsoft Office. What are we doing wrong?''

title: Bush Offers Plan to Help Mothers Avoid Passing H.I.V. to Babies
description: With both Republicans and Democrats in Congress urging him to increase spending to fight global AIDS, President Bush announced a $500 million plan today to prevent expectant mothers from passing the AIDS virus to their babies.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Museum Official Arrested
description: A conservator who oversaw artifact restoration for Nassau County's museums was arrested yesterday and accused of stealing century-old artifacts under his care. The conservator, Richard Kappeler, 54, of Oyster Bay, is charged with stealing objects worth at least $20,000, said Philip Tomich, the deputy chief of special investigations for the Nassau County district attorney's office. Mr. Kappeler has been dismissed. His lawyer did not return a call seeking comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Rights of Women: More Than a Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: No Margin for Error
description: Global warming is already attacking the world's coral reefs and, if nothing is done soon, could begin a long-term assault on the vast West Antarctic Ice Sheet. If the ice sheet begins to disintegrate, the worldwide consequences over the next several centuries could well be disastrous.

title: JERUSALEM BLAST KILLS SIX ISRAELIS; ARMY RAIDS START
description: For the second day in a row, a Palestinian suicide bomber struck this embattled city on Wednesday, this time killing six people at a bus stop, even as Israel began carrying out a policy of taking back land on the West Bank in retaliation for the attacks.

title: No to Plastics And Glass; Yes to Paper And Metal
description: New Yorkers will no longer recycle glass or plastic, at least temporarily, but will continue bundling paper and separating metals from their garbage, under a tentative city budget deal.

description: To the Editor:

title: How Do You Leave Carnegie Hall? Reluctantly
description: FORGIVE big, burly Jon Faddis, director for a decade of the soon-to-be-extinct Carnegie Hall Jazz Band, if he is not, in jazz parlance, feeling like his usual hepcat self.

title: Goldman Profits in Sale of Korean Bank Stake
description: In a long-awaited move for maximum profit from one of the largest foreign investments in the Korean economy, Goldman Sachs sold about 60 percent of its stake in the Kookmin Bank for $633.6 million today.

title: Corrections
description: Anews analysis article on Monday about American efforts to avert war between Pakistan and India misstated the given name of a South Asia expert at the Brookings Institution who commented on the outlook for a solution. He is Stephen P. Cohen, not Philip.

title: Real Estate Fever: A Lust for Listings
description: THE inventor of baseball cards missed a golden opportunity to capture another market: real estate addicts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNIFFE, JOHN F.
description: CUNNIFFE-John F. On June 17, 2002 at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania at the age of 61. Beloved father of Colleen, Anne-Marie, Katie and Kieran, and grandfather of Mariah. Dear brother of Hugh & Patrick. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Wednesday, 7-9 P.M. and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Holy Family Church, Bronx New York, on Friday, June 21, at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations be made to Transplant Speakers International Inc., P.O. Box 6395, Freehold, New Jersey 07728 (501C3).

title: Microsoft Antitrust Case Goes to Judge for Ruling
description: Microsoft and a coalition of state attorneys general pursuing antitrust sanctions against the company disregarded a federal judge's order to identify areas of compromise in their closing arguments today, reiterating instead their widely divergent views of the kind of restrictions she should impose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMAN, ACY RUDY
description: LEHMAN-Acy Rudy, 81. Of Peter Cooper Village, NYC, on June 15, 2002. He was born in New York City, September 18, 1920. A former Grammy winner, Acy was retired art director of RCA records. Beloved husband of the late Jocelyn, dear friend of Helen Roe, and Gordon Howard. Visitation Friday 2-5 and 7-9 pm at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave, NYC. (212) 475-2024. Funeral services Saturday, June 22, 10 AM at St. Alban's Episcopal Church, 76 St. Alban's Place, Eltingville, SI, NY. Interment in Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York. For information, Casey McCallum Rice, South Shore Funeral Home, 30 Nelson Ave, SI, NY. 718-317-7600.

title: The Kashmir Brink
description: The game of nuclear brinkmanship between India and Pakistan, already six months old, is far from over.

title: Supreme Court Bars Executing the Mentally Retarded
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  In one of the most important capital punishment cases in years, the United States Supreme Court ruled today that executing killers who are mentally retarded is unconstitutional.

title: Arts Abroad; A Film Peers Into Tehran, Through a Hall of Mirrors
description: For 14 years Reza Khatibi was an Iranian living in exile in Paris, but he was not a political refugee. That is, he was neither a militant opponent of the Tehran regime, nor had he been forced to flee Iran by persecution. Rather, he escaped the country in 1986 at age 17 out of an instinct for survival: to avoid fighting in the bloody Iran-Iraq war. For Iranian authorities he was simply a deserter.

title: A Part of a Band as the Whole Band
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Sports of The Times; Americans Learned Harsh Lesson
description: THE metaphor for German soccer is a knee in the kidneys. That is precisely what Claudio Reyna received from Jens Jeremies in the opening minutes of the World Cup four years ago. The assault left Reyna numb -- for 30 minutes, he said, but to some observers it looked like three games.

title: PATH Project Unloved in the Village
description: YOU do not have to stand long on the narrow dead-end PATH train platforms at Christopher Street or Ninth Street to know that another way into or out of the stations would be at least convenient. Maybe even a lifesaver.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Pope To Go Ahead With Americas Trip
description: Pope John Paul II will go ahead with a 10-day visit to Canada, Guatemala and Mexico next month, though his schedule will be curtailed because of his poor health. After flying to Toronto on July 25 to attend a World Day of Youth celebration, the pope will go to Guatemala City to canonize a 17th-century missionary and then to Mexico City for the canonization of a 16th-century Indian whose reported visions of Mary helped convert indigenous Mexicans to Christianity. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Drug Bill for Elderly Advances, and Stalls
description: A Republican bill to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly was approved early today by one House committee, but became bogged down in another panel, where Democrats denounced the legislation as a gift to the drug industry in return for large campaign contributions.

title: Childhood in Wackiland, Painful but Outrageous
description: RUNNING WITH SCISSORS

title: 2 Arrested After Wild Chase of a Stolen Van
description: Two men in a stolen van led the police on a lunchtime chase through several blocks of the Upper East Side yesterday, at times driving on the sidewalk and against traffic.

title: Bloomberg and Council Agree On Budget to Close Big Deficit
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council agreed last night on a budget that would close New York City's worst deficit in decades by going into debt, cutting many city services, suspending recycling of jars and bottles and raising the tax on cigarettes.

title: Jesse Ventura Packs His Trunks
description: Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, as everyone knows, used to be a professional wrestler -- a job in which the athletes change their persona constantly. The heroic champion on Monday may be a masked demon on Wednesday. So this week, when Mr. Ventura announced he would not run for a second term, it was easy to wonder if he was just preparing to morph into a new identity. The governor, who once famously called organized religion ''a sham and a crutch for weak-minded people,'' has never really tried life as a compassionate conservative. There's still time.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: DYNEGY'S CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER QUITS
description: Dynegy Inc. said yesterday that Rob Doty had resigned as chief financial officer, the second top executive to leave the company in less than a month amid investigations into its trading and accounting practices. Louis Dorey, 46, president of energy marketing and origination at Dynegy, was named to replace Mr. Doty, the company said in a statement. Chuck Watson, the chief executive, resigned late last month after Dynegy disclosed bogus electricity trades with the CMS Energy Corporation, whose chief executive also quit.

title: He Was Arab and Israeli And Now a Victim, Too
description: Ayman Kabaha, an Israeli Arab student killed by a Palestinian suicide bomber in Jerusalem on Tuesday, was buried here today on a rocky hillside, mourned by relatives on both sides of this Arab village that lies half in Israel and half in the West Bank.

title: Calibrating the DVD's Sound To Each Hearer's Vantage Point
description: The sound that comes from your speakers is not the sound you hear. Your room sees to that, emphasizing some frequencies while undercutting others. Equalizers -- arrays of tone controls that affect tiny slices of the frequency range -- can help. But setting an equalizer accurately by ear is very difficult, and using instruments to get perfect correction at one listening spot often diminishes the sound quality elsewhere in the room. And true as that is for stereo, the problem gets worse with 5.1-channel home theater systems.

title: More Services for Mac Users From Software-Update Site
description: For years, Macintosh and Windows power users thirsting for software updates have gone to the oasis of VersionTracker.com, a Web site dedicated to listing news and links to just about every program update, upgrade, patch and new release that has become available. The site, which also keeps tabs on the latest software for the Palm operating system, has recently announced updates of its own services for Macintosh users.

title: A Shop Where Fun Meets Function
description: ON prominent display at Tekserve, a giant Macintosh repair center in Manhattan, is a battery-operated ''farm radio'' from the 1920's, its vacuum tubes glistening inside a thick glass case. There are also old television sets in wooden cabinets, manual typewriters and mechanical adding machines.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: An Acquisition By Micromuse
description: Micromuse, which makes software to detect flaws in data networks, announced plans yesterday to acquire RiverSoft, a competitor. Micromuse, a 725-employee operation based in San Francisco, said that the offer for RiverSoft, based in Britain, was for 43.3 million, or $64.7 million. Micromuse said the deal would give it more products and technologies for finding and automatically solving problems in data networks like telephone networks. RiverSoft, which has 166 employees, said in a statement that the boards of both companies had reached an agreement on the offer. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Text of Congressional Hearing on the Proposed Homeland Security Dept.
description: Following is the text of a Congressional hearing of the House Government Reform Committee on the proposed Homeland Security Department

title: Bureaucratic Finger-Pointing Impedes Connecticut's Inquiry Into Enron Deal
description: Connecticut's piece of the Enron scandal a murky financial deal with the state trash authority that caused the largest loss of tax dollars in state history -- has drawn outrage and nearly unanimous criticism, from town leaders to the governor. But the state's effort to determine whether the loss included any criminal wrongdoing has gone nowhere, bogged down by bureaucratic finger-pointing and official inaction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEYLAND, TURKEN, CERI ANN
description: LEYLAND - TURKEN - Ceri Ann. Fifty-two. June 19, 2002. Beloved wife of her late husband, Stanley Turken. Devoted stepmother of her loving children, Greta and Jason. Cherished sister of her brothers, John and Rex. Adoring aunt to her nieces, Tamsin and Chelsea. Dedicated and loving relative to all in the Black, Levy, Leyland and Turken families around the world. Her gentle nature, wonderful humor & immense strength will be missed by her many friends and loved ones, and will remain an example to all of us. A service will be held on Friday, June 21, 2002, at 11 AM, at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, New York, New York.

title: Six Gauges for the Galloping Heart
description: LIKE most high-level athletes, every now and then Michael Barry, a professional bicycle racer, is prodded, poked and measured in an exercise laboratory. But during the long racing season with the United States Postal Service team (which includes Lance Armstrong, the three-time Tour de France winner), Mr. Barry is largely on his own when it comes to checking his fitness.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 4 about complaints by workers from Windows on the World, the restaurant atop the World Trade Center, referred imprecisely to the employment status of Orlando Godoy, a waiter who criticized David Emil, president of the company, who is opening a new restaurant. Mr. Godoy, who was among former workers seeking jobs, worked part time as a banquet waiter at Windows; he was not a full-time employee.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Anti-Radiation Pills Offered
description: Potassium iodide tablets will be distributed next month to anyone who lives within 10 miles of New Jersey's four nuclear power plants, state officials said yesterday. The tablets offer residents some protection against radiation-induced thyroid cancer if the plants malfunction or are attacked. Starting on July 13, more than 700,000 of the 130-milligram tablets will be given to residents, employees and vacationers near the Salem 1, Salem 2 and Hope Creek reactors in Salem County and the Oyster Creek plant in Ocean County.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Political Ads With a Twist
description: After being pummeled by Gov. Gray Davis's attack advertisements for weeks, Bill Simon Jr., left, the Republican candidate for governor, has started his own television advertising campaign, with a twist. His advertisements are in Spanish, and attack Governor Davis's record on education. More than 60 percent of Hispanic voters in California are Democrats, and Mr. Simon says he feels he can appeal to them because of their strong interest in education. ''We think there's tremendous opportunity for crossover votes,'' said Jeff Flint, a Simon media adviser.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLADSTONE, ANNA ROSENZWEIG
description: GLADSTONE-Anna Rosenzweig. Our beloved older sister Anna died June 17, 2002 in California. The first born of five daughters of our beloved late parents Jennie and Willie Rosenzweig. She leaves her 4 adoring Rosenzweig sisters, who mourn her passing; Blanche Golub, Ruthe Kahn, Miriam Nitzberg and Estelle Kellner, and sister-in-law Lillian Rosenzweig, the wife of our late brother Isaac. We have lost an irreplaceable treasure, the shining light of our family. She is survived by her devoted children and grandchildren in California and by many nieces and nephews on the East Coast, who adored their darling Aunt Anna. Rest in peace, our beautiful sister, we will love and cherish you forever. ''Many daughters have attained valor, but you have surpassed them all.'' The Sisters Rosenzweig

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Strict Defamation Law Repealed
description: Parliament has repealed a stringent criminal defamation law that critics said officials had used to stifle criticism of the government of President Chandrika Kumaratunga, which was defeated in elections last year. The change was promised by the new coalition government headed by the United National Party. Under Mrs. Kumaratunga the government also imposed censorship rules in what it said was part of the war to defeat separatist Tamil rebels. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: With Dinner, a Fern Course
description: JUST what a botanist, a neurologist and a Mexican chef were doing in a landmark 1866 town house in the East 50's a few Sundays ago says as much about New York as it does about Oaxaca, Mexico, the cradle of New World civilization.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Wild Ginger, Spreading

title: Italian Team Releases Korean
description: The Italian soccer club Perugia has cut its ties with Ahn Jung Hwan of South Korea after he scored the goal that knocked Italy out of the World Cup, Perugia's chairman was quoted as saying yesterday.

title: McCall Urges Giving Help On Tuition to Ex-Convicts
description: H. Carl McCall said yesterday that ex-convicts should get preference in the awarding of college tuition grants by the state and federal governments, arguing that government assistance was the best way to guard against inmates' returning to jail.

title: Ronaldo Again Doing What He Does Best
description: Before the World Cup began, the Brazilian star Ronaldo lamented that every article written about him, every television and radio report, referred to him as an injured player. He said he longed for the day when he would again be referred to simply as a player.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Airwave Auction Is Postponed
description: President Bush signed a law yesterday postponing a federal auction of airwave space for wireless telephone and Internet services that had been scheduled for yesterday. Wireless providers had sought the delay, saying there would be too much uncertainty over the transfers of frequency licenses. As part of the industry's transition to digital TV, some broadcasters must surrender their airwave licenses to the government by January 2007, or after digital reaches 85 percent of the nation's viewing market, whichever comes first. The move to digital TV has been slow, worrying some in the wireless industry.

title: Rights of Women: More Than a Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: HUNGARY: PREMIER WORKED FOR COMMUNIST POLICE Prime Minister Peter Medgyessy told Parliament he had been a Communist secret police officer 20 years ago. Mr. Medgyessy (pronounced MEHD-yeh-shee), who led Hungary's post-Communist Socialist Party to victory in national elections in April, was accused by the newspaper Magyar Nemzet of being a counter-intelligence officer when he worked in the Finance Ministry from 1977 to 1982. His centrist coalition partners, the Free Democrats, threatened to quit the government if Mr. Medgyessy did not tell the truth about his past.   Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Once Again, Bloomberg Displays His Power as a Rainmaker
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is not responsible for the rain. But since he sat down in his bullpen six months ago, most of what he has wished for has come his way. He has gained control of the city's public schools, settled a protracted contract dispute with teachers and cobbled together two major social policy initiatives. Even the drought emergency seems as if it might end, thanks to a series of downpours.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Bus Workers Set For Long Walkout
description: Commuters endured a third day without crucial bus lines in wide swaths of Queens yesterday as union officials reported no progress toward a settlement with the city and the three private bus companies that employ them. Dave Katzman, spokesman for the Transport Workers Union Local 100, which represents the 1,500 striking workers, said that no new talks were scheduled and that workers were digging in for a prolonged strike to get health benefits on a par with those given to city employees. The city, which provides millions of dollars annually in subsidies to the bus lines, has said it will not intervene in the strike. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Big Accounting Firm's Tax Plans Help the Wealthy Conceal Income
description: In private meetings with wealthy Americans and their financial advisers, the accounting firm Ernst & Young has for months been selling four techniques to eliminate or sharply reduce income taxes.

title: Grand Jury Says Churches Are Hiding Cases of Abuse
description: Without naming any churches or priests or issuing any indictments, a Westchester County grand jury investigating the sexual abuse of children by Roman Catholic priests released a report today accusing churches of cover-ups and urging state lawmakers to eliminate the statute of limitations on child sex-abuse cases.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Former Ally Of Koizumi Arrested
description: A former legislative ally of Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi was arrested on charges of taking bribes from a lumber company in a scandal that has embarrassed a government that has promised political reforms. Prosecutors accuse Muneo Suzuki, left, of accepting a $40,000 bribe to obtain leniency for the lumber company in an illegal-logging case. Mr. Suzuki, who first took office in 1983, belonged to the most influential faction in the governing Liberal Democratic Party until he quit the party in March over the accusations. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: 'Black Boxes' Recovered At Crash Site
description: Divers recovered the flight data recorder from a Hong Kong-bound China Airlines jumbo jet that crashed into the Taiwan Strait on May 25, killing all 225 aboard. The recorder was 1,000 feet from where the cockpit voice recorder was found and brought to the surface on Tuesday. Without even a distress call from the pilots, the Boeing 747 broke into four pieces 20 minutes after takeoff from Taipei and plunged more than five miles into the water. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: The Enforcers Of Wall St.? Then Again, Maybe Not
description: Owen Cheevers, 51, was head of high-yield bond research at the Bank of Montreal in New York when he wrote a cautionary report on companies in the radio industry. An experienced analyst, Mr. Cheevers was asked by investment bankers at his firm to make his report more glowing. He refused and pleaded with the bank's compliance department to intervene. He received no help. Two months later he was fired.

title: Palestinian in the Wings
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about plans by the Bloomberg administration to appeal a state court ruling that barred City Hall from ejecting homeless families from shelters misattributed a quotation. It was Michael A. Cardozo, the city's corporation counsel, not Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who said: ''Since this is an ongoing litigation, we intend to present our opinion in court. Therefore, it would be inappropriate to do so in the media.''

title: Rights of Women: More Than a Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Ex-Troops End Blockade
description: Some 1,000 former paramilitary troops ended a two-day roadblock around the Tikal Mayan ruins in the northeast after President Alfonso Portillo agreed to meet with them later this week. The former fighters, who are demanding money and land for having helped defeat leftist guerrillas during the country's 36-year civil war, earlier allowed 71 foreign tourists trapped by their protest to leave the area. The protesters were ardent supporters of the country's military rulers during the 1980's and have been blamed by religious and human rights groups for torture and massacres. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Jets Waste Little Time Signing First-Rounder
description: Bryan Thomas banked $1.1 million today as part of his $4 million signing bonus with the Jets, but he knows it costs money to live in New York.

title: The Many Ways to Serve America
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees' Latest Outburst Overwhelms Rockies
description: Coors Field is all about survival. Teams come in knowing there will be casualties -- to their earned run averages, to their players' patience, to their psyche. Hits will rain down for hours, leads will disappear and then return. It will be a long battle.

title: Leading Business Group Joins Drive for Corporate Changes
description: Add the Conference Board to the long and growing list of organizations offering recommendations on overhauling the way corporations govern themselves.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about speeches made at the meeting of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops in Dallas referred incorrectly to one speaker, R. Scott Appleby. He is director of the Cushwa Center for the Study of American Catholicism at the University of Notre Dame, not former director, and is a professor, not an associate professor.

title: Novice Collectors Are Magnets for Eager Art Advisers
description: ''The relationship generally starts innocently enough, often with the phrase 'Maybe I can help.' ''

title: Teaching in California
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, RICHARD
description: DIAMOND-Richard. Beloved husband of Alyce. Loving father of Roberta, Debra and Jeff. Cherished grandfather of Michael, Zachary and Margot. Dear son of Daniel and brother of Peter. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 9:30 A.M. Friday.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article last Wednesday reported a surge in the publishing of books written by subordinates about their bosses and cited the example of Richard Blow, who worked for John F. Kennedy Jr. at George magazine. The article said that immediately after Mr. Kennedy's death, Mr. Blow barred the magazine's staff members from talking to the media or writing about him.

title: Seven Held in Pakistan on Bombings
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, June 20  Authorities here said today that they had detained seven members of a violent sectarian group for questioning about their possible involvement in or knowledge of terrorist bombings, including an attack last week on the American Consulate here.

title: Star's 'Wink' May Be Clue To Creation Of Planets
description: A young star far away in the galaxy is winking in a regular pattern that astronomers say is unlike anything seen before. If science learns to read those signals, they may deliver a message about the early stages of planet formation.

title: Rebuilding May Expand Beyond Site
description: The agencies overseeing the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site have begun to look beyond the 16 acres where the twin towers stood for locations for some of the office and retail space that was lost at the site, officials said yesterday.

title: Adelphia Is Expected To Move by Monday On Bankruptcy Step
description: Adelphia Communications is expected to file for bankruptcy protection by Monday, according to people briefed on the situation. The company has been trying to negotiate financing of about $1.7 billion to help it through a bankruptcy reorganization, according to debt analysts.

title: The POP LIFE; A Part of a Band As the Whole Band
description: What is a band? To most rock fans (and dictionaries), a band is a group of people playing music. But to lawyers and record labels, a band is something that exists on paper, a business relationship with owners, employees and sometimes even shareholders. Some bands function as a democracy, with each member owning an equal share and having an equal say. Others are more like a monarchy (or in the worst of cases, a dictatorship), with one leader in charge of a bunch of hired guns. And then there's Third Eye Blind, the rock band that struck success in 1997 with the hit ''Semi-Charmed Life.''

title: ImClone Is Told That Charges May Be Filed Against It
description: The government is considering bringing charges against ImClone Systems for misleading investors about the status of its cancer drug, the company said yesterday.

title: Plane Prompts Evacuation of White House
description: The White House was partly evacuated tonight and military jets were scrambled after an unidentified light aircraft entered restricted airspace over the capital, Secret Service officials said.

title: Beating Tiger Woods: A Question of Mind Over Matter
description: Tiger Woods will not be among the 156 golfers teeing off in the first round of the Greater Hartford Open on Thursday. But Woods is here. The shadow of the world's greatest golfer lingers even in his absence.

title: California Living, Manhattan View
description: Ryan Hoagland, who lives in San Jose, Calif., longed to see the Manhattan skyline. So Mr. Hoagland, a 27-year-old computer engineer, designed and built a 3-D model, below, which he installed outside his kitchen window. He found a photo that fit his fantasy and used an image-editing program to customize it (the Chrysler Building is, he admitted, out of place). The model, with 1,540 windows and 700 Christmas lights, took five months to complete and cost $394.31. ''It looks really good at night,'' he said. The worst part of making it? ''Painting all those stupid little windows.'' A diary of the project can be found at www.hoagy.org/cityscape. MARC KRISTAL

title: U.S. SUIT CITES BIAS IN CITY PARK DEPT.
description: The federal government sued the New York City Parks and Recreation Department yesterday, accusing it of discriminating against black and Hispanic workers for the last seven years by favoring whites for promotions -- including those who were part of a special program to attract graduates of elite colleges.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bank To Close More Branches
description: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's biggest bank, plans to shut 12 more branches in Hong Kong as it cuts costs to lift profit in a city struggling to avoid recession. DBS, which owns the Dao Heng Bank Group and DBS Kwong On Bank, already cut its network by a fifth last year but does not plan to cut jobs, a spokeswoman said. The DBS Group, which recently acquired the two Hong Kong banks, has not set a time frame for the closings, which result from overlap between the two acquisitions. DBS closed 21 branches and opened one in 2001.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The bond business keeps Bear Stearns on the upswing, while Morgan Stanley's earnings fall.
description: WHEN investors do not want to buy stocks, sell them bonds, any bonds. That is the message embedded in the latest earnings reports from Wall Street investment firms.

title: Guilford Dudley Jr., 94, Nixon Diplomat
description: Guilford Dudley Jr., a Tennessee insurance executive who was an ambassador to Denmark in the Nixon administration and a Nixon aide, died on Thursday at his home in Nashville. He was 94.

title: Turn Down That Coffee Table: A Morphing Soundboard
description: There are people who are going to find the Soundbug useful, just like there are people who win lotteries. For the rest of us, though, this undeniably unique sound projection tool is a wonderful example of unnecessary ingenuity.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Alitalia Is Recapitalized
description: The European Commission gave the go-ahead for a 1.4 billion euro ($1.3 billion) recapitalization of the Italian airline Alitalia. The commissioner for transport matters, Loyola de Palacio, said that although Italy was financing 62 percent of the program, it did not constitute state aid because private investors were also taking part. The decision not to investigate the recapitalization comes shortly after the commission decided to investigate a public sector loan of 19.5 million euros to Olympic Airways of Greece. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Our Security Is First
description: To the Editor:

title: Hunger and Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITEHEAD, ROBERT
description: WHITEHEAD-Robert. The Stella Adler Studio of Acting is profoundly saddened by the loss of our dear friend Robert Whitehead. We will dedicate the coming school year to his memory. Ellen Adler Tom Oppenheim The Faculty and Students

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cruise Deal Approved
description: British antitrust regulators approved the merger of P&O Princess Cruises and Royal Caribbean Cruises in a deal that would create a company with a market capitalization of $7.4 billion. The merger has yet to be approved by shareholders of P&O, who have two bids for the company to consider. The second, a $6.8 billion bid by the Carnival Corporation, has not received regulatory approval. Regulators in Britain said a merger of P&O and Royal Caribbean would not restrict growth or competition within the industry or reduce the diversity of cruises available to British consumers. P&O's management favors the deal with Royal Caribbean, fearing that regulators will reject the Carnival deal but instead of voting on the measures, the company's shareholders adjourned a meeting in February until regulators could review them. A combined P&O Royal Caribbean would unseat Carnival as the world's largest cruise line. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, LILLIAN
description: WALKER-Lillian. Long-time member of NCJW-NY section; Lillian was a dynamic member of the Junior Committee and will be sadly missed. We grieve with her devoted family. Rita Fishman, President

title: Sports of The Times; No Changes Expected In Mets' Leadership
description: WE can stop the hand-wringing, the whining, the worrying and the speculating about the Mets. There will be no change at the top; no change in the middle. The general manager isn't going anywhere, nor is the manager. For better or for worse, for richer or for poorer, Steve Phillips and Bobby Valentine are steering this ship for the foreseeable future.

title: American Troops Will Begin Tighter Operations With Filipinos
description: Army Special Forces soldiers will soon begin training Philippine troops in smaller units than they do now and will join them on some jungle patrols to hunt a dwindling band of Muslim guerrillas linked to Al Qaeda, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Not-Guilty Plea In Dog Death
description: A man who the police said threw his girlfriend's dog off the balcony of a tall building three weeks ago pleaded not guilty yesterday to 13 charges, including extortion and aggravated cruelty to animals. Prosecutors say the man, John Jefferson, 43, of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, threw the dog, Ribsy, a mixed terrier, from the 23rd-floor balcony onto North Moore Street in TriBeCa on May 26. Prosecutors said he also threatened his girlfriend with a knife and threw a television set and an air-conditioner to the street. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSLEY, HARRY
description: KINGSLEY-Harry. Beloved husband of Helen, loving father of Shelly and Gary, Jeffrey and Karen. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan, Daniel & Emma. Devoted brother, brother-in-law, uncle and friend. Services, ''BoulevardRiverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 11:30 AM, Friday. May his soul be bound in everlasting peace.

title: Minor Leagues Have Major Action
description: Minor league all-star games are supposed to be exhibitions that are fun. That doesn't mean they have to lack excitement.

title: Knicks' Draft Plan Focuses on Wilcox
description: The Knicks were one of several teams to respond with a smile, if not a high-five, when Mike Dunleavy announced yesterday that he would skip his senior season at Duke to enter the National Basketball Association draft.

title: One Man Stands Watch On Billions In Farm Loans
description: Behind the door of Room 3300 at the Farm Credit Administration in McLean, Va., sits Carl A. Clinefelter, director of the Office of Secondary Market Oversight, and his lone employee, an administrative assistant.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZORN, IRIS SEGAL
description: ZORN-Iris Segal. June 20, 1998. ''not a day goes by.'' Jo

title: Taking One Away From Shakespeare
description: Donald Foster, a professor of English at Vassar College who made headlines in 1995 with his conclusion that Shakespeare was the author of an obscure 578-line poem called ''A Funeral Elegy,'' is now acknowledging that he was mistaken, agreeing with another scholar that a different poet and dramatist, John Ford, probably wrote the elegy.

title: . . . In Manhattan, A Lust for Large
description: LIKE their suburban brethren, New Yorkers have been struck by the urge for big, with sales of larger apartments surging, even as prices continue to rise.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Man Charged In Third Murder
description: A man accused of killing two women was charged yesterday with a third murder. The man, Matthew Johnson, is also a suspect in other murders, the Hartford state attorney's office said. The third charge came shortly after DNA test results linked Mr. Johnson to a crime scene, the state attorney said. The bodies of the first two victims, Aida Quinones, 33, and Alesia Ford, 37, were found in desolate areas. The third victim, Rosali Jimenez, 33, of Hartford, was found in an abandoned building in the city's Asylum Hill section in August 2000, the authorities said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Government Wants To Sell Bank Stake
description: Mexico is seeking to raise $1 billion and reduce its deficit by selling a stake in Grupo Financiero BBVA Bancomer, the nation's biggest bank. Mexico's commitment to trying to avoid deficits has helped the country obtain an investment-grade credit rating and bolstered the nation's stocks and bonds in a year in which other Latin American markets tumbled. Mexico will probably price the shares at about 5 percent below market prices, or at about 8.17 pesos based on Wednesday's trading, analysts said. At that price the government would raise about 8.95 billion pesos ($927 million).

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Executives Take Pay Cut
description: Mizuho Holdings will cut its executives' pay by as much as 50 percent as they take responsibility for a crisis in April in which the bank's computers rejected millions of consumer transactions. The president, Terunobu Maeda, and the heads of Mizuho Corporate Bank and Mizuho Bank will have their pay cut in half for six months from July, the company said. The wages of all 113 other executives will also be cut, while three former co-chief executives, responsible for integrating the lender's main units, resigned as advisers on Monday, the bank said.

title: A Russian Aluminum Mobster, Set Free, Gains Teflon Status
description: Anatoly Bykov, one of Russia's most infamous mobsters, who has been sought for years by the authorities here, was sentenced to jail by a Moscow court today -- and then promptly set free.

title: AES TO SELL $1 BILLION IN ASSETS TO CUT DEBT
description: The chief executive of the AES Corporation, Paul Hanrahan, a day after succeeding the company's founder, said the company planned to sell another $1 billion in assets or equity by 2003 to cut debt. Power-generation and distribution businesses in Brazil and other South American countries may be sold or spun off, Mr. Hanrahan said. AES will halt capital spending and acquisitions until its bonds recover more than 25 percent to trade at face value, Mr. Hanrahan said. The company wants to scale back to shore up its finances. The shares have tumbled 88 percent in the last year amid a plunge in electricity prices and the collapse of Enron.

title: CVS Drops Bates for Hill, Holliday
description: In another blow to Bates USA in New York, the CVS pharmacy chain said yesterday that it had ended its relationship with the agency as it selected Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston as the new lead agency on its account. Billings were estimated at $35 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Car With Baby Is Stolen
description: A car with a 2-year-old girl inside was stolen for 30 minutes yesterday, after the girl's mother left her alone in the car with the ignition on, the police said. The mother told the police that she went momentarily into her home, on Dahlgren Place in Fort Hamilton, at 3:25 p.m., Officer George Jensen said. When she went back outside, the child and car were gone. They were discovered at 3:55 p.m. about seven blocks away, on 90th Street and Fort Hamilton Parkway, the police said. The child was unharmed, Officer Jensen said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Tom Mallow, 71, Producer of Touring Shows
description: Tom Mallow, a leading producer of Broadway's touring shows, died on June 6 at a medical center in Deerfield Beach, Fla. He was 71 and lived in Lighthouse Point, Fla.

title: INSIDE
description: Messages Hinted at 9/11

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: FORMER ALLY OF KOIZUMI ARRESTED A former legislative ally of Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi was arrested on charges of taking bribes from a lumber company in a scandal that has embarrassed a government that has promised political reforms. Prosecutors accuse Muneo Suzuki, of accepting a $40,000 bribe to obtain leniency for the lumber company in an illegal-logging case. Mr. Suzuki, who first took office in 1983, belonged to the most influential faction in the governing Liberal Democratic Party until he quit the party in March over the accusations.    Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Education Chief Urges Restoring Local School Control in Newark, Paterson and Jersey City
description: The state education commissioner called for sweeping changes today in New Jersey's school takeover law that would return control of the state's three largest districts to local officials.

title: Doctor, You Have Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | West: California: $1 Million Settlement In Death
description: Sonoma County, Calif., has agreed to pay $1 million to the family of a woman killed by her husband after sheriff's deputies did not enforce a restraining order against him. The county admitted no wrongdoing on Tuesday in settling the lawsuit, which was brought by the family of Maria Teresa Macias, who was killed in 1996. Two years ago, a federal appeals court ruling cleared the way for the family to try to prove that the sheriff had violated equal protection laws by playing down the wife's complaints because she is a Hispanic woman.

title: Masses in Transit, to Anywhere but Work; Riders Like a Safer, More Reliable System, With MetroCard Discounts
description: It has been many years since the image of New York City's transit system was one of a crumbling and dangerous place used with grim determination only by those who had no better way to get to work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVILBISS, ROBERT A.
description: DeVILBISS-Robert A., 89 years of age, June 12, 2002, of Blairstown, NJ. Beloved husband of Margaret Berwick, father of Edwin L. DeVilbiss, and grandfather of two. A Memorial Service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church of Blairstown, 1 Main St., at 11:30 AM, July 16, 2002. Donations may be made to the Church, PO Box 385, Blairstown, NJ 07825 and to Pocono Medical Center, Development Office for the Cancer Center, 206 E Brown St., East Stroudsburg, PA 18301. For information Newbaker Funeral Home, Rt 94, Blairstown, NJ

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: One Talks; the Other Won't

title: PRIME-TIME OPEN FINAL
description: For the second straight year, the women's final of the United States Open will be televised by CBS Sports on a Saturday night in prime time. The United States Tennis Association will make the announcement today.

title: Reassessing Martha Stewart, the Brand
description: The face of the style priestess Martha Stewart has been all over newsstands this week, but there is one place you will be hard pressed to find the image of Ms. Stewart -- on the cover of her magazine, Martha Stewart Living. In all but one issue over the last three years, the magazine has been anchored by portraits of the lifestyle Ms. Stewart markets for her company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, not the woman who dreams it all up.

title: Facing Germans, Young Americans Display No Fear
description: As a 20-year-old might, Landon Donovan had questions before his first World Cup match. What's the level of play like, he wanted to know. Don't worry, his teammate Eddie Pope told him in the locker room. The Portuguese were just as nervous as he was. None of them had ever participated in a World Cup either.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAYSON, VIOLA M.
description: FAYSON-Viola M. Born July 26, 1946 in White Castle, LA, died June 7, 2002 at St. Luke's Hospital in NY. Survived by her companion Herman Bryant, daughter Bonnie Slater, stepmother Edna L. Bell, 5 brothers: Raymond Lewis, Lloyd Jr., Gregory, Eric, and Frank, three sisters: Vonola Avist, Katherine Davis and Vanessa Baptiste. Preceded in death by father Lloyd Bell, Sr./Ned Tucker, mother Margie Hughes Tucker Skinner, sister Lois Ann Skinner. She was a member of the Eastern Star Masonic Organization. Memorial service will be held on Friday, June 21st at 2 P.M. at the Metropolitan Baptist Church, 151 West 128th Street.

title: Firefighters Hear Tips About Pressure
description: Joe Theismann was trying to counsel the New York City firefighters Tom McCain, Kevin O'Brien and Guy Warren yesterday on how to handle pressure situations.

title: Jitter-Free, but Not Worry-Free
description: FLYING in his helicopter, Sgt. Frank Sheer of the Orange County Sheriff's Department in Southern California can be literally miles from the action. But that does not mean that he and his co-pilot do not know what's going on. In fact, Sergeant Sheer says they often have a clearer picture of a crime scene than the officers who are there.

title: Hitched to Your Laptop, the Little Camera That Could
description: A year ago, Xirlink, a leading maker of imaging devices sold under the brands of better-known companies like I.B.M., started its own line of consumer digital cameras. One of its newer products is the Veo Mobile Connect, a U.S.B. Webcam designed for use with laptops. To stand out from a crowded field of small, inexpensive cameras, the Veo's designers focused on what is important for those on the go: sturdiness.

title: Keep Primary Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Back to Elegance in Lamp Design
description: THERE are countless ways to make an elegant lamp, and many were displayed at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York last month. In a departure from organic forms of past seasons, this year's lamp designs emphasized clean lines and back-to-basics materials. Wood was abundant, with stems and shades clad in veneers like birch and mahogany. Plastic pieces were so clear they could pass for glass. The mood was restrained, with hints of humor, eliciting a smile rather than a hearty laugh; who wouldn't giggle at a glowing homage to the water tanks crowning New York buildings?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIMEK, JEAN G.
description: SCHIMEK-Jean G. Husband of Deborah Browning, father of David & Paul, grandfather of Samuel & Natalie. Services will be private.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Cherenson Group, Livingston, N.J., is forming a new unit, the Association Management Division, to provide professional management services and support for educational programs to medical groups. Linda Bartolo will lead the division as director; she had been director for administrative services at the Academy of Medicine of New Jersey, Lawrenceville, N.J.

title: Enter The Globocourt
description: Two weeks before a supernational criminal court opens over strong U.S. objections -- a U.N. war crimes tribunal is setting a legal precedent for the ''globocourt'' that will add to the dangers faced by war correspondents from every nation.

title: In Jerusalem, Despair and Determination
description: ''There are no words,'' Abraham Orel, 23, a quiet-voiced Talmudic student, said tonight. He was hard to hear for all the shouting of anger and vengeance, all the trucks and ambulances grunting by efficiently. ''You have a sick feeling in your stomach.''

title: Jury Awards $5.5 Million In a Secondhand Smoke Case
description: The nation's biggest tobacco companies suffered their first defeat in a secondhand smoke case this week, and they said yesterday that they would use the setback to challenge a critical ruling governing the $349 million settlement they struck with the nation's flight attendants nearly five years ago.

title: Economic Scene; Microsoft, Chicken Delight and competition for an imperfect world.
description: THE biggest antitrust case in recent years is drawing to a close. Yesterday in Washington, lawyers for Microsoft and the nine states pursuing antitrust action against it completed their final arguments. In addition to ruling in the states' case, Federal District Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly must decide whether to approve the settlement Microsoft reached in November with the Justice Department.

title: Dutch Nurse Indicted in 13 Deaths, Including War-Crimes Judge
description: A Chinese judge from the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague who ostensibly died of natural causes several years ago is now believed to have been killed by a hospital nurse, Dutch prosecutors said today.

title: For Fans, Wry Footnotes to the Funny Page
description: NORM began publishing a Weblog as a way of passing the time as he waited in line for several weeks to see the first showing of ''Star Wars: Episode I -- The Phantom Menace.'' Like so many of his fellow Gen-X'ers, Norm exposed his thoughts and experiences every few days at a special area of his Web site.

title: A Remote That Makes Things Rote For Presenters
description: Microsoft PowerPoint, laptop computers and digital projectors have brought corporate presentations into the electronic age. But one ritual from the era of overhead projectors lingers. When presenters need to move on, they often ask an assistant to call up the next slide. Oddly, they do this even though many, if not most, digital projectors have remote controls.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about the poet June Jordan misspelled the middle name of an author whose books she credited with having helped forge her identity as a writer. He was Paul Laurence Dunbar, not Lawrence.

title: Jack Buck, 77, Voice of the Cardinals, Dies
description: Jack Buck, whose nearly 50 years as the voice of the St. Louis Cardinals' games positioned him to describe the baseball exploits of Stan Musial and Mark McGwire, and to call games with his son, died Tuesday in St. Louis. He was 77.

title: Panel Debates Revising U.S. Policy on Smallpox Shots
description: On the eve of a planned vote on whether to change the government's recommendations on smallpox vaccine, a national advisory panel struggled today to determine what is the actual risk of a bioterrorist attack with smallpox.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Boy Struck By Police Car
description: A 9-year-old boy was hit by a transit police car when he chased a ball between two cars about 7:45 p.m. yesterday, Sgt. Harold Gregory said. The boy, in serious condition, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center. The incident, which occurred on Nostrand Avenue in Flatbush, was being considered an accident but was under investigation, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, J. CARTER
description: BROWN - J. Carter. The American Academy in Rome mourns the loss of our beloved friend J. Carter Brown. One of the longest serving trustees in our 108-year history and holder of our Centennial Medal, Carter was famous for his appetites for art, history, boats, gadgets and Italian cuisine and an avid participant in the Academy's policies and fellowship programs. He had brilliance, breadth, curiosity, energy, quirkiness, wit. He was a gigantic cultural presence, irreplaceable and terribly missed. Michael I. Sovern, Chairman of the Board David M. Childs, Chairman, Executive Committee Adele Chatfield-Taylor, President Lester K. Little, Director

title: Agencies to Merge In Massachusetts
description: Allen & Gerritsen in Watertown, Mass., said yesterday that it would acquire and absorb Greenberg Seronick O'Leary/Davis in Boston. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 15 Are Accused of Defrauding Sept. 11 Charities
description: In several cases, people who had been unemployed for weeks or months lied that they had lost work because of the attack on the World Trade Center, officials said yesterday. Others were still collecting their regular paychecks when they filed similarly false claims, investigators said.

title: NATIONSRENT FILES PLAN TO REORGANIZE AND CUT DEBT
description: NationsRent Inc., a construction equipment rental company that sought bankruptcy protection in December, yesterday filed a recovery plan that would eliminate more than half the company's debt. Under the plan, which is subject to approval by the bankruptcy court, all of the common stock in the company would go to banks with loan claims. Those creditors would also receive $197 million in cash and $150 million in new notes. About 59 percent of the total $762 million in claims would be paid, the plan said. NationsRent, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., sought bankruptcy protection after an industry slowdown and increased competition hurt its earnings. The company's plan would reduce its debt to about $550 million.

title: Know When To Hold 'Em
description: Cassius Marcellus Coolidge's seminal work is titled "A Friend in Need" however, most people know it as "Dogs Playing Poker," which is not unlike referring to one of Van Gogh's self portraits as "Guy Missing an Ear."

title: Magical Find Excites TV Historians; 'Cinderella' Film Reflects An Emerging Medium
description: The tape is grainy, black-and-white and primitive. The special effects are merely sparklers, used when the Fairy Godmother turns the pumpkin into a stagecoach and gives Cinderella an elegant cape for the ball.

title: Letters to the Circuits Editor
description: Doctor, You Have Mail

title: Market Crisis Management
description: With the conviction of Arthur Andersen for obstruction of justice, the Bush administration can claim an early, if shaky, victory in the Enron scandal. But that case does not address the central problem: the deceptive bookkeeping at Enron and elsewhere that has left a cloud of public distrust hanging over the financial markets.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: POLITICAL ADS WITH A TWIST

title: The World Cup in Spanish
description: To the Editor:

title: Survey Shows Opposition to Radio Consolidation
description: Radio listeners want local disc jockeys to have more control over programming, and they oppose federal laws that encourage more consolidation among radio conglomerates, according to a recent survey conducted by the Future of Music Coalition, an artists rights group based in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDAUER, PAUL
description: LINDAUER-Paul, 54 years old. Devoted son of Lillian and Ralph and sister Ivy. Brooklyn College graduate. BA degree history major. Passed away on June 17, 2002 of a heart attack.

title: Keller Isn't Playing, and He's Not Happy About It
description: The dissension that undermined American chances at the 1998 World Cup surfaced again today, when the reserve goalkeeper Kasey Keller expressed frustration at sitting on the bench while the United States has advanced to the quarterfinals.

title: Sampling the Music Beneath As It Prepares to Rise Above
description: 8:59 a.m., Grand Central

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Arrests In Cafe Fire
description: Officials in Beijing said two teenage boys had been arrested for intentionally setting the fire that killed 24 people last weekend in an unlicensed Internet cafe. The boys, who were identified only by their surnames as Zhang, 13, and Song, 14, were detained Tuesday and have confessed to setting the fire out of revenge after a dispute with staff members, the city government said in a statement. The disaster led Beijing's mayor to order the temporary closure of the estimated 2,400 cybercafes in the city, all but 200 of which are unlicensed. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: The Many Ways to Serve America
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Police Officers Wanted
description: The number of statewide openings for police officers has grown to 300, but local departments say inadequate salaries and a growing number of other law enforcement jobs make it difficult to recruit and retain officers. Honolulu has been hardest hit, with 13 percent of its 2,056 positions unfilled, said a department spokeswoman, Jean Motoyama. The starting salary for Hawaii police officers is roughly $32,000, she said. Since 1998, nearly 130 officers and dispatchers have left for other law enforcement jobs, mostly in the Pacific Northwest, she said.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Monday about American efforts to avert war between Pakistan and India misstated the given name of a South Asia expert at the Brookings Institution who commented on the outlook for a solution. He is Stephen P. Cohen, not Philip.

title: A Buoyant Karzai Is Sworn In as Afghanistan's Leader
description: Afghanistan's new president, Hamid Karzai, was in an ebullient mood this evening after being sworn in as president for the next two years. Just minutes before, the grand council had approved his new cabinet and the appointment of several vice presidents.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Hungary: Premier Worked For Communist Police
description: Prime Minister Peter Medgyessy told Parliament he had been a Communist secret police officer 20 years ago. Mr. Medgyessy (pronounced MEHD-yeh-shee), who led Hungary's post-Communist Socialist Party to victory in national elections in April, was accused by the newspaper Magyar Nemzet of being a counter-intelligence officer when he worked in the Finance Ministry from 1977 to 1982. His centrist coalition partners, the Free Democrats, threatened to quit the government if Mr. Medgyessy did not tell the truth about his past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, DAN
description: COLLINS-Dan. The officers and members of the United Federation of Teachers mourn the loss of a brilliant and sensitive labor arbitrator. Labor and management have lost a valuable asset and a wise counselor. We were honored that his last major work was serving as chair of the state fact-finding panel that formed the basis of a breakthrough teachers' contract. His completion of this intricate and demanding work, despite illness, is a testimony to his integrity and his dedication to the collective bargaining process. We will miss him and offer our deepest sympathies to his wife and children. Randi Weingarten, President United Federation of Teachers

title: Without a Bang or a Whimper, The School Board Fades Away
description: There were no cakes, no bottles of Champagne, no hugs. Quietly, the seven members of the New York City Board of Education filed out of the meeting room at 5:20 p.m. yesterday, and the board, as a functioning organism, was no more.

title: House Approves Speedy Pace For Vote on New Department
description: The House began a month of late nights and short weekends today by approving a quickened schedule for creating the proposed Department of Homeland Security.

title: The Many Ways to Serve America
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Seeking to End Amtrak's Monopoly
description: The Bush administration will propose ending Amtrak's monopoly on intercity passenger rail service, government officials said. The plan calls for states to help decide what service will be offered, and to help pay for it.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: PATHMARK STRIKE AVERTED

title: A Firewall That Tells You Who's Rattling the Locks
description: Q. Is the built-in firewall that comes with Windows XP enough protection, or should I buy a commercial firewall program?

title: Workers in Spain Strike to Protest Changes in Welfare
description: SEVILLE, Spain, June 20  Beaches were packed but airports deserted today as Spain was hit with its first general strike for almost a decade  a work stoppage called to protest against changes to the welfare system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHENOV, ALBERT
description: GERSHENOV-Albert. The Board of Governors and Members of Hampshire Country Club are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed member, Albert Gershenov. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his dear wife, Doris, and to all his family. Hampshire Country Club Board of Governors Paul Seidenberg, President

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Rebel Sought By U.S. Is Captured
description: A leader of Colombia's main rebel group has been captured and sent to the United States to face drug-trafficking charges, American officials said. Carlos Bolas, a leader of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, was arrested Tuesday in Suriname, after he was caught using a false Peruvian passport, the officials said. Surinamese authorities turned Mr. Bolas over to the Drug Enforcement Administration and he was flown to Washington where he will be arraigned. A federal grand jury in March indicted Mr. Bolas and two other rebels for conspiring to manufacture and import cocaine into the United States. Christopher Marquis (NYT)

title: Providence Journal; Mayor Enjoys Perks as Jury Considers His Fate, and the City's
description: The sun continues to rise in the East and set in the West, but still: Things here are not right. How could they be, when the fate of this city's outsize mayor rests in the hands of a federal jury that has been deliberating for six days now, going on seven?

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Oak Technology Shares Fall
description: The shares of Oak Technology plunged 54 percent yesterday after the company cut its fourth-quarter sales forecast and said it would report a loss. Oak, which designs semiconductors for optical storage and digital imaging, fell $5.38, to $4.52. Sales are expected to be $34 million to $36 million in the quarter ending June 30. Oak Technology, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., had estimated that sales would increase from the third quarter's $42 million, the chief financial officer, John Edmunds, said in a telephone interview. Personal computer makers, facing increased inventories, delayed taking delivery of orders, he said. The company expects a loss, excluding certain items, of 5 to 9 cents a share, Mr. Edmunds said. Without the write-off, the loss would be 2 cents to 6 cents a share, he added. The average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was a profit of 4 cents.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Yours, David

title: Zeile's Homer Lifts Rockies
description: DENVER -- Todd Zeile hit a three-run homer in the 10th inning and the Colorado Rockies outslugged the New York Yankees 14-11 Thursday to close out the highest-scoring three-game series in Coors Field history.

title: The Many Ways to Serve America
description: To the Editor:

title: The Many Ways to Serve America
description: To the Editor:

title: AT HOME WITH: Mark McDonald; Mr. Modernism Leaves Town
description: ARE you just starting to explore midcentury style? Seduced by magazine spreads of plate-glass-walled bungalows in Palm Springs, Calif.? Browsing on eBay, perhaps, for the groovy molded plywood work of the famous Eames brothers, Charles and Ray?

title: MASCO BUYS 5 MAKERS OF WINDOW AND PLUMBING PARTS
description: The Masco Corporation, the maker of Delta and Peerless faucets, said yesterday that it bought five window and plumbing parts makers in California and Britain for about $220 million in cash and stock. Masco bought Newport Brass of Santa Ana, Calif., a maker of plumbing products and bath accessories. It also bought Bristan Ltd., a provider of faucets, based in Britain; Duraflex Ltd., a provider of vinyl window-frame components, and the vinyl window-frame makers Cambrian Windows Ltd. and Premier Manufacturing Ltd.

title: MAKING BOOKS
description: For the owners of most gay and lesbian bookstores, there seems to be little to be celebratory about this Gay and Lesbian Pride Month. The owner of the Oscar Wilde Bookshop in Manhattan, generally acknowledged as the world's first gay and lesbian bookstore, said, ''It's about to go out of business.'' Little more than a year ago, A Different Light, one of the country's largest gay bookstores, closed its New York branch.

title: Leiter At the Bat Lifts Mets To Victory
description: Mets General Manager Steve Phillips was in a windbreaker and shorts, leaning on a bat behind the batting cage at Shea Stadium. He had just taken batting practice with his Jets counterpart, Terry Bradway, yesterday afternoon as a sort of fantasy camp the Mets had offered executives from the football team. Phillips thought he had had a decent outing until he watched Al Leiter hit a ball farther than he did during batting practice.

title: Bush to Present Strict Demands To Palestinians
description: President Bush has resolved to promote the formation of a Palestinian state within a few years, but only if Palestinian leaders meet specific benchmarks, including a lasting crackdown on terrorism and other broad reforms, according to senior officials and others familiar with the plan.

title: National Briefing | Education: Latino Student Population Rises
description: Latinos became the fastest-growing ethnic group in American public schools in the last decade, representing one of every six school children, a report by Senator Edward M. Kennedy's office found. The greatest surge occurred in the South and Midwest, which the report says have ''little or no history of serving'' Latinos. In Arkansas, Georgia, North Carolina and Tennessee, the number of Latino students has jumped 250 percent. The report criticizes the Bush administration for freezing spending on bilingual and migrant education, and cutting money for other programs used by Latinos. Diana Jean Schemo (NYT)

title: Swapping Blame as Drug Law Rift Widens in Albany
description: With one day left in the scheduled legislative session, the Senate Republicans said they would pass a new bill tonight aimed at breaking the deadlock with the Assembly Democrats over how to soften the state's strict sentences for drug crimes.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: NEW PAY GUIDELINES AT VODAFONE The Vodafone Group issued new salary guidelines in response to critics who say that the company is overpaying top executives even as it reports huge losses. Under the new policy, Christopher Gent, the chief executive, will receive total compensation in line with executives at the top quartile of European companies, or 3.4 million ($5 million) to 9.3 million a year, the company said. For the year ended in March, Mr. Gent received 2.4 million in salary and bonus. He was also granted 8.95 million share options with an exercise price of 1.58, and 844,000 shares of common stock. The options and stock grants can be exercised at the earliest by July 2004, providing certain performance targets are met. Vodafone reported a $24 billion net loss, as it wrote down the value of some acquisitions, for the year.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Love Song For A Whale
description: More than 50 years after researchers first detected the strange calls of the fin whale, an international team of researchers has deciphered the song's true purpose: romance. Only male fin whales sing, the scientists report today in the journal Nature, and the songs are sung near concentrations of food, like krill. This suggests that the whales are engaging in what scientists call ''mating at the restaurant.'' An increase in ocean noise from commercial vessels and military sonar is likely to interfere with mating, said Dr. Christopher W. Clark of Cornell University, an author of the paper. Carol Kaesuk Yoon (NYT)

title: The Palestinian Death Knell
description: While President Bush reworks drafts of a new Mideast plan, his agenda is being yanked from under him by delusional young Palestinians. For the second day in a row, Jerusalem yesterday witnessed the numbing routine of suicide bombing. And for the second day in a row, Mr. Bush's spokesmen said he was forced to delay his speech.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICKLIN, MARY
description: RICKLIN-Mary. Age 94. Wife of the late Abraham Ricklin M.D. Passed away Tuesday, June 18. She is survived by her daughters Cynthia Harmening, (Wayne) and Jane Fassler (James). Grandma to Seth and Theresa Harmening, Amy and Gary Ehrlich and Lee and Elizabeth Fassler. G.G. will be missed by her eight great - grandchildren. Services Thursday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: For Schwarz, New Trial Could Hinge On Partner
description: After an appeals court ordered a new trial for Charles Schwarz, the former police officer who had been convicted twice in the Abner Louima brutality case, Mr. Schwarz's lawyer said the coming trial would be different.

title: A Parade of Fins and Skin Tests How Little Cover Is Legal
description: The Mermaid Parade in Coney Island is one of New York City's bawdiest, an annual rite of summer, artistic freedom and scantily clad bodies. When this year's parade is held on Saturday, it may highlight a delicate question of personal expression and test women's rights to expose themselves.

title: Europe Orders Deutsche Post to Repay Public Money
description: The European Commission today ordered Deutsche Post, the postal group partly privatized in 2000, to repay 572 million euros ($545 million) in public subsidies it said were wrongly used to undercut the prices of rivals in the parcel delivery market.

title: Six Months of Mayor Bloomberg
description: Someday New Yorkers will be so familiar with Michael Bloomberg's mayoral quirks that it will not seem odd to watch him playing golf while his staff negotiates the budget. The golfing moment was widely explained as an indication that this mayor is a good delegator. But it is also a good example of how this mayor is uncommonly apolitical -- unaware, apparently, that when big things are happening, elected officials always make it a point to look as if they're in the center of the action.

title: Refugee Women's Plight
description: War has never just been the business of men. This is most stark in refugee camps where women and children are in the majority. Living in limbo, often for long periods of time, women lead households and stretch meal rations to last for days. Sexual violence is common. Even something as simple as collecting food aid can be dangerous. In West Africa, women have allegedly had to trade sex for food from aid workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEGUILLOU, YVES CORBEL
description: LEGUILLOU-Yves Corbel, 93. Of Forest Hills, Queens, died May 21, 2002. He is survived by his wife, Eleanor, three children, Peter, James and Eleanor Ingbretson, and three grandchildren. Burial was in Roudouallec Cemetery, Roudouallec, Brittany, France. There will be a memorial mass at Our Lady of Mercy Church, Forest Hills, Friday, June 28 at 10:30 AM.

title: Bush Plan Would End A Monopoly For Amtrak
description: The Bush administration will propose on Thursday to end Amtrak's monopoly on intercity passenger rail service, government officials said today.

title: Addled or Wily in a Retirement Residence?
description: After an exciting finish to the United States Bridge Championships in Memphis on Monday night, the team headed by Nick Nickell earned the right to compete in the 2003 world team championships. Nickell, together with Dick Freeman, Bob Hamman, Paul Soloway, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell, led by just 7 imps going into the final segment of 15 deals, then pulled away to win by 29.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Boys Arrested In Rape
description: A 12-year-old boy and a 13-year-old boy were arrested yesterday in the rape of an 11-year-old girl in Prospect Park, the police said. The attack occurred just before 2 p.m., and the victim knew one of her attackers, Sgt. Harold Gregory said. She was taken to Methodist Hospital for evaluation, and the boys were arrested and charged with sexual misconduct. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: CVS Drops Bates For Hill, Holliday
description: In another blow to Bates USA in New York, the CVS pharmacy chain said yesterday that it had ended its relationship with the agency as it selected Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston as the new lead agency on its account. Billings were estimated at $35 million.

title: Agency Is Under Scrutiny For Overlooked Messages
description: The National Security Agency intercepted two cryptic communications on the day before the Sept. 11 attacks that referred to a major event scheduled for the next day, but analysts at the secret eavesdropping agency did not read the messages until Sept. 12, American intelligence officials said today.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: PERU: MINISTER RESIGNS IN PROTEST In a sign Peru's government was not out of trouble even after reaching a deal to defuse the worst crisis to hit President Alejandro Toledo, Interior Minister Fernando Rospigliosi has quit, citing splits over the handling of protests in the south. Mr. Rospigliosi announced his "irrevocable" decision three days after Mr. Toledo declared a 30-day state of emergency in Peru's second-largest city, Arequipa. Some 1,700 troops and police were dispatched to quell protests by furious residents fearing layoffs after Mr. Toledo reneged on a pledge not to sell two state-owned power companies to a French conglomerate. Mr. Rospigliosi's announcement came hours after the government unveiled a deal with local leaders in Arequipa to halt the protests.    (Reuters)

title: England Expects Owen To Be Ready for Brazil
description: Having survived Argentina in the so-called Group of Death in the first round, England must now play Brazil, oh so very early, in the quarterfinals tomorrow in the Japanese city of Shizuoka.

title: No One Will Suspect It's Not Real Teak
description: Now there's a line of outdoor furniture, made of cedar but stained to look like honey-colored teak, for about half the price of the real McCoy. The furniture can be ordered from its manufacturer, Brookbend, which is in Hopkinton, Mass.

title: Senate Hedges On Artillery Bush Officials Want to Kill
description: The Senate left the door open today for some form of an artillery system the Pentagon wants to kill, shifting $475 million budgeted for the weapon, the Crusader, into research for future combat systems.

title: Ulster Protestant Says British Police Urged '89 Killing of Lawyer
description: A man who confessed to killing a well-known Roman Catholic lawyer in Belfast 13 years ago said today that he had acted at the direction of the Northern Ireland police.

title: Rights of Women: More Than a Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: Gillies Heads the List Into the Hall of Fame
