description: With the ice still melting from the Stanley Cup finals last week, the National Hockey League began its off-season activities today by naming Clark Gillies of the powerhouse Islanders teams of the 1980's to the Hockey Hall of Fame.

title: Variations on an Office With Windows
description: In todays Circuits, I looked at a fascinating challenger to the 800-pound gorilla of productivity software (Microsoft Office for Windows): something called OpenOffice.org.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Questioning Safety Of Police Cars
description: Gov. Jane Hull has halted state purchases of Ford Crown Victoria police cruisers after the second police officer in five years was killed in a crash involving the vehicle. The state is also asking the National Highway and Traffic Safety Administration to investigate the safety of Crown Victorias. The agency rejected a similar request by Arizona last year.

title: Nets Review Options For Improving Roster
description: One week after the season ended and one week before the N.B.A. draft -- a window never before connected to the Nets -- the team began exploring options for improvement.

title: Fears of Misuse of Encryption System Are Voiced
description: A leading European computer security and privacy advocate is challenging an effort by the American computer industry to create a standard to protect software and digital content, calling the plan a smoke screen by established companies to protect their existing markets.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of garden tours last Thursday with an article about rudeness among visitors to private gardens misspelled part of the name of an event scheduled for July 6 in Federal Way, Wash. It is the Laurelhurst Garden Walk, not Lurelhurst.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Iranian Shades of Gray
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYNUM, SADIE C.
description: BYNUM - Sadie C. Born March 13, 1927, died June 11, 2002. She was a 34 year NYC teacher/administrator. Sadie educated many students in her 34 years as a teacher and administrator. She was a part of the Rothchild/Reynold's Junior HS in Brooklyn, NY.

title: Gucci Posts 42% Decline In Net Income
description: Dragged down by the painfully slow recovery of the global economy, Gucci said today that its income in the first fiscal quarter -- February to April -- slumped 42 percent.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Pathmark Strike Averted
description: Pathmark and a major union have reached a tentative contract agreement, a union spokesman said yesterday. The agreement between the union -- the United Food and Commercial Workers Union Local 1500 -- and the supermarket chain was reached on Monday and involves pay increases of up to $105 per week and overtime pay on Sundays. The union represents 7,500 of the chain's employees. They voted last week to authorize a strike if an agreement was not reached by midnight June 22. The employees are expected to approve the four-year contract within the next month, a spokesman for the union said. A strike would have affected 55 Pathmark stores in the state. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: US Airways and Unions Still Negotiating Over Cuts
description: Labor officials said yesterday that US Airways and several of its largest unions were not ready to settle on concessions from employees even though they have to agree quickly on cuts to bolster the company's application for a federal loan guarantee. The airline is also continuing to talk with its competitors on a partnership that would be critical to its recovery.

title: Principal Sues The Diocese Of Brooklyn, Citing Abuse
description: The principal of a Catholic school in Ozone Park, Queens, whose pastor is under investigation by the Queens district attorney's office has filed a sexual harassment suit against the Diocese of Brooklyn, charging that for more than 18 months church officials did not respond to her complaints that the pastor intimidated and verbally abused her with sexually explicit language.

title: CHARLES SCHWAB NAMES EXECUTIVE TO RUN RETAIL DIVISION
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the discount broker, yesterday named John Phillip Coghlan, formerly head of its institutional business, to run its retail division, which is dealing with a decline in client trading amid falling stock prices. Schwab's co-chief executive, David Pottruck, had been running the retail business, Schwab's largest, on an interim basis since Steven Scheid quit in February. William Atwell, 52, a former executive of Citigroup Inc. and American International Group, succeeds Mr. Coghlan, 51, as head of the institutional unit, which provides processing and account management services to independent investment advisers.

title: U.S. Prosecutors in Newark Join Investigation of Schering
description: The United States attorney's office in Newark is investigating how the Schering-Plough Corporation manufactured one or more prescription drug products, the company said yesterday.

title: He's Designed It, But Will They Buy It?
description: IF the bright colors and patterns of Todd Oldham's new Dorm Room line at Target stores don't appeal to you, that is perhaps because they aren't supposed to. Target has already figured out how to woo sophisticated shoppers with its hip bull's-eye ads, Philippe Starck baby products and Michael Graves coffee makers.

title: Grand Jury Indicts U.S. Forest Worker In Colorado Wildfire
description: The Forest Service employee charged with starting the largest wildfire in Colorado history was indicted today by a federal grand jury on four counts that could bring up to 40 years in prison.

title: TRW to Shed Unit Amid Hostile Takeover Threat
description: TRW, the military contractor and automotive company, said yesterday that it would sell its aeronautical systems unit to Goodrich for $1.5 billion in cash amid the lingering threat of a hostile takeover from Northrop Grumman.

title: Germans Press Investigation Of Qaeda-Tied Businessman
description: Under American pressure, German officials say they are intensifying their investigation into Mahmoun Darkazanli, one of the most mysterious figures tied to the attacks by Al Qaeda on the United States, who is still living at large in Hamburg.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Probation For Easter Seals Thief
description: Martha Wittkowski, fired in January from her job as president of the state's Easter Seals chapter for stealing $230,000 of the organization's money, was sentenced to three years' probation, 500 hours of community service and was ordered to stop gambling. Donna Elbrecht, the chief executive of Iowa Easter Seals since Ms. Wittkowski's dismissal, said all major donors had continued to support the company. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Chip Makers Report Inquiry On Industry
description: Yesterday was a calling-all-lawyers day for the volatile segment of the microchip industry that makes memory devices for personal computers and other electronic products.

title: Far East Discounts
description: All 38 Shangri-La and Traders hotels have discounts up to 40 percent (with breakfast) through Aug. 31 under their Rate Break promotion. The hotels are in China (including Hong Kong), Singapore, Thailand and other Asian countries. At the 657-room Shangri-La Beijing, which has an indoor pool, rates start at $110 a night, double. At the beach-front 459-room Rasa Sentosa Resort in Singapore, it is $108 and up; the 832-room Shangri-La Bangkok, with two outdoor pools, starts at $138. Tax and service extra; subject to availability. (800) 942-5050 or www.shangri-la.com .

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the collapse of a 460-year-old oak in Wye Mills, Md., referred incorrectly in some copies to the term used by a state forester searching for signs of revitalization. The term, for root sprouts, is adventitious buds -- not advantageous.

title: Temporary Workers in Navistar Plant
description: CHATHAM, Ontario, June 19 (Bloomberg News)  Navistar International Inc., the truckmaker, plans to use temporary employees to resume production at an Ontario factory where union workers went on strike June 1.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Japanese Chip Makers In Alliance
description: Two of the largest chip makers in Japan, Fujitsu and Toshiba, said yesterday that they would form an alliance to create sophisticated computer chips. The companies said the alliance would focus on large-scale integrated circuits -- the chips typically used in digital consumer products like mobile phones and game consoles. The demand for such chips is expected to grow as a new generation of Internet-compatible consumer electronics reaches the market. Yesterday's move was expected to cut costs and could bring the companies closer together. ''The two companies may seek ways to effectively expand the scope of their partnership, including the possibility of integrating their operations,'' Fujitsu and Toshiba said in a statement. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Selection of Chief Seen at Eddie Bauer
description: Eddie Bauer Inc., the struggling retailer owned by the Spiegel Group, is close to a deal to hire a chief executive, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: US Airways and Unions Still Trying to Reach Deal

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ferry Service Scheduled To Expand
description: New York Waterway, the biggest ferry company in the region, is expanding its service in two directions. Starting on June 28, the company will run weekend boats to Belmar on the Jersey Shore from Manhattan, Hoboken and Jersey City. The ferries, former fishing-party boats, will head south on Friday evenings and return on Sunday evenings. The trip, which can take three hours by car on a summer weekend, will take an hour by boat and cost $30 for a round trip. In Brooklyn, starting on Monday, New York Waterway will take over the service from Bay Ridge to Lower Manhattan that New York City began offering after Sept. 11. The service, financed by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, will remain free for now, Waterway officials said.

title: Doctor, You Have Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Rooting for the Underdogs
description: Weekly highlights from 150 forums  from reactions to the renewed violence in the Middle East to comments on the World Cup.

title: Verizon Service in Maine
description: Verizon Communications Inc. has won the government's permission to sell long-distance telephone calling in Maine, the seventh state in which the company has been cleared to offer the service.

title: Some Players Want to Postpone Any Strike
description: They initially talked of boycotting baseball's All-Star Game and since then have considered setting a strike date for early August or striking in the postseason, jeopardizing the World Series. Now some players have thrown another option into the debate over their union's strategy in negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: Election Panel Rebuffs Effort To Weaken 'Issue Ad' Limits
description: Federal election regulators rejected an effort today that critics said would have watered down a provision of the new campaign-finance legislation aimed at eliminating those ''issue ads'' that are often thinly veiled attacks on federal candidates paid for by unrestricted donations from corporations, unions and other advocacy groups.

title: U.S. Defends Limits on American in Custody
description: The government argued today that it was perfectly legal to hold an American citizen in custody without filing charges against him and without giving him access to a lawyer.

title: The Fire Near Home
description: When we learned that a Forest Service employee, Terry Barton, had been charged with deliberately setting the fire now burning out of control near my home, I tried to imagine her in slow motion, lighting the match, setting it off and then watching the flames charge across the grass to the pines. Within a day or two the fire was leaping from the tops of trees, crossing roads and streams, exploding pine sap, creating heat so intense that whole weather systems whirled out of the flames. It has now burned more than 135,000 acres.

title: The Tricky Task of Shelving the Web
description: GREENVILLE, it seemed, was plagued with pornography. In the 12 public libraries serving the city and its county in South Carolina, adults were looking for pornographic images online and didn't care who saw them -- and, by some accounts, were showing the images to children passing by.

title: Footlights
description: Music and Words

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a federal appeals panel's refusal to delay the opening of deportation hearings for immigrants detained after Sept. 11 misstated the day of the decision. It was Monday, not Tuesday.

title: Boston Archdiocese Agrees to Talks on Settling New Lawsuits
description: Lawyers for 275 plaintiffs who are suing the Archdiocese of Boston in cases of sexual abuse by clergymen agreed tonight to engage in settlement talks with archdiocesan lawyers and postpone depositions of Cardinal Bernard F. Law and other local officials of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRUS, GERALD
description: CARRUS-Gerald. With great sorrow and heartfelt expressions of affection, we, The Center for Discovery Family, extend our hands in friendship and gratitude to Janet Carrus, and the entire Carrus family. The generosity and love of Gerry and Janet will forever live in the legacy they have provided to The Center for Discovery and the International Family Institute. He shall forever be our shining star. Elizabeth L. Berman, President, Board of Directors Patrick H. Dollard, C.E.O., The Foundation Board The Center for Discovery Family

title: Spanish Architect to Lend Flair To a Symphony's New Home
description: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra announced Monday that Santiago Calatrava, below, will be the architect for a new Atlanta Symphony Center, to open in 2008. Mr. Calatrava is best known in this country for the Milwaukee Art Museum's soaring Quadracci Pavilion, which opened in October.

title: Big, Bigger, Biggest: The Supersize Suburb . . .
description: TAKE a peek inside the master bedroom of Bob and Wendy Banner.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: EXECUTIVES TAKE PAY CUT Mizuho Holdings will cut its executives' pay by as much as 50 percent as they take responsibility for a crisis in April in which the bank's computers rejected millions of consumer transactions. The president, Terunobu Maeda, and the heads of Mizuho Corporate Bank and Mizuho Bank will have their pay cut in half for six months from July, the company said. The wages of all 113 other executives will also be cut, while three former co-chief executives, responsible for integrating the lender's main units, resigned as advisers on Monday, the bank said. (Bloomberg News)

title: Queens Boy, 15, Drowns Off L.I. as 3 Friends Swim to Safety
description: A 15-year-old Queens boy drowned yesterday while swimming in the ocean off Long Beach, on Long Island, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, ETHEL (FOWDEM)
description: RAND-Ethel (Fowdem), 80. Of Monroe Township, New Jersey (formerly of Brooklyn) on June 17, 2002. Beloved wife of Henry Rand, mother of Michael (Anne) Rand, and Judith (Barry) Dichter. title: In a NoHo Penthouse, Economy of Function on a Grand Scale
description: ''Everything had to move and retract,'' Suzan Wines said of a 3,000-square-foot, two-story penthouse she and Azin Valy, her partner at I-Beam Design, created in NoHo. The penthouse, a loft intended to be playfully minimalist, was for Ted Petroulas, a founding partner in the Clinton Group, an asset management firm in lower Manhattan; his wife, Nasim Alikhani; and their 7-year-old twins. Nothing -- kitchen cabinet, bathroom sink, or bathroom window -- wound up with only one function, if it could have two or three.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOK, DR. DAVID
description: BROOK-Dr. David. United Nations Secretary, professor and author. Service Friday, 10:00am, I.J. Morris, Brooklyn.

title: A Chip That Mimics Neurons, Firing Up the Memory
description: IN the 2001 movie ''Memento,'' the hero cannot hold onto any new memories. He forgets whatever he sees or hears within moments, distracted by new events that he also forgets in turn.

title: A Scholar Recants on His 'Shakespeare' Discovery
description: In 1995 Donald Foster, a professor of English at Vassar College, made a startling case for Shakespeare's being the author of an obscure 578-line poem called ''A Funeral Elegy.'' After a front-page article about his methods of computer analysis in The New York Times -- and after his reputation was further burnished by unmasking Joe Klein as the author of ''Primary Colors'' -- the poem was added to three major editions of Shakespeare's works.

title: Kanombe Journal; After the Horror, Truth and Some Healing, Maybe
description: As far as legal proceedings go, what unfolded today on a patch of dirt on the outskirts of this village was tantamount to a preliminary hearing. But the court was held in the open air, spectators sat on the edge of a cassava field, the judges had just three weeks of legal experience and many of the procedural rules were made up on the fly.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''No one who cannot rejoice in the discovery of his own mistakes deserves to be called a scholar.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Pay Guidelines At Vodafone
description: The Vodafone Group issued new salary guidelines in response to critics who say that the company is overpaying top executives even as it reports huge losses. Under the new policy, Christopher Gent, the chief executive, will receive total compensation in line with executives at the top quartile of European companies, or 3.4 million ($5 million) to 9.3 million a year, the company said. For the year ended in March, Mr. Gent received 2.4 million in salary and bonus. He was also granted 8.95 million share options with an exercise price of 1.58, and 844,000 shares of common stock. The options and stock grants can be exercised at the earliest by July 2004, providing certain performance targets are met. Vodafone reported a $24 billion net loss, as it wrote down the value of some acquisitions, for the year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

description: Noa Alon, 60, retired last year from her job teaching kindergarten, but she went back on Wednesday for something special: to direct a year-end children's concert in which her own 5-year-old granddaughter, Gal, performed.

title: Schneider Of France Is in Talks To Sell Unit
description: The board of Schneider Electric is scheduled to meet on Monday to decide whether to enter into exclusive negotiations to sell its Legrand unit to Wendel Investissement, a French conglomerate, and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity firm, for roughly 3.7 billion euros ($3.5 billion), people close to the negotiations said today.

title: Uruguay Lifts Limits on Peso to Assist Economy
description: The government of Uruguay announced today that it would allow the country's currency, the peso, to float freely against the American dollar, in an effort to soften the blow of a deepening regional economic crisis.

title: Half Full, Not Half Empty, in New Jersey
description: Thanks to spring rainfall that largely replenished reservoirs in New Jersey, and to lobbying by the golf and landscaping industries, the state's Department of Environmental Protection yesterday eased several restrictions on water use that were imposed on March 11 under a drought emergency.

description: Federal copyright regulators set a critical ground rule for the fledgling Internet radio industry yesterday, cutting in half a proposed royalty rate that Internet companies must pay to record labels.

description: HONG KONG:  Hong Kong legislators have voted to approve the most sweeping changes to the territory's government structure since China resumed sovereignty over the former British colony five years ago.

title: No Power, No Plumbing, No PlayStation
description: BY now, the summer drill is all too familiar. Waiting for a gap in traffic to make a death-defying left-hand turn on Route 27. Squeezing fresh tomatoes at a farmer's roadside stand only to be blindsided by the obnoxious parents you've spent the last week avoiding at the Chelsea Piers hockey rink. Begging the contractor's answering machine to please finish the construction that was supposed to be done by Memorial Day ''at the absolute latest.''

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Guilty Plea In Kickback Case
description: Two former members of the East Detroit school board pleaded guilty on Wednesday to accepting $69,244 in kickbacks from a contractor who had been awarded a $28 million district project. One member, Karen DeGrande, 44, resigned from the board. She may face 21 months of jail time while the second defendant, Bettie Huebner, 73, faces 6 to 12 months in prison. A sentencing date has not yet been set. The F.B.I. has investigated the district's bidding practices for three years, and several high-ranking officials have resigned. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITWELL, JOSEPH E. JR.
description: WHITWELL-Joseph E. Jr., long time leader of General Cigar Co., dies at the age of 82. Born in St. Paul, MN, he was educated at Northwestern University. As a Captain in the Army Air Corps, Mr. Whitwell was awarded the ''Air Medal'' as squadron commander in the battle of Kasserine Pass. Joining General Cigar Co. in 1948, he rose through the ranks and became President of the then parent company, Culbro Corporation. He retired in 1987 as President and Chief Operating Officer of Culbro. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Josephine Whitwell, 1 daughter, 1 son, 6 grandsons and 1 great granddaughter.

title: Progress Is Reported on Parkinson's Disease
description: Scientists working with human embryonic stem cells have converted them into the type of brain cell that is lost in Parkinson's disease, and have shown that the equivalent cells in mice alleviate Parkinson-like symptoms in rodents.

title: Hurt in Ground Zero Work, Firefighter Runs for Congress
description: A New York City firefighter whose lungs were injured during recovery efforts at the World Trade Center site announced his candidacy for Congress yesterday. But he did so in Manhattan -- about 35 miles and three counties away from his Suffolk home and the Second Congressional District that he seeks to represent.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: House Panel Approves Bill on Prescription Drug Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  After a marathon all-night session, the House Committee on Energy and Commerce approved a Republican bill today to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly under Medicare, clearing the way for House passage of the measure next week.

title: Sophie G. Untermeyer, 92, Supporter of the Philharmonic
description: Sophie G. Untermeyer, a longtime supporter and key staff member of the New York Philharmonic and a noted sportswoman, died on Saturday at the Jewish Home and Hospital in Manhattan. She was 92 and had lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Court, 5-4, Upholds Authority of States To Protect Patients
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the states' authority to protect the rights of patients in disputes with managed care companies over denial of recommended treatments.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: AUTO EXECUTIVE DISMISSED Brilliance China Automotive Holdings Ltd. fired its chairman, Yang Rong, less than a week after he denied speculation that he was under investigation by the Chinese government. Mr. Yang, who was instrumental in the company's 1992 New York share sale, the first by a mainland Chinese company, will be replaced as chairman by the vice chairman, Wu Xiaoan, Brilliance said. Su Qiang, who has worked with Mr. Yang for a decade, was named president and chief executive, positions that Mr. Yang also held.

title: An Edith Wharton Novella, Set to Music
description: For 20 years the Center for Contemporary Opera has been making the case that there are new operas out there, and that even if most of them are unlikely to find a place in the standard canon, the least they deserve is an occasional hearing. On Wednesday evening at the Kaye Playhouse, the company closed its season with the New York premiere of Stephen Paulus's ''Summer,'' a work that was given its world premiere in 1999 by another small but enterprising company, the Berkshire Opera.

title: James M. Howard Jr., 80, Teacher of Writing
description: James Merriam Howard Jr., a leading advocate of using writing as a tool for helping improve performance and thinking in all areas of the curriculum, died on Tuesday at a hospital close to his home in Westport Point, Mass. He was 80.

description: Sending a loud message to corporate executives, three former executives and a current employee at the Rite Aid Corporation were indicted today in what the Securities and Exchange Commission and the United States attorney's office described as a far-reaching securities and accounting fraud.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: A Tax Proposal Dies
description: Republican legislators said they would kill their proposal for a 50-cent cigarette tax increase despite its failure this week by only two votes in the state House. No Democrats voted for the increase, intended to ease a $350 million budget shortfall. The Democrats said the shortfall could be eliminated by smaller cuts to the state's business and income taxes than Republicans favor. Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

title: 7 Militants Questioned On Car Bomb
description: The authorities here said today that they had detained seven members of a violent sectarian group for questioning about their involvement or knowledge of terrorist bombings, including an attack last week outside the American consulate.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia Cuts Estimate
description: Only two months after forecasting second-half growth of at least 15 percent, Nokia trimmed the numbers once again, saying it now expects growth of up to 10 percent. The company, the world's leading mobile phone maker, said it was maintaining its profit target for 2002. Nokia also stuck to a forecast that the global handset market would grow to 400 million to 420 million and said it was hoping to control 40 percent of the market, up from a third. The news did not affect Nokia's share price. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Viewing an Ancient City With Futuristic Glasses
description: ''Banaras: The Luminous City,'' an exhibition at the Asia Society and Museum, is nominally about the ancient Indian center of learning and spiritual enlightenment, now called Varanasi (or sometimes Benares). But practically, it serves as a test case for using new interactive technologies to enhance the museum experience.

title: 23 Players Withdraw From N.B.A. Draft
description: A total of 23 players, including the 7-foot-1 center Chris Marcus from Western Kentucky, withdrew from the N.B.A. draft before yesterday's deadline. Twelve college underclassmen, one high school player and 10 international players wre on the list.

title: A Computer as Co-Pilot: You Talk and I'll Steer
description: I HAVE always taken maps on trips. But now I use them just for backup and to give me an idea of the territory. Since installing a navigation system in my car, I just get in, enter a destination, and let it tell me how to go.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arguing Over 9/11 Insurance
description: Larry A. Silverstein, the real estate developer who controlled the World Trade Center, suffered a legal setback this week in his attempt to recover more than $7 billion in insurance for the Sept. 11 terror attack. Mr. Silverstein has argued that he is entitled to two $3.6 billion payments for two separate attacks on the two buildings; the insurers argue it was one attack. But a federal judge in Manhattan ruled on Wednesday that employees at Willis, Mr. Silverstein's insurance broker, must testify about conversations last fall with Mr. Silverstein's lawyers. The insurers suspect that Mr. Silverstein and the broker initially considered the destruction a single event for insurance purposes. Lawyers for Swiss Re, one of the insurance companies, could start deposing Willis brokers next week. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Man Shot At Mall
description: A man in his early 20's was shot in the ankle last night at the Roosevelt Field Mall, the Nassau County police said. A gun was recovered at the scene, and a man believed to be the assailant was in custody, the police said last night. ''It looks like a verbal altercation between the two,'' Officer Adele Burke said. The shooting occurred just before 8 p.m. near the second-floor food court. The victim was taken to Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola and was reported to be in stable condition last night. The police did not release the name of the victim or the suspect. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Proposes a New Board to Oversee Auditors
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed yesterday setting up an accounting oversight board that could bar accountants from auditing public companies if it found that they had been unethical or incompetent.

title: Desire for Sons Drives Use of Prenatal Scans in China
description: In greater numbers than ever, China's villagers are using inexpensive prenatal scans and then abortion to prevent the birth of unwanted daughters and to ensure that they will bear a son, recent studies and census data show.

title: Microsoft and Verizon in D.S.L. Deal
description: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it would begin using Microsoft's content, software and marketing support for its high- speed D.S.L. Internet service and would pay Microsoft a portion of the revenue.

title: Corrections
description: The Weekender column in Escapes last Friday, about the town of Ocean Grove, N.J., misstated the surname of the owner of the Ocean Vista Hotel. She is Diane Herr, not Kerr. The article also included a musical group incorrectly among those scheduled for the Great Auditorium in Ocean Grove this season. Peter, Paul and Mary are not scheduled.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Steel Merger
description: Siam Cement, Thailand's largest industrial group, and NTS Steel Group plan to combine their construction-steel units into a venture that will have more than half of the country's steel-production capacity. Siam Cement will own 45 percent of the new steel unit, and NTS Steel shareholders and creditors will hold the balance.

title: Reporters Are Fined For Talking To Ex-Jurors
description: Four reporters for The Philadelphia Inquirer were fined $1,000 each yesterday and three of them were sentenced to community service for violating a trial judge's order barring reporters from identifying or contacting jurors after a murder trial of a rabbi in Camden last fall.

title: Germany Eases Restrictions On Workers From Abroad
description: The German president, Johannes Rau, signed an immigration law today that significantly expands the residence permits available to workers from countries outside the European Union at a time when countries across the Continent are moving toward tightening their borders.

title: Prosecution Completes Case in Trial of Slain Reporter
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, June 21  The man accused of organizing the kidnapping and slaying of the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl told a court today that the case against him was a jumble of lies and faked evidence concocted by the government to please the United States.

title: Watch What You Say
description: Before recounting how President Clinton burned alive dozens of Christians (this feint is known in the column trade as baiting the right), let me offer a quick historical quiz: What religion were Muhammad's parents?

title: Panel Allows Solicitation of Soft Money at Fund-Raisers
description: Angering backers of the new campaign-finance law, federal election regulators approved a rule today that will allow federal candidates speaking at state or local fund-raisers to seek unrestricted soft money contributions, although sponsors of the law say it bans lawmakers from soliciting such money.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Loudcloud Needs Cash, Auditor Says
description: The auditor for Loudcloud raised concern that the company would not be able to stay in business without additional cash, including the proceeds from the planned sale of its Web-site management business. Loudcloud said this week that it would sell the management business to the Electronic Data Systems Corporation for $63.5 million. Without that money and the $9 million that it is expected to gain from buying the Frontera Corporation, Loudcloud may not be able to sustain operations, its auditor, Ernst & Young said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. A Loudcloud spokeswoman declined to comment. Loudcloud is based in Sunnyvale, Calif.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: 100 Feared Dead At Coal Mine
description: More than 100 miners were feared dead after a gas explosion in a large state-run coal mine in the northeastern province of Helongjiang. China has the world's worst mine safety record. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSTER, IRWIN, DDS.
description: FORSTER-Irwin, DDS. Died on June 20, 2002 in White Plains, NY at the age of 88. He lived in Hartsdale and Lakeworth, Florida and was a former resident of White Plains and Brookfield, CT. Born in Brooklyn he was a graduate of NYU School of Dentistry. A Captain in the Army Air Force in WWII and subsequently taught at NYU and Albert Einstein School of Medicine. Dr. Forster practiced in NYC for 38 years. A scholar, tinkerer and fabled story teller. He was predeceased by his wife Jean Seixas Forster, his daughter Lee Seixas Forster, his sister Vera Fastenberg and his brother Joey Forster. He was the father of Andrea Ossip and father-inlaw of Al Ossip. Loving grandfather of Jessica and Joshua Fausty and Joshua's wife Edi Giunta. ''Poppy'' of Matteo, Emily, Muriel, Samantha and Emily and brother to Arnold and Sandy Forster and Eleanor Miller. Graveside services at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY on Friday, June 21 at 1:30 PM.

description: WOOD-BURNING COOKSTOVE

title: U.S. Charges 14 Reputed Members of Gambino Crime Family
description: Within weeks of the death of John J. Gotti and the indictment of his eldest brother, Peter, the new reputed chief of the Gambino crime family, federal prosecutors in Manhattan yesterday announced charges against 14 more people who they said were Gambino family members or associates.

title: Sports of The Times; Soccer Referees on Run, and They Can't Hide
description: Being a soccer referee is not an easy job. Ask Angel Sanchez of Argentina, who was swarmed by a gang of Portuguese players, one of whom held him by the cheeks while Joo Pinto was punching him in the back last Friday, after Sanchez had given a red card that sent Pinto out of Portugal's World Cup game against South Korea. Pinto has since been suspended.

title: City Hall Avoids Deep Cuts, But Full Bill May Come Later
description: The budget accord this week between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council to close the city's $5 billion deficit has managed to stave off many of the most-feared cuts for now. But it relies on a battery of revenue sources that will not be available to help close the city's widening budget gaps over the next few years.

title: How Czech Glass Burst Restraints Of Functionality
description: ''Let us conquer the world for Bohemian glass,'' the Czech glass artist Stanislav Libensky declared in 1945. And he nearly did, despite World War II, the Communist takeover of Czechoslovakia in 1948, the Soviet invasion of Prague in 1968 and the Velvet Revolution of 1989. The Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N.Y., has dedicated its summer exhibition, ''Glass Behind the Iron Curtain: Czech Design, 1948-1978,'' to Libensky, who died in February at age 80. The show has 100 works by Libensky and other top postwar Czech glass artists.

title: Overstaying 15 Minutes Of Fame
description: THE C.I.A., which is not what you think but rather an obscure group called Columnists Incorporated in America, was delighted to hear this week that Amy Fisher is about to join the ranks.

title: Trying to Make Sense of the Irrational
description: Is it possible to explain a phenomenon like Jeffrey Dahmer, the notorious serial killer who murdered 17 men and cannibalized parts of their bodies? Or are the social forces that shaped him the same pressures that thousands of other people have endured without being driven to kill?

title: Panel Rejects Immunizing All Against a Smallpox Outbreak
description: A panel of specialists advising the federal government on smallpox vaccinations unanimously rejected a proposal today to offer vaccines to every American. Instead, the panel recommended immunizing only the estimated 15,000 health care and law enforcement workers who would be most likely to respond to a biological attack and come in contact with victims.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: A Lame Duck, Heading South
description: Gov. Jesse Ventura, who declared on Tuesday that he would not seek re-election, plans to spend the rest of his term traveling, including a boat trip down the Mississippi River and visiting Cuba in the fall. Mr. Ventura, who complained of journalists' violating his family's privacy, also plans to chide reporters on his weekly radio show. A former professional wrestler, he said he would serve a second term if he was elected as a write-in candidate. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Tuesday about a United States Forest Service employee who has been charged with setting a fire that has burned more than 100,000 acres of Colorado misidentified the agency that inadvertently caused a wildfire outside Los Alamos, N.M., in 2000. It was the National Park Service, not the forest service.

title: Parks Dept. Says Bias Suit Cites Practices It Has Changed
description: City parks officials said yesterday that a federal lawsuit claiming the Parks and Recreation Department has a pattern of racial discrimination was invalid, because the department had revamped its hiring practices.

title: Trachsel Starts Out Perfectly, Which Is Just What Mets Need
description: Six times last night, Steve Trachsel watched a batter from the Minnesota Twins make the final out of an inning. Each time, Trachsel would turn his head down and trudge to the Mets' dugout. He looked miserable.

title: Is It Sharpton to the Rescue? India-Pakistan Trip Is Set
description: It is a delicate situation. A six-decade-long border dispute with religious roots that reach back centuries. A million heavily armed troops massed along Himalayan mountain passes. Two third world powers tapping their fingers on nuclear buttons.

title: UAL Endorses A Pilots' Deal With Pay Cuts And U.S. Aid
description: The board of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, approved a tentative agreement with its pilots yesterday on cuts that would save $520 million in costs over three years. But the agreement is subject to approval by United's 9,000 pilots, and it would not take effect unless the airline obtained a federal loan guarantee.

title: Quick Escapes
description: Boise, Idaho

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Court Upholds State Review Of Health Care Decisions

title: New Video Releases
description: I Am Sam

title: CIRCUIT CITY TO DROP VHS MOVIES TO CLEAR WAY FOR DVD'S
description: The Circuit City Group, the large electronics retailer, said yesterday that it was eliminating VHS movies from its stores to make room for faster-selling DVD's. The company has removed videocassette movies at some of its 622 stores and plans to stop selling them at other stores, said a spokesman, Bill Cimino. Retailers like the Best Buy Company, Borders Group and Blockbuster are increasing the space that is devoted to DVD's as more people buy DVD players. Circuit City is the first national retailer to quit carrying VHS movies at its stores, Mr. Cimino said. The stores will continue to sell videocassette recorders and blank VHS tapes.

title: Fear Of All Sums
description: ''It is difficult to get a man to understand something,'' wrote Upton Sinclair, ''when his salary depends upon his not understanding it.'' To make sense of what passes for debate over Social Security reform, one must realize that advocates of privatization -- of replacing the current system, at least in part, with a system of personal accounts -- are determined not to understand basic arithmetic. Otherwise they would have to admit that such accounts would weaken, not strengthen, the system's finances.

title: Will Wonders Never Cease?
description: The cabinet of curiosities seems to be having one of those cyclical moments. Earlier this year, the J. Paul Getty Museum wound up an exhibition called ''Devices of Wonder,'' which looked at sense-enhancing and image-making inventions over the centuries. In May, New York University held a symposium in honor of the 400th birthday of Athanasius Kircher, the polymath and founder of Rome's earliest wunderkammer.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: SETBACK FOR TRADE MEASURE

title: CITING 'NATIONAL CONSENSUS,' JUSTICES BAR DEATH PENALTY FOR RETARDED DEFENDANTS
description: The Constitution bars the execution of mentally retarded offenders, the Supreme Court declared today in a landmark death penalty ruling based on the majority's view that a ''national consensus'' now rejected such executions as excessive and inappropriate.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Israel's decision to seize Palestinian land after 19 people died in a suicide bombing misstated the ranking of the episode among deadly attacks. It was the third deadliest bombing since September 2000, not the second. (The worst killed 29 people at a hotel in Netanya on March 27; the second worst was on June 1, 2001, at a Tel Aviv disco, where 21 died.)

title: Goldman Results Beat Forecast, Just in Time for Stock Sale
description: One day before its employees could start selling company shares worth more than $4 billion, the Goldman Sachs Group reported yesterday that its quarterly earnings declined 2.4 percent, less than expected.

title: Weekender | Sachem's Head, Conn.
description: SACHEM'S HEAD takes its name from a violent part of its history. A 1637 skirmish between the Mohegan Indians, allied with the English, and the Pequots on what is now Bloody Cove Beach led to the beheading of a Pequot sachem, or chief. More than two centuries later, this small promontory jutting out from the jagged Connecticut shoreline started growing as a vacation community. Nearly all of its summer cottages have been winterized or renovated, and many weekenders have grown so fond of Sachem's Head that they now live there year-round.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Inquiry Expands
description: The information-gathering effort by investigators from the Justice Department who are looking at the memory chip market for possible antitrust violations has expanded to smaller companies, according to statements released yesterday by several of them. Elpida Memory of Japan, the fifth-largest maker of the chips, said its United States unit had received a subpoena, as did Nanya Technologies and Winbond Electronics, both of Taiwan. Elpida is a joint venture between the NEC Corporation and Hitachi. Separately, Samsung Electronics of South Korea, the largest manufacturer of the chips, said that its subsidiary in the United States had responded to a subpoena but was not a target of the investigation. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Fort Worth Dallas Ballet Picks Director
description: Ben Stevenson, the artistic director of the Houston Ballet, has been named director of the Fort Worth Dallas Ballet, effective July 2003.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about security changes at Logan International Airport in Boston referred incorrectly to the ownership of two jets from there that were hijacked on Sept. 11. Only one belonged to American Airlines; the other belonged to United.

title: Demand, but No Capital, at Nonprofit Hospitals
description: As nonprofit hospitals around the country struggle with a surprising growth in admissions, many are finding it increasingly difficult to raise the money they need to meet the new demands on them.

title: In California Gold Country, A New Rush for Old Wine
description: DURING the gold rush of the 1850's, Placerville, Calif., about 60 miles east of Sacramento, was known as Hangtown, for the violent justice meted out to prospectors and other fortune seekers who ran afoul of the law.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Setback For Trade Measure
description: Facing a probable defeat, House Republican leaders abruptly put off a vote that would have allowed the House and Senate to begin discussions on a final measure giving President Bush authority to negotiate trade deals. Lawmakers called the setback, though most likely only temporary, a sign of just how difficult it would be to win House approval of a final compromise trade measure. The trade bill passed the chamber last year by a single vote. Alison Mitchell (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swissair Is Investigated
description: A criminal inquiry has begun into the financial underpinnings of the collapsed Swiss national carrier, Swissair. Zurich prosecutors are looking into allegations of falsified documents and incorrect financial data after the seizure of company documents in several cities. Three former executive board members have been under scrutiny, but not named, according to prosecutors.

title: Massachusetts Priest Indicted on Charges of Raping 4 Children
description: The Rev. Paul R. Shanley, a central figure in the sexual abuse scandal of the Boston Archdiocese, was indicted today on charges of raping four children from 1979 to 1989, when he was the pastor at a church in suburban Newton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, PAULA
description: SCHULMAN-Paula. Of Millbrook, NY and Boca Raton, FL, June 19, 2002 at age 83. Cherished wife of the late Howard Schulman. Beloved mother of Ann Milbank, Judith Lederer and Janet Dicker, and mother-in-law of Jeffrey Lederer and Marshall Dicker. Adored grandmother of Dana, Aaron and Megan Milbank, Cecilia and Joshua Lederer, Claire Dicker, Donna DePasquale and Amelia Burgess. Devoted great grandmother of Isaiah Milbank. Also survived by brother Myron E. Berrick, sister-inlaw Frances Berrick, and six nieces and nephews. Funeral services today, Friday, June 21, noon at Gutterman Funeral Home, 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Israel's decision to seize Palestinian land after 19 people died in a suicide bombing misstated the ranking of the episode among deadly attacks. It was the third deadliest bombing since September 2000, not the second. (The worst killed 29 people at a hotel in Netanya on March 27; the second worst was on June 1, 2001, at a Tel Aviv disco, where 21 died.)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Reuters Shares Hit 9-Year Low
description: Shares in the Reuters Group fell to the lowest level in nine years on concern business is worsening after the company, the world's biggest provider of financial information, said it would eliminate 650 jobs. The job cuts, mostly from ''senior and middle management ranks,'' will cost about 100 million ($149.1 million) in 2002, said a spokesman, Adrian Duffield, twice what the company earned last year. A slump in stock markets has led the securities industry to trim about 62,000 positions in the last year, reducing demand for the information Reuters provides. Reuters stock fell 56 pence, or 14 percent, to 347.5 pence ($5.18), the lowest since July 1993. In the last year Reuters has announced plans to cut 2,750 jobs, or 14 percent of its workers.

title: More Than Child's Play
description: To the Editor:

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Back in 1982, seven years after Silvano Marchetto put his name on Da Silvano, he acquired the space next door to the north, broke through the wall and added a long rear room to the original front room. Now, 20 years later, after acquiring the space next door to the south, Mr. Marchetto has added another wing, though this time, because of a stubborn hallway that refused to be displaced, it required a separate entrance.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Accord With NATO On Sea Rescues
description: Russia and NATO have signed an agreement to cooperate on rescues at sea, a move intended to improve the response to disasters like the sinking of the submarine Kursk in the Barents Sea nearly two years ago. The agreement came a day after completion of a search for debris from the Kursk, whose sinking killed all 118 men aboard. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: CNN, Amid Criticism in Israel, Adopts Terror Report Policy
description: Executives at the Cable News Network dismissed reports yesterday that CNN might be removed from the air in Israel, saying it retains strong relationships with that country's satellite and cable distributors.

title: A New York Bouquet of Gauguin
description: Paul Gauguin (1848-1903) liked attention. He wore funny clothes, said shocking things, painted gorgeous pictures and traveled halfway around the world to get it. His efforts paid off. When he died of syphilis at 54 on an island in the South Pacific, people around the world took notice, and they have been noticing him ever since.

title: Beware the Plutocrats
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You can't play good tennis or hit the golf ball if what you are thinking about is how other people are perceiving you.''''

title: Bush Urges Nation to Follow His Lead and Get Fit
description: President Bush told Americans today to exercise more and to eat less, and to stop using drugs, tobacco and excessive amounts of alcohol.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Truth in Acting

title: Ravel's Many Moods and Moves
description: ''The Ravel Project,'' four works set to familiar Ravel scores by the modern-dance choreographer Pascal Rioult, makes one of the most original programs of the dance season.

title: Ingredients for a Margarita Summer
description: IF the sound of whirring blenders is any indication, margarita season has officially begun.

title: Webb Follows Own Path Away From College
description: They are here or en route for USA Track and Field's national outdoor championships: Maurice Greene and Tim Montgomery, the fast-talking male sprinters; Marion Jones, the world's dominant female sprinter; Allen Johnson, the world's fastest hurdler; Deena Drossin, Marla Runyan, Regina Jacobs and Suzy Favor Hamilton, intense rivals in the women's middle and long distances; Jeff Hartwig and Stacy Dragila, the highest American pole vaulters; and Kevin Toth, Adam Nelson and John Godina, the world's three leading male shot-putters this year.

title: Four Former and Current Rite Aid Executives Are Andicted
description: HARRISBURG, Pa. (AP)-- The former chairman and two other past senior executives of Rite Aid Corp. were indicted Friday in what authorities described as a far-reaching securities and accounting fraud that prompted the largest restatement of corporate earnings in American history.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Apartheid Victims Sue Banks
description: A class action lawsuit was filed in U.S. District Court in the Southern District of New York against Citigroup Inc., and Switzerland's two largest banks, Credit Suisse Group and UBS, on behalf of four South African victims of apartheid. Lawyers argue that the banks' financial dealings prolonged the white-only rule in violation of international law. They are seeking about $50 billion from the banks on behalf of as many as hundreds of thousands of clients. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKLEY, DENNIS F.
description: BUCKLEY-Dennis F. We mourn the passing of Dennis Buckley, who led North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset for nearly 20 years. With leadership, foresight and tenacity, Mr. Buckley directed North Shore through a period of tremendous growth and transformation. Mr. Buckley joined North Shore Hospital in 1964 as controller. Within a year, he was named executive vice president and ultimately became head of the hospital. Under Mr. Buckley's tenure as chief executive officer, North Shore created teaching affiliations with Cornell University Medical College. In addition, the hospital's original red brick building grew to include new patient buildings, as well as teaching facilities and the Boas Marks Research Institute. Mr. Buckley retired as CEO in 1983, but continued as a consultant until 1987. We extend our condolences to his wife Jean and two daughters, Marie and Anne. Mr. Buckley's unfailing commitment to the hospital and the community was instrumental in making North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset the renowned institution it is today. His legacy will endure. Roy J. Zuckerberg, Chairman, Board of Trustees Michael J. Dowling, President & CEO North Shore Long Island Jewish Health System

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: LINK TO MURDER VICTIM

title: Germany Sends the Americans Home
description: ULSAN, South Korea, June 21  When the whistle blew, there was more relief and exhaustion than celebration in the reaction of the German players. They raised their tired hands in triumph, but four of them fell to the ground, spent. Even Oliver Kahn, the goalkeeper and savior of this quarterfinal match, lay on his back, weary, knowing that his team was victorious, but not better.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a federal lawsuit alleging racial discrimination by the New York City Parks and Recreation Department misstated the position of Robert Wright, a black employee named in the suit as a victim of discrimination. He is the parks and recreation manager responsible for District 11 in Harlem, which includes parks, playgrounds and a recreation center -- not just the manager of a recreation center.

title: Ad Awards Given at Cannes Festival
description: Campaigns for Club 18-30, a travel package company, and for a body-piercing studio in Oslo won Grand Prix awards in the outdoor and press category at the 49th International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France.

title: He Steps In When the Rich Get Into a Squabble
description: THE air always seems fresher and cleaner inside a rich man's limousine, as if all the unpleasantness of life has been filtered out, and so it is at the Manhattan law offices of Schulte Roth & Zabel. The wide open space, when you get off the elevator on the 24th floor, is entirely Schulte Roth & Zabel space, the reception area pale gray, suffused with natural light. There are those who believe that in the final moments of life you see a similarly luminous light; but if you are rich, really rich, George Soros- or Claus von Bulow-rich, before that moment, you may have checked in with the lawyer William D. Zabel.

title: Scientists Make 2 Stem Cell Advances
description: Two significant advances in cell therapy, the notion of treating diseases with human cells instead of drugs, have been made by scientists at the National Institutes of Health and the University of Minnesota.

title: Ad Awards Given At Cannes Festival
description: Campaigns for Club 18-30, a travel package company, and for a body-piercing studio in Oslo won Grand Prix awards in the outdoor and press category at the 49th International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France.

title: Equity for Gay Victims of Sept. 11
description: One of the moving outgrowths of Sept. 11 is a wide appreciation for the common humanity linking its victims. In that spirit, New York State's elected leaders have been working to make it possible for gay partners of those lost in the attacks to collect awards from the federal fund set up to compensate bereaved families.

title: Curiouser And Curiouser
description: In ''A Cabinet of Curiosities'' at the Public Library, unusual objects like a feng shui compass, above, inspire wonder.

title: Rangers Opt to Drop Berard
description: Bryan Berard's comeback with the Rangers from an injury that nearly cost him his right eye has apparently ended after one season.

title: Supreme Court Finds Law On Educational Privacy Isn't Meant for Individuals
description: The federal law that requires schools and colleges to protect the privacy of students' educational records does not establish a personal right to privacy that can be enforced in court, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UEHLINGER, BERENICE
description: UEHLINGER-Berenice. Died June 13, 2002. Services July 13, 2002 at 11 A.M. in The Greenfield Hill Congregational Church, Fairfield, CT.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Bolster Education, Panel Says
description: The state must spend $700 million more a year to improve its public schools, a special state commission concluded. The money would be used to raise teachers' salaries, and to expand early childhood education programs, among other things. The state now spends $1.7 billion a year on education, but its formula for distributing aid is the subject of a legal challenge.

title: With Little Guidance, States Face Hard Debate on Who Is Retarded
description: The Supreme Court ruling yesterday that executing mentally retarded people is unconstitutional offered the states almost no guidance on who must be considered retarded and who gets to decide.

title: N.H.L. Arenas to Add Netting To Protect the Fans From Pucks
description: National Hockey League fans next season will be protected from pucks by netting, similar to baseball backstops, that will shield the seats behind the goals and in the corners of the rinks. The new policy, described as a mandate from Commissioner Gary Bettman, was presented to the league's board of governors today and comes three months after the death of a 13-year-old girl, Brittanie Cecil, who was hit by a puck during an N.H.L. game in Columbus, Ohio.

title: A Hustler's Heart Belongs to Mama
description: Although the title may suggest a malicious parody of Frank Capra's populist classics ''Mr. Deeds Goes to Town'' and ''Mr. Smith Goes to Washington,'' Ian McCrudden's ''Mr. Smith Gets a Hustler'' is a straightforward and straight-faced exercise in canned theater that owes much less to 1930's comedy than to Off Broadway drama of the 1970's.

title: Brazil Comes From Behind to Beat England
description: SHIZUOKA, Japan, June 21  Brazil came from behind to beat England 2-1 in a hotly contested World Cup game that revolved around the erratic fortunes of a mop-haired midfielder, Ronaldinho.

title: Investigators In Congress Want Inquiry Of Themselves
description: The leaders of a joint Congressional inquiry into the Sept. 11 attacks asked the Justice Department today to investigate their panel, after Vice President Dick Cheney complained that sensitive information had been improperly disclosed.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: DVD Renter Speeds Delivery
description: Netflix, an online digital videodisc rental company, said that it had 10 new distribution centers operating across the country. The company, which raised $94 million last month in an initial public offering, said that because of the geographical placement of the shipping centers, half of the company's 600,000 subscribers will receive DVD deliveries overnight, while the other half will receive shipments in two days. Previously, customers waited three to four days. ''In the San Francisco Bay area, where we've had overnight delivery for the past two years, 3 percent of all households subscribe to Netflix,'' Reed Hastings, the chief executive, said. ''By delivering that to a broader section of the population,'' he said, the company will be able to increase its business. Netflix previously had one distribution center, in San Jose, Calif. The new sites are in Atlanta, Boston, Denver, Detroit, Houston, Los Angeles, Minneapolis, New York, Seattle and Washington.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Sells 2 Supercomputers
description: I.B.M. sold both its largest unclassified supercomputer and a second big system to the United States military, keeping atop the latest ranking of makers of the most powerful computers. An I.B.M. system capable of six trillion calculations a second has been installed in Mississippi for ''the whole spectrum of scientific research'' at the Department of Defense, said Cray Henry, head of the Pentagon's computer modernization program. The contract for both new systems is valued at more than $30 million, an I.B.M. spokesman, John Buscemi, said. The company's other sale to the military was for a slightly less powerful supercomputer being set up at the Army Research Laboratory in Maryland. I.B.M., which is based in Armonk, N.Y., has built 24 of the 50 most powerful machines, according to a semiannual ranking issued yesterday by the University of Tennessee, the University of Mannheim in Germany and the United States National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center. That excludes the latest I.B.M. announcements.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Development Official Resigns
description: Terry C. Lane said yesterday that he had resigned as chief executive of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, a $250 million economic development program for Harlem and Washington Heights. Mr. Lane, a former investment banker, said he was leaving the program after three years to pursue what he described as a private business opportunity. Johnnie L. Cochran Jr., the lawyer and chairman of the organization, said the board would conduct a nationwide search for a successor. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Residential Real Estate; Condo Complex to Rise In TriBeCa by Late '03
description: Work is to begin next month on condominiums at Hubert and Collister Streets in TriBeCa, a onetime manufacturing neighborhood that in recent years has seen scores of buildings converted to expensive apartments but where few have been built from the ground up.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALFANDRE, DR. JULIAN E.
description: ALFANDRE-Dr. Julian E. June 21, 1940-September 7, 1997. Every day missed. Yet, your birthday and Father's Day especially remind us of the magnitude of loss. Your unerring kindness, character, strength and integrity animate and advise our lives. Precious memories are a quotidian treasure-you are never forgotten. Rachel, Jimmy David and Natalie

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit To Sell Loan Unit
description: Intuit, the maker of tax-preparation software, said that it would sell its mortgage-lending business and raised its forecast for sales and profit for fiscal 2003. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. The unit, Quicken Loans, is being sold to a group of investors led by Dan Gilbert, the chairman of Quicken Loans and the founder of the Rock Financial Corporation, which Intuit acquired in December 1999. Intuit is selling the mortgage-lending division to focus on providing tax and accounting software to small businesses, Linda Fellows, a company spokeswoman, said. Running a mortgage business made better sense when the company was more interested in selling to consumers, she said. Intuit, based in Mountain View, Calif., increased its estimate for fiscal 2003 sales to $1.65 billion to $1.73 billion, citing the effect of the sale and demand for its other products and services. Sales in fiscal 2002, which will end next month, will be about $1.36 billion, down from its previous forecast of as much as $1.51 billion, because of the sale.

title: After 14 Years, Zinter Is Right on Time
description: The first pitch of Wednesday night's game between the Houston Astros and the Milwaukee Brewers was 12 minutes away, but Alan Zinter was still talking excitedly. Too giddy, too polite and too happy to know any better or act any differently, Zinter gave sweet, honest answers about spending 14 draining years in the minor leagues and the last few precious days in the majors.

title: John Graham
description: Richard York

title: So Much More Than Just a Bodily Fluid
description: In the same way that people lined up to donate blood after the Sept. 11 attacks, Americans felt compelled to send blood to Britain during the London blitz of World War II. The man responsible for organizing the American Red Cross's Plasma for Britain campaign was Dr. Charles Drew, an African-American physician.

title: A Princess Sings Inside a Fairy Tale
description: Radio City Music Hall was awash in moonbeams and fairy dust on Wednesday evening as Bernadette Peters meandered through the Rodgers and Hammerstein songbook with an orchestra led by Jonathan Tunick. As she did, the thought occurred that there is something almost too perfect in the notion of Ms. Peters, the peaches-and-cream embodiment of an ageless storybook princess, singing romantic show tunes by the kings of Broadway songwriting in the 1940's and 50's.

title: Migrant-Camp Operators Face Forced Labor Charges
description: Six people who run migrant labor camps east of Buffalo were indicted this week on the unusual federal charge of forced labor, accused of virtually enslaving 40 Mexican workers and threatening them with physical harm if they tried to escape.

title: Flake Will Head Wilberforce U.
description: He has been a congressman, a minister, the founder of a school. Now the Rev. Floyd H. Flake is taking on another job: president of Wilberforce University in Wilberforce, Ohio, the oldest historically black university in the United States -- and his alma mater.

title: James Daugherty -- 'Late Abstractions'
description: Spanierman Gallery

title: Reform Drug Laws: A Rockefeller's Plea
description: To the Editor:

title: Americans Have Joined the World
description: ULSAN, South Korea

title: A Fire Stoking Realism
description: THE splendid Thomas Eakins retrospective, newly arrived at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, begins, as you would expect, with rowers, sailors and baseball players -- sporting pictures, American subjects, gravely imagined. If the country is to produce great painters, Eakins said, its young artists will have to stay put ''to peer deeper into the heart of American life.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about efforts by Martha Stewart to resolve questions about her sale of shares of ImClone Systems last December misstated the timing of the addition of a lawyer, James F. Fitzpatrick, to her team. He was brought in by Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz earlier this month to assist with a Congressional inquiry. He was not hired on Tuesday.

title: Colombia's Next Leader Seeks Drug-War Aid
description: lvaro Uribe Vlez, Colombia's president-elect, met with President Bush today and pledged to increase his country's commitment in the fight against drugs and terrorism, officials said.

title: The Fine Points of a Murder
description: With his "Gosford Park" due on Tuesday on VHS and DVD from Universal, Robert Altman sounded more ready than eager. "A lot more people are going to see this work on video and DVD than in theaters, so I can't ignore it," he said this week. "So the whole idea is to make it fit your film better."

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Party Suspends Ex-Foreign Minister
description: A former foreign minister was suspended from the governing Liberal Democratic Party over accusations that she misused public funds intended for staff salaries. Senior members of the party have accused Makiko Tanaka of failing to cooperate with an investigation. She has denied any wrongdoing. Ms. Tanaka, who became Japan's first woman to serve as foreign minister last year, was dismissed this year after falling out with Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi over what she said were the government's stalled reforms. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Elderly Woman Slain In Home
description: A 95-year-old woman was found bound and strangled in the bedroom closet of the Harlem brownstone where she had lived for 60 years, the police said yesterday. The body of the woman, Georgiana Werner, was found about 9 p.m. on Wednesday. Investigators said she had probably been dead for several days. Detectives were unsure whether Ms. Werner had been killed during a home-invasion robbery or had been targeted for another reason. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said that there were some leads and that the police were optimistic about solving the case.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Bishop Acts Against 2 Priests
description: In one of the first cases since the establishment of nationwide policies on priestly abuse, the leader of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Paterson has taken the first steps toward disciplining two priests. The bishop, Frank J. Rodimer, said that he had placed the Rev. William Cramer, 48, on leave. Father Cramer pleaded guilty in 1988 to groping two Sussex County boys. The bishop has also summoned the Rev. James T. Hanley, 64, accused of molesting at least six children during various diocesan assignments in the 1970's and 1980's, for a meeting. Father Cramer has worked as a chaplain at St. Joseph Regional Medical Center for the last nine years. Father Hanley, retired after being removed as a priest in 1987, has never formally faced criminal charges. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Quietly, Llamosa Helps U.S. Team
description: When Carlos Llamosa moved from Colombia to Queens in 1991, he had no intention of continuing his professional soccer career. There was no top-flight professional league in the United States. His plan was to join his three brothers and four sisters and start a new life.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Golden Share Cases Examined
description: The European Commission said it was examining 10 cases in which governments of member states have barred foreign domination of their countries' companies through mechanisms including golden share arrangements. Golden shares give governments majority voting rights over formerly state-owned companies after privatization, even when the governments are minority shareholders. Restrictions on the voting rights of private investors in Volkswagen of Germany and the Dutch government's role on the board of the Dutch telecommunications group KPN are among the 10 cases, a spokesman, Jonathan Todd, said. He said the cases show there was a potential violation of laws intended to ensure the free movement of capital in the union. Golden shares were struck down by the European Court of First Instance in Luxembourg two weeks ago.

title: The Court Gets It Right
description: By declaring yesterday that the Constitution's ban on ''cruel and unusual punishment'' bars the execution of mentally retarded people, the Supreme Court injected a limited but wholly welcome measure of human decency into the nation's use of the death penalty.

title: A Mechanic With Custody Grants a Weekend Visit
description: WHILE many New Yorkers spend their weekends in the Hamptons, I prefer Domenick's European Garage in White Plains. About once a month, I take the train to this nondescript two-story brick building to visit one of my cars.

description: Gauguin's Wild Alter Ego

title: Escaping Deep-Space Exile and Making Friends in Hawaii
description: For all the impressive innovations in the field of 3D computer-generated animation, the old-fashioned flat kind, with its warm colors and artful perspectives, has not lost its appeal. ''Lilo and Stitch,'' the new Disney cartoon adventure that was written and directed by Chris Sanders and Dean Deblois, is hardly a work of state-of-the-art virtuosity, but rather an example of quiet, confident craftsmanship that tells a sweet, charming tale of intergalactic friendship.

description: Tom Ridge, the White House domestic security director, was sharply questioned today by members of Congress who were skeptical about a core function of the proposed Department of Homeland Security: its ability to receive accurate intelligence about terrorist threats.

title: A Family Grows Bad Seeds By the Peck
description: You don't have to look further than the title of Hl ne Angel's film ''Skin of Man, Heart of Beast'' to discern its brutal perspective on the human condition. In ways large and small, the film, set in the rugged countryside of southern France, lays out an unremittingly bestial view of human life. As its characters rampage around the landscape, the movie not so subtly compares them to roaring beasts in a prehistoric environment. The geography is craggy and arid. And in a scene late in the film in which the camera gazes from below at characters walking across a hilltop, their gangling silhouettes suggest the skeletons of dinosaurs. One after another, they let out feral screams.

title: Bernie Zilbergeld, 62, Dies; Expert on Male Sexuality
description: Dr. Bernie Zilbergeld, a psychologist whose widely read books helped debunk popular assumptions about male sexuality, died on June 12 at his home in Oakland, Calif. He was 62.

title: Kidd Chooses to Wait on His Future
description: Jason Kidd is approaching his one-year anniversary of T-Day.

title: European Leaders Struggle With Distractions at Summit
description: SEVILLE, Spain, June 21  In a summit meeting punctuated by bomb blasts and marked by a distracting obsession with soccer's World Cup, European leaders today struggled with questions of illegal immigration, European enlargement and internal reform.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Burst.com Sues Microsoft
description: Burst.com, a provider of software for broadcasting audio and video over the Internet, has sued the Microsoft Corporation, accusing it of patent infringement and antitrust violations. Burst.com contended in the lawsuit, which was filed Tuesday in United States District Court for the Northern District of California, that Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., used Burst's patented video-on-demand technology and trade secrets in Microsoft's new Corona video product. Burst.com, which is based in Santa Rosa, Calif., said in a statement that Microsoft met with it over a two-year period and negotiated unsuccessfully for the rights to use Burst's technology. Officials for Microsoft and Burst.com could not be reached.

title: World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Rebel Leader Reported Dead
description: A leader of the Islamic guerrilla group Abu Sayyaf was reported killed this morning during a firefight with soldiers in the southern Philippines. Authorities said they were still looking for the body of Abu Sabaya, one of the five Abu Sayyaf leaders on the most-wanted list released by the State Department, which offered a $5 million reward for their arrest. The United States has been assisting the Philippine military in its pursuit of the guerrilla group, which was responsible for the kidnapping of American missionaries Martin and Gracia Burnham. Mr. Burnham was killed during a rescue effort early this month. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

description: HERBSTEIN-Sebastian. On June 20, 2002, following a brief illness. Beloved son of Judith and Diego. Cherished stepson of Roberta. Dear brother of Julian and Gabriela. Services Sunday, 12:45PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS NAMES CHIEF TO REPLACE FOUNDER
description: ICN Pharmaceuticals named Robert W. O'Leary chairman and chief executive yesterday, replacing Milan Panic, and said it would review a plan to spin off two businesses. Mr. Panic, the company's founder, said last week that he would retire after years of battling shareholders and regulators at the company, which makes a hepatitis drug called ribavirin. Investors have said the prospects for ICN, and particularly for ribavirin, have been overshadowed by concerns about management. Last month, Mr. Panic lost a proxy fight with dissident shareholders over three seats on the company's board. Mr. O'Leary is chief executive of the Sagamore Group, a consulting firm, and is one of the three new directors backed by the dissidents.

title: PALESTINIANS KILL 5 ISRAELI SETTLERS IN RAID ON A HOME
description: Palestinian gunmen killed at least five Israeli settlers in a raid Thursday night, a mother and three children among them, even as Israeli soldiers spread throughout the West Bank, enforcing a new policy to take back Palestinian land in reprisal for suicide bombings.

title: A Strange Case of Arson
description: Fire is a mysterious force, both protector and destroyer. Even when it's burning snugly in the hearth, we can sense its power, and when it gets out of control, all our instincts tell us to run the other way. Firefighters run toward the heat, and that is the source of their mystique, the aura of heroism that hangs over even the sleepiest of firehouses. In pyromaniacs, all these primal emotions get twisted up. But the scenario authorities are building around the Colorado forest fires sounds even more perverse. A longtime Forest Service employee, Terry Lynn Barton, has been charged with deliberately setting the biggest fire in the state's history.

title: Atlas Air to Talk to Union
description: Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings and its pilots' union will resume contract talks on Monday to try to avoid a strike that could come as early as June 28.

description: A panel of specialists advising the government on smallpox unanimously rejected a proposal to offer vaccines to every American. Instead, the panel recommended immunizing only about 15,000 health care and law enforcement workers.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the American composer Ralph Shapey on Saturday misidentified a teacher with whom one of his own teachers -- Stefan Wolpe -- studied. Mr. Wolpe's teacher was Anton Webern, not Arnold Schoenberg. (Mr. Webern, in turn, studied with Mr. Schoenberg.)
