description: A court-appointed lawyer for an American-born detainee today challenged the government's claim that it could hold him without giving him access to a lawyer or charging him with anything.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: State Bank Posts Profit Rise
description: India's largest commercial bank, the State Bank of India, said it posted an 80 percent increase in net profit in the fourth quarter. The government-owned bank said its profit for the year rose 52 percent, to $506 million. The bank controls nearly one-fourth of the Indian banking business, and its robust profit reflects falling interest rates in the country. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKIRBALL, KENIS, AUDREY
description: SKIRBALL - KENIS - Audrey. The President, Chancellor Emeritus, Boards of Governors and Overseers, faculty, administration and students of Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion record with profound saddness the death of Audrey Skirball-Kenis, Vice Chair of the Board of Governors and longtime generous benefactor of the College-Institute. A patron of art and culture, Audrey's vision found expression in her lifelong committment to the mission of Hebrew Union College. She recognized that a museum is a singular instrumentality in the life and survival of a people and was the driving force behind the creation of the HUC Skirball Cultural Center. Audrey had a deep appreciation of archaeology, the hand-maiden of history, which served to strengthen her love of the people and land of Israel. Her own devotion to Judaism was mirrored in her commitment to perpetuate its teachings. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her beloved husband, Charles, and family whose loss we share. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, Pres. Rabbi Alfred Gottschalk, Chancellor Emeritus Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors

title: A Boy's Innocent Eyes Take In Stinging Surroundings
description: ZigZag is the nickname of the mildly autistic 15-year-old boy (Sam Jones III) who is the hero of David S. Goyer's new film. The young man's life is a study in misery and deprivation. Brutally abused by his alcoholic father (Wesley Snipes), ZigZag finds solace in the unusual powers of his mind and in the company of Singer (John Leguizamo), a volunteer from the Big Brothers program.

title: Dribbling Like a Woman to Become a Better Man
description: ''Juwanna Mann'' is a sloppy, amusing comedy that proceeds from a stunningly unoriginal premise. Jamal Jefferies (Miguel A. Nuez Jr.) is a selfish, arrogant professional basketball player -- with a rubber stamp for signing autographs and a picture of himself on his vanity license plates -- who is suspended from the league after a sort-of-shocking episode of public exhibitionism. (His display makes you wonder just what it would take, in the real world, to be tossed out of professional sports, but as we shall see, plausibility is not one of this movie's main concerns.)

title: European Summit Talks Open Today; Focus Is Immigration Control
description: The European Union is at an important crossroads, 15 countries looking to enlarge to 25 while transforming its own ponderous procedures, trying to become both efficient and democratic. But the Union's summit meeting here Friday and Saturday will barely make a dent in the organizational problems.

description: THE $1 billion deal recently struck between the Walt Disney Company and OMD USA, the media arm of the Omnicom Group, has become a subject of much controversy in the clubby world of media advertising.

description: The Mexico City Journal article on Tuesday, about the blow to national pride when Mexico's soccer team lost to the United States in the World Cup, misstated the year the country gained its independence from Spain, an event commemorated by the Angel of Independence statue, where Mexicans often gather to celebrate victories. It was 1821, not 1812.

title: The Fine Points Of a Murder
description: With his ''Gosford Park'' due on Tuesday on VHS and DVD from Universal, Robert Altman sounded more ready than eager. ''A lot more people are going to see this work on video and DVD than in theaters, so I can't ignore it,'' he said this week. ''So the whole idea is to make it fit your film better.''

title: Halting Crime In Advance Has Its Perils
description: IT'S the year 2054. ''You'd think we'd have found a cure for the common cold by now,'' sniffs Burgess (Max von Sydow). He's the director of the Pre-Crime law enforcement unit that causes so much trouble in Steven Spielberg's atmospheric new thriller, ''Minority Report,'' a muscular and dense exercise of skill and verve. He's also the boss and mentor of the Pre-Crime chief, John Anderton (Tom Cruise).

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about plans by the jury foreman in the Arthur Andersen trial to write a book about the case -- and about the doubtful sales history of such books -- misstated the profession of an earlier author-juror, Hazel Thornton, who wrote about the first murder trial of Erik and Lyle Menendez, which ended in 1994. Ms. Thornton is an engineer, not a psychologist.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS LOWERS PROFIT FORECAST FOR 2ND QUARTER
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday that second-quarter profit might fall more than analysts expected on costs to reduce bloated customer inventories first disclosed in April. The company, the fifth-biggest drug maker, is cutting shipments to overstocked wholesalers, a process the company has said will trim profit by about 40 cents a share over the next year. Inventory costs will reduce second-quarter earnings by as much as 17 cents, the company said yesterday, more than the 14-cent reduction some analysts had estimated. Bristol-Myers still expects full-year profit, excluding inventory-related expenses, of $1.69 to $1.81 a share. Its shares fell 37 cents, to $25.90.

He attended Taft School, Yale University and was president of Bulwark Corp. and chairman of the Dorr Foundation. Services will be held at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY, Sunday, June 23 at 2 P.M.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Gas Company Stake
description: The government plans to sell about half of Gaz de France in the next few months, a union official said. The company, valued at about 7.5 billion euros ($7.18 billion), is one of Europe's five largest gas suppliers. A sale would help it form partnerships and expand abroad, where it has been losing market share. France's new government is expected to emphasize privatization. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

description: GENEVA, June 21  The World Health Organization declared today that Europe is free of polio, which once claimed hundreds of thousands of children yearly as victims.

title: Prosecutors Clear Clintons In Clemency of 4 Hasidic Men
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that no criminal wrongdoing was committed when President Bill Clinton commuted the sentences of four swindlers from a Hasidic enclave in New York State that voted overwhelmingly for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

description: Adelphia Communications released a letter yesterday that it sent last week to 3,500 agencies that grant cable franchises in which it assures them that it is working to provide good customer service, diverse programming and new services.

description: In the final weeks of preparation before the World Cup, many of the players on Senegal's unheralded squad shared one simple hope -- to do well in the opening match against the reigning champions, France, and earn tryouts with rich soccer clubs in countries like Germany, Britain and Italy.

description: Air traffic controllers in Baltimore first spotted the unidentified light aircraft heading toward Washington just before 8 p.m. Wednesday. The Air Force scrambled two F-16 fighters after the plane entered restricted airspace over the capital a few minutes later.

title: Within a Florida Civics Lesson, Rich Stories
description: Gazing across an immaculate Florida golf course that used to be a swamp, Murray Silver (Alan King), a multimillionaire developer, conjures the Florida dream of sunshine, orange groves and balmy breezes wafting through palm trees. Wearing the sly, imperious grin of a successful snake-oil peddler and waving his arms like a maestro, he proudly announces to his golfing partners, ''We created this nature on a leash.''

description: WHO -- Richard W. Gold, an interior designer (standing), and Brian Segel, a community development funder.

title: 36 Hours | Park City, Utah
description: BACK in the late 1800's, the predominantly Mormon community of Salt Lake City largely turned a blind eye to the decadent goings-on in neighboring Park City, if only because that mountain town's hard-drinking, brothel-hopping miners produced such a vast quantity of silver. (Then, as now, a rising tide lifted all boats.) Today, Park City's reputation is more genteel, with affluent skiers and house-hunting celebrities crowding the town's restaurants and bars, but it remains a world apart from most of Utah, which is staunchly conservative and comparatively low key. Skiing put Park City on the map a generation ago, and the Winter Olympics in February widened its fame. But this city of 7,000 people remains mostly overlooked by tourists in the off-season, when its few streets are quiet and the night air is crisp. Winters here at 7,000 feet are fine, to be sure. But the summers are sublime. KARL CATES

description: The dollar, after rising sharply in value for years in a reflection of American economic might, is weakening markedly, mirroring concern about the fragility of the economic recovery and the nation's financial condition.

title: PEPSI BOTTLING SAYS IT WILL STOP DISTRIBUTING 7UP
description: Pepsi Bottling Group said yesterday that it would stop distributing 7Up at the end of the year. Instead, Pepsi Bottling will expand its distribution of Sierra Mist to all of its United States markets starting next year. Sierra Mist and Diet Sierra Mist are made by the beverage unit of PepsiCo. 7Up is owned by Cadbury Schweppes, through its Dr Pepper/Seven Up subsidiary. Pepsi Bottling, based in Somers, N.Y., sells Sierra Mist in about 70 percent of its United States territories. In contrast, 7Up represents about 2 percent of the company's volume in the United States. Pepsi Bottling said it did not expect the change to have any effect on the company's financial performance.

title: Britain to Pull Out 1,400 Troops From Afghanistan Next Month
description: Britain will begin withdrawing next month some 1,400 marines who have been involved in the hunt for remaining forces belonging to Al Qaeda and the Taliban in Afghanistan, British officials announced today here and in London.

title: Perot Will Deliver Energy Papers
description: Perot Systems, an information technology company, said today that it would deliver five boxes of documents to California's attorney general and a California state senator as part of an investigation into whether the company improperly coached energy traders on how to manipulate power prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THROOP, WILLIAM M. JR. (''PETE'')
description: THROOP-William M. Jr. (''Pete''). The partners, associates and staff of Davidson, Dawson & Clark, LLP mourn the death of our distinguished and much beloved former Sr Partner on June 20, 2002. He practiced law with this firm for over 50 years and for almost half of that time was our leader in every respect. He was a brilliant and sensitive lawyer and a wise counsellor to his and our many individual and institutional clients. We will miss his sage and generous leadership and extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Ann and their family.

description: To the Editor:

title: Retreat on Fighting Global AIDS
description: The fact that 800,000 babies worldwide were born with the AIDS virus last year is not only one of the most heartbreaking aspects of the global epidemic, it is one of the most avoidable. Mothers with AIDS can keep the disease away from their unborn children with a simple, cheap and easily administered routine of drugs. Yet most poor countries do not get the drugs to the women.

title: Car Bomb Kills a British Banker in Saudi Arabia
description: A British banker was killed today when a bomb shattered the sport utility vehicle he was driving through the quiet residential neighborhood where he lived in Riyadh, the capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, J. CARTER
description: BROWN-J. Carter. For 25 years, from 1977 to 2002, J. Carter Brown served as a trustee of Storm King Art Center, bringing his wise counsel and wide experience in the museum world and contributing greatly to recognition of Storm King as the preeminent outdoor sculpture park in the United States. His ever-buoyant spirit, his wit and wisdom will be greatly missed at future board meetings and his fellow trustees send warm condolences to Carter's family, with whom they share a heavy loss. H. Peter Stern Chairman and President Storm King Art Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIMEK, DR. JEAN
description: SCHIMEK-Dr. Jean. The Institute for Psychoanalytic Training & Research (IPTAR) mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Dr. Jean Schimek. A valued member of our Faculty and Board of Administrators, he served as Chair of Curriculum. He had also been a Professor at Downstate Medical College, Yale University and New York University. He was the ultimate scholar, reseacher, teacher and psychoanalyst. He will be remembered for the many colleagues and students he mentored and inspired as well as for his enduring contributions to the fields of psychology and psychoanalysis. Our most heartfelt condolences to his wife Debra, his sons David and Paul and his grandchildren.

title: Minor Leagues Have Major Action
description: Minor league all-star games are supposed to be exhibitions that are fun. That doesn't mean they have to lack excitement.

title: Maia Wojciechowska, 74, Author of Children's Books
description: Maia Wojciechowska, an award-winning author of children's books, died on June 13 in Long Branch, N.J. She was 74.

title: Terror Inquiry Shines Light on Senator Seeking Stage
description: Senator Bob Graham is perhaps best known nationally for a succession of missed opportunities. Three times Mr. Graham, a Florida Democrat, was vetted for the vice presidency and passed over by presidential candidates.

title: Lawmakers' Reviews Mixed On Bush Plan for Amtrak
description: Elected officials gave mixed reviews today to the Bush administration's proposal for overhauling Amtrak by shifting financing for its operating losses from the federal government to the states.

title: Moviegoers Are Flocking To Forget Their Troubles
description: At a time when viewership and attendance are either flat or shrinking in virtually every form of pop-culture entertainment, Hollywood is enjoying one of the biggest bursts of popularity and profitability in its history.

title: Jersey Chic
description: The town of Red Bank, N.J., near the northern Jersey Shore, has become a popular place to shop for antiques, browse in boutiques and enjoy dining out. The contemporary 58-room Oyster Point Hotel, a block from the antiques district, with a small fitness center and a restaurant overlooking the Navesink River, has summer rates through Aug. 31 that include a Continental breakfast served in the room, ranging from $141 a night, double, up to $315 for a suite. Information: (732) 530-8200 or www.mollypitcher-oysterpoint.com .

title: A Voice of the Game Who Was Like Family
description: Jack Buck, who died Tuesday, was part of a fraternity of memorable baseball voices who began their major league careers on radio in the 1940's or 50's, adapted to television and were relevant, hard-working and beloved decades later.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Prison Terms In Yachtsman's Death
description: Six men accused of killing the world champion yachtsman Sir Peter Blake during a robbery attempt in December have been convicted and sentenced to up to 36 years in prison. Sir Peter and his crew, who won the America's Cup for New Zealand in 1995 and 2000, were on a round-the-world expedition to promote environmental awareness when their vessel was boarded at the mouth of the Amazon River by masked bandits. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: East Side School Board Makes Last Stand in Battle Over Superintendent
description: In the waning days of the decentralized school system, the community school board for the Lower East Side has set up a confrontation with Chancellor Harold O. Levy over who should become its superintendent.

title: Torricelli Heats Up Campaign With Accusations of Gouging
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli plans to escalate his campaign against his Republican rival, Douglas Forrester, sharply this weekend with a radio advertisement accusing Mr. Forrester of gouging consumers with his drug benefits company and of ''pocketing millions'' in rebates from drug companies.

title: Why Not Be Bold? Bush Has Reasons
description: On the foreign policy issues it regards as central from Afghanistan to Iraq, from the steel tariffs it imposed to the international treaties it abandoned -- the Bush administration has not shrunk from acting or taking strong stands, decisively and often alone.

title: Another American Team's Trip
description: ULSAN, South Korea, June 21 -- The players got to fly together, 45 minutes. Most of the writers took a bus, six hours. But we wouldn't trade it for anything. We even got to watch most of the Brazil-England game, flickering on a large screen at the front of the bus. All football, all the time. That's us.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Argos, a unit of Great Universal Stores, named Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper, London, to handle its creative account, which had been at the London office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group. Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper is part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas. Billings were estimated at $29.5 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Auto Executive Dismissed
description: Brilliance China Automotive Holdings Ltd. fired its chairman, Yang Rong, less than a week after he denied speculation that he was under investigation by the Chinese government. Mr. Yang, who was instrumental in the company's 1992 New York share sale, the first by a mainland Chinese company, will be replaced as chairman by the vice chairman, Wu Xiaoan, Brilliance said. Su Qiang, who has worked with Mr. Yang for a decade, was named president and chief executive, positions that Mr. Yang also held.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: PROSECUTION WRAPS UP PEARL CASE The prosecution completed its case against four men accused in the kidnapping and killing of the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl. The defendants now have the option of responding individually to the accusations made against them, after which defense lawyers are expected to present witnesses. Lawyers said it could be many weeks before a verdict. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France Tlcom Seeks Loan For Affiliate
description: One of Europe's largest phone companies, France Tlcom, said it had convinced a syndicate of 17 banks to refinance 4.7 billion euros ($4.5 billion) in loans to its German affiliate, MobilCom. Shares in MobilCom rose 7 percent yesterday, while shares in France Tlcom fell 15 percent, to a record of 12.76 euros. Analysts feared that France Tlcom's credit rating could be hurt by the deal, which had not been signed. Under the terms of the arrangement, the French company would guarantee 90 percent of MobilCom's loans, dependent partly upon the resignation of its chief, Gerard Schmid. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Drug Law Foes Make Their Case in Spanish Ads, and Pataki Aides Raise Objections
description: The city's largest Spanish-language television station pulled a commercial yesterday that had featured family members of imprisoned drug offenders and asked the governor for ''real reform'' on the Rockefeller drug laws. The ads were taken off the air at the request of Gov. George E. Pataki's senior aides, who called them inaccurate.

title: AMERISOURCEBERGEN IS BUYING AUTOMED TECHNOLOGIES
description: The AmerisourceBergen Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy AutoMed Technologies, a maker of automated pharmacy dispensing equipment, for about $120 million in cash. AmerisourceBergen, a pharmaceutical services company based in Chesterbrook, Pa., said the agreement included incentive payments based on AutoMed's achieving earnings goals over the next two and a half years. AutoMed, privately held and based in Chicago, expects revenue of more than $60 million in 2002. AmerisourceBergen reported sales of $22 billion for its six months ended March 31.

title: Charles Matton -- 'Within These Walls'
description: Forum Gallery

title: Glaxo Freezes Prices Of AIDS Drugs in U.S.
description: Acknowledging the budget constraints of many state programs intended to help people with little or no health insurance afford AIDS drugs, GlaxoSmithKline said yesterday that it was freezing the American prices of its six AIDS drugs through January 2004. The freeze includes its most widely prescribed AIDS medicine, Combivir.

title: Israel and Palestine, Side by Side?
description: To the Editor:

title: Six Icons Of Road And Track
description: These are the six cars in the Museum of Modern Art's collection, in order of their acquisition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEYLAND, TURKEN, CERI ANN
description: LEYLAND - TURKEN - Ceri Ann. Your fighting spirit inspires us all. Your kindness blessed us. We will miss you. Charles and Anne K. Johnson

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gunmen Shoot At Moscow Official
description: A Moscow deputy mayor escaped injury in what appeared to be an assassination attempt during the morning rush hour. Gunmen opened fire after cutting off Iosif Ordzhonikidze's car on a highway leading into Moscow, according to police and news reports. A bodyguard who returned fire and a passenger in a passing minivan were wounded. Mr. Ordzhonikidze, who oversees casinos and hotels in Moscow, was gravely wounded in a similar attack in December 2000. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELOUDIOS, KATHERINE
description: VELOUDIOS-Katherine. On June 18, 2002 of Palm Beach Gardens, FL formerly of Garden City, NY. Beloved wife of John. Loving mother of Stacy, Angela, Alice and Vickie. Dear sister of William Zolides and Kiki Athineos. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City Sunday and Monday 79PM. Religious service at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. Paul, Hempstead Tuesday 9:30 AM. Interment Flushing Cemetery. In lieu of flowers dontions can be made in Katherine's name to either The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, Inc., One Penn Plaza, Suite 1610, New York, New York 10119, or Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407.

title: Ruling Shakes Investors in Indonesia
description: The decision by an Indonesian court to declare the local subsidiary of a large Canadian life insurance company bankrupt, over the company's objections and despite the fact that it made money last year, has severely shaken the confidence of foreign investors here, who have grumbled for years about corruption in the judiciary.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: High Spirits And Beehives

title: With No New Taxes or Emergency Cash, Albany Won't Play Hero for City
description: When local governments complain of financial burdens too heavy to bear, Albany often comes to the rescue, plugging budget holes with millions of dollars in state money. But for New York City, the pumping heart of the state's economy, that has not held true.

title: Charitable Contributions in 2001 Reached $212 Billion
description: The bleak economy and the shock of terrorism failed to appreciably depress charitable giving last year, the latest annual survey by a major fund-raising group shows.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Prosecution Wraps Up Pearl Case
description: The prosecution completed its case against four men accused in the kidnapping and killing of the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl. The defendants now have the option of responding individually to the accusations made against them, after which defense lawyers are expected to present witnesses. Lawyers said it could be many weeks before a verdict. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Summer Intern Is Raped
description: A 21-year-old woman who was just beginning a summer internship at a publishing company was raped and robbed yesterday after returning home from dinner with friends, the police said. A man with a knife confronted the young woman shortly before 1 a.m. as she walked from the Fulton Street subway station to her Lower Manhattan apartment, the police said. The man forced her to a building near Water Street, where he raped her and stole about $80, the police said. After being evaluated at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital and released, she went home to North Carolina.

title: Yanks Lose by a Field Goal and Say Goodbye to the Rockies
description: Todd Zeile's game-winning home run had just sailed over the left-field fence, and Steve Karsay tossed up both hands as he crossed the foul line. I surrender, his gesture seemed to say, and the rest of the Yankees could have done the same. They are finally free of Coors Field, and winning two of three games has never been so draining.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, DAVID
description: ROSEN-David. The Frisch School family is saddened by the passing of Mr. David Rosen, father of our board member, Joseph Rosen, father-in-law of Marilyn and grandfather of Frisch graduates Alison and David Speiser, Brian and Adam Rosen. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to them and the entire Rosen family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mr. Arthur Goldberg, Pres. Dr. Kalman Stein, Principal Elaine Weitzman, Exec. Dir

title: Credit Suisse's Insurance Unit To Get Infusion of $1.1 Billion
description: The Credit Suisse Group said today that it would infuse $1.1 billion into its Winterthur insurance arm to shore it up after investment losses undercut its ability to pay claims.

title: Colorado Fire Defendant To Stay in Halfway House
description: A federal judge ruled today that the United States Forest Service worker accused of setting Colorado's largest wildfire could spend the weeks before trial in a halfway house, rather than in jail as government prosecutors had requested.

title: 18 Months After Giuliani, Hanover Files for Divorce, Citing Adultery
description: A year and a half after former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani filed for divorce from Donna Hanover, she has filed for divorce from him, citing what her lawyer called ''Rudy's open and notorious adultery.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, JOHN HARRIS
description: NELSON-John Harris, age 63, of Manchester-by-the-Sea, MA, died June 20th, 2002. Beloved father of Andrea Abbott and Trevor Nelson. Adoring grandfather of McLeod, Conrad, Lyric, and George. A graduate of St. Mark's School, Southborough, MA, and of Harvard College. He possessed a deep passion for literature, music, philosophy, and the history of art. His was a dazzling mind and he will be forever remembered as a dear and gentle soul. A memorial service will be held at Emmanuel Chapel in Manchester-by-the-Sea, MA. Details to follow Sunday.

title: Justices Bar Death Penalty for Retarded Defendants
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  The Constitution bars the execution of mentally retarded offenders, the Supreme Court declared today in a landmark death penalty ruling based on the majority's view that a "national consensus" now rejected such executions as excessive and inappropriate.

title: Fears for Jobs Could Bring Shutdown of West Coast Ports
description: For decades, the West Coast longshoremen's union could boast that its members had some of the highest-paying blue-collar jobs in the nation. Workers who unload ships commonly earn more than $85,000 a year.

title: Castillo Keeps Hitting, Passing Hornsby's Run
description: Every time Luis Castillo comes to bat these days, Manager Jeff Torborg makes sure he is standing on the first step of the Florida Marlins' dugout. Castillo's teammate Mike Lowell may want a drink of water, but he resists being distracted.

title: Under a Clunker's Paint, A Masterpiece Emerges
description: TRAVELING through the Arizona desert on an early morning in mid-May, Peter Reed was trying to keep calm. Mr. Reed, a Museum of Modern Art curator, was on the trail of a valuable addition to the museum's collection and had followed a circuitous journey -- from word of mouth to the Internet to the Phoenix airport and now to the sleepy town of Yuma -- to see if the reports were accurate.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Off-Duty Officer In Collision
description: An off-duty police officer was arrested early yesterday on drunken driving and assault charges after he ran a red light at a Brooklyn intersection Wednesday night and struck a motorcyclist, critically injuring him, the authorities said. The officer, Victor M. Wilson, 43, was also charged with reckless endangerment in the incident, which occurred about 10:30 p.m. at 88th Street and Fort Hamilton Parkway in Bay Ridge, the authorities said. The motorcyclist, Stephanos Kiliditis, 21, was in critical condition yesterday at Lutheran Hospital with severe head trauma, the authorities said. Under a new Police Department policy, Officer Wilson, who was assigned to the 120th Precinct in Staten Island, will be dismissed. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALKINBURG, JOHN NELSON
description: FALKINBURG-John Nelson. August 4, 1916-June 20, 2002. Graduated 1945 from Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. Had 40 year career with Union Carbide Corporation, NY Headquarters. Resident of Lake Worth, FL, since retirement. Survived by his wife of 62 years, Florence Middleton Falkinburg, three daughters, four grandchildren, one great-grandchild and a sister.

title: INSIDE
description: Dollar Mired in a Slump

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: More Authority For Chief Executive
description: The Legislative Council approved a government reorganization that transfers power from civil servants to personal appointees of Tung Chee-hwa, the territory's chief executive. The pro-Beijing majority presented the plan as making government more accountable to voters by giving more authority to Mr. Tung, who was re-elected in February when no one dared to oppose him. Pro-democracy lawmakers opposed the plan as giving too much power to Mr. Tung. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Teachers' Time-Waster
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Ad Reviews Near Completion
description: The New York Knicks basketball team narrowed a review for its account to two finalists, the New York offices of Deutsch, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, and Rapp Collins Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group.

title: Intimidation of monitors / Corruption stymies crackdown : Illegal logging topples Cambodia's forests
description: PHNOM PENH  Eva Galabru had returned to her office late one night. As she got out of her car several men, at least one of them masked, pushed her to the ground. Then they kicked and beat her.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: F.B.I. To Help In Nurse Case
description: Prosecutors have asked the F.B.I. for help in preparing a profile of a hospital nurse who has been charged with the murder of 13 people. The indictment says that the victims of Lucy de Berk, 40, included four infants and nine elderly patients, among them a Chinese judge, Li Haopei, who was a member of the appeals chamber of the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague. The trial, which was to start this week, has been rescheduled for Sept. 17, court officials said, to allow time for the preparation of the profile. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: SWISSAIR IS INVESTIGATED A criminal inquiry has begun into the financial underpinnings of the collapsed Swiss national carrier, Swissair. Zurich prosecutors are looking into allegations of falsified documents and incorrect financial data after the seizure of company documents in several cities. Three former executive board members have been under scrutiny, but not named, according to prosecutors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGEL, WILLIAM J.
description: SPIEGEL-William J. Of Delray Beach, FL, died at age 59 on June 19, 2002. Mr Spiegel formerly of Old Bethpage, NY where his family lived for many years succumbed to complications following surgery for cancer. A beloved husband, father, brother and grandfather, he had a long and successful career as a CPA. Previously a partner of Speigel, Weissberg and Speller, he most recently served his accounting clients from his individual practice in Florida. Mr. Spiegel was known for his deep devotion to his family, friends and clients and for his playful wit. He is survived by his wife of 38 years, Pamela, his sister Barbara Newberg, his son, Dr. Steven M. Spiegel of NYC, his daughter, Lori H. Koplik, of RI, his mother-in-law, Cynthia Zbar and his grandchildren, Peter and Samantha Koplik. Funeral services will be held at 1 PM on Friday, June 21 at the Riverside/Schwartz Bros. Memorial Chapel, on Queens Blvd and 76th Rd, in Forest Hills.

title: He's Ambitious, Cocky and Swaggering Into Trouble
description: The writer, director and star of ''Bobby G. Can't Swim,'' John-Luke Montias, has taken on a formidable task in making the protagonist of his debut feature a street hustler whose life is a series of embarrassments.

title: Recycle, or Leave Town
description: To the Editor:

title: South Koreans' Savior Is Found in Dutchman
description: He dresses as blandly as a civil servant, his suits conservative, his shirts as gray as his hair. Then, when South Korea scores a goal, he becomes exultant, slicing the air with jubilant uppercuts, his tie flying askew, his legend growing with each victory, with each bold and unfamiliar striving at history.

title: Israel and Palestine, Side by Side?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Antismoking Program Expands
description: The state is offering nicotine patches and prescription antismoking drugs to people who call its ''Quit Line.'' The antismoking kits were initially limited to adults with chronic health problems and groups with high rates of smoking, like teenagers and Indians, but are now available to the population at large. Since its start in January, the Quit Line has received 2,700 calls.

title: From the Foothills, Zinfandel With a Zip
description: THE zinfandel vines in the Sierra foothills are some of the oldest in the state. Many of their grapes went into jug wines, but today, as zinfandel has regained popularity, many of these old zinfandel vineyards have been rediscovered.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: The Warlords Win in Kabul
description: On the final night of the loya jirga, more than 1,500 delegates gathered for the unveiling of the new cabinet. Our hearts sank when we heard President Hamid Karzai pronounce one name after another. A woman activist turned to us in disbelief: ''This is worse than our worst expectations. The warlords have been promoted and the professionals kicked out. Who calls this democracy?''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Terrorist Report Discounted
description: A recent attempt by two Middle Eastern men to buy an ambulance with cash in Lyndhurst, N.J., was apparently unrelated to terrorism, the F.B.I. said yesterday. The two men told investigators that they wanted to use the ambulance in a movie, the police said. Nonetheless, the New York City police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, said that terrorists had used emergency vehicles in the Middle East and that residents in the New York region should remain alert to the possibility that the same could be done here. Special Agent Sandra J. Carroll, a spokeswoman for the Newark office of the F.B.I., said that agents had identified the owner of the van driven by the two men. City officials said that no emergency vehicles were missing. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: Artwork by Thomas Eakins
The Who, What, and Y of Design
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Germany Sends U.S. Home
West Bank Settlements
description: Even on normal days, tension is high around the settlements, where Jewish families have built homes and are expanding rapidly on what had been Palestinian land.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Europe Declared Free Of Polio
description: The World Health Organization has declared Europe free of polio, the viral inflammation of the spinal cord that once claimed hundreds of thousands of children yearly as victims. Europe is the third region worldwide to be officially certified as polio-free as part of the health organization's drive to eradicate the disease globally by 2005. The Americas and the Western Pacific region have already been certified free of the disease, and health officials hope to add some Central Asian countries to the list soon.

title: Subway Musicians Without the Subway
description: On Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall there was a recital by ''New York's finest subway musicians.'' Talk about a fare hike: the top ticket price was $65, about $63.50 more than it usually costs to see these performers.

title: Official Resigns at F.C.C.
description: A Federal Communications Commission official, Dorothy Attwood, resigned after six years to return to private practice and will be succeeded in July or August by a Washington lawyer, William Maher, the F.C.C. said.

title: Bill, Meant for Morgenthau, Would Restrict Jurisdiction
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, the venerable Manhattan district attorney, has a long history of reaching into other counties to take on politically charged cases. Some lawmakers in Albany want to stop him.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on June 9 about problems encountered by American officials in estimating the reach and aspirations of Al Qaeda misidentified the Qaeda figure whom officials placed in Malaysia in January 2000, at a meeting also attended by two of the Sept. 11 hijackers. He was Tawfiq al-Atash, not Khalid Shaikh Muhammad.

title: Americans Wake Up Early and Pay Attention
description: The United States is different. As a nation, it does not work itself into a frenzy about soccer, or about the American national team, but the interest is there and it is growing. Scenes around the country yesterday morning attested to that.

title: Fraud Charges For Executives At L.I. Firm
description: Forty federal agents raided the small headquarters of a company that leases medical equipment and arrested its top officers today for what prosecutors described as nationwide bank frauds that could total $200 million.

title: Democrats Want Clear Election Rules
description: To the Editor:

description: In percent

title: Panel Backs Relaxing Rules On P.&G. Drug For Heartburn
description: A Food and Drug Administration panel voted overwhelmingly yesterday to recommend allowing Procter & Gamble to sell the heartburn medicine Prilosec without a doctor's prescription.

title: Dangerous locations : Security risks often underrated
description: On moving to Paris, personal safety was the least of my concerns  I considered myself city savvy having lived in London for five years. Had I known that I would be sexually assaulted on a Paris Metro platform, I might have been a little less cavalier.

title: Suicide and Statehood
description: To the Editor:

title: Defendant in Pearl's Death Says Evidence Was Faked
description: The man accused of organizing the kidnapping and murder of the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl told a court today that the case against him was a jumble of lies and faked evidence concocted by the government to please the United States.

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: PENNSYLVANIA: CHILDREN DIE IN BUGGY ACCIDENT

title: Knicks Want to Make a Trade, but There Are Few Offers
description: For the Knicks, the months of June, July, August and September could be just as cold as last February. It was in February that Scott Layden, the club's president and general manager, burned up the telephone lines in vain trying to make a significant deal before the trade deadline. Now Layden is doing the same, and there are indications that his efforts could be just as futile.

title: Another Nystrom Seeks Shot at Cup
description: When Eric Nystrom was about 6 months old, his parents arranged a special pose for a baby picture. They dressed him in a T-shirt and a clean diaper and sat him down in the big, silver curvature of the Stanley Cup. Smile, Eric . . . Flash!

title: Hedging Bets
description: Despite the clarity of the Supreme Court's decision to abolish the death penalty for mentally retarded offenders, the court's next move is uncertain and the impact of the ruling on the overall death penalty debate is far from clear.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Antiradiation Pills For Everyone
description: The government began sending potassium iodide tablets to households across the country for use in case Ireland is exposed to radioactive fallout from a terror attack or an accident at the British nuclear reprocessing plant at Sellafield, across the Irish Sea. The tablets prevent the thyroid gland from accumulating radioactive iodine, which was reported to have caused at least 2,000 cases of thyroid cancer after the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in 1986. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: YUGOSLAVIA: EX-TV BOSS JAILED OVER NATO BOMBING A Serbian court jailed the former head of state television for nine and a half years for failing to protect 16 workers who were killed when NATO bombed the TV station in 1999. The court ruled that Dragoljub Milanovic had not ensured the safety of his staff even though he knew the building could be hit by NATO. Families of the victims have accused the government of Slobodan Milosevic, then the president of Yugoslavia, of deliberately sending the workers into mortal danger to score a propaganda coup against NATO should they be killed. In the 78-day air war over Yugoslavia's repression of Kosovo Albanians, NATO declared the studios a legitimate target on the grounds that the broadcasts were part of Mr. Milosevic's "war machine." (Reuters)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the federal indictment of six people on forced labor charges involving migrant labor camps near Buffalo misstated the given name of a lawyer who is representing one of them. He is Timothy W. Hoover, not Lee.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a decision by federal copyright regulators to halve a proposed royalty rate that Internet radio companies must pay to record labels to play music online misstated the new amount. It is 0.07 cent a song for each listener, not 0.007 cent.

title: 3 Priests May Be Removed, Detroit Archdiocese Says
description: The Archdiocese of Detroit said today that it would probably remove three priests who prosecutors believe sexually abused minors in the past. An earlier investigation of the three by the archdiocese had cleared them.

title: A Delayed Perception of the Rebellion in the Conservative 1950's
description: Morris Dickstein, distinguished professor of English at Queens College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, recently published ''Leopards in the Temple: The Transformation of American Fiction, 1945-1970'' (Harvard University Press, $15.95), in which he reassesses American postwar culture. Daphne Eviatar spoke with him.

title: ADELPHIA, CLOSE TO BANKRUPTCY, GETS A LOAN
description: Adelphia Communications, the troubled cable television operator, reached an agreement yesterday with two banks to receive a $1.5 billion loan that would allow it to operate while it reorganizes under bankruptcy protection, executives close to the company said. The company is planning to file for bankruptcy on Monday, the executives said. The loans were arranged through J. P. Morgan Chase and the Salomon Smith Barney division of Citigroup and are expected to be syndicated to other banks as well, the executives said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKIRBALL, KENIS, AUDREY
description: SKIRBALL - KENIS - Audrey. The New York University Community mourns the passing of Audrey Skirball-Kenis. Mrs. Skirball-Kenis was a warm, generous, witty and charming women whose philanthropy helped immeasurably in so many causes and was indispensable in the growth of NYU. Her extraordinary generosity helped promote excellence in many areas of NYU scholarship, including the Skirball Department of Hebrew and Judaic Studies, The Skirball Professorship for Bible and Ancient Near Eastern Studies, The Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine, The Skirball Directorship of the Bronsman Center for Jewish Student Life, The Jack H. Skirball Center for New Media and Film, The Jack H. Skirball Film Equipment Center and the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts. Her absence will be keenly felt. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband Charles, and to her entire family.

title: Sounds of the Delta Blues, And a Matter of Honor
description: ''Thunder Knocking on the Door'' is a small, blues-based musical that's been kicking around the regional theaters for several years, and it does have a kind of wandering-stepchild quality about it. That is, it's a cocky, swaggery show on the surface, loudly presumptuous of its cleverness and heart, but with a serious identity crisis underneath.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: OHIO: A MUCKRAKER'S REWARD

title: Sports of The Times; Americans Have Joined the World's Party
description: The young Americans have had their magazine covers and their network television gigs and their morning phone call from President Bush. They have enticed millions of Americans to get up at dawn to watch the weird spectacle of Americans winning soccer games.

title: Weaving Nile's Daily Life Into Dream of Change
description: THE phone rang late one evening and Attiyat al-Abnoudi picked it up to find a journalist from a leftist Egyptian newspaper on the line, asking her what she thought of boycotting products from America because of its support for Israel.

title: Jousting Over Drug Coverage
description: Voters coming out of the last presidential election had good reason to believe that no matter who won, there would be federal prescription drug coverage for older Americans in the near future. Now, both the Senate and the House appear to be moving toward votes on a Medicare drug plan. The two proposals are very different, and we feel the Senate version is by far the better version.

title: Another Tumble Gives Stocks Their Fifth Week of Losses
description: Stocks skidded for a third consecutive day yesterday as investors grew increasingly gloomy about the possibility of more terrorist attacks, slowing economic growth and corporate accounting scandals.

title: A Landmark on the Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Knoblauch Eyes Return Or the End of the Line
description: Chuck Knoblauch has drastically reduced his goals with the Kansas City Royals these days. Knoblauch has tendinitis in his left elbow and is on the disabled list, so he spent yesterday trying to catch as many fly balls as possible during batting practice at Shea Stadium. That was his challenge. Then Knoblauch turned into a restless spectator for the game with the Mets.

title: Homeless in Canada
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Take A Number And Study
description: Schools across the state will assign each student a number this fall to help chart his academic progress as part of a new system by the state's Department of Education. The program will help the department keep track of students who move often, making it easier to look up their past test scores and assess their development. The tracking system will also allow the state to rate school districts based on test scores. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Russian House Supports Bill On Farm Sales
description: Russia's lower house of Parliament today approved a bill to create a legal system for the purchase and sale of farmland for the first time since the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917. But the measure, which requires one more vote before it goes to the upper house, passed only after the government agreed to a late amendment prohibiting foreigners to own agricultural property.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON BERNUTH, CHARLES M.
description: von BERNUTH-Charles M. Of Lyford Cay, Bahamas, passed away on May 25, 2002, at the age of 89. Beloved husband of the late Eloise Fiamingo. He was educated in the U.S. and Switzerland, and joined the family business, Bernuth Lembcke Co of NY, creosote importers and a shipping company. During WWII, originally he was a Calvary officer in the U.S. Army at Ft. Riley, KS, and later was recruited as a Captain into the O.S.S, where he was awarded the Silver Star for bravery in action. At war's end he returned to the family business, retiring in 1962, when he moved with his family to Rome, Italy, living there for over 30 years. A superb horseman, horses were the center of his life. He trained horses, judged at the National Horse Show, played polo at Meadowbrook with the very greats, receiving honorable mention; he just genuinely loved horses. He was a world traveler visiting all seven continents with his late wife, multi-lingual, multitalented, a writer, actor, dancer, composer-lyricist, skier, yachtsman, leatherworker, even conquering the unicycle. Actively involved in community affairs, he was a member of Squadron A, The Sleepy Hollow Country Club and The Lyford Cay Club. On the human side there are no superlatives to adequately describe his dignity, his charm, his honesty, his generosity, his humor. Elegant and stunningly handsome with all the social graces, he lived a wondrous and joyous life. He is survived by his first wife Shirley Paige Bernuth, their four children, Antonia Cook, Ticia Agri, Victoria Bernuth and Charles P. von Bernuth, four grandchildren, his nephews, Ernest P. Bernuth Jr. and James T. Bernuth and his neice Barbara King, his loving friend Dorothy Kohler, together with a host of other adoring friends. Memorial www.charlesvonbernuth .com.

title: Sex Obsession By the Numbers
description: Contrary to all appearances, Catherine Millet considers herself no libertine. Being French and an intellectual, however, she has a particularly precise definition of that term. ''I don't think I am a libertine in the literary, 18th-century sense of the word,'' said the 54-year-old author of ''The Sexual Life of Catherine M.,'' a surprisingly dry memoir, given its clinically detailed descriptions of group sex and seemingly innumerable affairs energetically pursued over the course of two decades by Ms. Millet, the editor in chief of the highly respected monthly French art magazine Art Press.

title: 2d Kim son is arrested in bribe case
description: SEOUL:  President Kim Dae Jung apologized to the nation for the scandal surrounding his family Friday after prosecutors arrested the second of his three sons, Kim Hong Up, on charges of corruption and influence-peddling.

title: Filing Raises Concerns About Merck Unit
description: As Merck & Company prepares the initial public offering of its unit that manages pharmacy benefits next week, a regulatory filing has raised concerns about the subsidiary's future profitability.

title: G.O.P. DRUG PLAN FOR ELDERLY NEARS PASSAGE IN HOUSE
description: After an all-night session, the House Committee on Energy and Commerce approved a Republican bill today to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly under Medicare, clearing the way for House passage of the measure next week.

title: Social Security Tricks

title: SHARES IN BED BATH & BEYOND GAIN ON PROFIT REPORTS
description: Shares in Bed Bath & Beyond rose 5.1 percent after the company, the largest household-goods retailer in the nation, said profit this year would exceed forecasts. Shares of the company, which is based in Union, N.J., gained $1.76, to $36.26. Bed Bath & Beyond expects to earn 93 cents a share this year, 2 cents more than analysts forecast. The gain came one day after Bed Bath & Beyond reported a 54 percent increase in profit in its first quarter. First-quarter sales rose 35 percent to $776.8 million, and second-quarter sales should increase by more than 20 percent, the company said.

title: First Toyota Test Of Small Aircraft
description: Toyota Motor said that it conducted a successful first test flight of a small airplane that it had been developing for more than three years and had not decided whether to manufacture.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Wallace's Ex-Wife Faces Runoff
description: George Wallace's third wife, Lisa Taylor Wallace, is in a runoff election on Tuesday for the Republican nomination for state treasurer. Mrs. Wallace, 55, was married to Mr. Wallace for seven years before they divorced in 1987. She is president of a family business that invests money for energy companies. Her opponent, Kay Ivey, 57, a former bank executive, got 45 percent of the vote in the June 4 primary. Mrs. Wallace received 28.2 percent.

title: Ashcroft Petitions Justices For Secrecy in Deportations
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft asked the Supreme Court yesterday to permit secret deportation hearings for people arrested after Sept. 11, arguing that national security would be compromised by disclosure of any information about the detainees.

title: Near Summit Site, a Protest by North Africans
description: The protesters lie in stifling heat on the concrete floor of an indoor soccer stadium, whiling away hours of boredom during this sit-in by more than 400 North African immigrants demanding the right to work in Spain.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERBSTEIN, SEBASTIAN
description: HERBSTEIN-Sebastian. On June 20, 2002, following a brief illness. Beloved son of Judith and Diego. Cherished stepson of Roberta. Dear brother of Julian and Gabriela. Services Sunday, 12:45PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about James Merriam Howard Jr., an expert on writing and education, misstated the location of Blair Academy, the private boarding school in New Jersey where he was a headmaster. It is in Blairstown, not Morristown.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALLEN, MARSHALL
description: ALLEN-Marshall. Daddy, I miss & love you enormously. Your love has given me strength and courage in a world without you. Your generosity, intelligence and wit will never be forgotten. Schuyler

title: U.S. Tries to Win Over Angry Indonesian Muslims
description: On the edge of the rich rain forests and gold mines here in the world's most populous Muslim country, students at an Islamic boarding school learn to abhor the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKLEY, DENNIS F.
description: BUCKLEY-Dennis F. With vision and integrity he lived his life in the service of others. As CEO of North Shore University Hospital, he set standards of excellence stimulating others to aspire to higher goals. His two decade tenure of leadershipe allowed those who came later to achieve greatness, all in behalf of the health of the public. His presence shall be missed but his values will persist. Sincere condolences to all his family. Lawrence Scherr, MD, MACP Chairman Emeritus, Department of Medicine, Northshore Univ. Hospital

title: Man Is Killed On Third Rail As He Tries To Flee Police
description: A suspect fleeing undercover police officers in Greenwich Village was electrocuted early yesterday morning when he scrambled onto subway tracks and stepped on the electrified third rail, the authorities said.

title: Ruling in Shoe-Bomb Case
description: A federal judge ruled today that the man accused of trying to blow up a trans-Atlantic flight by igniting a bomb in his shoe was not coerced into confessing and was not impaired by sedatives when he talked with investigators. Lawyers for the defendant, Richard C. Reid, argued that injections of Valium and other drugs that passengers and crew members used to subdue Mr. Reid clouded his memory and made him unable to knowingly waive his right to remain silent or request a lawyer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELOUDIOS, KATHERINE
description: VELOUDIOS-Katherine. On June 18, 2002 of Palm Beach Gardens, FL formerly of Garden City, NY. Beloved wife of John. Loving mother of Stacy, Angela, Alice and Vickie. Dear sister of William Zolides and Kiki Athineos. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City Sunday and Monday 79PM. Religious service at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. Paul, Hempstead Tuesday 9:30 AM. Interment Flushing Cemetery. In lieu of flowers dontions can be made in Katherine's name to either The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, Inc., One Penn Plaza, Suite 1610, New York, New York 10119, or Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: ECONOMIC RECOVERY STALLS Japan's economic recovery stalled in April as demand for cellphones, stockbrokers and other services fell twice as much as expected and construction spending declined, a government report showed. The all-industry activity index, a gauge of gross domestic product, fell 1.3 percent in April from March, seasonally adjusted. Demand for services, which accounts for 60 percent of the index, fell 1.5 percent.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Bush Mideast Policy Delayed by Staff Debate
description: The announcement of President Bush's promised new Middle East policy has been delayed by renewed debate among his senior advisers over the terms and timing of creating any Palestinian state, administration officials said today.

title: Poetic Justice
description: Textual evidence giveth, and textual evidence taketh away. That's the moral of Donald Foster's admission that John Ford, not William Shakespeare, was the probable author of a 578-line poem called ''A Funeral Elegy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, MURRY
description: SHAPIRO-Murry. Of West Hartford, CT, husband of Evelyn ''Bobby'' Shapiro, died June 20, 2002. Retired Executive Director of the Greater Hartford Jewish Community Center. Besides his wife, he is survived by two sons and a grandson. For futher information contact Weinstein Mortuary, Hartford, CT.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Television section last Sunday with a highlight for today, at 8 p.m. on CNN, has become outdated. ''Harsh Continent: Life in Antarctica'' has been postponed until August 10. The replacement is ''Deadlocked: Russia's Forgotten War,'' a documentary about Chechnya.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THROOP, WILLIAM M., JR.
description: THROOP-William M., Jr., ''Pete,'' on June 20, 2002 at home in New Canaan, CT, of cancer. Survived by his wife Ann, sons William of North Hebron, NY, Mitchell of Greenwich, NY, Peter of Keene, NH, and Thomas of Rowayton, CT, and granddaughters Laura and Susannah. A graduate of St. George's School, Princeton University and Yale Law School, Pete completed 50 years of the practice of law in 2001 with the law firm of Davidson, Dawson & Clark LLP, of which he was the senior partner until becoming of Counsel as of January 1, 2000. A memorial service will be held at St. Michael's Lutheran Church, 5 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, CT on June 28, 2002 at a time to be announced. Contributions may be made to a scholarhsip fund in his memory at Gould Academy, Bethel, ME 04217, for which he had served as a member and Chairman of the Board of Trustees.

title: Another Jewel in New York's Crown of Organs
description: Neither of New York City's biggest concert halls, Avery Fisher Hall or Carnegie Hall, has a symphonic pipe organ, but its churches keep building them.

title: INSIDE
description: Whither the Death Penalty?

title: Fast Legs and a Deflection Extend Castillo's Hit Streak
description: Luis Castillo continued his march toward one of baseball's most revered records when he extended his hitting streak to 35 games tonight as the Florida Marlins beat the Detroit Tigers, 4-1, at Pro Player Stadium.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in some copies yesterday with a report in the World Briefing column about a government reorganization in Hong Kong was published in error. It showed Antony Leung, the territory's financial secretary, not Tung Chee-hwa, its chief executive.

title: Passage to India : It needn't be a dog's life when pets come too
description: Four years ago, when my husband and I found out we were moving from New York to Bombay where I was to work on a film project based in India, we seemed to deflect all our concerns about the future onto the welfare of our small cat. Grey and round, with rotted teeth, Mouse, who was about eight  she was a second-hand cat so we could only guess at her age  was the object of our deepest affection, and we were determined to bring her with us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGEL, RUTH F.
description: HAGEL-Ruth F. 84, died June 12, in Boca Raton, FL, after a long illness. She was born December 3, 1917, in New York City, daughter of the late Jennie and Leo Block. She graduated from Walton High School in the Bronx, and summa cum laude from New York University's School of Commerce. She later worked in advertising and for the World Telegram. Survivors include her daughter and devoted longtime caregiver, Wendy A. Hagel of Boca Raton; her son, Keith W. Hagel of Fairfield, CT; her husband, Raymond C. Hagel of Westport, CT; four grandchildren; and a special niece, Judy Gans Godshall of Willoughby, OH. She was preceded in death by her sister, Delphine Block Gans and her brother, Harry Block. Services at the convenience of the family. Memorials would be appreciated to: Florida Animal Health Foundation, c/o of Thomas J. Lane, DVM, College of Veterinary Medicine, P.O. Box 100136, Gainesville, FL 32610-0136.

title: CABINET IN ISRAEL ENDORSES SEIZURE OF THE WEST BANK
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's security cabinet followed through on a plan for all-out seizure of the West Bank today, scrapping a tactic of intermittent raids in favor of a permanent armed presence as tense Israeli soldiers in armored columns poured into Palestinian cities, towns and refugee camps, military officials said.

title: Now on the F.B.I.'s Short List: Two Men, Long Out of Sight
description: Giuseppe Arcuri and George DeCicco have good reason to worry. But their concerns are somewhat unusual for men of their age.

title: On Claiming a Contract: When in Doubt, Play It Out
description: If your opponent claims a contract, it is highly likely that the claim is correct. But on rare occasions the declarer may be mistaken, so insist that the cards are spread visibly on the table to allow verification. Do not permit an opponent to put his cards back in the board without revealing them, as some experts improperly and discourteously do.

title: Yanks Go Back to Reality, And Find It's a Bit Harsh
description: The Yankees rested two hitters with 19 home runs tonight, but they had plenty of reasons to feel confident.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Poland: No Economic Recovery Yet
description: The Polish economy, Eastern Europe's largest, grew 0.5 percent in the first quarter, failing to recover from two years of near-stagnation, the country's statistical office said. The slight expansion met analysts' expectations. Unemployment, which has nearly doubled since 1999, fell 0.6 percent to 17.2 percent as some people took seasonal jobs in agriculture and tourism. Poland hopes to join the European Union in 2004, but many member countries fear that its poor performance will hurt their economies and unleash a flood of Polish workers on the West.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about stabilization technology for airborne cameras included a misspelling of the name of NASA's space telescope in a comment by Mark Chamberlain, president of Wescam, on his company's stabilized cameras. The name is Hubble, not Hubbell.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Children Die In Buggy Accident
description: Two children were killed on Wednesday night when a sport utility vehicle driven by a man with a suspended license crashed into an Amish buggy in Lancaster County, Pa., the police said. The driver, Mark A. Tomassetti, 22, of Gap, Pa., was arrested after fleeing the scene, officers said. The buggy carried the required night reflector plus an additional lantern when it was struck from behind. Nine-month-old Rebecca Sue Ebersole was dead at the scene; her 12-year-old aunt, Rachel Anne Stoltzfus, died later. Francis X. Clines (NYT)

title: Police Take to Air Amid Fears Of Tampering at Reservoirs
description: Police aircraft scrambled yesterday to track a small plane after a report that it was flying low near upstate reservoirs that supply water to New York City, the authorities said last night. A plane matching the description was followed to a small airport in Lincoln Park, N.J., where the pilot was detained last night, questioned and then released.

title: AOL EXPANDS ITS TV REACH AMONG EUROPEAN YOUTH
description: AOL Time Warner agreed to buy the EMI Group's stake in the German music television broadcaster Viva Media for 52.3 million euros ($50.4 million). With the purchase, AOL Time Warner will raise its stake in Viva Media, a rival of MTV, to 30 percent. MTV's owner, Viacom of New York, said it had also been in talks to buy the Viva stake. Viva also operates channels in Hungary, Poland and the Netherlands. About 73 percent of Viva's viewers are 14 to 29 years old. EMI, whose artists include Janet Jackson, will gain about 43 million euros ($41.5 million) from the sale, it said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDER, SAMUEL
description: FELDER - Samuel. The members, attorneys and staff of Brown Raysman Millstein Felder & Steiner LLP, sadly record the loss of Samuel Felder, the father of our esteemed partner, Barry G. Felder. We extend heartfelt sympathy to the Felder family. Brown Raysman Millstein Felder & Steiner LLP

description: MISSISSIPPI: INCENTIVES FOR AUTOMAKER

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Antiviolence Measures
description: The upper house of Parliament ratified new laws aimed at curbing gun ownership and children's exposure to violence on computers. The gun law raises the legal age for carrying sports weapons to 21 from 18 and bans pump-action shotguns. Gun buyers under 25 must present certificates of medical and psychological health. Owners of illegal weapons have a five-month amnesty period to hand over their arms before the law takes effect. A second law is intended to protect young people from exposure to violence in computer games and on Web sites, setting up a rating index similar to that used to set age limits for film audiences. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARRY, EVA K.
description: PARRY-Eva K. Of Glen Ridge, NJ, formerly of Bethpage, NY, on June 20, 2002. Beloved wife of John. Devoted daughter of John and Ann Kislers. Fond sister of Ilma Hunsicker. Religious service Monday, 10:30 AM, at the Latvian Lutheran Church, Melville. Visitation at The Arthur F. White Funeral Home, Inc., 234 Broadway, Bethpage, conducted by Pastor Laris Salins. Interment Mt Carmel Cemetery, Mt. Carmel, PA. Visiting hours Saturday 7-9:30, and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9:30.

title: Under Fire, I.N.S. Begins Rolling Out a New Database to Track Foreign Students
description: Immigration officials this month began presenting to New York universities and colleges a new system the federal government will use to track foreign students, in the hope that smaller technical institutes will begin using it as early as next month and that any flaws can be fixed before its use becomes compulsory seven months from now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, DANIEL GERARD
description: COLLINS-Daniel Gerard. Suddenly on Sunday June 16th at age 72 after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Anne Weld Collins, dear brother of Muriel Collins, devoted father of Caitlin Ahl, Deirdre, Charles and Geoffrey Collins. Loving step-father of Serena, Evelyn, Alexander and Blake Crawford. Adoring grandfather of five. A memorial service will be announced at a future date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, ROSE
description: STONE-Rose. 97, of Cedar Rapids, IA, formerly of New York City, died Wednesday, June 19, 2002. Services will be held at 9 AM, on Sunday, at The Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 W. 76th St. Inurnment will be at the Riverside Cemetery in New Jersey.

title: Charges Against Forest Worker Surprise Hometown
description: For more than 150 years, people raised within sight of the giant sequoias that tower over the eastern horizon here have looked to the forest for their livelihood. Beyond pursuits like logging and catering to tourists, many sought work in taming the wildfires that any woodland must endure.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Recovery Stalls
description: Japan's economic recovery stalled in April as demand for cellphones, stockbrokers and other services fell twice as much as expected and construction spending declined, a government report showed. The all-industry activity index, a gauge of gross domestic product, fell 1.3 percent in April from March, seasonally adjusted. Demand for services, which accounts for 60 percent of the index, fell 1.5 percent.

title: Philippines Reports a Top Muslim Rebel Leader Died in Clash
description: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo of the Philippines said today that a top leader of Abu Sayyaf, a Muslim rebel group that had kidnapped Americans and dozens of other foreigners in recent years, had been killed in a clash with Philippine troops, who were assisted by American forces.

title: Airline Fails To Win Over A Key Union
description: The message did not win any awards for subtlety.

title: Right at Home With the Ghosts of Show Business
description: American popular music has no more devoted archivist than the singer and pianist Michael Feinstein, who seems to know every alternate verse of every Gershwin song ever written. So devout is his passion for tradition that during a typical performance, Mr. Feinstein often seems to play two roles at once. He is the humble, boyish acolyte honoring the Gershwins, Irving Berlin and Fred Astaire, who rank near the top of his personal hit parade, but also their peer, conversing with his idols in a musical time warp.

title: New Jersey's Repeat Cycle
description: The New Jersey Legislature will adjourn at month's end without taking up reform of the state's regressive property tax system. This news did not stop the presses. Legislators performed as they have for decades, pulling the pillows over their heads until the dawn of another session, which is cursed to end the same way, without tax relief. Indeed, where taxes are concerned, Trenton seems like the movie ''Groundhog Day,'' where every day begins with ''I Got You, Babe'' and is filled with recycled, pointless ceremony.

title: Ex-Rite Aid Officials Face U.S. Charges Of Financial Fraud
description: Three former top executives and a current employee of the Rite Aid Corporation were indicted yesterday in what regulators called a securities and accounting fraud that led to a $1.6 billion restatement of earnings, the largest ever.

title: Merrill Broker Who Worked With Stewart Is Suspended
description: Merrill Lynch yesterday suspended the stockbroker who handled the sale of Martha Stewart's ImClone shares, saying an internal investigation had uncovered ''factual issues regarding a client transaction.''

title: Priest Charged In Rape in 2000 In the Rectory
description: A Roman Catholic priest was arrested yesterday in Texas on charges that two years ago he raped a woman on a couch in a Brooklyn rectory, where she had gone for advice about annulling her marriage, the authorities said.

title: Timothy Findley, Canadian Author, Dies at 71
description: Timothy Findley, the prolific Canadian author whose complex novels and intricately layered plays often probed the madness and immorality of the last century, died on Thursday in a hospital in the south of France. He was 71.

title: Rapidly Growing Blaze Forces 8,000 to Flee in Arizona
description: As firefighters reported modest progress in Colorado's two largest wildfires, a fast-growing blaze in eastern Arizona was pummeling small towns today as it became the largest fire in state history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, BETTY J.
description: BERNSTEIN-Betty J. On June 20, 2002. Beloved sister of Morry, Seymour and Pearl. Survived by her brother Ira and sister Hilda, devoted nieces, nephews and cousins. Services Sunday, June 23, 2002, 11 AM, at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Court Upholds Giuliani-Era Ban on Pet Ferrets
description: The Bloomberg administration has not adopted every position held by the Giuliani administration, but it does agree that ferrets should not be kept as pets. Now it has won its case in court.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Smoker Wins Punitive Damages
description: A federal judge imposed $15 million in punitive damages against the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company in a case brought by a former smoker who lost his legs to vascular disease. It is believed to be the first time a federal judge has ordered punitive damages in a tobacco case, and adds to a series of losses for the industry in California, Florida and Oregon in recent weeks. The judge, John W. Lungstrum of Federal District Court, ruled that the company's ''determination to withhold, mislead and deceive the public'' about the dangers of smoking was ''particularly nefarious.'' Reynolds said it would appeal. Greg Winter (NYT)

title: How Much Is This Column Worth to You?
description: As a person of medium girth, I feel there's sound logic in the policy of Southwest Airlines, which it will begin enforcing next week, to charge very large people for two seats on its planes. I am like most people in not enjoying having a person in the next seat who sprawls or spreads to take up part of mine, though I'd still prefer that to a tiny tot in a bad mood.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on June 13 about a new law in Vermont requiring drug makers to disclose any gifts and cash payments made to health care providers -- and about a growing effort by state and federal lawmakers to rein in drug companies' marketing practices -- referred incorrectly to a law in Hawaii that created a discount drug program. It does not require drug companies to report the amount of their spending on marketing.

title: Flames Bursting Onstage, Showers for the Audience
description: Nickelback is a hard rock band that could be a practical joke. The members come from Canada; their live show is enhanced with flames and explosions; and -- the most obvious clue -- the bass player wears a cowboy hat.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Treason Trial Concludes
description: The treason trial of Oleg D. Kalugin, a retired K.G.B. general living in the United States, ended with prosecutors in Moscow asking a court to sentence him to 20 years in prison and strip him of his military rank and honors. Mr. Kalugin, being tried in absentia for disclosing state secrets, has refused to appear or defend himself. With a law allowing in absentia trials about to expire on July 1, the court rejected appeals by his lawyer, Yevgeny A. Baru, for more time to prepare a defense and contact his client. The court is expected to announce a verdict on Wednesday. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Smallpox Proposal Raises Ethical Issues
description: The decision by a government advisory panel to recommend smallpox vaccination for about 15,000 health care and law enforcement workers raises logistical and ethical issues involving not just the people who will get the vaccine but also those who will come in contact with them.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on June 9 about problems encountered by American officials in estimating the reach and aspirations of Al Qaeda misidentified the Qaeda figure whom officials placed in Malaysia in January 2000, at a meeting also attended by two of the Sept. 11 hijackers. He was Tawfiq al-Atash, not Khalid Shaikh Muhammad.

title: One More Rally, Late in the Game, to Win Over Critics of a Newark Arena
description: After failing this week, in the waning days of the legislative session, to advance a measure to build a sports arena here, the owners of the New Jersey Nets and Devils are planning one final push this weekend: an advertising blitz aimed at the districts of key Republican lawmakers who are opposed to the plan or on the fence.

title: It Can't Be: Alaska, the New Hot Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: President Apologizes
description: After a second of his three sons was arrested and charged with influence peddling, President Kim Dae Jung bowed before a national television audience, saying he was ''thoroughly responsible'' for their conduct and apologizing ''for hurting the hearts of people who supported me.'' He said both would be sternly punished under the law. Kim Hong Up, accused of taking nearly $2 million in bribes, was jailed in Seoul in the same detention center as his younger brother, Kim Hong Gul, 38, who was arrested last month on similar charges. Don Kirk (NYT)

description: Former Rite Aid Executives Indicted in S.E.C. Inquiry
