title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: President Quits
description: President A. Q. M. Badruddoza Chowdhury resigned under pressure from the governing Bangladesh National Party, which accused him of showing disrespect to the party's founder. Party leaders said Mr. Chowdhury, whose post is largely ceremonial, had acted in an insulting manner by not visiting the grave of the founder, Ziaur Rahman, on the 21st anniversary of his death. Prime Minister Khaleda Zia is Mr. Rahman's widow. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Bills Aplenty As Session Winds Down In Albany
description: The guardians of mentally retarded people would be permitted to remove them from life-support machines if they had no chance of survival, under a bill the Legislature passed in a frenzy of last-minute lawmaking on Thursday night.

title: A Landmark on the Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: For Morales and Barrera, National Pride Is the Prize
description: It was, in many ways, an archetypal fight, 12 nonstop rounds of left hooks to livers and heads, but Marco Antonio Barrera and Erik Morales, who are expected to do it all over again Saturday night, are hardly stereotypical fighters.

title: MAXTOR WIDENS ITS LOSS ESTIMATE ON DISK DRIVES
description: The Maxtor Corporation, the world's biggest computer disk-drive maker, expects a wider-than-forecast second-quarter loss and lowered its sales estimate, citing price cuts and lowered demand. The loss will be as much as $90 million, or 38 cents a share, excluding some costs, on sales of $880 million to $910 million, a spokeswoman, Jenifer Kirtland, said. The shortfall does not include amortization of good will from the $340.1 million purchase of the Quantum Corporation's hard-drive business last year, she said. Maxtor was expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call to have a loss of 24 cents a share on sales of $982.7 million. Maxtor is based in Milpitas, Calif.

title: MORTON'S RESTAURANTS AGREES TO A BID FROM ICAHN
description: Morton's Restaurant Group plans to scrap its agreement to be purchased by Castle Harlan Inc. in favor of a rival bid from the billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn, who raised his offer for the company by 11 percent, to $63 million. Mr. Icahn raised his bid to $15 a share from $13.50 on Wednesday after Morton's, the steakhouse chain, agreed on Monday to be acquired by Castle Harlan, a leveraged buyout firm based in New York. Castle Harlan had matched last month's $56.6 million proposal from Mr. Icahn. Under its agreement with Morton's, Castle Harlan has five days to revise its offer. Morton's is based in New Hyde Park, N.Y.

title: Vote by Hyundai Workers Is Inconclusive
description: The Hyundai Motor Company's labor union said that its members failed to agree on a company wage offer, and union officials will meet again on Monday to discuss their next move.

title: QUALCOMM SAYS PROFITS WILL EXCEED EXPECTATIONS
description: Qualcomm Inc., whose chips and patents are used in more than 120 million mobile telephones, said profit, excluding some one-time items, would meet or exceed its previous forecast because of higher demand in the current quarter. Profit excluding investments in wireless operators will be at least 23 cents a share in the period, which ends June 30, a spokeswoman, Christine Trimble, said. Qualcomm also said yesterday that it had ''strong order input'' for the fourth quarter, which ends Sept. 29. Despite the forecast, Qualcomm's stock fell, ending at $26.12 a share, down 21 cents, on Nasdaq.

title: Mourning Spawns Revenge for Israeli Settlers
description: The mourners, maybe 3,000 of them, were angry. They scuffled here with the Israeli police and the army this afternoon. They bought T-shirts that read, ''No Arabs, no attacks.''

title: Noted Hartford Museum Unveils Its New Design
description: The Wadsworth Atheneum has been the cultural heartbeat of this city since the art museum opened 160 years ago. But that beat will cease when it closes its doors in 2004 for an $80 million expansion and renovation expected to take two years.

title: Sports of The Times; Breaking Down the Institutional Barriers That Women Still Face
description: DONNA LOPIANO and I have this running joke about royalty payment. The joke goes back to a conversation we had eight years ago when we were discussing Lopiano's frustration that her greatest goal in life would never be realized. She wanted to play center field for the Yankees.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If anything, this demonstrated to the world that the U.S. belongs here.''''

title: Sovereignty Debate With U.S. Limits U.N. Support for Bosnia Force
description: The Security Council, locked in a dispute with the United States over the legal liability of American troops overseas, agreed today to extend the mandate of the international force in Bosnia for only nine more days.

title: Vast Change Looms for Florida Timber Tracts
description: For decades, a 40-mile stretch of snowy-white beaches and unspoiled bays on Florida's Panhandle has stayed out of the limelight, protected from development because its owner, St. Joe Paper, was interested mostly in cutting trees.

title: Gemstar Loses Initial Ruling On Patents For TV Guides
description: Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc., the world's leader in developing electronic television program guides, lost a major patent case yesterday, in a victory for four of its competitors.

title: MeriStar to Miss Estimates
description: The MeriStar Hospitality Corporation, an owner of Hilton and Marriott hotels, said today that its second-quarter profit would be less than it expected.

title: Prospect May Have Surgery
description: SAN DIEGO, June 21 — Brandon Claussen, the Yankees' top pitching prospect, expects to have Tommy John surgery on his left pitching elbow on Tuesday, his agent, Sam Levinson, said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DONNELL, JERRY
description: O'DONNELL - Jerry. Was born into an Irish family of Ellis Island immigrants in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan. Growing up in the Depression he excelled at street stickball and made the AllCity basketball team at De La Salle High School. He graduated from Manhattan College and started his aviation career with United at the NY Municipal Airport (La Guardia). During the War years he served with the Navy in the Pacific as a Transportation Officer. After the War he joined Pan American Airways. During the early years he opened Pan Am's Pacific routes working closely with Juan Trippe and technical adviser Charles Lindbergh. He was based out of Hong Kong for 20 years and became known as Pan Am's Ambassador to the Pacific. He rose to the level of Vice President and was transferred back to NY and then Beirut. While in Asia he also served as a Founding Board member for Mandarin Hotels and as Chairman for Pacific Asia Travel Association (PATA). Upon retirement he became the President of the Hong Kong Tourist Association, then based out of San Francisco, and developed travel programs to the Far East. After his retirement from HKTA he worked on consulting projects in air travel and tourism for the Kenyan and Chinese Governments. Jerry volunteered time as a board member for charities such as International Rescue Committee, Project Hope and the San Francisco Aeronautical Society. He lived his last 27 years in Menlo Park, CA, where he became a fan of the 49ers and the Stanford Cardinals. Jerry is survived by the children of his first wife Susan Merrill (San Carlos) and his second wife Madeline Sullivan (Brooklyn) and her children. Private family services have been held.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Days Off, Minus Pay
description: Gov. Angus S. King has imposed three unpaid days off for state workers in the 2003 fiscal year to help offset the state's $180 million budget shortfall. The first day will be July 5, when state offices will close. All employees must take two additional unpaid days by June 1, 2003. Carl Leinonen, head of the Maine State Employees Association, called the plan a political gimmick. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Senate Votes To Let Soldiers Overseas Pay For Abortion
description: American servicewomen overseas would be able to pay for abortions at military hospitals under a proposal approved today by the Senate.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a decision by federal copyright regulators to halve a proposed royalty rate that Internet radio companies must pay to record labels to play music online misstated the new amount. It is 0.07 cent a song for each listener, not 0.007 cent.

title: Federal Judge Denies Claim Of Senecas To Islands
description: A federal judge yesterday dismissed a claim by the Seneca Indians for roughly 18,000 acres in suburban Buffalo, giving New York officials a rare but significant victory in their protracted fight with numerous Indian groups for land across the state.

title: Woman Fatally Shot At Apartment Door
description: A Brooklyn woman was shot to death and her son was wounded Thursday night when a group of men knocked at their apartment door and then opened fire, the authorities said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Opera Executive Retiring
description: Walter Arnheim will retire as executive director of the Washington Opera at the end of this month, Michael Sonnenreich, president-elect of the board of trustees, announced yesterday. Mr. Arnheim, a former executive of the Mobil Corporation, has held the position since January 2000. No successor has been named.

title: Train Riders Are Vexed By (Others') Cellphones
description: Marian Lewis is among the three-quarters of riders on the Metro-North Railroad with a cellphone. She uses it occasionally to contact a family member in an emergency. She considers it a necessity, an unalienable right, and balks at the idea of segregating users in specified cars, like the smoking sections of yore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOXTON, ARCHIBALD R., JR.
description: HOXTON-Archibald R., Jr. On June 19, 2002 of Shepherdstown, WV. Age 86. Former Headmaster of Episcopal H.S., Alexandria, VA. Memorial service Trinity Episcopal Church, Shepherdstown, WV, Saturday, June 29th, 11AM. Memorial contributions to Episcopal H.S., 1200 N. Quaker Ln., Alexandria, VA 22302

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: PRESIDENT APOLOGIZES After a second of his three sons was arrested and charged with influence peddling, President Kim Dae Jung bowed before a national television audience, saying he was "thoroughly responsible" for their conduct and apologizing "for hurting the hearts of people who supported me." He said both would be sternly punished under the law. Kim Hong Up, accused of taking nearly $2 million in bribes, was jailed in Seoul in the same detention center as his younger brother, Kim Hong Gul, 38, who was arrested last month on similar charges. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Shell Chief Looks at Stake in Korea Gas
description: Philip B. Watts, the chairman of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies, said today that he had singled out Asia as ''a key growth area'' as Shell focuses on natural gas and negotiates for a 15 percent stake in the government-controlled Korea Gas Corporation.

title: An International Orchestra In All Its Youthful Energy
description: Now in its 15th year, the American Russian Young Artists Orchestra began as a cultural exchange program for young musicians before the collapse of the Soviet Union. Now it is a bit more international than its title suggests: although most of the players are Russian or American, the ensemble that performed at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening also included representatives from other former Soviet republics, as well as from England, Israel, Macedonia, New Zealand and Taiwan. The group is currently on an international tour that ends with a concert, to be conducted by Paavo Jarvi, in Red Square in Moscow on July 2.

title: Day for German Pride, and Worries
description: Divided loyalties are one thing, but $500 will buy a lot of the beer that Mike Schneider was drinking faster and faster as Germany's 1-0 margin over the United States looked more and more likely to hold.

title: In a word : Minding your 'Ps & Fs' in Manila
description: PARIS  One of the great pleasures of residing in a foreign land, for lovers of language, is the word play. By this I mean the weird and wacky and often wonderful way words we know in English can be used, misused or counterposed to produce new meanings that surprise and delight.

title: U.S. Says Banks' Earnings Are Up 18.6%
description: The nation's banks have taken advantage of low interest rates and stronger cost controls to increase earnings 18.6 percent in the last year as corporate profits have fallen, federal regulators said today.

title: The Changing Debate Over the Death Penalty
description: The Supreme Court's ruling Thursday that it is unconstitutional to execute mentally retarded people was good news for opponents of the death penalty. They hailed it as a landmark decision that signals a fundamental shift in the court's stance toward capital punishment.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Tariffs On Chips Sought
description: Infineon Technologies, a German producer of memory chips, said it had asked the European Commission to impose tariffs on chips produced by Hynix Semiconductor, a financially struggling competitor from South Korea that has been receiving subsidies from that nation's government. Infineon says the subsidies have allowed Hynix to sell chips at unfairly low prices. Hynix is the third-largest and Infineon the fourth-largest producer in the nearly $12 billion global market for the chips, which are known as DRAM, for dynamic random access memory.

title: Hip-Hop Is Enlisted In Social Causes
description: ON a sultry Tuesday this month, on lower Manhattan streets thronged with a mix of teenagers in baggy pants and fashion-challenged baby boomers, the hip-hop impresario Russell Simmons donned his trademark baseball cap to dominate a stage that also showcased Jay-Z and Alicia Keys. But the familiar sights and sounds of a rap concert dressed up a rally to protest school budget cuts and to support teachers.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Incentives For Automaker
description: State lawmakers meeting in a special session approved a $68 million package of incentives to encourage Nissan to expand a $900 million assembly plant near Canton that is under construction. In 2000, the Legislature approved a $295 million deal for the promise of 4,000 jobs. The expansion of the Nissan plant, which will be used to add an undisclosed new line of automobile, is expected to produce an additional 1,300 factory jobs.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Lieber and the Cubs Quickly Defeat the Cards
description: Jon Lieber did not have to worry about much offense, but he got what he needed from Fred McGriff.

title: 2 Exchanges Suspend Trading In Shares of Chinese Automaker
description: The rougher edges of Chinese capitalism were on display this week as a Chinese automaker replaced its chairman amid many questions and few answers, prompting stock exchanges in Hong Kong and New York to halt trading in the company's shares today.

title: The Invisible Advocate Goes Public; As Mayor Assaults Succession Rules, Gotbaum Is Being Seen and Heard
description: Little by little, Betsy Gotbaum has begun to emerge from what seemed like a prolonged hibernation, tucked away somewhere and hidden from the spotlight.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: POLAND: NO ECONOMIC RECOVERY YET The Polish economy, Eastern Europe's largest, grew 0.5 percent in the first quarter, failing to recover from two years of near-stagnation, the country's statistical office said. The slight expansion met analysts' expectations. Unemployment, which has nearly doubled since 1999, fell 0.6 percent to 17.2 percent as some people took seasonal jobs in agriculture and tourism. Poland hopes to join the European Union in 2004, but many member countries fear that its poor performance will hurt their economies and unleash a flood of Polish workers on the West.

title: Sacrifice Is for Losers
description: Last weekend marked the media's self-congratulatory 30th anniversary of the Watergate break-in, and it would have spoiled the mood to suggest that all the energy expended on searching for ol' Deep Throat might be better spent trying to crack the Watergate under way right now.

title: Sept. 11 as Right-Wing U.S. Plot: Conspiracy Theory Sells in France
description: Even before the fires were extinguished at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, conspiracy theories began flooding the Internet. A few quickly spilled out of Web sites and were widely circulated by e-mail before fading into oblivion. One, however, has taken on a life of its own in France. It was turned into a book that has become the publishing sensation of the spring.

title: Jury for Retrial Of Ex-Officer In Louima Case Is Mostly White
description: A Brooklyn federal judge seated an overwhelmingly white jury of 12 that includes two black men for the retrial of former police officer Charles Schwarz in the Abner Louima brutality case yesterday, as lawyers on each side accused the other of injecting race into the selection process.

title: National-Service Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: Unsung Successes Of the F.B.I.
description: The F.B.I. is being intensely criticized for intelligence failures before Sept. 11. But the F.B.I. that I have worked with in recent years, as the leader of an organization concerned with kidnapped children, deserves only praise. Our national leaders are focusing, as they must, on the F.B.I.'s role in rooting out terrorist threats. But they also must not lose sight of the bureau's important work in fighting domestic crimes that are beyond the scope of local police.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: A Muckraker's Reward
description: After 20 years of rousing fellow citizens of Youngstown to fight the city's deep-rooted political and mob corruption, James Callen, a legal aid lawyer, has been awarded a $7,500 stipend by the Petra Foundation for his work. The foundation, a nonprofit organization that recognizes and encourages individuals and groups that advance social justice, noted that Mr. Callen's efforts had prompted a special organized crime task force that has convicted more than 70 mob and political figures, including Representative James A. Traficant Jr., who is awaiting sentencing after a corruption conviction. Francis X. Clines (NYT)

title: Top Dog, Underdog
description: Soccer is one shared global pastime not dominated by American culture. So it was with a sense of alarm that much of the world watched the American team's storied run at the 2002 World Cup, and with a sense of relief that it greeted the United States' heartbreaking loss to Germany in yesterday's quarterfinals, a match the Americans dominated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRISKIE, BESS
description: BRISKIE-Bess. The residents of Round Dune, E. Quogue, NY, are saddened by her passing. Our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Gale Spitalnik, President

title: A Doubter Long Ago Said 'Sell'
description: As an analyst at Merrill Lynch, Gary Vineberg urged his clients in the 1990's to avoid shares of Rite Aid or sell if they owned them.

title: Europeans Struggle to Find Agreement on Immigration
description: European Union leaders struggled today with questions of illegal immigration, Union enlargement and internal reform in a summit meeting punctuated by news of bomb blasts and marked by a distracting obsession with soccer's World Cup.

title: Battles Over, Council Passes the City Budget
description: After days of false starts, delayed meetings and last-minute brinkmanship, the City Council -- almost unanimously -- adopted a budget last evening for the fiscal year that starts in a little more than a week.

title: It Can't Be: Alaska, the New Hot Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bittersweet McCarron Is Ready for One Last Ride
description: Chris McCarron has felt just about every imaginable emotion that comes with his profession, from the jubilation of victory in the Kentucky Derby and induction into racing's Hall of Fame to the despair that comes with every broken bone. Tomorrow, he will add another to his list: the bittersweet feeling of stepping away from the sport that has meant so much to him, but doing so on his terms.

title: Outlasting England, Brazil gains semifinal
description: The realities of life at the World Cup come rushing in when teams have reached the quarterfinals. You are on the threshold, you can glimpse the prize, but unless your reserves of stamina and skills are world class, this is when the effort of four weeks in hot and humid climates exposes you.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Prosecutor In Lawyer's Death Resigns
description: The prosecutor in charge of investigating the death of Digna Ochoa, a well-known human rights lawyer, who was found dead last October, has resigned. The prosecutor, Renato Sales, said in his resignation letter that his belief that Ms. Ochoa had committed suicide had created criticism of his capacity to continue investigating the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATWOOD, GERALD T.
description: ATWOOD-Gerald T. Tragically and heroically in the line of duty with his brothers of Ladder 21 at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Beloved son of Gerald and Elaine (nee Kenny). Loving husband of Barbara (nee Swat). Devoted father of Gerald J., Margaret M. and Robert T. Dear brother of John, Jane Duffy, Raymond, Gregory and Elaine. Funeral Thursday 11 AM from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Bklyn. Memorial Mass 12 PM at Good Shepherd R.C. Church. Memorial interment service to follow at Holy Cross Cemetery. Memorial visitation Tuesday and Wednesday 2 to 5 & 7 to 10 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations in Gerald's memory can be made to: New York Firefighters Burn Center Foundation C/O Ladder 61, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, NY 10475

title: Dream Ends in a Moment of Vulnerability
description: When the whistle blew, there was more relief and exhaustion than celebration in the reaction of the German players. They raised their tired hands in triumph, but four of them fell to the ground, spent. Even Oliver Kahn, the goalkeeper and savior of this quarterfinal match, lay on his back, weary, knowing that his team was victorious, but not better.

title: Currency concerns : How to keep fees down when moving large sums across borders
description: PARIS  September will mark the 10th anniversary of George Soros's notorious $10 billion speculative raid against the British pound, a bet that forced the pound out of its trading range within the European Exchange Rate Mechanism and made more than $1 billion for Soros's hedge fund when sterling fell 5 percent in a day.

description: Projected lottery order and picks for Wednesdays draft at Madison Square Garden:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi's Cash Plan
description: Shares in the world's largest media company, Vivendi Universal of France, fell 8.4 percent yesterday after the company announced a plan to raise cash. On Thursday, the company proposed leasing stock in its water subsidiary Vivendi Environnement to Deutsche Bank as collateral for a loan valued at 1.4 billion euros. That was seen as a sign that cash flow was weaker than investors had estimated. Vivendi was originally expected to sell 15 percent of the subsidiary. Acquisitions by the chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier, have left the company with $30 billion in debt. Shares in Vivendi Environnement fell 2.7 percent, to 32.1 euros.

title: Three Beauty Pageants Leaving CBS for NBC
description: Donald J. Trump is moving his three beauty pageants -- Miss Universe, Miss USA and Miss Teen USA -- from their decades-old home on CBS to NBC, he announced yesterday. But Mr. Trump and his former partner, CBS, could not agree on the reason for the switch.

title: On Bridges, The View Includes Chain Links
description: Pausing from her Wednesday morning commute, Claire Mifflin straddled her mountain bike at the entrance to the Manhattan Bridge and eyed the seven-foot-high chain-link fence that lines both sides of the bridge's bicycle and pedestrian path.

title: Beliefs; A Catholic bishop looks back at an effort in the 90's to deal with sexual abuse by clergymen.
description: It has been a season of jolting ups and downs for Bishop John F. Kinney of the Diocese of St. Cloud, Minn., a man who nine years ago was at the center of an effort to focus the attention of the nation's Roman Catholic hierarchy on the problem of priests who sexually abuse young people.

title: Mets Use Some Hustle to Beat the Royals
description: The Mets had runners on first and second base with two outs and Mo Vaughn batting in the ninth as Tony Tarasco crept off second and reviewed the possible scenarios. Tarasco recalled how Bobby Valentine stressed aggressiveness on the bases during spring training, so he told himself that even a trickling grounder could prove fortuitous for the Mets.

title: KMART HAD LOSS IN MAY, BUT BANKRUPTCY COSTS DECLINED
description: The Kmart Corporation said it had a loss of $96 million in May as sales declined. The loss includes reorganization costs of $11 million in professional fees and $6 million in employee-retention bonuses in the four weeks ended May 29. Same-store sales, excluding results at the 283 stores Kmart closed, fell 11 percent, a spokesman, Jack Ferry, said. Since filing for Chapter 11 protection Jan. 22, Kmart has reported a total loss of $2.12 billion as it reduced prices to clear out inventory and made payments to cancel leases. The May loss was less than some investors expected as bankruptcy-related costs decreased.

title: Who Was the Bard? Don't Ask a Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Mobilcom's Chief Dismissed
description: The supervisory board of MobilCom voted to dismiss the company's founder and chief executive, Gerhard Schmid, left, and replace him with its chief financial officer, Thorsten Grenz. Mr. Schmid fought for five months with France Tlcom, owner of 28.5 percent of MobilCom, over corporate strategy; a bank refinancing of MobilCom's $4.5 billion in debts, arranged by France Tlcom, was conditioned on his departure. France Tlcom is expected to buy Mr. Schmid's 49.9 percent share of the company for 10 euros a share and make an offer to other shareholders for the rest. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Greene Stares Down Montgomery and Wins Showdown
description: In the trash-talking world of sprinters, where big boasts and matching egos are often cover-ups for fear, Maurice Greene is basically a listener. He is simply the best and says it so casually that it is easy to believe him. He has made his statements on the track: Olympic gold medal in 2000; world championships in 1997, 1999 and 2001; world-record holder at 100 meters (9.79 seconds in 1999).

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Stocks And Currency Sink
description: With uncertainty about the performance of the economy and the outcome of the coming presidential election growing, the Brazilian currency, the real, hit a record low against the dollar and the stock market sank to its lowest level in eight months. The declines came after both the Moody's and Fitch's rating services lowered their outlooks for the Brazilian economy on Thursday, ignoring the country's access to a $10 billion line of credit with the International Monetary Fund. A new poll shows that the leftist presidential candidate Luiz Incio da Silva, who has threatened to renegotiate Brazil's foreign debt and break with the current government's market-friendly policies, continues to hold a 2-to-1 lead over his nearest challenger.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Warning On Song About Indians
description: The Broadcasting Complaints Commission said a song by the country's most prominent black playwright might incite violence against Indians and warned radio stations against playing it except for excerpts on news or public-affairs programs. The song, by Mbongeni Ngema, calls on blacks to confront people of Indian ancestry, who have been accused of discriminating against black Africans. About 80 percent of the country's radio stations are members of the commission and those that broadcast the song risk fines of as much as $3,000.

title: Giambi Still Finds First Base Challenging
description: SAN DIEGO, June 21  Jason Giambi was developed as a third baseman, and though he has not played there in years, the mentality is hard to shake. The ball will come to Giambi, and if he has to throw it, his instincts tell him he is holding a hot potato.

title: F.B.I. Warns of Possible Threat to Synagogues
description: The F.B.I. has warned its field offices and other law enforcement agencies that terrorists could use fuel tanker trucks for an attack on synagogues or Jewish schools, law enforcement officials said today, emphasizing that they had no solid evidence that such a plot was at hand.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: AMNESTY OVER TICKETS

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MEDICAL ACTION INDUSTRIES, Hauppauge, N.Y., a maker of disposable medical and surgical products, said it had completed the purchase of MD Industries, Northbrook, Ill., a maker of packaging and collection systems for biohazard and chemotherapy waste. Terms were not disclosed.

title: From Goal to Foul, All Ronaldinho
description: Brazil came from behind to beat England, 2-1, today in a highly anticipated and hotly contested World Cup game that revolved around the erratic fortunes of a mop-haired midfielder, Ronaldinho, and the terrible luck of the English goalkeeper, David Seaman.

title: TWO UTILITY COMPANIES ARE SUBPOENAED ON THEIR TRADES
description: The Avista Corporation, a utility owner in the Northwest, and the Portland General Electric unit of Enron received subpoenas from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission seeking records on ''wash'' trades. The commission asked Avista and Portland General Electric for records dating to January 2000, spokesmen for the companies said. In wash or round-trip trades, companies simultaneously buy and sell power or natural gas at the same price. The trades can be used to increase trading volume or revenue. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the Securities and Exchange Commission and other agencies have been investigating energy companies' trading practices after Enron sought bankruptcy protection in December.

title: Lillian Vernon Posts Loss
description: The Lillian Vernon Corporation, which sells toys, household and gardening items through catalogs and Web sites, said its first-quarter loss widened because of a change in the value of a contract related to buying paper.

title: Audit Firm Survives Criminal Charge, $16 Million Later
description: As Arthur Andersen fought criminal charges this year, several other accounting firms sought to capitalize on its woes by trying to hire some of its audit partners and acquire some of its practice groups.

title: Faces Behind a Reprieve
Home of the Jersey Chronicles
description: VIEW ASKEW, Kevin Smith's film production company, based in Red Bank, has a vision of the Garden State that is no rose garden, and his fans like it that way.

title: Is Melrose a Melrose By Any Other Name?
description: Ana Aquino is a 54-year-old physical therapist who lives in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx. But ask where she's from, and the best she can do is refer to the largest nearby street, Andrews Avenue. ''There is no neighborhood name,'' Ms. Aquino explained. ''It's all part of the Bronx.''

title: Hysteria, Hysteria
description: In her article, Talbot writes, ''Why, exactly, the idea of psychogenic illness should be so offensive is a little baffling.'' Perhaps it is not so difficult to understand when one considers that most of us are constantly struggling to maintain the fiction that we have control and choice in our lives. The notion that an unconscious emotional force is producing a gross physical problem confronts us head on, with a fact we are eagerly trying to ignore: hence, the offense.

title: New Faces and Old Achieve Final Four Of the World Cup
description: A World Cup that began in disbelief and came to celebrate the unexpected distilled itself to four teams today, two of the great soccer powers and two challengers who provided the tournament's engaging surprise.

title: Community of Learning at School
description: JOSEPH RIVERA spends much of his down time hovering over a chess board, and learning how to best plot his moves so he can move up the ranks of players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOWAL, HOWARD
description: KOWAL-Howard. Passed away June 15th, 2002, in Boynton Beach, Florida. Beloved husband of Joan, for 52 years, loving father of Andy, Dick and Valerie; and loving grandfather & brother. He is mourned by his many friends and family in Manhattan, Long Island and Florida, and colleagues from the garment industry.

title: Jennifer Liu, Andrew Sung
description: Jennifer Pei-Ju Liu, a daughter of Mary Y. Liu and Dr. John K. Liu of Princeton Junction, N.J., was married on Friday to Andrew Sung, the son of Chinyee Sung and Hsi-Yuan Sung of White Plains. The Rev. Dr. Clayton Z. Miller, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: June 16-22: INTERNATIONAL; CAFE SUBCULTURE
description: Like many of the estimated 2,200 unlicensed cybercafes in Beijing, the Blue Hyperspeed Internet Cafe, in the university district, was a firetrap, and when flames raced through one night last weekend, 25 students died. City officials, seeking to head off criticism for lax enforcement of fire codes, shut down all the city's Internet cafes, legal and illegal, and vowed tighter regulation in the future. When it turned out that the fire was started by two angry teenagers, officials also lashed out against the new evils of ''Internet addiction'' among the young. Erik Eckholm

title: Qaeda Says Bin Laden Is Well, And It Was Behind Tunis Blast
description: A spokesman for Al Qaeda claimed in an audio recording broadcast late yesterday from Qatar that the organization carried out the bloody April attack on a synagogue in Tunis and that the world would hear from Osama bin Laden soon.

title: Engineering Romance
description: THE IDEA OF PERFECTION

title: Rhodes Scholars
description: Zandra Rhodes is an exotic -- a rare species. She looks like a cross between Glinda the Good Witch and something you would find in an Easter basket. She has bright pink hair, an insane amount of blue eye shadow, two different colors of lipstick -- one for the top and one for the bottom -- and she sleeps in her makeup because ''to put it on every day would simply take too much time.'' With her chipped nail polish and Cockney accent, she's a psychedelic Mary Poppins.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 26 about the end of the close relationship between show business and Washington misstated the nature of a fund-raising event scheduled for the Playboy mansion in 2000, an event that was relocated at the request of Vice President Al Gore and the Democratic National Committee. The beneficiary was Hispanic Unity USA, the political action committee of Representative Loretta Sanchez, Democrat of California, not Gore's presidential campaign.

title: Before the Dodgers Even Arrived: Excelsiors vs. Eckfords
description: LONG BEFORE THE DODGERS: Baseball in Brooklyn, 1855-1884

title: Season for Shakespeare: This Time It's 'Henry V' Onstage
description: EVERYONE knows that Shakespeare is summertime's No. 1 theatrical sport, but it's the comedies and tragedies, 28 in all, that leap to mind. Only the most intransigent devotee will miss the histories, which add up to seven.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, DANIEL GERARD
description: COLLINS-Daniel Gerard. Suddenly on Sunday June 16th at age 72 after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Anne Weld Collins, dear brother of Muriel Collins, devoted father of Caitlin Ahl, Deirdre, Charles and Geoffrey Collins. Loving step-father of Serena, Evelyn, Alexander and Blake Crawford. Adoring grandfather of five. A memorial service will be held on Friday, Sept. 20, at 11 a.m. at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TUCKER, DR. STEPHEN H.
description: TUCKER-Dr. Stephen H. Nine years ago you left us with broken hearts. Remembered with love. Mothe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEIG, OTTO J.
description: FLEIG-Otto J., 92, a longtime resident of Manhasset died peacefully at home after a long illness. A retired Naval Reserve Commander, his distinguished business career with Metropolitan Life Insurance Company spanned 44 years. At his retirement he was Senior Vice President and Treasurer. His wife Melicent predeceased him in May of 2000. He is survived by his daughter, Melissa Ann Fleig and a niece Nancy R. Lomnicki. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution in his name to the American Cancer Society, 839 Stewart Ave., Garden City, NY 11530 or to the Long Island Alzheimer's Association, 3281 Veterans Memorial Highway Suite E 13 Ronkonkama, NY 11779. A Memorial service will be held at the Congregational Church of Manhasset, 1845 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, New York on Saturday, July 13, 2002 at 11:00 AM.

title: Sophistication on a Stick
description: For graduates of the Good Humor truck, chefs around the city are molding ice pops for grown-up palates. Tentation, Potel & Chabot, a catering company whose clients include Prada, Burberry and Herms, brightens its cocktail parties with ice pops in flavor combos like lemon grass and ginger, blood orange and Grand Marnier and Midori melon and Campari (212-564-7530). Chicama (35 East 18th Street) offers a Tropi-pop made from pineapple, cardamom and parsley ($6 for three). The Round Bar at the Royalton Hotel (44 East 44th Street) serves a pop infused with the turquoise-colored liquor Hpnotiq ($10.50), as does Blue Fin (1567 Broadway), whose new Finsicle ($7) has a gummy fish suspended inside.

title: Mom, Apple Pie and Sweet Roasted Corn
description: THE Harbes family of Mattituck could be the poster family for the North Fork's swing from tilling for spuds to agritainment and agritourism. From their sprawling white lattice farm stand on Sound Avenue, Monica and Edward Harbes III and their eight children offer visitors sweet roasted corn and homemade lemonade along with a slice of bucolic life.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: NOT a shot is fired in SEVEN DAYS IN MAY (1964), but with its perfect pacing and strong performances the film delivers the kind of heart-pounding suspense that noisier thrillers can only dream of. Burt Lancaster is a power-hungry general so upset with a nuclear arms treaty that he plans a military coup, and Kirk Douglas, ramrod straight, is the colonel who unmasks the scheme. The best performance, though, comes from Edmond O'Brien as a hard-drinking senator who supports the president. The film still packs a punch thanks to Rod Serling's lean screenplay (based on the popular novel), but there's no mistaking that the story is three decades old: a subplot involving incriminating love letters seems downright quaint, and a sturdy cigarette case ultimately saves the nation -- Tuesday at 6 p.m. on TCM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKIRBALL, KENIS, AUDREY
description: SKIRBALL - KENIS - Audrey. The Board of Trustees, staff, docents, and volunteers of the Skirball Cultural Center express our deepest sorrow upon the death of our beloved friend and founding Trustee, Audrey Skirball-Kenis. With astounding verve and imagination, she made a difference in life wherever she ventured-not the least in her passionate pioneering and nourishing of the Skirball Cultural Center. In 1981, Audrey, with her beloved husband, Jack Skirball (1896-1985), provided the initial funding for the development of a new Skirball Cultural Center in Los Angeles, which opened to the public in 1996 and has since servednearly 3 million visitors. In all her philanthrophic endeavors through the Skirball Foundation, she and her husband, Charles Kenis whom she married in 1987 continued and built upon a life-long service to education and culture. Shehelped the Skirball Cultural Center shape itself as a Jewish institution in an American context. She lived the Skirball's mission, which is dedicated to reaching out to people of every ethnic and religious identity around the globe through its cultural programs, museum exhibitions, and communal initiatives. We will miss her and never see her like again. Howard I. Friedman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Uri D. Herscher Founding President & CEO Skirball Cultural Center

title: Iran By the Numbers
description: The most striking thing about Iran today is the honesty you can find in the newspapers. Some mornings, they take your breath away. Consider the mainstream paper Entekhab, which ran a long piece the other day, headlined ''Skyrocketing Figures,'' that ticked off the following statistics: There are now 84,000 prostitutes operating on the streets of Tehran and 250 brothels, including some linked to high officials. There are 60 new runaway girls hitting Tehran's streets every day -- a 12 percent increase over last year. Forty percent of all drug-addicted women in Iranian prisons have AIDS. Two sisters, ages 16 and 17, recently gave AIDS to 1,100 people in a two-month period. Four million youths under the age of 20 suffer from depression. Unemployment (which is already around 30 percent) is steadily rising.

title: 'Herman Melville'
description: The first volume of this biography ends with Herman Melville and Nathaniel Hawthorne in the dining room of the Little Red Inn at Lenox, Massachusetts, on an afternoon in mid-November 1851. There Melville had been holding his publication party for Moby-Dick, to which he had invited a single guest. The two authors had shocked Lenox by dining in public in a village where by custom the hotel was for guests only, and the indigenous yokels (according to a new resident) had taken turns peeking in at them, sure that the two most notoriously reclusive literary men in the county had perversely chosen this indecorous way of meeting each other instead of going to Melville's Arrowhead outside Pittsfield or Hawthorne's rented little red cottage outside Lenox. The local belles and beaux, the newcomer wrote some weeks later, had found long-lasting amusement in this peculiar attempt at acquaintanceship between such dissimilar men, the dour author of the Puritanic The Scarlet Letter and the free-and-easy Melville, author of Typee and Omoo, books which had made him the first American literary sex symbol. There, alone in the dining room after the hotel guests had dined, the two had lingered with the first presentation copy of Moby-Dick while Hawthorne accustomed himself to the astounding dedication: "In token of my admiration for his genius, This Book is Inscribed to Nathaniel Hawthorne." Afterward they had made their farewells, for Hawthorne, unknown to most of the townspeople, was leaving the Berkshires.

title: 'Napoleon: A Biography'
description: Napoleon Bonaparte was born at Ajaccio, Corsica, on 15 August 1769. Such a bald, even banal statement is necessary when we consider that every aspect of the man's life has been turned into the stuff of legend. In 1919 Archbishop Whateley tried to push beyond legend into myth by suggesting, tongue-in-cheek, in his Historic Doubts Relative to Napoleon Buonoparte , that Napoleon had never existed, that his was a proper name falsely attributed to the French people collectively. The psychologist Carl Gustav Jung, while accepting the reality of Napoleon's existence, argued that his significance was wholly collective and not individual: that he represented the resurgence from the depths of the French unconscious of the savage and irrational forces the Revolution had tried to suppress through the cult of Reason (Déesse Raison) .

title: QUICK BITE/West Paterson; Fresh Fruit That Showers in Chocolate
description: Chocolates typically take a back seat to ice cream and Popsicles when it comes to summertime sweets. But that might change if word gets out about Bromilow's seasonal specialty: chocolate-covered fresh fruits ($13 a pound, available through Sept. 30). Every morning, Bromilow's owner, Thomas Stewart, heads to a farmer's market to select the day's ripest fare. Strawberries and bananas go in his basket, along with pineapple, blueberries, oranges and grapes. Back at the store, the fruit is washed, peeled and sliced, then placed on the enrober, a conveyor belt that passes through a spray of milk chocolate -- ''like a chocolate waterfall,'' Mr. Stewart said. Whole strawberries are his best sellers, but my vote goes to the banana chunks. Besides fruit, there are also chocolate-covered Twinkies, Devil Dogs, Rice Krispies treats and potato chips ($12.50 a pound). With so many chocolates to choose from (44-year-old Bromilow's makes about 160 varieties), your best bet is to nibble your way through an assortment. Try some plantations (taffy center), sponges (honeycomb candy center) and meltaways (flavored chocolate center). Add a few creams and truffles, some chocolate-covered dried fruits, and of course the store's signature butter crunch, toffee covered in chocolate and rolled in Brazil nuts. If stored away from heat and moisture, the chocolates have a good shelf life, but the fresh fruits must be eaten the day of purchase. Somehow, that's never a problem in my house. Gretchen Kurtz

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON BERNUTH, CHARLES M.
description: von BERNUTH-Charles M. Of Lyford Cay, Bahamas, passed away on May 25, 2002, at the age of 89. Beloved husband of the late Eloise Fiamingo. He was educated in the U.S. and Switzerland, and joined the family business, Bernuth Lembcke Co of NY, creosote importers and a shipping company. During WWII, originally he was a Calvary officer in the U.S. Army at Ft. Riley, KS, and later was recruited as a Captain into the O.S.S, where he was awarded the Silver Star for bravery in action. At war's end he returned to the family business, retiring in 1962, when he moved with his family to Rome, Italy, living there for over 30 years. A superb horseman, horses were the center of his life. He trained horses, judged at the National Horse Show, played polo at Meadowbrook with the very greats, receiving honorable mention; he just genuinely loved horses. He was a world traveler visiting all seven continents with his late wife, multi-lingual, multitalented, a writer, actor, dancer, composer-lyricist, skier, yachtsman, leatherworker, even conquering the unicycle. Actively involved in community affairs, he was a member of Squadron A, The Sleepy Hollow Country Club and The Lyford Cay Club. On the human side there are no superlatives to adequately describe his dignity, his charm, his honesty, his generosity, his humor. Elegant and stunningly handsome with all the social graces, he lived a wondrous and joyous life. He is survived by his first wife Shirley Paige Bernuth, their four children, Antonia Cook, Ticia Agri, Victoria Bernuth and Charles P. von Bernuth, four grandchildren, his nephews, Ernest P. Bernuth Jr. and James T. Bernuth and his neice Barbara King, his loving friend Dorothy Kohler, together with a host of other adoring friends. Memorial www.charlesvonbernuth .com.

description: Jean Marie Mink, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Mink Jr. of Ardsley, N.Y., was married yesterday to Barry Griffith King III, a son of Dr. and Mrs. King Jr. of El Paso, Tex. The Rev. Douglas L. Trees, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Andrew's Dune Road Church in Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Robert Benson, a United Church of Christ minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: If the Chair Fits (or Challenges), Settle In and Listen
description: ON a weekday afternoon last month, three 10-year-old girls were hanging out at the Langston Hughes Community Library and Cultural Center in Corona,, Queens, talking about capital punishment. They had just spent an hour with the installation ''A Chair Is a Throne Is a Freedom Fighter's Camp Stool,'' moving from seat to seat and listening on headsets to stories on CD's. Chair No. 17 represents an electric chair, and the sound track tells of a young man who, in 1946, simply would not die from electrocution. Spurred by this bit of history, the girls debated the execution of the Oklahoma City bomber, Timothy McVeigh, last year.

title: Music Listings
description: Classical/Opera

title: Hurting More, Helping Less?
description: DR. CHRISTINE MIASKOWSKI still remembers the patient, a woman in her 50's, who visited the pain management service at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, where Dr. Miaskowski worked in the 1980's. The woman was suffering from a burning, prickling pain -- punctuated by shooting spasms -- of a kind that tends to strike after breast cancer surgery, when the incision has healed and patients look outwardly fine.

title: Stacey Garsson, Brian Schwartz
description: Stacey Hillary Garsson, the daughter of Eileen R. Garsson of Graniteville, Staten Island, and the late Bertrand A. Garsson, was married last evening to Dr. Brian David Schwartz, a son of Carole and Irwin Schwartz of Jericho, N.Y. Rabbi Louis Stein performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, N.Y.

title: U.N. Finds AIDS Knowledge Still Lags in Stricken Nations
description: The largest global study of AIDS awareness ever compiled by the United Nations has found that most people in developing nations have now heard of the disease but that a significant number have only limited knowledge of how to avoid it.

title: Private Sector; A Banker in a Land of Risks
description: GALIA MAOR, chief executive of Israel's Leumi Group, had a tough time in New York earlier this month celebrating the banking company's 100th anniversary at Cipriani 42nd Street, where dinner guests were serenaded by Itzhak Perlman, the violinist.

title: Menopause Forever
description: ON April 15, eight million Americans tuned into ''The Oprah Winfrey Show,'' as they do every weekday as sure as the sun rises.

title: A New Drug Demographic: Supermoms
description: DRUG specialists are reporting an unsettling trend of late: the growing ranks of women who are selling and abusing methamphetamines. And they are not just any women. According to the people who counsel these abusers, a startling number of them are middle-class working moms who are trying to top off their energy so they can make it through a working mom's day.

title: Up From Rags, With Distractions
description: MY FAIR LADY remains an everflowing model of musical theater's taste, class and joy and -- some would rightfully say -- a tragic reminder of what an ideal musical once was.

title: Needles Have Made Way for Cupid's Arrow
description: It was a cloudless day at Bryant Park. Petunias were in full bloom. Yellow-breasted songbirds were grooming their feathers. But few people seemed to notice.

title: A Tale of One City
description: THE WEATHER IN BERLIN

title: Hysteria, Hysteria
description: It would have been interesting to hear theories on why there is such resistance to accepting a diagnosis of psychogenic illness. Why are people so afraid of the possibility that the most important organ of the body, the brain, can control the physical manifestations of illness? Why does this fear seem to be getting worse over the years? Is it our immediate-gratification-oriented world, where everything must be resolved before the TV episode ends or the H.M.O. refuses to pay?

title: June 16-22: THE COURTS; DOG CASE
description: A California judge threw out the unprecedented murder conviction of a woman, Marjorie Knoller, whose dog mauled a neighbor to death in January 2000, letting stand involuntary manslaughter convictions against her and her husband, Robert Noel. The judge sentenced Mr. Noel, 60, to the maximum four years in prison but delayed sentencing for Ms. Knoller until July 15 to allow stunned prosecutors to file motions asking him to reconsider. The San Francisco district attorney said his office might seek a new trial. Evelyn Nieves

title: Israeli Military Advances Into More of the West Bank; Plans a 'Crushing' Response
description: Israeli ground forces moved into a Palestinian village outside the West Bank city of Hebron today, acting after the Israeli security cabinet endorsed a plan to seize and hold Palestinian-controlled territory until Palestinian attacks ceased.

title: Footlights
description: The Youngest Docents

title: Critics Say Regents English Tests Push Immigrants to Drop Out
description: Regents tests that were meant to encourage high statewide standards are so frustrating to students who are not fluent in English that a third of them are dropping out of high school, according to two groups that advocate for immigrant children.

title: In Afghanistan, Where Pregnancy Is Still a Minefield
description: WOMEN cluster around the gate, crouching on the ground, their heavy veils pushed back from their faces. Waiting for news of their relatives inside the maternity wards, they jostle urgently to beg a foreign visitor for help. Inside the hospital, heavily pregnant women wait silently in a dingy outpatient room, their faces stoic and calm.

title: Ann Marie Rousseau, Duvall Hecht
description: Ann Marie Celeste Rousseau and Duvall Young Hecht were married yesterday at the Sofitel New York by Justice Richard F. Braun of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Movies Opening on June 28
description: HE CEDAR BAR"  Alfred Leslie's documentary is about the artists and critics who frequented this New York City barroom in the 1950s. (No rating) (1:24) Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Ave. at Second St. (212-505-5181) Opens Opens June 27, through July 3

description: When Val Skinner took an active role in the fight against breast cancer, her peers on the L.P.G.A. Tour were eager to help.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, FLORA
description: LEWIS-Flora. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Flora Lewis, associated with The Times from 1972 until retiring in 1991.

title: INSIDE
description: 500 Die in Iran Earthquake

title: Jenifer Coleman, Matthew Gorin
description: Jenifer Suzanne Coleman and Matthew Brad Gorin were married last evening by Rabbi Alvin Wainhaus at the New Haven Lawn Club in Connecticut.

title: June 16-22: SPORTS; SOCCER DREAMS
description: The surprising U.S. advance in the World Cup ended with a loss to Germany, which beat the U.S. in the last World Cup. Then, the U.S. team finished last; this time, it battled to the quarterfinals, its best showing ever.

title: In Troubled Teenagers' Corner
description: GERRY COONEY knows what it is like to be on the canvas. He also knows how to get back up after a crushing blow. Now the former fighter is preparing to teach troubled teenagers here how to box in a program aimed at imparting bigger lessons.

title: Two People Are Killed in a Brooklyn Accident
description: Two people were killed and at least six others were injured last night in a motor vehicle accident near the Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: 'The Fourth Star'
description: The fourth day of the new millennium. But to the chefs and captains at Daniel, the line cooks and dishwashers, the sommeliers and maitre d's and bakers and office assistants and reservationists and publicists and runners and busboys, it's business as usual. Behind them: the $650-a-head four-course New Year's Eve millennial gala dinner they turned out five nights earlier; before them, 354 covers: a busy Thursday night.

title: Letters
description: The Top 12

title: An Iconoclast's Last Days on His Late-Night Soapbox
description: JUST before ''Politically Incorrect'' joined the ABC late-night lineup in 1997, its host, Bill Maher, got a call from a venerated television newsman whose program would be preceding his five nights a week.

title: Waiting for the Raging Waters to Subside in Maine
description: The Androscoggin River was a tumult of white water as we drove beside it on Route 16 on our way to Errol in early June, and the usual clusters of trout fishermen's vehicles parked at various pools were not to be seen. It was obvious that the river was too high to fish successfully and I wondered what we would encounter the next day when we canoed across Lake Umbagog to the Maine shore and the Rapid River.

title: Growth Industry
description: FAIRWEATHER GARDENS is a rare specimen. It has a discerning clientele from all over the country, which orders plants from its eclectic catalog, a tour de force with offerings that vary from hardy agapanthus (African lilies) to sea buckthorn from Northern Europe and Russia.

title: Private Sector; For a Soccer Star, Many Options. (Just Don't Show Up in Perugia.)
description: The South Korean soccer star Ahn Jung Hwan may not be able to return to his team in Perugia, Italy, after infuriating the Italians by scoring the winning goal against their World Cup team, but he has no reason for concern.

title: You Get the Ideas
description: BRING OUT

title: In Following a Dream, A Bit of Reality Helps
description: THE success stories are enticing: Lawyer chucks it all to become a circus clown. Investment banker moves to Tuscany to grow olives, get a life. Hard-driving high-tech manager opens an ostrich farm, lives happily ever after.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Franka Potente; In the U.S., Lola Strolls
description: SAY what you will about Franka Potente, the lanky, flame-haired frulein who sprinted her way into Hollywood with the film ''Run Lola Run,'' becoming the first German star since Marlene Dietrich to turn heads on Sunset Boulevard, but she plays one tough game.

title: Playing Catch-Up With the Mobsters
description: LIKE Tony Soprano standing with his back to the sun, his bulk enveloping everything in front of him in darkness, the shadow cast by ''The Sopranos'' over everything else on cable television is vast and daunting.

title: June 16-22: NATIONAL; WHITE-COLLAR CRACKDOWN
description: In a warning that top executives may be subject to criminal trials for corporate wrongs, the S.E.C. and Justice leveled criminal as well as civil charges at three former executives and one current

description: I ARRIVE on time. I have always been punctual, even after living for 20 years in New York, a town that insists you arrive late.

title: Abigail Patner, Charles Glassenberg
description: Abigail Jane Patner, a daughter of Myra Mensh Patner and Bruce D. Patner of Potomac, Md., is to be married today to Charles Samuel Glassenberg, the son of Judith A. Glassenberg and Albert B. Glassenberg of New London, Conn. Rabbi Wesley Gardenswartz will perform the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Newton, Mass.

title: Editors' Note
description: The What's Doing article on Page 10 of the Travel section today, about Kansas City, includes a restaurant listing for the Cafe Allegro. After the section had gone to press, the owner said the cafe would close next Sunday.

title: For the True Reader, No Shortcuts
description: To the Editor:

title: Nice Guys Finish . . .
description: Consider, if you will, the conceit that every athlete has a Platonic injury: the young Michael Jordan bangs his head on the rim, Mark McGwire smacks himself in the back after a mammoth swing, Anna Kournikova trips over a courtside photographer.

title: A Producer That Even a Playwright Could Love
description: WHEN Robert Whitehead was honored with a lifetime achievement award at the Tony ceremonies three weeks ago tonight, the pride and pleasure I felt for him were circumscribed. I knew Robert was dying.

title: Americans Win The Nations' Cup
description: Craig Johnson of Gainesville, Tex., riding Sailing Smart, and Dell Hendricks of Tioga, Tex., astride Dunnit in Hollywood, both posted scores of 223.5 points yesterday to lead the United States equestrian team to victory in the Nations' Cup for reining horses at the team's Festival of Champions in Gladstone, N.J.

title: That Said
description: 'The South Carolina primary between Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain in 2000,'' wrote Eleanor Randolph, the New York Times editorialist, referring to Representative Lindsey Graham's current campaign for the Senate, ''left Republicans in his state bitter and divided. That said, both President Bush and Senator McCain have already campaigned for his election to the Senate.''

title: Swing Time
description: DOGS BARK, BUT THE CARAVAN ROLLS ON

title: Era of the Big Fire Is Kindled at West's Doors
description: The fires came early this year to the West, chasing people out of valleys in Colorado, rousting animals from late slumber in Alaska, choking the sky with smoke in Arizona woods that have so little moisture they seem kiln-dried.

title: Gazeteer
description: 4-bedroom, 3-bath ranch at 16 College Drive, $319,000.

title: Executive Life; Corporate Protection In a Violent World
description: MORE than 10 years ago, says a former vice president of a Fortune 500 company, he was called in to fire an employee who had been caught stealing. As the executive remembers it, he flew to the branch where the man worked and gave him the bad news; the employee went home, got a shotgun and started back to the office. His girlfriend called in a panic and alerted the executive, who then requested a police escort to the airport and sneaked out the basement.

title: Calling In the Pain Team, Specialists in Suffering
description: ONE winter morning when I was a second-year medical resident, a nurse paged me during rounds. A patient with leukemia that had transformed into what was called blast crisis, was in her room, screaming. She had been on a morphine drip to control the severe pain in her bones -- her bone marrow was churning out leukemia cells at a prodigious rate -- but her IV had fallen out. Could I come quickly and put in another one?

title: Elaine Huie, Ti-Hua Chang
description: Elaine Huie, a fashion designer, and Ti-Hua Chang, a television news reporter for WNBC, are to be married today at Oheka Castle, the Otto Kahn house in Cold Spring Hills, N.Y. The Rev. Danny Ho, an evangelical Christian minister, will officiate.

title: Financial Safety Nets For Chief Executives
description: To the Editor:

title: Tempting Students Away From Screens
description: SCHOOLS across Long Island may be closing for vacation, but the books are likely to remain open. That's because high school teachers, eager for their students to read something more challenging this summer than comic books and instant messages, are assigning vacation reading.

title: Doubts on Mammograms Do Not Affect Their Use
description: IN October last year, the medical journal The Lancet published a study asserting that mammograms do not save lives and, in fact, cause many women to undergo painful and unnecessary treatments. Because this news directly challenged orthodox belief, the community of breast cancer experts and advocates was thrown into turmoil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, MARY
description: O'CONNOR-Mary, 93. Of Kilreal Co. Kerry Ireland. Mother of John J. O'Connor Jr. and the late Eileen Ziek, Jeramiah, Maureen Mitchell, Anna Rita Kovack, and Arthur. Visiting will be Monday and Tuesday from 2-5 and 7-9 p.m. at Castle Hill Funeral Home, 1528 Castle Hill Ave., Bronx (718) 828-9222. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday morning at 9:45 A.M. at St. Raymond's Church, Bronx. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: How to Lose $850 Million -- and Not Really Care
description: As an owner of 24,000 shares of eToys in my retirement plan, I can report that the company's bankruptcy has resulted in my need to work a few years longer than I had hoped. Michael Sokolove's article (Money 2002, June 9) on Toby Lenk, the founder of eToys, confirmed that my anger over eToys' demise was correctly directed at Wall Street investment banks and analysts, along with venture-capital firms that made a quick buck and pulled the rug out from under a great company and a great idea.

title: Older Academics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Family Life: Making Ices Since 1930
description: THE man they used to call Joe Slush doesn't want the publicity. There is really no story, he says. He's just a guy with a big family who has spent summers since 1930 making and selling ices at Vecchitto's Froze-Rite, some in Middletown, some at Sound View Beach in Old Lyme, bottom line. And it's strictly 100 percent family, that's all. What else is there to know?

title: Suffolk Needs to Guard Its Open Spaces
description: A June 9 letter assailing resistance to a plan to build a Y.M.C.A. in a county park near Riverhead gets it all wrong. The assertion that ''we have in Suffolk County more parkland and open space than anywhere else,'' is nonsense. Has the writer never visited the Adirondacks nor the Catskills? Long Island is a national model of suburban sprawl.

title: Marisa Pearl, Luke O'Byrne
description: Marisa Lauren Pearl, a daughter of Carol B. Pearl of New York and Dr. Richard E. Pearl of Roslyn, N.Y., was married yesterday to Luke Christopher O'Byrne, a son of Dr. Natalie K. O'Byrne and William F. O'Byrne of San Anselmo, Calif. Rabbi Jerry Winston officiated at the home of Robert J. Kwasneski, the bridegroom's uncle, in Kenwood, Calif.

title: A Sophisticated White
description: Drawing on North Shore sauvignon blanc vines planted in 1975 -- some of the East End's oldest -- Larry Perrine has created one of his most sophisticated white wines since the founding of Channing Daughters, a South Shore winery, in 1997.

title: Undreamed of Surprises And a Lot of Other Stuff
description: THE title of the summer exhibition at the Wadsworth Atheneum, ''The Stuff of Dream,'' might allude to a line in ''A Midsummer-Night's Dream.'' It also makes one ponder the word stuff, one of the most overused words in the language. It's one of the wonders of the exhibition that the word can be applied to a collection of grand and rarefied objects that make an incredibly vivid history lesson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, BETTY J.
description: BERNSTEIN-Betty J. On June 20, 2002. Beloved sister of Morry, Seymour and Pearl. Survived by her brother Ira and sister Hilda, devoted nieces, nephews and cousins. Services today, June 23, 2002, 11 AM, at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, corner 91 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Visit to Toy Store Caps A Lesson on Careers
description: Everyone's workday should end so well.

title: The Nation; Death Row: Faces Behind a Reprieve
description: THERE are 455 people on death row in Texas, which has executed 272 people since 1982. Most of the condemned are held at the Polunsky Unit, a prison in Livingston. Somewhere between 20 and 50 of them are estimated to be mentally retarded.

title: Anne Kelligrew and David St. Clair
description: Anne Ringwood Kelligrew, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Kelligrew of North Eastham, Mass., was married yesterday to David Alexander St. Clair, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David W. St. Clair of Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Stanley E. Johnson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Siasconset Union Chapel on Nantucket Island in Massachusetts. The Rev. Paul Caron, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: It's Office Picnic Time. Are You Having Fun Yet?
description: There's no such thing as a free lunch. That saying has many applications, of course, and one of them may well be to company picnics. Intended to foster good will and camaraderie, they sometimes take a turn for the bizarre, leaving the impression that when it comes to picnics, maybe only the ants have a good time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINER, THOMAS MATLACK
description: MINER - Thomas Matlack. Died June 12, 2002 in Sarasota, FL. He was born January 21, 1922 in New York City.

title: The Work Force Is There. It Just Needs a Company.
description: When a company shuts down an operation, the affected employees are likely to scatter as they look for work elsewhere. But not the 360 employees of FCI Electronics in Clearfield, Pa., who were told last spring that their jobs would be cut in October when a plant in the town closes.

title: Jennifer Alfieri, Steven Frank
description: Jennifer Anne Alfieri, a daughter of Dominick Alfieri of New Vernon, N.J., and the late Eileen Alfieri, was married yesterday to Steven Mark Frank, a son of Marilyn and Gordon Frank of Teaneck, N.J. Msgr. John Corr officiated at the summer home of the bride's father on Nantucket Island in Massachusetts. Rabbi Richard Messing took part in the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about racial segregation on Long Island misspelled the surname of a white Garden City woman shown with a black neighbor who lives across the border in Hempstead. The Garden City woman is Rhonda Kraff, not Kraft.

title: Private Sector; From Fossil Fuels to Solar Panels
description: Robert C. Stempel spent the bulk of his career selling a very traditional power source: the internal combustion engine. But since his resignation as General Motors' chief executive nearly 10 years ago, his energy has gone into more environmentally friendly alternatives. Tomorrow, he dives even deeper into that realm by inaugurating the world's largest solar panel factory.

title: Jennifer Muller and Hayes Tauber
description: Jennifer Elizabeth Muller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Muller Jr. of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday evening to Hayes Douglas Tauber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Yale D. Tauber of New Canaan, Conn. Cantor Kerry Ben David officiated at Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. James Borstelmann, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Soft Money Ban Goes Into Effect, but the Effect Is Uncertain
description: The Federal Election Commission approved rules today that will put into effect provisions of the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law intended to ban national parties and candidates from raising and spending unrestricted ''soft money'' from corporations, labor unions and wealthy individuals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATWOOD, GERALD T.
description: ATWOOD-Gerald T. Tragically and heroically in the line of duty with his brothers of ladder 21 at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Beloved son of Gerald and Elaine (nee Kenny). Loving husband of Barbara (nee Swat). Devoted father of Gerald J., Margaret M. and Robert T. Dear brother of John, Jane Duffy, Raymond, Gregory and Elaine. Funeral Thursday, 11 AM, from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd, Bklyn. Memorial Mass 12 PM, at Good Shepherd R.C. Church. Memorial interment service to follow at Holy Cross Cemetery. Memorial visitation Tuesday & Wednesday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 10 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations in Gerald's memory can be made to: New York Firefighters Burn Center Foundation c/o Ladder 61, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, NY 10475.

title: Stacey Watkins, Robert Burton Jr.
description: Stacey Jane Watkins, the daughter of Linda Jane McConnell and Charles B. Watkins, both of Naperville, Ill., was married yesterday to Robert Gene Burton Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Sr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Robert Naylor performed the ceremony at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich.

title: Karzai, Seeking Ethnic Balance, Names Minister to Lead Police
description: Afghanistan's new interior minister took control of the nation's police force today, in the first test of strength for President Hamid Karzai since he won a new mandate from the country's grand council last week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ISSEKS, MURRAY
description: ISSEKS-Murray Dearest Daddy, the years cannot dim the memories of a most beautiful man who always wore a smile both outside and in. How very much I miss you. Your Joyce

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a biographical sketch last Sunday about James M. Roux, a lawyer from Portland, Me., who died on a plane that struck the World Trade Center, misidentified the piece of fishing equipment he used to transport food on a clothesline to his apartment from a restaurant next door. It was a creel  a basket for holding fish  not a reel.

title: Art Becomes an Instrument to Unearth Buried History
description: AT night on a heaving sea off the shore here, the Morris Island lighthouse seems to walk on water. Its sand spit is sinking and so is the post-Civil War lighthouse. At high tide the island disappears, and a needle of brick appears to float upright in a foaming blackness.

title: DREDGING PLANS
description: Governor McGreevey last week announced plans to dredge shipping lanes in Newark Bay, Port Jersey and Arthur Kill channels. To serve larger ships, the lanes will be dredged to a depth of 50 feet, from their present depth of about 35 feet. The $2.3 billion project, expected to take eight years, could begin this summer. State officials said that contaminated silt would be treated and used for construction or capping landfills and that clean silt would be dumped at sea. Jeremy Pearce

title: Larger Loss for Astacio Came Before the Game
description: Pedro Astacio found a quiet place in Shea Stadium after hearing about the death of a friend yesterday afternoon. Mets teammates would pass by and Astacio, his eyes red, would accept their condolences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, JOHN HARRIS
description: NELSON-John Harris. Age 63, of Manchester-by-the-Sea, MA, died June 20th, 2002. Beloved father of Andrea Abbott and Trevor Nelson. Adoring grandfather of McLeod, Conrad, Lyric, and George. A graduate of St. Mark's School, Southborough, MA, and of Harvard College. He possessed a deep passion for literature, music, philosophy, and the history of art. His was a dazzling mind and he will be forever remembered as a dear and gentle soul. A memorial service will be held at 11:30 AM on June 26th at Emmanuel Chapel, Masconomo Street, Manchester-by-the-Sea, MA.

title: The Wasteland
description: ''A probation officer adopts the child from one of her cases.'' -- In the Echo''

title: Lynn Feldman, Joseph Lowy
description: Lynn Rachel Feldman, a lawyer, and Dr. Joseph Lowy, a pulmonary and critical care specialist, are to be married this evening. Rabbi Alfredo Borodowski will officiate at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: Out of the Park
description: FOR more than a decade, the residents surrounding Carteret Park here lived with orange fences, construction trucks, torn-up fields and other daily reminders that they were living on one of the state's most infamous Superfund sites. Unfortunately, the area was built on landfill contaminated with radioactive waste from an early-20th-century watch-dial factory.

title: Shellfish, Year Round
description: The fresh, briny flavors of raw bars are particularly welcome in summer, when appetites turn to cool, lighter fare. Thanks to air freight, good oysters can be found in New York in any month, not just those that contain an r.

title: Eluding Family Ties As He Hunts For Stars
description: BILLY BUSH, the relentlessly gregarious first cousin of President Bush and currently the East Coast correspondent for the entertainment news program ''Access Hollywood,'' is looking over a fax from his producer in Los Angeles. It's the script for an introduction to Mr. Bush's interview with the singer of Korn, a band known for a raucous power-chord-crammed brand of depresso-rock. The segment's angle is that with its new album, Korn has gone soft. Mr. Bush is reading the script aloud when all of a sudden he seizes up. Korn's latest, the producer has written, is ''kinder, gentler.'' The script might as well have begun ''Read my lips.''

title: Elizabeth Kelly and Ronald Rossetti Jr.
description: Elizabeth Jean Kelly and Ronald Louis Rossetti Jr. were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert B. Curry at Grace Congregational United Church of Christ in Rutland, Vt. The Rev. W. Andre Houle, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Stacey Pashcow, Paul Gardi
description: Stacey Lee Pashcow, a daughter of Adrienne Brezel Harris of Huntington, N.Y., and Joel Pashcow of Great Neck, N.Y., was married on Thursday evening to Paul Jonathan Gardi, the son of Sylvia and George Gardi of Miami. Rabbi Marc Schneier officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Stourhead Vistas
description: To the Editor: Gary Krist's article on the gardens at Stourhead, ''In England, a Tranquil Landscape by Design'' (June 9), recalled a family visit many years ago. On the one hand, Stourhead's Pantheon, Temple to Apollo, and ''descent to the underworld'' struck us as slightly ersatz; and indeed, as Mr. Krist points out, even Stourhead's landscape is cunningly designed.

title: The Nation: Preservation; It Depends On How You Define 'Real'
description: IN December 1999, the worst storm in French history swept through Versailles, uprooting trees by the thousands and ravaging the great Baroque gardens. Since then the site has been a horticultural emergency room. But rather than just repair the gardens, their custodians have decided on something more audacious: recreate the original designs of Andr Le Ntre and return the gardens to their 17th-century splendor. Nothing could seem more reasonable, yet already the project has been greeted with controversy and dismay.

title: Striking First
description: For the past half-century, American military planning has proceeded from the assumption that the United States would respond quickly to aggression but would not be the first to strike. Now the Bush administration is arguing that such a purely defensive policy has become outdated in an age of international terrorism, rogue states and unconventional weapons. With one eye on Iraq, the White House is preparing a new national security strategy that would justify launching pre-emptive military campaigns against groups or nations that the president believes pose the threat of a future attack against America or its allies.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: By the (History) Book

title: Musical Magic From an Isle of Noises
description: TO whom does music belong? More particularly, to whom does folk music belong -- not as property but as a free, fresh language of expression?

title: Drag Racer Found Guilty for Role in Fatal Crash
description: Ajury convicted a drag racer on Long Island of two counts of manslaughter for his role in a race in which a rival driver crashed, killing himself and the driver of a third car.

title: Jennifer Jordan, James McCall
description: Jennifer Bennett Jordan and James Wilson McCall were married yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. William R. Phillippe performed the ceremony.

title: Q. & A.
description: Cycling in Northern Ireland

title: Just Around the Next Curve Lurks a $2.6 Billion Question
description: EVERY rush hour, morning and evening, traffic backs up for miles through Morristown as commuters jockey and cram their way through the long-outdated interchange linking Interstate 287 and Route 24.

title: A Montreal Feast For Jazz Gluttons
description: THE bookers of the Montreal International Jazz Festival -- whose 23rd annual edition starts on Thursday and runs through July 7 -- think like jazz gluttons. Montreal's may be the biggest jazz festival in the world, the reasoning goes, so it ought to have a bit everything.
