title: Paying for Condo's New Parking Gate
description: Q I own a unit in a condominium. The building has 70 apartments, one superintendent and an adjoining outdoor parking lot with 36 spots. Each parking space is owned by a unit owner and carries a common charge of $10 over and above the monthly housing common charge. The lot is accessible from the street through a remote-controlled gate. Only owners of parking spots have the ability to enter and leave the lot via the gate. Our board recently decided to have the gate replaced, with the money coming out of the condominium's funds. Since parking-spot owners pay a separate charge for their spaces, shouldn't the cost of a new gate come out of the parking-lot fund rather than the housing common charge? Since I do not own a parking spot, why should a portion of my monthly common charges be used to replace the gate? . . . Lisa Manatrizio, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASKELL, MARY DELAFIELD FINCH
description: HASKELL-Mary Delafield Finch. 87, beloved wife of the late Col. Francis W. Hask ell, died at her home in McLean, Virginia on Thursday, June 20. Called ''Noelle'' because she was born on Christmas Day, 1914, she was a graduate of the Nightingale-Bamford School in New York City and member of the Colonial Dames of America. She was the daughter of the Hon. Edward Ridley Finch, a judge on the Court of Appeals of New York State and Mary Livingston Delafield. She was a descendent of Chancellor Robert Livingston who administered the oath of office to George Washington. Mrs. Haskell is survived by her two sons, the Rev. Robert Finch Haskell of Oneonta, New York and Dr. Samuel Delafield Haskell of Douglassville, Georgia; by four grandchildren, Matthew Ridley Haskell, John Wyatt Haskell, Elizabeth Herbert Haskell and Lucy Livingston Haskell; and by her sister, Anne Crane Finch Cox, and her brother, the Hon. Edward Ridley Finch, Jr., both of New York City and Westhampton Beach, New York. Services will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church in McLean, Virginia on Monday, June 24 at 5 PM and at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Westhampton Beach, New York on Monday, July 1 at 11 AM.

title: DROUGHT RESTRICTIONS EASED
description: With reservoirs now at 92 percent of capacity in the northeastern part of the state, the state last week said it would allow residents of Bergen, Hudson, Passaic, Essex and Morris Counties to water their lawns. The state's environmental commissioner, Bradley Campbell, said that statewide, residents whose address ends with an even number can water on even-numbered days and those with an odd number can water on odd-numbered days. The northeast had been the only region totally to ban lawn watering. The state also now allows odd-even watering of shrubs and trees, and the washing of decks and houses as needed. Residents may now wash cars, only on weekends and only with a bucket and sponge. The drought emergency has not been lifted, Mr. Campbell noted. Jeremy Pearce

title: How to Prepare for a Smallpox Attack
description: We suspect that many Americans were as disappointed as we were by an expert committee's recommendation that smallpox vaccine be made available only to those expected to respond to a bioterror attack and not to the general public. Yes, we know the vaccine can occasionally cause disastrous side effects and might kill hundreds and injure thousands should everyone in the nation take it. Yes, we know that the risk of a terrorist attack using smallpox is considered small and thus perhaps not worth the risk of taking the vaccine. Even so, we believe that Americans should be able to make that judgment for themselves.

title: June 16-22: NEW YORK CITY; PARKS SUIT

But few questioned his dedication to the 1,700 parks, playgrounds and recreation facilities his agency operated. Now, a serious issue is being raised about how the department was run. The federal government is suing, accusing the department of discriminating against black and Hispanic workers by favoring whites for promotions for the past seven years. Mr. Stern, who resigned this year, early in the Bloomberg administration, said city lawyers asked that he not comment. The new administration, surprised by the suit, said that it had taken the department in ''a new direction.'' Benjamin Weiser

title: Registering the 9/11 Dead
description: Felix Martinez: ''My husband Jose worked in one of those very huge buildings. He called my cousin in Chicago when the planes hit. He tried to talk, but my cousin heard an explosion. Two days later, I left my four children and went to look for Jose, thinking New York was like here, a small town with shacks. I don't even understand how I did it; I can't read or write. I went to a coyote, and he crossed me over. Once I was in New York, I met a woman who helped me. She was from Puebla, near me, and said I could live with her because she didn't have a husband, either. She told me that it was going to be difficult to find Jose because people here don't know each other, so I told her I wanted a job so I could make money to return to my country. My daughter, Wendy Daniela, was born on Jan. 25 in Brooklyn. Now we're back home in Zaragoza. The baby makes me feel closer to him, but it's not the same.''

title: Milbury Makes Trades During Draft's First Day
description: Islanders General Manager Mike Milbury did not make any major trades today during the first session of the National Hockey League draft. One of them hinted at something significant to come through trades or free-agent signings.

title: 'Napoleon'
description: Few individuals have had more impact on history than Napoleon Bonaparte. He is the grandest possible refutation of those determinists who hold that events are governed by forces, classes, economics, and geography rather than by the powerful wills of men and women. Though Bonaparte exercised power only for a decade and a half, his impact on the future lasted until nearly the end of the twentieth century, almost two hundred years after his death. Indeed, his influence may not yet be spent. People love reading about him and his spectacular rise, just as in Roman and medieval times they read about Alexander. And they ponder the question: Might I, in comparable circumstances, have done as well? Few persons of ambition have failed to see Bonaparte as an exemplar or a spur. It is significant how many of those who exercise various forms of power, and wish for moremedia tycoons, for examplehave decked their offices or even their persons with Napoleonic memorabilia.

title: The Roses of Brooklyn
description: On June 11, 350 guests gathered at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden for its annual benefit gala, which began at sunset in the Cranford Rose Garden and raised $300,000. All 5,000 bushes, with their 1,200 varieties of roses, a few from the original 1927 planting, were in the prime of their blossom. In the midst of this explosion of color was the apothecary rose, which became the Red Rose of Lancaster, the oldest rose in continuous cultivation, going back beyond the year 1310 in Europe. Many guests promenaded through the rose garden in flower prints, picture hats and insect jewelry. Cocktails were served in the latticework pavilion and under the Doric pergolas, all smothered in pink climbing roses.

title: Hysteria, Hysteria
description: Margaret Talbot (June 2) did a wonderfully sensitive job of educating readers about psychogenic illness. In my psychiatric practice, I have had, on occasion, patients who have symptoms -- commonly pain -- that have been worked up to no avail. It is my job to introduce to them the idea that their symptoms may be psychogenic in origin. The article shows how sensitive people are to these implications. Talbot makes a statement toward the end of her article that I plan to use with my patients. title: 'Dogs Bark, but the Caravan Rolls On'
description: In 1968 a pal of mine who worked for The New Yorker was sent to cover the Democratic convention in Chicago. During the infamous police riots he was struck two or three times by a cop with a nightstick, and when he managed to get back to his hotel he found himself pissing blood. He eventually recovered, wrote his piece and left out the attack on himself. "Michael," I asked my always elegantly dressed, highly polite friend, "how could you leave it out? You weren’t protesting. It shows the scope of the violence. It’s important." He respectfully disagreed. "I wasn’t sent to write about myself," he said, with a certain amount of hauteur. New Journalism was in the air back then—an approach in which the observer was taken to be as important, or more important, than the stuff observed (Tom Wolfe, for instance, writing about auto shows, well before taking on the more ambitious role of American Balzac). The New Yorker frowned on New Journalism. People took sides. I never did, whether from laziness or a reluctance to box myself in, I don’t know. I dealt with each piece I wrote as seemed appropriate at the time.

title: 'The Dream of Scipio'
description: JULIEN BARNEUVE died at 3:28 on the afternoon of August 18, 1943. It had taken him twenty-three minutes exactly to die, the time between the fire starting and his last breath being sucked into his scorched lungs. He had not known his life was going to end that day, although he suspected it might happen. It was a brutal fire, which took hold swiftly and spread rapidly. From the moment it started Julien knew it would never be brought under control, that he would be consumed along with everything around. He didn't struggle, didn't try to escape; it could not be done. The fire ravaged the house—his mother's old house, where he had always felt most at ease, and where he always thought he had done his best work. He couldn't blame those nearby; any sort of rescue would have been foolhardy. Besides, he wanted no assistance and was content with the privacy they had granted him. Eight minutes between the fire starting and his collapsing into unconsciousness from the smoke. Another three minutes before the fire reached him and began to make his clothes smoke and skin bubble. Twenty-three minutes in all until his heart gave out, his breath stopped. Another hour until the fire finally burned itself out and the last charred rafters crashed to the floor over his body. But to Barneuve, as his thoughts broke into pieces and he stopped trying to hold them together, it seemed to have taken very much longer than that.

title: A New Leaf
description: During the early 20th century, when visionary European painters revolutionized art through Cubism, Futurism, Neo-Plasticism and Suprematism, type and typography were as much a part of change as brush and paint. Graphic design was employed in an assault on antiquated and official art and literature. Pass decorative motifs were rejected in favor of unbridled expression rooted in geometric and abstract composition. Radical formal concepts were further conveyed in books, magazines and posters through unconventional, indeed taboo, methods of page layout, typified by a clash of typefaces in different weights, sizes and styles that violently disrupted traditional reading habits and forced the eye to move from bottom to top, right to left, and diagonally up and down a page of print. Texts were often simulations of sounds, like a sputtering plane engine or an exploding artillery shell or falling rain. The Italian Futurist writer F. T. Marinetti called this typography Parole in Libert (words in freedom); the German typographer Jan Tschichold codified it as ''the New Typography''; and up to the 1920's it became the vernacular of progressive artists and designers. Jaroslav Andel analyzes the most innovative of these designs -- produced for everything from limited-edition art books to commercial magazines and newspapers -- in AVANT-GARDE PAGE DESIGN: 1900-1950 (Delano Greenidge Editions, $60). The extraordinary message of this book is not only that these pages set a standard for contemporary practice, but that they remain fresh-looking today. Steven Heller

There was an explosion of feathers, and the birds lifted off as one to form an undulating ribbon across the water, twisting from dark brown to brilliant white, then seeming to disappear completely, depending on how the birds tilted their wings.

He then began studying other networks and found that they had similar structures. The Internet in particular, he found, had taken on characteristics of a living ecosystem.

United States Army special forces are training in Florida to seize control of that zone once it is established. And, to accelerate the process, Harvard University advocates the immediate dismemberment of Brazil.

The team the Mets were supposed to supplant at the top of the National League East? So much for confusing contenders with pretenders.

title: The New Sod
description: When the players march onto the new Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia for the 2003 N.F.L. season, they will be tromping on South Jersey soil. The Eagles will be joining teams like the Pittsburgh Steelers, New England Patriots, Cleveland Browns and Green Bay Packers who have their Sunday tumbles softened by bluegrass sod provided by Tuckahoe Turf Farms of Hammonton. ''A lot of the new stadiums have sand bases, and the soil here in blueberry country is very sandy,'' said James Betts, one of the third generation of owners of the family-run Tuckahoe Turf Farms. And since the soil there usually doesn't freeze until December, there's some available for repairs. The Packers wanted a thick cut of turf, Mr. Betts said, so it took 32 refrigerated trucks to get their order to Wisconsin. The Eagles want a standard cut, and as the stadium is close, the sod won't need cooling, so nine flatbeds will do. Robert Strauss

title: Prescription for Allergy Sufferers
description: I CAN'T help but notice a resemblance between the towering pine that recently sprouted in the median strip of the Hutchinson River Parkway and the fake Christmas tree in my attic -- the one I bought five years ago after developing an allergy to the needle-dropping variety. Even the assembly of this immense artificial tree is familiar to me, as I watch workers jam color-coded branches into the perfectly tapered, 152-foot trunk. They use a crane. I use a footstool.

title: To Glow, Without the Sun
description: Fantasy tan salons may be the season's rage among those who are willing to pay hundreds of dollars for a defiantly dark full-body bronze, airbrushed on by a professional. Do-it-yourself tanners, however, can choose from the latest breeds of gels and creams that offer a more gradual, natural color, as well as a wider margin for error. Este Lauder's new Stay Bronze Moisturizing Tan Extender ($20 at Macy's) is a light self-tanning agent that can be used to prolong an existing tan or create a glow. Shiseido's self-tanning moisturizing gel ($20 at Macy's) is designed to mimic the process of a real suntan gradually, with color emerging over a stretch of several hours, while Frdric Fekkai's Self-Bronzer with Shea butter ($22.50 at Neiman Marcus) subtly shades the skin through a series of applications. Aveda's Sun Source bronzer ($16.50 at Aveda) and Clinique's Self-Sun body lotion and mist ($15.50 at Bloomingdale's) offer a somewhat slower-action tint to minimize blotches and streaks. And Philosophy's Healthy Tan self-tanner ($16 at Sephora) is made to be smoothed on every five hours until the desired color is achieved. Talk about a summer commitment.

title: Ann Landers, Advice Giver To the Millions, Is Dead at 83
description: Eppie Lederer, who as the syndicated columnist Ann Landers was widely considered responsible for bringing the advice column into the modern era, died yesterday at her home in Chicago. She was 83.

title: Private Sector; Knees and Airline Profits: Room for Both?
description: Road warriors in American Airlines' frequent flier program opened their mailboxes last week to find a newsletter promoting the carrier's completion of its ''more room throughout coach'' redesign. The numbers were impressive: 331,771 hours of labor spent removing 9,689 seats from 875 planes. ''So sit back, relax and enjoy the added legroom!'' the newsletter shouted. But airline executives and analysts wonder whether the program has cramped American's revenue. Even Donald J. Carty, its chief executive, said the program would be re-evaluated soon, to see if it really works. ''As we go through time, everything that American does will be on the table,'' he said.

Kiumars Gourki was named to the new post of art director; he had been art director at Fallon Worldwide, Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe. And Matt Johnson was named assistant media planner and buyer; he had been assistant broadcast media buyer at the Best Buy Company, Eden Prairie, Minn. Colle & McVoy is majority owned by the Maxxcom unit of the MDC Corporation.

title: Chile Will Privatize a New Span of Its Noted Social Safety Net

Augusto Pinochet's dictatorship made Chile the first country with a privately run pension system, its nominally Socialist government is relinquishing another part of the social safety net. Its plan will allow the private sector to manage the nation's unemployment insurance system.

Although your grandsons Ethan and Hunter have never met you, they are each filled with your spirit, your love of life, your sense of humor and your love of shopping. Twenty years have come and gone, and you are never far from my heart, Mommy. Love Always, Marc, Arnold and Family

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: NO PATROLS IN SIGHT Armed patrols of two Jewish neighborhoods in Brooklyn, which had been promised for the second time yesterday by a Queens rabbi, did not materialize early this morning. The rabbi, Yakove Lloyd, said yesterday at a news conference that about 50 people would patrol Borough Park and Flatbush, beginning at midnight, and would be armed with baseball bats or firearms to protect residents from terrorists. Similar patrols were called off by the rabbi two weeks ago in the face of neighborhood opposition and warnings of arrests by the police. By shortly before 1 a.m. today no one associated with Rabbi Lloyd had arrived at locations where the patrols were supposed to begin.   Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

The obligatory black T-shirt can be put away. No more purple shoeprints on the floors and rugs of her brownstone, on President Street in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: Election Law Coup d'tat
description: It took seven years for supporters of campaign finance reform to pass the McCain-Feingold law banning unregulated ''soft money'' in elections. It took less than seven days last week for a handful of political appointees on the Federal Election Commission to open up vast loopholes allowing the very fund-raising barred by the statute. Arrogantly ignoring the law's language, the intent of Congress and even the recommendations of their own legal staff, the commission members gutted major provisions and created huge exemptions out of whole cloth. This was a mugging of the statute that must be overturned by Congress or in the courts.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: No Patrols In Sight
description: Armed patrols of two Jewish neighborhoods in Brooklyn, which had been promised for the second time yesterday by a Queens rabbi, did not materialize early this morning. The rabbi, Yakove Lloyd, said yesterday at a news conference that about 50 people would patrol Borough Park and Flatbush, beginning at midnight, and would be armed with baseball bats or firearms to protect residents from terrorists. Similar patrols were called off by the rabbi two weeks ago in the face of neighborhood opposition and warnings of arrests by the police. By shortly before 1 a.m. today no one associated with Rabbi Lloyd had arrived at locations where the patrols were supposed to begin. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

True, Oliwa is primarily a large fistfighting specialist who has worn out his knuckles and his welcome with three teams. But summer is a time for optimism about the Rangers despite two years of failure under General Manager Glen Sather and no playoffs since 1997 under anybody.

The motorcyclist, Stephanos Kiladitis, 21, of Brooklyn, died Saturday afternoon at Lutheran Medical Center. He was struck about 10:30 p.m. Wednesday at 88th Street and Fort Hamilton Parkway, in Bay Ridge. The officer, Victor M. Instead, President Hamid Karzai presented delegates with the results of a backroom deal that confirmed the tight grip of Tajik leaders based in one small area, the Panjshir Valley, over the most important posts. If Mr. Karzai is to become Afghanistan's first truly national political leader since the monarchy's fall in 1973, he will have to emerge from the shadow of this narrow faction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, J. CARTER
description: BROWN-J. Carter. The Pritzker family and the trustees, jury and staff of The Hyatt Foundation mourn the loss of a dear friend who provided expert guidance as chairman of the Pritzker Architecture Prize jury since its inception in 1979. The prestige the prize has achieved must be credited in no small part to his dedication and vision, even when he had the enormous responsibility of directing the National Gallery of Art, along with countless other assignments that had great importance in the cultural world. He was a unique individual whose in-depth knowledge and creative energy made him an inspirational and irreplaceable leader. His brilliance and vision will be missed by all of us. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON BERNUTH, CHARLES M.
description: von BERNUTH-Charles M. Of Lyford Cay, Bahamas, passed away on May 25, 2002, at the age of 89. Beloved husband of the late Eloise Fiamingo. He was educated in the U.S. and Switzerland, and joined the family business, Bernuth Lembcke Co of NY, creosote importers and a shipping company. During WWII, originally he was a Calvary officer in the U.S. Army at Ft. Riley, KS, and later was recruited as a Captain into the O.S.S, where he was awarded the Silver Star for bravery in action. At war's end he returned to the family business, retiring in 1962, when he moved with his family to Rome, Italy, living there for over 30 years. A superb horseman, horses were the center of his life. He trained horses, judged at the National Horse Show, played polo at Meadowbrook with the very greats, receiving honorable mention; he just genuinely loved horses. He was a world traveler visiting all seven continents with his late wife, multi-lingual, multitalented, a writer, actor, dancer, composer-lyricist, skier, yachtsman, leatherworker, even conquering the unicycle. Actively involved in community affairs, he was a member of Squadron A, The Sleepy Hollow Country Club and The Lyford Cay Club. On the human side there are no superlatives to adequately describe his dignity, his charm, his honesty, his generosity, his humor. Elegant and stunningly handsome with all the social graces, he lived a wondrous and joyous life. He is survived by his first wife Shirley Paige Bernuth, their four children, Antonia Cook, Ticia Agri, Victoria Bernuth and Charles P. von Bernuth, four grandchildren, his nephews, Ernest P. Bernuth Jr. and James T. Bernuth and his neice Barbara King, his loving friend Dorothy Kohler, together with a host of other adoring friends. Memorial www.charlesvonbernuth .com.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Acquisition Talks

The man, Robert B. Cumberland, 37, appeared briefly before a justice in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The police said that Mr. Cumberland, who was arrested in May, lured his victims into desolate buildings with the promise of jobs, or ambushed them in lobbies or elevators. They said that he was linked to the cases through DNA evidence, and that he had an extensive criminal record, including serving seven years in prison in the 1980's for a rape conviction. title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: A WARNING TO PAKISTAN A spokeswoman for the Foreign Ministry warned Pakistan not to renege on commitments to "permanently" put an end to cross-border terrorism. Gen. Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's president, unambiguously made such a promise to the United States, according to American officials. But he said recently that while "nothing is happening" now along the Line of Control separating the Indian and Pakistani parts of contested Kashmir, he "will not give an assurance that for years nothing will happen." Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Bush Leaves for Canada Summit After Calling for Arafat's Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  President Bush left here today for a meeting of world leaders in Canada, where his Middle East plan calling for the removal of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat seems likely to dominate discussions.

title: Mayor Weighs Path to Solve Trash Woes
description: Turning his attention toward the city's expensive and seemingly intractable garbage problem, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg indicated yesterday that the city might need more than one large transfer station, especially as use of a site in Linden, N.J., has become more and more doubtful.

title: Let Them Sweat
description: When the G-8 leaders meet this week, cowering in a Canadian mountain resort beyond the reach of organized anarchists, here's a way for them to bolster terror-infested third world countries like Pakistan.

title: Fire Dept. Again Reminds Public, if Fleeing Fire, 'Close the Door'
description: At Christmastime in 1998, four people died when heat and smoke swept up the stairwell of an Upper West Side high-rise. Fire officials said at the time that one factor was a door left open when the family of the actor Macaulay Culkin fled their 19th-floor apartment after a fire had broken out there.

title: Police Look at Possible Driver Fatigue in Fatal Bus Crash
description: New York State Police officers investigating a charter bus crash near Rochester on Sunday that killed five members of a church group from this Connecticut city said today that the driver may have been fatigued to the point of nodding off because he had spent the two previous nights at a casino.

title: Providence Mayor Is Guilty of Corruption
description: The colorful career of Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. turned a shade darker today when a federal jury found him guilty of a racketeering conspiracy charge stemming from the government's contention that his corner office in City Hall was the base for a heavy-handed but effective crime operation.

title: Knicks Keep Options Open, But Remain Keen on Wilcox
description: Less than two days before the N.B.A. draft, the Knicks were open to all possibilities with their No. 7 pick. In a draft that many league executives consider more confusing than ever because of the glut of raw talent, the Knicks could feel the same way two hours, or even two minutes, before they are called upon to make their selection tomorrow night.

title: Near-Misses in the Hospital
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslav President Dismisses Milosevic-Appointed Army Chief
description: President Vojislav Kostunica of Yugoslavia today fired the commander of the army, as long demanded by domestic reformers and Western officials concerned by the man's links to Slobodan Milosevic.

title: After Dry Year, Maine Is Now Soaked
description: The meteorological torment of Emily Deering, 17, began last fall. The well ran dry at her parents' home here in the woods of southern Maine, as did the pond behind the house. Then came a long, weird, rainless winter of greasy hair, dirty dishes and toilets flushed once a day.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Criminal Inquiry On An Enron Deal
description: John M. Bailey Jr., the chief state's attorney, said yesterday that he was beginning a criminal investigation into last year's failed $220 million deal between Enron and the state's trash agency. Mr. Bailey said that he would ask for a grand jury inquiry and that he had sent a hand-delivered letter to Attorney General Richard Blumenthal. The letter formally requests records that Mr. Blumenthal subpoenaed in January from Enron; its auditor, Arthur Andersen; and the trash agency, the Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority. Mr. Blumenthal, who is limited to handling civil complaints, has subpoena authority but cannot petition a grand jury. Mr. Bailey, who prosecutes criminal violations, cannot subpoena records but may request the judiciary to impanel a grand jury. The petition for the grand jury could be filed within three weeks, Mr. Bailey said. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Prime Minister of Malaysia Stepping Down
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 25  His popularity at home and reputation abroad have rarely been higher, but today Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad delivered his second shock within a week by announcing that he was voluntarily stepping down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, ROBERT C.
description: FISCHER-Robert C. We mourn the passing of Robert C. Fischer, husband of our dear friend Diane, President of The Atran Foundation Inc. With heartfelt sympathy. The Executive Committee of the Teachers' Program on Holocaust and Jewish Resistance. Vladka Meed, Director

title: Japanese Father and Son Share a Liver and a Political Rivalry
description: One is a hawk, the other a dove. The younger man has built a reputation as an impatient, fist-shaking reformer, the elder is as smooth and staid as a felt-lined desk.

title: The Cemetery as Destination, and Not the Final One
description: DEATH brings decay, and Richard J. Moylan, the president of Green-Wood Cemetery and, if you must know, no great believer in an afterlife, is O.K. with that.

title: Calling From the Train? Please Read This
description: To the Editor:

title: Many designers at Pitti Uomo take the road to Morocco : For Florence, a colonial flair
description: FLORENCE  Acrobats dressed as the Seven Deadly Sins rappelling from the roof of the Palazzo Pitti provide a fantastic sight even for Florence, a city intoxicated by its own beauty. The spectacular tableau, inspired by Dante's "Divine Comedy" and sponsored by Classico Italia, a consortium of luxury menswear brands, opened Pitti Immagine Uomo, Florence's biannual menswear show for spring/summer 2003.

title: BUNGE IN TALKS TO BUY CEREOL, A FOOD OIL COMPANY
description: Bunge Ltd. is in exclusive talks to buy control of a French food oil company, Cereol S.A., to increase its share of the European soybean market. The negotiations cover the purchase of a 55 percent stake in Cereol held by Edison S.p.A, a Bunge spokesman, Hunter Smith, said. Edison is selling assets unrelated to its energy business. Bunge, which is based in White Plains, has been expanding its soybean-processing business since it first sold shares to the public in August.

title: Afghan Cabinet Sworn In Despite a Few Ill Omens
description: President Hamid Karzai swore in the new Afghan cabinet today under the hundred-year-old Chinar trees in the gardens of the old royal palace, managing a show of unity despite continued rumblings of dissatisfaction and intimidation.

title: American Cynicism: Not Just Watergate
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudi Effort To Revive Gas Deal Is Reported
description: Saudi Arabia is showing renewed interest in breaking the logjam holding up a landmark deal with eight major oil companies that would reopen the kingdom to foreign investment.

title: Fewer Death Sentences Likely if Juries Make Ultimate Decision, Experts Say
description: Fewer prisoners may be executed as a result of the Supreme Court decision yesterday requiring that juries, not judges, make the factual determinations supporting death sentences, experts said.

title: At Los Alamos, Two Visions of Supercomputing
description: Moore's Law holds that the number of transistors on a microprocessor -- the brain of a modern computer -- doubles about every 18 months, causing the speed of its calculations to soar. But there is a downside to this oft-repeated tale of technological progress: the heat produced by the chip also increases exponentially, threatening a self-inflicted meltdown.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Automaker Resumes Trading
description: Shares of the Chinese automaker, Brilliance China Automotive Holdings, began trading again after the company released a statement to explain the dismissal of its chairman, Yang Rong, last week and said he had not sold any shares in the company. The stock was suspended last week after the company disclosed in a newspaper ad that it had dismissed Mr. Rong, but it failed to issue a statement explaining the action. Talk that Mr. Rong was under investigation and had been forced to sell shares led to a sharp decline in Brilliance's share price last week. In its statement, Brilliance said it had replaced Mr. Rong to disperse management functions among more executives. Its stock rose 15.1 percent. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANIGAN, FRANCES OLMSTED
description: LANIGAN-Frances Olmsted. Beloved wife of the late John B. Lanigan, died on June 23, 2002, in Exeter, New Hampshire. She was a graduate of Vassar College and was an active volunteer in Irvington, New York, where she lived from 1948 to 1995. Mrs. Lanigan is survived by her three children, Tim of Washington, DC, Susan of Exeter, NH, Bob of Dover, MA., and four grandchildren. Mass of the Resurrection 10AM Wednesday Immaculate Conception Church, Irvington, New York.

title: More Failing Physics Exam, And Albany Is Investigating
description: Students, teachers and administrators have complained to the New York State Education Department that the Regents examination in physics was radically more difficult this year and caused a sudden drop in the percentage of students who passed.

title: Excerpts From Ruling and Dissent on Who Decides the Death Penalty
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today that juries, not judges, must make the crucial factual determinations that make a convicted murderer eligible for the death penalty. The vote in Ring v. Arizona was 7 to 2. Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg wrote the majority opinion, in which Justices Antonin Scalia, Stephen G. Breyer, Anthony M. Kennedy, Clarence Thomas, David M. Souter and John Paul Stevens concurred. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote the dissent, in which Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist joined. The full text is online at nytimes.com/national.

title: Suit Seeks Rent Aid to End Overnight Office Stays of Homeless
description: Objecting to a Bloomberg administration plan that would leave homeless families sleeping on the floors and benches of a city office this summer, lawyers for the families filed suit yesterday to seek court enforcement of past orders outlawing the practice.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Trumping The Governor
description: In near-unanimous votes, both houses of the Legislature overrode Gov. Frank L. O'Bannon's veto of cost-of-living increases for the pensions of teachers and public employees. The measure is expected to cost $3 million next year and $6 million in 2004.

title: Bus Heading to a Church Camp Crashes in Texas, Killing 4 Youngsters and the Driver
description: A chartered bus carrying dozens of youngsters to a church camp crashed today into a concrete pillar beneath a highway overpass, killing four passengers and the driver, the state police said.

title: Brazil's Roller Coaster Market
description: Brazilian stocks, bonds and the national currency, the real, oscillated widely in nervous trading today, amid continued concerns about the outcome of Brazil's coming presidential election and signs of weakness in the country's economy.

title: Market Place; For OPEC, Watchword Is Wait and See
description: When the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries meets in Vienna tomorrow, it is likely to decide to do nothing but wait to see what happens to the worldwide demand for oil, industry experts said.

title: When Brain Trauma Is at the Other End Of the Thrill Ride
description: Deborah Lee Benagh was at Six Flags Elitch Gardens in Denver when her sons coaxed her onto its daring new attraction, a giant serpent of loops and inversions ominously called Mind Eraser. It was among the first suspended roller coasters in the world, a new breed of rides that dangled people in harnesses beneath the tracks.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Amtrak Wheeze, New York Shudder
description: The worry ricocheting through the New York region's transportation agencies yesterday was that if push came to shove in Amtrak's fight for emergency help from the government, the railroad would not just shut down its own trains, it would park them in the tunnels under Pennsylvania Station.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Captured at Last (on Film)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: THE VALUE OF BURBERRY Burberry, the British fashion company known for its distinctive plaid pattern, said it would be worth 1.15 billion ($1.72 billion) to 1.45 billion ($2.18 billion) when it sells shares to the public next month. As much as 25 percent of the company will be sold to investors at 2.30 to 2.90 a share, raising 282 million ($422 million), the chief executive, Rose Marie Bravo, said. Burberry will use 25 million ($37 million) to buy out its Korean distributors, and 10 million ($15 million) for expansion, including the opening of new flagship stores in the United States and Asia. The rest of the money will be used to pay debt. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: F.T.C. CHALLENGES CYTYC'S PURCHASE OF DIGENE
description: The Federal Trade Commission challenged the Cytyc Corporation's planned $283 million purchase of a medical-test rival, the Digene Corporation, saying the acquisition would threaten competition. The five-member panel, voting 5-to-0, authorized its staff to seek a court order to block the transaction. The purchase would allow Cytyc, a leading maker of kits for Pap tests, to consolidate its dominance of the market for cell-collection equipment used by medical testing laboratories, the F.T.C. said. The F.T.C. said it would seek to block the purchase until an administrative law judge considers the agency's complaint. The merger agreement expires on Friday.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: SKAKEL HIRES APPELLATE LAWYERS The Skakel family has hired lawyers to handle the appeal of the murder conviction of Michael C. Skakel, left, who was found guilty on June 7 for the murder of Martha Moxley in 1975. The lawyers are Hope C. Seeley, Hubert J. Santos and Steven D. Ecker, all of Hartford. They will join David T. Grudberg and Richard Emmanuel to represent the appeal. Mr. Skakel, 41, faces a sentence of 10 years to life. His sentencing was postponed from July 19 to Aug. 9 to give the State Probation Department and his defense team more time on the case. (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUN, SHIRLEY W.
description: BRAUN-Shirley W. Of Cambridge, on Thursday June 20, 2002, (Worcester) wife of the late Dr. Edmund M. Braun, sister of Susan W. Light of CT & the late Dean K. Worcester, Jr. and Lucy W. Chauncey. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. A memorial Service will be held at a later date in New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Rectors Discretionary Fund, Church Of The Epiphany, 1393 York Ave., NY, NY 10021. For information J.S. Waterman - Eastman - Waring Funeral Service, Boston, MA.

title: Ad Urges Parents 'Don't Drop Out on Your Kids'
description: Apublic service campaign encouraging students to stay in school is, in a first for such efforts, aimed at parents rather than children.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BRONX: A DROWNING AT ORCHARD BEACH A young man drowned around 5 p.m. yesterday at Orchard Beach, said Jane Rudolph, a spokeswoman for the New York City Parks Department. Divers from the Police Department found him after he had been submerged about 25 minutes, the authorities said, and he was in cardiac arrest when he was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where he died. The authorities said he was 19; his name was not released last night. A sudden dropoff in the beach may have caused the accident, the authorities said.   Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: BUSH DEMANDS ARAFAT'S OUSTER BEFORE U.S. BACKS A NEW STATE; ISRAELIS WELCOME TOUGH LINE
description: President Bush told the Palestinian people today that they must replace Yasir Arafat as their leader before the United States will support an independent Palestinian state.

title: Bloomberg Endorses Democrat for State Senator
description: For shock effect, it did not rival Rudolph W. Giuliani's decision to cross party lines and endorse Mario M. Cuomo in 1994. But more than a few eyebrows were raised yesterday when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, a Republican, backed a Democrat to be state senator representing upper Manhattan and parts of the Bronx.

title: The Army is helping to pay for a 'stay in school' campaign aimed at students and their parents.
description: A PUBLIC service campaign encouraging students to stay in school is, in a first for such efforts, aimed at parents rather than children.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Friday about the challenges that states face as a result of the Supreme Court's ruling against executing mentally retarded offenders misidentified Ruth A. Luckasson, who commented on how mental ability could be documented. She is regents professor of special education at the University of New Mexico, not a law professor there.

title: Can the Placebo Treat Depression? That Depends
description: A patient of mine who had been depressed gleefully announced that he was going to stop his antidepressant because he had just read in the news that placebos were as effective as antidepressants. A provocative simple claim, but is it true?

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Kyocera Raises Outlook
description: The Kyocera Corporation's first-quarter pretax profit probably beat its forecast by more than half, led by orders for many products, like parts for mobile phones and personal computers and the company's own printers and handsets, its president, Yasuo Nishiguchi, said. Profit before taxes may reach 15 billion yen ($123 million) for the three months ending June 30, surpassing the company's estimate of 9.7 billion yen ($80 million), Mr. Nishiguchi said in an interview.

title: The Liberty Thinks Home Is the Key
description: The Liberty went scoreless for six minutes down the stretch against Orlando last Tuesday, got pummeled on the boards at Cleveland on Friday and wore concrete shoes in the second half at Orlando on Sunday.

title: Hats Are for Hiding, Yes, but How They Can Show Off
description: Simon Doonan, famous for his windows at Barneys New York and his wit, gave himself a once-over in the mirror. ''You have to be careful when you wear a hat,'' he observed, tipping his Greek fisherman's cap at an alluring angle, ''because it can start to look a bit English lesbian.'' He grinned. ''Radclyffe Hall.''

title: The Reality Thing
description: You can say this about the Bush administration: where others might see problems, it sees opportunities.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Attendance At Sept. 11 Memorial Meeting Is Urged
description: City Council members and officials of the Civic Alliance to Rebuild Lower Manhattan urged residents of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut yesterday to participate in ''Listening to the City,'' a July 20 town meeting at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. The meeting is being held for discussion of proposals for the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan and for a memorial to victims of the Sept. 11 World Trade Center attack. Up to 5,000 people will be chosen to participate in the forum based on several demographic features, including age, income, ethnic and racial background, occupation and state of residence. Anyone interested in participating may telephone (800) 862-3154, or go to the Web site, www.listeningtothecity.org. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; The Brothers Klitschko: From Kiev With Gloves
description: NOW that Lennox Lewis has ended both the aura and the era of Mike Tyson, boxing needs new faces. And two of those faces are strikingly similar: the brothers Klitschko, born in Ukraine, living in Germany, each with a doctorate in sports science and philosophy from the University of Kiev, each a towering puncher emerging as a heavyweight title contender.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHRENS, RHODA S.
description: BEHRENS-Rhoda S. Age 81 of Monroe Twp. died Sunday June 23, 2002 at home. Born in the Bronx, NY she lived in Westchester, NY for 25 years before moving to Monroe Twp. 15 years ago. Mrs. Behrens was a member of B'nai Brith, the Council of Jewish Woman, the Jewish Congregation, all of Concordia and a past President of the Sister Hood of Temple Rodeph Shalom of NY, NY. She was predeceased by her brother Jerome Shapiro. She is survived by her beloved husband Bertram, her two daughters Gail Yourstone and a son-in-law Wayne of Edison, NJ, and Andrea Behrens of NY, NY. Her two grandchildren Sam and Steven Yourstone. Services were 6/24 Monday 11:30 AM at Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels, 44 Wilson Avenue, Manalapan. Burial followed at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge.

title: A High School Gym Is a Home, for Some
description: Paul and Kimberley Hanlan were putting the finishing touches on their new house in the woods when the big fire came to Show Low.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSCH, S. HARRY
description: BUSCH-S. Harry, at age 103. Devoted beloved husband of the late Rose, the late Sayde Tisch Busch, and Jean Busch. Adored uncle, cherished stepfather, step-grandfather and step great-grandfather. Simply, a wonderful man.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon To Expand In New Jersey
description: Verizon Communications, the biggest local telephone company, won Federal Communications Commission permission yesterday to sell long-distance service in New Jersey. Verizon lets rivals rent phone lines and switches at discounted prices, meeting the legal conditions to sell long distance, the F.C.C. said in a statement. New Jersey is the eighth state where Verizon has won approval to sell the service.

title: From Turmoil, a Bold Vision; Director Plots Major Expansion for Boston Museum
description: A few years ago the director of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, Malcolm Rogers, emerged victorious from an ugly confrontation with a handful of powerful donors and long-serving curators.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: A Riverboat And A Bank
description: A decision by the City of Hammond to borrow $3 million from the Horseshoe Casino for the second time in two years for an economic development project left some officials worried that the city was becoming too dependent on the riverboat. Despite their objections, the city borrowed the money at 5 percent interest, agreeing to repay it in five years. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: European Leaders Praise Bush but Not His Call to Remove Arafat
description: LONDON, June 25  European leaders today praised President Bush's speech on the Middle East and hailed it as evidence of welcomed increased United States involvement in the region, but they refrained from backing his implicit call for the replacement of Yasir Arafat as the Palestinian Authority chairman.

title: Foreign Officials Question Guantnamo Prisoners
description: In an expansion of international cooperation in the war on terror, intelligence agents from several nations have interrogated fellow countrymen detained at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, and shared the information with the Pentagon.

title: Biohazard Warning
description: Q. What is the significance of the design for the biohazard symbol, something like a Ninja death star, commonly seen in hospitals?

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Meeting Fire on Its Terms
description: A wildfire near here has burned more than 500 square miles, and it and other fires burning now in the West will have swept over hundreds more before they are put out or burn themselves out. America is fighting the fires -- as it fights Western forest fires every year -- as if it were conducting military campaigns. Helicopters circle overhead, airplanes drop heavy loads of firefighting chemicals, uniformed firefighters march to the front and lines of refugees stream out of burning towns.

title: Speech Stuns Palestinians and Thrills Israelis, Who See End to Arafat
description: Delighted with President Bush's speech, Israeli officials expressed the hope tonight that perhaps, at last, Yasir Arafat would be ousted and a new, peace-seeking Palestinian leadership installed.

title: Group Objects to Center Plan for the Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  A group dedicated to preserving the work of Frederick Law Olmsted, the landscape architect of the Capitol grounds, Central Park and other well-known settings, is pressing for changes in the Capitol Visitor Center project now getting started.

title: Liberian Refugees Come Full Circle; Trying to Rebuild Their Lives in Staten Island Neighborhoods
description: Sundown at the Stapleton Playground can seem an unremarkable tableau, at first blush not much more than a flurry of whistles and whoops and sweaty shins chasing a ball.

title: Cooper-Hewitt Shake-Up And Layoffs Reverberate
description: When he first arrived at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum just over a year ago, Paul W. Thompson sent out clear signals that the country's pre-eminent museum of design -- part of the Smithsonian Institution -- badly needed a makeover. And that was before the events of Sept. 11 prompted museums all over New York to tighten their belts.

title: The Bard's New Lyric
description: My fellow Shakespeareans:

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Skakel Hires Appellate Lawyers
description: The Skakel family has hired lawyers to handle the appeal of the murder conviction of Michael C. Skakel, left, who was found guilty on June 7 of the murder of Martha Moxley in 1975. The lawyers are Hope C. Seeley, Hubert J. Santos and Steven D. Ecker, all of Hartford. They will join David T. Grudberg and Richard Emmanuel to represent the appeal. Mr. Skakel, 41, faces a sentence of 10 years to life. His sentencing was postponed to Aug. 9 from July 19 to give the State Probation Department and his defense team more time to prepare their case.

title: Dynegy Plans to Cut Dividend And Sell Assets to Raise Cash
description: Dynegy, one of the many energy companies dragged down by the trading and accounting scandals that emerged after the collapse of Enron, announced a series of measures yesterday to raise $2 billion.

title: Wrinkles Gone. Headache, Too?
description: A number of studies presented at the American Headache Society's conference in Seattle last week added evidence that shots of Botox, botulinum toxin type A, could help with migraine and tension headaches.

title: A Chronology of the Abner Louima Torture Case
description: AUG . 9, 1997 Abner Louima, 33, is arrested after scuffling with the police outside a nightclub in Flatbush, Brooklyn, and tortured with a broken stick in the 70th Precinct station house.

title: Soy Burgers That Keep the Beef
description: Meet a new cholesterol fighter: beef. Unlikely as that sounds, researchers found in a study released last week that adding soy to lean ground beef turned it into a cholesterol-reducing substance.

title: Vivendi Starts Sale of Stake in Utility Unit
description: Vivendi Universal began selling part of its controlling stake in its utility unit today, but doubts gathered about the planned sale of an Italian pay television unit. The uncertainty sent the company's stock to its lowest level in more than a decade.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: The Value Of Burberry
description: Burberry, the British fashion company known for its distinctive plaid pattern, said it would be worth 1.15 billion ($1.72 billion) to 1.45 billion ($2.18 billion) when it sells shares to the public next month. As much as 25 percent of the company will be sold to investors at 2.30 to 2.90 a share, raising 282 million ($422 million), the chief executive, Rose Marie Bravo, said. Burberry will use 25 million ($37 million) to buy out its Korean distributors, and 10 million ($15 million) for expansion, including the opening of new flagship stores in the United States and Asia. The rest of the money will be used to pay debt. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Agere To Sell Chip Unit
description: Agere Systems, the maker of communications chips that was spun off from Lucent Technologies, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a unit that makes chips for directing voice traffic on networks to Legerity for $70 million. Agere will transfer all 50 employees of the unit to Legerity, a former unit of Advanced Micro Devices that is majority owned by the buyout firm Francisco Partners.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about two scholars who recanted on their theory that the poem ''A Funeral Elegy'' was by Shakespeare after another scholar presented evidence that it was by John Ford misstated, in a second reference, the surname of the independent researcher who first identified Ford as the author. He is Richard Kennedy, not ''Mr. Richards.''

title: LAZARD REAL ESTATE FUND TO BUY REST OF KONOVER
description: A Lazard L.L.C. real estate fund will buy the 34 percent of a shopping center developer, Konover Property Trust Inc., it does not own for $23 million in cash, in a bid to save a money-losing investment. The investment bank will pay $2.10 for each share of the company, said Daniel Kelly, the chief financial officer of Konover, a real estate investment trust based in Raleigh, N.C. The Kimco Realty Corporation, an owner of strip shopping centers, is joining Lazard in the purchase. Lazard will assume about $229.2 million of Konover debt.

title: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER
description: Metropolitan Opera House

title: Germany Reaches World Cup Final
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 25  Fireworks boomed again in the night sky, and the South Korean players took their customary post-game bows, but this time there was nothing to celebrate. A wonderful dream came to an end tonight. The chanted appreciation from 65,256 fans came in salute for a month well done, not a match well played.

title: People
description: * The San Francisco office of Euro RSCG MVBMS Partners, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas, has named two executives as co-creative directors. They are Bertrand Grabassi, who had been a creative director at the New York office, and Doug Penman, who had been a creative director in San Francisco. They are assuming duties handled by Kevin McCarthy, who is leaving to become executive creative director at the San Francisco office of Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group.

title: Reports of Shredding Intensify Global Crossing Inquiry
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee is planning to step up its scrutiny of Global Crossing's business practices in light of the company's acknowledgment that employees at several of its offices had shredded documents after the Securities and Exchange Commission began investigating the company in February.

title: Speech Stuns Palestinians and Thrills Israelis
description: JERUSALEM, June 24  Delighted with President Bush's speech, Israeli officials expressed the hope tonight that perhaps, at last, Yasir Arafat would be ousted and a new, peace-seeking Palestinian leadership installed.

title: Empire Not Much Affected, Yet, By Cloud Over Martha Stewart
description: Martha Stewart was scheduled to make her regular appearance this morning on ''The Early Show'' on CBS to do a segment on summer salads. But to keep her plum spot on the show, she also had to agree to be interviewed by the co-anchor, Jane Clayson, on something even more timely -- her decision to sell her stake in ImClone Systems Inc. a day before it publicly announced that regulators had rejected its cancer drug, Erbitux.

title: Getting Best of Mets Is a Braves Specialty
description: His words preceded his return to Shea Stadium.

title: Prizes Given For Coverage Of Business
description: Gretchen Morgenson of The New York Times and Rebecca Smith and John Emshwiller of The Wall Street Journal were among the winners of the 2002 Gerald Loeb Awards for Distinguished Business and Financial Journalism.

title: Donovan Wastes No Time Getting Back to M.L.S.
description: Only 38 hours after trudging off the field in Ulsan, South Korea, where the United States lost to Germany in the World Cup quarterfinals, LANDON DONOVAN was back on the field for San Jose of Major League Soccer as a late substitute Saturday night when the Earthquakes won their eighth straight game at Spartan Stadium.

title: In the Animal Kingdom, a New Look at Female Beauty
description: In the grand story of evolution that scientists have been reconstructing since Charles Darwin's voyage on H.M.S. Beagle, the chapter on mate selection reads something like this: males compete among themselves to attract females, showing off their antlers, bright plumage or other ornaments that signal good health. Females watch the display from the sidelines, aloof and picky, like wealthy patrons at an art exhibition.

description: To the Editor:
