description: To the Editor:

title: British or Italian style?Make sure you don't miss the film
description: LONDON  For a snapshot of men's fashion today, you could watch the 1969 film "The Italian Job." This terrific slice of British propaganda has it all: suits, motors, jingoism. It's a heist movie with style. The plot has a gang of British crooks travel to Turin to steal a shipment of gold bullion from an armored car in heavy traffic. But the real story is  who's cooler, the British or the Italians?

title: Front Row
description: In 1967, Mia Farrow got a haircut that cost roughly what you might pay for a used Honda Civic today. The gamine cut associated with Ms. Farrow during her Frank Sinatra years was given to her by Vidal Sassoon in front of a live audience of 40 fashion stylists, 110 photographers and 5 television crews at the cost of $5,000.

title: Chasing the Giuliani Papers
description: That Rudolph Giuliani was mayor of New York City is a matter of public record. At least, we think it is. You see, Mr. Giuliani took City Hall's records of his administration with him when he left office and locked them -- hundreds of boxes' worth -- in a warehouse in Queens. There, only paper mites and people employed by the private, nonprofit organization bearing his name have ready access to them.

title: Justices to Hear a Major State-Immunity Case
description: While pressing to finish its current term this week, the Supreme Court today set the stage for resuming its battle over the boundary between state and federal authority when its next term begins in October.

title: Amtrak's Future Thrown Into Political Competition
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Amtrak's future, already clouded by debt and mismanagement, was thrown into the political competition on Capitol Hill today after a large group of Democratic senators pressured the White House to keep passenger trains running with an emergency infusion of cash.

title: Liposuction Grows Safer As Less Fat Is Removed
description: Cindy Laney, a former aerobics instructor, often runs five miles and lifts weights. ''But I always had these bulges around my middle that no amount of dieting or exercise would get rid of,'' she says.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Leader Appoints New Team
description: Tung Chee-hwa, the chief executive, appointed 14 senior officials who will report to him personally and oversee the civil service. The announcement was planned for Friday but delayed until yesterday, the local press reported, because the Chinese government had not yet approved all the appointees. Mr. Tung contends that the extra layer of officials above the civil service will improve the public accountability of the government, because Mr. Tung was elected, albeit after no one ran against him. Democracy advocates say the new appointees will give Beijing tighter control over the former British colony. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Suit on Seizing Polish Land Is Dismissed
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday dismissed a lawsuit against the government of Poland by a group of Holocaust survivors and their families, who said they were entitled to compensation for real estate seized by Polish Communists after World War II.

title: Two Feuding Indian Tribes Are Recognized, but as One
description: The Bureau of Indian Affairs granted federal recognition today to the Eastern Pequot and Paucatuck Eastern Pequot tribes, a determination that will give tribe members access to an array of new government benefits as well as economic opportunities including the possibility of casino gambling.

title: Hard Lessons, Born of Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Say Death Penalty Is Up to Juries, Not Judges
description: Juries rather than judges must make the crucial factual determinations that subject a convicted murderer to the death penalty, the Supreme Court ruled today in a decision that invalidated the death penalty laws of five states and cast doubt on the laws of four others.

title: Oppressors of Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: A Drowning At Orchard Beach
description: A young man drowned around 5 p.m. yesterday at Orchard Beach, said Jane Rudolph, a spokeswoman for the New York City Parks Department. Divers from the Police Department found him after he had been submerged about 25 minutes, the authorities said, and he was in cardiac arrest when he was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where he died. The authorities said he was 19; his name was not released last night. A sudden dropoff in the beach may have caused the accident, the authorities said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Administration Vows to Keep Amtrak Going
description: The Bush administration said today that it would keep Amtrak running beyond a threatened shutdown deadline of Wednesday. But without a clear plan to supply the railroad with cash, Amtrak officials did not pull back from the brink of a halt.

title: Hamas Leader, Under Attack From 2 Sides, Remains Defiant
description: Hamas, the militant Islamic group responsible for some of the most devastating suicide bombings here, has come under a double-barreled attack in the last 24 hours. But its spiritual leader, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, still wore his usual smile of serenity today.

title: Blaming the Cuisine
description: To the Editor:

title: Alsatian Calf's Liver Dumplings
description: Chef Soltner is a master of Alsatian cuisine, and this dish is a classic from his repertoire. Even if you don't like liver, don't be put off: the final product does not have a livery taste; it is rich and savory, but far from overwhelmingly meaty.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the equity and debt calendar of Business Day yesterday for an offering by Scientific Games misidentified the lead underwriter. It is Bear, Stearns & Company, not Jefferies & Company.

title: A House as His Home, but a Museum as His Dream
description: Sakip Sabanci is a billionaire with, he says, a mission. First, he wants Turks to have a museum that meets international standards. Then he intends to reverse the flow of cultural masterpieces departing Turkey for the last couple of centuries. Finally, he is dead set on instilling a sense of philanthropy in the country's business elite.

title: New Command Would Meld Missile Defense and Offense
description: The Pentagon plans to create a new command that combines the military network that warns of missile attacks with its force that can fire nuclear or nonnuclear weapons at suspected nuclear, chemical and biological weapons sites around the world, administration officials said today.

title: It's a Tablet. It's a Notebook. From Microsoft, A New Hybrid.
description: Microsoft began promoting its Tablet PC nearly two years ago with a clear message and vision: a powerful, pen-based computer unfettered by a keyboard. Bill Gates, the company's chairman, made the rounds of industry events, prototype tablet in hand, extolling the virtues of handwriting and digital ink.

title: Singing to Heal the Bruises of Stardom
description: Being a pop superstar isn't for everyone. Lauryn Hill's 1998 solo album after leaving the Fugees, ''The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill'' (Columbia), sold eight million copies in the United States and won five Grammy Awards, including Album of the Year. But it left her, as she said onstage at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, ''a mess.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 36 People Indicted For License Fraud
description: After a two-year investigation stemming from tips by motor vehicle workers, the State Division of Criminal Justice announced the indictment of 36 people yesterday, including eight employees of the New Jersey Division of Motor Vehicles. The agency said the employees were involved in schemes to obtain licenses for illegal immigrants. John Hagerty, a spokesman for the criminal justice division, said that the licenses were sometimes used to commit other crimes, including identity fraud, in which licenses created with information from legal drivers was used with other documents to purchase or lease expensive cars. In some cases, stand-ins would take written or road tests for the illegal applicants, officials said. The eight motor vehicle employees have been fired, Mr. Hagerty said. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: South Korea Pins Its Hopes on Heartthrob Ahn, Sprained Ankle and All
description: Even in an afternoon drizzle, dozens of schoolgirls gathered outside World Cup Stadium today to await the arrival of the South Korean team bus. They hardly seemed to care that midfielder Ahn Jung Hwan had scored the tying goal against the United States, the winning goal against Italy and one of the penalty kicks that bested Spain. It is his face, as much as his feet, that has made him the country's heartthrob.

title: If You Can Make It Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNHAM, I.W. II.
description: BURNHAM-I.W. II. June 24, 2002, age 93, died suddenly and peacefully at sea aboard his beloved Encore V, off the Virginia coast. Devoted husband of Lawrie Weil Burnham, who predeceased him in 1997. Adored father of Jon M. Burnham and Miriam Arnstein Burnham, and Wendy Burnham Morris and Michael Morris. Cherished grandfather of Debra Burnham Hyman, Suzanne Burnham Mankoff, Kimberly Burnham, Jon M. Burnham, Jr., Anthony C. Kaye, Hilary Kaye Kronowitz and Andrew B. Kaye. Blessed with nine loving great grandchildren. Services to be announced. Please no flowers.

title: Aruba Discount
description: The 358-room Radisson resort on Palm Beach in Aruba wants to encourage longer stays, with a rate of $175 a night (regularly $210) for a standard single or double room through Sept. 30, for five nights or more. The deal, which includes a $100 credit for food and drinks, is called Credit 2 U; ask for it by that name when reserving. Tax is extra; availability is limited. The resort has a casino and two pools; (800) 333-3333 or www.radisson.com/palmbeachaw .

title: Telling a Very Old Story, Tossing Pages to the Wind
description: Ancient epic was an oral tradition; performing it returns it to life. One of the happiest ideas in the production of ''Gilgamesh,'' a so-called operatic ritual by Stephen Dickman that opened at La MaMa E.T.C. on Thursday night, is its use of the written page. The costumes worn by the two singers feature portable music stands, strapped around their waists and jutting out like prows to hold the pages of the score at comfortable heights before them. As they finish a page, they drop it to the floor. The printed words and notes become no more than discarded shells of experience; the pages scatter like dead leaves, marking the passage of time through the epic.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Outlook Even For I.B.M.
description: I.B.M.'s effort to cut costs and drop losing businesses will make up for most of the slowing in its sales this year, a Goldman Sachs & Company analyst said yesterday. Though she cut profit estimates, the analyst, Laura Conigliaro, wrote that restrained spending by I.B.M. customers and recent cost cuts ''seem generally to offset one another.'' The company will probably gain market share, in part because it is reshaping its chip-making unit, she wrote.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about the challenges that states face as a result of the Supreme Court's ruling against executing mentally retarded offenders misidentified Ruth A. Luckasson, who commented on how mental ability could be documented. She is regents professor of special education at the University of New Mexico, not a law professor there.

title: Fire Destroys 7 Lives Lived Almost as One
description: It was a life that, like so many others, was filled with the double sacrifice of hard work and early mornings. Every day, Mohammad Nadeem woke at 6, his friends and neighbors said, bought a coffee with milk and sugar at the corner deli and went off to work construction in the neighborhoods of southern Brooklyn, often returning well past dark.

title: Better Welfare Reform
description: With the welfare reforms of 1996 expiring, Congress must build on the successes of the past while fixing the problems created six years ago. Tomorrow the Senate Finance Committee will take up a bill proposed by its chairman, Max Baucus of Montana, that improves greatly on the punitive welfare measure passed earlier this year in the House. It increases financing for child care for welfare recipients and it backs away from the harsh new work requirements of the House bill. The senators should increase child care financing still further. It should also expand welfare assistance and health benefits to legal immigrants.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Five staff members were promoted at 141 Communicator, New York, part of the Bates Worldwide unit of the Cordiant Communications Group. Roger Norris, art director, was named associate creative director. Four others were named creative supervisors: Daniel Armyn, Michael Landou and Jason Zangrilli, all art directors; and Jonathan Richter, copywriter.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Denying A Reprieve
description: Despite a state review board's recommendation that an abused woman convicted of murder should be released from prison, Gov. Gray Davis has denied parole to the woman, Maria Suarez. Although Ms. Suarez, 42, was found to be suffering from battered woman's syndrome when she conspired to kill her husband in 1981, Governor Davis cited police reports suggesting that her actions may have been prompted by jealousy, fear and greed. The governor asked investigators to continue examining the case and left the door open to revisit the issue next year. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, HAROLD
description: GOTTLIEB-Harold. Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the death of our cherished member Harold Gottlieb. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Rabbi Michael A. White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Toni Wiener, President

title: BMW Expects Growth at Carolina Plant
description: Bayerische Motoren Werke, the luxury-car maker, expects vehicle production at its Spartanburg, S.C., plant to double after 2005 to meet growing demand in the United States.

title: Science-Technology Drive Is Urged to Fight Terror
description: The United States should begin a program to help fight terrorism through science and technology with a vast range of efforts, including developing better protection for power supplies, improving communications and ventilation systems and creating sensors to detect toxic agents, a report released today by the National Research Council says.

title: Washington's Slow Pace in Trade Talks Annoys the Chileans
description: The United States first began wooing Chile as a free-trade partner more than a decade ago, only to back away when it came time to commit. Now the courtship has resumed, but American negotiators are finding to their chagrin that not only are they just one of many suitors, but they may no longer even be the preferred partner.

title: The Mini-Dumpling Called Quenelle  Recipes
description: Quenelles de Foie de Veau à l'Alsacienne (Alsatian Calf's Liver Dumplings)

title: Mortgage Company Profits Doubled Last Year, Survey Shows
description: Mortgage company profits about doubled last year as Americans refinanced a record $1.2 trillion in home loans to get the lowest rates in 30 years, according to a survey of lenders.

title: Win Big! Lie in Front Of a Train
description: A LAWYER who will go nameless called our attention to a recent court case, having seen a summary of it in The New York Law Journal. He was, to put it mildly, flummoxed.

title: Lianbian Journal; The Rage in China: Lunching on Wildlife, and Mao
description: ''Long Live the Proletarian Revolution'' screams one of the huge red banners, relics from Chairman Mao's Cultural Revolution, on this vast restaurant's walls.

title: Luxury Jet Outfitters Help Their Clients Live Large
description: Lufthansa Technik, a German company that specializes in luxury interiors for large private jets, has had its share of requests for Jacuzzis, dog kennels and even garages. But one of the features it is most proud of is the paper doors.

title: Ricoh Selects Lowe & Partners
description: The Ricoh Company, the office-equipment company in Tokyo, said yesterday that it had named Lowe & Partners Worldwide to handle its worldwide corporate-image account. Spending for the assignment, which had no previous agency, was estimated at $60 million to $80 million.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Microsemi Shares Plummet
description: Shares of Microsemi, which makes semiconductors, fell 40 percent after it said profit and sales this quarter would trail company forecasts. The shares fell $5.28, to $7.95, and have dropped 73 percent this year. Microsemi attributed the decline to slower demand for its chips used in aircraft, spacecraft, computers and cellular phones. Its customers include Boeing, Advanced Micro Devices and Motorola.

title: McCain Plans Bid to Force Election Panel Appointment
description: Frustrated by recent Federal Election Commission rulings that he believes will undermine a campaign-finance bill he helped sponsor, Senator John McCain said today that he would seek to block all nominations before the Senate until a proposed new appointee to the panel was allowed to take office.

title: INSIDE
description: United Seeks Loan Backing

title: Powell Says He Warned Arafat To Shift Course or Be Left Behind
description: President Bush's public demand that Yasir Arafat be replaced as the Palestinian leader began in private 10 weeks ago in a small room in Mr. Arafat's besieged and battered headquarters in Ramallah, with tough talk from Secretary of State Colin L. Powell.

title: Train Rolls Into Another In Tanzania, Killing 200
description: At least two hundred people died today when a passenger train in central Tanzania that apparently experienced mechanical failure rolled backward down a hill into a cargo train, the authorities said.

title: Pike Dumplings
description: This Lyonnaise specialty uses pike, a fish underused by Americans (though available from most supermarkets and fishmongers), but much beloved by the working class residents of Lyon. Instead of the semolina used in the calf's liver version, these quenelles use a panade  a binding paste made from a combination of milk, butter, egg and flour.

title: Partner Takes Cable Systems, 2 Million Users From AOL
description: AOL Time Warner, the world's biggest media company, said yesterday that it had lost control of cable television systems serving more than two million customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACDONALD, HELEN
description: MacDONALD-Helen Johnson of Short Hills, N.J. and Linville, N.C. on Sunday June 23, 2002. Wife of the late Nestor J. MacDonald. Mother of Mrs. Glenna M. Ackerman and Mrs. Sheila M. Bailey. Also survived by five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held in Community Congregational Church, 200 Hartshorn Dr., Short Hills, N.J. on Thursday, June 27 at 11 AM. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. Please omit flowers. Contributions may be made to Kessler Institute of Rehabilitation, Pleasant Valley Way, West Orange, New Jersey 07052 or Scottish Heritage U.S.A., PO Box 457 Pinehurst, North Carolina 28374 or Grandfather Mountain Highland Games, PO Box 1095, Linville, N.C. 28646

title: Suits Say Wal-Mart Forces Workers to Toil Off the Clock
description: After finishing her 10 p.m. to 8 a.m. shift, Verette Richardson clocked out and was heading to her car when a Wal-Mart manager ordered her to turn around and straighten up the store's apparel department.

title: Cerebral Style Tinged With Emotion in a Premiere
description: The New York City Ballet has brought this season's Diamond Project, a showcase for new choreography, to a close with ''In the Mi(d)st,'' choreographed by Miriam Mahdaviani. Set to music by two contemporary composers, Oliver Knussen and Aaron Jay Kernis, the piece is an enticing challenge to both ear and eye.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, J. CARTER
description: BROWN - J. Carter. The Board of Governors and staff of the John Carter Brown Library at Brown University deeply lament the death of Carter Brown, the third generation of his family to serve on the Library's Board, dating back to 1901, and a brilliant, dedicated, and irreplaceable contributor to its work. Ruth J. Simmons, Chairman Norman Fiering, Director

title: A New Set of Questions for Farmer Mac
description: The Farm Credit Administration has been considering bringing an enforcement action against Farmer Mac over the company's failure to furnish a business plan for its review, according to a confidential memo from the head of the agency.

title: Moscow Memo; Putin Shows Talent for Talk, and the Accordion
description: It might be an exaggeration to suggest that a cult of personality has coalesced around President Vladimir V. Putin, and he himself rebutted the idea today. But he has unquestionably become a master of his own image and the most dominant political voice in Russia.

title: In Dallas
description: Dallas visitors could comfortably do business in the same chain hotels and expense-account steakhouses as anywhere else. But they can also find lodgings, restaurants and entertainment that forthrightly reflect their Southwestern setting.

title: Kournikova Loses Match and Cool
description: Apparently, Anna Kournikova flirts with maturity, too.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about a plan by Verizon Communications to use Microsoft's content, software and marketing support for its high-speed D.S.L. Internet service misstated the surname of a senior vice president at Yahoo, a competitor of Microsoft's MSN service, who said Yahoo would continue to explore deals with D.S.L. and cable companies. He is Jim Brock, not Grant.

title: A Plan Without a Map
description: President Bush has offered a far-reaching, moral vision for the future of the Middle East. The question is how to get there from here.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Protests As World Bank Meets
description: Some 10,000 antiglobalization protesters took to the streets of Oslo peacefully as the World Bank convened its annual European conference on ways to fight global poverty. In opening remarks at an isolated hilltop hotel, the bank's chief economist, Nicholas Stern, urged rich nations to increase development aid and dismantle trade barriers against poor countries. Protest organizers, marching behind a banner proclaiming ''Our world is not for sale,'' said the bank forced debt-ridden countries to adopt market reforms harmful to the development of fair social and environmental policies. Last year's conference, planned for Barcelona, was canceled under the threat of huge street protests. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

title: U.S. Backs New Trade Rules on Drugs
description: The United States said today that it would back a revision of global trading rules that would allow poor countries to import patented drugs quickly and cheaply to deal with health crises like AIDS.

title: Lobster Cream Sauce
description: This wonderfully rich, flavorful sauce is hardly an essential partner for the pike quenelles, but they do go together perfectly.

title: Hard Lessons, Born of Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Bidding Farewell to Carnegie With the Best From the Past
description: The Carnegie Hall Jazz Band's farewell concert, part of the JVC Jazz Festival on Friday night, summoned up a good representation of the aesthetic currents within the group.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Manasquan: Body Of Missing Boater Is Found
description: Fishermen have discovered the body of a man who had been missing since a June 14 shark-fishing trip. Three other men from the same boat, the 25-foot Eleni II, remain missing and are presumed dead. The body recovered was identified as that of Bob Wright, 42, of Island Park, N.Y. He was found early Saturday morning off the coast of Manasquan, about 75 miles south of the south shore of Long Island where the boat is believed to have been launched. There were no results from a search of more than 80 square miles of ocean around the site where Mr. Wright's body was discovered, said Bill Barry, a Coast Guard spokesman.

title: Familiar Blood Pressure Drug Finds an Array of Novel Uses
description: For 20 years, doctors have used ACE inhibitors to control blood pressure in heart patients. But now it is becoming increasingly clear that these drugs -- with names like ramipril and capoten -- can do much more than merely relax the arteries, allowing blood to flow more freely.

title: Painstaking Progress Finally Pays Off for the U.S.
description: Bruce Arena, coach of the United States national team, did not start playing soccer until he was a high school junior on Long Island. His coach was his biology teacher, who seemed to know a lot more about dissecting frogs than opposing defenses.

title: Hard Facts of Hypertension Elude Too Many
description: The news about blood pressure is decidedly mixed.

title: Calling From the Train? Please Read This
description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwan Investigators Rule Out Blast or Pilot Error in 747 Crash
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 25  Investigators analyzing the crash last month of a China Airlines flight said today that the flight data and cockpit voice recorders, together with autopsies on the victims and an examination of the wreckage, showed no evidence of an explosion or pilot error.

title: A Family's Tearful Battle Against a Painful Death
description: Given the sad subject, it's surprising that ''The Smith Family,'' tonight's season-opening installment of the ''P.O.V.'' series on PBS, isn't more moving.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, HILDA
description: HELLER-Hilda. Died peacefully at home at age 98 on June 23. Devoted wife of the late Isadore Heller. Beloved mother of Sherry and Steven Schweitzer, Milton and Dorothee Heller. Loving grandmother of Audra and Brooke, Jonathan, Joshua, Robert and Billy; great grandmother of six. Services today, 1PM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tax Credits For Ground-Zero Jobs
description: The Internal Revenue Service has ruled that small businesses in Lower Manhattan that continued operating after the Sept. 11 terror attack are eligible for tax credits for employing others. The plan calls for companies to receive up to $2,400 in tax credits for each part- and full-time employee. Citing a recent tax code change, the I.R.S. announced yesterday that companies that operated on or south of Canal Street until the attack, and that currently employed no more than 200 employees, were eligible. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BOGEN COMMUNICATIONS INTERNATIONAL INC., Ramsey, N.J., a maker of sound-processing equipment, said it planned to repurchase up to 2.5 million of its shares in a self-tender offer of $4 a share.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Still Happy Being Blue

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIRARDI, PATRICIA SEARS
description: GIRARDI-Patricia Sears. 80. Beloved wife of Bill and mother of Grad, John, Nancy and Jay, passed away on June 23, 2002, after an extended illness. A longtime resident of Katonah, NY, she was active in many community organizations including the Herb Society and volunteering at Kitchawan Research Laboratory. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The American Cancery Society. Services and interment were private.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Journalists Sentenced
description: The former editor of the opposition newspaper Pursuit and another journalist from the paper were found guilty of libeling President Aleksandr Lukashenko and sentenced to prison. They were accused of insulting Mr. Lukashenko before the presidential election last September. Earlier this month witnesses said the police beat supporters of the two journalists at the courthouse. Western officials and human rights groups have criticized Mr. Lukashenko for cracking down on the press. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Presidential and Fit
description: To the Editor:

title: The President's Words of Warning: 'Things Must Change in the Middle East'
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's speech yesterday on his Middle East proposals, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Top Players Advance With Hardly A Scare
description: Three beleaguered stars in search of grass's natural healing powers played beneath the startling sunlight at Wimbledon today, with their deep scars and thinning hairlines illuminated like X-rays.

title: Judge Enters Plea of Not Guilty for Moussaoui
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 25  Zacarias Moussaoui, who is charged with being part of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, told the federal judge conducting his trial today that she was using trickery to "prepare me for the gas chamber." Judge Leonie M. Brinkema, struggling to maintain her patience, told Mr. Moussaoui that he is so unsophisticated in the law that he came close today to inadvertently pleading guilty and ending his trial.

title: Smokers Gasp, Not Just From Cigarettes
description: One state after another is raising cigarette taxes in this year of gaping budget deficits, tapping a source of easy revenue. But the three states in the New York region are going even further, effectively forming a high-tax district of their own.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Liberty To Buy Wink
description: Liberty Media, the cable television company, said yesterday that its broadband unit had agreed to buy Wink Communications, an interactive television company, for $99.9 million. Wink shareholders will get $3 a share in cash, the companies said. The offer from Liberty is 76 percent more than Wink's closing price of $1.70 on Friday. Wink, based in Alameda, Calif., allows TV viewers to use a remote control to get facts about advertised products or to buy them.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Reports of Shredding Intensify Global Inquiry

title: Corrections
description: The Patents column in Business Day on June 17, about a patent for an insomnia drug created by Neurocrine Biosciences Inc., inaccurately described the licensing arrangement between Neurocrine and American Cyanamid. Neurocrine's license to use a chemical compound patented by American Cyanamid was arranged through a third company, Dov Pharmaceuticals Inc., which like American Cyanamid would receive royalties from Neurocrine if the insomnia drug went on sale. Neurocrine did not obtain the license directly from American Cyanamid.

title: 2nd Boeing Pact for Army
description: Boeing has won an order valued as high as $2 billion to make radios for the United States Army, the Pentagon said today. The order is the company's second major Army contract this year. In March, Boeing won an order valued up to $4 billion to design a system of armored vehicles and robotic sensors. Like that system, the radios would allow troops to transmit voice, data and video information more quickly.

title: CNN Executive Issues Apology For Coverage
description: Eason Jordan, CNN's chief news executive, apologized on behalf of his network yesterday for giving more attention to the statements of a suicide bomber's family than to the parents of one of his victims in its coverage of the suicide attack in Petah Tikva in late May.

title: CRYOLIFE RECEIVES A LETTER FROM F.D.A. ON LAB INSPECTION
description: CryoLife Inc. said it received a letter from the Food and Drug Administration related to an inspection of the company's human-tissue-processing laboratories that was completed on April 12. The company, a maker of heart valves and grafts used in orthopedic surgery, said it planned to meet with the F.D.A. shortly. CryoLife, which is based in Kennesaw, Ga., declined to release a copy of the letter, but the F.D.A. was set to disclose it today. CryoLife said its supply of human tissue used for surgical procedures would not be affected as it works to address the concerns raised in the letter. Some of the F.D.A. concerns were about validation systems used to ensure that the work done in the laboratory is performed correctly, said Roy Vogeltanz, a CryoLife spokesman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNTON, JULIAN E.
description: LYNTON-Julian E. On June 23, 2002, at age 85. Beloved husband of Joan L. Lynton. Dear brother of Harold S. Lynton (Hattie). Loving father of Jonathan Lynton and Vicki Sendelle (Rick), Judy Schwartz (Edward), Barbara Sargent (Peter) and William L. Strauss III (Randi). Cherished grandfather of nine. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday 7-9 P.M. with service Thursday 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to The Center for Learning and Living at Marymount Manhattan College, 221 E. 71 St, NY, NY 10021, or New York Society for the Deaf, 161 William Street, NY, NY 10038.

title: Hard Lessons, Born of Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about Gary Vineberg, a Merrill Lynch analyst who was negative on Rite Aid's stock in the 1990's, misstated some of his ratings of the company. During Rite Aid's failed attempt to acquire Revco in 1996 and for several months afterward, he rated Rite Aid a sell, not a hold. He then rated the stock a hold, not a sell, but remained critical of the company until he left Merrill Lynch in 1998.

title: Panel Focuses on Martha Stewart Call
description: A Congressional committee investigating ImClone Systems is focusing on a call made to Martha Stewart by her stockbroker on Dec. 27 -- the day Ms. Stewart sold nearly 4,000 shares -- in which the broker left a message saying that the price of ImClone was about to fall, a committee spokesman said yesterday.

title: Mathis Set To Regroup After Cup Frustration
description: A trip to South Korea with the United States national team for the World Cup did not exactly qualify as Clint Mathis's excellent adventure.

title: The Sound of British Rock Reviving Grand Ambitions
description: Guitar chords washed over the Hammerstein Ballroom from Doves, a band whose No. 1 album in Britain, ''The Last Broadcast'' (Capitol), translated into a sold-out show on Thursday night. Huge, reverberating swells were backed by martial drums, all confident and larger than life: the sound of British rock reclaiming grand, bygone ambitions.

title: Clear Terms, Murky Future
description: Since October, President Bush has been saying more explicitly than any previous president that he believes in the principle of a Palestinian state, one that could live side by side with Israel in peace and security.

title: Town Looks for Luck to Shift as Crews Try to Outwit Fire
description: This is a town that was named for a stroke of luck, so maybe the fact it was still standing today is not so surprising.

title: Airline Tries to Quell Seating Storm
description: ON the supposition that there is no need to try to say something better when it has already been said perfectly, I am indebted to the editorial page of The Rocky Mountain News of Denver for the following trenchant comment last week regarding reports that Southwest Airlines has begun cracking down on extra large people by making them buy two airplane seats:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Lower Credit Rating
description: France Tlcom's credit rating was cut to a level just above junk status by Moody's Investors Service. The downgrade came over concerns about the company's inability to cut its debt, which now stands at 70 billion euros ($68 billion). France Tlcom failed to get approval from 17 banks to refinance 4.7 billion euros ($4.5 billion) in loans to its German affiliate, MobilCom. The French company accumulated debt in the last two years as it bought license fees for mobile phone services. Shares of France Tlcom fell as much as 16 percent. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Support For Embattled Neighbor
description: King Gyanendra of Nepal, left, , met Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee and other senior Indian officials, who pledged support in his efforts to put down Nepal's violent Maoist rebellion. India has already offered its neighbor military equipment and intelligence to combat the insurgency. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, ROSENMANMURIEL
description: ZIMMERMAN-ROSENMANMuriel. Beloved wife of Stanley Rosenman. Devoted mother of Joyce Slochower & Peter and Gale Rosenman. Loving grandmother of Jesse, Alison, Avi & Stephen. Services on Tuesday 11:30 ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLNIT, ALBERT J., M.D.
description: SOLNIT-Albert J., M.D. The Officers and Directors of the Psychoanalytic Research and Development Fund record with shock and dismay the sudden death of their close associate, colleague and good friend. Dr. Solnit, recently Commissioner of Mental Health of Connecticut, founder and builder of the Child Development Center at Yale University Medical School, Professor of Psychiatry, Founder and Editor of The Journal The Psychonanalytic Study of the Child, was a remarkable clinician, adminiministrator, teacher, leader, and ardent and effective advocate for the welfare of children all over the world. He served also as Freud Professor of Psychoanalysis at the Hebrew University in Jerusaleum. He worked closely with us on many projects having to do with child psychonanalyis, taught us, promoted our endeavors and inspired us. Like a good leader, he has raised generations of disciples and students who now give expression to his vision in many medical schools and hospitals in this country and abroad. We hope that his wife and children, his many close colleagues and disciples, will soon find comfort with each other and in the fruitfullness of his visions. Mortimer Ostow, M.D. President Peter B. Neubauer M.D. Vice-President Henry Nunberg, M.D. Professional Director

title: Ricoh Selects Lowe & Partners
description: The Ricoh Company , the office-equipment company in Tokyo, said yesterday that it had named Lowe & Partners Worldwide to handle its worldwide corporate-image account. Spending for the assignment, which had no previous agency, was estimated at $60 million to $80 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Poor Ad Outlook
description: The WPP Group said it did not expect a pronounced recovery in the advertising market until 2004, when the presidential elections in the United States and the Olympic Games in Athens may rouse the slumping industry. The company said revenue for the first five months of 2002 fell 8 percent, excluding the effects of acquisitions and currency fluctuations. Philip Lader, the company's chairman, said he expected a slow return to growth, with 2003 better than 2002. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

description: Sydney Airport, the largest airport in Australia, was sold today for 5.6 billion Australian dollars, or $3.2 billion.

description: With the Downtown Athletic Club closed and in danger of never reopening, the Heisman Trophy is expected to be awarded at the Yale Club in December. A news conference is scheduled today.

Mass of Christian Burial at the Holy Family Church on Thursday 9:45AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Robot Spacecraft Will Investigate Mysterious, Icy Comets
description: NASA is preparing to launch a spacecraft whose mission is to make the closest observations ever of the frozen cores of comets and to stand ready to be diverted if a newly discovered comet passes near the Earth.

description: D'AMATO-Hugo A. Formerly of Bronxville, NY recently residing Mohegan Lake, NY passed away on Sunday. Beloved husband of the late Julia D'Amato; father of John, Lorrie, and James; and grandfather of Daniel Ponte. He will be reposing at McGrath Funeral Home, 20 Cedar Street, Bronxville, NY on Wednesday from 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM followed by a funeral mass at St. Eugene Roman Catholic Church, Yonkers at 10 A.M. on Thursday.

title: On Hot Trail Of Tiny Killer In Alaska
description: Edward Berg has a pair of doctorates, one in philosophy and another in botany, but for the last decade he has been a forensic detective in the forest, trying to solve a large murder mystery.

title: Another Death Penalty Ruling
description: Only four days after its landmark ruling barring the execution of retarded people, the Supreme Court announced another big change yesterday in the application of the death penalty. A 7-to-2 majority declared that a jury, not a judge, must make the factual determination about the existence of ''aggravating factors'' that make a convicted murderer eligible for the death penalty.

title: United Wants Loan Backing From U.S.
description: United Airlines filed an application with the government yesterday for a $1.8 billion guarantee to back $2 billion in private loans, the largest such request since the Sept. 11 attacks crippled the industry.

title: Ninth-Inning Homer Further Dims Mets' Season
description: Scott Strickland turned on the mound, and as he watched Keith Lockhart's fly ball to right field in the ninth inning last night, he dropped into a crouch. Lockhart's drive dropped over the outfield fence and Strickland dropped his head, his glove flopping on the dirt. He lifted his glove and squeezed it tight with his right hand.

title: Armed Passenger Prompts a Plane's Diversion
description: An American Airlines plane from Newburgh, N.Y., to Chicago made an unscheduled stop here today after crew members learned that a federal employee on board had not informed airline officials that he was armed.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: AUTOMAKER RESUMES TRADING Shares of the Chinese automaker, Brilliance China Automotive Holdings , began trading again after the company released a statement to explain the dismissal of its chairman, Yang Rong, last week and said he had not sold any shares in the company. The stock was suspended last week after the company disclosed in a newspaper ad that it had dismissed Mr. Rong, but it failed to issue a statement explaining the action. Talk that Mr. Rong was under investigation and had been forced to sell shares led to a sharp decline in Brilliance's share price last week. In its statement, Brilliance said it had replaced Mr. Rong to disperse management functions among more executives. Its stock rose 15.1 percent. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

description: WASHINGTON, June 24  President Bush told the Palestinian people today that they must replace Yasir Arafat as their leader before the United States will support an independent Palestinian state.

title: Pettitte Is Still in Search of Pettitte on the Mound
description: It has been almost eight months since Andy Pettitte pitched a game worthy of a second look. Pettitte is back in the Yankees' rotation, but he knows he is not the same. So he sat in a small office in the Coors Field visitors clubhouse last week, searching for himself.

description: PALO ALTO, Calif., June 24  The major American track and field season ended here Sunday with the last 20 finals of the national outdoor championships. Now the scene shifts to Europe and the seven rich Golden League meets, other Grand Prix meets, lesser competitions and then the World Cup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, BERNE R.
description: SAMUELS-Berne R., on June 23, 2002. Beloved son, brother and uncle, he was born January 21, 1919 in NYC, son of Max and Betty (nee Lusthans). Berne was a C.P.A. in NYC for many years. Predeceased by parents and brother Daniel. Survived by sister Rhoda Anker and her husband Leonard, Dobbs Ferry, NY, nephews Mark and Warren. title: World Briefing | Asia: India: A Warning To Pakistan
description: A spokeswoman for the Foreign Ministry warned Pakistan not to renege on commitments to ''permanently'' put an end to cross-border terrorism. Gen. Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's president, unambiguously made such a promise to the United States, according to American officials. But he said recently that while ''nothing is happening'' now along the Line of Control separating the Indian and Pakistani parts of contested Kashmir, he ''will not give an assurance that for years nothing will happen.'' Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUCH, EDUARDO
description: RAUCH-Eduardo. The JTS community mourns the death of Eduardo Rauch, who, since 1978 was a dedicated member of the faculty and administration. A deeply spiritual man of wide-ranging intellectual interests, charismatic classroom instructor and ethical role model, he taught for twenty-four years in the university's Department of Jewish Education and served for twelve years as co-director of its Melton Research Center for Jewish Education where he also was founding editor of the Melton Journal, creating an indispensable resource for Jewish educators. Born in Chile and educated there as a biochemist, he was transformed by his experience living and studying in Israel in the wake of the Six-Day War in 1967. Author of a forthcoming history of American Jewish education in the early 20th century, he published numerous articles for scholarly journals during his career. He is survived by his wife, Chicky, of New York and his father, Nathan, and brother, Claudio, both of Santiago, Chile. Ismar Schorsch, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Chairman

description: HOCHFELDER-Patricia B., June 25, 1982. We lovingly remember our mother now and always. Jim, Tom, John, Andrew and Peter

description: A Virginia day trader has agreed to pay $160,892 to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that he had artificially inflated prices of FTD.com and five other stocks after the markets closed.

title: Last 4 Firefighters Leave Ground Zero: 'Our Work Is Done'
description: Days passed, then months. On the second floor of 10-10, a tiny city firehouse within spitting distance of the World Trade Center site, the passage of time, and the sad success of their brutal labor, was tracked with a yellow fluorescent marker.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POST, SHELDON
description: POST-Sheldon. 9/5/36 to 6/25/88. Founder Chelsea Pines Inn, Chairman NYC Gay Men's Chorus, Board, Congregation Beth Simchat Torah. Fourteen years gone: a moment, a lifetime. As we celebrate Gay Pride Week, we pause to recall those who have gone before us in the still-present war against AIDS. Sheldon was a proud gay man who never stopped fighting to create a better world, who never lost his dream or his passion. A remarkable lover, son, brother, uncle, friend. Tom Klebba and I ask you to take a moment & remember a generation that is lost but not forgotten: Mark Fuschetti, Peter Monette, Gary Olde, Tom Dickey, Jon Flaherty, Gary Brubach, Benn Brown and Wayne Kell, Tom Bradley, Garon Douglas, Jay ''Peggy Sue'' Farrar, Dean X Johnson, Allan Kendric and Ron McSwiggen, Bob Levine, Eddie Peters, Martin Teitel, Quinton Johnson, Norman Sweet, Eddie Tilchen, so many others. ''Sometimes people leave you halfway through the wood. Do not let it grieve you, no one leaves for good.'' Sheldon, my love, know that you will always be missed and cherished. All will be remembered & celebrated as long as we live. Jay Lesige

title: City Seeks M.T.A. Takeover Of 7 Bus Companies' Routes
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said last night that the city had begun preliminary talks to have the Metropolitan Transportation Authority take over the routes of seven private bus companies that operate in the city. Workers at three of the companies are on strike in Queens.

title: Delay Is Reported for Adelphia Filing
description: The bankruptcy filing of the cable television operator Adelphia Communications was delayed yesterday as representatives of the company and its bankers continued to negotiate over the terms of $1.5 billion in loans that the banks are making to allow the company to reorganize. One bondholder who insisted on anonymity said he was not surprised that the negotiations were taking so long. ''Nobody trusts anything or anybody,'' the bondholder said. ''Everybody thinks there is more bad news to come.''

description: The death of St. Louis Cardinals pitcher Darryl Kile at age 33 illustrates that the first sign of heart disease can be sudden death -- and that even physically active young people can be its victims.

description: JOHNSON - Elizabeth Taft. Died on June 19 in Delray Beach. She was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walbridge S. Taft of New York. She leaves a daughter, Libby Lourie of Seattle; a sister, Lucie Bard of Locust Valley; and a step-son, David Johnson of New York. She was also a sister of the late Henry W. Taft of Camden, ME. She graduated from Miss Porter's School and Columbia University. Formerly married to the late Leon Lourie, Edward Chaplin, Peter Campbell and Gerald Johnson. Funeral Saturday, June 29, 11AM at the River Bend Cemetery in Westerly, R.I. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Westerly Public Library or Delray Beach Public Library would be appreciated.

title: Spanish Police and F.B.I. Get Their Men and Stolen Art
description: With an undercover F.B.I. agent playing the role of expert art appraiser and a hundred Spanish police officers infiltrating a Madrid hotel, a sting operation on Friday recovered 10 of 17 masterwork paintings stolen last year from the mansion of one of the world's wealthiest women, the Spanish police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

title: ImClone Broker Wavering on Testifying
description: Peter Bacanovic, the Merrill Lynch stockbroker who consulted with Martha Stewart when she sold her shares of ImClone Systems, is showing some reluctance to talk to Congress, which he had earlier agreed to do, Congressional investigators said yesterday.

title: Lobster Cream Sauce
description: This wonderfully rich, flavorful sauce is hardly an essential partner for the pike quenelles, but they do go together perfectly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, LIZABETH
description: FREEMAN - Lizabeth. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Lu. A devoted wife and mother, a master teacher, and a joyous sailor. Love and tears join those of Don, Leslie and Kane and Adam and Orsula. Arlene and Donald Shapiro

title: Pike Dumplings
description: This Lyonnaise specialty uses pike, a fish underused by Americans (though available from most supermarkets and fishmongers), but much beloved by the working class residents of Lyon. Instead of the semolina used in the calf's liver version, these quenelles use a panade  a binding paste made from a combination of milk, butter, egg and flour.

title: A Gibson With Rural Character
description: IF your cocktail passions rest with the gibson, you are all too familiar with the standard slippery cocktail onion of infinite shelf life. But at Washington Park, Jonathan Waxman's new restaurant-as-Greenmarket-showcase, a surprise garnish awaits. Standing in for those mothballesque jarred onions, you will find a group of slender, slightly pink, cheek-puckering pickled ramps perched on the lip of your glass, reaching into the drink like long, supple fingers. Pungent, with a sweet and peppery kick, they add the right tang to the classic cocktail.

title: The View From Tehran
description: So a senior Iranian official is explaining to me how the world looks from Tehran: Let's see, he says, Iran helps the U.S. organize the Northern Alliance, a longtime Iranian ally, to oust the Taliban in Afghanistan -- a regime Iran staunchly opposed. (''We are civilized fundamentalists,'' unlike the Taliban, sniffed an Iranian official.) Once the Taliban were out, Iran quietly aided the U.S. in forming the interim government in Kabul. Not a single Iranian was involved in Sept. 11, not a single Iranian has been found in Al Qaeda, and Iran's nuclear reactor is under international inspection. Iran has the most democracy and freest press of any Muslim country in the Middle East. And as a thank you, President Bush labeled Iran part of the ''axis of evil.''

title: Afghan Women in Political Spotlight
description: If Afghanistan has produced a surprise of late, it is the vocal and fearless entry of its women into the traditional male domain of politics.

title: Blows Keep Coming for an Argentina Long in Crisis
description: The president says it may be impossible to reach any agreement with the International Monetary Fund, the head of the central bank is giving up and going home, and the economy minister embarked tonight on a desperate quest to pry $18 billion from foreign lenders.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teachers Approve Contract
description: As expected, members of the United Federation of Teachers have approved a 30-month contract with the city and the Board of Education that calls for raises of 16 percent to 22 percent. Union officials, who announced a tentative settlement on June 10 with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, said more than 94 percent of 81,748 votes were cast in favor of the contract in a ballot completed yesterday. ''This agreement is a giant step forward to making our salaries competitive,'' said Randi Weingarten, the union's president. Besides giving teachers a larger raise than other city workers, the contract adds 100 minutes to the teachers' workweek. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid For Food Supplier
description: Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, a venture capital firm, agreed to buy Brake Brothers, a British frozen food supplier, for 433.7 million ($651.1 million) plus assumed debt. The offer values each Brake share at 825 pence, or 10 percent more than the closing price on Monday, the day before the deal was announced. The agreement comes as a rival suitor, the Bidvest Group of South Africa, awaits a ruling from British regulators on its proposed acquisition of Brake Brothers. Bidvest executives urged Brake shareholders to refrain from approving the deal with Clayton, Dubilier & Rice until British regulators offered their views on its own proposal. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: One Swift Kick by Germany Ends South Korea's Dream Run
description: Fireworks boomed again in the night sky, and the South Korean players took their customary postgame bows, but this time there was nothing to celebrate. A wonderful dream came to an end tonight. The chanted appreciation from 65,256 fans came in salute for a month well done, not a match well played.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, ESTHER
description: LEVINSON-Esther of Greenwich, Ct. on June 23, 2002 wife of the late Samuel, mother of Rebecca Herman and Michael, grandmother of William Herman, Deborah Abraham, Samantha and Zachery Levinson and great-grandmother of Rachel Abraham.

title: Wagner Is First Player To Hold 3 M.G.A. Titles
description: Johnson Wagner, a 22-year-old from Garrison, N.Y., won the Metropolitan Golf Association Ike tournament today and cornered the market in local play. With the victory, he became the first player in M.G.A. history to hold the association's three major titles at the same time, having won the M.G.A. Amateur and the M.G.A. Open last year.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I know the man. If he were going to kill me, he'd just shoot me.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBERBAUM, BOBBY
description: LORBERBAUM-Bobby. Beloved husband of Lynn. Loving father of Mark and Jamie, Lisa, and Andrew and Gail. Proud Papa of Scott, Matt, Brandon and Tyler. Dear brother of Donald and Leah and Helene. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett L.I., 11:30AM, Wednesday.

title: Amtrak Gives Itself 2 Weeks, in a Lightless Tunnel
description: Amtrak officials said tonight that they had found enough cash to operate for about two more weeks but warned that continued inaction by the White House and Congress would force the railroad to shut down by July 8 or 9.

title: After Winning Cup, Hasek Leaves His Crease
description: Dominik Hasek, one of the greatest goalies in hockey history, retired yesterday, a decision that enhanced the employment and salary opportunities for several of his peers.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Bill Blummer was named vice president for United States sales at the New York office of Terra Lycos, succeeding Rich Gotham, who resigned. Mr. Blummer had been senior vice president for media sales and marketing at the Foster City, Calif., office of the Key3 Media Group.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the last day of recovery work at the World Trade Center site misidentified the firefighter at the command post gazing out a window. He is Battalion Chief Stephen Rasweiler, not Captain Michael Banker.

title: C.I.A. Instructs Spy Agencies to Use More Commercial Satellite Photos
description: The director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, has ordered American intelligence agencies to expand their use of satellite photography provided by private companies, freeing the government's own satellites for more specialized and secretive work, intelligence officials say.

title: Search of Biologist Is Uneventful
description: Federal authorities today searched the home of a biologist who has done work on germ defenses for the government, but they found no evidence linking him to the mailing of deadly anthrax spores, law enforcement officials said today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Mont Blanc Tunnel Reopens
description: The Mont Blanc tunnel, closed three years ago after a truck fire killed 39 people, reopened yesterday despite protests by thousands of residents and environmentalists. The protesters oppose the full reopening of the tunnel, which links France and Italy, arguing that pollution from heavy truck traffic soils the air and harms people and trees in an area of great beauty visited by many tourists. Environmentalists are again pressing their longstanding demand that freight should be hauled in containers on the backs of trains, rather than roaring through the Alps in a procession of heavy trucks. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, FRANCIS C. (TUG),
description: WILSON-Francis C. (Tug), 62, in Denver, on June 17, 2002. Resident of Santa Fe, NM and Denver, CO. Capt. U.S. Air Force, Past President, Wilson Oil Co., and General Partner, Wilson Oil Co., Ltd. Graduate of St. Paul School and Stanford University. Past Chairman of the Republican Party of Santa Fe County, past board member, Santa Fe Opera Co. He is survived by his beloved sisters, Mrs. Janet W. Nolan of Mt. Kisco, NY, and Ms. MacGregor W. Peck of Cleveland.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Council To Consider New Archives Plan
description: A City Council hearing on legislation to govern how former mayors handle papers and other records from their administrations has been delayed, pending consideration of a proposal by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. Under his plan, mayors would be allowed to choose where their papers went and those seeking information in them would have to file requests under the Freedom of Information Act. Historians and others objected to the way Rudolph W. Giuliani removed his mayoral papers when he left City Hall. City Councilman Bill Perkins said a bill backed by the the mayor deserved more scrutiny. They backed a measure compelling mayors, retroactive to Mr. Giuliani, to keep public records in the public domain. Michael Cardozo, the city's corporation counsel, said the city would oppose such a policy but was flexible on other issues. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFRANK, THOMAS, 85
description: GOLDFRANK-Thomas, 85, after a brief illness, June 18, 2002. Loving and beloved father of Edward and daughters-in-law Janice Goldfrank and Victoria Ettlinger; grandfather of Nicholas. Predeceased by wife Emma Pearlin, son Frederick and three siblings. He was an MIT graduate and Licensed Professional Engineer who made his career engineering and supervising the construction of large scale projects. One of the last of these before retiring involved a major on-site supervisory role in the building of the SUNY/Purchase Campus where for the rest of his life he enjoyed a wide variety of perfomances and academic programs.

title: Corrections
description: An article and picture caption in Science Times yesterday about rival approaches to supercomputing misspelled the name of the project leader for a computer that emphasizes efficiency over speed. He is Dr. Wu-chun Feng of Los Alamos National Laboratory, not Wu-Chung Feng.

title: Malaysia's Prime Minister to Step Down After 2 Decades
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, a man who has been a bitter critic of the West but whose tight hold over this Muslim country made him a new ally against Islamic militants, announced today that he would be stepping down after two decades in power.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Military Group To Sell Shares
description: The China Aviation Industry No. II Group, which makes planes, missiles and autos, plans to sell shares in Hong Kong to finance expansion, the first of China's 10 state-owned military groups to list its main business overseas. China Aviation plans to list its civilian aircraft business, auto manufacturing arm and aviation components business, said Su Xingshe, a director of the company's news office. The company has not set a date for a listing, hired underwriters or determined how much it wants to raise, he said.

title: A Birch Forest and a Foot in Two Camps
description: FROM the outside, it's difficult to fathom why Butter, which opened not long ago a few doors down from the Public Theater, requires a pair of grim hosts posted like sentries in a glass-walled vestibule, their arms mentally crossed. As with London beefeaters, I felt compelled on a recent visit to try to make them laugh, but I decided that they must have serious work to do, like fending off people who want to be seated before their full party has arrived.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: U.S. Aid Offer Accepted
description: President Mohammad Khatami said Iran would accept the United States' offer of aid for survivors of the earthquake last Saturday in northwestern Iran. The countries do not have diplomatic relations but the United States said on Monday that it had offered food, temporary housing and water purification equipment through the Swiss Embassy, which represents its interests in Tehran. In another development apparently intended to lessen tensions between the countries, Mr. Khatami's government picked a moderate, Javad Zarif, as its representative at the United Nations. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Reduction In Budget Cut Relieves Arts Groups
description: After years of strong budget support from the city, arts groups will have to weather a cut in funds under the municipal budget adopted last week.

title: Man Held In Killings Of Fiance And Her Son
description: Moments before she was killed, Melescha Francis argued with her fianc, Larry Smith, because he was reprimanding her son, the police said. The 6-year-old boy, Michael Stultz, had spilled a bottle of bubble-blowing solution, the police said, and Mr. Smith yelled at him until Ms. Francis intervened.

title: Germans Fear Bombers May Attack 'Love Parade'
description: German authorities have discovered clues that an attack by militants might be in the works for the annual Love Parade festival next month, says the tabloid newspaper Bild. The event, on July 13, features techno music, drugs and nudity.

title: Governor Defends Acts During Strike In Connecticut
description: In sometimes terse and evasive testimony that drew admonitions from a federal judge, Gov. John G. Rowland today defended his administration's hiring of replacement nursing-home workers last year after 4,500 union members walked off the job.

title: Aides to Bush Say Arafat Financed a Terrorist Group
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  President Bush decided to call for Yasir Arafat's removal after receiving intelligence information last week showing that the Palestinian leader had authorized a $20,000 payment to a group that claimed responsibility for the most recent suicide attack in Jerusalem, senior administration officials said today.

title: Security Tight For G-8 Talks At Idyllic Spot In Canada
description: The photo ops are guaranteed to promote Canada as a pristine oasis of Rocky Mountain tranquillity when President Bush and the other Group of 8 leaders discuss the world's problems Wednesday and Thursday in the resort village of Kananaskis.

title: Family Killed in Fire Will Be Buried in Pakistan
description: The family of seven that perished together in a blaze in their Brooklyn apartment will be buried together in Pakistan after a funeral service that is expected to draw hundreds of mourners to a Coney Island Avenue mosque today.

title: Seven Nights for Five
description: At the Sunset Beach Resort and Spa, a 420-room hotel on the Montego-Freeport peninsula in Jamaica, families can stay seven nights and pay for five through Dec. 15. A family is defined as two adults and at least one child 12 or younger, all staying in the same room. Rates start at $230 a night for the couple and $35 a child, and include all meals, snacks and beverages, nonmotorized water sports, nightly entertainment and all taxes and tips, as well as access to the children's activity program; (876) 979-8800, or visit www.sunsetbeachjamaica.com .

title: At 12th St. Academy, Resistance to Being Closed Down
description: The seventh-grade humanities class at 12th Street Academy ended last week with a lesson on the Civil War.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: BUSINESS CONFIDENCE FALLS German business confidence unexpectedly fell in June, a survey of 7,000 companies showed, as the country's economy struggled to recover from recession. The Ifo economic research institute's index of western German business confidence declined to 91.3 from 91.6 in May. Retailers and construction companies led the decline. Analysts had predicted confidence would rise to 92 this month. An index of future expectations for business fell to 104.9, compared with 106.2 in May. (Bloomberg News)

title: Beyond the Briefly Inflated Canon: Legacy of the Mysterious 'W. S.'

description: FRIEDHEIM-Eric A. On June 24, 2002. Distinguished Publisher and Editor. Former White House Correspondent and owner of ''Travel Agent Magazine.'' Loving husband of Edith Hall Friedheim. Also survived by a niece, Jacqueline Kremer, stepdaughters Lisa and Cindy, and four grandchildren. Visitation on Thursday, 11AM at Krtil Funeral Home - Yorkville Funeral Service Inc., 1297 First Avenue (70 Street) NYC. Funeral services 12 noon. Entombment 1:30PM at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla NY.

title: Cooking Utensils, From the Spear to the Spoon and Fork
description: At first, ''The Epicurean Collector'' by Patrick Dunne and the editors of the magazine Southern Accents (Bulfinch Press, $40) seems dedicated to collectors of cooking and serving utensils. But this beautifully photographed book is also a lively history of food and cooking, from the dawn of the Iron Age until the early 20th century.

title: Bush, in Canada, Is Facing Skepticism on Arafat's Role
description: President Bush arrived here tonight for the annual summit meeting of major industrialized nations, but instead of basking in compliments for his actions to combat terrorism, he faced skepticism over his demand that Yasir Arafat be replaced.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KESSLER
description: KESSLEROHEN - Estelle/d. Born in 1909, died in New York City on June 25, 2002. She married Louis M. Cohen, a lawyer, and textile manufacturer and founding member of the United Jewish Appeal. They had two daughters Hannah and Sandra. When Louis died Estelle continued to work closely with the UJA and served as a Board member of the American Jewish Committees Women's Campaign. She later married Henry H. Kessler, founder of the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation in New Jersey. In later years, after Henry's death, she spent most of her time working for Rehabilitation International and the Kessler Institute and watching her five grandchildren grow, David, Brian, Kenneth, Nikolas and Alexandr. She also stayed close to her son-in-law Herbert Halberg and David's wife Frances. You are welcome to pay your respects on Thursday, June 27th, from 7 to 9 PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 81st St and Madison Ave. Services Friday, June 28, 2002, 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave at 65th St. It will be followed by a burial service at Mt. Carmel Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about the appointment of two executives as co-creative directors of the San Francisco office of Euro RSCG MVBMS Partners misspelled the surname of one of the executives. He is Bertrand Garbassi, not Grabassi.

title: Vivendi Board Backs Chief Despite Loss Of Top Ally
description: Jean-Marie Messier, the beleaguered chief executive of Vivendi Universal, once again defied critics who have called for his resignation by winning the backing of his board at a crucial meeting today, despite the loss of an important ally.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: S.E.C. Issues Warning On Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had reprimanded a teenager from Georgia who posted a fabricated article on the Internet under the name of a journalist from Bloomberg News, the financial news and information company. Benjamin Snyder, 17, of Lawrenceville, Ga., said he used the name of a reporter, John Rega, to try to inflate the stock price of Viragen International Inc., a drug company in which he had invested. John R. Stark, the head of Internet enforcement at the commission, said Mr. Snyder did not profit from his scheme and would not be fined. But Mr. Stark called the action outrageous. The S.E.C. issued a cease-and-desist order to prohibit Mr. Snyder from repeating his effort. Using a computer in a public library, Mr. Snyder posted an article on online investor message boards saying Viragen had been working on an anthrax treatment called Vivox that had been approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: NEW FINANCIAL OFFICER AT PEREGRINE Peregrine Systems Inc. , the troubled maker of business software, named Ken Sexton as its chief financial officer yesterday. He replaces Fred Gerson, who was chief financial officer of the San Diego Padres baseball team before being appointed by Peregrine last month on an interim basis. The company also named PricewaterhouseCoopers as its third auditor in as many months. The company said in late May that it would restate results to correct inaccurate accounting of as much as $100 million in revenue. A group of former employees added to the company's woes on Monday by filing a securities lawsuit on top of another suit filed last week. Shares in the company ended up 8 cents, or 8.7 percent, to close at $1. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Down Down Down East
description: The state's fiscal year 2002 budget shortfall, originally predicted to be $90 million, will actually be closer to $115 million, the state's finance chief said. Jane Waldron, commissioner of the Department of Administrative and Financial Services, said the deficit was swelling because income and sales taxes were falling short of revenue projections for May and June. Officials say the problem can be solved by taking money allocated to pay for state programs next year. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

description: ''Wanna see a scallop spawn?''

description: To the Editor:

title: Once a Lowly Meatball, Now a Broadway Star
description: The meatballs at Rao's in Harlem and at Baldoria in the theater district are delicious giants, which is why Baldoria's hamburgers are so good. ''When I was a kid,'' said Frank Pellegrino Jr., an owner of Baldoria whose father is an owner of Rao's, ''my mom would make hamburgers by flattening the meat from her meatballs. I couldn't stand regular hamburgers.'' So Mr. Pellegino, right, with his wife, Carla, Baldoria's chef, came up with a counterintuitive burger. While a well-made burger usually calls for ground beef that's not too lean, the Baldoria burger is half ground lean beef and one-quarter each ground veal and pork well blended with grated cheese, eggs, parsley, garlic, salt and pepper, bread crumbs and water. It's $13.50 at lunch only, with a choice of cheeses, and comes with shoestring potatoes.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Algonquin Hotel Sold
description: The Algonquin Hotel, literary gathering place of the Jazz Age, was sold yesterday for an undisclosed sum to a Denver real-estate partnership. The 165-room hotel on 44th Street near Avenue of the Americas had been on the market for the third time in 14 years. The buyer, Miller Global Properties Fund IV, said the hotel would be managed by Destination Hotels and Resorts. Charles Peck, president of Destination, said the hotel would be renovated and most of its staff retained. The Algonquin, bought in 1997 for $32.6 million by a partnership led by the Olympus Real Estate Corporation of Dallas, underwent a $5.5 million renovation in 1998. Jason Begay (NYT)

title: A Temper Tantrum and a Preacher in a Car
description: Graduates of the California Institute of the Arts in Valencia presented their work on Saturday night at Danspace at St. Mark's Church in a program that also included a piece by an ''honorary alumnus,'' Donald Byrd.

title: Former K.G.B. General Convicted of Treason in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, June 26  Oleg D. Kalugin, a retired K.G.B. general who became a vociferous critic of the post-Soviet Russian governments, was convicted of treason in absentia today and sentenced to 15 years in prison for disclosing state secrets to the United States.

title: Woman Guilty of Killing Spouse and Moving Body
description: AStaten Island woman who was accused of killing her husband, a prosperous Russian businessman, and then taking her children to Walt Disney World before reporting the man missing was convicted yesterday of second-degree murder and evidence tampering.

title: Williams Sisters Find Independence Works
description: Normally, the Williams sisters arrive at the All England Club trailed by a commotion as loud as tin cans behind a newlywed's car: the outrageous Richard Williams.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: AFGHANISTAN: HEROIN FLOW CONTINUES Afghanistan remains the world's top supplier of heroin to Europe and produces most of the opium-based drugs consumed in Central Asia, a senior United Nations official said. Despite efforts by the new government to cut down on opium production, Afghanistan still supplies 70 to 90 percent of heroin that reaches Europe, and supplies about nine million addicts in the world, said Bernard Frahi, head of the United Nations Drug Control Program.    Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Squaring Off a Pizza In a Geometric Fashion
description: Remember the square tomatoes that scientists tried to develop years ago so that they could be stacked easily? They would have been perfect on top of Cindy Klotz's square pizzas. Ms. Klotz started Buonissima Pizza about a year ago with traditional round thin-crusted pizzas. She switched to 10-inch squares because she thought they would be easier to cut into small servings for hors d'oeuvres (the pizzas are hand-formed, so some may be rectangular). The excellent pizzas, sold fresh or frozen for $6 to $7.75, are topped with tomatoes, basil and mozzarella; spinach and mozzarella; or Yukon Gold potatoes, red onions, mozzarella and sage. They take about 6 minutes at 400 degrees to heat to satisfying crispness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, ARTHUR
description: GREENBERG-Arthur. The Board of Directors, staff, participants and friends of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children wish to convey our heartfelt condolences to Ann Greenberg on the loss of Arthur, her beloved husband. Ann, the founder of our Association, was supported in all her efforts by Arthur. Arthur Greenberg, who served in the United States Army for many years, went on to a 32 year career in the U.S. Postal Service. Arthur is survived by his wife Ann, daughter Bonnie, and three grandchildren, Matthew, Sarah, and Devin. The funeral will be held at Schwartz Brothers Funeral Home, on Queens Blvd, in Forest Hills on June 27 at noon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRON, CAROLYN
description: BARRON-Carolyn. The partners, associates and staff of Silverberg Stonehill & Goldsmith, P.C. extend their condolences to Liz Goldsmith and her family on the loss of her beloved mother.

title: Where Curtain of Smoke Parts, a Vista of Ruin Emerges
description: Slowly, words and images are coming back from the fire's vengeance. Through video taken by work crews and property assessments by county officials, a more complete picture of the devastation is emerging. Some of it is staggering.

title: No Explosion Or Pilot Error In Plane Crash Near Taiwan
description: Investigators analyzing the crash last month of a China Airlines plane said today that the flight data and cockpit voice recorders, together with autopsies on the victims and an examination of the wreckage, showed no evidence of an explosion or pilot error.
