title: Knicks Pick Seventh, Unless a Trade Occurs
description: On a Monday evening conference call with reporters, Scott Layden was admittedly in position to guarantee very little concerning tonight's National Basketball Association draft. But one thing Layden, the Knicks' president and general manager, promised was that the Knicks would be a better team tomorrow morning.

title: Watching as the Trains Pass, Then Having to Take the Bus
description: The tracks pass right by Co-op City on their way to Penn Station, but no commuter train takes the 55,000 residents of the housing complex in the Bronx to Manhattan. They must take either a bus and a subway (a trip of more than an hour), or an express bus that is usually faster but that on bad traffic days can take about 90 minutes to reach 34th Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Palestinians Confirm Their Plans to Hold Elections Next January
description: JERUSALEM, June 26  Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority officially announced plans today to hold elections for president and legislative offices in January, as part of a broad proposal for civic and security reform that stopped short of President Bush's demand for Mr. Arafat's replacement.

title: Northrop Said to Consider Raising Bid for TRW
description: Northrop Grumman indicated to TRW's top management yesterday that it would be willing to raise its bid for the company in hopes of finally securing a deal after being rebuffed for months, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: The White House Letter on Monday, about the frequency with which President Bush mentions the White House dogs, misstated the age of his twin daughters, whom he discusses in public much less often. The daughters, Jenna and Barbara, are 20 years old, not 19.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLIKOFF, RUTH
description: POLIKOFF-Ruth. On June 24, 2002. Devoted mother of Phyllis Opochinsky and Rhoda Traun. Loving grandmother of Laurie, Juliet, Jillian and Seth. Services Thursday, June 27 at 11am at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, NY.

title: Pro-Israel Voices of 2 Parties Praise Bush Mideast Speech
description: Pat Robertson, the founder of the Christian Coalition, called President Bush's Middle East policy ''brilliant.'' Representative Robert Wexler, a Democrat from a heavily Jewish district in Florida, termed it ''very bold.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DART, JUSTIN JR.
description: DART-Justin Jr. Disabled persons throughout the world will forever revere your blessed memory. Fenmore R. Seton, Past Pres. Rehabilitation Int'l

title: Shuttle Fleet Is Grounded To Fix Cracks
description: NASA has grounded its fleet of four space shuttles and indefinitely postponed a flight of the shuttle Columbia because of tiny cracks found in the fuel lines of the Atlantis and Discovery shuttles, agency spokesmen said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERENCZ, ZOLTAN
description: FERENCZ-Zoltan. Died at the age of 96 at his home in Southbury, Connecticut on June 24. Born in Maramarossziget, Hungary, he emigrated to the United States in 1928. He trained as a clothing designer in Vienna and owned a custom tailoring business in midtown Manhattan from 1930 until his retirement in 1971. Devoted husband of 67 years to Dolores. Loving brother of Michael and brother-in-law of Joan. Cherished father of Dr. Jonathan Ferencz and daughter-in-law Maxine, daughters Allison Morrison and the late Elizabeth Sass. Beloved grandfather to Julianne, Benjamin, Peter, Michael, Merrill, Stephanie and Armand, great-grandfather of twelve and uncle to Gerald and Karen. Graveside services at Beth-El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ at 11 am, June 26. Contributions may be made to the American Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place SW, Washington, DC 20024-2126

title: Moderates In Arab Lands Accentuate The Positive
description: Moderate Arab governments, which got no advance warning of President Bush's call for the removal of Yasir Arafat, brushed aside the demand today, focusing instead on the fact that the once aloof Bush administration is now deeply involved in Middle East diplomacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLNIT, ALBERT J., M.D.
description: SOLNIT-Albert J., M.D. The Officers and Directors of the Psychoanalytic Research and Development Fund record with shock and dismay the sudden death of their close associate, colleague and good friend. Dr. Solnit, recently Commissioner of Mental Health of Connecticut, founder and builder of the Child Development Center at Yale University Medical School, Professor of Psychiatry, Founder and Editor of The Journal The Psychonanalytic Study of the Child, was a remarkable clinician, adminiministrator, teacher, leader, and ardent and effective advocate for the welfare of children all over the world. He served also as Freud Professor of Psychoanalysis at the Hebrew University in Jerusaleum. He worked closely with us on many projects having to do with child psychonanalyis, taught us, promoted our endeavors and inspired us. Like a good leader, he has raised generations of disciples and students who now give expression to his vision in many medical schools and hospitals in this country and abroad. We hope that his wife and children, his many close colleagues and disciples, will soon find comfort with each other and in the fruitfullness of his visions. Mortimer Ostow, M.D. President Peter B. Neubauer M.D. Vice-President Henry Nunberg, M.D. Professional Director

title: THE CHEF
description: WE do simple desserts at Esca because there isn't room in the kitchen to be fussy. We don't like desserts with 3,000 ingredients.

title: Morocco Arrests 3 More Terror Suspects
description: The Moroccan authorities said yesterday that an airport security officer in Casablanca and two other Moroccans had been arrested as part of an investigation into a suspected Al Qaeda plot to attack American and British ships in the Strait of Gibraltar and set off bombs inside Morocco.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, JEAN (NEE KATTELSON)
description: ROTHSCHILD - Jean (nee Kattelson). Beloved wife of the late Manny. ''MomMom'', to all who knew and loved her. Daughter Judy, son Alan, grandchildren Jennifer and Chris Singleton, Joanna Rothschild, Jonny Rothschild, daughter-in-law Ilene Rothschild. Service today 12 noon at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, New York

title: Court Reverses Finance Ruling On City Schools
description: A state appeals court yesterday overturned a ruling that New York State had failed its constitutional duty to ensure ''a sound, basic education'' for New York City schoolchildren, giving state lawmakers at least a temporary reprieve from a daunting financial and political challenge.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bill On Banning Parties Approved
description: The upper house of Parliament approved a law aimed at banning Batasuna, the political party accused of direct links to the violent Basque separatist group E.T.A. The bill, approved 214-15, allows the Supreme Court to ban any party deemed to have terrorist, racist or xenophobic attitudes. Moderate Basque politicians warned that the bill could fuel E.T.A.'s deadly campaign for Basque independence but the government says the law is necessary to prevent parties from ''protecting killers.'' Emma Daly (NYT)

title: A Night of Purity and Grace to Cap a Career
description: It was anything but business as usual when American Ballet Theater presented its first ''Giselle'' of the season on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. A packed theater roared its greeting as Susan Jaffe entered in Act I for what was billed as her final performance with the company. As farewell rituals go, this evening was drenched in exceptional warmth and special detail.

title: Don't Just Say No
description: Conservatives in Congress are undoubtedly right when they say that abstinence is the best way for teenagers to avoid pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases. If you don't engage in sexual activity, you can't very well get into trouble on either count. But they are recklessly wrong when they insist that sex education programs in the schools should teach abstinence only. The Senate Finance Committee needs to modify the government's blinkered approach when it meets today to mark up the latest welfare reform bill.

title: Mexican Border Crash Kills 6 As Van Hits Oncoming Traffic
description: Six people were killed on Monday night and several more were injured when a van loaded with 27 people believed to be illegal immigrants, apparently trying to avoid a Border Patrol check, drove into oncoming traffic with its lights off and struck a sports utility vehicle head-on, officials said.

title: Margin of Victory Falls in Bowl Rating
description: Every off-season, the six conferences behind the Bowl Championship Series convene to tinker with the formula that determines which two college football teams will play for the national championship.

title: A Fruity Vinegar With Elegance
description: One letter means a lot. Moscatel vinegar from Tarragona, Spain, is nothing like muscatel, a cheap wine made from the lovely muscat grape. Uni Moscatel Wine Vinegar has a honeyed fruitiness that is far more elegant than what you get from inexpensive balsamics. The pale amber color won't spatter your mesclun with brown droplets, and its gentle acidity is tailor-made for those who hesitate to serve vinegar-dressed salads. A 17-ounce bottle is $4.99 at Fairway markets.

title: The Poison Is Arsenic, and the Suspect Wood
description: It took six hospitalizations and a number of misdiagnoses before Lynn Milam learned what was causing the vomiting and diarrhea that almost killed her in 1999. The arsenic levels in her body, her doctor said, were about 100 times what they should have been.

title: East of Midtown, It's the Art of the Meal
description: ''WHAT is food to one man may be fierce poison to others,'' wrote the Roman poet and philosopher Lucretius. He might as well have said the same of contemporary art -- and of New York neighborhoods. This weekend, as the Museum of Modern Art opens in its new temporary location across the East River in Long Island City, Queens, visitors will have a chance to determine the validity of all three claims.

title: Merrill Breaks Tradition and Puts Executives in Ad
description: In a break from tradition at a time of turmoil, Merrill Lynch & Company was planning to start running a newspaper ad today that features its two top executives, David H. Komansky and E. Stanley O'Neal.

title: Airport Improvements Are Adrift After Sept. 11
description: At 3 o'clock on a weekday afternoon, there are no fewer than 75 travelers standing before the security checkpoint at Raleigh-Durham International Airport here. Proposals to design an expansion of the airport, in part to address this bottleneck, are being considered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, RICHARD E.
description: DEUTSCH-Richard E. 0n June 13, at age 85, on Nantucket Island where he lived. He is survived by a large family, by his wife Susan, his children David Deutsch of Washington D.C., Judith Deutsch of Zionsville, Indiana, R. Woodruff Deutsch of Dechard, TN, three stepchildren: Anthony Lowenstein of Greenwich, CT, Kate Elizabeth (Betsy) Lowenstein of Cambridge, MA, and Christopher Lowenstein of Thornton, CO., ten grandchildren, one great-grandchild and a brother, Armand Deutsch of Beverly Hills CA. To these and many more he was loved as ''Uncle Dick.'' A memorial service will be held in Sept ember on Nantucket. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the South Church Preservation Fund, P.O. Box 1023 Nantucket MA 02554.

title: Lawyers See Logic In Ruling On Schools
description: The reversal of Justice Leland DeGrasse's decision on the financing of New York City schools was probably predictable, legal experts said yesterday, since appellate courts are generally reluctant to second-guess fiscal decisions by state and local governments.

title: Plumbing Inspectors Are Latest Charged In New York Graft
description: Fifteen of New York City's 24 plumbing inspectors -- including the top inspector and the top supervisors in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx -- were charged yesterday with extorting hundreds of thousands of dollars to approve projects throughout the city. Three former plumbing inspectors and a former boiler inspector were also charged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNTON, JULIAN E.
description: LYNTON-Julian E. On June 23, 2002, at age 85. Beloved husband of Joan L. Lynton. Dear brother of Harold S. Lynton (Hattie). Loving father of Jonathan Lynton and Vicki Sendelle (Rick), Judy Schwartz (Edward), Barbara Sargent (Peter) and William L. Strauss III (Randi). Cherished grandfather of nine. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday 7-9 P.M. with service Thursday 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to The Center for Learning and Living at Marymount Manhattan College, 221 E. 71 St, NY, NY 10021, or New York Society for the Deaf, 161 William Street, NY, NY 10038.

title: Gas Masks Being Stockpiled on Capitol Hill
description: The Capitol Police are stockpiling up to 25,000 gas masks to protect tourists, lawmakers and their staffs in case of a terrorist attack, Congressional officials said tonight.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Rebels' Offer To Talk Brushed Aside
description: The government rejected an offer of peace talks from the Chechen rebel leader, Aslan Maskhadov. A Moscow radio station said it had received a letter from Mr. Maskhadov addressed to President Vladimir V. Putin proposing talks on ending nearly three years of war and a cease-fire starting July 15. An attempt at talks by envoys of the two sides went nowhere last fall. Defense Minister Sergei Ivanov said yesterday that talks with Mr. Maskhadov would happen ''only if he comes out with his hands up and then the prosecutor will talk with him.'' Mr. Ivanov spoke at a briefing to present documents seized several days ago, which he said linked Mr. Maskhadov and the rebels to international terrorism. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Inquiry Into Verizon Marketing
description: Federal regulators are investigating whether Verizon Communications illegally marketed its long-distance service in New Jersey before receiving government permission to sell it there. On Monday, the Federal Communications Commission announced that it had approved Verizon's petition to enter the New Jersey market. In May, Verizon said that one of its direct-marketing companies accidentally sent out a mailing urging New Jersey residents to buy its long distance service. But a rival, A T & T Corporation, complained that Verizon had also included long-distance advertisements in Verizon local-service bills sent to more than 500,000 New Jersey customers. Verizon has agreed to send letters to customers informing them that the F.C.C. had not yet approved Verizon's application. If the F.C.C. decides against Verizon, it could impose a hefty fine or even revoke the company's license for New Jersey's $2.2 billion long-distance market. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Blaming the Victim
description: Skipping past New York State's long record of shortchanging the educational needs of New York City schoolchildren, the state's intermediate appellate court issued a wrongheaded decision yesterday overturning a trial court ruling that declared New York's educational funding unconstitutional.

title: Britain's Expectations Not Bothering Henman
description: The current darling of the British paparazzi is not a teary soccer star suffering from World Cup blues or a fallen Spice Girl in trouble with love, but a flavorless tennis player with a haircut straight off the set of ''My Three Sons.''

title: Defendant in Sept. 11 Plot Accuses Judge of Trickery
description: Zacarias Moussaoui, who is charged in connection with the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, told the federal judge conducting his trial today that she was using trickery to ''prepare me for the gas chamber.''

title: Israeli Curfews Expand Hardships Imposed on Palestinians
description: They came walking across the scrubby hillside this afternoon in long, ragged lines, hundreds of Palestinians, mostly women, picking their way along dirt paths under a burning sun, back to their home villages after mostly unsuccessful efforts to get food or medical treatment during a brief lifting of the curfew in Bethlehem.

title: New Jersey Is Likely to Be Gay Marriage Battleground
description: The contentious battle over gay marriage, previously fought in distant Hawaii and rural Vermont, will move into the New Jersey court system on Wednesday, when a national gay rights group plans to file a lawsuit in state court here on behalf of seven same-sex couples who have been denied marriage licenses.

title: Tasting Report: Getting Their Fill of Fruit
description: Niebaum-Coppola $40

title: The Modern Moves With a Bang (Several)
description: Talk about excuses for a party.

title: Hyatt Hotel Is Taking Its Place On Hudson
description: A pier on the waterfront, where the most memorable structures not long ago were warehouses, is about to become the home of the upscale Hyatt Regency Jersey City.

title: Senate Confirms 2 CUNY Trustees
description: The New York State Senate has confirmed two more new trustees for the City University of New York: CAROL A. ROBLES-ROMAN, Mayor MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG'S deputy mayor for legal affairs, and VALERIE LANCASTER BEAL, an investment banker. Ms. Robles-Roman, 39, was previously special counsel to New York State's chief administrative judge, JONATHAN LIPPMAN, and director of public affairs for the state court system. She lives in the Bronx and was nominated by the mayor, who names five of CUNY's 17 trustees. Ms. Lancaster Beal is a senior vice president with M. R. Beal & Company, an investment banking firm founded by her husband, and is on the Regents advisory group for Georgetown University, her alma mater. She is 47 and lives in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and was nominated by the governor, who appoints 10 CUNY trustees. Mayor Bloomberg has also nominated Deputy Mayor MARC V. SHAW as a trustee, and GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI has renominated NILDA S. RUIZ, who is now on the board.

title: Cooling Off the Backyard Barbecue
description: THE Fourth of July guests are wandering around the backyard -- nibbling chips, manhandling the carefully stuffed grape leaves, sipping beer or some ros from Provence. You, on the other hand, are standing in front of the hot grill with smoke blowing in your face, watching a piece of chicken catch fire.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Falls
description: German business confidence unexpectedly fell in June, a survey of 7,000 companies showed, as the country's economy struggled to recover from recession. The Ifo economic research institute's index of western German business confidence declined to 91.3 from 91.6 in May. Retailers and construction companies led the decline. Analysts had predicted confidence would rise to 92 this month. An index of future expectations for business fell to 104.9, compared with 106.2 in May.

title: It's all about suits, stupid : What do men really want?
description: PARIS  Let's get right to the point here. The simple question about menswear runway shows is, of course, why? We know all about the women's shows. They are the fancy photo layout of fashion to come. With a few exceptions (designers who deserve to win the British Turner Prize), fashion houses show clothes that, using the old Reagan trickle-down theory, will eventually be worn by women. Not Everywoman, but all sorts of different women: The shows offer an enormous range of styles and even adoptable personalities, from the lady who lunches to the streetwalker or the postmodern bonze.

title: Publishers Council Spinning Off Ad Unit
description: The Magazine Publishers of America in New York will spin off its Custom Publishing Council into a separate organization. The council represents companies that publish magazines on behalf of advertisers.

title: Moderates in Arab Lands Accentuate the Positive
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, June 25  Moderate Arab governments, which got no advance warning of President Bush's call for the removal of Yasir Arafat, brushed aside the demand today, focusing instead on the fact that the once aloof Bush administration is now deeply involved in Middle East diplomacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SUMNER THURMAN
description: BERNSTEIN-Sumner Thurman. Bernstein, Shur, Sawyer & Nelson (Portland, Maine) acknowledges with great sadness the death of our extraordinary founding partner, Sumner Thurman Bernstein. He was a towering presence in the firm and in the community. He represented ''Kings'', he represented ordinary people; they each received the same high quality of legal service and human respect. His gifts were substantial. He used them for good purposes every day of his life. We will miss him greatly. We extend our condolences to his wife, Rosalyne Spindel Bernstein, to his son, Andrew J. Bernstein, his daughter, Beth B. Schneider, their spouses and their children. Leonard M. Nelson, Senior Partner Peter J. Rubin, President Gregory A. Tselikis Managing Partner

title: Loud Stars Offering Hits, Minus the Expected Pose
description: Of all the hard rock bands that have achieved success over the last few years, Incubus is by far the lightest. Even when the guitar riffs are loud and low, the group's songs float and occasionally soar. On Friday night at Madison Square Garden, the group put on a convincing performance that was both restless and mellow. Half a dozen times, the lead singer, Brandon Boyd, gazed into the crowd and said, ''Thank you so much, my friends.''

title: Russia Says Capital Flight Is Reversing
description: Two senior Russian government officials said today that more money was now flowing into Russia than out, suggesting that Russians were bringing some of their ''flight capital'' back home to spend or invest after years of stashing it overseas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTER, HAROLD
description: KANTER-Harold. On Saturday, June 22, 2002, of Queens, NY & N. Miami Beach, Fla. Loving husband of Frances, father of Michael and Carolyn and Steven and Sue; loving grandfather of Drew; brother of Helen Miller and brother-in-law of Kiki Hohauser. Funeral was Monday, June 24th; burial Beth David, Elmont, N.Y. Southern Florida papers, take note.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Woman Guilty Of Killing Spouse
description: A Staten Island woman who was accused of killing her husband, a prosperous Russian businessman, and then taking her children to Walt Disney World before reporting him missing was convicted yesterday of second-degree murder and evidence-tampering. A State Supreme Court jury in Staten Island found the woman, Elena Kiejliches, 36, guilty after about three hours of deliberation. The police found the body of Ms. Kiejliches's husband, Borys, 49, in a cardboard barrel in a marsh near the Belt Parkway on the Brooklyn-Queens border on April 25, 2000. He had been dead for some time when he was discovered. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDER, SAMUEL
description: FELDER - Samuel. The Board of Directors, members and staff of The League for the Hard of Hearing mourn the loss of Samuel Felder, father of Barry Felder, Esq., Executive Vice President of our Board of Directors. We extend our sympathy to his wife, Evelyn, and to his entire family. Joseph R. LaBato, President

title: 5 Injured in Explosion and Fire at Connecticut Chemical Factory
description: Five people were hurt, two of them seriously, when a chemical solvent exploded in a storage warehouse on the campus of Pfizer, the international pharmaceutical manufacturer.

title: Dunleavy Leaving Early Just by Choice, Not Need
description: Mike Dunleavy enters the N.B.A. draft bearing more than a few labels of distinction: projected No. 3 pick by the Golden State Warriors, winner of a national championship at Duke, son of a former professional and coach, underclassman.

title: AIDES TO BUSH SAY ARAFAT FINANCED A TERRORIST GROUP
description: President Bush decided to call for Yasir Arafat's removal after receiving intelligence information last week showing that the Palestinian leader had authorized a $20,000 payment to a group that claimed responsibility for the most recent suicide attack in Jerusalem, senior administration officials said today.

title: Pairings: Embracing an Airy Wine With a Tapestry of Flavor
description: CABERNET FRANCS are deceiving. While their ruby red color suggests heft and body, the wines can actually be quite light and quite juicy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATERNO, GEORGE EUGENE
description: PATERNO-George Eugene. Of Southampton, NY, died of heart failure in State College, PA, on June 23. Survived by his brother Joseph V. Paterno of State College, PA, and a sister, Florence (Cissy) Mittleman of Locust Valley, NY. Memorial service will be held today at the Memorial Chapel of the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, NY, at 2PM.

title: Visiting Priest Is Arrested In Sex Abuse of Queens Boy
description: A priest visiting a Roman Catholic parish in Queens was arrested last night and charged with the sexual abuse of a 12-year-boy during a Father's Day excursion to Rockaway Beach.

title: Doubleday to Sue Over Sale
description: In his strongest remarks about the pending sale of his half of the Mets, Nelson Doubleday said yesterday that he would file a lawsuit contesting the validity of the appraisal, and that the Aug. 12 deadline for Fred Wilpon, the co-owner, to make his first payment was ''not going to happen.''

title: Golf and Water in San Antonio Civic War
description: The scorching summer heat has arrived, deepening a drought and ushering in a familiar ritual here in the nation's 10th-largest city: watering restrictions. The long-term situation is so serious that local officials have mused about desalinating ocean water or importing fresh water from a few hundred miles away.

title: The Mideast Plan: Voices From Across a Chasm
description: To the Editor:

title: Massachusetts Ballot Panel Allows Race By Republican
description: A state commission ruled today that Mitt Romney, the Republican candidate for governor, is eligible to run, despite contentions by Democrats that he did not comply with Massachusetts residency requirements while living in Utah for the last three years.

title: Europe Lauds Bush Speech, But Rejects Arafat Ouster
description: European leaders today praised President Bush's speech on the Middle East and hailed it as welcome evidence of increased American involvement in the region, but they refrained from backing his implicit call to replace Yasir Arafat as the Palestinian Authority chairman.

title: INSIDE
description: New Bishop for Milwaukee

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Body Found In Plastic Bag
description: A badly decomposed body was discovered yesterday about 5:30 p.m. in a plastic bag that had apparently been dumped in front of a building at 619 W. 56th Street, between 11th and 12th Avenues, the police said. Investigators said no identification was found on the body, which appeared to belong to a female in her late teens or early 20's. The city medical examiner is investigating the cause of death. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Right Stuff for an Airline Loan: Political Pull
description: As it scrambled early this month to put together an application for $900 million in federal loan guarantees that it says are vital to its survival, US Airways encountered a more immediate problem: a provision in a Senate spending bill that would have cut the size of the loan guarantee program.

title: Critic's Notebook | Sublime Architecture: Sacred Interiors Aglow; A 17th-Century Dutch Artist Gets His Due at a Getty Exhibition
description: Thanks to Vermeer and Rembrandt, art of the 17th-century Dutch Golden Age is box-office magic. Hang their paintings, open the doors, crowds appear. A sociologist could probably come up with reasons for this, but one is obvious: both artists are charismatic stylists and humane thinkers.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Complaint Filed On Unlicensed CD'S
description: Royal Philips Electronics said yesterday that it had filed a complaint with the International Trade Commission against 19 companies that make blank compact discs, or distribute them, in an effort to curb imports of unlicensed discs. Philips, which is Europe's largest electronics company, said it sought to keep companies from infringing its patents on recordable and rewritable compact disc technology by selling the discs in the United States without a license. Officials for Philips said the company asked the commission to issue an order ''excluding importation of all unlicensed discs into the United States.''

title: Record Number Heading to College
description: RONALD HEDMOND, an entrepreneurial 19-year-old who wants to own his own hotel and restaurant someday, said that five Regents exams were the biggest obstacles on his road to graduation. Mr. Hedmond and the other seniors from the Schermerhorn Program at the New York Institute for Special Education in the Bronx are all legally blind. Yesterday, they celebrated a historic graduation: 12 of the 13 graduates are going on to college, the highest number in school history. Stephanie Rosenbloom

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An editorial last Friday supporting a Supreme Court decision that bans execution of the retarded stated incorrectly that apart from the United States, only Kyrgyzstan and Japan permit the death penalty for retarded convicts. The law in Kyrgyzstan prohibits the execution of the retarded.

title: Drunken-Driving Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Turning Pro Too Soon? Why Wait?
description: I WENT looking for Lenny Cooke of Brooklyn yesterday at the N.B.A. predraft interview session in Manhattan and wound up in the entertaining company of Maybyner (Nen) Hilrio of So Carlos, Brazil, and Nikoloz (Call Me Nick) Tskitishvili of Tbilisi, Georgia. The pro basketball universe is expanding, with no apparent contraction in sight.

title: World Briefing | World: Chips, Fries And Cancer
description: World Health Organization experts began meeting yesterday in Geneva to examine new studies showing that a cancer-causing substance, acrylamide, can be found in potato chips, french fries and certain other fried or baked starchy foods. Jorgen Schlundt, coordinator of the organization's food safety division, said: ''If what we know from water and animal experiments is true, it could be a very significant source of cancer in humans. It is not just another food scare.'' Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAITH, MAE (NEE RUSS)
description: HAITH-Mae (nee Russ). Of Wallingford, PA. On June 21, 2002. Daughter of the late W. McCoy Russ and Glovenia M. Russ of Smithfield, N.C. Survived by husband Linwood R. Haith, Jr. of 28 years, daughter Anne C. Haith of Wallingford, and son Linwood R. Haith, III of Atlanta, GA., two sisters, Alice Littlefield and Geraldine Russ Cox, four nephews and three nieces. Memorial service Saturday, June 29th 11AM, White Rock Baptist Church, 5240 Chestnut St, Phila, Pa. Contributions may be made to Howard University, Washington, D.C. Inquiries Chew Funeral Home, Inc., 215-545-3230.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, EMANUEL (MANNY)
description: WEINTRAUB - Emanuel (Manny). Passed away quietly on June 25, 2002. Beloved father of Tina Weintraub. Loving brother of Morris Weintraub and Pauline Slott. Cherished uncle, step-father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Service Thursday 11:30 am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: REBELS' OFFER TO TALK BRUSHED ASIDE The government rejected an offer of peace talks from the Chechen rebel leader, Aslan Maskhadov. A Moscow radio station said it had received a letter from Mr. Maskhadov addressed to President Vladimir V. Putin proposing talks on ending nearly three years of war and a cease-fire starting July 15. An attempt at talks by envoys of the two sides went nowhere last fall. Defense Minister Sergei Ivanov said yesterday that talks with Mr. Maskhadov would happen "only if he comes out with his hands up and then the prosecutor will talk with him." Mr. Ivanov spoke at a briefing to present documents seized several days ago, which he said linked Mr. Maskhadov and the rebels to international terrorism.

title: If That TV Set Had Only Worked . . .
description: In the muggy hour before dawn the crowd began to fill the street in Flushing, Queens -- several hundred or perhaps a thousand people, mulling in front of the huge video screen, warming up their vocal cords. Many wore T-shirts that said ''Be the Reds.'' And every one of them anxiously awaited the moment when their ancestral country, South Korea, playing host to the World Cup for the first time, would make its first appearance in the semifinals.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Journalist's Appeal Turned Down
description: The supreme court rejected an appeal by the jailed journalist Grigory Pasko and also turned down an appeal by prosecutors to toughen his sentence. Mr. Pasko, a military journalist, has served more than half of a four-year prison sentence on a treason conviction for gathering information for Japanese television on the dumping of nuclear waste by Russia's Pacific Fleet. His case has been a major cause among Russian and international environmental and human rights advocates, who say he did not reveal any state secrets. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

description: Quenelles de Foie de Veau a l'Alsacienne (Alsatian Calf's Liver Dumplings)

title: Marching in Place, the Mets Look Ahead
description: Greg Maddux ambled out of the trainer's room in a T-shirt and long underwear, with his strained left calf freshly wrapped, as he carried a bag of potato chips. He glanced around the barren clubhouse and, between munches, wondered aloud where the rest of his Atlanta Braves teammates were hiding. It was a humorous sight yesterday, and even though the Mets did not witness it, it would have been a comforting sight.

title: Bozell in New York Loses Datek Account
description: Bozell in New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, will lose Datek, the online discount brokerage firm, as an account. The assignment is being shifted to the agency that handles advertising for the Ameritrade Holding Corporation, which is acquiring Datek's parent, the Datek Online Holdings Corporation.

title: The Age of Acquiescence
description: A friend of mine over the weekend was recalling her days as an idealistic child of the 60's. Students sitting around the dorm, amid the water bongs, water beds, strobe lights and Che posters, listening to Led Zeppelin and Dylan, dreaming about remaking the world in their own image, trading nightmares about spying Big Brother and soul-robbing corporations.

title: Perfect Start, but Mets Still Need Great Escape
description: Armando Benitez had just watched his full-count slider to Gary Sheffield tail off the plate. Sheffield took a step toward first base before being called out by Umpire Matt Hollowell and looked back in disbelief. Benitez was already celebrating, pumping his arms like a train and shaking his belly in celebration on the mound.

title: 10 Pakistani Soldiers Are Killed in Fight With Al Qaeda Suspects
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 26 — Ten Pakistani soldiers were killed today in a gun battle with suspected members of Al Qaeda, marking the deadliest encounter yet in the hunt for terrorists on this side of the Afghan border.

title: Political Donations Thriving at State Level
description: As state political parties prepare to assume a much larger role in campaign fund-raising, a new report shows them to be very skilled already at soliciting the sort of unlimited donations from corporations, unions and others that will soon be off-limits to national parties.

title: Kuwaitis Press U.S. Over 12 Held at Guantnamo
description: The notes arrive sporadically from the Kuwaiti prisoners held at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: A Threat of Derailment
description: Reckless brinkmanship in Washington is threatening to disrupt the Northeast's economy and jeopardize millions of Americans' summer travel. The Bush administration has said it will find a way to provide Amtrak with the $200 million it needs to hobble on until the end of the current fiscal year, but it has yet to do so. David Gunn, Amtrak's president, has warned that without a transfusion, the railroad will be forced to shut down.

title: Pope Chooses A Successor To Prelate In Milwaukee
description: Pope John Paul II yesterday named Bishop Timothy M. Dolan, who formerly headed an American seminary in Rome and has most recently served as auxiliary bishop in St. Louis, to succeed Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee.

title: Three Teenagers Charged in Fire That Spread Along Jersey Shore
description: Three teenagers who illegally lighted a campfire in a tinder-dry state park were charged today with accidentally starting a blaze that destroyed more than 1,300 acres of pineland near the Jersey Shore this month.

title: Lawyers Argue Over Rights of a Citizen Seized on Enemy Land
description: An appellate judge hearing one of the most closely watched cases pitting civil liberties against national security seemed favorable today toward the government argument that an American citizen can be held indefinitely without being charged with anything or represented by a lawyer.

description: BERGLAS-Alice (nee Pollak). On June 25, 2002. Beloved and devoted wife of the late Bernard. Daughter of Salo and Frieda Feigenbaum Pollak. Loving mother of the late Robert and of Peter. Dear mother-in-law of Alice Katz Berglas. Adoring grandmother of Nancy, and caring Lisl to Benjamin. Service Wednesday, 11:30 AM at ''the Riverside'', 76 St., and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to Temple Shaaray Tefila.

title: 2 Witnesses Put Schwarz With Louima
description: Sgt. Eric Turetzky, the police officer whose testimony essentially sent Charles Schwarz to prison once before in the Abner Louima brutality case, took the stand yesterday at Mr. Schwarz's latest trial and once again directly contradicted Mr. Schwarz's account of his actions on the night of the attack.

title: Orneriness Deserves Its Laureate As Well~
description: It took some time to get used to the world Chris Elam and his Misnomer Dance Theater created on Friday night at Joyce SoHo. Mr. Elam, a modern dancer trained in Indonesian traditional dance, sets inarticulate bodies adrift in unknowable situations and places. Most of those bodies are not pretty in the traditional dance sense. They are crabbed and fidgety -- not a straight line among them -- and they're seemingly uncertain of where they are headed or why. The dances' gnomic titles and the frequently gnarled music offer little relief.

description: The Bush administration moved ahead today with steps to strengthen the United States' borders, while Congress questioned whether other measures to prevent terrorism were being delayed by plans for a new department for domestic security.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Voting Talks Stall
description: The state and several counties are at an impasse in settlement talks with civil rights groups that have sued over voting problems in the 2000 election, a lawyer for the groups said. The N.A.A.C.P., the American Civil Liberties Union and three other civil rights groups want voters who were wrongfully purged from the rolls put back and standards created for voter registration. The groups have reached agreements with Broward and Leon Counties but not with the state and Miami-Dade, Duval, Hillsborough, Orange and Volusia Counties. A trial is set for Aug. 26; the groups want to continue mediation. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: Auto Union and Honda Dispute Safety Record at Plants in Ohio
description: Honda's four factories in central Ohio, including its sprawling assembly plant here that makes the highly popular Accord, turn out quality cars and motorcycles that are among the most profitable in the industry. But the United Automobile Workers says that the stellar efficiency comes at a price -- injury rates more than double the average for the American auto industry.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: F.B.I. Searches Software Maker
description: F.B.I. agents searched Speedera, a small Silicon Valley software maker, on Monday, the company said yesterday. The company said it was uncertain about the reasons for the search, given that the affidavit supporting the search was sealed. The F.B.I. could not be reached for comment. But officials from Speedera said that they received a civil complaint yesterday from a competitor, Akamai, that might be related to the search, both companies said. The complaint from Akamai contends there was trade secret theft by Richard Day, Speedera's co-founder and chief technology officer. According to the complaint, Akamai says its proprietary information about customer Web site performance was stolen by Speedera from the computers of Keynote Systems, a company that tracks Web site performance. Gordon Smith, head of marketing at Speedera, said the company denied the allegations. Mr. Smith said Speedera, based in Santa Clara, Calif., was visited on Monday by four or five F.B.I. agents, who removed documents and computer files from Mr. Day's office. Mr. Smith said Speedera was outraged by the search and believed it to be related to a patent infringement lawsuit brought against Speedera by Akamai in February. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Family Settles Police Abuse Suit
description: Lawyers for the children of a prisoner who died in police custody announced a $2.7 million settlement of a civil suit charging negligence and police misconduct yesterday. The prisoner, Earl Faison, an asthmatic, died after being beaten and pepper-sprayed shortly after he was mistakenly apprehended in the 1999 shooting of an Orange police officer. David Mazie, the lawyer for Mr. Faison's estate, said the settlement, ratified last week, has an annuity value of $5 million for each of the four children, who range from 4 to 7 years old. The announcement came a day after a federal appeals court panel reinstated guilty verdicts on conspiracy charges against the five police officers. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Tanzania, In Mourning, Investigates Crash of Train
description: The up-country train is always full and always slow. It hauls people, produce and anything else passengers manage to cram aboard between Dar es Salaam, on the coast, and the remote villages along Lake Victoria.

title: Liberty Protects a Sturdy Lead And Beats the Fever by 19
description: The Liberty did not fade away last night. Crystal Robinson made sure of it.

title: In Issue of Firing, Fairness Is Crucial
description: All large organizations have some employees who do not perform well. School districts are no exception, but getting rid of incompetent teachers remains a vexing problem for administrators. When teachers are fired, it is usually for gross misconduct, not inadequate instruction.

title: Flavors of Asia Infuse Chocolates From Brooklyn
description: Eric Girerd, right, was not fazed by the challenge of making chocolates flavored with spicy wasabi peas. Mr. Girerd just did what he does when he seasons spice- and tea-flavored ganache fillings: he steeped the peas in cream for a day, strained the cream and heated it before mixing it with chocolate. The wasabi chocolates were for Tao, an Asian restaurant in Manhattan, but he makes others for retail sale. Mr. Girerd, from Annecy, France, worked at Le Chantilly in Manhattan before going to Seoul for two years, and now works in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. He uses curry, nutmeg, cumin, coriander and various teas in his chocolates, which also feature traditional flavors like coffee, passion fruit, raspberry and hazelnut. They are mostly hand-dipped for sleek, tantalizing little bites that are not too sweet or too seasoned. His chocolates, $44 to $48 a pound, are sold at Likitsakos Market, 1174 Lexington Avenue (80th Street), and are served at hotels and restaurants. By mid-July, they will be available from www.ericgirerd.com.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: CHURCH BARS CANDID CANDIDATE

title: The Gunfire Is Past, but Not the Echoes
description: WHEN a gunman went on a rampage in the East Village two Sundays ago, shooting three people and taking hostages in a crowded wine bar, it seemed like an isolated act of violence in a neighborhood that is usually safe. But the incident had far-reaching effects on many of New York's top restaurants: the wine bar the gunman invaded is a popular hangout for many of their employees.

description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: New Financial Officer At Peregrine
description: Peregrine Systems Inc., the troubled maker of business software, named Ken Sexton as its chief financial officer yesterday. He replaces Fred Gerson, who was chief financial officer of the San Diego Padres baseball team before being appointed by Peregrine last month on an interim basis. The company also named PricewaterhouseCoopers as its third auditor in as many months. The company said in late May that it would restate results to correct inaccurate accounting of as much as $100 million in revenue. A group of former employees added to the company's woes on Monday by filing a securities lawsuit on top of another suit filed last week. Shares in the company ended up 8 cents, or 8.7 percent, to close at $1. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: The Mideast Plan: Voices From Across a Chasm
description: To the Editor:

title: Alsatian Beauties
description: Alsace is a food lover's paradise, famous for hearty dishes such as pork and sausage choucroute, cheese-laden onion tarts (flammekueche), and of course, quenelles. When choosing wines to go with the rich and often pungent cuisine, remember the old culinary adage "what grows together, goes together," and reach for white wine from Alsace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASKIN, HAROLD H.
description: HASKIN-Harold H. Died Sunday, June 23, 2002. Age 87 of Cape May Court House and Piscataway, NJ. Rutgers Professor and marine biologist specializing in shellfish research. Survived by wife, Peggy and children, Kathleen Haskin, Jean Haley, Elizabeth Haskin, Frederick H. Haskin, and Mary D. Haskin. Also survived by four grandchildren. Memorial service to be announced in the Fall. Memorials to: Harold Haskin Fisherman's Forum or Harold Haskin Memorial Scholarship Fund, both c/o Rutgers University Foundation, 7 College Ave., New Brunswick, NJ 08091. Condolences to: www.radzieta.com

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Auto Agreement With State Farm
description: State Farm Indemnity, the state's largest auto insurer, has agreed to postpone a decision to withdraw coverage from all of its 730,000 customers until late 2005, officials said yesterday. In return, the insurer will be allowed to drop 96,000 customers over the next two years. Gov. James E. McGreevey and the state's banking and insurance commissioner, Holly C. Bakke, issued what is known as a market stabilization order to the insurer. Starting in September, the state will allow the company to deny coverage to 4,000 vehicles a month, with a 60-day notice to policyholders.

title: African Opportunity
description: Africa has enjoyed too few of globalization's benefits and suffered too many of its costs. The continent's future should get the attention it deserves at this week's summit of Group of 8 democracies in Canada. On the table Thursday will be an African proposal for a new economic bargain that should push President Bush, the leaders of seven other industrialized nations and the presidents of South Africa, Nigeria, Senegal and possibly Algeria beyond the usual platitudes about cooperation.

title: Introduction
description: Almost every cuisine has its version of the dumpling: a small, self-contained mixture of meat and/or vegetable with some kind of binding agent, sometimes stuffed into a doughy wrapper. The French have a few different varieties of dumpling, but none is more identifiably Gallic than the quenelle. Quenelles are simply a paste made from minced meat, fish or vegetables, bound with eggs and/or flour, then poached in stock. When made correctly, they are indescribably airy and luscious  kind of like savory mini-souffles.
