description: WorldCom Overstated $3.8 Billion in Cash Flow

title: Here, Dignity Rubs Elbows With Demand; Ground Zero Crowds Don't Please Everyone
description: Remember when it was just hallowed ground?

title: Nets Plot Draft Pick With Eye On Future
description: The Nets no longer have the urgency to rebuild or restock their roster, so they can afford to be choosy with the No. 24 pick in tonight's N.B.A. draft. That choice, however, will most likely come down to the frantic five minutes allotted each team.

title: Africa's Development
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: MORE INTEREST IN DAEWOO Suzuki Motor of Japan said it would join General Motors as a partner in GM-Daewoo Auto and Technology, the company that has emerged from the complex deal under which General Motors is taking over the bankrupt Daewoo Motor. Suzuki Motor, in which G.M. has a 20 percent stake, said it would invest a significant but still undisclosed portion of the $400 million that G.M. has guaranteed as payment for two-thirds of the new company. G.M. has said it will own 42.1 percent of the company while its partners will own 24.9 percent. Fiat of Italy, in which G.M. also owns a minority stake, has also been mentioned as a possible partner. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: U.S. Clears Redistricting Plan
description: The Justice Department approved newly drawn lines for Congressional districts yesterday, the department said. The move clears the way for potential candidates to gather petition signatures to qualify for the ballot. Petitioning was set to begin June 4 but had been temporarily stopped by court order. On June 5, the State Legislature approved the new district boundaries, eliminating 2 of New York's 32 seats to reflect population changes from the 2002 Census. Shaila Dewan (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Death Benefits For Domestic Partners
description: President Bush has signed a bill to provide a federal payment to same-sex partners and other life-insurance beneficiaries of public safety officers killed in the line of duty. By signing the measure, the Mychal Judge Act, Mr. Bush authorized the paying of benefits to the domestic partners of officers killed in the Sept. 11 attacks who did not have a legally recognized spouse, son, daughter or parent. The president's action clears the way for payments of $250,000 to the partners.

title: Market Place; Master Fixer Of AOL Suffers First Setback In Cable Loss
description: Richard D. Parsons, AOL Time Warner's new chief executive, is not renowned for embracing big, visionary risks, as is Rupert Murdoch. He does not style himself a creative force, as does Michael D. Eisner. And he is not known as a financial guru, as is John C. Malone.

title: High Grades on Teacher Test
description: More than 97 percent of State University of New York students who took the teacher licensing exams in 2000-1 passed them, SUNY has announced. The passing rate at Cornell, which includes several SUNY campuses, was 100 percent. No SUNY campus had a passing rate below 90 percent. Other colleges at 100 percent included Bank Street, Barnard, Fordham's Tarrytown campus, New School, Sarah Lawrence, Siena, Skidmore, Union, Utica, Vassar and Yeshiva.

title: Remembering Kile
description: John Vander Wal went back to the clubhouse at Qualcomm Stadium for a quick break during the early innings of Saturday's Yankees-Padres game in San Diego. The television was on, and Fox was reporting the stunning news of the death of St. Louis Cardinals pitcher Darryl Kile.

title: Moscow Journal; In a Museum's Mauling, One More Disaster of War
description: Inside a cramped workshop here, a team of restorers are hurrying to repair the ravages of war. On an easel in one corner, a landscape painted by Fyodor Lvov in 1854 shows hardly a scar from the 25 holes torn through it by the shrapnel and falling bricks.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Pavarotti Says He's Busy

title: Floating Like a Feather In a Forbidding World
description: The new production here of Weber's ''Euryanthe,'' which opened this evening, offers a familiar overture followed by what will be for most visitors a trip into the unknown. That trip turns out to be well worth taking, thanks to a tremendous performance by the German soprano Anne Schwanewilms in the title role, to vigorous and flavorsome playing by the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment under Mark Elder, and to a production by Richard Jones that, despite some miscalculations, gives the drama an iron strength.

title: The Happiest Feet Are on His Legs
description: BIG raindrops are splattering onto the main plaza of Lincoln Center just as Paul Grecki arrives from his day job as a mail carrier. He's one of New York City's premier Lindy Hoppers, and he's here to show off some moves in the very spot that turns into an outdoor ballroom with the start of Midsummer Night Swing.

title: Harold Visotsky, 78, Dies; Revamped Mental Health System
description: Dr. Harold M. Visotsky, a psychiatrist who revamped the Illinois mental health system, creating a model that was adopted in much of the nation, died on June 16 in Park Ridge, Ill. A resident of Evanston, he was 78.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAKE, FREDERICK CHARLES II.
description: DRAKE-Frederick Charles II. Was born in Taft, CA on January 28, 1958. In 1993 he founded the Rancho de la Luna recording studio in Joshua Tree, CA. A resident of Houston for many years, Fred is survived by his beloved mother and father, Josephine and Charles, his sisters Melanie and Deidre, his nieces Taylor, Jordan and Kennedy, and his horse and dear companion Kashmir. On Thursday June 20, Fred died as he lived-with grace and dignity, surrounded by friends in his home in Joshua Tree.

title: Ex-Envoy Faults Salvador Army Over Torture
description: Testifying in a civil suit brought by three Salvadorans who accuse their country's military of torturing them two decades ago, a former United States ambassador to El Salvador said today that the failure of military leaders to rein in murderous troops had been the biggest obstacle to democracy.

title: Samuel Rabinove, 79, Lawyer For American Jewish Committee
description: Samuel Rabinove, who as legal director of the American Jewish Committee for more than 30 years was a prominent advocate of strict church-state separation, died on June 9 in White Plains. He was 79 and lived in White Plains.

title: The Commute to Shea
description: The Triboro Bridge has offered a particularly hairy ride for commuters the past few weeks as construction continues over the main span. Last Thursday was a particularly bad day, with traffic spilling over beyond the tolls. I had just crawled through the EZ-Pass lane when I noticed a black Mercedes creep alongside me. For some reason, the passenger caught my eye, perhaps because he was waving his arms frantically.

title: Agency Says 'Dirty Bomb' Could Be Made In Any Country
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency said today that virtually any country in the world had the radioactive materials needed to build a ''dirty bomb,'' and that more than 100 of these countries had inadequate controls to prevent their theft.

title: Alsatian Calf's Liver Dumplings
description: Chef Soltner is a master of Alsatian cuisine, and this dish is a classic from his repertoire. Even if you don't like liver, don't be put off: the final product does not have a livery taste; it is rich and savory, but far from overwhelmingly meaty.

title: The Collections / MILAN : Prada versus Burberry:both take the laurels
description: It was the battle of the bourses  a struggle between two powerful fashion houses to burnish their images before an initial public offering.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Wednesday about the dominance of Clear Channel Communications in the radio industry referred incorrectly to the company's relationship with the Hispanic Broadcasting Corporation. It owns 26 percent of Hispanic Broadcasting; it has not tried to buy the entire company.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Acquisition Of Baker Is Approved
description: The Barilla Group of Italy, the world's biggest pasta maker, won European regulatory approval to buy the German baker Kamps for 1.8 billion euros ($1.7 billion) after offering to scale back its crisp-bread business. Barilla will sell Kamps's Lieken Urkorn brand to a competitor with experience in the food industry, the European Commission said. Barilla owns Wasa, a Swedish maker of crisp breads that already has more than 50 percent of the German market.

title: Senator Vents And Gives Mayor a Start
description: Few issues stimulate as much public outcry as the question of where to locate homeless shelters. But rarely do elected officials come close to a physical altercation over the matter.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Preventing 'Blue Flu'
description: Detroit police officers planning to take part in a ''sick-out'' on Wednesday will have to prove they are ill, a judge ruled. The officers' union took Chief Jerry Oliver to court after he ordered any officer who called in sick that day to undergo a medical examination. Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

title: Mayor Seeks New Approach On Private Bus Companies
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said last week that he would not get involved in the dispute between striking bus company workers and their private employers, he was not simply staking out a position on a labor issue, but deviating from a transportation policy of sorts that has hamstrung several mayors before him.

title: Where New Teachers Find Old Hands Who Help Them Cope
description: Rachel Nall was feeling overwhelmed. As a rookie teacher at Public School 175 in Harlem, she was struggling to assert her authority, but nothing seemed to work.

title: US BANCORP UNIT FINED $250,000 BY NASDAQ BODY
description: US Bancorp Piper Jaffray and one of its senior investment bankers were fined by regulators for threatening to drop Antigenics Inc. as a research client unless the biotechnology company hired the firm to arrange a stock sale. The National Association of Securities Dealers fined the unit of US Bancorp $250,000 and a managing director, Scott Beardsley, $50,000. The case is the first in which the N.A.S.D. punished a company for making a threat linking underwriting and research coverage, said Brian Rubin, a deputy chief counsel with N.A.S.D. regulation. In settling, the firm and Mr. Beardsley neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing.

title: THE WORLD CUP : Germany shatters Korea's dream
description: TOKYO:  It is over. The dream of South Korea reaching the final of the first World Cup played on Asian soil ended Tuesday night in its own capital, Seoul, where 64,000 people, overwhelmingly Korean supporters, could not quite breathe enough hope and excitement into their team to push the phenomenal journey the last leg of the way.

title: House Panel Deplores Bermuda Tax Strategy
description: Republicans and Democrats at a House hearing today denounced as unpatriotic corporations that acquire a Bermuda address so they can stop paying taxes on profits earned in the United States, but made no progress toward an agreement on how to close the loophole.

title: BOEING AND MACHINISTS' UNION START NEGOTIATIONS
description: Boeing and its machinists began negotiations yesterday on the terms of a new contract. The current contract will expire on Sept. 1, and negotiators for both sides say that they hope to reach an agreement before then. The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents 25,000 Boeing employees, said the three main issues were job security, retirement funds and health care. Negotiators met yesterday in Wichita, Kan., and will meet again later this week in Seattle, where the talks will begin in earnest. Boeing has manufacturing operations in Kansas, Oregon and Washington State. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Washington Talk; Republicans' Passion for Term Limits Has Cooled
description: Politicians often embrace term limits when they are running for office, stirring voters with bold talk of reform and the need to regularly rotate the reins of power. But living with term limits is often far more difficult.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: COUNCIL TO CONSIDER NEW ARCHIVES PLAN

title: A Scrappy Rocker Howling And Yelping Above the Din
description: When people talk about rap-rock, they're usually talking about a simple division of labor: the band plays rock 'n' roll riffs, and the lead singer does the rapping. Korn's rap-rock works the other way around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, SHIRLEY (NEE LEVINE)
description: GREENBERG-Shirley (nee Levine), of East Meadow, N.Y. Beloved wife of Leon for 53 years. Loving mother of Edward and Richard. Devoted sister to Ruth Ciline. Adored grandmother of Jonathan. Great friend and cherished mother-in-law of Janet. She will be remembered for her loving kindness, great pride in her family, a wonderful sense of humor. She will be missed by all. Services Wednesday, June 26, 11:15AM, from the ''Riverside Chapel'', Amsterdam Avenue and West 76th St, NYC

title: Bozell in New York Loses Datek Account
description: Bozell in New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies , will lose Datek, the online discount brokerage firm, as an account. The assignment is being shifted to the agency that handles advertising for the Ameritrade Holding Corporation , which is acquiring Datek's parent, the Datek Online Holdings Corporation.

title: Henry J. Latham, 93, Queens Congressman
description: Henry J. Latham, who represented Queens in Congress for 14 years and was a New York State judge for two decades, died on Wednesday at his home in Southold, N.Y. He was 93 and had lived in the Queens Village section of Queens.

title: Punishing A Norman Princess In England
description: Is the apocalypse at hand?

title: A leading forecaster says this year will be better than expected.
description: ENCOURAGED by robust ad spending from movie studios and political campaigns and by upturns in the fortunes of broadcast television networks and radio stations, a leading advertising industry forecaster has significantly increased his estimates for this year.

title: New York Halts Plan to Add Jail Space for Youths
description: New York City has backed away from a plan to spend $65 million to expand jail space for children accused of crimes, halting a construction project that had become a focal point in the debate over the city's juvenile justice policy.

title: The Two Worlds of Cabernet Franc
description: THERE is more cabernet franc in France -- 35,000 acres -- than anywhere else in the world, but chances are that if it weren't for Americans, hardly anyone would know that. When it comes to wine, we are hooked on grape names, while most Europeans prefer places. Until a generation or so ago, London clubmen would sip their Bordeaux and have no idea what grapes were in it. ''It's Lafite, old boy,'' they might say. ''What else matters?''

title: Frustrating Evening For Pettitte and Yanks
description: Ramiro Mendoza approached Jerry Hairston Jr. last night with one thought in mind: double play.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Clementine's Successor

title: Andersen and Developer Scuttle Times Square Deal
description: Arthur Andersen's foray into Times Square has come to an end, even as the steel skeleton for the building that would have been its new headquarters rises on 42nd Street.

title: Kabuki Before Football
description: TOKYO  One of the great assets of being a sportswriter is the free time in good cities. The games are mostly at night. You get to do things during the day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNHAM, I.W. II.
description: BURNHAM-I.W. II. June 24, 2002, age 93, died suddenly and peacefully at sea aboard his beloved Encore V, off the Virginia coast. Devoted husband of Lawrie Weil Burnham, who predeceased him in 1997. Adored father of Jon M. Burnham and Miriam Arnstein Burnham, and Wendy Burnham Morris and Michael Morris. Cherished grandfather of Debra Burnham Hyman, Suzanne Burnham Mankoff, Kimberly Burnham, Jon M. Burnham, Jr., Anthony C. Kaye, Hilary Kaye Kronowitz and Andrew B. Kaye. Blessed with nine loving great grandchildren. Services will be held at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave East, Rye, NY on Friday, June 28, 2PM. Please no flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, MURIEL
description: ZIMMERMAN-Muriel. The Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research (IPTAR) mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Dr. Muriel Zimmerman. Muriel made many contributions to the IPTAR community during her career. She served on our faculty, and was a training analyst and supervisor. From 1982-84 she held the office of President. Earlier in her career Muriel was on the faculty of Brooklyn College and, more recently, an adjunct professor at Cornell Medical School until her retirement. Our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Stanley Rosenman; her daughter, Joyce Slochower; her son, Peter Rosenman, and her four grandchildren

title: Enron Criminal Investigation Is Said to Expand to Bankers
description: Criminal investigators examining the Enron debacle have expanded their inquiry to focus on activities at the commercial banks that provided billions of dollars in loans and other financial services to the company, according to current and former Enron executives and others involved in the investigation.

title: Germany Waves the Flag, but Retains Reserve
description: The German flags did not come out until the explosive relief of Michael Ballack's sudden goal, 15 minutes before the end of regular time in the World Cup semifinal against South Korea in Seoul. The cheering started, and suddenly the red, yellow and black of Germany was swishing unabashedly through the air.

title: The Mideast Plan: Voices From Across a Chasm
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The White House Letter on Monday, about the frequency with which President Bush mentions the White House dogs, misstated the age of his twin daughters, whom he discusses in public much less often. The daughters, Jenna and Barbara, are 20 years old, not 19.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: More Interest In Daewoo
description: Suzuki Motor of Japan said it would join General Motors as a partner in GM-Daewoo Auto and Technology, the company that has emerged from the complex deal under which General Motors is taking over the bankrupt Daewoo Motor. Suzuki Motor, in which G.M. has a 20 percent stake, said it would invest a significant but still undisclosed portion of the $400 million that G.M. has guaranteed as payment for two-thirds of the new company. G.M. has said it will own 42.1 percent of the company while its partners will own 24.9 percent. Fiat of Italy, in which G.M. also owns a minority stake, has also been mentioned as a possible partner. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSCH, S. HARRY,
description: BUSCH-S. Harry, at age 103. Devoted beloved husband of the late Rose, the late Sayde Tisch Busch, and Jean Busch. Adored uncle, cherished stepfather, step-grandfather and step great-grandfather. Simply, a wonderful man.

title: Second Career
description: To the Editor:

title: In the N.B.A. Draft, Bigger Is Better
description: The No. 1 pick in the National Basketball Association draft will not be in Manhattan tonight, unless a 7-foot-5 celluloid image broadcast live to Madison Square Garden counts. Yao Ming will watch the proceedings via satellite from the CNN bureau in Beijing, where millions of his countrymen will cheer the arrival of a new pro basketball era.

title: The Pursuit of Happiness Is Tough on a Marriage
description: Opposites attack in ''Money Buys Happiness,'' by the writer and director Gregg Lachow. This picture is about a couple whose decade-long marriage is self-destructing because each member is at liberty to pursue life and happiness.

title: Torricelli Wants Letter About Inquiry Kept Sealed
description: Lawyers for Senator Robert G. Torricelli urged a federal judge in Newark yesterday not to unseal a court document that offers an overview of the evidence gathered by federal agents during their five-year investigation of the senator's campaign and personal finances.

title: Quality Goals In Incentives For Hospitals
description: Prodded by big employers and hospitals, one of the nation's largest nonprofit health plans will announce a financial payoff today for hospitals that meet widely accepted standards for high-quality care.

title: Adelphia Files for Bankruptcy
description: Adelphia Communications, the cable television operator, and more than 200 of its subsidiaries filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday in Manhattan after a month of struggling to find an alternative.

title: Judges Ban Pledge of Allegiance From Schools, Citing 'Under God'
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 - A federal appeals court here declared today that the Pledge of Allegiance is unconstitutional because the phrase ``one nation under God'' violates the separation of church and state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERSFELDER, LESTER A.
description: MERSFELDER-Lester A. Of Basking Ridge, N.J. Died June 24, 2002 at age 94. Former engineer and an active community citizen. He is survived by wife Marguerite, son Jim, daughter Nancy, six grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Memorial service Friday, June 28th, 1PM at Fellowship Village, Basking Ridge, N.J. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Class of 1930 Scholarship, Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, N.J. 07030

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits on Friday with a film review of ''Dahmer'' misstated the name of the film's editor. She is Bipasha Shom, not Bipsha Bhom. The listing also gave an incomplete credit for the film's music. It was by Christina Agamanolis, Mariana Bernoski and Willow Williamson.

title: In a Cluster of Popular Spots, a Trattoria Takes a Stand
description: VIA EMILIA, a trattoria on Park Avenue South, seems like a puppy that has lost its way and fallen in among a pack of wolves. Within a couple of blocks of this lovely slip of a restaurant are some of New York's most powerful, or at least busy, restaurants: Patria, Gramercy Tavern, Sushi Samba and Olives. Innocent and energetic, Via Emilia just trots along, doing the best it can to survive. It seems to be working.

title: As Expected, Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged
description: The Federal Reserve Board said this afternoon that it has left a major short-term interest rate unchanged, noting that while the economy is improving the pace of the recovery is not strong enough to warrant an increase in rates.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Summer School For Test Graders
description: The standardized test scores of an estimated 340,000 students in grades three, five and eight must be recalculated, apparently because of mistakes made by the test publisher, Harcourt Educational Measurement, the State Department of Education said. This spring, Georgia administered the exams, known as the Stanford Achievement Test Series, Ninth Edition, to compare the performance of the state's students to children in other states. Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

title: WorldCom Says It Hid Expenses, Inflating Cash Flow $3.8 Billion
description: WorldCom, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier, said last night that it had overstated its cash flow by more than $3.8 billion during the last five quarters in what appears to be one of the largest cases of false corporate bookkeeping yet.

title: Palm Reports a Narrower Loss As Hand-Held Sales Rebound
description: Palm Inc., the world's largest maker of hand-held computers, said today that its fourth-quarter loss had narrowed as expenses dropped and sales rebounded from a year earlier, when product delays cut its revenue in half.

title: Arafat Says Ballot, Not Bush, Will Decide His Leadership
description: Yasir Arafat, flanked by the French foreign minister, today brushed aside President Bush's demand that he give up his position as Palestinian leader. ''This is what my people will decide,'' Mr. Arafat said, referring to who might lead them. ''They are the only ones who can determine this.''

title: India to Ease Limits on Foreign Ownership in Media and Tea
description: Hungry for foreign investment to help offset a swelling current-account deficit, India said today that it would relax restrictions on foreign ownership in two important industries that it had sheltered for decades, print media and tea.

title: They Won't Bark or Roll Over, But They're Experts at 'Stay'
description: New Yorkers tolerated the cows. They had no choice, really, so ubiquitous were the gussied-up fiberglass sculptures that decorated New York City's streetscapes in 2000. The cows were auctioned off the same year, after courting a bit of controversy about aesthetics, meat and the nature of public art.

title: Brazil Reaches World Cup Final
description: SAITAMA, Japan, June 26  Brazil defeated Turkey, 1-0, tonight in a tense, offensive-minded rematch between two teams that disputed a close first-round face-off.

title: Making Bush's Vision Realistic
description: After much hesitation and internal debate, President Bush has changed the ground rules on American involvement in ending the conflict in the Middle East. His call for a new Palestinian leadership as well as new democratic institutions and new security measures has raised the bar for Palestinian statehood. His central message is that the Palestinians are not entitled to a state -- they must earn it.

title: Consuming History
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Uncommon Materials and Objects
description:
By STEPHEN TREFFINGER
It took Robin Reigi, who opened her Art & Objects showroom in November, awhile to figure out her calling.

title: Show House Shopper
Love Is Fickle But Samba Is Forever
description: Pop songs are built on restrictions: of length, of vocal range, of neccessary repetition to stay catchy. Joo Gilberto, the 71-year-old Brazilian bossa nova master who returned to Carnegie Hall on Saturday night in a JVC Jazz Festival concert, limits his music even more rigorously.

title: State Says Many Hospitals Violate Laws on Work Hours
description: More than half of the teaching hospitals inspected by the state Health Department have violated state laws meant to ensure that medical residents are not exhausted when caring for patients, the department said yesterday. Thirty of the 54 hospitals in violation were in New York City.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CNA FINANCIAL CORP., Chicago, said it would sell the variable life and variable annuity business of its Valley Forge Life Insurance Co. to Phoenix Cos., Hartford.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Reading, Writing And Violence
description: Students will be able to transfer out of public schools that have a record of violence under federal and state regulations that are to take effect in 2004. The regulations would allow transfers from schools that report at least five criminal offenses for every 1,000 students for two years in a row are to be classified as ''persistently dangerous.'' Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASS, FRIEDA
description: BASS-Frieda. Age 83 of Pembroke Pines, FL died June 23, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Abraham Bass. Loving mother of Dr. Stuart (Caren) Bass of West Bloomfield, MI and Dr. Stephan (Lindsey Hallwood) Bass of Woodland Hills, CA. Devoted sister of Dr. Jerome (Dawne) Ratzan. Cherished grandmother of Robyn (Travis) Hunt & Julie (David) Sidder. Service today, 12:30PM at I.J. Morris, Dix Hills, L.I. 631-499-6060.

title: How Middle East Realities Unravel the Best-Laid Plans
description: Laying out the conditions for a Palestinian state earlier this week, President Bush acknowledged the difficulty inherent in any peace plan. ''All who are familiar with the history of the Middle East realize that there may be setbacks in this process,'' he said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about a dispute between Honda and the United Automobile Workers over the safety record at the company's plants in Ohio misstated the meeting place where Honda workers received material from union organizers. It was at a U.A.W. facility in Marysville, Ohio, not the Honda assembly plant there.

title: Bill Says Firms Cannot Use State Funds to Fight Unions
description: Employers who receive state money will not be able to use it for antiunion activities, under a bill passed by the State Assembly today and agreed to by the Senate and Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a hearing by a House subcommittee on closing a tax loophole used by companies that acquire a Bermuda address misstated the political affiliation of Representative Kevin Brady of Texas, who said no one on the panel was defending the loophole. He is a Republican, not a Democrat.

title: On Letting the Military Wage War, Not Lead It
description: SUPREME COMMAND

title: With Burn-On CD Labels, No Need to Scrawl-and-Stick
description: A friend of mine made some CD song collections for me with his CD burner, but as soon as I took the unlabeled disks out of their jewel cases I lost track of which was which. Maybe he needs Yamaha's CRW-F1 CD burner, which allows you to burn a title and track list directly onto a CD, eliminating the need for the stick-on labels and handwritten titles that he can't be bothered with.

title: Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
description: Faced with corporate scandals, skittish financial markets and an economic recovery that has little traction so far, the Federal Reserve voted today to hold interest rates steady, saying it was not yet clear how soon the outlook would improve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNHAM, I.W. II.
description: BURNHAM-I.W. II. June 24, 2002, age 93, died suddenly and peacefully at sea aboard his beloved Encore V, off the Virginia coast. Devoted husband of Lawrie Weil Burnham, who predeceased him in 1997. Adored father of Jon M. Burnham and Miriam Arnstein Burnham, and Wendy Burnham Morris and Michael Morris. Cherished grandfather of Debra Burnham Hyman, Suzanne Burnham Mankoff, Kimberly Burnham, Jon M. Burnham, Jr., Anthony C. Kaye, Hilary Kaye Kronowitz and Andrew B. Kaye. Blessed with nine loving great grandchildren. Services will be held at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave East, Rye, NY Friday June 28, 2PM. Please no flowers.

title: On the Rocks: Over Drinks It's Artists Versus Critic
description: Alfred Leslie's video feature ''The Cedar Bar'' defines itself, in an opening subtitle, as ''a true story about the war between people who make art and the people who write about it.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KESSLER
description: KESSLEROHEN - Estelle/d. Born in 1909, died in New York City on June 24, 2002. She married Louis M. Cohen, a lawyer, and textile manufacturer and founding member of the United Jewish Appeal. They had two daughters Hannah and Sandra. When Louis died Estelle continued to work closely with the UJA and served as a Board member of the American Jewish Committees Women's Campaign. She later married Henry H. Kessler, founder of the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation in New Jersey. In later years, after Henry's death, she spent most of her time working for Rehabilitation International and the Kessler Institute and watching her five grandchildren grow, David, Brian, Kenneth, Nikolas and Alexandr. She also stayed close to her son-in-law Herbert Halberg and David's wife Frances. You are welcome to pay your respects on Thursday, June 27th, from 7 to 9 PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 81st St and Madison Ave. Services Friday, June 28, 2002, 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave at 65th St. It will be followed by a burial service at Mt. Carmel Cemetery.

title: Soft-Money Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Peacekeeping Held Hostage
description: The International Criminal Court is designed to disturb the sleep of those who commit genocide and mass murder, but it also has become an unhealthy obsession of the Bush administration. Despite the fact that it is highly unlikely that an American would ever come before the court, the White House is bowing to conservatives who have a knee-jerk reaction to any international body that has even the most remote authority to tell the United States what to do. This week it is threatening to pull back American peacekeepers, and even cut off American funds for United Nations peacekeeping troops, if Washington is not given a promise that American soldiers will never be subject to the court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITMAN, CHARLES SEY MOUR JR.
description: WHITMAN - Charles Sey mour Jr. On June 25, 2002, at age 87, after a short illness. Son of former New York Governor Charles S. Whitman and Olive Hitchcock Whitman. Devoted husband for 61 years of Janet Russell Whitman, father of Charles S. Whitman III, John R. Whitman and Janet Whitman, and grandfather of Kate, Taylor and Elizabeth Whitman. Judge of the Civil Court of the City of New York 1956-1985. Memorial services 11am, July 27th at the Watch Hill Chapel and in New York in the Fall. Contributions to the Watch Hill Chapel Society, POB 173, Westerly, RI 02891.

title: U.S. Defends Its Farm Subsidies Against Rising Foreign Criticism
description: The Bush Administration's top trade and agricultural officials tried today to quell the rising chorus of foreign criticism of new American farm subsidies, dismissing the complaints as unfounded or hypocritical attempts to maintain trade barriers.

title: Mideast Diplomacy: You Give, I Give
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Congressman Lafalce To Retire
description: Representative John J. LaFalce, a consumer advocate on the House Financial Services Committee, announced yesterday in Washington that he would retire after 28 years in the House rather than go through a tough fight for renomination. New York's redistricting map will put him in the same district as Representative Louise Slaughter of Rochester. Mr. LaFalce, 62, said that he would have won, but chose not to contest ''other talented and honorable Democrats.'' Adam Clymer (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Neon Files For Bankruptcy Protection
description: Neon Communications Inc., which operates a fiber optic network in a dozen eastern states, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday in an effort to reduce its debt by about $250 million. The stock of the company, which is based in Westborough, Mass., has suffered badly in the telecommunications slump and was delisted from Nasdaq on June 10. In papers filed late Tuesday in United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware, Neon and its Neon Optica Inc. unit listed $208.4 million in assets and $258.1 million in liabilities. ''We expect the reorganization process to go smoothly and the company's operations to continue uninterrupted,'' said Stephen Courter, Neon's chief executive. Neon said it had obtained a $12.5 million loan commitment to finance reorganization, subject to a judge's approval. Two weeks ago the company's stock, which had traded below $1 a share for more than a month, was delisted from the Nasdaq stock market.

title: In Remote Library Stacks, an All-Seeing, Scanning Robot
description: AS many a university student will testify, it is a blessing to be able to visit a library Web site and download reference materials in electronic form. When deadlines loom, who wants to leave the house and roam the stacks of a library in search of a book?

title: Resolution on 'Political Prisoners' Roils Council
description: City Council resolutions are usually not the most relevant of actions taken by the City Council, often because they call for actions in jurisdictions where the Council has no authority.

title: House Republican Leaders Press for Votes on Drug Benefit Bill
description: House Republican leaders struggled today to round up the votes of about 20 wavering Republicans who expressed deep reservations about the party's bill to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly. But the leaders said they still hoped to push the bill through the House this week.

title: A Plea for Recognizing Humanity Everywhere
description: Newspapers almost smother the seven performers in ''Alive From Palestine: Stories Under Occupation,'' a plaintive, almost supplicating new work at the Long Wharf Theater here. The show is a presentation of Al Kasaba Theater, a Palestinian troupe from Ramallah making its timely American debut through Saturday. And the news is not just in the air, but on the stage. The set consists of mounds of crumpled newspapers -- newspaper igloos, almost -- and the actors, for their monologues and sketches, emerge from beneath and behind them. This is a fragile and rickety village, hardly protective, hardly safe, hardly a haven for people who live there.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Drug Research Acquisition
description: Serono, a Swiss drug maker, agreed to buy Genset for 107.4 million euros ($105.2 million), more than three times the French company's market value, to help it search for new medicines. Serono, Europe's biggest biotechnology company, offered 9.75 euros a share and 102.64 euros for each Genset convertible bond, a Serono spokesman, Nick Miles, said. The acquisition will reduce Serono's 2002 net income by $16 million to $17 million, he said. Serono, which is based in Geneva, needs to find new products to reduce its dependence on Rebif, a multiple sclerosis medicine that accounted for more than a third of first-quarter sales. Acquiring Genset, which focuses on finding drugs by analyzing the human genetic code, may enhance Serono's research and development, investors said.

title: Spotting Breast Cancer: Doctors Are Weak Link
description: Ten years after the federal government set out to clean up a mammography industry awash in scandal, many women are still getting inaccurate examinations at clinics bearing the federal seal of approval.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILL, PAUL H. JR.
description: TILL-Paul H. Jr. Died June 21. Memorial service was held on June 26. Survived by beloved wife Jean; daughter Jennifer; son Paul and three grandchildren.

title: 3 Inspectors Faced Charges Once Before
description: Three of the 19 present and former plumbing inspectors who were charged this week with extorting payoffs from New York contractors had been indicted and cleared of the same crimes nearly a decade ago, records show.

title: Destroy Sweatshops? No
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bar Association Sues F.T.C.
description: The State Bar Association is leading a national effort against a Federal Trade Commission ruling requiring lawyers to send out annual privacy notices just as banks and credit card companies do. The 70,000-member association is suing in Federal District Court in Washington to try to force the F.T.C. to stop applying the rule to lawyers, contending that it undermines confidence in lawyers' traditional obligation of confidentiality. An agency spokeswoman declined to discuss the litigation. Adam Clymer (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: A Thorn In The Laurels
description: While Gov. Mike Huckabee was in Washington to accept an industry award for the state government master computer he championed, legislators were warned that the system was plagued by technical problems and virtually defenseless against hackers. Randall Bradford, who was hired by Mr. Huckabee in October to supervise the system but was fired by him this month, told lawmakers that millions of dollars would be needed to make the $52 million Arkansas Administrative Statewide Information System trustworthy.

title: Deal Could Back Amtrak Through October
description: Amtrak and the Bush administration reached a tentative agreement last night that would provide enough cash to keep the railroad operating through October, but the deal requires that Congress come up with half of the money.

title: For Ex-Convicts, A Bed, a View, A New Outlook; Call It the Castle, Or Just Call It Home
description: Mike woke up in his own bed. It was just past 6 a.m. He cooked himself some breakfast with his own pots and pans and sat down to eat at his own kitchen table. He ate slowly and with profound enjoyment. He ate with his own plate and fork and knife.

title: Fed Statement On Rate Stance
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged:

title: Sheffield Spoils Strickland's Chance To Redeem Himself
description: Scott Strickland kept repeating that he would not change his aggressive approach as a pitcher, maybe figuring that the more he said it and the louder he said it, the easier it would be to somehow stomach another depressing night against the Atlanta Braves. Strickland does not plan to change his style, but he obviously needs to change the results.

title: New York State Weighs Suit Over Losses
description: The New York state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, said yesterday that he was considering a lawsuit against WorldCom because the state's common retirement fund had lost at least $200 million.

title: How Do You Get to Camp? Practice, Of Course; Teenagers Who Play Music, Not Tennis
description: When shopping for a new car, Lois Paley always lugs along two empty cello cases. If they fit, she then considers how much room is left for her three athletic sons: Gregory, 17; Bennett, 14, with his violin; and Todd, 11. Dad and the dog can always follow in their own car.

title: Lifting Veil for Photo ID Goes Too Far, Driver Says
description: A Muslim woman who says the state is violating her religious rights in demanding that she remove her veil for a driver's license photograph will be in court this week to try to regain her driving privileges.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe

The acquisition will reduce Serono's 2002 net income by $16 million to $17 million, he said. title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BELGIUM: SHARON WAR-CRIMES SUIT DISMISSED A court dismissed a suit filed by 23 Palestinians accusing Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel of war crimes for his role in the massacre of Palestinians by Christian militias allied with Israel at the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps in Lebanon in 1982, when he was Israel's defense minister. The group hoped to use a law that enables Belgian courts to try grave human rights abuses regardless of where they were committed, but the court ruled the case could not proceed because Mr. Sharon was not in Belgium. Lawyers said they would take the case to the Supreme Court. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Software Subscriptions: A Bad Idea Whose Time Has Come
description: In last week's "State of the Art" column, week, I reviewed OpenOffice and StarOffice, two versions of the same software suite that's designed to compete directly with Microsoft Office. I pointed out that Microsoft itself opened the door to such challengers. As of July 31, the company will no longer offer its corporate customers steeply discounted upgrade packs when new versions of Windows or Office come out. Instead, it offers them Software Assurance, a plan in which corporations pay Microsoft an annual subscription fee for these updates.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Skepticism About Milosevic
description: The judges trying Slobodan Milosevic on war-crimes charges ordered a thorough medical checkup of the former Yugoslav president after the prosecution said it was skeptical about claims of illness that have forced delays in the hearings and taken up time allotted to the prosecution's case. Sessions have been canceled for the last two weeks and were also canceled for two weeks in March because Mr. Milosevic said he was ill. Judges granted two more weeks to the prosecution to make up for lost time. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Brazil Earns a Spot in Its Third Straight Final
description: Brazil defeated Turkey, 1-0, tonight in a tense, offensive-minded, if seldom pretty rematch between two teams that disputed a close first-round game and had been rolling along ever since.

title: Former Tyco Chief Faces New Charges
description: L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chairman and chief executive of Tyco International, was indicted yesterday on two new charges of tampering with evidence in the case that accuses him of evading more than $1 million of sales taxes on six paintings that he bought last fall.

title: Knicks Get McDyess for Camby and Jackson
description: The charge was to create hope, to maximize a seventh pick in a draft high on hype but low on proven commodities and give Knicks fans a reason to expect more than another lottery pick next year. That was the demand on Scott Layden, the Knicks' president and general manager, in last night's N.B.A. draft.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: 'Environmental Racism' Suit Is Rejected
description: The United States Supreme Court has declined to consider a case in which residents of a predominantly black neighborhood in Camden objected to the approval of an industrial plant as a case of ''environmental racism.'' The justices on Tuesday declined to review an appellate panel's ruling that allowed the facility, the St. Lawrence Cement plant, to open. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Next Stop on the Local: The Weblogs of Borough Hall
description: A chance encounter that grew out of some Weblog postings in May has gone a long way toward putting New York's growing community of bloggers on the map. The subway map, anyway.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Plea On Child Pornography
description: The Grammy award-winning singer R. Kelly pleaded not guilty to 21 counts of child pornography in a brief court appearance in Chicago. Mr. Kelly, 35, who recently released a song about the case called, ''Heaven, I need a hug,'' was arrested in June because of a widely circulated videotape that the authorities say shows him having sex with an underage girl. Mr. Kelly, who denies that he is the man shown on the tape, faces up to 15 years in prison and a $100,000 fine if found guilty. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: From Low Profile to No Profile
description: Scott D. Sullivan was the ''whiz kid'' Bernard J. Ebbers relied on to put together the many mergers that lifted WorldCom from obscurity as a small long-distance phone company to prominence as a global telecommunications giant. And even after WorldCom's deteriorating prospects forced Mr. Ebbers to resign as chief executive last month, Mr. Sullivan, 40, appeared to retain the confidence of both Wall Street and senior WorldCom executives.

title: Yum Brands Expands Role With BBDO
description: Yum Brands in Louisville, Ky., formerly Tricon Global Restaurants, has expanded its relationship with the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, by awarding the agency the broadcast creative account of the Long John Silver's restaurant chain, which Yum recently acquired. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: No Specter on Ronaldo This Time
description: TOKYO

title: John D. Wirth, 66, Historian and Author
description: John D. Wirth, a scholar and historian of Latin American affairs with an interest in Canada, died on Thursday night in Toronto. He was 66 and lived in Atherton, Calif., and Santa Fe, N.M.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bethpage: Lightning Ignites Church Fire
description: Lightning struck a church here last night and started a three-alarm fire, causing several hundred thousand dollars in damage and sending nine firefighters with minor injuries to two nearby hospitals, a fire official said. The fire destroyed one gable and damaged portions of another. The church, St. Paul Evangelical Lutheran on Stewart Avenue, was founded in 1923, and about 200 families worship there. If services cannot be held there on Sunday, ''we'll be at the firehouse,'' said the pastor, the Rev. Mario Ancira, who is also a volunteer firefighter. ''A little fire smoke is not going to shake the faith of these people.'' Tina Kelley (NYT)

description: The Bloom's Off the Rose

title: Day of Upsets: Sampras Exits, As Does Agassi
description: The jolts to Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi were almost simultaneous as their Wimbledon runs ended today under Windex-blue skies, but the depth of their reactions was far from equal.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Appeals Court Upholds EBay Ruling
description: EBay is not liable if people sell fake merchandise on its site, a California appeals court ruled yesterday. The court affirmed a local court ruling last year in a case brought by people who bought baseballs and other items on eBay with forged signatures of baseball players. The court accepted the company's argument that a portion of federal communications law exempts Internet service providers from liability for actions of third parties -- in this case, dealers that posted auctions for the forged goods. It ruled that the federal law supersedes several California statues that otherwise might have made the online auction company certify the authenticity of sports-related collectibles sold on its site. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Palestinian Authority Sets a January Vote
description: Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority officially announced plans today to hold elections for president and legislative offices in January as part of a broad proposal for civic and security reform that stopped short of President Bush's demand for Mr. Arafat's replacement.

title: Jay Berwanger, First Recipient of Heisman Trophy, Is Dead at 88
description: Jay Berwanger, who in 1935 became the first winner of the Heisman Trophy as the outstanding player in college footballl and then became the first player ever drafted by the National Football League, died on Wednesday at his home in Oak Brook, Ill. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, MYRA F.
description: KAPLAN-Myra F. Devoted mother of Roger and Isabelle. Wife of the late Herbert Kaplan. Sister of Judith Davilman and the late Mary-Ellen Feinberg. Sister-in-law of Dr. Harvey Feinberg. Loving aunt of Monica Cohen and Jessica Lesnik. She will be missed every moment of every day. Services Friday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Puncturing Web Ads Before They Pop Up
description: IT'S a fundamental law of bubble theory: no bubble bursts without leaving a slimy residue. No wonder, then, that when the Internet bubble popped, every Web site felt the splash.

title: Dr. Albert Solnit, Advocate of Child's Needs, Dies at 82
description: Dr. Albert J. Solnit, a psychiatrist who helped introduce the idea that family law and custody disputes should focus on a child's needs, died on Friday in a car accident in Bethlehem, Conn. He was 82.

title: This Little Piggie Is Going to Washington
description: Picture a grass-roots advocacy group with up-to-the-minute graphics. To design its materials, TrueMajority, which runs a Web site (www.truemajority.com) and issues legislative alerts by e-mail, turned to Stefan Sagmeister, a graphic designer who is best known for rock album covers. ''It's gratifying to work on something you believe in,'' Mr. Sagmeister said. His Rolling Piggies, below, represent federal spending on, from right, the military, education and world hunger. The caravan will visit New York in August and go to other cities.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Custody Battle
description: The California chapter of the National Organization for Women released a report on Tuesday that found the state's family court system favors men in child custody rulings, prompting father's rights advocates to respond with federal census data showing that women are granted custody 80 percent of the time. The NOW report was based on surveys of women who say they unjustly lost custody. It was released in conjunction with a legal brief in State Appellate Court supporting a woman whose husband was given full custody after he accused the mother of brainwashing the girl into saying he had sexually abused her. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is the most pessimistic sentiment against the United States that I have ever experienced in my career. There is unanimous agreement that the U.S. is not the best place to invest anymore.''

title: Eclecticism and an Aura of Uncertainty
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival has opened what it calls its 70th anniversary season -- actually its 70th summer since its beginnings on an old Berkshire farm here in 1933.

title: A Hand Over the Nose, a Hand Still in Stocks
description: Americans' faith in stocks is being sorely tested.

title: A Phone Service That Lets Your Larynx Do the Surfing
description: If surfing the Web and sending e-mail from your cellphone seem like too much to ask of your thumbs, why not let your vocal cords pitch in? Pronto, a new phone service offered by i3 Mobile (www.i3mobile.com), allows customers to use voice-activated commands to retrieve information from the Internet and send e-mail.

title: In Defense of Martha
description: I'm no Martha Stewart fan -- I rarely pronounce her name without clamping it in quotation marks, as if that proved the falsity of her whole perfect-living enterprise. And yet I find myself wanting to defend her. Or at least wondering, Why do we get so much pleasure from cutting Martha with a mandoline into paper-thin slices?

title: Hard-Boiled And Still Hot
description: Live authors promoting the work of dead authors is not exactly a new way of making a publisher's backlist snap to attention yet again. But we are talking here about Philip Marlowe, private detective, one of the most astonishingly enduring characters in American fiction. So it's not surprising that a group of authors are going out of their way to promote a new edition of the major works of Marlowe's creator, Raymond Chandler. And doing it with gusto.

title: Rescuing Campaign Reform
description: After the Federal Election Commission voted last week to shred the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law, the cause of reform was looking tattered indeed. Yesterday there was new hope. Senator John McCain and other reformers announced a drive to reverse the commission's regulations by legislative action and a lawsuit. Anyone claiming to be a reformer should enlist in that effort and also join in a separate demand to replace a lame duck member of the commission who provided the key vote on wrecking the law. Once that's done, Congress should completely scrap the F.E.C. and establish an agency that can enforce the law as written by Congress.

title: Buyout Is Rejected by Penn Virginia
description: RADNOR, Pa., June 26 (Bloomberg News)  The Penn Virginia Corporation , an oil and natural gas explorer, said today that its board rejected a $329.6 million buyout offer by BP Capital energy partnerships, controlled by T. Boone Pickens.

title: Latest Scandal Lifts Prospects for Measures to Tighten Up Audit Industry
description: The WorldCom accounting scandal has improved the prospects for legislation to tighten auditing standards and reduce conflicts of interest in the accounting industry, members of Congress said today.

title: Struggling to Sort Out 9/11 Aid to Foreigners
description: Virtually nothing in the world of Sept. 11 relief efforts has come without complications. Charities are being criticized for failing to distribute cash fast enough. Family members are locked in tense struggles over inheritances.

title: A Wake-Up Call When Your Lover Has Gone
description: So your significant other is away? You can still wake to his or her voice. A new battery-operated radio by Lexon, below, allows you to tape a greeting up to 20 seconds long. ''Wake up, honey'' or other messages will play back at the programmed hour -- unless, of course, you prefer to be awakened by the buzzer or by the sound of music. The radio, a 3 1/4-inch cube oddly named Soap, was designed by Elise Berthier, whose father, Marc Berthier, designed Lexon's popular 1999 Tykho rubber radio. Soap is $52, available in white from Moss, 146 Greene Street, (212) 226-2190. Orange and lime versions are scheduled to arrive next month.

description: Manhattan

title: Yemenis Held in Money Scheme
description: Federal agents and the police yesterday arrested a dozen men, many of them shopkeepers in downtown Brooklyn, on charges they ran an illegal wire transfer service that they used to smuggle more than $100,000 to their native Yemen.

description: Stock prices plunged and then recovered yesterday after WorldCom's announcement that it had overstated its profits, leaving major market indexes just above their post-Sept. 11 lows.

description: BEFORE David Stern had even announced their team's pick in the N.B.A. draft last night, boisterous Knicks fans in the Theater at Madison Square Garden were winding up for lusty billows of boos.

title: A Big L.C.D. Panel Descends From the Stratosphere
description: While huge flat-panel monitors that use liquid crystal display technology have been around for a while, some manufacturers are now bringing out models at prices that at least a few consumers may consider paying. This week Sony announced its first 20-inch L.C.D. monitor, the X202, which has a suggested price of $2,000. While that's almost twice the recommended price for a new 18-inch L.C.D. monitor also introduced by Sony this week, the price in stores is likely to be considerably less. The screen accepts both digital and analog signals and offers an unusually high resolution: 1,600 by 1,200 pixels.

title: Washington Memo; The Most Unusual Story Behind a Gay Rights Victory
description: The White House sent out the news of the bill-signing as a one-sentence e-mail announcement when it was certain to be ignored, at 6 p.m. on Monday, right after President Bush's Middle East speech in the Rose Garden. That, at least, is not in dispute.

description: CASTELLE-Cynthia. Of Suffern. Died on June 25, 2002. She is survived by her loving family, children Michael & Melanie; Andrew & Karin; Gary and Tari; and three grandchildren, Matthew, James & Cooper. Predeceased by her husband Robert in 2000. Services Friday, June 28, 2002 11 AM at the Wanamaker & Carlough Funeral Home, 177 Rt 59 Suffern, NY. Burial to follow in Mt. Hope Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Ramapo Ambulance Corp, or Simon Wiesenthal Center would be appreciated.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Micron Shares Drop After Loss Is Posted
description: Shares of Micron Technology Inc., which makes memory devices for personal computers and other electronic products, dropped 75 cents, to $19 yesterday, or nearly 4 percent, after it said it would record a loss for the third quarter. Sales have failed to meet expectations, and chip prices have fallen about 50 percent since March, the company said. Officials at Micron said it had a net loss of $24.2 million, or 4 cents a share, on sales of $771.2 million for the period that ended May 30. Last week, the three largest chip makers, including Micron, said they had been contacted by the Justice Department as part of an industrywide antitrust investigation. The inquiry will probably focus on Samsung Electronics, the industry leader, based in South Korea; second-ranked Micron, based in Boise, Idaho; and Infineon Technologies of Germany, the third-largest company in the sector. Micron said that it did not believe it had broken any laws and that it was cooperating fully.

title: Excerpts From Federal Court Ruling on the Pledge of Allegiance
description: Following are excerpts from the ruling yesterday by a three-judge federal appeals court panel in San Francisco that reciting the Pledge of Allegiance in public schools is unconstitutional because it includes the phrase ''one nation under God.'' The vote was 2 to 1. Judge Alfred T. Goodwin wrote the majority opinion, in which Judge Stephen Reinhardt joined. Judge Ferdinand F. Fernandez wrote a dissent. The full text is online at nytimes.com/national.

title: Palestinian Resistance at Hebron Offices Thins Out, but Army Standoff Continues
description: The Israeli military kept up pressure on the West Bank today, firing thousands of rounds into an old British police station here in a standoff with suspected Palestinian militants that has ground on now for two days.

title: Russia Acquits 6 in Killing of Reporter Investigating the Military
description: In a verdict that outraged Russian journalists, a military court acquitted six men today, five of them army officers, in the murder of Dmitri Kholodov, a journalist investigating corruption in the Russian military in the early 1990's.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on Tuesday about President Bush's visit to New Jersey misstated the location of the pier where he discussed port security. It is in Newark, not Elizabeth.

title: As Trees Die, Some Cite the Climate
description: Morris Berman's photograph of Y.A. Tittle in 1964, one of the most famous photos in sports history, did not run in Mr. Berman's newspaper at the time because there wasn't any action in it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, ROBERT C.
description: FISCHER-Robert C. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the loss of the beloved husband of our dear friend, Diane Fischer, president of the Atran Foundation. A Benefactor of our institution and a Guardian of the University, the Atran Foundation has endowed a professorial chair in social medicine and established a floor of research laboratories in molecular pharmacology and an exchange scientist program at Einstein. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Diane and the family. Yeshiva University Dr. Norman Lamm President Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. title: Uncommon Materials and Objects (You, Too, Can Buy an Asylum Chair)
description: It took Robin Reigi, who opened her Art & Objects showroom in November, awhile to figure out her calling. Ms. Reigi studied sculpture at the School of Visual Arts, spent 10 years making advertising props (''I wasn't that good at it,'' she said) and worked for a lighting designer. ''I realized I wasn't that good with my hands,'' she said. Her true talent lay in sales.

title: TriBeCa's Local Voice in the Trials of Rebuilding
description: THE house rules are in effect the instant the ancient freight elevator, with its exposed cable and pitted floor, finishes groaning its way to a top-floor loft that, in stark contrast to the contraption leading to it, consists of an immaculate 5,000-square-foot sprawl. ''Take off your shoes!'' orders the housekeeper, politely but pointedly. These hardwood floors are varnished to a fare-thee-well, some of them painted by real artists: this is, after all, the real TriBeCa.

title: Nassau Police Revise Policy On Lineups
description: After complaints of racism from community leaders, the Nassau County Police Department says it has stopped paying black youths to appear in lineups.

title: Gay Bookstores
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Talks Are Focusing On Revenue
description: The issue of revenue sharing had the attention of baseball's labor negotiators yesterday. They spent virtually their entire meeting, lasting about three hours, discussing revenue sharing in relation to the use of additional money from Major League Baseball's central fund.

title: 10 Pakistani Soldiers Die Trying to Catch Qaeda Suspects
description: Ten Pakistani soldiers were killed today in a gunbattle with suspected members of Al Qaeda, Pakistani officials said, and other soldiers were wounded. For the government this was the deadliest encounter yet in the hunt for terrorists on this side of the border with Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALABAN, REUBEN, CPA,
description: BALABAN - Reuben, CPA, age 85 of Aventura, Florida died on June 20, 2002.

title: F.B.I. Chief's Muslim Speech Prompts Protest
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 — A planned appearance by Director Robert S. Mueller III of the F.B.I. at a meeting of the American Muslim Council has prompted protests because of accusations that the organization supports extremist groups and has antipathy toward Israel.

title: Judges Ban Pledge of Allegiance From Schools, Citing 'Under God'
description: A federal appeals court here declared today that the Pledge of Allegiance is unconstitutional because the phrase ''one nation under God'' violates the separation of church and state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORD, KATHERINE MURRAY
description: FORD - Katherine Murray. On June 22, 2002 at her home in Manhattan. A generoushearted woman blessed with intelligence and wit, Ms. Ford illuminated the lives of all who knew her.

title: Market Place; In this bear market, there is plenty of bad news to go around.
description: SOME bear markets look much worse than they really are for most investors, simply because the stocks that go down the most are ones that most investors do not own. But this bear market is just the opposite. The stocks that have suffered the most this year include some held by the greatest number of investors.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Sides With Church Group
description: A federal judge granted a preliminary injunction yesterday to allow a church group to rent space in a public school for Sunday morning meetings that include religious teaching and worship. Lawyers for the city, which opposed access, said they were considering their options. The church, the Bronx Household of Faith, said denying it access violated the First Amendment. The ruling follows a Supreme Court decision last year that public schools must grant access to buildings for after-school religious activity on the same basis as other after-hours activities. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a lawsuit by Lambda Legal, a gay rights group pressing for same-sex marriage in New Jersey, incorrectly described the people being addressed by the group's lawyer. They were gay couples who are plaintiffs in the lawsuit, not members of Lambda Legal.

title: WORLDCOM FACING CHARGES OF FRAUD; INQUIRIES EXPAND
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed fraud charges against WorldCom yesterday and President Bush vowed to ''hold people accountable'' for the bookkeeping scandal at the company, the nation's second-largest long-distance provider and a major carrier of Internet traffic.

title: Day After a Chemical Blast, a 2nd Alert
description: The day after two workers were severely burned in an explosion on the campus of the Pfizer Corporation here, neighbors were told that another explosion was looming and asked to evacuate their homes, and the plant was closed.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS HIRES FINANCIAL OFFICER FROM BG GROUP
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company hired the finance director of the BG Group, Andrew Bonfield, as its chief financial officer yesterday, two months after Bristol-Myers cut its 2002 profit forecasts and announced the departure of its previous chief financial officer, Fred Schiff. Mr. Bonfield, 39, will return to the pharmaceutical industry after almost two years at BG, a British natural gas company. Before that, Mr. Bonfield was chief financial officer for SmithKline Beecham, now part of GlaxoSmithKline, a leading drug maker.

title: Score One For the Ball, Kickers Say
description: ''CAN I touch it?'' one onlooker asked. Soon others were venturing over, awaiting their turn to stroke it, then poke it with their toes.

title: The Home Team Provides the Intrigue
description: Everyone and his mother knew where the first three were headed, so intrigue in last night's National Basketball Association draft would have to come from somewhere else, some high-risk, used-Volvo swap to make the Theater at Madison Square Garden simmer with gossip and chatter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, JULIA
description: DAVIS-Julia. On behalf of the members of 1199SEIU, New York's Health & Human Service Union, AFL-CIO, we mourn the death on June 15 in Lake Worth, Florida, of Julia Davis. Julia, was 94, was the widow of our Union's founder, Leon Davis, who retired as President in 1982 and died in 1992. She worked for many years in New York City's Welfare Department and actively pursued lifelong interest in art and social justice. She was a founder of the Workers' Children's Camp (Wo-Chi-Ca) in Hackettstown, New Jersey in the 1930's and taught art in retirement. Many 1199ers knew her as a constant companion and supporter of her husband's passionate work for justice for health care workers. She was at his side throughout his 50 year 1199 career and lived to see the tiny union he created come to represent 210,000 health care employees. She is survived by her daughter Jo; her son-in-law George Ubogy; her ''son'' David Brown; her grandchildren David and Seth Ubogy and Elia and Anthony Brown-Davis; and her great-grandchildren Alec and Nicolas Ubogy. The family thanks former 1199 Secretary-Treasurer Bill Taylor for his care of Julia Davis in recent years. In sympathy, Dennis Rivera, President, 1199SEIU George Gresham, SecretaryTreasurer, 1199SEIU

title: Reading Test Scores Of Seventh Graders Withheld by Board
description: Because the initial results of a citywide reading test that seventh graders took two months ago ''didn't seem right,'' the Board of Education decided not to include the scores with report cards sent out yesterday, a board spokeswoman said.

title: In the Role Of Manager At the Public Theater
description: In the latest attempt to establish effective two-pronged leadership at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, the board has named Mara Manus executive director to share the helm with the producer, George C. Wolfe.

title: Tips on Mammography Clinics
description: Dr. Barbara Monsees headed the expert panel that helped write the federal mammography rules. But when women ask her where to get a good mammogram, she does not tell them to look for the government seal of approval. "I tell them to go to a place where people specialize in mammography," she says.

title: In Rows 10 Deep, Brooklyn Mourns a Family of Seven
description: There were six wooden boxes for the seven members of the Nadeem family. The youngest, Zainab, who in life clung to her mother's bosom, as 9-month-old infants do, shared a simple pine coffin with her in death.

title: The next Europe / An expanding Union: EU pays the price for farm subsidies
description: PARIS:  Last of three articles

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Catholic Priest Agrees To Ouster
description: A priest formerly assigned to the Diocese of Paterson has agreed to ask the Vatican to remove him from the priesthood after facing a series of sexual abuse allegations, the diocese said. The priest, the Rev. James T. Hanley, offered to be removed after church officials sought to discipline him under new policies on sexual abuse by priests. Father Hanley, 64, who was dismissed from the diocese in 1988, was accused of sexual molestation in a 1987 civil lawsuit filed by a parishioner; the suit was settled by the diocese. In recent months, at least five other men have accused Father Hanley of molesting them as children. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Officer Resigns at Pension Fund
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 26 (Bloomberg News)  The Teacher Retirement System of Texas, the seventh-largest pension fund in the nation, said yesterday that its chief investment officer, John Peavy, had resigned after a 10-year association with the fund.

title: Jam Science
description: Traffic jams, accidents, road rage. The 20th century dream of free flowing highways seems more like a nightmare today. But a new branch of science may liberate the roadways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THROOP, WILLIAM M., JR., ''PETE,''
description: THROOP-William M., Jr., ''Pete,'' on June 20, 2002 at home in New Canaan, CT, of cancer. Survived by his wife Ann, sons William of North Hebron, NY, Mitchell of Greenwich, NY, Peter of Keene, NH, and Thomas of Rowayton, CT, and granddaughters Laura and Susannah. A graduate of St. George's School, Princeton University and Yale Law School, Pete completed 50 years of the practice of law in 2001 with the law firm of Davidson, Dawson & Clark LLP, of which he was the senior partner until becoming of Counsel as of January 1, 2000. A memorial service will be held at St. Michael's Lutheran Church, 5 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, CT, at 2:00 PM on June 28, 2002. Contributions may be made to a scholarhsip fund in his memory at Gould Academy, Bethel, ME 04217, for which he had served as a member and Chairman of the Board of Trustees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, HANNAH (NEE ROTHBERG)
description: LESSER-Hannah (nee Rothberg). Wife of the late Armende, mother of Paulyn Cohen and Eli, grandmother of six, great-grandmother of 19. Graveside services Thursday, at 11:30 A.M. at Beth-El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Giving Aid to World Trade
description: By meeting in an idyllic retreat in the Canadian Rockies, leaders of the Group of 8, a conference of the leading industrial powers plus Russia, may succeed in avoiding the critics of globalization. But they will hardly be getting away from the question of global poverty. Confronting Africa's appalling economic distress is at the top of their agenda.

title: Witness Against Schwarz Admits to Forgery in 1992
description: A 10-year-old lie by Sgt. Eric Turetzky, one of the main prosecution witnesses in the Abner Louima brutality case, came back to haunt him as he testified in federal court in Brooklyn yesterday during the latest trial of former Officer Charles Schwarz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REID, GERTRUDE
description: REID-Gertrude. Born March, 29, 1914 in New York City, died peacefully on June 26, 2002 in her sleep at St. Joseph's nursing home in New Jersey. She held an important position with the NY School of Design, retiring in 1985. An excellent singer and voice teacher, she belonged to the NY Singing Teachers Association. Being a member of the prestigious Huguenot Society, her family of Hasbrouck date back to the 1700's. Friends may call Thursday evening, June 27th, 3-5 & 7-9 at Frank E. Campbel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment private.
