title: Xerox to Restate $1.9 Billion in Revenue
description: Stamford, Connecticut, June 28 -- Xerox Corp., the world's biggest copier maker, inflated revenue by $1.9 billion over the past five years by misreporting the timing and makeup of equipment sales. The company's stock and bonds plunged.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Order On Battered Mothers
description: A federal appeals court, rejecting government appeals for delay, ordered officials of the Administration for Children's Services yesterday to immediately stop unnecessarily separating battered mothers and their children. In March, a federal judge, Jack B. Weinstein, concluded that the city routinely violated the constitutional rights of victims of domestic violence by separating them from their children because of ''benign indifference, bureaucratic inefficiencies and outmoded institutional biases.'' He gave the city until June 22 to end the practice and improve legal representation by increasing the hourly rate of lawyers appointed to represent such mothers in Family Court to $90 from $40. Yesterday, the Second Circuit Court of Appeals denied the city more time while it appeals Judge Weinstein's decision. Joseph Cardieri, a lawyer for the administration, echoing lawyers for the mothers, said progress had been made resolving problems. Nina Bernstein (NYT)

title: New Video Releases
description: Shallow Hal

title: The Anti-Candidate, Out to Anger the Rich
description: EVERY election year, it seems, a candidate emerges and, citing the erosion of our political system, the vapid sound bites, the fleeing from real debate, the fusion of entertainment and political campaigning, declares that it is not worth playing by the rules.

title: People
description: * Thomas Moore, president and chief executive at Nelson Communications Worldwide, New York, the medical marketing unit of the Publicis Groupe, is resigning to become president and chief executive at the Biopure Corporation, Cambridge, Mass., a biotechnology company. Roger Haupt, chairman and chief executive at the Bcom3 Group, Chicago, will head Nelson temporarily as a successor to Mr. Moore is sought. Publicis is acquiring Bcom3, which operates a health care agency, Medicus Group International.

title: VANGUARD AIRLINES FILES FOR $35 MILLION LOAN GUARANTEE
description: Vanguard Airlines filed a revised application yesterday asking the government for $35 million of backing on a $40 million loan. Today is the deadline to apply for the $10 billion loan guarantee program set up by Congress to help ailing airlines get credit after the Sept. 11 attacks. Vanguard has revised its application four times, having been rejected in the past by the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, which administers the program. In its last application, the airline asked for $13.5 million of backing on a $15 million loan. It has increased its request because the larger amount will make the airline more attractive to investors, said Alan Carr, a spokesman. United and US Airways have both applied in the last month. American Airlines, Delta and Northwest have all said they will not apply. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: 3 British Bankers Are Accused of Fraud in Offshoot of Enron Case
description: Federal prosecutors in the Enron investigation filed a criminal complaint yesterday against three Britons, accusing them of defrauding their employer, National Westminster Bank, of $7.3 million through their dealings with a partnership related to the company.

title: Panel Finds Brooklyn Judge Sublet Apartment Improperly
description: A state disciplinary panel found yesterday that a Brooklyn judge should be removed because he improperly sublet his apartment to his brother-in-law, used the rent money for child support and political contributions instead of holding it for the landlord, then intentionally tried to mislead the panel about his actions.

title: House Raises Debt Ceiling And Avoids A Default
description: Under intense pressure to avert a government default that loomed for as early as this weekend, the House tonight narrowly approved an increase in the legal limit on the national debt, with Republicans swallowing their own reservations about the bill to pass it over the objections of Democrats.

title: Few Records on WorldCom
description: Investigators are apparently finding no records to support the shifting of billions of dollars on WorldCom's books. Business Day, Page C1.

title: Bonuses Meant to Retain Talent Now Risk Outrage
description: As it moves to lay off thousands of employees to cut costs, WorldCom is also facing the conflicting problem of avoiding an exodus of experienced senior executives needed to help it survive.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Muslim Woman Wins Day In Court
description: An Orange County Circuit Court judge ruled that a Muslim woman fighting to have a driver's license should be permitted to pursue her claim in court. The Florida attorney general's office asked the court to dismiss the claim, but Judge Ted Coleman ruled that the woman, Sultaana Freeman, should have her claim decided at trial. The Department of Motor Vehicles revoked Ms. Freeman's license in January after it discovered that her face was covered in the photograph, with only her eyes showing. Ms. Freeman says her religious beliefs prohibit showing her face to strangers or men outside her family. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: Quarterly Profits Jump 28% at Nike
description: Nike Inc., the maker of athletic shoes, said profit rose 28 percent in its most recent quarter as the company increased shoe sales in the United States and sold more products at full price by holding down inventory.

description: FELSEN-Esther. June 3, 1921 -June 28, 1998. Remembered, missed and loved every day. Her Loving Famil

description: INDIANA: AIRLINE SETTLES FERRET SUIT

title: For Some, a Stamp; for Sinatra, a Post Office
description: Letters sent from Frank Sinatra Park on Frank Sinatra Drive in Hoboken, N.J., to the Frank Sinatra Memorial at Frank Sinatra's birthplace will now pass through the Frank Sinatra Post Office Building.

description: The outcome of the race for the Senate in North Carolina to replace Jesse Helms, one of the most compelling political contests of the year, will probably turn on a few key questions.

title: LIBERTY TO PLAY HOST TO CLEVELAND
description: The Liberty knows better than to take the Cleveland Rockers lightly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, DAVID
description: LESSER-David. Age 92. Died June 22, 2002. Husband of Tillie Lesser, father of Beatrice Martin and Jonathan, fatherin-law of Joan and Nancy, grandfather of Eric, Rebecca, Julia and Cassandra. USN World War II Veteran, worked as a tool and die maker. He was devoted to his family, lover of nature, Zionism and humanity. Services were held June 23rd at Parkside in Brooklyn, N.Y. followed by burial. Shiva ended June 28th.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Socialism Forever, Assembly Declares
description: Vowing never to return to capitalism, the National Assembly has voted unanimously that the country's socialist system is ''irrevocable.'' The vote Wednesday night was seen by opposition leaders as an effort to block a dissident movement calling for increased personal and political freedoms. President Fidel Castro also warned that he might cut Cuba's limited relations with the United States if Washington continued to support dissidents and human rights advocates on the island. American diplomats in Havana recently distributed hundreds of short-wave radios able to receive Radio Mart, the anti-Castro station financed by the United States. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Schwarz Trial Is Set to End Sooner Than Anticipated
description: Prosecutors in the Abner Louima torture case yesterday called their next-to-last witness -- a former police officer who was a confidant of the accused man, Charles Schwarz -- as the trial raced toward a conclusion far earlier than expected.

title: DVD Has Begun to Take Over
description: Introduced five years ago, DVD has moved from catching on to taking over. The process is gradual, but everywhere VHS is passing the torch to the new format. Last week Circuit City, the large electronics retailer, said it planned to drop videocassettes altogether in favor of the disc. Of the more than 10 million copies of "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" sold since its release by Warner on May 28, almost 60 percent were DVD's.

title: Souls Alone in the Universe, Connected by a Dying Man
description: The McCarter Theater's production of Edward Albee's ''All Over,'' staged in Princeton, N.J., in February, opened last night at the Roundabout Theater Company at the Gramercy Theater. Following are excerpts from Ben Brantley's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Feb. 25. The full text is online at nytimes.com/theater.

title: Back to the Beach for a Blast of 50's Cool
description: IF you grew up in or around southern New Jersey in the early 1960's, there is a good chance that at least once, your parents piled you into their new Chevy Impala and headed to the city of Wildwood on the Jersey Shore. There, you would have relaxed on the wide, clean beaches, indulged in the rides, games and fast food on the lively boardwalk, and spent evenings in one of Wildwood's many mom-and-pop motels, like the Eden Roc and the Caribbean, frolicking in the kidney-shaped pool while your parents sipped mai tais on the deck.

title: Parties Maneuver Over Risks In Growing Business Scandal
description: The financial meltdown of WorldCom left President Bush and the Republicans struggling today to limit the political risk from what strategists in both parties say could be a shift in the way voters view business and the economy.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: TAIWAN: RATES LOWERED Fighting to stop an appreciation of the Taiwan dollar that threatens to erode the competitiveness of Taiwan's exports, the central bank lowered all three interest rates that it controls by a quarter of a percentage point. Despite what traders describe as huge daily interventions by the central bank, the Taiwan dollar has been inching up against the United States dollar. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: 'Under God': A Decision That Jolted America
description: To the Editor:

title: Amtrak Halt Only Delayed, Many in Congress Suspect
description: Congressional supporters and opponents of Amtrak both reacted skeptically today to the Bush administration's agreement to keep the railroad running through September with short-term loans. Both sides expressed concern that a shutdown threat had simply been deferred until next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'ROURKE, JIM P.
description: O'ROURKE-Jim P. On June 26, 2002. Passed away at the age of 91. Retired Vice President of the Teamsters Local 807. Visitation will be today at the Bennett Funeral Home, Scarsdale, NY. For information call, (914) 725-1137.

title: Votive Candles and Wild Riffs
description: The Cuban-born pianist Omar Sosa has a nearly feral sense of showmanship: at the Blue Note on Monday night, performing for the first time in New York, he came to flatten the crowd, and he did.

title: China Emerges As Rival to U.S. In Asian Trade
description: From South Korea to Indonesia, China is rapidly strengthening its economic presence across Asia, gobbling up foreign investment and chipping away at the United States' position as the region's economic engine.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a federal appeals court's 2-to-1 decision that reciting the Pledge of Allegiance in public schools is unconstitutional referred incorrectly in some copies to the year in which the dissenting judge, Ferdinand F. Fernandez, was appointed. It was 1989, not 1980.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENTON, THOMAS L.
description: FENTON-Thomas L. Marketing entrepreneur dies at 61. A co-founder of Synchronal Inc., one of the earliest major successes in the infomercial industry, died at his home in Easton, Connecticut on Saturday, June 22, 2002 after a long struggle with cancer. Mr. Fenton began his career in advertising photography in New York City. He served two years as officer in charge of the Signal Corps photo unit at the U.S. Army Arctic Test Grounds at Fort Greeley, Alaska. Following his tour of duty, Mr. Fenton returned to Manhattan and actively pursued a career as a television producer at several advertising agencies and became Executive Vice President and Director of Broadcast Production at Doyle Dane Bernbach. Becoming a major force in the infomercial industry, Mr. Fenton was a founding member of NIMA, the national infomercial trade association which is presently titled Electronic Retailing Association (ERA). After selling his interest in Synchronal in 1992, he became a marketing consultant and independent entrepreneur. Mr. Fenton was born in Chicago, Illinois to Ruth and Thomas L. Fenton, who are both deceased. While attending public schools he excelled in academics and became a National Merit Scholarship winner. He began his undergraduate studies at the University of Chicago, particularly enjoying playing baseball. His education was completed at the Art Center School of Design in Los Angeles where he received a BFA in photography. He is survived by his loving wife Dana, his son Thomas Fenton and daughter Juliana Fenton of Easton, CT., his son Stephen Dirhold and grandson, Landon Dirhold of Marion, NC. He is also survived by his brother Timothy Fenton and sister-inlaw Elizabeth Fenton of Norwalk, CT and brother Robert Fenton of Kansas City, MO, and his loving nieces Laura and Anne Fenton of Norwalk, CT. A private service for the immediate family was held on Tuesday, June 25, 2002. A memorial service will be held at the Jesse Lee United Methodist Church in Easton, CT. at 4:00 P.M. on Saturday, July 13, 2002. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made in the name of Thomas L. Fenton to the Jesse Lee United Methodist Church, 25 Flat Rock Road, Easton, CT. 06612.

title: Senate Committee Approves Bill Mandating Big Cuts in Emissions
description: The Senate Environment and Public Works Committee approved a bill today that would require substantial reductions in emissions by utility companies, over the objections of determined opponents who said the measure would never become law.

description: LFL

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: General Catalyst Names Chief For New Unit
description: General Catalyst Partners, a private equity firm in Boston, said Jon Miller would be chief executive of a new portfolio company it has created to focus on ''multichannel, interactive commerce.'' The effort will include projects on sports, entertainment and travel, company officials said. Mr. Miller, who has more than 20 years of experience at USA Interactive, Viacom, the National Basketball Association and public broadcasting, has been president of the USA Information and Services Group since June 2000. The unit oversees all of USA's concerns except the Home Shopping Network. USA said he would remain in that post through the end of the year. Barry Diller, chairman and chief executive of USA Interactive, said of Mr. Miller, ''In the many years I've worked with him, I've known that not only is he one of the brightest thinkers, but that he has had a growing interest in more entrepreneurial pursuits.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Rates Lowered
description: Fighting to stop an appreciation of the Taiwan dollar that threatens to erode the competitiveness of Taiwan's exports, the central bank lowered all three interest rates that it controls by a quarter of a percentage point. Despite what traders describe as huge daily interventions by the central bank, the Taiwan dollar has been inching up against the United States dollar. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Weekender | Phoenicia, N.Y.
description: TO stand in the middle of Main Street in Phoenicia and gaze up at the towering mountains, which you can do on most weekdays without interrupting traffic, is to believe that whatever the maps say, city life is worlds away.

title: As Stewart's image tarnishes, advertisers start to reconsider.
description: THE mounting difficulties confronting Martha Stewart, centered on questions about her sale of stock in ImClone Systems, are starting to unnerve the marketers and ad agencies that buy commercial time and advertising space on and in the media properties that bear her name.

title: Monday Morning Point Guard
description: Dealings at the N.B.A. draft not only provided the Knicks with an All-Star power forward. Several other teams made significant upgrades. It's always tricky gauging the losers and winners the day after, but here goes nothing, anyway. By Mike Wise

title: World Briefing | Europe: Deadline For France In Beef Dispute
description: The European Commission, the executive arm of the European Union, set a 15-day deadline for France to drop its ban on British beef or face fines by the European Court of Justice. A union-wide ban imposed in 1996 after the outbreak of mad cow disease in Britain was lifted in 1999 but France has kept it in place, saying it still believes meat from Britain is risky. The French government said it would not make a decision until September but after a meeting of agriculture ministers in Luxembourg, David Byrne, the European commissioner for health and consumer protection, said the French minister had taken a position that ''seems to go in the right direction.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: U.S. Links Bosnia Role To Immunity From Court
description: The United States raised the ante today in its opposition to the International Criminal Court, threatening to veto a renewal of the multinational force in Bosnia unless the peacekeepers were granted immunity from the court.

title: The Lords of Reggae Are Rolling
description: BEFORE most summer music festivals, the questions are simple: What will the weather be? Who's performing? How much are tickets? But with reggae, it's a little different. New York City's biggest reggae concert of the season takes place on Sunday on Randalls Island, and some fans may have another question on their minds: Will any of the performers be booed offstage, or perhaps even attacked with beer bottles? It's a rare occurrence, but not unheard-of.

title: Prison Release Recalls Horror In L.I. Diner; 1982 Rampage Led to Law Raising Felony Penalties
description: In the 23 years since Nicholas J. Bouloukos opened the Seacrest Diner Restaurant, a stone building tucked next to a gas station on a bustling intersection here, certain things have changed.

title: Presbyterian Pastors Sued Over Church's Rule on Gays
description: Members of the First Presbyterian Church, in Greenwich Village, heard it directly from their pastor, the Rev. Jon M. Walton: he is being sued. A lawyer in Virginia had filed a complaint against Dr. Walton with the church's ecclesiastical court, accusing him of willfully violating the national church's ban on allowing active homosexuals to be ordained as ministers or church officers.

description: Bankers Accused in Enron

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Modem Media Plans Job Cuts
description: Modem Media, an interactive services agency based in Norwalk, Conn., said yesterday that it would close offices in Hong Kong, Munich and Toronto and lay off employees in most of its other offices. Modem executives cited reductions in expected revenue as the reason for the cutbacks. The agency will dismiss 90 employees, or 22.5 percent of its total staff of 400. Modem will continue to operate offices in London, San Francisco and So Paulo, Brazil, in addition to the Norwalk headquarters, but it will reduce its office space in London and Norwalk. The executives said they expected pretax charges of $12 million in connection with the cutbacks.

title: Flavors Of Fraud
description: So you're the manager of an ice cream parlor. It's not very profitable, so how can you get rich? Each of the big business scandals uncovered so far suggests a different strategy for executive self-dealing.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit To Buy Eclipse For $85 Million
description: Intuit, the world's largest maker of tax-preparation software, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Eclipse, a maker of programs for distributors of building supplies, for $85 million in cash. The acquisition will add $40 million to $50 million in sales in the year ending in July 2003, Intuit said in a statement. The company, based in Mountain View, Calif., said the purchase, expected to close this quarter or next, will ''slightly'' add to its 2003 profit. Stephen Bennett, Intuit's president and chief executive, has been expanding the company's line of small-business software and services through the acquisitions of companies like Omware, which makes programs for the construction industry. Intuit shares rose 46 cents, to $47.90, in trading after the purchase was announced. The stock gained 29 cents, to $47.44 during regular trading hours, and has climbed 11 percent this year.

title: Little Progress Is Made Before a Recess Is Taken in the Labor Talks
description: Fifteen years ago, major league clubs secretly created an information bank to which clubs reported all offers to free agents. The players' union, upon learning of its existence, filed a grievance, contending that the bank was the clubs' way of colluding against free agents. An arbitrator agreed, ruling that it violated the collective bargaining agreement.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Broadway producer Robert Whitehead on June 17 misstated the location of Trinity College School, the secondary school he attended. It is in Port Hope, Ontario, not Montreal.

title: $10 Billion Pledged to Ex-Soviets to Dispose of Unconventional Arms
description: After months of negotiations, Japan, Canada and the European members of the Group of 8 agreed at the summit meeting today to spend $10 billion over the next decade to help Russia and other former Soviet states dispose of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons, ending a long argument over how closely those countries could monitor the work.

Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.

description: BECKMAN COULTER, Fullerton, Calif., a maker of medical laboratory supplies, said it had signed two new contracts and two renewal agreements to supply instruments, test kits, and blood and heart products to Premier Inc., a purchasing organization owned by more than 200 hospitals and health care systems. Sales are expected to be about $173 million.

description: The College Board formally announced yesterday that it was undertaking a major overhaul of the SAT test, one that will include a handwritten essay and take an extra half-hour to complete.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, EILEEN
description: BENJAMIN - Eileen. The Board of Directors and tenants of 1155 Park Avenue mourn the loss of our friend, neighbor and longtime resident, Eileen ''Nicky'' Benjamin. While serving on the Board for many years, Nicky was held in high regard for her intelligence and constructive suggestions. Always gracious and elegant, Nicky will be missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her sons, Robert and Bruce, their families and to her sister, Peggy Dubois.

title: FEDEX TRUCKING UNIT FOLLOWS RIVALS IN RAISING RATES
description: The FedEx Corporation's trucking unit is raising freight shipping rates 5.9 percent, effective July 22, to pay for technology and equipment improvements and to help cover higher health care and insurance costs. Two FedEx rivals, the Yellow Corporation and Consolidated Freightways, raised rates earlier this month by about the same amount. FedEx Freight, Yellow and Consolidated provide less-than-truckload service, carrying freight from multiple customers in each trailer. Shares of FedEx rose $1.33, to $51.58.

title: A Long List Of Defendants With More To Be Named
description: Let the accusations begin. With the disclosure that WorldCom drastically overstated its profits, regulators and plaintiffs' lawyers are looking at the company, its officers, directors, investment bankers and accountants as possible defendants in lawsuits.

title: Recreating A Golden Age Of Radio
description: John Jenkins started collecting radios the way many enthusiasts did. In 1966, when he was 13, he found an old radio in his grandparents' basement in Bellingham, Wash., and took it home. It wasn't hard to make it work, said Mr. Jenkins, who retired last year as Microsoft's general manager of worldwide sales and marketing. ''My father was an electrician, and I had already set up an intercom between my friend's house and mine,'' he said. ''I was the neighborhood nerd.''

title: PEPPER RETURNING FROM INJURY
description: Neither shoulder surgery nor a lengthy layoff have diminished Dottie Pepper's expectations.

title: A Genial Trio Plays Stylistic Cat and Mouse
description: The Bad Plus, a new piano trio, at times errs on the side of smart-guy irony. Built of young, eclectic jazz musicians -- the pianist Ethan Iverson, the bassist Reid Anderson, the drummer David King -- it likes to present delicate music at close quarters with full-scale eruptions. Its sets include songs by Neil Young, Blondie and others who are generally considered gauche by the jazz world; its intrinsically amusing drummer has a loud, hungry energy that threatens to rival Keith Moon's.

title: A Pool of Swimmers
description: It's hard to tell which is more ironic: that in a city nearly surrounded by water, most children don't learn to swim or that the island of Manhattan is hiring lifeguards from Poland. It's been a long time since New York was able to produce enough home-grown swimmers to fill the jobs at the pools during the summer. Thanks to Eastern Europe, that's not one of the city's worst problems. The fact that so many of our children can't swim is far more worrisome, as we're reminded every year when we begin to hear tragic stories of drownings at private pools and restricted beaches.

title: Report on Pension Fund Is McCall's Response to Cuomo
description: After several attacks from his rival in the Democratic primary for governor, the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, released an annual report on the state's pension fund today that showed it grew more over the last fiscal year than other large funds.

title: In Hometown Of WorldCom, Loss and Shock
description: This city is big enough to hold the country's second-largest long-distance carrier, and small enough that many outsiders do not know this.

title: Old Agencies Promise to Share Information With New One
description: The directors of the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. told Congress today that their agencies would share secret intelligence with the proposed Department of Homeland Security. But they expressed support for a Bush administration plan that would keep their agencies independent of the new organization.

title: A Little of Lots of Things, With Irrepressible Zest
description: Tony Danza's cabaret act is an illustration of how sheer charm can override any number of technical deficiencies. The boyish 51-year-old television actor, who is appearing at Feinstein's at the Regency through July 5, conveys an infectious aw-shucks cockiness as he zips around the stage like a human sparkplug.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Strike After Death Of Protesters
description: Leftist parties and labor unions organized a daylong strike and led a march on the heavily guarded presidential palace to protest the deaths of two young protesters on Tuesday during a confrontation with the riot police on the outskirts of Buenos Aires. To condemn what they described as government repression against unemployed workers demanding jobs, food and medicine, teachers joined government workers in the strike, leading to the closing of many schools in the capital area. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: DVD Has Begun To Take Over
description: Introduced five years ago, DVD has moved from catching on to taking over. The process is gradual, but everywhere VHS is passing the torch to the new format. Last week Circuit City, the large electronics retailer, said it planned to drop videocassettes altogether in favor of the disc. Of the more than 10 million copies of ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'' sold since its release by Warner on May 28, almost 60 percent were DVD's.

title: Cars for Those With $300,000 Burning a Hole in Their Pockets
description: THE Maybach is hardly the only gilded marque making a comeback. For small-scale manufacturers of what are mostly 200-mile-per-hour, two-seat supercars, a famous name is a crucial part of a very expensive package. Here are some of the fabulous dream machines that may be coming soon to a showroom near you:

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Challenge To Ban On Unwed Sex
description: The American Civil Liberties Union Foundation has filed a brief with the State Supreme Court challenging a state law that prohibits sex between unmarried couples. ''Most unmarried people would be outraged if they knew that their private, consensual expressions of intimacy turned them into criminals,'' Beth Littrell, a lawyer for the foundation, said in a statement.

title: From Such Troubles, Such Sweet Music
description: One hundred years ago today the composer Richard Rodgers was born. This centennial year has elicited a rush of revivals and homages, as well as an outpouring of commentary and biography, much of it intended to reconcile the dark persona with the buoyant music. At least that's the excuse for serving up the dish.

title: Mets Look Bad, and the Future Could Be Worse
description: The Mets have played with the high-stakes crowd for five years now and they have had their moments when they hit big: the playoffs in 1999, the World Series in 2000. They built a championship-caliber team by taking out advances on their future, and anyone who saw Benny Agbayani's game-winning homer or Al Leiter's gritty Game 5 outing against the Yankees cannot have regrets.

title: SHAW SAYS IT HAS ENDED TALKS FOR TURNER INDUSTRIES
description: The Shaw Group, a construction company for the energy industry, said yesterday that it had ended talks to buy Turner Industries, a week after saying it would buy the company for $250 million to $350 million. The companies were unable to agree on definitive terms, Shaw said. Turner, a closely held company with about 10,000 employees, provides industrial-construction, maintenance, tank-cleaning, hauling and equipment-rental services. Turner gets as much as half its revenue from maintenance services at petrochemical companies, Shaw said. Both companies are based in Baton Rouge, La.

title: Behind Mental Illness, the Universal Sorrows of Life
description: YOU ARE NOT A STRANGER HERE

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Ailing Premier Speaks To Parliament
description: The ailing prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, made his first public speech in nearly two months, a rambling address to Parliament in which he first said new elections were on the horizon and then rejected holding a vote before April 2004 as scheduled. Mr. Ecevit, 77, who appeared unable to mount the stairs to the podium and spoke from the floor, is suffering from numerous serious ailments. Nine members of his own party called for him to step down amid calls for early elections. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Op-Art
Keeping Tradition, Bloomberg Will Join Gay Pride Marchers
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will continue the tradition of mayors before him when he takes his place among marchers at the gay pride parade this Sunday. For a moment there, it appeared that Mr. Bloomberg was going to break with one aspect of that tradition by taking his place at the beginning of the parade route at Fifth Avenue and 52nd Street.

description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Finish Business Before Their Break
description: Before the Nets left for their well-deserved vacation yesterday, they felt comfortable with their summer situation, having taken care of future and immediate needs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, SUZANNE
description: GILMAN-Suzanne. Died on 6/27. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Howard Gilman. Dear sister Ethel Goodstein. Beloved mother of Deanne. Adored grandmother of June, Jon, Elissa, Matt. Great grandmother of Isabel Rayna and Jackson. Frank E. Campbell, 81st & Madison on Sunday, 6/30, 9AM for graveside service, Mt. Pleasant Cemetery.

description: Christine Burgin

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Criticizing Limits On Rape Charges
description: The Suffolk County district attorney, Daniel F. Conley, is proposing legislation to eliminate the 15-year statute of limitations for rape and child rape cases. Prompted by recent accusations of sexual abuse by clergymen, Mr. Conley said those who report abuse should not be turned away because of timing. Of the 50 priests referred to his office for investigation, Mr. Conley said, more than 30 were covered by the statute of limitations. Alabama, Alaska, California, Kentucky, Louisiana and Maine have similar laws. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Lobbyist Pleads Guilty To Fraud
description: Donald A. Udstuen, a widely known lobbyist, apologized to residents after pleading guilty to tax fraud conspiracy. Mr. Udstuen, a political adviser to Gov. George Ryan, said he used a friend's company to launder money for another lobbyist for fixing contracts. Mr. Udstuen, the latest in a group of Ryan insiders to be indicted, also said he had accepted kickbacks for fixing contracts at Metra, the city's commuter service. His plea agreement calls for a 10- to 16-month sentence. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: When Love and Disease Both Strike Out of the Blue
description: Bille August's harrowingly sad film ''A Song for Martin'' contrasts two kinds of fate. One is romantic, in the sense that two people who meet and fall in love at first sight often feel they have found the soul mates fate meant them to have. The other is implacably bleak, as in fatal illness. By handing its lead characters the first kind and then the second in a rapid one-two punch, the film, by the director of ''Pelle the Conquerer,'' implies a karmic payback in which too much happiness (especially if purchased at the expense of others) should not be allowed to stand.

title: Russian Parliament Passes a Hate-Crime Bill Backed by Putin
description: A Kremlin-backed bill to fight hate crimes and attacks by fascist groups passed a final vote today in the lower house of Parliament, despite the concerns of some rights advocates that it may give too much power to the police.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Orbitz Passes An Antitrust Review
description: Orbitz, the online travel booking site owned by five major United States airlines, said yesterday that a Department of Transportation review of its business had found no anticompetitive problems. Both the Department of Transportation and the Justice Department have been watching Orbitz for potential antitrust violations since it was founded a year ago. Competitors like Expedia, a subsidiary of USA Interactive, and Travelocity, a subsidiary of Sabre, have charged that Orbitz's ties to the airline industry give it an unfair advantage. Orbitz, however, says it has generated more competition in the ticketing business, benefiting consumers with lower ticket prices. Since last June, Orbitz has grown to become the nation's third-largest online ticketer. It spent more than $50 million on sales and marketing last year, driving traffic to its Orbitz.com site by blanketing the Web with advertisements. In a statement, Jeffrey Katz, the chief executive of Orbitz, said, ''We look forward to the Department of Justice reaching a similar conclusion that Orbitz has energized competition and improved the Internet shopping experience for consumers and that the government should not intervene in the marketplace except to remedy actual problems and not speculative ones.'' Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Reliever Is Tested After Having A Seizure
description: Mark Corey, the Mets' rookie relief pitcher, was tested yesterday after having a seizure Wednesday night outside a hotel in Corona, Queens, about an hour after the Mets-Braves game.

title: State to Assist A L.I. Study Of Pet Cancers
description: For years, anecdotal evidence has suggested that Long Island has an unusually high rate of cancer. Now, the state has allocated money to find out whether the same holds true for Long Islanders' pets.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Keeping Mosquitoes at Bay Without Poison, Zap or Stink
description: MOSQUITOES either love you or they don't, and my sympathies if they do. As a lifelong object of desire myself, I have suffered a double whammy: the bites of the nasty little insects and the faintly derisive skepticism of those whose skin type does not attract the potential carriers of, among other things, malaria and the West Nile virus.

title: G-8 Adopts African Aid Package, With Strict Conditions
description: President Bush and leaders of the major industrial countries ended their meeting today by committing billions of dollars in aid to African nations that successfully reform their economies and governments. But they offered only the vaguest assurances that they would dismantle the huge subsidies for their own farmers, which African leaders bitterly complain have undercut the ability of the poorest nations to compete in world markets.

title: Quick Escapes
description: Boston

title: Where the Drag Queens Wore Beards
description: ''The Cockettes,'' a new documentary by David Weissman and Bill Weber, revisits the San Francisco of the late 1960's and early 70's, a time and place so encrusted with legend and clich that you might wonder if there is anything left to say. It turns out there is quite a lot that the endlessly recycled and diluted images of the storied counterculture have obscured about some of the most interesting and vital parts of the culture itself, which the filmmakers have brought triumphantly to life.

title: No Records Found to Back WorldCom's Shift of Billions
description: Investigators looking into the WorldCom scandal have found no records to support decisions to shift billions of dollars in expenses on the company's books, people close to the company said yesterday -- a fact that increases the likelihood that the transactions involved criminal fraud.

title: Budget Increases for Pentagon Pass Easily
description: Seeking to demonstrate strong support for the military, the House and Senate overwhelmingly passed major defense spending packages today, increasing pay for the armed forces and providing new money for military hardware and research.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: A Big Success For Sondheim

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New TKTS Booth Downtown
description: The Theater Development Fund, which sells discounted tickets to Broadway and Off Broadway shows and other arts events, said yesterday that it would open a new booth to replace the one destroyed at the World Trade Center. The booth is scheduled to open at John and Front Streets in August, while a temporary one will open in July at the South Street Seaport. The fund had been selling tickets from a trailer at Bowling Green Park Plaza. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Justices Strike Down Minnesota Law Prohibiting Political Statements by Judicial Candidates
description: Declaring that the First Amendment protects the right of judicial candidates to express their views, the Supreme Court today struck down a Minnesota rule that prohibited candidates in judicial elections from taking stands on disputed legal or political issues.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: CRITICIZING LIMITS ON RAPE CHARGES

title: Voucher Backers See Opening for a Wider Agenda
description: In response to the Supreme Court's endorsement of this city's voucher program, legislators around the country are likely to begin exploring ways of spending money previously reserved for public education. The measures they draft, if passed, would transform the way many families choose the schools their children attend.

title: Court's Stance on Searches Evolves
description: It was not until 1985 that students had any rights to be free of random searches in public schools. Principals and teachers were thought of as surrogate parents, and thus could legally order a student to open a locker or turn out a backpack, even if there was no reason to suspect a problem.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan Baby Is Stillborn After Attack
description: A man who attacked the mother of his unborn child may face additional charges after the baby was delivered stillborn, the authorities said. The man, Mario Bauza, 30, of West 106th Street in Manhattan, was arrested Wednesday and charged with first-degree assault for pushing a 26-year-old woman to the ground on the street near his home and kicking her in the back and stomach, the police said. She was eight months pregnant. The woman, whose name was not released, was taken to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in serious but stable condition. Yesterday she delivered a stillborn baby, after her labor was induced. The medical examiner is expected to determine the cause of death. ''Any additional charges probably would come from the district attorney's office,'' said Officer Louis Camacho. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAUGHTON, DENNIS J. (''UNCLE DENNIS'')
description: NAUGHTON - Dennis J. (''Uncle Dennis''). Son of the late John and May Naughton. Beloved brother of Dr. Rose Ann Naughton and John F. Naughton. Uncle of Helena Henderson and grand-uncle to Bill and Kevin Henderson. Cousin of Chris Tighe and Edward Higgins. Dennis, an Iona College graduate, was a long time employee of State Farm Insurance and an avid member of The Kiwanis Club of Rego Park where he served a term as president. Dennis was a generous, industrious, gregarious, fun loving, charitable man who loved life and enjoyed it to the fullest. He fought his cancer with determination, optimism, and good humor. He lost the battle on June 21, 2002. He has donated his body to science. A memorial mass will be held at Holy Child Church, Richmond Hill, Queens at 9:30 AM on June 29. In lieu of flowers donations in his honor may be sent to: The Kiwanis Club of Rego Park, C/O E. Romano, 61-38 85th Street, Middle Village, New York 11379.

title: Rio Journal; At Your Great Peril, Defy the Lords of the Slums
description: Gang leaders had taken control of the weekend funk dances in the neighborhood, selling drugs openly and forcing young girls to have sex with them. The police had been alerted but had done nothing, so the residents of the slum known as the Favela da Grota turned, like so many others here before them, to the crusading crime reporter Tim Lopes.

description: To the Editor:

description: I THANK the filmmaker Errol Morris for introducing me to the joys of the pruning shear.

title: Accounts

title: BANK ONE EQUITY UNIT IS TOP BIDDER FOR POLAROID ASSETS
description: The private equity arm of the Bank One Corporation was the top bidder in an auction for the assets of the Polaroid Corporation, the bankrupt instant-photo pioneer, Polaroid said in a statement last night. The $255 million offer from One Equity Partners will be considered at a hearing today in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. One Equity would hold a 65 percent stake in the new company, and Polaroid's unsecured creditors would control the remaining 35 percent, a Polaroid spokesman said. The company's unsecured-creditors committee and secured creditors backed the proposed sale, he said. If approved, the sale is expected to close in July.

title: Residential Real Estate; Condos Behind a Cascading Wall of Colored Glass
description: The condominium now rising at 497 Greenwich Street has been designed to stand out from its neighbors in the old industrial area. An undulating glass facade rises 11 floors from the street, extending, in an inverted L shape, over the roof of the adjoining six-story former warehouse that will contain 8 of the project's 22 apartments.

title: The Once Dreamy Woods Now Have Big, Bad Wolves
description: School's out, which is a good thing as far as the Royal Shakespeare Company's new production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' is concerned. We wouldn't want any unsuspecting English teachers shepherding their sophomores into the Shubert Theater here in anticipation of the gentle, giddy introduction to Shakespeare that has seduced generations. They'd all be perplexed by a production that seems to be willfully unattractive, drained of color and demonic in spirit, as opposed to magical. Of course, 10th graders might very well get a charge out of the director Richard Jones's sense of the perverse.

description: KESSLEROHEN - Estelle/d. Born in 1909, died in New York City on June 24, 2002. She married Louis M. Cohen, a lawyer, and textile manufacturer and founding member of the United Jewish Appeal. They had two daughters Hannah and Sandra. She later married Henry H. Kessler, founder of the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation in New Jersey. She leaves five grandchildren: David, Brian, Kenneth, Nikolas and Alexandr. She also stayed close to her son-in-law Herbert Halberg and David's wife Frances. Estelle supported many foundations during her life and the family would greatly appreciate contributions in her name to the Kessler Institute of Rehabilitation International, and The American Jewish Committee, UJA and Cerebral Palsy. Services Friday, June 28, 2002, 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave at 65th St. It will be followed by a burial service at Mt. Carmel Cemetery.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Foster's Outlook
description: The Foster's Group expects no profit from its Asian breweries until at least 2004 as a slump in tourism and new taxes hurt its results in India, the chief executive, Ted Kunkel, said. Foster's, Australia's biggest brewer, had not previously said when it would post a profit in Asia, where its operations in China, India and Vietnam have been losing money for much of the last decade. Foster's is approaching the point of benefiting from Asia, as it sells higher-priced beers, expands output and makes other drinks, Mr. Kunkel said.

title: Zlle Captures The Tour de Suisse
description: Switzerland's Alex Zlle won the Tour de Suisse for the first time, beating Piotr Wadecki of Poland by 1 minute 27 seconds after the final stage, a 34.5-kilometer time trial between the Swiss cities of Lyss and Biel.

title: Kasparaitis Will Be A Free Agent
description: Defenseman Darius Kasparaitis of the Colorado Avalanche will become an unrestricted free agent Monday without further challenge to his status by the National Hockey League. An arbitration scheduled for today between the N.H.L. and the N.H.L. Players Association was canceled by the league, a union spokesman said. The league did not respond to a request for comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEFFNER, MARILYN JEANNE HOOD
description: HEFFNER-Marilyn Jeanne Hood, 75. Of Irvington, New York, on June 24, 2002. Dearly cherished wife of Lee and beloved mother of Kristen, Lincoln & Amy. Grandmother of Claire, David, Melissa, Jesse, Kelby and Tanner and mother-in-law of Patty and Bill. We celebrate her life and the joy, love and strength that were an inspiration to all who knew her. She devoted herself to her family, church and community and her love and care touched and enriched the lives of so many. She will stay in our hearts & prayers forever. Memorial services will be held at the Irvington Presbyterian Church, Irvington, NY, Monday July 1, 11:00 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Memorial Garden of the Irvington Presbyterian Church or Doctors without Borders.

description: The Federal Trade Commission reached a settlement yesterday with two generic drug makers accused of using a licensing arrangement to prevent competition and to keep prices higher for a generic blood pressure medication.

description: BARAF-Jeri Lynn. Beloved wife of Charles. Devoted mother and mother-in-law of Joshua and Laura. Daughter of Ann Colby. Services today 12 noon at Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, NY.

description: Moving to fill what will be one of the most scrutinized jobs in the rebuilding of downtown, the agency in charge of the effort is preparing to appoint a Merrill Lynch executive who is a longtime organizer of downtown cultural events to oversee the creation of a memorial to the victims of the Sept. 11 attack, according to officials involved in the effort.

title: The Lords Of Reggae Are Rolling
description: BEFORE most summer music festivals, the questions are simple: What will the weather be? Who's performing? How much are tickets? But with reggae, it's a little different. New York City's biggest reggae concert of the season takes place on Sunday on Randalls Island, and some fans may have another question on their minds: Will any of the performers be booed offstage, or perhaps even attacked with beer bottles? It's a rare occurrence, but not unheard-of.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Investor
description: Suzuki Motor of Japan has agreed to pay $89 million for a 14.9 percent stake in GM-Daewoo Auto and Technology, the company that General Motors is forming as a successor to the bankrupt Daewoo Motors. The portion held by Suzuki, which is 20 percent owned by G.M., will make it the second-largest investor after G.M., which will own 42.1 percent of the company. G.M. is still looking for another partner to invest 10 percent, enough to cover the entire $400 million that G.M. has said the group will pay for a 67 percent stake in the company. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGELMAN, LEE
description: SPIEGELMAN-Lee. 92. Formerly of Great Neck, NY and FL, on June 25, 2002 peacefully at home in Laguna Woods, CA. Widow of Sidney. Beloved mother of Donald and Paul. Adored grandmother of Laura, Emily and Cabot. Past-president Engineers C.C. Women's Auxiliary. Memorial celebration Leisure World, CA. on August 7th.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Floods Wreak Havoc
description: President Vladimir V. Putin criticized local officials for failing to prepare for floods in southern Russia that have killed more than 80 people, left thousands homeless and caused more than $400 million in damage since last week. After a brief respite, waters began rising again yesterday in some places and meteorologists have predicted more torrential rains. Prosecutors in the hardest-hit region, Stavropol, said they might charge some officials with negligence. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Killer Indicted In Assault
description: A man convicted last week of murder in connection with a triple homicide in an apartment above the Carnegie Deli was indicted yesterday on charges that he assaulted a Riker's Island guard. The man, Sean Salley, 30, is accused of punching Officer Vincent Donovan on May 21, officials said. Officer Donovan fell backward and banged his head on a jail cell's bars, the authorities said. He needed eight staples for the head wound he suffered when he fell. Mr. Salley said he acted in self-defense. He would face up to seven years in prison if convicted on the assault charge. He already faces 25 years to life in prison for each of the three counts of his murder conviction. His murder sentencing is scheduled for July 29. Susan Saulny (NYT)

description: Russian oil companies are still going strong, expanding their roles on international markets, despite last year's drop in the price of oil.

title: Generally Accepted Accounting Abuses
description: As investors contemplate the allegations of accounting fraud at WorldCom, which follow accounting scandals at Enron, Global Crossing, Adelphia, Tyco and elsewhere, they will undoubtedly reach the obvious conclusion: The accounting profession has lost its way. They are right to demand that Congress and federal regulators take steps to improve standards and tighten oversight, and there are ways officials can better ensure financial transparency.

description: John Alec Entwistle, the bass player for the Who, died yesterday in Las Vegas, where the Who was preparing to start a United States tour today. Mr. Entwistle was 57.

title: Carbon Monoxide Kills Young Couple in Queens
description: Two young lovers were found dead, apparently poisoned accidentally by carbon monoxide, inside a two-car garage in Queens late Wednesday, the police said. The woman's body was lying on the back seat of a car parked with its engine running, they said, and her boyfriend's body was lying on the ground just outside the car's open door.

description: For the first time since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, a United States Olympic Committee task force will visit New York on Sunday and Monday to evaluate its worthiness to be America's designated host city competing for the 2012 Summer Games.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: REALNETWORKS' SALES WILL FALL SHORT Shares of RealNetworks fell more than 18 percent yesterday after the company, which makes software for playing Internet audio and video, said second-quarter sales would fall short of analysts' estimates. The shares fell 79 cents, or 18.4 percent, to $3.50. Shares hit a high of $96 in February 2000. The company, based in Seattle, has been paring costs and trying to sell more subscriptions to play music and video on the Internet to compensate for declining sales of its server programs, which let Web site operators distribute media files to users. The company had forecast that results in each quarter of this year would improve from the previous periods. RealNetworks said yesterday that second-quarter sales would be $42.5 million to $45 million, down from $47.9 million in the period a year earlier. (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, FRANK R.
description: MORAN-Frank R., 84. On June 27, 2002, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Ridgewood, NJ. Beloved husband of Joan and loving father of Joan Trout, Frank Jr., Douglas, Marybeth Wooters, Paul, and Thomas. Adoring grandfather of 15. Born in Brooklyn, NY, loyal Alumnus of Fordham University, most honorably served as an officer in the U.S. Navy during W.W. II. In 1956 he founded Moran Shipping Corp. and remained president until his retirement in 1986. He was an avid golfer and member of Ridgewood Country Club and Arcola Country Club. The family will receive callers at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave, Ridgewood, NJ from 2PM-4PM & 7PM-9PM Sunday, June 30. A Funeral Mass will take place at 1PM on July 1 at Mt. Carmel Church, Ridgewood, NJ, to celebrate his life. Interment to follow at St. Luke's Cemetery, Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ. Donations in his memory may be made to St. Vincent Ferrer School, Delray Beach, FL. 33483.

title: SUPREME COURT, 5-4, UPHOLDS VOUCHER SYSTEM THAT PAYS RELIGIOUS SCHOOLS' TUITION
description: The Supreme Court, concluding that Cleveland's voucher plan was ''a program of true private choice,'' today upheld the use of public money for religious school tuition in a decisive 5-to-4 ruling that the majority called a logical outgrowth of recent decisions and the dissenters described as a fundamental break with the past.

Fernandez, was appointed. It was 1989, not 1980.

title: PFIZER TO BUY BACK STOCK; MAY SELL 2 BUSINESSES
description: Pfizer, the world's biggest drug maker, said yesterday that it would buy back as much as $10 billion worth of its stock over the next 24 months, its largest repurchase ever. It also said it might sell its Adams candy and Schick shaving products businesses. Pfizer, best known for Viagra, the impotence treatment, and Lipitor, the cholesterol drug, also sells products ranging from animal vaccines to Dentyne gum. The shaving and candy businesses, which Pfizer acquired in its June 2000 purchase of Warner-Lambert, had combined 2001 sales of about $2.7 billion. Pfizer, based in New York, had to wait until two years after the Warner-Lambert purchase to put the units up for sale to avoid taking good-will charges in connection with the takeover.

title: Mammogram Team Learns From Its Errors
description: Seven years ago, Dr. Kim A. Adcock started a revolution in mammography: He decided to keep score.

title: For Renters, Weekend Flings (Just Don't Tell the Minivan)
description: AS economics professors will tell you, the value of a commodity invariably decreases over time. So the first drive in a new car is bound to be magical. The second drive will be a tiny fraction less exciting, the third a little bit less than that, and so on. By, say, the 3,014th trip behind the same wheel, most drivers are looking longingly at car commercials.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Scott D. Sullivan, the dismissed chief financial officer of WorldCom, misidentified the founder of MCI, the long-distance company, which WorldCom bought in 1998. MCI was founded in 1963 by a group of investors led by John D. Goeken, not by Bert C. Roberts Jr., who joined the company in 1972.

title: Rent Board Approves Increases Of 2% and 4% at Rowdy Session
description: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board voted last night to raise rents in rent-stabilized apartments 2 percent on one-year leases and 4 percent on two-year leases during a raucous meeting full of booing and shouting.

description: LEBOIT - Joseph. Passed peacefully June 26. Known as Artist and Psychologist. Member WPA Fine Arts Project. Graphic works permanent collection US mu seums. Exhibited ACA Gallery and San Francisco galleries. Artist newspaper PM. Long career as NY certified Psychologist. Co-founder and Executive Director over twenty five years Advanced Center for Psychotherapy. Author psychology monographs, co-editor text ''Advanced Psychotherapy of Borderline Patient''. Loving and admiring surviors are family, in-laws, many colleagues, friends. Cremation in California-recent residence.

Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion, and Justices Sandra Day O'Connor and Clarence Thomas wrote concurrences. Justices David H. Souter, Stephen G. Breyer and John Paul Stevens wrote dissents. The full text is online at nytimes.com/national.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Indictment In Money Scheme
description: A bank employee was indicted yesterday for her part in a black-market currency exchange operation in Brazil that involved more than $500 million, the authorities said. The employee, Maria Carolina Nolasco, 44, of Jersey City, worked at the Valley National Bank. She is accused of tax evasion and operating an illegal money-transferring operation that transmitted millions of dollars to Brazil in a scheme to evade United States and Brazilian regulations. Prosecutors said Ms. Nolasco, acting without bank permission, received $1.2 million over a three year period from the Brazilian currency-transfer businesses. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Breast Cancer Drug Is a Uterus Cancer Risk
description: The drug tamoxifen, widely prescribed for women with breast cancer or at high risk for it, may cause a rare but aggressive cancer of the uterus, the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cleanup At Stuyvesant High
description: The Board of Education agreed yesterday to clean the 300 classroom ventilators at Stuyvesant High School in Lower Manhattan, but said that the amount of lead in the classrooms was not hazardous. The ventilators have nearly 30 times the acceptable level of lead, according to Board of Education tests. Parents say the lead came from the collapse of the World Trade Center. Catie Marshall, a Board of Education spokeswoman, said the board agreed to the cleanup to ''allay fears fomented by the current Parent Association'' and to avoid litigation. Richard Ben-Veniste, a Stuyvesant graduate and former Watergate prosecutor who represented the parents' association, had hinted at litigation. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Richest Mare Will Race Tomorrow While Pregnant
description: Monmouth Park's racing secretary, Sean Greely, has not exactly been kind to Spain, assigning her high weight of 122 pounds for the Molly Pitcher Handicap tomorrow. Obviously, he failed to take into account the fact she's already carrying extra weight: for the second time in two weeks, the richest mare in the history of the sport will be running while pregnant.

title: An Imperfection Intrudes On a Perfect Sorority Life
description: Most of ''Pumpkin'' takes place on a fictitious Southern California college campus at a time identified in the opening titles as ''not long ago.'' In keeping with the vagueness of this phrase, the movie, which opens today in New York and Los Angeles, unfolds in a quaint, presatirized world of sorority sisters in sweater-and-skirt ensembles, square-jawed tennis champions and tight-faced country-club matrons who clutch tumblers of scotch in the middle of the afternoon and exude genteel suburban snobbery.

title: 2 Officials Seek Review Of Decision On Pledge
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft and Gov. Gray Davis of California said yesterday that they would ask the full United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, to reverse a decision by a divided three-judge panel that the phrase ''under God'' in the Pledge of Allegiance is unconstitutional.

title: Canada Extradites Bomb Suspect for Dutch Trial
description: A Canadian judge has ordered the extradition of an Algerian immigrant to the Netherlands, where the Rotterdam police have charged him in a plot to blow up the United States Embassy in Paris.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Deposit Sunglasses At The Door
description: The Massachusetts Bankers Association, reacting to an increase in bank robberies since Sept. 11, recommended security measures that include preventing customers from wearing hats, hoods and sunglasses so that bank employees can easily identify them. The recommendations, made to 200 of the group's members and developed with the advice of law enforcement officials, also include installing cameras in bank entrances and posting more guards and greeters in lobbies. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Navratilova Return? Don't Rule It Out.
description: Martina Navratilova could give up her family trips, vacation getaways and the time she spends training her puppy in exchange for a life competing on the Tour at age 45 -- if only she wanted to.

title: Los Angeles Director Is Retiring in 2004
description: Gordon Davidson, the artistic director of the Mark Taper Forum and the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles, will retire in 2004, the Center Theater Group's board announced yesterday.

title: Fiat Names Associate Of Founders As Co-Chief
description: Fiat, Italy's troubled industrial and automotive giant, named Gabriele Galateri di Genola e Suniglia, a veteran manager and close associate of the company's founding family, to be its co-chief executive today. The move fueled speculation that the company is preparing to exit the auto industry, its main business since 1899.

She is Shannon Bonnette, not Bonnet.

title: Justices Allow Schools Wider Use Of Random Drug Tests for Pupils
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the widespread use of random drug testing of public school students in a significant expansion of an earlier ruling that endorsed drug testing for student athletes.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Radiation Detectors
description: The New York City Police Department installed its first radiation detector outside police headquarters yesterday. The detector, which people must walk through to enter the building, is one of four the department has, a senior police official said. Another will be in the garage of police headquarters, one will be used by the Emergency Services Unit, and another will be given to the bomb squad, the official said. The detector, called a radiation portal monitor, consists of two upright black poles, about three inches in diameter and six to eight feet apart. ''They're easily deployable,'' the official said, calling the detectors a precautionary measure. ''There was no trigger, it's just another counterterrorism response,'' he said. It was unclear last night whether similar measures were being taken at other buildings across the city and how much the devices cost. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Pledge of Allegiance illegal?'Ridiculous'
description: WASHINGTON:  A federal court ruling that rejected as unconstitutional the words "under God" in the Pledge of Allegiance, which has been recited for decades by nearly every American schoolchild, drew a furious response Thursday from the president, an unusually united Congress and many ordinary citizens.

Mr. Adler, 50, a minister in the Religion of Jesus Church, argued that using marijuana was part of his religion. He also said he used marijuana to treat his asthma.
