Church, Setauket. Interment St. James Cemetery.

title: Stewart Inquiry Is Said to Focus on Lack of a Sell Order
description: With three separate inquiries under way into Martha Stewart's sale of shares in ImClone Systems, prosecutors are narrowing their focus to the apparent lack of documentation of the sell order that Ms. Stewart says she and her stockbroker at Merrill Lynch agreed on weeks before the sale took place, officials close to the investigations said yesterday.

title: Pricewaterhouse and I.R.S. Settle Tax Shelter Dispute
description: The accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers agreed yesterday to make a ''substantial payment'' to the Internal Revenue Service for marketing corporate tax shelters and then failing to comply with rules requiring it to keep a list of such shelters and the clients who used them.

title: Giambi's Power Surge Gives Yankees a Lift
description: He was not a bleeding Roy Hobbs or a gimpy Kirk Gibson. But Jason Giambi was an ailing left-handed power hitter, and his own manager could not have expected him to be a home run hero tonight.

title: Risk in Cancer Drug
description: The drug tamoxifen, widely prescribed for women with breast cancer or at high risk for it, may cause a rare but aggressive cancer of the uterus, the Food and Drug Administration said.

title: Chemical in Starchy Foods Baffles Health Groups
description: Two international health and safety organizations said yesterday that they were still a long way from solving the riddle of why a potential carcinogen appears in staples like French fries, bread and potato chips, and how much of a risk, if any, its presence may pose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEIER, CLAIRE
description: SPEIER-Claire. Born New York City. Age 70. Graduate of New York University. Modern dancer with the Charles Weidman Dance Company. Married 1954 to Leonard Speier, had two children (divorced 1979). Survived by sons Andrew and Matthew. Career as dance teacher at John F. Kennedy High School until her retirement. Avid painter, spent nearly 30 summers in San Miguel de Allende.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARGAFF, ERWIN
description: CHARGAFF-Erwin. The faculty, students and staff of Columbia University mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague, teacher and friend Erwin Chargaff. Dr. Chargaff joined the faculty of Columbia University in 1935 and was named professor of biochemistry in 1952. He was a central figure in the history of biochemistry, particularly in contributing to our knowledge of DNA. He was a member of the National Academy of Sciences and winner of numerous prestigious awards including the 1974 National Medal of Science, the nation's highest award for achievement in science, mathematics and engineering. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and friends. He will be greatly missed. Gerald Fischbach, MD Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculty of Medicine Columbia University David Hirsh, PhD Chairman and Robert Wood Johnson, Jr. Professor of Biochemistry & Molecular Biophysics Columbia University

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Railtrack Takeover Offer
description: Network Rail Ltd. agreed to take over the Railtrack Group, Britain's insolvent railway system, for 500 million ($764 million), but the deal ran into opposition from Railtrack shareholders, who want a higher price. Investors would receive 245 pence to 255 pence a share from the deal, taking into account Railtrack cash reserves and the value of assets, below the 280 pence at which the stock was suspended in October. The government proposed that the nonprofit company Network Rail replace Railtrack after forcing the unit into insolvency because of rising debt. Railtrack shareholders will vote on the agreement July 23.

title: Milosevic Is Unbowed After a Year in Detention
description: Exactly one year ago, on June 28, Slobodan Milosevic arrived in The Hague in handcuffs, under cover of darkness. He was whisked off to a United Nations prison to face the first modern war crimes trial of a head of state.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: City Found Negligent In Drowning
description: Eight years after a Bronx eighth grader drowned while on a class field trip, a jury has found the Board of Education and the water park where he died guilty of negligence. On Wednesday, the jury awarded the student's family $10 million in damages, of which $5.9 million must be paid by the city. A spokeswoman for the park, Dorney Park and Wildwater Kingdom, near Allentown, Pa., refused to comment. The city's corporation counsel plans to appeal the judgment. The student, Daniel Maracallo, 14, drowned at Dorney Park on June 14, 1994. Daniel was one of 138 students from Intermediate School 166 being supervised by six adults. School staff left the park even though Daniel was missing at the end of the day. His body was found around 4 a.m. the next morning at the deep end of a wave pool. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Farmer Replaced As Power Coach
description: Pat Farmer, who led the Power to a playoff berth in their inaugural Women's United Soccer League season, but whose team now sat in last place, heard a smattering of boos when the Power played the Carolina Courage at home Wednesday night. Yesterday, the Power fired Farmer and named the assistant coach Charlie Duccilli the coach for the remainder of the season.

title: Mercedes Revives an Old Name With a Big Price Tag
description: IN the 1930's, Germans who wanted to travel in high style had two choices: the 8-cylinder ''Grosser'' Mercedes 770 or the even bigger 12-cylinder Maybach Zeppelin, named for the airships that Maybach engines also powered. In its day, the Maybach's armchair-like leather seats served royal passengers like Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, King Paul of Greece, Prince Bernard of the Netherlands, assorted Indian maharajas and even commoners like Enrico Caruso and Max Schmeling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, MYRA F.
description: KAPLAN-Myra F. Devoted mother of Roger and Isabelle. Wife of the late Herbert Kaplan. Sister of Judith Davilman and the late Mary-Ellen Feinberg. Sister-in-law of Dr. Harvey Feinberg. Loving aunt of Monica Cohen and Jessica Lesnik. She will be missed every moment of every day. Services Friday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: WorldCom, WorldCon
description: No wonder George W. Bush looked frustrated when news of WorldCom's monster con game reached the hilltop in Canada where heads of the world's biggest economies were gathering. Long gone are the days when a triumphal American leader could attend these summit conferences and gloat about the superiority of our home-grown capitalism. Even President Vladimir Putin of Russia was moved to express grave concern about American accounting practices.

title: Your Cellphone, My Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Outward Appearances Fuel Inner Neuroses
description: Nicole Holofcener's smart, acidic comedy ''Lovely and Amazing'' zeroes in on contemporary narcissism and its fallout with a relentless, needling accuracy that illustrates exactly the way some people allow their personal insecurities and tics to poison their intimate relationships. Almost to a person, the film's mostly female characters are afflicted by our society's obsession with looks, to the degree that they never stop finding fault with themselves in the mirrors of their infinitely self-critical minds.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GREECE: ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS TO BE EXPELLED The government, moving toward a long-promised crackdown on immigration, said it would expel 3,000 immigrants who entered the country illegally overland from Turkey in the last few weeks. "The country and society have arrived at their limits," the government spokesman, Christos Protopapas, said. The immigrants will be sent back to their home countries, he said, adding that the government will offer them medical care and food until they are sent back. (Agence France-Presse)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Unemployment At Three-Year Peak
description: Brazil's jobless rate rose more than expected in May from the previous month to the highest level in more than three years. The unemployment rate rose to 8.5 percent from 8.2 percent in April, the government's statistics agency said. The unemployment rate was 7.6 percent in May 2001. The unemployment rate for last month was the highest since April 1999, when the figure was 8.8 percent.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: VIVENDI SUIT DISMISSED A French court dismissed a petition by a shareholder activist to name an independent expert to examine the way Vivendi Universal's management makes decisions. Roland Schiff, president of the Tribunal de Commerce de Paris, said the claim was "ill founded" and threw out the case. The shareholder, Colette Neuville, wanted the expert to determine whether the chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier, properly informed the board about his $100 billion of acquisitions that contributed to a record loss in 2001. (Bloomberg News)

title: Full Pockets, Big City
description: It could be said that the remake of Frank Capra's ''Mr. Deeds Goes to Town,'' starring Adam Sandler, is redundant, since the actor has been remaking Capraesque movies for most of his career. Mr. Sandler's films are always about the arrogant getting a deserved comeuppance at the hands of humbler types, but this is the first time he seems a little smug himself. ''Mr. Deeds'' has him rehashing a role he has performed so many times before he could be doing this picture in his sleep. The result is likely to be that he'll put audiences to sleep, especially those he won over with ''Happy Gilmore'' and ''The Wedding Singer.'' Here, Mr. Sandler speaks so slowly that he sounds like a dad trying to calm an overstimulated child at bedtime.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: MEDTRONIC WINS F.D.A. APPROVAL FOR HEART DEVICE
description: Medtronic Inc. won Food and Drug Administration approval yesterday of a pacemakerlike device combined with a defibrillator that treats advanced heart failure. The device, called an InSync ICD, is an improved version of a product that uses pacemaker technology. Guidant, a Medtronic rival, won approval in May for a similar device. Analysts estimate the market for the devices could eventually be $2 billion a year. The Medtronic device has a price tag of about $27,000, and the cost can go as high as $40,000. At least 100,000 patients may qualify for the InSync ICD device, Medtronic said.

title: A Circular Search For Futuristic Nostalgia
description: THE minute I saw the posters for the coming movie ''Men in Black II,'' I felt an undeniable rush of lust, triggered by the sight of the two egg-shaped, space-age chairs sheltering those suave alien chasers, Tommy Lee Jones and Will Smith.

title: In Trenton, Legislators Still Wrestle With Budget
description: State legislators will work through the weekend, against a deadline of midnight Sunday, to adopt a budget to pull the state out of its worst fiscal squeeze in a decade.

title: Timing of a Rating Shift Is Raising Some Questions
description: Jack B. Grubman used to laugh off suggestions that he was too close to WorldCom and other companies that he covered as a stock analyst for Salomon Smith Barney. He is not laughing anymore.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: YOUTHS EXPOSED TO GAMBLING ADS, STUDY SAYS A survey released yesterday by the Federal Trade Commission found that minors can not only easily gain access to gambling Web sites but that they are also often exposed to ads for online gambling on nongambling Web sites. The survey looked at more than 100 popular gambling Web sites and generally found inadequate or hard-to-find warnings about underage gambling prohibitions. Some 20 percent of the sites had no warnings at all. Most gambling sites, the trade agency said, have "no effective mechanism to block minors from entering." The agency urged parents and youths to understand the risks associated with gambling. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: The Knicks' Door Is Revolving Again
description: Antonio McDyess sashays in, Marcus Camby limps out. The revolving door for power forwards at Madison Square Garden spun again Wednesday night, four summers after the last change created a stir in an unsettled Knicks nation.

title: Voucher Ruling Seen As Further Narrowing Church-State Division
description: Having won the battle to convince the Supreme Court that government vouchers for religious schools are constitutional, religious advocates are now planning to push efforts to channel an increasing amount of public money into other religious programs, including charities and social services, hospitals and even foreign aid missions.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: NEW TRIAL IN MURDER

title: The Refining of Religious Neutrality
description: Yesterday the Supreme Court played a calming role in the culture wars by declaring that the era of strict separation between church and state is over. In a welcome decision, the court upheld a public program in Cleveland that financed vouchers that could be used in religious or secular, public or private schools. In doing so, it embraced a healthy vision of religious neutrality. But a day earlier, the old-line strict separationists had what may be their last hurrah. A decision by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit found that the Pledge of Allegiance, in its reference to one nation ''under God,'' violated the First Amendment.

title: 'Where Is Elvis? The Man and His Reflection'
description: Howard Greenberg Gallery

title: The Wrong Ruling on Vouchers
description: The country has been waiting for several years now to see how the Supreme Court would rule on school vouchers. Yesterday, in a 5-to-4 decision, the court issued a sweeping ruling upholding Cleveland's school voucher program. It was a bad decision on constitutional grounds, and a bad one for American education.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: The Hopeful Is Expecting
description: Julie Sabo, the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party candidate for lieutenant governor, has announced that she is pregnant. Ms. Sabo, 36, a first-term state senator, said she learned she was pregnant around the time that Roger D. Moe, the party's candidate for governor, asked her to join his ticket. If Ms. Sabo wins, she could be on maternity leave at swearing-in time. Lynette Clemetson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAAS, HERBERT
description: MAAS-Herbert. June 26, 2002 at the age of 90. Beloved husband of Vera, loving father of Susan and Frank, devoted grandfather of Jonathan, Todd, Edward and Arthur, uncle of Francis. Funeral service Friday, June 28, at 10:30 AM at Cedar Park BethEl Cemetery, Paramus, N.J. Contributions in his memory may be made to Hatzolah Volunteer Ambulance Corps, P.O. Box 540, NYC 10034.

title: THE COLLECTIONS / MILAN: Heavy metal, loud and clear
description: Milan  Ticking stripes, cropped pants, low at the crotch, glazed fabrics for suits, Asian prints and all-white outfits have emerged as trends in a quiet Milan menswear season. Accessories for next summer include narrow-toed loafers, the ubiquitous giant tote bags and silver metal chains. The other heavy metal story is zippers which are now used for decoration on jackets or baggy pants, rather than to fasten them.

title: 2 Accused of Looting Home For the Mentally Ill in Queens
description: The operators of a long-troubled adult home for the mentally ill in Queens have been indicted on an array of fraud and other charges, accused of turning what was supposed to be a refuge for some of the city's most vulnerable people into a vehicle for personal gain.

title: With Little Ado, Congress Put God in Pledge in 1954
description: The year 1954 was one of political upheaval in the United States.

title: From Everyday Objects, Oldenburg's Ideas for Sassy Sculptures
description: It's a pity that more of those who run things in our country do not take to heart Claes Oldenburg's proposals for civic monuments. Why not a cathedral in the form of a colossal faucet for Lake Union in Seattle? A humongous teddy bear for Central Park North? A massive Good Humor bar for Park Avenue? A gigantic ironing board looming over the Lower East Side?

description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: RealNetworks' Sales Will Fall Short
description: Shares of RealNetworks fell more than 18 percent yesterday after the company, which makes software for playing Internet audio and video, said second-quarter sales would fall short of analysts' estimates. The shares fell 79 cents, or 18.4 percent, to $3.50. Shares hit a high of $96 in February 2000. The company, based in Seattle, has been paring costs and trying to sell more subscriptions to play music and video on the Internet to compensate for declining sales of its server programs, which let Web site operators distribute media files to users. The company had forecast that results in each quarter of this year would improve from the previous periods. RealNetworks said yesterday that second-quarter sales would be $42.5 million to $45 million, down from $47.9 million in the period a year earlier.

title: The Battleground Shifts
description: The Supreme Court decision today swept away what had been one of the biggest obstacles to a bedrock goal of the conservative movement: letting parents use government money to pay for religious and private school.

title: Minis Fly The Flag
description: On the eve of the Fourth of July, the United States leads Britain, 380 to 350.

title: Mature Keeper Leads Germany
description: The sideburns do not fit the man. They suggest an era of paisley nonchalance, and no one has ever called Oliver Kahn nonchalant. The sideburns run the length of his face like goal posts, and it seems that no distraction has gotten between them.

title: Afghan Leader Swears In 5 Deputies With an Eye to Balance
description: President Hamid Karzai swore in five vice presidents today, among them three powerful regional leaders, to strengthen his central government and gain some control over the regions and wayward provincial rulers.

description: MANHATTAN: POLICE RADIATION DETECTORS

title: CONAGRA FOODS SAYS QUARTERLY EARNINGS INCREASED 58%
description: ConAgra Foods said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 58 percent as improved profit in retail brands like Healthy Choice meals and Hunt's ketchup offset weakness in its agricultural businesses. Conagra, the No. 2 food company in the nation, behind Kraft Foods, posted net income of $192 million, or 36 cents a share, for the quarter, up from $121 million, or 23 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue in the quarter, which ended May 26, dipped to $6.41 billion from $6.43 billion. Profit in packaged foods, which includes Butterball turkeys, Chef Boyardee prepared meals and Armour meats, rose 42 percent, to $443 million, on better product mix and cost controls, ConAgra said.

title: Largely Spared by the Israelis, Jericho Is Quiet, Too Quiet
description: The casino is dead. The cable cars that once took tourists up to where the Bible says Jesus faced down the Devil now dangle pointlessly, like a clump of dates just out of reach. Half of this city, which claims to be the world's oldest and the lowest in elevation, is now out of work.

title: CUNY Contract Raises Pay for Part-Time Professors
description: The City University of New York trustees approved a new faculty contract this week that CUNY and union officials said would better compensate part-time professors, known as adjuncts, for working with students.

National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: West Virginia: Fewer On The Dole
description: Without ruling on a claim that the welfare system violates the state Constitution, a Harrison County judge has refused to restore benefits to two families who had used up their 60 months of lifetime benefits. The judge said the families had received repeated warnings that their benefits would end. The families remain eligible for food stamps, Medicaid and other aid.

title: Roddick Joins the Group on the Outside Looking In
description: Andy Roddick was stretched out in the air today, dangling from an imaginary clothesline over the worn grass, desperate to reach the one volley that could change the glum mood of the American men.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TALBOT, DONALD
description: TALBOT-Donald. Always in our hearts-Love is all there is. Roslyn, James and Car

title: Full Justice for Ulster Killings
description: In February 1989 a lawyer in Northern Ireland named Patrick Finucane, who often defended those accused of Irish Republican Army activity, was eating dinner in his Belfast home with his wife and three children when Protestant paramilitary gunmen broke down the front door and killed him with a dozen shots at close range. For years afterward there were reports that British agents had suggested Mr. Finucane as a target.

title: A Chance Reprieve, and Another Chance at Life
description: Thirty years ago today June 29, 1972 -- the Supreme Court ruled in Furman v. Georgia that the death penalty was unconstitutional because it was administered in a racially and geographically discriminatory manner. The decision ended up saving the lives of 611 inmates on death rows in 31 states. This week, in Ring v. Arizona, the court may have done the same for some of the 800 killers now housed on death rows in the nine states that allow judges, not juries, to impose a sentence of death, a procedure that the Supreme Court found violates a defendant's right to a trial by jury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SIMON (SY)
description: KAPLAN-Simon (Sy). Of Baldwin, NY and Boca Raton, FL, died on June 27th, 2002. Devoted husband of Carol. Loving father of Andrew and Sara, Evan and Pat, Mitchell and Andrea. Adored by his six grandchildren, Ashley, David, Jake, Paige, Brooke and Stephanie. Beloved uncle. Services at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, LI, Sunday, June 30th, at 12 noon.

title: Team Leader For Andersen Had Years Of Expertise
description: Melvin Dick, the managing partner that Arthur Andersen assigned in 2001 to take over leadership of its team of auditors working on WorldCom's accounts, arrived with plenty of experience in the complexities of the telecommunications business.

title: Parole Denied To a Follower Of Manson
description: Leslie Van Houten tried today for a 14th time to win parole after more than 30 years in prison for her role in the Manson cult's killings of Rosemary and Leno La Bianca in 1969, but the parole board led her through a chilling recollection of the stabbings and again denied her freedom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EAKER, IRA
description: EAKER-Ira. The Officers, Governors and Members of The New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed Member, Friar Ira Eaker on June 26th. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Services will be held on Sunday, June 30th, 2PM, Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach, FL. 561-499-8000. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict misstated the amount of bail for an Israeli settler, Yosef Cohen, who had been arrested in connection with the killing of an Arab man in a revenge attack. It was $500, not $50.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bell Canada Stake Bought
description: BCE Inc., the Canadian telecommunications and media group, said it would regain full ownership of Bell Canada, the country's dominant telephone company, by buying back a 20 percent stake from SBC Communications for 6.32 billion Canadian dollars ($4.2 billion), in promissory notes, cash and stock. Michael Sabia, above, who took over as BCE's chief executive less than three months ago, said that regaining full ownership of Bell Canada would help BCE ''diminish uncertainty and focus our operations.'' In recent years, the company has diversified into media ownership, e-commerce and other internet services. SBC, which is based in San Antonio, acquired the stake when it bought the Ameritech Corporation. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Cher's Goodbye Tour Reaches New York, With Glitter and Nostalgia Galore
description: Jewelers are nervous. Sequin and rhinestone manufacturers despair. Cher, the 56-year-old pop singer, who has made it her mission to reflect more light than the mirror of the Hubble Space Telescope, is on her farewell tour, which appeared at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday and Thursday. ''How sparkly am I?'' she asked the crowd on Thursday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ALEXANDER
description: COHEN-Alexander. June 27, 2002. Loving father of Ronald and Valerie Fenimore. Dear brother of Max and Jack. Cherished grandfather. Services on Sunday, at 11:30 AM, Weinstein Garlick Kirschenbaum, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: PORTUGAL: TELECOM WRITE-DOWN Portugal's biggest phone company, Portugal Telecom, has taken a write-down of 500 million euros ($494 million) against 2001 earnings to cover a reduction in value of its 42 percent stake in the Brazilian mobile phone carrier Telesp Cellular Participacoes. The privatized state carrier said in March it would have to restate its 2001 earnings to account for the fall in the value of Telesp, which is involved in a merger with Telefonica of Spain. Portugal Telecom's first-quarter earnings were 90 million euros this year, and it had a profit of 307 million euros in 2001. Analysts said the write-down would not affect results or the share price.

title: INSIDE
description: Russia Rethinks the Draft

title: Rookies In the Schools
description: This month, in a report to Congress, Education Secretary Rod Paige stated accurately that teacher quality is a key determinant of student success. But his definition of a high-quality teacher was alarming in what it left out: it dismissed the need for any knowledge of teaching and child development -- or even student teaching experience.

title: Vaughn's Revival at Bat Is Mets' One Bright Spot
description: Throughout the dreariness of the first three months, the Mets have pitched optimism as much as anything else. They have kept searching for any positive sign as their numerous holes were exposed during their tumble down the standing.

title: '90 Study Aided Experts in Stockpile Decision
description: It was the fall of 1990, a month after Saddam Hussein's army invaded Kuwait. Amid fears that Iraq would wage biological war using anthrax, a team of government scientists was commissioned to answer an urgent question: Could a prolonged course of antibiotics, anthrax vaccine, or a combination of the two keep people exposed to anthrax from getting sick?

description: To the Editor:

description: MILLER-Lillian Last. Lillian Miller of Haverstraw, NY died on June 28, 2002. She was ninety-seven. She is survived by her loving sons Daniel Miller, Esq. and Dr. Joshua Miller; devoted sister Mollie Levine and their families. For further information, please call the Hellman Memorial Chapels, 845-356-8600.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Rev. Peter Kiare, a missionary priest who is charged with sexually abusing a 12-year-old boy during a trip to Rockaway Beach, misidentified the lawyer who represented him during an arraignment on Wednesday. He is Michael Gaffey, not Kenneth Appelbaum. Mr. Appelbaum was the assistant district attorney at the hearing.

title: Major Central Banks Sell Yen To Try to Stem Recent Rise
description: The world's three main central banks sold yen for dollars yesterday on behalf of the Japanese government, in hopes of stemming a rise in the value of the yen that threatens to hamper an export-driven recovery in Japan.

title: VERIZON WIRELESS TO GIVE $600 MILLION IN DISCOUNTS
description: Verizon Wireless Inc. agreed to provide as much as $600 million in discounts to settle a lawsuit with customers nationwide who had claimed that the company hid service charges. Cell-phone customers sued Verizon and its predecessors two years ago in California State Superior Court in San Diego, claiming they did not fully explain special offers and hidden charges for rounding up calls to minute increments, operator assistance, busy signals, service switching, contract cancellation and local and long-distance tolls. Verizon denies the allegations in the lawsuit and plans to issue ''a new, uniform customer agreement'' approved by the plaintiffs' lawyers, according to the company's Web site and documents mailed to customers this week.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Drop In Emissions
description: The economy slowdown and the warm winter last year caused the first annual drop in American emissions of heat-trapping carbon dioxide since 1991, the Department of Energy said. Carbon dioxide, released by the burning of fossil fuels, has been linked to rising global temperatures. Through the 1990's, emissions from energy use rose an average of 1.2 percent a year. Last year, they fell by 1.1 percent, with most of the drop coming as a result of a sharp dip in manufacturing. Emissions from transportation, housing and other kinds of businesses rose. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Fears Over Dengue Fever
description: Health officials have declared a national alert against dengue fever after tallying 789 cases of the disease in the first five months of the year. Officials urged people to clean their homes to stop the breeding of mosquitoes that carry the potentially fatal disease. An outbreak in neighboring El Salvador has claimed four lives and led the authorities there to declare a state of emergency in four regions. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Disney Says It Made Accounting Mistake
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that it had included expenses it should not have in a recent regulatory filing that showed how new accounting rules would have affected past financial results.

title: Serena Williams Slips, But She Doesn't Slip Up
description: Serena Williams has been conforming to the Wimbledon dress code by trading the gold Pumas she wore at the French Open for a new white pair, but the traction does not seem to be the same.

title: SANYO SPECIAL STEEL TO START VENTURE WITH TIMKEN
description: Sanyo Special Steel Company, a Japanese maker of custom steel products, said it had agreed with the Timken Company, the biggest maker of bearings in the United States, to form a venture in September to take over production at Timken's Kentucky factory. The venture, Advanced Green Components L.L.C., capitalized at $19.4 million, will be 62 percent owned by Timken and 31 percent owned by Sanyo Special, said Yusuke Katayama, a spokesman for Sanyo Special. The remainder will be owned by the Showa Seiko Company, an Osaka-based bearing processor, Timken said. Timken is based in Canton, Ohio.

title: Shots Fired Into Bronx Crowd Injure 2, Including 16-Year-Old
description: A 16-year-old Bronx girl clutching her baby boy was shot through the neck by a stray bullet Thursday night when a couple's argument nearby erupted in gunfire, the police said yesterday.

title: Hitchcock Goes on D.L.
description: The Yankees placed the left-hander Sterling Hitchcock on the disabled list with a strained lower back, and recalled another left-hander, Randy Choate, from Class AAA Columbus.

title: In a Sign of the Times, the City Begins Deploying Radiation Detectors
description: As a part of the Police Department's new measures to guard against potential terrorism, radiation detectors will be installed outside several city buildings, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday. City Hall will probably be among the locations, he said.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the decision by the major industrial nations to commit billions of dollars in aid to African nations misspelled the surname of the president of South Africa in some copies. The president, who was instrumental in drafting a plan that sets conditions for receiving the money, is Thabo Mbeki, not Mbeke.

title: German Leader Hopes Soccer Will Lift His Standing in Polls
description: Although the German election is still nearly three months away, there is anxiety in the camp of Chancellor Gerhard Schrder, whose Social Democrats continue to trail their conservative opponents, led by Edmund Stoiber, in the polls.

title: Juilliard Names Director of Dance Unit
description: Lawrence Rhodes, an internationally known ballet dancer and administrator and the former director of the dance department at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, has been appointed artistic director of the dance division of the Juilliard School, effective on Monday. Mr. Rhodes succeeds Benjamin Harkarvy, who died in March.

description: BASEBALL

title: Job Cuts Take Heavy Toll on Telecom Industry
description: WorldCom's downfall is swelling the exodus of workers from the telecommunications industry, which alone has accounted for more than one out of every 10 jobs lost in the United States since the recession began in March last year.

title: Charlie's Ghost
description: Two years ago this summer, my wife and I lost a baby. I say ''lost,'' as if we had misplaced it. There is nothing like abortion to make you appreciate the solace of euphemism. Lord knows the zealots who have occupied the field and mined it with moral explosives have left little room for comfort.

description: In percent

title: Within an Enchanted Forest Behind the Everyday World
description: Happiness is a performance of George Balanchine's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' as led with verve and poetry by Darci Kistler's Titania and Peter Boal's Oberon on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Amtrak to Cut $100 Million in Expenses to Get a Loan
description: Amtrak agreed last night to the Bush administration's terms for a $100 million loan that will avert an immediate shutdown and promised to find $100 million in expense cuts from next year's budget.

title: Sports of The Times; European Buildup Is a Put-Down
description: I'M all for progress and evolution, but this talk about a European explosion in the N.B.A. and that Europe has supplanted the United States as the hotbed of pro basketball is specious at best and devious in its darkest inferences.

title: Internet Address Group Approves Overhaul
description: The group that manages the Internet's address system moved forward with its reorganization process yesterday, approving the outline of a plan that is intended to streamline operations and speed decision-making.

title: No Runs, No Hits and No Hope in Mets' Season
description: Maybe the Mets should take a page from the Cleveland Indians' newly published book and just give up. Maybe the Mets wouldn't find it as easy because they don't have a Bartolo Colon to trade for a package of terrific young minor leaguers, but it would probably be more merciful. The only place this team is headed is down.

title: Canadian Press Freedom Questioned in Publisher's Firing
description: Canadian news organizations are not known for digging deeply into the closets of politicians to look for skeletons.

title: Senator Says New Agency Needs Greater Access
description: The ranking Republican on the Senate Intelligence Committee has termed ''unacceptable'' President Bush's proposal that the new Homeland Security Department receive only completed intelligence reports from the C.I.A. and F.B.I.

title: After the Voucher Ruling, the Debate Rages
description: To the Editor:

title: Gores Buy a New Base in Tennessee
description: Nearly two years after he lost his home state, Tennessee, in the 2000 presidential race, Al Gore and his wife, Tipper, have bought a new $2.3 million home just outside Nashville in Belle Meade, his associates said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Representative Indicted
description: State Representative Nathan Suzuki was indicted by a federal grand jury on five counts of tax fraud involving filing false income tax returns and failing to reveal his interest in bank accounts in Tonga and Hong Kong. Mr. Suzuki, a 54-year-old Democrat, could face nearly 30 years in prison and up to $1.75 million in fines. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Sharp Rise In Violence
description: Deaths and injuries from guerrilla activity rose sharply last year despite cease-fires by paramilitary groups that have ended the systematic sectarian violence that cost 3,600 lives over three decades before the 1998 peace agreement. Police figures said gunmen killed 18 people compared with 7 in 2000 and so-called punishment beatings nearly doubled to more than 300. A police report said most killings were by Protestant paramilitary groups, while Catholic and Protestant gangs were equally responsible for maimings and beatings by vigilante enforcers. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Stewart Inquiry Is Said to Focus On Words Used
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation into Martha Stewart's sale of ImClone shares last December is centering on what her stockbroker may have told her just before the stock was sold, a lawyer involved in the investigation said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: From Councilwoman To Prisoner
description: Former Councilwoman Rene Mansho of Honolulu was sentenced this week and began serving a one-year prison term for theft. Ms. Mansho, who pleaded guilty earlier this year to stealing more than $20,000 in city money, was also ordered to pay $25,000 in restitution. She was charged with two counts of felony theft and could have received up to 10 years in prison. The city accused her of using her staff to perform campaign activities on city time, and of using campaign funds for personal expenses. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: No Rings, Brass or Not, for Chinatown Jewelers
description: Where have all the lovebirds gone?

title: Use of Marijuana Preceded Seizure
description: Mark Corey and Tony Tarasco of the Mets were smoking marijuana after the game late Wednesday night on their ride to Corey's hotel in Queens when Corey collapsed and had a seizure, two people familiar with the incident said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Portugal: Telecom Write-Down
description: Portugal's biggest phone company, Portugal Telecom, has taken a write-down of 500 million euros ($494 million) against 2001 earnings to cover a reduction in value of its 42 percent stake in the Brazilian mobile phone carrier Telesp Cellular Participaes. The privatized state carrier said in March it would have to restate its 2001 earnings to account for the fall in the value of Telesp, which is involved in a merger with Telefnica of Spain. Portugal Telecom's first-quarter earnings were 90 million euros this year, and it had a profit of 307 million euros in 2001. Analysts said the write-down would not affect results or the share price. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Talks in Mexico Push Regional Growth
description: The presidents of Mexico and Central America today reiterated their commitment to a regional development plan aimed at stimulating their struggling economies as they ended a two-day summit meeting in the southern Mexican state of Yucatn.

title: I.W. Burnham II, a Baron of Wall Street, Is Dead at 93
description: I. W. Burnham II, a financier whose surname has been on the front door of a Wall Street firm virtually since the depths of the Depression, died on Monday after boating near Norfolk, Va. He was 93 and lived in Manhattan.

title: New Era Cap Strike Ends
description: The New Era Cap Company, which makes baseball hats for the New York Yankees and other teams, has signed a new contract with workers at a plant here, ending an almost yearlong strike, the union said. Members of the Communications Workers of America, which represents workers at the factory, approved a four-year contract with New Era, the union said. Officials from New Era could not be reached for comment.

title: Salomon Brothers May Face WorldCom Shareholder Suits
description: For nearly a decade, the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup has stood in the shadows behind WorldCom's meteoric rise. Salomon's bankers have done everything from whispering merger advice to promoting stock offerings to arranging billions of dollars in loans -- making more than $100 million in fees in the process.

title: Lawmakers May Vote on a Newark Arena Tomorrow
description: New Jersey's weekend rush to pass a budget could also include a vote on a long-delayed $355 million Newark arena, legislators said. But the fate of the arena plan was seen as uncertain by some of its staunchest supporters, who cited the political and procedural hurdles that remained.

title: Tweaking Numbers to Meet Goals Comes Back to Haunt Executives
description: On Wall Street, it is called backing in.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MOODY'S INVESTORS SERVICE downgraded the debt rating of Dynegy Inc., Houston, the energy provider, to junk status Friday, noting concern about whether the company's restructuring plan would succeed in shoring up the company's finances with more than $8 billion in debt looming.

title: After Coach's Firing, Power Regroups
description: In some instances, change is gradual. For the Power, it was not.

title: After Criticism, U.S. Broadens 9/11 Aid Pool
description: After months of criticism about its missteps and delays in distributing financial help to New Yorkers affected by the Sept. 11 terror attack, the Federal Emergency Management Agency announced yesterday that it was formally changing its eligibility criteria to allow aid to thousands more people who suffered economic hardship as a result of the disaster.

title: No Fit With Indians
description: The Yankees had some interest in starter Bartolo Colon before the Cleveland Indians traded him to Montreal on Thursday, but the discussions did not advance far. The Indians may continue to trade high-salaried players, but a baseball official said the Yankees do not see themselves as having a fit with Cleveland.

title: Russian Vote to Ease Draft Rules Draws Criticism
description: The lower house of Parliament passed legislation today that would offer some young Russian men an alternative to the draft, but only under conditions that liberals and advocates of military reform have called onerous and very possibly dangerous.

title: The Saturday Profile; A Doctor-Spokesman Attends to Papal Image
description: ''These cardinals,'' said Joaqun Navarro-Valls with mock chagrin as he swept a visitor into his office just off St. Peter's Square. ''They come by without any appointment. You cannot say no. So it's, 'Yes, your eminence, just have a seat.' ''

title: Qaeda Fighters Still on the Run After Killings Of Pakistanis
description: Hundreds of Pakistani troops combed the desolate hills near the Afghan border today, searching for suspected Al Qaeda fighters who killed 10 Pakistani soldiers earlier this week.

title: Williams to Get a Chance
description: For two hours, the N.B.A. draft Wednesday got more and more disappointing for Frank Williams. A projected lottery pick less than a year ago, Williams was bypassed until Denver selected him for the Knicks with the 25th pick.

title: Police Dept. Rule on Alcohol Offenses Altered
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that the department would no longer hire police recruits who had misdemeanor convictions for drunken driving.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: MIXED ECONOMIC SIGNALS Japan's industrial production rose 3.9 percent in May over April, but the jobless rate inched up to 5.4 percent, as 270,000 new people swelled the ranks of the unemployed. Over the last year, the number of Japanese with full-time jobs has declined by 1.17 million, or 1.8 percent. Highlighting a societal shift to temporary, low-paying jobs, the number of employees with job contracts fell by 2.7 percent, while the number of employees with temporary jobs grew 5.3 percent, or 290,000. With employment worsening, household spending by wage earners fell 0.4 percent in May, compared with the year before. With spending weak, consumer prices in Tokyo, a bellwether for the rest of the nation, fell by 1 percent in June from a year earlier, the 33rd consecutive monthly drop.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Court to Review Mandatory Detention of Immigrant Felons
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide a question on the rights of immigrants facing deportation proceedings under the strict rules of the 1996 revision of immigration law.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP TO ACQUIRE ERIN FOODS FROM GREENCORE
description: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Erin Foods unit of the Greencore Group for $26 million to gain sales in Ireland. Erin Foods is Ireland's second-largest maker of dry soup, Campbell said. The purchase also includes William Rodgers Foods, a private-label soup maker in Britain. Campbell, based in Camden, N.J., has been buying European soup brands, including Erasco and Homepride, since 1995 to add to sales outside the United States.

title: Bonuses Once Meant to Retain Talent Now Risk Outrage
description: As it moves to lay off thousands of employees to cut costs, WorldCom is also facing the conflicting problem of avoiding an exodus of experienced senior executives needed to help it survive.

title: Aldeburgh Greets a New Generation
description: The sun, these last few days, has been shining on this small coastal town where Benjamin Britten made his home, and the musical weather, too, was set fair at the festival he and Peter Pears founded 54 years ago: the mood was cheering, with breaks of brilliance. In Thomas Ads, the festival has an artistic director who is not only a formidable composer but also an outstanding pianist and conductor and a font of excellent programming ideas.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: New Vote Set On Europe Expansion
description: Prime Minister Bertie Ahern called a new referendum for October to try to reverse Irish voters' surprise rejection last year of the so-called Nice Treaty, which would pave the way for nations of the former Eastern bloc to join the European Union. Ireland has gone from being a poor nation to a prosperous one largely thanks to the union, and Irish voters were faulted at the time for denying the same chance to the Eastern Europeans. Mr. Ahern said he had secured agreement that a yes vote would not compromise Ireland's military neutrality, a cause of concern a year ago. In Brussels, union officials and the aspiring members squabbled over the last steps in their talks on enlarging the union by 2004. The union has balked at paying the newcomers the same farm subsidies it gives existing members; the Easterners say they cannot wait until the last weeks of talks, in December, to settle the issue. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Cheney Raises Money in Limelight, and Wields Power Behind Scenes
description: Dick Cheney was called a curious pick as George W. Bush's running mate even by many Republicans during the 2000 election because -- despite his stature in government -- he was never known as impressive on the stump.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Higher Tax, Less Debt
description: Ending a deadlock on a proposed 50-cent increase in the state's cigarette tax, Democratic and Republican lawmakers met with Gov. John Engler and tentatively agreed to use the tax increase to help cover a $350 million budget shortfall. Democrats have opposed the higher cigarette tax, instead favoring a rollback in business tax cuts. As a compromise, Republicans agreed to halt the business tax cuts if the state's rainy day fund dips below $250 million. A 1 percent across-the-board cut in spending would also be imposed. Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Economic Growth
description: Beating projections, India's gross domestic product grew 5.4 percent in the fiscal year ended March 2002, compared with a 4 percent growth in the previous year. In the January-to-March quarter, the economy grew 6.4 percent, compared with 1.5 percent in the period a year earlier, according to data released by the government's Central Statistical Organization. The economy was led by growth of 5.7 percent in the farm sector, and a spike in demand for cement and steel set off by tax breaks that led to a housing boom. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Taiwan: Down With Chiang Kai-Shek
description: The Interior Ministry told government offices and schools to remove portraits of Chiang Kai-shek, who ran Taiwan under martial law for 26 years after losing China's civil war to the Communists in 1949. Portraits of his son, former President Chiang Ching-kuo, are also to be removed. Government walls will now have pictures of only the current president, Chen Shui-bian, and of Sun Yat-sen, the Chinese revolutionary claimed by Taiwan as the founder of its government. While the government said the decision was apolitical, President Chen, from the Democratic Progressive Party, has put less emphasis on ties to the mainland than the Nationalist Party of the Chiangs. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Dolores Gray, 78, Sultry Star Of Stage and Movie Musicals
description: Dolores Gray, a singer and actress whose success on Broadway and London's West End led to starring roles in several 1950's Hollywood musical extravaganzas, died on Wednesday in her Manhattan apartment. She was 78.

title: ECLIPSYS STOCK DROPS 45% AFTER REPORTING LOSS
description: The Eclipsys Corporation, a maker of health-care software, said it expected to post a second-quarter loss and fall short of forecasts, which set off a 45 percent decline in its stock price. The company, which sells to hospitals and physicians' practices, said it expected to lose 7 cents to 10 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, Eclipsys expects to lose 4 cents to 6 cents, compared with its earlier forecast of a profit of 11 cents to 13 cents. The company, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla., said some of its customers had not signed contracts by the end of the quarter. Eclipsys disclosed the forecast after markets closed on Thursday, and yesterday its stock price fell $5.44, to $6.56 a share.

title: Mayor Says Careless Investors Share Blame for Stock Losses
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that investors who sank their paychecks into companies with no earnings and no prospects for ever having them were just as culpable for the mess in the markets as those companies that government officials say defrauded investors.

title: Nets' First-Round Pick Has Built-In Problems
description: The Nets are going to have to do some negotiating sooner rather than later to secure their first-round draft pick, Nenad Krstic, his agent, Marc Fleisher, said yesterday.

title: Choi Hong Hi, 83, Korean General Who Created Tae Kwon Do
description: Gen. Choi Hong Hi, widely acknowledged as the founder of tae kwon do, a martial art that began in Korea and spread rapidly to community centers and storefronts around the United States, died on June 15 in Pyongyang, North Korea. He was 83 and lived in Mississauga, Ontario, a suburb of Toronto.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the overturning of a court mandate that New York State increase school spending referred incompletely to the background of Justice David Saxe, a member of the state Appellate Division panel, who dissented from the ruling. Although Justice Saxe was indeed appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, he was elevated to the appellate bench by Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican.

title: After the Voucher Ruling, the Debate Rages
description: To the Editor:

title: Honda Considers Airlift of Steel
description: The Honda Motor Company is prepared to airlift 2,000 tons of carbon sheet steel to its auto factories in the United States and Canada next month if it cannot secure adequate supplies from steel producers in the United States, the company said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mixed Economic Signals
description: Japan's industrial production rose 3.9 percent in May over April, but the jobless rate inched up to 5.4 percent, as 270,000 new people swelled the ranks of the unemployed. Over the last year, the number of Japanese with full-time jobs has declined by 1.17 million, or 1.8 percent. Highlighting a societal shift to temporary, low-paying jobs, the number of employees with job contracts fell by 2.7 percent, while the number of employees with temporary jobs grew 5.3 percent, or 290,000. With employment worsening, household spending by wage earners fell 0.4 percent in May, compared with the year before. With spending weak, consumer prices in Tokyo, a bellwether for the rest of the nation, fell by 1 percent in June from a year earlier, the 33rd consecutive monthly drop.

title: Misery in Mississippi, Reward on Maui
description: What it meant to be a WorldCom employee yesterday depended a great deal on location.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Trying to Make the Books Fit the Earnings Forecasts

title: Want a Piece of WorldCom? Contact the Company's Bankers
description: WorldCom's bankers have been contacting investors and competitors to gauge their interest in buying major pieces of the embattled telecommunications company -- and to assess how much those pieces might be worth, bankers and executives said yesterday.

title: An Invitation Ruffles Philosophical Feathers
description: The black studies scholar Cornel West, who may be best known for recently cutting a rap album and for feuding with the president of Harvard University, is also the author of a well-regarded book on American pragmatism that includes a section on the philosopher Sidney Hook. So he seemed a natural choice to invite to a conference on Hook that the Graduate Center at the City University of New York is planning to hold in October.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He's standing by. He'll realize he's not going to be president that long.''

title: Supreme Court Allows Secrecy To Stand in Deportation Cases
description: The United States Supreme Court granted a Justice Department request yesterday to allow secret deportation hearings for people arrested after Sept. 11 to continue while the government appeals a federal judge's order to open the hearings.

title: MORTON'S ACCEPTS CASTLE HARLAN'S $63 MILLION OFFER
description: Morton's Restaurant Group, owner of a chain of steakhouses, announced yesterday that it had accepted a $63 million takeover offer from Castle Harlan Inc., a leveraged buyout firm, that matches a rival bid from the billionaire financier Carl Icahn. Castle Harlan raised its offer for Morton's to $15 a share, Morton's said. The change comes a week after Morton's agreed to scrap its agreement to be acquired by Castle Harlan in favor of a $15 a share bid from Mr. Icahn, which was $2.40 higher than Castle Harlan's offer.

title: Hernndez Shines in New Role
description: Take away the setting, and they could have been buddies playing a friendly scrimmage on a city sandlot. As Charlie Hough, the pitching coach, met with Jeff D'Amico on the mound at Yankee Stadium in the third inning last night, all three Yankees' base runners chatted amiably with the Mets' fielders.

title: Rx for Cellphones
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Swiss Banks Are Sued For South Africa Dealings
description: Five years ago, Swiss banks were at the center of an international dispute over their handling of Holocaust victims' assets. Now, some are facing a legal challenge over their financial assistance to South Africa's former apartheid regime in a class-action lawsuit filed by a lawyer, Edward Fagan, who played a leading role -- and helped win a huge settlement -- in the Holocaust actions.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Victory For Same-Sex Partners
description: The University of Colorado regents approved health care benefits for same-sex partners and their dependents after 15 years of debate on the issue. The 5-to-4 vote reverses a decision nine months ago to deny such benefits and makes the university the first state entity in Colorado to offer gay partner benefits to employees. The policy will take effect in November. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Torre's Tough Calls
description: While the Yankees take batting practice this morning, Torre will meet with an official from Major League Baseball and determine his choices for the reserves and the pitchers for the American League All-Star team. The teams for the All-Star Game, which will be held July 9 in Milwaukee, will be announced tomorrow.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the daily performance of the stock market on Wednesday misstated an investment strategy involving the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the 10-year Treasury note. In general, analysts say, investors should sell bonds and buy stocks when the earnings yield on the S.& P. 500 -- the level of corporate profits compared with stock prices -- is significantly above the interest rate on the 10-year note, not below it.

title: With Hernndez Back, Yanks' Express Rolls
description: Take away the setting, and they could have been buddies playing a friendly scrimmage on a city sandlot. As Charlie Hough, the pitching coach, met with Jeff D'Amico on the mound at Yankee Stadium in the third inning last night, all three Yankees' base runners chatted amiably with the Mets' fielders.

title: Mexico Is Attracting a Better Class of Factory in Its South
description: The numbers add up to doom for cheap labor, one of Mexico's most marketable commodities since World War II. In the last two years, some 280,000 jobs have vanished with the closure of more than 350 maquiladoras, the foreign-owned assembly plants that manufacture for export everything from blue jeans to blenders, televisions to toys.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, EILEEN KELLNER
description: BENJAMIN-Eileen Kellner. On June 26, 2002 in New York City. Beloved wife of the late Edward, loving mother of Robert and Bruce. Cherished grandmother of Sarah, Susannah and Marguerite. Devoted mother-in-law of Ellenore and Candy. Dear sister of Peggy Ann Dubois. Services private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation, 675 Third Ave, NY, N.Y. 10017.

title: Looking for X In the Algebra Of Leadership; Is Impact the Criterion or Charisma? Experts Ransack Leaders' Psyches
description: Sigmund Freud may have been the first to put an American president on the couch. He collaborated on a psychoanalytic study of Woodrow Wilson with an American diplomat, William C. Bullitt. (The book, which made a case for Wilson's ''Christ Complex,'' was deemed such an embarrassment when it was finally published in 1967, however, that some critics doubted whether Freud had all that much to do with the project.)

title: Flawed Voting Tally Alleged in Racially Charged L.I. Election
description: A black group in the racially divided Amityville school district on Long Island is taking legal action to overturn last month's school board election, charging that its slate lost because officials mishandled the results from a faulty voting machine, resulting in an all-white board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, ELEANOR
description: WILSON-Eleanor. A celebration of the life of Eleanor D. ''Siddy'' Wilson, actress, artist and friend who died on May 31, 2002, will be held on the Main Stage of the Berkshire Theatre Festival, Main St. Stockbridge, MA. on Sunday, June 30th at 3:30 P.M.

title: BUSH TO UNDERGO COLON PROCEDURE
description: President Bush said today that he would transfer the powers of the presidency to Vice President Dick Cheney for a short time on Saturday while he was under sedation for what he described as a routine colonoscopy.

title: Distilling Dionysus from the Ancient Greeks and Bringing His Power to Life
description: When a group of Florentine composers invented opera at the turn of the 17th century, they imagined that they were reviving the spirit, if not the letter, of ancient Greek drama. Many of their works had librettos based on Greek myths, and because Greek theater was known to have been sung rather than spoken, the early opera composers developed a style of vocal writing that was meant to convey something (characterization and emotion, for example) beyond the plain text.

title: Tribute to Richard Rodgers Fills the House on His 100th
description: The line in front of the Gershwin Theater yesterday afternoon ran from Eighth Avenue to Broadway, appropriately enough. The occasion was a free all-star tribute to Richard Rodgers, the Broadway legend who would have celebrated his 100th birthday yesterday.

title: Fire Threatens Still Another Town
description: Crackling fire threatened another Arizona community today, drawing hundreds of firefighters who started an intense effort to save some 700 homes.

title: Xerox Revises Revenue Data, Tripling Error First Reported
description: The Xerox Corporation, which conceded earlier that as part of a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission it would reclassify more than $2 billion of revenue from previous years, said yesterday that it was in fact restating a much larger amount, $6.4 billion.

title: Golden Does Not Regret Quitting Her Day Job
description: In 1994, a frustrated Kate Golden lost her L.P.G.A. Tour card and quit golf for four months. During her hiatus, Golden worked at a golf course in Florida, where she had a taste of the real world.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Inflation Decline Expected
description: Annual inflation in the 12-member euro zone is expected to fall to 1.7 percent this month from 2 percent in May, the lowest level for two and a half years, according to estimates by the European statistics office Eurostat. The projection is based on June inflation estimates from Germany, Italy and Belgium and on Europewide energy prices. European central bankers this week said the recent surge in the value of the euro had helped curb inflation by reducing the price of imports into the euro zone. The euro reached 99.88 cents yesterday.

title: Hit by Drought and Fire, Apaches Pray for Rain
description: Everett Massey sold off five head of skinny cattle the other day and got a bad price.

title: The Fire This Time: Seeking a Way Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Schumer Proposes Lower Manhattan Park
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer called yesterday for a waterfront park to be built with some of the money set aside by the federal government for the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan. He proposed an apron of parkland that would stretch from Canal Street on the West Side to Pier 42 on the East Side, where it would meet East River Park.

title: U.S. May Veto Bosnia Force In a Dispute Over New Court
description: The United States has refused to budge in its demand to exempt American peacekeepers from the jurisdiction of a new International Criminal Court, raising the possibility that the United Nations mandate for the international forces in Bosnia will expire at midnight Sunday.

title: Amid Hoopla, McDyess Promises Big Things Next Season
description: The lobby of the Theater in Madison Square Garden appeared to be set up for a New Year's Eve party yesterday.

title: Report Says Guard Roster Was Inflated
description: New York State systematically inflated troop strength figures for its Army National Guard in the late 1990's, in an attempt to make recruitment efforts appear more successful than they were, state officials reported yesterday.

title: Six Priests Are Dismissed For Abuse Of Minors
description: When America's Roman Catholic bishops met in Dallas this month over the scandal of child-abusing priests, Bishop Howard J. Hubbard of Albany helped lead the campaign for more leniency, or at least some leeway for the redeemed.

title: Brazil Now Admits Its Guys Can Play a Bit
description: Last January, Brazilians had so little confidence in their national soccer team that an auto dealership here offered what it thought would be a cost-free deal to attract gullible customers. If Brazil won the World Cup, the dealership would return the down payment to everyone who bought a car there this year.

title: RAYTHEON AND LOCKHEED TO SHARE 2 CONTRACTS
description: The Raytheon Company and the Lockheed Martin Corporation will share two Federal Aviation Administration contracts with a combined value of $2.7 billion to settle a complaint over the handling of one of the project awards, company and government officials said. The agreement gives Raytheon a piece of a $1 billion project awarded to Lockheed to improve computer software in 20 F.A.A. centers that direct planes at high altitudes. Lockheed will be a subcontractor in a $1.7 billion upgrade of software and processors at 173 centers at or near airports that guide planes within 50 miles of takeoffs and landings.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Police Suspended After Deaths
description: Two police officers, including a senior inspector, have been detained on suspicion they were responsible for the shooting deaths of two demonstrators during an anti-government march on Wednesday. The police initially blamed factional disputes among the protesters for the killings, but President Eduardo Duhalde ordered the officers held after newspaper photographs showed the inspector pointing a shotgun at one of the victims and then disposing of his body. Nearly 100 other officers have been suspended as a result of what Mr. Duhalde condemned as ''an atrocious hunting down'' of marchers. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The Online Shopper column in Circuits on May 30, about selling a car on the Internet, misstated the surname of the chief executive of Autotrader.com, which lists used cars for sale online. He is Chip Perry, not Barry.

title: Court Nullifies Finding Against a Reporter
description: A federal appeals court in New Hampshire ruled yesterday that a former business reporter for The New York Times did not intentionally present the subject of a 1994 article in a false light.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Merrill Lynch executive, Anita F. Contini, who is expected to be appointed to oversee the development of a World Trade Center memorial, misstated her age. She is 58, not 55.

title: An Air of Inevitability
description: When the House voted early today to help elderly people buy prescription medicines, it was a major moment in the history of American health care and politics. The vote foreshadows a deepening federal commitment to the elderly and the aging baby boom generation, as well as a significant expansion in the role of government.

title: Her Cart's Wheels Slow to a Halt; A Fixture at the Fish Market May Not Make the Move
description: This is Annie's life.

title: World Briefing: Asia/Pacific
description: JAPAN: WHALE HUNT STARTS Two whaling ships sailed for their annual north Pacific hunt, leaving from the Shimonoseki, site of an acrimonious meeting of the International Whaling Commission last month. Hunting under the umbrella of what Japan calls "scientific whaling," the ships plan to kill 10 sperm whales, 50 Bryde's whales, 50 minke whales and 50 sei whales, a species listed as endangered. Two more ships are to leave today. James Brooke (NYT)

title: After the Voucher Ruling, the Debate Rages
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fire This Time: Seeking a Way Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Textbook Publishers Learn: Avoid Messing With Texas
description: ''Out of Many,'' the work of four respected historians, is one of the biggest sellers among American history college textbooks in the United States, but it is not likely to be available to Texas high school students taking advanced placement history. Conservative groups in Texas objected to two paragraphs in the nearly 1,000-page text that explained that prostitution was rampant in cattle towns during the late 19th century, before the West was fully settled.

title: Enron's Connecticut Connection
description: No one would accuse them of moving expeditiously, but Connecticut prosecutors have begun a criminal investigation into the way that tentacles of the Enron fiasco squeezed state taxpayers out of nearly $200 million. The implications are potentially enormous because of questions over the role of the popular two-term governor, John Rowland.

title: Closing the Door to Public Scrutiny
description: The Supreme Court has been the quietest branch of government about the events of Sept. 11. Congress passed the U.S.A. Patriot Act, rolling back civil liberties in key areas, and the Bush administration has held hundreds in secret detention. The court, meanwhile, said nothing. Yesterday the justices made themselves heard for the first time, blocking a federal judge's order to open to the public immigration hearings for terrorism suspects. It is a troubling move, and we hope it does not signal more broadly how the court will decide civil liberties challenges to the war on terrorism.

title: Messier Is Expected to Return To Rangers for One More Season
description: With the signing period for unrestricted free agents beginning after midnight tomorrow, there is little question that Mark Messier, the Rangers' 41-year-old captain, will be back for a 24th N.H.L. season, several people close to Messier confirmed during the last week.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the beginning of an article in Business Day yesterday about WorldCom's need to retain crucial executives was omitted in some copies. The article is repeated today on Page C3.

title: The Politics of Embarrassment
description: Having finally come to grips with the necessity of raising the federal debt limit, Congress may feel it has earned the right to a weeklong Fourth of July holiday. Perhaps only in Washington can people plunge the nation deep into debt and then think of themselves as profiles in courage when they summon the nerve to authorize the Treasury to borrow money to pay the bills.

title: Mercer Is the Next Hurdle As Klitschko Chases Lewis
description: Ray Mercer won the Olympic heavyweight gold medal in 1988, yet over the last 14 years he has had hepatitis B and has sustained a broken neck, a broken leg, broken fingers, broken dreams and a busted career.

title: What Are the Standards for Striking First?
description: To the Editor:

title: Well Before Sept. 11, Congress Overtaxed the F.B.I.
description: The F.B.I. and other federal law-enforcement agencies have their hands full searching for terrorist cells, protecting our borders and rooting out crime that is truly national (or international) in scope and effect. Yet they still have other prescribed crime-fighting duties to perform. Last week, as Robert S. Mueller III, the F.B.I. director, explained his reorganization plans to a House committee, House members expressed concern about whether even after hiring 900 new agents, the bureau would have enough staff to support its necessary new emphasis on terrorism as well as its traditional domestic crime-fighting activities.

title: Ex-Broker Pleads Not Guilty to Charges of Money Laundering
description: A former broker for Lehman Brothers pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that she helped launder $15 million in drug money for a former Mexican politician.

title: Short List for the School Chancellor's Post is Actually Rather Long
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that his short list for schools chancellor was still growing, rather than narrowing, while the city's borough presidents were closing in on their appointments for the city's newly structured Board of Education.

title: After the Voucher Ruling, the Debate Rages
description: To the Editor:

title: Daniel H. Case III, 44, Banker for Silicon Valley
description: Daniel H. Case III, an investment banker who helped take public many of the highest-flying technology companies in the 1980's and 1990's, died Wednesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 44.

title: Presence of Prejudice
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Issues Call for Honesty in Corporate America
description: President Bush said today that American executives had the responsibility to be honest about their balance sheets, as the White House announced that Mr. Bush would make a major speech on corporate responsibility July 9 on Wall Street.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Legislators, Not Violators
description: Two legislators with ties to drugstores did not violate ethics laws when they voted on Medicaid legislation, the State Supreme Court ruled. In 1998, a judge said the two, Representatives Bobby B. Howell, a Republican, and John O. Read, a Democrat, broke the law because their drugstores participated in the Medicaid program. But the court found their personal interest in the legislation to be ''so remote'' that the law did not apply.

title: After the Voucher Ruling, the Debate Rages
description: To the Editor:

title: Waltz or Samba, Winner Will Dance
description: While newcomers and opportunists provided the endearing surprise of this World Cup, only the sport's two dominant powers are still around to decide soccer's global championship.

title: ATLAS AIR REACHES TENTATIVE AGREEMENT WITH PILOTS
description: The freight unit of Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings Inc. reached a tentative contract agreement with its pilots and flight engineers, avoiding a strike. Atlas, the largest handler of freight for other airlines, and the Air Line Pilots Association reached the agreement about 90 minutes after a midnight deadline Thursday. They declined to release details of the accord, which must still be voted on by the 631 union members. Negotiations began 26 months ago.

title: Company Settles in School Contract Case
description: An office supply company has agreed to pay $400,000 to settle civil charges that it improperly sought a Board of Education contract. One of its salesmen still faces criminal charges of trying to bribe school officials, and its president has pleaded guilty to an antitrust charge.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: South Korea: Trial Starts For President's Son
description: Kim Hong Gul, the son of President Kim Dae Jung, denied on the first day of his trial that he had used his influence to steer a government contract to a sports lottery company though prosecutors say he received about $3 million in stocks, stock options and cash. Prosecutors said another son of Mr. Kim, Kim Hong Up, will also be tried on corruption charges. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: When Lizards Interact With a Couple on the Beach
description: Couples in a face-off is one of Edward Albee's favorite tropes, but ''Seascape,'' his 1975 Pulitzer Prize winner, differs from plays like ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' and ''The Play About the Baby'' in two important respects. For one thing, the two pairs of lovers in ''Seascape'' -- the beachcombers Nancy and Charlie and their surprise visitors Sarah and Leslie -- are inclined to mutual compassion and, literally as well as figuratively, they manage to find common ground. For another, Sarah and Leslie are green lizards that have crawled out of the ocean.

title: Justices Accept Case on Maine's Drug Discount Program
description: The Supreme Court today added two important cases on health care to the docket for its next term, including a closely watched case from Maine on the state's effort to force drug manufacturers to reduce their prices to Maine residents.

title: Mayor Changes Tune on Trash; Sorted or Not, It's for Pickup
description: The Bloomberg administration has decided to step back from a policy of leaving improperly sorted trash on the streets while New Yorkers get used to major changes in recycling that go into effect on Monday.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Japan: Whale Hunt Starts
description: Two whaling ships sailed for their annual north Pacific hunt, leaving from the Shimonoseki, site of an acrimonious meeting of the International Whaling Commission last month. Hunting under the umbrella of what Japan calls ''scientific whaling,'' the ships plan to kill 10 sperm whales, 50 Bryde's whales, 50 minke whales and 50 sei whales, a species listed as endangered. Two more ships are to leave today. James Brooke (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: BELL CANADA STAKE BOUGHT BCE Inc. , the Canadian telecommunications and media group, said it would regain full ownership of Bell Canada, the country's dominant telephone company, by buying back a 20 percent stake from SBC Communications for 6.32 billion Canadian dollars ($4.2 billion), in promissory notes, cash and stock. Michael Sabia, above, who took over as BCE's chief executive less than three months ago, said that regaining full ownership of Bell Canada would help BCE "diminish uncertainty and focus our operations." In recent years, the company has diversified into media ownership, e-commerce and other internet services. SBC, which is based in San Antonio, acquired the stake when it bought the Ameritech Corporation.

title: Judge Considers an Inquiry On Radio Case Confession
description: A federal judge in Manhattan is considering opening an inquiry into how the F.B.I. got a criminal confession from an innocent Egyptian student who was detained in connection with the attack on the World Trade Center, people with knowledge of the case said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEFRIES KELLNER, ZIRA
description: DeFRIES KELLNER-Zira. A memorial service for Dr Zira Defries Kellner will be held at the Union Chapel in the Grove, Shelter Island, NY on July 6 at 10:30 AM.

title: Rockers' Hold Over Liberty Continues at the Garden
description: The Liberty came into last night's W.N.B.A. game against Cleveland braced for Rockers forward Chasity Melvin, bitterly remembering the 30 points she scored when the teams met last week.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: GUATEMALA: FEARS OVER DENGUE FEVER Health officials have declared a national alert against dengue fever after tallying 789 cases of the disease in the first five months of the year. Officials urged people to clean their homes to stop the breeding of mosquitoes that carry the potentially fatal disease. An outbreak in neighboring El Salvador has claimed four lives and led the authorities there to declare a state of emergency in four regions. David Gonzalez (NYT)

description: HAWAII: FROM COUNCILWOMAN TO PRISONER
