description: Consumer confidence fell less than expected in June, and incomes rose in May, according to reports released today.

title: National Briefing | West: California: A More Expensive Crossing
description: A drive across the Golden Gate Bridge will become more expensive on Sept. 1 after a vote by bridge authority officials to increase the toll $2 per car to $5. The increase comes as officials look for a way to offset lagging revenues, complicated by increased security costs since the Sept. 11 attacks, and to help pay for an earthquake retrofitting. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: PENTAGON SHIFTS ANTHRAX VACCINE TO CIVILIAN USES
description: The Bush administration announced a new anthrax vaccination policy today, including plans to continue vaccinating some military personnel and to stockpile for civilian use a large part of all the anthrax vaccine being produced for the Pentagon.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Water Company Write-Off
description: The world's second-largest water group, Suez, wrote off 500 million euros ($494 million) in its accounts for the first half of 2002 to cover its risk in Argentina, in light of worsening economic conditions there. Suez cited the peso devaluation and deteriorating negotiations between the group and Argentine authorities. ''These dispositions are exceptional measures in an exceptional situation,'' said the chairman of the company, Gerard Mestrallet. ''Suez is determined to maintain an essential service to 11 million people in Argentina.'' Argentina currently accounts for 2.5 percent of the company's revenue. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: PAYOUT SCHEDULE SET FOR UNITED FLIGHT ATTENDANTS
description: An arbitration panel has ruled that flight attendants at United Airlines should get $48 million from April 1, 2002, to March 21, 2003, to make up for lower-than-average wages, a union representing the attendants said yesterday. The yearlong payment is not what the attendants had asked for, which was to have the amount awarded entirely this year, giving them a 7.5 percent raise. The 12-month payment schedule only gives the workers a 5.49 percent raise, the union said. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: PRIVATE CAPITAL COUNTERS WYLY'S BID FOR BOARD SEATS
description: Private Capital Management L.P., the third-largest holder of shares in Computer Associates International Inc., said it would back the board of Computer Associates, a software maker, against a renewed proxy challenge by the investor Sam Wyly. The firm urged shareholders to oppose Mr. Wyly's effort to gain five seats on the 11-member board in a vote at the company's annual meeting Aug. 28. Private Capital, which is based in Naples, Fla., owns 33.9 million, or 5.9 percent, of Computer Associates' shares. Mr. Wyly, a Dallas billionaire acting through his firm Ranger Governance Ltd., began a new bid on Thursday to oust the chairman, Charles Wang, the chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, and three other directors of the software maker. Computer Associates is based in Islandia, N.Y.

description: As the World Cup, the world's most heavily watched sporting event, closes Sunday hopes that it would help reinvigorate the Japanese economy failed to come true.

Maybe the Mets wouldn't find it as easy because they don't have a Bartolo Colon to trade for a package of terrific young minor leaguers, but it would probably be more merciful. The only place this team is headed is down.

description: The United States is pressing hard to resume assistance to the Indonesian military in an effort to re-establish American influence here in the world's most populous Muslim nation after nearly a decade of keeping its distance from the Indonesian Army because of its human rights abuses.

description: Four South Korean marines were killed, one was missing and 18 other marines and sailors were wounded this morning in a furious gunbattle with a North Korean navy vessel in the Yellow Sea off the South Korean west coast, the Defense Ministry said today.

description: The Israeli military blasted away a section of the huge and sturdy Palestinian Authority building in Hebron late Friday night, in an attempt to end a four-day standoff with some 15 Palestinian militants who are believed to be inside hiding from heavy Israeli fire.

description: Fifteen real estate companies had eagerly bid for the staggering project: the consolidation of a sprawling suburban portfolio of 750 buildings and 2,500 parcels of land. The client is Nassau County government on Long Island, which is reorganizing its numerous, fragmented agencies. In its Police Department alone, headquarters operations are in 11 sites, not counting 8 precinct houses and dozens of smaller outposts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHALEN, PHILIP
description: WHALEN-Philip. Respected ''Beat'' poet, Zen Buddhist monk, abbot, teacher, original thinker and key figure in the literary canon of the second half of the twentieth century, died June 26th in San Francisco at the age of 78. Whalen hailed from Portland, Oregon, born October 20th, 1923. He was drafted in 1943 into the U.S. Army and later went to Reed College on the G.I. bill where he met up with poets Gary Snyder and Lew Welch. By the fifties, the three wound up in the Bay Area, encountering Allen Ginsberg, Jack Kerouac, Michael McClure, Jack Spicer, Robert Duncan, and Joanne Kyger to name a few, and the explosive American poetry revolution began. He is credited by some as one of the progenitors of both the Language School poetry movement and of Zen poetry in America. He published his first major book of poems in 1960, ''Like I Say''. Whalen's inspirational sources and great loves were diverse: Kyoto, Buddhist practice, calligraphy, Gertrude Stein, peanut brittle, and Dr. Who, however he was not a dilettante. He was perhaps the wisest and wittiest of his Beat cronies and surely the most elegant with vast resources of literary and historical knowledge at his fingertips. He referred to his writing as ''a continuous nerve movie.'' His fans termed it the stream of consciousness of a brilliant man. His many friends found him affectionate, cranky, perfect, daring, and necessary. His buddy Robert Winson called him ''a large, soft, bear-elephant w/ clever speech.'' Whalen wrote dozens of books of poetry and two novels in over 40 years, including ''On Bear's Head'', ''The Diamond Noodle'', ''You Didn't Even Try'', ''Canoeing up Cabarga Creek'', ''Overtime: Selected Poems'' and the recently released ''Goofbook''. He is survived by his sister Velna Whalen of San Diego. Donations in memory of Philip Whalen can be sent to Poets In Need Inc. For info write: Lyn Hejinian, Poets In Need, Inc., 2639 Russell St. Berkeley, CA 94705. From PW in 1977, ''...Today, I have my head to shave/There are lights and shadows in it/All too soon empty open ashes/Join mirthfully to earth.''

description: STEP aside C3PO and R2D2.

title: PrivateSector; His Name on Another Door
description: Some months before he died in 1993, Reginald F. Lewis, the financier, told his wife that he someday hoped to provide for an African-American history museum. Last week, in honor of his longtime wish, his namesake foundation pledged $5 million to endow such a museum in Baltimore, Mr. Lewis's hometown.

title: The Movies Can Credit A Cop Show
description: OF course I'm respectable,'' purrs the omnivorous villain Noah Cross in Roman Polanski's ''Chinatown.'' ''I'm old. Politicians, ugly buildings and whores all get respectable if they last long enough.''

title: Amy Barker, Mark Kuntze
description: Amy Leigh Barker, the daughter of Judith F. Barker and Robert G. Barker, both of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark Kuntze, a son of Sandie and Chuck Kuntze of Faribault, Minn. The Rev. Mario Marzocchi performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Visiting the Barnyard Creatures Can Outshine TV
description: Of all the farm animals Damaris Figueroa was expecting to meet on her summer vacation -- the horses, the cows, the cats, the pigs and the goats -- she was already pretty sure that she would like the cats the best. ''They're cute and you can pet them,'' said Damaris, 7, as she sat Friday morning on the floor of the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan with her 10-year-old sister, Vanessa. They were waiting for the bus to Canton, N.Y., and the start of their first vacation arranged through the Fresh Air Fund.

title: Advice From the Clueless
description: There have been more than a few delusional moments when I've thought that Ann Landers had nothing on me. Even without so much as a degree in counseling, divinity or movement therapy, I've always been full of important advice.

title: Sports of The Times; Soccer Must Keep The Ball Rolling
description: SEPP BLATTER has been known to be wrong. Most spectacularly remembered is his past advocacy of holding the World Cup every two years. He seemed to have no clue he was proposing the dilution of his product.

title: Sarah Taylor and Matthew Dunn
description: Sarah Stewart Taylor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David F. Taylor of Huntington, N.Y., was married yesterday to Matthew Bailey Dunne, a son of the late Faith Leah Weinstein Dunne and the late John Bailey Dunne. The Rev. Thomas Mousin, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the bridegroom's house in Hartland, Vt.

title: Woman Sues Priest Over Secret Tape-Recording Used in Custody Battle
description: When Ray Mabus, the former governor of Mississippi, discovered that his wife was having an affair, he arranged for a meeting with her and their Episcopal priest. He told the priest, the Rev. Jerry McBride, that he would secretly tape-record the meeting, which took place in the Mabuses' living room.

title: Faltering in the Footsteps of Beckett
description: THE PLAYS of Samuel Beckett mirror the unfathomable grip of life, our helplessness and inadequacy as we try to figure out what it's all about. No other playwright looms as a more enduring model of the phenomenon known as theater of the absurd, drama made up of apparently pointless situations and dialogue that ''strives to express its sense of the senselessness of the human condition,'' wrote Martin Esslin, author of the definitive book about the innovative and influential movement that took hold in the 1950's.

title: D'Amico's Struggles Mirrored by Mets
description: When the Mets were in first place earlier this season, their players had a simple argument to defend their dreadful performance at the plate and in the field: If we're doing good now, imagine how good we'll be once those hitters get going. Of course, that logic was based on the questionable durability of the starting rotation standing up, not cracking.

title: Against Humanity
description: To the Editor:

title: Kristen Patterson, Christian Warner
description: Kristen Ann Patterson, a daughter of Carol and Michael Patterson of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Christian Michael Warner, a son of Sheila Warner of Watertown, Mass., and John D. Warner of Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Thomas Fleming performed the nondenominational ceremony in the backyard of the bridegroom's home in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Friday referred incorrectly to a United Nations human rights investigator who accused rebels in eastern Congo of massacring 150 people, and also misspelled the official's given name. The investigator, Asma Jahangir, not Asna, is a woman.

title: A Beautiful Tree That Shows a Sinister Side
description: DANNY BLICKENSTAFF stood in the middle of an acre of 100 royal paulownia trees planted eight years ago on his hilly 55-acre farm. The trees -- about 40 feet tall, as straight as telephone poles and eight inches in diameter -- marched down the slope like rows of corn. Mr. Blickenstaff, 56, a retired federal employee, went through the grove, which is near Hagerstown, Md., knocking any shoots off the brown speckled trunks, because these trees bring a high price for lumber. The durable, light wood can bring as much as $4 a board-foot, compared with 70 cents for black walnut, 50 cents for oak or 30 cents for pine. So it is becoming a popular hobby crop for farmer-gardeners like Mr. Blickenstaff with a bit of land.

title: The McGaughey Touch Works From a Distance
description: The trainer Shug McGaughey wasn't at Monmouth Park today. He was home in Long Island recovering from the triple-bypass heart surgery he had June 13. Not that that could stop him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, ELEANOR
description: WILSON-Eleanor. A celebration of the life of Eleanor D. ''Siddy'' Wilson, actress, artist and friend who died on May 31, 2002, will be held on the Main Stage of the Berkshire Theatre Festival, Main St. Stockbridge, MA. on Sunday, June 30th at 3:30 P.M.

title: Deeper Into the Oceanic Imagery
description: ''I'M into the jazz of words,'' said Davey Ray Moor, the keyboardist and main songwriter of the English band Cousteau. ''If they sound good, that's enough for me.'' He was speaking of the sinuous beauty of the word sirena, which is the title of Cousteau's second album, to be released in the United States on July 9. In Italian and Spanish the word means mermaid, and it's related to the English word siren, the term for those mesmerizing women of the sea who lure sailors to their death. It's a notion well suited to the dangerously seductive atmospheres that pervade so much of the band's music.

title: The End Of Something
description: Recent events in the Middle East leave me wondering whether we're witnessing not just the end of the Oslo peace process, but the end of the whole idea of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Nuclear Stockpiling
description: I have the pills. At the moment, they are in my kitchen cabinet, where I keep the Tylenol and the Mylanta. I am thinking, though, of moving them to the locked drawer in my bedroom, or maybe even carrying them wherever I go. I will send a supply to camp with the boys, but I haven't yet brought myself to inform the camp nurse. I think that's because I tend to lower my voice when I talk about these pills, as if they were illegal, which they are not, or valuable, which they one day might be, or discomforting, which they definitely are.

title: 'The Birth of Pleasure'
description: For years, without knowing why, I have been drawn to maps of the desert, drawn by descriptions of the winds and the wadi—dry watercourses that suddenly fill with rain. I began following an ancient story about love told in North Africa in the second century, written in the coastal city of Carthage, carried into Europe as the winds carry the desert sand, falling like rain into a tradition whose origins lie in the birth of tragedy, coursing through the centuries like an underground stream. Set in the landscape of tragedy, this story leads to the birth of pleasure.

title: Burning Flags Is Good Deed For a Scout
description: IT will be a little harder to tell it's a patriotic holiday on Thursday. Usually, there's a sudden sprouting of red, white and blue this time of year. But since the flags have been up nonstop for 10 months, it's bound to look more like business as usual.

title: A Society And a Series Bent on Independence
description: EVERY year at this time, members of the Suquamish nation set up temporary roadside stands and transform the Port Madison reservation, just outside Seattle, into a bustling, booming market for fireworks. As throngs of mostly white customers descend upon the American Indian reservation to load up on rockets and sparklers for Independence Day celebrations, the air is filled with bartering, cross-cultural exchanges and, most of all, explosions.

title: Mixing and Matching in a Yankee Bistro
description: IMAGINE my surprise. I had been extolling Cafe Routier's French menu and ambience in its former location in Old Saybrook to my three companions as we drove to the restaurant's new locale in Westbrook, but as we entered the parking lot, the first words to greet our eyes were: ''Cafe Routier, a Yankee bistro.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, DR. V.O.
description: McCARTHY-Dr. V.O. 74, died on June 25, 2002. Born in St. Margaret's Bay, Parish of Portland, Jamaica, he studied in Jamaica and Manchester, England, and later received his doctorate in Audiology from Columbia University. After serving as headmaster at St. Christopher's School for the Deaf in Jamaica, he worked for the NYC Dept. of Health as the Director of Audiology for the Vision & Hearing School Health Program. Dr. McCarthy dedicated himself to helping the hearingimpaired. He is survived by his wife Brenda, daughter Janette, and sons Paul and Mark. Funeral service on Monday, July 1, 2002, at 7 PM at Bronx Baptist Church, 331 E. 187th St., Bronx. For more information contact Granby's Funeral Service, 718-519-6047.

title: A Japanese Hideaway Worth the Search
description: THE two best Japanese meals I've had on Long Island were both eaten at the same restaurant, Minami, in Massapequa. This 11-month-old spot, hidden away at 12 Central Avenue (516-799-4799) off Broadway, is difficult to find but more than worth the effort.

title: INSIDE
description: Koreas Trade Accusations

title: Court That Ruled on Pledge Often Runs Afoul of Justices
description: Over the last 20 years, the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has developed a reputation for being wrong more often than any other federal appeals court.

title: Rebirth in Venice And Two Lethal Queens of Hearts
description: WHEN we're young we take it for granted that great art (like love) is just around the corner: a new writer or composer; a fresh way of painting; an unexplored continent of foreign films. As we get older, we experience the ''new'' in a different way. There are all those books we never read; that music we listened to, then rejected; the works we acknowledged with the dutiful admiration that means we won't be returning to them any time soon.

title: Questions for Ralph Nader
description: David Wallis (The Way We Live Now, June 16) allowed Ralph Nader to slither out of answering the question about his costing Al Gore the election. Nader's comments about Tennessee, about the debates, et cetera, do not change the incontrovertible fact that had he not diverted approximately 4 percent of the national vote, George W. Bush would have been defeated.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; In South Amboy, a New and Upscale Neighborhood
description: A DECADE ago the shoreline in this modest little city was not a place where people visited, let alone where they considered living. Created with silt dumped from the dredging of Raritan Bay in the 1950's, South Amboy's coast had no entry road -- and there was no reason to go.

title: For a Scout on a Mission, a Good Deed Blossoms
description: A GARDEN often offers drama, in its exuberant yellows, its heady blues, its sensual reds. At the fledgling garden that now graces the front of the state Library for the Blind and Physically Handicapped, some of that drama unfolded long before a plant was put into place, as Jimmy Dossot, an aspiring Eagle Scout, went door to door seeking donations for the garden.

title: Sarah Kroon, Benson Chiles
description: Sarah Elizabeth Kroon, a daughter of Mary Jane and Richard E. Kroon of Rumson, N.J., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Walter Benson Chiles, a son of Rosalie and Gene T. Chiles of Austin, Tex. The Rev. John Monroe, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: June 23-29: TRANSPORTATION; CHUGGING ALONG
description: Amtrak reached an agreement with the Bush administration that would keep passenger trains running through September, but Congress will have to come up with at least half of the $200 million package. The administration hopes to restructure the railroad to end three decades of losses and taxpayer subsidies, but many Congressional Democrats said that Amtrak simply needed more money in next year's budget. David Firestone

title: Some Intriguing Accounting, This Time at EDS
description: ADD EDS to the list. Shares in Electronic Data Systems plunged last week, mainly on concerns over its relationship with the accounting disaster du jour, WorldCom. EDS manages computer systems for companies, including WorldCom, which paid EDS about $600 million last year under a contract set to run until 2010.

title: If You Build It
description: RACING FOR THE BOMB

title: The Course That Trump Built
description: CALLING Donald Trump proud of his new golf course is like saying Tiger Woods has a nice little golf game. And it is as much an understatement to say that Mr. Trump enjoys showing off the layout, the Trump National Golf Club, in Briarcliff Manor.

title: Play Dates With Destiny
description: ON Wednesday, a trio of speedy mini-heroes flies off television sets to invade the summer matinee. Make way for ''The Powerpuff Girls Movie.'' But who are these strange creatures that mesmerize little girls?

title: Wisconsin's Beguiling Back Roads
description: TRAILING the candidates through the key primary states as a political correspondent many years ago, I decided that, California aside, I liked Wisconsin best. I respected its political creativity, especially under the La Follettes, who prefigured the New Deal. I grew fond of its rich, bucolic landscapes -- the red barns, the black-and-white cows and the fields of lime-green grass interrupted by bands of chocolate-brown earth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAMCHECK, FRANCESCA (SMILER)
description: ZAMCHECK - Francesca (Smiler), of Newton, MA. Wife of the late Dr. Norman Zamcheck. Mother of Norman Zamcheck, Erika Wilton, Deborah Atwood and Mark Zamcheck, grandmother of eight. Services will be in Boston.

title: INVESTING WITH: Clyde S. McGregor; Oakmark Equity and Income Fund
description: VALUE fund managers should be penny pinchers, says Clyde S. McGregor, lead manager of the $2.4 billion Oakmark Equity and Income fund.

title: Union Says the Liberty Limits Access to Players
description: A misunderstanding.

title: Rosemary Harris Has a New Specialty: Albee's Women
description: IN a half-century onstage, Rosemary Harris has conquered Shakespeare, Coward and Beckett, not to mention Neil Simon, Tennessee Williams and J. B. Priestley. But at a time when some performers might be considering retirement, Ms. Harris has found a new challenge: she is tackling the works of Edward Albee -- the playwright of repressed emotion and knotty syntax.

title: The Sheltering Sky
description: I usually love to read Amanda Hesser's lighthearted columns on food, but this one (June 16) upset me and many people I know who belong to ''that small but very vocal group with nut allergies.'' I joined this group four years ago when we found out that my daughter Rachel, then 10 months old, had life-threatening allergies to peanuts, tree nuts and eggs. When we fly, I, too, am convinced that she may die. It almost happened once when she was 3: she left her seat to pick up a crayon and crawled back holding a peanut along with the crayon. Fortunately, she did not have an anaphylactic reaction, but I did have to give her emergency medications and notify the flight crew of the potential for a medical emergency. Contrast the inconvenience of an emergency landing or the horror of a death on board with the choice of snack food, and I think eliminating nuts makes sense.

title: Film Openings and Film Series Listings
description: Opening This Week

title: This Year, the Action Is Just Off the Highway
description: MAYBE it's patriotism. Maybe it's fear of terrorism. But for many Americans planning a summer vacation, the destination this year will probably be closer to home, and it is more likely to be reached by car, offering some welcome news to the tourism industry in parts of the United States where drive-in tourism came close to collapse in the weeks and months after Sept. 11.

title: Toasting a 'Dream' in an Enchanted Forest
description: AWAY from the downpour, on stage at the New York City Ballet, a gorgeous dream unfolds. Demetrius loves Hermia, who loves Lysander. Little girls in pastels whoosh past. Titania tickles a donkey under the chin. She arches, twirls and raises her leg up and up and up.

title: Spoiled Kids: What's a Parent to Do? Try a Little Volunteering
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving Grucci Fireworks a Run for the Money
description: ROBERT YALE and Charles Rappa were entranced by fireworks as boys growing up in Oyster Bay and remained so through high school, college and first jobs. Both went to work as salesmen for Wall Street brokerage firms, but they remained buddies and went to as many pyrotechnic displays as their schedules and the season allowed.

description: FLASHOVER

title: Designing Buildings To Resist Earthquakes
description: IT not only can happen here, it has happened here. New Yorkers who imagine themselves insulated from the threat of earthquakes received a gently rumbling reminder to the contrary two months ago.

title: SUMMER OF '77
description: I GREW up hearing stories about the New York of my father's childhood, the New York of the 1940's and 50's. The lower-middle-class Jewish neighborhood in the Bronx that was thick with semidetached houses; the broom handles swiped from his mother's closet, the pink Spaldeens sailing over manhole covers. That was my mythology.

title: Bush Returns to Activities After 20-Minute Procedure Finds No Polyps on His Colon
description: President Bush transferred the powers of the presidency to Vice President Dick Cheney for two hours and 15 minutes this morning while under heavy sedation during a colonoscopy at Camp David, the White House said.

title: 2 Sparkling Wines
description: Two North Fork producers, Martha Clara Vineyards and the Lenz Winery, have unveiled sparkling wines, in separate styles, just in time for the Fourth of July.

title: Nuclear Nightmares
description: You published 10 letters (June 16) from readers in New York to California in response to Bill Keller's article (May 26). All talked about fighting, preventing, forestalling, averting or otherwise stopping a possible nuclear attack. Has it occurred to anyone that a better solution would be to change some of our actions and attitudes so that people would not want to attack us?

title: It Now Costs 3 Cents More to Mail a First-Class Letter
description: The cost of sending a first-class letter will rise on Sunday by 3 cents, to 37 cents, as part of a broad postage increase. A postcard will cost 23 cents to mail, or 2 cents more.

title: Do You Ditch the Place Cards of Infamous Pals?
description: IT'S a strange feature of the summer social season that the most talked-about invitations in town are not to parties on Lily Pond Lane in East Hampton but rather for meetings with investigators from Congress or the United States attorney's office. Between allegations of insider trading, price-fixing, accounting irregularities and novel offenses like assault with an S.U.V, a surprising number in Manhattan's privileged class are spending summer at their lawyers' offices rather than at the beach. Indeed, being connected these days almost certainly means being connected to someone in a heap of trouble.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LINDENBAUM, ABRAHAM M. (BUNNY)
description: LINDENBAUM-Abraham M. (BUNNY) March 12, 1909-July 3, 1980 Lovingly remembered. Belle, Sandy, Linda, Erica, Laurie

title: The Money Flows In. The Value Keeps Falling.
description: Investors kept pouring money into mutual funds in their retirement accounts last year, but the accounts lost value anyway, almost entirely because of the drop in the stock market.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-12

title: Clifford Possum, a Painter of Aboriginal Masterworks, Dies
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 29  Clifford Possum, who painted some of the masterpieces of Australian aboriginal art, died on June 21 in Alice Springs in the Australian desert, an ancient landscape he depicted in the mythical terms central to his heritage. He was about 70, art historians said.

title: Hawaiian Connection
description: The 521-room Outrigger Wailea Resort on the southern coast of Maui offers two connecting rooms for the price of one, as well as free meals for children 12 and under through Aug. 15. Children can also take advantage of the daily Kids' Club program, as well as five pools. The Kids Connect Free and Eat Free program is $425 to $525 a night per pair of rooms, plus tax. Availability is limited and there is no minimum stay required. Information: (800) 367-2960 or www.outriggerwailea.com .

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for ROBERT D. REISCHAUER; Better Medical Decisions, Not Higher Costs
description: THE Supreme Court ruled this month that states had the right to insist on an independent review for patients whose managed health care plans refused to pay for a treatment or drug prescribed by their doctor.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Keepers of the Past
description: THERE are more than 100 brown, blue and white antique wedding dresses in the Ossining Historical Society Museum, some dating back to the Civil War. There are at least 100 military uniforms, a few nearly 200 years old, packed in acid-free boxes or draped on mannequins. There is a life-size wooden mannequin of George Washington. There are eight spinning wheels. There is the actual bell rung on the special train that carried Abraham Lincoln, both for his inauguration and for his funeral.

title: Those H-1B Visas And Americans' Jobs
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Dump Disrupts a Peaceful Taiwan Island
description: Steep volcanic slopes carpeted with tropical vegetation vault out of crystalline waters and magnificent coral reefs here, while a peaceful tribe of aborigines, largely insulated from the outside world until the early 1970's, tries to cling to ancient ways.

title: Big-Ticket Plans And Taxes to Match?
description: Last week, Westchester County officials announced that they might have to raise property taxes by 29 percent next year to meet a budget gap. County Executive Andrew J. Spano's office warned the County Legislature that next year's deficit would likely be $101.8 million. In April, Mr. Spano projected that it would be $70 million.

title: Not Just Soap
description: To the Editor: The article by Debra A. Klein brought back memories.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on May 12 about a fireworks competition in Quebec reversed the currency exchange rate. (A reader reported the error by e-mail on June 17.) While the prices shown were correct, the rate was $1.57 Canadian to the United States dollar, not 63 Canadian cents to the dollar.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Police Hero in 1994 Is Now a Bitter Retiree

title: June 23-29: NATIONAL; ONE PLUS ONE
description: Two wildfires in northern Arizona converged and grew: at more than 417,000 acres, it was the biggest blaze in state history and the largest of hundreds in the Western states this year. The fires forced more than 30,000 people -- most of them retirees, second-home owners and Apache Indians -- to flee White Mountain towns. As the week ended, firefighters had progressed enough to make it less likely that the fire would destroy the largest town in the area, Show Low. Michael Janofsky

title: Seeking a Consensus for Fire Island; Reading Shouldn't Stop Just Because It's Summer
description: I was pleased to read that many school districts are assigning summer readings [''Tempting Students Away From Screens,'' June 23]. It reminds me of a similar attempt when I was a high school principal in Nassau County.

title: Cachet of the Day
description: The first time I looked at the menu at Sandor's restaurant in Seagrove Beach, Fla., I almost fell off my bike. I had ridden to the village market for a pound of shrimp and a can of bug spray when I noticed that the abandoned fish market down the road had been fixed up and that a menu was posted outside. All my life I've vacationed on Florida's gorgeous Gulf Coast, and until recently that meant eating at places like Captain Dave's or the Sandflea. The fish was deep-fried or broiled (too long) in vats of margarine, the salads were topped with Thousand Island and the baked potatoes were wrapped in foil. Now I was staring at a menu that listed Belgian Salsify Soup With White Truffle Oil, Jumbo Lump Crabmeat Salad With Cumin Crisps, Crawfish in Puff Pastry With Pananga Curry Sauce. And those were just the starters.

title: Luxury Jet Outfitters Help Their Clients Live Large
description: Lufthansa Technik, a German company that specializes in luxury interiors for large private jets, has had its share of requests for Jacuzzis, dog kennels and even garages. But one of the features it is most proud of is the paper doors.

title: CONVICTIONS REINSTATED
description: The convictions of five Orange police officers charged with conspiring to violate the civil rights of Earl Faison, who died while in custody in April 1999, were upheld by the Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia last week. The officers, all of whom have left the force, were charged with civil rights violations in connection with the death of Mr. Faison, shown here, who died after being assaulted and pepper sprayed during his arrest on suspicion that he had gunned down a police officer a few days before. Another man later confessed to the shooting. The conspiracy conviction had been thrown out by a federal District Court judge, but the three-judge appeals panel reinstated it. Each officer faces up to 10 years in prison. Also last week, a settlement was reached awarding Mr. Faison's four children a total of $2.7 million in a wrongful death suit. Karen DeMasters

title: Necessary Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters
description: Sara Corbett's report of corruption in Cambodian adoptions left readers concerned, but less surprised than resigned. They reserved their outrage for Amanda Hesser, whose admission that her in-flight snack of choice is roasted nuts touched a nerve in parents of allergic children.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: HOLLOW GROUND

title: Soon, Dry Feet
description: FOR the last 10 years, Gary Ackerman, the Democrat whose Fifth Congressional District includes portions of Suffolk, Nassau and Queens, has reliably summoned peals of laughter when describing the bizarre boundaries of his district.

title: Cay Rabinowitz, Christian Rattemeyer
description: Cay Sophie Rabinowitz, the daughter of Jeanne and Ralph Rabinowitz of Virginia Beach, was married yesterday to Christian Rattemeyer, the son of Heide and Volker Rattemeyer of Kassel, Germany. Cantor Judi Tal officiated in the Japanese Garden at the Norfolk Botanical Garden in Virginia.

title: Joanna Tucker, Linn Davis
description: Joanna Lloyd Tucker, the daughter of Helen Tucker and the Rev. W. Hugh Tucker of Elmira, N.Y., was married yesterday in Keuka, N.Y., to Linn Dion Davis, a son of Joyce and Marvin Davis of Salt Lake City. The bride's father, an American Baptist minister, performed the ceremony in the Norton Chapel at Keuka College.

title: Anne Baxter, Chip Rewey
description: Elizabeth Anne Baxter and Robert Livingston Rewey III were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan. The Rev. David Stout performed the ceremony.

title: Does It Cost The Wealthy Too Much To Die?
description: NOT content to phase out the estate tax through President Bush's 10-year plan, Republicans in Congress are now seeking to abolish the tax forever. But what is the economic rationale?

title: 7 Williamsburg Sites Combine on Packages
description: A new vacation package for visitors to Williamsburg, Va., includes unlimited admission to the area's main attractions along with hotel rooms. The Williamsburg Flex Vacation combines admission to Colonial Williamsburg, the reconstruction of Virginia's colonial capital; the Jamestown Settlement, a re-creation of the fort at England's first permanent settlement in America; the Yorktown Victory Center, a living-history museum near the Yorktown battlefield that chronicles the life of late-18th-century settlers; and two theme parks, Busch Gardens Williamsburg and Water Country USA.

title: Let's Go to the Hops
description: The Garden State Brewers may sound like a baseball farm team, but it's the informal name of the Garden State Craft Brewers Guild, 15 brewpubs and microbreweries in the state. Its members will make their best lagers, ales, stouts and porters available for sampling at the Jersey Brewers Festival at Waterloo Village in Stanhope from 1 to 5 p.m. today. One new brewer, Cricket Hill Brewing Company of Fairfield, is among those offering at least two kinds of beer, including some exotic ones known only to the serious students of zymurgy, the science of fermentation. Fancy sodas and other nonalcoholic beverages will be available, as well as food from vendors, and home brewing techniques will be demonstrated. Local musicians will provide entertainment. Admission is $20, $15 for nonsamplers and those aged 12 to 21. Tickets include admission to Waterloo Village and are available through Ticketmaster and at the Village, (973) 347-0090. Karen DeMasters

title: The Circus Is Coming, on Wheels
description: I CRAVE a front row seat at passing spectacles, be it the Carnival dance parade called Ra Ra in the streets of Haiti, the parade-pilgrimage of El Rocio in Andalusia, Spain, where women in ruffled skirts ride in ox carts with men in bolero jackets, or the Halloween parade through Greenwich Village with floats bearing the ice cream moguls Ben and Jerry in cow costumes.

title: Accomplices in Love and Vengeance
description: CARLA, the heroine of Jacques Audiard's new film ''Read My Lips'' (''Sur Mes Lvres''), is a 35-year-old secretary who works for a Parisian real estate development company. Awkward and partly deaf, she is intensely lonely in her personal life and mocked by her male superiors at work.

title: Struggling to Master a New Fishing Language
description: I will not say that my first fish on a jig and pig was as momentous as my first fish on a fly, but it was satisfying nonetheless. It was a fat little crappie (or calico bass) that took the lure in the weeds while I was pretending to be a bass fisherman.

title: Amanda Grove, Robert Holmn
description: Amanda Beth Grove was married yesterday to Robert Christopher Holmn. The Rev. Brian Zinnamon performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York City.

title: June 23-29: BUSINESS; THE HARDER THEY FALL
description: WorldCom, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier, said that a random internal audit revealed more than $3.8 billion in expenses disguised as profits in 2001 and 2002, in what may be the largest accounting fraud ever. The S.E.C. filed fraud charges against the company, whose board fired its chief financial officer, Scott Sullivan, upon the discovery of the accounting strategy. In Washington, Republicans scrambled to contain the risk of damaged confidence in business and the economy, and Democrats stepped up efforts to spotlight corporate abuses. Simon Romero

title: Commercial Property/Long Island City; Work Begins on Long-Awaited Queens Development
description: BRAUSE REALTY has begun work on a 280,000-square-foot addition to its existing 404,000-square-foot building facing the Queensboro Bridge in Long Island City that together will be occupied by up to 2,000 workers for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company who are leaving Manhattan.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THIS BLINDING ABSENCE OF LIGHT

title: The Young and The Restless
description: I've always been fond of the movie ''A Summer Place,'' one of those late-50's Technicolor melodramas that can barely contain the enormous and genuine emotions it evokes. Its subject is the dangers for teenagers of sexual repression, and the dangers for their parents of lying to them about it -- quite a radical subject when you think about it, though sometimes it's hard to with the made-for-Muzak theme song swelling on the soundtrack. Molly, played by the 17-year-old Sandra Dee, of the cotton-candy hair and the candy-apple lips, willingly goes all the way with lanky, sensitive Johnny, played by Troy Donahue, of course.

title: New York: Comeback (After a Lag) Kid
description: DO you remember the last recession? Lots of New Yorkers don't. Some -- ah, youth! -- were still in school back in the early 1990's. And many of those old enough to have been employed back then have been happy to forget those dark economic days, along with grunge fashion, ''Dances With Wolves'' and Marilyn Quayle's hairdo.

title: Nuclear Nightmares
description: A reader writes that the difference between the Cuban missile crisis and today ''is not fear.'' It's that we ''seem defeated without trying.'' Another asks: ''Wouldn't it be possible to rig all containers entering this country with indestructible plexiglass windows? At least we could get some idea of what's inside the damned things.'' A third asserts, ''Forty years ago we had Civil Defense, perhaps an idea whose time has returned.''

description: An essay last Sunday about shopping for a graduation dress in Ecuador misstated the name of a band in a side comment about the availability of bootleg CD's. It is Linkin Park, not Linken Park.

title: In Bantam, Rebuilding From Scratch
description: WHEN B/E Aerospace announced last October that it would close its factory in Bantam, about 350 people knew they would soon be looking for new jobs. The company, which shut down Feb. 28, made airplane seats and was the biggest employer in Litchfield County.

title: Pharmaceutical Research Is Focusing on the Elderly
description: Pharmaceutical companies may be steadily losing the patent protection on their established drugs in the United States, but sales from new medications that cater to an aging population could more than make up for any lost revenue. And there are plenty of these drugs in the pipeline.

title: Daphna Caperonis, Christopher Cox
description: Daphna Caperonis, the daughter of Serena and Charles Caperonis of Boxford, Mass., was married yesterday to Christopher McKay Cox, the son of Barbara Cox Sachs of Summit, N.J., and the late Winston Hill Cox of New York. The Rev. Dr. Craig Whitcher, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at the Somesville Union Meeting House in Somesville, Me.

title: Melanie Fischer, Daniel Rubenstein
description: Melanie Susan Fischer, an artist in Brooklyn, and Daniel Kikuji Rubenstein, a mathematics teacher in Washington, were married yesterday. Aaron E. Fischer, a brother of the bride and a minister of the Universal Life Church, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Thursday about the marketing of the PBS brand misstated the organization's full name. It is the Public Broadcasting Service, not System.

title: What's the Big Idea?
description: To the Editor:

title: Being Beribboned
description: Ribbon belts -- by Hadley Pollet put a fresh spin on the season's preppy grosgrain cinchers, mixing elements of the old with the new. Made from vintage silk ribbon, the brightly striped belts ($90 at www.hadleypollet.com) come in pink, aqua, yellow or brown, and are modernized with a streamlined Lucite buckle. As a bonus, waist-watchers can do a double take -- all the belts are reversible.

title: Brooke Hotchkiss, Chad Gould
description: Brooke Chapin Hotchkiss, the daughter of Barbara and Sherman Hotchkiss of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Chad Alan Gould, a son of Judith A. Gould and Dr. Robert A. Gould of Traverse City, Mich. The Rev. Jeffrey H. Walker, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Greenwich.

title: Trying to Catch WorldCom's Mirage
description: ON Dec. 6, 1999, AT&T replaced the chief of its huge business services division, Michael G. Keith, after barely nine months on the job. To the outside world, it appeared that C. Michael Armstrong, the company's chairman and chief executive, had moved Mr. Keith to the company's wireless unit simply because he was not getting the job done.

title: British Airways
description: To the Editor: Concerning Susan Catto's article ''Airline Seating: Timing, Luck,'' (Practical Traveler, June 2), on overseas flights, we leave from Baltimore and the most convenient airline is British Airways. But after being unable to reserve a window seat and the one next to it in late April for a flight between Sept. 13 and 15, we chose to fly US Airways. This means we will have to transfer at either Philadelphia or Pittsburgh.

title: Isn't She a Bit Like You and Me?
description: She's daring. She's droll. She's Daria. And she's back.

title: Corrections
description: The On Language column on June 16, about the origin of the phrase ''goodness gracious,'' misspelled the name of the Illinois high school attended by Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld, who often uses the phrase. It is New Trier, not New Treir.

title: The World: Remember the Cold War?; How to Rig a Democracy
description: PRESIDENT BUSH'S blueprint for an acceptable Palestinian government -- a vision he outlined last week as he demanded the replacement of Yasir Arafat as the Palestinians' leader -- would be the envy of Arabs everywhere. It was a vision of an open democratic society with clean elections, a parliament that is more than a rubber stamp and ''a vibrant economy where honest enterprise is encouraged by honest government.''

title: New Coach Isn't Answer as Power Falls Again
description: It was unfortunate for Charlie Duccilli, in his debut as coach of the Power tonight, that Mia Hamm was on the opposing team. Duccilli's players performed with inspiration and had their best game at home this season, but two second-half goals by Hamm sealed a 4-1 triumph for the Washington Freedom at the Mitchel Field Athletic Complex.

title: The Home Team
description: MY older brother played Little League baseball as a boy. He was a pitcher, a talented player, something of a star. His team won most of their games and always did well in the playoffs. The funny thing is, I never saw him play. My mother did not go to his games, and she never took us younger children to see them.

description: MASTERS OF DEATH

title: Easy Beauty
description: To the Editor:

title: A Determined Klitschko Is Too Much for Mercer
description: There were questions about Wladimir Klitschko's boxing ability, power and stamina. Fans tonight walked into the Mark G. Etess Arena at the Trump Taj Mahal looking for answers.

title: Ramona Sanderson, Paul Burglin
description: Ramona Miriam Sanderson and Paul Richard Burglin are to be married today in Ross, Calif. The Rev. E. Michael Krieg is to perform the ceremony at St. Anselm Roman Catholic Church.

title: 'Sunset Serenades,' Sing-alongs and Other Sounds of Summer
description: LIKE the child who can't wait for his birthday to open his presents, Philharmonia Virtuosi has decided to get a jump on its silver anniversary. It has proclaimed its summer ''Sunset Serenades'' series the opening of its 25th season, instead of just the coda to its 24th.

title: There's Something About A Schoolkid in Uniform
description: Mayor Bloomberg may be easier than his predecessor was on jaywalkers and the homeless. He may even have smoked marijuana and enjoyed it. But lest he be chalked up as a laissez-faire flower child of a mayor, there is one position on which he sounds positively Giuliani-like: the mayor likes school uniforms.

title: A Harlem Renaissance With Broadway Partners
description: AMID the excruciating stops and starts of a technical rehearsal, as lights were being adjusted and missing actors located and musical cues played over and over, the director George C. Wolfe paused to take in the view. Climbing out of the darkness of the orchestra, he mounted a tiny staircase and planted himself at center stage of one of the most celebrated theaters in the world, the Apollo.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Adding New Gallery at Florence Griswold Museum
description: AN 11-acre section of Old Lyme that was once at the heart of the artists' colony known as the American Giverny or the American Barbizon has added another reason for art lovers to visit with the construction of an innovative new wing to the onetime boarding house that is now the Florence Griswold Museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, SEBASTIAN
description: KING-Sebastian. 37, painter, husband, writer, poet, philosopher, hair cutter and friend. Sebastian brought beauty, light and love into many lives. Memorial Service Monday, July 8, at Shambhala Center, 118 West 22nd St., #

title: I Can Be Your Hero
description: CITIZEN McCAIN

title: Luring the Couch Potato With Pizza and a Movie
description: When Dobbs Ferry's lone local video establishment closed in May, Brett Zechar and Kus Behan, owners of All Night Wireless, a cell phone store, decided to rent DVD's. But few customers expect to find DVD's in a wireless communications outlet, so the two decided to partner with Brick Oven Pizza down the block and add movies to the delivery menu. The service started two weeks ago. Movies rent for $3 a night; Mr. Zechar and Mr. Behan let Brick Oven set the fee it wanted for the video delivery; the pizzeria decided on $1. Mr. Zehar and Mr. Behan plan to expand the venture to other restaurants that deliver.

title: Mammograms That Miss Tumors
description: Pity the poor mammogram patient. For months now she has been witnessing a dispute among professionals over whether mammograms can save lives by detecting tumors early, when they are most treatable. Now she must confront the sad truth that in day-to-day medical practice, many mammograms are interpreted by radiologists who miss an alarmingly high percentage of the cancers they should be detecting.

title: Honoring a Life of Shushing, Cajoling and Teaching
description: When Ena Ellwanger started her teaching career on City Island in 1961, she had reddish-brown hair, wore a size 8 dress and talked nonstop. Forty-one years later, having taught more island children than she can count, she is silver-haired, hasn't worn a size 8 in years and, if anything, has grown more talkative.

title: The Nation; Vouchers: A Shift, But Just How Big?
description: WHEN the Supreme Court upheld Cleveland's school voucher program, voucher supporters exulted that the decision would be as important as Brown v. Board of Education. It would, they said, create a seismic wave of similar programs across the country, shifting students, money and attention from public to private schools.

title: Laura Urquhart, Jay Weinkam
description: Laura Jane Urquhart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Urquhart of Hamden, Conn., was married yesterday to Joseph Henry Weinkam III, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Weinkam Jr. of Neshanic Station, N.J. Msgr. John T. Ferry performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: RACIAL PROFILING
description: Statistics released by State Police last week suggested that black drivers are disproportionately stopped by state troopers on the New Jersey Turnpike. Consent searches seemed essentially to have halted. Only three stopped drivers were searched, against 83 searches in the same six months a year earlier. Officials of the State Troopers Fraternal Association said race had nothing to do with the traffic stops, and made reference to a study that suggests black drivers may be more prone to speeding. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, WILLIAM H.
description: NEWMAN-William H. Lifelong business educator, influential author, and the last surviving founder of the Academy of Management, died May 31, 2002. He was 92. Dr. Newman was the first Samuel Bronfman Professor of Democratic Business Enterprise at Columbia University, the chair endowed during Dwight D. Eisenhower's tenure as president of Columbia. He held the post until his retirement in 1978. He joined Columbia Business School in 1949 and went on to create its management division as well as its executive education program at Arden House. Dr. Newman taught business executives in 17 countries, including Turkey and Nigeria, & was one of the first Western professors to teach in China following the institution of the Open Door Policy in 1979. Dr. Newman co-founded the Academy of Management in 1936. Today the Academy is the premiere society for management scholars, with 12,000 members internationally. In 1999 the Academy created an award in Dr. Newman's name, to recognize outstanding young scholars. Before entering academia, Dr. Newman worked as a management consultant. For several years he was executive assistant to James McKinsey, first at the fledgling McKinsey & Company and later at Marshall Field's. He taught at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School from 1939 to 1949. Dr. Newman authored some ten books, including the first textbooks on basic management practices and strategy. His works have been translated into ten languages. A tireless educator and traveler, he taught senior executives in China until 1995. In April 2002 he lectured at the Darden School at the University of Virginia. During the last ten years he visited Thailand, Siberia and Tibet. At the age of 90 he traveled to the North Pole. A member of the Religious Society of Friends, Dr. Newman was active in the Ridgewood, NJ Meeting. He served on the Board of Directors of Pendle Hill, a Quaker community in Wallingford, PA. He was a leader in the development of a new program which will explore the relevance of Quaker ideas to the social issues confronting the world in the 21st Century. Dr. Newman was married for fifty-seven years to Clare Berry Newman until her death in 1993. He is survived by three sons, Tom, Ken, and Roger, a daughter, Judy, seven grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren.

They were not told what their assignment would be, but their commonalities offered a clue: many of them had served in SS detachments in Poland, which Germany had invaded and occupied in 1939, and preference was given to men who spoke Russian.

Guggenheim Museum caused a ruckus when it postponed a survey of Matthew Barney, an esteemed sculptor and filmmaker whose work extracts a surprising grandeur from subjects like satyrs, car wrecks and homicidal dentists. But this time the uproar did not involve morally offended sensibilities. It was simply a matter of saving money. Kasimir Malevich and James Rosenquist, slated for major retrospectives later this year, were also bumped from the Guggenheim's calendar.

title: Argentina's Contagion
description: Argentina's economic collapse six months ago permitted the Bush administration to traffic in a couple of myths. The first was that unlike countries like Mexico or Russia, Argentina could become bankrupt without causing any impact beyond its borders. The second was that the United States could stay on the sidelines indefinitely without damaging its interests in the region. It figured that it would dispense a little tough-minded neglect that would not only do the Argentines a bit of good but would also serve as a lesson to others seeking an instant bailout. It is time to expose both notions for what they are -- false and dangerous -- and for the administration to do more to help solve Argentina's crisis. Otherwise, the ongoing implosion of Argentina, Latin America's third-largest economy, threatens to undermine political and economic stability throughout the region.

title: For Montreal, a Happy Return

Museums today constantly struggle with the question of whether to return objects that may not be rightfully theirs. It seems obvious enough that stolen goods should go home, but if all the military, imperial and archaeological thefts in history were to be righted, most great museums would be empty. So not everything goes back, and some things that do are presented as gifts, rather than returns, to avoid setting a dangerous precedent.

title: QUICK BITE/Hoboken; A Restaurant You Hope Will Fold
description: I steered clear of the Duds 'n' Suds during college. Though intrigued by the concept of a coin laundry place that served beer, I feared overindulging and mistakenly downing a shot of All Tempa-Cheer. But now, a few years down the line, I noticed the grand opening of Hoboken's Spinnin' Spirits, a cafe, laundry and bar. I decided to give it a spin. Early one Sunday, I entered through the laundry side. There were 10 standard washers ($2) and 5 jumbo machines ($4.50). I separated my whites and colors, and headed to the cafe side. The bar, which doesn't serve till noon, offers Yuengling ($2.75 a pint) and Coors Light ($2.50 a pint) on tap, wine ($3), mixed drinks ($3), soda, juice and bottled water. There's a smaller espresso bar, too. Two sets wired with DirecTV adorned the walls. Amid the modern, computerized washing machines entered an Old World mother in a blue apron. ''Would you like something to eat?'' she asked. ''Eggs, bacon, a bagel, some coffee? Three eggs -- you are strong and young. Sit in the garden, relax, while I make it.'' Was she an apparition, a signal to seek out the simple pleasures of home? I pondered this, sitting under an umbrella on the patio furniture out back. But she was real, and she makes a wonderful breakfast ($5.50). Apparently, the menu is whatever Mom chooses to cook that day. Before finishing my eggs, I shifted my clothes to one of 11 dryers in the sunny back room. Farther back, in a small sitting room, there are potted plants, paperbacks, magazines and a television and VCR. Friendly people, terrific laundry service and great meals: this business should clean up. Jack Silbert

title: The Most Wanted Palestinian

He looked up and saw Israeli special forces emerging from behind some trees on the nearby hillside and from cars with Palestinian plates to surround a small stone house that belonged to his son. ''Jaish, jaish'' (''army, army''), he shouted to his son, and told him to send his wife and daughter down the slope. He did not suggest that his son, Munqas Sawafta, try to escape. Sawafta had given refuge the day before to five Palestinian fighters, in the midst of Israel's Operation Defensive Shield.

title: Darkness at Noon
description: In his new novel, THIS BLINDING ABSENCE OF LIGHT (New Press, $22.95), the Moroccan writer Tahar Ben Jelloun (who emigrated to France in 1961) presents a moving story based on the experiences of a real-life soldier, whom he calls Salim, after he takes part in an abortive attempt to overthrow King Hassan II of Morocco in 1971. For his role in the rebellion, Salim is sent to prison for nearly two decades, most of the time spent in the dungeons at Tazmamart, a honeycomb of underground cells with a regimen designed to kill the occupants as slowly and painfully as possible. Salim survives many tortures, but the worst of these is perpetual darkness. ''This Blinding Absence of Light,'' fluently translated from the French by Linda Coverdale, is a kind of gloss on suffering, with some passages achieving an almost mystical beauty (''My survival, my wretchedness, my agony were inscribed on the veil of night''). Salim entertains his fellow prisoners by reciting from memory long passages from favorite books -- notably the Koran and Camus's novel ''The Stranger'' -- but at length he succumbs to the idea that he himself has become ''a book no one would ever open.'' This novel sold well in France last year; it seems that people did indeed want to hear Salim's story just as it is presented in this sad and splendid book. William Ferguson

I am so furious at Stop and Shop's deceit and disregard of its customers that I too will drive the distance to go to the Fairway to make a point. title: 'Dostoevsky'
description: The last ten years of Dostoevsky's life, the subject of the present volume, mark the end of an extraordinary literary career and of a life that touched both the heights and depths of Russian society. It became customary during these years, even among people who disagreed (and sometimes quite violently) with Dostoevsky on social-political issues, to regard him with a certain reverence, and to feel that his words incarnated a prophetic vision illuminating Russia and its destiny. One of his favorite poems, which he often read aloud, was Pushkin's powerfully evocative "The Prophet"; and each time he did so, his mesmerized listeners invariably felt that he was assuming this function himself. The unprecedented stature he attained astonished even his friends and admirers, and transcended all personal and political boundaries. In the eyes of the vast majority of the literate public, he became a living symbol of all the suffering that history had imposed on the Russian people, as well as of all their longing for an ideal world of (Christian) brotherly love and harmony.

title: 'Charles Dickens'
description: Charles Dickens was a public man and a famous man, and he assumed both of these slightly different roles in his early twenties. His first sketch, "A Dinner at Poplar Walk," was published in the Monthly Magazine in December 1833. Dickens, born on February 7, 1812, was only twenty-one, but because of his work as a parliamentary reporter (he had taught himself shorthand and was able to take down speeches word for word), he was already familiar with seeing his name in print. Nevertheless, he related later that "I walked down to Westminster Hall, and turned into it for half an hour, because my eyes were so dimmed with joy and pride, that they could not bear the street, and were not fit to be seen there." Further sketches published in monthly and weekly magazines over the following months attracted considerable notice, and when Sketches by Boz appeared in volume form in February and December 1836, they were well reviewed. What everyone, including Dickens himself, considered especially remarkable was their breadth of scope, and in particular the variety of lower-class characters and scenes depicted, perhaps a first in English literature. One reviewer called them "a perfect picture of the morals, manners, and habits of a great portion of English Society."

title: Sometimes, Beauty Goes More Than Skin Deep
description: The University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey has looked into the blue tint, and it sees danger. A study it just released found that a visit to the beauty parlor could cause a stroke in elderly patrons. Prompted by various medical reports of older beauty salon patrons suffering strokes shortly after a primping session, the U.M.D.N.J. team set out to study the so-called Beauty Parlor Stroke phenomenon. More than 80 percent of the 25 subjects used in the study said they suffered neck pain after a simulated shampooing in the researcher's faux salon in the U.M.D.N.J. quarters in Newark. And 40 percent experienced dizziness or felt light-headed after the extending their necks into the shampoo sink; both effects are warning signs for a stroke. None of the study participants, who averaged 72 years old, suffered a stroke, researchers said. The study showed that tilting the head into the salon sink reduces blood flow to the brain.

title: Bloomsbury Becomes Me, and Vice Versa
description: I STILL think of it as the summer Lytton Strachey saved me. I was 19 or 20, and life should have been tipped in gold, glinting with possibility, but it wasn't. I see myself lying in the garden, muffled under antidepressants, sunk in a silent mourning that was impinged on only by the constant trilling of the cicadas in the bushes behind me, and by Michael Holroyd's two-volume biography of Strachey. The books came as a boxed set, like the Compact Oxford English Dictionary, which added to their aura. They have been with me through several apartments, and by now they might almost be taken for antiques, with their embossed endpapers, faintly penciled underlinings and yellowing pages. Volume II, ''The Years of Achievement, 1910-1932,'' lost its dust jacket somewhere along the way, but otherwise they sit intact on a bookshelf within view, as they have always done. (Holroyd went on, with astonishing industry, to publish a wholly new one-volume biography in 1994, drawing on previously inaccessible material -- much of it to do with Strachey's homosexuality -- and although this book duly stands next to the earlier version, it does not have the talismanic value of the cased edition that got me through that unhappy summer.)

title: Endangered Landscape
description: Landscapes, no less than people, are transformed by the eyes that behold them. When an environmentalist travels the Jack Morrow Hills, in Wyoming's Red Desert, he sees a near-perfect ecosystem of soaring buttes, badlands and shifting sand dunes, while desert elk and pronghorn antelope hoof across the sands, pausing to drink from tiny ponds formed when the winter snows melt between the dunes. At 600,000 acres, the Jack Morrow Hills are part of this country's largest untouched high-elevation desert, indeed one of the largest roadless areas of any kind in the U.S. -- what Mac Blewer of the Wyoming Outdoor Council likes to call ''the wild heart of the West.'' When an energy developer treads that same path, however, he often sees with a kind of seismic vision, sensing beneath those same geologic sands a portion of the approximately 137 trillion cubic feet of natural gas that is believed to lie within the Rocky Mountain region.

For dessert, Noir's baby-T ($110 at Shop Noir in New York, 212-966-6868) gets its message across with a luscious silk-screened cupcake. If you can't eat them, wear them.

title: A Place They Can Call Their Own
description: SIX years ago, in Conway v. Wilton, the State Supreme Court ruled that municipalities were not immune from lawsuits resulting from injuries at public recreation sites. The fallout from the decision was swift: Town after town closed skate parks, mountain bike trails and other areas that officials deemed risky. The skaters, often prohibited from skating in their downtowns, had no place to go.

title: June 23-29: THE COURTS; VOUCHER RULING
description: The Supreme Court finished its term with the most important ruling in many years on religion in the schools, upholding the constitutionality of taxpayer-financed vouchers for parochial school tuition. A program that is neutral and lets parents choose between religious and nonreligious schools will pass muster, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist's majority opinion made clear.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE GOOD GERMAN, by Joseph Kanon. (Picador USA, $14.) An American journalist searching for his former lover in postwar Berlin, a ravaged city where everything is for sale, stumbles onto a murder linked to a secret program that protects Nazi criminals from being brought to justice. The result is ''a novel that brings to life the ambiguities at the heart of our country's moral legacy,'' Neil Gordon said here last year. ''It also offers the promise of a writer who is fast approaching the complexity and relevance not just of le Carr and Greene but even of Orwell: provocative, fully realized fiction that explores . . . the reality of history as it is lived by individual men and women.''
